editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .
The poore mans Librarie.
RAPSODIAE G. A. Biſhop of Exceter vpon the firſt epiſtle of ſaint Peter, red publiquely in the Cathedrall church of ſaint Paule, within the Citye of London. 1560.

p.hi: Detrahebant mihi: Ego autem orabam.

q.p: For my frendſhip they were mine aduerſaries, but I gaue my ſelfe to prayer.

div.p: Qui veritatem occultat, & qui mendacium dicit, vterque reus eſt: Ille, quia prodeſſe non vult: Iſte, quia nocere deſiderat.

q.l: He which the truth at any tyme doth conceale,
And which deliteth a lye to reueale,
Are both ſubiecte to a giltie zeale.
The one to do good doth not deſire.
The other to do hurt doth much aſpire.

div.p: ¶ Here are adioyned at the end of euery ſpecial treatie, certaine fruitful annotacions which may properly be called Miſcellanea, bicauſe they do entreate of diuerſe and ſundry matters, marked with the nombre and figures of Angrime. 2.

q.l: Tutior eſt diſcentis, quam docentis conditio.
Of him that doth learne better is the condicion,
Then of him which to other doth geue erudicion.

p.hi: Reade firſt, and then iudge.

div.p: ¶ Imprinted at London by Iohn Day.

div.head: ❧ To the ryght honourable and hys ſingular good Lord, Lorde Ruſſell, Earle of Bedforde, one of the Queenes moſt honourable priuye Counſell. G.A. wyſheth health and peace in Chriſt Ieſu.
div.p:
I Woulde verelye wiſhe (moſt vertuous and ryght honourable Lorde) that as I perceaue my ſelfe moſt addict and tied with the bondes of ſingular & great benefits flowing from you, euen ſo Fortune would ſuffer that I might feele, although no faculty or abilitie of recompence, yet at the leaſt ſome hope of rē dring of thanks, which may flow likewiſe from me vnto your honor. For as often as the remembrance of your munificent liberalitie towardes me, entreth into my mynde (which entreth truly very often) euē ſo often am I affected and vexed with incredible ſorow, fearing leaſt the note of a Gethicall Gethical. 2. ingratitude (thē the which ther is nothing more odious) ſhould be imputed and layde to my charge. But that this kinde of life might be no longer bitter & ſharpe vnto me: I haue thought good to ſeeke ſome waye and meanes to produce and ſhewe forth ſome argument of a gratefull hart, and thankeful minde towards your Lordſhip. And although I am not ignoraunt that you do not much regard nor boaſte of your benefites beſtowed (as the cōmon ſort of welthy men do) nor do therfore helpe them that be of lower degree, becauſe you do eyther aſpire or deſire to haue thankes to be geuen vnto you for a recompence, or that you woulde haue your liberalitie to be prayſed and ſetforth vnto others: yet I (as my dutie is) do greatlye eſteeme and weigh them which you haue diſpoſed, not onely vpon me, but alſo do beſtow them daily vpon others, and for my part do iudge them worthy immortal laud & praiſe. In recompence whereof, becauſe I haue no other treaſures to exhibite vnto your honour but only the litle Talent Talent. 3. of my exile & ſclender learning, I haue thought good to dedicate vnto your lordſhip theſe my Prelections and readinges (although ſimple and rude, yet playne and profitable (vttered of late by me in Paules Church in London,Paules church. 4. London. 5 that they may bee defended and deliuered from the malignant aduerſary, by your honourable wiſedome & ready helpe. And this to attempt three things haue enforced and moued me: that is honeſty, fidelitie, and grateful duty. Honeſty to auoyde occaſions of obloquie, fidelitie, to accompliſh promiſe, gratefull duty in one or other thing to benefite my Country, vnto the which (as Plato
Plato. 6. ſaith) and not onely vnto our ſelues we be borne and brought forth:Gicero lib. 1 officiorum. Sed ortus nostri (inquit) partē patria vendicat, partem amici. That is, but part of our birth and being, our Countrye Country. 7. doth vendicate and chalenge, the other part our Parentes and frendes doe requyre. Caſſiodorus,
Caſsiodorus. 8 who of a Senator of Rome, was made a deepe diuine, writeth of thys thus in hys Epiſtles: Nobiliſsimi ciuis est, patriae ſuae augmenta cogitare, ſed eorum maxime quos reſpublica ſummis honoribus obligauit. It is the part (ſayth he) of a noble and worthy Citizen to haue regarde for the good encreaſe & aduancement of hys Country, but in eſpeciall it behoueth them ſo to doo, whom the welthe publique hath tied and enhaunced to honour & dignity. Hierocles,
Hierocles. 9. est patria (ait) velut alter quidem deus, et primus maximuſ
que parens, quare qui nomen ei impoſuit a reipſa non temere patriam appellauit, vocabulo quidem a patre deducto, pronunciato tamen feminina pronūciatione, vt ex vtro
que parente mixtū eſset. &c. The Country (ſaith he) is as it wer an other god, and the fyrſt and the greateſt parent, therfore he which ſet vnto it that name, did not vnaduiſedly name it of the thing it ſelf, Patriam, the word being deriued a Patre, a father, yet pronounced in the feminine termination, that it ſhould be a mixt thing deriued from both the parentes. And thys reaſon doth inſinuate and declare the Countrye, being but one, to be honoured equalie with both the Parentes, and when it doth thus ſet vp the honour of the Countrye, it doth graunt that both the Parentes are not of a greater price and eſtimatiō, then the Country, but doth vouchſafe to beautifie it with equall honour. What ſhould I moleſt your honourable eares with the multitude, not onely of authorities, but alſo of examples of moſt valiant and noble men? Which did not onely employ & beſtow al their induſtrie, ſtudy, labour, and diligence, goodes and landes, but alſo did aduenture their owne liues for the benefit, profite, and ſafegarde of their Country. But becauſe I will not ouerpaſſe them all, I wyll recite two or three, and will firſt beginne with Gods booke. What prayſe
worthy is that mighty Capitaine and man ful of prowes Ioab, which fighting againſt the Syrians for his Country ſayd to his brother Abiſai:2. Sam. 10. If the Syrians be ſtronger then I, thou ſhalt helpe me: and if the children of Ammon be to ſtrong for thee, I wil come and ſuccour thee: be ſtrong therfore, and let vs be valiaunt for our people, and for the Cities of our God, and let the Lord do that which is good in his eyes. It would be to long to rehearſe the hiſtory and chiualdry of Iudas Machabeus Iudas Macha. 10. & other Emperours of great puiſſance, whoſe piety and loue toward their Country, is compriſed and ſhewed in the holy ſcriptures, I could bring forth (beſides theſe) the notable vertue and courage towarde their Country, of certayn Gentils. Curtius a famous Romayne, and a noble yong man, for the ſafegarde of his Countrye, caſt himſelfe into a gaping Caue of the earth, and ſo willingly dyed. Publius Decius the father, and Publius Decius the ſonne, aduentred their heades for the ſafety of their common wealth, and manfully dyed for the loue of their Countrye. Chodrus king of Athens, when he vnderſtode by the oracle of Apollo,
Apollo. 11. that Athens Athens. 12. coulde not be ſaued, but by the death of the king (the enemies for that cauſe commaunding that no man ſhould wound or touch the body of the king) to ſaue his country, put of his princely apparel, and put on beggers raymēt, and ſo went to his enemies, and of them was willingly ſlayne. Phileni
Phileni 13 the twoo brethren, had leauer to haue the boundes of theyr Country, then the courſe of theyr liues to be enlarged, and therefore ſuffered them ſelues to be buried quicke. Herodotus,
Herodotus. 14 of all writers of hiſtories compted the chiefe, doth record in his ſeuenth booke, that two of the Countrye of Lacedemonia tooke their iourney frankly and of their own accord vnto Xerxes,
Xerxes. 15. king of Perſians, to the end that they might ſuffer ſuch paynes as the Lacedemonians were iudged by oracle to ſuſtaine. The cauſe which moued them was this: The Lacedemonians, contrary to the nature of al leagues and lawes, had ſlaine the Embaſſadours ſent vnto them from Perſia. Which fact being both haynous and odious, deſerued a reuengement to be inflicted vpon the Lacedemonians. Wherupon theſe two men before mencioned, came to Xerxes, willing him to execute on them what kinde of torment and death it pleaſed him, that he might be moued by that to ſpare their Country, Xerxes the king (expending & weighing both their piety toward their country, & alſo their bold & ſtrōg encouragemēt of mind) did not onely deliuer thē frō al ſpices of tortures, but alſo deſired them that they would remayne and make their abode with him. The parties anſwered: how can we liue here ſay they forſaking the good rules and lawes, which are put in vre in our country, & abandoning our ſelues frō the ſociety & company of noble & notable mē, for whoſe ſakes we repaired hether to aduenture our liues? If theſe men (being but Heathen and Paynims, deſtitute and voyde of al diuine knowledge) were ſo feruently enclined to the beneficiall furtherance of their Country: how much more ought a Chriſtian (indued with the knowledge of God and his lawes) to be zealouſly enflamed toward his country? Theſe reaſons and enſamples, as wel taken out of the holy ſcriptures, as other prophane authours, moue me to conſider (right honourable Lord) both my duty that I owe to my natural Country, and alſo the accompt that I haue to render for the litle talent which God hath deliuered vnto me, wherby I am violently enticed to beſtow for the benefit of my Country, ſome part of my ſtudy vttered in certaine Lectures. Which attemptate I truſt wyl not be takē in the wurſt part, neither of your honor, neither of thoſe that ſhal read them, for here is not onely the expoſition of the Epiſtle it ſelfe ſet forth, but alſo certaine controuerſies in religion Religion. 16 ſo debated, certayne hereſies ſo refelled, and the glittering face of Papacye ſo defaced, that neyther the Scotiſt, Scotiſt. 17
Negry. 18 Furies. 19 the Sectary, nor the Papiſt ſhal haue any iuſt and lawfull occaſion to ſaye 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , to the contrarye.Ariſtiphon. in Pluto. Notwithſtanding the furies of certayne ſnuffing detractours, and the Momiſh Momiſh. 20 affections of biting Zoilous
Zoilus. 21 perſons, had almoſt diſanimate me from ſo vertuous an atchiefe, and godlye attempt. But no maruaile, for that pernicious and noyſome Stepdame of Vertue Diſdayne and Enuy, Enuie. 22 putteth in her foote, to let euery honeſt enterpriſe. Saynt Auſtine Austen. 23 in a certayne Sermon ſayth: Inuidia eſt odium alienae faelicitatis, reſpectu ſuperiorum, quia eis non equatur, reſpectu inferiorum, ne ſibi equentur, reſpectu partum, quia ſibi equantur. Vnde Cain inuidit Abel Cain & Abel. 24
pro ſperitati, Rachel Liae Rachel & Lia. 25
fecunditati, Saul Dauid faelicitati. Enuie is the hateful diſdaine of an other mās felicity, in reſpect of the ſuperiours, bicauſe enuious men be not equal with thē, in reſpect alſo of inferiours, leaſt other mē ſhould be equal with them, & in reſpect of their equals, bicauſe they be equal with thē, wherupon Cain did enuy the proſperity of Abel, Rachel the fruitful deliuerāce of Lia, Saul the felicity of Dauid. Valerius Maximus Valerius Maximus. 26 ſaith: Nulla tam modeſta faelicitas eſt, quae malignitatis dentes vitare poſsit, Lib. quarto. dinites enim ſunt alienis iacturis, locupletes calamitatibus, immortales funeribus. Vnde quidam interogatus,
quomodo inuidos non haberet, reſpondit: ſi nihil (inquit) ex magnis rebus habueris aut nihil feliciter geſseris, nam ſola miſeria caret inuidia. There is no felicity ſo modeſt & gentle, which can auoyd the teeth of malice & yll wil. Enuious men be rich with other mens loſſe, welthy with other mens miſery, immortal with other mens death. Wherof a certaine man being demaunded how he might haue no enemies, if (ſaith he) thou haue no part of great and woorthy giftes, or if thou do nothing luckely & worthy prayſe,De complāc tu naturae, for onely miſery is far from enuye. Alanus Alanus. 27. writeth. Quod inuidis aliena proſperitas aduerſa, aliena aduerſitas proſpera iudicatur: hi in aliena gratulatione triſtantur, in aliena triflitia gratulantur. Vnto the enuious other mēs proſperity is counted aduerſity, & other mens aduerſity is counted proſperity, they reioyce whē other mē be ſad, & they be ſad, whē other be glad. Which to cōfirm with enſample, what nede I go any further then to Plinie Plinie. 28. the writer of the natural hiſtory, who maketh mencion of one Caius Furius Cteſinus, Lib. 1 • . ca. 16 who being enfraunchiſed from ſeruile bondage, & dwelling as it wer in a poore cotage, receauing of a lytle plot of grounde belonging to the ſame more ample, large, & aboundant fruit of grain, then his neighbours did of great & wyde fieldes, fel into the handes of enuious perſons, who accuſed him that he with ſorcery & witchcraft did intoxicate other mens fruites and graines, wherupon he had a day indicted vnto him by Spurius Albinus (being one of the Ediles
Aediles. 29.) to appere to his anſwer to cleare himſelfe. Caius (fearing condemnation by the verdict of the people) brought al his ruſtical inſtruments preſently into the iudgement place, he brought alſo his daughter, a ioly ſturdy dame, wel decked and dreſſed, beſides fat & well fed Oxen, and ſaid with a loud voyce: Haec ſunt Quirites
Quirites.
• , 0 mea veneficia. O you Romaines (ſaid he) theſe be the ſorceries that I vſe, & I cānot at this preſēt ſhew vnto you the hard labours of my handes, the careful carckes of my watchings, and dayly trauelinges: which things the Iudges hearing, ſenſibly vnderſtoode that this occaſion proceded from dame 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which (as Bias Bias. 31 ſaith) is euer faelicitatis comes, the collaterall companion of felicitye,Stobeus ſer 1. de pruden ſhe neuer ſleepeth, but euer watcheth to bring vertue and good fame to deſolation and deſtruction: I wyll not nowe ſtande to recite what ſiniſter reportes, diuers flattering paraſites, Paraſites. 32 not lyfe, but lippe Goſpellers, bearing two faces in one hoode, carying fier in oneFire in one. 33 hand, & water in the other, ſowers of diſcord, reapers of miſchief, hath not long ſith bruted. But how vntrue theſe reportes were, I prouoke no further then to theſe aduerſaries, which wer the original authors of the ſame brutes, what care is and hath bene taken both for the ſetting foorth of Gods glory, encreaſe of vertue, & repreſſing of vice, the ſayde muttering Argi
Argi. 34. may them ſelues (if they wyl) teſtify. I call them Argos, bicauſe they be nec luſci nec paeti, Pontanus, poreblinde nor ſquint eyed, but of a very perfect and quicke ſight: forſomuch as they haue a ſoueraigne collyry for their eyes. Actius Sincerus (a man of a rare wit, and of no les nobilitye) when a queſtion was propoſed among the Phiſicions, what ſhould be the moſt ſpecial remedy for the perſpicuity of the eyes (one ſaying that the moyſt vapour of fenel Fenel. 35 was good, an other that the vſe of chriſtall or glaſſe) affirmed that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 was the beſt ſoueraigntie for the eye ſight. At the which the Phiſicions Phiſitions. 36. were ſo diſmayed, that they were had in deriſion of al the auditours, & not a litle offended. Why (ſaith he) doth not enuy cauſe a man to beholde and vewe al thinges very largely and fully? and what is a more preſent remedye for the eye ſight, then when the vertue and facultie of feing is made greater and broader? And forthwith he rehearſed this diſtichon out of Ouid. Ouid. 37.

q.l: Lib, 1, de ar te amandi.Fertilior ſeges eſt alienis ſemper in agris

Vicinum
que pecus grandius vber habet.

div.p:
But as diſdainful as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is, ſhe cānot hurt them which euer haue in ſtore the precious iewel of pacience. Caſſiodorus vpō the Pſalmes writeth. Quod patientia eſt quae omnia vincit aduerſa, non colluctando, ſed ſufferendo, non murmurando, ſed gratias agendo. Patience Patience. 38 is that which ouercōmeth al aduerſitie, not in wraſtling againſt it, but in ſuſteining & ſuffering it, not by murmuring, but by thankes geuing. Xenophon
Xenophon. 39 maledicenti ſibi cuidā tu (inquit) maledicere didiciſti, ego (cōſcientia teſte) didici maledicta contēnere. Xenophon ſaid to one that enuiouſly railed vpon him, thou haſt learned to ſpeak euil: but I (my conſcience bearing me witnes) haue learned to contemne & deſpiſe all euil ſayings. But what nede I to trouble your honorable eares (being otherwyſe occupied with moſt vrgent & waighty matters) with this my heaping ſentence vpon ſentence, example vpon example, hiſtory vpon hiſtory, for aſmuch as theſe my expoſtulations are vtterly impertinēt vnto the porte, to the which I entend by gods grace to ariue. Therfore I wil end & ceaſe to trouble your Lordſhip with ambagious winding of words in this tedious & trifling epiſtle, & wil enter into the porch of my diſordered diſcourſe, deſiring God to repleniſh your mind with the light & grace of his holy ſpirit, that al your doinges may wholy redounde to the glory of Gods holy name. Amen.

l.hi: Veritati non praeiudicat antiquitas.

q.l: Although antiquity clayme the chiefeſt place,
Yet ſhal it Verity neuer deface.

div.head: ❧ Hic ſequntur Miſcellanea. ¶ Here followeth the mixt annotations vppon the preface going before.
Anſelmus. 1.
div.p: THys Anſelmus, was Archbiſhop of Canterburie, he was a blacke Monke, and an Abbot of a certayne monaſterie in Normandie: he wrote workes almost infinite, and floryſhed in the tyme of Henry the first, being King of Englād, which Henry for his learnyng was called Beuclarke. There was a great controuerſie betwen him and Anſelme, concerning the inuestiture of Biſhops, and geuing of benefices. This Anſelme condemned the lawful mariage of prieſtes, and conſtrayned thē to forſake their wyues. He accuſed alſo the King at Rome before Paſchalis the ſecond, who was then Byſhop of Rome, becauſe the King had made and ordained certaine Byſhops and Abbotes in Englād. And one VVilliam VVarluuaſte being the Kinges Proctor and Clarke, aunſwearing for the Kinges ryght amonge other thinges ſayd boldely, that the King woulde not for the loſſe of his kyngdome, loſe the prerogatyue of the inueſtiture of hys Byſhops. Vnto the whiche Pope Paſchalis aunſwered full proudlye. If (as thou ſayeſt) thy King will not ſuffer the donation of Churches to bee alienate from him, for the loſſe of hys kingdome, know thou (flatlye and playnely, I ſpeake it before God) I would not ſuffer him quietly to enioy them for the price of his hedde (O proud Sathan.) VVhich talke being finiſhed, Anſelmus deſyred the Pope, that he hauyng no regard to the King, would depoſe the ſayd Byſhoppes, whiche thyng when it came to the Kinges eares, he did confiſcate Anſelmus goodes, and depriued hym of hys Byſhoprike. Notwithſtandyng as ſome write, the King reſtored Anſelmus agayn frō excile and banyſhment. This Anſelme was Archbyſhop of Canterburye after Lanfrancke, Anno Domini. 1100. or there about.
There were three Anſelmes beſydes thys Archbyſhop, one was Byſhop of Lukes, who was by the craft and falſehode of Hildebrand made Pope, and named Alexander ſecundus, as Benno writeth.

But the Lombardes with the conſent of Henry the Emperour, ſet vp an other Biſhop agaynſt hym, whom they choſe at Baſile in a greate aſſemblye. Thys prelates name was Cadolus Byſhop of Parma, who with a mighty hoſt of men beſieged Rome, but after one or two battailes foughte, he was put to flight. Henry the Emperour to take awaye this ſciſme, ſent thether with his authoritye, one Otho Archbiſhop of Colyne,
who commyng to Rome, made and ſayd very muche of the Emperours ſyde, for the election of the Pope, and dyd greatlye blame and accuſe Alexander for that he was elected without the Emperoures conſent. Then Hildebrand interruptyng the Archebiſhoppes oration, defended ſtoutelye Alexanders parte, and affirmed that the election of the Pope perteyned onelye to the Clergie. Otho eaſely gaue place to Alexander and entreated that there myght bee a Counſell aſſembled at Mantua for the appeaſing of the ſciſme. In the whiche Counſell Alexander decreed that no man ſhould here the Maſſe of any Prieſt that kept a concubine. He depriued alſo all maried Biſhops, Prieſtes, and Deacons of their benefices. Yet he permitted Prieſtes ſonnes to entre into holy orders, hauing at the leaſt the Popes authoritie. He decreed that the Pope ſhoulde be choſen onely of the Cardinals, he commaunded Alleluia not to be ſong or ſayd from Septuageſima vnto Eaſter.

Benno Cardinalis writeth thus of this Alexander. VVhen Alexander vnderſtode at the laſt that he was elect and intronizate by the ſubtletie and crafte of Hildebrand and the Emperours enemies, made vpon a certeine day a Sermon vnto the people, and ſaid that he would not ſit in the ſee Apoſtolicke without the Emperous licence, and ſaid openly that he would for the ſame cauſe ſend letters to the Emperour: which whē Hildebrand hard, grudging and murmuring, could ſcarſe refrayne his hāds before the Maſſe was ended, but whē all was finiſhed, he led Alexander with a ſtrōg cōpany into his chāber, and before he could vnraye him ſelf of his pontificalibus Hildebrand ſo fel to buffeting of him, that he made him to beraye the roſt (as they ſay.) And Hildebrād appointed that frō that day forward no more money ſhould be geuen to Alexander, but fiue ſhillings of the Lucenſes coyne. And ſo caſting Alexander into priſon, reteyned all the reuennewes of the Church of Rome to his owne vſe. In the end Alexāder in the night departed this world and perchaūce not without poiſon. And Hildebrand was intronizate of his ſouldiours without the conſent either of the Clergie, or of the people, fearing leaſt an other would preuent him. Vnto whoſe election not one of the Cardinalles did ſubſcribe. Vnto the whiche place when the Abbot called Abbas Caſsinenſis came, Hildebrand ſayde vnto hym, Frater nimium tardaſti, the Abbot aunſwered. Et tu Hildebrande nimium feſtinaſti, for thou (the Pope thy Lorde and maſter beyng not yet buried) haſt vſurped the ſee Apoſtolicke contrary to the Canons and lawes.

There was alſo an other Anſelme, whiche did expounde the whole courſe of holy Scriptures with the gloſe called, gloſa interlinearis, and with other notes ſet in the mergent, whiche he tooke out of the writtinges
of certeine fathers.
An other Anſelme alſo was a blacke Moncke & a Frenchman which wrote the booke named. Itinerarium Leonis Papae.

div.head: Gethicall. 2.
div.p: GEtae, were people in Scithia, Appianus doth call thē Dacos. But Strabo in his ſeuenth booke doth make this differēce betwene the people called Getas, and the people called Dacos. That is that Getae dwell in the Orient toward the great region Pontus: Daci dwell in the parte oppoſite towarde Germany, and by the fountaine of the great riuer Iſter, which people many in the old time would haue to be called Danos. Among the Athenians the names of the Danes and the Getes were vſually compted and called ſeruile.
Aelius Spartianus writteth them to haue bene called Getas who afterward were named Gothi. Ouid in his boke de Ponto writeth this people to be barbarous, fierce and cruell, his wordes be theſe.

l.hi: Nulla Getis toto gens eſt truculentior orbe.

q.l: No people in the worlde permanent.
Then the Getes are more fierce or truculent.

div.p: Therfore this Epitheton Gethicall is applied to them that be barbarous, fierce and vnthankefull, whereupon this verſe is ſpoken of an vnthankefull man.

div.head: Talentum. 3.
div.p: BVdeus, in his booke de Aſse, doth throughly define what Talentum is, and how many wayes it is taken.

Concerning the ſignification of Talentum, when it betokeneth a ſomme of money, it ſhalbe ſufficient to knowe that Talentum Atticum minus is moſt written of, and conteyneth 60 Minas, euery Mina conteining 100 drachmes, or Denaries, and euery Denary being a grot • ſterling, ſo that the value of Mina is. 33. s. iiij. d. or after Tunſtall 40. s. and Talentum 100. poundes, or after Tunſtall. 120. poundes ſterling, of this Talentum in this ſignification there be Tot ſenſus quot capita.

But Talentum by a Metaphor doth ſignifie a gift, a dowry, a charge committed to man,Math. 25. as in Matthew it is ſaid that vnto one he gaue fiue talents, to an other two, and to an other one, to euery man according to hi • habilitie. Talentes in this place, are the giftes of God and of grace committed and geuen to man to worke and labour, whether it be to teache, to preach, to exhorte the people, or to benefite and profite our neighbours
any maner of way, Chriſt doth not giue theſe giftes cōcerning the largenes and ſcarſenes of them, to one man more, and to an other leſſe, but to euery man according as he is able to take and receaue. As the fielde being fertile and plentifull by nature doth bring forth fruite more abundant, then that fielde whiche holpen by the induſtrie and labour of man, euen ſo he that is holpen with the inſtincte and furtheraunce of nature. To one therfore whiche by nature is of a quicke wit, and of a liuely ſpirite ar committed fiue talents, vnto an other (according to his capacitie) ar geuen two, to an other one, wherupon ſaint Paule confeſſeth that he fedde certaine of the Corinthians with milke,2. Cor. 3. whiche (as yet) coulde digeſt no whole meate. And to the Epheſians he ſayth, Ephe. 4. to euery one of vs is geuen grace according to the meaſure of the gift of Chriſt.

Chriſoſtome ſayth, that talentes in this place of Mathew doo ſignifie that which any mā is able to do, whether it be to defend with authoritie, as Princes and Magiſtrates may, or to helpe with money, as the rich may the poore, or to admoniſh by doctrine, as the elders eccleſiaſticall may, or by any maner of meanes to furder their neighbour. And no mā cā excuſe him ſelfe from one good exerciſe or other, nor ought (ſay I) haue but onely one talent. For in diſtribution of almes who was poorer then that widowe that caſte but two mites into the treaſurie cheſt? Nar. 12. Matth. 10. Yf there he any poorer, he may yet giue a cup of water to them that neede it.

div.head: Cautio.
div.p:
BVt we muſt take heede, that we thincke not to haue of our owne, or of our ſelues that which we haue,1. Cor. 4. for (as Paule ſayth) Quid habes quod non accepiſti? what haſt thou that thou haſt not receaued? Therfore we muſt graunt and cōfeſſe not onely the offices, but the facultie and power to the adminiſtration of them, to come of the Lorde. VVe be not (ſayth Paule) ſufficient of our ſelues to thincke any good thing,2. Cor. 3 but all our ſufficiencie is of God. It is farre otherwiſe in Gods caſe, then in mans caſe, for a prince and ruler may conferre and giue an office to any man, but to giue him the gifte and facultie to do his office well, it lyeth not in mans power. But in Gods caſe our heauenly king can giue vnto man not onely 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is libertie and authoritie to do thinges, but alſo he can giue him 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
raſtonin, that is power, facultye and ſtrength to do it.

div.head: Paules Churche. 4.
div.p:
IN the yeare of our Lord .1087. and the vij day of Iuly the Churche of Paules and all that was in it with a great parte of the Citie were burned, (Maurice then beyng Byſhop of London,) and in the 21. yeare of VVilliam Conquerour. In the yeare alſo 1132. the moſt part of the Citie of London, was burned by
the fire of Gilbert Becket and in the .32. yeare of king Henry the firſt. Of this kindred came that goodly impe Thomas Becket.

In the yeare likewiſe .1137. and in the firſt yeare of king Stephen began a fire at London Bridge, and burned all the Citie and Churche of Paules vnto ſaint Clementes Churche without temple barre, which was then called the Danes Churche.

In the yeare likewiſe .1382. and the .21. day of May with a great earthquake through the realme, the Croſſe in Paules Churcheyard was ouerthrowne, in the ſixt yeare of Richard the ſecond. To the building of that Croſſe again VVilliā the Biſhop of Canterburie gathered great ſommes of money, and enriched him ſelfe, and becauſe men ſhoulde be more liberall and willing to giue, he and the reſt of ſuche holy Biſhops, graunted many dayes of pardon, to them that would freely geue money to the building of that Croſſe agayne.

Furthermore Polichr. telleth that a great piece of London, and Paules Church with the principal cities of Englād, were burned, Lib. 7. ca. 4 & he ſaith that a hurlewind threwe downe an hundred houſes in London, and many Churches alſo.
On Candlemas euen, in midwinter, Paules ſteple was burned with lightening, in the time of king Henry the ſixte.

div.head: London. 5.
div.p: THe citie of London was founded and builded of Brutus, in that tyme whē Heli the high Prieſt was iudge of Iſraell, whiche was about the yeares before Chriſt .1125. and was firſt named Troye nouant. This Brute had three ſonnes whoſe names were Locrine, Cāber and Albanact. Vnto Locrine he gaue the middle parte of Britayne, with the ſuperioritie of the Ile: Vnto Camber he gaue VVales, vnto Albanact, Scoteland.

Ebrancke the fith king after Brute, builded the Citie of Yorke, and the Caſtles of Dunbar and Edenbrough, and one Leyle the ſeconde kyng after Ebrancke builded the Citie of Carlell, and Lud his ſonne builded the Cities of Canterburie, VVincheſter, and the Towne of Shaſtisburie. Bladud the ſonne of Lud builded the Citie of Bath, and made therein the hote bathes, and by vayne truſt of the Art of Necromancie toke vpō him to flie in the ayre, from whence he fell downe and brake his necke. Leir the ſonne of Bladud builded the citie of Leiceſter.

At the laſt after the houſe of Brute was cruelly deſtroyed, Mulumſius Dunwallo duke of Cornewall: brought this realme into one Monarchie, and he made the foure notable wayes in Britayne, called the Foſſe
wayes. In London he builded a great temple, whiche ſome ſuppoſe to be Paules Church, ſome Blackwel hall. He liued about .441. before Chriſt.

Bellinus ſonne of Mulumſius, did cōſtitute thre archeflamins, whoſe ſees were at Lōdon, Yorke & Carlion, he finiſhed the foure great wayes begon by his father, he made Denmarcke tributarie vnto him. In Londō he made the hauen called Billinſegate, and as Leiland writeth, builded the towre of London.

div.head: Plato. 6.
div.p: THis Plato was called Diuinus Plato, for his excellent doctrine, which doctrine cōteyneth many things (as S. Auſtē ſaith) which accorde with the holy Scriptures, ſo that in thē is perceaued the firſt part of Geneſis, vnto this text, Spiritus dn̄i ferebatur ſuper aquas, and the miſtery of thre perſons in diuinitie, is there expreſſed, his name was firſt Ariſtocles, and after called Plato, bycauſe as ſome ſuppoſe, he was broad in the ſhoulders, other write bycauſe he had a broade viſage. He was before Chriſt .342. yeares, he liued ſole and chaſte (as S. Auſten ſaith) and died being of ye age of .81. yeares. Plato lieng in his cradle, bees brought honie into his mouth wtout hurting of him, which thing diuerſe did interpret, to ſignifie, that from him ſhould flow eloquēce moſt ſweete and delectable Socrates dreamed the night before yt Plato was brought to him to be inſtructed in learnyng, that he helde betwene hys knees a white Cygnet, who hauing fethers quickelie growen, flew vp, towarde heauen, and filled the ayre with moſt pleaſaunt tunes. So the day after Plato being brought by his father vnto Socrates, who beholdyng him well, ſayd: This is the birde, whoſe Image I beheld this laſt might, but his end and death was (as ſome ſay) the diſeaſe of the lowſy euill, called of the Phiſitions Ptyriaſis.

div.head: Countrie. 7.
div.p: HOmer writeth that Vliſſes ſo loued his countrie, that he deſired to ſee the ſmoke thereof once appeare before he died, yea although he ſhould dye fourth with.

One named Seriphius, when it was obiected againſt him that his countrie was poore and baſe, made this aunſwere. Mihi patria dedecus eſt, tu autem patriae, my countrie is a diſhonor to me, but thou art a diſhonor to thy countrie.

Teucer hearing certaine conferring together of the ſweetenes of their countrie, ſayd. Patria eſt, vbicun
que eſt bene. VVhere a man liueth well, there is his countrie, for it is often tymes ſeene, that certayne hath better
ſucceſſe, and be of more eſtimation among ſtraungers, then they be in their owne countrie. And therfore it is a good and a golden ſaying: Omne ſolum forti patria eſt.

div.head: Caſsiodore. 8.
div.p: THis Caſsiodore, was a Moncke of Rauenna, but was firſte conſul, & thē Senator of Rome, he wrote vpō the Pſalter, and many godly and learned Epiſtles, anno domini. 550.

div.head: Hierocles. 9.
div.p: HIerocles, was a Philoſopher of Alexādria, whoſe conſtācie, magnanimitie and eloquence, is of Suidas with maruelous prayſes cō mended. This his magnanimitie of minde (ſayth he) may be perceaued and vnderſtoode by the commentaries whiche he wrote vpon the verſes of Pithagoras, called Aurea Pithagorae carmina. He wrote alſo of prudence, and many other bookes, in the whiche his excellent wit and learning do playnly appeare. Of this read more in Suidas.

div.head: Iudas Machabeus. 10.
div.p: IVdas Machabeus was ye ſonne of Matathias the Prieſt. This Iudas did with a moſt godly zeale, withſtand the edictes and commaundements of Antiochus. VVho cōmaunded the Iewes to reiect the law of God, and to receaue and embrace the Idolatrie of the heathen. He (vanquiſhing and putting to flight certeine hoſtes of Antiochus) at the laſt repayred to the citie of Ieruſalē, & to the temple which he did purifie and clenſe againe, the .xxv. of Nouember.
Afterward, when he had made a league with ye Romanes, he was ſlaine in the battayle by Demetrius the king, as it is recorded in the firſt boke of the Machabees, the .ix. chapiter.

div.head: Quaeſtio.
div.p: Some will demaunde what is to be thought of the bookes of the Mabees, whether they be Canonicall or no, and whether they be of a ſufficient authoritie to confirme any doctrine?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p:
For that our aduerſaries do mixt and mingle vnto bookes auctenticall & Canonicall, other bokes named Eccleſiaſticall or Hagiographall (as ye bokes of the Machabees & others) they do it for this coūſel & end, to make equall traditions and vnwritten verities, with ye holy ſcriptures. But to omit other their doings, they take vpon them to proue and ſhewe
out of the ſecond booke of the Machabees, that it is an holſome thyng to pray and offre for the dead, that they myght be looſed from their ſinnes. They bragge alſo that they can ſhewe out of thoſe bookes, that the prayers of the ſaintes beyng in heauen, are offred vnto God, for them whiche lyue in the earth. VVhen notwithſtandyng in the primatiue Church, the ſeconde booke of the Machabees, and other lyke, were neuer rehearſed nor nombred among the bookes canonicall.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: VVhy ſyr? ſaint Auſten in his boke De doctrina Chriſtiana, doth nomber among the bookes canonicall, not onely other bookes Eccleſiaſticall, but alſo the ſecond booke of the Machabees.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: If we looke well vpon the Hiſtories and other monumentes of the auncient fathers, it will appeare that euen thē firſt, that is in ſaint Auſtens time, this boke was receaued into the nomber of the bookes cononicall, in the thirde counſell holden at Carthage, aboute the yeare of our Lorde. 400. or .399.

Nor ſaint Auſten doth diſſemble or denie the ſame, for in his booke De ciuitate dei, & in his worke Contra Gaudentii epiſtolam, he doth admoniſhe and teach the bokes of the Machabees not to haue bene nombred of the olde fathers in the Canon. Notwithſtanding he addeth, that they were not vnprofitably receaued, ſo that they be redde ſoberly and with diſcretion.

He ſaith alſo in an other place, they are taken for canonicall, bycauſe they conteine the vehement and maruelous paſsions and death of certein martyrs. Beſides this he writeth, that euery thing which is ſet fourth in that booke, is not to be receaued, except it be well examined and conferred with other Scriptures. It may be ſhewed out of the moſt aunciēt and noble Churches of the Eaſte, that the bookes of the Machabees were neuer receaued for canonicall. Meliton Sardenſis epiſcopus, whiche lyued not many yeares after the death of the Apoſtles, about the yeare of our Lord .173. vnder the Emperour Anthonius verus (to whom he wrote an Appologie for our faith) doth recite the bookes of the old Teſtament, making no mention of any of thoſe bookes called Eccleſiaſticall. He ſayth that he went into the Eaſte, where our preaching began, and where all thinges were done, whiche are written, that he might diligently inueſtigate and ſearche out all thyngs, whiche doth pertayne to the veritie and certaynetie of the bookes canonicall, and that there he founde out the certayne and true nomber.

Origine hymſelfe doth rehearſe no more bookes of the olde Teſtament then .22. Lykewyſe ſaint Hierome not onelye in hys Prologue
named Galeatus, but alſo in his Epiſtle vnto Paul, doth know and nomber onely .22. bookes, other bookes ſaith he, muſt be ſet out of the Canon.

In his Prologue alſo vpon the Prouerbes of Salomon, after he had ſpoken of the booke of wiſedome, whiche is ſayde to be Salomons, and of the booke called Eccleſiaſticus, he addeth this. As the Churche therefore doth reade the booke of Iudith, of Tobie, and the bookes of the Machabees, but yet doth not receaue them amongeſt the Canonicall Scriptures, ſo likewiſe doth ſhe receaue theſe two bookes of Machabees to the edifieng of the people, and not to the aucthoritie of any Eccleſiaſticall doctrine to be confirmed.

This Hierome coulde not be ignoraunt of the Decree of the Counſell of Carthage, for (as many do write) he dyed aboute the yeare of our Lorde .422, and therefore it is to be iudged, that ſaint Auſten ment no otherwiſe, but as Hierome did, that is, that he nombred the ſeconde booke of the Machabees among the Canonicall, but yet vnderſtoode it to be Eccleſiaſticall, that is not of ſo great aucthoritie, as the bookes, which of olde antiquitie were counpted Canonicall.

Ruffinus in the expoſition of the Apoſtles Symbole, doth recite no more bokes of the old Teſtamēt, but ſo many as are rehearſed before, & amonge other thynges theſe be his wordes. Hec ſunt veteris Teſtamenti volumina que ſecundum maiorum traditionem, per ipſum ſpiritum ſanctum inſpirata creduntur, & Eccleſiis Chriſti tradita ſunt. Sciendum tamen eſt, quod & alii libri ſunt, qui non Canonici, ſed Eccleſiaſtici, a maioribus ſunt appellati: vt eſt ſapientia Salomonis, Eccleſiaſticus, Tobiae & Iudith, & Machabeorum libri, que omnia in Eccleſiis legi voluerunt, non tamen proferri ad authoritatem fidei ex his confirmandam. Theſe be the bookes of the olde Teſtament, whiche after the tradition of the Elders, are beleued to be enſpired by the holy Ghoſt him ſelf, and deliuered to the Churches of Chriſt: Yet we muſt knowe, that there be other bookes, whiche are not called of the elders canonicall, but Eccleſiaſtical: as the boke of Sapience, the boke named Eccleſiaſticus, the bokes of Tobie and Iudith, and of the Machabees. VVhiche bookes all they woulde haue truely to be red in the Church, but not to be brought fourth out of them any aucthoritie to confirme our faith.

Finally, the fact and dede of Raſias, recorded in the ſecōd boke, is not greatly commended of certeyne learned and godly men, bycauſe he in a maner killed him ſelfe, alſo in the ende of the booke it is written: Si bene ſcripſi, eſt quod volui: Sin exiliter, eſt quod potui. If I haue written wel, it is that, that I woulde: If I haue written ſclenderly, it is that which I could. Theſe wordes are not to be attributed to the holy ghoſt, for he is the author onely of wordes and woorkes moſt perfect and pure.

div.head: Apollo. 11.
div.p: CErtaine Authors write, that Apollo firſt brought in the vſe of Phiſicke, and therfore deſerued to be called a God. He is called alſo the Autor and inuētor of Verſes and Muſicke, wherfore the Poetes coumpte him their chief God.

In the Yland called the Rhodes, there is an image named Coloſſus, of ſuch great quātitie and bignes, that it is nōbred among the ſeuē wonders of the world. Three folde power and authority is geuen vnto him, that is, In heauē he is called Sol, the Sunne, in earth he is called Liber Pater, the father of Vine and wines, in hell he is called Apollo. Three thinges are painted alwaies wt his image, an Harpe, a Buckler, and Arrowes. There is aſcribed vnto him continuall youth, and therefore he is fayned of the Poetes to be alwayes remaining among the floriſhing herbes and greene graſſe. There is a prouerbe whiche ſprange of Apollo. Apollonis oraculum, the oracle of Apollo, by the whiche is ſignified a thing moſt true, bycauſe Apollo being cōſulted, gaue euer true anſweres. There is alſo an other prouerbe Ex tripode dictum, the originall and meaning wherof ye ſhall reade at large in Chiliadibus Eraſmi.

div.head: Athenae. 12.
div.p:
AThens was a noble citie where all liberall ſciences were taught, it is called the mother of all Philoſophers, all Greece had not in it a more beautifull and nobler thing. The ſituation thereof was very ſpectable and pleaſaunt. It was alſo as it were a certaine mother citie and refuge, into the which all other cities nere adioygning, (afflicted and preſt with terrors of warre or any other calamities) did flie & had recourſe. It was a moſt ſafe and ſure receptacle of all ſhippes, mariners and Marchauntes. It was the nobleſt vniuerſitie of all the worlde, and none in times paſt was coumpted learned, which had not geuen diligēce to learning at Athens. Strabo writeth that there was in Athens a certeine rocke ſet in a plaine, which was inhabited rounde about circle wiſe. In that plaine was the temple of Minerua, and in that temple there was an image, whiche the inhabitantes did beleue to haue fallen from heauē. In the ſayd Churche there was a perpetuall fire with a companie of virgins. This citie was called alſo Cecropia, of a certaine kyng named Cecrops, and Mopſopia of one Mopſus, as of Ianus the ſonne of Iaphet, was named (as ſome write) Ionia, At the laſt this citie was called of this word Minerua, Athens, for the Grecians do call Mineruā, Athenā. And Minerua the virgine founde out Clothemakyng, VVeauyng and Spinning, and manye other Artificiall things. And therfore ſhe was taken as a famous goddeſſe. And bycauſe all her inuentions did procede out of the
quicknes of wit and greate wiſedome, the Poetes do fable that ſhe was borne of Iupiters brayne.

As Cecrops was repairing and fortifieng the citie of Athens, water broke fourth ſodenly in a certaine place, and in an other place there was founde an Oliue tree, vpon the which wonders, Apollo being demaunded at Delphos, what was ment therby, and what were beſt to be done, made aunſwere: that the Oliue tree did ſignifie Mineruam, and the water dyd betoken Neptunum, and that they both were ſiſters children, and both Gods, and that it was in the arbitrement of the citezens, to call the citie after one of their two names. So (al the citizens beyng aſſembled) the mē did cleue and conſent to Neptunus, the women vnto Minerua: who obteined that the citie ſhould be called by the name of Minerua. The Poets do ſay that Neptunus and Minerua did builde the citie of Athens, and whē there was altercation betwen thē for the impoſition of the name, (other Gods being preſent,) they conuented betwene them ſelues, that whether of them (ſmityng the ground) ſhould bring fourth the moſt laudable and worthy effect, ſhould name the citie. Neptunus ſmiting the ground with his mace, brought fourth an borſe, an inſtrument of war, but Minerua throwing her ſpeare vpon the ground, brought fourth an Oliue tree, of peace & quietnes, which bicauſe it was coūted more profitable by their iudgemēt, the city was called by her name, Athens. Therfore the Athenians were not ſtraungers, nor a rablement of people gathered together which gaue ye originall of the citie, but they wer borne in the ſame groūd wher they dwelt. They firſt taught ye vſe of Clothemaking, and of Oyle, they taught the maner to Ploughe and to ſowe Corne, vnto them whiche before did eate Acornes. Learning, Eloquence, and al ciuill order of diſcipline did floriſhe at Athens.

Cecrops alſo made .iij. lawes againſt their womē, to pacifie ye ire of Neptunus, whō the womē did ſet behind Minerua. The firſt law was that no womā ſhould euer enter into the Senate, the ſecōd law was, that no child ſhould be called by ye mothers name. And the third was, yt no man ſhould call them Mulieres Athenienſes, but Atticas. There be three prouerbes which had their originall of Athens. The firſte prouerbe is this: Athenienſium inconſulta temeritas: the vnaduiſed raſhenes of the Athenians, It may be applyed agaynſt them whoſe raſh conſultation cometh to good ſucceſſe. For in tymes paſte it was commonly imputed to the Athenians, that they would ſlackelye conſulte for their affaires, and had litle foreſight, or no prouidēce in their doinges. But Minerua Lady Preſident of the citie did accuſtome to turne their ill purpoſes to a good end.

The like prouerbe is at this tyme in euery mans mouth: Eſt fortunatior quam prudentior. It is better to be happy, then wiſe. It may be ſpoken
of hym whiche hath good ſucceſſe and chaunce, not by hys induſtrie and wiſedome, but by commoditie of fortune.

div.head: The ſecond prouerbe is this.
div.p: ATticus teſtis vel Attica fides, a witnes of Athens, or the fidelitie of Athens, whiche prouerbe may be ſpoken of a moſt vncorrupte and vpright teſtimonie and faith.

The originall of this prouerbe ſprang of this, bycauſe that at Athens there was a Churche builded vnto the Lady faith. Velleius Paterculus maketh mention of this in theſe wordes: If any do impute to the Athenians that time of rebelliō, in the whiche Athens was taken of Silla, truly he is ignoraunt of al truth and antiquitie. For the faith of the Atheniās, was ſo certaine & ſure toward the Romanes, yt alwayes and in al things what ſoeuer was done wt a ſincere and vncorrupt fidelitie, the Romanes would pronounce that to be don Attica fide, by the faith of the Atheniās.
Quintilian doth write that the ſoyle and grounde of Athens, did alwayes rendre more ſede then it did receaue.

div.head: The third prouerbe is this.
div.p: NOctua volauit. The owle hath floen: The fleing of the owle was to the aūcient Atheniās, a ſimbole & preſage of victory, bycauſe this birde was dedicate as an holy thing vnto Minerua, who alwayes as it is ſayde before, brought to good ſucceſſe the ſlacke conſultations of the Athenians. And therfore when any matter cōmeth to a good ende contrarie to our expectation, It may be prouerbially ſayd, the owle hath floen, as Suidas doth write.

It ſhall not be vnaptely applyed, when matters are brought to effect, not by any industrie and ſtrength, but by the mediation of money. The originall wherof, came of this, bycauſe the coyne of the Athenians had an owle ingraued in it. It may well be obiected agaynſt them whiche doo both giue and receaue bribes.

div.head: Phileni. 13.
div.p:
THey were two brethren of Carthage of whō it is written, that where they of Carthage and they of Cyren did ſtriue for their boundes, it was agreed that out of eche citie two men ſhoulde iſſue, and where as they met ſhoulde be the boundes, then the ſayde brethren beyng ſent, went a greate waye into the boundes of the other, eare they did returne, and when they of Cyren did ſee that they were preuented, they tooke it diſpleaſauntly, and manaced the two brethren, that if they woulde not go backe they ſhoulde be put quicke into the earth, but they notwithſtandyng woulde not departe, wherefore they beyng buried alyue, their countrie men made ouer
them two alters, which at this day be called Arae Philenorum.

div.head: Herodotus. 14.
div.p: THis Herodotus was borne in a citie of Halicarnaſſus in Aſia, and he wrote nyne bookes of Hiſtories, whiche he did entitle by the name of the nine Muſes, in the which he wrot the Hiſtorie of all the Actes done in Europa, and Aſia, by the ſpace of .240. yeares. He came of a noble linage, he began hys Hiſtorie with Cyrus king of the Perſians. He was before the incarnation of Chriſt .200. yeares.

div.head: Xerxes. 15.
div.p: THis king was Darius ſonne, & he inuaded Grece, with ſeuē hundred thouſand ſtraūge ſouldiours, & yet was vāquiſhed by a few Greekes, and cōſtrayned to flie away in great feare in a litle boate vnknowē, and at the laſt was ſlaine by Artabanus the greate Capitaine of his armye. On a time whē he ſaw the whole Sea called Helleſpontus couered wt his Nauie, and all the bāckes and plaine fieldes repleniſhed with his armie of men, he boaſted hym ſelfe bleſſed, and yet ſtraight way fell on weepyng. Artabanus his vncle whiche had diſſwaded him from that viage, maruelyng at ſo ſodayne a chaunge, demanded the cauſe. Then Xerxes ſayd, I nowe recorde in my mynde, howe ſhort the life of man is, when of this great multitude after an hundres yeares not one of theſe ſhall remayne alyue. He was before Chriſt .485. yeares.

div.head: Religion. 16.
div.p: CIcero de natura deorum ſayth, that this worde Religio cometh a Relegendo, of readyng agayne, or gathering agayne together, and ſo ſaint Auſten, Lib. 2. de ciuitate dei ſayth, Religio dicitur a relegendo deum, quem amiſeramus negligentes, Religion is ſayde of gatheryng God againe, whom we beyng negligent, had loſt. Lactātius Li. 4. affirmeth yt it cometh a Religando of bynding, bycauſe we be binde bounde to do our duety towarde God. And ſo Iſidorus Lib. 18. Etimo: writeth ſaying. Religio dicta eſt, quod per eam, vni ſoli deo religamus animas noſtras ad cultum diuinum, It is called Religion, bicauſe we be it our ſoules to one onely God to do him diuine and godly honor. Religio is taken ſomtime for feare and ſcruple of conſcience, as Dignus es tua religione odio. Thou art worthy to be hated for thy peuiſhe ſuperſtition. Sometime it ſignifieth wickednes, as Hoc patrare Religio eſt. It is an hainous thing to do this.

div.head: Scotiſte. 17.
div.p: IOhn Duns, by ſur name called Scotus, whom they call the moſt ſubtle doctr and prince of all diuines, did expound the foure bookes made by Petrus Lombardus, called the maſter of the ſentēce. He propoſed and wrote alſo. 21. queſtiōs, called quodlibetates, beſide many other ſubtle workes. Al his ſcollers & followers were called Scotiſtae. He was about the yeare of our Lorde 1304. and died as ſome write, of the diſeaſe named Apoplexia, whych maketh the patiēt to leeſe his feeling, his ſpeche & mouing, but the moſt part write, that he was buried quicke and a liue. He was a gray Frier.

There was an other Scotus, a Benedictine Moncke, a great Philoſopher, the hearer and diſciple of Bede, and liued in the time of Carolus Magnus, and Bertramus. He tranſlated the bookes of Dioniſius the Martir into Latin, and made a booke of the ſacrament of the bodye and bloud of Chriſt. Sabellianus writeth, that ſome iudge the Vniuerſitie of Paris to haue bene inſtitute of this Iohannes Scotus, but it is more likely that the Vniuerſitie was made by the meanes of Carolus Magnus, & furniſhed with learned men, and expert readers by the ſame Scotus. Alcuinus, Claudius, and Rabanus, which came out of Scotland. Vincentius in ſpeculo hiſtoriali, ſayth: That Elfridus king of England, being rauiſhed with the fame of this Scotus name and learning, brought him into England, where (being in a Monaſterie called Monaſterium Melbrinē ſe) taught children, and at the laſt was digged and perſed with writing penſels, with which kind of martirdome he finiſhed his lyfe.

div.head: Negry. 18.
div.p: NEgry quidē, is as much to ſay as he is able to ſay litle or nothing to it. For gry doth ſignifie a very vile or baſe thing, as the paring of the nayles, or the grunting of a ſow, and therfore ſome thinke that grunire, which is to grunt as a ſow, commeth of this word gry.

div.head: Furies. 19.
div.p: THe Poetes fayne that there be three furies of hell, whoſe names are: Alecto, Tiſiphone, Megera, and they ſignifie the worme and painful remorſe of conſcience, which horriblye tormenteth the mindes of wicked perſonnes. Theſe three furies betoken the three folde affections of the minde, anger, greedines, and pleaſure. Anger deſireth reuengement, greedines deſireth riches, pleaſure deſireth wantonnes.

div.head: Momiſh. 20.
div.p:
MOmus the God of reprehenſion, of whom all curious reprehenders ar called Momi, that is finding fault with euery thing. This
Momus (as Ariſtotle writeth) found fault with Nature, bicauſe ſhe placed the hornes in the head of the Oxe, and not in the ſhoulders, whereby he might geue the mightier ſtroke. Alſo (as Luciā ſaith) he blamed Vulcan, for that he had not ſet eyes in mans breſt, that he might ſee what is within him, and of this riſeth a prouerb, Momo ſatisfacere, to ſatiſfie Momus minde, which is very hard to do.

div.head: Zoilus. 21.
div.p: ZOilus was an enuious Poet, and called the rhetorical dog, very buſie to write and ſpeake ill, not onely of Homer, Plato, and other noble writers, but alſo contencious and full of enuye and ſtrife againſt al mē. He being demaūded of a certain learned mā, why he ſpake ſo ill of al mē, bicauſe (ſaith be) I cānot do il when I would, & therfore the enuious, of al learned mē ar named Zoili Aelia. lib. 11. de varta hiſtoria.

div.head: Enuie. 22.
div.p: BIon beholding a certain enuious man very ſad, ſaid: Neſcio vtrū tibi acciderit aliquid mali, an alteri boni quippiam, I cannot tell whether any ill thing be chaunced vnto thee, or ſome good thing happened to ſome other mā. For an enuious man is no les tormented with an other mans felicity, then with his own miſfortune. Laertius. lib. 4.

Antiſthenes ſaid, that it was very abſurde, to purge the wheate, frō cockle and Darnel, and to ſeperate warre from an vnprofitable ſoldiour, and not to put away enuious perſons, from a cōmon welth, ſignifieng enuious perſons to be more vnprofitable to a City, then cockle or darnell is vnto wheate, and a coward and daſtard vnto battaile. Idem. lib. 6.

Socrates being demaunded what thing was greuous to good mē, made anſwer, Malorum faelicitas, the good ſucces of ill men. And being aſked what was greuous to ill men, ſayd: Bonorum proſperitas, the proſperity of good men. Antonius, in Meliſs.

div.head: Sainct Auſten. 23.
div.p:
AVſten was a famous doctor of Chriſtes church, borne in Affrick, in a towne called Gathenſis. His mothers name was Monica, & his father was of the order of Senators. They were verye honeſt perſōs, but yet of no hie nor rich degree, his brothers name was Nauigius. He was of ſuch excellent wit, that in his childhood he learned all the ſeuen liberal ſciences, without any inſtructor. He was wonderfully learned, ſpecially in the doctrine of Plato. His maiſters name was Manlius Theodorus. He hated the Greeke toung, and was in great loue with the Latine toung. In his youth beyng ſixtene yeares of age, he was greatlye geuen to fleſhly luſtes, and by the reaſon of ill companye cōmitted theft.
About the age of .xix. yeares (his father being dead two yeares before) chaunſed vpon the booke of Cicero called Hortenſius, and being moued thereby, fel to the ſtudy of philoſophy. He ſomwhat applied his minde to the holy ſcriptures, but for the ſimplicity of the ſtile he did lothe them. He being of the age of .xx. yeares, by himſelfe did read the Catagories of Ariſtotle, and vnderſtode them, & was expert in al the Mathematical ſciences. A litle after he chaunced vpon the Manichies, and did embrace and receiue their opinions.

And by the ſpace of ix. yeares, that is from .xix. vntil he came to the age of .xxviij. he did perſiſt in the ſame hereſye, and diſceaued manye. He vſed the vnlawful companye and bed of one Concubine. At the age of .xxix: he heard one Festus a Manachie reade at Carthage, whom at the firſt he prayſed aboue all other: but when by conference and diſputacion, he perceaued him to be ignorant of the liberal ſciences, and to be expert in nothing but grammar: he diſpeired that he mought be taught by the Manichies of the truth, which to attaine he much deſired. At the laſt he went to Rome, agaynſt his mothers wyll, who pitifully lamented the ſame: wher he profeſſed Rhetorick, hoping that he ſhould find ther more obedient and more thankful diſciples. And ther he fel ſick of a feuer, & was in great daunger, but he recouered his health, and vſed ſtil the company of the Manichies, but did not ſo much defend their doctrine, bicauſe after the opinion of the Academickes he iudged all things to be doubted of. And being forſaken of his ingrate diſciples, went vnto Millen, where he was fatherly receaued of ſaint Ambroſe, whom he alſo loued agayne, not for true doctrines ſake, but onely for his benificence. He heard Ambroſe diligently, not for the deſire of the knowledge of truth, but bicauſe he would proue whether Ambroſe were of the ſame eloquence as he was reported to be. At the laſt he became neither a Manichy nor a catholike, but doubted how the way of life and ſaluation mought be found out, his mother came to Millen vnto him, hoping her ſonne to be conuerted by ſaynt Ambroſe.

VVhen he was .xxx. yeares of age, he maried a wyfe, and was betrothed vnto her, but ſhe was not mariageable by twoo yeares, and he was faine to exſpect and tary for her ſo long. VVhen his Concubine vnderſtoode that he minded to mary a wife, ſhe departed from him into Affrica, and left him a ſonne, which he had by her, and then he tooke an other Concubine. At the laſt he came to one Simplicianus, and did vtter and open vnto him al the circumſtances of his errours, and deſired counſel of him, how he might come to a more perfect and fuller knowledge of the truth, who did exhort and counſel him to reade the holy ſcriptures,
and to follow the example of Victorinus, who with the diligent reading of them, became a Chriſtian, and profeſsing openly his fayth, was bapzed. Auſten being very deſirous to follow the ſame example, his mynde was drawen hether and thether what he might do, and by chaunce one Pontinianus did recite vnto him the hiſtory of Antonius, and of other two, which readyng the booke of Antonie (forſaking al their goods & their wiues) embraced the monaſtical life. VVith the which narration, Auſten being greatly moued, lamented his life, and departing into a garden with his friend Alippius, fel to pouring out aboundaunce of teares, and deſired God to giue him a more pure minde and better life. And ther he heard as it were out of the next houſe, a voice of children or maidens, ſinging and ſaying: Tolle, lege, Tolle, lege, take and read, take & reade. But when he ſaw no perſon, he thought it to be Gods admonition and warning. And then taking the booke of the new teſtament, chaunced vpon this place of Paule. Induite dominum noſtrū Ieſum Chriſtum, et carnis prouidentiam ne feceritis in concupiſcentiis. Put vpon you our Lord Ieſus Chriſt, and make not prouiſion for the fleſh in concupiſcence and luſte. After he had red theſe woordes, all darknes and ignorance were ſhaken from his eyes, ſo that he ſaw the truth, and imparting this to Alippius, they both purpoſed to embrace Chriſtes riligion: not without the great comfort and ioy of his mother Monica, who al the time that he was a Manichie, both dayly and moſt earneſtly prayed to God for his conuerſion. In the meane time, he was greatly tormented with the tooth ache, but by the praiers of his brethren he was miraculouſlye healed. At the laſt he renounced the profeſsion of Rhetoricke, by the reaſon that he was ſhort winded, and pained in his ſtomache, and gaue his minde wholy to the reading of the holy ſcriptures. He wrote to ſaint Ambroſe, declaring and confeſsing vnto him al his errors, and ſheweth what he purpoſed to do, and aſketh counſell what bokes of the holy bible he ought chiefly to reade. Ambroſe perſwaded him to read the prophet Eſay, but when it ſeemed ſomwhat hard vnto him, he deferred the readyng therof vnto an other time. About ye feaſt of Eaſter, he was baptized at Millen, with Alippius his friend, and his natural ſonne Adeodatus, which was of the age of .xv yeares. After his conuerſion, he led a moſt godly and vertuous life. He wrote notable and worthy workes, he was very liberal and beneficiall to the poore. He kept no company with women, for auoiding of ſuſpition. His apparel was neither to coſtly nor to baſe, but of an honeſt and comely ſorte. His table was not ſumptuous, but frugall and honeſt, hauing fleſh for ſtraungers ſakes, and for them which were diſeaſed. At his meales he did more regard reading and diſputing, then eating or
drinking. He was very harberous, and kept a good houſe. He moſt earneſtly hated detractions, and ill reportes of ſuche as wer abſent, and had written vpon his table theſe two verſes.

l.hi: Quiſquis amat dictis abſentum rodere vitam,
Hanc menſam vetitam nouerit eſſe ſibi.

lg.l: He that delighteth to backebite them that be abſent,
I forbyd hym this table to frequent.

div.p: Often times, he would very ſharply reprehend his fellow Biſhops, for deprauing other, and ſayd that he would either put out thoſe verſes, or els that he would depart from thence himſelf. Finally, the city Hippona being beſieged three monethes of the Vandoles and Gothes (at whych time the ſtate of the Church, and all things was moſt ſorowful) he often prayed vnto God, that either it wold pleaſe him of his goodnes to diſſolue and breake of that ſiege, or els to graunt him an happy and bleſſed ende, and ſo he fel into a feauer, and kept his bed, and the diſeaſe waxing more and more, he by him ſelf did reade certaine pſalmes of repentance, & deſired other alſo to reade them. And ſo geuing himſelf, by the ſpace often daies to reading and prayer, at the laſt departed out of this miſerable life, Poſsidonius and other of his frendes being preſent. He liued .lxxvj. yeares, and was Biſhop .xl. yeares, and died Anno domini. 437. Saynct Ambroſe and he, being both repleniſhed with the holy Ghoſt, did ſing together the pſalme Te deum, anſwering mutually one the other.

This man ſainct Auſten doth wonderfully ſet forth to vs by his lyfe, the vnſpeakable mercies of God, who made of a fornicator, a chaſte Father, who made of an hereticke, an Apoſtolike Doctour, who made of a theefe, a Biſhop, who made of a wicked and naughty man, a ſound member and ſure piller of his Church. It is he that can make of a Saul a Paul, of a Publicane an Euangeliſt, of a fiſher a Preacher, of a theefe a Confeſſor, and of a wanton Auſten, a deepe diuine, and a worthy preacher (O the great mercies of God toward mankinde.)

div.head: Cain & Abel. 24.
div.p: ALthough the geſtes of Cain & his brother Abel, are not vnknowen: yet that the ſecretes and miſteries which they contayne may more depely and worthely be pondered and weighed, I will compendiouſly ſet them before your eyes.

Not long after that our firſt parents were driuen out of the place of pleaſure, they begat a ſonne, whō (partly bicauſe he was the firſt borne, partly bicauſe they ſuppoſed him to be that ſtrong ſeede, which ſhoulde • halenge and deliuer vs from the tiranny of the Serpent) they made not
onely head and chiefe of their poſterity, but alſo the treaſure and poſſeſſion of all their deſire, for the which cauſe they named him Cainū, which doth diſcend of this Hebrue word Canah, which ſignifieth to poſſeſſe.

They begat alſo an other ſonne not long after, of whom they dyd not onelye not depende, and had no regarde, but did compt him as a vayne thing, and made almoſte no compt of him, wherupon they named hym Abelum, which doth ſignify vanity, and as it were but a vapour, enduring but a litle time. But how blind and diſceauable the iudgement of the fleſh is, and how many times he iudgeth darkenes light, and light darkenes: in this act of Adam it doth euidently appeare.
The hiſtory of theſe two brethren is ſet forth at large in the boke of Geneſis, but of the miſtery of the ſame, I entend at this preſent to make ſome diſcourſe.

div.head: ¶ The miſtery ſignified by Cain and Abell.
div.p: IN theſe two brethrē, two peoples are ſignified. In the yonger are ſignified the elect people of God, and eſpecially of the Gentiles. In the elder are ſignified reprobates, and ſpeciallye of the Iſraelites. Nor yet two peoples onelye are ſignified by them, but alſo the chiefe heades of them. VVherefore Abel is the tipe and figure of Chriſt which is the elect of all electes. And on the other ſide Cain is the tipe & figure of Antechriſt, which is the reprobate of all reprobates. The elect, I ſay, are noted in Abel, bicauſe he is counted the firſt iuſt man, not by the righteouſnes of nature, law, and fleſh, but by the righteouſnes of grace, faith, and the ſpirit. He is iuſt by the righteouſnes of Chriſt, of whom he was partaker through the ſpirite, no otherwiſe then as the mēbers are partakers of the influence of the head: and as the riuer is of the exundant flowing of the ſpring. For Chriſt is not onely full of grace and righteouſnes, but is ful of the original iuſtice, and capital grace, that al perſons may draw therof.
And wher it was ſaid before that in Abel wer ſignified the elect people, and ſpecially of the Gentiles: that was ſpoken partly bicauſe he is the yonger, and partly bicauſe his name is Abel.

For the firſt it doth playnly appeare that the Gentiles were younger then the Hebrues, for the Hebrues had their original being of Sem, which was Noes eldeſt ſonne, and the Gentiles came of Iaphet, a younger ſonne of his. They were younger I ſaye, not onelye in nature, but alſo in fayth, for as much as God did firſt open him ſelfe vnto the Iewes, and ſhewed them away how they ſhould worſhip him.

For the ſecond, Abel doth ſignify vayne, which doth well agree vnto the Gentiles, both before they were conuerted, and after they wer conuerted,
but yet in a diuers reſpect. Before they were conuerted, not onely bicauſe they were Athei, that is, knowing no God, vncertayne, vayne, ſwelling in their euil thoughtes, worſhipping idols, being without hope, without promiſe, without teſtament and couenantes, but alſo bicauſe God made none accompt of them, but as one ſuffring them to folow their own luſtes and wayes, yea and regarding them not onelye not to be hys people, but as though they were no people, as the Apoſtle Paule doth often times record.

Nowe after they were conuerted, they were likewiſe vaine, but yet in an other ſenſe. For when the moſt higheſt began to call thoſe thinges which were not, euen as thoſe thinges which were, and after it pleaſed him to make a people not his, to be his people: and after he had opened their eyes, and had ſurrogate them in the place of the Iſraelites, and made them his members: yet they were compted vayne, partly, bicauſe ſuch is the peoples iudgement of Gods elect, compting their life madnes, and their end without honour: partly, bicauſe they which be elect, are inwardly taught by Gods ſpirite, that there is nothing firme and ſure vnder the ſunne, but that all thinges are vanity, and affliction of the ſpirit, and ſpecially that the life of man is nothing els but a vapour, and that man is nothing els but Bulla, a buble of the water. The elect I ſay, being thus perſwaded, do litle regard thinges temporal: nor greatlye paſſe for them ſelues, nor do truſt to their own good woorkes, but deny them ſelues, hating their own life, and coumpting all thinges filthynes, which are without Chriſt, as Paule ſayth to the Philippians.

In Cain (as is ſayd before) the reprohates are ſignified,Philip. 3. bycauſe he is coumpted the firſt wycked man, the reprobate I ſay, ſpeciallye of the Hebrues, and that partly bicauſe he was the elder brother, and partlye bicauſe his name is interpreted poſſeſsion. The Hebrues did greatlye flatter them ſelues, and boaſted them ſelues to be the peculiar people of God, they were puft vp with incredible pride, and dyd perſwade them ſelues, that the whole world pertayned to them, bycauſe they dwelled in the chiefe and beſt place thereof. They bragged often ſaying:Phan. 8. Nos natura Iudaei, we by nature are Iewes, and not ſynners of the Gentiles. VVe are not borne in fornication, but we haue God for our father, wyth mary other ſuch brags.
Looke more of this matter, if ye wyll learne the fulnes thereof, in the booke called Scripturae medulla, compoed by Iacobus Naclantus.

div.head: Rachel & Lia. 25.
div.p: BY Rachel and Lia, are ſignified (as the diuines do writ) the two kinde of liues of man. By Lia, the actiue life, by Rachell, the contemplatiue life.
Lia is interpreted labour, and therfore it may well be applied to the actiue life of mā, which ought to cōtinue alway in ſome trauel & labor.
Lia was bleare eyed, by the which is ſignified the great cares and daily troubles, with the which man is preſſed, and enforced ſometime to weepe and mourne.
Rachel doth ſignifie the life ſpeculatiue, which is alwaies occupied in diuine matters, as the ſinfull woman did ſit at Chriſtes feete, pondering and weighing the wordes which ſhe heard of him.

Rachel is interpreted Ouis, a ſheepe, by the which is ſignified, that they which be geuen to the life contemplatiue, ſhoulde be meeke, geuing place, ſtudieng peace and quietnes, alwaies recording and chewing the cud of Gods law and his holy word.

div.head: Queſtio.
div.p: Geneſ. 31.VVhy did Rachel ſteale and conuey away her fathers idols, and what is ſignified therby?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Epheſ. 5. 1. Sam. 15.Couetouſnes is the ſeruing of idols, as ſaint Paule writeth to the Epheſians, and not to obey God, by the ſentence of Samuel it is coumpted alſo idolatry. Furthermore to obſerue ſuperſticiouſly the letters, the titles and the pointes of the law, (as the Cabaliſtes do) cannot be without the compaſſe of idolatrie.

Therfore that Rachel ſtole her fathers idols, is manifeſtlye ſignified that they which do truly know God, and do vewe godlye thinges, do not onely coumpt the thing before recited, to be fooliſh and vayne, but alſo wicked and diabolical.

Alſo by it is ſignified, that theſe twoo thinges, idolatrie and ſuperſtitious obſeruation of the law, are taken away by Rachel, that is to ſay by the faith in Chriſt, who did manifeſt and open the ſecretes of God, & taking away from the Phareſeies, the ſcriptures and oracle of the Prophetes, which they had corrupted with their falſe gloſes, did reſtore the true ſenſe and natural meaning vnto the law.
The whole miſtery that is ſignified by Lia and Rachel, is deſcribed at large in the ſayd booke of Naclantus before named.

div.head: Valerius Maximus. 26.
div.p:
THere were two of that name, the one called Valerius Potitus, who after the enuy which roſe concerning the office called Decem
Viratus, did mitigate and appeaſe with lawes, and certaine conditions, the people being ſtirred and moued againſt the Seniors.

The office of Decem viratus, was this: Ther were .x. men choſen and appointed, which ſhould make lawes, write, and publiſh them, and their authority was aboue al other, ſo that they might not onely make lawes, but alſo, if nede were, interprete them. And wher before were but .x. tables of lawes, they added vnto them two more, and ſo all theſe lawes together were called Leges duodecem tabularum. He (beyng the firſt Conſull after the .x. men called Decem viri, when he had vanquiſhed the people called Volſci) had a denial of the fathers for his triumph, but yet being the firſt, did make his triumphe, without the authoritye of the Senate, with his companion and fellow Marcus Horatius, and therefore he got this name to be called Valerius Maximus.

The other Valerius Maximus wrote worthy and memorable ſayings and geſtes, vnto Tiberius the Emperour, and did digeſt them in .9. bokes into common places. He was ſouldiour vnto Sextus Pompeius. He is called Valerius Maximus Hiſtoricus.

div.head: Alanus. 27.
div.p: THere were many of this name, one an engliſhe man called Alanus de Lynna, Allin of Lynne, a white Friar. He wrote one booke of diuers ſenſes of the ſcripture. He wrote alſo a booke of the morals of the Bible, and alſo the booke entituled, Sermones notabiles.
Maiſter Baal maketh mention of him in his booke De ſcriptoribus Angliae.
An other Alanus was called Alanus Teukeſberienſis, he wrote of the exile and life of Thomas Becket, Biſhop of Canterbury.
VVhat ſhal I ſpeake of other, as of Alanus Reſtaldus, which wrote the inſtitutions of the Hebrue Grammer?

But this Alanus, whome I alledge, was a Germane, and wrote many good workes, as the worke De complanctu naturae, and foure bookes vpon the ſentences. Likewiſe vpon the fiue bookes of Moſes, wyth many other. He flouriſhed in the yeare of our Lord. 1300.

div.head: Plinius. 28.
div.p: THer wer two of that name, who both were notably learned, the one was called Plinius ſecundus Veronenſis. He lyued in the time of Veſpatian, in whoſe affaires he was muche buſied. He wrote the moſt excellent woorke called Naturalis hiſtoria, which he wrote by night, and at certayne times by ſtelth.

Yet ſome ſay, that in that worke be many fables, and therefore he is named Pater fabularum, the father of lies. He would leeſe no time. He periſhed at the laſt in a certain hill, called Veſuuius, by fire, while he attempted to inueſtigate and ſearch the cauſe why the toppe therof ſhould be baren.

There was an other called Cecilius Plinius, neuew to the firſt Plinie by his ſiſter, who wrote eloquent Epiſtles, and one oration to Traian the Emperour, in his commendation, which oration is named Panegericus. In the which he geueth thankes vnto Traian, who made him Conſul. He helped the doughter of Quintiliā with a dowry, and alſo he ſuccoured Martialis the Poet, departing with neceſſary coſtage for iourny, as Volateranus writeth. Lib. 18.

div.head: Aediles. 29.
div.p: AEdilis was an officer, whoſe charge was to ſee the mayntaining of the Temples and priuate houſes, and to make prouiſion for ſolemne playes. Of them ſome were called Ediles curules, of a chair with crooked feete, wherin they did ſit, other wer called Aediles plebis, bicauſe they were choſen out of the people or commons.

div.head: Quirites. 30.
div.p: QVirites was a name, wherby the Romanes wer called by their firſt king Romulus, called Quirinus, who was ſo called of thys word Quiris, which ſignifieth in the Sabin tounge a ſpeare, which weapon Romulus did continually beare. Other write that he was ſo named of his father Mars, who was called when he was fierce, Gradiuus, when he was peaceable and quiet, Quirinus.

div.head: Bias. 31.
div.p: BIas was one of the ſeuen wyſe mē of Grece (beholding his coūtrye taken by enemies) fled, other men carying with them ſuch goods as they might beare: he was demaunded why he tooke nothyng with him, whereto he anſwered: Trulye I carye all my goods with me, meaning vertue and doctrine, reputing the goods of Fortune none of his.

div.head: Paraſites. 32.
div.p:
PAraſitus is properlye he which haunteth other mens trenchers, which alſo doth prayſe all the wordes and dedes of him, in whoſe companye he is, doth neuer reſiſt, but ſuffereth all thinges, and refuſeth to do nothing, for his bellies ſake, in the which he doth conſtitute his chiefe pleaſure, & of this he tooke his name quod
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , hoc eſt, e cibo totus pendeat, he hangeth altogether of meate. The image and nature of a paraſite Terence doth trimly deſcribe
in his Comedie called Eunuchus. The name of a Paraſite, as Atheneus teacheth. lib. 6. was once an honeſt name, for they were geuen to the holy miniſtery, and Paraſites were called in times paſt the companions and fellowes of Biſhops and Magiſtrates. This word Paraſitus, hath the laſt ſillable ſauing one long. Horatius, lib. 2. epiſt. 1. quamuis ſit Dorcennus edacibus in paraſitis.

div.head: Fire in one hand. 33.
div.p: THe like prouerbe is in Plautus, Altera manu fert lapidem, altera panem oſtentat. In one hand he beareth a ſtone, in the other hand he ſheweth bread. By this they are ſignified, which to the face flatter and ſpeake faire, but priuely they do detract and report the wurſt.
