And although ſuch Pamphelions (for the moſt parte) do ſauer groſſe & ſuperſticious doctrine, yet ſometime they ſpeake truly and profitably, as the common prouerbe runneth. Sepe etiā eſt holitor valde opportuna locutus. The gardiner ſomtimes ſpeaketh apt & meete things. One demaūded of Virgill, what he did with Ennius workes in his hādes, who made anſwere: Ex ſtercore Ennii aurū colligo. I gather golde out of Ennius doung. So one may gather out of barbarous writers, ſome profitable leſſons. The rule concerning faith is this. That Chriſtiā faith (ſaith he) may be accepted of God, it ought to be perfect, according to the ſignification
of euerie letter in this worde Fides, which be fiue in nomber.

Rom. 2. Matth. 7.The firſt letter is F. which ſignifieth Facere, to do, as Paul ſaith, nō auditores legis ſed factores iuſtificabuntur. And as Chriſt himſelf ſaith, nō omnis qui dicit mihi dn̄e, domine, intrabit in regnum caelorū, ſed qui facit voluntatem patris mei. Not al, which ſay to me maſter maſter, ſhal enter into the kingdome of heauē, but he that doth the will of my father. Alas, how many be there, whiche ſay with mouth, I beleue in Chriſt the ſonne of God, but in dede do deny him? VVhat is it to beleue in God and Chriſt his ſonne, but to grow in vertue & grace, toward God as S. Auſtē ſaith? VVere it not (thincke you) an horrible thyng to heare any mā ſay, I do not beleue in Chriſt, but in the deuill? And yet it is more horrible, to profeſſe it in word,Tit. 1. & to deny it in worke, for workes be of greater efficacie thē wordes. I pray God yt the ſaying of S. Paule maye not iuſtely be verified in ye moſt part of people. Confitētur ſe noſce deum, factis autē negant. They confeſſe God with mouth, but with workes they deny him.

The ſecōd letter of this word Fides, is I. which ſignifieth integritie & fulnes in faith, yt is, that the Chriſtiā mā, beleue al ye articles of ye faith to be true, & to doubt & erre in none of thē: As to beleue in Chriſt to be verie god, & to deny his true māhood, as ye Anabaptiſtes do: Alſo to beleue Chriſt to be natural mā (ſinne onely excepted) & to deny him to be god, as ye Arriās do. But euery Chriſtiā mā muſt beleue fully & wholy euery article cōteined in the ſimbole of ye Apoſtles, cōmōly called ye Crede. Other wiſe his faith is not perfect, for he lacketh this letter I, as al heretikes & ſectaries do againſt this letter, and all ſouth ſayers & enchaunters likewiſe offende, as the ſaying is in the lawe: Qui diuinationibus, credit fidē perdit, he that beleueth enchauntements, leeſeth his faith.
The third letter is D. which ſignifieth Dilectionē, loue & charitie, as Paul ſaith,Gal. 5. Fides que ꝑ dilectionē oꝑatur, faith whiche worketh by loue.

S. Bernard writeth, yt Mors fidei, eſt ſeparatio charitatis. The lacke of charity, is ye death of faith. And againe he ſaith. Credis in Chriſtum? fac Chriſti opera in charitate: vt viuat fides tua, fidē tuam dilectio animet. Dooſt yu beleue in Chriſt? do the workes of Chriſt in charity & loue, yt thy faith may liue, let loue giue life vnto thy faith. The ſcholaſticall diuines haue a generall rule, that faith without charitie, is Fides informis.

S. Auſtē writeth. Quod cū dilectione fides eſt chriſtiant, ſine dilectione fides eſt demonis, nā demones credūt & cōtremiſcūt: with loue it is the faith of a chriſtiā, without loue it is ye faith of the deuill, for ye deuils beleue & feare. Againe vpon Iohn he ſaith: Cōfitebātur demones Chriſtū, credēdo nō diligēdo, fidē habebāt, charitatē nō habebant. Ideo demones erāt. The deuils cōfeſſed Chriſt in beliefe, not in loue, fayth they had, but charitie they had not, and therefore they were deuils. So all chriſtians whiche do beleue, and not loue, as long as they do continue, are not chriſtians, but in a maner are to be called deuils.

The fourth letter is E. whiche ſignifieth externe, & expreſſe, outwardely,
expreſly and plainely, for it is not ſufficient to haue and holde faith in hart, vnleſſe you confeſse it with mouth and workes, as Paule ſaith. Rom. 10. Corde creditur ad iuſticiā, ore fit confeſsio ad ſalutē, with harte we beleue to be iuſtified, and with mouth we confeſſe to be ſaued. Yf at the leaſt opportunitie and time will ſerue.

div.head: Quaeſtio.
div.p: VVhat if a man in the time of perſecution, reſerue and keepe in hys hart the true faith, but for feare of death, loſse of goods, or any other like plague, doth conſent to heretickes, and doth conceale and kepe cloſe the truth?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: All the ſchole Doctors to this queſtion make this aunſwere, that if by his ſilēce and enſaumple other take offence, or do ſwerue from the right faith, then the ſaid partie is in the ſtate of dampnatiō. But after my iudgement he offendeth, and that greatly without all exceptions, and conditions, becauſe the confeſsion of faith is neceſſarie, De praecepto, to be declared outwardly, aſwell as to be beleued inwardly.

The fifth letter is S. which ſignifieth Semper, alwayes that is to haue faith aſwell in the ende, as in the beginning, euen to perſeuer and continue as Chriſt ſaith. Beatus ille qui perſeuerauerit vſ
que ad finē. Matth. 24. Bleſſed is he which cōtinueth to the ende. And as S. Paule ſaith. Heb. 11. Heb. 11. Sine fide impoſsibile eſt placere deo, without faith it is vnpoſsible to pleaſe god. But you muſt here vnderſtād, yt this faith before deſcribed, is not ye iuſtifieng faith, but it is yt faith, which doth declare a man to be already iuſtified. VVhich faith ye ſchole mē call Fidē formatā: but the faith that doth iuſtifie, doth praecede and go before all maner of good workes, as S. Gregorie writeth vpon Ezechiell. VVhoſe wordes be theſe. Niſi prius Fides teneatur, nullatenꝰ ad ſpiritualē amorē attingitur, non enim charitas fidē ſed fides charitatē praecedit, quia nemo poteſt amare, quod nō credidit. Except faith be firſt had and holden, you cā by no maner of wiſe attaine to ſpirituall loue, for charitie doth not go before fayth, but faith doth praecede charitie. &c. The like ſaying hath S. Auſten writing vpon Iohn Sicut in radice arboris nulla prorſus apparet pulchritudinis ſpecies, & tamen quicquid eſt in arbore pulchritudinis vel decoris, ex illa procedit ſic exfidei humilitate quicquid meriti, quicquid beatitudinis anima ſuſceptura eſt, ex fidei fundamēto procedit. That is: Like as in the roote of a tree there appeareth no bewtie at all, and yet whatſoeuer ornament or comelines is in the whole tree, it procedeth of it: So whatſoeuer merite, whatſoeuer happines, the ſoule ſhall receaue of the lowlineſſe of fayth, it ſpringeth of the foundation of faith.

I am not ignoraunt how the maſter of the ſentence, doth reſtraine the
ſaying of Gregory, to that faith que nō eſt virtus (as he ſaith) whiche is no vertue: but how aptely and truly, I referre it to the iudgement of the learned, or els (ſaith he) you may referre it to the acte of faith, whiche naturally doth go before the acte of charitie.
But of this matter I ſhal entreate (by the grace of God) more at large hereafter in that Lecture, wherein I ſhall diſcourſe the article of iuſtification.

div.head: Arte. 7.
div.p: THis worde Ars (as ſome do write) is deriued, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . That is to ſay Virtus, vertue. Other write that it commeth of this verbe Arcto, whiche he tokeneth to binde straight together, bycauſe by arte, workes are aptely restrayned together.
The definition of this worde Ars, is diuerſe. Some define it to be Facultatē quae preceptis quibuſdā ac regulis continetur, whiche is conteyned in certayne preceptes and rules.

Diomedes doth define arte after this maner. Ars eſt rei cuiuſcun
que ſciē tia, vſu, traditione, vel ratione percepta, tendens ad vſum aliquē vitae neceſſariū. That is to ſay, Arte is a ſciēce or knowledge of any thing perceaued by vſe, traditiō or reaſon, tēding to ſome neceſſary vſe of mās life.
Ariſtotle in the ſixte of his Ethickes defineth arte after this maner. Ars eſt habitus quidā faciendi cū vera ratione. That is, It is a certayn habite or doing with true reaſon.

div.head: Diuiſio.
div.p: Artes are deuided three maner of wayes: ſome be called Theoricae, that is, Speculatiue, which doth conſiſt in the knowledge, eſtimatiō & ſpeculation of thinges as Aſtrologie, whiche doth not require any arte, but is contented onely with the vnderſtandyng of that thynge whiche it doth ſtudie.

Other artes be called Practicae, that is, actiue, and they do conſiſt & ſtande in doing, whoſe chief ende is to be made perfect in acte, and after the acte is done, doth leaue no ſigne nor token, as daunſing, wreſtlyng, and ſuch lyke.

Thirdly other artes be called Effectiuae, that is, whiche doe conſiſt and ſtand in effect, which doth ſet fourth ye conſummation, and bringing to paſſe the worke which is ſet before the eyes, as paynting, caruing, & ſuch like. Ars ſignifieth ſometimes, ſubtletie and craft, whether it be in the beſt part, or in the worſt, by the which a mā wil not lightly be diſceaued, but may rather diſceaue other, which is called in ye Greeke: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .
Virgill in his Aeneidos, writeth thus of one Sinon. Dolis inſtructus & arte pelaſga: that is, armed with deſceit & craft of the Grecians.

div.head: Draconites. 8.
div.p: DRaconites is a precious ſtone, whiche is made of the braine of Dragons, but the braine doth neuer waxe to that vertue, except the head be cut of from the Dragon beyng aliue, and that is through the enuie of the beaſte, perceauing and feeling him ſelfe to die, therfore the maner is to cut of their heades, when they be a ſleepe. The ſtone is of a wonderfull bright colour, and cā not be better poliſhed and trimmed, then it is of his own nature.

div.head: Philoſophie. 9.
div.p: TErtuliā in his booke Contra Hermoginē, doth call the Philoſophers, the patriarkes of all heretickes. Pithagoras was the firſt that euer named himſelfe a Philoſopher, refuſing the name of Sophos, a wiſe man, as the name of a more arrogancie, for he had rather be called a louer of wiſdome, then a wiſe man.

div.head: Sinagog. 10.
div.p: SYnagoga, betokeneth in Latin a congregatiō or company of people. The Churche of the Iewes which were the peculiar people of God, was ſometyme called Synagoga, for Synagoga doth ſignifie, that ſame thing that Eccleſia doth, but for the obſtinacie and vnplacable hatred of the Iewes, which they bare agaynſt Chriſtian Religion, it is become vile, and almoſt out of vſe.
Saint Hierome Ad Geronciam viduam: doth write, that Lia with her bleare eyes, and Rachel (whom Iacob loued verie wel) doth ſignifie, the firſt, the ſinagoga of the Iewes, the ſeconde, the Churche.

div.head: Epitheton. 11.
div.p: EPitheton, is a figure, which may properly be called a worde caſt or put vnto a nowne ſubſtantiue: and that for diuerſe and ſoundry cauſes, either for the cauſe of difference, as Ida Phrigia, a great hill by Troye. VVhiche word Phrigia is an Epitheton and maketh the ſubſtantiue Ida, to differ from an other hill ſo called, which is in the countrie of Creta, now called Candie.
Secondly, Epitheton is added for the cauſe of ſome proprietie, as Venuſta venus, fayre Lady Venus. Coelum profundū, the great high heauē.

Thirdly, it is put vnto a ſubſtātiue, for the cauſe of ſome Emphaſis or vehemencie, to make the worde ſeeme more, then if it ſhould be without it, whether it be in the better ſenſe, or in the woorſe. As O ſacratiſsimū dei verbū, O thou moſt holy worde of God. O ſcelus abominādū. O moſt
abhominable wicked dede, ſo in the better ſenſe, is this Epitheton Sacra, holy, put vnto Scriptura, ſcripture, to make it differ from all other ſcriptures, in dignitie and worthines, whatſoeuer they be.

div.head: Superſtition. 12.
div.p: SVperſtition is a falſe worſhipping of God, a mad, & foliſh error contrary vnto true religion, bycauſe it doth giue yt honor, either to whom it might not be giuen, or els after what maner it ought not to be geuē, & therfore Aulus Gellius, in his tenth boke doth call ſuperſtitiō, a foliſh religiō out of ſeaſon. Lucretius doth thincke yt it is called ſuperſtition, of a vayne & ſuperſtitious feare of things, ſtanding vpō, or ouer, that is of heauenly or diuine thinges, whiche ſtand aboue vs.

Cicero in his ſecond booke De natura deorum, writeth of this worde after this ſorte. Non ſolū Philoſophi, verū etiā maiores noſtri ſuperſtitionē a religione ſeperauerunt, nā qui totos dies precabantur & immolabant, vt ſibi ſui liberi ſuperſtites eſſent, ſuperſtitioſi ſunt appellati, yt is to ſay. Not onely ye Philoſophers, but alſo our aūciēts, did ſeperate & deuide ſuperſtitiō frō religion, for they which did offer & pray ye whole day, yt their childrē might be lōg liued, were called ſuperſtitioſi, ſuperſtitious, of this word ſuꝑſtes, which ſignifieth, to ſtād euer, or remaine ſtil.

Lactātius doth coumpt thē chiefly to be called ſuperſtitious, which do celebrate the continuall memorie of ye dead, or which do worſhip at home in their houſes, images ſet vp for their parēts, as though they were Gods.

div.head: Alchoran. 13.
div.p: ALchoran is an Arabicall worde, and ſignifieth by interpretation Collectaneū praeceptorū, a gathering together of cōmaūdemētes into one booke, the whiche booke Machumet, fained to be ſent to him from God by the aūgell Gabriell. In the which booke are mixt moſt ſhamefull and abhominable lyes, with ſome part of ſcripture, and neceſſarie lawes (although theſe be feweſt.) And as the Turkes & Saraſens are directed by the Alchoran: So the Iewes haue a booke called Talmud, whiche by interpretation, is a doctrine or diſcipline, conteyning all their former cōmentaries, ſtatutes, lawes, and hiſtories, which were collected into one booke by Rabbi, written and made as ſome ſay the yeare after Chriſt .CCC. other ſay .CL. Galatinus writeth .CCCC. xxxvi. yeares after the burnyng of the ſecond Temple.

Machumet was firſt a poore man, and a byer and ſeller of Cammels. Afterwarde he fell acquainted with an hereticke moncke called Sergius, by whoſe meanes he declared himſelfe to be a Prophet: and tooke vpon him aſwell to refourme ye olde law, as the new. He wonne great realmes, and at the age of fortie yeares died (as ſome ſuppoſe) of ye falling ſickenes,
which he long time did diſſemble, fayning that the aungell Gabriell was ſent to him in meſſage, whoſe brightenes he might not ſuſteyne.

div.head: Chaan. 14.
div.p: CHaan, he is alſo called the Emperour of the Tartarians, there is vnder him as much land (within litle) as in the reſidue of all Aſia, Europa, and Africa. He hath vnder hym the great region called Cathay, whiche is deuided into nyne realmes. This Cathay, is wonderfull rich in golde and ſiluer, abounding in graine, wines, and all other thinges neceſſarie for mans ſuſtenaunce. The people there (for the moſt parte) honor Christ as God, but they are not Baptized, they are curteous, and reaſonable, and very cunnyng artificers.

div.head: Sacrum. 15.
div.p: THis diſeaſe is a vehement inflamation and burning of the body, it is called in the Greke toung 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. feruens tumor, of this diſeaſe Celſus. Lib. 5. Colum. lib. 1. cap. 5. and Plinie ſpeaketh more at large. And here note that this word Sacer, hath many ſignifications: firſt it betokeneth venerable or holy, ſecōdly it ſignifieth curſed & wicked, as in this place of Virgill. Auri ſacra fames &c. In the old time yt man was called Sacer homo, which after horrible curſings was ſlaine & offred to one of the gods, to ceſſe the peſtilence, or to put away any other kind of calamity, and it is taken generally for euery naughty and wicked perſon, as it is taken alſo in Horace. Plinie calleth this diſeaſe Zoſter, alſo the falling ſickenes is called Sacer morbus.

div.head: Liberall ſciences. 16.
div.p: THere be ſeuen liberall ſciences, of the which three are called Artes benedicendi, as Grammer, Logicke, and Rhetoricke, and Grammer is called Ars triuialis, quia in triuiis docetur, bycauſe it is taught almoſt in euery ſtreete and place.

The other foure are called Mathematicall, as Arithmeticke, Geometrie, Muſicke, Aſtronomy, and they be ſo called, bycauſe they are learned by moſt firme and ſure demonſtrations, and doth make the thyng to be knowen by reaſon, and by ſome certaine cauſe.
Mathematicum, is a Greke worde, and ſignifieth diſciplinall, or doctrinall, or demonſtratiue.

All theſe ſeuē ſciences be called liberall ſciēces. i. Quod liberū hoīem potiſsimū deceant, bycauſe they be moſt meete & expediēt to be learned of gentilmen and of free men, for it is illiberall and ſeruile to get the leuing, with hand labour and ſweate of the body. All artes & occupations exerciſed and vſed with trauell of handes and payne of body, are called
Artes maechanicae, as carpentrye and ſmithes worke, with ſuch like and they are ſo called of this Greke worde 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . VVhiche ſignifieth Inuentionem, inuention, or an excogitation, a craft.

div.head: Diſcipline. 17.
div.p: THat is called diſcipline which is learned of ye ſcholler, and yt doctrine which is taught of the maiſter. S. Cipriā writeth diſcipline to be an ordinarie reformation of maners, and an obſeruation of the rules and inſtitutions of our auncetours, and forefathers. It is properly an ordre preſcribed for the maintenaunce of good and honeſt life, and for the reſtrainte of all enormities and diſorders.

S. Auſten in his boke De moribus eccleſie, writeth that Diſciplina ad duo diuiditur, ad correctionē & inſtructionem, primū timore, ſecundū amore perficitur, that is to ſay, diſcipline is deuided into two, into correction, and inſtruction, the firſt is done by feare, the ſecond by loue.

Againe in his ſermons: Sermone. 52. he ſayth. Non enim ſuperbia, niſi vbi negligitur diſciplina, nam diſciplina eſt magiſtra religionis & verae pietatis, quae nec ideo increpat vt ledat, nec ideo caſtigat vt noceat, denique mores hoīm irata corrigit, inflāmata cuſtodit. There is no pride, but where diſcipline is neglected, for diſcipline is ye maiſtres of Religion and true godlines, which doth rebuke, not to hurte, and doth chaſten, but not to anoye, beyng angrie, it doth chaſten the maners of mē, being inflamed in loue, it doth preſerue and kepe them.

div.head: Darcke. 18.
div.p: THe body is darcke, Chriſt ſaith in Mathewe. cap. 6. If thine eye be wicked, then all thy body ſhalbe darke. Hilarius vpon this texte doth write, that Chriſt did expreſſe hereby the office of the light of the eye, the light of the hart, which if it be clere, it geueth vnto the body the clerenes of euerlaſting life.

And (as Chriſoſtome ſaith) Quod eſt oculus corpori, hoc eſt intellectus animae. Sicut ergo oculis orbatis, multū operationis reliquorum membrorū amittitur, lumme eis extincto, ita mēte corrupta, multis malis vita tua impletur. That is, what the eye is vnto the body, the ſame is vnderſtanding vnto the ſoule. Therfore as the worcking of all the other mēbers is loſt, vnto thē which lacke their eyes (the light of thē being put out) ſo the minde being corrupt, the life is filled with many euils.

The darckenes of vs are the carnall ſenſes, which do alway deſire and couet thoſe thinges whiche ſauour of darckenes, as concupiſcence, couetouſnes, and all other corrupt affectiōs, whiche affectiōs make the whole mā both body & ſoule, darcke. And this teache the holy ſcriptures, who if they be wel redde, digeſted and folowed, giue light & life to the whole body, which thing no other ſcripture could at any tyme perfourme.

div.head: Enchaunters. 19.
div.p: SAint Auſtē in his worke De natura demonū ſaith, the maner of diuination and enchauntment to haue bene brought frō the Perſiās. Varro nombreth foure kindes of incantacions, of the earth, of ye water, of the aire, & of ye fire, wherof ſome thincke Geomancie, Hidromācie, and Pyromancie to haue taken their names.

Alſo in his booke De ciuitate dei, he writeth. Nec mirum de magorum praeſtigiis, quorū in tantum prodiere maleficiorū artes, vt etiā Moyſi in illis ſignis reſtitiſſe, vertentes virgas in dracones, aquā in ſanguinē dicā tur. &c. that is. Neither is it maruel of the deluſions & diſceit of the enchaunters, whoſe wicked artes and craftes went ſo farre, that they reſiſted Moyſes in thoſe great wonders, turning their roddes into ſerpentes, and water into bloud. And a litle after he ſayth. Theſe by the permiſsion and ſufferaunce of God, do make the elementes to ſhake, and do trouble the mindes of men, not hauingful truſt in God, yea and without any taſt of poyſon do kill men, by the violence and force of enchaunting. VVherupon Lucanus writeth.

p.hi: Mens hauſti nulla ſanie polluta veneni Incantata perit.

div.p: The minde whiche is enchaunted, doth periſhe and dye, yea being not polluted with any kind of poyſon.

div.head: Quaeſtio.
div.p: VVhy could not the inchaunters of Pharao bryng to paſſe this wonder, of turning the duſt of ye earth into Lyce, aſwell as they did the other thre wonders before, in turning the roddes into ſerpentes, the water into bloud, and to bring fourth the frogges?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Certaine of the Hebrues doo aſsigne this cauſe: The deuils (ſay they) whoſe helpe and power ye ſorcerers do vſe, haue no power vpon that body or matter, that is leſſe then a Barly Corne, whiche cauſe is fond, foliſhe and cleane agaynſt reaſon, for that which hath power ouer great, hath power ouer the ſmall, but not the contrarie.

Therfore the true cauſe is, becauſe the deuils can do nothing, but ſo much as the wil of God doth permit and ſuffer. And therfore the ſorcerers whiche reſiſted Moſes, were let of God in this, that they ſhould be confounded and aſhamed, bycauſe they could not do ſo ſmall and ſo litle a thing, for God doth often times confounde the wiſedome and great authoritie of the world, in thinges moſt vile.

Two thinges are here to be obſerued, the one is this. Satan (by whoſe power the ſorcerers worke wonders) is a mighty & ſtrong ſpirit if God ſuffer him, but if God reſiſte his power, there is nothing weaker then he, feare therfore the Lord, and thou ſhalt not nede to feare Satan.
The other is, although the wicked worke miracles and wonders, yet the Lord God is wont to bring ſuch to good ſucceſſe and end, that ye elect may clerely vnderſtād the diſceit and craft of Satan.
Saint Auſten in his booke De natura demonum, reciteth the difference and diuerſe ſortes of ſorcerers, his wordes be theſe. Incantatores dicuntur, qui artem verbis peragunt.

p.hi: Arioli dicuntur, qui circa aras Idilorum, nefarias preces emittunt, & funeſta ſacrificia offerunt.
Haruſpices dicuntur, horarum inſpectatores, dies enim & horas in agendis negotiis & operibus cuſtodiunt, exta pecudum inſpiciunt.
Angures dicuntur, qui volatus auium & voces intendunt.
Pythoniſſae dicuntur a Pythone, id eſt, Apoline, quae dicunt ſe habere ſpiritum per quem poſſunt futura praedicere.
Geneſiani dicuntur, qui geneſes, id eſt natiuitates hominum, per duodecem ſigna caeli deſcribunt, ac per hoc mortes, actus, euentus predicere conantur.
Salitores dicūtur, qui alicuius mēbri parte offenſa, aliquid mali, proſperum ſiue triſte, ſignificari praeſumunt.

div.p: Sorcilegi communi nomine, a ſorte dicuntur, the whole ſentence of S. Auſten is thus much to ſay in Engliſhe.
They are called enchaunters or chermers whiche worke by wordes.
They be Arioli, which ſend out their wicked prayers, and offer cruell and bloudy ſacrifices about altars of Idols.
Haruſpices be they, whiche marke and behold the houres, for in all their buſines and workes, they kepe and obſerue houres, and looke vpon the inwarde partes of beaſtes.
Angures are they, which waite & obſerue ye flieng & crieng of birdes.
Pythoniſſae are ſo called, of Pithonius, that is Apollo, which (ſay they) haue a ſpirite, by the which they can tell thinges to come.
Geneſiani be they whiche deſcribe the natiuities of men by the twelue ſignes of heauen, and by that attempt to foreſhew the deathes, the actes, and endes of perſons.
Salitores, be they whiche by obſeruing of any part or member beyng hurte, doo preſume ſome euill or ſad thing to be ſignified vnto them.
Sortilegi, are called by a common name of caſting lottes.
But of what vertue & goodnes all theſe kindes be, S Auſtē in his firſt boke De doctrina chriſtiana, doth moſt godly declare, his words be theſe.

Oēs artes huiuſmodi, vel nugatoriae, & noxiae ſuꝑſtitiones, ex quadā peſtifera ſocietate hoīm & demonū, quaſi pacta infidelis & doloſe amici tia cōſtituta, penitꝰ ſūt repudiādae & fugiēdae chriſtiano, that is to ſay.

All ſuch crafts and artes of a trifling and hurtefull ſuperſtition, which came by a peſtiferous and naughtie felowſhip and familiaritie, betwene men and deuils, made by the pacte and couenant of an vnfaithfull and
diſceitfull friendſhip, are to be forſaken, and fled of euery Chriſtiā man.

God in the .20. ca. of Leuiticus ſayth. If any turne after ſuch as worke with ſpirites & after ſouth ſayers, to go a whoring after thē, I wil ſet my face againſt that perſon, & will cut him of from among his people.

Fulgoſus lib. 1. ca. 2. writeth of one Miſonianus an Hebrew, a noble and valeaūt horſeman, who when he perceaued that the whole company of horſemē were cauſed to ſtaye and tarry, in the which he was one, with the other ſouldiours of Rome, and vnderſtood the cauſe of their tarieng to be, for that a certayne ſouthſayer would firſt ſee what diuination he could take of a bird, which he found in the way, Miſonianus feinyng him ſelfe to do an other thing, bent his bowe and at the firſt ſhout, ſmote the bird through, downe to the grounde, and laughing ſayd to his fellowes. A man may hope for litle counſel and helpe of beaſtes voyde of reaſon, for as much as it is now opened that they know not what pertayneth to thē ſelues, by whoſe deede and worde he ſhewed, what a vayne thing, this kinde of ſouthſaying is, and what a fooliſhe thing it is to giue any credit vnto any enchaunting or ſouthſaying.

div.head: Digitus Dei. 20.
div.p:
SAint Auſten ſaith. Dicitur ſpiritus ſāctus digitus dei, propter participationem bonorum, quae in eo dantur vnicui
que propria, ſiue hominum ſiue angelorum. In nullis enim mēbris noſtris magna tam apparet partitio, quam in digitis.

That is to ſay, the holy ſpirite is called the finger of God, for the participation of the giftes, whiche in it are geuen, as proper to euery one, either to men, or to aungels, for partition doth in no member or parte of ours, more appeare, then in the fingers.

Cirillus Biſhop of Alexādria writeth, Quod filius manus & brachiū patris dictus eſt, operatur enim pater cūcta per eum: Sicut igitur digitus non eſt alienusa manu, ſed ei naturaliter inſitus, ſic ſpiritus ſanctus cōſubſtantialiter cōnexus eſt filio, & per eum omnia filius operatur. Non eſt igitur aliud ſpiritus a deitatis eſſentia, ſed ex ipſa & in ipſa naturaliter, ſicut & digitus in manu, & manus in corpore eſt, that is to ſay.

The ſonne is called the hād and arme of the father, for the father worketh all things by him. Therfore as the finger is not diuerſe frō the hād, but naturally graffed to the hand, ſo the holy ghoſt is eſſentially connexed and knit to the ſonne, and the ſonne by the ſame ſpirite worketh all things. VVherfore the ſpirite is not an other thing from the ſubſtaūce of the deitie, but is naturally of it and in it, as the finger is in the hand, and the hand in the body, for the finger is of the ſubſtaunce of the hand, and the hande is of the ſubſtaunce of the body. The like writeth Didimus Alexandrinus lib. de ſpiritu ſancto. Alſo Hugo Etherianus lib. de proceſsione ſancti ſpiritus.

div.head: Liuius. 21.
div.p: LIuius being prince and chiefeſt of ye Latin writers of hiſtories, wrate. 120. bookes of hiſtories, which by the malignitie of time are loſt, & there remaine onely thre decades & an half. Decas properly is yt which conteineth 10. bookes, or 10. ſermons or treaties. Saint Hierome in his Epiſtle Ad Paulinū ſaith, that many noble men came out of the coſtes of Spayne and Fraunce vnto Liuie, who did flowe with the milckie fountaine of eloquence, and that the onely fame of Liuie, brought to Rome them whom the Citie her ſelfe could not bryng, to behold her: he liued 80. yeares and died in the .4. yeare of the Empire of Tiberius, and was buried at Padwaye.

div.head: Faedus. 22.
div.p: FAedus is properly a league made betwene princes, and a truce after battell. Some men thincke the etymologie of this word originally to be deriued of this word Faeciales, whiche ſignifieth an Ambaſſadour of armes, whiche denounceth warre or peace.
Other do thincke it to come of Fides, becauſe in makyng the treatie of peace, faith was promiſed.

Certayne other do thincke it to come of Faede caedendo, that is to kill cruelly, for two Heraldes of armes were ſet on either ſide, & a ſowe betwene them, whē they ſhould confirme any league, and with a flint ſtone did kill the ſowe, praying that lyke ende might happen vnto hym that firſt did breake the treatie made.

div.head: Immolatio. 23.
div.p: IMmolare properly is to offer with the ſacrifice a cake made of meale and ſalte, for Mola, ſignifieth the ſayd cake, and it doth differ from Litare, for Litare, properly is with the ſacrifice to pacifie the gods, and to obteine their requeſte, and deſire, and (as Feſtus ſayth) it commeth of the Greke worde, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which betokeneth prayers.
Sacrificare, is petereveniā, to aſke pardon and forgiuenes, as Nonnius writeth.

div.head: Seruius. 24.
div.p:
THere were two of yt name, one called Seruius Maurus honoratus, which was alſo named Marius Sergius, he wrote commentaries In vtram
que artem, Aelii Donati, and commentaries vpon Virgils workes.
The other was named Seruius Sulpitius, verie familiar and welbeloued of Marcus Cicero, he wrote two bookes of edictes vnto Brutus, he wrote alſo other workes vnto other men.

div.head: Myſterium. 25.
div.p: MYsterium is a Greke word, it cōmeth 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and it ſignifieth certaine ſecrete holy thinges, which ought not to be reuealed: we may cal it in Latine Secluſum, ſhut vp. It was not lawful, but very haynous for any man, to reueale and open the holy miſteries, vnles he were one of the religious order. Therfore a certaine Poet was ſtriken blind, bicauſe he vttered and ſhewed forth certain miſteries

Euſebius libro ſecundo de preparatione Euangelica writeth, that in the holy feaſts and places of the goddeſſes Iſis and Seraphis, the image of Harpocrates was ſet, which holding his finger vpon his lips, did admoniſh that there ſhould be ſilence kept.

Chriſoſtomus. cap. 2. 1. ad Corinth, writeth that Miſterium is taken three maner of wayes. Firſt (when of that thing which we ſee wyth our outward eyes) we behold and iudge an other thing to be ment and ſignified, as our Sacramentes are. The heatheniſh man, when he ſeeth Baptiſme to be miniſtred, he beholdeth onely the water. But we ſeing it, doo conſider remiſsion of ſinnes, waſhing of the minde, regeneration of the ſoule, and ſuch lyke matters.
Alſo in the Sacrament of the Lords table, the Heathen behold onely bread and wine, we conſider and behold with the eyes of fayth the body and blood of Chriſt, which were geuen for vs.

Secondly, a miſtery is that, by the which is ſignified Paradoxa, and thoſe things which do come beſides hope, & not looked for. In the which ſence Paule ſayth: Ecce miſterium dico vobis. Behold I ſhewe you a miſtery, we ſhall not all ſleepe, but we ſhal al be chaunged.
Againe to the Romanes he ſaith: I wyl not haue you brethren to be ignorant of this miſtery, that blindnes is chaunſed vnto Iſrael.

In like maner Eſay the Prophet faith: Secretū mihi, ſecretum mihi, Eſay. 24. a ſecrete to me, a ſecret to me, he ſpeaketh of the euerſion & ouerthrow of the people, which ſhould come ſodenly, and vtterly oppreſſe them.

Thirdly, that is called a miſtery, which partly is knowen, and partly vnknowen, and in this kinde is the wiſdome of the Chriſtians ſet and repoſed, for now we ſee darkly, as it wer in a glaſſe,1. Cor. 13. but then in heauen we ſhall ſee clearely face to face. And by this it behoueth vs Chriſtians to be ſturred to render thankes vnto God, for that he woulde haue his miſteries after a ſort to be knowen vnto vs, when they are concealed and kept cloſe from other.

div.head: Prophanum. 26.
div.p:
PRophanum hath manye ſignifications. Firſt, it is that which is not holy. Secondly, it ſignifieth a temporal, vnlearned, and lay-man.
Thirdly, wycked and vngodly.

The Etimologie of the word is this. Profanum dicitur quaſi porro a fano, farre of from the church. Some deriuing this word out of the greke, thinke, it ſhould be rather writen with (Ph.) then with (F) and the olde authors dyd write Hanum, for Fanum.

div.head: Paule. 27.
div.p: COncerning the name of Paule, diuers learned men haue diuers iudgementes. Saint Hierome thinketh that he was called firſt Saulus, and afterward Paulus, by conuerting one Sergius Paulus vnto the fayth, and receaued that name Paulus, tanquam trophaeum, as a victory.
Other ſuppoſe, that he being a Phareſie, was called Saulus, but after his conuerſion, was called Paulus, ſo that his religion being chaunged, he chaunged his name.

Origine thinketh that he had two names, and was called both Saule and Paule, as many in the Bible were called by two names, as Leuie and Mathew wer the names of one man, Idida and Salomon the names of one man. Vnto Paule is applied the prophecy and bleſsing that Iacob gaue to Beniamin. In the morning he ſhall eate his pray, and at euening he ſhall deuide his ſpoyle. For Paule in his youth, before his conuerſion, as a rauening woolfe, perſecuted and deuoured the faithful, but being made of Saule a Paule, he diſtributed the food of the Goſpel vnto the world.

Of the time of the conuerſion of Paule, authors do vary, but the better and aunciēter ſorte, as Euſebius, Hieronimus, Euthalius, Diaconus, and other, iudge the conuerſion of Paule to be done, the yere after Chriſt 34 and of Tiberius the .19 yeare.

Euodius (whom Nicephorus doth alledge) doth ſay that there were ſeuen yeares betwene the aſcention of Chriſt, and the ſtoning of Steuen, and that Paule was conuerted .6. monethes after the death of Steuen.
Clemens Alexandrinus writeth, lib. 3. Stromatum, that Paule had a wife, whom he called his faithfull yokefellow.

Origine alſo hath theſe wordes: Paulus ergo (ſicut quidam tradunt) cum vxore vocatus eſt, de qua dicit ad Philippenſes ſcribens: Rogo te etiā germana compar, adiuua illas quae in euangelio decertarūt mecum.

Paule therfore (as ſome write) was called with his wife, of whom he ſpeaketh, writing to the Philippians: I beſeche thee alſo faythfull yokefellow, helpe thoſe women that labored with me in the Goſpell.

Ignatius alſo in his ſixt Epiſtle to Philadelphenſes ſaith: Non detraho caeteris beatis, qui nuptiis copulati fuerunt, quorum nunc memini, opto enim deo dignus ad veſtigia eorum, in regno ipſius inueniri, ſicut Abraham, Iſaac, & Iacob. ſicut Iſaias, & caeteri prophetae, ſicut Petrus &
Paulus, & reliqui Apoſtoli, qui nuptiis fuerunt ſociati.
Euſebius alſo lib. 3. cap. 30. maketh mencion of Paules wyfe, alledging both Ignatius and Clement.
Yet ſaint Ambroſe doth write that al the Apoſtles wer maried, Paul and Iohn onely excepted.

Chriſoſtome likewiſe doth diſſent from them, which doo thinke that Paule doth make mencion of his wife in the Epiſtle to the Philippians, but he ſheweth no reaſon why he doth diſſent: but whether (I pray you) ſhould we geue credite to Ambroſe and Chriſoſtome, and other whyche were ſo long a ſpace after Paule, or els to Clement and Ignatius, the one being ſaint Peter his cōpaniō, the other being ye diſciple of ſaint Marke? The ſtature of Paul is deſcribed of Nicephorus: he had a litle body, crouked, and ſomwhat bowing, aſmal head, a white face, bearing ſome age in it, his eyebrowes hanging downward, a long noſe, but comelye bowed, a thick & a lōg berd, & white hore heares, aſwel in his buſh as in his berd.

At the laſt he was beheaded of the moſt filthy and cruell tirant Nero, the ſame yeare and daye that Peter was hanged on a croſſe, that is the .14. yeare of the raigne of Nero, which was after the death of Chriſt 37. yere, as Hierome, Euſebius, and other do write. But the authour of the booke of the life of Paule, which is falſly aſcribed vnto one Abdias, doth ſay that Paul was ſlaine two yere after the death of Peter.

Of the cauſe of his death, the auncient writers make no record, vnles it were generally for the fayth and confeſsion of Ieſus Chriſt. Yet Chriſoſtome Lib. 2. Contra vituperatores vitae monaſticae, writeth after this maner. Paulus pellicem Neronis (quam deperibat Nero, ac in deliciis habebat) cum ad fidem inducens religionis ſacramenta, ſuſcipire ſimul etiam impurum congreſſum declinare perſuaſerat, Nero Paulum corruptorem, nebulonem, & flagitioſum hominem vocans, primum eum comecit in vincula. Deinde popoſcit vt puellae eiuſmodi conſilia monitaue dare, deſineret, quod cum a Paulo impetrare non poterat necait tandem virum ſanctiſsimum.

That is: Paule alluring vnto the faith a certaine harlot, whom Nero did inordinately loue, and made very much of, did perſwade her to receaue the ſacrament of Chriſtes religion, & likewiſe to decline & leaue the filthy and fleſhly copulation. Nero calling Paul a corrupter, a knaue & a wicked mā, did firſt caſt him into priſon, and after that did require him to ceaſe to geue any ſuch counſel or perſwacions vnto the young woman, which thing when he coulde not obtaine of Paule, he cauſed that moſt holy man and apoſtle to be ſlayne.

div.head: Litle ones. 28.
div.p:
IN the .x. of Mathew Chriſt ſayth: whoſoeuer ſhal geue to one of
theſe litle ones, a cup of cold water, onely in the name of a diſciple, verely Iſay vnto you, he ſhal not leeſe his rewarde. He calleth here them litle ones, not in age, but thoſe which are contemned and perſecuted of the proud and arogant of the world, & are counted vile, & are les eſtemed.

Likewiſe in the .18. chap. Videte ne contemnatis vnum ex puſillis iſtis. Math. 18. See that you deſpiſe not one of theſe litle ones, whiche caſting of the hautines of the minde, not ſtanding in their own conceyte, doo put vpon them modeſty, humility, and meekenes. Litle ones alſo may be taken for the poore, nedy and impotent perſons, which paciently ſuffer aduerſitie, and are diſdeined as abiectes, of the rich worldlinges.

div.head: Simple. 29.
div.p: SImple here is not taken for an ideot, or an ignorant man, but for ſincere, or poore, and a true dealing man, and one that is wythout ſubtiltye or guile, as contrarywiſe, Duplex ſignifieth hym which is crafty and deceitful.

Simplex is called in the Hebrue toung (thom) as in Geneſis Iacob is called (thom) that is, a ſimple and innocent man, not ſubtile nor crafty, and ſuch are called in the Greeke 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 vnto whom God doth reueale his ſecretes. Math. xi. Ouer whom alſo God hath ſuch care and regarde, that he wil greuouſly reuenge, if any do offend them. Math. xviij.

Math. 10.Chriſt ſayth: Eſtote ſimplices ſicut columbae. Be innocent as Doues, that is, not reuenging wrong, much leſſe doing wrong. The Doues although they be feareful of nature, and in much daunger of hurt, yet they do flie quietly and ſimply, as though they were in no peril.
So doth Chriſt exhorte his diſciples, to this ſimplicity, that to muche feare ſhoulde not let nor hinder them from the courſe and runnyng of their profeſsion.

div.head: Righteouſnes. 30.
div.p: THe name of righteouſnes is ſometime generall, and than it doth ſignifie all piety and godlines, as it is written in an old verſe.

l.hi: Iuſticia in ſeſe virtutem continet omnem.

q.l: Iuſtice in it ſelfe doth truly contayne,
All that to vertue doth long and pertayne.

div.p:
Prouer. 11.Alſo in the Prouerbs of Salomon, Iuſtitia rectorum liberauit eos. The righteouſnes of the godly ſhal deliuer them. To be ſhort, Iuſtitia is nothing els, but a general vertue, & an vniuerſal perfectiō, hauing in it no kinde of iniquity or ſynne. VVherof ſaint Hierome, writing ad Demetriadem, ſaith: Omnes virtutum ſpecies vno Iuſticiae nomine continentur. And in this ſignification, that which the Hebrues do cal zadick,
we call Iuſticiam, that is to ſay, an abſolute goodnes, a perfect integritye and ſoundnes, a ful obſeruance of Gods lawes. And he properlye is called a righteous and iuſt man, which obſerueth equitye, and doth auoyde all kinde of iniquity Therfore Chriſt requiring iuſtice and righteouſnes of his, deſireth nothing els but a ſound, ſincere, and pure minde, obſeruing the law, aſwell inwardly, as outwardly.

Saynt Ambroſe in his Hexameron writeth: Vbi prudentia, ibi & malitia, vbi fortitudo, ibi iracundia, ſed vbi Iuſticia, ibi concordia eſt ceterarum uirtutum. Non enim per ſe pars eſt iuſticia, ſed quaſi mater eſt omnium. That is.

VVhere there is wyſdome, there is ſomtime noughtines, where there is ſtrength, there is ſomtime anger, where righteouſnes is, there is the concord and harmonie of al vertues, for Iuſtice is not a part by it ſelfe, but as it were the mother of al vertues.

Secondly, it is taken ſpecially for one of the foure cardinal vertues, wherof ſaint Ambroſe writing in his firſt booke De officiis ſayth: Iuſticia eſt quae dat cuilibet, quod ſuum eſt, nihil vendicans alienum.
There be foure cardinal vertues, wiſdome, fortitude, temperaunce, & iuſtice: of all the which ſaint Auſten writeth in lib 14 de trinitate. ca. 9

p.hi: Iuſticia eſt in ſubueniundo miſeris, prudentia in precauēdis inſidiis, fortitudo, inperferendis moleſtiis, temperantia, in coercendis delectationibus prauis.

div.p: That is to ſay: Iuſtice doth helpe and ayd the weake, and them that be in miſery, wiſdome doth take hede before hand of diſceit, or any other in conuenience, fortitude doth ſuffer ſtrongly al griefes and hardnes, temperaunce doth reſtraine wanton pleaſures and luſtes.

They be called cardinall vertues, bicauſe they be the chiefe of all other vertues political, and in them doth depend the whole life of an honeſt ciuil man. And euen as a doore doth hang vpon an hooke, called in latine Cardo, and moueth to and fro: ſo all the doinges of a good, honeſt, politicke man, muſt be directed, moued and ordered by theſe foure vertues cardinal, which are ſo called of this word Cardo.

The other vertues called Virtutes theologicae, be three in number: that is, faith, hope, and charity, and they differ from the cardinall vertues in ſundry pointes: for the theologicall vertues, do pertaine to inward actions and motions, the cardinal vertues pertaine to externe and outward workes and dedes. The theological vertues tend vnto God, the cardinal vertues vnto our outward neighbours and dealing. &c.

To end, Iuſtitia ſpecially is as Cicero writeth De legibus, obtemperatio ſcriptis legibus inſtitutiſque populorum, that is: It is an obedience geuen to lawes written, and to the ordinances and decrees of the people,
and concerning this ſignification we haue twoo notable examples, for the preſeruing of law and equity. Valerius Maximus doth record of one Seleucus, who did defend and gouerne the city of the Locretians wyth moſt wholſome and profitable lawes, of the which this was one, that whoſoeuer committed adultery, ſhould by a ſtatute made by him, leeſe both his eyes. It ſo chaunced that his own ſonne was taken firſt with the ſame fact and fault, and was condemned according to the law, to ſuſtaine the paine that was inflicted to adulterers, but the whole city, for honour of the father, requeſted Seleucus to remit the payne vnto his ſonne, but he for a certaine time gaue them repulſe. At the laſt Seleucus being ouercome with requeſtes and deſires of the people, cauſed one of his own eyes firſt to be put out, and afterward one of his ſonnes eyes, & ſo leauing the vſe of ſight vnto them both, did according vnto equity and preſcription of the law, take that due puniſhment which the lawe appointed to adulterers, and ſo, wyth a goodly temperature, did ſhew him ſelfe both to be a mercyfull father, and a righteous iudge.

The other examples, Nicephorus doth reherſe of Traianus the emperour, who gouerning the Romane Empire, was ſo ſtudious of conſeruing iuſtice and good order, that he did geue, in the ſight of all the Citizens, aſword drawen to the ruler of the city, ſaying after this manner. Cape ferrum hoc, & ſiquidem recte imperium geſſero, pro me, ſin aliter, contra me hoc vtere. That is to ſay. Take this weapon, if I gouerne the Empire wel, vſe it for me, if I do otherwiſe, vſe it againſt me.

div.head: Rudis. 31.
div.p: RVdis is properlye that which is vnpoliſhed, vntrimmed, hauing no artficiall fourme, as ſiluer is before it be coyned and ſigned. And as a booke which is not throughly nor ſufficiently perfited: and by a tranſlation, it is referred to the mynde, and ſo they be called Rudes, which haue not yet beautified and decked their mindes with diſcipline, doctrine, and wyth experience and vſe of thynges.
Rude is taken for rawe or vndreſſed, as Chriſt ſayth in Mathewe. Nemo immittit commiſſuram panni rudis, in veſtimentum vetus. That is: No man peeceth an old garment with a peece of raw cloth.
Eraſmus in his annotacions, doth cal it in Greke 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is, that cloth whych is not yet tucked or fulled, but euen clothe as it came from the weauer.

By this ſimilitude Chriſt doth ſignifie, that it behoued hym not, in the beginning of the calling of his Diſciples (beyng yet rude and raw) to
lay heuy & weighty matters, & not ſo necaſſary vpon thē, as ſtraight faſting & praiers extraordinarily, which be workes more ſpirituall, then may be at ye firſt exacted of thē, which haue but newly receaued religion.

Muſculus writing vpon the ſame place of Mathew doth diſagree and vary both from Chriſoſtome and other new writers, which do expound the ſame place, as I haue ſayd before, for he writeth that Chriſt vnderſtood by the old garment & the old bottels, the Phariſeis, & the mindes of Iohns diſciples, rooted & groūded in the traditiōs of their forfathers, & by the new cloth and new wine, he vnderſtode ye doctrine of the new teſtament of chriſtian liberty, & of a ſounder righteouſnes. And Muſculus ſheweth foure probable reaſons, which moueth him ſo to iudge.

Chriſt doth not here (ſaith he) with this parable & ſimilitude defend his diſciples (for that he had done before) but ſheweth a reaſon, why Iohn did not cōmit this doctrine of liberty (as new wine) vnto his diſciples, not bicauſe this new doctrine was euil, but for that it behoued him to haue a regard & reſpect of his diſciples, being more infirme and weake, then vnto whō this new & vnaccuſtomed doctrine might as yet be exhibited and geuen, as though he ſhould ſay: That the diſciples of Ihon, be not inſtituted vnto this doctrine of liberty as my diſciples are, neither he is in the fault, nor yet this my doctrine: but the diſciples themſelues, for they haue bene ſo much acuſtomed and practiſed in old traditions, that Ihon ſhould haue ben counted to haue done no otherwiſe (if he had forthwith cōmitted this doctrine vnto them) then if one ſhould ſow a peece of raw cloth into an old garment, or put newe wine into olde bottels, for your mindes may be compared vnto the palat and taſte of them which alwaies do vſe to drinke old drinke, and can drinke no new.
This was ſpoken againſt the Phariſeis, Scribes, and the diſciples of Iohn, and not to be imputed to the diſciples of Chriſt, neither yet to hys doctrine, nor vnto Ieſu hymſelfe.

By the old bottels, and by the old garment, I vnderſtand, not the diſciples of Chriſt, but of Ihon, and by the new wine, I vnderſtand, not the doctrine of faſtinges, but the doctrine of faith and Chriſtian libertye. And ſo certaine of the fathers doo vnderſtand this place, as ſaint Hierome and Hilarius.

Hierome ſaith after this maner: Veteres vtres debemus intelligere Scribas & Phariſeos, plagula panni noui, et vinum nouum precepta euangelica ſentienda ſunt, quae non poſſunt ſuſtinere Iudei, ne maior ſciſſura fiat. Sermo igitur euangelicus Apoſtolis potius quam Scribis & Phariſeis eſt infundendus, qui maiorum traditionibus deprauati ſynceri tatem preceptorum Chriſti non poterant cuſtodire. That is to ſay: VVe ought to vnderſtande by the olde bottels, the Scribes and the Phariſeis.
The piece of new clothe, and the new wine, are to be vnderſtand the preceptes and rules of the Goſpell, which the Iewes coulde not ſuſtaine nor beare, leaſt there ſhould be a greater breach and rent. Therfore the euangelical woordes and workes are rather to be poured vnto the Apoſtles, then to the Scribes and Phariſeis, which being corrupted with the tradition of the Elders, coulde not obſerue and keepe the ſinceritye and purenes of the preceptes and rules of Chriſt.

Hilarius wordes be theſe. Vt autem intelligerent non poſſe ſibi in veteribus poſitis perfecta haec ſalut is ſacramenta committi: comparationis exemplum poſuit, pānum rudem veteri veſtimento non aſſui. That is to ſay: That they ſhould vnderſtand theſe perfect ſacramentes of ſaluation could not be committed vnto them, being ſetled in old traditions, he putteth an example of compariſon, which is, that raw clothe cannot be ſowed into an old garment.

Eraſmus in his Paraphraſes, writeth thus: Iohn endeuored to put no other thing to old bottels, then old wine, as faſting and ſuch other lyke, which are farre diſtant from thoſe thinges, which ought to be done of men, that preach the Goſpell: but I (ſayth Chriſt) doo not commit the ſweete wine of my doctrine vnto any other thing, but vnto new veſſels, as though Chriſt ſhould ſay: It is no maruell thoughe my doctrine doo not pleaſe you: for how will you embrace it, which haue ſo long bene accuſtomed to the traditions of your Elders? In ſo much that you thincke to haue lyfe and health by them. And by this it commeth to paſſe, that you (not knowing the libertye of the chyldren of God) are offended in this, that I doo not inſtitute and teache my diſciples the often obſeruation and keeping of faſtinges.
Of this word Rudis, commeth Erudio, which ſignifieth to teache, and to make of a rude perſon, a learned perſon, quaſi ex ruditate detrahere aliquem, that is, to draw one out of rudenes.

Rudis, being a ſubſtantine, ſignifieth a rod, or a yarde, which was geuen to ſword players, when they came to .lx. yeares old, in token that they were ſet at liberty. It ſignifieth alſo liberty, as Horace in his firſt epiſtle doth vſe it, ſaying: Spectatum ſatis et donatum iam rude, quaeris Mecenas iterum antiquo me includere laudo? He calleth here Donatū rude by a tranſlation, to be diſcharged of attendance, to be ſet at liberty.

div.head: Euangelium. 32.
div.p:
EVangelium being a Greeke word, doth ſignifie good and mery tidinges, and it cōmeth of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which ſignifieth Bonum good, and of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
nuntio, to ſhew (as you would ſaye) a good meſſage or glad tidinges. Therfore, that moſt wholſome tidinges
and meſſage, which was brought vnto vs by Chriſt, the true meſſenger of the father, we call properly Euangelium, bicauſe Chriſt, according to the promiſes of the father, being made man, did pacifie his wrath, did ſatiſfie for our ſinnes, and purchaſed to vs eternal life.
Euangelia, in the plurall nomber betokeneth ſupplications and ſacrifices, which were wont to be offered and geuen for ioyfull and merye tidinges.

It ſignifieth alſo the reward which is geuen to him that doth bryng the mery meſſage. So Homerus vſeth it in Odiſſea, and Cicero alſo ſaying. O ſuaues duas epiſtolas quibus euangelia deberi fateor. O the two ſwete and pleaſant epiſtles, to whom I confes to be due great rewardes.

Euangelium generally betokeneth tidinges, that is pleaſant and ioyful to the minde of hym to whom they are ſhewed, as if one being captiue in priſon, doth heare that he ſhall be ſet at liberty the next day, audit Euangelium, he heareth glad tidinges, and ſo like of other.

div.head: Oraculum. 33.
div.p: ORaculum is properly the aunſwer which the Gods doo geue, and it is deriued of this word Oratio, as Cicero witneſſeth in his Topices, ſaying: Oracula ex eo ipſo appellata ſūt, quod ineſt his, deorum oratio. That is: Oracles are called of this, for that the cō munication and aunſwer of the Gods, is in them.

VVe cal properly Oraculum dei, the oracle of God, by the which god either by inward inſpiration, doth comfort the minde of the godly, both in priuate or publike callamities, or els by the which God doth partlye correct the offenders, by the ſending of his prophetes, and ſpecially doth promiſe proſperity to them which do repent.

Oraculum ſometime doth ſignifie the churche or place in the which the aunſwers are geuen, and ſo it is taken in Exodus,Exod. 25. where God doth ſay vnto Moſes: Duos quoque Cherubin aureos & productiles facies, ex vtraque parte oraculi. That is, thou ſhalt make two cherubins of golde, of worke beaten out with a hammer, ſhalt thou make them, at the two endes of the mercy ſeate. In this place he calleth Oraculū propitiatoriū, bicauſe through praiers, the oracles and aunſwers of God are obtained, which was herd frō that place which was called Propitiatorium, as the Hebrue Rabbines do declare, and as Lyra alſo doth write vpon the ſame place.

And here note, that this mercye ſeate was a table of golde, ſet ouer the Arke, of the ſame meaſure that the Arke was of, vpon the whyche table God did ſyt and appeare vnto Moſes, and talking with him, ſhewed
mercy vpon the people. The interpretour tourning the Hebrue word into the latine woord propitiatorium, had a regarde vnto the woorde, Chaphar, which doth ſignifie remouere iram, placare, condonare peccatum, to put away anger, to pacefie, to pardon ſynne.

Thirdly, Oraculum doth ſignifie a ſhort and a worthy ſentence, as vnum illud optimum oraculum eſt, pugnandum eſſe pro patria, that is, one oracle very good, and worthy to be noted, we muſt fight for our countrye. Oracula loqui, is a prouerbe which ſignifieth to ſpeake thinges moſt certaine and vndoubtfull. And vpon this comme other prouerbes, as Apolinis oraculum, Sibillae folium, ex tripode dictum, which thre prouerbes do ſignifie any thing to be as true, as truth it ſelf.

div.head: Tripartite. 34.
div.p: THere were three Greke authors, Theodoretus, Biſhoppe of Cyrus, Sozomenus, and Socrates, whiche all wrote eccleſiaſticall hiſtories, almoſt at one time, the which Epiphanius the ſcholeman tranſlated into latin, out of the which Caſsiodorus a Senator and Moncke, made one continual hiſtory, which he called Hiſtoriam tripartitam, that is, an hiſtory written of three, couched and driuen into one. They began their hiſtories where Euſebius made an end, that is, from the end of the Empire of Conſtantine the great, vnto the time of Theodoſius the younger, contayning the diſcourſe of an hundred and fortye yeares.
After theſe ſucceded Theodorus, which in two bookes touched thoſe thinges which were done from the time of Theodocius the younger, vnto the time of Anaſtaſius.

Euſebius wrote .xv. bokes, Socrates wrote ſeuen, Theodoretus wrote v. Sozomenus wrote nine, and Theodorus twoo. Euagrius ſcholaſticus wrote alſo .vi. bookes, from the Empire of Theodoſius the younger, not onely eccleſiaſtical hiſtories, but alſo ſtories of Empires and kingdomes, vnto the .xij. yeare of the Emperour Maurice, ſo that all the hiſtories from Chriſt our ſauiour, vnto the time of Maurice the Emperour, written by Euſebius, Socrates, Theodoretus, Sozomenus, Theodorus, and Euagrius, comprehended in .xliij bookes, doo containe the geſtes & doinges of thinges, by the ſpace of 590. yeares.

div.head: Conſtantinus. 35.
div.p:
COnſtantinus the great was the ſonne of one Conſtantius a duke of Rome, which was ſent into Britaine to recouer the tribute that was due. After whoſe ariuall, Coill which was the king of Britaine died, and the Britaines to haue more ſurety of peace, wylled
the duke to take to wife Helena, the doughter of king Coil, which was a wonderful fayre mayden, and therwith wel learned. This Conſtantius when he had recouered the tribute, returned with hys wife Helena to Rome, as chief gouernour of Britaine, and at the laſt died at Yorke Yet Iulius Firmicus doth record, that Conſtantine was borne of Helena, being a concubine, and begotten at Tharſus. Eutropius ſayth that Conſtantine was borne in Britaine, in an obſcure and baſe matrimonye, of his mother Helena, whom ſaint Ambroſe in his funerall oration of the death of Theodotius, doth call Stabulariam, that is a woman which kept a vitailing houſe for wayfaring men.

This Conſtantine became a noble and valiant Prince, and ſo mighty in martial proweſſe, that he was ſurnamed the great Conſtantine. He was firſt an idolatrour, and by the impulſion of his wyfe Fauſta, did ſacrifice vnto idols. But after he had vanquiſhed Maxentius, he vtterlye renounced the worſhipping of idols, and became a chriſtian man. But he deferred his baptiſme vntil his old age, bicauſe he purpoſed to take a viage into Perſia, and was reſolued in him ſelfe to be baptiſed as he went, in the floud Iordane. In wytnes of hys beliefe, he cauſed a booke of the Goſpels to be caryed before him, and made the Bible to be copied out, and ſent into all partes of his Empire.

Some wryte that, as he went with his army agaynſt Maxentius, in his iourney he ſaw the ſigne of the croſſe in the element, ſhining lyke fire, and he heard an aungell ſaying: Conſtantine 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Id eſt: In hoc vince, in this ſigne ouercome thou, wherwith he being greatly comforted, ſhortly after vanquiſhed the army of Maxentius, who flying out of the battell, was drowned in Tiber. He was Emperour, as Eutropius writeth .xxx. yeares, and as Pomponius Laetus writeth .xxxij. yeares lacking two monethes.
He was baptized of Euſebius, Biſhop of Nicomedia, and ſhortlye after ended his life in the ſame citye, and was buried at Conſtantinople.

Notwithſtanding Iacobus Philippus in ſupplemento Cronicorum, that Conſtantine was chriſtened of Pope Silueſter the firſt. He writeth alſo, that for the great ſlaughter of Martirs, and for the tormenting of people innumerable through his prouinces, God ſtroke him with a kinde of leproſy, the which could not be cured nor holpen by his phiſicions, nor any other learned men, but the Prieſtes of the Capitol of Rome, gaue this counſell, yt a certayn pond ſhould be filled with the bloud of yong childrē, & the emperour to waſh & hath himſelf in it being hot, & ſo ſhuld recouer his helth. But that this is nothing els but a fable, not onely Valla and Platina, but alſo Euſebius, Eutropius, Socrates, Theodoritus, Sozomenus,
Hieronimus, Ruffinus, Croſius, and other do ſufficiently teſtifie. For all theſe, writing moſt copiouſlye, amply, and largely of hys lyfe, do make no mention of this leproſie: but certayne late wryters doo rehearſe it out of an Apocriphall booke, wrytten of thinges done by Silueſter. Alſo how true it is that Helena after ſhe had found the croſſe, did build a temple ther in that place, and from thence went to Conſtātinople vnto her ſonne, and brought with her the. 3. nailes wherwith Chriſt was crucified, of the which, Conſtantine put one in his horſe bridle, which he vſed onely in Battel, and did ſet the ſecond in his helmet, and threwe the third into the ſea called Mare Adriaticum, to appeaſe the tempeſtuous rages of the ſea. How true I ſaye theſe thinges be, I referre to learned mens iudgements. I for my part count them fabulas aniles.

Yet I am not ignoraunt, that ſaint Ambroſe writeth almoſt the like in his funerall oration, of the death of Theodotius the Emperour. But Eraſmus writeth that the orations, the Epiſtles, and ſermons which are contained in the thirde tome, be foreged & fained in S. Ambroſe name, and that in them ther is nothing of ſaint Ambroſe veine or phraſe.

Againe, that Conſtantine was baptiſed at Rome, of Silueſter, it is a very lye. For Euſebius. lib. 4. of the life of Conſtantine, doth affirme that he was chriſtened a litle before his death, in an aſſemblye of Biſhoppes, at Nicomedia, of one Euſebius, biſhop of that place. And ſaint Hierome declareth no leſſe in his cronicle, & ſayth, that this was done in the thre ſcore & fift yeare of his age, and the .xxxi. yeare of his Empire, when Silueſter was dead almoſt fiue yeares before, as Ruffinus, Theodoretus, and other do record in their hiſtories.

Iſidorus in his cronicle doth write, that Conſtantine was rebaptized of Euſebius, being an Arrian: but Socrates and other more auncient & better approued authours, do affirme him to haue bene baptized, but neuer rebaptiſed. And the Arimine counſell, in their letters to Conſtantius doth teſtifie, that Conſtantine embracing the true fayth of the Nicen counſell, and being baptiſed, departed from this preſent life.
I omit here the ſaying of Gracianus, who writeth that Melchiades baptiſed Conſtantine, when Melchiades was before Silueſter his time, and Conſtantine was baptiſed after the death of them both.

I omit alſo Nicephorum, who affirmed that the Arrians throughe a diueliſh mynde, did faine that Conſtantine was baptiſed at Nicomedia, and he iudgeth that he was baptiſed at Rome of Silueſter, and that Conſtātine made at Rome Baptiſteriū, that is, a Fonte, or a place to chriſtē in. But how friuolous theſe thinges be, he that is conuerſant in the auncient authours, may eaſely iudge.

div.head: De donatione Conſtantini.
div.p: THoſe thinges whiche are written of the donation of Conſtantine, to be both feined and fooliſhe, who will or can doubt? or that he with all his nobilitie and the whole ſenate, and all the Peeres of the Citie, and all the people of the Romaine empire, ſhould giue vnto Silueſter all his emperiall eſtate and honor, ſhould giue alſo the Citie of Rome and al Italie, and ye thre partes of Fraūce, ye two partes of Spaine, Germany, Britaine and all other places & Cities, is moſt diſcrepant and farre frō the truth. For the ſenate of Rome and the greateſt part of ye people of Rome, were moſt ſtraunge from the Chriſtian religion, not onely in the tyme of Conſtantine, but alſo in the reigne of Valentinian, whiche reigned almoſt xl. yeare after Conſtantine. And therfore if he would haue graunted this donation vnto Silueſter, neither his own ſonnes, neither his frendes, neither his kinſfolke, nor the ſenate of Rome, would haue ſuffred him ſo to do: yea his faith and his owne conſcience would not haue led him to the ſame, for being learned in the holy ſcriptures, he did know that a Magiſtrate was the ordinaunce of God, and that the offices of the Miniſters of the Church, and of the tēporall Magiſtrate, were two diſtinct things, and that they ought not to be confounded and mingled, as he him ſelfe was wonte to ſay, as Euſebius writeth: Deū ſacerdotibus commiſiſſe internam Eccleſiae curā, ſibi vero externā, that is to ſai, God did commit the inward cure of the Church vnto Prieſts, & the outward cure vnto him.

On ye other ſide, if ye cōſider Silueſter to haue ben a true & a godly Paſtor of ye Church, as many were in thoſe dayes, will you iudge yt he would haue ſuffred Conſtantine to haue giuen him thoſe things, the vſe wherof was forbidden of Chriſt? for he knew well inough that ſaying of Chriſt, Principes gētium dominantur eis, vos autem non ſic. Luce 22. The princes of the gentils beare rule ouer thē, which you ſhal not doo. Agayne: Date Caeſari, quae ſunt Ceſaris, geue that to Ceſar, whiche belongeth to Ceſar.

Do you beleue, that Peter the Apoſtle would haue receiued the ſecular power with the Empire, if the Emperour Nero had offred it hym? no truly. Before Peter receaued the holy ghoſt, he being diſceaued with other of the Iewes, did imagine, that the kingdome of Chriſt ſhould be a terreſtriall kyngdome, but after he had receiued ye holy ghoſt, he vnderſtood, the kingdome and ſeate of Chriſt not to be ſet in earth, but in heauen, and that his kingdome was not of this world. He knew, that Christ did flee into the deſerte, when the people went about to make him kyng. He knew how Elizeus did refuſe the donation and offer of Naman the prince, and how that Geezi his ſeruaūt, for requiring and receyuing the ſame, was ſtriken with a fowle leoprie. Peter would not take vpon him the cure and care ouer the poore, leaſt he ſhould be hindered both to pray
and preach as often as he ſhould. As the acte of the Apoſtles doth teſtifie. And I beſech you, is it like then, that Peter would caſt of his Apoſtleſhip, and receaue vpon him the gouernment of the whole world? He denieth that one mā can conueniently Miniſter the word, & alſo Miniſter to the tables. And what Pope can they geue vs, which had a better and a more ample ſpirite, then Peter had, whiche could perfourme that thyng which Peter could not? Therfore they be but toyes and trifles, which are written of the donation of Conſtantine.

Conſtantine was more ſound in religion, thē to purpoſe ſuch a graūt, which he knew to repugne vtterly agaynſt the doctrine of Chriſt. Silueſter alſo was more ſounde, then to receaue ſuch agraunt, which he vnderſtood that he could not without the ſubuerſion and ouerthrowing of the word. But if Conſtantine had graunted it, & Silueſter had receaued it, they had hoth offended agaynst the word of God.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p:
Lib. 1. ca. 2. Ruffinus writeth, that Constantine ſayd vnto the Biſhop after this maner. Deus (inquit) vos cōſtituit ſacerdotes, & poteſtatem vobis dedit, de nobis quoque iudicandi, & ideo nos a vobis recte iudicamur. Vos au tē non poteſtis ab hominibus iudicari. Propter quod dei ſolius inter vos expectate iudicium, & veſtra iurgia quaecun
que ſunt, ad illud diuinum reſeruentur examen. Vos etenim nobis a deo dati eſtis dii, & conueniens nō eſt vt homo iudicet deos, ſed ille ſolus de quo ſcriptum eſt Deus ſtetit in ſinagoga deorum, in medio autē deos diſcernit. Et ideo hiis omiſſis, illa quae ad fidem dei pertinent, abſ
que vlla animorū contētione diſtinguite, that is to ſay.

God hath made you priestes, and hath giuen you power to iudge of vs, and therfore we are rightly iudged of you, you cannot be iudged of men. Therfore among your ſelues looke for the iudgemēt of the onely one god, and let al your contentions be reſerued to the examination and iudgemēt of God, for you are giuen as goddes vnto vs of God, and it is vnconueniēt that man do iudge Gods. But he onely of whom it is written. God ſtandeth in the aſſembly of Gods, he iudgeth amōg Gods, and therfore omitting theſe thinges, diſcerne you thoſe things whiche perteine to the faith of God, without contention of mindes. Behold ſaith our aduerſaries here is the teſtimonie of a chriſten Emperour, by the whiche it may be proued that the Biſhop of Rome hath power and autoritie to iudge all Emperours, and he to be iudged of none, but of God.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p:
I aunſwere that in theſe wordes of Conſtantine, there is no mention made of the Biſhop of Rome, but he ſpeaketh generally of litigious and contentious Biſhops, whiche accuſed eche other before the Emperours
maieſtie, and thoſe thinges whiche the prudent and christen Emperour did aunſwere vnto them, he ſpake for the cauſe of reconciliation among them ſelues, not thincking of the preeminence of the Biſhop of Rome.

Secondly he did not ſend thoſe Biſhops vnto the ſeat and iuriſdiction of the Pope, for he ſayd not, you haue the Biſhop of Rome Christes vicar, and Peters ſucceſſor, bring the cauſes of your contētion to be iudged of him, but he ſayd, let your ſtrifes be reſerued to the triall of God onely, looke for his iudgement. And by theſe wordes it appeareth that he thought not that the Biſhop of Rome ſhould haue any iuriſdiction ouer the other Biſhops.

Thirdly, the Biſhops thēſelues did not thinck the iudgement of their cauſes to pertaine to the examination of the Biſhops of Rome, but they iudged the power and iuriſdiction of the Emperour, to be moſt auctenticall ouer them, and therfore they brought their cauſes vnto him.

Fourthly, it doth manifeſtly appeare out of the hiſtories, that the Emperour did exerciſe power and auctoritie ouer ye Biſhops, as other Emperours did, which ſucceded him. He did not onely iudge of euery one of them, if they had offended, but alſo did vſe his power ouer all that were ſubiect vnto his Empire, compelling them by his edict and commaundement to come to the generall counſell, preſcribyng vnto them both tyme and place.

VVhen the fathers were aſſembled at Tirus, they did declare vnto Conſtantine the names of them which wer abſent, whom they deſired to be preſēt and ſo he wrote to thē that they ſhuld come to the counſell, and ſhould adioyne their care and ſtudie with the other in the ſayd counſell: he cōmaūded alſo his Ambaſſadour, yt he ſhould put to exile and baniſhment, all them which did either refuſe to come, or els did litle eſteme the commaundement of the counſell.

Alſo when the ſayd Conſtantine vnderſtood, that Athanaſius was wrongfully condemned in the counſell holden at Tirus, he ſent vnto thē ſeuere and ſharpe letters, in the which he commaundeth all thoſe fathers to come vnto him to Conſtātinople, and there to declare before him, how purely and truly they had iudged: and doth openly obiect vnto thē, that they went about nothing els, but thoſe thinges which did tende to diſſention, debate, hatred, and the ſubuerſion of mankind.

Athanaſius alſo himſelfe being condēned at Tirus, did flee vnto Cō ſtantine. Saint Auſten alſo writeth, that Donatus being condempned in the coūſel Arelatine, did appeale vnto Conſtantine: which hearyng both the parties, did iuſtifie and pronounce Cecilianus to be innocent.

Euſebius doth teſtifie, that Conſtantine did confirme the definitions
of the Biſhops concluded in the counſels, and did commaunde the rulers of the people, that none ſhould infring nor breake thoſe thinges whiche were decreed of the Biſhops. Alſo he embraced the decrees of the Nicene counſell, and did proteſt, that he would baniſh all thoſe which would not ſubſcribe vnto thē: which alſo he did, for he ſent Arrius with a .xi. of his fellowes into exile, and commaunded the bokes of Arrius to be burnt. And if any man had bene taken to haue kept thē either priuatly or apertly, he commaunded him to be put to death.

By theſe examples ye may ſee, that Conſtantine did not giue ouer his aucthoritie and power vnto the Biſhops, but did both intermeddle with ſpiritual matters to rule and iudge biſhops, yea and cal general coūſels: and not onely he, but alſo his ſucceſſors did call by their auctoritie and power, Biſhops and fathers vnto counſels.

Leo the Pope, firſt of that name, with his whole ſinode gathered at Rome, moſt humbly deſired the Emperour Theodoſius, that he would commaunde a generall counſell to be celebrated and kept in Italie. And yet the prouidēt Emperour did not appoint the counſell, in Italie, where there was no contention riſen, but in Grecia in the Citie called Sedon.

S. Hierome alſo Ad Euſtochiū, in the Epitaph of her mother Paulae, writeth after this maner. Cū
que orientis & occidentis Epiſcopos ob quaſdam Eccleſiarum diſſentiones, Romam Imperiales literae contraxiſſent, that is to ſay. VVhen the Emperours letters had gathered together the Biſhops aſwell of the Eaſt as of the VVeaſt.

Alſo in the Epiſtle of Pope Agatho, ſent to the Emperour, by whoſe commaundement the ſixt counſell was called and gathered together, ye may read after this maner: Ideoque Chriſtianiſsimi dn̄i, ſecundū priſsimā miſsionem māſuetudinis veſtrae, pro obedientia quā debemus preſentes famulos noſtros miſimꝰ, yt is to ſay. Therfore O most Chriſtiā ſonnes of ye Lord, according to ye moſt godly cōmaūdemēt of your gētlenes, & for the obedience which we do owe, we haue ſent our preſent ſeruauntes.

Note here (good reader) this clauſe, Pro obedientia quā debemus for ye obedience which we do owe, wil the Pope acknowledge ye like obediēce vnto the emperours maieſtie? will he acknowledge the iuriſdiction and power of emperours to be ouer Biſhops? no, no, his Antichriſtian pride will not ſuffer him.

VVhich of all ye Biſhops of Rome did gouerne the Apoſtolicke Church with a greater care & diligēce, then Gregory the great? & yet he writyng Ad Theodorum the Phiſition, ſayth of the Emperour Mauricius, as followeth: Valde autem mihi durum videtur, vt ab eius ſeruitio milites ſuos prohibear, qui ei & omnia tribuit, & dominare eum nō ſolum militibus, ſed & ſacerdotibus conceſsit, that is to ſay: it ſemeth a very hard thyng, that he ſhould forbid hys ſoldiours from his homage and
ſeruice, whiche hath both giuen to him all thinges, and alſo hath graunted him to haue dominion & rule, not onely ouer the ſouldiours, but alſo ouer the Prieſts. Againe in the ende of the Epiſtle which he wrote to the Emperour himſelfe, he ſayth thus: Que debui, exolui, qui & imperatori obedientiam prebui, et pro deo, quod ſenſi minime tacui, that is: I paid thoſe thinges that I ought, which haue giuen both mine obedience to the Emperours, and alſo haue not holde my peace in Gods cauſe, but ſpake yt whiche I thought. Do you not here ſee that this Gregory being Pope, did not onely obey the Emperour, but alſo did acknowledge that he ought to ſhew obedience vnto him, And will his ſucceſſors and ye clergie of ye inferior ſort, plucke their neckes out of the yoke of obediēce, which by Gods law is due vnto Magiſtrates, but ye may ſee, to what diſorder pryde and ambition hath driuen the Biſhops of Rome.

One Auguſtinus Stenchus, is not aſhamed to write, that the Biſhop of Rome was called a God, & coumpted for a God, and ſaith, that this was done when the Emperour did beautifie him with a noble title, worſhipped him as God, and as the ſucceſſor of Chriſt and Peter, and gaue hym godly honor, and did reuerence him, as the liuely image of Chriſt. This writeth the ſame Stenchus ſexione. Lib. 67.

O intollerable blaſphemie, O vnſpeakable knauerie, O moſt ſacrilegious and deuiliſh flatterie, cleane repugnant to the moſt ſacred and holy word of God. VVhat did Peter I pray you, whē Cornelius did fall down, and would haue worſhipped him? did he not lift him vp and ſay, Surge, Act. 10. & ego ipſe homo ſum. Ariſe, I my ſelfe alſo am a man.Act. 12. VVhat did the aungell ſay vnto Iohn, when he fell down at the aūgels feete, to worſhip him? did he not ſay, Vide ne feceris, conſeruus enim tuus ſum, & fratrū tuorū Prophetarū. Take hede thou do it not, for I am thy fellow ſeruaunt and of thy brothers ye Prophets. And will the Pope be better then Peter? hollier then Iohn? well he may take an example of Herodes Agrippa, which gaue eare vnto the flattering voyces of the people, which cried, Vox dei non hominis. It is the voyce of God, and not of man.Act. 12. He did not ſtay the people, but tooke a glory in their wordes, and therfore was ſtriken of the aungell, and like a wretch did rot, beyng eaten of Lice. It behoueth vs to know, that Chriſt the ſonne of god doth reigne yet in his Church, as chief head and ruler, vnto whom onely and alone, all glory and power is giuē: and not to thincke, that he did ſubſtitute any man, in whom he would be worſhipped, for Chriſt onely ought they to worſhip, honor, and to pray vnto. And as for the Pope and all his ſacrilegious flatterers, we ought to deteſt and abhorre as the very Antichrist. To conclude, ſome writers do recorde, that when Conſtantine gaue riches and honor vnto the Church,
there was a voyce heard, which ſaid, Iam venenum irrepſit in eccleſiam, now is poiſon crepte into the Churche, he that will know more of the life of Conſtātine, let him read the v. bookes of Euſebius Ceſarienſis, whiche he purpoſly wrote of the ſame.
Of this man Conſtantine, the kinges of Brittanie had firſt the priuiledge to weare cloſe Crownes.

div.head: Phariſies. 36.
div.p: THere were three ſectes or factions among the Iewes, ye Phariſies, the Saduces, and the Eſſeens.
It appeareth out of Ioſephus, that theſe ſectes began the yeares before Chriſt. 125.
Phariſei, the Phariſies receyued their name of this Hebrue worde Phares, that is ſeparation or diuiſion, bycauſe they would be diſtincte, and differ from other prophane men.

Or els (as ſome other write) they are called, Phariſei, of this Hebrue word Pharaſch, Pharaſch. which betokeneth an interpretacion, gloſe, or expoſitiō: As you would ſay, expounders and interpreters of the bokes of Scriptures, which they did chiefly profeſſe, they were called Doctors and teachers,Mat. 23. they ſate in the chaire of Moſes: that is, they taught the lawe of Moſes, and did expounde the bookes of the olde Teſtament. Although they beleued In genere, certeine chief pointes of doctrine, as God to be but one God, and Meſsias to come, and to bring great benefites with him, and the ſoules after the death of the bodies to be immortall, yet had they certeine horrible ſpots, and prophane and wicked opinions in many articles of the heauenly doctrine. They were moſt cruell and bitter enemies vnto Chriſt and his diſciples: And (as Hierome ſayth) they conſented to the death of Iohn the Baptiſt. They were proude, boſting in their owne workes,Mat. 23. deſiring honor and chief rowmes in the feaſtes and ſinagoges: they were ambitious, deſiring to be ſaluted in the market, and to be called of men Rabbi, they were couetous, deuouryng widowes houſes vnder the pretence of long prayer: They were mighty and much regarded of the people. Ioſephus writeth in the booke of his antiquities. Phariſeos apud Iudeos plurimū poſſe, ſiue exoſum aliquē cupiūt ledere, ſiue amicū iuuare, that is, that the Phariſies could do much among the Iewes, whether they would hurt any man whom they hated, or whether they would helpe any man whom they loued. They were ſuperſtitious, obſeruing litle things,Mat. 7. and omitting things waighty. And when they came from the market they would not eate before they had waſhed: They were hypocrites, and therfore Chriſt likened them to painted ſepulchers. They did weare long garmentes,Mat. 23. and made the hemmes of them broader then other did:
They did make broade phylactaries, which Epiphanius doth ſay, to haue bene purple: but Eraſmus in his annotatiōs doth cal them ſcroles of parchement, in the whiche the commaundementes were written, and ſayth, that Phylacterium, is a Greke word, and ſignifieth in Latine,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Conſeruatoriū, bycauſe the memorie of the law is conſerued in them. For the Phariſies, bycauſe they would be ſeene to be good obſeruers of the lawe, did write the ten commaundementes in two pieces of parchement, the one, conteyning the firſt table, they put on their foreheads in ſteade of a crowne: The other conteyning the ſecond table, they put vpon their arme, that whitherſoeuer they moued their head, or did reache forth their hand, the lawe ſhould be in ſight before their eyes. They tooke the occaſion of this ſuperſtition out of the ſixth of Deutronomie, where God ſayth: Ligabis ea quaſi ſignum in manu tua, Deut. 6. eruntque & mouebuntur inter oculos tuos: that is, thou ſhalt binde thē as a token in thy hand, & they ſhalbe moued betwene thine eies, partly out of the .xv. chapter of Numeri where God ſpeaketh after this maner:Num. 15. Speake vnto the children of Iſraell, and thou ſhalt ſay vnto them, that they make to them hemmes in the foure borders of their garmentes, and put vpon the hemmes of the borders a ribande of blewe ſilke: that when they looke vpon them, they may remember all the commaundementes of the Lord.

Vpon this, theſe hypocrites, huntyng after popular prayſe, and ſekyng lucre and gaynes of ſely women, did make to them ſelues great hemmes, and did tye ſharpe thornes in them, that they ſhould be pricked with them, both when they did walke and ſit, leaſt they ſhould be counted at any tyme to forget the law.

div.head: Saducaei.
div.p:
