The Saduces did ſet this name to themſelues of this Hebrew worde Zedec, Zedec. rightuouſnes, and ſo called them ſelues Zadichim, iuſt and right:Zadichim. when notwithſtāding they were the moſt wicked of all other. This ſecte began, by reaſon yt the Phariſies did onerate & burden wtout meaſure, ye people wt ouer many rites & ceremonies. Therfore they willing to loſe theſe boūdes, did ſwarue & diſſent frō ye Phariſies. They had many corrupt and Epicurial opiniōs, which they drew out of Philoſophy, & mingled thē with religion. They were enemies vnto Chriſt, vnto Iohn the Baptiſt, and vnto Chriſtes diſciples, and did aſſault thē with their craft & ſubtill diſputations, as it appeareth in the .xxii. of Mathew,Mat. 22. And the xx. of Luke, demaunding which of the ſeuen brethren ſhould haue yt one woman to wife after ye reſurrection. They helde that both body and ſoule periſhed together, & yt neither the godly ſhould receiue, any reward, for his good workes, neither the wicked ſhould receaue any payne for his ill dedes, otherwiſe thē in this life. They helde, yt there was neither hell nor
heauen, neither aungell nor ſpirite, and that it was in our power to be the authors vnto our ſelues, either of felicitie or els of miſerie.
They were great enemies to the Phariſies, yet agaynſt Chriſt they agreed together as one.
The ſecte of the Saduces was moſt deueliſh, and directly contrarie to the confeſsion of our doctrine, and to the true inuocation of Gods name.

div.head: Eſſaei.
div.p: Eſſaei, or as ſoone call them Eſſaeni, were the thirde ſecte among the Iewes, and they be called Eſſaeni quaſi operatores, workers, for they would be coumpted doers of the lawe, and not onely teachers or diſſemblers. The originall of this faction beganne of this, bycauſe they ſawe in the Phariſies nothyng but hypocriſie, fained holines, enuie, deſire to beare rule, and other thinges. VVhiche were diſcrepant from true godlines, they ſwarued from them. They did alſo abhorre the groſſe and prophane Epicuriſime of the Saduces. Therfore that thing whiche they deſired and ſawe to wante, both in the Phariſies and the Saduces, they endeuoured to perfourme and declare in workes. And that they might the better bring to paſſe the thing whiche they did attempte, they went into the vttermoſt coſte of Iurie, to a certain lake, named Asphaltites, not far from Ierico, where there were moſt fragrant and ſwete orchardes of baulme, as Plinie writeth of them: Ioſephus De bello Iudaico, writeth thus of them as foloweth.

The Eſſens be Iewes by nation, and be ioyned together with moſt deare and mutuall loue, whiche aboue all other doo ſhunne, and flie all pleaſures as moſt peſtiferous and wicked. They coumpte it the greateſt vertue to kepe continēcie. Therfore they do loth mariage. They take not withſtanding other mens children, and bring them vp in learning, and do inſtitute them moſt diligently in their maners and trade of life. They do not loth matrimony, for yt they iudge yt the ſucceſsiō of mākind ſhuld be deſtroyed, but bicauſe they thinck the intemperancie of womē ſhould be auoided, beleuing that none of them do kepe true faith vnto one man. They be alſo contemners of riches, ſo that one of them is not richer then an other, but haue all thinges in common. They neuer chaunge their apparell nor their ſhewes, except they be rente or torne, or els by long time conſumed & worne. Toward god they be very religious: for they ſpeake no worldly thing before the riſing of the ſunne, but they offer certeyne vowes to it, as if they prayed that the ſunne ſhould riſe. After that, they go euery one vnto their worke and buſines, and after they haue wrought to the fifth houre, they congregate them ſelues together agayne. And then being girte with linnen clothes, waſh their bodies with cold water.
And being ſo purified, they came into their ſupping, or dining chamber, and when euerie man is ſet with ſilence, the baker doth ſet a loſe to euerie one in order, and the cooke in likewiſe doth giue to euery one a diſhe of potage. And before they eate, the Prieſt doth call vpon God with his prayer, and likewiſe when diner is done, doth rendre thanckes, and then they put of thoſe holy veſtementes, and go agayne to worke vnto the euenyng. VVhen they diſpute, they come together, no leſſe then a hundred, and whatſoeuer is decreed of them, ſtandeth immouable, and not to be chaunged. Yf any man blaſpheme God, they condempne him to death. To ſpit before them, or on the right ſide of thē, they do greatlye abhorre. On the Saboth day, they be very ſcrupulous and ſuperſtitious to do any maner of worke, in ſo much that they will not kyndle the fier that day, nor cary any veſſell, no nor go to the ſtoole to eaſe thē ſelues. In other dayes, they digge a pit of a foote deepe, and couering thēſelues with a long garment, do eaſe themſelues in the ſame pit. And whē they haue done, couer it agayne with the ſame earth, and this thyng among them is counted very ſolemne. Their opinion is, that the bodyes be corruptible, and the matter of them is not perpetual, but they beleue the ſoules to be immortall, and do ſay, that the good ſoules ſhall lyue beyond the Occean ſea, where they ſhall haue their fruition and pleaſure. For they thincke, that that region is not ſubiect to heate, colde, ſhowers, or tempeſtes, but very pleaſaunt and delectable. The ill ſoules ſhalbe ſent (ſaye they) to tempeſtuous and colde places, full of mournyng and payne without end. Theſe wordes and many other, doth Ioſephus write of this ſecte in the ſame place, and likewiſe in hiis antiquities.

div.head: Monachus. 37.
div.p: CHriſoſtome writyng vpon the Epiſtle ſent to the Hebrewes, doth teſtifie that in the tyme of the Apoſtles, there was not one ſtep, or iote of Moncke or Monckerie.

Alſo two hundreth yeares after Chriſt there is no mention made by any worthy writer of Monckerie: ſauyng that the Decretal Epiſtles of ye Biſhops of Rome, do giue certaine cōiectures, of the Decrees of Virgins to be conſecrated. But of what authoritie and force thoſe Epiſtles be, a certaine Moncke named Caltheſen, doth geue iudgemēt, whoſes wordes be theſe: Nunc meo iudicio illa de Conſtantini Donatione Apocripha ſunt. Sed fortaſsis quaedā alia longa & magna ſcripta, ſancto Clemēti & ſācto Anacleto, ſūt attributa, ſūmis pōtificibus: in quibꝰ volētes Roma nā ſedē oī laude digniſsimā, plus quā expedit exaltare, ſe penitus fundarunt
cum tamen omnino non videantur illorum ſanctorum Epiſtolae, cōſideratis contentis in iis. Scribitur enim in Epiſtolis Clementis, quo modo Papa, fuerit & Petri ſucceſſor, & poſt Petri mortem ad ſanctū Iacobum has fingit ſcriptor miſsiſſe Epiſtolas, qui fuit frater domini & Hieroſolimorum Epiſcopus: Et eſt tamen hoc omnino falſum cum ſit manifeſtum, prius Petro Iacobum octo annis finiuiſſe martyrio vitam. Scribit quoque ipſum Clementem ſucceſſorem fuiſſe Petri, ſed hoc idem in aliis quae ſancto Anacleto adſcribuntur, legitur. Sed ſi hoc eſſet verum, quomodo ſancti viri Hieronimus, Auguſtinus, Optatus, Mileuitanus, & ceteri, qui omnium pontificum Romanorum catalogum poſuerunt, hoc ignoraſſent, vel ſaltem nō immediate poſt Petrum ponunt, ſi ipſas Epiſtolas ad tunc vidiſſent, aut pro auctenticis habuiſſent? Inuenitur inſuper in ipſis Epiſtolis de Epiſcoporum a ſacerdotibus differentia, quae tamen longo tempore poſt Clementē hunc, (vt Hieronimo placet, & Damaſo) in Eccleſia orta eſt: hactenus Caltheſen, that is to ſay. By my iudgement, thoſe thinges whiche are written of the donation of Contine, are Apocriphall, yea and perchaunce certeine other long and great written workes, which are attributed vnto Saint Clement, and Anaclete, being the high Biſhops, in the whiche they do vtterly ground them ſelues, willing to exalte the ſee of Rome, worthy of all prayſe more than is expedient.

VVhen notwithstandyng theſe Epiſtles do not ſeeme to be the Epiſtles of thoſe holy men, if the contentes and circumſtances of them be duely conſidered, for it is written in the Epiſtles of Clement, howe he was Pope, and the ſucceſſor of Peter, and that he ſent theſe Epiſtles after the death of Peter, to ſaint Iames, which was called the brother of the Lord, and was Biſhop of Hieruſalem, but this is vtterly falſe, for it is manifeſt, that Iames finiſhed his life with martyrdome eight yeares before Peter. He writeth alſo, that Clemēt was the ſucceſſor of Peter, but this is red alſo in other thinges, which are aſcribed vnto Anaclete. But if this ſhould be true, how do theſe holy mē, Hierome, Auſten, Optatus, Mileuitanus and other whiche do write the cataloge and order of all the Biſhops of Rome, not knowe this? VVhich do not ſet in Clement, or at the leaſt, do not put him immediatly after Peter, if they had then either ſeene the Epiſtles, or counted them auctentycall. Furthermore there is founde in the ſame Epiſtles, the difference of Biſhoppes from Prieſtes, whiche notwithſtanding began long after in the Churche after Clement, as it pleaſeth Hierome and Damaſus.

There is alſo the authoritie of moſt auncient and great learned writers, whiche do declare, that theſe Biſhoppes of Rome ſhould not be the authors of theſe Epiſtles. For neyther Hierome, nor Damaſus, nor Euſebius, nor the ſixte counſell of Carthage, doo make any mention of the
Epiſtles, nor ye ſhall finde theſe Epiſtles to be cited of any author worthy credit, vnto the tyme of Carolus Magnus. And it is not vnlike to be true, that about that tyme, when the VVeſt Churches did aſke & ſeeke bookes out of the Librarie of Rome, that theſe Epiſtles were feyned, forged, and diſperſed abroad by the fraude & craft of ye Biſhops of Rome, whiche then did affecte Empire and rule, not onely ouer all Churches, but alſo aboue kynges and princes of the earth.

But to (come to our purpoſe agayne) Monckerie began about the beginnyng of the foure hundred yeares after Chriſt, and that in Egypt, where Antonius, Macarius, Panubus and Paulus, floriſhed in that kind of life, and likewiſe in other places of the world, as Sozomenus doth teſtifie. And truly it is maruell, when that age had ſo great learned men, that they did not onely approue, but alſo inſtitute and ordeine thoſe kindes of life, which were not institute, nor ordeined of God. Sozomenus doth recorde, that there were two kindes of Monckes: the one, whiche liued in the wildernes: the other, which liued in cities, but yet ſeparate from the companie of other men. The maner of a monaſticall life, Baſilius doth rehearſe, and ſhewe, In ſermone Aſcetico, out of the which it appeareth, that they whiche profeſſed Monckerie, did firſt geue all their goods, before they went into the monaſterie: his wordes be theſe. Oportet monachum ante omnia id vitae genus amplecti, vt nihil poſsideat, corpus habeat quietum, & habitum honeſtum, vocem moderatam, & ſermonem bene diſpoſitum, cibum ac potum ſumere tranquille, ac cum ſilētio, apud ſeniores tacere, that is to ſay:

It behoueth a Moncke aboue all thinges, to embrace that kinde of life, that he poſſeſſe nothyng, that he haue a quiet body, an honeſt habite, a moderate voyce, communication well diſpoſed and ordered, that he take his meat and drincke quietly and with ſilence, that among his Seniors and elders, he hold his peace. But of what holynes, pouertie, chaſtitie and obediēce our monckes of late time haue bene, it is horrible to ſpeake. And becauſe their hypocriſie, ſuperſtition and abhominable kynde of lyfe, is knowne to all the world, I will ſpeake no more of them.

div.head: Biblion. 38.
div.p: Βίβλοσ ſignifieth properly Papyrū, whiche is a great ruſh, whiche groeth in the fennes & mariſh grounde in Egipt and Syria, ten cubites in height, wherof the firſt Paper was made, wheron mē did write. It betokenneth alſo a booke, wherof we call the booke conteining the holy Scriptures, Biblion, or ſacra Biblia in the plurall nūber, and not Biblia in the ſinguler number.

Note that in olde time, men did write in the leafes of Palme trees, whereof we call the leafes of bookes Folia, whiche be called alſo in the Greke 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . After that they wrote in the rindes of certaine trees, which are called Libri, and therfore our bokes be named Libri, and by a diminitiue Libelli. They be called alſo Codices, of this worde Codex, or Caudex, which is ye lower part of the tree next the root, from the which the rinde is drawen. After that, publique and cōmon workes were written in volumes of lead, and priuate workes, were writtē in clay, & after in waxe: for the vſe of tables to write in, were before the battell of Troy.

But after the victory of Alexander the great (when the citie Alexandria was builded in Egypt) Paper was inuented of kyng Alexander (as Varro teſtifieth) whiche was made of the calles, that grewe in the fennes of Egypt.

It is called Charta, of the name of a citie of Tire named Charta, from whēce Dido came, and therfore ſhe called the citie which ſhe builded afterward Carthaginē, of the name of the citie Charta, frō which ſhe cam.

Parchemēt was inuented (as Varro writeth) after yt Paper was foūd out by Alexander, to the vſe of the libraries of Ptolomie & Emmenes, kinges of Pergamus, and therfore it is called in Latin Pergamena.
It is called alſo Membrana a membrorū tectu, that is of coueryng the members, that is, of the ſkinne, which couereth the body, of which ſkinne the Perchement is made.

div.head: Coloſsis. 39.
div.p: COloſſae or Coloſsis, was (as Strabo writeth) Lib. 12. a towne of Phrigia, adioyning to Laodicea, whiche as Oroſius, teſtifieth with Laodicea and Hierapolis, was deſtroyed, and fell downe by an earthquake in the tyme of Nero the Emperour.

The inhabitāts of this citie Coloſsis, were inſtitute and conuerted to ye faith of Chriſt by one Archippus and one Epaphras. Archippus was Paules diſciple. Epaphras was borne in ye town Coloſsis, who afterward was captiue with Paul at Rome: he was ſuppoſed to be one of ye .70. diſciples.

But the Coloſsians were auerted from the ſinceritie of the Gospell by falſe Apoſtles, who perſuaded them, that Chriſt was not come, nor yet ſhould come at all, but that aungels were the auctors of our ſaluation, beſide that, they preached vnto them both Iudaicall and Philoſophicall ſuperſtitions. Agaynſt thoſe falſe Apoſtles, Paule ſtrengthnyng and confirming the Coloſsians, doth ſend vnto them an Epiſtle, in the which he ſheweth & proueth the one onely Chriſt, beyng aboue al aūgels, to be ye auctor of our ſaluatiō, And defēding his own authority, doth admoniſh them to beware of the falſe viſions, reuelations & doctrines of the falſe
Apoſtles. And finally doth exhorte them to auoyde al il things, & to folow good thinges, and doth admoniſh alſo euery age of their ſtate, condicion, and calling.

Although it ſeme impertinent to be ſet among theſe Miſcellanes, yet for the nerenes of the wordes Coloſſe and Coloſsi, I will not leaue vntouched what Coloſsi be, neither will I omit the nature of the prouerbe that ſprong of them, nor the diſcourſe of the ſeuen wonders of the worlde, of the number of whom Coloſsi is one. The .vij. wonders be theſe yt follow.

div.head: 1. Coloſſi.
div.p: Coloſsi were images of horrible greatnes, like to towres. One of Apollo in the capital at Rome, was .xxx cubites. Alſo one made at Tarrentum by Lyſippus, was .xl. cubites hie. But at Rhodes one of the Sunne exceding al other was in height .lxx. cubites, made by Colaſsis, ſcholer to Lyſippus. The thombe of that image few men might fathome. It was in making .xii. yeres, and the charges drew to .300. talents, which amounteth to .43115 pound. Strabo writeth, that the image was of Iupiter, other write, yt it was of the Sunne, & made by Chares Lyndius, and thys is it that was compted one of the ſeuen wonders. Some cal it a braſen pyller, (as Ariſtotle writeth) ſixe hundred cubites hie. Beſides this were an hū dred leſſe Coloſsi in Rhodes, and at Rome were many made of mettall.
Of this commeth twoo prouerbes: Coloſſica onera, that is, great and heauy burthens.
Vir Coloſſicus, a huge, mighty, and taule man.

div.head: 2. Templum Dianae.
div.p: This temple was edified by al Aſia in an. 120. yeres, and was ſet in a fenne or marſhe ground, the foundacion being firſt layd with coles, troden or rammed hard, then flieces of wool layed theron, and al this was to ſaue it frō earthquakes. The temple was in length .425. foote, in bredth 220. In it wer a .127. pillers, euery of them .60. foote hie, made by kings. The roofe was of cedre trees, and the doores of cipres. A lewde perſon of purpoſe to get a renowne in hiſtories (being couetous of glorye, and hauing no excellent quality to attaine therunto) putting wilde fire into the roofe, did burne this temple. His name was Heroſtratus, as Strabo writeth, wherof proceded a prouerbe: Heroſtrati gloria, applied vnto them that do ſeeke for a renowne or prayſe of a miſcheuous act.

div.head: 3. Piramides Aegiptiae.
div.p: The Piramides in Egipt, were nothing els, but a vaine and foolyſhe oſtentation of the riches of kinges, as Plinie writeth. The cauſe of the building of them, of moſt writers is reported to be, that they might not leaue any money vnto their ſucceſſors, or to ſuch as ſhould enuy them.

There were many euery wher in Egipt, but ther wer none more noble
and famous, thē thoſe three, of the which Pomponius Mela ſpeaketh, the which filled al the world with their fame, being apparant and conſpicuous vnto all ſuch as ſhould ſayle by them, ſituated in a part of Affricke, vpon a ſtony and barren hil, betwixt the towne called Memphis, and the towne Delta. They are towers (as Solinus ſayth) of ſo marueylous a high top, as is almoſt vncredible to be built by mans hand. Vnder theſe towers were the kinges of Egipt buried.

Cheopes a king of Egipt, was twenty yeares in building one of theſe towers, hauing three hundred, threeſcore thouſand woorkemen, daylye laboring about it. It was declared in the Egiptian letters, which were written about it, that there was a thouſande, eight hundred talentes, ſpent in radiſh rootes, garlike, and onions, which the workemen deuoured. VVhich talentes are in our coyne ſeuen hundred and thirtye thouſand crownes, for the talent of Egipt was fifty Minae. Beſides, if thou wilt make but a meane eſtimation of all other kinde of victual or meate, of apparell and wages for their woorke, if thou accompte alſo the yron wherwith the ſtones were bound together, and the wood wherof the engines were framed, there wyl ariſe in the end aboue two thouſand, twoo hundred tonels of French crownes.

Some affirme thoſe Pyramides to haue bene made by Ioſeph a Iewe, for the ſafe keeping of corne, wherof they tooke their name. For 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , is called corne or wheate. Other ſay, they are Sepulchers, builded in the honour of Fire, the which the Egiptians dyd woorwip for a God, and therefore to growe foure ſquare, and ſharpe vpwarde, to the lykeneſſe of Fyre.

div.head: 4. Cyri Regia.
div.p: Cyrus was a noble King of Perſia, the ſonne of Cambyſes and Maudanes the daughter of Aſtiages, king of Media.

This Cyrus was (by the commaundement of his Grandfather Aſtiages, when he was borne) caſt out, to be deuoured of the wylde beaſtes, bicauſe he ſaw in his dreame a vine tree, ſpringing oute of the children of hys onely begotten daughter, with whoſe braunches al Aſia ſhould be ouerſhadowed. He beyng caſt foorth, was marueilouſlye nouriſhed a great while by a Bitche of a dog kinde. At the length being brought vp by the kinges ſhepheard (as Gods prouidence would) was choſen king of the Perſians. Ouer whom when he had raigned certayne yeares, he was ſlayne of Tonigris Queene of Scithia, wyth twoo hundred thouſande Perſians, ſo that there was not one left to beare home tidynges of ſo great a ſlaughter.

The head of Cyrus being cut of, was caſt into a veſſell filled with mans bloud, with this exprobration: Fil thy ſelfe with bloud, which thou haſt alwaies thirſted after. He was firſt called Agradatus, and afterwarde Cyrus, of a riuer of the ſame name, rūning through Perſia, by the which riuer he was caſt forth.
This man excelled al men of his time in goodly perſonage, gentlenes, proweſſe, liberality, wiſdome, and memory.
Solinus writeth, that of the exceeding multitude of men, which wer in his hoſt, he ſo retayned the names, that he called euery man by his proper name, when he ſpake vnto them.
Plutarchus alſo writeth, that he made a gallery al of gold & Iuery, he made alſo ſuch a coſtly pallace, that for the ſumptuouſnes thereof, it was counted one of the ſeuen wonders of the world.
The reſidue of his wonderfull vertues are wrytten by Xenophon, moſt eloquently in Greeke.

div.head: 5. Mauſoleum.
div.p: This was the tombe of one Mauſolus king of Caria, the which tombe his wife Artemiſia made, of whom is written this ſtory. Artemiſia was of ſuch chaſtity, and ſo excelled in loue towards her huſband, that whē he was dead, ſhe cauſed his hart to be dried in a veſſel of golde into poulder, and by litle and litle ſhe dranke it vp, ſaying: Their twoo hartes ſhould neuer depart a ſunder, and that ſhe thought there might be no worthy ſepulchre made for it, but her own body. Notwithſtanding ſhe made for his body ſuch a ſepulchre, that for the excellent workmanſhip, beautye, & coſtlynes thereof, it was taken for one of the maruels of the world, and for the notable fame therof, all ſumptuous and great ſepulchers wer after called Mauſolea.

div.head: 6. Babylon.
div.p:
Babilon a noble city, being ſet & placed by the riuer Euphrates, once head of all Chaldie, of the which great Meſopotamia, and part of Aſſyria was called Babilonia, as Pline writeth.Lib. 6. cap. 20. This city Strabo writeth to be builded by Semiramis. But the Hebrues doo referre the originall beginning of it vnto Nemrothe the Giant, who ſay that it was called Babilon of the confuſion of tounges. This city being afterward reſtawred and enlarged by Ninus or Semiramis, was very notable and famous, for her walles and hanging gardens, and for her temple and walking places. The fieldes were verye playne and pleaſant, the nature of the ſoyle very fertile and fruitful, the walles wer quadrant with towers and caſtels in them. Her walles wer of an incredible magnitude and ſtrength, being fifty cubites in breadth, and .300. cubites in higth The circute and compaſſe
of it is ſayd to be .480. furlonges, the riuer Euphrates running in the middle of it. The walles were made of bricke, compacted together wt lime & pitch, ye which ſome write to be ſo brod, yt .2. waynes meeting together might eaſely paſſe. About the walles ther rūneth abrod ditcheful of water, as though it were a riuer, which walles are beutified wt an hū dred gates of bras. This city being in a time reuolted frō her alegiaūce, Semiramis being occupied about the ornature and decking of her body, made haſte immediately to recouer it, one part of her heare being looſe, neither did ſhe make vp her head, and bring her heare in an order, before ſhe had recouered the city into her dominion againe.

Here note a worthy example of this valiant woman Semiramis, againſt couetouſnes and greedy deſire of money. This woman, when ſhe had made a tombe, wherin ſhe intended to be buried, being dead, cauſed this ſuperſcription to be writtē vpon it: VVhat king ſo euer ſhall lacke money, let him open this ſepulchre, and take as much as he wyl. VVhych wordes, when Darius had read, being a very greedy perſon, commaunded the graue to be opened, but he founde no money there at all, but he happened vpon theſe wordes: Ni malus vir fores, & pecunia prorſum inexplebilis, nō vtique mortuorum loculos moueres. That is: If thou wer not an euil man, hauing an vnſatiable deſire of mony, thou wouldeſt not breake open the graues of the dead.

div.head: 7. Simulacrum Iouis.
div.p: The ſeuenth wonder Caſsiodorus writeth to be the image of Iupiter Olympicus, which was made by one Phidias, firſt a Painter, and afterward a Caruer, for the making of which image, he became exceedyng famous. He made alſo other excellent workes, as the image of Venus at Rome, in the porche of Octauia, and the image of the Goddeſſe Nemeſis, being ten cubites, at Rhamnus, a famous village in the countye of Athens, which helde in her hande a braunche of an apple tree, out of the which roſe a litle folde, wherin were wrytten theſe woordes: Agoracritus Parius fecit. He was the ſcholler of Phideas, whom he ſo loued, that he wrote his name in his own woorke. Of thys riſeth a prouerbe: Rhamnuſia Nemeſis.
This Nemeſis was a Goddeſſe, whom the Paynims ſuppoſed to be the puniſher of greuous offenders. Some call her Fortune.

Suidas ſayth, that Nemeſis is Iuſtice, complaint, reproche, enuy, fortune. And Eraſmus ſaith, Nemeſis is a goddeſſe, the reuenger of inſolency, and arogancy. She is called Adraſtia, of Adraſto the king, that firſte conſtituted to her a tēple, ſhe is called alſo Rānuſia, of the town Rānus.

But Gregorius Nazianzenus, in the funerall ſong which he wrote vpon Baſill the great, prayſing the gorgeouſnes and coſtlynes of the hoſpital
builded of him, ſayd in this maner: I truly (ſayd he) conſidering this place, being ſo notable, for the bignes and fine woorkemanſhip of it, would count it nothing inferior vnto the ſeuen wonders of the world.
Of the which numbers he numbreth and writeth theſe three following, to be three of the ſayd ſeuē: that is, the city Thebae, and the Capitall of Rome, and the temple of Adrian in Cyzicke.

div.head: Thebe or Theba.
div.p: Of this name there were nine cities, one in Beotia, an other in Egipt, the third in Theſſalia, the fourth in Cilicia, the fift in Iouia, the ſixt in Attica, the ſeuenth in Cataonia, the eyght in Italy, the ninth in Syria.

That in Egipt was the moſt famous, builded of Buſiris king of Egipt, in compaſſe (as Herodotus declareth) a hundred and fortye furlonges, called Stadia. This City had many fayre buildinges, both publike & priuate. Plinie writeth that it was holow vnderneath, and ſtoode all vpon vawtes. It had an hundred gates, and in euerye gate were two hundred kepers, which excelled in great horſes and chariotes, vnder the which city kings were wont to bring forth great and huge hoſtes of armed men, none of the citizens perceauing it.

There was in this city (ſayth Calliniachus) a caue, which being at all other times full of wynde, yet in that ſpace, which is betwene the olde Moone and the new, which is called in latine interlunium, there was no ayre perceaued at all.
Bicauſe there hath bene often mention made of a furlong called Stadium, it ſhall not be out of the way to declare what Stadium is.

Stadium was properly the place where horſes or men did runne, or wher wreſtlers did ſtriue, called ſtadium,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is, a ſtatione, bicauſe that Hercules ranne that ſame ſpace, drawing his breathe but once, and then ſtoode ſtyll.

The furlong was firſt inuented of Hercules, and he met it at Piſis, where Iupiter Olimpius was. The length of that ſame furlong, was two hundred feete, wherupon ſome inuented after, other kindes of furlongs in Grece, being likewiſe of twoo hundred feete of length, yet ſomewhat ſhorter then Hercules furlong. Hereof Pithagoras gathered, that the foote of Hercules was ſo much more long thē other mēs feete, how much the furlong called Olympicum ſtadium was longer then other furlongs.
Stadium properly containeth the eight part of a myle, and before the Romanes found out their miles, men did diuide and meaſure the ſpaces of the earth by furlongs.

But the Perſians dyd vſe a furlong, but an other kinde of meaſure, which they cal Paraſangam, which conteineth the ſpace of ſixe myles &
a quarter of our miles. Cenſorinus writeth, that of theſe Stadia ther wer three ſortes. The one was of Italy, and that contained .625. feete, which is .125. paſes. The ſecond was called Olympicum, and that was of .600. feete, that is .120. paſes. The third was called Pythicum, which contayned .1000. feete, which is .200. paſes, which peraduenture was forgotten of Plinius and Solinus, when they wrate the deſcription of Cicilia, which maketh the variaunce betwene them and Diodorus Siculus. Of the ſtadia called Italica, eight doo make an Italian myle, contayning a thouſand paſes, euery paſe being fiue feete, we haue none other name to geue it, but a furlong.

div.head: Capitolium.
div.p: Capitolium was a great and mighty tower in Rome, ſet in the mount called Saturnius, & builded of the king Tarquinius ſuperbus, as Plinie writeth, lib. 3. cap. 5. Some write, that it was the temple of Iupiter, ſet in the cleue called Tarpeius. It was called Capitolium a capite hominis ibi reperto, of a mans head there found, while they digged vp the foundacion, for before it was called arx Tarpeia, of the veſtal virgine Tarpeia, which was killed of the Sabines, and there buried. Capitolinus was the name of him that found the head, when the capitoll began to be builded. It muſt nedes be a faire coſtly and ſumptuous thing, for as much as Nazianzen doth number it among the ſeuen wonders of the world.

div.head: Templum Hadriani.
div.p: This temple was builded in Cyzicum, a noble City of Bithynia, ſo named of Cyzicus a king, as Pomponius Mela writeth. It is a citye famous and notable, with caſtels, walles, towers, hauens, and turrets of marbell, as Florus writeth. lib. 2. It was had in great honour, eſtimation and price of the Romanes, as Strabo writeth, lib. 12. In this place by likelyhoode Adriane did builde that ſumptuous temple, which is counted of Nazianzen to be one of the ſeuen wonders of the world.

Theſe (by the teſtimony of Caſsiodore and Nazianzen) be the ſeuen ſpectacles or wonders of the world, recorded almoſt in euery place, both of the Hiſtoriographers and Poetes. Of the which wonders there remaineth nothing at this day, but their vaine names and titles, wherby we may vnderſtand, that ther is nothing, that can be made ſo glorious and gallant, by the power and induſtry of man, which antiquity & time cannot diſpatch and conſume.

I would God that the princes, and noble mē of the earth with others, would heare and conſider theſe thinges, and ſpecially they which would purchaſe vnto them ſelues perpetual renowme, with ſuch outragious & fond buildinges. For what is more fond, then to waſt and ſpend out of meaſure much riches in vnprofitable buildings, that ſhall do good to no
man? And here by the way, I wiſh the Clergie and the people would expend with them ſelues, what they do, which diſpoſe ſo prepoſterouſly & vainly, the reuenues and yearely profites of the Churches (I meane in building of great and ſumptuous temples) with ſpires ſo high and long, yt they may be almoſt cōpared with ye Pyramides of Egipt. For theſe things cannot be done without the wrath of God. For (I pray you) what other cauſe is ther why, yt temples builded more curiouſly and ſumptuouſly, thē is conuenient to chriſtian modeſty, are touched and deſtroyed ſo many times, with ſo often lightnings? which thing I take to be a warning frō heauen, that we ſhhould refraine from ſuch fondnes and gaſing ſhewes. That the poore and oppreſſed with calamities, ought to be relieued and maintayned with the goods of the church, the old cuſtome and maner of the primitiue church doth teach and declare. VVhich you may eaſely perceaue, partly out of other mens writings, and ſpecially out of epiſtles of the holy martyr ſaint Ciprian, writing chiefly of a certain ſcoffer to be excommunicated, vnles he would leaue his arte and facultye. His woords be theſe. Quod ſi penuriam talis, & neceſſitatem paupertatis obtendit, poteſt inter caeteros, qui alimentis eccleſiae ſuſtinentur, huius quoque neceſsitas adiuuari: ſi tamen contentus ſit frugalioribus & innocentibus cibis. If ſuch a one do make a pretence of penury & lacke his neceſsity among other, which ar ſuſtained with the goods of the church, may be eaſed and holpen, ſo that he be contented with ſober and meane diet. And a litle after in the ſame epiſtle he writeth of the ſame perſon, after this maner. Quod ſi (inquit) illic eccleſia non ſufficit vt laborantibus praeſtentur alimenta, poterit ſe ad nos tranſferre, & hic, quod ſibi ad victum atque veſtitum neceſſarium fuerit, accipere. If the church (ſaith he) ther, be not able or ſufficient to geue nouriſhment to ſuch as labour, and haue neede, he may come hether vnto vs, and here receaue that which ſhal be neceſſary vnto him, both for meate, drinke, and cloth. By thys place of Ciprian you may coniecture, that the needy and miſerable perſons, did not onely make their refuge vnto the liberality of the Churche, wher they dwelt, but alſo that one church did communicate her riches vnto other Churches, in the nouriſhing of the poore, according to the moſt Chriſtian inſtitution of Saint Paule.

Neyther for any other cauſe did Baſilius Magnus, or other of lyke pietye, builde hoſpitales for poore wayfaring men, and houſes for beggers and ſycke men, but that they myght eaſe wyth their priuate expenſes, the common charges of the Churche, whiche at that tyme was verye poore.

If any man be of a contrary iudgement, and will prefer the exceſsiue
riches of the church, before the neceſsitye of the poore, let him conſider (whatſoeuer he be) what ſaint Ambroſe a noble father & doctor of the church doth write to ye cōtrary. His words be theſe in his boke of offices Aurum eccleſia habet, non vt ſeruet, ſed vt eroget: vt ſubueniat in neceſſitatibus. Quid opus eſt cuſtodire quod nihil adiuuat? An ignoramus quantum auri atque argenti de templo domini, Aſſyrii ſuſtulerint? Nonne melius conflant ſacerdotes propter alimoniam pauperum, ſi alia ſubſidia deſint, quam ſacrilegus aſportet hoſtis? Nonne dicturus eſt dominus, quur paſſus es tot inopes fame mori? Et certe habebas aurū, vt miniſtrares alimoniam. Quur tot captiui deducti in commercio ſunt, & non redempti? Melius fuerat vt vaſa viuentium ſeruares, quam metallorum. His non poſſet reſponſum referri. Quid enim diceres? Timui, ne templo dei ornatus deeſſet. Reſponderet. Aurum ſacramenta non quaerunt, neque auro placent, quae auro non emuntur. &c.

That is to ſay: The church hath gold, not to keepe, but to beſtow it, and to helpe men in their neceſsity. VVhat nedeth to keepe that whych helpeth nothing? Are we ignorant how much gold and ſiluer, the Aſsirians tooke away out of the temple of the Lord? VVere it not better that the Prieſtes ſhould beſtow it to the ſuſtentation of the poore (if other ſuccours lacke) then that it ſhould be caried away by the ſacrilege of the enemy? VVill not the Lord ſay: why didſt thou ſuffer ſo many poore men to dye for hūger? And yet truly, thou hadſt gold wherwith to relieue thē. VVhy are there ſo many caried away captiue, by the entercourſe of marchaundiſe, and not redemed? VVhy are ther ſo many ſlaine of the enemy? It were better that the veſſels of the liuing were preſerued, then the veſſels of mettal. Vnto this ther can be no anſwer made. For what wouldeſt thou ſay? I feared, leaſt there ſhould lacke to decke the temple of God withall. He would anſwere: Holy things doo not require gold, neither thoſe things can be made acceptable by gold, which cannot be bought with gold. The ornament of the ſacraments, is the redemption of ye captiue. And thoſe are truly precious veſſels, which redeeme the ſoules from death. That is, the true treaſure of the Lord, that doth worke that, which the Lordes bloud wrought. And a little after he ſayth. Laurentius, qui aurum eccleſiae maluit erogare pauperibus, quam perſecutori reſeruare, pro ſingulari ſuae interpretationis viuacitate, ſacram Martyrii accepit co ronam. Saint Laurence, which had leauer to diſtribute the gold of the churche to the needye, then leaue them to the perſecutour, for his ſinguler and liuely interpretacion, receiued the bleſſed crowne of martyrdome. VVas it ſayd (thinke you) to ſaynt Laurence, thou oughteſt not to do away the treaſures of the church, and ſel the holy veſſels? To what vſes the veſſels of the Churche are to be diſpoſed, or after what ſorte, or for what cauſes, it is needefull onely that thou conſider this with a
pure faith, and a prouident iudgement. Truly if a man employ them vpon his own cōmodity, it is a fault, but if he beſtow them vpon the poore, it is a deede of mercy. For no man can ſay why do the poore liue? No mā can complaine, bicauſe the captiue are redemed. Haec Ambroſius. The which wordes of Ambroſe, for this cauſe I haue alledged, that it might be vnderſtoode, vpon what vſes chiefly, the eccleſiaſticall goods ought to to be beſtowed. Yea, and to ſpeake freely the truth, the priuate money of the chriſtians pertaineth to none other vſe, if any man haue more then is ſufficient for the maintenance of his life. It is not to be reproued nor diſalowed (after the opiniō of ſome learned mē) if any do build temples, beutifiyng them with marbel and gold, ſo that it be not done to the diſcommodity of other, but the care and regard of the poore is to be counted a great deale better, then all ſuch thinges, yea ſo much, that if a mā do the other without this, he may be iudged rather to offend, then to profit. For God is not ſo much delighted, with dead temples made of ſtone, as he is with liuely temples, made of fleſh and bone. VVherupon Chriſoſtome both nobly and notably (as he doth all thinges) writeth vpon Mathew, after this maner Tu ſi praeparaſſe quoſdam vaſa videris ſacra, aut ornatum quem piam alium circa parietes eccleſiarum, acpauimenta confeciſſe, nolito reprihendere, aut iubere vt vendatur quod iam factum eſt, ne animum eius qui fecit, perturbes. Sin vero antequam fecerit te conſuluerit, pauperibus offerre iubeto. If thou perceiue any mā to haue prepared holy veſſels, or adourned the walles of ye church, and to haue beſtowed charges in the making of the pauement therof, reproue him not, nor commaund that which is made to be ſold, leaſt thou trouble the mind of him that made it. But if he aſke thy counſell firſt, commaund him to beſtow it vpon the poore.

Theſe woordes of Chriſoſtome do declare, that ther were once certayne oblacions made in the church, to eaſe the incōmodity of the poore. VVhich partly ſaint Paul doth plainly ſhew (who doth cal thē collectas, gatherings) partly ſaynt Ierome in his explanations, vppon the Prophet Ezechiel, his woords be theſe.

Juſtus panem ſuum eſurienti dat. Per hoc docemur elemoſinam non ſaturis faciendam, ſed eſurientibus, nec dandum panem his qui ructant plenitudine, ſed his qui inanitate cruciantur: In pane autem omnis continetur cibus. Et ſignificanter dicitur ſuum, ne de rapinis & vſuris, & de alieno malo quaeſitum panem vertamus in miſericordiam: Redemptio enim animae viri propriae diuitiae. Quod multos facere conſpicimus, clientes & pauperes & agricolas (vt taceam de militantium & iudicum violentia) qui opprimunt per potentiam, & furta committunt, vt de multis parua pauperibus tribuant, & in ſuis ſceleribus glorientur: publice
que Diaconus recitet in eccleſiis offerentiū nomina, tantū offert ille, ille tātū pollicitus eſt, placētque ſibi ad plauſū populi torquēte eos cōſcientia. &c
That is to ſay: The iuſt man wyll geue his breade vnto the hungrye. By this we are taught not to geue our almes vnto the ful, but vnto the hungery, nor to geue breade vnto ſuche as belke with a ful bellye, but vnto ſuch as are pinched with ſcarcety of meate. And it is ſayd very well, his, that we turne not ye bread gotten by extorcion, vſerye, and other mens hinderaunce, into almes. For the redemption of the ſoule of man, are his owne riches. VVhich thing we ſee many to doo, which oppreſſe by might their Clientes, the poore, and huſband men of the country (that I maye not ſpeake of the violence of warriers and Iudges) and commyt robbery and theft, that of much, they may geue a litle to the poore, boaſting and gloriyng in their wyckednes. And that the Deacon recite openlye in the Churches, the names of them that offer. So muche he geueth, an other promiſed ſo muche, and they ſtand in their own conceite, at the prayſe and ſhoute of the people, their conſciences pricking them in the meane whyle. And they geue an occaſion vnto wretched men, to reioyce at theyr giftes, and not contrarywiſe, to lament for their ſpoyles.

I haue brought in ſaynt Ierome for this purpoſe, that it might appeare, the cuſtome of offering in the Churches, to be verye auncient, but at this time to be greatly abuſed, the Paſtours and Miniſters challenging it wholy vnto them ſelues, what ſo euer is offered in the Church. By what right, and how lawfully, let them take heede. But yet notwythſtanding, I doubt not, but that in ſhort ſpace, all pouertye and beggerye wyll be expelled out of the commonwealth, if this cuſtome were renued and had in vre againe.

But (to returne from whence we haue gone aſtraye) I thincke it is made euident inough, that it is not lawfull for Chriſtians ſo vaynelye to caſt away vpon earthly, bridge, and baren woorkes, the riches, due onely vnto the poore, whether they be of the Churche, or prophane ryches. For ther is nothing more meete, then that the members of Chriſt ſhould be relieued with Chriſtes money. Ther is nothing more decent and comelye, then that a Chriſtian man, what ſoeuer riches he poſſeſſeth, more then neceſſary, that he reſtore them vnto Chriſt, the geuer of all riches and goodnes.

The which thing then he ſhall doo moſt truelye, when he ſhall haue regarde of the poore, and (no occaſions being let paſſe) ſhall helpe them both in deede and in wyll. For whatſoeuer we doo vnto the poore, it is accompted and taken, as thoughe we did it vnto Chriſt beyng preſent. All our lyfe is nothing but a temptacion, and therefore it hath neede of Gods diuine counſell and helpe.

And we are tempted, not onely with afflictions and pouerty, but muche more with wealth and riches, the which God is wont to geue vnto men, as an occaſion to benefite and helpe the poore. For in this onelye thing chiefly riche men excel, bicauſe they haue a great occaſion to helpe other. It is meete therfore, that they in their good deedes, agree and anſwer vnto the goodnes and benignity of God, and that they beſtowe their goodes geuen them by God, not vpon high turrets and mighty images, not vpon towers and caſtels, but in nouriſhing, clothing and defending of Chriſtes body, which is the church. Vpon this body we ought all to attende, vnto this body we ought earneſtly to ſticke, prouiding by all meanes for it, of the whych body we our ſelues are alſo members: and for thys cauſe if we conferre any thing vpon this bodye, that onely is kepte vncorrupt, as though it were in a cheſt of Adamant ſtone, and doth, & ſhal remayne for euer. VVe brought nothing into this worlde with vs, nor when we ſhal depart, we ſhal cary any thing away, beſides that onely, which we ſend afore by the handes of the poore. VVilt thou erect pyllers which ſhal endure and ſtand a long time, and wilt thou in building of high Turrets and ſpires, purchaſe vnto thee a perpetuall memorye of thy name with the poſteritie? Then follow Saint Laurence, which diſtributed the churches monie vnto the church. Then follow Baſill, who builded a fayre hoſpitall for the poore. Then followe Ceſarius Nazianzenus his brother, the which dying, ſayd: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . That is: I wyl almine to be the goods of the poore, Finally, follow Hilarius the Biſhop, who was ſo great a louer of the poore, that althoughe he came of a noble parentage, yet notwithſtanding, he exerciſed huſbandry, more then his body could well ſuſtaine, being tenderly and nicely brought vp, that he might miniſter vnto the poore of his own labors, And (that we may bring the Heathen for an example) follow Simon of Athens, who dyd dayly feaſt the poore, and brake downe the hedges & walles of his orchardes and gardens, that the needy might haue the more acceſſe to gather the fruietes thereof. To conclude, follow Traiane the Emperour, who in gathering and chuſing fiue thouſand free borne children out of his whole empire, found them at his owne charges, and dyd cauſe them to be inſtituted with the rules of vertue, vnder godlye and learned maſters, whereby he might prouide a number of good men, to ſerue the common wealth in time to come. Follow (I ſay) theſe men before named, or at the leaſt, one of them, and chuſe them, whom thou may eſt benefite. Bryng vp the Pupilles, ſet the Orphanes to learning, and cauſe them to be trained wyth the knowledge, as well of the tounges, as of good literature.

div.head: Diocleſian. 40.
div.p: THree hundred and ſixe yeares after Chriſt, Diocleſian beganne his moſt fierce & cruel perſecution againſt the church of Chriſt. Euſebius writeth, that ther was no perſecution ſo cruel and bloudy, neither before nor after. He ioyned wyth him in the Empire, one Herculius Maximianus, a cruel, a fierce, and an vnfaithful man, and yet a foole, and a lecherous man. The ſeate of the Emperours at that time which ruled, was in Nicomedia. VVhen Diocleſian was there, he ſhot out fires and flames, as it were out of the moſt fierce and burning hill Aetna, and there, by chaunce the Emperours palace was burnt, the which by and by certaine malicious enemies did laye to the Chriſten mens charge, and did exaſperate and kindle the Emperour againſt them, and ſo began his perſecution, and foorthwith commaunded all the temples of the Chriſtians, to be throwne downe flat to the ground through the whole Empire, which they did moſt diſpitefully, euen vpon Eaſter day. And afterward commaunded all the bookes of the holy ſcriptures to be burned, which they did in the market place.

Eutropius writeth, that Diocleſian, would be woorſhipped as God, and commaunded that men falling downe flat to the ground, ſhould kys his feete. Of this Tirant tooke the Pope of Rome example, who offered his feete likewiſe to be kiſſed, yea of Princes and Emperours. He raigned .xx. yeares, and gaue ouer the Empire at Nicomedia, and liued after as a priuate mā, alledging for his excuſe, the great waight & charge that an Emperour had, & alledged alſo his age. But as Nicepborus writeth, he confeſſed vnto his frendes, that he did it of a certaine deſperatiō, bicauſe he could not extinguiſh nor deſtroy the religion of the Chriſtians, and ſaw the noble and conſtant mindes of the martirs, which dyed ſo valiantly in the quarel of their maſter Chriſt. Afterward, as Euſebius writeth, he fel into a diſeaſe, wherwith he dyed miſerably.
Ruffinus doth write, that he was firſt afflicted with diuers and ſundry diſeaſes, and at the laſt fell into a conſumption, and ſo into a frenſy, wherwith being taken, he deſtroyed himſelfe.

Nicephorus ſaith, that Diocleſian being ſmitten of God with diuers plages, had firſt in his body a great ſwelling, which being broken in diuers places, did ſo conſume away by title and litle, that his moſt wycked & blaſphemous toung, which had vomited out ſuch blaſphemies againſt the moſt high God, did gendre wormes within the iawes: which wormes creeping out of his mouth, did infect all the place where he abode, wyth moſt filthy ſtincke, and at the laſt barking like a dog, gaue vp his wycked and damnable lyfe with great violence.
Diuerſe others authors write diuerſly of his death.

Euſebius writeth, that in the time of the perſecution vnder Diocleſian, he ſaw with his eyes, that beaſts moſt fierce and cruell, (as Beares, Libardes, Bulles and ſuch like,) vnto whom the Martirs were throwne to be deſtroyed, although they were ſturred with famine and fire vnto furie, yet they would not come to the Martirs. And when they went violently vpon them, lept backe againe from them, their mouth being ſtopt.
Nicephorus doth adde and ſaye, that a certaine Bulle did licke the feete of a Martir with his tounge, and ſo departed from him, as it were with a certaine reuerence and feare.

div.head: Laicus. 41.
div.p: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 commeth of this nowne. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . that is a ſtone, for ſome authors report that Deucalion, and Pyrrha his wife, did procreate and make men by the caſting of ſtones, as Virgill writeth ſaying, Vnde homines nati durum genus.

Certayne doe make a difference betwene theſe two wordes, Saxum and Lapis, that the one (that is Lapis) is more leſſe and more tendre, & that the other (that is Saxum) is greater, ſharper and harder, wherupō they call precious ſtones Lapides, and not Saxa, as Pliny writeth.

Plinie his wordes be theſe: Nunquam hic vtilior, Lib. 36. cap. 38. quam in Italia gignitur, Lapiſque nō ſaxum eſt. This ſtone is no where more profitablie brought forth, then in Italie, and it is called, Lapis, non Saxum.

The ſame Pliny writeth after this ſort. Eſt & viridis Lapis vehemē ter igni reſiſtens, ſed nuſquam copioſus, & vbi inuenitur, Lapis non Saxum eſt. There is a greene ſtone which doth vehemently reſiſte fire, but it is no place plentifull, and where it is founde, it is Lapis, & not Saxum.

But this difference doth nothing ſeeme to agree with Pliny him ſelfe, who maketh no difference betwene Lapis, and Saxum, in quantitie and greatnes: for he affirmeth that great pillers were made, Ex vno Lapide, & yt the image of one Laocoon, (who was the firſt that thruſt his ſpeare into the woden horſe at Troye) was cut out Ex vno Lapide. But it is rather to be ſayd that Saxum is properly that which is cut out of rockes, or quarries: And that Lapis, is yt which is digged or takē out of the groūde.

Alſo bycauſe in olde time the end of miles, were ſignified and ſhewed by the ſetting vp of ſtones in the ſame place, Lapis, doth ſometime ſignifie a mile, wherupon we ſay, Ad tertium aut quartum Lapidem, three or foure miles.
Of this word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , are the common people called Laici, lay men, euen as the cleargy are called Clerici, of this worde 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .

div.head: Clerus.
div.p: Clerus ſignifieth Sortem, a chaunce, a lot, an inheritaunce.

Baſilius Magnus, doth vſe it, Pro ordine ſacerdotū. In my ſimple iudgement (yet I do referre it to the determination of the learned) the clergy were called Clerici, originally of the Hiſtory of Mathias the Apoſtle, who ſucceded in Iudas place, bycauſe that Clerus doth ſignifie electiō or lot, for that Mathias was choſen into the Colledge of the Apoſtles by geuing forth of lots as it is recorded in the actes of the Apoſtles,Act. 1. and this was the maner of the Hebreues.Ion. 1. For Ionas (ſleaping in the ſhip) was deprehended by lot, that he was the occaſion of the terrible tempeſtes that came vpon the Marriners,1. Sam. 14 And likewiſe Ionathas was espied, for that he taſted of a litle hony contrary to the edict of his father, And in like maner was Achan eſpied of his ſacrilege.Ioſu. 7. The Apoſtles vſed theſe lottes for that as yet they had not fully receaued the giftes of the holy ghoſt, and had certaine ſteppes of the Iewiſhe rites remaining with them, and they thought it lawfull to execute that figure vntill the veritie were accompliſhed, by the comming of the holy ghoſt.

div.head: Obſeruatio.
div.p: Note here that the lot fell vpon Mathias, although Ioſeph were commended by his ſurre name, and by kinred vnto Chriſt.

By the which we may learne, that in ſuch elections and lots, nothing is to be attributed to the affections of mā, But that where there be two equall and like in worthines of life, we ſhould rather fauour him, whom fleſhe and bloud doth not commēde: And yet this Ioſeph, called Iuſtus, did not diſdaine his equall to be preferred before him. Nor yet Mathias did not flatter him ſelfe for that he was choſen of the .11. to fulfill the holy number of the twelue.

div.head: Queſtio.
div.p: Here is to be demaunded, whether it be lawful or vnlawfull (as they ſay Simpliciter,) to vſe lottes or no.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: You muſt vnderſtand that there be three kindes of lots.

list.item: 1. Diuiſoria.
2. Conſultoria.
3. Diuinatoria.

div.p: THe lot called Sors diuiſoria, whether it be by caſting of chaūces, by drawing of cuttes, by taking of balles, or anye other meanes, for taking part of thinges deuided, is not vnlawfull, ſo that there be no ſuperſtition, no inuocation of ſprites, nor looking for any euent or effect from the conſtellations or power of the Planets aboue.

Saint Auſten in his booke De doctrina Chriſtiana, writeth after this maner. Si forte fortuna duos haberes obuios, aequalis piaetatis at
que neceſſitatis, & tantum haberes quo ſolum alteri eorum ſubuenire poſſes. Ita
cōſtitutus in ancipiti, nihil melius ageres, quam vt ſortito deligeres, vtri benefaceres. Sic exiſtimabis, quadam ſorte hunc vel illum ex dei voluntate, tibi adiunctū eſſe, aliquo neceſsitudinis gradu. If thou chaūce (ſayth he) to meete two perſons equally to be pitied and releaued, & haſt onely ſo much about thee, wherewith thou canſt releaue but one of them, being ſo ſet in a certaine perplexitie and doubt, thou canſt do no better then to caſt lots, to which of them thou mayeſt diſpoſe thine almes. So ſhalt thou iudge as it were by a certaine lot, whether this mā or that mā be nereſt vnto thee, in ſome degre of kinred or friendſpip.

div.head: Sors conſultoria.
div.p: The lot called Conſultoria, whiche is practiſed to do this, or not to do this determinatly, as if any man ſhould conſulte by lots or by any other chaūce, whether he ſhould ride fourth, go to the faire or market, or take any other iournie, is not lawful. As I my ſelf knew a certain mā of honor, who being commaūded, by his prince to reſiſte the enemies (who attempted to inuade certeine borders of this realme) did retire backe to his houſe, bycauſe his horſe ſtumbled in the morning.

div.head: Sors diuinatoria.
div.p: The lot called Sors diuinatoria, is that which is exerciſed to know by it, what ſhall come hereafter, which is directly againſt the word of God.

To end, concernyng this worde Clerus. It ſignifieth ſometime, patrimonie, inheritaunce or any portion which came by lot. It is ſometime taken for an acre of ground, or an orchard or garden. It is taken likewiſe for a worme whiche hurteth and deſtroyeth honie combes, which of ſome is called Pyrauſta.

div.head: Olephantes. 42.
div.p: MAtholus writing vpon Dioſcorides, declareth and deſcribeth the hiſtorie and nature of an Oliphant after this maner.
Aphrica beyond the deſertes, called Solitudines Sirticae. Alſo Mauritania and Ethiopia doe bryng forth and breed Olephantes, but the greateſt of all do come from India.

Ariſtotle writeth that the Olephantes, although they be the greateſt of all foure footed beaſtes, yet they are made ſo tame, yt no wilde beaſt cā be made more gentle & milde, for they do receaue inſtructions of their teachers and tamers, in ſo much yt they vnderſtand them and their language, they haue ſkinnes like to an Oxe, but with heare ſet very thinne, they haue a great head, a ſhort necke, long eares, as long as two ſpānes, a very lōg ſnowt or noſe, which they call properly Promuſcidē Elephātis, the noſe is hollowe, like a great trompet, and reacheth down beneath the foreteth, almoſt downe to the grounde, which they vſe inſtede of their
handes. They beare their mouth nigh to the breſt, which mouth is like a ſwines ſnowte, out of the vpper part wherof, two great & mightie lnog teeth do grow vp, which teeth be ye very true • uerie: They haue fete roūd like a diſhe, and two or three handfulles broad, fleſhie and harde, and in them fiue round clawes, as bigge as a good meane cockell ſhell. They haue great and ſtronge legges, not hauing one whole bone onely (as certeine vnexpert writers do thinke and declare,) but they bow the knee as other foure footed beaſtes do. And as Aloiſius Cadamuſtus writeth, they fall downe on their knees, and receiue certeine vpon their backes, and ſo riſe agayne. They haue a taile like to an Oxe, very thinne ſet with heare, therfore they cannot well defende them ſelues from the iniurie and byting of flies, but nature hath giuen them another defence, for their ſkinne is cancelled and wrinckled, whiche they contracte or draw together, and ſo kill the flies. They hurte no man, except they be prouoked and ſtyrred to anger, but if they be moued, they take the man with their longe noſe, and throwe him vp ſo hie, that before he fall to ye ground agayne, he is choked & dieth. Furthermore there is no mā ſo ſwift of foote neither in going nor running, but that the Olephāt, not running but going his paſe, will ouertake, the reaſon is, bycauſe of their mightie body and long legs. They do feede on the bowghes and fruite of trees, and there is no tree ſo great, but that the Olephant will breake him, throwe him downe, and teare him with his Promuſside, that is his lōg noſe. They grow to ye hight of ſixtene handfulles, therfore they whiche are not wonte to go vp vpon them, are affected with lothſomnes euen as they whiche be not accuſtomed to arriue in the ſeas. They can ſuffer no bridle nor halter vpon their heades, therfore they go looſe and at libertie with their heades, but they do greatly obey their gouernours, they vnderſtand their ſpeache and are eaſily ruled with their wordes. They do feare fire ſo greatly, that if they once ſee it, they runne away, and cannot be called againe. The Olephātes do not couple them ſelues together, nor gender before they be of the age of .xx yeares, as Ariſtotle writeth in his booke De hiſtoria animalium. VVherin the error of Plinie is manifeſtly ſeene, which wrote, that the Male Oliphant doth ioyne him ſelf to the Female at the age of .v. yeares, and that ye Female doth bring forth at the age of .x. yeres. The Oliphātes abhorre adulterie, for euery Male Oliphant, doth vſe the company onely of one Female. And whē ſhe is great, ye Male toucheth her no more. How long tyme the Female doth go with her young, it is not knowne, bycauſe beyng ſtriken with a certeine ſhame; they neuer couple together, but in a ſecret and priuie place. Therefore ſome do appoynte vnto them one yeare and a halfe, ſome two yeares, other three yeares. The Females
bring fourth their young with great dolour and paine, they licke their young with their mouth, whiche aſſoone as it is brought forth, doth both ſee and go.

Ariſtole ſayth, how ſome thincke, that Oliphantes liue two hundred yeres, but are moſt luſtie at the age of threſcore, they can ſuffer no cold, nor abide the hard winter. They haue great delight to be about riuers and floudes, whiche they go into after the maner of Oxen and Kie. They ſeme to ſhew a certaine religion in them, for they worſhip the ſunne and moone, as the inhabitantes of Mauritania, can declare. For in thoſe regions there be innumerable, which when ye moone is newe and doth ſhine, doo go in a great companie together into the riuers, and there waſh thē ſelues, and when they be waſhed, kneling on their knees, they ſalute the moone, and ſo returne into the woodes. Some doo ſay, they be ſo quicke of vnderſtanding, that when they ſhould paſſe ouer the ſeas to other regions, they will not go into the ſhippes, before they which lead them do promiſe with an oth to returne againe. VVhen they go into the woodes, they go alwayes in a great flocke together, the oldeſt of them leadyng and going before, the next of age comming behind and driuing them. Some write that when they be hunted, perceiuing that the praye which men ſeeke of them, is onelye in their teeth, they ſtrike them with great violence into the trees, and ſo pull them out, but this is as vayne and falſe, as the beaſt called Fiber, doth bite of his ſtones when he is hunted. The Oliphantes are by nature very wilde and vntameable, but they are made milde and gentle by arte and pollicie as many other beaſtes be. If they be litle and yong, they are made tame by other Oliphātes, which are already tame, if they be put among them. But Plinie writeth, that the great ones are tamed by honger and ſtripes. The teth of the Oliphantes are of a meruelous bignes, and are ſolde in many cities of Italie, as at Rome, Venice, Millein, and Naples, of the which teeth are made not onely combes, but many other inſtrumētes to the vſe of man: This Iuery is very good for the white diſeaſe of women, if it be beatē into moſt fine pouder, if it be drōke with the iuice of the ſeede of Lectuice beyng laid in water, in the whiche ſteele hath bene quenched. Hitherto Mathiolus.

Iſidorus writeth that their crie is properly called Baritus. Solinus writeth, yt they eate great blockes, deuoure ſtones, and that they loue dates aboue all other things. Ariſtotle ſaith, that ſome Oliphantes doo drinke Oile, ſome do not, and they which drinke Oile (if there be any Iron in their bellie) it is drawen out by the drinking therof and ſome do drinke wine. And when they cannot drincke it, then they make medicines with Oyle, and ſo geue it them to drincke.

div.head: Apologeticus. 43.
div.p: Ἀπολογία, ſignifieth a defence, an excuſe an Oration, or Purgation, in the which he that is coumpted giltie, doth defend him ſelfe either by Oration or by writing. Of this word cōmeth Apologeticꝰ, and certeine bookes of learned authors are entitled Apologeticus, as the booke of Tertulian, which he wrote againſt the gentiles in ye defence of ye Chriſtians. Baſilius Magnus, and many other wrote bokes of ye like title.

div.head: Vnwaſhen handes. 44.
div.p:
THere are two Prouerbes; which are neceſſarie to be obſerued and borne away. the firſt is Illotis pedibus ingreda that is, to go in with vnwaſhē feete, & it ſignifieth no more but raſhly, boldly, and vnexpertly to attēpt and ente priſe any notable thing. It is tranſlated and borowed of the ceremonies of holy things, in ye which all things were cōmaūded to be pure, waſhed, cleane & fine. Lucianus in his boke entituled Rhetorum preceptor, doth note them, which being inſtructed and armed with no good diſcipline nor learning, do come and take vpon them the office of a Rhetorician. They come (ſayth he) Illotis pedibus Macrobius, in his Saturnals doth ſay, Illotis pedibus pretereunt. They paſſe by with vnwaſhen feete. He ſpeaketh of certein ſmatterers of learning, which neglect & diſpiſe ye great hidden doctrine in the Poemes of Virgill. The other Prouerbe is. Illotis manibus, with vnwaſhen hāds & it ſignifieth vnreuerently & vnreadily to take any thing in hand. Both theſe Prouerbes may be vſed againſt thē, which either to boldly or raſhly, or not being expert in thoſe things in which it behoueth thē, do take any matter in hand. As if any ſhould take vpō him ye office of a prince, & yet is not endewed with any proweſſe, vertue, wiſedome or learning. Or el • if any ſhould endeuour to enterpret & expoūd ye ſcriptures beyng ignorant of ye Latin, Greke, & Hebrue tonges, & being rude & vncunning of all antiquities, ſhould attempt to teach the miſteries of diuinitie, which were not onely a fooliſh thing, but alſo a wicked. Notwithſtāding certeine of late (which being armed with certeine colde Sillogiſmes and childiſh argumētes) haue attempted both to define and debate almoſt all matters. But if they ſaw what laughture or rather ſorow they miniſter vnto thē which are expert and cunning, they would be aſhamed of their temeritie and raſhnes. Men doe giue a good iudgement without the preceptes and rules of Logicke. And mē were both learned and wiſe before their great God Ariſtotle was borne. Saint Hierome, whē he went about to interprete the holy Scriptures, leaſt he ſhoulde attempt ſuch a great matter with vnwaſhen feete and handes, did with vnſpeakable labour
and ſtudy obteine and get the knowledge of the three toūges, Quas qui ignorat (ſaith Eraſmus) nō Theologus eſt, ſed ſacrae Theologiae violator. Of whiche whoſoeuer is ignorant, is not a diuine, but a diſteiner of diuinitie, and with vnwaſhē feete & vnwaſhē hands doth not entreat ye moſt hollieſt thīg of al, but doth make it prophane, defile it, & diſteine it.

Theopompus the hiſtorian, that he might cauſe his writinges to be of greater eſtimation, intermingled with them a portion of Moſes law, for the which cauſe he loſt his wit, and fell mad for the ſpace of .30. dayes or therabout. Beſides alſo in his ſleepe in the night, he was admoniſhed that if he would not ceaſſe from his attemptate, he ſhould neuer recouer his right minde agayne. Therfore being terrified and perſwaded yt he ought to credite and obey the heauenly oracles, reuolted from his purpoſe, and ſo receaued agayne the right vſe of his minde.

Theodectes a tragicall Poete began to atchief ye ſame thyng, but in yt ſame moment & inſtant he was ſtrikē ſtarck blind, but acknowledging and confeſsing his error, & deſiring pardon, receaued agayne his ſight.
The ſecretes of Gods miſteries are to be ſearched with great reuerence and feare.
The Oracles of the heauenly ſpirit are to be vewed with great ſobriety and wiſedome.

Epictetus the Philoſopher, tooke it in very ill part, when he perceiued raſh and corrupt mē (being of ſiniſter and filthy maners) to entermedle with the ſtudie of Philoſophie, as Gellius doth recorde.

How much more ought we Chriſtians (who in godlines and vertue of life ſhould be an exāple vnto all gentiles) to iudge it no ſmale vnworthynes, if we ſee any ſpotted with vnpure and wicked maners, to diſpute of diuine miſteries, and to diſteine, with ther filthie conuerſation, the pure Philoſophie of Chriſt? How much more (ſay I) ought we Chriſtians to be offended? Yea & as mē being deſpoſed to vomite, to require 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 when we ſee ſuch raſhe and fowle enterpriſes.

Gregorius Naziazenus, writeth of this, very aptly. Mundificari (inquit) prius oportet, & ita alios mundificare: ſapientem prius reddi, & ſic caeteros reddere ſapientes, lumen fieri, & ita alios illuſtrare: accedere ad deum, & ſic tandem alios quoque ad dominum adducere. VVe muſt firſt (ſaith he) be made cleane, and then to clenſe other: we muſt firſt be made wiſe, and ſo teache other wiſedome: we muſt firſt be made a light, and then to giue light vnto other: we muſt firſt come to God our ſelues, and then to bryng other vnto God.

div.head: ❧ Praelectio ſecunda die Iouis videlicet .xv. die Februar. 1560. The Chriſtian fayth doth leane and depende onely of the written woorde of God.
div.p: I Purpoſe at thys preſent by Gods grace, to confyrme your mindes by the teſtimonie of the holy ſcriptures, that our Chriſtian fayth is eſtabliſhed & throughly proued by the onely written worde of God, and that all the articles of religion neceſſary to our ſaluation, are wholie conteined in the holy ſcriptures.

Deuteronomie. 1. To adde & take away. 2.Fyrſt it is writtē in the boke of Deuteronomie, non addetis ad verbum quod loquor vobis, nec auferetis ex eo. Ye ſhall put nothing vnto the worde whiche I commaunde you, neither ſhall you take ought from it. What man vnleſſe he bee voyde of all ſenſe and reaſon, wil expound thys place of the worde not written?
I am not ignoraunt how that certayne diſceitfull cauillers, would auoyd this ſentence, ſaying: that there be foure maner of addicions, that is.

list.item: Addition diminiſhing.
Addition alienatyng.
Addition enlarging.
Addition completing.

div.p: By the which laſt addition they vnderſtand, that the ſentence and ſenſe of the ſcriptures, is to be iudged and weighed by the commentaryes of men and the decrees of counſels.Decrees. 3.

But to refell thys comment and gloſe, manifeſt ſcripture written in the .xii. of Deuteronomy, is ſufficient. Quod tibi precipio, hoc tantū facito. Non addas quicquam nec minuas. What ſoeuer I commaund thee, take hede thou do it, thou ſhalt put nothing therto, nor take ought there from. And in the laſt of the Apocalips.Apoc ••
Qui addiderit ad haec, Apocalips. 3. addet ei dominus plagas quae ſunt ſcriptae in libro hoc, &c. If any man ſhall adde vnto theſe thinges, God ſhall adde vnto him the plages that are writtē in this booke. And if any man ſhal diminiſh of the wordes of the booke of this prophecie: God ſhall take away his part out of the booke of life, and out of the holy citie, & from theſe thinges which are written in this booke. Which place both Scotus and all the ſchoolemen do graunt to be vnderſtande of the holye ſcriptures. Wherfore they euidently offend agaynſt Gods cōmaundement, which do aſſent and affyrme the worde not written to be neceſſary to ſaluation, & who alſo doth iudge of the will of God without the manifeſt word of God.

In Deuteronomie,Deut. ••
it is written how all maner of bleſſings are ſet forth vnto them that obſerue thoſe thinges which are written in the booke of the lawe. And in an other place Moyſes doth euidently ſaye. Ponite corda veſtra in omnia verba quae ego teſtificor vobis hodie, &c. Deut. ••
Set your heartes vnto all the wordes whiche I teſtifie vnto you this day that you may commaund them vnto your children, that they may obſerue & do all the wordes which are written in the booke of thys law.

Beholde, here is clerely promiſed eternall lyfe vnto them that obſerue thoſe things which are written, and Moyſes doth ſay, that this is the onely finall cauſe why God would haue his word written, that all and ſinguler men, of what ſtate and condition ſo euer they be, ſhould haue and learne the word of God, by which they myghte be ſaued. And here they are conuinced of ignoraunce and blindne • , which aſcribe vnto God ſuch necligence and ſlacknes, as though he coulde not or would not cōmend & cōmit all things neceſſary for ſaluatiō to ye holy ſcriptures.

Furthermore, in the ſame booke of Deuteronomie, the king is commaunded to haue alwayes in his handes,Deu. 17. his hart, and his ſight, the booke of the lawe, and he ſhall read therin all the dayes of his lyfe, that he may learne to feare the Lord hys God, that he may prolong his daies in his kingdome, & his ſonnes in the middeſt of his Realme. And here I would to God that Chriſtian Kinges, princes, noble, honourable, and men of worſhip were reſolued, that thys perteyned principallye vnto their office and dutie, I meane the reading of the holy ſcriptures. And that they would rather haue in their houſes Gods booke (out of the whiche they maye learne the will of God) then the booke of King Arthur, the booke of Trollous,Arthure. 4. Troilus. 5. VVanton bookes. 6. & ſuch other vayne, prophane vanities, and Wanton bookes, whereby God maye geue them a longer life, and a death and end leſſe tragicall and troublous. For they without doubt which are ſo cruel againſt the ſacred ſcriptures & the readers therof, that they will execute their crueltie againſt them, can not come to a good end: but God will puniſh them for their tiranny, and oppreſſe them with violent death, for ſuch is the end of all tyrauntes, as the Poet ſayth.

l.hi: Ad generum Cereris ſine caede et vulnere pauci
Deſcendunt reges, et ſicca morte tyranni.

q.l: Few Kinges and rulers bent vnto tyrannie,
Deſcende to their graue with death that is drie,
But make their end both miſerable and bloudie.

div.p: Sedechias King of Iuda ſawe all his ſonnes ſlaine before his eyes,Sedechias. 7. Hieremie. 8. Heate and colde. 9. Antiochus. 10. and had his own eyes put out, and was bound in chaines, and caried captiue into Babilon, becauſe he burnt the booke of Hieremie: for the which dede he heard before, that none of his ſonnes ſhould ſit vpon the throne of Dauid, & that his carcas ſhoulde be throwen in the day time vnto heate, and by the nyght tyme vnto colde.

Daniel. 12. 2. Theſ. 2. Antiochus which cōmaunded the holy ſcriptures to be burned, dyed deſperately and miſerably, and that he was the very image of the laſt Antichriſt, Daniell & Paule do teſtifie.

Becauſe it wil be to long and tedious to bring teſtimonies through the whole ſcriptures, I will alledge onely one place more out of the law, and ſo come to the teſtimonie of the Prophets, and of the Goſpell.

Deut. 30.In Deuteronomie it is ſayd. Mandatum quod tibi praecipio, non eſt ſupra te, ne
que procul poſitum, nec in caelo ſitum, &c. This commaundement which I commaund thee this day, is not hidde from thee, neither is it farre of. It is not in heauen that thou ſhouldeſt ſay: who ſhall go vp for vs to heauen and bring it vs, and cauſe vs to heare it, that we may do it: but the word is very nere vnto thee, euē in thy mouth and in thy hart, to do it.

Theſe thinges do pertaine and may be aptly obiected againſt the Epicures of this latter time, who although they fayne neuer ſo godly a ſhewe of holines, and ſay that they burne and kill men for no other cauſe, but to conſerue & defend true fayth and the authoritie of the Church: Yet they do ſufficiently ſhewe, that they denie the power of godlines, foraſmuch as they be defiled and ſpotted with bloud, ſlaughter, luſtes, craft, diſceipte, and with all kinde of filthines and impietie, ſo that it doth verely appeare, that they perſwade them ſelues, that there is no god, who will take vengeaunce of thys their wickednes,Epicure. 11. but do in all ſecuritie laugh to ſcorne with Epicurus true religion.

Leo the tenth called together a counſel to debate whether the ſoule of mā were immortall: And when he heard euery mans ſentence,Leo. 12. it is reported him to haue ſayd,Soule. 13. that this controuerſie was harder then that he could iudge which part had the ſtronger reaſons. But whatſoeuer (ſayd he) ſhall become of the ſoule, I will not defraude my ſoule of the preſent commodities, delightes and pleaſures of this lyfe. And if there be any life after this life, I would gladly reioyce there wt other, if I thought them to be no worſe companions there, then they be here.

This is the voyce of that hygh Byſhop, by whoſe ſentence & cenſure we muſt
iudge of the worde of God, and of whoſe arbitrement doth depende and hang our faith and ſaluation. This I ſay is the ſentence of that holy Senate, vnto whom we muſt paſſe ouer the ſeas, to conſulte and conferre with, to this holy vicare of Chriſt, men muſt come out of Africa, Aſia, and Europa, to conſulte I ſay him, and alſo his holy Cardinals (whiche as they ſay ſucceded the Apoſtles) of the will of God,Cardinall 14. and of the right intelligence of the Scriptures.

From this Epicuricall ſentence Moſes doth withdraw vs ſayeng,Deu, 30. Prope eſt verbum in ore tuo, & ante oculos tuos. The worde is nere vnto thee, euen in thy mouth and in thine hart, and before thine eyes. Take hede ſayth he, and remember, that I put before thine eyes, that thou mayeſt read in this booke and vnderſtand it alſo, for otherwyſe it were a madnes to write thoſe thynges, that cannot be vnderſtande.

Serpent. 15. The tree of knowledge of good & yll. 16.The Serpent did lye and diſceiued Adam, when he perſuaded to geue vnto hym the knowledge of good and euill, by the tranſgreſſion of Gods worde. And as the deuill did delude and mocke by hys ſophiſticall and ſubtile Amphibologie, euen ſo he doth nowe when he doth promiſe vs by mans traditions and vnwritten verities, the knowledge of good and euill. God will not be worſhipped with the doctrine of the Serpent, and the doctrines of deuilles: God will not be reuerenced and feared with the preceptes and doctrines of men, contrarie or beſides his worde, he doth forbid all kinde of honouryng, he doth condempne all kinde, of worſhyppyng and ſeruice, whiche he hym ſelfe hath not commaunded, preſcribed and appoynted. Theſe thynges are learned out of hys worde, and the wyll of God is knowne onely out of the holy Scriptures, what doth pleaſe hym and what doth not pleaſe hym. Excepte we beleue this, heauen and earth ſhall teſtifie agaynſt vs at the laſt day, as Moſes ſayth, Teſtes hodie inuoco caelum & terram. I call to witnes heauen and earth, that I haue ſet before thee in thy ſyght, lyfe and death, bleſſyng and curſyng, not that curſe whiche the Pope doth thunder out vnder the name of Peter and Paule, but euen that curſe, whiche (if we herken vnto, and obeye the Pope) we ſhall heare of Chriſt.Math. •
Ite maledicti in ignem eternum, qui paratus eſt Diabolo & miniſtris ipſius, go ye curſed into euerlaſtyng whiche is prepared for the deuill and hys aungels.

Chriſte alſo doth call vpon theſe witneſſes agayne the vnbeleuyng, ſayeng.Math. •
Caelum et terra tranſibunt, Heauen & earth 17. verba mea non tranſibunt. Heauen & earth ſhall paſſe, my worde ſhall not paſſe, by thys ſayeng Chriſte doth warne vs to take hede of falſe Prophetes, and falſe Chriſtes, which ſhall fayne a newe worde, and a newe Chriſt, appoyntyng and faſtning him to certeine places, Dayes, Meates, Othes, Vowes, and Abſtinence from the good and lawfull creatures of God.

Eſaie. 18. Eſaias the Prophet doth lykewiſe thunder agaynſt the doctrines and traditions of men for the defence of Gods worde, ſayeng. Omnis caro faenum, et omnis gloria eius, et cetera. verbum autem domini manet in eternum. All fleſhe is graſſe,Iſa. 40. and all the glory therof, that is all the wiſedome and power of man, is as the flower of graſſe, whiche withereth awaye and falleth of: but the worde of the Lorde remaineth for euer. He doth menace and threaten alſo, euerlaſtyng darcknes & perpetuall nyght of infidelitie, if we beleue newe reuelations without the word, or beleue the apparicions of ye dead,Apparitions. 19. ſayeng. Nūquid populus cōſulet deū ſuū, an propter viuos petendū eſt conſiliū a mortuis, Iſa. 8. an non magis lex conſulenda et teſtimoniū dei in conſiliū adhibendum? ſi non dixerit inquit nuxta verbū hoc, non erit eis lux matutina. Should not the people enquire at their God, ſhould they aſke counſell for the lyuing, at the dead, is not the law and the teſtimonie rather to be conſulted? if they ſpeake not accordyng to the worde, it is bycauſe there is no lyght in them. Whiche is as much to ſay as thus. Aunſwere the wicked thus, ſhoulde not Gods people onely ſeeke ſuccour at hym? Will they refuſe to be taught of
the Prophetes who are the mouth of God, and ſeke helpe at the dead. Whiche is the Illuſion of Satan. Seke remedie in the word of god, where his wil is declared

Nowe let vs here the teſtimonie of the eternall worde of God hym ſelfe concerning his Scriptures: for thys queſtion was moued in the Church, in the time of Chriſt, of the chief doctours whiche thought not the Scriptures to be ſufficiēt to ſaluation without traditions of their fathers.

One of the nomber of theſe Rabbines, came vnto Chriſt, and ſayd,Rabbines. 20. what ſhall I do to poſſeſſe eternall lyfe. But Chriſt ſent backe this vnbeleuyng and ſcrupulous doctour vnto the Scriptures ſayeng.Luk 10, In lege quid ſcriptum eſt? quomodo legis. What is written in the lawe? Howe dooſt thou read? As thoughe he had ſayd, dooſt thou thincke, that God is not conſtant vnto him ſelfe, but that he doth often chaunge hys mynde as men do chaunge their lawe, and do alwayes fayne newe opinions of God? the worde of God doth remayne for euer, do thou ye onely that thou findeſt written, and thou ſhalt lyue. Chriſte did not ſay to hym, doo thou as thou ſhinckeſt beſt, thy ſelfe, or as thou dooſt here the Phariſies and Scribes teaching, but he ſent hym barke to the Scriptures ſayeng, howe dooſt thou read, do thys and thou ſhalt lyue. Here Chriſte doth manifeſtly teſtifye, that this was the mynde and ſentence of the olde Churche, that iudgement of the will of God, and of doctrine pertayning to fayth and ſaluation is to be had onely of the Scriptures.Ioan, 5. And he doth byd his preachyng to be examined and driuen to the Scriptures. He doth euidently ſhewe, that the Goſpell, was conteyned alſo in the Scriptures, and that they be verye dull and ignoraunt, whiche denye that the Scriptures of Moyſes ought to be herde, and that they do not perteyne to vs, bycauſe the Apoſtles had not as then written their bookes.Apoſtles. 21 For this was the rule of the Apoſtles, when they did teſtifie vnto ye Church of the Goſpel, that no boke ought to be receyued whiche did not conſent with the olde Scriptures, and by this rule they did reiecte and refuſe Apocripha, and receyued the Euangeliſtes, who confirmed theyr Hiſtoryes and wrytynges out of the Prophetes.
