By thys rule Paule doth purchace and get authoritie and credite of hys Epiſtles ſent to the Romaynes,Rom. 1. when he ſayth. Euangelium ſuum ante promiſſum eſſe per Prophaetas in ſcripturis ſanctis.

Ioan. 5,To this alſo perteine theſe ſayengs. Si Moyſi crederetis, et mihi vti
que credere tis. If you wil beleue Moyſes, you will beleue me alſo: for he hath written of me. Alſo this ſayenge of Chriſte. Scrutamini ſcripturas, quia putatis in illis vos vitam eternam habere. Illae enim ſunt quae teſtimonium perhibent de me. Searche the Scriptures, bycauſe you thinke to haue euerlaſtyng lyfe in them for they be they whiche beare witneſſe of me. Nowe in thys controuerſye of the worde not written and of the traditions of men if we ſhoulde conſulte antiquitie and ſtand to the iudgement of the Romiſhe Churche, we ſet agaynſte it this ſentence of the olde Churche confirmed by Chriſte.Ioan. 12. Sermo quem locutus ſum iudicabit eos in nouiſsimo die. The word, which I haue ſpoken ſhal iudge them at the laſt day. Nowe if this worde had not bene written, yea and all throughly written, who ſhould be ſure of his ſaluation, and of the will of God. If our fayth and the ſaluation of mankynd ſhould depende onely of the relation of men, and if the ſome of our religion had not bene committed to letters, who could hope one ſentence of Chriſt to haue bene left whole and vncorrupt?

But they whiche be intoxicate and made blinde with the deuill, do not ſee this intolerable blaſphemie, they do not conſider what ſluggiſhnes,Blaſphemy 22. ignoraunce and malice, they do impute vnto God, when they affirme, that God had no care nor regarde, that his worde ſhould be written, by the whiche he ſayth we ſhalbe iudged at the laſt day. But the holy ghoſt did foreſee this malice of the deuill, and to repreſſe his crueltie, and to ſtoppe the mouthes of other, the holy ſpirit (I ſay) did enioyne his Scribes the Prophetes, Apoſtles and Euangeliſtes, that they
ſhould write this worde, wherby we might haue a permanent and continuall teſtimonie to truſt vnto. He commaunded the Apoſtles that they ſhould beare witnes of this Scripture, and to reiecte the writtynges of all other, whiche did attempte to inſerte and put in their lyes and gloſes into the Goſpell.

Luke. 23.Saint Luke in the preface of his Goſpell, geueth a goodly teſtimonie of the ſame, ſayeng, for aſmuch as many haue taken in hande to ſet forth the ſtory of thoſe thinges, whereof we are fully perſwaded, as they haue deliuered them vnto vs, which from the begynnyng ſawe them their ſelues, and were Miniſters of the worde.Theophilus. 24. It ſemed good alſo to me (Theophilus) aſſone as I had ſearched out perfitly all thyng from the begynnyng, to write vnto thee therof from poynt to pointe, that thou mighteſt acknowledge the certeinty of thoſe thinges wherof thou haſte bene inſtructed, with this cleare teſtimonie the holy Ghoſt hath made quiet our myndes and conſciences agaynſt the blaſphemies of Antichriſt.Antichriſt. 25. But the holy Ghoſt, not content with thys one teſtimonie, did conſtrayne hym (I meane Saint Luke) whiche promiſed to write all thinges from the begynnyng, to teſtifie alſo in an other booke the ſame. For in the begynnyng of the Actes he ſayth: I haue made the former treatice, O Theophilus, of all that Ieſus began to do and teach, vntill the day that he was taken vp.Act. 1.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: How could Luke write of al ye ſayings and doyngs of Chriſt, where Iohn doth affirme, that if all things ſhould be written, which Ieſus did, the world could not conteyne the bookes that ſhould be written?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p:
Chriſoſtome maketh aunſwere and ſayeth, Lucas non dixit omnia, ſed de omnibus ad ſalutem neceſſariis. Luke did not ſay that he would write all things, but of all thinges neceſſarie to ſaluation. But what nedeth the holy ghoſt, the helpe of mans teſtimonie? for he of him ſelfe is ſufficient, and hauing all knowledge and foreſeyng alſo what the deuill would in this poynte calumpne and cauill, doth make aunſwere by the euangeliſte. For when Iohn had ſayde, that Ieſus had done many miracles,Iohn. 26. whiche were not written, he added immediatly Hae • ſcripta ſunt vt credatis. Theſe thinges be written that you might beleue, that Ieſus is the ſonne of God, and that beleuyng, you maye haue life through his name. Wherefore it is manifeſt, that the ſome of Chriſtes words, and ſo many miracles alſo, are written, as are ſufficient to confirme oure faith,Iohn. ••
and to declare all thinges, whiche we ought to beleue.

Cirillus writting vpon Iohn ſayth: Magna eſt multitudo ſignorū dn̄i & immē ſus numerus, Cap. 12 Iohan •
ſed haec quae retulimus ſufficiūt ad pleniſsimā fidē faciēdā attēte legenti bus: nec accuſandus ſū ſi oīa non ſcripſi, nā ſi cōſiderētur ſingula nullo praetermiſso, orbis librorum multitudinem nō caperet. Hyperbole 27. Hyperbolicos aūt dicimus ſermonis eius virtutem proferri. Non igitur omnia quaefecit ſcripta ſunt, ſed quae ſcribentes tam ad mores, quam ad dogmata putauerunt ſufficere, vt recta fide & oporibus ac virtu tibus rutilantes ad regnum caelorum perueniamus per Chriſtum dominum noſtrū. Great is the multitude and number of the Lordes ſignes and miracles, but theſe which we haue ſhewed, are ſufficient to make a ful and perfect faith, to thē which ſhal reade them attentiuely. Nor I am to be accuſed, if I haue not written all, for if euery one ſhould be conſidered, and none omitted, the world could not hold the number of the bookes. We ſay that the vertue of his words, is vttered Hyperbollically, therfore all thinges are not written, which he did, but thoſe things which they ye wrote, thought to be ſufficient, as wel to good maners, as to doctrine, that we ſhining with a right faith, with good woorkes and vertues, may come to the kingdome of heauen, through Chriſt our Lord.

It is therfore a new inuention and lye, inuented lately in the diuels ſhoppe, that all doctrine of religion cannot be proued out of the ſcriptures, and that mēs traditions without the beſides the ſcriptures, are neceſſary workes to ſaluation. The Church in Cirils time knew no ſuch kinde of blaſphemy.

Saynt Auſten writeth the like vpon the ſame place. Cum dominus Ieſus inquit multa ſigna feciſſet, non omnia ſcripta ſunt, electa enim ſunt quae ſcriberentur, quae credentium ſaluti ſufficere videbantur. When our Lord Ieſus (ſaith he) had done many miracles, all were not written, but theſe thinges were choſē out to be written, which were thought ſufficient for the ſaluacion of the beleuing.

To make an ende in citing of teſtimonies, I wyll adde onelye twoo witneſſes more, moſt approued, and moſt certain, Peter and Paule by name. For euery mā not being at the leaſt voyde of common ſence and reaſon, may clearely vnderſtād, that Peter wrote the ſecond epiſtle againſt thoſe blaſphemers, which doo fayne a new woord, beſide the written word of God, for he calleth the ſcriptures a prophecy, and calleth them falſe prophets, which do teache any thing contrarye and beſides the prophetical and apoſtolical ſcripture, & doth geue this rule, by the which their lyes might be auoyded, if we expounde and weighe them by the propheticall ſcripture, to the which he biddeth vs to take heede, as vnto a light that ſhineth in in a darke place. In the third chapter he writeth thus. This ſecond epiſtle I write vnto you, beloued, wherwith I ſtyrre vp and warne your pure mindes, to call to remembraunce the woordes which were told before of the holy Prophets, and alſo the commaundement of vs the Apoſtles of the Lord and ſauiour. This firſt vnderſtand that there ſhall come in the laſt dayes mockers, which wyll walke after their own luſtes.

Agayne in the firſt chapter he writeth:A moſt ſure worde. 28. Priuate interpretation. 29. We haue alſo a moſt ſure woorde of the Prophetes. And a litle after he ſayth: Firſt knowe this, that no prophecye in the ſcripture is of any priuate interpretacion. For the prophecy came not in old time by the wyl of mā, but holy men of God ſpake as they wer moued by the holy goſt.

Note here, yt whē Peter had alledged for his doctrine, ye ſeene maieſty of Chriſt, the voyce of the father heard from heauen, the teſtimony of Moſes and Helias geuen to Chriſt vpō the holy hyl, yet he doth preferre before al theſe allegacions, the firmnes and ſurenes of the ſcriptures, ſaying: we haue a moſt ſure woorde of the Prophets, to the which ye do wel that ye take hede, but the holy ghoſt is alwaies one, and euer like him ſelf, both in Moſes, the Prophets, Chriſt, and the apoſtles. Chriſt doth ſay: ſearche the ſcriptures, and by thoſe wytneſſes examine my preachinges.Io •• , 5. 2. Pet. 1. Peter doth ſubſcribe to the ſame, ſaying: you do wel, which doo examine euery doctrine by the prophetical ſcripture.

2. 〈◊〉 4 〈◊〉 . 3Saint Paule in both his epiſtles to Timothy, and in his epiſtle to Titus,Timothie. 30, Tite. 31. doth earneſtly admoniſh vs to beware of the blaſphemies of the latter time, & of them which do thruſt in new and wicked doctrine, without Gods written woord, and doth ſay, if we ſhal continue in the woord and holy ſcriptures, and teach them vnto other,1. Tim. 5. we ſhal ſaue our ſelues, and them that heare vs.
So it doth appeare by the teſtimonie of theſe two holy Apoſtles, that the ſcriptures onely are the pyller and ſtay, both of our faythe, and alſo the foundacion of the Churche.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p:
The Churche was inſtitute and taught after the aſcention of Chriſt, when there was neither Goſpell nor any parte of the new Teſtament yet written, for Mathew wrote eight yeares after the Aſcention, Marcke .x. yeares, Luke. xv.Mathew. 32 Marke. 33. and Iohn long tyme after, therfore the Church was gouerned by the vnwritten word and traditions of the Apoſtles. Whereupon we conclude, that we muſt not onely ſtay vpon the Scriptures, but alſo vpon vnwritten verities, and giue no leſſe credite vnto them, then to the wordes written in the Scriptures, and ſo writeth
Baſilius Magnus, Baſilius. 34 in his booke De ſpiritu ſancto.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p:
When the Apoſtles had preached certaine yeares, Viua voce, onely by mouth, they committed alſo vnto writtyng thoſe things which they had preached before, for ſome of them did write the hiſtory of Chriſt, both of his doyngs and ſayinges, other wrote of the doyngs and ſayings of the Apoſtles, other wrote & ſent diuers epiſtles to diuers & ſundry nations. Furthermore, for ye confirmation of ye truth, they vſed the teſtimony of ye old ſcriptures, both out the law, & alſo of ye prophets, therfore the church was inſtitute & gouerned wt the ſelf ſame word before ye goſpel was written, wherwith it was directed and ruled after the goſpel was written, for it was one & the ſame as Ireneus doth teſtifye.Ireneus. 35 Cap. 1. Quae primū concionati ſunt apoſtoli, poſtea per voluntatem dei ſcripto nobis tradiderunt, ea
que literis erant prodita, quae ad ſalutem noſtram videbantur neceſſaria, vt Iohannes dicit haec ſcripta ſunt vt credatis. Theſe thinges which the Apoſtles preached firſt were afterwarde by the will of God deliuered vnto vs in writing, and theſe things were vttered in letters which were counted neceſſary for our ſaluatiō (as Iohn ſayth) theſe things are writtē yt you might beleue. Wherfore the obiection is of no force & very vaine.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: The church hath a promiſe of the holy ſpirite, that ſhe ſhalbe neuer voyde therof, foraſmuch then as ſhe is gouerned with the ſpirite of God, ſhe may walke ſafely without the written word: Whether ſo euer ſhe go, ſhe can neither iudge nor ſpeake any thing but the truth, therfore if ſhe decree and commaunde anye thing without or beſides the woord, it is to be taken for a ſure oracle of God. Wherupon we conclude, that we muſt not leane onely, to the written woorde, but to the cenſures of the Churche.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: This kind of argmentacion is not effectual, (it hath the promiſe of the ſpirite, or the ſpirite it ſelfe) ergo what ſoeuer it doth or ſayth, it is well ſayd and done, it is a fallace called Paralogiſmus accidentis: Paralogiſmus accidentis. 36. For they which haue the holy ghoſt, do not alwaies thoſe thinges which they do, by the inſtinct of the ſame. As a builder or chiefe maiſter of any workes doth not offend in building, but bicauſe il happeneth ſometimes, that being occupied with other thougsts and fantaſies, not pertayning to the building, he doth ſometimes ſlyde and fayl in his worke: euen ſo it cannot be gathered by the force of the promiſe made to the church, that al thinges alwayes are rightly defined in the church, for the greater part ouercommeth the leſſer,The greater part. 37 and the wurſt the better. It may be that the church ſomtimes doth labor and is ſubiect to affections, and ſomtime holden in dymme miſt. Howe therefore ſhal we vnderſtand whether the church hath decreed wel or yll, except we expend and examine it by the true touchſtone of the holy ſcripture, where nothing is to be found but truth? Wherfore the church which is the ſpouſe and wyfe of Chriſt, ought to be ſubiect ſo to her huſband, that ſhe depend onely on his mouth, & harken onely to his voyce, and that houſe is euer wel ordered, wher the wyfe doth obey the voyce of her huſband: and that ſchole is wel taught and nourtured, wher the doctrine of their maiſter onely is heard. Wherfore let not the church be wyſe of it ſelfe, but place there the limites and boundes of her wiſdome, where Chriſte doth make an end of ſpeaking. The ſpirit (ſayth Chriſt) whom I wyll ſende from the father, ſhal leade you into al truth. But howe? bicauſe he ſhall miniſter vnto you thoſe thinges which I haue ſpoken.

Chriſoſtome. 38.Chriſoſtome very aptly doth write of the holy ghoſt after this maner.Iohn, 15. Multi ſpiritū ſanctum iactant, ſed qui propria loquuntur, falſo illum praetendunt, vt Chriſtus nō a ſeipſo loqui ſe teſtabatur (quia ex lege loquebatur et prophetis) Ita ſi quid preter Euāgeliū ſub titulo ſpiritꝰ obtrudatur, ne credamꝰ. Quia ſicut Chriſtꝰ legis &
prophetarum impletio eſt, ita ſpiritus euangelii. Haec ille.

Many do boaſt of the holy ſpirite, but they which ſpeake their own, do falſely pretend him, as Chriſt did teſtify, that he ſpake not of him ſelfe, bicauſe he ſpake not out of the law and the prophets, ſo if any thing be obtruded, or brought in beſides the Goſpel, vnder the title of the ſpirite, let vs not beleue it, bicauſe as Chriſt is the fulfilling of the law and the Prophets, ſo is the ſpirite of the Goſpell. Thus farre Chriſoſtome.

By this we may eaſelye perceaue, howe prepoſterouſlye they doo, which brag & boaſt of the holy ghoſt, for no other end, but to commend and commit vnto vs vnder the title therof, their ſtraunge doctrines, and very vayne traditions, and thus we may ſee what fond obiections they haue.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: Ireneus and others doo much magnify and aduaunce the Church againſt heretickes, and not the ſcriptures, Ergo we muſt not leaue onelye to the iudgement of the ſcriptures.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: I anſwer. Ireneus and others had to do with ſuch heretickes, as did denye the ſcriptures, and yet dyd magnify the Apoſtles, ſo that they wer enforced to vſe the aucthority of thoſe churches, wherin the Apoſtles did preach, & which had ſtil retained the ſame doctrine, ſo that they vſed the authority of the ſame Churche, whiche grounded her ſelfe vpon the ſame woord and doctrine which the Apoſtles had before taught and wrytten.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: Iorn, 16.Chriſt ſaid vnto his Apoſtles, I haue many thinges to ſay vnto you, but you can not as yet beare them, therfore many things may be ordeined by the church, of the worſhiping of God and of religion, which the holy ſcriptures haue not deliuered.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: I anſwer, Chriſt did not in thoſe wordes, eyther meane or ſpeake of traditiōs, rites and ceremonies, for it were very abſurde to gather ſo of the woordes. For could not the Apoſtles beare ſuch things, in the which they were conuerſant and brought vp from their childehoode? Moſes was able to teache the rude people the legal ceremonies, and coulde not Chriſte teache and inſtruct his Apoſtles in the lyke thing? O double foolery. Thoſe many thinges which Chriſt had to ſay, were thoſe thinges which he had ſpoken already, and were more plainly and effectually to be expounded vnto them, and more depely to be printed in their mindes, by the vigor and vertue of the holy ghoſt,Ioan 14. whom he did promiſe to ſende vnto them,Paracletus. 39. for he ſayth a litle before: Cum Paracletus venerit, ille ſuggeret quaecunque dixi vobis. When the comforter ſhal come, he ſhal miniſter vnto you althinges, whych I haue ſpoken. Furthermore, Chriſt doth teſtify that he told thē all things which he heard of his father.Ioan. 15. Omnia (inquit) quae audiui a patre meo, nota feci vobis. All thinges which I hearde of my father, I haue made knowen vnto you, therefore there ſhalbe nothing left neceſſary to ſaluation, which eyther church or man may make, ordayne, or conſtitute.

Tertulianus in his booke De velandis virginibus. Cum venerit (inquit ille) ſpiritus veritatis deducet vos in omnem veritatem, & ſuperuenientia renunciabit vobis, quae eſt ergo paracleti adminiſtratio niſi haec? quod diſciplina dirigitur, quod ſcriptura reuelatur, quod intellectus reformatur, quod ad meliora proficitur? When the ſpirite of truth ſhal come (ſayth he) he ſhall leade you into all truth, and ſhall ſhewe what thinges ſhal happen vnto you, what other therfore is the adminiſtration of the ſpirite, but this, that diſcipline is directly vnderſtand, that the ſcriptures are reuealed and opened, that vnderſtanding is reformed, and that there is proceeding to better thinges?

Paule came to Ieruſalem vnto Peter and the other Apoſtles, not to receaue any doctrine of them, but he came for the commodity and profit of others, that thei ſhould vnderſtand his doctrine and preaching, not to be diſcrepant from the doctrine of the other Apoſtles. For if Paule had perceaued any thing to be defined & concluded of the other Apoſtles, which he himſelfe had not hearde of Chriſte, he would neuer haue geuen his aſſent vnto them, no not to an Aungel of heauen, if they had brought any other Goſpel then he taught. Therefore we ought in matters of fayth and ſaluation, to leane onely vnto the written woord of God.

Well, I haue bene very tedious and longe, and was minded to retaine you a litle longer in the diſcourſe of this matter, but bicauſe I would rather edify then tedify, I wyl deferre the finiſhing of this, and ſo of the whole firſt part, vntyll the next day, and ſo ſhal I make three dayes woorke of the firſt part, where I promiſed but two, but I truſt it ſhall not be withoute profit vnto you, by the ayde and helpe of Gods holy ſpirite, vnto whom with the father and the ſonne, be all honour and glorye. Amen.

div.head: Deuteronomion. 1.
div.p:
THe fift booke of Moyſes is called of the Grecians Deuteronomion
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , whiche ſignifieth ſecundum (the ſecond) and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which betokeneth Legem: the law, as you would ſay a ſeconde lawe, not becauſe it is an other law diſcrepant from that law, which was geuē in the Mount Sinai, but becauſe it is repeted agayne after a new ſort by the miniſterye of Moſes, before them which heard it not, when it was firſt geuen in the Mount Sinai, for they which then & there heard it, were al dead in the wildernes. And this booke is a commentarie or expoſition of the ten commaundementes. And in it is lykewyſe ſet forth, the wonderfull loue of God towardes his Church, for albeit through their ingratitude and ſundrie rebellions againſt God for the ſpace of .40. yeares, they had deſerued to be cut of from the number of his people, and for euer to haue bene depriued frō the vſe of his holy word and ſacramentes: yet he did euer preſerue certeine in his church, euen for his own mercies ſake, and would ſtill haue his name called vpon among them.

div.head: To adde and take away. 2.
div.p:
TO adde vnto the ſcriptures is, when any worſhip or ſeruice of God is fayned & inuented, which is not comprehended within the compaſſe of Gods booke, of the which crime how giltie the Iſraelites were, the bookes of the Kinges do ſufficiently ſhew and proue. VVhat nede I to make mention of our time, which is vnder the loſte ſonne that Antichriſt, who hath added his owne traditions,
(beſides Gods word, yea and contrary to the word) as neceſſary thinges to ſaluation? Furthermore it is added vnto the word, when rites, ceremonies, and other ordinaunces being abrogate, be reuoked and called againe to vſe, to the which fault both the Iewes in theſe daies, and alſo the aduerſaries of Chriſt, are much ſubiecte.

The Iewes for that they haue in reuerence, and doe yet obſerue and kepe circumciſion and other Moſaicall ceremonies, with new rites of their own inuention. The aduerſary for that he doth bring in and commaund after the example of the Leuiticall prieſthode, vnctions and annoylings, halowed churches, altars, ſalt, coniured water and ſuch other traſhe.

Finallye it is added vnto the worde, when vnto the true interpretations of the holy ſcriptures, which the Prophets and the Apoſtles did ſhew them ſelues, we bring our owne vaine, blinde, and groſſe expoſitions, after the iudgement of worldly reaſon & blind affectiō, yet it is not ment, but that men may enlarge and amplifie the holye ſcriptures with paraphraſes and other plaine enucleations, ſo that they keepe the verye true ſenſe and meaning of the holy ſpirite, ſpeaking in the ſcriptures.

To take away from the ſcriptures, is when we make voyde the commaundement of God through our own traditions, as for example: where God commaundeth the Parents to be honoured and relieued, we thinke it better to caſt our money into Corban, and to beſtow it vpon pilgrimages, images, lightes, banner clothes, & ſuch other trumpery. Alſo it is taken away from the word, when that thing which God commaundeth to be geuen whole, is but halfe geuen, as the ſacrament vnder one kinde.
Finally, when yt thing which god made free & ſet at liberty, is reſtrained and made bond, as matrimony, meates, & other things of indifferēcy.

Of this aduerſary doth the prophet Daniel write, ſaying. Et ſermones contra excelſum loquetur, the beaſt ſhall ſpeake wordes againſt the moſt higheſt. And Iohn ſayth alſo: Cui datum eſt os loquens magna & blaſphemias. Vnto the which beaſt was geuen a mouth, ſpeaking great thinges and blaſphemies.

div.head: Decrees. 3.
div.p: DEcretum, doth ſignifie a ſtatute, a ſentence, as Plinie writeth in his Epiſtles. Decreta quibus damnati erant proferebantur, the ſtatutes or ſentences, by the which they wer condēned, wer brought forth. And the conſtitutions of the biſhops are called Decreta.
Budeus doth write, that Decretum doth ſignify, a firme conſent in opinion, which the Grecians call Dogma.

Some learned men make a difference and diſtinction betwene decreta, ſenatus, and ſenatus conſultum, ſo that Decretum is but a ſpecial part
and a portion of ſenatus conſultum, and ſenatus conſultum, is generall. Dies decretorius, is called, a day of iudging: it is alſo called Dies criticus.

div.head: Apocalipſis. 3.
div.p: Ἀποκάλυψις ſignifieth the reuealing and opening of ſecrete and hidden thinges. It cōmeth of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ; which betokeneth patefacere, detegere, to make opē, or to vncouer. S. Hierome denieth this word Apocalipſis, to be found in any of the Ethnicke writers, and ſayth that it is a new word, fayned of the .72. interpreters.

Euſebius. lib. 4 cap. 24.Euſebius ſpeaking of his time, writeth that ſome do recken ye Apocalips of Ihon, among ye canonical and auctentical bookes of ye ſcripture, & that ſome other do not number it among thoſe bookes. And againe in the ſame booke, after yt he had proued by the teſtimony of Papias that there were two Ihons at Epheſus, he addeth theſe woordes. Truly it is like that one of them hath ſene that reuelation which is caryed about in the name of Iohn. But if we geue credit vnto them whiche came before Euſebius (as Iuſtinus, Tetullianus, Ireneus, Appollonius, Theophilus, Antiochenus, & other,) it may be affirmed, that it was the very worke of Iohn the apoſtle. For why ſhould theſe men ſo conſtantly confirme it to be the booke of Iohn the apoſtle, if they had knowen any doubtful ſentences of their predeceſſors to be had of the ſame? Neither he bringeth any one witnes of any notable authority, or any doctor, either of his time, either of any other age, which denieth the Apocalips to be ſaint Iohns, ſauing the teſtimony of Dioniſius Alexandrinus, whoſe reaſons are not of ſuch force, that they ſeme to exclude the Apocalips out of the number of the approued bookes of the new teſtament. And wher they argue & reaſon out of the opiniō of their predeceſſors, that Cerinthus ſemed to build his doctrine of the voluptuous raigne of Chriſte vpon the earth, by the ſpace of a thouſād yeres, out of this booke, & that ye phraſe doth not agre with other of Ihons epiſtles, & therfore not to be ye work of Iohn ye Apoſtle: Al theſe reaſons (I ſay) be not of ſuch weight to deſerue any credite, for their aunceſtors, who being of a cōtrary iudgemēt, may be alledged againſt thē. As Tertuliā & Origen. Cerinthus, & other heretickes, hath not only abuſed that ſcripture, but other places of ſcriptures alſo. As for the phraſe, it is not greatly diſcrepant from the ſtile of Iohn, if at ye leaſt we wil expend and weigh, that viſions ought to be writtē in one kinde of ſtile,In cronico. and hiſtories in an other kinde. Yea Euſebius himſelf ſayth, yt in the xiiij. yeare of Domitianus, the Chriſtiās began again after Neroes time to be perſecuted, and vnder him was the Apoſtle Ihon baniſhed into the Iland Pathmos, wher he ſaw this reuelation, which Ireneus did interprete. Truly the old writers ſeme not without good reaſon to iudge the
Apocalips to be wrytten by ſaynt Iohn the Apoſtle. For they affirme that woorke to haue come foorth about the time of the end of Domitianus hys raygne, at what tyme Iohn was ſayd to haue retourned out of Pathmos, and they had the Aſian churches for a witnes, vnto whom the Apocalyps was dedicated. For Ireneus in the end of his fift boke, doth correct by the authority of them that ſawe Ihon, the number of the beaſt written thus in Greeke . 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . declaring that it is thus wrytten . 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . that is .666.

Furthermore, that periphraſis wherwith Iohn doth note himſelf, in the title, muſt needes ſignifie to them which read with attention, that it is Iohns woorke. The title is this: That it is he, the which bare record of the word of God, and of the teſtimony of Ieſus Chriſt, and what ſo euer he had ſene. VVhich woordes commonly be aſcribed to none other, but to Iohn the Euangeliſt.

Beſides this, if they do well examine it according to the proporcion of fayth, they can finde nothing in it, cōtrary to the apoſtolick doctrine. For although ſome thinges ſemed to be ſpoken not according to the maner of other ſcriptures (as that he doth pray for grace of the ſeuen ſpirites in the firſt chapter, and that Chriſt is called Alpha and Omega, and the beginning of the creature of God, in the third chapter, and of the thouſand yeares, in the which the godly ſhall raigne with Chriſt in the twenty chapter, the which Cerinthus, Papias, Iuſtinus, Ireneus, and other vnderſtood that it ſhould be after the reſurrection) yet they dyd well perceaue thoſe phraſes miſtically to be vnderſtande, as in propheticall writinges.

And it is eaſy to be perceaued, many articles of the doctrine of the Apoſtles to be opened in it, as the article of iuſtification by the bloude of the Lambe, of repentaunce, of the reſurrection of the dead, and of euerlaſting life, but eſpecially the doctrine of the Church. VVhoſe whole ſtate he doth wholye deſcribe, that it ſhoulde haue perſecutours, heretickes, and other enemies, and yet that it ſhoulde remayne and continue with the miniſtery.

But eſpeciallye, he doth liuelye paynt and ſet foorth Antichriſt, of whom Daniell, Chriſt, the Apoſtles, and Ihon hym ſelfe in hys Epiſtles alſo do entreate, expreſsing hys name, the place, and the idolatrye whiche ſhoulde be committed by hym, the confuſion of hys raygne, and the worſhippers of the worlde, the perſecutions, the time howe long it ſhoulde endure, the reuelation of hym, and hys laſt deſtruction.

Furthermore, they might wel vnderſtand, by conferring both together, that the Apocalips doth not much ſwarue from the nature of the viſion of the prophets, and eſpecially of Ezechiel. Yea, rather it doth open and ſet them forth, of what ſorte the viſions of the .4. beaſtes are, & of Gog & Magog, & of the meaſuring of the temple, & other of like ſort.

Finally, if they did conſider either the preſent ſtate of the church, either the ſtate before, they might coniecture of the end, that the Apocalips proceded from the holy ghoſt, and not to be a booke vnworthy of the Apoſtle Iohn. For thoſe things which in the ſeuen firſt epiſtles are written vnto the ſeuen churches in Aſia, do ſet foorth the preſent ſtate of thoſe churches, either the ſtate which followed ſone after, which was knowen to euery man at that time, wherby they might haue declaratiōs of things folowing. For that in thoſe epiſtles, the biſhops of the Churches are called Angels, it was a declaration, that by other Angels alſo, both good & euil preachers were vnderſtood & ſignified. Furthermore that whych followeth, the which intreateth of Antichriſt and his kingdom, hath certain notes, the which declare thoſe monſtrous images, as for example, that he calleth the harlot a city, the which beareth rule ouer the kinges of the earth, where he poynteth as though it were with his finger, vnto the city of Rome. Vpon this, the city of Rome, or the Romane empire was ſuſpected, both in the age folowing, and alſo in other ages, to be the receptacle and ſeat of Antichriſt, as it appeareth by Ireneus and others.

div.head: King Arthur. 4.
div.p: ARthur the ſonne of Vter Pendragon, a ſtripling of xv. yeares of age, began his raigne ouer Britaine, and gouerned the land .26 yeares, hauing continual warre and mortal battel with the Saxons. Of this Arthur are written many thinges in the engliſhe cronicle of ſmal credence, and farre diſcordant from other writers. But yet al agre, that he was a noble and victorious Prince in all his deedes, and they teſtify that he fought .xii. notable battels againſt the Saxons, and was alway victor. But notwithſtanding, he could not clearely auoyd them out of his land, but they held their countries, of which they were poſſeſſed.

This ſame Arthur, after he had brought the Realme of Britaine into ſome good ſtaye, he poynted the rule thereof vnto Mordred hys Nephew, and ſayled hym ſelfe into Fraunce, where he dyd manye marueylous thinges.

Mordred, who had now the gouernaunce of Britaine, in the abſence of Arthur, by treaſon was crowned king, through the helpe of Cardicus
king of ye weſt Saxons. Of which treaſon, whē relation came to Arthur, being thē in Fraunce, wt al haſt he made to Britaine, where he was met of Mordred, which gaue to him three ſtrong battels. In the which many noble and valiant knightes periſhed. And laſtly, in a battell foughten be ſides Glaſtenburye, Mordred was ſlayne, and Arthur wounded vnto death.

div.head: Troilus. 5.
div.p: TRoilus was the ſonne of Priamus and Hecuba, whoſe death was the fatal end of Troy, for as long as he liued, Troy could not be taken, as the Poets fayne. He being a young man, durſt to haue combat with Achilles, the valiaunteſt champion of al the Grecians, but yet was he ſlain of him, as Virgil writeth.
div.q: Parte alia fugiens amiſſis Troilus armis.

div.head: Wanton bookes. 6.
div.p:
IT is to be lamented, yt not onely in the time of the idolatrous and ſuperſticious Church, but euen in this time alſo, ſuch laſciuious, vnpure and wanton bookes, pearce into manye mens houſes and handes. Alas, what doth ſuche kinde of bookes woorke and bring with thē? Forſooth nothing els but fire, that is, euē ye burning flames of an vnchaſte minde, the brandes of pleaſure, ye coales of filthineſſe, ye fire I ſay yt doth conſume, deuour, & roote out al the nouriſhmentes of vertue, the fire I ſay, which is a proheme and entraunce into the eternal fire of hell, what is ſo expedient vnto a common wealth, as not to ſuffer enchaunters and witches to lyue? For ſo the Lord commaunded by his ſeruant Moſes. And (I pray you) be not they wurs, thē an hundred witches, which take mens ſenſes frō them? not with Magical deluſions, but with the enchaūtments of dame Venus, and as it were doo geue them Circes cup to drinke of, and ſo of men do make them beaſtes. VVhat puniſhment deſerue ſuch, as either make or print ſuch vnſauery bookes? Truly, I would wiſh them the ſame reward, wherwith Alexander Seuerus recompenſed his very familiar Vetronius Turimus, Vt fumo videlicet pereant, qui fumum vē dunt, that they periſhe with ſmoke, which ſell ſmoke. And what other thinges doo theſe ſet foorth to ſale, but ſmoke, readye to breake out into flame? For, that certain perſons bequeath them ſelues wholy to the reading of ſuch laſciuious and wanton bookes, who knoweth not, that therof, ſo commeth the firſt preparatiue of the minde, that when anye one ſparke of fire (be it neuer ſo litle) fal into ye tinder of lady Venus, ſodenly it is ſet on fire, as towe or flaxe. Many do read the verſes which Lycoris the Strumpet, the Paramour of Gallus the Poet did reade, and the
verſes which Corynna mentioned in Ouid, and which Neaera did reade. It wil perchaunce be replied, that they do reade them, either for the encreaſe of knowledge, or to driue away idlenes. I anſwer. Yf any do ſalute Venus but a limine, as they ſay, that is, a farre of, as it wer in the entry, what kindling and flames wil enſue therof, I pray you, when the coales be once ſtyrred?

It is to be feared, that no ſmall number of them, who profeſſe chriſtianity, be in this reſpect a great deale wurſe then the Heathen. The people called Maſsilienſes, before they knew Chriſt, yea or heard whether ther wer a Chriſt, but were very Paganes, and ſacrificers to idols, yet were knowen to al the world, to be of ſuch pure and vncorrupt maners, that the maners of the Maſsilies (as Plautus teſtifieth) are cōmōly counted the beſt and moſt approued maners of al other. Theſe among many other good orders of their wel nourtured city, made a ſeuere law that ther ſhould be no Comedy plaid within the city, for the argumēt for the moſt part of ſuch playes, did containe the actes of diſſolute and wanton loue. They had alſo within their City (about .613. yeares before the birth of Chriſt) a ſword of execution, wherwith the gilty and offendours ſhould be ſlayne, but the vprightnes of their liuing was ſuch, that the ſwoorde not being vſed, was eaten with ruſt, & nothing mete to ſerue that turne.

And alas, are not almoſt al places in theſe daies repleniſhed with iuglers, ſcoffers, ieſters, plaiers, which may ſay and do what they luſt, be it neuer ſo fleſhly and filthy? and yet ſuffred and heard with laughing and clapping of handes.

Hiero Syracuſanus, did puniſh Epicharmus the Poet, bicauſe he rehearſed certaine wanton verſes in the preſence of his wife, for he would that in his houſe, not onely other partes of the body ſhould be chaſte, but the eares alſo, which be vnto other members of the body, in the ſteede of a tunnell, to bee kept, ſartas tectas, that is, defended and couered, as the prouerbe ſayth, and to be ſhut to all vncomely and ribaudrye talke. Vnto this fact of Hiero, the worthy ſentence of Pericles is much conſonant and agreable.

Sophocles, who was ioynt fellow with Pericles, in the Pretorſhyp, beholding, and greatly prayſing the welfauoured beautye of a certayne boy paſsing by him, was rebuked of Pericles his companion after thys ſorte. Praetoris eſt, non ſolum manus a pecuniae lucro, ſed etiam oculos a libidinoſo aſpectu continentes habere. Not onely the handes of him that is a Pretor ought to refrayne from lucre of money, but alſo the eyes to be continent from wanton lookes.

The Athenians prouided very well for the integrity of their iudges,
that it ſhould not be lawfull to any of the Ariopagites, to write any Comedy or play. And as I ſayd a lytle before, Epicharmus ſuffred puniſhment at the handes of Hiero, for the rehearſall of certaine vnchaſt verſes, (but I ſpeake it with ſorrow of hart, to our vice ballet makers, and enditers of wanton ſonges, no reuengement, but rewardes are largelye payd and geuen.) Is not this the nouriſhing and feeding of ſuch Crocodiles, which deuour the chaſtitye both of ſingle and maryed women? O the noble voice and anſwer of Hiero his wife, geuen vnto him. He being in braule and contention with a certaine perſon, was embrayded with ye vnſauery breath of his mouth, did expoſtulate with his wife (whom he maryed a virgin) bicauſe ſhe neuer told him of that infirmity, which he might haue cured. I would (ſayth ſhe) haue admoniſhed you, but that I thought euery mans breath to be of the like ſauour. O what a ſeuere and ſtraight keeper of chaſtity was this faythfull and truſty wyfe? O what an example of continency is geuen here to all Matrones? O what a preſident of chaſtity is this, not to come ſo neare any other man, that ſhe did neuer ſauour his breath, but onely her own huſbandes?

Yf ſhe ment truly, as ſhe ſpake, there could be no greater argument of a notable continency. If ſhe diſſembled, yet was it a great ciuilitye toward her huſband. It was likewiſe a marueilous tollerauncye, to ſuffer ſuch an incommodity, ſo long without lothſomnes?

Geradas, a very auncient man of Lacedemonia, being demaunded of hys hoſte, what payne adulterers ſuffered at Sparta, made this anſwer: O hoſpes, nemo apud nos fit adulter, neque fieri poteſt. O mine hoſt, ther is no adulterer among vs, neither can there be any. For this was the maner among them, that they were neuer preſent at any Comedy, nor anye other playes, fearing leaſt they ſhould heare and ſee thoſe things, which were repugnant to their lawes.

In dede that which is wyllingly and gladly heard, is ſoone embraced and put in vre, nor it canne be farre ſet from wyll, which is ſeene with pleaſure. Plutarch in Pelopida writeth, that the Lacedemonians did ſo abandon all vnhoneſt pleaſure, and followed vertue, with ſuche labour, that one of the Sybarites denied the Lacedemonians to doo anye great atchiefe or act, when they did in battel ſo valeauntly offer themſelues to death, for they doo that (ſayth he) to be rydde of the trauels and baſe diet, whych they vſed at home.
O ſhameles wretche, an yll man, a diſſolute man, and a ryotous man to preſume to reproue the moſte valeaunt men, the beſt nurtured men, the moſt ciuill men of all the world.

VVhat an impudent face was it? Of the Sybarites, and of their diſorders there be large volumes written by men moſt eloquent. Philo the Iewe in the life of Moſes, doth cal the leudnes of the Sibarites, Laſciua poemata, wanton poemes, ſonges and plaies: And Martiall nameth impudent and vnchaſte bookes Libros Sybariticos. The Syberites were the firſt that taught horſes to daunce, at the ſound of the troumpe. To be ſhort, ther is a prouerbe ſprong of them the prouerbe is, Sybaritica menſa, by which is ſignified all notorious riot, farre exceſsiue, gurmaundiſe, belly chere, al diſſolute and wanton maners, & ſybariſſare, is nothing els, but to play the Epicure, and to become bond ſeruants to Bacchus and Venus.

But to reuert to our purpoſe, concerning wanton bookes, which can be no other thing, but the fruites of wanton men, who althoughe they write any one good ſentence in their works, yet for the vnworthines of ye perſons, the ſentence is reiected. The Senate of Lacedemonia would haue refuſed a worthy and a very apt ſaying of one Demoſthenes, for the vnworthines of the author, if certaine men of authority called among them Ephori, had not come betwene, & cauſed an other of the Senators to pronounce the ſentence againe as his own ſaying. Plutarch writeth, that there was a law among the Grecians, that euen the good bookes of ill men ſhould be deſtroyed, that the memory of the authours alſo, ſhould therby vtterly be blotted and cleane put away.
Gerſon, ſomtime chauncelour of Paris, ſpeaking of a certaine booke made by one Ioannes Meldinenſis, the title wherof is the Romant of the Roſe, writeth of that booke two thinges.
Firſt he ſayth, if I had the Romant of the Roſe, and that there were but one of them to be had, and might haue for it fiue hundred crownes, I had rather burne it, then ſell it.

Againe ſayth he, if I did vnderſtand that Ioannes Meldinenſis dyd not repent with true ſorow of minde, for the making and ſetting foorth of this booke, I would pray no more for him, then I would for Iudas Iſcariote, of whoſe damnation I am moſt certaine. And they alſo which reading this booke, do apply it vnto wicked and wanton maners, are the authors of his great paine and puniſhment.

The like Ioannes Raulius ſayd of the booke & fables of one Operius Danus, that he was a moſt damned man; vnles he repented and acknowledged his fault, for the ſetting forth of that booke. I would God they heard theſe things whom it delighteth to write or reade ſuch ſhameleſſe and laſciuious workes. Let them remember the ſaying of Saynt Paule: Quae ſeminauerit homo, eadem & metet. A man ſhal reape thoſe things which he hath ſowen.

Chriſoſtome a great enhaunſer of Paules prayſes, writeth that ſo lōg ſhall the rewardes of Paule riſe more and more, how long there ſhall remaine ſuch, which ſhall either by his life or doctrine be brought vnto the Lord God. The ſame may we ſay of all ſuch, who while they liued, haue ſowen ill ſeede, either by doyng, ſaying, writing or reading, that vnleſſe they repēted, the more perſons that are made ill by thē, the more ſharpe & greater groweth there payne. As ſaint Auſten wrote of Arrius, God ſaue euerie Chriſten hart, from either the delighting or readyng of ſuch miſerable monumentes.

div.head: Sedechias. 7.
div.p:
SEdechias was the ſonne of Ioſia ye king, & the vncle of Ioachim, he was ye laſt king of Iuda and Hieruſalē, being appointed and cō ſtituted of Nabuchodonoſor, and he regned .11. yeares. Nabuchodonoſor chaūged ye name vnto this Sedechias, for a token of his ſubiectiō, inioyning tribute vnto him by taking of an othe, cōmaundyng him neuer to preſume to make warre againſt him, and that he ſhould not fauour the Egiptians. But when that not onely the rulers of the Prieſts, but he him ſelfe, with all the reſt of the people had offended God in all filthineſſe of life, and in couetouſnes and ſlouth, he was moſt ſhamefully at the laſt with all his people caſt out from his kingdome & ſlaine. For in the ninth yeare of his raigne, by the ſuggeſtion and entiſeyng of the Egyptianes, he withheld the tribute which he promiſed vnto the Chaldies, & endeuoured to recouer his libertie agayne. VVherfore Nabuchodonoſor being in a great rage, with a mighty hoſt marched vnto Hieruſalem, but firſt he tooke into his friendſhip and amitie all the Cities of Iurie. Afterward when Nabuchodonoſor, had ſpoiled & burned all the villages and ſuburbes about, he pitched his campe about Hieruſalem, and beſieged it the ninth yeare of the raigne of this Sedechias, the tenth day of the month of Decēber, the whiche Citie, when it was puniſhed with famine and peſtilence by the ſpace of .18. moneths, at the length he wanne it, and the king and his children with the rulers of the Citie beyng taken captiue, were brought as priſoners vnto Nabuchodonoſor. VVhen Sedechias the kyng was brought vnto Nabuchodonoſor, he called him a wicked, falſe vnhappie man, and vnmindfull of his othe by whiche he ſwore vnto him faithfully to keepe his prouince, farthermore he called him a chorle and ingrate, bycauſe wheras he had receyued the kingdome at his handes, he ſhewed himſelfe moſt vnworthy of ſo great liberalitie. VVhen he had ſpoken theſe wordes agaynſt Sedechias, he commaūded forth with his ſonnes to be ſlaine in his preſence. Afterward plucking out his eyes, ledde him bounde vnto Babilon. For ſo Hieremias and Ezechiel before had Prophecied,
that he ſhould be caried bounde vnto the king of Babylon. And the Chaldies when they had taken the king Sedechias priſoner, ſlew all the people, ſuch as eſcaped the ſworde, were made bonde ſlaues vnto the Chaldies. And ſo the Iewes, hating the admonition of the Prophetes, reiecting the feare of God, and refuſing the Lordes benediction, at the laſt did eate the fruites of their owne wayes, and were filled with their owne Counſels.

div.head: Hieremias. 8.
div.p: HIeremias was a very holy Prophet, ſanctified from his mothers wōbe. He was a Prieſt borne of ye Prieſtes in a litle village called Anatotites, being not much diſtāt frō Hieruſalē. He began to Prophecie being but a child. And afterward he did not only foretell of the deſtruction of the citie, & the captiuitie of ye people, but he ſaw it alſo as it were with his carnall eyes. He prophecied therfore onely in Iuda and Beniamin, and he prophecied of the fall of Hieruſalē by the Ebrue Alphabet foure times repeted. The which S. Hierome & Iſidore tranſlated into verſes & metre. This Hieremias, therfore after the ſubuerſion and captiuitie of Hieruſalem, was violently of his own countrymen caried into Aegypt, & there after many iniuries done vnto him was ſtoned to death by his own people at Taphnas, and was buried in that place where Pharao the king once dwelled. And bycauſe by his prayer, he had driuen away from that place many noiſome ſerpentes, and had deliuered the Egiptians from the perill of thoſe venemous wormes, they after that worſhipped him with great deuotion and religion.

div.head: Heate and colde. 9.
div.p: THat is, he ſhall not be honorably buried among his fathers, but as carions are caſt in a hole, bycauſe their ſtincke ſhould not infect. Ioſephus in antiq. 10. cap. 8. writeth yt the enemy ſlew hym in the citie, and commaunded him to be caſt ouer the walles vnburied.

div.head: Antiochus. 10.
div.p:
THis Antiochus was called the noble Antiochus, he was the ſeuenth king of Siria, and Aſia, and raigned .xi. yeares, he gaue his ſiſter for wife, vnto Ptolomeus Epiphanes, and therfore that he myght the better obteyne the kingdome of Egypt, vnder pretence of affinitie, entred into Egypt, and cauſed hys ſiſter to kil Ptolomie ſitting at meate, & being choſen of the Egyptiās, after two yeres he returned to ye ſiege of Alexādria, vnto whō one Gneius Pōpilius was ſent as an ambaſſadour frō the ſenate, & thē he departed from the ſiege of the citie. This Antiochus ſubdued the Iewes, which
dwelte in Hieruſalem, whoſe proweſſe and power was ſo great, that they ſuffred no kyng of Siria, after this Antiochus, who by the treaſon of Menelaus tooke Hieruſalem and ſpoyled and prophaned the holy Citie, commaundyng their lawes to be burned and deſtroyed, and ſlewe many. At this time alſo it chaunſed (as it appeareth in the Machabees) throughe the whole Citie of Hieruſalem, horſemen hauing coate armour of golde to courſe in the ayre by the ſpace of fifty dayes, and the horſes to be ſet in their rancke and araye, wherfore all the Iewes deſired that this monſtrous ſight might be tourned vnto good ſucceſſe. Notwithſtanding all theſe thinges were foreſignifications of ſorowes vnto the Iewes, for not long after the treaſures beyng taken out of the Church, this Antiochus ſent wicked mē vnto thē, who conſtrayned the Iewes to eate ſwines fleſh, and to depart from the lawes of their countrie, & to defile the holy place and not to cal it the tēple of the Lord but the tēple of Iupiter Olimpicus. He enforced thē alſo to relinquiſhe their religion, and to worſhip idoles, and to builde in euery Citie and ſtreete, Churches, Chapels, and altars, and to offre and ſacrifice vpon them euery day a certeine nomber of ſwine. He commaunded alſo that none ſhould be circumciſed, threatning great tormentes, if any preſumed to the contrary. It chaunced alſo at that time, the ſeuen brothers with their mother, to be taken of the ſouldiours, and to be conſtrayned almoſt to eate ſwines fleſh. VVho notwithſtanding, with conſtant myndes ſuffred martirdome for ye obſeruation of their lawes. At the laſt the Lord God, who beholdeth all things, ſuffred not this mā vnpuniſhed, but ſmote him with an incurable plage, for an intolerable dolor came vpon him, wormes boyling out of his body, which did ſo corrupt his fleſh, that no man could abide the ſtinch therof. At the laſt hauyng ſome remorſe, he went into the mountaynes where he dyed miſerablie.

div.head: Epicurus. 11.
div.p:
EPicurus was the author of yt ſect, which was called of his name Epicurea. He did coūpt the chief felicitie to conſiſt in pleaſure, but not in the pleaſure of the body, as Ariſtippus did, but in the pleaſure of the mind, that is in the lacke and abſence, of all griefes and ſo rowes. He condempned Logike, affirming that Philoſophie might be cō prehended in ſimple and plaine wordes. He ſayd the gods had no prouidence of worldly things. This Epicurus, Lucretius ſo much preferreth & commendeth, that he ſticketh not to affirme that he doth ſo darcken the light of all other Philoſophers, as the ſunne doth darcken the clearnes of the ſtarres. He is ſaid to haue bene of a moſt continent life, but yet it came to paſſe that through the name of pleaſure (in the which he ſayd
mans chief felicitie to conſiſt) ſuch as be geuen to pleaſure were called Epicures. Laertius writeth yt Epicurus was a mā of a very ſpare diete, and that he liued onely with browne bread and water. Notwithſtanding his diſciples did degenerate from him, and tourned their maſters opinion to a bodely and beaſtely pleaſure.

The like happened to one Nicolaus, one of ye ſeuē deacons, as Euſebius writeth, his words be theſe. There was a certeine ſecte of heretickes called Nicholaites, ſo named of one Nicholaus, whom they boſted to be one of the deacons which wt Stephē were appointed of ye Apoſtles to Miniſter to the poore. But Alexandrinus Clemens, in his third boke, intitled Stromata, writeth thus of Nicholaus.

This man (ſayth he) hauyng a faire woman to his wife after the Aſcention of Chriſt, being reproued for the faulte of ielouſie, bringing hys wife into the midle of the congregatiō, gaue any mā leaue, that would, to marie her. For they ſay, that this action was conſonant vnto that talke, which affirmeth that it is lawfull to vſe fleſhly luſtes, and they whiche embrace this hereſie, folowing without conſideration both this doing & ſaying, do geue themſelues moſt impudently and vnmeaſurably to fornication and whoredome. But I heare that this Nicholaus neuer vſed any other wife, then her vnto whom he was maried, and that of his children the daughters continued virgins vnto their old age, & that his ſonnes remained vncorrupt & vnſpotted. VVhich things when they were ſo done, the bringing of his wife, of whom he was coumpted to be gelouſe, into the middeſt of the Apoſtles, was rather a wipyng away and a purgation of the faulte obiected againſt him. And he taught that the fleſh was to be brideled by continencie from pleaſures, which is ſo much vſed, for I ſuppoſe he would not contrarie to the commaundement, ſerue two maſters, wanton pleaſures, and the liuing Lord.

div.head: Leo decimus. 12.
div.p:
LEo the tenth of that name, being a florentine borne, comming of the noble houſe of the Medices, & called Iohn Medices, before he was high Biſhop of Rome, he was a deacon, and ſomtime Cardinall of S. Maria in Dominica. He was choſen Pope of ye Cardinals contrarie to all mens expectation, and placed in the rowme of Iulius the ſecond next afore deceaſed, he was diligently inſtructed from his youth wt good literature, and vſed moſt learned ſcholemaſters, eſpecially Angelus Politianus being a man excellēt in the knowledge both of the Greke & the Latin tongue, and he exceedingly fauoured all learned men. He was made Cardinall by Innocētius, the .xiii. yeare of his age, and he was elected Biſhop of Rome, when he was .38. yeares olde. This Leo of his owne
nature was meke and gentle, but he was often times gouerned and caried away of vnquiet and rough perſons, by whoſe intiſement & arbitremēt he did many thinges inſolently and proudly. He being geuen to delicate idlenes of the body, nouriſhed his fleſh all vnto pleaſures, in diuerſe deſires of the world, and in pleaſant and wanton delightes. He loued Muſicians, wyne and coſtly fare, to ſturre his mind to mirth at his table, but he perſecuted the Goſpel of Chriſt, like Caiphas with an vnſatiable hatred, both againſt Luther, and other learned men: for he made this diſſolute aunſwere vnto a certeine Cardinall named Bembus, proponing vnto him a certeine queſtion concerning the glade tidings of God. It is ſufficiently knowen (ſayth he) to all the world how much that fable of Chriſt hath profited vs, and all our company. This moſt wicked impe, expreſſed openly him ſelfe to be that Antichriſt, whom Paul called the man of ſinne, & the child of perdition.

He ſpred abroad moſt large and fooliſh pardons by his friers, running without nōber throughout all Chriſtiā realmes, to get him mony, which he might waſte in nouriſhing of harlots, & in enriching of his Baſtards. He made .31. Cardinals in one day, gathering a great ſome of mony together, many horrible wonders happening that ſame time.

In the yeare of our Lord .1521. (At what time Solimanus wanne the Citie of Rhodes) vppon Chriſtmas day, whyle he went out of his priuie chaumber to celebrate the firſt Maſſe in the morning, ſodenly behind his backe a certeine faire houſe, ſumptuouſly builded of Marbell ſtone; fell downe to the ground, and many of his garde were ſlaine. By this token God ſignified that the Popedome through his wicked and heynous lyfe, ſhould ſhortly periſh. He maruelouſly enriched his Baſtardes, and did aduaunce them to high dignities, both ſpirituall and temporall, doyng iniurie and dammage to other mē. For he made Iulianus whom they called his ſiſters ſonne, duke of Mutina, and he created Laurentianus, duke of Vrbine, and gaue to one of them to wife, the ſiſter of Carolus Sabandus, and to the other the douches of Bolonia. For he had depriued but a litle before the duke of Vrbine, from the poſſeſsion of his dukedome, that he might place one of theſe two baſtards in his rowme. He attempted ye like alſo agaynſt the duke of Ferraria, but in vayne, but he made Iulius his nephew a Cardinall. In the yeare of our Lord .1521. and in the firſt day of December, when he hard that the Frenchmen were ouercome at Millen of the Emperours ſouldiours by his meanes, & that they were ſlaine, taken and driuen out of Italie, ſitting at a bancket wonderfull merry, and laughing gaue vp the ghoſt, beleuing that there was neither heauen, nor hell after this life. Some write yt at the ſame tyme he ſpake theſe wordes.
God hath geuen vnto me three benefites, the firſt is that I being an exile from my countrie, returned againe with glory, the ſecond is yt I deſerued to be called Apoſtolike. The third is, yt I haue cauſed ye frenchmē to be put to flight by my meanes & helpe, & ſo being takē wt a merrie feuer, died.

div.head: Soule. 13.
div.p: WHat the ſoule of mā ſhould be, the wiſe men of this world could yet neither conſent nor agree. Lactātius de opificio dei, doth deny that man, is able to attaine the true reaſon & nature of the ſoule, yet ſome there be which haue ſayd, the ſoule to be the ſpirit of lyfe, created after the image of God, and inſpired into the body of man. Other define it after this maner. Anima rationalis, eſt ſpiritus intelligēs, altera pars ſubſtātia hominis, nec extinguitur cū a corpore diſcedit, ſed immortalis eſt. The reaſonable ſoule of man is an vnderſtanding ſpirite, the ſecond part of the ſubſtaunce of man, nor it doth periſh when it departeth from the body, but is immortall. But the verie true definition of the ſoule (after the cenſure of great learned men) is this. Anima eſt ſubſtātia ſpiritualis, corpori humano a deo infuſa, vt ei ciuncta, ipſum animet & diri, gat, ſeperata autē a corpore, non intereat, ſed immortalis aeternum viuat. The ſoule is a ſpirituall ſubſtaunce infuſed of God into the body of man, that being ioyned therto, may geue it life direct and rule it, & being ſeperate from the body, doth not periſh, but liue immortally and eternally.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: The ſoule is no ſubſtaunce but a certaine vitall power and qualitie in man.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: The Scripture doth proue that the ſoule is a very ſubſtantiall eſſence, and not a qualitie.Luke. 16. VVhat do you ſay I pray you of the ſoule of the riche glutton,Luke. 23. Apo. 6. which was tormented in hell? what ſay you of the ſoule of ye theif which was in Paradiſe with Chriſt? what ſay you of the ſoules vnder the altar, of them which were ſlaine for the word of God? did they not crie with a loud voice and ſay. O Lord which art holy & true, how long dooſt thou tarie to iudge and reuenge our bloud vpon them that dwell in the earth? All theſe things did not agree vnto qualities, but vnto very being ſubſtaunces.

div.head: Queſtio.
div.p: Here may be demaunded what maner of ſubſtaunce, the ſubſtaunce of the ſoule is.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p:
Cap. 1.S. Auſten in his booke De quātitate animae writeth thus. Subſtantiam anime nominare non poſſū, non enim eā puto eſſe ex hiis vſitatis notiſ
que naturis, quas iſtis corporis ſenſibꝰ tāgimꝰ. &c. I cā not name ye ſubſtaūce of the ſoule, for I do not thinke it to be of theſe vſual & knowen natures
which we touch & perceaue with theſe ſenſes of the body. For I iudge the ſoule to conſiſt neither of earth, neither of water, neither of the aire, neither of the fire, neither of any of them ſeuerally, neither of thē all ioyned together. The ſubſtaunce and nature of the ſoule may be called Simplex ſubſtantia, ſimple ſubſtāce, bicauſe it is not of other natures. Caſsiodorus folowing theſe wordes of S. Auſtin doth ſay, that the ſoule of mā created of God, is Spūalis & propria ſubſtātia, is a ſpiritual & proper ſubſtaūce.

div.head: Queſtio.
div.p: It is wont to be demaunded from whence the ſoules come: when and how they enter into the bodies?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: S. Hierome doth declare, that there were in times paſt, many & ſundry ſentences of the originall beginning of ye ſoule. He writing vnto Marcellinus & Anapſichias ſaith. Super animae ſtatu memini veſtrae queſtiū culae, imo maxime eccleſiaſticae queſtionis, &c. Concerning the ſtate of ye ſoule, I remember your queſtion, yea rather the queſtion moued of the Church. Firſt whether the ſoule doth ſlide from heauē as Pithagoras & all the folowers of Plato, and as Origene doth thinke. Secondly whether it come from the proper ſubſtaūce of God, as the Stoickes, ye Manichies, and the Priſcilians do ſuſpecte? Thirdly whether all the ſoules beyng ones made together, are reſerued in the treaſure houſe of god, and ſo ſent into ye bodyes after the perfection therof, as ſome of the Church, by a fooliſh perſuaſion do beleue?

Fourthly whether ye ſoule come Extraduce, as Tertulian, Apolinarius and the moſt part of the weaſt Church do ſuppoſe? That is as the body commeth of the body, ſo the ſoule ſhould ſpryng of the ſoule, and ſo be of one condition with brute beaſtes.

Fiftly and finallye, whether that the ſoules be made dayly of God, & ſo ſent into the bodies, according as it is written in the Goſpel Pater meus vſque modo operatur, & ego operor. My father doth now worke, and I do worke.

But al theſe opinions being confuted wt ſtrong arguments of the Eccleſiaſtical writers, yt onely is receaued & affirmed to be moſt true, which doth affirme the ſoule to be made by God of nothing, and to be poured of God into the body, when yt the fruit is made perfect in the mother's wōbe wt ſhape and al other partes. For ye Eccleſiaſtical definitions do pronoūce after this maner. Dicimus creationē animae ſolum creatorē oīm noſſe, & corpus tantū per coniugii copulā ſeminari, dei vero iudicio coagulari in matrice & compingi at
que formari, ac formato iam corpore animā creari & infundi. VVe ſay yt the onely maker of al things doth know the creatiō of the ſoule, & yt the body is gēdred onely by ye copulatiō of wedlocke, & by the true iudgement of God, to be brought together and to be made & faſhioned in the wombe, & when the body is perfited, ye ſoule to be made
and ſo infuſed: The Prophet Eſay writeth, Qui format ſpiritū hominis in ipſo, which maketh ye ſpirit of man in him. Dauid in his Pſalmes ſaith Qui fingit ſingulatim corda eorū, Pſal. 33. He faſhioneth & maketh their harts euery one.Iob. 10. Iob doth moſt lyuely & manifeſtly ſet fourth the making both of the body and of the ſoule, ſaying: Thine hands haue made me & faſhioned me round about, and wilt thou deſtroy me? Remember I pray thee yt thou haſt made me as the clay, and wilt thou bring me into duſt again? haſt thou not poured me out as milke, and turned me to cruddes lyke cheeſe? Thou haſt clothed me with ſkinne and fleſh, and ioyned me together with bones and ſinowes.

Behold in theſe wordes Iob deſcribeth the conception & faſhioning of the bodye of man in the mothers wombe. Nowe he ſpeaketh of the ſoule ſaying. Thou haſt geuen me life and grace, and thy viſitation hath preferred my ſpirit. By the teſtimonies of theſe ſcriptures, it muſt nedes be graunted, yt the ſoule is created of god, and poured into the body being made perfect in the mothers wombe, loke more for this matter in the .28 Epiſtle of ſaint Auſten ſent to ſaint Hierome.

div.head: Cardinalis. 14.
div.p:
AFter the inſtitution of Prieſts was ordered, it ſemed good to the auncient fathers to deuide & diſpoſe their offices, that euery one might both know his duetie, and do it accordingly. Therfore the chief matter of all, that is the cure of ſoules, was appointed vnto Prieſts, and yt eſpecially begā at Rome, where the Apoſtolike ſee was now coūpted to be placed. And leaſt, that adminiſtratiō ſhould be confuſed, Euariſtus the Biſhop firſt of al, deuided titles vnto prieſts, & inſtituted .vij. deacōs, who for the truthes ſake ſhould wayt vpon ye preachers, folowing the exāples of the Apoſtles, who did make ſo many deacons to Miniſter vnto them. Secondly, afterward in the yere of our Lord .267. Dioniſius appointed Churches, Churchyardes & pariſhes, aſwell vnto the Prieſts of Rome, as vnto the prieſts of other coūtries. Beſides he appointed vnto Biſhops dioceſes, commaunding euery one to be contented with his owne boūdes and limites. Theſe townes in which ſeuerall Churches of any dioceſſe are ſet, we call pariſhes, hauing their boundes & limites ſeuered & ſet fourth. The inhabitants within the ſayd territories are called Parochiani, and the ſaid places are called, Parochiae, of this word Parochi. For Parochi, were certeyne officiers among the Romanes, who did prouide woode and ſalt for cōmon legates & embaſſadours, & bicauſe there was no ſacrifice made among the Iewes without fire and ſalt. And as the officers called Parochi, did prepare things neceſſary for the vſe of ye legates: ſo the Prieſts being ye officers of ye church, did prouide vnto their pariſhners ſuch things as are nedefull for ye ſoule. Therfore we call thē not with out a cauſe Parochias, yt is pariſhes. And not lōg after Marcellus limited
into a certeine nūber, the titles which Euariſtius firſt gaue to Prieſts at Rome, cōmaunding by a decree yt there ſhould be .25. titles, which in a maner were as dioceſes, to Baptiſe ſuch as came dayly from the gētils, into ye congregation of the Chriſtiās, and to bury the dead. Theſe things, I haue takē out of Damaſus & Platina & other late writers of the Eccleſiaſticall hiſtory, of whom I maruell yt they did not either in this place, either in any other, yt I can read, declare who were the Prieſts, vnto whom theſe titles were geuē at Rome, from whence vndoubtedly the Cardinals toke their beginning. But they (as we may coniecture) thought it good to paſſe ouer yt matter by ſilence, being a thing nothing notable, which certeine lawyers endeuoured after to ſeeke out. But they hauyng no certeinty to bring for thēſelues, went about to ſhew, yt the order and colledge of Cardinals did diſcend from the Iewes, & before all other, one Andreas ſurnamed Barbatius, made a cōment of this matter, whoſe words are theſe: That goodly ſaying in the firſt of Samuel, Dn̄i ſunt cardines terre, & poſuit ſuper eos orbē. The pillers of ye earth are ye Lords, & vpō thē he hath ſet the foundation of the world, which authority one Hoſtienſis, a doctor of the law, applied vnto the Cardinals of Rome. For as the doore (ſayth he) is directed and holden vp by the hookes, ſo the Church of Rome is gouerned and ruled by the counſell of the Cardinals.

VVill you ſee here how ſome of the lawyars doth ſometimes racke, rent, and ſtretch fourth the holy ſcriptures, euen as the ſhoemakers do drawe and ſtretch fourth their lether with their teeth? Yf thoſe wordes ſpoken by Anna ſhould be ſo applied, that they which be called Cardinals ſhould gouerne the Chriſtian publique weale at Rome: why ſhould it not rather be referred vnto Biſhops and Prieſtes, which were long before the Cardinals, and as chief and principall gouernours, did direct and order matters of religion, which thing Andreas himſelfe doth proue by the teſtimonie of one Guido, Archdeacon of Bononie, whoſe wordes be theſe: In times paſt the chief prieſts or Biſhops in euery Church, were called Cardinals, that is principall and heads: And then he procedeth. It is written in Deutronomie. If thou perceaue anye matter to be hard and doubtefull to be iudged, go vnto the Prieſtes of the Leuiticall order,Deut. 17. and vnto the iudge, that is at that time appointed, for they ſhal declare vnto thee, the truth of the iudgement. And vpon this he ſayth, marcke here that the Leuitical Prieſts in ye old Teſtament were counſellers, in ye diuine law of God, although they were not called Cardinals, but ſuch Prieſts, now adayes as are counſellers of the Lord, are called Cardinals. Here Siculus Andreas, doth not conſider, yt Biſhops & other inferior Prieſts did at ye firſt occupy yt place, which now Cardinals do occupy, the which gouerned
the dioceſſe of Rome, together with the Biſhop of Rome, more then by ye ſpace of a .1000. yeares before any man obteyned yt glorious name of a Cardinall, the whiche now euery where is of great eſtimation.

And therfore it may well be ſayd, that theſe Lordes Cardinals began but of late time, and lately ſucceded in the rowme of ye Leuitical Prieſts. But at length a long time after, when one Boniface the .iij. had obteyned of the Emperour Phocas to haue a prerogatiue aboue all other Biſhops, & when alſo the Romaine Biſhop, with the whole ſenate of the Prieſts of yt citie began to haue authoritie and preeminence aboue all other, then theſe Prieſtes vnto whom theſe titles in times paſt were geuen, ſpecially the cure and charge of ſoules, began to be adorned with the name of Cardinals, as a proper name of ſupreme dignitie, and ſo that function which at the beginning was onerous, at the laſt became honorable. In ſo much that Innocentius the fourth, which in the yeare of our Lord .1244. occupied that ſee, enacted at the laſt by a publique decree, that the Cardinals riding vpon horſes, ſhould were a read hat, that greater renoume might growe to that order. So that he in concluſion made the name and the order of Cardinals, famous, honorable, and very ſupreme and high, who at the firſt being but of a baſe calling, and very paynefull in the function, doth now place & ſet all their ſanctimonie, holynes, and labour in vaine titles, of ſkarlet gownes, and red hattes, and be vnprofitable burdens of the earth, Fruges conſumere nati, waſtyng and deuouryng thoſe reuenewes, which ſhould ſuſtaine and maintaine a nomber of godly and learned preachers, Hec pro maxima parte, ex Polidoro & Balaeo.

div.head: Serpent. 15.
div.p:
THere may a queſtion be moued, whether the Serpent which deceaued Eue were a very true ſerpent, or els ſome phantaſticall ſhewe in the likenes of a Serpent. It is to be marueiled, that the ſerpent did not vſe a worde or two when he ſpake to the woman, but did vſe a ſenſible and diſtinct communication, yea and ſpake not playnly and ſimplie, but demaunded ſuttelie, and aunſwered craftly. VVherupon ſuſpition may ariſe, that this was not a very Serpent in dede, but feigned, and onely apparent, but the woordes of Moſes do reiect this ſuſpition: for Moyſes doth not ſay, Simpliciter, that the ſerpent ſpake to the woman theſe wordes (why hath God cōmaunded you) but Moſes ſpake before other things of this ſerpēt, wherby it is manifeſt, yt he ſpake not of a feined ſerpent, but of a very true ſerpent made of god, wt other beaſts of the earth, for he ſaith. Et ſerpes erat callidior cūctis animātibꝰ terrae quae fecerat deus. And the ſerpent was more ſubtle then all the beaſtes of the earth which God made, behold he ſaith (which God made.) It cannot be
therfore a feined ſerpent, but a very naturall ſerpent. The payne alſo which was inflicted to the ſerpent that he ſhould go vpon his breſt, eate earth, and be moſt odious to mākind, doth declare, that it was no feyned but a very Serpent in dede.

div.head: Queſtio.
div.p: Howe coulde it be that a true and a naturall ſerpent did ſpake with the tounge and voyce of man? ſeyng that the gift of ſpeakyng was geuen not vnto beaſtes, but onely to man, in ſo much that ſpeeche is called, Proprium, ac differentia hominis.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: The ſerpent did not ſpeake by his owne proper facultie and power, but by the inſtinct and operation of ſome other power, that is, either by the power of man, or by the operation of God, or els by the vertue of the good or ill ſpirites. He could not be impelled by the power of man, for Adam and Eue, which then as yet were onely alone, did not know ye thing which was done. Neither is it agreable that they could or ſhould geue the facultie of ſpeaking vnto the Serpent, for aſmuch as it was in a cauſe moſt pernitious and hurtful vnto themſelues. Neither can we, nor ought we to aſcribe this facte vnto the operation of God: for neither the temptation it ſelfe, neither the tranſgreſsion of the commaundement, neither the payne following, can ſuffer, that God might be thought to haue ſpoken vnto the woman by the Serpent in ſo crafty and gilefull maner. Therfore the opinion which certain perſons, called Ophitae, held of the ſerpēt, is moſt deteſtable and wicked.

Thirdly it cannot be ſayd that the good aungell did it, for the thing it ſelfe doth euidently declare, that it was not an aungell, which was the faithful Miniſter of God, & a louer of man, but the enemie of God, and aduerſarie of man, and a very lyer and deceauer.
VVherfore it can no otherwiſe be concluded, but that the Serpent did ſpeake, by the inſtinct and inſtigation of the ill aungell.

The ſlaunderous cauillation of Iulianus Apoſtata, in the whiche he ſcoffingly demaundeth in what maner of ſpeache the Serpent communed with Eue, and wherein this fable doth differ from the fables feigned by the Greciās, is moſt found & friuolous. For thoſe things which are read in their hiſtories, as of Xanthus, Achilles horſe, which told before his maſters death, and of Cāſus the floud, which ſaluted Pythagoras, of the tree whiche ſpake vnto Apollonius: of the oke in Dodona, vſing the voyce and ſpeache of man: and of Iupiter his Bull, in the Ile of Rhodes, ſpeaking like a man, are no fables, but may be counted true, as things done by the inſtincte and operation of the wicked ſpirites. Notwithſtandyng this
impulſion of Satan, tooke nothing away from the nature of the Serpent, no more thē the nature of Balaams Aſſe was diminiſhed, when he ſpake in the voyce of a man, by the helpe of the Aungell of God vnto his maſter, neither thoſe Prophetes which being impelled dy the inſpiration of the deuils, foreſhew things to come, ceaſſe to be men, but do ſtill retayne the nature of man.

div.head: Queſtio.
div.p: VVhy did Satan, in tempting of the woman, vſe rather the Serpent, then any other beaſt?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: The ſerpent was a moſt mete inſtrument for Satā, by the reaſon of the wiſedome wherwith he was endewed, by the which he excelled all other beaſtes. Therfore Satā vſed the ſerpent to accompliſh his purpoſe, that his worke and enterpriſe might therby be leſſe ſuſpected, for that thyng which ſemed to be done by ye naturall wiſedome of the Serpent, might be thought to be fartheſt from ſuſpition and diſceite.

Therfore Satan choſed not either ſhepe or Pigeon or any other beaſt, but onely the helpe of the wyſeſt beaſt, to deceaue the woman, and did directe the Serpentes tounge, and did conceale and couer his owne acte and inſtinct, vnder the nature and wiſedome of the beaſt, that he might therby deliuer himſelfe from ſuſpition of his owne craft and deceite.

Saint Auſten vpon Geneſis, writeth that the Serpent was called wiſe, not properly in his one lyfe voyde of reaſon, but by the ſpirit of an other, that is, the deuill whiche was called the wiſeſt of all beaſtes. For although the Angels, whiche tranſgreſsing did fall from the hygh ſeates, yet by nature they be more excellent then all other beaſtes, by the preeminence of reaſon.

Agayne Saint Auſten writeth ſaying. Proinde & prudētiſsimus om nium beſtiarum, hoc eſt, aſtutiſsimus ita dictus eſt Serpens propter aſtutiam Diaboli, qui in illo & de illo agebat dolum, quemadmodum dicitur, prudens & aſtuta lingua, quam prudens vel aſtutus mouet ad aliquid prudenter aſtuteque ſuadendum. Non enim eſt haec vis ſeu virtus membri corporalis quod vocatur lingua, ſed vtique mentis, quae vtitur ea.

Furthermore the Serpent was called the wiſeſt beaſt of all, that is the ſutteleſt, throughe the craft of the deuill, which wrought his deceit in him, and by him, as it is wont to be ſayd of a mans tong, it is a wiſe & a ſuttil tong, which a wiſe & a ſuttill man doth wiſely & craftely moue to perſuade any thing. This power and ſtrength is not the vertue of the corporal mēber, which is called the tong, but of the mind of mā, which vſeth the toung as an inſtrument.

div.head: Queſtio.
div.p: It may be demaunded, how it came to paſſe, that the womā did not abhorre and feare to come with the ſerpent, but did ſo lightly and ſo ſoone make anſwere to his queſtion?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: It is credibly and moſt like to be true, that the Serpent had not that ſhape of body which he hath now, for that he goeth vpō his breſt, & crepeth on the ground, drawing his body after him, it came not that he was ſo made at the beginning, but by the curſe and vengeaunce of God inflicted vpon him, for the tempting of Eue. For God ſayd quia feceſti hoc, maledictus es inter omnia animantia terrae, &c. Bicauſe thou haſt done this, curſed art thou amonges all the beaſtes of the earth. Thou ſhalt go vpon thy breſt, and thou ſhalt eate earth al the daies of thy life. VVherfore it is to be gathered, yt the Serpent at the beginning had an vpright body, a faire countenance, and pleaſant to behold. Beda writeth, that the Serpent had, before God curſed him, the face of a virgin. Luther ſayth, that he went vpright as a Cocke, but to diſpute aboute this, maketh not ſo greatly to edifye.

Furthermore, it is moſt certaine, that ther was not at the beginning ſuch enmity betwene the woman and the Serpent as is now, for that enmity was inflicted after the fall, when God ſayd: Inimicitias ponā inter te & mulierem, I wyl put enmities betwene thee and the woman. Therfore there is no apparent reaſon, why the womā ſhould abhorre or feare the talke of the Serpent: yea, it may be geſſed, that the Serpent before this temptation, did inſinuate himſelfe vnto the woman, by a ſingular familiarity, whether this were done by a natural fauour and ſtudy, and ſo by that occaſiō offred vnto Satā, or whether Satan by his inſtinct did moue the Serpent before, to enter ſuch familiarity with the woman, that he might be afterward the ſooner admitted to ſeduce and deceaue the woman by his temptation.
Cirillus doth ſuppoſe, that the woman did not feare the communication of the Serpent, bicauſe through her ſimplicity ſhe thought it to be geuen to all beaſtes to ſpeake with mans voyce.

div.head: Nota.
div.p:
Marke here, that the firſt Parents were not ſafe againſt temptaciō, no, not in Paradiſe, being a place of ſo ſinguler and great prerogatiue. Let no man therfore, in what place ſoeuer he be ſet, flatter and promiſe to himſelfe, any ſecurity, for the reſpect of any place, be it neuer ſo holy. Conſider alſo what an euil ſucceſſe that temptation brought vnto man, which was ſuggeſted in the garden of pleaſure. Chriſt was tempted alſo of the ſelfe ſame enemy of mankinde, yet not in Paradiſe, but in a wilde
and deſerte place he was tempted, but not vanquiſhed. There is greate difference betwene the fyrſt man and the ſecond, there is great difference betwene paradiſe and the wildernes, betwene the place of pleaſure, and the place of abſtinence and faſting. The tempter did practiſe the power of his malice in both the places, but the euent and end was diuers and ſundry. This is not ſpoken to make any difference of places, but to exhort men to beware & take hede when they be enhaunced on high, and when they liue in pleaſures and al proſperity, as it were in a certaine terreſtrial Paradiſe, to take hede (I ſay) that their felicitye be not turned by the craft of Satan, into the occaſions of infelicity.

Saint Ambroſe doth note, that the ſerpent did rather tempt the woman, then Adam, bicauſe that he knew Adam to haue heard out of the mouth of God him ſelfe, the cōmaundement of the tree of the knowledge of good and ill, and the woman to haue receaued the cōmaundement not from the mouth of God, but from Adam. But this cōiecture of Ambroſe is not allowed of certayne learned men.

div.head: Heauen and earth ſhal paſſe. 17.
div.p: THer are two places of the ſcripture, which ſeme repugnant one to the other. The firſt is. Pſalm. 101. Thou aforetyme haſt layd the foundacion of the earth, and the heauens are the worke of thy handes, they ſhall periſhe, but thou ſhalt endure. The other is Eccleſiaſtis. Cap. 1. The earth remaineth for euer. But if thou expend and vewe well theſe two places, they do not diſſent one from the other. There be many which thinke and ſay that heauen and earth ſhall vtterly periſhe,Math. 24. Lu. 21. bicauſe they reade in the Goſpel theſe wordes ſpoken by Chriſt: Caelum & terra tranſibunt, Heauen and earth ſhal paſſe. But Chriſt meaneth no ſuch thing, but animating and encouraging his diſciples mindes paciently to ſuſtaine the afflictions to come, doth ſpeake of the perpetuity & firmnes of his word, as though he ſhould ſay, heauen and earth being moſt firme and ſure, ſhal ſoner periſh, then my word ſhal fayle, which word is ſo ſound, ſo conſtant & ſo firme, that no age or oldnes ſhal empeire it, or cauſe it to periſh, no daungers and tumults ſhall ſuppres it, no aſſaultes nor aſſeiges ſhall throw it downe.

Terra in eternum ſtat, The earth ſtandeth for euer, and the heauen ſhal not paſſe. That is. The ſubſtance of them ſhall remaine for euer, but the forme and ſhape therof ſhal be chaunged and made new,Apoca. 21. we reade in the Apocalips, of a new heauen and a new earth, and how the firſt heauē and the firſt earth paſſed away. The heauens at the laſt cōming of Chriſt
ſhalbe diſſolued, and the elements ſhal melt with heate. But we looke (ſaith Peter) for new heauens and a new earth, according to his promis,2 Peter. 3. wherin dwelleth righteouſnes.
