As gold is diſſolued by fyre, not to peryſh and to be loſt, but that it might be made more pure, the droſſe being purged from it, ſo the elements ſhal be made more fine and pure. VVherof Tertulian in his booke De eccleſiaſt. dogma: Cap. 60. (if at the leaſt he be author of the ſayd booke) writeth thus: Elementa, id eſt, caelum & terram nō credamus abolenda per ignem, ſed in melius commutanda. &c. VVe may not beleue (ſayth he) the elements, yt is heauen & earth, to be takē away by fire, but to be chaunged into a better ſtate, the faſhion of the world alſo, that is the image, and not the ſubſtance to paſſe. Euen ſo our fleſh alſo ſhalbe diſſolued, not eternally to periſh, but ſhall be made more holy and more incorrupt. Saint Paule writeth to the Corinthians, Cadit corpus animale, reſurgit ſpirituale. It is ſowen a naturall body,Cor. 15. it riſeth a ſpiritual and an immortal body. In the earth, wher we now dwel, ther is no righteouſnes, but malediction and curſe, as it is written in Geneſis .3. Maledicta terra in opere tuo. Curſed be the earth in thy worke. Sathan is the prince and God of this world Paul writing to the Romanes, ſaith: The creature is ſubiect to vanity, not of his own wyll,Rom. 8. but by reaſon of him which hath ſudued it vnder hope, but the creature ſhalbe deliuered from the bondage of corruption, into the glorious liberty of the ſonnes of God. But that heauen and that earth in which we ſhall then dwel, ſhall be made new and more perfit, wher we ſhall reigne perpetually, all the wicked being deſtroyed, and put from the ſayd earth. To this purpoſe pertayneth that which is written in the prouerbes of Salomon.Prouerb .2. Recti in terra perdurabunt, & probi in ea ſuperſtites erunt. Impii e terra extirpabuntur. The iuſt ſhall dwell in the land, and ye vpright men ſhall remaine in it, but the wicked ſhalbe cut of the earth, and the tranſgreſsours ſhall be rooted out of it. Againe Dauid in his .27. Pſalme, I ſhould haue fainted, except I had beleued to ſee the goodnes of the Lord, in ye land of the liuing. Again in an other place he ſaith: Euil doers ſhalbe cut of,Pſalm. 37. but they that waite vpon the Lord, ſhal inherite the land, meke men ſhall poſſeſſe the earth, and ſhal haue their delight in the multitude of peace. Chriſt in Mathew doth ſay: Beati mites, quoniam ipſi hereditabunt terrā, Math. 5. bleſſed be the meke, for they ſhall inherite the earth. It is aptly ſayd, they ſhal inherit, bicauſe the ſayntes ſhal dwel on the land being made new, & ſhall liue in it eternally, & therfore it is called the land of the liuing. VVherfore when Chriſt ſayd, heauen and earth ſhall paſſe, it is to be vnderſtand, that it ſhall paſſe to a pefection, that is, they ſhalbe made more pure and vncorrupt, they ſhall be chaunged, that is, they ſhal haue an other
face, forme, and ſhew, and there ſhall dwell rightuouſnes, wher now raygneth iniquity. Ther ſhalbe peace and ioy, wher now is deceit & iniury, but my woord (ſayth the Lord) remaineth for euer, it ſhal neuer be chaunged, nor ſhal put on any other face, but ſhall endure one, & the ſelfe ſame woord perpetually.

Of burning and melting of the Elements at the latter day, looke vpon one Hieronimus Magius, who hath written .v. bookes De mundi exuſtione, & de die iudicii, of the burning of the worlde, and of the day of iudgement.

Saint Gregory writeth of the fire that ſhal come in the latter day after this maner: Tantum accendet ignis iudicii, quantum aſcenderunt aquae dilunii. The fire of iudgement ſhal burne ſo muche as the waters of the great floud did occupy in aſcending aboue the tops of the mountains, which ſaying is to be vnderſtand as touching ye effect of purging, but touching ye effect of īnocatiō, it ſhal aſcēd further, as Aquinas doth expoūd it

Some after the gloſe of Bede do ſay, that the two Elements, that is, fire & water, ſhalbe wholy and vtterly conſumed, but the other two Elements the earth and the ayre, ſhal remaine whole after an other ſtate. Yet it ſeemeth more true, that the whole foure ſhal remayn, concerning their ſubſtance, and not concerning the ſtate of generation and corruption. For then the mouing of the heauenly bodies aboue, which as a ſecōd cauſe, are the beginning of alteration and chaunge, ſhall ceaſe. But concerning their proper ſubſtaunce, they ſhal remayne, hauing qualities agreable to their incorruptible ſtate. The fire and water ſhalbe wholy cō ſumed, bicauſe they be ſpecialiter actiua, yet not by ſubſtancial property, but concerning the property and power of conuerting other things into them. The other two which be paſſiua, bicauſe paſsibility ſhalbe turned into impaſsibility, ſhalbe chaunged into a better face and forme. Heate in the fire, and coldnes in the water, ſhalbe vtterly conſumed. This is the cenſure and iudgement of Thomas Aquinas.
If thou deſire to learne more of thys matter, looke vpon ſaynt Auſten De ciuitate dei, libro .20. cap. 18. &. 16.

div.head: Eſay. 18.
div.p: THis Eſay was a moſt holy prophet, borne at Hieruſalem of a noble family. He gouerned by his learning and counſel, the church of the Iewes .80. yeares, and at the ſame time liued theſe Prophets, Amos, Oſeas, Micheas, Ionas. He was the ſonne of one Amos, not Amos the prophet, for his name is written with Ain, being the firſt letter, and Samech, being the laſt letter of his name. But Amoz the Father of Eſay, is writen with Aleph, and the laſt letter is Zade. VVhat maner of man this Amoz was, there is no certayne tradition.

Rabbi Kimhi geueth this note. Ignoramus familiam eius de quanam ſit tribunatus, patres tamen tradiderunt quod ſtarres fuerint Amazias et Amoz. VVe know not his family of what tribe he came, notwithſtanding the fathers wrote that Amazias and Amoz, were brothers. He ſpeaketh of Amazias the king, father to Ozias.

Vpon this roſe the opinion that this prophet was a noble man borne, and of a kings bloud. Notwithſtanding, although this opinion haue ſome likelihood of truth, yet the prophet hath neuer the more eſtimation by yt, for he is much more noble by ye preeminence of viſions, thē any king. For there be many worthy thinges to be recorded of him: firſt, that hys prophecy is ſet before other prophetes in the holy ſcriptures, which is not ſo to be vnderſtanded, that he was the firſt of all other, which dyd either prophecy or write. For ther were many other, which did not onely prophecy, in his time with him, but alſo before him. As Nathan, Gad, Addo, and Ahias, did prophecy before him. And in his time did prophecy Oſeas, Amos, and Zacharias, not that Zachary which is the laſt of the twelue leſſer prophets, but an other of the ſame name, which was before him. But yet their prophecies are ſet after, and placed among ye prophecies of the ſmaler prophets. The reaſon wherof is this. Although thys prophet Eſaias were not firſt, neither in order nor time, yet he is had of ſuch eſtimation, for the worthines and excellencye of his prophecies, that he is worthely ſet before the other. And truly, thoſe things which he prophecied of Chriſt, are ſo perſpicuous and playne, that he was counted of the auncient fathers, not onely a Prophet, but alſo an Euangeliſt and Apoſtle, and as it were, a preſent beholder of the croſſe of Chriſt. Saynt Hierome ſayth, that Eſaias writeth not a prophecy, but rather a Goſpel. The ſcriptures of the new Teſtament do manifeſtly declare, of what efficacy and force his prophecies were in the eyes of Chriſt, of the Euangeliſts, and of the Apoſtles. For ther is no booke of the old teſtament (except the Pſalter of Dauid) out of ye which we reade moe teſtimonies to be brought in the new teſtament, then out of it. If you number them, you ſhal plainly perceaue that there be .60. places cited out of that booke, and 64. out of the Pſalmes. Chriſt himſelf in the ſinagoge of Nazareth,Lu. 4. whē he roſe to reade, tooke the booke of this Prophet into his hands, did read it, and ſhut it agayne. Yea, this prophet was had in price among the very Heathen, as it appeareth in the hiſtory of a certayn Eunuch of Aethiopia, Candaces the quene of the Ethiopians chief gouernour. At the laſt when he moſt ſharply & oftentimes had reproued Manaſſes the king of Hieruſalem, he was by him cauſed to be cut a ſunder with a woodden ſaw, and was buried vnder an oke, at a place called Rogel, which is a wel nigh vnto Hieruſalem.

div.head: Apparitions. 19.
div.p: RAbanus Archbiſhop of Magunce, doth ſhew out of the teſtimonies of Gregory the firſt, and of Beda, that the ſoules of perſons deceaſed, haue often times appeared, and haue declared, that ſacrifices & praiers of the liuing, haue much profited them after their death. But it is to be marueiled, that mē of ſuch good learning would build vpon ſo weake a foundation.Deut. 18. Eſay. 8. For the Lord doth forbyd in his law, to aſke or to ſeeke any truth of the ſpirites of the dead. The prophets do ſend vs from ſuch oracles, vnto the law and teſtimony of Gods worde.Luk. 16. You may heare in the Euangeliſt Saynt Luke, howe the riche glotton, lying in torments, doth cry and ſay: O father Abraham, I pray thee, that thou wylt ſend Lazarus vnto my fathers houſe, for I haue .v. brethren, that he may teſtifye vnto them, leaſt they alſo come into thys place of torment. But Abraham ſayd vnto him: they haue Moſes and the prophets, let them heare them. And he ſayd: nay father Abraham, but if one came vnto them from the dead, they wil amend their liues. Then he ſayd vnto him: if they heare not Moſes and the prophets, neither wil they be perſwaded, though one riſe from the dead againe. By this place it is moſt certaine, and euidently confuted, that the ſoules haue not, nor cannot appere after their death, no not the bleſſed ſoules, much leſſe the ſoules of the wycked.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: But many partly by arte Magicke, partly by the power of god, haue returned againe into this life, after their departure from hence.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: To this obiection Tertullianus maketh anſwer in theſe words. Sed & ſi quaſdam reuocauit in corpora dei virtus, Libr de anima. in documēta iuris ſui, non idcirco communicabitur fidei & audaciae Magorum, & fallaciae ſomniorum, & licentiae poaetarum, atqui in reſurrectionis exemplis, cum dei virtus ſiue per prophetas, ſiue per Chriſtum, ſiue per Apoſtolos in corpora animas repreſentat ſolida & contrectabili, & ſatiata veritate praeiudicatum eſt hanc eſſe formam veritatis, vt omnem mortuorum exhibitionē incorporalem praeſtigias iudices.

Although the power of God hath called again certain ſoules into their bodies, in token of his might and right, it ought not therfore to be aſcribed to the truſt and boldnes of the Magicians, neyther to the vanities of dreames and the licence of Poetes, but rather in the examples of the reſurrection, whē the power of god, whether by the Prophets or by Chriſt, or els by ye Apoſtles, doth render ſoules into their bodies: it is declared by the ſenſible and ſufficient truth, that this is the very forme of thy truth, that thou maiſt iudge euery incorporall apparition of the dead to be deceytes and deluſions.

Chriſoſtom writing vpon Saynt Mathew, doth demaund this queſtiō Quid ergo reſpōdebimus ad illas voces: Anima talis ego ſum? (excipit) Non anima defuncti eſt quae iſta dicit, ſed demon, qui haec vt audientes decipiat effingit. Et mox: Quare vetularum haec verba, imo deſipientium ducenda ſunt, & puerorum ludibria. Et iterum, no poteſt anima a corpore ſeparata in his regionibus errare. Iuſtorum animae in manu dei ſunt, in fantium ſimiliter, non enim peccarunt. Peccatorum vero poſt hunc exitum continuo abducuntur, quod a Lazaro & diuite planum efficitur.

VVhat ſhal we ſay therfore to thoſe voices which ſay: I am ſuch aſoule? He anſwereth: that voice which ſpeaketh theſe things, is not the ſoule of any perſon departed, but it is the deuil which doth faine theſe thinges to deceaue the hearers. VVherfore ſuch words are to be counted old wyues tales, & fooliſh fables of childrē: for the ſoule ſeparate frō the body, doth not wāder in this world, for the ſoules of ye righteous are in the hands of God, likewiſe ye ſoules of infants, for they haue not ſinned. The ſoules of ye ſinners after their departure, ar ſtraightway caried to their place, which plainly appeareth by Lazarus the righteous, and the wicked rich man.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: It is found in the holy ſcriptures, that Samuel the prophet did appeare after his death, therfore it may be concluded that ſoules do returne after their departure, and do informe men of certain demaundes.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p:
That thing which appered, ſemed in ſhew to be Samuel, & therfore by a Trope is ſo called, but in dede it was not Samuel, but a phantaſtical appearance, & an illuſion of Satā, which to proue, I vrge this argument. Magick was ſtraitly forbidden in the law of God, therefore the bleſsed ſpirits, which liuing yet in their bodies, did abhor & reſiſt all il meanes, did not obey wicked artes forbidden, but the damned ſpirits do exerciſe themſelues in ſuch vnlawful waies & meanes. It may again be ſayd, that Samuel did foreſhew that thing which came to pas the next day after. VVhat then? what wil you gather of that? It was no hard matter for Sathan ſo to do, who a litle before had heard Samuel being a liue, to ſpeake many things vnto Saul. Likewiſe he might know by certain tokēs, as by ye feare of Saules hoſt, he might know before ye iudgmēt of god againſt Saul
Tertullian ſaith: Abſit (inquit) vt animā cuiuſlibet ſancti ne dum prophaetae a demonio credam a • extractam, edocti quod ipſe Sarhanas tranſfiguretur in angelum lucis, nedum in hominem lucis, & iam deum ſe aſſeneraturus ſignaque portentoſiora editurus ad euertendos, ſi fieri poſſit, electos.

That is to ſay: God forbid (ſaith he) yt we ſhould beleue, the ſoule of any ſaint, much les of a prophet, to be brought out by the diuel, foraſmuch as we be taught, yt ſatan doth chaūge him ſelf into an angel of light, and not onely into the ſhew of a mā, & wil affirme himſelf to be god, & will worke marueilous ſignes, to ouerthrow (if it be poſsible) the very elect.
Saint Auſten doth iudge the like of the apparition of Samuel in his ſecond booke & .3. queſtion, Ad Simplicianum, & ad Dulcitii quaeſtiones.

div.head: Rabbi. 20.
div.p: THis word Rabbi cōmeth of this verbe Rauau, which hath two ſignifications. Firſt, it ſignifieth to encreace & to multiply, as in the Pſalme, Multiplicati ſunt ſuper capillos capitis mei, et in Geneſi. Pſalm 69. Gene. 1. Creſcite et multiplicamini. Of this verbe cōmeth Rau, which be tokeneth multum, magnum, copioſum, much, great, aboundant.

The other ſignification is iaculare, ſeu arcum trahere, to ſhoote, or to draw a bow. And Roueh Keſheth, is no more but magiſter arcus. Moreh hachitzim, id eſt, habens peritiam multiplicē eiiciendi ſagittas. Hauing much cunning to ſhoote arrowes. Of this the Hebrues do cala maſter & a teacher Rabbi, for much and great learning which one hath, or ought to haue. For Rab (as I ſayd) ſignifieth multus much. The Caldeans and the Sirians do cala maiſter in their toung Ribbon, in ſteede of which in the Goſpel is written Rabboni.

The Iewes in theſe daies, dare not vſurpe & challenge to thēſelues this name Rabbi, yea although they be neuer ſo wel learned, except they redeme this title of their elders by fauour and money, wherby it cōmeth to paſſe, that they which be rich; and yet ſlenderly learned, obtayne thys name and degree, but the poore, although they be neuer ſo well learned, are defrauded of that name and title. And we learne out of the Goſpell, that this ambition did then raigne among the Iewes.

The great doctors (which write cōmentaries & paraphraſes) vpō ye old teſtament, & vpō other their bokes, are called Rabbini, whoſe names you ſhal finde in reading their workes, and ſpecially in Petrus Galatinus booke entituled De miſteriis arcanae veritatis.

div.head: Apoſtoli. 21.
div.p: Αποςολοσ cōmeth of this verbe 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which ſignifieth to ſend out one in meſſage, or to ſend in commaundement, and ſo Apoſtolus ſignifieth him that is ſent, a meſſenger, a legate, an apoſtle, wherof be foure kindes. Some were Apoſtoli, ſent of God, without man, as Moſes and Paule. Some ſent of God, but by mā, as Ieſus Naue, & which be ordinarely called, ſome by man alone, as they which come to that fūctiō by ſauour, and for lucre and eaſe, the fourth, be they which thruſt in them ſelues, without ordinary calling, of whom the prophet Ieremy ſpeaketh:Iere 23. Ecce currebant & ego non mittebam eos, behold they ran, & I ſent them not. Apoſtoli alſo do ſignify letters miſsiue, vt fregit apoſtolos in ſenatu, he rent the letters in the ſenate houſe. Apoſtoli alſo were certain Magiſtrates at Athens, whoſe office was to rule and ouerſee the nauy & ſhyps, properly the maiſter of the gallies.

div.head: Propheta.
div.p: PRopheta ſignifieth a foreſhewer of things to come, a prelat, a prophecier, and an interpreter of prophecies (as Plato witneſſeth in Timaeo:) A poet, as Paul writeth ad Titum. ca. 2. a ſeer, as it is ſayd. lib. Regum. 1. cap. 9. and as Hierom writeth in .12. chapter of the prophet Oſeas.

Prophetare in the ſcriptures, is taken diuers and ſundry waies. Firſt it ſignifieth the declaration, as wel of things paſt, as of things to come, as Moſes, who wrote of the creation of the world, and of other things paſt, is called a prophet, as well as Eſay,Eſay. 7. who prophecied before that a virgin ſhould conceiue, and as al the prophets which ſhewed things to come. As for example, one wrote of Chriſtes natiuity, an other of his doctrine, an other of his paſsion, an other of his kingdom. And ſo al other who prophecied of him to come, & to be the redemer of ye world, are called prophets.
Secondly, prophetare is to expound & open prophecies word for word

Thirdly, prophetare is to ſing pſalmes, & to ſing laud & praiſe to god as you rede of Aſaph, Idithum, and Heman, which thre ſang confeſsion,1, Para. 25. praiſe, & thankeſgeuing vnto God, with harps, viols, and Cimbals. Heman is called there the kings ſeer, that is, a prophet.

Aſaph ſang, or as ſome write, made theſe. 12. Pſalmes. 49.7 • .73.74.75.76.77.78.79.80.8.1.82. And in .1. Reg. 18. prophetare is takē to ſing ſongs, & to do ſacrifice, as ther it is ſayd of Baals prophets, when the midday was paſſed, and they had prophecied vntil the offring of the euening ſacrifice

Fourthly, prophetare is to preach ye ſcriptures, to open ye true ſence & meaning of thē to ye people, to teach, to admoniſh, to exhort, to comfort, to improue and correct corrupt maners by the holy ſcriptures,1. Cor. 14. Act. 13. and in thys ſignification Saynt Paule vſeth it.

Fiftly, ſome take prophetare to heare the word of god,1. Cor. 11. & to be exerciſed diligently in the law of God, as mulier orans et prophetans, a womā praying or prophecieng, that is, hearing the word, or els prophecieng, But prophetare in this place, is to ſhew ye miſteries of god, to ye edifieng of the hearers. Therfore the words of Paul ſeme not to make for the ſenſe of hearing, foraſmuch as he ſpeaketh of a woman, which did either pray or prophecy For although wemē wer forbidden to ſpeake in the congregacion, wherby it ſignified that they ought not to haue any publik function in the church, which is ordinary and perpetual, yet if the ſpirite of God come vpō thē, they are not forbiddē, but yt they ſomtime may ſpeake. Anna the prophetiſſe ſpake in the temple, of our Sauior,Luk. 2. Iudic. 5. Exod. 15. whē the virgin Mary was purified. Debora ſang praiſes to god opēly. So did Maria ye ſiſter of Moſes, & ther be many places which teſtify yt womē in old time did opēly prophecy,Regū. 2. Ioſias ye king did aſke coūſel of Holda the prophetiſſe
Anna the mother of Samuel,1. Samu. made a godly ſong. Mary the virgin, the mother of Chriſt,Luk. 1. Iohn. 20 ſang a godly pſalme. The Aungel commaunded Magdalene to ſhew Chriſtes reſurrection vnto the Apoſtles. And God ſayth in Ioel,2. Ioel. De ſpiritu meo effundam ſuper vos, & prophetabunt filii veſtri, & fili • veſtrae. I wyl poure my ſpirite vpon you, and your ſonnes & daughters ſhal prophecy.Act. 21. Philip alſo had many daughters, which did prophecie. And that it was the maner in the old tyme, to prophecy openlye in the congregation,Ier 27. &. 28. it doth plainly appeare in Ieremye, and many other places. Agabus the prophet, did openlye prophecye vnto Paule, that he ſhould be bound and tyed at Hieruſalem.Act 2 • .

The name of a prophet is taken ſomtime for a name of honor, as in the prophet Eſay,Eſay. 8. wher it is ſaid that Eſaias came ad prophetiſſam, he came vnto the prophetiſſe, which conceaued and bare a ſonne. Eſay meaneth it by his own wife (as Muſculus writeth) whom he calleth a prophetiſſe, not that ſhe had the gift of prophecy, as far as we can reade, but bicauſe ſhe was the wife of a prophet, whoſe office was moſt noble & honorable Notwithſtanding ſome do referre the name of a prophetiſſe here, to the virgin Mary, and by this may we ſee, ther be, tot ſenſus, quot capita.

Vnder the name of a prophet are vnderſtād ſomtimes falſe prophetes, as in Zachary,Zach 13. & they be knowen by .3. notes, which do diſcerne thē frō true prophets. The firſt note is, if they be taken in lies. Such were they in whō the lying ſpirit ſpake,3. Reg. 22. ſent of God to deceaue Achab. The ſecōd note is, if they ſpeake truth, & that in the name of the Lord, which yet they ſpeake, for that end that they may deceaue the people, or if they prophecy openly, in ye name of their falſe gods. The third note is, if in a rage, fury, or traunce, they foreſhew things to come, and yet vnderſtand no part of thoſe thinges which they vtter.
On the other ſide, the true tokens of godly prophets are three, verity, piety, and intelligence. Verity conſiſteth in this, when thoſe thinges which they foreſhew, are certainly performed and done.
Piety, is when with their prophecies they do exhort the people vnto ye ſtudy of godlines, & induce them to the worſhipping of one true God.

Intelligence, is when they vnderſtād with a ſober minde thoſe things which they do prophecy. VVher theſe thre things do concurre, there is a moſt ſure argument of a true Prophet, endued with the ſpirite of God. And ſuch which are adourned with theſe thre properties, are inſtructed to prophecy thre maner of waies. Firſt, eyther by viſions and ſignes ſene in ſlepe, or by expres woords, or els by inſpiracion of the holy ſpirit. Of prophecy by viſions,Num 12 you may reade in the booke of Numbers, where God ſayth. Si quis inter vos fuerit propheta domini, in viſione apparebo ei, et
per ſomnium loquar ad illum. If ther be a prophet of the Lord amōg you, I wyll be knowen to him by a viſion, and wyl ſpeake vnto hym by dream. Of prophecy by expreſſe words without figures or ſhewes, is mencioned alſo in the ſame chapter, wher God ſayth: At non talis ſeruus meus Moſes, ore enimad os laquar ei. But my ſeruāt Moſes is not ſo,Ibidem. who is faith ful in al mine houſe, vnto him wil I ſpeak mouth to mouth, & by viſiō, & not in darke words, but he ſhal ſee the ſimilitude of the Lord. Of prophecy by the inward inſpiration of the ſpirit,Num. 12. we reade alſo in the booke of Numbers, wher it is recorded, how the .70. Elders, receiuing the ſpirit of God, did prophecy. In which place, & in many other, ther is no mentiō made, either of viſions, or of expres wordes. A Prophet is called of the Hebrues Neuia, of the Grecians Propheta, & of the latine men Vates.

div.head: Luke. 23.
div.p: SVch things as pertain to the hiſtory of Saint Luke the Euangeliſt. Hierome hath ſufficiently touched, which hiſtory I thought it good here to recite. Luke (as he ſayth) a Phiſicion of Antioch, was not ignorāt of ye Greke toung, he was ye folower of the apoſtle Paul, and a companion vnto him in all his peregrinacions. He wrote the goſpel, of the which the ſelfe ſame Paule, thus ſayd:2. Cor. 8. VVe haue ſent our brother with him, whoſe prayſe is in the goſpell throughout all Churches. And to the Coloſsians: Our dearely beloued brother,Col. 4. 2. Tim. 4. Luke the Phiſicion ſaluteth you. And vnto Timothy: Luke onely is with me. He did ſet forth alſo an other noble worke, which is entituled. The actes of the Apoſtles, the ſtory of which endureth vnto the end of the two yeares, in the which Paul abode at Rome, that is, vnto the fourth yere of Nero, by ye which it is to be gathered, that the booke was made in the ſame city. VVherfore, that treaty of Paul and Thecla, and the whole fable of Leo his baptiſme, are to be counted among the apochriphal ſcriptures. For what a likely matter is this, that Luke being the vnſeparable companion of the Apoſtle Paul, among other actes of his, ſhould be ignorant of this thyng onely? And Tertullian alſo, liuing not long after that time, declareth, that a certayne prieſt in Aſia, a fautor of the Apoſtle Paule, being conuicted of thou, that he was the authour of that booke, confeſſed that he did it for the loue that he bare to Paule. And therfore ſome thincke, that as often as Paul in his Epiſtles ſayth (iuxta euangelium meum) according to my Goſpell, he meaneth the volume of Luke. And he ſayth, that Luke learned the Goſpel, not onely of the Apoſtle Paule (whych lyued not wyth Chriſt in the fleſh) but of the other Apoſtles. The which he hym ſelfe declareth in the beginning of hys woorke, ſaying.

Luke. 1.Euen as they deliuered them vnto vs, who ſaw thē from the beginning, and were Miniſters of the word. Therfore he wrote the Goſpell according as he heard, but the Actes of the Apoſtles, according as he ſaw. He liued .84. yeares, hauing no wife, and was buried at Conſtantinople, vnto the which citie his bones with the reliques of Andrew the Apoſtle, were remoued from Achaia the .20. yeare of Conſtātius, but Nicephorus. lib. 2. cap. 43. writeth thus of Luke. Luke borne at Antioch, which is in Celo ſyria, being a Phiciſiō, and alſo a notable painter, came vnto Paule from Thebe, and there renouncing the errors of his coūtry, beleued in Chriſt, and became of a curer of the body, a Phiſicion of the ſoule. He wrote his Goſpel being inſtructed by Paul, & alſo the actes of the Apoſtles. VVhē he had hene a tyme at Rome wyth Paule, he returned into Grece, inſtructing much people there, in the knowledge of the Goſpell, and at the laſt by the enemies of Gods woord, he was hanged vppon a greene Oliue tree, bicauſe there was ſcarſity there of dry wood to make a gallowes of. He yelded his life vnto God, when he had liued .80. yeares.

Platina in the life of Cletus the firſt, writeth thus. In the tyme of Cletus was Luke the Phiſition, wel learned in ye Greeke toung, the follower of Paule the Apoſtle, and fellow vnto him in all his iourneys. He wrote the Goſpel, which is much commended of Paule. VVherfore, not wythout cauſe Paule calleth it his Goſpell. He wrote the actes of the Apoſtles, according as he ſaw with his owne eyes. He lyued .83. yeares, he had a wife in Bithynia. He was buried at Conſtantinople.

div.head: Theophilus. 24.
div.p:
ERaſmus with others, doo ſuppoſe Theophilus to be a proper name, and to haue bene a very ſpeciall friend of Saynt Luke, vnto whō Luke did dedicate both the bookes, written by him, that is, the booke entituled, the goſpell of Luke, and the booke named the actes of the Apoſtles. Others iudge, that Theophilus is no proper name, but a generall name, ſignifieng euery frend of God, for ſo is the etymology of the word, which is compounde of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
id eſt, deo: God, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , id eſt amicus, a friend. Howſoeuer it be, it is moſt certaine, that ſaint Luke in both his bookes, would not teache onely one man, but all men ſtudious of gods glory, and deſirous of eternall ſaluation, whom we maye well call Theophilos.

Other do think, that thys Theophilus was a mighty prince, or ſome noble man, bicauſe that Luke in the preface of his goſpell, doth geue him this Epitheton, Preſtantiſſime Theophile, moſt noble Theophilus. Notwithſtanding, this Epitheton in the Greeke, hath diuers and ſundrye interpretacions, as Eraſmus doth note in his annotacions. VVhoſe
wordes be theſe: I maruell, why Lyranus, did ſuſpecte this Theophilus, to be ſome prince or noble man, bicauſe Luke ſaith (Optime Theophile. Luke. 1.) Is it peculiar and proper onely to great men, to be called the beſt? But it may be, yt Lyranus, did read this in ſome gloſe, whiche as he might read, yet through the ignoraunce of the Greke toung, he could not vnderſtād for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , among the Grecians ſignifieth Robur, ſiue imperium, ſtrēgth, might or imperie, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , is Vincere, to ouercome, and one to haue his full purpoſe. Therfore Paul in the Actes of the Apoſtles doth call Feſtū,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is, as you might ſay, of great power. And ſo doth ye interpreters, as Origene, Theophilactus, and Ambroſius, teſtifie. Although 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , doth not onely ſignifie a mā of might, but alſo a good mā, & a mā worthy much to he eſtemed: and of that commeth the ſuperlatiue 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which ſignifieth Optimum. Hactenus Eraſmus.

Other learned men will haue thys Epitheton,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , to come of thys word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , whiche ſignifieth a ſuperiour, mighty, of great authoritie, wherupon they iudge this Theophilus, to haue bene ſome notable prince.

There were diuerſe other of that name, as Theophilus, Biſhop of Antioche the .vi. after the Apoſtles. He wrote certeine bookes,Lib. 4. ca. 24. whoſe titles Euſebius reciteth. He liued in the time of the Emperour Marcus Antonius verus.
There was an other of that name, who was Byſhop of Alexandria: he was immediatly before Cyrillus.

div.head: Iohannes euangeliſta. 26.
div.p: THe hiſtorie of Iohn before the Aſcention of Chriſt, & like wiſe of a long time after, is euidently declared in the ſcriptures: but what he did at the laſt, and what became of him, diuerſe authors do diuerſlye write. Euſebius doth ſhew that when the Apoſtles were gone into ſtraunge and farre countries, the region of Aſia, chaunced to Iohn: & many do affirme, that Iohn remayned at Epheſus, as Biſhop and Paſtor there: but this doth not certaynly appeare, nor at what time it ſhould be done. For all the time in the whiche Paul paſſed through Aſsia, and did there accōpliſh his Miniſterie, there is no mention made of Iohn. And it is plaine and manifeſt, that S. Paule did conſtitute and make Timothie Biſhop of the Church of Epheſus, & that he wrote two Epiſtles vnto him being there. Therfore it may be, yt Iohn being very aged, after the death of Timothie, went to Epheſus, whē he had before in other partes of Aſsia, accompliſhed his miniſterie.

Irenaeus writeth, that Paule was ye founder of the church of Epheſus, Lib. 3. cap. 3. and that Iohn remayned there vnto the tyme of Traiā the Emperour:Lib. 3. cap. 1. he alſo ſayth, that Iohn made his abode at Epheſus, when he wrote his Goſpell.
The occaſion why he wrote the Goſpell,Lib. 3. cap. 11. was (as Irenaeus, ſaieth) to reſiſt ye deluſions & hereſies of one Cerinthus, who ſaid Chriſt, not to be the true ſonne of God, nor coeſſentiall with the father.

Saint Hierome in his Cataloge writeth, that Iohn the laſt of all other Euangelistes, wrote his Goſpell, at the requeſte of ye Biſhops of Aſia, againſt certaine heretikes, and chiefly againſt the doctrine of the Ebionites, which then began to ſpring, who did affirme, yt Chriſt was not before his birth corporall. VVhervpon he was driuē to write his Goſpell, by the which he confirmeth the diuine natiuitie of Chriſt, which was without beginning.

Lib. 3. cap. 24. Euſebius ſheweth an other cauſe, which is this: VVhen Iohn had ouerſeen and vewed the writings of the other thre Euangeliſtes, he did allow all things rehearſed of thē as moſt true. Becauſe he ſaw & perceiued certain things omitted, which were done before ye captiuity of Iohn ye Baptiſt, he thought good yt they alſo ſhould be added to them and recorded.
Other learned men do thinke, that Iohn perceiuing the other Euangeliſtes fully to proſequte the hiſtorye of Chriſt, he therfore in his Goſpell did ricite many ſermons of Chriſt.

The perſecutions and conflictes which Iohn ſuffred of the raging perſecutors, ar not al cōmitted to writings: but doubtles he was moſt cruelly entreated and handled, he was one of the firſt that was put in priſon, with Peter at Hieruſalē, and (as certaine do recorde) he was baniſhed from Epheſus into the Iland of Pathmos, by the cruel Emperour Domitianus the .14. yeare of his raigne. VVhere ſome write, that Iohn was put into a veſſell full of hot ſcalding Oile, it is vncertayne, in ſo much yt ſome doubte of ye place, whether it ſhould be done at Epheſus, or at Hieruſalē. Saint Hierome of this matter maketh no mention. He without queſtion wrought many miracles by his life time, but wher certain of thē are written and reported of ſome authors, neither auctentike nor worthy great credit, it is not beſt nor moſte ſafe to receyue euerie thyng that they write, and ſpecially to geue no great faith vnto one Iulius Africanus, otherwiſe named Abdias, who reporteth, yt Iohn brake precious ſtones and made them whole againe, that he did turne boughes, trees, & ſtones, into gold, and brought them agayne to their former nature.

Nor it is without ſuperſtition whiche is aſcribed to Iohn, yt he ſhould allowe the dede of one Druſiana, who beyng coupled in matrimonie, did withdrawe her ſelfe from her huſbandes companie without hys conſent. And thoſe words ar moſt horrible which Abdias, doth attribute to Iohn, the words be theſe. Virtutū opes habere non poteſt, qui vult diuitias habere terrenas. He can not haue ye riches of vertues which hath a deſire of
riches of the worlde. O ſaying moſt wicked, do we not read in the holy Scriptures of many whiche were very riche and notwithſtandyng were good and godly.

The like doctrine for the ſpace of thirty dayes to be geuen for repentaunce, is repugnaunt to the wordes of Chriſt, who taught to forgeue ſeuenty tymes ſeuen, if nede were, in one day. It ſemeth alſo a new thing, that Iohn in his life time ſhould builde a Church in his own name at Epheſus, for it euidently appeareth, that Churches and temples began not to be ſumptuouſly builded in the memorie of ſaintes, before the tyme of Conſtantinus, the great. Abdias, doth alſo write, that by the prayers of Iohn the temple of the great goddeſſe Diana, at Epheſus, Lib. 3. cap. 23, together with the great idoll was deſtroied, and how that Iohn dranke poyſon without hurt, theſe & ſuch other things I referre to the iudgement of ye reader.

Euſebius reciteth a very elegant hiſtory out of Clemēs Alexādrinus, concerning Iohn. Clement (ſaith he) doth both note the time, and alſo declare the hiſtory, being moſt neceſſary for all ſuch as are delighted with honeſt and profitable matters, which hiſtory Sozomenus alſo toucheth in his commentary. The words of Euſebius, are theſe. Heare a fable, and not a fable, but rather a true hiſtorie which is written of Iohn the Apoſtle, and left to be read of the poſteritie. The hiſtory is this: VVhen Iohn returned from the Ilande Pathmos, vnto Epheſus after the death of the tyraunt Domitian, he went, being requeſted, vnto ſuch places and countries as lay nigh about Epheſus, partly that he might conſtitute & order Biſhops, partly that he might ſet in an order the Churches, and partly yt he might chuſe the clergie by lot, out of the nūber of ſuch as wer appointed by the holy ghoſt. At what tyme therfore he came vnto a certaine citie not farre diſtant frō Epheſus, (whoſe name alſo ſome do rehearſe) and when among other things he had comforted his brethrē, turning his countenaunce vnto him that was appointed head and Biſhop ouer ye reſt, ſeing a certaine yonge man there being of a ſtrong body, a comlie face, & of a feruent mind, I commit this yong man (ſayth he) moſt earneſtly vnto the, here before Chriſt and this congregation. VVhen the Biſhop had receiued him, promiſing him all diligence and endeuour, Iohn ſpeaking after the ſame maner, requeſted him againe ye ſecond time. Thē afterward he returned vnto Epheſus. But the Biſhop had this yong man home into his houſe, and kept him & brought him vp, and wonne him vnto ye knowledge and light of the Goſpell: and at the laſt he was Baptized, and became a Chriſtian. But when the ſaid Paſtor became ouer gentle and remiſſe vnto him, he ſuffred this yong man to vſe the companie of idle and diſſolute and naughty perſons, to his great hurte and deſtruction, who
firſt led him vnto ſumptuous bāketting & feaſting, and afterward they toke him with thē to robbe and to ſteale in the night. After this, they entiſed him to attēpt more heynous and greater actes, he being accuſtomed a litle & litle, & trayned in naughtines according to his ſtoute courage, like a couragious horſe and vntamed colte, hauing hys mouth hardened, gnawing vpon the bitte, and leauing the right way, was caried headlong toward hel more & more. At the last diſpairing of his ſaluatiō in Christ, he toke in hād no ſmall entrepriſes. And becauſe he had once periſhed, he thought to commit ſome great and notorious thyng, diſdaining to haue equall lot with his fellowes. Calling therfore his cōpanions vnto him, and gathering together a great cōpany and rablement of theues, he became a capitaine and head ouer thē, and began to be most cruell and moſt addict vnto manſlaughter. It chaunced in the meane tyme, that through vrgēt and neceſſary buſines, the congregation of Epheſus, ſent for Iohn. VVho when he had ended ſuch matters, wherfore he came to them, ſayd to the Biſhop. Go to, go to, rendre agayne to vs that thing which Chriſt and I committed to thy charge, in the preſence of the cōgregatiō, wherof thou art Paſtour and ruler. The Biſhop firſt of all was abaſhed, thyncking that certayne mony which he had not receiued, ſhould be demaunded of him, and he could not aunſwere for ſuch thinges, whiche he had not, and yet did not diſcredit Iohns wordes. But when Iohn had ſayd, I require againe the yong mā & the ſoule of my brother, the Biſhop bowing down his countenaunce, with ſighing and teares aunſwered, he truly is dead. Iohn demaunded how, and of what death. He ſayd he is dead vnto God, for he became an euell and a pernitious man, and in the ende he became a theefe and a common robber, and now of late hath he remayned with hys like companions in this hell againſt the Churche. The Apostle therfore hearing theſe words, rent his clothes, and with great lamentation ſmote him ſelfe vpon the head, ſaying. I haue left a good keper of my brothers ſoule, let me haue a horſe & one to conduct me in the way: And ſo taking his horſe, he made as much haſt out of the congregation as might be. And when he came to the appointed place, he was taken of the ſcoute watches of the theues, & neither flieng nor refuſing, cried, ſaying. I am come for this purpoſe, lead me vnto your Lord and maſter, who in the meane time looked for his pray all armed. Aſſone as he knew that it was Iohn that was brought, being aſhamed, fled away. Olde Saint Iohn followed with all his might, forgetting his great age, and cried vnto him. O my ſonne, why flieſt thou from me, why flieſt thou from thy father, a naked & old man, haue pitie vpon me my ſonne, feare not, thou haſt yet ſome hope of ſaluation. I will rendre vnto Chriſt • an accoumpt for thee, yea if nede be,
I wil dye for the, euen as Chriſt died for vs. I wil geue my life for thee, beleue me, Chriſt ſent me vnto thee. VVhen he harde theſe thinges. Firſt he ſtoode ſtill: but with a ſad and heauy countenaunce, afterward he threw away his harneſſe, and forthwith trembled and wept full bitterly. He embraced Iohn when he came vnto him, and aunſwering with weping as wel as he could, was Baptized againe with teares, hauing his right hand onely hidden and couered. The Apoſtle when he had promiſed him, and had proteſted yt he would obtaine remiſsion of his ſinnes, and had prayed & fallē vpon his knees, and had kiſſed his right hand, as purged again by repentaunce, he reduced him againe vnto the Churche. And after he had prayed for him with continuall interceſsion, and had ſtriued with continuall faſtings, and had quieted and confirmed his minde with comfortable ſayinges, he went not from him (as they ſay) vntill he had fully reſtored him vnto the Churche. And ſo gaue a goodly example of true repentaunce, and a great experiment of regeneration, and a noble badge of the viſible reſurrection.

Irenaeus, doth recite a ſtory worthy memorie:Lib. 3. cap. 3. there be (ſaith he) which hard Policarpus, ſay, yt Iohn the diſciple of the Lord goyng to be bathed at Epheſus, when he ſaw Cerinthus within, did leape out of the bathe vnwaſhed ſaying, that he did feare, leaſt the bath would fall downe vpon them, foraſmuch as Cerinthus, the enemie of truth, was wtin the houſe.
Finally of the death of Iohn there is no certainty. Saint Hierome doth ſay, that in the .68. yeares after the death of Chriſt, he died at Epheſus, and was buried by the ſaid Citie.

Other do write, that Iohn went downe aliue into the graue, whiche he cōmaunded his diſciples to make, and ſo bad thē to couer him with earth, whiche being done, there appeared out of the graue a very great brightnes, and manna alſo flowed out of it. But when theſe things cannot be certaynly proued, they muſt be left to them which loue to read Legendes.

Some ſuppoſe, that young man which folowed Chriſt and was clothed in linen vpon his bare body, (and whom when the yong men would haue taught,Marke, 14. S. Marke doth write to haue left his linen cloth and fled from thē naked) to be Iohn the Euangeliſte. Other do ſay, that it was Iames, the brother of the Lord, which was named Iuſtus, and who after the Aſcenſion of Chriſt was made Biſhop of Hieruſalem, but it is an opinion voyde of reaſon to thincke, hym to be Iohn, for what nede was it to conceale hys name, when that the fall of Peter, being more fowle and greater, was openly declared. Furthermore Iohn did folow Chriſt ſtrayght waye when he was taken, and did helpe Peter to entre into the Biſhops palace, and how could he haue his clothes ſo ſone again, for aſmuch as he was a ſtraū ger
at Hieruſalem. Agayne the name of a yonge man did not agree vnto Iohn, for he was almoſt of the ſame age with Chriſt. Furthermore Iohn fled with all the other Apoſtles (as Saint Marke ſayth) Diſcipuli eius relinquentes eum, omnes fugerunt. All his diſciples leauyng him, did flye. Others do ſay, that he was a young man of the ſame houſe, in the whiche Chriſt kept his paſſeouer. Other do coniecture, that it was a certayne younge man of the village of Ieſſemanie, or of ſome other houſe more nygh adioyning, in whoſe large orcharde Chriſt was with his diſples. But let euerie man haue his ſentence. It maketh no great force who it was. But the holy Ghoſt woulde haue this example to be teſtified, that he myght ſhewe with what furie and rage the enemies did flee vppon Chriſte, and that the miracles myght be more cleare, by the whiche he preſerued hys Diſciples that they ſhoulde ſuffer no hurte of theyr enemies, for when the rage was ſo great, that they layde their handes vpon an vnknowen ladde, who will doubte but that all his diſciples were preſerued by the hande and power of Chriſte? foraſmuche ſpecially as Peter by his fighting did prouoke the enemyes before. And here is left vnto vs, a document, that perſecution once begon, doth ſpare none, but is fierce and cruell againſt all, without exception, agaynſt hygh and lowe, yong and olde, ſparyng no ſexe, man, woman, childe or infant.

div.head: Hyperbole. 27.
div.p: HYperbole is a trope in Rhethorique, and it is a worde or a ſentence that paſſeth mans fayth and credit: and it is ſpoken either to augment a thyng, or to diminiſhe it. To augment, as this: Eſt fulminis oty or alis. Swifter then the wynges of the lyghtnyng. Niue candidior. VVhiter then ſnowe. To diminiſhe, as this: Eſt tardior teſtudine. He is ſlower thē any ſnaile. Vix oſsibus heret. The ſkinne ſcarſe cleaueth to the bones. To augment alſo. Ieremie. 31. Ad caelum vſque peruenit. It came vp to heauen. Lykewyſe. Geneſis. 15. faciam ſemen tuum ſicut puluerem terrae. I will multiplie thy ſeede as the duſte of the earth. And in Iohns Goſpell the laſte Chapter: there are alſo many other thynges whiche Ieſus did, the whiche if they ſhould be written euerye one, I ſuppoſe the worlde coulde not contayne the bookes that ſhoulde be written. To diminiſhe, as in Leuiticus .26. Terrebit te ſonitus folii volantis. The ſounde of a leafe that falleth ſhall make thee afrayde. And many other ſentences in the holy Scriptures, are full of Hyperboles.

div.head: A moſt ſure worde. 28.
div.p: HAbemus firmiorem ſermonem Propheticum, 2. Pet. 1. we haue a moſt ſure worde of the Prophetes. The teſtimonie of the father from heauen when he ſayd. Hic eſt filius meus dilectus, Math. 3. Mat. 17. this is my beloued ſonne, in whom is my pleaſure, heare him. But as yet all did not beleue the Euangelicall hiſtorie, nor the preaching of the Apoſtles. Therfore for their cauſe Peter teacheth the certeyntie of the Goſpell, to haue his foundation in the oracles of ye Prophets. For the doctrine of the Prophetes was verie familiar vnto the Iewes, and for that cauſe he calleth it a more ſure worde. Peter doth vſe here more teſtimonies to proue the veritie of the Goſpell. Firſt, that Chriſte was approued and affirmed to be God, by the magnificent voyce of the father from heauen. Secondly that all the oracles and ſayinges of the Prophetes doe tende to that ende (as Paule writeth) quod (inquit) promiſerat per Prophaetas ſuos in Scripturis ſanctis. Rom 1. That (ſayth Paule) which be promiſed by the Prophetes in the holy Scriptures.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: It ſemeth verie obſurde, that Peter doth call the ſayinges of the Prophetes more firme, then the voyce pronounced by the verie mouth of God. Firſt foraſmuch as the authoritie of the word hath bene all one from the beginnyng. Agayne the worde was more confirmed by the comming of Chriſt.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p:
Peter here hath a reſpecte vnto his countrie men, and to their nation, whiche were accuſtomed and nouſled in the Prophetes, of whoſe doctrine they had no doubt, but to be infallible and moſte true. VVherfore when the Iewes were perſuaded that whatſoeuer was written in the Prophets, did come frō the Lord, it is no maruell that Peter ſayd, we haue a more ſure word. In the whiche words this is no queſtion to be moued. VVhether the Prophets deſerued more fayth and credite, then the doctrine of the Goſpell, but Peter in ſpeakyng theſe wordes, had a reſpect onely what reuerence, honour, and credite the Iewes gaue to the Prophetes. In whoſe ſtudye the Iewes are brought vp euen from theyr childhoode. In fine, Peter calleth it a more firme worde, for their ſakes whiche were infirme and weake in the fayth, to make the texte playne. Becauſe there were many, whiche as yet gaue no credit to the Goſpell, and to the preaching of the Apoſtles. Peter willing and wiſhing to allure and driue them to the light of truth, he ſayth, that he preacheth
nothynge, but that whiche was ſhewed before by the Prophetes. As though he ſhould ſay, that which we ſpeake of the diuinitie of Chriſt, the Prophetes ſpake the ſame (As Dauid writeth in his Pſalmes.Pſal. 2.) Dominus dixit ad me, filius meus es tu, ego hodie genui te. The Lord hath ſayd vnto me: Thou art my ſonne, this day haue I begotten thee. Agayne. Ex vtero ante luciferum genui te. Pſal. 110. Therfore Peter calleth it a more ſure worde, for their cauſe, whiche were not yet confirmed in the fayth, and which were newly conuerted from the Iudaicall religion vnto Chriſtianitie, and who alſo were wholly bent to the Prophetes and to the ſtudy of them. And not that Peter doth by theſe wordes preferre the teſtimomonie of the Prophetes before the teſtimonie of God ſpoken from heauen: but that he myght the better receyue them into the faith, he doth allowe and commende their diligent ſtudie in the Prophets, and ſo calleth it a more ſure worde, not bycauſe it was ſo Simpliciter, but bycauſe the Iewes ſo counted it. VVhere ſome do ſay that the comparative is put here for the poſitiue, they do not thoroughly expounde the texte and circumſtaunce therof.

div.head: Priuate interpretation. 29.
div.p: THere may be two ſenſes and meaninges of theſe wordes. For this Greke woorde 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , doth ſignifie aſwell violent entraunce, as an interpretatiō. And in yt ſenſe doth ye moſt part take theſe wordes: That is, that we ought not to runne raſhly to the readyng of the Scriptures, brynging nothing with vs, but onely our owne ſenſe and meanyng, for the Scriptures are not to be expounded after euery mans luſte and phantaſie, but as the holy Ghoſt doth require, whiche inſpired the Prophetes, whiche ſpirite is the onely one interpreter of himſelfe in the Scriptures, and that expoſition doth conteyne moſt true, moſt godly, and moſt aboundaunt doctrine, when we leauyng our owne iudgementes, do ſubmitte our ſelues to the teachyng and expoſition of the holy Ghoſt. On the other ſide, it is a moſt wicked prophanation of the Scriptures, when we arrogantly thruſt our ſelues in, to vnderſtand the Scripture by our owne wiſedome and our owne reaſon: for the Scriptures do conteyne hygh miſteryes of God, hidden and vnknowen vnto our heades. Yea it doth conteyne the noble treaſures of life, farre paſsing our capacitie.

Here maye we learne, that the proper and priuate interpretations
of the fathers are conuelled and quite ouerthrowne, and we be forbidden to truſte and to leane to ſuche expoſitions. If Sainte Hierome, Saint Auſten, or any other of the fathers do expounde the Scriptures of themſelues or by their owne heades, we muſt refuſe their interpretation. For Sainte Peter doth here forbidde, any man to expounde the Scriptures by hys owne ſpirite. The true expoſition is propre, onely to the ſpirite of God. VVherefore, if any of the fathers can ſhewe hys enarrations, aptely to be taken out of any part of the Scriptures, which doe allowe the place by hym expounded to be ſo expounded in dede, we ought to embrace his interpretation, otherwiſe to geue no credit vnto hym nor his expoſitions.

The Papiſtes here do ſhewe themſelues to be twiſe fooliſhe and ignoraunt, when they gather out of this place, that the interpretatation of one priuate man ought not to be taken as auctenticall, but the interpretation of manie, and eſpecially of generall Councelles ought to be receyued (ſaye they.) In this they be childiſhely deceyued: for Peter here doth not call a priuate interpretation, the expoſition of one priuate man, but doth teache, that whatſoeuer commeth from manne or menne, fewe or manye, if they brynge nothyng but their owne iudgemente, to be prophane, and ought not to be receyued. Therefore if all the whole worlde ſhoulde conſpire together, and all their wyttes were layde together in one head, yet whatſoeuer ſhall come onelye from them, Sainte Peter doth counte it nothynge but proper and priuate. For the Prophetes and other holye menne of God beyng inſpired of the holy Ghoſt, dyd wryte and ſpeake that whiche they vttered. VVithout the whiche ſpirite, whatſoeuer one or manye doe brynge, is nothynge elles but priuate, (that is to ſaye) theyr owne imaginations.

To make it playne, Saint Peter here doth put downe the pride of certeine vaine men, and ſpecially of the Iewes, who flattering them ſelues with the perſuaſion of great readyng and much learnyng, thought they might interprete the Scriptures as pleaſed them. God forbidde (ſayth Peter,) for then were the gifte of Prophecie, comming from the holy ghoſt, in vaine, which prophecie is ſo to be expoūded, as the holy ghoſt doth inſpire, and not by priuate interpretation of any other whatſoeuer they be, and how many ſoeuer they be.

Other learned men do expounde this place of priuate interpretation, to be nothyng els but that the holy Scriptures were not geuen by man, nor by the power of man, but by the holy ghoſt, as Peter ſayth after in
the ſame place, and when we read them, we must be fully reſolued that god ſpeaketh vnto vs, & not mā. To end, Peter therfore doth bidde, that faith and credit ſhould be geuen vnto the Prophetes, as to the infallible oracles of God, and not as comming and flowing out of the proper motion of men.

div.head: Timotheus. 30.
div.p:
TImotheus Saint Paules dearling, hauyng one of Grece to his father, and a mother of the nomber of the faythfull, whoſe name was Eunica, was borne at Lyſtris, a towne in Lycaonia,2. Timo. 1. where Paule found hym, beyng then a younge man and ſomewhat ſickely, he was verie well learned and brought vp in the holy Scriptures from his childehoode.Act. 16. And therefore Paule tooke him with him,1. Tim. 4. 1. Tim. 5. to be a mete companion and felowe for hym, and did firſt circumciſe hym: that the Iewes who there knewe him to be borne of an hethenyſhe father, ſhould not be offended, and that he might alſo with more frute haue ye function of the miniſterie, for Paul (willing to winne, as much as lay in him, all vnto Chriſt) became a Gentile to the Gentiles, and a Iewe to the Iewes, and ſo Paule hauing obtayned Timothie to be his felow Miniſter, did in proceſſe of tyme ſo loue him, that he counted no man more deare or precious vnto him, and therfore he calleth him Timothie my welbeloued ſonne, faithfull in the Lord. And in many of his Epiſtles he doth greatly commend him, for the ſinguler and rare giftes that were in him, as for the conſtancie of his faith, his integritie and ſoundnes of life, and ſuch other notable vertues and qualities. Paule vſed him his companion in his peregrinations, in his meſſages, and diuerſe and ſondrie other wayes. VVhen Paule was by tumulte caſte out of Theſſalonica, he lefte Timothie there with Sila. And when he came to Athenes, he ſent a commaundement to them both, to repaire vnto him. Timothie iourneing with Sila from Macedonia, found Paule at Corinthe, frō whence he ſent him agayne to Theſſalonica,Act. 7. to comforte the Chriſtian brethren, yt they ſhould not be to much troubled and thoughtfull for hys afflictions and perſecutions.Act. 18. Acte. 19. 1. Theſſ 3. And ſo returnyng from thence, he came to Paule to Corinth, from whence he followed Paule takyng hys iourney towardes Macedonia, euen vnto Aſia, where he was deſired of Paule to ſtaye at Epheſus, where he remayned. And as Euſebius, and Sopronius, and other do write, he was made firſte Biſhop of Epheſus, but after what ſorte and how long he was Paſtor and gouernour of that Church,Act. 20. there is no certeynty to be red in any auncient or approued writter.Lib. 3. cap. 14. And
it cannot be certeynely concluded, that he ſuffred Martirdome, beyng beaten with ſtakes and ſtones to death at Epheſus, bycauſe he repayryng nigh to the porche of the temple of the goddeſſe Diana, did rebuke and reprehende the idolatrie of the Epheſians, whiche many do affirme to be ſo, as Antoninus, and Vincentius. Henricus de Erfordia do write,Lib. 38. cap. 10. that he was ſlayne vnder Nerua. Nicephorus ſayth,Lib 3. cap. 71. that he ſuffred vnder Domitianus. Iacobus Philippus in ſupplemento Chronicorum, doth ſay, that he was martyred at Epheſus, & yet (ſayth he) ſome write, yt he ſuffered vnder Nero, and yt vnto hym appeared two Aungels, when he was in tormentes ſpeaking vnto him. Erige caput in caelū & vide. Lift vp thy head to heauē and ſee, who ſo diong, ſawe ye heauens opē, and Ieſus holdyng a Crowne of precious ſtone, and ſaying vnto him: this ſhalt yu receiue of my hands. VVhich thing whē one Apollinaris ſaw, did cauſe him ſelf to be Baptized, and that the Liuetenaunt cauſed both of them, perſiſtyng in the Confeſsion of Chriſte, to be beheadded. Vnto this Timothie, Paule wrote two Epiſtles from Laodicea, whiche are extant in the new Teſtament.

div.head: Titus. 31.
div.p:
TItus lykewiſe was the diſciple of Paule. Euſebius, writeth and Sophronius alſo, that Titus, Lib. 3. cap. 4. was made firſt of Saint Paule Biſhop of Carthage. He was alſo Biſhop of Creta, where he died, and was buried. But when Paule was captiue at Rome the ſecond tyme, Titus went into Dalmatia, as Paule writeth in his Epiſtle to Timothie. Vnto this Titus, 2. Tim. 4. Paule wrote one worthy Epiſtle frō Nicopolis. Paule maketh mention of Tite, in the Epiſtle ſent to the Galathians, his wordes be theſe: Neither yet Titus, Galat. 2. whiche was with me, though he were a Grecian, was compelled to be circumciſed. The cauſe why he would not circumciſe him, he rendreth in the ſame place, ſaying bycauſe of the falſe brethren that crepte in, who came in priuily to ſpie out our libertie, which we haue in Chriſt Ieſus, to bryng vs into bondage. Circumciſion being a thing then counted indifferent, was thought either to be vſed, or omitted, as edification myght riſe therof: And this rule is alwayes to be reſpected, that all thinges are lawfull, yet all thinges are not expedient. Paule therfore circumciſed Timothie, leaſt he ſhould haue geuen an offence vnto the infirme and weake brethren. And than he was conuerſaunt and remayned amongeſt the weake, to whom he ought to geue place for a tyme. And he might haue done the like in Titus, but the ſtate and condition was diuerſe from the other, for certayne falſe brethren were there alwayes in a redynes, to ſlaunder him and his doctrine, and would haue ſayd: Beholde this bolde marchaunt
Paule, whiche is ſo ſtoute a chalenger of libertie, when he once commeth into ye preſence of ye Apoſtles, he is ſore quayled, and putteth downe hys ſtoutnes. And note here, that when Saint Paule denieth Tite to be circumciſed, by reaſon of the falſe brethren, the wordes may be taken two maner of wayes. The firſt is this: They that owe no good will vnto my preachyng, could not obtayne at my hande, that I woulde circumciſe Titus beyng a gentile, no not amonge the Iewes, whiche were conuerted vnto Chriſt And this did I to defende my libertie agaynſt them, whiche thought and taught that circumciſion was neceſſary to ſaluation.

The ſeconde ſenſe and meaning is, this Paule, of a ſet purpoſe would not circumciſe Titus: for he knewe, that certayne thruſt them ſelues into his company, either to get him enemies among the Iewes, if he would frely diſpiſe their ceremonies, or els if he had wholly refrayned from the Christian libertie, than they would haue triumphed agaynſt hym among the Gentiles, as agaynſt one that beyng confuſed, had retracted and reuoked his former doctrine. Therfore as ſometyme we muſt beare with the weake in the beginnyng, ſo ought we alſo ſtoutlye to defende the chriſtian libertie againſt the wicked, who will make a thing of no importaunce neceſſary to ſaluation. Here may be diſcourſed the doctrine of ſcandalum datum, & ſcandalum acceptum, but that I wyll deferre vnto an other tyme.

div.head: Agrapha.
div.p: AGrapha, be called properly vnwritten verities, which be moſt learnedly and pithely anſwered, by the moſt excellent, prudēt, graue, and wiſe counſeller, the Archbiſhop of Canturburye, who of late ſealed the truth of Chriſtes Goſpell with his bloud. He made a lytle boke, which anſwereth vnto the enemies, concerning vnwritten verities, wher you ſhal rede not onely ye authorityes of ſcriptures & learned fathers againſt vnwritten verities, as things neceſſary to ſaluacion: but alſo anſwers and ſolutions to euery obiection. As for Baſilius Magnus, who ſemeth to make equiuolent the traditions of the Church, wyth the written woorde of God, you muſte haue a reſpecte when the fathers write 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is, to aſſerte any doctrine, and when they write 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is, when they fight agaynſt heretikes for then they be verie vehement, and do vrge both vnwritten and written verities, to impugne the heretikes, and to conuince them, as Baſilius doth in this place, agaynſt that deteſtable heretike Enomius, which denied the holy ghoſt to be God. That the Scriptures onely are ſufficient to ſaluation, I haue touched it largely before.

div.head: Irenaeus. 35.
div.p: EVſebius among all other that liued in his time, gaue ye firſt place & price vnto the great learned father Irenaeus. For when there were at that tyme moe monumentes, and other infallible teſtimonies of the ſaid Irenaeus in the handes of the godly and learned, then are now had or may be had: who could geue a more certayne iudgement of Irenaeus doings, then Euſebius, aboue all other that followed him?

Of what parentes, or in what place he was borne, it is vncertayne, yet I will ſhew you hereafter the coniectures of certayne learned men. In his youth he was conuerſaunt in the ſchoole of Policarpus, who was Biſhop of Smirna, and one of the diſciples of Iohn the Euangeliſt. He heard this reuerend, graue, and godly man with ſo great admiration and attention, that he moſt depely engraued in his breſt Policarpus doctrine, and what ſoeuer he receiued of him, kept it in a moſt liuely memorie, vntill he came to extreme age. VVherupon ſome write that Ireneus did deſcribe & ſet forth, euen as he ſaw with his own eyes, the geſtures of Policarpus, and did declare wt what things, and with what words he was wont to reaſon.

Of thys, coniecture may be made, that Irenaeus was an Aſian borne, & not farre from Smyrna. To this opinion is much agreable that a Greeke name was geuen vnto him: for this word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ſignifieth pacem and thys word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 betokeneth pacificum. And as good lucke is ſometimes the inſetting of names, ſo the euent and ſucceſſe did proue in Ireneus, for he was moſt ſtudious of peace and tranquility in the church of Chriſt. But let it be that he was borne in Europa, it is the more to be marueiled by what meanes he came into Polycarpus ſchole. He ſo paſſed ouer the ſtudies of his youth, that he knew al liberal artes, beſide chriſtian piety: for theſe ſubtill and moſt conſtant diſputations which he had againſt hereſies, doth manifeſtly declare that he was not rude nor ignoraunt of prophane artes, for the monſtrous opinions of heretickes, were builded vpon the foundacion of prophane Philoſophers, of the which opinions to iudge ſo exactly, and to confute with ſuch arte and ſtrong argument, he could not haue done, vnleſſe he had bene very expert in prophane ſtudies. Nor it is without cauſe, that Tertullian did beautify him with his praiſe, ſaying, that he was a moſt curious ſearcher of al doctrines, but ſpecially dyd employ his diligence and labour in the knowledge of Chriſtes doctrine, and did chiefly adioyne himſelfe vnto the company of them, who are adourned with the ſingular giftes of the doctrine of the Goſpel.

He exerciſed the function of prieſthod in the church of Lions, which is a notable city, and noble Marte in Fraunce, in which place wythout
doubt he did moſt ſincerely, and with ſingular dexterity, expounde the ſcriptures. He liued moſt familiarlye with one Photinus, a reuerende, graue, and conſtant father.
But perchaunce ſome deſire more to haue the knowledge of his publicke factes and doinges.

The church of Aſia was much vexed, as it were with inteſtine & ciuill warre, when Montanus, Alcibiades, and Theodotus, did moleſt the ſound doctrine of the Goſpel, with their new prophecies, and vayne fantaſies. For theſe fantaſticall ſpirits, did marueilouſly bewitch the mindes of men, and wrapped them in great errors. The French church therfore, being moued with a certayne louyng zeale towarde the brethren of the church of Aſia, did ſend their iudgement of the doctrine of their falſe prophets, vnto the churches which were in Aſia and Phrigia, and did communicate their helping hands, againſt the corrupters of the Goſpel. That this legacy ſhould be the more honeſt and fruitfull, they perſwaded Ireneus, that he as a meſſenger would cary their letters in ſo great a iourney, and that he would alſo comfort with his own voice, the afflicted & troubled churches, and confirme them in the truth already knowen, and manfully confute the errors of theſe heretickes. In this iourney Ireneus paſſed by Rome, and ſaluted the biſhop ther, he had letters alſo from the French churches, by the which he was honorably commended vnto Elutherius then biſhop ther: the copy of which letters, Euſebius doth record. The tenor wherof here followeth.Lil. 5. cap. 4, Salutem tibi in omnibus ac ſemper per deum optamus (pater Elutheri) Irenaeum fratrem ac conſortem noſtrum ad hortati ſumus, vt has ad te literas perferret, vt hunc teſtamenti Chriſti ſtudioſum, commendatum habeas obſecramus. Etenim ſi gradū cuiquā iuſtitiam conferre, atque aſſerere ſciremus vtpote, quod eccleſiae preſbiter ſit, qui et hic eſt: hoc in eo ſanc cumprimis commendaſſemus. VVe greete and wiſh you wel, in all things, and at all times through god (O father Elutherius) we haue exhorted our brother & felow Ireneus to bring vnto thee theſe letters, whom we beſech thee gentlye to entertayne, as one moſt ſtudious of Chriſtes teſtament. &c.
Theſe words are alledged out of that Epiſtle, which doubtles was longer, and comprehended more things, which if they were extant, would make very much for this preſent purpoſe.

VVhen Photinus was murthered for the confeſsion of the euangelicall truth, Irenaeus was choſen in his roume, who ſo ruled this church and did inſtructe it with ſuch doctrine and integritie of life, that he was beloued & worſhipped both of his own countrymen, & alſo of ſtraūgers. He had great conflictes with a great number of heretikes, but ſpecially with the Valentinians, agaynſt whom he wrote a notable booke which is nowe
extant. He had alſo an action againſt Victor then Biſhop of Rome, the cauſe was this. The controuerſy for keping of Eaſter day, which was before moued, began now to waxe hot, & broke out at this time into a manifeſt ſciſme, & there was throwne as it were an apple of contention, betwene the two churches, the eaſt and the weſt. For the eaſt church was fully reſolued to kepe their liberty and old cuſtome concerning the Eaſter, and refuſed in any wiſe the yoke of al ceremonial obſeruations, whervpon Victor being moued, did excommunicate all Churches diſſenting from the church of Rome. And although the paſtors in Aſia did teach by moſt weighty arguments, that they could not depart from their cuſtome receiued of the Apoſtles them ſelues, yet they did litle preuail therwith. Ireneus therfore with his brethren of the French churches, not thinking it good to behold this lamentable contention in the church of Chriſt, gathered, as it may be coniectured, a counſell, in the which they made letters, & ſubſcribing them with their own hands, ſent them to Victor the biſhop of Rome, hauing good hope that they ſhould mitigate and breake the rage of Victor, and ſo bring tranquility into the church againe. As touching the ſentence of the feaſt of Eaſter, to be kept vpon the Sonday, they approued Victors minde and iudgement, as pertayning to the weſt church: but that he ſhould not alienate or chaunge other churches, obſeruing the cuſtome of their old tradition, they did exhorte him with many profound arguments. He had in his writings certaine ſpots, whereby he was noted and ſuſpected, not to be of a moſt ſound iudgement. Firſt he ſemed not playnly to make a difference betwene verbum ſubſtantiale, that is Chriſt, & verbum vocale. Secondly, he ſemed to iudge, that man in the beginning was not made perfect, and that ſentence which was ſpoken of man to be made after the image of God, to be ſpoken of Chriſt. Thirdly, he doth geue vnto man free wyl, in cauſes ſpirituall. Fourthly, he ſayth that Chriſt was baptized in the thirty yeare of his age, and to haue begone his preaching at the age of forty, and ſuffered his paſsion at the age of fifty, and doth relate that the Elders of Aſia, did learne this of Iohn.Lib. 2. cap. 40 &. 43. Finally, the errours of ye Millinaries is imputed vnto Ireneus, but theſe things cannot be gathered expreſly out of his bookes. To ende, how he dyed, it is not noted in approued authours.

Henricus de Herfordia, Ado, and others, which did write the lyfe of Martirs, do ſay that he was moſt cruelly ſlayne with a great multitude of the Church, for the confeſsion of Chriſt, vnder Seuerus the Emperour of Rome.

div.head: Paralogiſmos. 36.
div.p:
PAralogiſmos, cōmeth of this verbe 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which ſignifieth
to deceiue with falſe and crafty reaſons and argumentes, and to diſpute with captious concluſions. The Logitians call ſuch kinde of argumentes, Paralogiſmos, or Elenchos. Ariſtotle termeth thē modos ſophiſticos, they be called alſo impoſturae, fraudes, ſophiſmata, and they be called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .

Paralogiſmi, be deuided of the Logicians into two lymmes. Some be Paralogiſmi, in dictione, and ſome extra dictionem. You maye ſeeke the examples of the Logitians, who do moſt plainly ſet them forth. Yet for the ignorauntes ſake, I wyll geue you onely two of them.

q.l: Omnes gemmae ſunt precioſilapides,
In palmitibus inueniuntur gemmae:
Igitur in palmitibus ſunt ptecioſi lapides.

div.p:
This argument is
Paralogiſmus in dictione. Agayne.
Anacharſis eſt albus.
Anacharſis eſt philoſophus:
Ergo Anacharſis eſt albus philoſophus.

div.head: Chriſoſtomus. 38.
div.p: IOhannes Chriſoſtomus was borne at Antioche, at the riuer Orō tes in Coeleſiria. He came of a noble houſe, hauing to his father one named Secundus,Lib. 6. cap. 3. Lib. 8. cap. 2. Lib. 13, cap. 2. and to his mother one Anchuſa, as Socrates, Sozomenus, and Nicephorus do write. He learned Rhethoricke of his ſcholemaſter Libanius, & Philoſophy of Andragathius. At the age of 18. yeares he went vnto the vniuerſitye of Athens, where he profited ſo much,Georg. de vita Chriſoſt. that all men wondred at it. He was honored of the ſenate for his humility, aboue Anthemius, and the reſt of the Philoſophers.

Lib. 8. cap. 2.Hetherto he ſemeth to haue bene an Ethnicke, for Sozomenus ſaith that Libanius whē he died, complained that Chriſoſtome was taken away as a pray of the chriſtians from him, otherwiſe he might well haue taught his ſchole after him.Georg. in vita cius. He was conuerted and baptiſed by Meleſius at one time, with his father and mother: he was metely wel expert in the knowledge of the law, and woulde haue bene verye profitable in iudgements, but fearing the moleſtation of that profeſsion, did chuſe to hymſelfe an eccleſiaſtical kind of life, and changing his habite, did apply hys minde to the reading of the holy ſcriptures, hauing to his maiſters Diodorus & Cartherius, his fellow diſciples were Theodorus and Maximus, which were his companions, vnder Libanius his ſcholmaſter. He was alſo very familiar with Baſilius byſhoppe of Ceſarea in Capadocia, whom he vſed alſo as his ſcholemaſter. Suidas doth ſay, that Euſebius Emiſſenus was alſo his ſcholemaſter.

Zenon biſhop of Gaza, when he was returned from Hieruſalem, did conſtitute Chriſoſtome a Reader at the church of Antioche. After that
he was ordeined Deacon of Meleſius, in the which office he remayned almoſt three yeares. VVhen Meleſius was dead,Socra. Lib. 6. cap. 3. he was ordayned Prieſt of Euagrius.

Nicephorus doth report,Lib. 13. cap. 2, that he was made Deacon and Prieſt of one Flauianus, and maketh relation of the miracle of the Doue, which came fliyng, and did ſit vpon his head. And Georgius doth triflingly ſhew, beſides the apparition of the Doue, that the aungell commaunded Flauianus to fetch Iohn Chriſoſtome out of the Monaſterye, and to make hym Prieſt. He ſheweth alſo a fable, how Chriſoſtome did ſee Heſichium in his dreame, and that Iohn the Apoſtle dyd deliuer to him a booke, and how Peter brought him the keyes.

VVhen Nectarius was dead, Chriſoſtome was choſen biſhop of Conſtantinople, by the commaundement of Arcadius,Theodoretus Lib. 5. cap. 28. Sozom. Li 8. cap. 2. and by the conſents & voices, both of the people, and of the clergie. He was had away by the Emperour from Antioche, againſt the inhabitantes will, and was ordeyned byſhop, by a counſel aſsembled together very ſolemnely.

He was endewed with ſingular gifts: for beſides the knowledge of liberal ſciences, of philoſophy, and of the toungs, he was very excellentlye ſene in the holy ſcriptures. He was very apt and ready to teach, and in his words he had a marueilous faculty to perſwade. He was ſo eloquent, that this name Chriſoſtome was geuen to him, which betokeneth golden mouth. He was of a ſtout and conſtant minde. Some ſay that he had the gift to heale all maner of diſeaſes. In the adminiſtracion of his biſhoprick he behaued him ſelf very faithfull, conſtant, and like a vigilant Miniſter of Chriſt. He preached often, and in his preaching did apply him ſelfe to the capacity of his auditours and hearers. He rebuked ſynne ſo ſharply, as though he had ſuſtained ſome iniury himſelf. And cauſed them whych wer gilty in conſcience, to breake forth oftentimes into teares and weeping. He did not onely touch the faultes of the common people,Sozo. Lib. 8. cap. 16. but the ſinnes of all ſortes, with great liberty of toung. He reprehended ye diſorders of ye empreſſe,Nicepho Li. 13. cap. 13. and did exhort her to reſtore againe ye vineyard which ſhe had takē away frō Calitropa. He did exhort al perſons to repentance, & did comfort ſo greatly the doubtfull and diſmayed conſciēces,Socra. Lib. 6. cap 21. yt he promiſed pardon and forgeuenes, to thoſe that fel and ſynned, yea although it were a thouſand tymes.

He did inſtitute and ordaine praiers to be ſayd in the night agaynſt the Arrians. If he perceaued any vnworthy of the office of prieſthoode, either through ignoraunce or filthines of life, he depoſed them, and dyd ſubſtitute others more mete and worthye. He did profitte the church not onely by his voyce, but alſo by his writing. VVhen he was but a reader, he
wrote a boke againſt the Iewes, and certaine homelies De vita monaſtica. VVhen he was Deacon, he made bookes and certain dialoges of prieſthood, and three bookes Ad Stagirium Daemoniacum. VVhen he was prieſt, he made many commentaries and expoſitions vpon many bookes of the ſcripture,Niceph. lib. 13. cap. 2. as vpon Geneſis and other bookes of the old teſtament, vpon the Goſpels,Socra. Lib 6. cap 4. vpon the pſalmes. &c. VVhen he was biſhop, he made many notable ſermōs, partly writtē of himſelf, partly of certain notaries.

Al his workes which are now extant, are digeſted into fiue tomes. In the firſt tome are contained the commentaries which he wrote vpon the old teſtament. In the ſecond, the cōmentaries vpon Mathew, Marke, & Luke. In the third, the cōmentaries vpon Iohn, and the actes of the Apoſtles, wherin alſo are certain ſermōs, & certain apologies. In the fourth, the cōmentaries vpon Paules epiſtles. In the fift are contained .80. homelies Ad populum Antiochenum, & .8. epiſtles, with other diuers bookes.
Although he was very ſtudious of tranquility, and a louer of peace, yet when he was biſhop, he was muche moleſted and vexed by falſe brethren, by courtiers, by heretiks, and heathen men.

Concerning falſe brethren, whan he by reaſon of his office, was carefull to amend the maners and life of his Clergie, ſome of them tooke it grieuouſly, and accuſed him of to much auſterity and rigour, and toke an occaſion euery way to ſpeake ill of him. Other ſlaundred him, bicauſe Serapion a Deacon did ſay, that he could not rule them, except he woulde beate them alway with one ſtaffe, wherupon they called him a proud & an ambitious man. They found fault with him alſo, bicauſe he did alwaies eate alone without company, as though he did contemne and loth others. But his aduerſaries did litle preuayle with theſe reproches. For all men had him in much eſtimation and honor, for the ſingular gift of teaching, and it was well knowen, that through his ſickly ſtate, and by the reaſon of the infirmity of his head and ſtomacke,Nicepho Li. 13. cap 9. Socra. Lib. 6. cap. 4. and his great abſtinence, he did eſchew and auoyde all feaſtes and banckets.

He had great contention with one Seuerianus, who in his abſence did much trouble the church, which contention Serapion did ſo muche augment, that Seuerianus was expelled out of the city. For this Serapion did falſly accuſe him, & ſayd yt he did affirme Chriſte not to be made man, when he ment nor ſayd no ſuch thing. For theſe were his woordes: Si Serapion Chriſtianus fuerit mortuus, Chriſtus homo non eſt factus. If Serapion die a chriſten man, then Chriſt is not made man.

He was alſo in contention with one Theophilus, Biſhop of Alexandria, which roſe by this occaſion. VVhen one Dioſcorus, and certayne Monckes, called Longi fratres, came to Conſtantinople to the emperour,
and to Iohn, and had complained of the inurye which Theophilus had done vnto them, Iohn did receiue them honorablye, and did gentlye entertayne them, and did admit them vnto common praiers, yet did he reſtraine them from the Communion, vntil their cauſe ſhoulde be hearde and debated.

VVhē the fame & report of this was brought to Theophilus, and that Iohn alſo had admitted thē to the holi miſteries, Theophilus did craftely imagine, how he might reuenge himſelf of Iohn, & to depoſe him frō his office, which he attempted this way. Theophilus reconciled him ſelf vnto Epiphanius which was before offended with him, and did prouoke & allure him to condemne Origines bookes. Epiphanius not perceiuing this crafty fetch, did obey him, and wrote vnto Iohn, that he alſo woulde abſtayne from the reading of Origines bookes, and that he would cal a counſell, and make a decree therof.

Not long after, Theophilus alſo dyd call a counſell, and condemned the bookes of Origen: but Iohn not regarding the letters of Epiphanius, tooke heede to his owne office and charge. Nowe when they of the Clergye, and of the Emperours court, vnderſtoode what Theophilus went about to compaſſe, they alſo did put their helping handes,Socrat, Lib. 3. cap. 10. and cauſed a counſel to be called to Conſtantinople. A little after Epiphanius came to Conſtantinople, and without the citye did celebrate the ſupper of our Lorde, and ordayned a Deacon: and calling vnto him certaine Biſhoppes, did rehearſe vnto them the condemnacion of Origines bookes. Iohn did inuite and bid him vnto his houſe, but hee aunſwered, he would not come, no not to pray with him, before hee had baniſhed Dioſcorus out of the Citye, and hadde alſo ſubſcribed to the condemnacion of Origines bookes. Iohn on the contrarye ſide ſayde, that nothing ought to bee done raſhlye, before an vniuerſall knowledge might be had therein.

VVhē Epiphanius came abrode openly, and would haue cōdemned Origines bokes, and would haue drawen Dioſcorus out of the citie, and haue accuſed Iohn, Iohn ſent vnto him Serapion, who ſayd theſe words. O Epiphanius, thou dooſt many thinges againſt the Canons. Firſt, for that thou haſt geuen orders in the churches within my iuriſdiction. Secondlye, becauſe thou haſt without my commaundement or ſufferaunce, celebrated the holy miſteries. Finally, bicauſe being gently biddē of me to my houſe, thou diddeſt refuſe. Take hede therfore, leaſt there be a tumult rayſed by the people, and thou alſo be wrapped in the daunger therof.

VVhen Epiphanius heard thys, he went out of the Churche, and as he was goyng, ſayde: Spero te non moriturum Epiſcopum. I hope thou
ſhalt not die a byſhop.Soc, lib. 6 ca. 14 To whom Iohn anſwered, Spero te non ingreſſurū patriam tuam, I hope thou ſhalt not returne into thy country. The euent did approue and verify both their words: for Epiphanius died in the ſhip, before he came home, and Iohn was a litle after depoſed from hys ſee.

Concerning temporal men, and eſpecially them of the court, he ſuſtained many afflictions, and much trouble.
