They were offended wyth hym for no other cauſe, but for that he did ſharply and frely reprehēded their diſordered life. He tooke vp very ſharply, and rebuked Eutropius, lying before the altar, bicauſe when he had cauſed a law to be made, that no fauour ſhould be ſhewed vnto offenders, which did flee to the altar, and yet he himſelfe did couet to vſe that ſame priuiledge, and ſo to ſaue hys life. The nobles of the court tooke theſe words in very il part, & accuſed him to be an vnmercyfull man, and called him 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is ſpitefull and malicious.

Gainas alſo captaine of the hoſt, was much againſt him, and very infenſiue vnto him, bicauſe when Gainas did requeſt before the emperour and certaine biſhops, that one certayne church ſhoulde be aſsigned vnto the Arrians at Conſtantinople, Iohn did plainly and openly ſay, that hys requeſt was wicked, and that the emperour could not without treaſon to Gods houſe, and without abrogation of certaine lawes made of the auncetors, ſuffer any conuenticles of the Arrians within the city, and did embraid alſo Gainas wyth hys country and fliyng from thence,Soc. Lib 6. ca. 5. Sozora. Li. 8, cap. 4. and did obiect vnto him periury.

Eudoxia alſo the Empereſſe, was ſore ſet againſt him, for expelling of Seuerianus out of the City, & did prouoke Epiphanius againſt hym, wherof when Iohn had knowledge, he made a very ſharp ſermon againſt the enormities of womē. His aduerſaries taking hādfaſt of this, brought it to the court, wher all flatterers made an exclamation, that it was vnworthely done of Iohn, and accuſed him as one gilty of treaſon. The Empreſſe her ſelfe made her complaint to the Emperour, that ſhe was very contumeliouſly handled, and requeſted him to haue a regard of her ſtate and calling. VVherupon ye emperour conſentyng, a counſel was aſſembled, in the which Theophilus Alexandrinus and many other, which bare malice vnto Iohn, came to Calcedon, wher Cyrinus the biſhoppe dyd ſpred many reproches & rebukes againſt Iohn, & ſaid, that he was an arogant & proud man, & one that would neither bow nor breake, which words wer receiued of the biſhops, wt great ioy and reioycing. But Iohn refuſing to appeare in that ſynode, & appealing to a general coūſell, was condemned, & ſent into exile into a towne by the ſea ſide, called Hierō. But the multitude & cōmon people,Socrat. Lib. 6. cap. 16. riſing (as it wer) in a tumult, Iohn was called again from exile of the emperour, and reſtored vnto his ſee.

Not long after, when certain enterludes and plaies were practiſed at the ſiluer image of the Empreſſe, which image was ſet by the Church of Sophia, Iohn in his ſermon did reprehend it Eudoxia the empreſſe, deſirous to be reuenged, called againe an other counſel. Then Iohn made opē ly in the church, that homely or ſermon which beginneth thus: Rurſus Herodias inſanit, rurſus turbatur, rurſus ſaltat, rurſus in diſco caput Iohannis accipere quaerit. Herodias againe waxeth mad, againe ſhe is troubled, againe ſhe daunceth, againe ſhe ſeeketh Iohns head in a diſhe. But when the biſhops were come together, he deſired that inquiſition might be made of the crimes obiected againſt him of his aduerſaries: but they neglecting al other things, went about that that was more plauſible and pleaſaunt vnto them, that is to ſaye, they layde to Iohns charge, that after he was depoſed, he entred againe into his biſhopricke, of his own authority, without the ſentence and conſent of any counſell. And although Iohn did reply, that he was reſtored againe of .v. or .vi. biſhoppes, and dyd ſhew that ye canon which they alledged, was a canon of ye Arrians againſt Athanaſius, yet he was condemned and remoued from his miniſtery, and ſo baniſhed at the laſt by the inſtaunce of Seuerianus Porphyrius, and other Byſhoppes of Siria, vnto a place named Pitymita,Sozo Lib. 8. cap. 18. ſituate in the vttermoſt coaſt of all the Romane Empire. And as he was in his iourney going thitherward, and came vnto the ſea called Pontus Euxinus,Socra. Lib. 6. cap. 21. being greued wyth great payne of the head, and taken of a feuer, dyed. After his death great diſſention folowed among the byſhoppes, of whom ſome condemned him, and ſome dyd defend his cauſe and innocency. His bones at the requeſt of Proclus, were tranſlated to Conſtantinoble.

That Peter and Iohn the Apoſtles did appeare to him the night before he died, and did ſhew to him the victory againſt the deuils,Niceph. lib. 13. cap. 37. Baſiliſcus. and that Baſiliſcus the martyr did foreſhew him, that he ſhould be buried in hys own church, ſauoureth of a fable, rather then of truth. He dyed at the age of .lii. and when he had bene biſhop fiue yeares and a halfe.
Concerning the ſanctimony of his life, he lyued chaſte, and did vtterly abſtaine from al feaſtes, and was very liberal towards the poore, and was in great eſtimation emong the learned.

Theodoretus doth cal him Magnum Iohannem, Lib. 5. cap. 28. et. 32. & doctorem orbis terrarum. He wrote a very eloquent ſtile, and did very ſtrongly fight & wryte agaynſt heretikes, namely againſt the hereſie of Martion, Valentinus, Arrius, and againſt the deteſtable doctrine of the Nouatians. He doth pithily confute, writing vpon the ſecond chapter to the Philippians, theſe heretickes, Paulus Samoſatenus, Marcellus, Sabellius, Manes, Appollinarius, Photinus, Sophronius, and others.

Homil. 3.1 in cap. 4 et. 3. et. 4. concione de Lazaro.Yet he himſelf was not without his errours in his writinges. He affirmed, that in what houſe ſoeuer the booke and hiſtory of the Goſpell was, that ye deuil durſt not enter into that houſe. He did attribute to much to allegorical interpretacion. For he ſaith: non hiſtoriam negamus, ſed ſpiritualem intelligentiam praeferimus. In Matheum hom 10. In prolo. in Iohannem. VVe do not denye the hiſtorye, but we preferre the ſpiritual vnderſtanding. He writeth alſo, that the aungels did learne much of Iohn the Baptiſts ſermons, and out of the ſermons of other preachers.Homil. 70. cap. 3. Iohn. He doth not moſt purely intreate of iuſtificatiō, for he expreſly ſaith, that faith onely is not ſufficient to ſaluation.

Hom. 48. in, 7. cap. Iohan. Ho. 1 in acta Apoſtolo. In T • tū. cap. 1.Furthermore he ſaith, that the onely vertue of the ſoule may ſaue vs, and deliuer vs from eternall fire, and ſend vs to the kingdome of heauen. His opinion is, that ſicke men ought not to be chriſtened. Although he doth not condemne ſecond mariages, yet he ſemeth to wyll, that none ſhould be taken into the miniſtery of the church, if they haue twiſe maried.Ho 4 in Marcū et. cap 16. in Lucam. He affirmeth, that the fathers were in hell before Chriſt roſe from death. But in this opinion, he hath the moſt part of the Fathers of both the churches conſenting with him. He died about the yeare of our lord, as Socrates and Sozomenus do write 408. Lib 6. cap. 21. Lib, 8. cap. • 8. Yet he himſelfe in hys thyrde oration agaynſt the Iewes, doth ſay: Nunc agitur annus quingēteſſimus.

div.head: Hieruſalem.
div.p: HIeruſalem is an hebrew word, and it ſignifieth Doctrinā pacis, the doctrine of peace, and that commeth of the radicall Iarah, Iarah. id eſt, docuit for it was the ſeat of the true doctrine of god, or it may come of this radical Raah, Raah. that is, to ſee with eyes, and that Hieruſalem is as much to ſay, as viſio pacis, the ſight of peace, for Shalom Shalom. betokeneth pacem, peace.
Lib. 1. cap. 18. Lib 7. cap 3In the time of Abraham it was called Salem and Solyma (as Ioſephus writeth in his antiquities.)

Ioſua. 18. Iudic. 19.After that, it was called Iebus. And when it was conquered of Dauid, it tooke the name of Ieroſolyma. At the laſt, when it was vanquiſhed and deſtroyed of Titus, Vaſpaſianus ſonne, and after reſtored and builded agayne by Aelius Adrianus, it was named Aelia. But thā the place where Chriſt ſuffred and roſe againe, was incloſed within the northwall, wher before it was all without, and no part of the city.
Lyranus in Geneſim, writeth vpon theſe wordes (Appellauit nomen vrbis Bethel) hath theſe twoo verſes concerning the name of Hieruſalem, which was a city of many names.

q.l: Solyma, Luza, Bethel, Hieroſolyma, Iebus, Aelia.
Vrbs ſacra Hieruſalem, dicitur atque Salem.

div.p:
Melchiſedech was the firſt founder therof, and called it Salem pacificam.
• udi 18. After that the Iebuſites did inhabite it, and then it was called Iebus. Not long after, it had an other name compounded of both the words before mentioned, and ſo it was called Hieruſalem, B. turned into R.

The Hebrues do aſsigne an other reaſon of this name, which ſay, that firſt it was called Salem of Melchiſadech. After it was called Hiere, Hiere. hoc eſt, videbit, bicauſe that Abraham, when he would haue offred his ſonne Iſaac, called the name of that place dominus videt, Dominus videt. and ſo of theſe twoo were made one name Hieruſalem, E. turned into V. It was named alſo Luza, hoc eſt, Amigdalus, an Almond,Luza. bicauſe thoſe kinde of trees were there very plentifull. After that, it was named Bethel of Iacob. After that Salamon had made it more large, and wholy fortified it, it was named Solyma, quaſi Salomonia, and ſo by compoſition of the names before, it is called Hieruſalem. Hitherto Lyranus. VVhy it is called Aelia you haue heard before.

div.head: ❧ Praelectio tertia habita die Sabbati .xvii. die Februarii. Anno. 1560.
div.p: I Wil (at this preſent by Gods grace) entreate whether the iudgement of the ex • ounding of the ſcriptures doth perteine onely vnto the church, that is (as they expound it) vnto coū ſells & vnto their approued doctors and fathers.

Although euery man ought to confeſſe & acknowledge the maner of hys fayth, and to heare the church, teaching and moniſhing the word of God, as Chriſt and Paule do commaund, and alſo to rendre great thankes vnto the fathers, who haue expounded vnto vs many hard & vnknowen phraſes of the ſcriptures, nor did ſuffer ye heretickes for their pleaſure to racke and rent thē for the defence of their wicked opinions,Opinio. 1. but did moſt ſharpely reſiſte them & confute thē by the conference & manifeſt ſentences of the ſcriptures: yet it is farre frō Chriſtian modeſtie, and moſt contrary to the minde of Chriſt and Paule,Modeſtie. 2 that we ſhould receaue or embrace any doctrine made by mans authoritie, as neceſſary to ſaluation, without the teſtimonie of ye ſcriptures. For ye authoritie of Gods word ought alwaies to remaine as chiefe maiſtres in all iudgementes. For of the word the church hath her authoritie, & by it onely ought to pronounce & geue ſentence of all controuerſies.
〈…〉 . 12 〈◊〉 . 2. As both Moſes commaundeth, and Chriſt confirmeth, ſaying: the word which I ſpeake, ſhall iudge you in the laſt day. Again, that which I commaund, yt onely do, and you ſhal not adde one word to ye which I ſpeake vnto you.

〈◊〉 . 2.Alſo, S. Iohn ſayth. If any do not remaine in the doctrine of Chriſt or do bring any other doctrine, receaue him not into your houſe, nor bidde him God ſpeede, for if it were lawfull, either for man, be he neuer ſo holy & well learned, or to the Synodes of Biſhops, to expound the ſcriptures as they would after their own iudgments, not being able to rendre ye reaſon of their doings, out of the manifeſt ſcriptures,
why, then by this pretence & meanes they might make daily newe articles of the fayth, & wrie the ſcriptures to their owne pleaſures. I will geue you thre or foure examples of their expoſitions.

Origine doth expound this ſentence of Paule (Arbitramur hominem iuſtificari fide abſ
que operibus legis. We ſuppoſe man to be iuſtified by fayth without ye works of the lawe) that is,Ceremonyes. 3. of ceremonies. And this interpretation doe the ſcholemen follow with their whole aſſent. But Saint Paule ſpeaketh of ye works of the whole law, as it ſhall plainely appeare vnto them that wil throughly expend and weigh the circumſtances of Paules writing.

Tertullianus doth condempne ſeconde mariages, becauſe it is not lawfull to mary the brothers wife,Brothers wife 4. Iouinianus 5. Not good to touch a woman 6. Of one wyfe. 7. for ſayth he, all Chriſtians be brethren: what a fonde and farre fette expoſition is this?

Hierome diſputing againſt Iouinian, writeth after this maner.1. Cor. •
Bonum eſt mulierem non tangere, igitur coniugiū eſt malū. It is not good to touch a womā, therfore mariage is naught. O affectate and groſſe ignoraunce.

How much detorted is this ſaying of Paule, Epiſcopus ſit vnius vxoris vir. Let the Byſhop be the huſband of one wife, that is (ſay they) let not him that is Bigamus or hath maried a widow, be admitted to the miniſterie, but he that hath had a virgin, and now is ſingle, may be ordeined.
Other do referre it to the pluralitie of benefices, as though this word, vxor, did ſignifie Sacerdotium.

The Pope himſelf doth reaſō after this ſort, the prieſthode being tranſlated, it is neceſſary that there be alſo a tranſlation of the law.Heb. • . Therfore it perteyneth to me to make newe lawes, by the which the Chriſtians ſhould be reſtrayned and ruled as the Iewes were by the preſcription of Moſes.

To be ſhort, and to ſpeake ſummarilie, what abuſe ſo euer there be, or Idolatrie in the church, they do defend it by the commentes and gloſes of the fathers, and detorted expoſitions of the counſelles.

They alledge for the inuocation of ſaintes & worſhipping of images, this verſe out of the Pſalme, Laudate dominum in ſanctis ſuis, prayſe the Lord in his ſaints,Pſal. 1 •
what is that ſay they, but by inuocation and calling vpon them, with prayers and by manifeſt idolatry in worſhipping their images. And yet when they be conuinced by manifeſt ſcriptures of their impietie and ignoraunce: then they defend them ſelues by the authoritie of the church, & haue nothing els to ſay, but, thus ye church expoundeth it. But it is writtē in the Hebrue, Laudate dominū in ſanctuario ſuo, prayſe the Lord in his ſanctuarye, that is, in his church, and the Hebrue worde is Kedaſch, which ſignifieth ſanctuarium. Keda. • 1.

They alledge for images the ſeuenth Synode holden at Nice, for it was decreed ye images ſhould be retained in the church,The. 7. Synode holdē at Nice. 8. as bookes of lay men. And whē there is layed againſt this Synode the Counſell of .330. Biſhops, whiche Conſtantine held at Bizaunce in the which Counſell images were vtterly aboliſhed, then they aunſwere, that, that Counſell was not of ſo great eſtimation & price, as ye Counſel holden at Rome by the Biſhop there. And ſo it is brought to paſſe, that the expoſition of the ſcriptures whiche was committed to the iudgementes of the true church, and of the whole multitude, to courſe, wilde, and wanton wittes, wherby euery phantaſticall head ſhoulde not wrie the ſcriptures to the maintenaunce of their wicked doctrine: Now at the laſt doth ſerue the arbitrement and pleaſure of one Biſhop, that be may turne it whether he will, for the beneuolence and loue of a ſuperſticious woman, Hirene by name. For this ſeuenth Synode was ſolemnely kept of the Biſhop of Rome at the requeſt of one Hirene a Queene, who would haue the image of the Virgin Mary to be worſhipped, that wemen might haue alſo their goodeſſe, euen as men had Chriſt their God. So that there is nothing ſo well conſtitute and ordeyned of God, which the diuell doth not abuſe, to the prouoking of Gods wrath, and the deſtruction of man.

To be plaine, there is no man ſo holy, nor ſo well learned, but yt he may & doth erre, ſome more daungerouſly and more erroniouſly, then ſome, as Origen, Tertullian, and Ciprian, which did openly defend wicked opinions.

Other haue brought into ye church, chaffe, haie & ſtuble, which they haue mingled to the expoſition of the ſcriptures, and yet haue kept and left the chiefe articles of the fayth vncorrupt. But after the Biſhop of Rome occupied the chiefe place in the church, and that the iudgements of fathers and Synodes was cōmitted vnto him, he hath tempered and framed all religion, to his own pleaſure and luſt. But chriſt ſaith: Oues meae vocē meam audient, my ſhepe wil heare my voyce. Therfore they which do acknowledge any other doctrine,
•• hn. 10, then yt which is deliuered of Chriſt in the Goſpell, do not perteine to the church, becauſe the ſheepe of Chriſt do not heare the voyce of ſtraungers, but to this I know what they haue to ſay.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: If it be lawfull for euery man to expound the ſcriptures,Licence. 9. Platonical. 10. Reſidue ſhal iudge. 11. then there will be an infinite licence geuē to racke and rent the ſcriptures at libertie, and to deſpiſe the church: Yea the church then ſhould be no other thing but a platonical, and immaginarie common wealth, and ſo Chriſt ſhould in vayne cōmaund vs to heare the church, and Paule alſo ſhould commaund without a cauſe, that two or three Prophets ſhould ſpeake, and the reſidue ſhould iudge.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p:
There hath bene alway ſome church and company of godly men in the worlde, which euer held the pure word of god, who were worthy to be heard, becauſe they taught the word, not for their own authorities ſake, but for the woordes ſake, of which they haue their authoritie, but this church hath euer bene oppreſſed of the wicked and of the greater multitude: which euer had the title, the ſwaie, and rule of the church, as Chriſt ſpeaketh to that falſe church. Ve vobis qui occiditis prophaetas et ſapientes, qui ad vos mittūtur, vt veniat ſuper vos omnis ſanguis iuſtus, qui effuſus eſt ſuper terrā a ſanguine Abel iuſti, vſ
que ad ſanguinē Zachariae filii Barachiae. Zacharias. 12. Woe be to you which kill the Prophets and wiſe men, which are ſent vnto you, that vpon you may come all the righteous bloud, that was ſhed vpon the earth: from the bloud of Abell the righteous, vnto the bloud of Zacharias the ſonne of Barachias, whom you ſlewe betwene the temple and the altar.

In the death of Abell beganne the combate, and perſecution of the church, & ſhal endure vnto the generall iudgement, nor any other thing is to be loked for, of the godly, then that which hapened vnto Abell, to the Prophets, to Chriſt, to the Apoſtles, Martyrs, and other godly confeſſours. But in this conflicte, Chriſt doth alwayes remaine a marueilous conquerour, which by his death doth ouercome the world and the diuell:
〈◊〉 16. Nolite (inquit) metuere, ego vici mundum: Feare not, I haue ouercomed the world. The church therfore is no platonicall and imaginarie common welth, but it is a congregacion of the godly, which doth retaine the worde of God. And there hath bene alwaies ſome good doctors and teachers in the church, although oftētimes they haue bene ſo fewe, yt the church could ſcarcely be knowen.

In the time of the generall floud, there were onely eyghte ſoules as Peter doth teſtifie. And in the great multitude of the people of Iſraell, that is, ſixe hundred thouſand, which heard God ſpeake frō heauen: onely two perſons, Ioſue and Caleb, kept their fayth ſound and vnſhaken.

In the time of Helias, there ſemed onely a platonicall cominaltie, whē he ſaid:Helias. 13. They haue ouerthrowen thine altars, they haue killed thy Prophets, & I am left alone,
〈◊〉 . 17. and they ſeeke my life alſo.

In the time of Hieremie: The king, the people with the prieſtes did aduouche & affirme thē ſelues to be the church, and yt the lawe ſhould not peryſhe nor depart from the prieſt: and that the temple of the Lord ſhould not be deſtroyed, whē they
cryed,Templum Domini. 14. Templum domini, Templum domini, Templum domini, Iere. •
the temple of the Lord, the temple of the Lorde, the temple of the Lorde, and therfore they ſet themſelues againſt Hieremie, they laughed to ſcorne his prophecie, & burned his boke.

The Church in Chriſtes time beganne in the Maunger, and then there was a very ſmall multitude of the godly, as onely of the ſhepeherdes, of Ioſeph, of Mary,Simeon. 15 Anna. 16. of Simeon, and of Anna the Widow, and a fewe other. And yet the Aungells dyd acknowledge ye ſlender multitude for a church,Luc 2. and ſong to thē their hymnes when the hygh prieſtes, the princes, and the people did ſleepe, but not ſo much rocked a ſleepe, as fully buryed in infidelitie. Then dyd the prince of this world kepe his holde in peace, but when he ſawe a ſtronger then him ſelf to haue entred, he beganne ſtraightway to rage, and fel to murthering & killing infantes. And this is moſt certaine, that Chriſt is not there where the deuill doth not exerciſe his tyrannie and crueltie: When the church is voyde of perſecution, then all things are in peace, which that ſtrong harneſſed perſon doth profeſſe. But to our purpoſe againe. The iudgement of the expoſition of the ſcriptures is geuen of the church, of counſels and holy fathers, when they confirme their ſayings and doings by the manifeſt word of God written in the ſcriptures.
Biſhops & counſels ought not to haue rule ouer faith, and therfore ought not to be beleued when they propoſe newe doctrines, without the authoritie of the Scriptures.

Conſtantine the great (which is reported to be the firſt) that richlye endowed ye Churche, and gaue to her great authoritie & many priuileges (but of this I ſpake before) did plainly refute this gloſe in the Nicene Counſel, with the conſent of al the Biſhops there. His wordes be theſe. Euangelium & Apoſtolici libri, nec non antiquorum Prophetarum oracula, plane inſtruunt nos quid de voluntate de • ſentiamus. Quare hoſtili poſita diſcordia, ſumamus ex dictis diuini ſpiritus queſtionum explicationes. The bookes of the Euāgeliſtes and Apoſtles, likewiſe the oracles of the auncient Prophets, do playnly inſtruct vs what we may thinke of the will of God, wherfore all hoſtile diſcorde ſet a part, let vs diſcuſſe and expound al queſtions out of the ſayinges of the holy ſpirite. And by this it euidently appeareth that it was than the iudgement of the Churche to geue ſentence in all controuerſies out of the Scriptures, and to refuſe thoſe (whiche wreſted obſcure and darcke places, to confirme their wicked doctrine) by other manifeſt and playne places of the Scripture.Arrius. 17. Arrius him ſelfe that great heretike was not ſo impudent nor ſo much paſt ſhame, that he durſt to thruſt in his doctrine to the Churche without the authoritie of the Scripture,Anathaſius 18. but did contende and obiect agaynſt Athanaſius, and others, that they did not righly vnderſtande and expounde the Scriptures. Yet the ſayd Arrius, was conuinced and confuted, not by the authoritie of Athanaſius, and of other Biſhops, or by the power of the Emperour, but by manifeſt Scriptures.

Ciprian. 19Saint Cyprian hath a notable ſentence of the authoritie of the Scripture, and how much we ought to credit the fathers ſpeakyng wtout Scriptures. His words be theſe. Mandant martyres aliquid fieri, ſi iuſta, ſi licita, ſi non contra dominum, a dei ſacerdote facienda ſunt, ſi obtemperantis facilis & prompta conſenſio, ſi petentis fuerit religioſa moderatio. Mandant aliquid martyres fieri, ſed ſi ſcripta non ſunt in domini lege, quae mandant, aut ea ſciamus illos de deo impetraſſe quod poſtulāt, & tunc facere quod mandant. Ne
que enim poteſt ſtatim videri de diuina maieſtate cō ceſſum, quod fuerit humana pollicitatione promiſſum. Ita martyres nihil poſſunt, ſi Euangelium ſolui poteſt, aut ſi Euangelium ſoluere non poſſunt qui de Euangelio martyres ſunt. When the martyrs do commaunde any thyng to be done, if they be iuſt, if they be lawfull, if they be not againſt the Lord, they ought to be done of the Lordes Prieſtes, if the conſent of him that doth obey, be eaſie and ready to do them, and if the religion of the commaunder be meane and reaſonable: if the martyrs
commaunde any thing to be done, and if the thinges whiche they cōmaunde be not written in the lawe of the Lord, let vs firſt know, that they haue obtayned of God that whiche they commaund, and then let vs do their commaundement, for it cannot ſeme ſtraight waye to be graunted of Gods maieſtie, which was offred by mans promiſe. So the martyrs, &c. Here you ſee how this godly martyr & Byſhop, ſaint Cyprian doth clearely affirme, that no doctrine is to be receyued in the Churche by the authoritie of the Biſhop, or for the holynes of martyrs, without the ſcriptures, but they muſt proue their doctrine to be ſound, out of ye word, before they put it to the Churche. Therfore it may be concluded, that they whiche attribute vnto the Church & to the fathers, authoritie to ordeine any thyng without the ſcripture, and to define of controuerſies of religion, without the word, do offer great iniurie and wrong to the primatiue Churche. And what can be more clearely ſpoken, then that whiche was alleged before in S. Peter, whiche is that the prophetical Scriptures (to the whiche he biddeth vs to take heede) is not, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , of our priuate interpretation, or to be comparde with the cōmentaries of men? Saint Peter will in any wiſe theſe two, to be diſtinct one from the other, euen as the iudge and the thing to be iudged, as light and darkenes to be lightened, are diſtinct thinges, euen ſo Peter doth not make our priuate interpretation iudge of the Scripture, but contrary, maketh the Scripture iudge of our interpretation. He doth not ſaye that the interpreters giue light vnto the Scripture, but the Scripture to be a Lanterne and Candle to diſcuſſe and ſhake of the darckenes of all priuate interpretation. This cauillation therfore of the deuill is moſt vile and full of poyſon, by the whiche he would perſuade the worde of God to be ſo obſcure, darcke, ambiguous and doubtfull, that it can not be vnderſtande without the commentaries of men, and the expoſition of the Church. But what is the deuils drift I pray you? forſooth nothing els, but to driue euery man from readyng of the ſcriptures, and to make the word of God odious to all men. But will you haue the truth? The aunſwers of the deuil him ſelfe are ſo obſcure and doubtful, that no mā almoſt is able to vnderſtād them. What ſay you to the oracles of Appollo? by the whiche he deceiued him, to whom he ſpake theſe wordes.

Aio te Aecida Romanos vincere poſſe, which wordes are ſo perplexe, that it cā not euidently be gathered of them, whether he ment that the Romaines ſhould ouercome Achilles, or Achilles, them. So he likewiſe dalied with the woman in paradiſe, when he did promiſe vnto her the knowledge of good and euill, which ſhe vnderſtood of the diuinitie and Godhead, and not of the knowledge of miſerie, & of the experience of eternal dampnation. It is Satans property to lye and to murder, which things to be performed, Nothing is of more value then doubtfulnes & obſcuritie. On the contrarie ſide, it is Gods propertie to teach ye truth plainly, & to giue life, to which appertaineth light, certeinty, affiaunce, truſt, & perfect fayth. The firſt ſuggeſtion of Satan, is to make a man to wauer, ſtagger, and doubt of the will of God, and of his worde, that he might make vs to thincke God to be a lyer. On ye other part, it is the proper action of god, to make vs aſſured of his good will towardes vs, that we might aſcribe vnto God the glory of all truth. Chriſt and the Prophetes doth call the worde of God, the truth, the way, the light, the life, as Chriſt him ſelf ſayth. Ego ſum via, veritas, & vita, ego ſum lux mundi, qui ambulat in tenebris,
〈◊〉 . 14. neſcit quo vadat. I am the way, the truth, and the life, I am the light of the world, he yt walketh in darkenes, knoweth not whether he goeth.

div.head: Antitheſis.Antitheſis. 20.
div.p: The deuill calleth ye word of God, darke and doubtfull, which cauſeth men to erre from the true faith, and doth leade to eternall death.

Chriſt ſayth, Manifeſtaui nomen tuum hominibus, I haue made thy name manifeſt and open vnto men.
〈◊〉
• 7. The deuill ſayth, the Goſpel is not manifeſt and eaſie, but very obſcure and harde.
Chriſt ſayth: Wo be vnto you Scribes and Phariſeis, which take away the key of knowledge, and ſhut the kyngdome of heauen before men,Luke. 11. Math. •• . that they ſhould not enter in.
The deuill ſayth, and curſeth all thoſe whiche dare read the holy Scriptures without the gloſes and commentaries of men, and cauſeth the bookes of God to be burned.

The ſpirite of God ſpeaketh by Dauid, ſaying:Pſal. ••
Veſtubulum verborum tuorum illuminat, & dat intellectū paruulis. The entrie into thy wordes doth giue light, the teſtimonie of the Lord is ſure and giueth wiſedome to the ſimple.
The deuill ſayth, not the Scriptures of the Lord are not mete for lay men.
Thy worde ſayth Dauid is a Lanterne vnto my feete, Nay ſayth Satan, The holy Scriptures, without the Popes Canons are mere darcknes, and can not be vnderſtand without the Popes Decrees and Decretals.

Paule ſayth, perſiſte and continewe in the holy Scriptures,2. Tim •
which may inſtruct thee vnto ſaluation thorough fayth, and make the perfect to all good workes.
No ſayth Satan. The Scriptures be not ſufficient without vnwritten ver •• es and conſtitutions of Synods, and Counſelles, and without traditions excogitate and inuented by men.
Chriſt ſayth: Vos amici mei eſtis, ſi feceritis quae ego precipio vobis. Iohn •• .
No ſayth Satan, with the Pope, except you obſerue and kepe my conſtitutions and traditions, you ſhall haue the eternall curſe of God.
Chriſt ſayth, I am the light of the worlde. No ſayth, the Pope,Iohn. 8, There be two lightes in the world. The Pope and the Emperour.

Here may you ſee what a great conflict is betwene theſe two princes, Chriſt and Satan. Chriſt, being the prince of light, life and truth. Satan being the prince of darcknes, lyes and death. Which conflict began in the beginning of the world, and ſhall continewe to the ends of the ſame.

Agayne, God is not to be had in admiration and reuerence onely for his maieſtie, by the whiche be paſſeth infinitly all creatures, and their vnderſtandyng, but alſo for his humilitie, by the whiche he abaſed him ſelfe vnder all men, as ſaint Paule ſayth, he humbled him ſelfe and became obedient vnto death,Philip •
yea vnto the death of the Croſſe. Satan deſpiſed this humilitie of Chriſt, and did ſet • him ſelfe agaynſt Chriſt, truſting in his owne wiſedome, power, might, and glorious ſhow, vnto this proude deuill, what ſoeuer is written in the Scripture of the humilitie and paines of the ſonne of God, is counted fooliſhnes. But peraduēture you will ſay: What is this to the purpoſe? I aunſwere. Chriſt the ſonne of God doth ſo abaſe him ſelfe in the Scripture, that there may be ſene in hym no craft, no colour, no arrogancie, but all thinges moſt playne, moſt cleare, ſimple and moſt familiar. In ſo much yt he compareth him ſelf to a ſelfe henne, and to other inferior things. He vſeth not a proude or high kind of ſpeaking, no glorious phraſe, but ſhort, eaſie, playne, ſimple, homelie, and common. And therfore may the better be vnderſtand of the poore ſimple and ſely people, he ſent his worde immediatly after hys birth, not vnto kynges and princes, but vnto poore and playne ſhepeheardes. To whom he ſpake, not in a glorious, eloquēt, and hard phraſe, but plainly and ſimplely. He entred not into famous Cities and princes palaces, but was borne in a pore cottage, or rather a ſtable. He thoſe not to his diſciples. Emperours, Dukes and Lordes, but a ſorte of poore fiſhers, and by them diſperſed and ſpread his Goſpell thorough out the whole world, ſignifying, that the ſimple, make and abaſed people were very were, both to teach and vnderſtand his wordes.

Ariſtotle. 21. Galenus. 22 Ariſtotle, Demoſthenes, Cicero, Lucian, Galen: in ſumme, al the wiſe of ye world derided and contemned this homelie kinde of ſpeaking of the ſcriptures, As ſaint Paule complaineth, writting to the Corinthians.2. Co •
•
The wiſe and eloquent did not
deſpiſe the Scriptures for the maieſtie of the Oration, but for the baſenes & rude ſtile, for the ſcripture is familiar, and not to harde for the capacitie of fiſhers, marchauntes, artificers, huſbandmen, and other rude people. Vnto ſuch the ſcripture doth appertaine, as Chriſt ſayd when he gaue thanckes to the father, bycauſe be had hidden thoſe things from the wiſe,
• ath. 11. and had reueled them to the ſimple & litle ones. The deuill hath engraffred into mans minde, to meruayle at and to haue in great admiration, glorious, gaye, hard, and doubtfull matters, and to contemne vulgar & eaſy things. And thus may you learne, how impudent Satan is to driue men from the Scriptures by two contraries: firſt he ſayth, they be ſo harde and obſcure that they can not be vnderſtand without mans gloſe. On the otherſide he ſayth, they be ſo baſe and ſo rude, that they be ſcarce worthy the readyng and loking on. Oh ſubtil Satan, the father of al lyes, the murderer of ſoules, the ſclaū derer and defiler of the moſt pure and ſacred worde of God, the peruerter of all truth, who alwayes laboured, & yet doth labour, to deſtroy the true and pure doctrine of God, and eſtabliſhe and ſet vp mans traditions and doctrines of deuils. As forbidding matrimonie and meates, and mainteinyng works of ſupererogation, to ſatiſfie for the ſinne of man, defendyng of monckiſhe vowes, popiſhe pardons, maſſing Sacrifice for the quicke and the dead, inuocation and merites of Saintes, redeming ſoules out of purgatory, the worſhipping & groſſe ydolatrye, of Images, pilgramages and ſuch pelferie. And for theſe thinges and ſuch like to be defended, what contention, what diſputing, what perſecution, what murthering hath bene of late dayes? for theſe things fathers are brought forth, the authoritie of the Churche is alleged, curſinges, and excommunications haue ben thundred out, O horrible blaſphemie and vnſpeakable blindnes.

Is this the true doctrine of Chriſtes Churche? did they learne theſe thinges out of the mouth of Chriſt?
〈◊〉 10. 〈◊〉 14. Chriſt ſayth, Oues meae vocem meam audiunt. My ſheepe heare my voyce, they know and vnderſtande my woordes. And he that hath my wordes and doth keepe them, he it is which loueth me.

Paule ſayth, if any preach any other Goſpell than that which I haue preached, yea though it be an Aungell of heauen,
•• lat. 1. curſed be he.

• oh. 1,Saint Iohn ſayth. Si quis in doctrina Chriſti non continet ſe, ſed diuerſam affert doctrinam, non recipiatis eum in domum, Ne
que aue ei dixeritis. If any do not continewe in the doctrine of Chriſt, but bringeth a contrary doctrine, receyue him not into your houſe, nor bid hym good ſpeede.
Pet. 1. Peter commaundeth, that we examine and trie euery doctrine by the Scripture, giuen by the holy ghoſt.

Paule writting to the Epheſians, defineth the Church to be the congregation, whiche Chriſt hath ſanctified by the lauer of water in the worde of life, wherfore it appeareth, the word of God to be the life, and as you would ſay the ſoule of the Church, whiche without the worde is but a dead body.

Saint Auſten doth ſay the Churche to be that congregation, whiche doth holde the wordes of he bread Chriſt. His words be theſe. Queſtio eſt vbi ſit eccleſia, quid ergo facturi ſumus? In verbis noſtris, an in verbis capitis domini noſtri Ieſu Chriſti quaerimus? puto quod in illius verbis quaerere debemus, qui veritas eſt, & optime nouit corpus ſuum. There is a queſtion where the Church is, what ſhall we therfore do? ſhall we ſeke it in our owne wordes, or in the wordes of our head our Lorde Ieſus Chriſt? I thinke we ought to ſeke it in his wordes, whiche is truth it ſelf, and doth beſt know his body the Churche.

Saint Paule doth call them the Churche, whiche are buylded vpon the foundation of the Apoſtles and Prophetes.
〈◊〉 2. But what the Churche is, and wherupon it is builte, I will intreate more at large in the fourth and laſt lymme of my generall particion. And will here make an ende of this leſſon, ſauing that I will aunſwere to one or two obiections of our aduerſaries.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: The Churche beſide the worde and without the authoritie of the Scriptures, hath altered and abrogate the Sabb • th day, which is receiued vniuerſally of the whole Churche, Ergo the Churche may conſtitute, preſcribe, appointe and order without the Scriptures.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: The Schole men thē ſelues do coumpt this argument to be a very blind & vnlearned cōment and gloſe, for as they ſay Genus, in this precept is not altered nor abrogate, whiche is the chiefeſt point of this commaundement: for God doth alwayes require a conſeruation and obſeruaūce of ſuch ceremonies as he him ſelfe hath appointed, and would that certayne dayes ſhould be prefixed and appointed to the Miniſterie of his worde and Sacramentes, and this part of this precept is immutable, and can not be abrogate or chaunged, but that part whiche is called Species, that is, that the ſeuenth day and none other ſhould be kepte, is abrogate, bycauſe the Chriſtians ſhoulde be free from the Ceremonies of Moſes. As Paule writeth to the Colloſſians. And thus you ſee, that the Churche in this hath done nothing but by ye authoritie of the word. Furthermore the Sabboth of the Iewes was aboliſhed by the Apoſtles them ſelues, & ſo it is recorded in the Scriptures, as in the Actes of the Apoſtles, it is writen that the firſt daye of the weeke the diſciples came together to breake bread. The firſt day of the weeke, we call Sonday. And by this place and many other mo we gather, that the Chriſtians vſed to haue the ſolemne aſſemblyes, layeng aſſide the Ceremonies of the Iewes Sabboth. And bycauſe the Iewes were ſo ſuperſtitiouſly wedded & addicte vnto the ſabboth day, the Apoſtles did abrogate it, and place in the ſtede thereof the Sonday, bycauſe the reſurrection of the Lord (whiche was done that day) brought an ende to all ſhadowes of the lawe. And that day doth admoniſhe vs of our Chriſtian libertie. For as by the diſpoſyng of the law, the Sabboth was celebrate and kepte, to keepe in remembraunce the makyng of the worlde. So the Sonday is nowe obſerued to put vs in remembraunce of the reſurrection of Chriſte, and to confirme the hope of our reſurrection. In this day Saint Paule ordeyned at Galatia and at Corinthium, that collection and gatheryng for the poore ſhould be vſed. Of this day Saint Iohn ſpeaketh in the reuelation ſaying, Fui in Spiritu in dominica die. I was rauiſhed in ſpirite on the Lordes day.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: The Apoſtles did altar the forme of Baptiſme, bicauſe they baptiſed onely in the name of Chriſt, where Chriſt commaunded them to Baptiſe, in the name of the father, of the ſonne, and of the holy ghoſt. Ergo the Church which is ſignifyed by the Apoſtles, may diſpence and altar the Scriptures.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p:
Saint Iohn ſayth. Qui confitetur Ieſum Chriſtum eſſe filium dei, 2. Iohn. •
is habet patrem & filium. He that confeſſeth Ieſus Chriſt to be the ſonne of God, he hath the father and the ſonne. And Sainte Ambroſe in his booke De Spiritu Sancto, doth refute this calumnious cauillation ſaying.Ambroſius 23. Si fide myſterium Trinitatis tenetur, & vna tantum nominetur perſona, plenum eſt Sacramentum. Yf the Myſterie of the Trinitie be beleued, and one onely perſon named, it is a ful and a perfect Sacrament.

And vnder the name of Chriſt is comprehended the myſterie of the Trinitie. For whē Chriſt ſayd: Ego et Pater vnum ſumus, I and the father are one,Iohn •
he therfore that is Baptized in the name of Chriſt, is Baptized in ye name of the father, and in the holy ghoſt, whiche is not deuided from them.
Other expounde to be Baptized in the name of Chriſt, to be no more but to be baptized of the Apoſtles, after the inſtitution and commaundement of Chriſt.

Other do ſay, that Chriſt is Complementum et proprium obiectum baptiſmi. for all the myſteries of Baptiſme, are ſet forth vnto vs in Chriſt the onely ſonne of God. Chriſt ſayth, Qui credit in me, non credit in me, ſed in cum qui miſit me, He that beleueth in me, doth not beleue in me, but in him that ſent me. Wherupon it may be concluded, that be which is baptiſed in Chriſt, is baptiſed alſo in the name of the father: To be baptiſed of Chriſt, is to be made the annoynted of God the father, which hath annoynted him, and in the holy ghoſt, by whom he was annoynted of the father. Beſides this, the name of Chriſt in the Hebrue, is Meſſiah, which ſignifieth annoynted. Lyranus ſayth,Meſſias. 24 Liranus, 5 that the Apoſtles and other of the primatiue church, by the inſtincte of the holy ghoſt, did baptiſe onely in the name of Ieſus Chriſt, to make that man more amiable, and to be had in more price & honor which was than odious & hateful to the Iewes. And Chriſtus, in greke is Vnctus, annointed, & in that name the holy trinity is vnderſtand, the father who doth annoint the ſonne which is annointed, the holly ghoſt whiche is the vnction it ſelfe And Chriſt can not be conceiued and apprehended by faith, without the father, of whome he was geuen vnto vs, nor without the holly ghoſt, by whom he doth renew & ſanctify vs. Therfore, this obiectiō of the papiſts is nothing worth, by the which they chalendge autoritye to chaunge the inſtitution and order of Chriſte. And when they make a diſtinction inter ſubſtantiam et formam, ſayinge, that nothing ought to be altered concerning the ſubſtance, but the cōcerning the forme they may altar & change the Ordinance of Chriſt. It is an argument ſone refelled, for Chriſt did not geue to the apoſtles magical words to vſe incantation, as they dreame, but did comprehend in a few words the ſumme of the whole miſtery. And Peter here doth not ſpeake of the forme of baptiſme, but doth ſhew ſimpliciter the whole vertue of baptiſme to be auaylable in Chriſt.

div.head: Opinio. 1.
div.p: OPinari, is (as Donatus ſayth, to be in doubt of a thynge. His wordes be theſe: Quae opinamur, putamus: quae putamus, incerta ſunt. Thoſe thinges whiche we ſuppoſe, we thincke or denie them: And of thinges whiche we denie, we are vncertayne.

Cicero dicit ſapientem nihil opinari, lib. 4, Acado id eſt, nunquam aſſentiri rei falſae vel incognitae. A wiſe man (ſayeth he) doth neuer ſuppoſe any thyng, that is, he doth not geue his aſſent to any falſe thing, or thyng vnknowen.

Lactātius dicit. Id opinatur quiſ
que quod neſcit. Illi aūt, libro. 3. qui de rebus naturalibus diſputāt, opinātur, id eſſe vt diſputāt. Neſciūt igitur veritatē quoniā ſciētia, certi eſt: opinatio, incerti. That doth euery mā (ſayth he)
ſuppoſe, which he knoweth not. They which diſpute of naturall thinges, do ſuppoſe thē to be ſo as they diſpute, therfore they know not the truth. For ſcience and knowledge, is of a thyng certeyne: opinion and ſuppoſition, is of a thing vncertaine. And ſo the Philoſophers and the ſcholaſtical diuines do define Opinionem.

a • . q, 79 ar, 4. Aquinas dicit, quod opinio eſt actus intellectus, declinantis in vnam partem contradictionis cum formidine alterius. An opinion is an actiō of the vnderſtāding, declining to one part of the contradiction, with feare and doubt of the other part.
There is much difference, Inter opinionē, fidē, ſcientiā, & ſcrupulum.

div.head: Opinio.
div.p: Opinio, is the aſſent of the vnderſtāding to ſome thing, not bycauſe it is ſufficiently moued by the proper obiecte, but by a certayne election ſeming reaſonable, declining to the one parte, more then to the other: yet with doubting and feare of the other part.

div.head: Fides.
div.p: Fides, is with all certainty, and without all feare and doubt.

div.head: Scientia.
div.p: Scientia, is the aſſent of vnderſtāding moued by the obiect, & knowē by it ſelfe, as, In principiis: or els knowne by an other thing, as, In concluſionibus quarum eſt ſcientia.

div.head: Scrupulus.
div.p: Scrupulus is whē vnderſtādyng is moued by light cōiectures & weak meanes to the one partie. Haec exſcholaſticis.

de vtilitate credendi, cap, 11,S. Auſten doth write. Tria (inquit) ſunt hominū genera, profecto improbanda & deteſtanda. Vnū eſt opinantiū, id eſt, eorū qui ſe arbitrantur ſcire quod neſciūt: Alterum, corū qui ſentiunt quidē ſe neſcire, ſed nō ita quaerūt, vt inuenire poſsint. Tertiū, eorū qui ne
que ſe ſcire exiſtimant, nec quaerere volūt. There be thre ſortes of men (ſayth he) which are vtterly to be improued and deteſted. The firſt is of ſuppoſers or demers, whiche thinke thēſelues to know yt, which they do not know. The ſecond, is of thē which ſuppoſe thē ſelues to know nothing, & yet do not ſo ſeke, that they may finde knowledge. The third is, of them which do iudge themſelues to know nothing, nor yet will ſeeke any knowledge at all. Here may you ſee by Saint Auſten, that Opinio, is of things vncertayne.

dialo, 3 Origene, in his dialoge De chriſto homine, doth take Opinionē for a ſhewe or a phantaſie. He bringeth in one of the interlocutors, ſpeaking theſe wordes: Ille nēpe xp̄s paſtꝰ eſt opinione, id eſt, ſpecie & phātaſia, ac non veritate. He ſuffred in opinion, that is in ſhew and phātaſie, but not in truth, againſt whō he bringeth in an other ſpeaker, which aunſwereth thus: Si opinione, nō veritate paſſus eſt, opinione Herodes iudicat: opinione Pilatus manus lauat: opinione Iudas tradidit, opinione & Cayphas, opinione eū & Iudaei cōprehenderūt, opinione & illi erāt Apoſtoli, opinione,
ſanguis ipſiꝰ eſt effuſus, opinione Euāgeliſtae predicarūt Euāgeliū, opinione deſcēdit de caelis, & opinione aſcendit, deni
que & ſalus hominis opinione, nō veritate conſtāt. If he ſuffred by opinion, not in verity and truth, then alſo Herode iudged him but by opinion, then Pilate waſhed his hāds but by opinion: thē Iudas betrayed him but by opinion, then Cayphas did examine him but by opinion, thē ye Iewes did apprehend & take him but by opinion, then he had Apoſtles but by opinion, then his bloud was ſhed but by opinion, then the Euangeliſtes did preach and write the Goſpels but by opiniō: thē he diſcēded frō heauē and went vp to heauē but by opinion, finally the ſaluation of man doth ſtande in opinion, and not in truth. By theſe wordes Origene doth refute the Martioniſtes, whiche held, that chriſt ſuffred but by opinion, which is an hereſy: for as Herode did iudge him and as Iudas did betraye him in very dede, euen ſo did he ſuffer in very dede. And here you may learne, that Opinio is taken, not for a thing certayne, but vncertayne.

Tertullian alſo calleth him that is of a ſiniſter opinion, Opinioſum. Opinio, ſomtime is takē for eſtimatiō or cōmēdatiō, as Cicero writeth Ad lētulū. Magna eſt hominū opinio de te. Mē haue a gret eſtimatiō of thee.Lib. 1.

div.head: Modeſtia. 2.
div.p: MOdeſtia eſt (inquit Cicero) in animo continens moderatio cupiditatum. Modeſtie is (ſayth he) in the minde, a continēt gouernement of deſires and luſtes.
By Modeſtie, all thinges that appertayne to man, are gouerned and driuen to a certayne moderation, which are in nomber theſe foure.

list.item: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . 1.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . 2.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . 3.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . 4.

div.p: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , are the inward partes & motions of ye mind, which whē they intend to clime high, ar gouerned & moderated by humility, whoſe cōtrary is pride & arrogācy. Alſo the feruēt deſire of ſuch things as pertayne to knowledg and lernyng, is gouerned and moderated by earneſt and diligent ſtudie, whoſe contrarie is curioſitie.

〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , are the motions, actions & doings of the body, that all thinges may he done comely and modeſtly, aſwel in ſerious & earneſt matters, as in other. VVhich doings or motions are gouerned & moderated by three vertues, that is per
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , by the whiche it may be diſcerned, what ought to be done, and what ought to be omitted, in what order and in what ſort things may be put in vre.

The ſecond is per
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , by the whiche, decencie and comelines is obſerued in all actions and doinges.

The third is per
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , by the which there is a certaine grauitie & moderation in talke and communication, and in other familiar affaires.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is that which doth moderat mās doings about iocund recreatiōs, merie words & pleaſaūt dedes wt the obſeruatiō of thre circūſtāces.
The firſt circumſtance is, that the wordes and dedes be not obſcene, filthy, or noyſome.
The ſecond is, that the grauitie of the minde, be not wholly turned to a certaine looſnes.
The third is, that mery wordes or dedes be conuenient, agreable, and mete to the perſon, tyme, and place.

〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , is the outward decking, & furniture of ye body, as in apparel, & buildings, & diet, & other lawful prouiſiōs. This part alſo is moderated by thre vertues: The firſt is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , yt is humilitie, which refuſeth all ſuperaboūdaunt and ſuperfluous coſtes and charges, whiche alſo doth wholly exclude the intention of glory or brauerie.

The ſecond is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which is frugalitie, when a mā is contēted with that whiche he hath, and doth not deſire any other thing aboue his ſtate and calling. It is called of Macrobius, Parcitas.

The third is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which is prudent ſimplicitie, which doth exclude all ſuperfluous carefulnes, & cauſeth a mā to be content with that whatſoeuer happeneth vnto him. It is called of Macrobius, Moderatio.

Of modeſtie much mētiō is made in the holy ſcriptures, as in ye epiſtle of. S. Paul to the Philippiās.cap. 4. Modeſtia veſtra nota ſit oībꝰ hominibꝰ. Let your modeſtie be knowē to all mē. Modeſtia, is called in ye Greke 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which word. S. Ambroſe doth expounde to ſignifie a conuerſation reaſonable, when one doth not contend or ſtriue for the maiſtry, chief right, or title, but when one doth geue place to an other for the time, whiche thing humanitie doth require.

cap 3Again in the epiſtle to the Coloſsiās. Induite vos ergo, ſicut electi dei ſācti & dilecti, viſcera miſericordiae, benignitatē, humilitatē, modeſtiam, patiētiā. Now therfore as the elect of god, holy and beloued, put on tēder mercy, kyndnes, hūblenes of mind, modeſtie, long ſuffring. S. Paul in this place doth meane by modeſtie, where one doth lay aſide and put down all hawtines & pride of mind, & doth hūble him ſelf, chalēging nothing to him ſelfe arrogātly, we haue not a more expres exāple of modeſty in al ye ſcriptures,Math. 11. then Chriſt himſelf, which did abaſe him ſelfe vnder al men, and commaunded vs to learne of him, which was meke in harte.

To be ſhort Paul in his epiſtle to the Galathiās, doth nōber modeſtie to be one of the fruites of the ſpirite,Gal. 5. ſaying, the fruite of the ſpirite is loue, ioye, peace, long ſuffring, gentlenes, goodnes, fayth, modeſtie, temperancie, agaynſt ſuch there is no law.

This modeſtie is a vertue, by the which a Chriſtian is not lightly moued to wrath and anger, but taketh all things in good part. It may be called tractability, contrary to contention and variāce, it doth throw out of
the mind, all fearcenes, and cruelnes, and doth engraffe therin, mildenes and humanitie.

Such modeſtie was in Dauid: who whē he was caſt out of his kingdō, & reuiled & railed at with taūts by one Semei,2. Reg. 16. yet he was nothing moued to anger or reuēging, but toke it in good worth, and did forbid yt any mā ſhould hurt Semei. The like vertue was in Moſes. The like vertue alſo was in Paul. The like modeſty was in one Onias,Lib. 2. cap. 4. of whom record is made in the Machabees, where it is written thus: Contriſtatus ita
que eſt animo Antiochus propter Oniam, & flexus ad miſericordiā lachrimas fudit, recordatus defuncti ſobrietatē & modeſtia. Therfore Antiochus was ſory in his minde, and he had compaſsion and wept, bycauſe of the modeſty & great diſcretion of Onias, that was dead.
Salomon in his Prouerbes doth ſay, the reward of modeſtie,Prou. 22. and the feare of God, is riches, glory and life.
Modeſtie (ſayth Lyranus) doth ſignifie euery morall vertue, whiche doth conſiſte in the moderation of mans doyngs and ſuffraunces.

S. Hierom doth cal Modeſtiā in this place, Cōſtātia bonorū operū, the perſeueraūce in good works. It is called in ye hebrew Gnanuah which doth ſignifie, not onely modeſty and mekenes, but alſo affliction (as in the Pſalme) Gnaniti Id eſt, afflictus ſum; or (as other do expound it) afflixi me. I puniſhed my ſelfe.Pſal. 116.

To make an end, you ſhall vnderſtād, yt tēperācy doth differ frō modeſty. For tēperācy is an abſtinēce & meane vſing of al things, as of meate, drincke, clothes, ſlepe and ſuch other like things. It is a vertue contrarie to ſurfeting, riote, pleaſure, wantonnes, vncleanelines, prodigality, and to all other abuſes.
VVhat modeſtie is, it is ſufficiently declared before.

p.hi: Examples of Modeſtie.

div.p: VVhē one Lucas a phiſitiō, amōg al orators of yt time moſt eloquent, had with a moſt abſolute oratiō ſet forth the vertues naturally engraffed in king Alphonſus, the king hearing his wordes, ſaid: Si vera ſint quae de me predicaſti, diis immortalibꝰ merito gratias ago, ſurminꝰ vt iſthaec faciāt, oro & obſecro. If thoſe things, which yu haſt reported of me be true, then I render thanckes vnto the immortall gods: If they be not true, then I pray and beſech them, that they may be true. O modeſtie moſt worthy in a prince to be prayſed.

VVhen Ageſilaus alſo adourned his iourney towardes his countrie out of Egipt, he was ſtriken with a mortall diſeaſe, when he came to the porte of Menelaus. And at the very inſtant of his death, he commaunded, that they ſhould not erecte any image in his honour or memorie. Si quod (in quit) praeclarum facinus geſsi, hoc erit monumentum mei. Sin minus, ne omnes quidem ſtatuae illuſtrabunt mei memoriā. If ſayth
he, I haue done any noble actes, they ſhalbe a monumente of me. If I haue done no ſuch things, all the images in the world, neither will nor cā ennoble my memorie.

div.head: Caeremonia. 3.
div.p: THis worde Caeremonia, is diuerſly written ſome write it with a diphthonge, other with a ſingle e. The etymologie of the word is alſo diuerſe.Lib. 2. cap. 3. Macrobius and Sulpitius do ſay, that this word Caeremonia, is deriued of Carendo.

Feſtus, and other do ſay, that it tooke this name of a certaine town called Cere. For when Rome was expugnat and taken of the frenchmē, the virgins named Veſtales, tooke the images of the goddes, whiche they had reſerued from the hands of their enemies, and went into the towne Cere, bringing thither their gods with them, where they were gently receyued and entertained, and where they made their abode vntill ye Citie of Rome was deliuered againe from the frenchmen by one Camillus. And in the memorie of this benefite, the Romaines euer after that, called the maner of the worſhippyng of their gods and their whole religion, Ceremonias, of the towne Cere.

Lib. 5. Liuius doth write, that Lucius Albinus one of the commons, did bring the virgin Prieſts and all the holy things vnto the towne Cere in a carte or wayne (wherof ſprang this name Caeremonia) which name we Chriſtians do now retayne and vſe, calling the rites and formes of our religion ceremonies, yet we do make a difference betwene the ceremonies appointed by God, & other preſcribed by mā: of the which later ſort, there hath bene a great heape, not onely vayne, fooliſh and ſuperfluous, but alſo blaſphemous and iniurious to the bloud of Chriſt.

Saint Auſten in his Epiſtle Ad Ianuarium did take it in very ill part, that in his tyme the Churche of Chriſt, whiche God of hys mercye would to be free with a fewe ordinaunces, was Prieſt with ſo many ſeruile burdens and bondages, in ſo muche that the condition and ſtate of the Iewes ſemed more tollerable and more eaſie, then the Churche of the Chriſtians.

div.head: Diuiſio.
div.p: The lawe is deuided into three partes, Videlicet, to the lawe morall, ye law iudiciall, and the lawe ceremoniall. The law morall, which pertay-to the lawe of nature, is not abrogate, for it reſpecteth the inwarde man, and the will of God is eternall, and the lawe of nature cannot be chaunged. This lawe is conteyned in the Decalogo, that is, the tenne commaundementes.

The law iudicial, which reſpecteth ciuil affaires, and politike order, for the defence of the good, and for the ſuppreſsing of the wicked for publicke peace. &c. although it be abrogate in forme and circumſtance, yet it remaineth in force concerning the ſubſtance, which is, that the ſword be drawen vpon malefactors, that publike peace and tranquility may be kept and maintained. Notwithſtanding no publike weale, no city, no nacion is bound, or ought to be conſtrained to receiue and obey the qualitye of thoſe iudicial lawes, appointed by Moſes, but is ſet at liberty and made free to vſe ſuch lawes, ſuch time, ſuch place, ſuch puniſhments, as it wyll and ſemeth beſt, ſo yt the ſubſtance therof be not reiected & abrogated.

The law ceremonial did contain certain externe ceremonies, which (as Rabbi Salomon writeth) were .600. in number, and wer onely figures, and not ordeined to remaine for euer (as Paul writeth to ye Hebrues) Ad tempus correctionis, which was a figure, and they wer carnal rites, vntil the time of reformation, that is vntil ye new teſtamēt was appointed.

Iacobus de valentia doth ſay, that the olde law was nothing els but a certain way directing and leading vnto Chriſt, tanquam in finem immediatum, as to the very end. Et ideo (inquit) nunquam petit regnum coelorum, ſed ſemper petit meſſiam, qui doceat viam in regnum caelorū. Iohn. 10.14. Chriſtus oſtium, via & veritas dicitur. And therfore (ſaith he) the law neuer aſketh the kingdome of heauen, but alwaies deſireth Chriſt, which teacheth the way to the kingdome of heauen. For Chriſt is the doore, the way, and the truth.

Saint Hierome is very ſore againſt the obſeruers of the ceremonies of the Iewes. His wordes be theſe: Ego libera voce pronuncio, caeremonias Iudeorum & pernitioſas eſſe, & mortiferas Chriſtianis, & quicunque eas obſeruanerit, ſiue ex Iudaeis ſiue exgentilibus, eum in Barathrum diaboli deuolutum. I do frely pronounce and ſay, that the ceremonies of the Iewes be pernitious and moſt deadly vnto Chriſtians, and that whoſoeuer doo obſerue them, whether he be Iew or Gentile, ſhalbe thruſt down to the gulfe or dongeon of the deuill. But ſome ſuppoſe Hierome to haue ſpoken this in his coller againſt ſaynt Auſten.

For great diuines hold, that to obſerue a ceremony with a Iew, is not mortal of it ſelfe, but the opinion that perſwadeth a man to put hope or confidence in the worke, as a thing helping to iuſtification, is peſtiferous and eroneous. If circumciſion in the new teſtamēt had bene mortal, why did Paule circumciſe Timothy? why did he make a vowe, in cenchreis? why did he ſhaue his head? Theſe workes be not mortall ſimpliciter, but by opinion of iuſtificatiō. For nothing doth iuſtify, but onely faith, which is ſufficient of it ſelfe without any worke, as concerning the iuſtifieng before God. Therfore when Paule did put in vre thoſe legall rites, he dyd
it onely to ſerue the charitye of the brethren, and to geue place for that time, to their infirmity, that he might wyn them, as he ſayth hymſelfe: Iudaeis factus ſum Iudaeus, to the Iewes I became a Iew.

div.head: Iouinianus. 5.
div.p: IOuinianus, who was firſt a ſolitary monke, and afterward becam one of the clergy, being but a baſe man of birth, but rich, neither learned nor yet eloquent, endeuoured to renew the hereſy af Baſilides, being of long time before buried and extinguiſhed, writing commentaries vpon the ſame matter, in the which he went aboute to proue out of the teſtimonies of the ſcriptures, yll vnderſtanded, that ſuche as were truely baptized, could not falagaine into ſynne. The which errour ſaint Auſten aſcribeth vnto Pelagius. Thoſe thinges when he taught at Rome, he was able to draw into his errour none of the Prieſtes, nor any of the Clergie, being of any name or eſtimation: he onely corrupted certayne ſimple wemen, in ſo much that when this was heard of certaine ſacred virgins, being ſtriken wel in yeares, maried huſbandes. But he hym ſelfe would not mary a wyfe, not bicauſe he hoped to receiue any reward for it, but bicauſe he would not be entangled with the troubles of matrimony, and bicauſe he woulde be at more liberty. Saint Auſtē doth lay certaine errours vnto Iouinianus his charge, which notwithſtanding Hierome doth not impute vnto him. That is, that the virgin Mary, the mother of Ieſu, was defiled in her childbirth, & that al offences wer equal, as the opinion of the Stoickes was. But it doth appeare, that ſaint Auſten neuer red either the bookes of Iouinianus, or the booke of Hierome againſt Iouinian, but did onely learne of the rumour of the people. But he declareth notwithſtanding, that ther was no mention made of Iouinianus, either of Epiphanius, either of Philaſtrinus in his Cataloge of Archheretickes, but that he found in a certayne booke, without any title of the authour of it, that Iouinianus was numbred among the Archeheretickes. He ſayth furthermore, that this hereſy ſpranke vp, he being but a childe, and that it was forth with repreſſed, infecting none of the prieſtes. But it doth appeare, that his hereſy was cōdemned by the meanes of one Victorinus and Pammacbius, and before that Hierome wrote againſt him. Notwithſtanding Hierome gladly and willingly tooke that argument, alwayes earneſtly fauouring virginity, and for that cauſe was more bent againſt mariages, then certayne biſhops would be.

Ther was alſo an other Iouinianus, who was the fourth emperour of Conſtantinople, next after Iulianus Apoſtata, he raigned eight monethes. Thys chriſtian emperour was borne in the country of Pannonia, indued
with al vertues from his youth vpwardes. VVherefore being ſcarce yet come to mans ſtate, the hoſt did create him Emperour, bicauſe they had an opinion, that he would do many noble acts. VVhen he was called of the whole hoſt Auguſtus, that is to ſay, imperial, he would not profeſſe that name, vntil the whole number had proclaimed thēſelues to become chriſtians, and then he tooke vpon him the Empire, and deliuered the hoſte from the hands of the Barbarous. But neceſsity conſtraining, he deliuered Niſibni, and a great part of Meſopotamia, vnto one Sapor, kyng of Perſia, which thing neuer happened before, by the ſpace of .300. yeares. At the laſt he died, being yll affected with much crudity and rawnes of the ſtomake, or (as ſome write) by the euil ſauour of coales, whereof he commaunded a great fire to be made.

div.head: Bonum mulierem non tangere. 6. It is good not to touch a woman.
div.p: BOnum here, is taken for commodum, that is commodious, and not for that which is contrary vnto euyll, as cōmonly that is called good, that profiteth a man, and Horace calleth him Malus bello, euyl for war, which is vnmete for war. Neither is it thought, that this was demaunded of the Corinthians, whether it wer lawfull to mary a wife, but whether it were expedient, as their ſtate was then, to be entangled with the bonds of mariage. Saint Hierome doth reaſon after this ſorte againſt them, who did attribute to muche vnto matrimonye. Si bonum eſt mulierem non tangere, ergo malum eſt tāgere, If it be good not to touch a wyfe, then it is euyl to touche one, ſince that good and euyll be contrarie.

This argument ſaint Auguſtine thus refuteth,In Epiſtola aduerſus Hiero. de medio inter bonum & malum who had read the predicaments of Ariſtotle, ſaying: ther are ſome thinges indifferent, whych are neither good nor euil, as for to wipe the noſe, or to ſpit. For where as he did place thre commodities in mariage, he would not make any mention of euyl, and therfore ſaith ſaint Auſten, bonum, here is taken for melius, better, leaſt any man ſhould thinke it a filthy thinke to mary a wyfe, as though bonum, good, in this place, were contrary vnto, turpe, filthye. Yf that in the words of Hierome malum & bonum good and euil be taken a like in both places, his argument is good, according to the queſtion propoſed of the Corinthians. Yf it be commodious not to mary a wyfe, for the burden of cares, and the bonds of affinitye, then is it vncommodious to mary. As if one ſhould be demaunded, when a man ſhoulde enter into along iourney, and ſhal paſſe by many theuiſh places, whether it be good to take mony with him, & ſhould anſwer it is good not to cary mony, it doth well follow, therfore it is euyll to cary money. For that which here
is contrary vnto good, ſaint Paule a litle after calleth a tribulation and affliction of the fleſh. Neither doth he ſimply and flatly ſay: It is good to tary and remaine as I am, but it is good for the vrgent neceſsity. VVherfore, that which is good for the time, and for the preſent ſtate, is not by and by ſimply, and vniuerſally good. In the time of ſaint Paule, when amongeſt a great ſort of Ethnickes, ther were but a few Chriſtians, perchaunce it was then more requiſite to abſtaine from mariage: but nowe the ſtate of thinges being altered, it is not onely expedient, but alſo neceſſary, for al men of euery degree, whether they be prieſts or laymen, votaries or not votaries, eſpecially if they haue not the gift of chaſtity to enter into the honorable ſtate of matrimony. This place of ſaint Paule may be expounded alſo after this ſort: It is lykely, that the falſe Chriſtians endeuoured them ſelues to make all men afraid of taking a wife, by reherſing many incommodities of wedlocke: and contraryly to perſwade thē to liue ſinglye, for the commodities belonging thereto, as in tyme paſt alſo the Monkes and Prelates being defenders of the Romiſh chaſtity, wer wont to do. But the anſwer of the Apoſtle is contayned in twoo partes.
In the firſt part he teacheth, that it is good for all men if they maye, to abſtaine from women.
In the ſecond part he addeth a correction, bicauſe that the imbecillity of the fleſhe, is a let vnto many men, they ought not to deſpiſe the lawfull remedy ordayned by God.

There are many thinges to be obſerued in this place. Firſt this word bonum in Greke 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , is vſed for commodious, quiet, honeſt, and pleaſaunt, and for bonum, which is contrary, to vice and euyll. He maketh therfore a falſe argument, which diſputeth after this ſorte: If it be good not to touch a woman, it is euyl therefore to touche a woman, where as good and euyl are contrary.

But Paule onely ſheweth what is expedient, bicauſe of the troubles and cares which commonly married men haue. For it was ſayde vnto Ieremy, bicauſe of the tempeſtes of warre to come, Noli vxorem ducere, marry no wyfe, not becauſe it was an offence, but bicauſe it was vncommodious, then to marry. VVherefore there can bee nothing els gathered out of the words of Paule, but that it is expedient for a man not to be coupled wyth a wyth, if he can be without her.

Euen as if a man ſhould ſay: It is good not to eate nor drinke, nor ſleepe: he wyll not condemne meate, drinke, and ſleepe, as thinges hurtfull, but bicauſe ſo much goeth from the ſpirite, how muche more is geuen vnto them He meaneth that we ſhould be more happy, if being free frō theſe things, we could wholy geue our ſelues vnto ye meditatiō of heuēly things.
Therfore bicauſe ther are in matrimonye manye impedimentes, by the which a man is letted & troubled, by this reaſon it wer good not to marry. VVherfore this propoſition muſt be indefinite, where as it cannot be true in al kindes of men. The which is plaine in the firſt man Adam: for this propoſition could not agree vnto him, neither can it be ſaid vnto thē, who either burne or liue incontinently, whom Paule doth commaund to marry. Therfore he correcteth this propoſition, leaſt anye man ſhoulde iudge euill of matrimony. But bicauſe there ſemes to be a contrariety in theſe words of Paule, with the wordes of Chriſt, wher he ſaith,Gene. cap, 2 it is not good for a man to lacke his wife. Theſe places maye eaſely be reconciled, if that we can diſtinguiſh betwene the pure ordinaunces of God, and the puniſhments of ſynne, which afterward folowed. For whatſoeuer euil & incommodity is in mariage, that commeth of the breaking of Gods commaundements. According to this diſtinctiō: At the beginning it was good to haue a wife without any exception, but now it is good in ſuch ſort, that ſorrow is ioyned with pleaſure, by the curſe of God. But they that haue not the gift of continencie, vnto thoſe it is a neceſſarye and a lawfull remedy to marry.

div.head: Huſband of one wife. 7.
div.p: IT is a childiſh gloſe, to interprete the huſband of one wife, to be the paſtor of one church. The Apoſtle doth ſimplye commaund, that a biſhop haue not twoo wiues together at one time, as certaine of the Iewes, and alſo of the Gentiles, being newly conuerted, then had, which was a ſuſpicion of much vnchaſtitye, and great wantonnes. Therfore (ſaith Paule) let a biſhop be the huſbād of one wife. It maketh no matter, whether he marry twiſe or thriſe, one after an other, or whether he do marry mayde or widow, ſo that he haue but one at one time. And here may you ſee that Poligamia is condemned of Paule by name, which Poligamie was then amogeſt the Iewes counted almoſt lawful: but Paule wil haue this ſpot far from a biſhop or prieſt.

Note alſo, that he maketh mencion of an huſband, leaſt through ſuperſtition, matrimony ſhould be forbidden to the Miniſters of the Goſpell, as it happened afterward moſt vngodly, and moſt vnlawfully. And truly there is no doubt, but that the holye ghoſt here woulde meete and come agaynſt this diabolical ſuperſtition, as though he had ſaid: biſhops & miniſters of the Goſpel, are not to be enforced to ſingle life, but much more it behoueth the godly to marrye. But yet he to whom it is geuen of God to leade a ſingle and pure life, is not to be reiected, but the more to be beloued. It is written, that euery man ſhoulde haue his owne wyfe,1 Cor. 7 to
flee fornication.Heb. 13 Alſo it is better to marry, then to burne. Furthermore, wedlocke is honorable, and a bed vndefiled among al men, yet this is alwaies to be excepted (except one haue the ſingular gift of continencie.) VVherfore, it was moſt tirannical to interdict mariage to ſpiritual mē, yea, although they liued moſt vnpurely and filthily, as Gratianus & certaine biſhops after him, haue decreed againſt all lawes, both of God and man, contrary to cuſtome and to nature. Siricius endeuoured to breake the mariage of ſpiritual men in Spaine, ſo did Gregory in Sicilia, & many other attempted the ſame in Germany. But the biſhops of Anguſta, of Magunce, and of Curia, did alwaies gainſay and reſiſt the edict & decree of Hildebrand, and did alwaies permit and ſuffer ſpirituall Miniſters to haue their wiues.

I am not ignorant, what Chriſoſtome doth ſay: who interpreting this place of one wife, which a Biſhop ſhould haue, yet doth adde, that ſome do expound, the huſband of one wife, to be him, which hath onely once alredy married, although nowe he haue none. And Chriſoſtome ſeemeth to be in doubt, whether that Paule doth exact and require of a Biſhop, that he haue one wyfe, or els whether he may haue manye at once, after the example of the Iewes.

Other do very ſtraightly vrge alſo, that in that age, in the which ther was a rare number of prieſtes, Paul did inſtitut, that no biſhop or prieſt which haue had two wiues, ſhould aſcend to that honour, that is to ſay (as they terme it) if he were bigamus.

Some other do affirme, that if anye had a wife before his baptiſme, & had married an other after his baptiſme, the former wife being dead, he ſhould be reſtrained from the miniſtery. But ſaint Hierome to thys doth greatly reclaime and gainſay.

One thing is much to be marueiled at, that when Paule doth require here ſo manye noble giftes and dowries in a biſhop, all other clauſes and partes ſet apart, this clauſe (the hauing of one wife) is onely vrged. He that committed inceſt, is admitted, the murtherer may be admitted, the pirate may be admitted, the ſacrileger maye be admitted. Finallye, who not admitted? But he that hath had two wiues, or hath one, or intendeth to haue one, is onely excluded from this honor. O double ignoraunce and blindnes. Marke here, how narrowly and how ſtraightly they vrge ſome thinges, vtterly wincking at other things.

It is to be feared, that a great number be made chaſte, more for feare of loſing eccleſiaſticall liuings, then for anye pietye or godlynes, being in feare, leaſt that thing that they haue (if they marrye) ſhoulde bee taken from them.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: I know the banbery gloſe of the Sarboniſtes of Paris, & other ſchole men, who doo ſaye, that they haue read of married prieſtes, but neuer of prieſts married, that is to ſay, that married men hauing wiues, & ruling wel their family, haue bene choſen vnto the miniſtery, as one Germanus Antiſsiadorenſis was choſen. And yet Hierome woulde haue them after they are married, to abſtaine from their wiues. But neither the Greciās nor any other ſay, that thei did euer marrye after they wer made prieſts.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: That ſpiritual Miniſters after they entred into the miniſtery, did marry wiues, I wil proue it both by counſels, & alſo by their own ſcholemen.

In the counſel called Synodus Amyrana, it was decreed, that whē the Deacon was ordered, if the vow of cōtinency wer required of him, & he do make proteſtation that he wil not liue without a wife, and doth reſiſt their requeſt, & do marry after he is ordered, it is no hinderaunce vnto him,, but that he may lawfully and frely liue in the function of the miniſtery. Out of the which place we are euidently taught, that it is lawful to marry after orders receiued. Of this Gratianus was not ignoraunt, and therfore he writeth, that concerning that Synode, we muſt reſpect the time and place, for it was kept in the eaſt church, which in ordering of miniſters did not exact of them any promiſe of chaſtity. Concerning the time, he ſaith, that the continency of miniſters, was not than brought into the church. This Synode was kept vnder Syricius, which liued in the time of Hierome, and Auſten.

div.head: Notio.
div.p: But I pray you let vs conſider how this tirannie did growe, and what roote it had. In the beginning miniſters that had contracted matrimony, were not ſo ſeuerely and rigorouſly handled.Deſtincti, 28 ca. preſbate For the counſell called Sinodus Naeoceſarienſis, did depoſe them only from their office, and not from their benefice, but were noriſhed and toke their ſtipende of the Churche. After that they began to remoue them not only from their office,Diſt 33. Eos et. cap, Decreuerūt but alſo from their office, but alſo from their benefice: yea and thoſe which did ſo contract, they did ſhut into ſome monaſtery, or into ſome ſtrait and narrow places to do penance. But our holye father (thankes be to god) doth make a cleane diſpatch of them by fagot and fier.

Not long after they began to practiſe their cruelty vpon the women,Diſt. 81. ex quo dam concilio Toletano cap, quidam. with whom the miniſters had contracted, whom they commaunded to be ſold, & to become the ſeruants of ye church, in the which the prieſt was, which contracted with them And if the biſhop coulde not driue them to that ſeruitude, thē they cōmitted the ſame to the prince, or to the lay magiſtrate. Yet their tirannye did not here ſtay, but woulde theyr chyldren
that wer begotten in ſuch mariage, to be made the ſeruaunts of that churche, in the which their fathers wer, & to be depriued of al their fathers inheritaunce. O double and triple cruelty, and prepoſterous paines & puniſhments, wherewith they puniſhe prieſts, lawfully maryed, and theyr lawfull children, ſparing adulterous prieſtes, hooremongers, and theyr hoores, and their baſtards. But to our purpoſe againe.

Caietanus the Cardinall doth affirme, that the Pope may diſpence with a prieſt of the weſt Churche to take a wife, after that he is made prieſt, and doth ſay furthermore: Nec ratione, nec authoritate probatur, quod abſolute loquendo, d • ſtinct, 3 • cap, alite, ſacerdos peccet contrahēdo matrimonium, nec ordo in quantum ordo, nec ordo, in quantum ſacer, eſt impeditiuus matri monii. It cannot be proued, neither by reaſon, nor yet by authority, that to ſpeake abſolutely, a prieſt doth ſinne in contracting matrimonye, nor the order, in that it is order, nor in that it is an holy order, is a ſtay or let of matrimony. As for the gloſe which doth expound Copulantur, id eſt, copulatio vtantur, is vayne and foliſh, for the very order of the text doth ſpeake of the contract of matrimony. Alſo he ſayth, that prieſthood doth not diſſolue nor breake matrimony contracted, whether it be before or after, if we (al other eccleſiaſtical lawes being ſet apart) ſtand onely to thoſe things, which we haue receiued of Chriſt and the Apoſtles.

The ſame Caietanus doth alledge out of Thomas, that the church may diſpence in both the vowes, that is, in the ſolemne vow of religious men, and in the vow of ſecular prieſts, ſo that it be for ſome great neceſsity, or ſome vrgent cauſe: & that he proueth by the fact of the Pope, which did diſpence, yea rather compell the king of Aragonia being a Moncke, to forſake hys religion, and to mary a wife, for the diſpoſition & ordering of that kingdome.

Yea, and furthermore he doth ſay, that the high Biſhop may in ſome other cauſe (though it be not for publike ciuility, nor eccleſiaſticall vtility) with a ſafe conſcience diſpence with a prieſt of the weſt churche to contract matrimony wythout ſynne, and ſayth, that that matrimony is of force.

To be ſhort in thys, I could bring a nomber of examples, that prieſtes after they were ordered, did marrye, not onely in other places, but alſo in this realme of England, which were diſpenſed with by the Pope.

div.head: Queſtio.
div.p:
Now I aſke whether his diſpenſation were lawfull, then I aſke againe, why it is not lawful aſwel for one, as for an other, & why the Pope doth by his lawes reſtrain yt liberti, & free vſe of thoſe things which god hath permitted & ſet at liberty to al men? If he haue a reſpect to ſome, & not
to other (for whoſe infirmity God hath prouided a lawfull remedye) he ſheweth him ſelfe, to be a tyraunt, a theefe, and a murtherer of ſoules. If his diſpenſation be vnlawful, than he ſheweth him ſelfe to be a very Antichriſt, which turneth the rootes of trees vpward, and doth tranſuerte all godly order. But that euerye man hauing not the gift of continencye, may lawfully marry without his diſpenſation, the holy ſpirit doth geue forth in many places of the holy ſcriptures: as in the Epiſtle to the Corinthians, in the epiſtle to the Hebrues, in the epiſtle of Paule to Timothie, in the epiſtle ſent to Tite, and in other places. As for the vow which they do ſo greatly vrge, is ſoone refelled. If chaſtity be the gift of God, what nedeth anye vowe of that which is alreadye geuen? If it be not the gift of God, than the vow is wicked, blaſphemous, and contrary to the worde of God. For what is he, that wyll preſume to promiſe that, which he is not able to performe?

Againe, euerye Chriſtian man ought to be perſwaded, that he is the ſonne of God. For otherwiſe how doth he call God father in his prayers, whoſe ſonne he doth miſtruſt him ſelfe to be? Therfore, if he be Gods already, why doth he vow himſelfe to God? Is not he that doth vow, in that opinion, that he is not Gods before his vow? And if he be reſolued that he is Gods ſonne, let him knowe, that he cannot vow that thing vnto God which was Gods before. Thoſe things which thou dooſt vow, either they be commaunded of God, or not cōmaunded. If they be commaunded, why doeſt thou vow thoſe things which thou art bound to do? Doth the ſonne vow to accompliſh his fathers cōmaundement, or is he bound to doo it? If they be not cōmaunded, whye doeſt thou inuent a proper worſhippinge of God of thine own head, as though the holy ghoſt had not ſufficientlye taught by the holy ſcriptures, by what meanes God woulde be worſhipped?
