Bernard doth call his votarye life, a loſt life. But I ſhall hereafter make more ful anſwer to all obiections of votaries and vowes.

VVher they ſay, that the apoſtles and other, did put away their wiues, after they were made prieſts, let vs ſomwhat examine this cauſe. Saynt Paule in the firſt epiſtle to the Corinthians hath theſe words.1, Cor. •
Haue we not power to eate and to drinke? Or haue we not power to leade about a wife being a ſiſter, as wel as the reſt of the Apoſtles, and as the brethren of the Lord, and Cephas?

This text is of diuers diuerſly interpreted. Some do ſay, that as certein women did folow and ſerue Chriſt, which followed him out of Galile, ſo did certayne godly, honeſt and rich Matrones follow the Apoſtles, which Matrones dydde miniſter of their goodes vnto the Apoſtles, that they might more expeditely apply the preaching of the Goſpell.

Lib. 3.Of this minde is ſaint Ambroſe, ſaint Auſten, and Chriſoſtome. Other do vnderſtand this ſentence of the wiues of the Apoſtles. Of this mynde is ſaint Clement an old writer, whoſe wordes Euſebius recordeth in the eccleſiaſtical hiſtory, which be theſe: Paulus quidem vxorem habuit, quā tamen, vt Petrus & alii, minime circumduxit. Paule had his wife, whom notwithſtanding hee led not about, as Peter and others did. Ignatius alſo in one of his epiſtles, doth teſtifie Paule to haue had his wife.
Now I aſke: whether better credite be to be geuen to Ambroſe, Auſten, Hierome, and Chriſoſtome, or els to Clement and Ignatius, who lyued in the Apoſtles time? Let other iudge.

Valla, a man of aſharpe iudgement, bringeth in a reaſon, by the which he ſeemeth to conuince, theſe wordes of Paule, to be vnderſtande of the wiues of the Apoſtles. His words be theſe: Satis fuiſſet dicere ſororem circumducendi, neque addendum erat
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , quis enim ignorat ſorores eſſe mulieres? &c. It had bene ſufficient to ſay, to leade about a ſiſter, & not to adde a woman or wife, for who doth not knowe ſiſters to be women: For there was neuer any ſiſter found, which was man, but contrariwiſe euery wife is not a ſiſter, bicauſe an infidel in wedlocke, may be a wyfe: but bicauſe ſhee is not of one religion with her huſbande, ſhe cannot be called a ſiſter. Therefore it behoued Paule, when he named a woman or wife, to adde to, a ſiſter, that therby it might be vnderſtand, the Apoſtles wiues, which were led about, to haue bene Chriſtians.

To this argument of Valla, two other argumentes maye be coupled, the one may be brought of the ſignification of this word circumducendi, to leade about. For this word cannot be vnderſtand of them, which do folow of their own accord. For theſe honeſt matrones, whereof ſaint Ambroſe ſpeaketh, were ſaid in the Goſpel to haue folowed Chriſt from Galile, that they might miniſter vnto them, and not to haue bene led about. For they are counted to leade about women, which haue power ouer thē, as the huſbands ouer their wiues, and maiſtreſſes ouer their maides.

Secondly, Paule in this place doth contende, that he gaue place to hys own right and intereſt, leaſt he ſhould burden the church, in taking coſtes & charges of the church toward his finding. But if rich women had folowed him, and had miniſtred vnto him of their goods, truly the church had not therwith bene burthened, but rather relieued & eaſed. For that which the Churche was bound to doo, thoſe Matrones being thereabout ſhould haue done.

To proue that Paule had a wife, ſaynt Clement doth bryng in the words of the Epiſtle written to ye Philippiās, where it is writtē in Greke after this ſort 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ,Lib. 3 cap. 4. Rogo te quo
que germana cōiunx. I
pray thee faithful yoke fellow: The latine interpreter doth ſay, germane compar, in ye maſculine gēder. Theophilactus alſo doth ſay, yt
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , is put in the maſculine gender, as thoughe Clemente and other whiche were Grecians, vnderſtoode not the Greke phraſe, as wel as Theophilact For the Grecians in certaine phraſes do ſometime abuſe the maſculine gēder, to expres the feminine. For example, Paule in the epiſtle to Titus,cap. 2. when he had put this word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which is the feminine gender, he added vnto it a maſculine Epitheton 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Furthermore, this woord 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 maye properly ſignify an huſband or wife.

Ouer and beſides theſe, Paul here doth cōmende women, which doth moſt aptly agree, if ye vnderſtand it of Paules wife. And wher he writeth to the Philippians, and doth expres ther no proper name, who ſhuld be vnderſtād to be that yoke fellow, except ye wil ſay with Lyra, compar to be a proper name, which ſauoureth to be far fet. And where ſome do iudge, not to be likely that Paules wife ſhould remaine at Philippos, but rather at Tharſus, which was Paules city, I anſwer, there might happen many occaſions, through the which at that time ſhe ſhould make her abode at Philippos. But let it be as ſome wil haue it, that Paule had no wife, it followeth not therfore, but that this place to the Corinthiās, may moſt aptly & likely be vnderſtand of the Apoſtles wiues, which if it be graunted, as the text doth enforce the ſame, the papiſts may euidētly ſe, yt the apoſtles kept their wiues after their calling, & after thei wer made prieſts. Saint Clement doth affirm, that Peters wife was with him in his peregrination, & when he did perceiue his wife to be led vnto death, for the profeſsion of her faith, he cried out with a loud voice vnto her, calling her by her name, ſaying: O conſūx, memēto dn̄i. O wife remēber ye lord.

Paphnutius, in the counſel of Nice, not willing to conſent to the decree of the whole counſel, that prieſts ſhould put away their wiues, and liue ſole, obtained that they ſhould kepe their wiues ſtyl, and that the liberty of mariage ſhould be reſtrained from no man, and that cohabitacion with a mans own wyfe, was chaſtity, and ſaid that the counſel in going about to diſplace prieſts wiues from them, opened a wyndow to ſcortation and whooredome. The whole coūſel reuolting frō their former decree, did conſent to Paphnutius. Saint Hierom him ſelfe, which was ſo ſtout a defender of virginity, and an vtter ouerthrower of matrimonye, writeth vpon the epiſtle to the Epheſians after this ſort: Legant epiſcopi atque preſbiteri, qui filios ſuos ſecularibus literis erudiunt, & faciunt comaedias legere. Let the biſhops and prieſtes reade, which inſtruct their children with prophane literature, and cauſe them to reade comedies. By theſe wordes of Hierome it maye appeare, that the Biſhops in his daies did keepe both their wiues and their children.

Hilarius the biſhop had a wife. Saint Auſten in his booke De bono coniugali, doth ſay, Quidam nubentes poſt votum aſſerunt adulteros eſſe • ego autem dico vobis, quod grauiter peccant, qui tales diuidunt. Certaine do affirme, them to be adulterers, which doo marry after they haue vowed: but I do ſay vnto you, that they doo greuouſly offend, which do ſeperate ſuch. By this ye may ſee, that ſaint Auſten willeth, not onely prieſtes, not to put away their wiues, but alſo doth greatly burden them with ſinne againſt God, which do put them apart.

Conſilium Gangrenſe, made this decree: Si quis nuptias in accuſationem duxerit, & mulierem fidelem & religioſam cum viro ſuo dormientem abhominandam crediderit, aut etiam accuſandam, tanquam non poſſint comugati in regnū dei ingredi, anathema ſit. If any man ſhal blame mariage, and beleue a faithfull and religious woman ſleeping wyth her own huſband, to be abhominable, as though marryed perſons coulde not enter into the kingdome of God, curſed be he.

Huldalrichus biſhop of Auguſta, writeth an whole epiſtle vnto Pope Nicholas, the firſt of that name, what a daungerous thing it was to ſeperate prieſtes frō their wiues. In the which epiſtle among al other things, theſe words following are cōtained. Sunt vero aliqui qui ſanctū Gregorium ſuae ſectae ſumūt adiutorium, quorum quidem temeritatem rideo, ignorantiam doleo. Ignorant enim, quod periculoſum huius haereſis decretum a ſancto Gregorio factum, condigno paenitētiae fructu, poſt modum ab eodem ſit purgatum. Quippe cum die quadam in viuarium ſuū propter piſces miſiſſet, & allata inde pluſquā ſex millia infantum capita videret, intima mox ductus paenitentia, ingemuit, & factum a ſe de caelibatu decretum tantae caedis cauſam confeſſus, condigno illud (vt dixi) paenitentiae fructu purgauit, ſuoque decreto prorſus damnato, apoſtolicum illud laudauit conſilium: 1, Cor. 7 Melius eſt nubere, quam vri. Addens ex ſui parte: Melius eſt nubere, quam mortis occaſionem praebere.

There be ſome which take Gregory for a mayntainer of their ſecte, whoſe temerity I laugh at, whoſe ignoraunce I lament. For they do not know, that the perilous decree of this hereſie eſtabliſhed of Gregorye, was afterward purged of him, with the woorthy fruite of repentaunce. For vpon a certaine daye, he ſent vnto his pondes for fiſhe, and when he ſaw ſixe thouſand childrens heads drawen out of the ſame, being ſtricken with a very inward and earneſt repentaunce, did muche lament it, and confeſsing the decree which he made for ſingle life to be the cauſe of ſo great ſlaughter, did purge the ſame, as I ſayd, with the woorthy fruit of repentaunce, and vtterly condemning his decree, did praiſe the coūſell of the Apoſtle, ſaying: It is better to marrye, then to burne. Adding of hys own part theſe woodes. It is better to marrye, then to miniſter occaſion of death.

div.head: The ſeconde Synode of Nice, 8. being the ſeuenth generall Counſell.
div.p:
Συνοδος Synodus, cōmeth of this praepoſitiō
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which he tokneth Cū & this word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which betokneth Via, away, & the whole word ſignifieth a Counſell, a couenticle, a congregation: which if it be generall, it is called Synodus
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , of the whiche, this ſecond counſell of Nice was coumpted one: which, how it was called and gathered, and by whom, I will declare anone. But firſt I will ſhew you the very ſomme and argument of the ſaid Counſell, which conſiſteth in theſe two verſes.

q.l: Nam deus eſt quod imago docet, ſed non deus ipſa,
Hanc videas, ſed mente colas quod cernis in ipſa.

div.p:
ALthough the image it ſelfe be not God (as they ſay) yet God is the ſelfe ſame thing, that the image doth teach vs, neither is the image it ſelfe to be worſhipped, but that which thou ſeeſt in the image. But ſome man perchaunce would maruell, whether theſe fathers wanted diſcretion and iudgement, or (according vnto the ſaying of Terence) An cum ratio ne inſanierint, were mad with reaſon, or els if they went about, malapertly to lay a myſt, and to blind the eyes of the whole Church. I truly vtterly perſuade my ſelfe, that to be verified in thoſe fathers, whiche Chriſt in the Prophet doth threatē vnto the diſpiſers of his word. The wordes are theſe: Facite voſmet ipſos ſtupidos, & obſtupeſcite ex coecati ſūt & exoecant ebrii ſunt, & non a vino, commoti ſunt, & non a ſicera. Quoniam operuit vos dominus ſpiritu ſoporis, Eſay, cap. 27. & obſtruxit oculos veſtros quin & prophaetas & praecipuos veſtros videntes operuit. Make your ſelues dull and wonder: they are blind, and do blind others: they are dronck, but not with wine: they ſtagger, but not by ſtrong drinke. For the Lord hath couered you, with the ſprite of ſlōber, and hath ſhut vp your eyes, the Prophetes alſo and your chief ſeers hath he couered &c. VVho at any tyme, which hath had but a taſt of Gods worde, did euer affirme, that to be God, which the image doth teach: and that to be worſhipped in ſpirite, whiche is ſene in the image? O ſhameleſnes. VVhat other thing can a man ſee in an image, but matter and forme? The forme of an image doth repreſent a man, hath therfore God a ſhape and membres like a corruptible man? why therfore were the Anthropomorphites condemned of hereſie? The matter of an image is either gold, ſiluer, ſtone, or woode, and ſometime earth & clay: but who would ſay, that God is either like vnto earth, a ſtone, woode or metall? how therfore is that God which the image doth teach? Agayne if he be to be worſhipped in the minde, which is ſeen in the image, then ſome earthly thing is to be worſhipped. For we ſee nothing in an image, but that which is earthly and corruptible. By this it is euident,
that blind buſſardes haue gone farre out of the way, definyng and conſtitutyng that whiche is agaynſt true religion and the infinite and vnmeaſurable maieſtie of God. Saint Paul is cleane contrary agaynſt them,Act. 17, ſaying: Synce that we are the generation of God, we ought not to thincke, that the Godhead is like either vnto golde, or ſiluer, or ſtone grauen by arte, or inuention of man. Neither do they onely offend againſt the diuine Scripture, but alſo they haue forgotten what the holy fathers before haue written. For Athanaſius agaynſt the gentiles writeth thus: If they thincke God to be of a corporall ſhape, geuing vnto him handes, feete, necke, breſte and all other members like a man, ſee vnto what impiety they are broughte, whiche are not afraide to haue ſo fonde a cogitation of God. For then it would neceſſarily folowe, that it ſhould be thought to ſuffer all thinges pertayning to the imbecillity of the body, if it be circumſcribed after the maner of the bodies of men. It will folow alſo, that it may be cut and deuided, and wholly periſhe. But who is ſo mad to thincke, that thoſe things happen vnto God? for theſe things are proper onely vnto earthly bodies. For God is without a body and incorruptible, immortall and euerlaſting, who hath nede of nothing. But theſe thinges are corruptible, and the lineamentes of their bodies hath nede of mans aide and arte. For we ſee them oftentimes to be renewed, whē they are olde, and that which either the length of time, rayne, or any liuyng beſt by chaūce haue deſtroyed, to be made new againe by mans helpe. But Lactantius writeth more plainly of this matter,lib. 2 • inſtituti •• am. cap, 2 ſaying: After yt God began to be preſent with vs, we haue not now any nede of the image of him. I aſke this queſtion, whether if a man continually behold the image of him yt is abſent, and is gone into farre countreis, that he may take cōfort of him being away, ſhal this man appeare to be in his wits, if he ſhal cōtinew ſtill in beholding the image of him who is now returned agayne and there preſent, and would rather enioy the ſight of ye image, thē of the mā himſelfe? no truly. For the image of a man then ſemeth neceſſary when the man is abſent and far of, but it is ſuperfluous when he is preſent. But the image of God is alway ſuperfluous and vayne, whoſe ſpirite & Godhead being euery where diffuſed & ſpread, cā neuer be abſent. VVhat cā be more plaine & perſpicuous againſt ye decree of theſe fathers? The ſame author hath wordes not vnlike to theſe, ſaying. But they are afraide, yt all their Religion ſhould be voyde, if they ſhould ſee nothing whiche they might worſhip, and therfore they ordein images: which bycauſe they are the images of ye dead, they are dead thēſelues, for they are deſtitute of all ſenſe & feling. But ye image of God which liueth for euer, ought to be ſenſible & liuely. If an image toke his name of likelines, how cā thoſe images be iudged like vnto God, which cannot moue or feele any thing, therfore
that is not the image of God, whiche is made with mans handes, of golde or ſtone, or of any like matter, but man him ſelfe is the image of God, bycauſe he feleth and moueth, and doth many actions. &c. And there is no cauſe, why our aduerſaries ſhould trāſferre the ſtate from God vnto the ſaintes: for as concerning the pictures and images of God, they are manifeſtly found to be in a wicked error. Now as cōcerning the images of the ſaintes, let the images of the ſaintes tell, whether they be the images of the ſoules, or of the bodies. The ſoules, bycauſe they are without a body, cā not be expreſſed in images. For we beleue, that the ſoules liue in felicitie with God in heauen, and the bodies rot in the earth, vntill the reſurrection. For this cauſe you will ſay, that you repreſent the bodies by bodily images. But how is it, that they do not behold and worſhip liuely bodies, rather then the ſhadowes of bodies rotten? do not theſe fooliſh men perceiue, that if the images could feele or moue, they would worſhip their makers, of whom they were poliſhed and decked? who if they had not ſo bene formed, they had remayned vndoubtedly a rude ſtone or blocke, mā therfore is, in a maner the father of images, by whoſe handes they were framed, and by whom they began to haue their ſhape, figure and beautie. And therfore he is better that made them, than they whiche are made. And no man doth worſhip the image makers, wherfore Seneca wrote worthyly in his mortall books agaynſt the gentils. They worſhip the images of the goddes, they humble them ſelues vnto thē, bowing their knees, they fall proſtrate before them, they ſit or ſtand by them the whole day, they offer rewardes, and burne ſacrifice vnto them. Finally, wheras they ſo much wonder, at thē, yet notwithſtanding the caruers that made thē, deſpiſe and contemne them. The Chriſtians likewiſe, wonder at images, they beholding them, prayſing and extolling the curious worckemanſhip in them, do in the meane time diſpiſe the workemanſhip of God. For very fewe do conſider the beauty and comelines of the things in the world, & do ſet forth the prayſe of their maker, as it is worthy. They ar occupied in the beholding of the fond & trifling toies of mā, wheras the diuine prouidence hath exhibited more arte, cunning, and wiſedom to be ſene and perceyued of vs in the litle Emmet or in a ſmall flower of the field, or in one leafe of a tree or herbe, then we can find in all the pictures or images of all the paynters and caruers, being neuer ſo finely wrought. And theſe fooliſh fathers, be not aſhamed, to ſend the ſimple people vnto the vaine and fond workes of mens handes. Let them therfore beleue theſe Counſels, vnto whom it is a pleaſure and delight to erre, ſtomble, and to fall. They which are wiſe, beleue the Scriptures, and therfore they beleue,
that theſe Counſels were mad & out of the way. For the Counſels which were after gathered by the authoritie of the Church of Rome, were nothing better, yea rather more fond and fooliſhe. But they ſay, that in all theſe general counſels the hereſie of not worſhipping of images, was condemned: For now they boldly and raſhly call that hereſie, which hetherto in the Church of Chriſt was called Orthodoxum, that is, of ſound and right religion. Surely they haue in their Councels defined and decreed thoſe things, which are contrary to the law of God, which neither was obſerued of the Apoſtles, nor the Apoſtles diſciples, nor can be ſhewed or proued by any Scriptures. Let them therfore ſee by what ſpirite, or how catholikly they haue intruded into the Churche of God the vſe of images. Saint Auſten writeth,In catalo. 8 hereſeon that there was a certaine woman named Marcellina, of the ſect of the Carpocratianes, which worſhipped the image of Ieſus and of Paul, of Homer, and of Pythagoras, humbling her ſelf vnto them, and offring incenſe. VVhat will our aduerſaries ſay here? Marcellina is ſet in the Cataloge of heretiques, bicauſe ſhe was a felow vnto the Carpocratians, & worſhipped ye images of Ieſus and Paul, and the images of the chief Poetes and Philoſophers. Ye call vs heretiques bycauſe we oppugne the images of the ſaintes, and teach with all the Catholiques and faithfull, that they are not to be worſhipped, that no kinde of adoration is to be done to them, no incenſe to be layd before them. Lactantius alſo iudged, that there was no religion, whereſoeuer images were ſet vp. VVe are called the ſubuerters of religion, bycauſe we endeuour to ouerthrow the deſtruction & peſtilēce of all religiō. If any mā deſire to know the wordes of Lactantius, they are theſe: There can be nothing greater then man, but that which is aboue man, therfore God is aboue man, and not vnder man: neither is he ſet in the loweſt region, he is to be ſought in the higheſt place. VVherfore it is not doubtfull, but that whereſoeuer any image is, there is no religion. For if religion do conſiſte only in diuine things, and there is no diuine thing but that which is heauenly, therfore all images ar without religion. For there can be nothing celeſtial in that thing which is of the earth.Libr, ſuſti. cap. 19. And for this cauſe the aunciēt and catholike Church did vtterlye auoyde all images. For we can bring proofe out of one Aelius Lampridius, an Ethnicke writer, that the primitiue Church did abhorre images,In vita imper Alex, Seueri for Lampridius writeth thus: Alexander Seuerus (ſayth he) aſcended into the Capitolle the ſeuenth day after he had ben in the Citie, he frequented the Churches, and he would haue a tēple erected vnto Chriſt, and receyue him among the goddes. The which thing al ſo Adrianus is ſayd to haue minded, who commanded Churches in euery Citie to be builded without images, which at this day, bycauſe they haue
no goddes, are called Adriani, that is the Churches of Adrian, which he was ſayd to haue made for this purpoſe, but he was forbidden of thē Aſking counſell of their goddes, learned, that all men would become Chriſtians, if that ſhould come to paſſe, and that all Churches would be forſaken. Hetherto Lampridius: manifeſtly declaryng, that it was the vſe of the chriſtians to haue no images in their churches. This thing Seuerus entēded to haue don, & Adrianus alredy had builded ſuch churches euerye where, that he myght geue an occaſion to induce the manner of the chriſtians, except the deuils had perſwaded the contrary, that is, yt images ſhould be ſet vp in the churches, leaſt their religion ſhould decay. If our aduerſaries refuſe the teſtimonie of an Ethnick man, let them heare Eraſmus Roterodamus, writing in this ſort: vntil the time of Hierome,In Catacheſino, the chriſtians were of a good and ſound religion, who ſuffred no image in the church, nor painted, nor grauē, nor wrought, no not ye image of Chriſt which way as I thincke, to ſtay the hereſie of the Anthropomorphites. But after that, the vſe of images crept into the churches by litle & litle. Thus much Eraſmus. Saint Hierome liued almoſt. 400. In proemie, lib, 3, continent, in Amos, yeares after the Natiuitie of Chriſt, as he him ſelfe doth witnes. VVherfore it is manifeſt, that the primatiue church of Chriſt was without images by ye ſpace almoſt of 500. yeres. Therfore it may not hereafter ſeme greuous vnto vs to be condēned of hereſie, & blamed with the primitiue church. Thou vnderſtādeſt therfore (gētle reader) how vnworthily and without a cauſe, our aduerſaries endeuour to condemn vs of hereſie, wheras it manifeſtly appeareth, all our endeuour and labour to tende to this end, that (all heatheniſhneſſe and hereſie beyng taken away) we may bryng in agayn, and reſtore the auncient orders of the Apoſtles, and of the Apoſtolicke Churches.

Now will I declare the cauſe, why this councell, and by whom this coū cell was called and gathered. There was one Irene, wife vnto the Emperor Leo the .iiij. of that name, who was the ſonne of Conſtantinus the fift, being ſonne to Leo the third, whom they called in deriſion I conomachus, that is to ſay a wreſtler and fighter againſt Images, & called Conſtātine his ſonne Copronimus, bicauſe, whē he was chriſtened, he defiled ye fonte with his dung. But other do ſay, yt when he was oftentimes waſhed of his nurſe, he would hādle his own doung with his hands, and therfore he was called Copronimus. Theſe two Emperours Leo & Conſtātine his ſonne cōmaunded images to be takē out of the church, and to be vtterly defaced.

Now this Leo the .iiij. Irenes huſband, begat a ſonne of her, who alſo was called Conſtātinus. And whē Leo was dead, & Conſtātine his ſonne very yong, Irene thempres toke vpō her ye gouernmēt of thempire. Vnder this Irene, images wer reſtored into ye churches. She alſo beīg accōpanied
with a great garde vpon the feaſt of the Natiuitie of our Lord, went into the great church of Conſtantinople, and reſtored agayne the crowne of golde adourned with precious ſtones, which her huſband Leo, had before taken frō thence. At this time in the country of Thracia, when a certayn man had digged vp a certaine piece of ground, there was found a certain coffin of ſtone, in the whiche was buryed a certayne man, and a certayne plate or peece of Braſſe was founde vpon the dead man hauyng theſe words written in it: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Chriſtus naſcetur de virgine: & credo in eum. Sub Conſtantino & Irene Imperatoribus, ò ſol, rurſus me videbis. That is to ſay, chriſt ſhalbe born of a virgin. I beleue in him, vnder Conſtantine and Irene themperous, O ſunne, thou ſhalt ſee me agayn. But whether this be true or no, Aliorum iudicium eſto. By the cō maundement of this Irene a councell of .iij. hundreth and fifty Biſhops was celebrate at the towne of Nice. The cauſe of this Synode was this. One Paulus was then Patriarke of ye Church of Conſtantinople, he being takē with a feruent ſicknes, left the cure & charg of his church, & lay in hys bed, as it had ben a man in diſpayr, to whō thempreſſe Irene made her repayre, and comforting him, did inquire the cauſe of his departing from the Churche. To whom he aunſwered, ſaying, I would to God, O Queene I had neuer entered into this ſee, which being oppreſſed with Tiranny, hath in it ſo many diuiſions, and none obediēce. But when he would vtter no more of his minde vnto the Queene, ſhe ſent vnto him the wiſeſt men of the Senate, which required of him the cauſe of his penſifnes. Vnto whō he anſwered, except ther be a generall councell called to redreſſe diſorders, & to vnite all Churches together, all things would come to wracke and confuſion. To whō the Senators ſayd agayn. VVhy diddeſt thou promiſe thy prince, when thou cameſt to thy See, that images ought not to be worſhipped. That thing ſaith he, cauſed the madnes of the rulers & your crueltie. So ſpeaking theſe wordes, with a few mo, he departed out of this lyfe. After him was choſen one Taraſius to be Patriarke, but he could not be conſtrained, neither by prayers, nor by manacies to take vpon him this dignity, except they would promiſe a general councell, which beyng graūted, he became Patriark went to Rome to Adrianus ye biſhop to haue conferēce wt him. VVhich Adrianus did write to al Patriarks & biſhops, yt they ſhould aſſemble to the citie of Nice, to celebrate a general coūcel, which was accōpliſhed. And thoſe things which were there agreed vpon were writtē in a certaine brief, & brought to Cōſtātinople, where they were opēly red & ſubſcribed vnto of ye princes & gouerners. The images were reſtored againe to ye tēples, & al Churches, vnited in one. This was the courſe of yt noble & worthy (Si diis placet) vii. generall coūcel, which ſat onely to maintaine ye honoring of ſtockes, blockes, & ſtones. But as yt
Prouerbe ſaith. Dignum patella operculū. Such a cup, ſuch a couer. Similes habent labra lactucas. Such lips, ſuch lettaſſes, ſuch councell ſuch doctrine. But I pray you marke ye charity of this ſtout and idolatrous dame, which being moued with ambition to beare rule, moued a conſpiracy againſt her own ſonne, and did hire and allure her Dukes and Lords with faire promiſes and large gifts, to kill him. To the which conſpiracy they all did aſſent, and haſtning into the court, toke him being alone, and moſt cruelly did put out his eyes. O bloudy fact, worſe then any Tyranny committed by Phalaris, which for the loue ſhe bare to images and idoles, did not ſticke to murder her owne ſonne made after the ſimilitude and likenes of God. Thus much for the ſecond Councell of Nice, and for the author and fautor of the ſame, is ſufficient.

div.head: Licentia. 9.
div.p: LIcētia & Libertas, differ in ſignification, for Libertas, is an honeſt & mean libertie, to do things comely not to paſſe the bonds of honeſty, Licētia, is an vnmoderat and diſſolute maner of ſaying or doing, as Terēce vſeth it, ſaying Omnes deteriores ſumus licētia, we are all made worſe by to much libertie. And Quintiliā ſaith: Quae in aliis libertas eſt, in aliis licētia vocatur. That whiche is called libertie in ſome, is called licence in other: and he that runneth to much at libertie, is called Licentioſus.

Plutarch doth report, how that Cato the elder, was wont alwaies moſt earneſtly to admoniſh the Magiſtrates, ſeuerly to puniſh the offenders in a common wealth, iudging nothing to be more pernitious in a publique weale, then licence, which he thought not to be born within a Citie, in ſomuch, that he iudged the Magiſtrate whiche could reſtrayne the offenders, and would not: worthy to be ſtoned to death.

Xenophō in his worke of ye ſayings & doings of Socrates.Lib. 4. Dic mihi (inquit) ò Euthy deme, putas ne bonā magnā
que poſſeſsiouē homini at
que ciuitati libertatē eſſe. Maximā (inquit) Quicū
que igitur corporeis ſeruit libi dinibꝰ, et ob eas nequit quae ſūt optima exequi, putas ne tu hūc eſſe liberū minime (inquit) Tell me (ſaith he) O Euthydome, doſt thou thinke libertie to be a good and great poſſeſsion to a man and to the Citie? Very great (ſayth he) whoſoeuer therfore doth ſerue bodily pleaſures, and through thoſe cannot execute thoſe thynges that be good, dooſt thou coumpt hym to liue at libertie? no verely ſaith he.

Demochares, being one of the legats, ſent frō Athenes to king Phillip, ſhewed forth the licēce of his tong. For whē king Phillip had gētly entertained thē, & ſaid ſay on you ambaſſadors, tel me, if I may do any thing to gratifie the citie of Athens. Thē ſayd Demochares, Suſpēde te, hang thy ſelf, which wordes ſauoured of to much liberty of ſpeech. This Demochares was called for the malapertenes and ſawcines of his toung Therſites.

div.head: Platonicall. 10.
div.p: OF Plato I haue written before, what he was: yet I thought good in this place to note two thinges. The firſt is of Idea, whiche Plato doth call the firſte ſhape or intelligence of thinges. VVhiche Plato denieth to be gendred and made, but doth ſay, that they be alwayes and are conteyned in reaſon and vnderſtandyng. Theſe were named firſt Ideae by Plato. And they be the eternall exemplars of thoſe thinges, whiche be naturally made: they be immortall, immutable, and inuiolable. And that the matter may be made more playne, it is nedefull beſide all men, to vnderſtand and conceaue in reaſon and vnderſtanding, an other certaine man, and beſide al horſes, to conceaue an other horſe: and beſides other beaſtes, to conceaue a beaſt vnbegotten. And as of one ſeale there be made many printes of the ſame ſeale, ſo of one man there commeth ſix hundred thouſand men. This is the Idea, of Plato, from whom Ariſtotle doth diſſent, and doth thincke, that ther be no ſuch Ideae. If you will more of theſe Ideae, red S. Auguſtin, who writeth of them at large in diuerſe and ſondrie places.

Secondly although the Academickes (of whiche ſecte Plato was author) were coumpted more modeſt then other Philoſophers, yet not all whiche were called by the name of Academickes, did obſerue the rule of modeſtie, but ſome of them did ſhewe forth both their great follye and their great errour. For what is more fooliſhe, then to haue the name of a Philoſopher, and to doubt and wauer in euery thyng, and to haue the certaynty of nothing? for they that doubt of all things, are very far both from faith and knowledge. Man is more noble then all other beaſtes by reaſon and vnderſtanding, but in certaine ſenſes, he is inferiour vnto certaine beaſtes. For the beaſt called Linx, is of a quicker ſight then mā, the Sowe of a quicker hearing, the Dog of a perfecter ſent and ſmel, the Ape of a better taſt, and ye Spider of a readyer touching. &c. But for as much as man doth excell all beaſtes by the power of diſcerning and vnderſtanding, who doth not coumpt that man more brutiſh then beaſtes, whiche thincketh him ſelfe to haue no reaſon to iudge things, and none vnderſtā ding to ſauor things. In ſo much yt we do perceaue, certaine brute beaſtes almoſt to embrace the image of reaſon. For the dog hath his affectiōs, & is mindfull of the benefites done vnto him: he knoweth his maiſter with whō he is familiar, and as though he were enobled with ſome wit and reaſon, he returneth to his maiſters houſe, when he hath loſt him, yea although the dog be .300. miles from his home, as I my ſelfe knew a dog of a certayne mans in Cornowall dwelling almoſt by the mount, being loſt in Londō, beyond the temmes came home agayne a fourthnight before hys
maiſter came out of London. The Camell is very mindefull of iniuries and wrongs done vnto him: the Vnicorne doth know the integrity of his virgin femall, in ſo much that he is delighted onely with the embracings of her, and none other. All other beaſtes haue a marueilous delight in the ſwete ſauour, that commeth from the Panther, and in beholding of him. Therfore feling by the ſwete ayre where the Panthers haue their reſort, thither will all beaſtes come. The fiſhes being in the deepe ſtreames, doe come to the ſhew of gold, wherupon that prodigall and laſciuious Emperour Nero did fiſh with golden nettes. VVhat nede many wordes. Torua Leona lupū ſequitur, lupus ipſe capellam. Florētē cithiſum ſequitur laſſiua capella. The cruell Liones doth chaſe the woulfe, the woulf him ſelfe doth chaſe the goat, and the wanton goat doth folow the grene herbe called Trifoly. So after this ſort is euery beaſt drawen and led with his pleaſure, which cannot be, if they ſhould doubt of their affections. They therfore which doubt at all things, by what temeritie or by what impudencie do they chalenge the profeſsion of Philoſophie? Looke more for the folly of this ſect in Saint Auſten, and in Cicero, who both with ſtrong reaſons do diſpute againſt theſe kindes of Academickes.

div.head: The reſidue ſhal iudge, 11. 1. Corinth. 14.
div.p:
THe Apoſtle Paul will haue .ij. or .iij. Prophetes to ſpeake in the congregation, meaning, that one ſhould ſpeake after an other. For if .ij. iij. or more ſhoulde ſpeake at one tyme, one ſhould let ye other and ſo there ſhould ariſe a great cōfuſiō, By this place of Paul it appeareth, that it was not the maner at yt tyme, that one alone ſhould make a ſermon by the ſpace of .ij. or .iij. houres vnto the people. But certain which were choſē, did propoſe vnto the congregation ſuch things as they had before purpoſed, geuing place in order ye one to the other, for then through the aboūdaūce of the ſprit many might be choſen, the nōbre of whō at this day is not ſo plentifull. Therfore to one alone is cōmitted ye prophecieng & preaching vnto the people. It foloweth in Paul: Et ceteri di iudicēt, & let the reſidue iudge. Paul doth cōmaūde,1, Cor. 14. that the hearers do expēde and waigh what is ſpokē, how aptly, and how godly things be expoūded, whether the interpretatiō of the preacher do correſpond & be agreable to ye analogie of faith. And here he ſheweth, yt it is lawfull to vſe ye gift of God to the edifieng of the cōgregatiō in keping of ſilēce, yt is, if diligēt hede be takē what is ſaid of others. Yet notwithſtā dīg here is not to be gathered, yt the word of god is ſubiect vnto ye iudgmēt of mā, but yt by the ſprit of god it be wel vewed, whether it be gods word or no, that is propoſed. For the Prophetes and holy men did not alwaies ſpeake by ye inſtinct of the holy ſprite, nor did alwayes vtter their mindes
out of gods word, for they were ſomtimes deſtitute of gods ſpirit, & therfore we read oftētimes in the prophetes theſe wordes. Et factū eſt verbū dn̄i ad me. And the word of the Lord ſayd to me. VVherby we myght vnderſtand, thoſe things that be written there, to haue proceded frō the ſpirit of God. The ſonne of god becōming mā, had onely this prerogatiue that he had the ſpirit of God alwayes remaining in him, which was declared to Iohn the Baptiſt, when it was ſaid vnto him: Super quē videris ſpiritū deſcēdētē & manentē ſuper eū, Iohn. 1 ipſe eſt, qui Baptizat ſpiritu ſācto, Vpon whom thou ſhalt ſee the ſpirit diſcending, and abidyng vpon hym, he it is which doth Baptize with the holy ghoſt. Marke here this word, Manentē, For the ſpirite of God deſcendeth vpon other, but it doth not alwayes remayne with them. And many of the holy fathers did often admoniſh the readers of their bookes, not to geue honor to their writings, which is due onely to the holy Scriptures. If this iudgement which Paule would to be obſerued, had bene warely and wiſely practiſed in the Churche, we ſhould not haue had at this day ſo many fooliſh traditions and wicked decrees of the Biſhop of Rome. But this ſeruitude wherin the Churche hath bene lately wrapped, came partly through ouer much flatteryng of the Biſhop of Rome, and partly through his violent tyranny, by the whiche he decreed it to be an horrible ſacrilege, to iudge and make inquiſition of his reſcriptes and conſtitutions.

Furthermore, ſluggiſhenes and idlenes hath ſo inuaded the mynds of men, that they had rather truſt to other mens iudgementes, then to their owne. But if God would haue vs to be iudge of his Prophetes, why may not the like be done of the Pope and his decrces. Yet men ought not here to take an occaſion of contention, and to vexe and to diſturbe the church. For Paule doth not ſay, let other make altercation, let other contende, but (ſayth he) let other iudge. It is one thing to heare him, that teacheth, and to vnderſtande and to iudge, and an other thyng by the ſpirite of contention to call all thinges (be they neuer ſo well ſpoken) into queſtion and disputation. For to iudge, it nedeth not nor behoueth, that the hearer doo gayneſaye the teacher in the open congregation: but it is ſufficient if he iudge in his harte of thoſe thinges whiche he heareth. And when the congregation is diſſolued, if he deſire any thing, to aſke it of him, when they be alone, for except this modeſtie be kepte and obſerued, we ſhould looke for nothing els but a vayne, hurteful, and vncomely altercation in the Churche.

div.head: Zacharias. 12.
div.p:
THere were many of this name. The one was a Prophet, raiſed vp of God to comfort the people of Iſraell, when they were returned
from Babilon, & to tell them that they ſhould renew again their temple and politicall gouernement, and that they ſhould certainly know, yt God would defend their common wealth vntill the cōming of Chriſt,cap. 9. 12. 13 1. Eſdras. 5. 3 2, paral. 24 of whoſe paſsion & benefites he doth Prophecy in many places of his booke.
An other was the ſonne of Ioiada the high Prieſt, who was ſlayne of Ioas the kyng of Iuda.
An other was a Prophet very familiar with the king Azaria.2. paral 26. Eſay. cap. 8
An other called zacharias was father in law to king Ezechias.
An other was the ſonne of Hieroboam the .xiiij. king of Iſraell,4, Reg. ca. 15 who raigned ſix monethes.

An other was a prieſt of ye courſe of Abia (of ye which courſe there is mētiō made in the firſt boke of Paral. cap. 24. Luke, 1) he was ye father of Iohn Baptiſt VVhich zacharias (Baſilius writeth) was ſlain betwixt the tēple & the altar, bicauſe he ſaid yt Meſsias was come, & was borne of a virgin.Math, cap 23.

Some do not allowe this opinion, nor yet the opinion of them whiche referre this to that zacharie, which exhorted the people being returned from exile out of Babilon, to the reedifieng of the tēple, who alſo is coūpted one of the ſmaller Prophetes, for althoughe thinſcription of the boke doth ſhew him to be the ſonne of Barachias, yet it is no where read, that he was ſlayne. Of the other zachary, the ſonne of Ioiada the whole Scripture doth report that thing which is moſt agreable to this place. That is to ſay, when after the death of his father, the religion decaied by the wicked apoſtaſie of the king and the people, zachary being indued with gods holy ſpirit, did very ſeuerely, ſharpely and openly rebuke their Idolatry, and therfore they ſlue him in the court of the temple. Nor it is any abſurdity, for his father Ioiada to haue had ye name of Barachie.2. paral. 24 For in ſo much he was al the dayes of his life a maintayner of Gods true religiō, he ought worthyly to be called Barachias, that is, the bleſſed of God. But whether he had two names, or whether there be an error in the worde, as Saint Hierome doth thincke, there is no doubt of the matter, but yt Chriſt doth note the ſacrilegious & bloudy ſtoning of zacharie in the place aboue alleged. He nameth this zacharie, not as the laſt martyr yt was killed: for ye poſterity of the Iewes did ingurge thē ſelues with ye bloud of martirs, of the which their fathers before had but a taſt, for there was great ſlaughter vnder Manaſſes. VVho knoweth not how cruelly they murdered the Prophet Ieremy? The Lord doth not imbrayd them with latter ſlaughters, but layed to their charge this one murder of zacharie, whiche was as it were the very beginnyng of theyr wicked and bloudy licentious doings, which afterward came to an vnſpeakable cruelty. Chriſt did comprehend vnder this ſlaughter of zachary, all other ſlaughters, whiche were or ſhould be done by them.
In Hebrew zachariah ſignifieth, Memor dn̄i yt is, mindfull of the Lord.

div.head: Helias. 13.
div.p: HElias Theſbites, was the greateſt Prophet of his tyme, he was rapte and taken away from men, whoſe ende no man knew. He did many miracles while he liued, and was like vnto a burning fier, in ſo much that his wordes burned like a torche. This Prophet firſt of al came vnto Achab, and ſpake vnto him in the name of the lord, for he had forſaken the commaundements of the Lord and folowed Baal, and he foreſhewed him the great drouth and famine, which ſhould folow and continew for thre yeares in Samaria. VVhiche when he had told him, he fled, and hid himſelfe thre yeares in a caue by a riuer, where continually euery day a rauen came & brought him meat. After when the riuer waxed dry, he departed into the citie of Sarepta, where he was nouriſhed of a certaine poore widow, during the time of all the drouth. And after it chaunced, that the ſonne of that woman whiche gaue him meate, dyed, who had no more children, and he was reſtored vnto life agayne by the prayer of the Prophet Helias, who as ſome ſay, was the Prophet Ionas. After thre yeares ended Helias prayed in the ſight of Achab the kyng, and there came forthwith, aboundaunce of rayne and hayle from heauen. VVherfore when Helias had ſlayne .450. Prieſtes whiche deceyued Achab and the people, he was perſecuted by the queene Ieſabel, in the reuengement of them. But he at the length departing into Oreb, the hill of the Lord, from thence came to Damaſcus, where by commaundement of the Lord,libr. 3. Regum, cap. 18. et 19 he anoynted Azael kyng of Siria, and Iehu king of Samaria. From thēce returning vnto the country of Iewes, and finding Helizeus at the plough and twelue other, he caſt his cloke vpon him, and began to Prophecie. Afterwarde when he had cauſed the Lord to burne with fier ſent from heauen the two capitaynes of Ochozia the king,Lib. 4. Regum. cap. 1 with their hundred men, he was caried vp into heauen with a hurle wynde in the ſight of Helizeus, leauyng him to Prophecie in his place. He gouerned the common wealth of the Iewes about .20. yeares.

Luk, 1 Math. 11.17, Mark 9,VVhere Malachias the Prophet doth write, that Helias ſhall come agayne before Chriſt, that the aungell Gabriell doth expounde of Iohn Baptiſt. Eliah in Hebrew, is as much to ſay, as Deus meus Iehoua, my God Iehoua.

There be two places in the Scripture cōcerning Helias, which ſeme one cōtrary vnto the other.Matheum, 11 cap. 4. Iohn, 1. The one is this. Ipſe eſt Helias. The other is, Non ſum ego Helias. In the Prophete Malachie Helias is promiſed in theſe wordes: behold I will ſend vnto you Helias the Prophet before the great and horrible day of the Lord come, and he ſhall conuert the hartes of the
fathers vnto the childrē, & the hartes of ye childrē vnto the fathers. &c. That Helias is Iohn Baptiſt, may be proued by the interpretacion of the Aungel, ſaying: he ſhal go before, in the ſpirite and power of Helias. And Chriſt in Mathewe: This is he, of whom it is written,cap. 11. beholde I ſende my meſſenger before thy face,Mark. cap. 1. Luke, 17 whyche ſhall prepare thy waye before thee. And if ye will receiue bym, he is that Helias which ſhould come. And in Marke, as before in Luke: Beholde I wyll ſende. &c. And in Mathew: I ſay vnto you, that Helias is alreadye come, and they knew him not. &c.lib. 4, Reg. ca. 2, Iohn therfore is that Helias of whom Malachy prophecied. But that Iohn denieth him ſelfe to be Helias, he doth not denye him ſelf to be that Helias, of whom Chriſt ſpake, but that Helias Theſbites, one of the citizens of Giliad, who was in the time of Achab, king of Iſrael, and taken vp into heauen in a firy chariot, of whom the Iewes dreamed that he ſhoulde come againe into the earth before the comming of the Meſsias, he denieth him ſelfe to be that Helias, aunſwering to their opinion, or elles hee aunſwered per
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , by thys figure tapinoſis, not arogating vnto him ſelfe anye dignitye, in the whyche he confeſſed him ſelfe to be leſſer then Helias, as he did alſo when hee ſhould haue baptized Chriſt, as though he himſelfe had muche neede of the water of regeneration. For this is peculiar vnto the holy fathers, that they wil not acknowledge in them ſelues any iuſtice, or manye vertues, nor ſtand in their own conceite, but will abaſe and humble them ſelues, which thing appeareth in Iohn:
To be ſhort, Iohn was not Helias proprie, but ſignificatiue.

div.head: Templum domini, templum domini. 14. Ieremiae. 7.
div.p:
FOr the better vnderſtanding of this clauſe, I thought it expediēt firſt to ſhew the cauſe why theſe words wer ſpoken, and to make diſcourſe therof from the beginning of the chapter. The Empire of Aſsiria vtterly fell and was deſtroyed vnder Sardanapalus, a moſt laſciuious and diſſolute king, but it was mightely reſtored, and repayred again by one Nabuchadonozor Priſcus, who was father to the great Nabuchadonozor, and euen then alſo it beganne to be called both the kingdome of Chaldea, and the kingdome of Babilon, not manye yeares before Manaſſes (graundfather to Ioſias the king) was taken of the Babilonians. Therfore, when the Iewes ſaw the prowes and ſtrength of the Chaldies to grow more & more (when Ioſias raygned) they did greatly feare their might and power, and did by diuers and ſundrye waies conſult betwene them ſelues, both of the wealth of their kingdome, and alſo of the preſeruation of the church. One was in one minde, and an other in an other
mynd. This mā truſted to one thing, & that mā truſted to an other thing, and ſo the mindes of the whole people were diuers, and did greatly varry: but the bounteous Lorde in theſe their doubtfull cares, commeth in very good ſeaſon, and helpeth at a pinch. He doth exhibite vnto them certaine good counſels, and ſendeth vnto them the prophet Ieremy to inſtruct them, how they might be deliuered out of theſe daungers, & how they might preſerue their kingdome whole, and kepe the integritye of religion. Firſt, he doth greatly vrge all eſtates and perſons, of what age ſo euer they were, to confirme themſelues to the good counſel of god, and (leauing al their vaine hopes) to truſt onely to the Lord God, to put away their corrupt maners, and to faſhion them ſelues to the wil of God. There wer ſeuen thinges, in the which ſpecially they did put their affiaunce. Firſt in the temple, in interceſsion of ſaintes, in manifolde ſacrifices, in mans wiſdome, in the large promiſes of falſe prophets, in mutuall conſent, finally in the aboundance of riches. Al theſe things doth the prophet moſt ſtrongly confute, and doth vtterly manace vnto them a moſt ſure and horrible deſtruction, except they would amend in due time.

And I beſech you, what haue our men done of late daies? Haue not the counſels bene their refuge? Haue they not there often conſulted how to preſerue the church and the common wealth? And what do their coūſels bring forth? Nothing els but Cockatrice egges. For al the counſels which haue bene aſſembled vnder the Romiſh biſhops, theſe. 500 yeares, haue diſcourſed and bebated nothing but theſe clauſes following. Firſt to extirpe al the Popes aduerſaries, that is (as they cal them) heretickes. To make reformation of ceremonies in al churches To haue gorgious altars, great nomber of Maſſes, fine chaunting and ſinging, to haue images in euery corner of the church, to diſſolue and breake the lawfull ſtate of mariage of the ſpirituall miniſters, to haue ſumptuous and rich copes, ſenſers, banner clothes, baſons, cruets, and what not? Finally, to ſet forth an army againſt the Turkes, to wynne the city of Hieruſalem out of theyr hands. But what commodity and profit haue iſſued from ſuch counſels, hiſtories, time, and dayly experience can declare. But for the extirping of idolatry, for the purity of preaching Gods word, for the right admiſtration of the ſacraments, for the cleane life of the clergy in putting away their hoores, and marying lawfull wyues, no reformation. Theſe things be bugges to them, with theſe thinges they wyll not meddle, leaſt theyr glory ſhould be defaced.

But the prophet here doth commaund the Iewes to heare the counſell of God, and to redreſſe their liues, and to forſake their hyll alters, theyr idoles, and their hie groues, which in dede they did in part, but not in the
whole. For their corrupt maners remained vncorrected, and the woorſhipping of Baal, was not vtterly aboliſhed and left. The prophet therfore was commaunded, to ſtand in the gate, and to preach to the people. Some write, that ther were in the city ſeuen gates, three on the North ſide, thre on the South ſide, and one which was moſt famous on the Eaſt ſide, in the which the prophet is reported to haue ſtand, and to haue ſaid thus: Bicauſe ye come to the temple to woorſhip the Lord, heare what the Lord ſpeaketh to you. And here by the way note, that although God be in euery place, and is included in no place, and ought to be woorſhipped in euery place, in ſpirite and truth, yet ſpeciallye and ſingularlye he ought to be worſhipped in the temples, and in the holye congregacions, which temples were inſtituted and ordained for that ende: that is, that worſhip and honor might be geuen vnto God openly, and in ſome certain place, as eccleſiaſticall diſcipline doth require. Out of the wordes of the prophet may be learned alſo, what all faithfull ought to do, when they come to the temples. Nempe vt adorent dominum, forſoothe that they worſhip the Lord. To worſhip the Lord (I ſay) and not dead ſtockes: to worſhip the Lord, and not to garniſh images with rich coates, with ſiluer and gold, with burning tapers and candels.

After this, the prophet doth ſhew them the whole counſell of God, ſaying: Emendate vias veſtras, & ſtudia veſtra. Mende your waies and your ſtudies. By waies and ſtudies, he vnderſtandeth althoughts & inuentions, and (as Hierome ſaith) al their ſayings and doings, whych be amended & reformed, when we omit thoſe things which god forbiddeth, and do thoſe things which God commaundeth. But the moſt part of men do contemne or litle ſet by, this wholſome counſell of God, and doo conſult of other inuentions. Now foloweth the vtility and profit of this coū ſel, which the prophet gaue them. Et faciam vos habitare in loco iſto, & I will make you to dwel in this place, that is, you ſhall not be deuoured in battel, you ſhal not be beaten with calamities and miſeries, but you ſhall be happy and bleſſed in your country, out of the which you ſhall neuer depart into captiuities, nor into the lands of your enemies.

But bicauſe the fooliſh people thā toke no great regard of the wholſom counſel of God, bicauſe they had vtterly conceiued vaine hope and truſt in vaine things (as in figures and ſhadowes) the prophet goeth foorth to open their folly, and to refute them, as it is the part of a good teacher, vtterly to take away thoſe things, which did let and hinder obedience and reformation of life. Ieremy therfore ſayth: Nolite fidere verbis mendacibus, dicentes: templum domini, templum domini, templum domini. That is: Truſt not in lying woords, ſaying: the temple of the Lord, the
temple of the Lord, this is the temple of the Lord. He repeateth thys word thre times, to ſignifie the ſure truſt that they had in the temple & in their ſacrifices, as though they ſhould haue ſayd: Is it like, that we ſhould be cut of by the battels of ſtraunge nacions, which haue here with vs the temple of the Lord? Yea, the temple which is the noble woorke of Salomon. VVhich temple hath theſe great promiſes, that is, if there come either battel, famine or peſtilence, yet they ſhal not anoy vs, if we go vnto the temple to craue pardon. VVho therfore would beleue vs to be deſtroyed of the Heathen, as the prophets do triflle?

In the like madnes are they, which in theſe dayes cry and ſay: Neither Turke nor Saraſen can ouercome vs Chriſtians, for we haue Abbeies of both the ſexes, in the which both men and women do ſerue the Lord, we haue Colleges, we haue temples, in the which ther is ſinging and reading day and night, in the which we haue mattenſing & maſsing, ringing & piping. It cannot be, but God wil heare vs. But let thoſe hipocrites perſwade them ſelues, that God did not ordaine by his word any ſuch kinde of worſhipping, any ſuch kinde of praying and prating as they vſe.

But to the prophet againe. Are ye not aſhamed (ſaith he to the Iewes) being defiled with ſo many horrible ſinnes, to enter into the temple of the Lord, which is called by his name, and conſecrated vnto him, and to perſwade your ſelues to be deliuered from all maner of calamities, onely for that ye enter into my temple, and are beholders of holy things? And yet notwithſtanding you ſteale, you murther, you be adulterers, you cōmit periury, you offer incenſe vnto Baal, you follow thoſe Goddes whom you know not. VVhat do you meane? Is my houſe in your eyes nothing els but a den of theues? I know that you reſolue your ſelues, that your doings are hidden, & that with your hipocriſy you may deceiue both God and mā. You are deceiued, for I know (ſayth God) the very ſecretes of your mindes, I vnderſtand al the wicked imaginations of your harts.

It ſhalbe beſt to excuſſe and examine certaine ſingular wordes of thys ſentence going before, & ſo to apply thē to our erudition and doctrine, with out the which the words of the prophet are not ſo much auailable.
The prophet here doth recite certaine receiued & cōmon kinds of ſin.
By theft, he vnderſtandeth fraud, guile, diſceite, vſury, & ſuch other vnlawful and vngodly craftes and meanes.
By murther, he vnderſtandeth wrath, hatred, ſtriuings, enuy, ſtripes ſlaughters and vnlawful warres.

By adultery, he vnderſtādeth voluptuous luſts, inordinate pleaſures, & al vnclenlynes in mind, word & dede, filthines, fornicatiō, hooredōe, & ſuche other impurities. By periury, he vnderſtādeth lies, vnfaithfulnes, breaking of othes & couenāts, execratiōs, curſings & blaſphemies.

By inſenſe offred to Baal, he vnderſtandeth and comprehendeth all vnlawfull rites and ceremonies, idolatry, apoſtaſy, and vnlawfull worſhippings. And yet the ſuperſticious and proud Iewes, beyng corrupted with al theſe ſpots, came vnto the temple, and ſtoode without ſhame in the ſight of God, ſaying: Although we haue done al theſe abhominaciōs, yet are we deliuered and made free, onely bicauſe we viſit the temple.Iere. 7. For if ther be nede of any expiatiō or purging, we be made cleane by viſiting the temple. But the Lord ſaith vnto them: Theues & robbers, after they haue ſpoiled and robbed waifaring men, vſe their dennes and caues, lying lurking ther, thinking to eſcape vnpuniſhed. And do ye (ſaith God) endeuour to abuſe my houſe, as theues do their dens? For ye go through all kindes of miſchiefes, & then run to my temple, as though you might (by that) take your pleaſures and liue without puniſhment. You are fouly deceiued. VVhat deſerueth he, that abuſeth the court of a prince, as it were the ſtewes? Truly, not to much puniſhment.

This place may be ſomwhat applied againſt the abuſe of our temples. Temples be not vaine and vnprofitable, but ordained for the holy aſſemblies, to heare the word of God, to poure out their publike praiers before God, to receiue the ſacraments, to learne rightuouſnes, and to liue godly. The abuſe therfore of the temples is, if we perſwade our ſelues to be accepted of God, if we enter once into the temple, and do no more. For it is not ſufficient to heare, and ſee onely, except we beleue in God, & walke in the integrity of life alſo.

Saint Hierome expounding this place of the Prophet, writeth after this ſort. Praecepit (inquit) & tunc populo Iudaeorum, & hodie nobis, qui videmur in eccleſia conſtituti, ne fiduciam habeamus in aedificiorū ſplendore, auratis que laquearibus, & veſtitis parietibus, marmorum cruſtis, & dicamus: Templum domini &c. Illud enim templum domini eſt, in quo habitat vera fides, ſancta conuerſatio, omniūque virtutum chorus. Et mox: Quid enim prodeſt, audactar ingredi domus dei limen, erecta ſtare ceruice, & nōſoſum cor, ſed & manus habere polutas furto, homici dio, adulterio. &c. Haec ille. God then cōmaunded the people of the Iewes and now vs, which are conſtitue in the Church, that we haue no truſt in the beautifulnes, and golden beames, and gilted roofes of buildinges, and the walles decked and pargetted with ſhardes of marble, & that we ſay not: The temple of the Lord, the temple of the lord, the temple of the lord is here. For that is the temple of the lord, in the which dwelleth tru faith, holy conuerſation, and the quier of vertues. VVhat doth it profit to enter boldly into the houſe of God, to ſtand bolt vpright, and to haue not onely the hart, but the hands alſo embrued with theft, hooredome and murther? Let vs apply theſe thinges to our temples and our maners, & let vs learne not to truſt in temples, but to flee all impiety & hypocriſie,
and to ſerue God in truth and verity.

To make an end. Note here, that as the Iewes did truſt, call, and cry: Templum domini, templ m domini, ſo our Papiſtes haue nothing in their mouthes, but the church, the church, the church. And if the holy ſcriptures be alledged againſt them, and their adulterous doctrine: tuſh (ſay they) howſoeuer ye vnderſtand the ſcriptures, we wil expound thē after the ſenſure of the church, for the church is lady and iudge ouer the ſcriptures. Theſe may be wel compared to the pariſh clarks wife, which made anſwer to one, that, howſoeuer the ſunne went, her huſbands clock went true. So whatſoeuer the ſcripture ſaith, be it neuer ſo ſtrong & pithy, for the confutacion of their errours, yet their church muſt nedes be true, with the pariſh clarkes cloke:

div.head: Anna. 16.
div.p: • , Reg. 1. THer were thre of this name. The firſt was Anna the wyfe of Helcana, the mother of Samuel the prophet, which of a lōg tyme was barren, and derided by Peninna, the other wife of Helcana, yet at the laſt God did viſit her, and made her wombe fruitful. This Anna may be an image of the true church of God, which before the worlde is barren, that is comfortles, and deſtroyed with the croſſe and many calamities, which croſſe doth feare away many frō the doctrine of ye goſpel

The true church therfore ſemeth to be barren, that is, to haue a few diſciples, yea almoſt none, in ſomuch that it ſemeth vtterly to periſh. It hath not thoſe worldly praiſes, thoſe magnificent braueries, which the hipocritical church hath. It hath not theſe corporal commodities, & gaye glitterings, it hath not that great multitude and nomber aſwell of ſubiectes as of princes. But as Peninna did moleſt and vexe poore barren Anna, with ſharpe checkes and tauntes: ſo the church of Antichriſt doth lay and heape al maner of opprobries, vpon the true church of Chriſt.

The ſecond Anna was a prophetiſſe, the daughter of Phanuel, of the tribe of Aſer, and did with her confeſsiō and teſtimony anſwer vnto Simeon, confirming Chriſt to be geuen, and did render thankes vnto the Lord, that Meſsias the redemer was exhibited. If this Anna were .xv. yeares of age when ſhe was married, and lyued 7. yeares wyth her huſband after ſhe was married, and than .84 in her widowhood, we muſt nedes confeſſe that ſhe was .106. yeares old. She might therefore in her youth haue ſene old men, which were familiar with Iudas Machabeus. The Euangeliſt ſaint Luke declareth the genelogy of this chaſt widdow,Luke, 2 ſaying, that ſhe was the daughter of Phanuel, of the tribe of Aſer. Thys Anna tooke her name of the thing which ſhe had, that was the grace of the prophetical ſpirite, being called the daughter of Phanuel of the tribe
of Aſer, did after a certaine ſecret maner ſignify the bleſſed reſurrectiō. For Aſer betokeneth in the Hebrue toung beatum, bleſſed, whereof we reade in Geneſis, when Zilpha the handmaiden of Lia, had borne an other ſonne to Iacob, then ſaid Lia: bleſſed am I,Gen. 30 for the daughters wyll bleſſe me, and therfore ſhe called his name Aſer.Gen. 49 And Iacob before he departed out of this life, bleſſed Aſer, ſaying: his bread ſhall be fat, and he ſhal geue pleaſure for a king. This Anna I ſay, gaue likewyſe teſtimonie of Chriſt. Note here, that Ieſus tooke teſtimony of Zachary the prieſt, of Elizabeth his wife, of the angel, of the ſhepheards of Bethlem, and of the wiſe men of the eaſt, that is, of al perſons, of what ſtate, what age, what ſect ſoeuer they were. Now that nothing might want, Luke doth bring in here the teſtimony of Anna the widow, wherby it maye throughly be cōfirmed, yt God had ſent his ſon, the ſauiour of the world, into the world.

The third Anna was, as Epiphanius and Procopius writeth, the mother of the virgin Mary, yea and the nurſe of Chriſt alſo, as one of them ſaith, ſhe was the daughter of Iſachar, of the tribe of Leui, or as it pleaſeth Damaſcene, ſhe came of the tribe of Iuda, being married vnto one Ioachim of her own tribe. VVhen ſhe had remained barren a certayne time, at the laſt ſhe conceiued & brought forth Mary the mother of god. After Ioachim her huſband was dead, ſhe married Cleophas, of whō ſhe bare an other daughter called Mary. Cleophas betrothed Mary the virgin, vnto his brother Ioſeph, and coupled Mary his own daughter, vnto one Alpheus. Of this Mary was borne Iacobus Alpheus, Symon Cananeus, and Iudas Thaddeus, who alſo was called Barſabas. VVhen Cleophas was dead, this Anne married the third huſband, whoſe name was Salome, of whom ſhe bare the third daughter, called by name Maria Salome: who being married to zebedeus, did beare Iames the greater, and Iohn the Euangeliſt. Of this Anna, theſe verſes following wer made.

q.l: Anna ſo let dici tres congenuiſſe Marias,
Prima parit Chriſtum, Iacobum ſecunda minorum,
Et Ioſeph iuſtum peperit cum Symone Iudam
Tertia maiorem Iacobum volucremque Iohannem.

div.p:
This Anna alſo is ſaide to haue had a ſiſter, whoſe name was Emeria, of whō Elizabeth Iohn the baptiſts mother was borne. And therfore ye āgel ſaid to Mari, Ecce Elizabeth cognata tua, Luk. •
behold thi coſē Elizabeth hath cōceiued. Anna is writtē in ye hebrue Hāna, which betokeneth gratioſa.

div.head: Arrius. 17.
div.p: ARrius (as Epiphanius writeth) was the ſonne of one Ammonius, who being at Antioch, hauing to companion Euſebius of Nicomedia, heard Lucianus the prieſt and Martyr, of whom he was inſtructed in the holy ſcriptures.

By what occaſion he came to the dignity of prieſthood at Alexandria, it is not knowen, except that the interpretation of the ſcriptures was committed vnto him aboue the other prieſtes, bicauſe he was very expert in the arguments of Dialect, and well exerciſed in ſuch diſciplines. Of the ſtature and habite of his body and minde Epiphanius reporteth thys: He was of a very long ſtature, of a countenaunce ſomwhat ſad, figured lyke a ſuttle Serpent, which could deceiue euerye innocent hart through hys crafty pretence. He alwaies did weare his mantle or robe but halfe vpō the one ſide. He was pleaſant in talk, a faire & flattering perſwader, by the which crafts he allured & brought in a ſhort ſpace .700. Virgines (which had profeſſed chaſtity) into his ſentence and opinion, beſides .7. Prieſtes, and .12. Deacons.

His hereſy was, that Chriſt concerning the godhead, was not of one ſubſtaunce with the Father, with many other errours. Nicephorus writeth, that one Alexander Baucalis the ſecond Prieſt next vnder Arrius, the authour of this diſſention, who (diſdaining that Arrius ſhoulde be preferred in honour before him) did caſt this newe doctrine vpon Arrius, as the authour therof. Saint Hierome doth ſay, that Arrius, Euzoius, Diaconus and Achillas the Reader, were authours of this hereſy, but emulation and enuy towards Alexander, Biſhop of Alexandria, ſtirred and moued Arrius to vtter this new doctrine. For he thought hym ſelfe nothyng inferiour in doctrine and learnyng vnto Alexander, for he thought by this meanes to come in eſtimation, and to be in euery mans mouth. Ruffinus wryteth, that other Biſhoppes and Doctours of the Church (who had great delight in ſuttle and crafty queſtions) ſpurred foorth Arrius to this fury. Zonaras doth write, that Origine was the firſt authour of this hereſy, for he was the firſt that affirmed, the onely Sonne of of God to be made, and to be diuers from the nature of God the Father. But theſe thinges lay hidden in papers, couered with ſcilence, & not yet publiſhed, but Arrius brought them foorth into light, preached them openly, drawing many vnto this his impiety, as is ſayd before. Thys his hereſy being deprehended and knowne, Alexander the Byſhoppe did conferre with hym verye familiarlye, endeuouring to wythdrawe hym from hys wicked and bold enterpriſe, but al was in vayn. Therfore he remoued him from the dignity and function of prieſthood. Arrius being thus remoued and confuſed, fled into Paleſtine, and there laboured with flattering and faire meanes to get vnto him, companions to be partakers of his error. He cōming to Nicomedia to his old frend Euſebius, was verye gentlye entertayned of him in his houſe, and when hee had remayned ther a good ſpace, he allured Euſebius fully and wholly into hys ſentence:
And vſing that for a chiefe helpe, he and his companion Euſebius, ſent letters to Alexander. VVhen the fame and talke of Arrius came to the eares of Conſtantinus the Emperour, he much deſiring to heale this peſtilent and heretical contagion, which had infected not onely the city of Alexandria, but alſo many other cities and prouinces beſide, commaunded a generall Counſel to be kept at Nice, in the which Counſell Arrius was conuicted, reiected, and condemned. A certaine Prieſt receiuer of Conſtantia (who was the ſiſter of Conſtantine, and the wife of Licinius the tiraunt) fauouring the doctrine of Arrius, talked oftentimes by occaſion vnto Conſtantia of Arrius, excuſing Arrius cauſe, and that he thought not ſo, as was layd to his charge, and that he was vniuſtlye condemned of the counſell, and ſo had ſoone perſwaded the woman, beyng light of credite. It happened, that this Quene fel into a deadly ſickenes, and the Emperour came to viſit her, ſhe hauing oportunitie, commended this Prieſt vnto him, as a godly and diligent man, and one that wyſhed wel to the Empire, and a litle while after ſhe dyed. The Prieſt being thus commended vnto the Prince, beganne not long after to intreat of Arrius cauſe vnto the King, and ſayde, that he was oppreſſed with ſlaunders agaynſt all right and reaſon. Then aunſwered the King, ſaying: If Arrius doth conſent and hold with the Synode, I wyll cauſe hym to be reſtored vnto hys own place and dignity at Alexandria. And ſo directed his letters to Arrius, written in this manner.

p.hi: Victor Conſtantinus, Maximus Auguſtus. I am olim ſoliditati tuae ſignificatum eſt, vt in caſtra mea venires, quo conſpectu noſtro frui poſſes, vehementer vero admiramur, quod id non confeſtim feceris. Quapropter iam aſcenſo publico vehiculo, ad caſtra noſtra propere venias: vt clementia ac prouidentia noſtra potitus, ad patriam reuerti queas. Deus te cuſtodiat frater .6. Calend. Decembris.

div.p: The conquerour Conſtantine, and mighty Emperour. VVe did ſignifie vnto thy ſoundnes heretofore, that thou ſhouldſt come to our court to appeare before vs: but wee doo greatly marueyle, that thou haſt not ſo done forthwith. VVherfore, euen nowe taking the common chariot, come vnto our caſtell with expedition, that hauing obtained our clemencie and prouidence, thou mayeſt returne to thy country. God keepe thee brother. The .6. Calendes of December.

Beſids theſe letters, ye diligent endeuour of Euſebius & his cōpanions, moued Arrius to go to ye Emperor, of whō when he cam, being cōmaunded to declare & proteſt in plaine writing his ſentence & minde of the Chriſtian faythe, dyd exhibite vnto the Emperoure, a writinge of hys fayth, agreing to the woordes of the fayth of the Nicene counſell, notwithſtanding
he ment ſimulation, craft, and diſceite. The tenor of the writing was this.
To the deare and beloued in God, our Emperour Conſtantine, Arrius and Euſebius Prieſts, ſende greting.
VVe do expound in this writing, O Emperour, vnto thee our fayth, as thy holines beloued of God hath commaunded. VVe, and al that be wyth vs, do confeſſe to beleue as followeth.

VVe beleue in one God the Father almightye, and in the Lord Ieſus Chriſt his ſonne, begotten of him before all worldes, true God, by whom al things were made, aſwel things in heauen, as thinges in earth, which came, tooke fleſh, ſuffred, roſe againe, aſcended into heauen, and ſhall come againe to iudge the quicke and the dead. And in the holy ghoſt, & the reſurrectiō of the fleſh, and the life of the world to come and the kingdome of heauen, and one holy catholike church, diſperſed from one ende of the world vnto the other endes of the ſame.

This faith we haue taken out of the Goſpell, the Lorde ſaying vnto his Diſciples: Go and teache all nations, baptiſing them in the name of the Father, the Sonne, and the holye Ghoſt. If we beleue not theſe thinges, and trulye receiue the Father, the Sonne, and the holy Ghoſt, as the whole catholike church doth beleue and receiue, and the holy ſcriptures do teach, according to the which we beleue al things, let god be our iudge, both now, and in the day to come.

VVherfore we deſire and beſech thy pitifull goodnes (O Emperour) that thou wylt vnite and ioyne vs as eccleſiaſticall perſons, holding the faith and iudgement of the church, & of the holy ſcriptures, to our mother the church again And that al ſuperfluous queſtions and words iſſuing out of the ſame, being cut of, we and thy church may peaceably be reconciled and reſtored agayne eche to other.

After that Conſtantine hadde taken notice and knowledge of theſe writings and words,Sozom Li, 2. cap. 7. he aſked Arrius, whither he had any other thing in hys mynde or no, and whither he truly beleued yt which he had profeſſed? Arrius aunſwered, yt he would affirm by an othe, that he holdeth the faith of the catholicke Churche, and doth rightlye beleue. The Emperour then did abſolue & acquite him, ſaying: Si recta eſt fides tua, probe iuraſti: ſin impia eſt fides tua, & iuraſti: Iudicium dei de te erit de caelo. If thy fayth be right, thou haſt ſworne wel, if thy fayth be wicked, and haſt ſworne, the iudgement of God ſhalbe vpon thee from heauen.
Lib. 1. cap 38.Socrates ſayth, that Arrius caried his doctrine written in paper vnder his arme, and ſo did craftely and falſly ſweare, that he truely beleued as he had wrytten.

Conſtantinus doth ſend Arrius with his adherentes to Hieruſalem, and the Biſhoppes, who than by chaunce were ther gathered and aſſembled: and wrote alſo, that they ſhould vew wel and conſider the writing of Arrius, and whither he had truly repented or no, and to examine diligently whither he had ſuſtained iniury at Alexanders handes or no. The biſhoppes, bicauſe they woulde doo nothing contrary to the Emperours minde, did receiue Arrius and his fellowes into their communion and fellowſhip again. And they ſent forthwith, letters to the Emperor, to the church of Alexandria, and to the Biſhops and Clergie throughout al Aegipt, The baida and Lybia, exhorting to receiue Arrius and his company with a willing minde, and ſayd, that the Emperour had hy himſelfe geuen teſtimony vnto their faith, that it was right and true, and that the whole Synode had ſubſcribed to the Emperours ſentence.

Arrius being glad of this iudgement,Sozo Lib. 2. cap. 27 and of the ſucceſſe of his diſsimulation and deceit, after the Synode holden at Hieruſalem, was diſſolued, returned into Aegipt. And remaining at Alexandria for a certain ſpace (but yet in vaine) when Athanaſius would ſuffer by no meanes him to be admitted to the communion, he departed to Conſtātinoble, wher whē they would haue brought him in by a certayn violence, Alexander, who at that time had the gouernment of that church, did reſiſt him with the like violence, and ſaid, yt it behoued not the author of hereſies, & the troubler of ſo many churches, to be receiued. The matter at laſt grew to great contention and ſtrife, the Euſebians manacing and threatning, that except Alexāder would admit Arrius, he ſhould be caſt out of the church and liue an exile, and that his ſucceſſour ſhould receiue Arrius vnto the communion and fellowſhip of the church againe. The Euſebians the next day following, purpoſed to bring in Arrius into the church. Alexander repoſing greater truſt in the armour of godlynes, went into the Temple with two of his familiars, and lying proſtrate before the aulter or table, weping al the nighte, poured out praiers to God the Lorde of churches, that he would not ſuffer the woulfe to be mingled with the ſhepe, & that he would not admit him, who entending to play the woulfes part, had couered him ſelfe with a ſhepes ſkyn. He prayed alſo as ſome write, after this manner: If Lord thou wylt permit hym, who endeuoureth thus to creepe into the church, I beſeche thee by thy vnſpeakeable counſell, that thou wilt deliuer me thy ſeruant out of this preſēt life. After he had thus prayed, he returned home weeping.

The next day following, Arrius cōmeth forth with a great pompe, being proud & malapert, through the truſt which he had in the Euſebiās, by whom he thought, or rather dreamed, that he ſhould be placed forthwith in the biſhops throne. But marke a marueilous example of Gods
iudgement: Arrius was led with a great and ſolemne triumphe, when he came vnto the court of Conſtantine, a great feare wounding his conſcience, came ſodenly vpon Arrius, and the loſenes of his belly conſtrayned him to deſire ſome ſecrete place out of the way, wher he might eaſe hymſelfe. The train which came with him, to bring him to the temple with a pompe, looketh in the meane time when Arrius would come foorth, but he was thought to haue taried very long. Certaine therfore of them went in, and found Arrius ſitting dead vpon the draught, al his guts & bowels being diſſolued and gone from him by the neather partes.

This was the miſerable end of Arrius, whom although they which were of his iudgement and minde, laboured to deliuer from ſuche a foule ſhame (ſome ſaying that he was ſodenly taken about the hart) other ſaiyng that ouermuch ioy & mirth killed him, ſome affirming that he was poyſoned, yet many iudged, that Arrius through his impiety & wickednes, ſuffered paine, ſent of God worthy his deſertes.
Athanaſius doth write in his epiſtle Ad Serapionem, that by the ſodaine and miſerable death of Arrius, many which before were deceyued by him, were conuerted againe to the faith.
Saint Auſten doth ſay, that the paine of Arrius in hell doth encreaſe, as often as any one in the church is infected with his hereſy.
Sulpitius doth write, that there were twoo of the name of Arrius, which were as two Serpents hiſsing with one mouth.

div.head: Athanaſius. 18.
div.p: AThanaſius biſhop of Alexandria was a famous man in holines & knowlege: he ſuffred many & greuous perſecutions of the Arrians. For he being conſtituted againſt the Arrians, in the coūſell of Laodicen, with moſt euident reaſons & very ſtrong argumēts affirmed, God the ſonne to be of one ſubſtāce with the father, which thing Arrius and his adherents could not refel. Therfore ſtirred vp almoſt the whole world to perſecute Athanaſius: who flieng away (as Hierome ſaith) dyd hide himſelf .6. yeares continually, in an empty and dry Ceſtern, where he neuer ſaw the ſunne. VVhich yeares being expired, when a certayne wench had vttered him to be ther, by Gods prouidence he fled frō thence. For then al princes, countries and kingdoms with their hoſts, came together to purſue him, by means wherof he wandred about the world, inſomuch that he could finde no place to hide him ſelfe ſafely. At the lēgth after many vexations and ſufferinges, he dyed in the time of Valentinianus and Valens the Emperours, in the yeare of the Lord .379. the ſyxt Nones of May, and in the .46. yeare of his prieſthood.

Ruffinus writeth in his Eccleſiaſticall hiſtorie, that the Arrians fearing leſt Athanaſius ſhould haue occaſion of acceſſe to the Emperor Cō ſtantine, did accuſe Athanaſius of Magicke and murther, and ſayd, that he had cut of one of the armes from the body of one Arſenius to practiſe Magicke. VVhich thing the Emperour hearing, commaunded a councell to be gathered at Tirus, where he bad Athanaſius to be condēned. Athanaſius was led thither, & one of the Emperours noble men was ſent thether to be as Lord iudge and examiner of the ſaid cauſe. Now this Arſenius whoſe arme was ſaid to be cut of, had ſomtime bene Athanaſius his reader, which Arſenius, fering leſt he ſhould be corrected for ſome fault, withdrew himſelfe from Athanaſius, and fled away. VVhoſe running away (the wicked taking to be a iuſt occaſion of laieng the fore ſaid crime to Athanaſius charge) tooke Arſenius, and kept him cloſe in a certaine mans houſe, who was of the ſame conspiracie with them againſt Athanaſius. And whither it were by the contēplation of his owne humanity, or by gods prouidence eſcaping, priuily in the night out of the priſon arriued by ſhip vnto Tirus. And the day before Athanaſius ſhould be arreigned, Arſenius came to his maiſter Athanaſius, & opened all the matter vnto him, how his enemies wēt about falſly to accuſe him of murther. Athanaſius cōmaūded Arſenius to kepe him ſelfe cloſe within the houſe, that no man might know of his returne againe and preſence there. The councell did ſit, to the which al they which were of a malicious and ſpitefull minde againſt Athanaſius, did repaire. At yt tyme one Paphnutius a confeſſor of God, was preſēt with Athaſius, who knew very well Athanaſius innocencie and giltleſnes. VVhen he ſaw Maximus Biſhop of Hieruſalem (who had his eye cut out, and his hamme cut of, as Paphnutius had for the confeſsing of gods truth) to ſit with other of ye Arrian factiō, came before the middeſt of the coūcel, and ſaid: O Maximus, with whom I haue one & the ſame badge of Chriſtiā confeſsion, with whom alſo one of my bodily eyes being put out, hath purchaſed a more cleare ſight of heauenly light, I will not ſuffer the to ſit in the councell of the wicked, & to entre in with them that imagine miſchief. And ſo caſting his hande vnto him, did lift him vp, and tooke him from the middeſt of the councell. And geuing him inſtructions of the whole matter, coupled him euer after to the communion and felowſhip of Athanaſius.

But in the meane time the cauſe agaynſt Athanaſius went forward.
