Firſt of all they brought in a certaine woman (whome they had ſuborned to exhibite falſe accuſation and teſtimonie agaynſt him) who ſayd, that vpon a certaine night ſhe receyued Athanaſius into her houſe to lodging, and that ſhe ſuſpecting nothing leſſe, was violently corrupted and rauiſhed
of Athanaſius the ſame night. The iudges commaunded Athanaſius to be brought forth, who commyng in, admoniſhed Timotheus his Chaplayn, that aſſone as the woman had tolde her tale, he ſhuld aunſwer and ſpeake vnto her, for he would holde his peace. Nowe when this woman had finiſhed her Oration, as ſhe was taught, Timotheus turnyng vnto her, ſayd: VVas I euer receyued into thy houſe, O woman? and did I euer oppreſſe thee, as thou haſt ſayd? then ſhe (as the malapertnes of women is ſhameles, ſpeaking ſharply vnto him. Thou, thou (ſayth ſhe) euē thou haſt defiled my chaſtitie, and turning vnto the iudges made obteſtation of her faith in God, that ſhe had ſpoken nothing but the truth. Then were they all aſhamed, and laughed at the matter, that the faction of this forged crime was ſo euidently and manifeſtly knowen.

Notwithſtanding the iudges could not be ſuffred to examine this woman, where and by whom ſhe receyued the leſſon of this forged ſlaunder, for the accuſers did vſurpe to them ſelues the whole libertie of geuyng iudgement. VVell (this pageaunt beyng played) they obiected agaynſt him an other crime. They brought forth ſuch a wicked dede, as was neuer herde of before. They ſet before the iudges a coffin, vpon the whiche lay a dead mans arme. This is that, ſayd they, that cannot be coloured by crafty wordes, the matter is apparente, you may ſee it with your eyes, although wordes ceaſſe. This is the right arme of Arſenius, thy ſeruaunt, which how thou dideſt cut it of, or wherfore, now ſhewe and declare.

Then ſayd Athanaſius: whiche of you all here did knowe Arſenius, that you do knowe ſo well his right arme? Certayne aroſe vp, who were not of this faction and ſayde, that they knewe Arſenius very well. Then Athanaſius requeſted the iudges: that they would be ſo good, as to commaund his ſeruaunt whom he had ſent out for certaine buſines, to be called and brought thither. And when Arſenius came in, Athanaſius lyfting vp his head, ſayd to the whole coūcell and to the iudges: there is Arſenius, this is euen he, and lifting vp his right hande, behold ſayd he, here is his right hande, and this is his left hande. Nowe inquire you, whoſe arm this is, which they haue broght here before you. Then a certain myſt and darckenes came before the eyes of the accuſers, not knowyng, what they might do, nor what waye to turne them. For ſure teſtimony was brought, that this was very Arſenius, who ſtoode there.

Neuertheles, bycauſe the councell was not kept for right iudgements ſake, but onely to oppreſſe an innocent man, forthwith, they al made a great ſhout and cryed, ſaying, that Athanaſius was a Magitian, and that he had deceyued their ſight, and therfore was a man not worthy to lyue any longer. And comming vpon him with great violence, would haue
torne and rente him with their handes. But Archelaus, who was preſident of the ſayd counſell, at the Emperours commaundement, tooke hym out of their handes, conueighed him into a priuie way, and bad him ſaue him ſelfe by flight, and depart from thence. Notwithſtanding the counſell ſitting agayne, as though nothing had bene perceyued of their malice and deſpitefull ſlaūders, cōdēned Athanaſius of the crimes before layd to his charge, and did ſend the acts therof through all the world,Lib. 1. cap. 15.16 & 17. & allured al the Biſhops by the Emperours commaundemēt to conſent to the ſame. Haec Ruffinus.

div.head: Cyprianus. 19.
div.p: CEcilius Cyprianus, doth ſeme alſo to haue ben called Statius, as the hiſtorie of his martirdome doth declare, which was written by one Pontius a deacon: how be it the inſcription of the .9. Epiſtle of the .4. booke, doth name him Thaſcius. He was borne in Africa, in the Citie Carthage. For Hierome writeth, that he was both Prieſt and Biſhop there. Of what parentes he came, or what kind of ſtudie he vſed in his youth, it cannot be gathered in any place out of his writinges, but Hierome in his Cataloge and in his commentes vpon Ionas, writeth, that he profeſſed Rhethorique, with great commendation in Africa, while he was yet a gentile and an idolatour. At which time Nazianzenus affirmeth, that he was geuen much to the ſtudy of Magicke, who nameth him a Magitian and a witch, wheras both Hierome and Auguſtin write nothing of him. Other write of one Cyprian a Magitian, which being a child was conſecrated of his parentes vnto the deuils, as Iacobus de voragine, Henricus de Eufordia, and Volateranus, do write But this Cypriā they ſay, either was borne at Antioche or els at Nicomedia, yet notwithſtandyng they affirme that he was cōuerted, and became at the length both a Biſhop and a martyr.

Saint Hierome writeth that this Cyprian of Carthage in Africa,In catal virorū illuſtrium et cō mētario in lonam. was firſt perſwaded and conuerted vnto the Chriſtian faith through the conuerſatiō, which he had with one Caecilius a Prieſt (whoſe name he afterward tooke vnto him ſelfe) & eſpecially through the reading of the Prophet Ionas. And he him ſelf wrote the hiſtorie of his conuerſion & Baptiſme in a floriſhing and an eloquent ſtile, that it did wel appere,Lib. 2. epiſtola 2 that he came out of the ſcholes of the Rhethoritians.

Alſo Hierome declareth, that aſſone as he was conuerted,In Catalogo forthwith he beſtowed all his goodes vpon the poore: and not long after he was choſen Prieſt, and laſt of all made Biſhop of the Church of Carthage. But it is vncertayne, whither he ſucceded Agrippinus Biſhop of Carthage, of whom he maketh often mention, and who alſo was the firſt author of rebaptizing,
or whether he ſucceded ſome other. But it is moſt certaine, yt in his dignitie and office he excelled in vertue and in ſondry godly qualities, but eſpecially in authoritie, by ye which Nazianzenus writeth, that he gouerned the Churches of all the orientall partes & of all Spaine. And in the forme of his proſcription he is called the Biſhop of the Chriſtians, which forme he him ſelf reciteth.Lib. 4. epiſtol. 9 He was alſo a moſt diligent and faithfull ouerſeer of his Churche, beyng alwayes very carefull and penſiue for it, he being both preſent & abſent, as it doth appeare by many of his Epiſtles. He writeth thus of him ſelfe, that he was gentle, meke, patient, and liberall,Lib. 1. epiſt. 3. and that he was alſo ſeuere and ſtout in matters pertaining vnto his office. Sondrie of his Epiſtles alſo do teſtifie, that he was moſt louing vnto his brothers. He toke great paynes in deliuering & helping of martyrs, for being abſent he would write vnto his Prieſts and Deacons, that they ſhould with care and diligence embrace and make much of the martyrs, which were captiue. The fortitude and godly ſtoutnes of his minde in executing of his office, the .iij. Epiſtle of his .1. boke do declare. Neither did there lacke in him wiſedome and circumſpection. Beſides this, he was of a ſingular modeſtie, for he would take vpon him to do nothing of his priuate councell and iudgement, without the conſent of his fellowes in office. He was very beneficiall and kinde towardes his poore brethren, & ſuch as were ſtraungers. For how oftentimes in his abſence doth he commit ye cure and charge of the pouertie, vnto his felowes in office? yea being abſent, he doth commaunde them, to geue of their owne proper goods, to the neceſsitie of their brethren being in exile.Lib. 3. epiſt. 24

He him ſelfe alſo doth recite his ſingular reuelations and other gifts, as his viſions and his warnings from heauen,Lib. 1. epiſt. 3. et Lib. 4. epiſt. 4. of his perſecutions to come, and of other things perteining vnto the gouernement of the Church, he had alſo afore knowledge of things that ſhould after happen.Lib. 4. epiſt. 6

Saint Auſten alſo (who doth greatly prayſe him) doth attribute vnto him certain noble vertues,Contra Donat. Lib. 2. cap. 4 as humilitie of ſprit, reciting theſe wordes: let vs not thincke our owne wit and iudgement to be beſt, but whatſoeuer profitable and good coūcell ſhalbe geuen vnto vs of our brethren and felowes, let vs embrace and follow it: he ſetteth forth alſo his long ſuffering and patience with his great courteſie and gentlenes, through the whiche vertue he kept nothing priuie that he thought, but would vtter it peaceablie and quietly. He cōmendeth himſelf alſo, for that he would not beare malice agaynſt any man, that was of an other iudgement then he himſelf was, but would notwithſtanding kepe peace and concorde with him. Finally,Cōtra Donatiſt lib, 5. cap. 17 that he would preſcribe and appoint no man, to followe any other thing, then that which ſhould ſeme beſt vnto him ſelfe.

Neither this is to be omitted, that ſaint Hierome doth write of him,
that he was geuen alwayes vnto reading, and ſpecially of Tertulliā. For he ſaith, that one Paulus told him, that he heard of Cyprianes notarie, whom he ſaw at Rome, that Saint Cypriane ſuffred no day to paſſe, in the which he red not ſomewhat of Tertullian, and that he would oftentimes aſke of his ſeruaunt for his maiſter, ſaying, Da Magiſtrum, geue me my maiſter, ſignifieng Tertullian.

div.head: ¶ Of certaine faults of doctrine in Cyprian.
div.p: HE calleth repentaunce oftentimes, ſatiſfactions and open confeſsions, following Tertulliā, vnto the which he doth attribute the cauſe of abſolution & remiſsion of ſinnes, as in one of his ſermōs he ſaith:In ſermone de lapſis The Lord muſt be appeaſed and pacified through our ſatisfaction.

In an other perilous doctrine he vſeth this ambiguitie: he biddeth thē whiche are fallen, not to diſpaire of the mercy of God, and yet would not haue the penitent, to promiſe himſelfe forgeuenes of ſinnes. VVhat other thing is this, but that it is to be doubted,In ſermone de lapſis. whither God forgeueth the penitent ſinner, or no?

He goeth about to proue very rigorouſly and vnmercifully (out of this place of Saint Iohn: Ecce ſanus factꝰ es, noli amplius peccare, Ioannes, 5 behold yu art made cleane, ſinne no more) yt there is no hope of pardon left vnto him, yt doth offende, after that he hath once knowen God: And that, whatſoeuer ſinne is committed agaynſt the Lord, cannot be abſolued of the Prieſt.Sermo. 5. de lapſis In all his writinges he is a vehement maintainer of frewill. Hereof he attributeth to much vnto good workes, as of almes, he ſaith, that almeſdedes are the way vnto ſaluation,In Sermo, de elecmoſina & that it waſheth cleane away all ſpottes & filthines gotten after baptiſme.

He borowed alſo certaine ceremonies out of Tertullian, and out of the traditiōs of Montanus, as the conſecratiō and vnction after Baptiſm, for he ſaith, the water muſt firſt be made cleane, and conſecrated of ye Prieſt, that it may waſhe away the ſinnes of him that is Baptized. Againe it is alſo neceſſary, that he that is Baptized, ſhould be anointed, that the vnction being receyued, he may be annoynted of God, and haue in hym the grace of Chriſt.

div.head: ¶ Of the conflictes of Cyprian.
div.p:
HE ſuffred many and great conflictes, which moſt commonly did exerciſe and try the true and conſtant profeſſors of the pure and ſincere doctrine. Firſt, againſt the Ethnickes, which thing his hooke written againſt the ſlaūders of Demetrianus doth teſtifie, who imputed the cauſe of all the euils and calamities of the world vnto the Chriſtians, bycauſe they did not worſhip the goddes of the gentiles. The which ſlaunder S. Cyprian examining, doth ſo regeſter, that he proueth calamities therfore
to be multiplied in the world, bycauſe the gentils worſhipped idols, and would not acknowledge the true God.

After this he ſtriued with the Iewes, ſettyng forth two bookes agaynſt them, in the whiche he proued euidently, that the Iewes did incurre the anger and offēce of God, bicauſe they diſpiſed Chriſt, and killed the Prophets, and that they could not vnderſtand the Scriptures, except they beleue in Chriſt, that the circūciſion, that the old law, that the tēple, that the ſacrifice of the Prieſts, that the Prophets are ended, and yt they being reiected ye kingdome of heauen did more appertaine to ye gētils. &c.

Lib. 1. epiſt. 8. Lib. 3. epiſt. 5He ſtriueth againſt the fiue falſe brethren, who layed counterwatch vnto his Biſhoppricke, while he was in baniſhment, he anſwereth in many wordes vnto the reprehenſions and ſlaunders of the backbiters, for the whiche cauſe he vehemently rebuked one Pupia a martyr,Lib. 4. epiſtol. 9 bicauſe he gaue credit vnto their backbitings.

So likewiſe had he a long and painefull fight with the heretickes, as with Nouatus, whom he had once excōmunicated in Africa, & with thē which were of his ſect, the which would haue the Churches to be ſhut againſt them that returned home after they had offended and gone aſtray. Through this occaſion, he wrote certaine godly & learned Epiſtles, and a ſermon of the receyuing agayne of the offenders.

His next conflict was with Nouatianus & Faeliciſsimus, and wt their adherents, who cōtrarie vnto Nouatus did receiue againe & did abſolue wtout reſpect, all ſuch as were fallē, & alſo heretikes (no diſcipline of repentaūce going before) onely for that they might diſpleaſe the Biſhops.

Againſt the ſame men that is, Nouatus, Nouatianus, and Faeliciſsimus he defendeth Cornelius Biſhop of Rome,Lib. 4, epiſt. 4 whom they ſlaunderouſly affirmed to be vnlawfully created Biſhop, and did alienate the mindes of his brothers from him. He ſtriued alſo very manfully in many generall coū ſels againſt all heretickes and ſciſmatikes. But his greateſt conflict of all (I know not by what authoritie or reaſon he did it) was in defending the cauſe of rebaptizing againſt Stephen Biſhop of Rome.

He inueighed alſo learnedly agaynſt idoles, yea rather he deſtroyed them (as Hierome ſayth in his treaty of the vanitie of idolles) he was a helpe alſo vnto diuerſe other Churches, but not without ſtrife with his authoritie and cenſure,Lib 3. epiſt. 5. eſpeciallye vnto the Churche of Rome, vnto the whiche Churche he ſent in his perſecution .13. Epiſtles.

div.head: ¶ Of his kinde of ſtile.
div.p: Hierome attributeth vnto him in his writing a perſpicuitie & maieſty of ſentēces And in an other place he writeth, yt his ſtile doth runne ſwetely and ſtilly, like vnto a most pure wellſpring.

And Lactātius ſayth, Cypriane was of a ready and prompt wit, copious
and pleaſaunt, and (which is the greateſt commēdation of all) in talke or writing, he was ſo perſpicuous and playne, that a man could not diſcerne whither there were any man, either more eloquent in vtteryng, either more plaine in expounding, or more earneſt in perſwading.

div.head: ¶ Of the baniſhment and martirdome of Cyprian.
div.p: THat he was a baniſhed man, many of his Epiſtles witnes, which he wrote vnto his brethrē, and vnto his Church liuing in exile. In which thing he performed this vertue worthy of a faithfull paſtor, that he had no leſſe regarde of his owne Church and of other Churches being abſent, thru if he had ben preſent He declareth him ſelfe yt in a ſedition & ſtu r moued of the raging people, he willingly gaue place and departed,Lib. 3. epiſt. 5 leaſt yt through his preſence he ſhould more hurt then profit the Church. For ſo he writeth vnto the Prieſtes of Rome, ſaying immediatly in the beginning of the tumult, when the people with a violent cry had oftētimes called for me, not ſo much reſpecting my own ſauegarde as the cōmon quietnes of my brethren, I departed in the meane while, leaſt through our intempeſtiue preſence, the ſedition begon ſhould be more prouoked. In lyke maner he writeth vnto his brethren of his corners and dennes,Lib. 3. epiſto. 10 in the whiche he was oftentymes ſought. The whiche thyng ſemeth to haue bene done in the yeares of Decius and Gallus. For from that baniſhment, he returned vnto his Churche: but beyng baniſhed by Valerianus, he was called home agayne of Paternus proconſull of Africa into the Citie Thurbis. Cyprian him ſelfe declareth, that either in this his laſt exile, or in the former, he with all his goodes was proſcribed, ſo that it was lawfull for any man to ſlea him that met him.

Paternus the proconſull being dead, Galenus maximus who ſucceded Paternus, commaunded his ſeruauntes to carie Cyprian in a carte to the place of puniſhment, where the liefetenaunt being about to do Sacrifice vnto his gods, brake out into theſe wordes.

Thou haſt liued a great while beyng of a peſtiferous mynde, and haſt gathered vnto the mē of a wicked conſpiracie, and haſt bene an open enemy vnto the Romaine gods and their holy lawes: neither could the godly and ſacred princes Valerianus and Galenus reduce thee by any meanes vnto the ſecte of their ceremonies. After whiche wordes he was ſlayne with the ſword, vnto the which (as Hierome ſayth) he willingly bowed his nacke. At this tyme Sixtus was Biſhop at Rome (as Euſebius writeth) in the yeare of our Lord .259.

VVhat things Nazianzenus writeth of his buriall, and the miracles about it, both Hierome and Auſten, and they which liued in that time, & after, either they were ignoraūt of them, or they coūpted them as vayne
tales vnworthy to be recited. That is prayſe enough to hym, that S. Auſten calleth him a catholicke biſhop and a catholicke martyr, ſo much the more humbling him ſelfe as he was great and noble. And the ſame Auſten ſaith in an other place. I cannot attaine vnto the prayſe of Cypriane. I do not compare my writings vnto his great learning. I loue his wit, and am delighted with his ſtile. I wonder at his charitie, and worſhip his martyrdome. I do not beleue, that he was of that opinion, that heretiques & ſciſmatiques ſhould be rebaptized.

div.head: Antitheſis. 20.
div.p: ANtitheſis ſignifieth in Latin Contrariū, contrary. It is a figure by the which we amplifi by cōtraries. It maybe in ſingle words, as Seruaui nō extinxi. I ſaued him & not deſtroied him. Alſo in whole ſentences. Vt habet aſſentatio iucunda principia, eadem exitus amariſsimos adfert. Aſſentation or flattry bringeth pleaſant & ſwete beginnings, but the ſame bringeth moſt bitter & ſowre endes. Alſo, Inimicis te placabilē, amicis inexorabilē praebes. Thou behaueſt thy ſelfe to thine enemies placable & tractable, but to thy frēds inexorable. In Paul this is Antitheſis. If you liue after the fleſh, you ſhal die, if after the ſprit, you ſhall liue.Rom. 8 1. Cor. 3 Agayn, the letter killeth, the ſprit quickneth. Cicero. In pace bellū quaeritas, in bello pacem deſideras. In time of peace thou ſekeſt warre, in tyme of warre thou deſireſt peace. Alſo in idlenes thou makeſt tumultes, in tumultes thou art only idle. In refrig idiſsima cales, in referuentiſsima friges. In a cold cauſe thou art hote, in a hote cauſe thou art cold. This is a very apt Antitheſis. Non obruiſti me muneribus, ſed ſceleribus. Thou haſt not ouerwelmed me with rewards, but with wickednes. Finally Tacito cum opus eſt clamas: cum loqui conuenit, obmuteſcis. VVhen ſilence nedeth then thou crieſt out, when ſpeche is required, thou art dom. Ades, abeſſe vis, abes, reuerti cupis. VVhen thou arte preſent, thou wouldeſt be abſent, when thou art abſent, thou wouldeſt returne. Note that there is no figure ſo elegant and apte, as this is, to amplifie & varie any Oration.

div.head: Ariſtoteles. 21.
div.p:
ARiſtotle the prince and monarch of all the Philoſophers, was very famous in his time, who had to his maiſters & teachers Socrates, and Plato, as witneſſeth S. Auſten in his booke De ciuitate dei, ſaying. Ariſtotle was the diſciple of Plato, being a mā of excellēt wit, not only equal to Plato in eloquēce, but otherwiſe far exceding him: whē he had inſtituted the ſect of Peripatetikes, his maiſter being yet aliue, he gathered many ſchollers to be of his ſect. Amōg whom for his renowne he had Alexander Thēperour alſo to his ſcholler, and liued .23. yeares after the death of Plato, ſomtime teaching Alexander and
ſomtime compoſing and making bookes, and other whiles applyeng doctrine. In his ſeal (as it is ſayd) he cauſed this to be engraued. Sapiētior eſt qui quod nouitabſcondit, quam qui propalat quod neſcit. He is more wiſe which doth hide that which he knoweth, then that man whiche vttereth ye thing which he knoweth not. Ariſtotle was very eloquēt in vtteraunce & (as Saint Hierome ſaith to Euſtochius) he was (without queſtion) a great and maruelous miracle in nature. At the length when he had taught very excellently in Licium many yeares, and was accuſed through enuie that he did not iudge right of the gods, fearinge leaſt he ſhould be adiudged to death (as Socrates was) forſakyng to purge him ſelf, wēt into Calcis, wher he was of very good liuelines of wit while he liued, & did lyue .62. yeres & dyed ther (as Leonardus Aretinus, fully declareth in his life.) He treated of all the partes of Philoſophie, and gaue preceptes to euery part. He was called Philoſophus the Philoſopher, by the figure Antonomaſia. Laertius witneſſeth that there were .viij. Ariſtotles. The firſt was this before rehearſed. The ſecond ruled the common wealth at Athenes, whoſe very elegant orations are extāt. The .iij. wrote vpon the Iliades of Homere. The .iiij. was the oratour of Sicilie. The fift was called Mintheus the familiar frende of Eſchines. The .vi. was of Siren, which wrote Poetrie. The .vii. was a ſcholemaiſter, of whom Ariſtoxenus made ment you in the lyfe of Plato. The eyght was an obſcure and baſe Grāmarian. And it is ſaid, that Ariſtotle ye Philoſopher wrote many workes, who ſurely (if he were aliue again) he would deny many of them to be his, whiche we now attribute vnto him. And he was in better caſe then other were, whoſe workes were vtterly aboliſhed, and he hym ſelfe was the cauſe why many of his workes were loſt, bycauſe he tooke vnto him other mens glory and praiſe.

Plutarch writeth, that ſome report, that Ariſtotle was the author of Alexāder the Emperours death, for that he gaue counſell to Antipater, and brought poiſon for to poiſon Alexāder. Plutarch alſo writeth, that there was a ſuſpitiō of poiſonning Ariſtotle, but ſome did write, that he drancke a very exceding venimous herbe called Aconitum, and ſo periſhed, but that is falſe (ſayth Plutarch) for what nede he to fly from Athenes, if he would haue wyllyngly put hym ſelfe to death. Agayn, the order of his teſtament which he made in Euboea, is very much diſcrepant from a voluntarie death. For it began thus: Erunt omnia recte. Si tamen quid contingat, Ariſtoteles Teſtamentum ſuum in hunc modum fecit. All things ſhalbe well: yet notwithſtanding if any thing happeneth, Ariſtotle made his teſtament after this maner: who doth not perceiue, that the very beginning of the Teſtament doth not ſauour of a man deſperate, but rather of one deſiring life? for he ſayth, all things ſhalbe well, if lyfe do remayne.
His ſect was called Peripateticorum ſecta, bycauſe he taught Ambulando, for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , betokeneth to walke.

Plato was wont to name Ariſtotle a mule, bycauſe a mule, when ſhe hath filled her ſelfe with her mothers milke, ſhe will beate her damme with her heles. Plato ſignified by this the ingratitude of Ariſtotle, for when he had receyued of Plato the principles of Philoſophie, and the encreace of knowledge therin, he became enemie to ye ſchole of Plato, and wt his familiars and ſcholers did alwayes contende and ſtriue againſt Plato.

div.head: Gallenus. 22.
div.p: GAlenus was a noble Phiſicion, borne in Pergamo, ſonne of Nicon a great Geometriciā. In the arte of Phiſicke he excelled all other before his time, and ſence: In ſo much, as in his miniſtration, counſell, or doctrine, he neuer had reproch, as he him ſelfe writeth. Alſo, liuing (as ſome do write) as good as an hundreth yeares, after he paſſed the age of eightene yeares, vntill the tyme of his death, he was neuer vexed with any ſickenes, except the grudge of a a feuer of one day, as he ſayth in his worke, De ſanitate tuenda, and that happened onely by to much labour. He floriſhed in the tyme of Marcus Comodus, and dyed onely for feablenes of age, after the incarnation of Chriſt about .160. yeares. He was famous at Rome, and is thought to haue excelled all men in that arte (Hippocrates excepted) for that he compoſed many bookes, and with a wonderfull wit expounded all Hippocrates workes. For the Grecians do ſay, that he put forth .150. bookes of that facultie, and therfore this ſentence was very notable. Scientia in inſenſato non prodeſt, nec ei qui non vtitur prodeſt ſenſus. Science in a ſenſeleſſe man, doth not profit, nor ſenſe profiteth hym that cannot vſe it.

Lib. 10.Galen in his booke of ſimple medicines ſpeaketh of a ſtraunge experiment whiche he practiſed by a peece of olde cheſe. VVhen I had (ſayd he) in tymes paſt cheſe brought vnto my table, which was of a very tarte taſt, I caſt it awaye, and my ſeruauntes ſpente it, and did eate it among them. But they being wont to ſaue ſuch meates, brought within ſhort ſpace after out of the ſpence or buttry, of the ſame cheſe agayn, and aſked what I would commaund to be done with it. And becauſe it could not be eaten, for the tartenes therof, we merely being diſpoſed, did propoſe to what purpoſe or vſe any mā could put it. In the meane tyme of our talke, a certayne man diſeaſed with the goute, was brought vnto me in a chariot, hauing goutiſhe knobbes vpon his ioyntes. It came to my minde to proue a practiſe. I commaunded the cheſe and a gambon of bacon to be ſod together, and to be poūded well in a morter, that it might be plaiſterlike, and to lay it on the partes grieued. And truly the ſickeman was very well
holpen by this medicine, for the ſkinne being broken of it owne accorde, that is to ſay, without cuttyng, the pieces of the knottes fell of dayly with out grief. And when all the cheſe that I had was ſpent, the ſicke man bieng him an other cheſe of the ſame taſt, ſaued it, for to occupy afterward about hys old diſeaſe. And when he tooke the ſame commoditie therby agayne, he perſeuered to occupy the ſame oftener, and taught it certayne of his frendes being likewiſe diſeaſed. And that thing truly did we inuent newly, whiche experience proued and confirmed afterwarde to be good.

div.head: Ambroſius. 23.
div.p:
AMbroſe Biſhop of Millayn, and ſpiritual father to Saint Auſten, was a Romaine borne, and ennobled with the dignitie of a Conſull. He being a very godly man, and the chief of all the doctours in his time, was ſent frō Rome of Valētinianus the Emperour, to gouerne the prouinces of Liguria and Aemilia: where ſhortly after the death of Auxētius Biſhop of the Arrians, a very great ſedition aroſe among the people, the whiche to repreſſe according to his office, when he had entred into the Churche, and like an eloquent man had reaſoned for the agremēt of both parties, ſodenly ther was heard the voyce as it were of an infant, ſaying. Dignus eſt hic Ambroſius vt ſit Epiſcopus. This Ambroſe is worthie to be a Biſhop. At the ſounde of the whiche voyce, the people did reioyce, fauouring him, and crying aloude, that the Biſhoppricke ought not to be committed to any other man, but to Ambroſe, the which thing was done by commune conſent and peace of them all, who being forthwith made a Christian, of one that before learned the principles of his faith, and hauing taken orders, was created the ninth Biſhop of Millaine, in the tenth yeare of Valentinianus his Empire. VVho beyng placed in the See, all Fraunce on thiſside the the Alpes forthwith embraced the Orthodoxe fayth. VVhoſe gentlenes truly was ſo great, his maners and conditions ſo holy, his wit ſo prompte and ſharpe, and his knowledge was ſo godly, that not onely while he lyued, but alſo being dead, he brought Italie and all the worlde into deuotion, charitie and veneration of hym. VVho alſo beſides the grace of holines, was very like Plato the Philoſopher, both in his birth, in his infancie, and alſo in doctrine. For like as the Bees did put a great deale of hony into Plato his lippes, as he ſlept in the cradle, ſo alſo there chaunced vnto Ambroſe a wonder very like to this, yea and a greater. For as the ſacred hiſtory telleth of him, whē he lay a ſlepe in the cradle, being a litle infante, ſodeinly a ſwarme of bees did ſo couer his mouth and face, as it were entring into the hiue, ſome goyng in, and ſome going out by courſe.
VVhich wonder hath bene declared of all the interpreters, to haue ſignified none other thing, but that the ſwetenes of eloquence ſhould flow out of his mouth ſweter thē hony. The which Prophecie in the end was declared to be true, if that ye will reſpect and viewe the ſubtility and ſtrength of his diſputing, reaſoning, and the ſwetenes of his ſpeaking and writing. He wrote vncorrupt, and many pure bookes, whoſe ſentences (ſayth Saint Hierome) are the moſt firme pillers of the fayth of the Churche, and of all vertues. In which bookes alſo (ſayth Saint Auſten) the true fayth doth appeare, bycauſe he (as a flower) did ſhyne among Latine writers.

In the Citie of Theſſalonica, a great ſedition beyng moued, certayn of the Magiſtrates beyng ſlayne with ſtones, were handled deſpitefully. The Emperour hearyng theſe tidinges, and beyng ouercome with great coler, coulde not reſtrayne the ſame, but with a furious mynde, ſuffred the arbitrement of reuengement to take place. And he hauing gotten this power (lyke a Tyraunt, and one that would rule the matter as hym ſelfe luſted) ſlewe vnreaſonably the innocentes and the giltleſſe together with the vniuſt perſonnes. For it is ſayd, that there were ſlayne. 7000 men, not beyng adiudged by the lawe to death, neyther was there any iudgement geuen agaynſt the wicked offenders, but they were all hewen downe like vnto the Stalkes of corne, whiche are cut downe in harueſt. Now when Ambroſe heard of this lamētable calamitie, he mette ye Emperor entring into Millayne, which would haue gone into the tēple (as he was wōt to do.) But Ambroſe would not ſuffer him, to go any further thē the Church porch, ſaying vnto hym. O Emperour, thou ſemeſt to be ignoraunt, how great a ſlaughter thou haſt committed. Nor (as I ſuppoſe) thy reaſon hauing appeaſed thy wrath, did waigh and conſider what thou haſt boldly done. Alſo peraduenture thine Imperiall principalitie doth not ſuffer thee to acknowledge thine offence, but power reſiſteth reaſō. Yet neuertheles thou oughteſt to know, that we are by nature mortall and tranſitorie men, and that we were at ye beginning duſt, vnto the which we ſhal returne agayne. Nor it is mete thou that being deceiued with thy beautifull purple robe, ſhouldeſt not know the imbecillitie of thy body couered with the ſame. Thou haſt O Emperour ſubiectes ioyned with thee in kin, yea in ſeruice alſo, for there is one Lord & emperor the maker of the world. Therfore with what eyes wilt thou behold the temple of God; which is Lord ouer al, or with what feete wilt thou tread vpon the ſacred pauement? wilt thou hold forth theſe hands yet dropping with the bloud of an vniuſt ſlaughter, and with them wilt thou receyue
the body of the moſt holy god. Or wilt thou put that moſt precious bloude vnto thy mouth, whiche haſt ſhed ſo muche bloud in a ſhort ſpace in thy furious ſtomacke? VVherfore depart, neither wyll thou to encreaſe thy former iniquity with this an other iniquitye: nor refuſe thou the bonde which the Lord of all (which is aboue) doth allow. This trulye is but a ſmall thing, and it getteth health. The Emperour hauing bene brought vp in holy doctrine, and knowing what was the duties of Prieſtes and Emperours, with ſighings and teares, returneth into his palace. But a long time after (for eight monethes wer expired) the feaſt of the natiuity of our Lord came. But the Emperour ſat in his palace lamenting, and pouring forth great drops of teares, the which thing when Ruffinus the Emperours maiſter vnderſtood (who through familiarity had free liberty to ſpeake his minde to the Emperour) he went vnto him, and aſked the cauſe of his weping. Then the emperor ſorowfully crying out, & pouring forth teares more and more, ſayd: O Ruffinus, thou mockeſt me, for thou art not moued with the feeling of my harmes: but I doo ſigh and lament, whileſt I conſider my calamity, foraſmuch as the temple of God is open for ſeruants and beggers to go in freely, for to pray to god, wheras both it and alſo heauen is ſhut vp againſt me. For I do remember the words of the Lord which ſaith plainly, whomſoeuer thou ſhalt binde vpon earth, the ſame alſo ſhalbe bound in heauen. Than ſaid Ruffinus: I wil therfore runne to the biſhop, if it pleaſe you, and wil moue him by petition to looſe your bondes. He wil not be turned, ſaid the Emperour, for I knowe the iuſtice and equity of Ambroſe ſentence, neither wil he tranſgres the law of God, for the imperial power. But Ruffinus inſtantly vrging him, and with long talke, perſwading the Emperour, that he would pacifye Ambroſe, the Emperour biddeth him to go with expedition, and he himſelfe induced with hope, followeth a litle after, truſting to Ruffinus his promiſe. But ſaint Ambroſe anon beholding Ruffinus, ſaid vnto him: O Ruffinus, thou dooſt imitate the impudency of Dogs, for thou being a councealer of ſo great ſlaughter, haſt put on thy braſen face, and caſting away ſhame, neither art abaſhed, nor yet feareſt the image of God in cō mitting ſo great a ſlaughter. Ruffinus beſought him, and ſaid, that the Emperour would come vnto him. But ſaint Ambroſe burning with godly feruentnes, ſayd: O Ruffinus, I tel thee truly, that I wil not admit him to the church doore. And if he wil chaunge the Empire into a tyranny, I alſo wil ſuffer paines of death willingly. VVhen Ruffinus heard this, he certified the Emperour of the biſhoppes minde, by ſome man, exhorting him to keepe himſelf within his palace But the Emperour receiuing the meſſage in the middeſt of the way, ſaid: I wil go & ſuffer deſerued checks and tauntes. And when he was come to the church, he woulde not enter
in, but going to the biſhop, which ſat in a litle oratorie, prayed him that he would looſe him out of bonds. But Ambroſe ſaid, that Theodoſius his comming was tirannous, and that he waxed wood againſt God, by violating and breaking his lawes. The Emperour anſwered: I do not offer my ſelfe to ſtand againſt the ſanctions of lawes, nor to enter vniuſtly within the holy temple: but I pray thee releaſe me out of bonds, and that thou haue in minde the clemency of the Lord towards vs al, & that thou wilt not ſhut vp againſt me the gate which the Lord hath opened to al thoſe that do repent. Then ſayd the biſhop, what repentance haſt thou ſhewed ſince yt thine ſo great wicked ſlaughter was don? or with what medicine haſt thou healed thy moſt greuous wounds? It ſhal be thine office (ſaid the Emperour) to temper the medicine, and to heale my very greuous woūds, and it ſhal be my part or duty, to vſe thoſe medicines, that thou ſhalt lay vnto them. Then ſaid Ambroſe: bicauſe thou committeſt thy iudgement to coler and anger, and not to reaſon, but a raging & furious mind doth pronounce and geue ſentence: write thou a lawe, by the which the conſent of thy iracundious minde may be made fruſtrate and vaine, and let ther be thirty daies preſcribed to geue ſentence of any murther, or confiſcation of any goods, that thoſe daies might tary and expect the iudgement of reaſon. And when thoſe daies be paſt, let the writers of thy ſentence exhibite vnto thee ye worke yt is cōmaūded. Then when thine anger is appeaſed, onely reaſon with iudgement ſhal be able to weigh, conſider and perceiue, whither that ſentence be iuſte or vniuſt. And if reaſō ſhal proue it to be vniuſt, truly the writing ſhal be torne in peeces. But if it ſhal befound a iuſt ſentence, than it ſhall be eſtabliſhed, nor the number of the daies ſhal hinder or annoy the right ſentence. The Emperour admitting and allowing his order, commaunded forthwith a law to be written, which he confirmed with ſubſcription of his own hand. So at the laſt ſaint Ambroſe did abſolue him. And the Emperour than being bolde to enter into the church, not ſtanding, nor vpon his knees kneling, did pray vnto God, but lying flat and proſtrate vpon the ground, did vtter forth this voice of Dauid: Adglutinata eſt pauimento anima mea, viuifica me, ſecundum verbum tuum. My ſoule is glued and faſtened to the pauimēt, reuiue me according to thy word. Thus tearing his heare with his hands, ſmiting his forhead, & watering the pauimēt with many drops of teares deſired pardon and forgiuenes to be graunted vnto him.

div.head: Meſſias. 24.
div.p: THe radical of this woord is Maſhah, which ſignifieth vngere, to annoynt,Exod. 10, as in Exodus: Et vnges eos quemadmodum vnxiſti patrem eorum. And thou ſhalt annoynt them, as thou haſt annointed their father.

The participle of the preter tence is Maſhuah, id eſt vnctus, anoynted, as in Samuel: Ego autem tener ſum, & vnctus rex. I am this daye weake, and newly annointed king. It is ſomtime red Maſhoah, for a difference of the other vnctiō, or rather painting mētiond in Ieremy.2. Sam. 3 Iere. 22 Et vnctum ſinopide, and painted with vermilion, for coulours wherwith they paynt, are mixt and ſeaſoned with oyle.

Of Maſhah commeth this nowne Maſhiah, which is called in Greeke 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in Latin vnctus, in enliſh annointed. And bicauſe aſwel kinges as prieſts were annointed with oyle, therfore they, and all that were conſecrated to God, were called Meſſiae and Chriſti. Exod. 30 1. Samu. 1 And the kings & prieſts annointed, were a type and figure of the true and onely Chriſt our Sauiuiour, and our chiefe Monarche and prieſt: our Monarch to vanquiſh Satan, our prieſt, to offer ſacrifice for the ſinnes of the whole world.
Alſo in the plural nūber as in the .cv. Pſalm. Ne tāgatis chriſtos meos.

The Chaldeans do name it Meſicha. Damaſcenus hath a ſentēce worthy to be noted concerning this name of Chriſt. His words be theſe, tranſlated out of the Greeke into Latin. Chriſtus nomen ſuppoſiti dicimus, non ſolitarie quidem, ſed duarum naturarum ſignificatiuū exiſtens, Ipſe enim ſeipſum unxit, vngaens quidem vt deus, qui corpus diuinitate ſua vnxit vnctus vero vt homo, Ipſe enim eſt hoc & illud, vnctio autem humanitatis diuinitas. VVe wil cal Chriſtus a name of the perſon, not ſimply alone, but ſignifieng two natures, for he annointed him ſelf, annoynting as God, which annointed his body with his diuinitye, annointed as man, for he is this, and that, and the diuinitye is the annoynting of the humanitie.

div.head: Nicholaus Lyranus. 25.
div.p:
NIcholaus Liranus was borne in Englande, of the ſtocke of the Iewes, as Tritenius and VVermerus do teſtifye, and beynge inſtructed of the Rabbines from his childhood, in the Hebrue letters, had that holy toung at his fingers end (as we cōmonly ſay.) This Lyranus, aſſone as he had bene conuerſant in the publicke ſchooles, and had heard ye ſermōs of certain gray Friers, which wer of a ſoūder iudgemēt thē the reſt, he begā to abhor the doctrine writtē in the Talmud, and al the reſt of their moſt fond madnes Being conuerted therfore vnto the faith of Chriſt, and being baptized, he became one of the Friers called Franciſcani, wher being very ſtudious in the ſcripture, and expert thorough long exerciſe, he maruailouſly encountred, both in diſputacion and in writings with the Rabbines at Oxford, and at Paris, who inueigled the common people of the Iewes, with the vaine promiſing of the cōming of the Meſsias. Finally, he expounded both the olde Teſtament and the new very learnedly, againſt their moſt manifeſt blaſphemies. Yf in any
things (as it is ſayd of him) he erred, it is to be imputed vnto the corrupt time, in the which althings were darkened with the cloudes of the hypocrites. Truly, he did more good in the ſcripture, than any other at yt time. There is no cauſe why a man ſhould finde fault with the ſimplicitie of his wordes, foraſmuch as the truth of the eternall God is not to be eſtemed and wayed by wordes. He wrote many notable workes, by the which hys name is famous and renowmed in hys poſteritie.

Doctor Martin Luther ſaith, that he therefore loued Lyranus, and counted him among the beſt interpreters,Luther in. 2. c • . • . cap. in Gene. bicauſe he proſecuted the hiſtory more diligently, then the other interpreters. He liued in the yeare of our Lord .1327. in the which yere he expounded Daniel, and dyed at the laſt at Paris.

At that time the tiranny of the Papiſts did ſo much preuaile againſt the holy ſcriptures, that it enforced them, which otherwiſe were good and learned men, and diligent ſearchers of Gods woord, to fall into moſt abſurd interpretations. The which thing happened alſo vnto this Nicholaus de Lyra, vnto whom the ſtudents of the ſcriptures are not a title beholding.cap. 16, Apoc. 30 As for example in the Apocalips, Lyranus expoundeth the vyal of Gods anger and reuengement poured out vpon Euphrates, to be ſpokē of Carolus Magnus, as who being deſired of ſaint Iames, made ready & plaine the way vnto his ſepulchre in Spaine, which before was vnknowen, he expoundeth the text after this maner. Sextus Angelus, that is S. Iames, poured out the power of Carolus Magnus, whom he procured to puniſh the Saracenes, who are called a great floud, for the multitude of that people. And he dried vp the water of the floud, that is, by vā quiſhing the might of the Saracenes: that the waye might be prepared vnto kings, that is, to the pilgrims of ſaint Iames. &c. In like ſort he expoundeth the aungel which had the key of the bottomles pit, to be Innocentius the third, who allowed the orders of the graye and of the blacke Friers. I ſawe an Angell ſayth Lyranus that is, the Pope Innocentius the thirde, who allowed the orders of the Graye and of the blacke Friars. I ſaw an aungell (ſaith Lyranus) that is, the Pope Innocētius the third, diſcending from heauen, that is, from the high pontifical honour, and condeſcending and meting with ſaint Fraunces & ſaint Dominick, hauing the key of the bottomles pit, that is, the power to allow the foreſaid orders of Friers, and to ſubdue the power of the deuill, and hauing a great chayne, that is, the multitude of the brothers of both orders. And they apprehēded the Dragon, bicauſe by their life & doctrin the power of the deuil is reſtrained, and ſhalbe reſtrained vntil Antichriſts cōming &c. Som other papiſtical expoſitours do affirm, this angel to ſignify the Pope, and they ſay the chaine to be the order of Cardinals and Prelates, and that the Emperour is ment by the Deuil and the Dragon. By theſe
ſubtil meanes, they draw and ſtretch the woord of God vnto their owne luſt, ambition and profit. Theſe men haue broken the egges of the Aſpes, and haue weaued ye web of the ſpider. He that ſhal eate of their egs, ſhall die. The perſuaſions of the traditions of men againſt the word of God, is the egge of the ſeuen headed Dragon, which was great and redde, which was a murtherer, and the father of lyes frō the beginning, out of ye which he hatched the Cockatrice, the king of the Locuſts, the aungel of the botomles pit, which in Hebrue is called Ahidon, in latin pernicies, in Engliſh deſtruction.

div.head: Articles of the faith.
div.p: THe twelue articles of the faith, are the very ſubiect of the true faith, and the matter about which the faith is exerciſed. VVhich faith, for aſmuch as it is a ſubſtance of things hoped for, it is expounded ſimply and briefly in theſe articles, what thinges they be which are to be hoped for. Vvho was the firſt that ordeined and wrote thoſe articles as an abridgement of the Chriſtian faith, it is vncertaine, nor it is expreſſed in the holy ſcriptures. Certaine doo aſcribe this to the Apoſtles, and therfore cal it the Symbole of the Apoſtles. Saynt Ciprian concerning this matter, writeth thus.

p.hi:
Tradunt maiores noſtri (inquit) quod poſt aſcenſionem domini, cum per aduentū ſancti ſpiritus ſuper ſingulos quoſque poſtolos igneae linguae ſediſſent, vt loquelis diuerſis variiſ
que loquerentur, per quod eis nulla gens extra, nullae linguae barbarae inacceſſae viderētur, et in via praeceptum eis a domino datum ob praedicandum dei verbū ad ſingulas quaſque proficiſci nationes: diſceſſuri itaque ab inuicem normam praedicationis in commune conſtituunt, ne forte alius ab alio abducti, diuerſum aliquid, hiis qui ad fidem Chriſti mutabantur, exponerent. Omnes ergo in vnum poſiti, & ſpiritu ſancto repleti, breue iſtud futurae ſibi, vt diximus praedicationis iudicium, conferendo in vnum quod ſentiebat vnuſquiſque, componunt, atque hanc credentibus dandam regulam eſſe ſtatuunt.

div.p:
Our Elders do declare, that after the aſcenſion of the Lord, when by the comming of the holy ghoſt, fiery toungs did ſit vpon euery of the Apoſtles, that they might ſpeake with diuers and ſundrye tounges, by the which no forraine nations, no barbarous toungs ſhould be ſtraunge vnto them, and bicauſe they wer commaunded of the Lord to go to euery nacion, to preache the woord of God: they therfore, being readye to departe one from an other, did conſtitute a certain briefe rule of preaching, to be had in commune amonge them, leaſt one being ſeparate from the other, ſhould expound anye thing contrarye vnto thoſe which pertaine to the faith of Chriſt. All they therefore, being aſſembled together, and full of the holy ghoſt, did conſtitute and ordeine, that this abridgement ſhould be the note & ſomme of their preaching hereafter to come, and alſo that
it ſhould be geuen as a rule to al faithful beleuers Haec Cyprianus.

This abridgement and rule was called the ſymbole of the Apoſtles. It is called Symbolum, bicauſe it is a collation and a true marke. It is called a collation, bicauſe the articles were compoſed, written, and made by the conference of the apoſtolical doctrine, that there ſhoulde be an Epitome of the whole chriſtian faith, both preached of the Apoſtles, and alſo receiued of the vniuerſal church.
It is called Iudicium, that is, a ſhew or note, bicauſe by theſe twelue articles, as by a ſure marke, the true Chriſtians might be diſcerned and knowen from the falſe.

To make the matter more plaine, Symbolum is a greke word, which commeth of this verbe 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which ſignifieth the ſame that confero, doth in the latin toung, that is, to bring together. This word Symbolum the Grekes haue vſed many maner of waies, and in diuers ſignifications, for other whiles they do cal Symbolum the ſeale or marke which is imprinted on letters or veſſels, to the intent that they ſhould not be opened of ſuch as were not mete and conuenient. Sometime agayne they doo call Symbolum a gage, whither it be mony or a ring, or any other thing, that they gaue from them, as many as were appointed, and had made promyſe to haue a common bancket or feaſt together, to the aſſuraunce, that euery one of them ſhould kepe his appoyntment, and no man withdrawe and abſent hym ſelfe.

Thirdly they do cal ſymbolum the token that is geuen betwene the ſpouſe and the ſpouſeſſe of their conſent eche of them to other: to the end that neither of them may ſhrinke from their promiſe and bargaine.

Fourthly, they cal ſymbolum that token or cogniſaunce, that was geuen to the ſoldiours, as many as fought vnder one and the ſame ſtanderd and banner, which ſomtime was a watche woord, ſometime it was without words, and therefore of them it is called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which is as much to ſay, as a dombe token without any voyce or ſound. And thys was done, to the end that the ſoldiours, which were all vnder one capitayne, ſhould know ech other, and that if any perſon would attempt or go back (when they were growen in age, and did take this marke and token) that they might haue perceiuing and knowledge of hym.
Al theſe foure ſignifications of ſymbolum, do agree vnto the ſymbole of the Apoſtles, commonly called the Crede.

Firſt, ſaint Paule calleth the Corinthians, which had profeſſed the Goſpel, his epiſtle, not written forſoth, with yncke in parchment, but in their hartes with the ſpirite,2. Cor. 3 which ſpirite is called the finger of God.

Secondlye, the mynde that is once ſealed and marked to God, it is not
lawfull to breake vp, or open to the Deuil. And the ſame Paule ſpeaketh in this wiſe to the Corinthians: we haue this treaſure in earthen veſſels. The minde therfore of man, through baptiſme,2. Co. 4 is made the veſſell of the holy ghoſt, which veſſel is ſealed or marked with the ſignet of faith, yea more ouer Chriſt hath ſealed it with his own bloud. And in the Goſpell,Luk. 14 our Lord compareth the kingdome of heauen, that is to wyt, the grace of the Goſpell, vnto a feaſt royall, vnto which all men of al nations are called. Now, whoſoeuer hath profeſſed Chriſt in baptiſme, he hath geuen a gage to come vnto this noble feaſt, ſo that it is not lawfull for hym nowe to ſtart backe.

Thirdly, we do reade often times, that Chriſt is called by the name of a ſpouſe, as the church likewiſe is called by the name of a ſpouſeſſe,Cant. 3 Ioh. 3 as in the miſticall Canticle, and in Iohn, yea moreouer, the ſoule of man in the profeſsion of the faith, is wedded vnto Chriſt her ſpouſe. Saint Paul declareth this writing vnto the Corinthians, ſaying:2, Cor. 11 I haue married you vnto one huſband, that you ſhoulde ſhewe your ſelfe a chaſte virgine to Chriſt. Therfore a token is geuen of both parties, that it cannot be lawful for either other at any time to go about a diuorcement. Chriſt geueth the earneſt or pledge of his ſpirite. Man beleuing with his hart to his iuſtification, and confeſsing or acknowledging wt his mouth, to his health and ſaluation: doth agayne of his part, geue a token or pledge to Chriſt.Eph. 5
Great is the miſtery (as ſaynt Paule ſayth) of thys marriage, whych is made and knytte wyth a faſt and a ſure vnlooſable bonde, betwene Chriſt and the Church.

Finally, and laſt of al, they which are newe borne againe by the holy bathe of baptiſme, they do profeſſe the euangelical chiualry or warre, & do become ſeruauntes and ſoldiours vnder the immortall captaine Ieſu Chriſt, and are bound with his military ſacraments, and doo receiue the gift or reward of the ſprit. So that it is a point of extreme vnfaithfulnes, and alſo vnkindnes, to forſake this captaine, and runne from him to the tyraunt the Deuil. Now al they do forſake him, not onely which do deny Chriſt, and doo runne vnto the Turke or vnto the Iewes, but alſo which with their whole hart and minde are geuen to the worlde and worldlye commodities and pleaſures. For the righteous man alſo falleth euen ſeuen times a day. But he riſeth anone againe, by the quicknes and ſtrength of faith, which like fire doth alwaies labour vpward vnto heauenly things.

Symbola alſo, doth ſignifie by an allegory, ſome ſecrete thing, as the Curlew is called ſymbolum pietatis, bicauſe Curlewes haue a certayne natural affection and loue towards their Parentes, in relieuing and ſuſteining them in their age.
Alſo in the ſacrifice of Bacchus, whē they bare about a ſiue, they ſignified therby drunkards to be blabs, & that they could conceale nothing

Furthermore, certain ſentences comprehending ſome miſtical & hidden ſenſe, were called by an allegory, Symbola, Symboles. As the ſymbols of Pythagoras, wherof this is one. Ne guſtaris quibus nigra eſt cauda, taſt not of thoſe things which haue a blacke taile. This ſymbole by an allegory doth teach vs, that we ſhould beware to accompany with the wicked, & with them that be infamous, or (as Triphen ſaith) that we ſhould vtter no lieng communication, bicauſe a lye in the ende of the tale waxeth blacke, and is eſpied.
An other of them is this. Ignem gladio ne fodito, ſturre not the fire with thy ſword, that is, prouoke & ſtur not him, which is already angry.
An other is. Aduerſus ſolem ne loquitor, ſpeake not againſt the ſunne, by which is ment, that we ſhould not repugne or gaynſaye the open and manifeſt truth.
If you deſire to learne mo of theſe, looke in the Chiliades of Eraſmus. Symbolum alſo ſignifieth a ſhot, yt a mā paieth for his dinner or ſupper.
It is alſo the mony, that diuers perſons lay together, as in a cōmon purs, to make good cheare withal. It may be called the banketting mony.
Symbolus in the maſculine gender, is a ſignet, ſeale or ſigne manuel.
Symbulus with v, betokeneth a good and wyſe counſailer.

div.head: Trinitie.
div.p: SAint Auſten in his boke De Trinitate, hath a moſt godly & profound ſaying concerning the Trinity. His woordes be theſe. Vbi quaeritur vnitas trinitatis, patris, filii, & ſpiritus ſancti, nec periculoſus alicubi erratur, nec laborioſius aliquid quaeritur, nec fructuoſius aliquid inuenitur. Non pigebit me ſicubi haeſito, diſcere. Quiſquis ergo audit vel legit, vbi pariter certus eſt, pergat mecum: vbi pariter haeſitat, quaerat mecum. Vbi errorem ſuum cognoſcit, redeat: Vbi meum, reuocet me. Ita ingrediamur ſimul charitatis viam, tendētes ad eum de quo ſcriptum eſt: pſal. 105. Quaeritefaciem eius ſemper.

VVhen the vnitie of the trinitie, that is, of the father, of the ſonne, & of the holy ghoſt, is ſearched, there is no errour more daungerous, neither is there any thing ſought wt more labour, nor any thing found with more fruit and profite. I will not be aſhamed to learne whē and where I doubt. VVhoſoeuer therfore doth heare or read, where he is certaine with me, let him go forward with me, where he doubteth with me, let him ſearch with me. VVhen he knoweth his own errour, let him returne, where he knoweth mine errour, let him call me backe. So let vs both together enter in to the way of charity, repayring to hym, of whom it is written: Alwaies ſeeke ye his face.

Saint Bernard hath not the vnlike worthy ſentence. Inquirere de trinitate, peruerſa curioſitas eſt: & credere, & tenere, ſicut ſancta eccleſia te net, fides & ſecuritas eſt, videre autem eam, ſicuti eſt, perfecta & ſumma faelicitas eſt. To enquire of the Trinity, is a peruerſe curioſitie: to beleue and to hold as the holy church holdeth, is faith and ſecurity, to ſee it as it is, is moſt perfect and chiefe felicity.

I remember an old report, which is told of one Alanus, who promiſed his auditorie to diſcourſe the next Sonday following, the miſterye of the Trinity It chaunced, that walking by the ſea ſide, he ſaw a young boy lading water of the ſea into a litle hole, Alanus demaunded of him, what he ment. I entend (ſaith he) to bring al the whole ſea into this hole. VVhy thou goeſt about a thing vnpoſsible, aunſwereth Alanus. So doeſt thou (ſaith the boy to him) for it is as poſsible for me to bring al the whole ſea into this hole, as for thee throughly to diſcourſe the miſtery of the Trinity. Alanus was very much diſmaid, and when he came into the pulpit, his auditory looking for the perfourmaunce of his promiſe, he was ſilent for a prety ſpace, and at the laſt ſaid no more, but this: Sufficit vobis vidiſſe Alanum. It is enough for you to haue ſene Alanus. For to vtter that which I promiſed, is aboue my reache, and ſo came downe.

The Hebrue Rabbines do aſsign & expreſſe ye myſtery of ye Trinity by this name of god, Iehouah which the Grekes cal Tetragrammaton, yt is, a name of foure letters, which are but three in deede, but that one is put twiſe, that is, in the ſecond place, and in the fourth place, yt is, this letter He. Theſe three letters, ſay they, do expreſſe the thre perſons of the Trinity. For the firſt letter Iod, betokeneth principium, a beginning, which letter doth moſt aptly ſignifie the Father in diuinity, which when he commeth of none, and the other perſons do flow from him, is called principium ſine principio, a beginning without beginning.
The ſecond letter He, which ſignifieth to be, or to liue, doth expreſſe the ſonne in diuinitie, by whom althings that were made, had their being and beginning.

The third letter Vau, which is a coniunction copulatiue, moſt aptly ſignifieth the holy ghoſt, which, foraſmuch as it is the loue of the father, and the ſonne, wherwith they loue eche other, is called rightly copula, bicauſe it is the knitting together of both.

This letter He, being put twiſe in this name Iehouah, doth ſignifye onely the ſonne, which is the ſecond perſon in Trinitye. For the Father which is the firſt perſon, hath onely one reſpect, that is, he is producēs, et non productus. The holy ghoſt alſo hath onlye one reſpect, yt is, he is productus, and not producens. But the ſonne, which is the ſecond perſon, hath two reſpectes, that is, he is productus a patre, & vna cū patre producens ſpiritum ſanctum.

This name Iehouah, is founde written in the auncient bookes of the Hebrues with three Iods, which are incloſed with a circle, and the point Camets ſet vnderneth them, after this maner. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 By the whyche two miſteries are ſignified. The three Iods are the thre perſōs, one camets vnderneath, is the diuine nature, which is wholy proper vnto euery perſon, the circle is the vnitie of the diuine Eſſence.

The ſecond miſterye is this, the three Iods beinge equall, betokene the equalitie of ye three perſons. One camets doth ſignifie one diuine ſubſtance in Trinitie. The circle betokneth the Identitie of ye ſame diuine Eſſence,

The Iewes had this name, Iehouah, in ſuch reuerence, that whenſoeuer it did occurre in reading, they would not read it nor name it, but expreſſed in ſtede therof, this name, Adonai, and therfore this name Iehouah, was called of them, nomen ineffabile, a name not to be ſpoken. It is written In libro Sanhedrin thus: whoſoeuer pronounceth the name of the .4. letters, as the letters them ſelues do ſound, ſhal haue no part in the world to come. Therfore, wherſoeuer they found this name, they durſt not pronounce it, but in ſteede thereof vttered this woorde, Adonai, Dominus, the Lorde. Notwithſtanding the Prieſtes did pronounce it, when they bleſt the people in the ſanctuary. For out of the ſanctuary it was vnlawful for any man to vtter it.

The bleſsing with the name of foure letters, was geuen with the lyftinge vp of three fingers of both handes, twoo fingers beinge preſſed downe, to ſignify the Trinity of the diuine perſons. This benediction vtterly ceaſed after the death of Simeon, who tooke Chriſt in his arms, being preſented in the temple.

Ther be great learned men, which doo accompt this inuention of the Iewes, to be but inuented of their own braines, and do count it but an explicatiō of ſubtilties. For Iehouah is deriued of this word houah, a verbe ſubſtantiue, before the which Iod being put, is made the word Iehouah, that is, a being or a ſubſtaunce of him ſelf, lacking nothing, but geuing to al things, without beginning and end, in whom we liue, moue, and be.

I do not a litle maruayle, that the Papiſtes are not aſhamed to ſay, that we haue not this name Trinity in al the ſcriptures, & by that wold proue, that vnwritten verities are neceſſary to be beleued to ſaluation, beſide the ſcriptures. But if they would put on their ſpectacles, and looke better on their bookes, they ſhould finde the whole miſtery of the Trinity, in diuers and ſundry places of the ſcriptures.
But to aduoyde prolixitie, I wyll bryng onelye but three or foure places.2. Cor. 3

Firſt, in Deuteronomie it is written: Audi Iſrael, Deus, Deus noſter,
Deus vnus eſt, God, our God, is God onely. VVhy did Moſes in this place put the name of God thriſe, but to ſignify diſtinctly the Trinity of the diuine perſons? And why is this word, vnus, put immediately after, but to ſignify the three diuine perſons, not to be three Gods, but one God.
Note wel, how that place written, Deut. 6. is read in the Hebrue, namely thus: The Lord our God, is Lord onely.

div.head: Queſtio.
div.p: But here may be demaunded, why this word noſter, is not aſwel put to the firſt woorde, and to the laſt, as vnto the ſeconde onelye, which is Deus noſter.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: By this it is manifeſtly declared, that neither the Father, which is firſt perſō in Trinitie, neither the holy ghoſt, which is the third perſō in the ſame Trinity, but onely the ſon, which is the ſecond perſō of the Trinity, ſhould become ours by the partaking of our humane nature. To the which, wel agreeth that, which is written in the .67, Pſalme. Benedicat nos Deus, Deus noſter, benedicat nos deus, pſal. 67 & metuant eum omnes fines terre. God, euen our God ſhal bleſſe vs, God ſhal bleſſe vs, and al the ends of the world ſhal feare him.

Here is put thriſe Deus, which ſignifieth the diſtinction of the three perſōs. And wher in the ſecōd place this word noſter is put, it betokneth the ſon onely to become ours, by the taking of our nature.

VVher it is ſaid in the laſt place, metuent eum, non eos, feare hym, and not them, the vnity & identitie of the ſame perſons is ſhewed & expreſſed. By this it is plainly declared, that the three diuine perſons, are not thre Gods, but one onely God.

Thirdly, it is written in the prophet Eſay: Sanctus, ſanctus, cap. 6. ſanctus Deus exercitum, plena eſt omnis terra gloria eius. Holy, holy, holy is the Lord of hoſtes, all the earth is ful of his glory. In that he ſayth Sanctus, three times, the three perſons are expreſſed, the Father, holy, the ſonne, holy, the holy Ghoſt, holye. And for that after he had ſaid three times Sanctus, he addeth immediatly the name of God Iehouah, which importeth the diuine ſubſtaunce, and doth clearelye expreſſe, that thoſe three perſons are not three Gods, but one God. For this cauſe the old Thalmudiſtes, which were not ignorant of this miſterie, ordeined, that as well thoſe woordes of the Prophet Eſay, as thoſe written in Deuteronomie, ſhould be ſpoken of euery Iew twiſe a day, morning and euening.

Fourthly, in the Epiſtle of ſaint Iohn it is writtē: Tres ſunt qui teſtimonium dant in caelo, pater, verbum, et ſpiritus ſanctus. There be three which geue teſtimonie in heauen, the father, the word, & the holy ghoſt, and theſe three are one.

Yf theſe teſtimonies both of the old teſtament and of the new, be not ſufficient to proue, not onely the matter and miſtery of the Trinitie, but alſo the name, I cannot ſee what may be ſufficient. But what cauillations and cauſations wil not captious heads inuent, againſt the verity? Vnleſſe they be (as the prouerbe ſayth) 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Caeciores Leberide, they may finde the Trinitie fully expreſſed in the ſcriptures.

To make an end, although earthly things are incomparable to things caeleſtial, and eſpecially to the maieſtye of God, yet for the infirmitye of our capacity, I wil bring in one example or two, in ſome part to expreſſe the miſtery of the Trinity.

Saint Auſten bringeth a goodlye ſimilitude, which is this: Videmus ſolem in caelo currentem, fulgentem, calētem. Similiter ignis tria habet, hoc eſt, motum, lucem, & feruorem. Diuide ergo ſi potes Ariane, ſolem, vel ignem, & tunc demum diuide Trinitatem. VVe ſee the ſunne in heauen running, ſhining, and geuing heate. Likewiſe the fire hath thre properties, mouing, light, and heate. Now thou Arrian, if thou canſt diuide the ſunne or the fire, than diuide thou alſo the Trinity.

The ſoule of man being really one thing, hath three powers, Memoriam, intellectum, & voluntatem, memory, vnderſtāding, and wil, which thre make one eſſential ſoule, but in property they are diſtinct. For the property of the memory is to remember, the property of vnderſtanding is to perceiue and vnderſtand, the property of the will is to chuſe. Out of the memory ſpringeth intelligence, out of both ſpringeth the wyll. So the diuinitie hath thre perſons, the Father, the Sonne, and the holye Ghoſt, which thre conſtitute one eſſential God, yet euery perſon hath his propertie. From the Father commeth the Sonne, and from both commeth the holy Ghoſt.

div.head: Iohannes Fiſſherus.
div.p: IOhannes Fiſſherus, ſometime biſhop of Rocheſter, and high Chauncelour of the Vniuerſity of Cambride, was cōmended of Eraſmus Roterodame, to haue bene beautified & adourned with al ſortes of biſhoplike vertues. He was (ſaith Eraſmus) indued with a ſingular grace of eloquence, and therefore he was in very great eſtimation wt the lady Margaret, grandame to king Henry ye eight. For at his inſtant requeſt (as Polidore ſaith) ſhe erected. 2 goodly Colleges in the ſaid vniuerſity, & dedicated the one to our ſauior Chriſt, & the other to ſaint Iohn the Euangeliſt. She gaue them to their finding large and greate landes. But when the eternall veritye of Chriſtes Goſpell beganne to ſhyne in Germany, no man was more wood and cruell agaynſt it, than this pratlyng and popiſh deceiuour.

He did not onely write agaynſt the ſincere preachers and Miniſters of the worde of God for the aduauncement of Antichriſtes euill doctrine, but alſo ſeditiouſly withſtood king Henry, which laboured to expell the pernitious yoke of the purpled harlot out of his realme. VVherfore let all godly mē iudge, what ingritie of life that was, what great learning, what holines of blameles life, what puritie of minde, with other dowries of Biſhoplike vertues (which his fauters ſo greatly, but falſly do brag of) was founde in him. At the laſt, almoſt he was beheaded doting, at what time a Cardinals hate was ſent to him from Paul the third, the Romiſh Pharao for the reward of his paines, the yeare after the natiuitie of Chriſt. 1533. and the .22. day of Iune. Haec Baleus.

div.head: Manicheus.
div.p: MAnes was a Perſian by his countrie (of whom the heretikes called Manichei, did ſpring) he began to diſpute amonges his ſchollars of a certaine new and ſtraunge doctrine. And when no man gaue him credit, and hys auditorye was diſpleaſed wyth hys doctryne, and euerye manne alyenated from hym for hys innouation, hys horrible fablinge, and his vayne fraude, he ſeinge the crafte of his feined wordes to be ouerthrowen, inuēted a way wherby he might eſtabliſh his deueliſh doctrine, for hearing the kings ſonne of Perſia to be very ſick, he came vnto ye king, promiſing to heale his ſonne in ſhort ſpace, truſting to his enchauntment, by the which he hoped to bring this weighty matter to good effect. But the child being taken away from the Phiſitians which had him in hand, and deliuered vnto Manes, periſhed in his hands, wherfore he was forthwith caſt into priſon, out of the which he being deliuered either by a ſomme of mony or by flight, came into the middle of Perſia and Meſopotamia, & entred the caſtle or towne of Arabion. The which thing the king of Perſia vnderſtanding, ſent for him, and tooke him, and ſkinned him aliue, and tooke his ſkinne, and filled it with chaffe where it remaineth at this day in Perſia.6. tomo operū Auguſtini

But his ſect was ſpred abroad in Arabia, Aegipt, and Africa, almoſt 206. yeares after his death. And Saint Auſten him ſelfe continued in the hereſies of Manes .9. yeares, but afterwarde acknowledging his errours, refuted the Manichies, as namely, Fauſtus, Faelix, Fortunatꝰ, Adimātus, and others of that ſecte. Theſe folowing were the chief opinions of the Manichies.

They feined that there were two Gods: The one a good God whiche was the author of good things, whom they named 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is, light. The other an euil God of like power, whom they called Hyles, of whom he ſaid, mariage, gouernement, and all euill things ſprang. Therfore they abſteined from marying and politike gouernement. They boſted that through
their ceremonies, they attayned vnto the ſprite of God. They affirmed, that the ſonne of God tooke not vpon him mans nature truly, but feinedly and imaginatiuely. They vtterly tooke away fre will in all pointes from man, aſwell in outward actions, as in inward motions. They feined, the lawe of Moſes to be geuen of an euill God, and therfore to haue ben abrogated. They abſtained from fleſh and from killing of beaſts: Finally, there was a great confuſion of their phantaſticall opinions, which he that will, may read them in Epiphanius and in Saint Auſten.

div.head: Catholique.
div.p: Καθολίκός, in the Greke, is in Latine, Vniuerſalis, in Engliſhe vniuerſall, or all (as though one would ſay) occupied about all. It is compounded of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , whiche ſigniſieth Circa, about, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which betokeneth Totum, all. Therfore the Church is called Eccleſia Catholica, bycauſe it doth extende and reach through all places, and through all tymes. For all holy men are ſo vnited together in the Churche, as members in one bodye, whiche depende of one heade. Therfore the whole multitude of all faythfull, is called the Churche. And bycauſe the Churche of Chriſt ſhould not be reſtrayned vnto one corner of the worlde (as the Donatiſtes do reſtrayne the Churche of Chriſt onely into Africa) it is called Eccleſia Catholica, the vniuerſall Church, diſperſed throughout the whole world.

But yet we muſt not ſtay here onely vpon this worde Catholique, for then we muſt graunte the Churche of the great Turcke to be a Catholique Churche. For his Churche hath an vniuerſal multitude, and a Catholique nomber. For this worde Catholique may not onely be applied to the Churche, but alſo to other prophane thinges, as that medicine which is profitable to euacuate al humors, is called Catholicum medica mentū. Alſo thoſe precepts which are geuen to al mē to be obſerued, are called, Catholica praecepta. And thoſe ſinnes whiche are vſually committed of euery man, and coumpted in a manner for no ſinne, are called, Catholica peccata. Therfore we muſt adde to our Catholique Churche, this Epitheton, Apoſtolica, and ſay with the Symbole made at Conſtantinople, Credo Eccleſiam Catholicam & Apoſtolicam. I beleue the Catholique and Apoſtolique Churche, or els this, Epitheton, Orthodoxam, and ſo terme the Churche to be, Catholicam & Orthodoxam, that is, to be vniuerſal and of a right and ſound doctrine, that is, not ſwaruing from right faith, true opinions, and good iudgementes.

Therfore ye may ſee, how the Papiſtes did caſt doung in their owne
eyes, when they thoght them ſelues to be of a true church, in naming them ſelues catholiques, that is, vniuerſal men, yet they neither embracing the right faith, nor ſetting forth the puritie of the apoſtolique doctrine: behauyng them ſelues more worthy to be called, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , then 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is, ill, bloudy, and deuouring woulues, thē true catholiques. For what bloud haue they ſpared vnſhed, either of high or low, poore or rich, young or old? wheras Chriſt him ſelfe being the head of the Church did ſay, Filius hominis non venit perdere, ſed ſaluare. Luk. 9 The ſonne of man came not to deſtroy, but to ſaue.

div.head: Biſhops.
div.p: WHat difference is betwene a Biſhop and a Prieſt, Saint Hierome writing Ad Titū, doth declare, whoſe wordes be theſe: Idem eſt ergo Preſbiter, qui Epiſcopus. &c.

A Prieſt therfore is the ſame that a Biſhop is. And before ſciſmes and factions by the inſtinct of the deuill begon in religion, and before it was ſayd amōg ye people: I am Pauls I am Apollos, I am of Cephas, the Churches were gouerned with the common councell of the Prieſtes (or Elders.1. Cor. 2)

But after that euery one thought thoſe whom he Baptized, to be his, and not Chriſtes, it was decreed throughout the whole world, that one of the Prieſts or Elders ſhould be choſen to be ſet ouer the reſt, vnto whom all the cure (or charge) of the Church ſhould apparteine, and that the beginnings of ſciſmes ſhould be taken away. Some do thincke, that it is not the ſentence of the Scriptures, but ours, that a Biſhop and Prieſt (or Elder) are one thing, and they do alſo thincke, the one to be a name of age, and the other to be a name of office. Let them read agayne the wordes of the Apoſtle to the Philippians, ſaying: Paul and Timotheus the ſeruaūts of Ieſu Chriſt, to all ye Saints in Chriſt Ieſu, which are at Philippos,Phil. 1 with the Biſhops and Deacons, Grace and peace be with you. &c. Philippi, is one of ye Cities of Macedonia. And truly there could not be many (as they ar called) biſhops in one Citie. But bycauſe at yt tyme they called thoſe biſhops, which they did alſo call Prieſts (or Elders,) therfore indifferently he ſpake of biſhops as of Prieſts (or Elders.) It may yet ſeme doubtful to ſome, vnles it be approued by other testimonie. In ye acts of thapostles it is written, that whē the apostle came to Miletū, he ſent to Epheſus, & did call the Priestes or Elders, of the ſame Church vnto whom among other things he ſayd thus: Attend to your ſelues. &c.Act. 2. And here marke you diligently, how that he calling ye Priestes or Elders of that one city of Epheſus, did afterward call them Biſhops. &c. And Peter which tooke his name of the firmenes of his faith, in his Epiſtle ſaith: I your fellowe Elder
do beſech the Elders which are among you &c. Haec Hieronimus. Theſe wordes are alledged, that it may appeare, Prieſtes among the Elders, to haue ben euen the ſame that Biſhops were. But it grew by litle and litle, that the whole charge and cure ſhould be appointed to one Biſhop within his precinct, that the ſeedes of diſſention might vtterly be rooted out.

div.head: Cerdon.
div.p: CErdon was borne in Siria, from whence he came to Rome, at the ſame time that Valentinus came thither,Ireneus lib. 3 cap. 4 Euſebius Lib. 4 cap. 10. 11 Antoninus Pius being then Emperour, and Higinus the Biſhop. This thing doth argue that he had a variable and ſuttle wit, for that he ſometimes endeuoured to ſpred abrod his errours priuily, and fearing nothing, did ſometime openly teach them. But he being ſometime reproued of the brethren, came againe to the Churche, feining repentaunce and amendement. The which vnſtedfaſtnes being at length perceiued of the brethren, he was repulſed and put backe from the communion of the Churche. Of this Cerdon the heretiques called Cerdoniani, tooke their name, whoſe hereſie was this, that the holy ghoſt was not ſent vnto the Apoſtles,Cant. 24. q. 3 but to him alone. He did alſo affirme, that there were twoo gods, one good an other ill, whiche gaue the law and the Prophets. He taught furthermore, that Chriſt did appeare onely in phantaſie and ſhew, and not in ſubſtaunce. He denied the reſurrection of the dead. He reiected Moſes and the Prophets. Loke more for this Cerdon, in Epiphanius, Ireneus, and Tertullian.

div.head: Marcion.
div.p: MArcion the heretique was the diſciple of the foreſayd Cerdon, a Stoike Philoſopher, & born (as Epiphanius writeth) in Sinope, which is a citie in Pōtus of Galatia, or of Paphlagonia ſaith Ptolomeus. Ireneus writeth, that Marcion did ſuccede Cerdon, and waxed ſtrong vnder Anicetus then Biſhop:Lib. 3. cap. 4. the whiche Marcion did not begin his hereſie firſt at Rome, whether he came after Cerdō, but a long tyme after, he ſowed his ſtraunge hereſies in other places. For Philaſtrius writeth, that he was at Epheſus in the time of Saint Iohn the Apoſtle, of whom Marcion being ouercome, and being driuen from Epheſus, fled to Rome. Albeit Epiphanius doth plainely declare, he did apply his minde to the hereſie of Cerdon, firſt at Rome. And when Marcion came thither, he was excōmunicate of his own father, a very godly & honeſt byſhop, bycauſe he committed whordome with a virgin.

Euſ. Lib. 4, ca. 11Furthermore Euſebius ſaith, that Iuſtinus in his bookes againſt Marcion did write, that he did know him aliue, when he wrote his bookes againſt him. Vpon a certaine tyme Marcion did mete Policarpus, and aſked
him, if he knew him? Policarpus anſwered, I know thee to be the firſt begottē ſon of the deuill. His hereſies were theſe. He feigned, that there were to gods, the one the maker of the world, and of the law, & the Prophetes, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , the cauſer & author of euill, a bloudy God & vnſtedfaſt. The other God, he feined to be ſuperiour and mighty. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , the father of our Lord Ieſu Chriſt, which did diſſolue and breake a ſonder al the works of the other gods. He taught, that only the ſoules are ſaued, and that ye bodies do not riſe agayn: He did not allow wedlocke. &c.
See Ireneū, and eſpecially Tertullianū, in fiue boks againſt Marcion.Lib 1 ca 29. lib 2. ca. 1. lib. 3. cap 3, 4. & alibi.

div.head: Praxeas.
div.p: PRaxeas againſt whom Tertulliā wrote a ſpeciall booke, affirmed, that there is onely but one diuine perſon, as alſo Sabellius after him affirmed the ſame. Alſo he did contende about the yeare of Chriſte .250. that God the father was Ieſus Chriſt whiche ſuffred and was crucified. Of this hereſie, his ſectatours were called Patripaſsiani.

div.head: Proſcriptions.
div.p: PRoſcribo hath diuerſe ſignifications. Firſt it betokeneth to proclaime any thing to be ſold by writing: Therfore houſes, when they ſhould be ſold, hauing an inſcription vpō them, were called Aedes proſcriptae, (as Cicero writeth. Itaque Calphurinus, Lib. 1, officio Chriſoſt. quum cogno uiſſet Claudium aedes poſtea proſcripſiſſe. Therfore when Calphurinus had knowledge yt Claudius had put forth the houſes to be ſold). In Greke it is. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Mulctatus bonis.

Secondly it ſignifieth to baniſhe out of the country. Vlepianus ſayth, that they are ſayd properly to be proſcribed, whoſe names are written in faire, plain and legeable letters, and ſet before ſome ſhop or place of marchaundiſe, to geue notice, that they are exiles.
Macrobius ſayth. Non eſt facile ſcribere aduerſus eum qui poteſt pro ſcribere. It is no eaſy thing to write againſt him, who hath authoritie to proſcribe.

Thirdly it ſignifieth, to cauſe by ordinaunce, that whoſoeuer findeth one, he may lawfully ſlea him, and haue a rewarde for his labour. And Proſcriptio, is that maner of commaundement. Proſcriptio, may ſignifie alſo an ateynder.

div.head: Strangled meates.
div.p:
BEfore the lawe, in the tyme of Noe, God did forbid the eatyng of bloud, and fleſh, with the bloud of any dead thing, either beyng killed of wild beaſtes, or els being ſtrangled. The fathers did eate herbes and frutes of the earth before the drowning of the world. And after,
God graunted them libertie to eate of the beaſtes, and commaunded to kill them, and to ſhed their bloud. Furthermore in the law, God with a great ſeueritie, ſaith: whoſoeuer of the houſe of Iſrael, or of the inhabitaunts which do dwell amongſt you, ſhall eate any bloud, I wil ſet my face agaynſt ſuch a ſoule, and I will put him out from among the people. Nor it was without iuſt and very great cauſes, yt God did forbid with ſo great ſeueritie the eating of bloud. For at the beginning after the wordes recited, he addeth: For the ſoule or life of the fleſhe is in the bloud, and I gaue it you vpon the aultar to purge your ſoules. For the bloud ſhal clenſe the ſoule. And therfore I ſayd to ye children of Iſrael: let neuer a ſoule among you eate bloud. &c. Lo, a very cleare and manifeſt reaſon is here rendred in theſe wordes, why it is not lawfull to eate bloud, ſeing that bloud is a moſt excellent thing, being appoynted for the ſanctification of men. For God gaue bloud to be as it were a price, whereby ſinnes might be clenſed, a reward, (I ſay,) for their redemption, by the whiche they might be abſolued from their ſinnes. Furthermore, bloud is life, that is, the nouriſhment of life. The bloud therfore ſignified, Chriſtes bloud to be ſhed vpon the Croſſe, by the which as a moſt full and perfect propitiation, the faithfull beleuers, are purged and ſanctified, and in the which is the nouriſhment of the ſoule vnto euerlaſting life. And as it was not lawfull to eate of the fleſh of the Sacrifices, the bloud wherof was brought into the holy places, for ſinnes, but the Sacrifices were brent without the court: ſo like wiſe, it was vnlawfull to eate bloud, as though it were a purging for ſinne.
