div.p: The ſecond circūſtance is, that in ye old Teſtament wer many types, ſhadowes and figures, but we in the new Teſtament haue receyued the thing it ſelfe,Typus. 10 that was then figured, and fore ſignified.

Therfore what God promiſed vnto them, he hath performed and geuen vnto vs. They beleued Chriſt to come, and to deliuer the faithfull: We beleue, that he is come,
〈◊〉 . 10. and hath accompliſhed all things. Our Lord Chriſt ſaid in Mathew. Lex & Prophetae vſ
que ad Iohannem. As Eo tempore regnum dei annunciatur, & qui vis in illud vim facit.

The law and the Prophets Prophecied vnto Iohn,Vnto Iohn .11. Violēt take it. 12. and from the tyme of Iohn the kingdome of heauen ſuffred violence, and the violent take it by force. By the whiche this is deriued, that all ſhadowes and figures then ſignifieng thinges to come, do ceaſſe and fall away, when the thing it ſelfe that was figured, is come and made preſent.

Moreouer the yoke and burthen whiche our fathers did beare, are taken from our ſhoulders. Their kinde of worſhipping God was onerous and paynfull, as the Aaronical prieſthoode. The tabernacle or temple decked and furniſhed with thinges moſt exquiſite and coſtly, the diuerſe kind of ſacrifices, with a great nomber of ſuch like things. But Chriſt the complement and fulfiller of all lawes and ſacrifices, hath deliuered vs from ſuch rites & ceremonies, both onerous & ſumptuous, & hath geuen vnto vs very few extern things: that is to ſay, Only ye preaching of his word, and the adminiſtration of his Sacramentes, whiche are but two in nomber.

Sainte Paule in the Epiſtle to the Galathians bringeth for this purpoſe a goodly allegorie of two mothers,
〈◊〉 4. the one named Agar,Agar et Sara. 13. whiche gendreth vnto bondage, the other named Sara, whiche gendreth vnto libertie and fredome.
By the whiche two women, he ſignifieth two maner of doctrines, the legall doctrine, and the Euangelicall.

The law gendred the holy fathers and the Prophets vnto bondage, not yt they ſhould be bond ſlaues, but that they ſhould be retained vnder a diſcipline, which as a ſcholemaiſter ſhould lead them to Chriſte the perfection and performaunce of the law. The Goſpel gendreth vnto libertie, and maketh vs free from al bonds and burthens of the lawe, And that is, that Sara the free mother, whiche geueth vs the ſeede of life, doth faſhion vs forth into the light, doth noriſhe vs in her boſome, hauing for vs both milke and whole meate, that is, the holy Goſpell wherwith ſhe bringeth vs vp, nooriſheth vs, and preſerueth vs.

div.head: The third circumſtaunce.
div.p:
The third circumſtaunce is this, the people of God in the old Teſtament were contayned and ſhut vp within ſtreit and narrowe boundes and limittes (as the Prophete Dauid ſayth.
〈◊〉 . 76 〈◊〉 . 9. 〈◊〉 10 〈◊〉 16.) Olim notus in Iudea deus, et Iſraell magnum nomē eius. But now ſeying yt Chriſt is exhibited vnto vs, his people are diſperſed through the whole world, as it is writtē: In omnē terrā exiuit ſonus eorū, et in fines terrae verba eorū, Alſo in Mathew Chriſt ſayth. Ite et predicate euangeliū omni creature.
In tymes paſte the noble and godly menne, the kynges and the Prophetes might haue bene nombred, for they were onely in the land of promiſe.

But nowe, who is able to recite and nombre the kynges, the princes, the nobilitie, the Prophetes, the Byſhops, the Martyrs, the Doctours & all other honorable perſonages of both ſortes & kinds, beſide the inferiour ſort of people, which all not onely Iudea hath and doth geue and bryng forth, but alſo Arabia, Meſopotamia,
Perſia, Egyptꝰ, & to be ſhort al ye .iiii. coſts of the world eaſt, ſouth, north & weaſt. To al kingdomes is preached the free remiſſion of ſinnes, al the faithful of all kyngdomes are receiued into the fauour and grace of God. All people haue the knowledge of the Lord and his word. Finally, where a lande terreſtriall and earthlye was promiſed vnto them, a lande celeſtiall and heauenlye is promiſed vnto vs,The land of liuing. 14 as Dauid writeth in the Pſalme.pſal. •
Credo videre bona domini in terra viuentium.
To make an ende of this matter, both ſuccinctly and playnely, beare this leſſon awaye.
Both the Teſtaments are al one, for in both there is al one and the ſame God the father, the ſame Chriſt the ſonne, the ſame holy ghoſt.
And the diuine and godly nature knoweth neither oldnes nor newenes, but certaine pointes are chaunged and made new onely externely and outwardly.
Choyce of meates. 15. Linſey wolſey. 16.The Iewes had choiſe of meates, we eate all manner of meates, and none are forbidden vs.
The Iewes wer forbidden to weare Linſey wolſey: we may weare al maner of garments, and all maner of cloth.
The Iewes were forbidden to plow the ground with Oxe and Aſſe together: we may till the grounde with all maner of cattel, mete for the ſame turne.
To be ſhort, in the ſtead of ſo many diuerſe kindes of Sacrifices, we haue but onely one miſticall Sacrifice.
In ſtead of the holy Temple of Hieruſalem, we haue a Churche ſpread through the whole worlde.
Sabbatum. 17.In ſtead of the paynefull circumciſion, is brought in the eaſie bath of Baptiſme: the Sabboth is chaunged into the ſonday.

In ſteade of Moſes the ſeruaunt of God, is ſucceded Chriſt the ſonne of God. For theſe thyngs, and many other that are altered and chaunged, it is called the newe Teſtament, not for that it is vtterly an other Teſtament, then it was before, but that it is otherwiſe geuen and taught.
Of the Iewes ſuche as throughe hope of heauenly lyfe dyd lyue in chearefulnes of the ſpirite, were alſo within the compaſſe of the new Teſtament.

Agayne, thoſe menne now a dayes whiche do meaſure and iudge holynes by outwarde ceremonies, beyng colde in charitie, and hote in vengeaunce, do yet ſtande and continue ſtill within the compaſſe of the olde Teſtament.
Thus I haue at large ſhewed you the difference betwene the old Teſtament and the newe.

Nowe I woulde alſo geue you notes and rules, howe you may attayne to the true meanyng and vnderſtanding of both the Teſtaments, but tyme wyl not ſuffer me. Yet I will open the doore, and ſhewe you, howe you may enter into theſe heauenly houſes of Gods booke.
Firſte you ſhall obſerue and note, that there bee two worthy dayes menne (if I maye ſo terme them) whiche teache vs to attayn to the very true ſenſe and meanyng of the holy Scriptures.
The firſt, is Spiritus ſanctus, the holy Ghoſt.
The ſeconde is, the worde of God.

Concerning the ſpirit, Chriſt ſaith in the goſpell of Iohn. Spiritus ſanctus quem mittet pater in nomine meo, omnia vobis ſuggeret, quae locutus ſum vobis. Iohn The holy ghoſt, whom the father will ſend in my name, ſhall bryng you all things to remēbraunce which I haue told you. And Paul writeth,1. Co •
that Spiritus profunda dei ſcrutatur. The ſpirit ſercheth al things, yea ye depe things of God. Likewiſe ſaint Iohn in his firſt Epiſtle ſayth. Vnctio docebit vos omnia, you nede not that any man teach you,Vnctiō. 18. but the anointing teacheth you all thinges.1. Io •

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: In dede ſaith our aduerſaries, theſe things are true, but we deſtitute and voide of the ſpirite of GOD, therefore we cannot attayne to the true meanyng • of the Scriptures.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: 〈◊〉 . 8.I aunſwer, if you be voyde of gods ſpirit, how dare you be ſo bold to call your ſelues chriſtians, ſeing ye Paul to the Romaines doth teach, yt they be not of Chriſt, which hath not his ſpirit. I do not meane here, yt euery mā hath the like gift of the ſpirit, but the degrees of the ſpirite are geuen, as it pleaſeth God, to ſome more, & to ſome leſſe. And he that is a true Chriſtian man, hath at the leaſt this ſpirit, that he doth know what thinges are neceſſarie to his ſaluation, which neceſſaries are conteyned in the holy Scriptures.

The ſecond daies mā, which teacheth vs to inueſtigate & ſearch out the truth of the holy ſciptures, is gods word it ſelfe. For it is mete & conuenient, yt we iudge that place of ſcripture, whiche is obſcure & darke, by an other place which is more cleare & open. And to theſe two vmpers & dayes men, we may couple & adioyne the third, which is the conſent and authoritie of the catholicke Churche. But yet not ſo, as though the Church were the chiefeſte vmper and ladye and maiſtres ouer the worde.

div.head: Queſtio.
div.p: Here wil be ſaid, how can we obtain & purchace vnto vs theſe two daies men, the holy ſpirite, and the worde of God?

div.head: 〈◊〉 . 119Reſponſio.
div.p:
Concerning the firſt interpreter & vmper, which is gods ſpirit, we muſt knocke at the eares of God with feruent & deuout prayers: Dauid prayed, ſaying. Retege oculos meos, vt conſiderē mirabilia de lege tua, open mine eyes, that I may ſee the wonders of thy law.
• m Alſo in an other place: Doce me iuſtificationes tuas, Iuſtifications. 19, intellectū da mihi, et ſcrutabor mādata tua. Teach me O Lord thy ſtatutes, geue me vnderſtandyng, and I will ſearche thy commaundementes.

Saint Paul alſo prayeth in his Epiſtles, that the ſpirite of God and heauenly wiſedome myght be geuen to them,
〈◊〉 . ad • . 1 to whome he wrote, and that God woulde lighten and open their eyes, to the knowledge of the will of God.

Cōcerning the ſecond interpreter & vmper, which is the word of God, we muſt employ our induſtry & diligence, in earneſt reading and ſtudy, wherby we may be able to conferre place with place, and to pronoūce & vnderſtād thoſe places which are obſcure and darcke, by thoſe places whiche are manifeſt and plaine.

• n. 4. • m. 4.S. Paul warneth & exhorteth Timothie, Vtincumbat lectione, that he ſhould apply to reading, & Paul him ſelfe whē he was in priſon at Rome, prayed that his bokes & parchement might be ſent him from Troada, which he had left there.Swinckfeldius.

And here by the way, we may note the Swinckfeldians and other fantaſticall heades, whiche do depraue the holye Scriptures and the woorde written, callyng them Egena elementa, bare and naked elementes and letters. They truſtyng to ſpirituall reuelations ſaying, that they ought not to paſſe for the Scriptures written, ſhewyng forth their foly: Where contrary wiſe the holy veſſell of God Saint Paule tooke great care for hys bookes and writinges, whiche he had lefte with his deare frend Carpus at Troada, and did earneſtly deſire, that they might be ſent hym with expedition. For althoughe he were then olde, and almoſt at deathes doore, yet he gaue him ſelfe to the readyng of Scriptures. And will thoſe hellhoundes preferre their owne iudgementes and found doctrines, before ſo holy an Apoſtle? God amend them, or els roote them out.

Vpon this we may inferre and conclude, that they which ſlide and fall into errours by expoūding the ſcriptures, fall by their owne folly, for that they geue not them ſelues ſufficiently vnto prayer nor reading and ſtudy, accordingly as they are bounde to do.

But there is one caution aboue all to be obſerued, when we come to read the ſcriptures, we muſt put away al affectiōs & ſingularity. We muſt come to learn, & not to wreſt & writhe the ſcriptures (will they, nil they) to ſerue our fantaſtical braines & affections, as the Arrians, the Pelagians, the Papiſts & other ſectaries do,Pelagiꝰ. 20 who racke & rent the ſcriptures from their naturall & true ſenſe and meaning to frame their hereſies and falſe opinions. This ſhalbe ſufficiēt for the firſt part.

div.head: ¶ Now to the ſeconde parte of this Prelection, that is, to the deliuery of foure rules, how to vnderſtande the holy Scriptures.
Prima regula.
div.p:
THe firſt rule is this, we muſt take hede in our interpretations, that we admitte not nor allowe any expoſition, whiche is againſt the receyued articles of our faith, conteined either in the ſymbole, of the Apoſtles, or anie other aunciente ſymboleSimbole. or Creede. As the ſymbole of Nice, Conſtātinople, & the ſymbole of Athanaſius. Therfore reading theſe wordes in Iohn (Pater maior me eſt.) (The father is greater then I.) We muſt conſidre, that to cō ſtitute any inequalitie in the diuinitie betwene the father & the ſonne,Iohn., is cōtrary to the articles of our faith. And therfore we ought to beleue and expounde thoſe wordes, otherwiſe then the wordes doth ſhew in the firſt face, and to ſeke ſome other or mo places in the ſcripture, that do aunſwere to the true meaning of theſe words. As Pater et ego vnū ſumus. And in thepiſtle of Iohn. Hii tres vnū ſunt: Ibide • Epiſt • Heb •
theſe thre be one.Theſe three be one. To turn to repentance. Catholike. And here we muſt interpret the one ſentence to be ſpoken of the manhode of Chriſt, & the other to be ſpoken of his diuinitie. We reade likewiſe in S. Paul, that it is impoſſible for them which were once lightned, & fall againe, to be renued by repentaunce. We muſt not expounde theſe wordes, as though pardon were to be denied to the penitent and to them that riſe againe. For the catholicke faith doth beleue, yt at al times & in al places, & to euery perſon ye turneth to the lord, remiſſion & forgeuenes of ſinnes is promiſed, through ye death of Ieſus chriſt our Lord. Alſo reading theſe words of thapoſtle Paul. Caro et ſanguis dei hereditatē conſequi non poſſunt. Fleſh & bloud cannot inherit the kingdome of heauē.Cor. •
We muſt not expounde fleſh and bloud here for the ſubſtaunce of mans body, for then we ſhould deſtroy this atticle of our faith (I beleue the reſurrection of the body.) But we muſt take fleſhe and bloud to ſignifie here, fleſhly affections and infirmities of mankind.

div.head: Secunda regula.
div.p: • ubuerſion of charity.The ſecond rule is this: We muſt beware aboue all thinges, that our expoſition of the ſcriptures do not tende nor go to the ouerthrowinge and ſubuerſion of charitie and good politicque ordre.

Saint Auſten de doctrina Chriſtiana. Quiſquis (inquit) ſcripturas diuinas, Lib. • cap. 3. vel quamlibet earum partem intellexiſſe ſibi videtur, ita vt in eo non edificet, geminam charitatē dei et proximi nondum intellexit. Whoſoeuer (ſaith Auſten) ſemeth to himſelf to vnderſtande the holy ſcriptures or any parte of them, and yet in his expoundyng or vnderſtandyng doth not edifie and plante the two folde charitie, that is, the loue of God, and of hys neighboure: playnlye (ſaythe Auſten) he vnderſtandeth not the ſcriptures. And example. It is writen in the ſcriptures. Ne reſtiteris malo. Reſiſte not ill. Nowe if we will expounde this generally, and that it pertayne aſwel to the publicque Magiſtrate as to the priuate ſubiect,Mat •
both good order ſhalbe diſturbed, and charitie and loue towarde our neighbour vtterly broken and taken awaye. For if theues, rebels and traitors, extortioners, adulterers,
& ſuch like, ſhoulde not be puniſhed by the Magiſtrate, who coulde liue in ſecuritie and ſafegarde? The wydowes, the Orphanes,VVidowes & Orphans the people ſhould be oppreſſed, and troden vnderfoote, and al iniquity would raygne.

div.head: Tertia regula.
div.p: • n. 4. • . 3.The third rule is this: we muſt expend and vewe, by what occaſion any thing is ſpoken, what goeth before, what doth followe, at what time, and after what ſorte, and of what perſon any thing is ſayd or written. Saint Paule did obſerue the circumſtaunce of time, and therof concluded, Abraham to be iuſtified, neither by circumciſion, nor yet by the law.

Agayne, when it was ſayd vnto ſaint Peter: put thy ſword into thy ſcabbard, Qui gladium ſumit, gladio perit, he that draweth the ſword, periſheth wyth the ſword. The perſon of Peter is here to be cōſidered, that is, that he was not a magiſtrate,
〈◊〉 . 23. • n. 16. 〈◊〉 . 2. but an Apoſtle. For we reade, that the ſword is geuen to the magiſtrate to puniſh the gilty, and to defend the gilties. It wyl be to long, to heape example vpon example, concerning this rule.

div.head: Regula quarta.
div.p: The fourth rule is the collation and conferring of places, eyther of like or of vnlike, and that the harder places are to be expounded by places more clere, & fewer places to be expounded by the more. As for example: When Iames the Apoſtle doth ſay that AbrahamAbrahā iuſtified by workes. and we be iuſtified by workes, the more places are to bee ſet out againſt this by ſaynt Paule. Tertulian writeth, that heretickes, and not men that be Orthodoxi, Orthodoxi do excerpe and draw out of the ſcriptures, a few thinges to defend their opinions, and that they haue no regarde, nor do reſpect to vow other places. Ita paucula (inquit) ſibi delegerunt teſtimonia, quibus omnino credi poſtulant, reclamante interim tota ſcriptura, quum oportet ſecundam plura intelligi pauciora. So (ſayth he) they chuſe to them a few things, by the which they require alwayes to be credited, wher al the whole ſcripture doth ſay agaynſte them, that it behoueth the fewer thinges to be vnderſtanded by the more.

Wel, bicauſe the houre is paſt, I wyl here ende, committing you vntill ſaterday next, to the eternal God (through Ieſus Chriſt our Lord) to whom wyth the father and the holy ghoſt, be al honour and glory for euer. Amen.

div.head: Vayle of the temple. 1.
div.p: IT is written in Exodus the ſeconde booke of Moſes, that Beſeleel beſides other workes that hee had made for the tabernacle (as God had commaunded Moſes) made alſo a vayle of blue ſilke and purple, and of ſcarlet, and of fine twined linnen, wyth Cherubins of brodered woorke: whyche vayle was betwene the ſanctuary and the holyeſt of all.

Aquinas doth write, that there were euen two vailes in the temple of the Iewes, as ther were in their Tabernacle. For there was a vayle in the holieſt of al, and an other in the ſancturie.
Theſe two (ſaith he) do ſignify two maner of coueringes and concealements: for the inward vaile doth ſignify the couering of heauenlye miſteries, which ſhalbe reueled and made open vnto vs after the general iudgement, for then we ſhalbe like vnto him, when he ſhall appeare in hys glory.

The outward vaile doth ſignify the couering of thoſe miſteries which pertain to the church militant, and therfore this vail was rent in pieces: to ſignify, that thoſe miſteries which pertain to the church, were reuealed by the death of Chriſt. But the inward vayle was not then deuided, nor rent aſunder, bicauſe the ſecretes of the heauenly kingdome do yet remaine vnreuealed, wherupon Paul writeth to the Corinthians ſaying: Cum autem Iſrael conuerſus fuerit ad deum, amouebitur velamen. VVhen Iſrael ſhalbe turned to God, the vayle ſhalbe taken away: wherupon all the miſteries which were written in the law and the prophets, were made open by the paſsion and death of Chriſt. As it is written in the Euangeliſt Luke, how that Chriſt began from Moſes & al the prophets, interpreting to the two diſciples,Luk. 24. all the ſcriptures which were written of him. &c.
The foure coulours in the vayle do ſignify the foure elements.
Firſt, by the twined linnen, is ſignified the earth, bicauſe linnen doth grow out of the earth.
By purple is ſignified the water, bicauſe the purple coulour is made of certaine ſhelfiſh, which are found in the ſea.
By the blue coulour is ſignified, the aire, bicauſe it hath the coulour of the ayre.

By ſcarlet is ſignified, the fire. And therefore, bicauſe the matter of the foure elements, is an impediment and let (by the which impediment, incorporal ſubſtances are hidden from vs.) The high prieſt alone by him ſelfe went into the holieſt of all, and that but once in the yere, to ſignify that the final perfection of mā is to be broght at the laſt to that world, which is the world of glory.

The vayle alſo may ſignifye by theſe foure coulours, foure ſpirituall miſteries. The fine linnen doth ſignify the purity of the fleſh. The purple doth figure the croſſe and troubles which holy men do ſuſtaine for Gods cauſe. The ſcarlet doth ſignify double charity, that is, the loue of god, & the loue of our neighbour. The blue coulour doth ſignify heauenly meditations. Other learned men do make this allegory of the vayle, when it was rent in the middle, at the death of Chriſt. The renting of the vayle doth ſignify, that the way vnto God the father is made open by the death of Chriſt, alſo that the fiery ſword is remoued from the doores of Paradiſe, and that thoſe things be throwen downe and deſtroyed, which dyd
ſeperate vs from God: and that thoſe thinges are nowe made open which before were hidden, that is, that the Gentiles are now made coheires & partakers of the kingdome of God. For it was ſayd before: Notus in Iudaea deus, in Iſrael magnum nomen eius. God is knowen in Iewry onely,Pſal. 76. and in Iſrael great is his name: but now it is ſayd, from the riſing of the Sunne, to the going downe of the Sunne. Laudabile nomen domini, Pſal. 113. Mat. 10. the Lords name is to be praiſed. And wher Chriſt before his death did ſay to his diſciples, In viam Gentium ne abieritis, go not into the way of the Gentiles. After his death he ſayd: Euntes docete omnes gentes, Mark. 16. go and teache all nations.

Origine ſpeaketh of two vailes, as Paule alſo doth to the Hebrues. The firſt vaile is rent in peces and taken away,Hebr. 9. but the ſecond vaile doth remain, & doth couer thoſe things which we ſhal ſee in the life to come.1. Cor. 13. For here we know onely but in part, but ther we ſhall know perfectly.
In fine, Moſes & ye prophets are now made perſpicuous, clere & plain.
Note one thing concerning the ſtory, which is, that the vayle was rent in two peces in the middeſt.

The Iewes when they heard any wickednes and blaſphemie agaynſt God, they rent their clothes. And ſo did thē the temple of God, for it rent his clothes, that is, the vaile, being aſtonied, and hauing great indignatiō for thoſe iniuries which were done vnto Chriſt. And not without cauſe, when the true temple of the Lords body, in whom all fulnes of the godhead dwelt corporally: was diſſolued by death. The figurall temple doth rent his vayle, and in a maner mourne and lament the ruine of the greater temple, that is, of the body of Chriſt put to death.

To end, by the renting of the vaile, the Iewes wer admoniſhed, that al their legal ſacrifices ſhould then ceaſe, & that ther ſhould be no more vſe of the old prieſthood. And although the edifice of the temple did yet ſtand ſtil, yet God ſhould not be worſhipped ther after the olde accuſtomed maner. Alſo, bicauſe the ſubſtaunce & truth of thoſe ſhadowes was now found, all the legall figures were turned into the ſpirite.

div.head: Fleece of woolle. 2.
div.p:
IT is written in the booke of Iudges,Iud. 6. how that Gideon ſaid vnto God: if thou wylt ſaue Iſrael by my hand, as thou haſt ſayd, behold I wil put a fleece of wooll in the threſhing place. If the dew come on the fleece onely, and it be dry vpon al the earth, then ſhall I be ſure, that thou wilt ſaue Iſrael by my hand, as thou haſt ſaid. And ſo it was, for he aroſe vp early on the morrow, and thruſt the fleece together, & wringed the dew out of the fleece, and filled a bowle of water. Again Gideon ſayd vnto God: be not angrye with me, that I maye ſpeake once more, let me proue once againe, I pray thee with the fleece: Let it nowe
be dry onely vpon the fleece, and let dew be vpon al the ground. And god did ſo that ſame night, for it was dry vpon the fleece onely, and ther was dew on all the ground.
Pſal. 71. lib. 1, de ſpiritu ſancto.The allegorie of this miſtery is deſcribed of ſaint Ambroſe and ſaint Auſten, who wrote after this maner.

The fleece doth ſignifye the people of the Iewes, which in times paſt were all moiſt and wet with the woord of god. Al the earth which was dry, did ſignify other nations, who lacked the preaching of gods woord. For Chriſt was the miniſter of circumciſion,Rom. 15. Math. 10. & ſent his Apoſtles in their firſt ambaſſade onely vnto the Iewes. But the matter cam ſo to paſſe afterwards, that it was throughly conuerted and chaunged. For the whole world was made plentifull with the word of God, by the comming of the holy ghoſt vpon the Apoſtles,Act. 2. which word the Iewes vtterly wanted, & as the barren and drye braunches they were cut of from the fertile and fat Oliue tree.

Other learned men do ſay, that the fleece doth ſignifye the fleece of that Lambe,Iohn. 1. of whom ſaint Iohn ſpake, ſaying: Ecce agnus dei, qui tollit peccata mundi, Behold the Lambe of God which taketh away the ſinnes of the world. The fleece of this lambe being ſprinckled with the heauenly dew of gods ſpirit, doth certify ye elect, of the good wil of God towards them, and doth ſtrengthen them againſt their enemies. This fleece alſo being thus ſprinkled, and al the earth being dry, doth ſignify, that all other perſons were deſtitute and voyd of gods grace and his ſpirit. Alſo it is written in the pſalme:Pſal. 14 Omnes declinauerunt, & inutiles factiſunt. All are ſtrayed out of the way, and are become vnprofitable. The fleece being moiſt,Col. 2. 1. Pet. 2. doth ſignify Chriſt, in whom dwelt the fulnes of the godheade corporally. And as it is writtē, Non eſt inuentus dolus in ore eius, ther was found no guile in his mouth, nor any ſpot in al his life.

div.head: To ſpeake with diuers toungs. 3.
2, Actorum.
div.p:
THis place is of diuers, diuerſly interpreted. Vnto ſome it ſemeth probable, that the Apoſtles did not ſpeake at that time wyth diuers toungs, but with onely one tounge, which was the Hebrue toung, which toung was vnderſtand and thought to be of the hearers, to euery one his own natural toung. Vpon this they haue one cōiecture, that Peter made one ſermon vnto a great number gathered together of many nations and countries, which could not vnderſtand that communication, except a ſtraunge voice came vnto their eares. Of this opinion be certayne of the Doctours, certayne other Expoſitours, and certayne Schoolemen, and ſome alſo of the latter writers, namelye Eraſmus in his Annotacions, the woordes be theſe: Dubitandum non eſt quin apoſtoli fuerunt diuerſis locuti linguis, quoties id poſtulabat euangelii negotium,
verum eundem hominem, eodem tempore diuerſis loqui linguis, implicat contradictionem. It is not to be doubted, but that the Apoſtles did ſpeake with diuers toungs, as often as the affaires of the goſpell did ſo require: but one man to ſpeake at one time with diuers tounges, it doth importe a contradiction. Vnto this agreeth Lyranus, whoſe wordes be theſe: The Apoſtles not onely ſpake and vnderſtood al manner of languages, but they ſpeaking in one certain language, what ſoeuer it were, all the hearers, although they were of diuers nations, vnderſtoode theyr own proper language, by the power of the holy ghoſt For as by rebellion in building the tower of Babilon, tounges were diuided: ſo by the infuſion of the holy ghoſt, tounges here were vnited.

But certain of the Germanes do not embrace this iudgement, but do ſay that the Apoſtles at that preſent time did ſpeake with diuers toungs, otherwiſe (ſay they) the miracle had not bene in the ſpeakers, but in the hearers. Yet it may be (ſay ſome of them) that the ſermon of Peter might then bee vnderſtoode of the moſte parte of the auditoures, bicauſe the greateſt part of them which came to Hieruſalem, were experte in the Caldie toung.

div.head: Daniel. 4.
div.p: DAniel was a famous and notable prophet, borne of the ſtocke of the kinges of Iuda. He was led captiue with kinge Ioachim into Babilon, of Nabuchadonozor, king of the Caldeans. After that in his youth, he had deliuered giltles Suſanna from death: being ennobled by the ſpirit of god, he did ſhew & expoūd the firſt viſiō vnto king Nabuchadonozor: wherfore the king wondring at his wit and gift,1. Daniel. 4. Reg. 24. fell vpon his face, and did ſalute him, and rendring to him thankes, cōmaunded a ſacrifice to be geuen to Daniel, as to god. He ordained him his chief gouernour, and had him in great honour, partlye bicauſe he perceiued in him a comely beuty and great wiſdome, partly bicauſe he vnderſtode to be in him the intelligence of al viſions and dreames. For when Daniel ſtoode in the kings ſight, euery word that the king demaunded of hym, he anſwered ſo, that it did excel and paſſe ten times the anſwers of other ſouthſaiers. VVhen Nabuchadonozor was dead (who thought him ſelf for a certain time, to be a brute beaſt) Daniel did declare vnto Balthaſar his ſonne, what thing ſhould come vpon him, when he ſaw the letters written with a mans hand, as it did appeare.

Now whē the monarchi of the Babilonians was deſtroied, Daniel was brought of Darius the king vnto Media, wher the king did adourne him with great honor, and did prefer him aboue al his other Lords. But enuy preuailing, Darius was conſtrained to caſt Daniel into the Lions den, wher he ſuffring no hurt of them, & knowing that God had ſaued him,6. Daniel
Darius did ſet him in greater honor thē euer he was before. And bicauſe he was a religious & holy mā, Darius did build vnto him a moſt coſtlye & ſumptuous tomb, in a certain city of Media, named Echathenis, wher at the laſt he was buried. This Daniel did not onely prophecy of thinges to come, as other prophets did, but alſo did preſcribe & appoint the time, in the which his prophecy ſhould be fulfilled. He wrote a booke of prophecies deuided into ten viſions. Thre viſions of them were vnder Nabuchadonozor. Thre other vnder Balthaſar. The ſeuenth and the eight viſion vnder Darius. And the two laſt vnder Cyrus.

His booke written in Hebrue, hath not the ſtory of Suſanna, nor the ſong of the three children, neither the reherſal of Bell and the Dragon, which ſaint Hierome did gather together into one booke, being diſperſed before abrod in ſundry partes. Saint Hierom doth cal Daniel philoſtoricum totius mundi, bicauſe he didde ſcribe ye ſtone bewen frō the hill without mans hand, and many other things. Yet ther be certain which do not accompte the booke of Daniel amongeſt the prophetes, but doo recken it amongeſt thoſe ſcriptures which be called Hagiographa, that is, bookes entreating of holy hiſtories.
Daniel ſignifieth in the Hebrue tounge Iudex dei, the Iudge of God.

div.head: Sacramentum. 5.
div.p: THis word Sacramentum, is no wher vſed in al the holy ſcriptures but the theological interpreters doo often times vſe this word.

Saint Auſten in his epiſtle Ad Marcellum, writeth thus: Longum eſſet diſputare de varietate ſignorum, quae cum ad res diuinas pertinēt, ſacramenta appellantur. It would be a long thing to diſpute of the variety of ſignes, which pertaining to godly things, are called ſacraments. VVherupon roſe this vulgar & cōmon diffinition, Sacramentum eſt ſacrae rei ſignum. They haue alſo an other diffinition more exact then the other, which is this: Sacramentum eſt inuiſibilis gratiae viſibilis forma. A ſacrament is the viſible forme of an inuiſible grace.
The latin writers do vſe this word ſacramentum, pro iuſiurando, for an othe, or els for a religious obligation and bond.

Marcus Varro, in his booke De lingua latina, doth expounde what it is to contend by a ſacrament. Qui petebat (inquit) qui
que inficiebatur de rebus aliis, vtri
que quingentos a ris ad pontem deponebant, de aliis item rebus certum numerū aſſium, pui vero iudicio vicerat ſuum ſacramentum a ſacro auferebat, victi ad aerarium redibat. The agent (ſaith he) & defendant of ſomthings, did both put down at the bridg. 500. peices of money, & of others a certain number of thoſe which ar called Aſſes. He that ouercam in iudgement, tooke away his ſacrament (that is his bond) from the holy place, the mony of him which was ouercom, was appointed to the treaſury. And bicauſe by the mediation of holy things, we be bound vnto
God & his ſaints by the participation of ſacraments, he doth in a maner binde him ſelfe by an othe vnto vs, by the teſtimony of the ſacramentes.

Vegetius in his booke De re militari, doth take ſacramentum, for an othe, taken by ſoldiours. For it was not lawful for any to fight, vnles he were firſt ſworne by an othe, with conceiued words they did ſwear, that they would do althinges manfullye, whatſoeuer the Emperour had commaunded, & that they would neuer forſake the wars for the defence of the Romane publike weale. And ſo they had a pledge & rewarde, and their names were written & recorded, & they wer ſigned with certain notes. Now bicauſe we in our ſacraments, ſpecially in baptiſme, are receiued and writtē into the wars of Chriſt, & bicauſe receiuing the ſacraments we profes & teſtifye that we be the ſoldiours of Chriſt, therefore not without cauſe the holy ſignes of Chriſt & of the church are called ſacraments.

div.head: Notio.
div.p: Al men for the moſt part, do confes & beleue, that God onely, & that neither men nor the church did inſtitute the ſacraments.
A certain ſcholmā doth warne the church ye ſhe ſhould remember her ſelf, not to be the lady of the ſacraments, but the miniſter of them.
Aquinas in his queſtion doth write ſaying. Ille inſtituit aliquid, qui dat ei robur et virtutem: ſed virtus ſacramenti eſt a ſolo deo: ſolus itaque deus poteſt inſtituere ſacramenta.

q.l: He doth make any thing, which geueth vnto it ſtrength and vertue:
But the vertue of the ſacrament is onely of God.
Therfore God onely can and doth inſtitute the Sacraments.

div.p: Saint Auſten hath a ſentence which is common in euery mās mouth. Accedit verbum ad elementum et fit ſecramentum. The word commeth to the element, & a ſacrament is made: wherof you may gather, a ſacrament to conſiſt of two ſpecial partes. The firſt is the ſwoord of God, not the word of man. The ſecond is, the ſigne appointed by God, not by man.

Chriſoſtome writing De cauſis ſacramentorū. Homilia in Math. 83 Nihil ſenſibile (inquit) tradidit nobis dominus. Res quidē ſenſibiles ſunt, omnia tamen intelligibilia. Sac in baptiſmo per rem ſenſibilem datur aqua, quod autem perficitur nempe regeneratio & renouatio, mente percipitur &c.

The matters of the ſacraments are ſenſible, yet al things are ther intelligible, So in baptiſme by a ſenſible thing water is geuen, but the thing which is made perfecte, is perceiued by mind, as regeneration, and renouation. For if thou wer wythout bodye, God woulde deliuer all his gifts vnto thee naked & ſimple: but bicauſe the ſoul is ioyned to ye bodie, he hath deliuered in things ſenſible, thoſe things which are perceiued in mind. The holy ſcriptures do nūber to be among the chriſtiās onely. 2. ſacraments, yt is baptiſm, & the ſupper of the lord. But Petrus Lūbardus doth accōt. 7. baptiſme, penāce, the Euchariſt, confirmatiō, extreme vnction, order, & matrimony. Of this iudgemēt is, for the moſt part ye whole cōpany of the interpreters, & the felowſhip of al the ſcholaſtical diuines But the auncient doctors of the church do reherſe onely. 2. ſacramentes.Lib 1. &. 4. & in lib. de corona malitis.
Tertullian, in hys booke Contra Martionem, and in his booke De corona militis doth recite onely two, Baptiſme, & the Euchariſt.

Saint Auſten de doctrina Chriſtiana, writeth ſaying. Dominꝰ ſignis nos non oncrauit (inquit) ſed quaedam pauca pro multis eadem
que factu facil ſima, et intellectu auguſtiſima, et obſeruatione caſtiſsima, ipſe dominus et Apoſtolica tradidit diſciplina, ſicuti eſt baptiſmi ſacramentum et cele bratio corporis et ſanguinis domini! The Lord hath not burdened vs wt ſignes, but for many, he & the apoſtolike diſcipline hath geuen vs a few, and thoſe in doing, very eaſy, in vnderſtāding, very noble, & in obſeruation, very pure, as the ſacrament of baptiſme, & the celebratiō of the body & bloud of the Lord. Again in his epiſtle Ad Ianuarium, he ſaith. Sacremētis numero pauciſſimis, obſeruatione facillimis, ſignificatione preſtantiſſimis, ſocietatem noui populi colligauit, ſicuti eſt baptiſmus trinitatis nomine conſecratus, communicatio corporis et ſanguis ipſius. &c. The lord hath tied together the congregation of the people of the new teſtament, with ſacraments in number very few, in obſeruation, very eaſy, in fignification, moſt worthy, as baptiſme, conſecrated in the name of the Trinitie, & communication of his body, and of his bloud.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: Vvhy ſir, ſaint Auſten maketh mention in that place by you alledged, of ſome other thing beſides thoſe. 2. For he ſaith in the ſame ſentence: Et ſi quid aliud in ſcripturis canonicis cōmendatur. Againe, he maketh mention of the ſacrament of order, which two places do impugne your aſſertion in numbring onely. 2. ſacraments.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p:
To the firſt I anſwer: Saint Auſten doth not ſay, et ſi quae alia, but & ſi quid aliud. That is: & if any other things are commended in the holy ſcriptures: but, if any other thing, in the ſingular number, which doth euidently declare, that he ſpake not of ſacraments, but of certain obſeruations, vſed & receiued of ye church, as his words following in ye ſame place doo ſhewe. To the ſecond I anſwer, that S. Auſten doth cal chriſma, prophecy, praier, and other ſuch like, ſacraments, as wel as order. Therfore when he maketh mention of order, as of a ſacrament, he taketh not ſacra mentum, in the proper ſignification: for if he did, then you muſt make alſo preaching & praying ſacraments, which wer very abſurde to graunt. Furthermore S. Auſten hath often times in his mouth, ſcripturarū ſacramenta. Now I dare ſay ye wil not graunt, the ſcriptures to be properly a ſacrament: wherupon it is euident that this word Sacramentum is vſed in his writings, ſomtime in one ſignificatiō, ſomtime in an other. He called theſe ſacraments, bicauſe as holy things they came from the holy ſprit of God, & bicauſe they be the ordinaūces of god, obſerued of al holy men. But the other, that is baptiſme, and the ſupper of the lord, do differ from thoſe, for theſe be holy actions, conſiſting of words & ceremonies, binding
the congregation into one fellowſhip.

Rabanus biſhop of Mentes, in his booke De inſtitutione clericorum, doth ſay: Sunt ſacramenta, baptiſmus, et chriſma, corpus et ſanguis: quae ob id ſacramenta dicuntur, quia ſub tegumento corporalium rerum virtus diuina ſalutem eoruudem ſacramentorum operatur, vnde et a ſecretis virtutibus, vel ſacris ſacramenta di cuntur. Baptiſe and Chriſma, the body & the bloud be ſacraments, which for this cauſe are called ſacraments, bicauſe vnder the couer of corporal things, the diuine power doth worke ſecretly the helth of the ſame ſacraments, wherof they are called A ſecretis vel ſacris virtutibus ſacramenta, of ſecrets & holy vertues ſacraments. As for the authority of the bookes of Dioniſius, it is manifeſt what euery learned man doth iudge of them.

div.head: Obſeruatio.
div.p: A ſacrament doth conſiſt of theſe things folowing: Of the ſigne, and of the thing ſignified. Of the word, and of the rite. Of the promiſe of the goſpel, and of the ceremony of the outward thing, & of the inward thyng. Of a thing earthly, and of a thing heauenly.Lib. 4 &. 5. contra hereſis. And (as Ireneus ſayth) of a thing viſible, & of a thing inuiſible, of a thing ſenſible, & of a thing intelligible. And of. 2. which haue their different natures in their properties being receiued, it is manifeſt, bicauſe that many which be partakers of the outward ſigne, haue no part of the thing ſignified. But if ye nature of both partes ſhould be one, and ioyned together naturally, then it muſt nedes follow, that they alſo receiue the thing it ſelfe, which be partakers of the ſigne. VVe haue examples in the ſcriptures to the contrarye. For Simon Magus in the actes of the Apoſtles did receiue the ſigne,Cap. 8 and was baptized: but of the thing it ſelfe, that is, of the holye ghoſt ſignified by water, he had no part at al. Iudas I ſcarioth, who betrayed the Lorde, did eate of the bread of the Lord, but not the bread the Lord (as ſaynt Auſten termeth it.) For otherwiſe if he had eaten the things it ſelfe, he ſhould haue liued moſt happy & bleſſed. For whoſoeuer eateth me (ſaith Chriſt) ſhal not die for euer. But Iudas periſhed with eternal death, therfore he had no part of the liuely meate. And it may be eaſily proued, that neither the preaching of the goſpel, nor receiuing of the ſacramēts with out faith, doth profit any thing at al: for S. Paul ſaith:Heb. 1 • . Sine fide impoſſibi le eſt placere deo. Saint Auſten Contra Fauſtum hath theſe words. Peter doth ſay (ſaith he) baptiſme hath made vs ſafe, and leaſt they ſhould thinke the viſible ſacrament to be onely ſufficient, he addeth: Non carnis depoſitio ſordium, ſed bonae conſcientiae interrogatio. Not the putting of the filthines of the fleſh, but the minde of a good conſcience.

div.head: Queſtio.
div.p: Some wil demaund whether the grace of God be contained and ſhut in the ſacraments, & ſo deriued into them, which receiue them?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: The ſchole diuines, Monkes, Friers, and other of that ſort, doo iudge the very vertue of God, yea and God himſelfe to be contained in the ſacraments. VVherupon riſeth this friuolous and vaine queſtion, that is, what the Mouſe doth eate when ſhe doth gnaw the ſacrament.

Lib. 4. cap. 11. de ſacrameto altaris.Innocentius the Pope doth ſay, that the ſubſtaunce of bread doth returne miraculouſly, but not that ſubſtaunce (ſaith he) which was tranſubſtantiate into the fleſh, but an other bread is made by a miracle in the ſtede therof. And that bread (ſaith he) is gnawn of the Mouſe, O ſuttle and wonderfull diuinity, not worth a meſſe of vinegar.

Bonauenture, who wrote vppon the maiſter of the ſentence, among many other wordes ſayth thus:Lib. 4. diſt. 1. queſtio. 3. Non eſt aliquo modo dicendum (inquit) quod gratia contineatur in ſacramentis eſſentialiter, tanquam aqua in vaſe, vel medicina in pixide, imo hoc intelligere eſt erroneum. Sed dicuntur continere gratiam, quia ipſam ſignificant, & quia ibi niſi ſit defectus ex parte ſuſcipientis, in ipſis gratia ſēper confertur: ita intelligendo quod gratia ſit in anima, non in ſignis viſibilibus. Pro tanto dicuntur etiam ya ſa gratiae. Poſſunt etiam dici vaſa alia ratione, quia ſicut quod eſt in vaſe, non eſt de ipſo nec ex ipſo, ſed tamen ab ipſo hauritur ab ipſa anima in ipſis ſacramentis. Et ſicut quis recurritad vas cum requirit liquorē, ſic quae renti liquorem gratiae, et non habenti recurrendum eſt ad ſacramenta.

That is: VVe muſt ſay by no meanes, that grace is contained in the ſacraments eſſentially, as water is in a veſſel, or medicine in a boxe, for it is erronious ſo to be vnderſtanded: but the ſacraments are ſayde to contayne grace, bicauſe they ſignify grace, and except therbe default in the receiuer, grace alwaies is geuen in them. Yet this is ſo to be vnderſtāded, that grace is in the ſoule, and not in viſible ſignes, & for that ſo great a cauſe they are called the veſſels of grace. They maye alſo be called the veſſels of grace by an other reaſon, which is this: As that which is in the veſſel, is not of the veſſel, nor commeth thereof, yet it is drawen out of the veſſel: So grace is not of the ſacraments, nor cōmeth of them, but ſpringeth of the eternal fountain, of the which fountain the ſoule ſeketh in the ſacraments. And as a man doth runne to the veſſel when he ſeeketh the licour: So muſt he which ſeketh the licour of grace, and hath it not, run to the ſacraments. Theſe be Bonauentures words, which moſt rightlye referred grace to God onely, the fountain of al goodnes. He ſayth alſo, not the ſenſible ſignes, but the ſoule of man is the ſeate and receptacle of grace, and of all the giftes of God.

The holy ſcriptures do teach in euery place, that the minde of man, & no element is the houſe of Gods grace. Salomon doth ſay. Si caeli caelorum te non continent, quanto minus domus haec? If the heauen of heauens do not contayn thee, how much leſſe this houſe? Saint Stephen doth ſay alſo: The moſt high God doth not dwell in temples made with mens handes.
Beſides many other places of the ſcripture.

div.head: Corinthus. 6.
div.p: COrinthus was a famous city in Achaia, builded, as Euſebius reporteth, in the time of Moſes, being 80. yeres of age. It was builded of one Siſyphus, a notorious theſe, who was ſlain of Theſeus and (as the Poets faine) is puniſhed in hel with a certaine kinde of torment, that he is compelled to beare a great ſtone to the top of the mountain▪ and when he hath caried it to the very top, it roleth down agayn to the botom, wherof Ouid maketh mention, ſaying: Aut petis, aut vrges rediturum Siſyphe ſaxum. VVherupon riſeth this prouerbe, Siſyphi ſaxū voluere. To role vp and down Siſyphus ſtone. By the which is ſignified vnceſſable ſweate and labour, but vnprofitable, & vtterly vain. As you would ſay, Siſyphi ſaxum voluit, he taketh vnmeaſurable pain, but that which he doth, is all in vaine.

This city Corinthus was builded betwene two ſeas, the one called mare Ioinum, the other mare Aegeum. The place wher it was ſet, was properly called Iſthmos, which is a narow place of the countrye, where two ſeas are but a ſmal diſtaunce a ſunder, encloſing the land on both ſides. Strabo writeth, yt it was a very rich & notable Marte, vnto the which Marchants out of al places of the world had their recourſe. And as for ye moſt part wantōnes, riot, & pleaſures do flow out of power & wealth, ſo at Corinth was ther al kind of wickednes: inſomuch yt euery man liued as he luſted, & yt without puniſhmēt. As Paul writeth to the Corinthiās ſaying: Eratis ſcortatores, idololatrae, adulteri, molles, auari, ebrioſi, 1. Cor. 6. raptores. You were in times paſt whoremōgers, idolaters, adulterers, wanton, couetous, dronkards, extorcioners. Strabo writeth, that ther wer aboue a thouſand yong women conſecrated, to be defiled in the temple of Venus, in the honor of her. Alſo in this city of Corinth, ther was a notorious ſtrumpet called Lais, of whom Aulus Gellius reherſeth this hiſtory. Lais (ſaith he) a ſtrumpet of Corinthus, did gaine great ſums of money through her beuty and fairenes. Vnto her al the wealthy men of Grecia did repaire, to ſatify their filthy luſt. She admitted none, vnles he would geue that which ſhe demaūded. Demoſthenes on a time came priuely vnto her, and made requeſt to haue the vſe of her body: but Lais demaūded of him ten thouſand Dragmas. Demoſthenes being diſmaied, and made a feard with ſo great a ſumme of mony, turned his backe, and going away, ſayd theſe woords: Ego penitere tanti non emo, I wil not by repentaunce ſo deare. VVherupon riſeth this common prouerbe, Non eſt cuiuſ libet Corinthum appellere. Euery man cannot arriue at Corinth. This prouerbe is elegantly vſed & applied of high & waighty matters, and daungerous to be compaſſed, and not euery mans part to attempt.

Suidas doth refer the original of this prouerbe, vnto the daungerous & not eaſy paſſage or arriual for the Mariners vnto the port of Corinth. Ariſtippus was wont to ſay and glory, that he onely had Lais, and that all other were had of her.

Of this filthy ſincke of men beinge geuen vnto pleaſure, wantonnes, riot, and polluted with all kinde of vice, the eternall God made and gathered vnto him a Chriſtian congregation, by the miniſterie of Paule, who wrote vnto them his firſt epiſtle, out of Epheſus, a citye of Aſia, in the. 21. yere after his conuerſion. And the congregation being firſt by him conuerted, were afterward marueilouſly ſubuerted, of certayn falfe Apoſtles: but Paule in his firſt epiſtle did reuoke them againe to the true faith, and euangelicall verity.

This city was firſt called Certhera, & being encreaſed & made more populous, it was afterward called Ephyra. Strabo alſo writeth, that the Corinthians did defoule the Embaſſadours of Rome with filth caſt out at the windowes, as they paſſed by their ſumptuous and gay houſes. For the which cauſe and other inſolent and proude partes practiſed by the Corinthians, Lucius Mumius the Emperour, accompanied with a huge & mighty hoſt, threw down the city of Corinth flat to the ground: ſuch is the reward of pride. This city being deſtroyed and ouerthrowne, was reſtored and reedified of one Corinthus, Oreſtes ſonne: but being at the laſt burned of the Romains, it could neuer be reſtored againe.

div.head: Simeon. 7.
div.p: SImeon betokeneth in the Hebrue audiens vel auditio, hearing or report. Of what parents this Simeon came, or what function he vſed, it is vncertain. It may be, that he was ſome priuate mā, that they might the more be aſhamed, which chalenged vnto themſelues great and famous titles of renowme and dignity.

He is ſet forth worthely & praiſed, for that he embraced true godlines, & perfectly knew and vnderſtoode the promiſes of Meſsias, deſiring nothing more, then that he ſhould ſpedely come into the world. For this cauſe vndoubtedly he offered earneſt praiers dayly vnto God, eſpecially when he now ſaw the time to be at hand. And when he perceiued, not without great grefe, al things among the people of God, to be daylye wurs & wurs (for there raigned in the temple horrible corruptiōs & de luſions, & in the political gouernmēt al things wer ful of bloudy tirāny) he receiued of god a ſingular reuelatiō, that he ſhoulde not die before he beheld Chriſt with his corporal eyes. That benefit he preferred before al other commodities, and vndoubtedlye he communicated thys ioyfull tidings to his family and other good men: but of other ſtiffe necked people, being blinded in their ſuperſtitious opinions and ceremonies, he was
not beleued, but rather mocked and laughed to ſcorne.

He was notwithſtanding the temple of the holy ghoſt, through whoſe paculiar motion, he came into the Churche at that ſame houre, when Ieſus Chriſt, accordyng to the lawe of the firſt borne, was offred of his parentes, and preſented before the Lord.

And he was ſo inſpired and kindled with heauenly light, that without delay he tooke the infant in his armes, whiche was borne of the virgine Mary, pronouncing openly and boldly with great reioyſing of hys hart, that this was he whiche was promiſed of God, and that there was none other to be looked for. Theſe his wordes folowing are worthy to be rehearſed and pondered.Luk. 2. Now thou letteſt thy ſeruaunt to departe in peace according vnto thy word. For mine eyes haue ſene thy ſaluation, whiche thou haſt prepared before the face of all people. To be a lyght to lighten the Gentils, and to be the glory of thy people Iſrael. He doth not onely plainly and euidently ſhewe of thinges preſent, but alſo of thinges that ſhould folow, and of the whole office of Chriſt, And he Prophecieth of gathering together of the Church out of the Gentils: finally he ſingeth a moſt ſwete ſong like vnto the ſwanne before his death. Ioſeph and Marie do greatly maruell at this, ſo manifeſt and noble teſtimonie of Ieſus Chriſt, geuen of ſo holy a man, for they had nothyng opened this matter vnto him. And certaynly there were other Prieſtes preſent at the hearing of theſe wordes, but they were moued nothing at them. It may be alſo, that they ſcorned at him, countyng him a doting olde foole. Yet notwithſtāding this ſentence of the Meſsias is vttered, as it were before the congregation, and before the Arke and ſight of the Lord.

After that, Simeon proceedeth in prophecienge, and doth execute the office of a Prieſt, bleſsinge them, and wiſhinge vnto them, all gladde and luckie thinges accordinge to the office of Meſsias, adding vnto, theſe words: Behold, this child is put for a fal and a riſing againe vnto many in Iſraell, and for a ſigne againſt the which they ſhall ſpeake. Simeon doth not dreame here of the golden and wealthye worlde, as other did looke for at Meſsias hands, no other thing then worldly commodities, but Simeon knew, that Meſsias ſhould ſuffer: finally, he ſtrēghneth and comforteth Marie, agaynſt the ſorowes whiche ſhe ſhoulde feele, ſaying: The ſword of ſorow ſhal pearſe thy ſoule, that the thoughts of many mens hartes might be made open. He feared not the hatred & euill will of the chief rulars, neither did he expecte their determination and mynde, but was onely contented with the heauenlye reuelation. VVhen and howe he died, it is not knowne. It is to be thought, that he departed in ſhorte tyme after out of this miſerable lyfe,Luk. 1 into the lande of the lyuyng.

div.head: Aenigma. 8.
div.p: ENigma is an obſcure allegorie, and a ſentence couered with ſubtill and crafty wordes, Man.

q.l: Obſcurus ſermo cunctis aenigma vocatur.
Vt: mater me genuit, mox gignitur ex me.

div.p: That is to ſay: Aenigma is called of al men a darke and obſcure ſpeach. As, my mother hath brought forth me, and anone ſhe is brought forth of me. By this ſentence is ſignified water, for of water Iſe is congeled, & is reſolued againe into water.

Aenigma differreth from an allegory in this, that an allegorie is euident, cleare, and manifeſt, and aenigma is ſomewhat obſcure and ſubtill. Neither it ought to be reprehended if you, either ſpeake, or write to the learned or vnlearned, that there by they may be compelled to ſearch and learne the ſure meaning therof. Phe Prophetes haue many aenigmata, ſo hath the Apocalipſe. Likewiſe in the Ethnicke writers, there be many aenigmata, of the goddes and of the Sibilles. As Sibillae folium, extripede dictum, dixthera Iouis. &c. This figure is coumpted of Fabius to be rather a fault, than a vertue in any oration. VVherupon Diomedes beyng moued, doth nomber this trope aſwell among the faultes, as among the vertues of an oration.

Heſiodus ſheweth a very apt example of this figure in his Georgikes, ſaying, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Dimidium plus toto. That is to ſay: Half is more then the whole, by the whiche aenigma is ſignified golden mediocritie: for he that is content with halfe, doth conſiſt in the meane, but he that doth aſpire and deſireth the whole, tendeth to extremitie.

Plutarchus doth report of Darius, that when he called vnto him the Lordes liuetenauntes of his prouinces, he aſked of them, whether the tributes were to greuous for the ſubiectes or no. And when they aunſwered that they were meane, he commaunded the one halfe onely to be payde, iudging it to be better to take half with the good wil of his prouincialles, than the whole with their hatred.
In aeglogis.The like aenigma is in Virgill who writeth thus.

q.l: Dic quibus in terris & eris mihi magnus Apollo,
Tres pateat caeli ſpatium non amplius vlnas.

div.p:
Agayne in the holy Scriptures are diuerſe and ſondrie aenigmata, as for example in the Pſalme. Pennae columbae de argentatae &, poſteriora dorſi eius in ſpecie auri. Though ye haue lyen amōg pots, yet ſhal ye be that is as ye wings of a doue,pſal. 68. that is couered with ſiluer, & whoſe fethers are like yellow golde. By the whiche is ſignified, though God ſuffer his Churche for a time to lye in blacke darcknes, yet he will reſtore it and make it moſt ſhining and white. In the boke of Iudges there is an aenigma
of Sampſon, hauing ſubdued the Lyon. De comedente exiuit cibus, Iud 14. & deforti egreſſa eſt dulcedo: that is, meat came forth of the eater, & ſwetnes went out of the ſtrong. And in the Goſpell. Vbicum que fuerit corpus, Math. 24. illic congregabuntur & aquilae That is, wherſoeuer the body ſhalbe, thether will the Egles ſtocke. VVherby Chriſt ſignifieth, that the elect will flie vnto him, when he commeth. Alſo Ezechiell:Cap. 17. Fili hominis propone aenigma, & narra parabolam ad domū Iſrael, & dices: Haec dicit dominus deus. Aquila grandis magnarum alarum, longo membrorum ductu, plena plumis, & varietate, venit ad Libanum, & tulit medullam Cedri. that is. Son of mā, put forth a parable, & ſpeak a prouerb vnto the houſe of Iſraell, and ſay: Thus ſayth the Lord God, the great Egle with great winges and long wings, and full of feathers, whiche had diuerſe colours, came vnto Libanum, and toke the higheſt braunch of the Cedre. VVherby is ſignified, that Nabuchadonozor who hath great power, riches, & many countreis vnder hym, ſhall come to Ieruſalem and take away Ieconiah the kyng. And in the booke of Iudges:Cap. 9. Ierunt ligna vt vngerent regem ſuper ſe dixeruntque oliuae, Impera nobis. Quae reſpondit, nunquid poſſum deſerere pinguedinem meam? &c. That is. The trees went forth to anoynte a kyng ouer them. And ſayd vnto the Oliue tree: Reigne thou ouer vs. But the Oliue tree ſayd vnto them: ſhould I leaue my fatnes? &c By the whiche parable is declared, that thoſe whiche are not ambitious, are moſt worthy of honour, and that the ambitious abuſe their honour, both to their owne deſtructions and others.

Alſo Ezechiel. Duae mulieres filiae matris vnius fuerunt.Cap. 23. Et fornicatae ſunt in Egypto, in adoleſcentia ſua fornicatae ſunt: ibi ſubacta ſunt vbera earum, & fractae ſunt mammae pubertatis earū. That is to ſay. There were two women, the daughters of one mother. And they committed fornication in Egypt, they committed fornication in their youth: ther wer their breſtes preſſed, and there they bruſed their teates of their virginitie. By the whiche parable Iſraell and Iuda are mente, whiche came both out of one familie. They became Idolaters after the maner of the Egyptians.

Furthermore in the fourth boke of kīgs.Cap. 14, Carduus Libani miſit ad Cedrum quae eſt in Libano. Trāſieruntque beſtiae ſaltus quae ſunt in Libano, & conculcauerunt Carduum. That is. The thiſtle that is in Libanō, ſent to the Cedre that is in Libanon. &c.

By the whiche parable Iehoaſh compareth himfelfe to a Cedre tree, bycauſe of his great kingdom ouer ten tribes, and Amaziah to a thiſtle, bycauſe he ruled but ouer two tribes. And the wilde beaſtes are Iehoaſh his ſouldiours, that ſpoyled the Cities of Iuda.

div.head: Daye ſtarre. 9.
div.p:
VNtill the day ſtarre ariſe in your hartes. By the day may be vnderſtanded the manifeſt knowledge of the godhead. By the
riſing of the day ſtarre may be ſignified the open knowledge of the humanitie of Chriſt. The bleſsednes of the Saintes ſhalbe in both, as Chriſt ſayth in the Goſpell of Iohn. Haec eſt vita eterna vt cognoſeant te ſolum deum & quem miſiſti Ieſum Chriſtum. This is lyfe eternall, that they know thee to be onely very God, and whom thou haſte ſent Ieſus Chriſt.
Or by the day is vnderſtanded the knowledge of the Saints after the iudgement: by the riſing of the day ſtarre, the knowledge before the iudgement.

But to omit ſuch ſcholaſticall allegories, Saint Peter meaneth no more in this place, but doth ſet the whole day with all his partes againſt darknes, which would vtterly ouerwhelme all our ſenſes and vnderſtandings, except the Lord had holpen vs with the light of his word.

div.head: Typus. 10.
div.p: TYpus doth properly ſignifie a forme, a figure, an example, a ſhadow, and an image of an other thing.
Archetypa, are properly the firſt and principall examplars, whiche are not taken out of other thinges, but are the verie originall thinges them ſelues.
Typi alſo (as Gellius writeth) are the letters whiche we call deſcriptions, not exactly made, but rude.

Typus alſo is a figure and ſymboll of the veritie and truth, In whiche ſignification we ſay, the old Teſtament to be a type of the new, and the Sacrifices of the ſame to be types of the Sacrifice of Chriſt.

VVe call the noble arte of printyng Typographiam, whiche was firſt inuented by one Iohannes Gutenbergius, a man of a rare and maruelous wit, in a certayne Citie of Germany called Maguntia, in the yeare of the incarnation of Chriſt. 1450. No leſſe glory, no leſse immortall memorie is to be geuen to this worthy man, than to them whiche firſt inuented letters.

div.head: Vnto Iohn. 11.
div.p:
THe Prophetes & the law prophecied vnto Iohn, as though Chriſt ſhould ſay: It is no maruell if God worcke nowe ſo mightylye in the myndes of men, bycauſe he doth not ſhewe him ſelf a farre of vnder darcke ſhadowes, as he did before, but is openly preſent to eſtabliſhe his kingdome. VVherupon it foloweth, that they haue leſse excuſe whiche do contēptuouſly reiect the doctrine of Iohn, then the contemners of the lawe and of the Prophetes. For that whiche Iohn preached, is the ſelfe ſame thyng wherof the law and the Prophetes ſpake before. For Iohn doth teſtifie thoſe thinges whiche
be now accompliſhed and perfourmed.

Saint Hierome writing vpon this place, doth ſay, that Chriſt doth not exclude all Prophetes after Iohn,Act. 11. et. 21. for we read in the Actes of the Apoſtles that Agabus did prophecie: likewiſe the foure daughters of Philip prophecied. Therfore where it is ſayd here, that the Prophetes prophecied vnto Iohn, is ment and declared the time of Chriſt, whom Iohn did ſhew with his finger, that he was come, whom the Prophets ſhewed before, that he ſhould come.

div.head: Violence take it. 12.
div.p:
FRom the dayes of Iohn the Baptiſt vntill now,Math. 12. the kingdome of heauen ſuffreth violence, and the violent take it by force. That man would labour with all his power to prouide for his ſaluatiō which might hear a worthy preacher ſay that it ſuffiſeth him to get eternall life, if he returne and amende from his former wickednes. This is a very eaſy way to attayne ſaluation, whiche who ſo holdeth not, but wandreth alwayes, and goeth aſtray, is wretched, and of a deſperat life. The Lord doth not require thy gold, ſiluer, or earthly poſseſsions, wherby he may leade thee out of darckenes, and deliuer thee from the bondage of ſinne, but onely he requireth a ready and prompt mynde of repentaunce. Shew vnto him the filthines of thy minde, if thou cannot ſhewe him thy innocent and pure life, and he will frely wipe them away. Offer vnto him teares guſhing out of thine eyes, and he will receiue them in a maner for part of amendement. He doth not abhor thee, though thou be a wicked ſinner, but of his great gentlenes allureth thee to repentaunce. He doth not deſire the death and deſtruction of thy ſoule, but that thou be rather conuerted and liue. He it is whiche reioyſeth more ouer one ſinner,Luk. 15. than of ninety and nine iuſt perſons, whiche nede not repentaunce. Acknowledge thy fault with a ready will, and he will haue mercye on thee. He it is, that ſayd: Tell thine offences, that thou maiſt be iuſtified. And bycauſe thou haſt promiſed to deteſte thine vnrighteouſnes,Pſal. 32. he hath already remitted thine vngodlines. The good theefe faithfully beleuing, that the moſt plentifull well of Gods mercy could not be ſpent and dried vp, with great violence entred into the kingdome of heauen,Luk. 23 the which thing he obtained by this his confeſsion. Memento mei domine dum veneris in regnum tuum, That is: Remember me Lord when thou ſhalt come into thy kyngdome.Math. 11. But wherfore is the kingdome of heauen inuaded and ſet vpon, from the time of Iohn vnto theſe dayes? bycauſe he ſhewed the ſcope & marke of eternall life, which we may eaſely attaine. For he ſayd: Repēt ye, and the kingdome of heauen will drawe nigh vnto you.Math. 3 The Lord alſo (when he preached) ſhewed the ſame to be an eaſie
way to entre in, yea, euen vnto the blind. And aſſone as the multitude did know that an eaſie way of ſaluation was open for them, they ranne to attayne it, and breaking in by heapes into the kingdome of heauen, they ſhotte onely at this ſcope, ye Lord notwithſtanding directed the mouing of their ſhot with his grace. The violent tooke by force the kingdome of heauen, when with feruent deſire they haſtned to cleaue vnto Chriſt: & he that was born a mā, deſired to become an angel & an erthly creature ſought an heauenly habitation (as writeth Hierome) ſaying.Queſt. 1. ad Algatian. The Gentils chiefly entred into the kingdome of heauen by feruent faith and humilitie, who loued Chriſt more then the Iewes, wherupon Hilary ſayth. Gloria Iſrael a patribus debita a Prophaetis nunciata, a Chriſto oblata, fide gentium occupatur & rapitur. That is. The glory of Iſrael, due from the fathers, declared of the Prophetes, and offred of Chriſt, is obtayned and readyly taken by the faith of the Gentils. As God ſtirred Iohn to be the criar of the kingdome of his ſonne, ſo did he put into his doctrine the efficacie of the ſpirit that it might pearſe into the harts of mē, & kindle their feruencie toward it. But bicauſe the great part of the people were no more moued, than if no word had ben ſpoken either by the Prophetes of chriſt, or as though Iohn had neuer come forth as a witnes: chriſt doth teach this violencie of the which he ſpeaketh, to be but in certain kind of mē. The ſēce is this. Ther is now a great concourſe & repaire of men to ye kingdome of heauen, and they do ruſh in violently to attayne it, for they being ſtirred by the voyce of one man, come in flockes and in heapes, and do not onely with much deſire, but gredyly embrace the grace offred vnto them, although there be many ſluggardes, whiche are no more moued, then if Iohn ſhould tell them but a fable, pertayning nothing vnto them, yet many I ſay do runne to it with a violent loue and zeale. The kingdom of heauen is taken here for the new doctrin of the Goſpell.
The kingdome of heauen to ſuffer violence, is with great and gredy deſire to runne to the open preaching therof, and to breake in by ſtrēgth.

The violent to take the kingdome of heauen, is no more, but to be ſo hoat with the zeale of the goſpell, that a man is ready to diſpiſe and loſe life and all yt he hath, ſo that he may be partaker of the kingdom of God.

div.head: Agar & Sara. 13.
div.p:
AGar written without aſpiration was handmaiden of Sara, and concubine of Abraham. She was the mother of Iſmaell. And note here, that this word Concubina, was taken in the olde tyme for an honeſt name (as Maſurius writeth.) And in the lawes of the Romanes, a concubine was not counted a ſtrompet, nor a maried mans lemman, but Concubina was properly ſhe, which had coniugall companie with a ſingle man: yet ſhe differed from her whyche
is counted Vxor, a wife, bycauſe the cohabitation of a concubine is not indiuiduall or inſeparable, and for that both the parties ſo ioyned, might be eaſly ſeparated agayne.

Saint Hierome, writyng Ad Oceanum, doth diſcerne a concubine from a wife, in theſe two poyntes. Firſt, that a wyfe had neede of Tables or writinges to recorde the contracte. Secondly that a wife had a dowrye, whiche both (ſayth Saint Hierome) a concubine had not: but this ſentence of Hierome is not generally true, for this his ſayinge is to be ſtrayned to that wyfe, whiche was before a concubine. In deede ſhe that was the concubine, had neede of Tables and recorde, bycauſe ſhe ſhould be no longer named a concubine, and that the childrē after borne of her, ſhould be legitimate. As for dowry, is not alwayes required of neceſsitie, for a dowry cānot be without matrimony, but matrimony may be wt out a dowry. The Romain lawe did allow concubines to be lawfull, yet it doth ſomewhat note that kynde of coniunction, bycauſe it doth not ſuffer children begotten of concubines to be iuſte and ryght heyres, oneles that the concubine be made at the laſt a wyfe, or els that the princes authoritie do legitimate them.

div.head: Queſtio.
div.p: But what is this to the concubines ſpoken of in the Scriptures, whom the fathers had?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: A concubine is called in the Hebrue toung Pilaegaeſch that is, a mayden ioyned to a man without wryting, that is, without contract, or betrouthing, yet ſhe was counted a true wife in the holy Scriptures, as it plainly appeareth in Cethura, who was called Vxor, a wife, Et addidit Abraham, & accepit vxorē, & nomen eius Cethura, & peperitei Zimran. &c. Geneſis. 28 Now Abraham had taken him another wife called Cethura, which bare hym Zimran, And in the ſame Chapter ſhe is called alſo a concubine, where it is ſayd, that Abraham gaue all his goods to Iſaac, but vnto the ſonnes of the concubines, whiche Abraham had, he gaue giftes, and ſent them away to the Eaſt countrey.
Here may you ſee, that the concubines among the Hebrues were very wiues, although they were oftentymes handmaydens, as Agar, Bala, Zilpa and others.

Concerning the ciuile ordinaunces of the places where the fathers dwelt, the free men could not contract matrimonie with their handmaydens▪ and therfore it might be, that in the holy Scriptures, they be called Concubinae concubines, and not wiues, notwithſtanding before God they were wiues.

There be two differences betwene the lawes of the Romaines, and the lawes of the Iewes. Firſt the Romaines counted not Concubinatum, to be matrimony. Among the Iewes it was counted matrimonie before God.
Secondly the Iewes had their handmaidens to their concubines, the Romaines would not haue that to be lawfull.

It is to be noted, that where it ſeemeth in the decrees, concubines to be approued and allowed, they are to be vnderſtande of thoſe, whiche were wyues in deede, that is, when both parties do conſent and agree to dwell continually together, and to acknowledge eche other as man and wife. Otherwiſe concubines be vtterly forbidden.
Theſe ſhalbe ſufficient for this name, concubine, whiche now in theſe dayes is not lawfull.
Agar written with chet, ſignifieth Cingulum, or Perezoma, a girdle, or any thing that compaſſeth about.
Agar written with he, betokeneth a ſtraunger, it commeth of this verb Hagar, id eſt, peregrinatus eſt.
Sarah ſignifieth Dominam, or Principem.
Ye ſhall finde, that Abraham had two ſonnes, that is Iſmaell of Agar, and Iſaac of Sara.

Both were the true ſonnes of Abraham, Iſmael was no leſse the true ſonne of Abraham then Iſaac, for both came of one father, one fleſh & one ſeede. VVhat is than the difference? this maketh not the difference (ſaith Paule) bicauſe one of the mothers was a free woman, & the other a bonde woman (althoughe it maketh for the allegorie) but bycauſe Iſmaell whiche was borne of the bonde woman, was borne of the fleſhe, that is without promiſe and without the worde of God, but Iſaac was not onely borne of the free woman, but alſo accordyng vnto promiſe. VVhy ſo? notwithſtandyng Iſaac was borne of the ſeede of Abraham aſwell as Iſmaell. I graunte they were both the ſonnes of one father, and yet there is a difference, for although that Iſaac was borne of the fleſhe, yet there went before a promiſe and a nomination of God. This difference Paul would haue to be noted. He gathered this difference in this maner out of the text of Geneſis.

That Agar conceyued, and brought forth Iſmael, it was not the voyce and the worde of God, which had foretold that this ſhould come to paſse: but by the permiſsion of Sara, Abraham went vnto his handmaid, Agar, whom Sara beyng baren (as Geneſis witneſseth) gaue him to wife. For Sara had heard,Gene. 16. that Abraham by the promiſe of God ſhould haue ſeede of his body. Vnto this ſeede ſhe hoped, that ſhe ſhould be mother: but when ſhe had many yeares looked for this hope, after the promiſe was made, ſeyng the matter to be differred, ſhe thought her hope to be fruſtrate. VVherfore this holy woman doth yelde vnto the honour of her huſband, and her owne ryght, reſignyng her ryght vnto another and that vnto her handemayd, yet ſhe doth not ſuffer her huſband to marrie
another wyfe without his houſe, but ſhe geueth her owne mayden vnto hym in matrimonie, that ſhe myght haue children in her owne houſe. For ſo hath the Hiſtory of Geneſis.

Sara vxor Abraham non genuerat illi, Cap. 16. ſed habens ancillam Egyptiam nomine Agar, dixit marito ſuo: Ecce, concluſit me dominus, ne parerem, Ingredere quaeſo ad ancillam meam, ſi forte ex illa aedificer, & cete. That is to ſay. Sara Abrahams wyfe bare hym no children, and ſhe had a mayde, an Egyptian, Agar by name. And Sara ſayde vnto Abraham: beholde nowe, the Lorde hath reſtrayned me from childebearyng. I pray thee go in vnto my mayde, it may be that I ſhall receyue a chylde by her. &c. It is a great humilitie, that ſhe ſo much directed her ſelfe, takynge in good parte this temptation of her fayth. She thought thus with her ſelfe, GOD is no lyer, what he hath promiſed vnto my huſbande, that will he ſurely performe, but perchaunce God will not haue me to be the mother of this ſeede, I wyll not enuye Agar thys honour, vnto whome lette my huſbande goe in, perchaunce I maye haue children by her.

VVherfore Iſmaell is borne without the woorde, onely at the petition of Sara her ſelfe, for there is no woorde of God whiche commaunded or promiſed Abraham a ſonne, but it ſeemeth all to be done by chaunce, whiche the woordes of Sara declare. If perhaps (ſayth ſhe) I maye haue a chylde by her. Since that therfore there preceded no voyce of God vnto Abraham, as there did when Sara ſhould bring forth Iſaac, but the voyce of Sara onely goeth before, it is ſufficiently ſhewed, that Iſmaell was the ſonne of Abraham accordyng to the fleſh, onely without the woorde. Therefore he was looked for and borne lyke vnto any other chylde. This thynge Sainte Paule diligently pondered and weyghed.

He vrgeth alſo the ſame argument vnto the Romayns, which here including in an allegorie, he doth repete & ſtrongly conclude,Rom. 9 yt all ye ſonnes of Abrahā are not the ſonnes of God. Abrahā (ſayth he) hath two ſorts of ſonnes: the one ſorte are borne of his fleſhe & bloud, but the woorde and the promiſe of God goyng before, the one as Iſaac, ye other ſort with out the promiſe, as Iſmaell. Therfore (ſayth he) the children of the fleſh are not ye children of God, but ye children of promiſe. &c. And with this argument he ſtoppeth the mouthes of the proude Iewes: as Chriſt doth alſo in Mathewe and in Iohn,Math. 3. Iohn. 8. who glorified them ſelues to be the children and ſeede of Abraham. As though he ſhould ſay, It foloweth not. I am the carnall ſeede of Abraham, therfore I am the ſonne of GOD. Eſau is the naturall ſonne, therefore he is the heyre. They that will (ſayth he) be the ſonnes of Abraham, they, beſides their carnall birth, muſt be the children of promiſe and belief. And they that haue the
promiſe and beleife, are onely the true children of Abraham, and conſequently the ſonnes of God.

But Iſmaell bycauſe he is not promiſed of God vnto Abraham, is onely the ſonne of the fleſhe, and not of promiſe, and therefore he is looked for and borne as other children are. For no mother knoweth whether ſhe ſhall haue any childe or no, or if ſhe perceyue her ſelfe to be quicke, ſhe knoweth not whether it be a manne or woman childe, but Iſaac was certaynely named. Sara vxor tua inquit Angelus ad Abraham, Gene. 17. pariet tibi filium, vocabiſque nomen eius Iſaac. Thy wyfe Sara (ſayth the Aungell vnto Abraham) ſhall bryng foorth vnto thee a ſonne, and thou ſhalte call his name Iſaac. Here both the ſon and the mother are expreſſely named. So for thys humbleneſse of Sara, that ſhe dyd yelde her ryght, and ſuffred the contempte of Agar, God recompenced her, and gaue her this honour, that ſhe her ſelfe was the mother of the promiſed ſonne.Gene. 16.

div.head: Simile.
div.p: Abraham is the figure and token of God, who hath two ſonnes, that is, two peoples repreſented by Iſmaell and Iſaac. They were borne vnto hym, of Agar and Sara, who do ſignifie the two Teſtamentes, the olde and the newe.

The old Teſtament is of mount Sinai, begettynge bondage whiche is Agar, for the ſame hill whiche the Iewes call Sinai (whiche ſemeth to haue his appellation of Buſhes, brambles and briars) the Arabians call in their toung Agar. VVhiche thing beſides Paule, Ptolomie doth alſo witnes, and the Greke ſcholies. After the ſame manner there are geuen diuerſe and ſondrie names vnto other hilles alſo, amonges diuerſe nations. So the hill whiche Moſes called Hermon, is called of the Sidonians Sirion, and of the Amorites, Senir.

It doth well agree, that the mount Sinai in the toung of the Arabians hath the ſame name that a handmayd hath, & I think, that the ſimilitude of that name miniſtred vnto Paule an occaſion and lyght to ſeeke out an allegorie. Therfore as Agar the handmayd, brought forth vnto Abraham a ſonne in dede, yet not an heyre but a ſeruaunt. So Sinai the allegorical Agar, brought forth truly vnto God, a ſonne, that is a carnall people. Alſo as Iſmael was the true ſonne of Abraham, ſo the people of Iſraell had God their true father, vnto whom he gaue a law, and deliuered his oracles, religion, the ſeruice of him and his Temple, as it is in the Pſalme.Pſal. 147. Qui annunciat verbum ſuum Iacob. &c. He ſheweth his worde vnto Iacob, and his ſtatutes and iudgementes vnto Iſraell. But this was the difference. Iſmaell was borne of a handmayde after the fleſhe, that is without promiſe, and therfore he could not be heire. So the miſticall
Agar, that is, the mount Sinai, vpon the which, the law and the old teſtament was geuen, begat vnto God a people, but without promiſe, that is a carnall and a ſeruile people, and not the heire of God, bycauſe yt vnto the law there were not added ye promiſes of Chriſt (whiche ſhould bleſſe them) and of their deliueraunce from the curſe of the law, from ſinne, and from death, alſo of the fre giuing of the remiſsion of ſinnes, of Iuſtice and euerlaſting life. But he that doth thē (ſaith the law) ſhall liue in thē

div.head: The Land of lyuing. 14.
div.p: DAuid ſaith in his Pſalmes. I ſhould haue faynted,27. pſalm. except I had beleued to ſee the goodnes of the Lord, in the land of the liuing. Of ye land of ye liuing, diue • s do diuerſly geue iudgement. Euthinius doth ſay in this place, the land of the liuyng to be this preſent world, as a ſeat moſt apt for the liuyng, and the lande of them that be deade, to be the inferior regions.

Furthermore, certayne do ſay, that the earth is neuer founde in the Scriptures to be called heauen, but that heauen and earth be two places much diſtant (as it is written in the Pſalme. Out of heauen did the Lord behold the earth.102. pſalm. The earth therfore (foraſmuch as it muſt be vnderſtand in his owne proper ſignification, except there be a manifeſte Metaphore) muſt be taken in this place the very earth wheron we dwell.

Ezechias fearyng death complayneth ſaying.Eſay. 39. Non videbo dominum deum in terra viuentium, neque aſpiciam hominem vltra qui morior, That is. I ſhall not ſee the Lord God in the lande of the liuing, nor behold man any more whiche do now dye.

In an other Pſalme it is ſayd likewiſe.pſal. 115. Placebo domino in regione viuorum. I will pleaſe the Lord in the lande of the lyuing, that is I will pleaſe him in this preſent life, for if I do not pleaſe him here, how can I pleaſe him in the life to come?

Agayne in an other place. Portio mea domine, in terra viuentium. Pſalm. 142. O Lord thou art my portion in the lande of the liuing. As though he ſhould ſay, in this lyfe I couet and deſire none other inheritaunce beſide thee, whiche art my portion and lot.
Eſay prophecieng of Chriſt ſaith. Abſciſſus eſt de terra viuentium. Cap. 53. He was cut of from the land of the liuing, and ſo is Terra viuentium, taken in many places of the Scripture.

Saint Auſten doth take the lande of the liuyng for heauen, his wordes be theſe. O bona domini, dulcia, immortalia, incomparabilia, in pſa. 27. ſempiterna, incommutabilia, & quando vos videbo bona domini, credo videre ſed non in terra morientium. &c. O the goodes of the Lord, moſt ſwete, immortall, incomparable, eternall vnchaungeable, and when ſhall I ſee you, but not in the lande of the dieng. The Lord ſhall deliuer me from
the lande of the dieng, who voucheſaued for my ſake, to take vpon hym the lande of the dieng, and to dye betwene the handes of the dieng.
Lyranus expoundeth Terram viuentium, to be Vitam beatam.
Rabbi Kimhi doth vnderſtand the land of the liuyng, of the ſtate of the lyfe to come.

Pellicanus expoundeth this verſe: Credo videre bona domini, in terra viuentium, I beleue to ſee the goodnes of the Lord in the lande of the liuing, after this manner. I feele nothing in this preſent life but calamities and miſeries, although I am not without diuine and godly conſolations: but after this life in the lande of the liuing, and in the world of the bleſſed ſoules, I ſhall ſee the goodnes of the Lord, that is, I ſhall haue the fruition of the goodnes of God, without al trouble, and with great pleaſure. Neither of theſe two ſenſes are to be reproued, but the firſt ſemeth to be more nere the truth.

div.head: Choyce of meate. 15.
div.p:
