IN the beginning God created all thinges, and ſo created thē, that as the creation of thē is good, ſo the thinges created, are at this day very good: neither is God contrary vnto him ſelfe, when he forbiddeth vs certain kind of meates, as though any thing in it ſelfe were vncleane. There lieth hid certaine miſteries vnder this doctrine. The lawes whiche were made concerning meat, and apparell, appeare to be of litle eſtimation, for God would haue his authoritie in litle thinges to be reſpected, for the authoritie of the law, dependeth vpon God, and he is the maker of the lawe, and the law it ſelfe is the inuention of God. Theſe lawes reſtrayne and kepe downe the audacitie of man, whiche oftentymes maketh lawes, and repealeth them agayne, and euery day inuenteth new ſtatutes and ordinaunces. VVherfore god wold haue his people to ſhew due and faithful obedience vnto ſuch lawes. As when at the beginning God commaunding Adam,
•• . 11.3. that he ſhould not taſt of the tree, of the knowledge, of good & euil, he required therby faythful obedience of him. The obedience of the faith, whiche was in the Machabies,2. Mac. 6.7. in Eliazarus, & in certain other godly men, reſiſting king Antiochus, euen vnto the ſhedding of their bloud, & moſt cruel death, pleaſed God. But many other abſtaining from the eating of ſwines fleſh, deſerued no praiſe nor commendation therfore. VVhen the word of God pronounceth any thinge to be holye, that thing is holye, and for this onelye cauſe, that he yt doth commaund it, is holy. VVhen God ſaith any thing to be vncleane, it is vncleane, inſomuch, that whoſoeuer eateth any thing, contrary to the word of God, he polluteth and defileth himſelf. You are
now cleane (ſaith Chriſt in his Goſpel) for the wordes which I haue ſpoken vnto you. It is neceſſary therfore that we do beleue the word of god,Iohn. 15. and that the obedience of faith do go before, and after that, whatſoeuer worke or fact commeth of faith (as the fact of Eleazar was, which wold not taſte of ſwines fleſh) cannot but be allowed of god: with whom, whatſoeuer is not of faith, is ſinne. Furthermore, in theſe lawes concerning the abſtinence from certain kinds of beaſts, god had a reſpect and conſideration of the helth of the body of mā: for certain meats which ar not permitted to bee eaten of man, are alſo condemned of the Phiſitions, as ſcarſe wholeſome. VVherof the holy fathers gather this argument: If god haue care of the health of the body, truly he muſt nedes be much more carefull for the health of the ſoule. Furthermore, manye of the Gentiles refrained both from the eating and touching of certain beaſtes. Therfore, that the people of Iſrael (being otherwiſe curious and ſuperſtitious, ſhoulde not herein permit any thing to them ſelues, and attempt things at their own pleaſure) God gaue vnto them certaine miſticall lawes, concerning this point, by the which he both drew them backe from their inuentions, & alſo ſeuered them from the Heatheniſh nations, Moſes ſayde:Deut. 14. Thou art a holy people vnto the Lord thy God, and the Lord thy God hath choſen thee, that thou ſhouldſt be vnto him a peculiar people, among al ye nations, vpon the face of the earth. Alſo in the Actes of the Apoſtles, ther is a viſion ſhewed vnto ſaint Peter, in the which by the vncleane beaſtes, the Gentiles are repreſented. Furthermore, god woulde that we ſhoulde haue reſpect vnto the nature of the beaſts, which he forbiddeth to be eaten. For in our table and meate by extern ſymbolles, he hath deſcribed and ſet forth this heauenly wiſdome, miniſtring at the table it ſelf an occation vnto vs, both to thinke and ſpeake of the true holynes of the mind, leaſt we ſhould be impudent, vnpure, vncleane and filthy. And therfore this clauſe is often repeated. Ego dominus deus veſter ſanctus ſum. I the Lord your God am holy, as though he ſhould ſay. To this point pertain al theſe thinges, that ye ſhould employ and geue your ſelues vnto holines. Therfore he taught in theſe tokens, what the godly ſhould folowe, and what they ſhould auoyde.

Firſt he declareth generall rules of vncleane and cleane beaſtes, then he proſecuteth euery one in their kyndes in a moſt naturall ordre, the place is copiouſly ſet forth in Leuiticus and Deuterono:Leui. 11. Deut. 14 Such beaſtes as are clouen footed and chew the cud, are graunted vnto the vſe of man. VVherin two thinges are ſet before our eyes, in the whiche the office of a good man is comprehended. For if we wilbe pure and cleane beaſts, we muſt both deuide the hoofe and chewe the cudde. The foote is the affection of the mynde, which is not to be folowed. There muſt be a differēce
had in things: and as in a clouen foote there are two partes, the right and the left, ſo a good man choſeth that which is good, and fleeth the contrary. The ruminating or chewing of the cud, is iudgement. for euery thing is not to be admitted, which we ſee & heare, but thoſe things onely, which we with a diligent examination weigh, & conſider, and find them not to be repugnaunt vnto God and his law.

Afterward, ther are adioyned ſundry liuing things in a certain cataloge or number by their kindes, of which it was vnlawfull for the people of God for to eate. Theſe were either foure footed beaſtes of the earth, either beaſtes of the water, or birds of the ayre, or creping things.

Of foure footed beaſtes of the earth, ther are foure namely forbidden: The Camel, which hath a high and long neck, teaching pride and arogā cy, by al meanes to be aduoided. Alſo the Cony or the Mouſe of the mountaine, by the which is ſignified, that ſuch men as are drowned in earthly things, are not allowed of God. The Hare, being a fearful beaſt, doth admoniſh vs to put away al daſtardly cowardnes, as the ſwine all filthines and vncleanes. For the Hog is a figure and token of al impurity, wherof roſe this prouerbe: Sus ad volutabrum. And it is written of Cyrces, that ſhe turned through her enchauntments,2. Pet. 2. Vliſſes companions into ſwine. Al fiſhes of the water were permitted to be eaten, which haue ſcales & fins. If they did lacke either of thē, they wer forbidden, as the Ele, which although it haue ſinnes, yet it hath no ſcales. For as the bodies of the fiſhes are gouerned by their fynnes: ſo it behoueth mā to be gouerned with a ſtedfaſt fayth. The ſcales are hard, and couer the bodye, ſo except we be conſtaunte, and pacient in the worke of the Lorde, he doth worthely abhorre vs.

Of the foules of the ayre, ſuch as are moſt rauening and ſpoyling, are forbidden, and ſuch as feede vncleanly, and deſire filthye meate. Alſo ſuch birds as flye onely in the twy light, and in the night, aduoyding the day light, and ſuch as are ſubtill, vnſtable, and nothing quicke. By the which the contraries, as beneficiency, abſtinence, temperaunce, alſo ſimplicity, clearnes, conſtancy, alacrity, integritie, and cleannes of lyfe are commended vnto vs.

Finally, not a few of the creping beaſtes are noted. For men which ar altogether ouerwhelmed in filthines, diſpleaſe god. I wil not reherſe the names of al the beaſts which wer forbidden, partly bicauſe it had bene a buſy matter, partly, bicauſe the Expoſitours of the Bible do wonderfully vary & alter in the interpreting of them, in ſo much yt I cānot inogh meruel of ye extreme blindnes & frowardnes of ye Iewes, in the earneſt obſeruing of the choiſe of meats, wheras the Rabbines in this place are darke and obſcure, nor can declare certainly, what thoſe beaſtes be, which God hath forbidden them to eate.

But I pray you, may we not cal the proctors and doctours of the Romiſh church, more preciſe, more ſcrupulous, and more ſtrait laced about the choiſe of meates, then euer the Iewes or Rabbines were? They would not ſuffer a poore man to eate an egge on the Friday, or in the Lent, and other their preſcribed daies, vnles he had a pardon from the Pope. Yea, if a man being ſicke and ready to die, had taſted of any kinde of fleſh, with out their diſpenſations & pardons, he ſhould haue bene curſed with bel, booke, and candle, as blacke as a coale down to hel. O bloudy tiranny, O ſeruile bondage, wors then the bondage of the Iewes.

Saint Paul commaundeth: Omne quod in macello venditur, 1. Cor. 10. manducate, nihil interrogantes propter conſcientiam. VVhatſoeuer is ſold in ye ſhambles, eate ye, and aſke no queſtion for conſcience ſake.

Agayne to Timothie he ſayth: Prohibentium abſtinere a cibis quos deus creauit ad percipiendum cum gratiarum actione, ſidelibus et us qui cognouerunt veritatem. Quia omnis creatura dei bona, & nihil reiicien dum, quod cum gratiarum actione percipitur, That is:1. Tim. 4. Forbidding to abſtain from meats, whiche God hath created to be receiued with geuinge thanks, of thē which beleue & know ye truth: for euery creature of god is good, & nothing ought to be refuſed, if it be receiued wt thanks geuing.
Alſo to the Coloſsians: Nemo vos iudicet in cibo aut potu. &c. Coloſ. 2. That is: Let no man condemne you in meate and drinke. &c.

Furthermore, to the Romanes: Qui veſcitur, domino veſcirur, gratias enim agit deo: & qui non veſcitur, domino non veſcitur, Rom. 14. & gratias agir deo. He that eateth, eateth to the Lord, for he geueth God thankes: and he that eateth not, eateth not vnto the Lord, and geueth god thanks. And in many other places of the ſcripture, as in Marke: Nihil eſt extra hominem introiens in eum, quod poſſit eū coinquinare. Cap. 7. Ther is nothing without man, yt can defile him, when it entreth into him, but the thinges which procede out of him, are they which defile the man.

Saint Auſten in his booke De eccleſiaſticis dogmatibus, writeth, quod cibos qvoque credere malos, vel maliciae accuſare percipientes, Lib. 1.66. non eſt Chriſtianorum, ſed potius Herachitarum & Manichaeorum. That is: to beleue meates to be ill, or to accuſe them of ſinne that do receiue them, is not the part of Chriſtian men but of thoſe heretiks which are called Herarchitae and Manichaei.

Again, writing Ad Ianuariūm, he ſaith:Epiſt. 119. Quod ſcripſiſti quoſdam fratres ita temperare a carnibus comedendis, vt immundos qui comederint arbittentur, apertiſſime contra fidem ſanamque doctrinam eſt. That is, wher as you haue written, certain brethren ſo to abſtain from fleſh, that they iudge them vncleane, which haue eaten fleſhe, is moſt manifeſte againſt the faith and ſound doctrine.

In the counſell named Concilium Martini Papae, it is written after
this maner: Si quis etiam non pro abſtinentia, ſed pro execratione eſcarū a carne abſtinet, placuit ſancto concilio, vt praeguſtet, & ſi ſic vult abſtine re, abſtineat. Si autem ſpernit ita, vt olera cocta cum carnibus non deguſtet, iſte non obediens nec ſuſpitionem haete ſis a ſe remouens, deponatur de ordine clericatus. If any, not for abſtinence, but for the execration & abhorring of meates, do abſtain from fleſh, it hath pleaſed the holy coū ſel, that he ſhal at the leaſt taſte of it, and then if he will abſtain, let him abſtaine, but if he ſo contemne, that he wil not taſte herbes ſodden wyth fleſh, then let him (not obeing nor remouing ſuſpition of hereſy frō him) be depoſed from the order of his clergy.

Conſider I pray you, how ſaint Auſten in his boke De moribus eccleſiae, painteth out, and moſt manifeſtlye deſcribeth the faſt of the Manichies, to be ſuch a faſt as is now adaies the faſt of our Papiſts (that is to ſay) gluttony, & not a meanes to tame the fleſh, as they do pretend. And that the ſober diet of the chriſtian mā, eating ſparely of fleſh, is the right kinde of faſting. Thus ſaint Auſten reaſoneth: if there be a man (as it is poſsible) ſo ſpare of diet, & profitable withal, that he wil eate but twiſe in one day, ruling and tempering with that abſtinence, the appetite of his throte and belly. And be it alſo (ſaith he) that ther be ſet at ſupper before this man, a few herbes, & a litle bacon ſodden with the ſame herbs, ſo much in quantity, as may ſuffice to put away his hunger, & that the ſame man quench his thirſt with three or foure draughtes of pure wine, that is vnmingled with water, and that this be his dayly diet. And againe on the other ſide: if ther be one yt taſteth no fleſh, nor drinketh no wine, but ſtraunge kindes of diſhes, made of ſedes and fruites, with aboundāce of pepper caſt vpon it, wherof he eateth plentifully at nine of the clock in the morning, and againe at night at ſupper. And alſo that the ſame man drinke of the water, wherwith the huſkes of grapes be waſhed, after the preſsing, and of Sider and ſuche other licours, which though they bee no wine, yet they ſerue in ſteede of wine, yea & paſſe it alſo in ſwetenes. And be it that this man drink, not onely ſo much as he thurſteth, but ſo much as him luſteth, and that he hath a dayly prouiſion for this diet, and hath plenty of theſe delicates, wherwith to ſerue not only his neceſsities, but al ſo his luſt: whether of theſe twayn iudge you, as touching meat & drink, do liue in more abſtinence? I thinke (ſaith ſaint Auſten) ye be not ſo blind but that ye wil prefer the mā which liueth with the litle baken & wine, to the other glotton, for the truth it ſelf driueth you to this anſwer. But you heretickes be of the contrary opinion (ſaith he) for by your opinion if this ſecond man ſhould ſup with the firſte but one night, & ſhoulde but touch his lips, and ſmell of his baken, though it were reſty, ye would ſtraight way condemne him to hell fire, as a breker of your ſeale (that is)
of your religion. Thus farre ſaint Auſten.

p.hi: Spiridion qualis circa peregrinorum ſuſceptiones faerit, huic apparet. Inſtante iam quadrageſima, quidam ex itinere venitad eum,
p.note: Hiſto. Tripa • Lib. 1. cap. So zomenus.
p.hi: quiuis diebus ſine cibo conſiſtens. Videns itaque peregrinum valde defectum, perge (inquit filiae ſuae) laua peregrini pedes, & cibos appone. Cunque virgo dixiſſet nec panem eſſe, nec 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , hoc eſt farinas (quarum rerum ſolebat nihil habere conditum propter ieiunium) orans primum, veniamque petens, filiae iuſſit vt porcinas carnes quas domi ſalitas habebat, coqueret. Quibus coctis, ſedens cum peregrino, poſitis carnibus comedebat, & rogabat, vt vna cum eo ederet peregrinus. Quo recuſante,
chriſtianumque ſe profitēte. Propterea (inquit) recuſare non debes. Omnia enim mūda mū dis, ſicut ſermo diuinus edocuit.

div.p: VVhat manner of man, Spiridion, was about the entertaynement of ſtraungers, it appereth by this that followeth: In the beginning of Lent, a certaine mā iourneing, came vnto him, who was without meate .v. daies. Spiridion ſeing the ſtraunger very weake, ſaid to his daughter, go and waſh the ſtraungers feete, and ſet meate before him. And when the virgin had ſaid that ther was neither bread, nor meate in the houſe (of the which he was wont then to haue no ſtore, by reaſon of the faſt) Spiridion firſt praying and aſking pardon, commaunded his daughter to ſeeth pork, which he had in his houſe ſalted, which being ſod, he ſitting with the ſtraunger, did eat of the fleſh ſet before him, and requeſted, that the ſtraunger would eate with him. VVho refuſing, and profeſsing himſelf to be a chriſtian, therfore (ſaith Spiridion thou oguht not to refuſe, for to ye cleane al things are cleane, as the woord of God hath taught.

I do not bring in this doctrine to that end, that I would ſet althinges on cocke and hoope (as they ſay) or that I do meane, that the euangelical liberty, ſhould be turned into carnal liberty, or that men might eate at al times all maner of meates, without obſeruation of the lawes of Princes, made for a common wealth: but I ſpeake it for this end, that we ſhould not put anye religion or righteouſnes, or anye vnholynes in the meates them ſelues, for they be neither of, nor on, as ſaint Paule writeth to the Corinthians, ſaying: Atqui eſca nos non commendat deo, and meate doth not commend vs vnto God.

div.head: Cautio.
div.p: If the church, or the magiſtrat do make any lawes, certain condiciōs, and circumſtaunces are to be obſerued.
Firſt, that their decrees be not repugnaunt with the woord of God.
Secondly, that the true ſeruice of God, iuſtification, and remiſsion of ſinnes, be not put in them.
Thirdly, they are not to be counted ſo neceſſary & inuiolable, but that they may be chaunged, whē the ſtate of the faithful ſhall ſo require.

Fourthly, they ought not to be made in ſuch ſorte, that if any mā ſhal
not without offence, or contempt obſerue them) he ſhalbe thought to offend deadly. Therfore, ſince theſe lawes of the choyce of meates are repugnaunt vnto the word of God, by the which word al meates are made lawful, they appeare to be pernitious and hurtfull. Furthermore, our aduerſaries in this their decree of the choiſe of meates, doo accompt a certayne holines, and ſeruice of God to conſiſt, in ſo much, that they eſteme them, which do not abſtain from ſuche meates, which they haue preſcribed, to be leſſe holy, leſſe good, and leſſe religious. Afterward theſe their ordinaunces ſo encreaſed, and multiplied out of meaſure, that neither almoſt ther was any end of them. Saint Auſten complained that in his time all thinges were full of ſuperſtitions, ſo that the condition, and ſtate of the Chriſtians was wors, then the ſeruitude of the Iewes. Vvhich thing, foraſmuch as, he ſpake of his time, what, I pray you woulde he ſay nowe of our time, the church being oppreſſed with ſuch infinite burdens. Firſt of all they ordeined, and inſtituted the Lent, after they added the Friday and the Saterday, and in ſome countries the wedneſday in euery weke. They brought in the imbering daies, foure times in the yeare, alſo the vigils of many ſaintes, in the which not to faſt, Gregory the ſeuenth, made it mortall ſinne. Since that, therfore theſe traditions are ſo greuous vnto the church, that they may be called in tollerable burdens, which Chriſt did reprehend, to be layd vpon mens backes of the Scribes & Phariſies, thei ought not to be tollerated, and ſuffered. Finally, they would haue theſe traditions to be ſo neceſſary and inuiolable, that the church could not cō ſiſt without them. And they eſteme ſo much their own inuentions, that they puniſh the tranſgreſsours of them more greuouſly, then the breakers of Gods commaundementes, as theeues and adulterers Churche robbers. &c.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: They alledge the Rechabites for an example, who are prayſed in Ieremy, becauſe they obeyed their father, which commaunded them that they ſhould drinke no wine, neither ſhould haue any certain poſſeſsions, but ſhould be wanderers, and ſhould dwel in no city. Vnto whom God, bicauſe they performed theſe thinges, promiſed a long life and poſteritie. Here they ſay, that they do as Ionadab the ſonne of Rechab commaunded his ſonnes concerning the choyſe of meates. Vvherfore, the church appereth not to haue erred, in cōmaunding ſuch things. And as god commended the obedience of the Rechabites, ſo alſo he will allow the doings of the Chriſtians, if they obey ſuch decrees of the church.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p:
I anſwer: It was commaunded in the the old law, not to drinke wyne, & it did not diſpleaſe God, yea rather in ſome perſons it is cōmēded, as it
is manifeſt of the vow of the Nazarits, which vow, Samſō & Ihon Baptiſt receiued, from their mothers wombe. For at that time, ſuch an intēt pertained vnto a certain holy ceremony. Alſo, their father cōmaunded thē that they ſhould liue a wandring life, bicauſe perchaunce he appointed them not to huſbandry and tillage of the groūd, but to be ſhepherds, vnto whom it was moſt conuenient to wander through the woods and hyls. Or els, bicauſe they wer not of the children of Iſrael, therfore they could not haue any poſſeſsion of them in their land, & yet he would not haue them to depart into other countries, bicauſe he worſhipped the true god of Iſrael. For this Rechab was of the poſterity of Iethro, as it appeareth in Paralipome. If thou wilt contend that they wer Ethnickes,Lib. 1. Cap. 2. and therfore that they dwelt among ſtraungers, I anſwer, that their father wold not withſtāding, that as they differed from thē, among whō they dwelt, in religion, ſo alſo they ſhould be known from them, by outward tokens & ſignes, as to abſtain from wines, and to haue no certain dwelling places. Furthermore, God praiſed their duty done vnto their father, whom they wer bound in moral life, and in maners to obey, for he cōmaunded theſe things vnto them, as ciuil, proper, & peculiar badges of his family, and not vnder the title of religion. For when they wer bidden of Ieremy to drinke wine, they did not pretēd a holines or a ſeruice of god, that they would not conſent vnto him: they declared onely what their father had cō maūded. Vvhich obedience pleaſed God, & ſhould haue pleaſed him, if it had ben exhibited in any other domeſtical or ciuil actions. But the Pope & his prelats do not cōmaund choice of meate, but vnder the title of holines & diuine honoring of God, which may not be ſuffred, ſince it is ye office of god, & not of man, to make decrees of religion. If that the Magiſtrate or officer ſhould commaund vs not to eate or drinke this thing, or that thing, for the common wealthes ſake it ought to be obeied. But as concerning diuine honour, or Gods ſeruice, it is to be ſayd, that the eaſye yoke of the Lord is not to be encombred & agrauated with mans traditions.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: They obiect alwaies this ſaying: Qui vos audit, me audit, Math, 10. qui vos ſpernit, me ſpernit, that is: He that heareth you, heareth me, and he that deſpiſeth you, deſpiſeth me.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: I graunt that the paſtors ar alwaies to be herd, ſo long as they teach vs Chriſt and his doctrin. It wer an vniuſt matter, if that they ſhould think that when they commaund their own traditions, they ſhoulde be as well heard as Chriſt. In the old law God would not haue anye thing added or diminiſhed from his lawes. VVith what face then, durſt they to attempt any ſuch thing in the new Teſtament? Is the doctrine of the new Teſtament more imperfect, then the old law was?

Chriſt rebuked the Scribes, bicauſe they added their own traditiōs, who notwithſtanding ſaid vnto the people, that they ſhoulde heare them, bicauſe they ſat in the chaires of Moſes: but they ſit in that chair, whē they teach ſuch things as were written of Moſes, but when they will appoint their own decrees, their authority is worthely diminiſhed. The ſame may be ſaid of our biſhops & paſtours. They rede frugality & ſobriety to be commended in the ſcriptures of Chriſt, and of the holy ghoſt, let them exhort the people vnto that, as earneſtly as they can.

1. Pet. 5. Rom. 13Saint Peter writeth, Fratres ſobrii, eſtote, vigilate in orationibus. &c Brethren, be ye ſober and watch in praier. And likewiſe Paul: Nō in cō meſſationibus et in ebrietatibus. &c. That is: Not in banketting & drō kennes, neither in chambering & wantōnes &c. Alſo Chriſt ſaith: Vide te ne grauentur corda veſtra crapula, Luk. 21 & ebrietate. Se that your minds be not oppreſſed with ſurfet, and dronkēnes. Let them alſo cōmend and ſet forth, faſting and abſtinence as profitable things, which are prayſed in the holy ſcripture, but of the times, maner, & choice of meates, let them leaue to ſpeake of, except by the choice they vnderſtand frugall meat, & ſuch as is eaſy to be gotten, & not ſumptuous & delicate. Theſe thinges are continually to be beaten into the heades of the people, that modeſty, and temperancy may be embraced in the flock of chriſt. But to make eccleſiaſtical lawes concerning theſe things, by the which the conſcience is entangled, it is not good nor requiſite. Saint Auſten ſaith, yt the Apoſtles cōmaunded men to faſt, but as cōcerning the daies of faſting, they ſpake nothing. But ſaint Hierom ſaith, yt the feſtiual daies, & daies of faſting wer apointed of wiſe mē, for their cauſe, which do not almoſt at any time faſt, & do not alwaies come vnto the church. Vvherfore the lawes both concerning daies, & the choice of meats, are to be counted as the tradicions of men, & not the cōmaundements of god. And we rede, that the faſt of the ſaterday had his beginning, of this, bicauſe, Peter a little before he ſhould diſpute with Simon Magus on the ſonday, cōmaunded a faſt vpon the ſaterday, wherfore vpon a ſuperſtitious zeal of this fact, they did alwaies faſt that day, which thing was not vſed of the churches of Africa, and of the oriental parts. But when ſuch thinges are inſtituted and decreed of the choice of meates, what is to be done of ye faithful? Firſt, that they which vſe the liberty graunted of Chriſt and of the church, be well perſwaded in their conſciëce, which Paul moniſheth ſpeaking to the Romanes: Quiſque in ſenſu ſuo abundet, let euery man be perſwaded in his minde,Rom. 14 bicauſe nothing is to be attempted againſt the conſcience. Let him alſo geue thāks vnto god, of whō he receiueth this liberty through chriſt as in the ſame Epiſtle the apoſtle cōmaundeth him that doth eate, not to be iudged of the weaker, bicauſe he eateth wt geuing of thanks. Farthermore,
that which he doth, let him do it vnto the glory of God, neither let him ſeeke his own delight, or couet to ſatiſfy his own luſts. For the ſame apoſtle ſaith: Siue manducatis, ſiue bibitis, omnia in dei gloriam facite. VVhether ye eate or drinke, let al things be done to the glory of God.1. Cor. 10. Let him beware alſo, leaſt he offend his weake brethren. Let him teach them and inſtruct them with lenity and gentlenes, but not ſo, that he nouriſhe their infirmity. For ſome are to be ſuffred for a time, but not continually, except they wil alwaies be lerners, & neuer come vnto knowledge. Neither doth this ſaying of thapoſtle make againſt vs: Si eſca offendir fratrē meum, inaeternum carnes non manducabo. 1. Cor. 8. Rather then I ſhould offende my brother, I wil neuer eate fleſh. He doth ſhew with theſe words, how he was minded, & doth put a cauſe, ſaying: leaſt I ſhould offend my brother. But he that is already taught, and is not offended, but of a certayne ſtubbournes, we ought not to beare with him, leaſt long diſsimulation tend to the detriment of the whole church.

div.head: Queſtio.
div.p: From whence came this ſuperſtition, to abſtain from fleſh, and wher had it firſt his original?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: It is to be thought, that it came firſt from the Heathen, bicauſe the prieſts of the Egyptians did abſtain from fleſh. So did Apollonius, Thianeus, & Pythagoras alſo, and this they did, bicauſe by this means they thought to make their ſenſes more pure, and to wipe away al groſnes & darknes out of their mind, wherof they hoped for certaine reuelacions by their own induſtry and labour, but theſe be the gifts of the holy ghoſt, which doth diſtribute them at his pleaſure.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: How ſay you then to Daniel and his felowes, who did abſtaine frō the meates of the kinges table, from fleſh and from wyne?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: They did abſtain for none other cauſe, but that they would not be polluted with meates forbidden in the law, which ſhoulde haue bene eaſilye brought to paſſe, if they had ſitten at the kings table. The wine alſo dyd moue thē ſome ſcruple, leaſt it were not preſt out of that vine, which was not yet foure yeres old, wherof to taſte the law did forbid.

div.head: Lynſey wolſey. 16.
div.p: IT is cōmaunded in Deuteronomy, thou ſhalt not weare a garmēt of diuers ſortes, as of wollen and linnen together.Cap. 22.

Ioſephus doth expound, that this was forbidden for the dignitie of the prieſthood of Aaron, bicauſe there was ſuch a mixt weauing in the garmēt of the high Prieſt. And therfore it was not lawful for other to weare the like kinde of garment.

Other doctors doo ſay, that it was forbidden to auoid the maner of idolaters, which worſhipped the conſtellations of heauen, who did weare ſuch kinde of clothes, and other mingled matters, to ſignify the coniunction of the planets, in the ſolemnity of their ſacrifices.

other do make a moral of this ſaying, that by wool is ſignified ſimplicity, by linnen is ſignified ſuttlety, and the cloth which is made of linſey woolſey doth couer the linnen in the inſide, and doth ſhewe the wooll in the outſide.
He weareth a garment of linnen & wollen, which, vnder the innocēt pretence of faire words, doth couer the ſuttlety of miſchief and craft.

div.head: Sabbatum. 17.
div.p: SChauath, agreeth in ſignification with theſe verbs, Iaſchau, & Schou, Schauah, but yt as they vary in forme, ſo alſo they differ in maner of ſignification. For as ſchou, betokneth returning to a place, ſchauah, a leding away, or mouing from a place, & Iaſchau, remaining in a place, ſo ſchauath betokeneth a ceaſing or reſt from mouing & labour. Therfore ye may tranſlate it with the verbe of ceaſing or reſting Geneſis. 1. Et benedixit deus diem ſeptimum, et ſanctificauit eum, quia in eo ceſſauit ab omni opere ſuo, quod creauit deus, vt faceret, That is: And God bleſſed the ſeuenth day, and halowed it, bicauſe in it he ceaſed from all his worke, which he ordayned to doo. And again: Et ceſſauit die ſeptimo ab omni opificio ſuo. That is: and God ceaſed from all hys worke the ſeuenth day.
Exod. 20Of this verb commeth this nowne Schabbath, which betokeneth quiet or reſt, as in Exodus: Quia ſabbatum eſt ipſi Iehouah.

Sabbatum, therfore doth ſignify a reſt, and vacation from al ſeruile labour. And it is to be obſerued, that the Lord ſaith not, kepe holy the Saboth, but remember that thou keepe holy the Saboth. It doth ſignify that the inſtitution of the Saboth day was moſt auncient, and of moſt antiquitie, being deliuered vnto the fathers a long time before, and now repeated and receiued by the Lord, among the people of Iſrael. But the ſumme of the whole cōmaundement, is this, kepe holy the ſaboth day. The ſame he expoūdeth more at large, nūbring the daies thē ſelues, rehearſing alſo the whole family, vnto whō it was enioyned to kepe the ſaboth. Laſt of al is added the example of God him ſelf, reſting and ſanctifieng the ſaboth.

This word Sabbatum, is of a large ſignification. For firſt, ye ſcripture maketh mēcion of a certain ſpiritual & perpetuall ſaboth, in yt we ceaſe from our ſeruile labour, abſtaining frō ſinne, endeuouring, yt we do not folow our own wil, & yt we do not employ our labor vpon our own works but ceaſing frō thē, yt we ſuffer god to work in vs, & yt our bodies be ſubiect vnto • gouernmēt of the ſpirit.Eſay 58. et 66 Hebr. 4. After this ſaboth doth folow ye ſpiritu al ſaboth, or ye eternal reſt, of ye which Eſaias & Paul to ye hebrues intreateth.
But then we do truly worſhip God, when reſting from euil, and obeying the holy ghoſt, we are exerciſed in good workes. It is not requiſite to entreate at large of the allegory of the ſpiritual Saboth. Let vs endeuour rather, while we are in theſe mortal bodies, to ſanctifye a pleaſaunt and acceptable Saboth vnto God, wyth a continual and wylling deſire, and loue of godlynes.

Furthermore, the Saboth is an externe and outward ordinance of religion, for God would deliuer vnto vs in this precept, an outward religion and worſhipping of God, in the which we ſhould all be exerciſed. But ther muſt nedes be a time to worſhip God. He therfore hath appointed a time, in the which we ſhould abſtaine from all corporall labours, and ſhould be occupied in the workes of the ſpirite. For therfore is the outward reſt commaunded, that the ſpiritual operation might not be let & hindered by the corporal actions. This operation of the ſpirite with the fathers, was occupied about foure things, that is, in reading, interpreting and hearing of the ſcriptures, in priuate and publike prayer, in celebration of ſacramentes and ſacrifices, and in collecting and diſtributing to the poore. In theſe pointes conſiſted the outward keping of the Saboth: for the people (al buſines laid apart, and being at reſt) gathered them ſelues together into the ſinagoge, wher the prophets did read, and interprete the word of God, and did inſtruct the auditory in true godlynes. After this, the faythfull prayed together with one accord and common aſſent, for all their neceſsities. They praiſed the name of god, and thanked him for all his benefites. Furthermore, they offered ſacrifice according vnto the word of god, celebrating the miſteries and ſacraments of god, and ſo exerciſed their fayth.

And they were admoniſhed of their office and dutye, and that they ſhould offer them ſelues a liuely ſacrifice vnto god. Finally, they laied together their gifts liberally vnto the vſe of the church. Theſe gifts were emploied partly vpō the neceſsary vſes of the church, vpō the miniſters, and to the reliefe of the poore. Theſe truly were the holy workes of God, which as long as they vſed, being inſtructed in faith and charity, thei did ſanctify the Saboth, and the name of the Lord, that is, they perfourmed thoſe workes in the Saboth, which doo both ſanctifye the name of God, and alſo adourne the doers of them, & they are verily the workes, which are holy and acceptable vnto God. If thou require a manifeſt and worthy example, and paterne of the Saboth or feaſt truly ſancttified, thou ſhalt finde it in Nehemias,Cap. 8. for ther the prieſtes expounde and interprete the word of God, they praiſe his name, they pray with the people, they offer ſacrifice, they are liberal in their gifts, and finally behaue them ſelues holy and religious in al pointes

But ſome man wil obiect and ſay: idlenes bringeth vice, & men muſt labour with their handes, that they may haue to relieue them ſelues and their family, leaſt they ſhould periſh through famine. To this, it maye be anſwered, that ther is other time ſufficient permitted of God, wherein thou maiſt labour, and wherin euery man may prouide ſuſtentation ſufficient for his family. For it is lawfull to labour ſixe daies, but the ſeuenth day God requireth to be conſecrated vnto him ſelfe. Euery weeke is complete, and ended in ſeuen daies, & of theſe ſeuen daies, God chalēgeth but one onely vnto him ſelfe. VVho can worthely complaine, that ther is iniury done vnto him? Ther is more time appointed for thy labours, then for holy reſt. And it is God who doth require this reſte, the creator of man, his father and Lord.

Furthermore, the Lord commaundeth this holye reſt, this diſcipline, and worſhipping of him, to be obſerued of al thy family. VVherof we gather, that ye office of a good gouernour of a houſe, is to ſee, that his whole family do ſanctify the ſaboth, that is, that they do theſe good workes in ye Saboth, which before were reherſed. And for bicauſe God knoweth the nature of man, who, when he is promoted vnto gouernment, for the moſt part is inſolent and proud, therfore, leſt that fathers and maiſters ſhould vſe their family ouer ſtraightly and rigorouſly, or ſhould be an impediment vnto them in keping the Saboth, he commaundeth in plain words and diligent reherſal, that they ſhould graunt vnto their familye, and to euery one of their houſhold, a holy reſt and quietnes, wherein he maketh no exception of the ſtraunger. He wil not haue them to folow the rule of certaine ſlothful perſonnes, whiche ſay, that faith and religion ought to be free, and that no man ought to be compelled vnto religion. For God cō maundeth thee to force vnto religion, the ſtraunger that is within thy gates, that is, being in thy iuriſdiction and gouernment. This reſt is not commaunded for it ſelf. for reſt, and idlenes are wont alwaies to be blamed: but is commaunded for theſe cauſes following. God will haue a time and place reſerued for religion. Theſe muſt nedes be hindred by external labours. He is not in the fellowſhip of the holy congregation, he doth not heare Gods word, he praieth not with the church, he is not preſent at the celebration of the ſacraments, who, at the commaundemēt of his maiſter, either taketh a iourney, or ſelleth thinges for his maiſter in the market, or clenſeth the corne in the barne, & doth exerciſe ruſtical labour in the field, or woorketh at home at the ſtithe, or mendeth his hoſen or ſhooes. Therfore faith and godlines biddeth thee to ſuffer thy ſeruaunts to be at leaſure and vacation, yea and it commaūdeth thee to prouoke & enforce ſuch as are otherwiſe ſluggiſh, to be godly occupied. Alſo God wold haue yt ſuch as haue laboured, ſhould ſomtimes ceaſe, & take their reſt, according
vnto this verſe of Ouid. Quod caret alterna requie, durabile nō eſt.

q.l: That whiche of reſt ſometymes is not ſure,
Cannot continewe long tyme, nor endure.

div.p: Therfore the mercifull Lord, who hath alwayes a reſpecte vnto the obſeruation of his creatures, doth appoynte a meane and meaſure, and prouideth, that the couetouſnes and rigorouſnes of their maiſters do not to much afflicte the creature of God. In Deuteronomie,Deut. 5. Moſes addeth the affection of Gods mercifulnes, ſaying: Remember, that thou alſo waſt a bondeman in Egipte. Charitie therfore and humanitie require a meaſure, that we do not greue and vexe our ſeruauntes with to much labour.

Farthermore, fathers and maiſters in plantyng of godlineſse, in their houſholdes, do not a litle promote their owne vtilitie and profite: for wicked ſeruauntes are commenly theuiſhe and vntruſty, but the godly ſeruauntes are faithfull and diligent. There is alſo mention made of the beaſtes and cattell, not onely bycauſe man is Lord and maiſter of the beaſts, but bicauſe without the miniſterie and ſeruice of man, the beaſts cannot be exerciſed. Therfore we are plucked away from the religion of the Sabbaoth, through our beaſtes, from the which, leaſt we ſhould be let and troubled, it is commaunded, that we ſhould permit our cattell to take their reſt.

Laſt of all God bringeth an example, by the whiche he teacheth vs to keepe holy the Sabbaoth. Becauſe (ſayth he) in ſixe dayes the Lord made heauen, and earth, the ſea, and all that in them is, but the ſeuenth day he reſted, therfore God bleſſed the ſeuenth daye, and hallowed it. God laboured ſeuen dayes in creatyng the heauen, the earth, the ſea, and all that is therin, but in the ſeuenth day he reſted, conſecrating a certain appoynted day to reſt in. In the ſeuenth day, we muſt conſider the works, which God did the ſixe dayes before. The children of God muſt call to remembraunce, what, and how great benefites they haue receyued the whole weeke before. Then God is to be thancked, prayſed, and to be learned in his worckes. VVe muſt conſecrate vnto hym our whole body and ſoule, and we muſt conſecrate vnto hym all our ſayinges, and doynges. The Lord reſted from creating, but he reſted not from preſeruing, and gouernyng ſuch thinges as he had created. VVe muſt reſt therfore from handie and bodilie worckes, but we muſt not ceaſſe from ſuch worckes as pertayne vnto the worſhipping of God. VVherfore, the diuine reſt hurted not the thinges created, and reſtyng, and ſeruing of God in the Sabbaoth day, wilbe no hynderaunce vnto our worldly buſineſse, and affaires: for God bleſſed the Sabbaoth, he will therfore bleſſe thee and thy houſe, thy doynges and all thy poſſeſsions, if thou be carefull to kepe holy the Sabbaoth of the Lorde, that is, if thou do thoſe worckes whiche he commaunded to be done vpon the Sabbaoth. They do erre
therfore and are much deceyued, whiche deſpiſe the religion and the holy reſt of the Saboth, and call it an vnprofitable idlenes, and do labour in the Saboth day like as they do in other prophane dayes, pretendyng the care and neceſsitie of their familie.

All theſe thinges muſt be applyed alſo vnto vs Chriſtians, and to our Churches. It is moſt certaine, that the ſpirituall Saboth is before all other thinges commaunded vnto Chriſtians. Neither is it to be doubted, but that god wil hau a iuſt ordre to be obſerued in our churches as wel as afore tyme in the Churches of the Iewes, and eſpecially an exerciſing of externall Religion, we knowe that the Sabboth is ceremoniall, in that, it is ioyned wyth Sacryfices and other Iudaicall ceremonies, and in that, it is tyed vnto a certayne tyme: but in that Relygion and godlines, is furthered in the Saboth daye, and a iuſte order is retayned in the Churche, and charitie keept with our neighbour: It is morall and not ceremoniall: we muſt in this tyme alſo ſpare our familie, and we muſt in theſe dayes inſtruct our houſhold in Religion. God did no where diſsipate or put a ſonder the holy congregations, but he chiefly gathered them together. As there ought to be a certayne place, ſo there ought to be a certayne and a preſcribed tyme, conſecrated vnto the exerciſe of religion, and therfore there muſt be a holy rest alſo. Therfore the primatiue Churche chaunged the day of the Saboth, least they ſhould ſeeme to be like the Iewes, and to ſticke vnto ceremonies, and celebrated the holy reſt the next day after the Saboth day,Apoc. 1. whiche Saint Iohn calleth Dominica, yt is, the ſonday, or the day of the Lord, becauſe God in that day gloriouſly roſe agayne from the dead. And although the ſonday is commaunded in no place of the new Teſtament, yet becauſe in the fourth precepte of the firſt Table, the care of Religion and the exerciſe of the externe worſhippyng of God is earneſtly required, it were contrary to godlines and Christian charitie, not to ſanctifie the ſonday, eſpeciallie ſince this externe worſhipping cannot conſiſte without an appoynted tyme of holy rest. The ſame is to be thought of certayne other feastes and holy dayes dedicated vnto our Lord Christ, in the whiche we celebrate the memoriall of his natiuitie, incarnation, circumciſion, paſsion, reſurrection, his aſſention into heauen, and the ſendyng downe of the holy Ghost vpon his Diſciples. For this is not the Christian libertie to breake and violate Eccleſiasticall and godly obſeruations, whiche helpe and ſet foorth both the glory of God and the charitie of our neighbour. But becauſe the Lord will haue holy dayes onely vnto hymſelfe, ſuch feſtiuall dayes as are dedicated vnto creatures, are not to be allowed This glory and ſeruice onely appertayneth vnto God.Col. 2. Saint Paule ſayth, I will not that any man ſhould iudge you in the parte of any festiuall day or Saboth,
whiche are but the ſhadowes of thinges to come. And in an other place he ſayth. Ye obſerue dayes and monethes, tymes, and yeares. I feare leaſt I haue bestowed my labour vpon you in vayne. And therfore we haue nothyng to do at this tyme with the obſeruation of the Iewes, in the Churche of Chriſt Let vs keepe onely the Christian obſeruation, and the exerciſe of Christian Religion.

div.head: ¶ The ſanctifieng of the Saboth of the Chriſtians.
div.p: The ſanctifieng and exerciſe of our Sonday, doth conſiſte alſo in foure thinges, whiche must be founde in the holy congregation of the Christians, if it be holy in dede.

First, all holy men ought to enter into the Church, where the Goſpell muſt be expounded and declared, by the which the auditory may learne what to thincke of God, what is the true ſeruice of god, & how ye name of God may be glorified. Next there muſt be petitions and prayers made in the congregation for the neceſsities of all men. VVe muſt extolle the goodnes of God geuing thanckes for his dayly and ineſtimable benefites. And (if the tyme, occaſion and cuſtome of the Churche do ſo require) the Sacramentes muſt religiouſly be celebrated: for it is chiefly required in this fourth precept, that we ſhould diligently obſerue and deuoutly exerciſe the holy Sacraments, and rites of the Churche, beyng lawfull, profitable, and neceſſarie.

Finally, humanitie, and beneficence muſt take place in the congregation, al men muſt learn dayly to be beneficial in geuing of almes priuately, but to be moſt liberall publiquely, whenſoeuer the neceſsitie of the tyme, and oportunitie ſhall ſo require.
By theſe offices and duties, the Saboth is alſo ſanctified in the Chriſtian Churche, especially, if there be added vnto this a continuall endeuour of an vpright and innocent life.

This diſcipline and order is aſwell to be vſed in euery houſholde of the fathers and maiſtres among the Chriſtians, as among the Iewes. Of the whiche matter it is not nedefull to make many wordes, where as I haue ſo intreated of this place a litle before, that it is agreable in all pointes vnto our Chriſtian Churche. This onely will I adde at this preſent, that it is the office of a chriſtian Magiſtrate, or at the leaſt wiſe of a good father, to bring and keepe in order all ſuch as do violate and contemne the Sabboth of the Lord, and his diuine ſeruice. The chief of the Iewes and the people of God by the commaundement of God, ſtoned to death one that contemptuouſly gathered ſtickes on the Sabboth daye.Num. 15. VVhy therfore is it not lawfull for a chriſtian Magiſtrate, to puniſh in body, goods, or lyfe the deſpiſers of Religion, and the true and lawfull ſeruice of the Sabboth? If that in this corrupt and wicked tyme the negligent
Magiſtrate do not his dutie, yet euery father and maſter muſt endeuour, that his familie be not wicked, let hym puniſhe his owne ſeruauntes by ſuch lawfull meanes and wayes as is permitted vnto him: for it is lawfull for euery houſeholder, although he dwell among Idolaters to gather a holy congregation in his owne houſe, (as we read that Loth did in Sodome, and Abraham, Iſaac and Iacob, in the land of Canaan, and in Egypt.) And it is a great offence and a detestable ſciſme, if when lawfull companies and conuenticles be aſſembled together in townes & villages, a Chriſtian man ſhould deſpiſe the Churche of Chriſt and the congregation of Saintes, as the Anabaptiſtes do.

div.head: The abuſe of the Sabboth.
div.p: Here is requiſite, that we recite the abuſes and offences committed agaynſte this commaundement. They offende agaynſte this precepte, whiche ceaſse not from euell worckes, yea rather abuſe this holy reſt, vnto the entiſement and pleaſures of the fleſhe: for ſuch keepe not the Sabboth of God, but they ſerue the deuill in playeng at dice, in eatyng and drynkyng, in daunſing, and followyng other vanities of the world, by the whiche worcks, we are not onely ledde awaye from the holy congregation but pollute and defile our owne bodies, whiche we ought to ſanctifie. They offende alſo whiche exerciſe handye worckes in the Sabboth, or wrapped and couchyng in their beddes, ſleepe much parte of the day, neglectyng the congregation of God. They offende, whiche burdenyng their ſeruauntes with labour, let them from the ſeruyng of God, preferryng other corruptible and filthy thynges before the honouryng of God. But they offende moſt of all, whiche do not onely not ſanctifie the Sabboth, but are an occaſion alſo vnto others by their impure tauntes and euill example of prophanyng the holy day, whiche diſprayſe and diſdayne the holye rites, the miniſtery, the Miniſters, the ſchooles, & al godly exerciſes. And all gouernours of houſeholdes offende greatly agaynſte this precepte, if they do not their diligence to vſe, and to retayne the ſanctifieng of the Sabboth in their houſes: VVho ſoeuer deſpiſe the Religion of the Sabboth, do geue an euident teſtimonie in them ſelues of impietie and contempte of God. Therefore, the obſeruation and contempte of the Sabboth, hath greate promiſes and threatninges in the Scripture.

For the declaration of the whiche thyng, I will recite the wordes of Ieremie, whiche are theſe: Thus hath the Lord ſayd vnto me, go, and ſtande in the gate of the children of the people, wherby the kynges of Iudah come in, and by the whiche they go out, and in all the gates of Hieruſalem, And ſay vnto them: heare the words of the Lord, ye kinges of
Iudah, and all Iudah, and all the inhabitauntes of Hieruſalem, that entre in by theſe gates. Thus ſayth the Lord: take hede to your ſoules, and beare no burden in the Sabboth daye, nor bryng it in by the gates of Hieruſalem, neyther cary foorth burdens out of your houſes in the Sabboth day, neyther do ye any worcke, but ſanctifie the Saboth, as I commaunded your fathers. But they obeyed not, neyther enclined their eares, but made their neckes ſtiffe, and would not here, nor receiue corction. Neuertheles, if ye wil here me (ſayth the Lord) and beare no burden through the gates of the Citie in the Sabboth day, ſo that ye do no worcke therin, then ſhall the kyngs, and the princes entre in at the gates of this Citie, and ſhall ſitte vpon the throne of Dauid, and ſhall ride vppon the charettes, and vpon horſes, both they and their princes, the men of Iudah and the inhabitauntes of Hieruſalem, and this Citie ſhall remayne for euer, and they ſhall come from the Cities of Iudah and from about Hieruſalem, & from the land of Beniamin, and from the plaine, & from the mountayns, and from the South, which ſhal bring burnt offringes and Sacrifices, and meate offringes and incenſe, and ſhall bryng Sacrifice of prayſe into the houſe of the Lord. But if ye will not here me to ſanctifie ye Sabboth day, and not to beare a burden, nor to go through the gates of Hieruſalem in the Sabboth day, then will I kindle a fire in the gates therof, and it ſhall deuoure the palace of Hieruſalem, and it ſhall not be quenched. Hetherto Ieremie.

Not without good cauſe therfore Leo, and Anthemius beyng religious princes, writing vnto Armaſius, commaunded hym in theſe wordes: That the feſtiuall dayes beyng dedicate vnto the excellent maieſtie of God, ſhould neyther be occupyed in paſtime & pleaſure, neyther be prophaned in exacting of tributes.

Likewiſe we decree, that the ſonday ſhalbe reuerently honored, that it ſhalbe excepted from al buſines. In this day let no ſuretyſhip be takē, let no man be ſummoned to appeare, let no pleadyng be vſed, and let no cauſes or matters of controuerſie be heard &c. And a litle after it followeth. Neyther do we ſuffer, that this day (beyng exempted from all trauell) ſhould be ſpent in wantonnes, and filthy delightes, let there be no enterlude or pagent played one the dominicall day, nor any game or paſtime in the place of exerciſe called Circus, nor the lamentable ſpectacle of wylde beaſts, yea although the ſolemnitie of our birth happen vppon this day, let it be deferred. If any man on this day ſhall haue any acceſſe vnto ſpectacles, or vnder the pretēce of publique or priuate affaires, ſhalbe an apparitor or ſergeant to any Iudge, violating and breakyng theſe ſtatutes, let him ſuſtayne, let hym leeſe the commoditie of warfare,
and runne into the daunger of preſcription & atteinder.

But in the meane time, the Christian men do not forget theſe words of Christ in the Gospell. The Sabboth was made for man, and not man for the Sabboth.Math. 12. And therfore is the ſonne of man Lord alſo of the Sabboth. The godly do vnderſtand, that the Sabboth was inſtituted of God, to conſerue, and not to destroy man: and therfore the Sabboth is to be diſpenſed withall, as often as it ſhalbe through our neceſsitie or health ſo required.12. Cap. 6. et 13. cap. Of the which thing our ſauiour Christ diſputeth in Mathew and in Luke, for in ſuch thinges the libertie of the Christians doth conſiste. And wheras the Priestes and Leuites are excuſed openly ſlayeng of beastes in the Temple, ſkinning, ſeething and burning them, that is, preparing their Sacrifice in ſuch ſorte, that they be not counted gilty of the breach of the Sabboth. In like ſort it ſhalbe lawfull to prepare meate for our neceſsitie on the Sabboth day, and to feede the body. It ſhalbe lawfull alſo to heale the ſicke, to viſite the impotent and diſeaſed perſons, to ſuccour the nedy, that we may preſerue the creature of God. In this, the exāple of our ſauiour Christ doth inſtruct vs, executing the workes of charitie and mercy on the Sabboth day. Of this there are ſondry examples in the Hiſtory of the Goſpell,Luk. 6. et. 13. Iohn. 5. but eſpecially in Luke and Iohn. If it be lawfull to plucke a beast out of the dich or mier on the Sabboth, why is it not lawfull on the Sabboth to post and ſuccour an olde houſe beyng ready to fall to the ground? VVhy is it not lawfull vpon the Sabboth, to gather together or cary in haye or corne, whiche hath layne abroad a long tyme, and to ſaue it, leaſt it ſhould through the iniury of the weather periſhe, and be vtterly deſtroyed? Conſtantine the Emperour in his ſtatutes writing to Elpedius, ſayth thus: Let all Iudges and the common people of the Cities, and all offices and craftes, ceaſſe, and be at rest vpon the Sonday. But the people of the countrey may ſometimes frely and lawfully attend their tillage and ground: becauſe it oftentimes happeneth, that the corne cannot be committed vnto the earth, nor the vyne tree be ſet in the trenches more commodiouſly and conueniently on any other day. And let not the commoditie which is geuen by Gods prouiſion, periſh through the occaſion of a momentary or ſhort tyme. Theſe be the woordes of Conſtantine. He doth not permit vnto the men of the countrey, al maner of violatyng of the Sabboth: for it is required alſo of thē, that they ſerue God, and that they do not breake this fourth precepte, but they haue a libertie graunted thē in their vrgēt neceſsitie, but herein, godlines, and charitie ought to be our beſt maiſters, and to diſpenſe with vs in this caſe, leaſt vnder the pretence of libertie and neceſsitie, we exerciſe impietie, and do the workes of couetous, and not of religious perſonnes.

Thirdly, the Sabboth hath a miſticall ſignification: for it is a perpetuall token, that it is God onely whiche doth ſanctifie his worſpippers, for thus Lord ſpeaketh vnto Moſes: Thou ſhalt kepe my Sabothes, be cauſe it is a ſign betwixt me & you vnto your posterities, yt ye may know that I am the Lord whiche doth ſanctifie you. And the rest as followeth in Exodus. And it is repeted in Ezechiel.Exod. 13. Ezech. 20. To this vſe it doth alſo conferre it cauſeth mutuall helpe and charitie, whiche was ſpoken of before in the declaration of the ſecond vſe: for God doth ſanctifie his faithfull through the holy Ghost, the whiche thyng he declareth vnto his Churche by the worde of his Goſpell, whiche he testifieth and ſealeth with his Sacramentes: and he commaundeth vs, to deſire of hym this ſanctification with continuall prayers. All whiche thynges are exerciſed chieflye in the Sabboth day, in this, that we may receyue our ſanctification of God whiche is onely holy.

div.head: Vnction. 18.
div.p: SAint Iohn in his Epistle ſayth. The annointing whiche you receiued of him, dwelleth in you,1. Iohn. 2. and you nede not that any man teach you, but as the ſame annoyntyng teacheth you of all thinges &c. This worde Vngere, and Vnctio, do ſignifie many thinges in the Scriptures.
First, by the trope Synecdoche, it ſignifieth to constitute and ordayne a kyng or a Priest.

Secondly, it ſignifieth all ciuil and humaine furniture and dealing as in the booke of kinges. Surrexit Dauid, & vnctus & lotus eſt, that is Dauid aroſe from the earth, and annoynting and waſhed him ſelfe.
Likewiſe, ſaint Luke ſpeaking of Mary, ſayth, Vnxit oleo caput eius, Luk. 7. ſhe annoynted his head with Oyle.

Thirly, by this word vnction is vnderstād the holy ghoſt,2. Cor. 1. as Paul writeth to the Corinth. ſaying: Et qui vnxit nos deus eſt, qui etiā obſignauit nos, dedit
que arrā ſpiritus in cordibus noſtris, that is And it is God which hath annoynted vs, who alſo hath ſealed vs, and hath geuen the erneſt of the ſpirite in our hartes.

Alſo, in this place of Iohn, this worde Vnctio, ſignifieth the holy ghost:1. Iohn. 2. And ye meaning of this ſentēce is this after the minde of Chriſoſtome. The faithfull in ye primatiue church had not much nede of bokes (ye holy ghoſt teaching thē all things neceſſarie to ſaluation) and that which Iohn ſpeaketh here, that the vnction, that is the holy Ghost, teacheth you of, all is true. Remayne therfore in that vnctiō, that is in the doctrine of the holy Ghoſt, and ye ſhalbe preſerued from deceiuers.

div.head: Iuſtification. 19.
div.p:
IVſtificare, & iuſtificari, to iuſtifie, and to be iuſtified, is Verbum forenſe, in the Scriptures, and chiefly among the Hebrues, and
it ſignifieth properly, to be iudged, & aſſoiled by ſome man, as if I ſhould ſay, the people of Rome hath iuſtified Scipio, beyng accuſed of the Tribunes, that is to ſay, they haue aſſoyled or pronounced him to be a iuſt man, Likewiſe in the holy Scriptures, as in Deuteronomie Cum inter litigantes iudicandum eſt, Cap. 25 iuſtum iuſtificent, & impium condemnent, that is, whē there ſhalbe ſtrife betwene men, they ſhall come vnto iudgement, and ſentence ſhalbe geuen vpon them, and the righteous ſhalbe iuſtified and the wicked condemned. And in Mathew. Ex verbis tuis iuſtificaberis, Cap. 12. that is, by thy wordes thou ſhalt be iuſtified, that is to ſay, thou ſhalt be made free and deliuered.

Secondly, it ſignifieth any man to be approued, knowne, and prayſed to be iuſt. Hereupon Saint Luke writeth, that the people and publicanes whiche were Baptiſed at Iohns preaching,Luk. 12. did iuſtifie God, yt is, acknowledged, iudged, confeſsed, and prayſed God to be iuſt.

Thirdly, this worde Iuſtificari, to be iuſtified, ſignifieth alſo a man to be allowed for doing well, the whiche ſignification S. Iames vſeth, when he concludeth, that Abraham was iuſtified by workes, and not by faith onely, becauſe God praiſed Abraham for his obediēce, which he was ready to do by the offering vp of his ſonne, and alſo confirmed the promiſe of multiplieng Abrahams poſteritie, and geuing him a bleſsed ſeede which was our ſauiour Chriſt. This iuſtification was coumpted nothing els but a prayſe and rewarde of his well doyng, and not receyuinge of hys perſonne vnto grace and ſtate of adoption by his worckes. It is manifeſt therfore, that this worde is taken alſo to ſignifie a mans good cauſe to be allowed, that is, for any man to be prayſed and rewarded of GOD for ryghteouſnes and obedience done vnto hym.Cap. 22 VVe ſee this worde to be ſo vſed of Saint Paule, when he wrote that the hearers are not iuſtified before God, but the doers of the lawe. Likewiſe we ſee it to be vſed in the Apocalipſe, for to profite in righteouſnes. Therfore, to be iuſtified by worckes, ſignifieth to obtayne remiſsion, and to be ryghteous and accepted vnto God by our owne power and dedes, which is a falſe doctrin. But contrarywiſe to be iuſtified by faith in Chriſt, ſignifieth to obtayne remiſsion, & to be coumpted righteous, that is accepted to God, not by our owne powers, but by the fre grace of our mediatour, the ſonne of God.

Fourthly, Iuſtificare, to iuſtifie, ſometime is vſed for Excuſare, to excuſe,Cap. 44 as in Geneſis, Quid loquemur? & quo nos iuſtificabimus? that is what ſhall we ſpeake? and how can we iuſtifie and excuſe our ſelues? And in Luke.Cap. 18. Ille autem volens iuſtificare ſeipſum, id eſt, expurgare. &c. that is to ſay. And he willing to iuſtifie, that is, to cleare him ſelfe. &c. Agayne in Luke,Cap 16. Ieſus ſaith to ye Phariſeis. Vos eſtis qui iuſtificaſtis vos coram hominibus. &c. id eſt, exiſtimaſtis vos probos, iuſtos, that is, you are
they, whiche haue iuſtified your ſelues before men. &c. that is, haue thought your ſelues to be good and iuſt men.

Therfore properly iuſtification is none other thing, than a remiſsion, reconciliation, or acceptation of a perſon to eternall life, that is iuſtification ſignifieth remiſsion of ſinnes, a quiet conſcience, and a ſure hope of eternall life giuen frely by the onely mercy of God.

The iuſtifications of God are the wordes of his promiſes, which whē we beleue, we are iuſtified before God, like as we be condemned for beleuing lyes. Pſalme. Vtinam dirigantur viae meae ad cuſtodiendas iuſtificationes tuas, that is. O, that my wayes were directed to kepe thy ſtatutes, that is to ſay. O that my wayes were right, that is, the affection of my harte, and my conuerſation, and that I might not be ſeduced with ſtraūge doctrine, with other mens commaundements and with other ſtatutes.Heb. 9.

Saint Paul in the Epiſtle to the Hebrues calleth not, Iuſtificationes, the word and promiſes of God, but he calleth thē thoſe things which declare iustification after a ſorte, although they do not geue it, as are the Sacrifices, and purifications of the law.

Saint Luke ſemeth to put, Iuſtificationes, Luc. • . for externe and outwarde religion, rites (I ſay) and ceremonies ordeined of God. Theſe rites and ceremonies are called, Iuſtifications, not becauſe they iuſtifie by thē ſelues, but becauſe they are done of them that be iuſtified, and do Sacramentally repreſent the maner of Iuſtification by Christ, and alſo do exerciſe them that be iuſtified in the worſhipping of God.

div.head: Pelagius. 20.
div.p: PElagius was a moncke and a wicked heretike, who came from Rome about the yeare of the incarnation of Christ. 400. into England, or as ſome do ſay, he was a Briton borne, he infected the whole realme with curſed and execrable errours: for he preached, yt man might be ſaued without the grace of God, and that euery man is iuſtified by his owne merites and power. He ſayd alſo, that infantes are borne without originall ſinne, and therfore ought not to be Baptiſed that they might be deliuered from ſinne, as is declared in the Canon. Alſo he ſayd,24. q. 3. ca. Pelagiani. man may liue without ſinne in this life. Saint Auſten confuted moſt profoundly theſe errours in his ſix bookes written againſt Iulianus, whiche with one Caeleſtinus, defended Pelagius faction and errours. Alſo in three bookes De peccatorum meritis & remiſsione & Baptiſmo paruulo tam, and in his booke, De natura et gratia.
This Pelagius (before he was vttered to be an heretike) made three bookes De Trinitate fidei: and after he was pronounced and publiſhed an heretike, he wrote doctrines conſonant to his hereſies.

div.head: Praelectio ſexta.
div.p: I Entēd at this preſēt by ye help of gods holy ſpirit to diſcourſe vnto you the fourth and laſt member of my general partitiō, which ſhalbe of the church and of the authority of the ſame, with certayn obiections of our aduerſaries & anſweares vnto the ſame. And firſt I wil entreat whether there, hath bene, is, and ought to be a church alway or no.

div.head: Of the Church.
div.p: Firſt whether there be a church or no.

Neither ther hath ben, nor hereafter ſhalbe any age in which god hath not ſāctified,God. 1. or doth not ſanctify at the leaſt ſome people in whom he dwelleth being his holy and peculier houſe: For the Prophetes do teſtifie, that ye Churche is continuall. It is written in the Pſalme.Pſal. •
Dominus elegit Syon, elegit eam inhabitationem ſibi, haec requies mea in ſeculum ſeculi, hic habitabo, quoniam elegi eam. That is, The Lord hath choſen Syon, he hath choſen it, for an habitation to him ſelfe, ſaying, this is my reſt for euer, here I dwell for I haue choſen it.

How neceſſary the faith of the Church is, it appeareth by this, Becauſe, that we may be regenerate to eternall life, we muſt firſt be conceyued in her wombe, and that we may be preſerued. And if we ſwarue frō the Church, yet we may return to her agayne by repentaunce.Repentance 2. We muſt be cheriſhed in her lap, for the Churche is the mother of vs all: without the vnitie wherof the Scriptures declare, that there is no ſaluation. For ſo are theſe prophetical ſpeaches to be vnderſtanded.Cap •
In Sion et in Hieruſalem erit ſaluatio. In Sion & Hieruſalē ſhalbe ſaluation. Ezech. In concilio populi mei non erūt, et in ſcriptura domus Iſrael non ſcribētur, that is They ſhall not be in the aſſēbly of my people, neither ſhall they be written in the writing of ye houſe of Iſrael. And ſ. Paul ſaith to the Epheſiās. Vnū corpus, Cap •
vnus ſpiritus, vnus dn̄s, vna fides, vnum baptiſma, vnus deus et pater omniū. &c. That is. Ther is one body, one ſpirit, one Lord, one faith, one baptiſme, one God & father of all. &c. Vnto theſe teſtimonies the wordes of the auncient fathers do agree.

S. Cipriā ſaith. Eccleſia vna eſt quae in latitudinē latius incremē
• o faecūditatis extenditur, quomodo ſolis multi radii ſed lumē vnū: & rami arboris multi, ſed robur vnū, tenaci radice fūdatū, & quū de fōte vno riui plurimi defluūt, numeroſitas licet diffuſa videatur ex vndātis copiae largitate, vnitas tamē ſeruatur in origine. Auelle radiū ſolis a corpore, diuiſionē lucis vnitas nō capit. &c. The church is one, which is largly ſtretched forth by a plēteous increaſe, Euē as there be many beames of ye ſone, & but one light, & many boughes of a tre, & yet there is but one body ſtrōgly rooted, And as out of one ſpring many riuers do flow, though many ſtreames of water do ſeme to be ſcattered abroad, yet notwtſtādyng the vnitie is kept in ye head of the ſpring. Take away the beame of the ſon from the body the vnitie taketh no participation of the light.

Breake ye bough frō the tre & it wil not bud. Separate ye riuer frō the foūtain & it wilbe dried vp. So ye church beīg diſperſed by ye light of ye Lord reachech out her beames through ye whole world, & yet there is but one light which is ſcattered abrod īto al places, neither is ye vnity of ye body ſeparated, ſhe extēdeth her beames into the whole world by her plentifulnes, ſhe largly ſpreadeth out her flowing riuers, and yet there is but one head, one begynning, & one mother of plentie.

Therfore ſeing ye diuers names are read to be attributed to ye church, we muſt not imagine yt there be many churches in ye world, nor we muſt pull in ſonder the body which receiueth not nor ſuffreth any diuiſiō. The writers do call ye catholike church vniuerſal, cōſiſtīg of mē womē & childrē, becauſe it is one, neither cā there be many churches, for although ye church be diſtinguiſhed into a triūphant & militāt church, & into a churche of ye old fathers, & of ye new people: yet notwtſtandyng
al theſe mēbers remain alwayes in one body, beīg vnited vnder one head Chriſt. As ye ſōdry cōditiōs of bond mē & fre mē do not deuide ye cōmō wealth into parts, ſo yt felicity of ye bleſſed cōpanies in heauē, & the labours wherwt we are exerciſed in this world fighting vnder Chriſt his bāner, do not make ii. churches.Felowe ſeruant, 4. The aungel ſaith to ſ. Iohn.
• oc. 22 Cōſeruus tuus ſū et, fratrū tuorū prophaetarū, yt is. I am thy felow ſeruaūt & of thy brethren ye prophetes. He knowledgeth both ye Prophetes & alſo ye Apoſtles to be the ſonnes & houſhold ſeruaūts of one God. We read in the goſpel but of one vineyard, & not of ii. or diuers vineyards to be placed diuerſly, & ſo ther is but one church of the old fathers going before chriſts cōming, & of ye people takē of the gētils after the cōmīg of chriſt, of this we haue ſpoke largly before.

The vnitie & ſociety of this church of god is ſo great, yt wtout ye felowſhip of it, ther is foūd no people acceptable vnto god. If any mā in times paſt had offred ſacrifice to god wtout ye tabernacle or tēple in ye high places, he was thought to haue ſacrificed altogether to deuils, & to haue ſhed innocēt bloud. And therfore Cipriā writeth wel ſaying. Quiſquis ab eccleſia ſegregatus iūgitur adulterae, a promiſsis eccleſiae ſeparatur, nec ꝑtinet ad xp̄i p̄mia qui reliquerit eccleſiā xp̄i. &c. yt is. Whoſo euer being ſeparated frō ye church, is ioyned to a coūterfeit or adulterous church, he is ſeuered frō ye promiſes of the church, nor the rewards of chriſt do appertain vnto ye mā which hath forſakē the church of chriſt. He is an alien, a prophane mā, & an enemi: he now cānot haue god to his father, which hath not the church to his mother. If he could eſcape whiche was wtout the Arke: he alſo which is wtout the church doth eſcape. That man muſt be very wicked whiche forſaketh his owne countrey, and the felowſhip of very good men, and goeth to hys enemy.

Lactātius ſaid, it is onely the church ye retaineth true religiō. This is (ſaith he) the foūtaine of truth,
〈◊〉 3. cap • nſtit, 〈◊〉 . 15 •• de ad • t. 152 this is the houſhold of faith, this is the temple of god,Lactantius 5. in the which who ſo entreth not, or frō the which who ſoeuer goeth, he is without hope of eternall life. For our ſauiour firſt ſaid, without me there is not found life.

Auſten writeth, without the ſocietie of the catholike church, neither baptiſme cā profit any mā, nor the workes of mercy. The ſame ſ. Auſtē ſaith in an other place. Whoſoeuer ſhalbe ſeparated from the catholike church, although he iudgeth him ſelfe to liue commendably,
〈◊〉 , 3. by this onely wickednes that he is ſeparated from the vnitie of chriſt, he ſhal not haue life, but the wrath & āger of god abideth vpō him.Anger. 6.

S. Hierome ſaith, It is not to be thought yt there is one church of Rome, & an other church of the whole world Fraunce, Britanie, Perſia, the eaſt countrey and India, and al the barbarous nations, do worſhip one Chriſt,Britaine. 7 and do obſerue one rule of veritie. If authoritie be aſked, the whole world is greater then one citie.

div.head: ¶ What the Churche is, and firſt wherof this word Eccleſia, that is the Church, is deriued, and why it is ſo called.
div.p: This word Eccleſia, (ſignifieng ye Church) is deriued of this Greke word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , whiche betokeneth Vocare, to cal, for no man can haue any parte of the Church, whiche hath not come vnto it by the calling of God.

Eccleſia, is a Greke word, but it is vſed of the Latines, as their owne, and ſignifieth Caetū, a companie, a communion, an aſſemble of people gathered together to beare matters pertayning to the common wealth: for ſo doth Saint Luke vſe this worde in the Actes of the Apoſtles.

It is trāſlated to an holy vſe, & ſo Eccleſia, is called a cōpanie of ye faithful, inuocating & calling vpō the name of God. S. Paul ſaith yt he perſecuted the churche of god, & in the acts of the apoſtles, Accepi poteſtatē a principibꝰ ſacerdotū vinciē di omnes qui inuocāt nomē xp̄i, yt is. I receiued power of ye chief of ye prieſts to bind al thoſe which do inuocate ye name of chriſt. For now he calleth thoſe mē chriſtiās & inuocatours of ye name of Chriſt, which before he had called Eccleſiā, ye church.

In times paſt ye cōpanie or church of ye Iewes (whiche were ye peculiar people of god) was called Sinagoga, a ſinagoge for Synagoga, & Eccleſia, do ſignifi one thīg, but for the ſtubburnes of the Iewes & their vnappeaſable hatred againſt Chriſte religion, this word ſynagoge hath almoſt ceaſed to be vſed, and is become vile.

The Northē men of our countrey do cal Eccleſiā, the kirk, alluding perchaūce
to the Greke worde 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . For the Grekes do cal 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Domum, that is, a houſe or a common place, or the people of the Lord, and the place alſo in the whiche the people are gathered, to the worſhipping of God.

div.head: VVhat the Churche is.
div.p: We may call Eccleſiam, the Churche, a company of them that beleue, and of them that are regenerate, whiche God gathereth in Chriſt by the worde and the holy Ghoſt, and ruleth them by the Miniſters and teachers of pure doctrine, and by the lawfull vſe of the Sacramentes, and by diſcipline.

It is called the body of Chriſt becauſe all his members take him for their head, of whom they take their increaſing, and do obtayne lyfe by the ſendyng abroad of the holy Ghoſt. And theſe members are ſo faſt ioyned to the head, that they be called fleſhe of his fleſh, and bone of his bones.

div.head: The notes of the Churche.
div.p:
And it hath alwayes thre notes or markes wherby it is knowne. The firſt note is pure & ſound doctrine. The ſecond note are the Sacramēts miniſtred according to Chriſtes holy inſtitution. The third note is the right vſe of eccleſiaſticall diſcipline. This deſcription of the Church is agreable both to the ſcriptures of God, & alſo to ye doctrine of the auncient fathers, ſo that none may iuſtly find fault ther with, for Paul to the Epheſiās ſaith. Chriſtus ſemetipſū expoſuit pro eccleſia, vt il lā ſanctificaret mundatā lauacro aquae per verbum, Auncient. 8 that is.Cap. 5 •
Chriſte gaue him ſelfe for the Churche that he might ſanctifie, it and clenſe it by the waſhing of water through the worde.

The notes of ye Church in this teſtimony of Paul, is the word & the ſacrament, for grace calleth & purifieth through ye bloud of Chriſt. Theſe things he ſheweth by the word, yt he may be receiued by faith, & he ſealeth it with the Sacrament, ye the faithfull may not doubt any thing of ſaluation gotten by Chriſt.

Theſe things are properly mete for the faithfull and holy members of Chriſt. As touching that the hypocrites are not purged, the fault is in them ſelues, and not in God or in the holy miniſterie. They are viſiblie ſanctified, wherby they are taken and counted for Saintes.

When Peter had preached the word of God at Hieruſalem,Act. •
& the people aſked him what they ſhould do, Peter aunſwered them: Repente you, and let euery of you be baptiſed in the name of Ieſu Chriſt for the remiſſion of ſinnes. Peter ioyned baptiſme to doctrine, the Sacrament to the worde.

Alſo in the actes of the Apoſtles. Erāt perſeuerātes in doctrina apoſtolorū & bene ficētia, ac fractione panis ac praecatione, that is,Cap. •
the diſciples cōtinued in ye apoſtles doctrine & folowſhip, & breakyng of bread & prayers. And thus you ſee the ſupper of the Lord, and the Sacrament of baptiſme, to be added to the word.

div.head: Queſtion.
div.p: What maner a worde that ought to be whiche is a note of the Churche.

It is not enough to boaſt of ye word of god, vnles we do alſo embrace the natiue ſēſe agreable to the articles of our faith. For if ye do corrupt the ſenſe of ye Scriptures, and vrge the ſame in the church, ye do not ſpeake the Scriptures, but your own opinion, inuented if your owne minde.

The Churche of the Arrians did not refuſe the word of God, but did as it were mainteine & defend their errours by the teſtimonies of the Scriptures. By this one exāple a man maye iudge the Churches of all heretikes, which although they do not ſeeme to lacke the teſtimonie of Gods word, yet in dede they haue not the pure worde of God, nor the true ſenſe of the ſame.

So the Papiſticall Churche doth not forſake the word of God, but yet taketh away the true ſenſe, & doth ſubſtitute a ſtraunge ſenſe, which that it may haue the faire ſhew, they call it the ſenſe of the holy mother ye Church. In ſo much that vnleſſe, ye ſpeake and wreſt the whole ſcriptures to their mindes and commoditie, that is, temper them with their decrees, ye ſhalbe ſaid to preach hereſies.
By examples the matter ſhal be made more playn and manifeſt.

• pheſus • p. 1. 4 et • d Co
• s. 1. &. 2 • m. 8. 〈◊〉 . epiſt. Tim. 2. • n. 1. E
• ſt. 2. • m. 2.1 Cor. 1. Cor. 10. • 1.The holy ſcriptures do teache, that Chriſt is the onely head of the church: they teache that the Pope is the head of the church militant vpon earth.
The ſcripture teacheth, that Ieſus Chriſt is the onely interceſſiour or mediatour: they adde, that Chriſt is the mediatour of redemption, and the ſayntes to be mediatours of interceſſion,

The ſcripture teacheth,Hoſt. 9. that onely Chriſt is the only hoſt expiatory of the faithful: They teache that Prieſts do offer dayly vnbloudy hoſt or ſacrifice, for the remiſſion of ſynnes, both of the quicke and the dead.
The ſcripture teacheth, that Ieſus Chriſt is the righteouſnes of the faythfull, which is receiued of vs by fayth? They teach, that righteouſnes is gotten by our own workes and merites.

The ſcripture teacheth that bread and wine remaine in the ſacrament:Bread and wyne remaine. 10. Both kinds 11. They teach, that they are tranſubſtantiated into the body and bloud of Chriſt, and that no part remayneth, but onely accidentes.
• dem. 11. • th. 26.The ſcripture teacheth, that both kindes muſt be geuen: They teache, that one kinde onely, muſt be geuen to lay people.

• im. 3.The ſcripture teacheth, that all things neceſſary to our ſaluation, are written in the ſcriptures: They teach, that ſome things are nedefull to ſaluation, whych are not contayned in the ſacred ſcriptures, But Tercullian ſayth, happy is that church, to the which the Apoſtles did exhibite with their bloud all doctrine. Auguſtine alſo ſaith:
• actatu. • cap. 11. • cannē
Cum dominus Ieſus multa feciſſet, non omnia ſcripta ſunt, ſicut Euangeliſta teſtatur, multa dominum et dixiſſe et feciſſe quae ſcripta non ſunt: electa autem ſunt quae ſcriberentur, quae ſaluti credentium ſufficere videbantur. That is: When the Lord Ieſus had done many things, all were not written, as witneſſeth the euangeliſt, that all things were not written, which the Lord both ſayd and did. But there wer choſen to be written thoſe things, which ſeemed to ſuffiſe to the ſaluation of the beleuers.
Who ſeeth not here theſe moſt filthy men to treade down the holye woorde of God, and to eſtabliſh lawes, & to vndo them againe by their tyrannical boldnes?

div.head: The ſecond note of the Church is the Sacraments.
div.p: Sacraments, vnles they be vſed as the Lord him ſelfe ordayned them, they be not markes and tokens of the church of God.
Ieroboam offred ſacrifice, but bicauſe he did it vnlawfully, he is called a ſtraunger, and a ſwaruer from the true church of God.Ieroboam. 12.

Dauid alſo, with very great deuotion and ioy, caried himſelf the Arke of God, and daunced before it, but bicauſe it was not lawfullye caried vpon the Prieſtes ſhoulders, forthwith in ſtede of great gladnes, a great mourning ariſing, argued and proued that it is not enough for a man to vſe the ſacraments and ordinaunces of God, vnles they be lawfully and rightly vſed.

The auncient Catholiques, woulde not rebaptize them, that were baptized of heretickes, bicauſe the heretickes did not baptize them in the name of any man, or for the felowſhip of their hereſy, but in the name of the father, of the ſonne, & of the holy ghoſt, neither they inuocated their own name, but the name of Chriſt, therfore that fourme of baptiſing was lawful enough.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: The churche of Rome hath a moſt ſure marke of the Apoſtolicke church, that is, the perpetual ſucceſſion of Biſhops, from ſaynt Peter, by Clement the firſt, vnto Clement the ſeuenth, and ſo to this preſent biſhop that now is. Furthermore theſe members are cut away, which haue ſeperated them ſelues from that church. Therfore onely in the church of Rome is the apoſtolicke ſucceſſion found.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p:
The certayne ſucceſſion of Paſtours, was greatlye eſteemed in the primatiue
church: for they that were then called, were true paſtours, and executed the offices of true paſtors. But ther haue bent ſuch other maner of paſtors for theſe many yeres, as Zacharias deſcribeth ſaing. Dixit dominꝰ ad me: adhuc ſume tibi vaſa paſtoris ſtulti: quia ecce ego ſuſcitabo paſtorem in terra, qui derelicta non viſitabit, Cap. 11. diſperſum non quaeret, et contritum non ſanabit, & id quod ſtat, non enutriet, & carnes pinguium comedet, & vngulas eorum diſſoluet. O paſtor et idolum derelinquens gregem. &c. That is. The Lord ſayd vnto me: Take to thee yet the inſtruments of a fooliſh ſhepheard, for loe, I will raiſe vp a ſhepheard in the land, which ſhal not looke for the thing which is loſt, nor ſeeke the tender Lambes, nor heale that that is hurt, nor feede that that ſtandeth vp, but he ſhal eate the fleſhe of the fat, and teare their clawes in peeces. O idol ſhepheard that leaueth the flocke. &c.

Therefore the Churche is no more proued by the continuall ſucceſſion of Byſhops, ſpeciallye as oft as they doo not preach the woord of God, nor do the office of paſtors, than if there were a great number of idoles ſet foorth to the face of the world to proue the ſame.
Who can deny, but that the moſt part of the Romiſh Biſhops after Gregorius Magnus, were ſuche lyke Idolles, ſuche maner of Wolues, and deuourers as Zachary deſcribed?
In the old church of Iſrael the order of Biſhops was common, & the ſucceſſion was vnbroken from Aaron, to Vrias, and from him to Achas, and to other wycked Biſhops that ſwarued to idolatry.
