By this learned ſentence of Auguſtine we know, that the ceremonies of the Iewes, were not immediatly after Christes Paſsion pernitious and hurtfull, for they ſinned not whiche obſerued them for a tyme, although there was no hope of ſaluation to be put in them. For otherwiſe they ſhould haue deadly offended, whiche would haue thought, that they ought to be obſerued of neceſsitie, as though ſaluation and iuſtification ſhould be taken by them.

In Epiſt. ad Auguſtin.Hierome notwithſtanding in this altercation with Auguſtine diſſenteth from hym, affirmyng, that the ceremonies of the Iewes, after the Paſsion of the Lorde, were alwayes pernicious and deadly to the Chriſtians, and that who ſoeuer, either of the Iewes or of the Gentiles, obſerued them, he ſhould be caſt downe to the pitte of hell.

Neither he thincketh, that Paul or Peter obſerued theſe ceremonies, but that they diſſembled the matter, to auoyde the offence of the Iewes, but the ſcolaſticall doctours do diſagre from this opinion.
But after the ſufficient preaching of the Goſpell, the ceremonies of the Iewes were pernicious.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: Some men will ſay, was not Paul likewiſe to be reproued aſwell as Peter, when he circumciſed Timothie, when he purified him ſelfe ſeuen dayes, when he ſhore his head in Cenchreis, and when he let his heare growe by a vowe, and when Sacrifices were offred for him accordyng to the lawe, leaſt ſome of the Iewes whiche beleued, ſhould be offended? And if he knewe that the circumciſion of Timothie was nothing worth, and likewiſe his purification, and the offering of the Sacrifices, and notwithſtandyng did thus, vndoubtedly he diſſembled, and therfore he was to be reprehended as well as Peter.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: They that diſsolue this argument, doo note ſimulation, as ſimulation, not to be any euill, but to be indifferent both to good and euell: for if it ſaue, edifie and kyndle godly zeale, as the ſimulation of Chriſt when he feigned him ſelfe to go farre, he enflamed his Diſciples the more to require his preſence, than it is good.
But if it deſtroye or take awaye charitie, or be agaynſt edifieng, it is euill and to be reproued.

They do graunt, that Paul diſsembled in theſe Iudaicall obſeruations, when he knewe that they were nothyng worth, but at ſuch tyme as he myght not hurte by his example, but myght profit by his diſsembling. VVhen he came to Lystra, he circumciſed Timothie whom he would haue to be his iourney felowe, fearyng leaſt he ſhould hynder the fayth of the Iewes, by whom he ſhould paſſe, if he ſhould lead aboute with him an vncircumciſed man, furthermore he did appeaſe tumultes and ſeditions, whiche might be moued agaynſt him. Alſo be circumciſed Timothie, becauſe he would ſend hym to teache the Iewes, and he did ſo, that the teacher myght be the more accepted of his auditours, yet for that end (as Chriſoſtome ſaith) he circumciſed Timothie that he might abrogate circumciſion. And if the Iewes had knowen that Timothie had not bene circumciſed, they would not at all haue hard Timothie preach.

Neither Paul did offende, when at Hieruſalem, he feyned the Iudaicall purifications, for they profited and ſaued charitie, neyther did they hurte or hinder the fayth of Christ beyng receyued, therfore he was not to be reproued in theſe ſimulations. But Peters diſsimulation was euill, becauſe it dyd hurte and offende the Gentiles, that were lately called to the fayth.
Saint Auguſtine calleth Peters diſsimulation and feinyng, Peruerſam & hypocriticam diſsimulationem, that is, a peruerſe and hypocriticall diſsimulation.

div.head: Praelectio ſeptima.
div.p: I Entend at this preſēt by gods grace to confute & to anſwere to certain arguments of our aduerſaries whiche they lay agaynſt vs, and agaynſt the true Churche.

div.head: Firſt they reaſon thus againſt vs.
div.p: You vſe nothing but the expreſſe word of God. The falſe Prophetes in times paſt vſed nothing but the expreſſe worde of God: Ergo, you be falſe Prophetes.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: I denie the cōſequent: for he is not a falſe Prophet whiche vſeth the expreſſe worde of God, but he yt doth falſely vſe it and doth detort it from the natiue ſenſe. They call the expreſſe worde of God the texte of the Scriptures, whiche (as Swinckfeldius doth vtterly reiecte) ſo the Papiſtes make it doubtfull and vncertayne.The text. 1.

div.head: The ſecond argument.
div.p: The falſe Prophetes preached nothing in tymes paſt, but peace, tranquilitie, & libertie, you preache nothyng but peace, tranquilitie, and libertie: Ergo, you be falſe Prophetes.Peace. .2.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Conſciēce. 3.I denie the minor, for we terrifie and make a feard the conſcience of men firſt, with preaching of the law, and then we do teach vnto our auditours the peace & promiſes of the Goſpell. Ergo, your minor is not worth a minorites graye hoode.

div.head: The third argument.
div.p: The old Prophetes taught men to doubt & to be in a ſuſpenſe of the remiſſion of their ſinnes. You do preache certeintie and make men ſure, of the remiſſion of their ſinnes, Ergo, you be not true Prophetes.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p:
I denie the maior: although you ſeme to proue it out of Ioel, out of Daniell, and out of the actes of the Apoſtles.Ioel. 4. Ioel. 2. The wordes of Ioel are theſe. Quis ſcit ſi conuertatur dominus? Who knoweth if the Lord will returne? This ſentence you would haue to be a dubitation, when in very dede it is an aſſeu • ration, and a phraſe of the Hebrue tounge. The Prophet in dede here ſemeth at the firſt ſight to leaue men perplexe and doubtfull, but in the next verſe he offred them grace & fauour, if they would repent from the bottom of their hartes. Wherfore the Prophet ſemeth not to proſequute his talk, but rather to be diuerſe: And al exhortatiōs with the which God exhorteth vs to repentance, are cold, yea rather friuolous except he teſtifie him ſelfe to be ready & willing to reconciliation. Wheras therfore the Prophet here doth leaue the mindes of men in ſuſpenſe, he ſemeth to cut of that whiche he before entreated of the mercie of God. But this maner of ſpech is to be obſerued whiche oftentimes is founde in the Scriptures. For as ofte as God is deſcribed vnto vs, hard to forgeue ſinne, this pertaineth to the ſturring vp of our ſlouth, and to ſhake of our negligence. At the firſt we are colde, when God doth inuite vs, except he pricke vs forward by ſondrie wayes. And alſo, whē we come vnto him, we do it remiſſely and ſlenderlie. Wherfore it is neceſſarie, that both theſe faultes be corrected in vs, that is, that our ſlomberyng be quickned and ſturred, and that theſe delightes be driuen awaye with the whiche we ouermuch flatter our ſelues: And to this end is the counſell of the Prophet, for he ſpeaketh vnto deſperate perſons. If he onely had ſayd, God is ready to forgeue, If he had vſed onely this forme of ſpech, perhaps they would haue come negligently, &
would not earneſtly haue bene touched with the feare of God. Therfore the Prophet doth as it wer conſult with them. Although we may worthely diſpayre (for we be vnworthy, whō God at any tyme ſhould receyue vnto hym) yet there is no cauſe why we ſhould be vtterly diſmayed. Quis enim ſcit. &c, that is, God is placable. Wherfore we ought not diſpeir, for the Prophete doth propone vnto vs a difficultie of obteyning gods fauour, not that he might leaue men in a doubte (for that were contrarie to his former doctrine) but that he might geue ſome taſt of the mercie of god, that they ſhould gather theyr ſpirites vnto them by litle and litle, and yt they ſhould not perſuade them ſelues to be in ſecuritie, but that they ſhould come vnto god carefully, and with much deliberation, after that they haue conſidered their offences.

Let it be that the Prophete ſpake, Dubitatiue, yet that dubitation is not to be taken of the remiſſion of ſinnes, and of eternall payne, but it is to be vnderſtand of the remiſſion of temporall payne. Agayne a Facto ad ius, is no good argument.

As for the place of Daniel, is manifeſtly corrupt, for it is in Hebrue a plaine aſſeueration. Althoughe the grecians reade 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Forſitan, the Hebrue texte hath Hen, whiche betokeneth, Ecce, ſo that Daniell meant when he ſpake to Nabuchadonozor aſſertiue, when he ſayd, Ecce erit ſanatio delictorū tuorum. Loe,Nabuchodonozor. 5▪ this ſhalbe a healing for thy ſinnes, or as ſom read Id enim erit. Chriſoſtom alſo doth ſay, that the Prophet ſpake not doubtfully, but ſayth, that the prophet did ſmite ſuch a terror and feare vnto the kyng, as though he had ſinned a ſinne more greuous, then that deſerued pardon. His wordes be theſe. Hoc ſic dixit non ambigens (valde enim perſuaſum erat Prophetae, ſed volens illum terrere & cogere vt hoc faciat. &c.) He ſaid, this not doubting (for it was thoroughly perſuaded vnto ye prophet) but mindyng to put him in fear, & to conſtrain him to do this. For if he had ſpokē affirmatiuely, the king would haue ben the more negligent. So likewiſe we thē most of al do inſtigate and make him the more earneſt, when we ſay, deſire him & ſhewe vnto him, perchaunce, he wil heare thee: for feare riſing of a doubt doth prouoke a man the more, for this cauſe the prophete made it not ſure and certayne. What ſayeſt thou? wil god forgeue ſo great wickednes? There is no ſinne which almeſdede cannot purge and extinguiſhe. Euery ſinne geueth place vnto almes, and is a remedie profitable for euery wounde.

This and ſuch like places of ſcripture are not to be vnderſtand as though the worck it ſelfe of almes geuing, doth iuſtifie mā: but that if it be geuē out of a liuely faith and godly loue, it doth declare and teſtifie man to be iuſtified. The like place we haue in the Euangeliſt ſ. Luke, where Chriſt ſpeaketh to the phariſies after this ſort: Date cleemoſynam, & ecce omnia mūd a ſūt vobis. Geue almes, & behold all things are cleane vnto you. That the papiſtes out of this place do inferre almes deedes to bee a ſatiſfaction, by the whiche wee are made cleane from our ſinnes, it is more vayne then that it nedeth any long refutation. Neither Chriſt doth here diſpute by what price, we may attayne the remiſſion of our ſinnes, but that they do eate their bread vndefiledly whiche geue parte vnto the poore. The conſcience is not purged, but by repentaūce. And repentaūce doth conſiſte chiefly in two pointes, the one in the acknowledging of our faultes, the other in a ſure faith, that through Chriſt our ſinnes are remitted. Wherfore, when Chriſt admoniſhed the phariſies to purge their conſciences from ſinne, by the ſame wordes he willed them to acknowledge their ſinne, and to beleue that through Chriſt they were forgeuen, for he onely can reconcile vs vnto god, and make ſatiſfaction for our wickednes. Alſo he addeth the fruietes of repentaunce, that is the worckes of charitie whiche procede of faith.

As for the wordes of Peter out of the actes of ye Apoſtles whiche he ſpake vnto Simon Magus, ſaying, Repent from thy wickednes, and pray,Simon Magus. 6. if perchaunce god will forgeue thee. It helpeth the papiſtes nothing at all, which will haue men to pray with ſuſpenſe and doubtful mindes, and counted it a temeritie and raſhnes
for a man to perſuade him ſelfe any certayntie in his prayers. But if the wordes of ſaint Peter be wel vewed, the anſwere is ſone made, for this greke word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , is asmuch to ſay, as if a man ſhould ſay in Latin. Si qua tibi remittat deus. If god by any means may forgeue thee. This maner of ſpech Peter vſeth not, yt he might leaue ye mind of Simon in doubt, but that he might ye more prouoke him to erneſt prayer, for the difficultie of the matter is of no ſmall force to excite and ſturre vs: becauſe when we ſe that the matter is more eaſie, and in our own power, we are to ſecure and ſluggiſh. Wherfore Peter doth not here put Simon in a terror and feare, to the intent that he might put all confidence and hope out of his mind and ſo diſcourage him, but declaring that there was a certayne hope leaft vnto him, if he called for mercie with an humble and lowly ſpirite (onely to make hym the more ardent,) ſheweth him, that for the greuouſnes of his ſins, it was hard to obtayne pardon: for faith is moſt neceſſarie when ſoeuer we haue acceſſe vnto god, and pray vnto him, yea rather it is the mother of prayer.

div.head: The fourth Argument.
div.p: The deuil vſeth the Scriptures, the falſe Apoſtles vſe the ſcriptures, the Anabaptiſtes vſe the Scriptures aſwell as Chriſt and the Apoſtles, and you alſo of this new Churche vſe the Scriptures, Ergo, the ſcripture is an vncertayne thing to leane vnto.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: I denie the argument, for what ſoeuer is vſed of diuers hauing diuerſe iudgements, is not of it ſelfe doubtfull, but it behoueth vs to beholde & examine, who doth vſe it falſly & who truly for it is not the diuerſitie of mēs wits that maketh a thing ſure or vnſure, for in euery thyng there is a veritie.

div.head: The fift Argument.
div.p: The true Churche hath ordeyned, that the lay ſorte ſhould receyue the Sacrament vnder one kynde onely, that is, vnder the kynde of bread and not of wine.
But your Church commaundeth to geue to the laye ſorte both kyndes. Ergo, your Churche is not the true Churche.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: I denie the maior, for the true Churche of Chriſt doth neuer alter nor chaunge Chriſtes Inſtitution. Now Chriſts Inſtitution was that al mē ſhould drinke of the cup, Ergo, your Churche forbidding the ſame is the Synagoge of Antichriſt, and not the Churche of Chriſt.

div.head: Replicatio.
div.p: You take theſe woordes to be ſpoken generally, Bibite ex hoc omnes, Drincke you al of this.Infantes ought not. 7. But infants, do not, nor ought to drinke of the cup. Ergo, you are deceyued in ſaying that all men generally ſhould drincke of the cup.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: This whiche you bring of infantes, who ought not to be admitted to this Sacrament before a certayne tyme is friuolous and childiſhe: for ſaint Paule would haue all them whiche come to this Sacrament,To proue themſelues 8. to proue and examine them ſelues, before they eate of this bread or drincke of this cup.

Therfore this ſaying, Bibite ex hoc omnes, is generally ſpoken to thoſe, whiche be of thoſe yeares that they bee able to trie and proue thinges. And I praye you haue you forgotten your logicall diſtinction of thys vniuerſall ſigne, Omnis, whiche is taken in the Scriptures ſometyme diſtributiue, ſometyme collectiue, Turne the leafe I beſeche you, and ſee howe theſe wordes are to be vnderſtāded. Omnis Hieroſolima exiuit ad Iohannem. Agayne, decimatis omne olus. &c. Deus vult vt omnes homines ſalui fiant: hoc eſt, ex omni genere aliquos, that is.Ma • Ti • cap •
God would haue all men to be ſaued, that is to ſay, of euery ſtate ſome.

div.head: The ſixt Argument.
div.p: In the true Church there are no ſects, but in your Church ther ar ſectes. Ergo, your Churche is not the true Churche.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: 〈◊〉 11. 〈…〉 3. 〈◊〉 2Firſt I aunſwere S, Paul ſayth. Oportet hereſes eſſe vt electi probentur, there muſt be hereſies, that the elect might be tryed and made manifeſt. It is written alſo, Sathan ſtood among the ſonnes of god. Alſo there are tares among the corne, furthermore they went from vs, but they be not of vs.

Now ſecondly I aunſwere: I denie this argument. Heretikes be among the electe, Sathan among the children of god, tares among wheat, goates among ſhepe, Ill fiſſhes among the good. Ergo, the electe children of God, are not the children of god. Ergo, wheat is not wheat, Shepe be not ſhepe, But if you will make a good argument, you ſhould conclude thus. Ergo, tares be tares, heretikes be heretikes,
〈…〉
Ill fiſhes be ill fiſhes.

div.head: Notio.
div.p: Althoughe the whole rablemence of Papiſtes do agree together in perſecutyng of Chriſt and his goſpell, yet there is great diſſention and ſectes among thē, as it may well appeare vnto them, whiche ſhall read their worckes,Original ſinne of Mary. 9. As the Thomiſtes, the Scotiſtes about the originall ſinne of the virgine, the Henriciſtes & other queſtioniſtes, who fighteth and writeth one agaynſt another. What ſay you to your owne men whiche wrote of late dayes, Gardener & Smith, who do write contrary doctrines about the Sacrament. Likewiſe Pighius and E • kius write contrarie doctrines about originall ſinne.

div.head: The ſeuenth Argument.
div.p:
Loue is the ende of the law and of al the Prophets, but you of this Church do not loue,
〈…〉 . 13. becauſe you departe from the vnitie and concorde of the Churche of Rome. Ergo, you do agaynſt the manifeſte worde of god, agaynſt the lawe and agaynſt the Prophetes.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p:
I denie the argument, loue is of two ſortes. The loue of god, & the loue of man The loue of god whiche is the foundation of the firſt table, and doth conſiſte in a Chriſtian faith,
〈…〉 . 6. is to be preferred aboue the loue of al men. Yea Chriſt cōmaūdeth. If thy eye offende thee, pull him out and caſt hym from thee.
Alſo Saint Iohn ſayth, if any man come vnto you, and bring not this doctrine, receyue hym not into your houſe, nor bid hym god ſpede. Agayn, what felowſhip is there for lyght with darcknes.

div.head: Replicatio.
div.p: If any man bryng any ſentence out of the Scriptures whiche is profitable to edification & charitie, (Although he who wrote the ſentēce do not ſo meane) yet he is not deceyued with any great daunger, nor doth ſwerue from the word of god.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p:
He racketh theſe wordes out of Saint Auſten, and would, that willyngly we ſhould erre from the true vnderſtandyng of the Scriptures, as for example, where Chriſte ſayth,
〈…〉
• 4. Drincke you all of this, you would not haue vs to knowe theſe woordes, leaſt we ſhould trouble the concorde and vnitie of your Churche, you would haue vs to learne that leſſon out of Terence. Tu quod ſcis neſcis. Theſe wordes be mete for an Infidell, & not for one that profeſſeth gods worde. That kynde of edifieng and charitie whiche is done to further the cauſe of Antichriſt, is no true edification, but is a deſtruction of godly loue, and a ruine of our ſaluation.

div.head: The eight Argument.
div.p: The true Churche is a viſible congregation, whiche maye bee ſeene and knowen.
But you cannot ſhew a viſible & known church, for Flacius cōdemneth Philip and Philip condemneth Flacius. Ergo, neither you nor they be any Church.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: I deny the conſequent, for condemnation doth not exclude both the parties: for it is neceſſarie, the condemnation of the one parte to be iuſt and good, and of the other vniuſt and wicked.

I will make you the like argument. Moſes rebuked Aaron being foully deceyued. Paulus rebuked Peter when he diſſēbled. Ergo, none of thē be of the church.Exod. 〈…〉 Gal. 2, •
Who would not cal ten Democritos, Democritus. 10. to laugh hartly at theſe vnſauery ſequeles.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: They that be of the Churche, muſt folow and obſerue thre thinges, that is, vniuerſallity, antiquitie and common conſent, otherwiſe they cannot be true Catholicques.Vincentius 11. This ſaith. Vincentius Lirinenſis.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: If the Churche were now in ſuch ſtate as it was when Vincentius. wrote this ſaying, we would gladly folow it, and embrace vniuerſality & antiquitie, but the Church ſince that tyme hath eſtabliſhed many thinges that repugne agaynſt the Scriptures, and therfore it is not to be followed in all thinges.
We ought to folow that vniuerſalitie, which contayneth ſuch kind of doctrine as the ſacred Bible appointeth and ſetteth out vnto vs.
Alſo euery faithfull mā ought to receiue and regarde ſuch an antiquitie, which nothing ſwarueth from the canonicall veritie, and the meanyng therof.

Or els no vniuerſalitie, antiquitie nor conſent (though they haue ben put in vre neuer ſo long) ought to be admitted: for the vniuerſall church of Chriſt beareth the voyce onely of her paſtour, and doth not knowledge the voyce of ſtraungers.

div.head: ¶ The vniuerſall nomber maketh not the true Church.Iohn, 〈…〉
div.p: The Churche of the Iſraelites was in tymes paſt a great and notable Church, in whiche were the nomber of ſixe hundred thouſande men beſide women, and children:Aaron. 12. Phinies. 13. in the whiche were excellent men, noble men, holy and learned men, yea & the workers of miracles. The wiſe & eloquent man Aaron was in that Church, There alſo were Eleazar, Iſchamar, Hur, and Phinees, which were renowmed and famous men in all kinde of literature, beyng aged and experte men in many thinges. Did not (I pray you) this vniuerſall Churche, in whiche were ſixe hundred thouſand armed men, receyue the calfe by generall conſente? for no man did put forth hym ſelfe to reſiſte that filthy Councell. Did this worke (thincke you) pleaſe God, becauſe it was made by the vniuerſall conſent of the Churche? yea and the holy and learned men allowed it by theyr ſilence, yea and Aaron furtheryng & openly agreyng to it. But the Lord ſayd to Moſes: get the down, the people hath broken the couenaunt, They haue gone out of the way, which I cōmaū ded them to walk in,A calfe. 14. for they haue made them an image of a calf to worſhip it.Exod •

Loe, the mouth of the Lord calleth thoſe learned and holy men, couenaūt breakers and Apoſtataes, yea and the vniuerſall Churche of the Iſraelites, only Moſes, or at the moſt Ioſua and Moſes excepted.
Helias. 15. Baaliſts. 16.Helias alone reſiſted many hundredes of Baaliſtes.

Chriſt alone put him ſelfe agaynſt the whole colledge of Prieſtes & Phariſies. The Apoſtles beyng few, went forth into all the worlde, and had agaynſt thē the fayth and cuſtome that was vſed many yeares before, the rites of the fathers, the iudgementes and dedes of very wiſe and religious men (as they ſemed.) Therfore were thoſe thynges true, whiche ſo many learned, wiſe and iuſt men taught, whiche ſo many Realmes and nations obſerued and kept ſo long time before? & contrarie wiſe, were thoſe thynges falſe whiche a fewe Apoſtles taught, beyng new, baſe and contemptuouſe men?

But wherefore did the Apoſtles teache truth, and the other falſhood? ye ſhall fynde the cauſe, not by exernall deedes, but becauſe they taught by the will of God expreſſed in his holy woorde, and the other men tooke their doctrine of men of whom it was written. Omnis homo mendax, that is, all men are lyars. That vndoubtedly is an errour which fighteth,
〈…〉
• 5. with the wil of the eternall God, with the lawe and worde of God, or that agreeth not with it.
Therfore the Churche erreth, as oft as it followeth her owne mynde, not regardyng the Scriptures.
The olde Churche before Chriſtes tyme erred many yeares, when it neglected the commaundement of god, and loued her owne will.
Therfore it is a great fooliſhnes, to will to defend any errours vnder the pretence of the Churche, as though the Churche could not erre, but all thinges were true and ryght that it doth.
The Churche erreth, not when it heareth the voyce of her ſhephearde, but it doth erre when it hereth it not.

Therfore we muſt enquyre whether the Churche hath herde the voyce of the ſhephearde in that thyng whiche hath bene called in queſtion. Yf this thyng do appeare, it wilbe manifeſt, that the Churche doth well.
But ſome men go a ſtraunge waye, gatheryng this argument: this thyng the Churche doth and obſerueth: therfore it doth wel. But this is not to play the diuine, but to playe the Sophiſter.
Paphnutius alone ſtoode agaynſt the councell of Nice and was heard: wherby it appeareth, that this note of vniuerſalitie is not a true note of the Church.Paphnutius 17

div.head: Antiquitie.
div.p: As touching antiquitie, who I pray you was auncienter than Chriſt? by whoſe guidyng the true Church is gouerned, and whoſe onely wordes it ought to here: the whiche thyng Cyprian affirmeth ſaying. Et quod chriſtus debeat ſolus audiri, pater etiam de caelo conteſtatur dicens, hic eſt filius meus dilectus, in quo bene conſenſi, ipſum audite. Quare ſi ſolus Chriſtus eſt audiendus, non debemus attendere quid aliquis ante nos faciendum putauerit, ſed quid prior Chriſtus qui ante omnes eſt, fecit. Neque enim hominis cōſuetudinem ſequi oportet, ſed dei veritatem, yt is. And that Chriſt onely ought to be heard, god the father witneſſeth frō heauē, ſaying, this is my beloued ſon in whom I am well pleſed, here you him. Wherfore if onely chriſt muſt be heard, we ought not to regarde what any man before vs hath thought good to be done, but we muſt take hede what Chriſt did whiche is before all, for we muſt not folow the cuſtome of men, but god his veritie.

Auguſtine ſaieth. Quia quod anterius eſt inquiūt falſum eſſe non poteſt. &c. that is to ſay.
〈…〉 no 〈…〉
• m. 〈…〉 4. 〈◊〉 de 〈◊〉 b. Becauſe they ſay that cannot be falſe whiche is firſt, as though antiquitie and olde cuſtome doth hinder and let the veritie. For thus men ſlayers voluptuous men and adulterers may defende their wickedneſſes, becauſe they were auncient.

Alſo Saint Ambroſe ſayth. Nos noua omnia quae Chriſtus non docuit, iure damnamus, quia fidelibus via Chriſtus eſt, Si igitur Chriſtus non docuit quod docemus, etiam nos id deteſtabile iudicamus, that is. We do ryghtly condemne all newe thynges whiche Chriſte hath not taught, becauſe Chriſte is the waye vnto the faythfull. If therfore we teache that whiche Chriſt hath not taught, we iudge it deteſtable.

Felix the Biſhop writteth. Nemo conſuetudinem rationi et veritati praeponat, quia conſuetudinem ratio et veritas ſemper excludunt, that is. Let no mā preferre cuſtome before reaſon and truth, becauſe reaſon and truth do alwayes exclude cuſtome.

Saint Hierome writing vpon theſe wordes. Dominus numerabit quādo ſcribet populos. Iſte natus eſt ibi, or as the Septuaginta interpreters doth tranſlate.Pſa •
Dominus narrabit in ſcripturis populorū, Septuagīta. 18. et principū eorū qui fuerūt in ea. that is. The Lord ſhall cauſe it to be written & preached among the pleople, that he was borne there. Se (ſaith S. Hierome) what the Prophet ſayth, they which were (ſayth he) and not which be: wherby he ſignifieth that what ſoeuer other thyng ſhalbe ſayd or taughte (excepte the Apoſtles and their doctrine) maye he cut of and haue no authoritie, yea although he be neuer ſo holy, neuer ſo eloquent, yet he commyng after the Apoſtles, hath no authoritie.

Origene writing vpon the Prophet Ezechiel. Nullū imitemur (inquit) et ſi volumus imitari quēpiā, Ezech. 19. propoſitus eſt nobis ad imitandū chriſtus Ieſus, deſcripti ſunt actus Apoſtolorū, et Prophaetarū geſta de ſacris voluminibus agnoſcimus, Ho •
Illud exē plar firmū eſt, Illud propoſitū ſolidū: ꝙ qui ſequi cupit, ſecurus ingreditur, that is, Let vs follow none (ſaith he) and if we will folow any, Ieſus Chriſt is ſet before vs to followe: the actes of the Apoſtles are written, we knowe the doynges of the Prophetes out of holy bookes, this example is firme and ſure, this purpoſe is ſounde, whiche who coueteth to followe, doth go ſafely.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: In the true church there be no ſciſmatikes, and they be ſciſmatickes whiche doo forſake the old church of Rome and make to them ſelues new conuenticles & congregations, but you haue forſaken the Churche of Rome and made your ſelues a new Churche Ergo, you be ſchiſmatikes.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: There be ſome phantaſticall men, whiche theſe many yeares haue not, neither yet do communicate with any church, for in all thinges & perſons they finde ſome want, but in thē ſelues only they find nothing to be accuſed. And therfore they cō ceiue and imagine a maruelous forme of a church, which vnleſſe they do perceiue to be conſtitute in ſome places according to their minds, they do contend, yt there is yet no true Church of Chriſt in the world. But they ſeme to thē ſelues to haue iuſt cauſes of ſchiſmes. They will not cōmunicate with our Churche, becauſe the doctrine of the miniſters of ye church doth not as yet ſeme pure, cleane, & ſpirituall enough. They cōplain in ſome churches, that there are very many & diuers rites vſed,Rites. 20. & alſo they deſire to haue rigor & ſeueritie of diſcipline, & a very exquiſit puritie of life, for they do feare, leaſt they ſhould be polluted & defiled with the cōpapanie of certaine perſons. Many do forſake the church, through the offēces & vices of ſome miniſters, of which nomber the Anabaptiſts are: but this is no iuſt cauſe to ſeparate them ſelues from the church. Yet ther be certain iuſt cauſes, wherfore the godly and faithfull may ſeparate them ſelues from the companie of the wicked men, in whiche not onely the lawfull vſe of the Sacramentes is corrupted, but alſo the ſincere doctrine is adultered.

div.head: ¶ Cauſes wherfore ſchiſme ought not to be made, firſt not for the diuerſitie of doctrine.
div.p:
In primis no ſchiſme ought to be made for diuerſitie of doctrine. For cōcernyng doctrine, it is exerciſed partly in certayne and ſure determinations, of which ſorte are the articles of the faith, and the neceſſarie and true ſentences of the Scriptures, whiche if they be agreablie, purelie and ſimplie taught in the Churche, it is ſufficient, although there be none other ornamentes or decking ſhewes. Irenaeus ſaith. Cum vna & eadem fides ſit. et cet. that is, for ſo much as there is one onely fayth, neither he that cā ſpeake much of it ſpeaketh more than behoueth hym, nor he that ſpeaketh litle doth therfore diminiſhe it. Therfore ſeyng the doctrine of the Miniſters in the Churche expoundeth thoſe thynges whiche are of the Scripture, of the true and ſincere fayth, what more haue thoſe ſchiſmatikes to require. Doctrine is partly exerciſed in ye dayly expoſition of the Scriptures, and in applying the ſame to tymes, place, and matter. In expoundyng hath bene alwayes a
maruelous varietie and diuerſitie, but yet no wiſe man therfore hath ſeuered him ſelfe from the Churche. For it happeneth oftentymes, that two or three or mo do expounde one place not a like, but diuerſely. One maketh it darcker,To tyme place and perſons. 21▪ an other man maketh it playner, the one hitteth the marke, the other doth not touche it fullye, one man applieth the place whiche he intreateth verie aptly, an other man hath not the like dexteritie in applying the Scriptures: Yet he ſpeaketh nothyng contrary to fayth and charitie, but vttereth all thinges to edification. Through this diuerſitie no man may take occaſion to ſwarue and go from the Churche, for all godly men do allowe all thinges, and do retayne that whiche good is. The learned diſdayne not the ſermons of them that be leſſe learned: Agayne, the vnlearned do not enuie them that be better learned, neither their gifts, neyther they diſdayn to learn perfecter things, nor do condemn the lerned ſermons of the lerned preachers, but they prayſe God in them.

Auſten ſayth. Quiſquis ſcripturas diuinas vel quamlibet earum partē intellexiſſe ſibi videtur. et cet. that is. Whoſoeuer thincketh, yt he vnderſtādeth the holy ſcriptures or any part of them,
〈1 paragraph〉
ſo that by the vnderſtanding of them he do not edifie to double charitie of God and mā, he hath not ye vnderſtood them. But whoſoeuer ſhall gather ſuch a ſenſe out of the ſcripture, that may profite to the edifieng of the ſaid charitie, and yet doth not ſpeake that thing, whiche he when he readeth doth meane, is not deceyued with any daunger, nor doth vtterly ſpeake a falſhood. He ſaith alſo ſhortly after. Corrigendus eſt tamen. et cet. that is. He muſt be admoniſhed and taught. More profitable it is not to forſake the true way, left by accuſtoming to go out of the way, he be compelled to go in a froward and peruerſe way. Therfore if the interpreter ſhall in any place groſſely erre, he that is better learned may admoniſhe him brotherly, but he may in no wiſe make a ſchiſme.

div.head: ¶ Secondly no ſchiſme ought to be made for the diſordered life of the Miniſters, nor for the impure life of any other perſon.
div.p: If the Miniſters haue vices and infirmities, and yet be faithful in teaching, aduertiſing, exhorting, accuſyng and comforting the people, and alſo if they do lawfully Miniſter the Sacramentes, no man hath iuſt cauſe therefore to forſake the Churche. The Lord ſayd in the goſpell. In cathedra Moyſi ſedent ſcribae & phariſaei. &c. that is. The ſcribes and phareſies ſit in the chaire of Moſes,Cath. Moſ. 22. therefore do you all thinges, that they commaunde you to keepe and to do, but do you not accordyng to their works, for they ſay and do not. Loe, the Lord ſaith: They ſay and do not. Therfore theyr life agreed not with their doctrine, yet bicauſe they ſate in the chaire of Moſes, that is, becauſe they preached the word of God truly and ſincerely, the Lord biddeth to receyue their ſincere doctrine, and to forſake their lyfe, not aunſweryng to their teachyng.To ſay and not to do. 23. Therefore God forbiddeth vs to make any ſchiſme for the vices of teachers. The Churches of the Prophetes and Apoſtles do make for this place, for Eſay and Ieremie accuſyng the maners of their tyme, did greatly inueigh agaynſt the corruption of doctrine and manners, neither dyd they lay vnto their charge light offences, but haynous and capital.

Eſay crieth out: A vertice capitis ad calcaneum vſque pedis nō eſt boni quidpiā. that is, from the crowne of the head vnto the ſole of the feete there is no goodnes. And yet he did not ſwarue from the Churche, nor made hym a newe Churche. thoughe he tooke diligente heede to keepe hym ſelfe cleane from all their impietie. How many vices and errours were in the companie of the verie Apoſtles of Chriſt? Did the Lord therefore departe from them? The Churche of the Corinthians was corrupted not onely in maners but alſo in doctrine. There were in it great contentions, factions, chydynges, certation and prophanyng of wedlocke. Beſide that many did communicate with prophane Sacrifices, they did alſo erreniouſly referre baptiſme to the vertue of man, they polluted the ſupper of the Lord with priuate and riotous banckettes, and iudged not well of the reſurrection.
But did the Apoſtles therfore departe from it, or commaunded others to departe from it?VVith bankets. 24. No, he affirmeth the ſame Churche to be an holy Churche, and greatly diſprouing their diſſētions, exhortyng al men to the vnitie of the Church, and to ſincere veritie.
They therfore vndoubtedly do erre, whiche reſtrayne them ſelues from that Catholicque congregation, in whiche although there be great errours of corrupt liuing, yet the doctrine is ſincere and pure.

div.head: ¶ Thirdly no ſchiſme is to be made for the diuerſitie of rites and ceremonies.
Obiectio.
div.p: Some obiect, ſaying, that there is not one forme and maner vſed in the baptiſing of children.One forme of baptiſing of children Likewiſe ſay they, in the Lordes ſupper, ſome receiue the Sacrament ſitting, ſome ſtandyng, ſome knelyng, ſome receyue it with their handes, ſome into their mouthes out of the Prieſtes handes, ſome receyue it often, ſome ſeldome, ſome neuer but once a yeare. Agayne they haue not one forme and maner of praying. How therfore can the ſpirit of vnitie and peace be in that Church, in whiche is founde ſo great diuerſitie? We do therfore (ſay they) iuſtly departe from you.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Do not theſe miſerable mē know, how great diuerſitie there hath alwayes ben in the rites (the vnitie of Chriſtes Catholique Churche neuertheles remaynyng vnſeparated? Socrates largely expoūdeth the diuerſitie of rites in the church. And amongs other things, he ſaith. Nulla religio eoſdem ritus cuſtodit. No religion kepeth like or the ſame rites, albeit they embrace one maner of doctrine: for they that be of one faith, do diſſent among thē ſelues about the ceremonies. And againe he ſaith. It would be a laborious, greuous & vnpoſſible worke to write all the rites of the churches vſed in cities and countreis. Irenaeus rehearſeth a great diuerſitie of churches in faſting and celebrating Eaſter.Celebrating Eſter 25. And afterward addeth. Et tamē nihilominus omnes iſti etiā cum in obſeruantia variarent. &c. that is. and yet neuertheles all theſe when they varied in their obſeruations, they were & be alwayes at peace within them ſelues and with vs. Did this diuerſitie of faſting breake the vnitie of faith? And agayn he ſaith when Policarpus came to the citie of Rome in the time of Anicetus, and had a litle controuerſie betwene them of certayne other things, they were forthwith reconciled, but of this pointe they did nothing contend among them ſelues.Policarpus 26. For neither Anicetus could perſuade Policarpus, not to obſerue thoſe things whiche he had obſerued with Iohn the diſciple of the Lord & other the Apoſtles with whō he was alwayes conuerſaūt, neither did Policarpus perſuade Anicetus not to obſerue ye cuſtome which he obſerued with thoſe elders whō he ſucceded. And notwithſtāding this diuerſitie, they had agrement betwene them. Thus farre Irenaeus. Therfore the primatiue Churche vſed a great libertie in vſing ceremonies, yet, ſo that it diſſolued not the bonde of vnitie.

Auguſtine ſaith. Nulla diſciplina eſt in his melior. &c. that is. There is no diſcipline better to a wiſe, graue, & Chriſtiā man (concernyng theſe ceremonies) than to do after that maner, as he ſhall ſee that Church to do to the which he ſhal happē to come: for that thing whiche is enioyned neither agaynſt the fayth nor agaynſt good manners, is to be counted indifferent and to be obſerued, as the company doth, among whom we liue and are conuerſaunt.

div.head: ¶ Fourthly, no ſchiſme is to be made for them, whiche do not worthily communicate the Lordes ſupper.
Obiectio.
div.p:
Blaſphemers. 27.You admitte all men indifferently to the Lordes table, whoremongers, dronckardes, couetous perſons, blaſphemers & other of that note, with whom the Apoſtle
forbiddeth to eate common meate, muche leſſe he doth graunt to receiue the bread of the Lord with ſuche. Therfore except ye will be polluted with the company of ſuch, it is neceſſary either not to come to ſuch a company, or els vtterly to flye from it.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p:
Paule the faithful ſeruant of Ieſus Chriſt,Iudas. 28. was not more rigorous than hys maiſter, who did admit Iudas to the holy table, whom he knew throughly, both inwardly and outwardly, and yet put him not backe, but he would haue repelled him, if he had knowen that the reſt of the Diſciples ſhoulde haue bene corrupted with his company. Iudas him ſelfe was polluted, for his minde & conſcience was corrupted, but the Apoſtles could not be defiled through an other mans infideliti. And therfore the Apoſtle Paule ſayth: Probet ſeipſum homo, & ſic de pane edat, et de poculo bibat.
〈◊〉 , 11. That is: Let a man proue him ſelfe, & ſo let him eate of the bread, and drinke of the cup. He byddeth euery man examine him ſelfe, and not to iudge an other mans ſeruaunt. If thou be taught in the faith, and dooſt woorthely partake of the Lords table, thou art not polluted with an other mans malice. Therfore thou haſt no iuſt cauſe to be ſeperated from the church, for that thou wouldeſt auoyde corruption, in which church thou ſeeſt euill men mingled with good men to be partakers of the Lordes ſupper. And if thou be ſeperated, thou plainly declareſt,
〈1 paragraph〉
that thou dooſt arrogantly partake with them whom Auguſtine deſcribeth in theſe woordes: Illi filii mali, qui non modo iniquitatum alienarum. &c. That is to ſay: Thoſe ill children, which not onely in the behalf of other mens iniquities, but alſo in the ſtudy of ſetting foorth their own contentions, doo affect and deſire either to drawe, or to deuide the weake people entangled with the boaſt of theyr name, being puft vp with pride, furious with heddines, deceitful with ſlaunders, troubleſome with ſedicions, leaſt they ſhould beſeme to lacke the light of truth, do pretend a ſhew of rigorous ſeuerity. And thoſe things which in the holy ſcriptures are commaunded to be done, to correct the faultes of the brothers with a certaine moderation, the ſincerity of loue being ſaued, and the vnity of peace preſerued, they vſurpe and driue to the ſacrilege of ſchiſme, an occaſion of diuiſion. Alſo in the two chapters following, he geueth this councel to quiet & peaceable wits, that as much as they may, they correct moderatelye that thing which they can, & that they may not, to ſuffer paciently, and that they be ſorye and lament it wyth charity, vntyll God hymſelfe eyther redreſſe them, or els in the latter day ſcatter the chaffe from the wheate.

div.head: Concluſio.
div.p:
To conclude with Ciprians authority concerning this matter, I wil alledge his words: Si videntur in eccleſia eſſe zizania. &c. If there ſeeme tares to be in the church, yet our faith and charity ought not to be letted or hindered, that bycauſe we ſee tares in the church, we ſhould therfore departe from the church, we ought rather to labour to be made the good wheate, that when the wheate ſhal be layde vp in the Lords barne,
〈1 paragraph〉
we may receiue fruite for our worke and labour. The Apoſtle in his epiſtle ſaith: In domo autem magna. &c. That is: In the great houſe there are not onely veſſels of gold and ſiluer, but alſo veſſels of wood and earth, and ſome to honour, and ſome to diſhonour.

Let vs endeuour our ſelues as much as we can, that we may be veſſels of gold and ſiluer. But it pertaineth to the Lord onelye to breake in peeces the earthen veſſels, to whom alſo the yron rod is geuen. The ſeruaunt cannot be greater thē his maiſter, neyther let any man thinke to chalenge to himſelf that thing, which god the father geueth onely to his ſonne, that he maye thincke him ſelfe able to purge the floore, and to fanne the chaffe from the wheate, or to ſeuer the tares from the wheate by mans iudgement. This is a proud obſtinacye and ſacrilegious preſumption, which a mad fury vſurpeth to it ſelfe. And whyleſt ſome men alwaies take the Lord to them ſelues, more then meeke iuſtice doth require, they
do periſh and go out of the church, and whileſt they do extoll them ſelues proudly, they being blinded with their owne pride, doo leeſe the light of the veritye. Hec Cyprianus.
The Lord Ieſu reduce againe the wādring ſhepe into the vnity of the church, and preſerue them, & further them to liue in vnity, quietnes, and peace.
Thus it is declared at the ful, wherfore ſchiſmes ought not to be made in the Church. Now wyl I make anſwer to your obiection, wherfore we departed from the Church of Rome.

We make a diſtinction betwene the old Churche of Rome, and the late newe Church. For the church of Rome at the beginning was holy and faithful, which the Apoſtolicall men and the Apoſtles them ſelues founded and buylded vpon the woord of God.

That church not onely lacked the ceremonies now vſed, but alſo wanted the decrees and conſtitutions, which the late new church leaneth and cleaueth vnto. That old church knew no Monarchie, nor that ruflyng court. Therfore we haue not gone, nor at any time wyl go from that primatiue church. But we doo not agniſe that new church of Rome, which affirmeth the Pope to be Chriſtes Vicar in earth, and that we ſhould obey his lawes. And where they ſaye, that the ſcripture hath his authority in the church of Rome, & that it is recited in their church, & that it is vſed in the diſtribution of the ſacramēt, the contrary may be ſhewed.
Firſt, they make ſubiecte the interpretacion of the ſcriptures vnto their ſee, and doo attribute all Iudicial iudgementes to the Biſhops of Rome. That Canon following is wel knowne.
All men muſt obſerue whatſoeuer the Pope decreeth and ordeineth foreuermore, and without gaynſaying.

Alſo the whole church through the world knoweth, that the holye churche of Rome hath right and authority to iudge of all thinges, and that no man maye iudge of his ſentence. Therfore he iudgeth alſo the ſcripture, expoundeth & wreſteth them after his own mynde.

But al men do ſee playnly, that they take away the natiue ſenſe, and do ſubſtitute a ſtraunge ſenſe vnto the ſcriptures, as I haue largelye declared before in my former Lectures, wher ye may reade & perceiue, that the late church of Rome is not the true church of Chriſt.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: By this meanes there ſhal be no church left in earth. For when the gouernors of the church do erre, what hope of the church remaineth? Or when the ſignes: markes of the church do not appeare, where is the church?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: God in the calamities of the church, in which the gouernours decline from the word and true worſhipping of God, reſerueth neuertheles vnto him ſelf in earth a church, which was defended and preſerued by certaine preachers and teachers, although they were in nomber very few.

The matter ſhal be made more playne by examples. In the time of Achaz king of Iuda,4. Regum. ca Ibidem. 2 Para. 28. when Vria the high prieſt wincked at idolatry, and the rulers and other prieſtes did not reſiſt it, the king ſhut the temple of the Lord, and tooke away the holy ſeate. And therfore the ordinary miniſtery of the woorde and ſacrifices ceaſed. But neuertheles ther was an holy church in the kingdome of Iuda, in which no doubt Eſay and other godly men taught, as it were extraordinarily.

4. Reg. 22.21. 2. Par. 33.34.When Manaſſes raigned, ſincere doctrine, celebration of the ſacramentes, and circumciſion were vtterly taken away, and that ſame apoſtaſie continued vntyll the church was reformed of the moſt godly king Ioſia: yet al this meane time prophetes were ſent, and the church of God was in Iuda, although the greater parte of the people with their gouernours, followed the impiety of Manaſſes.

In the kingdome of Iſrael, Hieroboam the king did put the Leuites, whyche
wer teachers and preachers of the law of the Lord, from the miniſtery, and placed prophane, and vnlearned prieſtes vnto the people, and founded newe and great churches, ſetting vp Idoles & Calues, a new worſhipping, new altars, and newe feaſtes, and by this meanes abrogated the true worſhipping of God, ſo that in Iſrael no external ſigne of Gods church appeared, and yet there is no doubt, but there was a notable church of God in Iſrael, to the conſeruation wherof the prophetes were often ſent.

Amos the ſecond of that name, being a prophet, a ſhephearde, or heardman of Tecoa, taught the true woord of God vnder Hieroboam.Amos. 1. et. 7. But Amaſia the hyghe prieſt ſaid thus vnto him: Go forthwith and get thee into the land of Iuda, & ther do thou prophecy, but in Bethel hereafter doo thou not preache,Bethel. 29. bicauſe it is the foundation and temple of the king.

In the time of Achab, who ſucceded al the kings before him in impiety, who alſo added the abhominable worſhipping of Baal, vnto Hieroboams impiety and apoſtaſie, and had ſet vp al maner of ſuperſtitions, idolatries, and ſacrileges, and cruelly perſecuted the ſincere word of God in the Prophets, there was found notwithſtanding in Iſrael a noble and cleare church of God.

Helias the great and moſt excellent prophet of God, fleing into deſert,3. Reg. 19. for the foule apoſtaſy of the people from God, hid him ſelfe in dennes, and being aſked of the Lord what he did there, anſwered: Zelo quodam zelatus ſum pro domino deo exercituū, quod filii Iſrael faedus tuū dereliquerūt, aras tuas diruerūt, et prophaetas tuos occiderunt,, et ego ſolus relictus ſum, et quaerunt animam meam, vt tollant eā. That is, I haue bene very zelous for the Lord God of hoſtes. For the children of Iſrael haue forſaken thy couenant, broken downe thine altars, and ſlayn thy prophetes with the ſword, and I alone am left, and they ſeeke my lyfe alſo to take it away. But he was ſent againe into the land, from whence he fled, God ſpeaking theſe wordes vnto him: Reliqui mihi in Iſraele ſeptem millia virorum, quorum genua nunquam curuata ſunt ante Baal, neque os oſculatum eſt eum. That is I haue left vnto my ſelfe ſeuen thouſand men, whoſe knees haue neuer bowed to Baal, nor their mouthes kiſſed him.
Loe, this great prophet thought that he was left alone in Iſrael, but he heareth that ſeuen thouſand holy men were reſerued of God, which ſerued Baal wt no external worſhipping.
Who knoweth not, but that the prophet by the number of ſeuen thouſande, ment an infinite number of people which were circumciſed into the couenaunt of the e • ernal God?Seuen thouſand. 30.
Theſe men lacked not fayth, and therfore they did not lack doctrine, although it was not common & ordinary, nor ſemed to the prieſtes of Baal to be catholick.

But vndoubtedly they lacked ſacrifices, bicauſe when lawfull ſacrifices were not exhibited, they would not be partakers of vnlawfull ſacrifices. Notwithſtanding they wer not deſtitute of theſe thīgs that were ſignified by theſe ſimboles or ſacraments, and were partakers by faith of al the giftes of God.

div.head: Now to the Romiſh Church.
div.p: In like maner, after the biſhop of Rome had corrupted & oppreſſed the church of God, yet it was not extinguiſhed through ye whole world: neither did ye holy miniſtery of the word & true worſhipping of God ceaſe or fayle among al men. For ther haue bene found many men diſperſed through the whole world, which neuer allowed the Pope nor his adherentes.

God ſent almoſt in euery age (euen from the beginning of popery) graue, godly and learned men, which conſtantly required the church to be purged from all corruptions, teaching the true doctrine and the true vſe of the ſacraments. But when pure reformation could not be obtayned, yet there was found a continual deſire of puritie.

Furthermore, the Lord without doubt could haue kept to him ſelfe a copious
and great church, aſwel vnder the papiſme, as vnder Machumetes religion: For who iudgeth that ther remaineth no members of the church of God, throughout all Aſia and Africa?

We ſee, that it hath happened through the great bounty of God, that like as circūciſion was geuen in times paſt to the people for a ſigne of the couenaunt of God, in the middeſt of their apoſtaſy: Euen ſo alſo we now ſe, that holy baptiſme is geuen to the Chriſtians for a ſeale of remiſſion of ſynnes, and of the inheritance of the ſonnes of God.

Furthermore (that we may omit other thinges) was it not receiued for a very certainty by a general conſent, that al the cōmaundements wer geuen very perfectly and briefly in a ſhort ſumme? And that in the lords praier there is geuen a verye perfect forme of praying to god? And in the Symbole of the Apoſtles, that ther is contained a very perfect rule of our faith?

The .xii. articles haue bene accuſtomed to be recited almoſt to all that departe out of this world, as the very perfect rule of our faith. Neither is it to be doubted that the mercyful god hauing compaſſion on them that were oppreſſed, hath touched with his heauenly grace the harts of the liuing, and of the dead, and by the holy ghoſt hath taught them, that Ieſus Chriſt the ſonne of god, pardoning all their ſyns, hath ſanctified the ſoules of al faithful, and hath tranſlated them vnto eternal life.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: Be al our forefathers yt wer before this time of the light of ye goſpel, cōdemned?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: It happeneth many times, that they to whom it was not geuen in all their lyfe time to iudge wel of religion: it was graunted them at the laſt houre, and being at the point of death, did perceiue, that the abuſes which thei had bound them ſelues vnto before, were vaine and pernicious, which thing vndoubtedlye happened to Bernard, Franciſcus, Dominicke, and to other fathers. For when they liued in the foundation that is in Chriſt, although they had inuented many ſuperſtitions, they might notwithſtanding be ſaued.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: We do not reade, that in the time of the Biſhops and prophets of the Iewes church, the rulers of the faithful, or the faithfull them ſelues did decline from the biſhop, or from the vniuerſal church, and inſtituted new ſacrifices, as you now a daies do, declining from the biſhop of Rome, yea from kings and Emperors, and from the vniuerſal church to your ſelues.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: It appeareth, that the fathers before the comming of Chriſt, for the cauſe aboue written (the temple being prophaned with idolatry) did not ſeeke newe places for their ſacrifices,Leuit. 17. Deut. 12. for it was not lawful to do ſacrifice without the limites of the temple of Hieruſalem: neyther for any other cauſe did the people of Iſrael (being holden in the bondage of Babylon. 70. yeares) offer no ſacrifices. Notwythſtanding it is moſt certaine, that the holy and true worſhippers of god did ſeperate them ſelues from the worſhipping and ſacrifices vſed againſt the woorde of god. The lawes being fulfilled of the Lord, and abrogated by the Lord, the Apoſtles manifeſtly declined not onely from the Byſhop and the Church of Hieruſalem, but alſo they gathered a new church vnto Chriſt by the preaching of the goſpel, and by the adminiſtration of the ſacraments, which church is deſcribed in the Actes of the Apoſtles.
To conclude, there be three kindes of ſchiſmes.

list.item: 1. Apoſtatical.
2. Hereticall.
3. Schiſmaticall.

div.head: Apoſtatical. 1.
div.p: Apoſtatical ſchiſme is that, by the which through hatred of the Chriſtiā faith and by mere impiety and contempt of God, the Athei with their wicked Lucian & Iulian Apoſtata do go from the Orthodoxe and Catholicke ſayth, and from the communion of the faithful: and wickedly do taunt and blaſpheme the chriſtian verity, and do ſcorne and perſecute the very true church of god.

div.head: Heretical. 2.
div.p: That defection is hereticall, the whiche Valentine, Marcion, Arrius, Manicheus, Artemon, and ſuch like proud, bold, ſtiffnecked and wicked men, either forſaking or wreſting the ſcriptures, do contemne and ſpurn it, or els do deny, ſubuert and oppugne the moſt ſure articles of the faith, and ſound opinions of the church, and do affirme & ſet vp new opinions, and by this means do build them heretical churches, and do go away from the true Orthodoxe and catholicke church.

div.head: Schiſmaticall. 3.
div.p: Schiſmatical is ſuch as was the ſchiſmes of the Donatiſtes, which ſeparated them ſelues from the true Churche of god vnder the pretence of a more abſolute life, and a more perfect holines. The two firſt ſchiſmes are very abhominable and wicked, and alſo the third cannot by any meanes be defended. But none of theſe can be iuſtly imputed vnto vs declining from the Romiſh church, for that departing is without al blame, which is not from a true church, but frō a falſe church, not from the people of god, but from the perſecuters of the people of god, not frō the articles of the faith and ſound doctrine of the church, but from errours which darken the articles of the faith, and from the wicked traditions of men, which ſpeſially is not don by any lightnes, but by neceſſity, not for the deſire of innouaciō but for true religions ſake, and to recouer the true faith, according to the teſtimonie of the eternal verity, that leauing the felowſhip of darknes, we may be gathered againe in true light, placed with Chriſt and al his members. So we at thys day haue forſaken that Romiſh Sea ful of falſe doctrine and idolatrye, and flowing wt the innocent bloud of martyrs, and haue embraced the Euangelicke & Apoſtolike doctrine. And ſo Chriſt him ſelfe being head of the Church which is the commmunion of al ſaintes beleuing in Chriſt.

Thus I haue long troubled you with my tedious and prolixe doings, before the entry into the text, deſiring you of pardon and pacience, and to take in good parte theſe foure general lyms, which I haue diſcourſed vnto you, and by gods grace, I wil enter at my next comming into this place, into the text, in the mean time I commit you to the eternal god, to whom be praiſe for euer.

div.head: The Text. 1.
div.p: THe moſt part of writers are wont to deuide the interpretation of the ſcripture into a litteral ſēſe and into a ſpiritual ſenſe. Againe, they deuide the ſpiritual, into a tropological, allegoricall and anagogical ſenſe.
They cal that literal, which is vnderſtande according to the Grammatical ſenſe and the proper ſignification of the words.

This maner of interpreting muſt alwaies be firſt ſought out, and frō
it, it is not lawful to ſwarue in waighty diſputacions.

The knowledge therof commeth out of the rules of Grammer, Logicke, and Rhethoricke, and alſo of the knowledge of the Phraſes, and of cuſtomed ſpeeches of the ſcriptures. And this litterall ſenſe is called properly, the text.
That is called a ſpiritual interpretation, when an other thing is ſignified, than the words do ſimply importe.

Tropologia (which hath the firſt place in ſpiritual interpretation) is that in which are noted ſuch things that pertain to maners, & to the framing of mans life, and it is called a moral ſenſe. An example. Out of the ſtory of Loth being dronke, it is gathered, how much to be deteſted dronkennes and ſurfets are in al ages, but chiefly in old age, and alſo what horrible wickednes doth follow dronkennes, for ſhe is neuer alone, without ſome enormity following.

Allegoria, is that, in which actes or ſentences are otherwiſe vnderſtoode, than the wordes do ſound, and be applied and conferred wyth other things, which haue a certaine ſimilitude or analogie with them, but ſpecially with thoſe things which concern Chriſt the head, or the church his body. Of this ſorte the moſt part of thoſe thinges, which in times paſt were done of the holy fathers, are applied to theſe things, which long after were accompliſhed in the Goſpel by Chriſt, or by the Church, and it is manifeſt, that both theſe do wel agree together.
Eph. 5.The coniunction of man and woman is declared, to conteine a great ſacrament of the loue, wherwith Chriſt loueth the church.

Anagoge, is a maner of expounding the ſcripture, wherin, biſides the ſignification of the words, ſome thing is affirmed, pertaining to the heauenly glory to be looked for after this life, & pertaining to the miſteries of the Trinitie, or of the diuine nature As if one would ſaye: The City of Hieruſalem repreſented vnto vs the kingdom of heauen How apt theſe definitions and this diuiſion are, I wyl declare hereafter. But firſte I wil euidently ſhew, wherof they, which made theſe diſtinct intepretations, haue taken occaſion of this partition.

The fathers, aſwel Greekes as Latines, haue ſomewhat intreated of ſpiritual interpretation, which things theſe diuiders, reading wythout iudgemēt, either haue not wel vnderſtand them, or els vnfaithfully haue abuſed thoſe things that wer faithfully and wel ſpoken.

Eccle. hiſt. li. 2. Cap. 17.Euſebius declareth, that ther wer certain men called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is to ſay, ſuppliantes, which were wholy occupied in the perpetuall contemplation of diuine thinges, and that they did ſo interprete the ſcriptures, that they gaue them ſelues wholy to allegorical expoſitiō. For the whole law (ſayth he) ſemed to them to be like to a liuing beaſt, conſiſting of bodye
and ſoule: ſo in this law they called the letter it ſelfe, and thoſe things that were ſignified by the letter, the body: but the ſpirituall, ſecrete and inuiſible ſenſe, hidden in the letter, they call it the ſoule. Thus much Euſebius·
But what maner of making of Allegories was at that time, it is euidently inough ſhewed in diuers woorkes of Philon,Eccleſ. hier. 2. and chiefelye in the two bookes of the Allegories of the law.

And ſo are certayne things read of Anagoge in Dionyſius (if at the leaſt it were Dionyſius woorke) which thinges are applied to the interpretation of the ceremonies, which were than vſed in the adminiſtration of the ſacraments.

Origen iudged, that euery thing in the ſcripture might aptly be expounded by an Allegorye and Anagogicallye, and hee brought into the ſcholes and churches a marueilous boldnes, for other men ſo to doo He writeth moſt plainly of this in his commentaries, whom certayne other Greke writers did imitate and follow.

Among the latine authours, Hierome tooke the like out of the Grecians ſtorehouſe, as it appeareth in diuers places of his workes. For he writing vpon Amos, ſayth: Debemus ſcripturam ſanctam, In Amos. 4. primum ſecundum litteram intelligere. &c. That is: VVe muſt vnderſtande the holye ſcriptures, firſt according to the letter, doing what thinges ſo euer are commaunded, pertayning to manners, ſecondly, per allegoriam, that is, ſpirituall vnderſtanding, and thirdly, per anagogen, that is, pertayning to the bleſſednes of things to come.

Agayne he writeth, praecipitur nobis Salomone dicente. &c. It is commaunded vnto vs (Salomon ſpeaking it.)Prouerb. 2. But write thou three times in counſel and knowledge, that thou mayeſt aunſwer the word of truth to them which propound vnto thee. &c. There is (ſaith Hierome) a tripple deſcription and rule of the ſcriptures in our hartes.
The firſt is, that we vnderſtand them according to the Hiſtory, the ſecond, according to the Tropologie, the third, according to the ſpiritual vnderſtanding.
In the Hiſtory, the order of thoſe thynges whych are written, is obſerued.

In the Tropologie we riſe from the letter, to greater thynges, and what ſo euer hathe bene carnallye done in the former people, wee doo interpreate it morallye, and doo turne it to the wealth of our ſoules.

In the ſpirituall contemplation, we paſſe ouer to higher thynges, we leaue earthlye thynges, and we diſpute of the bleſſedneſſe of thynges to
come, and of heauenlye thynges, that the meditation of the life preſent, may be a ſignification of the bleſſednes to come. Thus muche ſayth Hierome.
Lib de vtili. credendi. c. 3.But Auguſtine writeth otherwiſe. For he declareth, that the ſcripture is expounded foure maner of wayes.

Lib. imperfe. de geneſ. ad literam. c. 2. 2. Samuel. 21. Math. 12The firſt, according to the hiſtory, that is, when it is taught what is written, and what is done, what hath not bene done, but onely hath bene written, as though it had bene done. As for example, when Chriſt alledgeth out of Samuell, that Dauid did eate the ſhew bread.

The ſecond is ſecundum
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , when it is declared, for what cauſe any thing was ſayd or done. As for example, Chriſt prohibiting the diuorce of the wife, vnleſſe it be for fornication, ſheweth prudentlye the cauſe, why the libell of diuorce was before permitted to the Iewes. He ſayd, Moſes permiſit enim vobis propter duritiam cordis veſtri, That is:Math. 19. Moſes ſuffered you to haue a byll of diuorce, for the hardnes of your hartes.

The third he calleth ſecundum
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , in the which the congruency of both the teſtaments is ſhewed.

The fourth is (ſayth he) ſecundum allegoriam, when it is taught, that thoſe thinges which are written, are not to bee taken according to the letter, but are figuratiuely to be vnderſtand (as for example) Saynt Paule declareth,1. Cor. 10. that the hiſtory of Exodus was an allegorie of the chriſtian people, and that all thynges happened to the Fathers in a figure.
Hereby it came to paſſe, that ſome men haue taken in hande whole hiſtories, yea whole bookes to be expounded after theſe diuers wayes.
Ruffinus, (as witneſſeth Genadius) expounded the benediction of Iacob vpon the Patriarches, in three maner of ſenſes, that is, hiſtoricall, moral, and miſticall.

But after that time, boldnes to expound the ſcriptures diuerſe waies grew more and more. For ſome men ſhameleſly attempted to interpret by allegories and anagogies what thing ſo euer is written in the ſacred ſcriptures: and not onely the hiſtories (in which it is often times done wyth a grace) but alſo the preachings and diſputations of the Prophetes and Apoſtles, the preceptes alſo and promiſes, in the which there can be no digreſsion (without perill) from the ſimple grammatical ſenſe.

But now I wyll ſhew, what ought to be iudged of theſe diuers formes of interpretations, and wyl alſo declare, how the ſayinges of the holy fathers are to be vnderſtand. I wyl intreate orderly of euery one, and firſt of the litterall ſenſe, next of the tropologicall, then of anagogicall, and laſt of the allegorical.

The literal ſenſe (which otherwiſe is called hiſtorical or Grāmatical) ought firſt to be ſought out as ye moſt nobleſt & chefeſt ſenſe, foraſmuch as it alone bringeth forth perſpicuous & euident ſentences It is only apt to frame argumentes by which the doctrines of religion are confirmed, it alone geueth neceſſary probations, where out of the allegoricall and anagogicall ſenſes onely probable and apparant aſſertions are brought.

It is not lawfull at any time to leaue the ſimple and natiue ſenſe of the wordes, vnleſſe there be figures in the wordes, or the ſentence it ſelf taken grammaticallye, do ſignifie ſome abſurditie, for the which cauſe it is nedefull to flye to the allegoricall interpretation, wherof I wyll ſpeake hereafter.
VVherfore I would gladly haue men to iudge, that he doth well and wiſely, which exerciſeth himſelf diligently in labouring to attaine the literall and grammaticall ſenſe.

That maner of interpreting which Auguſtine woulde haue to bee done per
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , ought vtterly to be referred to thys kynde: for in it there is no digreſſion made from the Grammaticall ſenſe, but onely the cauſe of the dede, or of the woorde being expounded, the ſentence is made more plaine and open.

For in all interpretation of euery kinde of writing, the ſame is moſt neceſſary to be done: for oftentimes it is expedient, that we ſet before our eyes the intent of the writer, and to be ſhewed as it were with pointing of the finger, to what end the oration tendeth, why it is ordayned, and how great weight euery part hath.

Furthermore the other kind of intepreting which Auguſtine calleth ſecundum
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , can not be ſeparated from the Grammaticall interpretation, for it is not like vnto an allegorie (as ſome do ſuppoſe.) For analogia, is none other thing than a certaine collation and conference, wherin what ſoeuer haue bene eyther done or ſayd in the old Teſtament, are compared with thoſe things that are found to be ſpokē or done in the newe Teſtament. Of which ſort this is. If any man reaſoning of Iudas betraying his Maiſter vnto his enemies with a kiſse, which is a ſimbole or ſigne of amitie and frendſhip, doth ſaye, that he did the ſame which once did Ioab, who killed Amaza, while he feyned to kiſſe him.
Likewiſe if any man doth ſhewe, that the woordes of Chriſt or of the Apoſtle doe in all things agree with the wordes of Moyſes or of ſome other holy Prophet or worthy man.

Euery mā vnderſtandeth, that when this is done, nothing is chaūged in the Grāmatical ſenſe, but yt only a compariſon being made, and examples ſhewed to teach with al, ther is added an ornament and euidency to the ſentence, after ſuch a ſort as the Rhetoriciās ſomtimes are wont to ioyn
the actes of the Greeks or forayne nations, vnto geſtes of the Romanes.

Plutar. in. Paral.VVhich thing we ſee Plutarch and Valerius Maximus haue done very elegantly. Therfore we may wel call the intreating of theſe maner of examples in the holy ſcriptures argumentationem a typo.

To be ſhort, euery expoſition deduced out of Rhethorick or Logick, when it leadeth not from the ſimple ſenſe or meaning of the woords, it is iudged moſt aptly to pertaine to the literal or Grammatical ſenſe.

div.head: Tropologia.
div.p: Tropologicall expoſition is not far from that ſenſe, which the wordes of the ſentence doo bring forth, but is an applying of that which is ſignified by the words, to the framing of mās life & maners. As for an example, when we reade the hiſtory of Loth being dronken, it is wel gathered per tropologiam, that we learne by it, that dronkēnes ought to be by all meanes deteſted and ſhunned.
Likewiſe, it is no hard thing to gather out of holye hiſtories and ſermons, thoſe things which induce vs to ſeeke after vertues, and to auoide vices.

Vvhoſoeuer wyl fruitfully reade holy hiſtories or ſermons, it is nedeful that he gather vp al the beſt ſayings and doings to the framing of his own priuate life, which thing Titus Liuius wiſely moniſhed in hys preface to the hiſtory of the actes of the Romanes.

Vvherfore this maner of interpretation is more rightly called moralis or Ethica, than Tropologica, For although this word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in Greke ſignifieth not onely 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is a figuratiue ſpeache, but alſo the life and maners of man▪ yet by a very long vſed cuſtome it repreſenteth vnto the hearers a figuratiue ſpeche, that by the name of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , they maye vnderſtand the ſentence, in the which a woorde is declined from the natiue ſignification.

How be it, the Apoſtle Paul had leuer haue thoſe thinges which are gathered to the ordering of life and maners to be noted with the names of inſtitution and correction. For he ſaith: Vtilis eſt ſcriptura ad inſtitutionem et correctionem, That is. The ſcripture is profitable to teache and to correct. And I pray you, why do we not heare and follow Paul, who is the beſt maiſter to teach, and to interprete diuine matters, rather than other men, which ſomtime dote in their interpretations?

div.head: Anagoge.
div.p: Anagoge ſemeth to be of more difficulty, but if we doo well expende and weygh it, Anagogicall interpretation vtterly agreeth wyth the Allegoricall interpretation, neither they are diſtinct, which to bee true I wyll proue both by the diſcription of them both, and alſo by the iudgement and ſayinges of the Fathers.

They call that an anagogicall interpretation when a ſentence of the Scripture is ſo expounded, that by going a litle from the firſt ſignification of the wordes, there may be ſomething gathered to be meant of the celeſtiall glory to be looked for after this life, or els ſome thing to be meant of the myſtery of ye Trinitie, and ſo a paſſing to be made from things viſible, to inuiſible things, from a darke ſpeach (as Paule ſayth) to ye cleere ſight of God. As Iohn diſputing of baptiſme,Iohn. 3. Coloſſ. 2. procedeth from water to the ſpirit. The Apoſtle alſo ſpeaking of our reſurrection with Chriſt, biddeth vs to looke onely vpon heauenly things, affirming that our life and conuerſation is in heauen. But you ſhall finde this kinde of interpretation to be very ſeldome, and rare in the Scriptures VVhat is an allegoricall interpretation, but that in which a deede or a ſentence is expounded by a new ſenſe, being ſomewhat remoued frō ye literall words? But in ſuch ſort yt ſomthing may be gathered of Chriſt or of the church, eyther of ye law or els of the goſpell, or els of the offices of fayth or of charitie?
Therfore it is manifeſt concerning the knowledge and maner of interpreting, that an allegorie and anagogie in all pointes do agree. And as touching the matter, there is a very ſmall difference.

Notwithſtanding it is no more neceſſary to put a difference betwene them, than it is nede to make a difference betwene an allegoricall interpretation, which is made of Chriſt, or of the glory of the celeſtiall citie of God, and betwene yt interpretation which is made of mā or of the church which is the earthly citie of God, or of any other matter.

But let vs weigh the ſayings of the fathers. Dioniſius after he had deſcribed the rites of baptiſme addeth,Eccl. hier. c. 2. yt he would expound them ſecundū anagogen. And yet that which he there writeth, ſauoureth an allegorye, and ought ſimply to be reduced to the order of an allegory, which thyng euery meane learned man may iudge.

Auguſtine plainly ioyneth and mingleth an allegorie with anagoge. for he ſayth. Quis ſit modus interpretandae allegoriae. &c. VVhat is the way and maner to interprete an allegorie, which is beleued to be ſpoken by wyſedome in the holy Ghoſt: whether it be ſufficient to fetch it from the elder viſible thynges vnto the latter viſible thinges, or ells vnto the affections and nature of the ſoule, or els vnto vnchaungeable eternitie?
In which words the two latter members do importe anagoge: yet neuertheles they are comprehended vnder an allegorie, when he affirmeth, that he ſpeaketh of interpreting an allegorie.

Hierome knowledgeth but three maners of interpreting, that is,ad Hedibia. Hiſtoricall, Tropologicall, and Theoricall, or iuxta intelligentiā ſpiritualē: for he vnderſtode and allegorie and anagoge in like ſort, which he iudged not to be diſtincte.
He alſo in his commentaries expoundeth ſome things, as it were per anagogen, which (if we wil narrowly vew them) we ſhall finde them to be intreated per allegoriam.

Eſay. 1.I wil bring forth one or two examples, Cognouit bos poſſeſſorem ſuum, et Aſinus praeſepe domini ſui. That is. The Oxe knoweth his owner, and the Aſſe knoweth his maiſters crib. Hierome ſayth: Bos iuxta Anagogen refertur ad Iſrael, qui legis portauit iugum, et mundum animal eſt: Aſinus peccatorum onere praegrauatus, gentium populus accipitur. That is: That Oxe per anagogen, is referred to Iſrael, which caried the yoke of the law, and it is a cleane beaſt: the Aſſe being oppreſſed wyth burthen of ſinnes, is taken for the Gentiles.

Eſay. 1.Agayne, vpon the wordes of the Prophet, Derelinquetur filia Sion, ſicut vmbracula in vinea. That is: The daughter of Sion ſhall be forſaken, as the ſhadow in the vineyard. Hierome ſaith: Iuxta anagogē, vinea dei et pomorum paradiſus homo appellari poteſt, cui ſi mens praefuerit. &c. That is, The vineyard of God, and the pleaſaunt garden of fruit may be called man, in whom if the ſpirit and mind doth rule, he hath God for the keeper af the ſpirite and minde, but if ſinne and vices doo take a praye of vs, as it were of certain wilde beaſtes, we are forſaken of God being our keeper, and we ſhalbe all left deſolate.

He declareth, that theſe interpretations are made ſecundum anagogen, which if ye wyll diligently examine, ye ſhall perceiue that nothing is ſpoken of the life to come, or of the miſterye of the Trinitye, but of the life preſent, of the church, & of holy mens exerciſes. Therfore ye ſe that the allegorical ſenſe is ther onely ſimply to be conſidered, and no other diuers ſenſe.
It were an eaſy thing to bring foorth more examples out of Origene, whom Hierome ſemeth to haue diligently followed.

By theſe examples therfore it is euident, that Anagoge, and Allegoria be all one. And as much as it is, ſo euery man may perceiue, that ther be not foure ſenſes of the ſcripture, but onelye three, according to Hieroms iudgement, and the cenſure of other holy fathers, that is to ſay, the firſt is litteral, which is otherwyſe called Grammaticall or Hiſtoricall, the ſecond is Tropological (which ſome haue leauer cal morall) but the Apoſtle doth more rightly terme it, inſtitutionem & correctionem, & the third is Allegoricall, whych they call ſpirituall, miſticall, and ſpeculatiue.
But a worde or two more agaynſt our aduerſaries, concernyng the literall ſenſe.

div.head: Expoſtulatio.
div.p:
I do greatly diſſent from the opiniō of them which iudge, that we may
attayne to the miſticall ſenſe without the vnderſtandyng of the ſimple letter, They do leane to this authoritie ſaying. Litera occidit, ſpiritus vero viuificat, that is, the letter killeth, but the ſpirit quickneth, wheras no letter killeth, but that onely whiche is peruerſly vnderſtood and violently wreſted, to that whiche is farre ſtraunge, from that whiche God the author meaneth. As for exāple. The phariſeis wreſted the good worckes whiche God commaunded in the old Teſtament, vnto vayne ceremonies. For when God had geuen the commaundementes of the law by Moſes, at the lenght he inferred this. Ligabis ea in manu tua, Deut. 6. & erunt immota ante oculos tuos. that is. Thou ſhalt binde thē in thy handes, and they ſhalbe alwayes ſet before thine eyes, of which wordes this is the meaning. Let my preceptes be in thine handes that they may be accompliſhed in your worckes. Let them be before thine eyes, that thou mayeſt remember thē day and night.

The phariſies miſunderſtanding this, wrote the tene commaundemēts of the law in parchment, & to the end they might alwayes haue them in ſight, they wrapte thē vp in a garland, and bound them vpon their foreheades Here the letter killed, becauſe the phariſies corrupted the meaning of God. But if the letter be well vnderſtood, there is meant an other thyng, And we ſhall perceyue a great congruencie betwene the miſticall worde and the letter of the law. VVhich thing I proue thus.

VVe read in the old law, that Pharaos magicall men, when Moſes & Aaron wrought miracles before their faces, (God working by thē) ſaid. Vere digitus dei eſt hic. Indede, this is ye fingar of god.Exod. 8 Luk. 11. we read alſo in the goſpel, that chriſt ſaid. Ego in digito dei eiicio demonia. that is, I caſt out deuils by the fingar of God. VVhat other thing can we vnderſtand in the olde and newe lawes here by the fingar of God, than the holy ghoſt and the power of God? as Saint Baſill interpreteth, beſide many other learned fathers.
Likewiſe as it is ſayd before, where Chriſt commaundeth,Math. 5. in the Goſpell to cut of and caſt away eye, hande and foote, if they offende vs.
Saint Hierome ſaith, that they be miſtically ſignified, which are ioyned vnto vs in kindred, familiaritie and frendſhip, who all in reſpect of loue toward Chriſt, are to be reiected and contemned.
How could any miſterie here be gathered, excepte Chriſt had ſignified the ſame in the better by a parable?

Origene gathered out of theſe wordes an higher myſterie, interpreting by the eye to be vnderſtande the Biſhop and Prieſt in the Churche, who ought to haue reſpect to ſaluation of all perſons, by the hand he vnderſtandeth the deacon, becauſe he is a miniſter, by the foote the people.
And all theſe ought to be caſt of, if they behaue not them ſelues rightly in matters of fayth.

For aſmuch then as the myſticall ſenſe is builded vpon the letter as vpon a foundation the letter is not to be reiected. Notwithſtanding there be infinite places in the holy Scriptures, which if they be drawē to miſticall ſenſes, they do rather kill than edifie, as for example, this ſentence. Ecce virgo concipiet & pariet filiū, & vocabitur nomen eius Emanuel, that is, beholde, a virgine ſhall conceaue and bring forth a ſonne, and his name ſhalbe called Emanuell. Theſe wordes ought to be none otherwiſe vnderſtand, but as the letter ſpeaketh: yet Saint Hierome maketh record of one, who did interprete this place, myſtically ſaying, that the virgine betokened the ſoule, beyng corrupt with no ſpotte of ſinne. This virgine bryngeth foorth Emanuel, yt is, the worde of God. This ſenſe is as fondly ſought out as it is farre fetched.

Let vs therfore take the literall ſenſe for the foundation, vpon whiche euery doctrine ought to be builte (whiche I ſpake by a ſimilitude) vnleſse any wilbe ſo fooliſhe, as to thincke, that we ought to caſt awaye the rudiments and alphabeticall letters, that we may the ſooner come to the ſtudy and knowledge of Philoſophie.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: The law and the letter is called of the holy and learned fathers ſometymes a type, ſometyme a figure. Ergo. &c.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: I graunt this to be moſt true, yea and I will ſay alſo, that it is ſometyme called Vmbra, a ſhadow. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , is a Greeke word, whiche ſignifieth the forme of ſome one thing, that is called in Latin Figura, a figure.

Nowe let vs vewe to what perſons and things types and figures in the law do pertayne. Saint Hierome, Origene, and all other holy fathers do affirme, the godly man Iob to be a type and figure of Chriſt, partly for his other excellent vertues, but ſpecially for his great patience, wherwith he did moſt conſtantly reſiste the deuill.
I pray you, what will you ſay of this type and figure? is it not a forme and repreſentation of Christ him ſelfe?
