To proue Chriſt her ſauiour, to make Chriſte a whole Sauioure of all that be or ſhall bee ſaued: I reaſoned after this maner. Either ſhee was a ſinner, or no ſinner. There is no meane, if ſhee were a ſinner, then ſhee was preſerued from ſinne by Chriſte: ſo that Chriſte ſaued her, and was her neceſſarie ſauiour, whether ſhe ſinned or no Now certayne authours (ſayd I) as Chriſoſtome, Theophilact, and other, writeth as though ſhe had ben ſome thyng faulty in her tyme. Alſo I ſayd, that certayne Scriptures ſtandeth ſome thyng to the ſame, vnleſse they be the more warely vnderſtanded. As theſe Scriptures. All haue declined, that euery mouth be ſtopped, and all the worlde is bounden in daunger to God. Agayn, all haue ſinned, and nede the grace of God. Alſo death paſſed through into all men and women, for aſmuch as al haue ſinned. But to theſe Scriptures I ſayd, it might be aunſwered, that the priuiledge of one or of a fewe doo not derogate or miniſhe the veritie of an vniuerſall expoſition in Scriptures. And as to ye doctours I ſayd, that other mo ſaith otherwayes, and for aſmuch as now it is vniuerſally & cōſtātly receiued & applied, that ſhe was no ſinner, it becommeth euery man to ſtand and agre to the ſame, and ſo will I (quod I) nor any man that wiſe is, wil do the cōtrarie:
But to my purpoſe, it is neither to nor from, to proue neither this nor that, for I will haue her ſaued, and Chriſt her Sauiour, whether euer ſhe was a ſinner, or no ſinner. And to that, (ſome ſayd) what nede you to ſpeake of this? I aunſwered, great nede: when men cannot be contented, that ſhe was a creature ſaued, but as it were a Sauioreſſe, nor nedyng of ſaluation, it is neceſſarie to ſet her in her degree, to the glorie of Chriſt, creatour and ſauiour of all that be or ſhalbe ſaued. Good authours haue written, that ſhe was not a ſinner: but good authours neuer wrote that ſhe was not ſaued, for though ſhe neuer ſinned, yet ſhe was not ſo impeccable, but that ſhe mighte haue ſinned, if ſhe had not bene preſerued. It was of the goodnes of God that ſhe neuer ſinned It had come of her owne ilnes, if ſhe had ſinned. There was difference betwixte her and Chriſt. And I will geue as litle to her as I can (doyng her no wrong) rather then Chriſt her ſonne and Sauiour ſhould lack any parcell of his glorie. I am ſure, that our Lady will not be diſpleaſed with me for ſo doynge, for our Lady ſought his glorie here vpon earth, ſhe would not defraude hym nowe in heauen, but ſome are ſo ſuperſtitiouſly religious, ſo prepoſterouſly deuoute towarde our Lady, as though there could not to much be geuen to her. Such are zeleous without knowledge and iudgement, to our Ladies diſpleaſure. No doubt, our Lady was throughe the goodnes of God, a good and a gracious creature, a deuoute handmayd of the Lord, indued with ſingular giftes and graces from aboue, whiche through the helpe of God ſhe vſed to Gods pleaſure, accordyng to her dutie, ſo geuyng vs enſample to do likewyſe: ſo that all the goodnes that ſhe had, ſhe hadde it not of her ſelfe, but of God the authour of all goodnes: the Lorde was with her fauourablie, and powred graces into her plentuouſly: as it is in the Aue Marie. The ſonne of God whan he would be come man to ſaue both man and woman, did choſe her to hys mother, whiche loue he ſhewed to her alone and to none other, of his benigne goodnes, by the whiche ſhe was the naturall mother of Chriſte: and through fayth in Chriſt, ſhe was the ſpirituall ſiſter of Chriſte, ſaued by Chriſt, bleſſed by hearyng Chriſtes worde, and kepyng the ſame. It ſhould not haue auailed her to ſaluation to haue bene his natural mother, if ſhe had not done the will of his heauenly father. By hym ſhe was his mother, by hym ſhe did the will of his father: She was the handemayden, he is the Lorde. The handemayden did magnifie her Lorde, the handmayden would that all ſhould magnifie the Lorde, to whome be honour and glorie. Amen.

Theſe be the words of that godly and conſtant preacher. But whither he conſidered and had a reſpect to the corrupte tyme, when he ſpake
theſe woordes, or els that he would geue no offence to the weakelynges not able to receyue as yet whole meate, he ſemeth in theſe woordes to graunt the ſcholaſticall diſtinction De duplici redemptione, id eſt, ſubleuatiua, & preſeruatina. The ſchole men ſay that Redemptio preſeruatiua, is more noble and more perfecte, then Redemptio ſubleuatiua. As for example. It is much better to preſerue a man from receyuing a wounde, then to geue him remedie after the wounde is geuen. So is it more noble and muche better to preſerue one that he fall not into ſinne, then to deliuer hym from ſinne after his fall Euen ſo the Virgine Marie, and none but ſhe, was redemed by Chriſt, Redemptione preſeruatiua, whiche farre excelleth Redemptionem ſubleuatiuam, wherwithall ſinners are redemed from ſinne. Thus reaſon the ſcholemen.
But if the Scriptures be well weyghed and vnderſtanded, it will manifeſtly appeare that none, no not the virgine Marie was exempted from Originall ſinne (Chriſt alway excepted)

Saint Paule writyng to the Romaines doth ſay.De fide ad petrum parte prima q. 24. Omnes in Adam peccauerunt & egent gratia Dei. All haue ſinned in Adam and want the grace of God. VVherupon it foloweth neceſsarily that Marie ſinned in Adam, and that Prima materia eius, was infected with the ſinne of Adā, and ſo corrupted in originall ſinne.

Secondly if Marie ſhould haue ben conceiued without Originall ſin, ſhe ſhould haue ben begotten Sine concupiſcentia, without luſt,De fide ad petrum. which Saint Auguſtine doth denie, his wordes be theſe. Holde ſtedfaſtly and doubt not by no meanes, that euery perſon whiche is conceiued by copulation of man and woman, is borne with Originall ſinne, and ſubiecte vnto death. And all that be borne with luſte of copulation, are conceyued with Originall ſinne. Then ſeyng that the virgine Marie was begotten by the copulation of father and mother, ſhe muſt nedes as other are, be begotten in Originall ſinne.

Thirdly if the virgine Marie ſhould be vtterly voyde of ſinne, Chriſt had not bene an vniuerſall redemer,3. diſt. queſt. 3 whiche to graunte were verie inconueniente. Therfore Chriſt was alſo her redemer and Sauiour, as ſhe ſingeth her ſelfe in her ſonge, ſaying. Et exultauit ſpiritus meus in deo ſalutari meo, and my ſpirite reioyced in God my ſauiour. Now redemption or ſaluation doth preſuppoſe ſinne, for none can be ſayd to be redemed or ſaued, except it were from ſome ſinne. The redemptiō whiche the ſcholemen call Preſeruatiuam, ſemeth more ſuttle then ſauerie.

Fourthly and finally, Aquinas writeth after this manner. Alius error fuit eorum qui dicunt, quod peccante Adam, Dominus aliquid incorruptum & non infectum in Adam conſeruauit, per quod natura humana ſeruari poſſet, & quod hoc idē transfuſum eſt ſine aliqua infectione ad beatā virginem, & exinde formatū eſt corpus Chriſti, hoc autē erroneū reputatur
propter duo, that is. There was an other errour, of whiche they ſay, that when Adam ſinned, the Lord preſerued ſome thyng incorrupt, and not infect in Adam, by the whiche the nature of man myght be ſaued. They alſo ſay, that the ſame thyng was transfuſed without any infection into the virgine Marie, and that of that, the body of Chriſt was fourmed and made. But this is erroneous for two cauſes, firſt, becauſe after this poſition, Chriſt ſhould not be the ſonne of the virgin, nor ſhould be borne of any ſtocke or linage but onely of Adam, for that part becauſe it remayned vncorrupte in the nature of man, ſhould be farre fet and ſtraunge from all other, beyng borne of Adam, and ſhould be proper and connaturall onely vnto Adam, as much as concerneth the firſt ſtate.

Secondly, becauſe the due order of ſignification ſhould be taken away, for as it was not decent, that any ſhould ſatisfie for Adam and his corrupt ſucceſsion, whiche were not of his ſtocke, ſo it had not ben mete that the ſonne of God ſhould haue healed by ſatisfaction, a nature infected, vnles he had taken that thing whiche before was infected. Therfore it is to be ſayd, that the fleſhe of Chriſt, as concerning beyng in the fleſh of the parentes, yea and in the virgine Marie, was infected with ſinne before it was taken. But in the very actuall takyng of the fleſh, it is purged from all infection, ſo that concernynge the fleſhe of Chriſte, there is founde no ſpot in it. Theſe be the wordes of Thomas. By whiche it appeareth that the fleſhe of the Virgine was infected with originall ſinne. He that will read more of this matter Pro & contra, Let him read Galatinum, in his booke, De arcanis Catholicae veritatis.

div.head: Democritus. 10.
div.p: DEmocritus was a philoſopher borne in a citie called Abdera, who receauing of his elder brothers the portiō of his fathers inheritaūce, being kindled wt the great deſire of knowledge of things, went through the greateſt part of the world. He returnyng afterward into his countrie, being in great penurie, gaue him ſelfe to the contēplacion of naturall things, in a certayne orchyard neare to the walles of his Citie.

It is reported, that he, what thing ſoeuer chaunced by fortune, or what ſoeuer he heard of the mutabilitie of things, fell into a maruailous laughter. And therefore by the figure, Antonomaſia, all diſsolute laughters be called Democriti.
At the laſt (as Cicero ſayth) he pulled out his owne eyes, and made him ſelfe blinde of purpoſe, that he might the more narowly and nearely ſearche out the ſecretes of nature.

He died at the age of .109. yeares He ſaid, that al things were made, Exatomis, and yt there were many worldes, and thoſe corruptible, he ſo excelled and profited in al kind of Philoſophie, yt he might haue ben called, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , ſiue quinquertio. For he attained to the knowledge of things naturall, morall, mathematicall, all the liberall ſciences, and to the connyng of all Artes.
His father was meruailous riche, for he made to the whole armie of the ſouldiours of kyng Xerxes, a ſolemne feaſt.

He had a very excellent ſaying, which is this: Cōueniētius eſt, vt parcitatē in tuo ſerues,
quam luxū in alieno: parcitas enim eſt remediū neceſsitatis vt medicina dānorū, that is. It is more conuenient to be ſparefull of thine owne, then to be prodigall of an other mans, for parcitie is a remedie of neceſsitie, euen as medecine is of hurtes.
Laertius writeth that there were ſixe Democriti.

div.head: Vincentius. 11.
div.p: THere were many of that name. But ye firſt Vincētius was a very godly mā, borne in Spain, & ſcholer to Sixtus Biſhop of Rome.

He ſuffered very cruell martirdome at Valēce in Spaine, with Valerius ye Biſhop of that citie, vnder Dacianus the preſident. In ſo much that being cruelly hādled in priſon with hunger, and noiſe of chaines, & bearing great yrons vpon his hands and necke, he ſuffered deadly puniſhmēt in all his limmes. VVhich martirdome ſ. Auſten declareth in a ſermō, ſaying: Magnū & admirandū ſpectaculum noſter animus caepit. &c.

Our minde conceaued a great and meruailous ſpectacle, and we ſaw with our inward eyes, not a cruell and pernitious pleaſure taken of trifles, as it is wont to happē in places appointed to behold games, but a very profitable and fruitfull pleaſure, when the paſsion of Vincētius was read. It cauſeth me to trēble, to behold the vnuinceable ſtomake of this martyr, ſtryuing with very ſharpe conflict of the fleſh againſt ye cruelty of Dacianus, and againſt the paines of death, and at length by the helpe of god ouercō ming al torments For Dacianus cauſed this godly man first to be racked and tormēted in his whole body in Equuleo, that is, a place made of burning plates, in likenes of an horſe, and thē his body ſo racked and rent, to be diuerſly wounded, and torne in peeces with cardes or hookes. And yt he might more cruelly vexe him, he made the tormētors to whip and beate him, with much more cruelty, as S. Auſten declareth.

Saint Auguſtin alſo in an other ſermon ſpeaketh of this Vincentius, after this ſorte. Bleſsed Vincentius was truly called Vincentius. For he moſt ſtrongly ouercame all the perils of death. He ouercame in words, he ouercame in paines, he ouercame in confeſsion, he ouercame in tribulatiō, he ouercame being burned, he ouercame beyng drowned, he ouercame
being aliue, he ouercame being dead. For when he was dead, it is ſayd, that angels ſpake thus vnto him: Agnoſce, O vincenti, quia pro cuius no mine vitiliter decertaſti. &c. Know thou, O Vincent, that he for whoſe ſake thou haſt manfully fought doth kepe a crowne prepared for thee in heauen, whiche hath made thee a conquerour in paynes.
His paſsion and noble Triumphes Prudentius hath expreſsed in very elegant verſes.
Saint Auguſtine alſo in many ſermons declareth, how much the martirdome of Vincentius is to be had in reuerence and prayſed.

This Vincentius, wherof mention is made in the Prelection before, was a French man borne, a Monke and Prieſt of a monaſterie in the Ile of Lirinenſe. He wrote two bookes, Contra omnes haereticos, he wrote a booke alſo, Pro antiquitate, & vniuerſitate Catholicae fidei. He liued in the yeare of our Lord .430. as Gennagius writeth.

There was an other Vincentius, whiche was a Frenche man alſo, a blacke frier. He wrore .iiij. great bookes, the firſt entitled, Speculū hiſtoriale, the ſecond, Speculū naturale, the third, Speculū morale, the .iiij. Speculū Doctrinale, beſide other workes, he liued in ye yeare of our Lord 1240

div.head: Aaron. 12.
div.p: AAron was the ſonne of Amram, he was Moſes brother. He was very eloquent the Oratour and interpreter of Moſes, he was the firſt high Prieſt called of God by Moſes to ye miniſterie of ye Leuitical prieſthood. He bare the type and figure of the high Prieſt Chriſt.Numb 12.

It is recorded, that he with his ſiſter Miriam murmured agaynſt his brother Moſes, and therfore prouoked the Lord agaynſt hym, he was let to enter into the land of promiſe, becauſe he was ſomewhat vnfaithfull at the waters of contradiction.

He had foure ſonnes. Ithamar, Eleazarus, Nadab and Abiud. VVhē he was .123. yeares of age, he died in the mount, Hor, an hill of the Idumeans. Ahorā, in Hebrue, is in Latin, Mons fortis, vel mons cantici ſeu laudis a Ranan, laudauit. A ſtrong hill, or an hill of ſinging or of prayſe.
Becauſe I haue made mencion of Aaron, being high Prieſt, I will geue you ſome notes, cōcerning his apparell and the ſignification therof.

There are noūbred nine kinds of the apparell belonging to the Prieſts: ſome noūber but eight, but Ioſephus reciteth tene. Firſt of all the Prieſts were waſhed with cleane water before they went to do Sacrifice, and then they did put on their holy garmentes. There was certaine apparell common to the high Prieſt and to the other Prieſtes.

Firſt the Prieſtes had lynnen breches to couer their priuities, whiche
breeches did reache from their loines, vnto their thighs, the higher part wherof was made firſt aboue the huckle bone, much like vnto our truſſed hoſe, that when they ſhould do ſacrifice, and draw or beare any burden, if they fel, the thing that ought to be cloſe, ſhould not be ſene. Then they put on a ſhort and ſtraight coate without ſleues, which ſat plain vp on the body, without plaite or wrinkle, and reached downe to the calfe of the legge.

Thirdly, they had a girdle which girded the ſame coate vnto them. This girdle was made of purple ſcarlet, fine linnen, and blew ſilke. The endes of the which girdle ſhould hang downe to the calfe of the leg, but in their miniſtery they caſt it vpon their left ſhoulder.
The fourth kinde of garment was a round cap, or a myter, which couered the head to the eares.

The fift maner of garment was the Ephod, whiche was the vtmoſt part. It was a roabe made of linnen. Suche a garment did Dauid weare when he daunced before the Arke. This Ephod was not much vnlike our Surplices.

Theſe fiue kindes of garments were common both to the high Prieſt and to the inferiour prieſtes. The other foure ſortes of garmentes were proper onely to the high prieſt. The firſt garmēt was called Megil, which was a broad garment, rēaching down to the heeles, made all together of blew ſilke, and was al whole, ſauing that it had two holes to put out the prieſtes head and his armes. It had beneath in the ſkirts .72. bels of gold, and ſo many Pomegranets of blew ſilke, ſo ſet, that betwene euery two bels was a Pomegranate, and betwene euery two Pomegranates a bell, which was done for this cauſe that when Aaron miniſtred, a ſoūd might be heard when he went into the holy place before the Lord. For if he had gone without this garment, they ſhould haue died.

The ſecond garment of the high prieſt was an Ephod, nothinge lyke the Ephod, mencioned before, for it was not linnen, but made of cloth of gold, and was girded vnto him, wherin was the breſt plate, with the .xii. ſtones, which was tied about with two chaines to two Onix ſtones, and beneth with two laces. In the two Onix ſtones were engraued the names of the twelue tribes of Iſrael vi. vpon the one ſtone, and ſix vpon the other, which two ſtones were vpon the ſhoulders of the Ephod.

The third garment was called, Rationale, whiche the Hebrewes call hoſen, which was the breſt plate of iudgement, ſo called, bicauſe the high prieſt could not geue iudgement without that on his breſt. It was made of gold, blew ſilke, purple ſcarlet and fine trimmed linnen. It was foure ſquare, and double a hand breadth longe, and a hand breadth broade. It was full of places for ſtones euen foure rowes of ſtones, which ſtones wer
according to the names of the children of Iſrael. In this breſt plate was put alſo theſe two words, Vrim, and Thummim, which were vpon Aarons hart. Vrim ſignifieth light, and Thummim perfection. Vrim alſo doth ſignify knowledge, Thummim holynes, ſhewing what vertues are required in the Prieſtes.

Some interprete and turne Vrim Thummim, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is, doctrina & veritas, doctrine and truth, wherby is ſignified, that Prieſts ought to be able to preach doctrine, but yet none other but true doctrin.

The fourth and laſt kind of garment was, a myter, & ther was made a plate of pure gold, which had grauen theron, ſanctum domino, holines to the Lord. It was ſet vpon the high Prieſtes for head. And this plate of gold was tied with blew ſilke lace vpon the fronte of the myter.

Theſe garments had a godly and manifold ſignification. God him ſelfe declared by Moſes the vſe and the end of them, that they were inſtituted vnto the glory and comlynes of the Prieſts, which garments did not onely procure an authority vnto the Miniſters, being occupied about the ſacrifices, but alſo made the ſacrifices commendable. For they muſt needes appeare glorious, whiche are celebrate with ſo great pompe and preparaunce.
Alſo, it was profitable and neceſſary, that the people being very prone to embrace the rites of the Heathen, ſhould be kept within the compaſſe of their duties by theſe ceremonies.

Furthermore, they do exhibite Chriſt the true and high prieſt to be conſidered of vs. He was appareled with the garment of iuſtice, temperaunce and vertue, which garment he hath common with vs, for it behoueth al Chriſtians to put vpon them, Chriſt.

Chriſt excelleth as an high prieſt, not onely in that he ſanctifieth vs, and indueth vs with vertues, but alſo hath certaine peculiar properties, as a true God and Sauiour of the world. He beareth vs on his ſhoulders and in his breſt, as precious ſtones, for we be not vile, but precious in his ſight. The light of the eternal wiſdome ſhineth out of the breſt of Chriſt our Biſhop. For in him, as in a cheſte of the euerlaſting wiſdome of God, are al treaſures of wiſdome & knowledge layd vp. He is the light of the world, he is truth and perfection, that al the world of onely Chriſt maye aſke iuſtly lawes, oracles, and whatſoeuer nedeth to the obtaining of perrfection, and true bleſſednes. He is Sanctus ſanctorum, the diuine Maieſty and holynes it ſelfe, vpon whoſe head the crowne of glory doth wel & rightly ſit, who onely doth ſanctify, raigneth glorious, & liueth for euer.

Finally, theſe ceremonies were ordained for the prieſts, yt they might vnderſtand by their apparell, what was required of them, and of what condicions they ought to be. Let prieſts be alwaies prepared to their office.
Let them walke honeſtly in the ſighte of God and menne. Let them kepe a temperaunce, and be voyde from riot and euill luſtes. Let theyr loynes be girded wt the girdle of iuſtice and truth. Let their breſts, ſides, and backes be ſenſed with the word of God. Let their heades be couered with the helmet of ſaluation, in Chriſt our Sauiour. Let him be the head of the Miniſters, and miniſtery, but eſpecially let him be a vocall Prieſt ſpeaking in the Church. For if the prieſt be dum, he ſhal die, but if he doo boldly preache the name of the Lord, and his law, he raiſeth vp a ſweete ſauour of Pomegranates in the Church. Therfore, vnder the ſhadow of the garments, are couered maners, vertues, and vices. Next after preaching, nothing doth more commend and ſet foorth man, then garmentes. Such as the minde is, ſuch almoſt are the words and garments. Therfore the garment ſignifieth a mans conuerſation. Vvherupon we are commaū ded in holy talke to put on an other garment, when conuerſacion is required to be chaunged. In ſo much that a good part of prieſtly doctrine is contained by a ſhadow, what becommeth them in this apparel of Aaron.

div.head: Phinees. 13.
div.p: PHinees was the great prieſt of the Iewes, ſonne to Eleazarus the high prieſt, & was ordered the ſame yere that Othoniel was made prieſt, but how long he ſat, it is vncertain. He was a ſtout and valiaunt man, and vanquiſhed many of his enimies (before he was prieſt) when Ioſua made him general of the armies. But after he was made prieſt, he continually ſerued God with al good and vertuous life, reuerence and feare. And therfore the Lord him ſelfe gaue him a couenaunt of peace. He ſemed from his youth to haue a feruent zeale to God. For when the ſonnes of Iſrael, that is, the ſonnes of Belial had done ſacrifice to Belpehor in Moſes preſence, and had eaten the ſacrifices of the dead, as the Heathen were wont to do, and when Phinees ſaw the captain of the tribe of Simeō, named Zambri, in the preſence of al the people, come to a Madianite woman, a faire harlot, he riſeth vp, and with his iaueling in his hand, entred in a rage into the tent, and ſtroke them both in doing the dede through the priuities, & ſlew them. For the which act the lord ſaid forth with to Moſes: Phinees my ſeruaunt, the ſonne of Eleazarus, ſonne to Aaron the Prieſt, hath turned away my wrath from Iſrael, bycauſe he was zelous for my ſake among them. Therfore I haue not conſumed the children of Iſrael in my ielouſy. For that cauſe the Lord appointed to him a perpetual prieſthood. He being aged, died in the fauour both of God and man, and was buried in the burials of his fathers, and is worthely numbred among the ſaints of the old law.

div.head: A Calfe. 14.
div.p: A Queſtion might be demaunded, why they made the image of a Calfe, rather than of man, or of any other beaſt.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: It is not vnlikely, that they by a peruers emulation did folow the Egiptians, which did worſhip, as their god Apim, that is, Taurus, an Oxe or Bul in the ſimilitude of a Calf. And to this they fel by reaſon of dayly familiarity wt the Egiptiās. For although they wer ſundred frō the Egiptiās, yet they wer ſomtime cōuerſant with them. And here is to be conſidered what miſchief the company and euil examples of naughty men do gender and bring. The Egiptians, after they had worſhipped for a certain time a liue Bull or Oxe, than they drowned him, and ſought for an other Oxe or Bul with great mourning, as Strabo and Plinie alſo do write.
Saint Ambroſe doth ſay, that by this Calfe was ſignified, that Hieroboam ſhould in long time after ſet vp golden Calfes, and cauſe the people to worſhip them.

div.head: Queſtio.
div.p: Many cal into queſtion, whether Aaron ſinned or no, in cauſing this Calfe to be made?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Some write, that he offended not: other write that he greuouſly offended. Theodoretus ſaith, that Aaron was not in ſo great a fault, his words be theſe: Aaron propoſitū in vitulo formando quaerendū eſt, ita enim fiet vt omnino venia indignū fuiſſe non iudicemus &c. That is: The purpoſe of Aaron is to be ſought out in making the goldē Calf, for ſo it ſhal come to pas, yt we may iudge Aaron not vtterly to be vnworthy of pardon and forgeuenes. For when his brother Moſes had bene in the hill by the ſpace of .xl. daies, & the people wer in ſuch a rage, that they would returne again into Egipt, Aaron firſt attempted to mitigate & aſſwage their fury with gentle words. But when he perceiued he could not preuail, he required the earings of the women, yt he might ſomething that way turne their minds (louing iewels) & draw from them the rage of ſuperſtition, & did (as it were) ſet one ſoldiour againſte an other in the front, but he could not this way pacify their fury. Therfore he was of neceſsity cōſtrained to faſhion a Calf. Vvherfore ſuch a purpoſe and intent was to be forgeuen of the great goodnes of god, which Moſes himſelf declareth in Deuteronomie, wher he ſaith: I deſired my Lord God for my brother Aaron, and he died not. Thus much Theodoretus. Diodorus is alſo of this opiniō.

Other learned fathers, to whō alſo ye ſcolaſtical diuines do cōdiſcend, do hold yt Aaron did greatly offend, bicauſe he feared mā more then god, by which fear he cōſented to ye ſin of ye hebrues, & as S. Paul ſaith, not onely thei which do il, ar worthy of death, but alſo they which cōſent to ye doers
If you wil obiect, that he did it for feare of death, yet he cannot therby be excuſed from ſinne. For he being as it were, a ſpiritual gouernour, ſhould rather haue ſuffered corporal death,Eccleſ. 4. than to haue conſented to the idolatry of the people. For it is written: My ſonne, be not aſhamed to ſay the truth for thy life. Againe, ſtriue for the truth vnto death, and defende iuſtice for thy lyfe.

Caietanus writeth of Aaron, as followeth: Inſaniuit ipſe longe magis quam alii, nam alii non niſi elohim & elohe (quae ſunt nomina cōmunia) attribuerunt idolo: ipſe autem in cōmunicabile et ineffabile nomen tetra grammaton attribuit idolo, nullo ad hoc inſtigante: & quod peius eſt voce publica. &c. That is: Aaron was much more mad than the other people, for other attributed vnto ye idol no names, but theſe names, Elohim, and Elohe, which are common names. But Aaron attributed vnto the idole the vnſpeakeable name of God, the name Tetragrammaton, no mā inciting him vnto it, and that he did alſo with a publicke proclamation, which is wurſt of all. This is written here, euen as the ſinne of Peter is written in the new Teſtament (which ſinne of Peter notwithſtanding was muche leſſe than this) to the commendacion of Gods diuine grace, which tooke Aaron after ſo haynous ſinne, to be notwithſtanding the high prieſt.
Other do by this, excuſe Aaron, and do ſay, that when Aaron named the great name Iehouah, he ment, that the ſacrifice ſhould be offred onely to the liuing God, and not to the Calfe.

div.head: Apoſtata. 15.
div.p: THat man is called Apoſtata, which ſwarueth from his captain, and fleeth to his enemies, or from the Chriſtians to the Ethnicks or Iewes.
Moonkes alſo, whiche ſwarued from their inſtitution and orders, were called Apoſtatae.
This kinde of ſwaruing is called Apoſtaſia.
Apoſtata is a Greke word, & ſignifieth in Latine deſertor, defector, a ſwaruer.

div.head: Baaliſtes. 16.
div.p:
BAal and Baalim in the Hebrue, for the moſt part, are vain gods & idoles of the Gentiles, bicauſe they are Lordes ouer them, of whom they are worſhipped. For Baal ſignifieth a Lord, Maiſter & Huſband, and ſomtime it is a common name of the heathen gods. For the Hebrues do ſeme to vſe this word indifferently for all idoles of the Gentiles. After this maner they ſerued Baalim, that is al maner of Heathen idoles, wherupon it is put for euery idole. In ſo much that this woord Baal, in the ſcriptures oft times doth ſignifie all maner of idolatry. For
Baal ſignifieth not onely Dominum, Hiere. 9. Hier in Oſ. 2 Lord, but it is taken alſo ſometime pro adamato, a louer, as appeareth in Oſeas the prophet.

Bel or Baal (or in the latine Belus) was the firſt king of the Aſsirians.pſal. 105. Rom. 1. In honour of whom Ninus his ſonne ſet vp an image, and pardoned al them which had recourſe vnto it: which manner of idolatry afterwarde crept in among the common people, ſo that now of the original or heade, the whole body of idolatry taketh his name.
Baalim is a word of the maſculine gender, and Aſtaroth of the feminine gender,1. Saw. 7. and by theſe two woords the gods and goddeſſes of the Gē tiles are ſignified.
The ſcripture in many places is wont to terme them with filthye names, that it may the more cal men from the worſpipping of them.
The Hebrues cal idoles moleſtations & griefes contemptuouſly, that they may declare, that they bring nothing but calamities, when foolyſhe men do hope for ſaluacion of them.
But bicauſe mencion is made of Baal the idole, I haue thought good to ſpeake ſomwhat of idolatry both concerning the woord, and the matter.

Idolatria, idolatry is a Greeke word, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is, of woorſhipping, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is, of an idole or image, which ſignifieth none other thing than the worſhipping of idoles.

〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is deriued 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which ſignifieth forma, a forme or ſhape which men haue inuented vnto them ſelues, to repreſent a God with all. And as ther are found diuers and ſundry kindes of matter, whereof the idoles are made: ſo ther are diuers kindes of idoles. If it be ſtone, wood, or metall, wherof the god is made, & in it to be worſhipped, thoſe are groſe & moſt manifeſt idoles. Somtimes the matter of them is ſpirituall, which than happeneth, when thoſe formes and images are none other things thē conceptions of the minde, by which mē do imagine to repreſent God him ſelfe, not as the ſcripture ſetteth him forth, but according to their own phantaſy and raſhnes.
Vvherfore ther are two ſortes of idoles, according to the condicion of the matter, of the which the one is called externall and viſible, the other internall and inuiſible, which is imagined in minde.

Alſo ther are two true kindes of worſhipping of God, the one is inward, when we beleue in God, put our truſt in him, & geue him thanks, and ſubmit our ſelues and al ours vnto him, and call vpon him deuoutlye in our praiers. In theſe actions conſiſt the inwarde worſhipping of God. The other kinde of worſhipping of god hath external notes, by the which we teſtify this our mind, as in proſtrating of the bodye, in bowing of the knee, in vncouering the head, in ſpeaking & in exerciſing thoſe rites & ceremonies, which are inſtituted of God. And this is ye outward honoring
of God. But it is to be noted, that ſuch externall ſignes, as of bowing the body and the knees, and ſuch like are done alſo vnto creatures, as vnto Princes & Kings, which repreſent the authority of God, vnto men here in earth, and execute his office in the adminiſtration of thinges. And then truly they are to be eſtemed no otherwiſe then certain manifeſt teſtimonies, by the which al they which ar appointed in this inferior place, do declare truly and from the bottom of their hart, that they are contented for Gods ſake to be ſubiect, and to obey ſuch higher powers, as farre as godlines, and Gods word doth permit.

But we muſt take heede, leaſt in our inward iudgement we attribute more vnto them, than is meete or expedient, and looke for greater things at their handes, then their authority and power is able to perfourme: for otherwiſe we ſhall not auoide idolatry.

Vvherfore, if any man by bowing him ſelfe vnto his Prince, woulde ſignify thereby, that the Prince cannot erre, and that it is lawfull for him to do what he liſt, to his pleaſure, and to commaund whatſoeuer he liſteth, ſuch a one without doubt ſhould commit idolatry, both inwardly and outwardly.

Vvhether this fault be in the bondſlaues of the Pope or no, we maye gather of this, that they ſo humble them ſelues vnto him, that they doo kis his feete. They declared that they were ſo ſubiect vnto him, as vnto the onely Vicar of Chriſt vpon earth, and as to the vniuerſall Biſhop of the Church, who cannot erre in the faith, vnto whom onely power is geuen to diſcerne and iudge of religion, and of Chriſtian doctrine at hys pleaſure.

Let this therfore be a ſure and a firme rule, that the exteriour humbling of the body, whenſoeuer it is a token and witnes of the mind, attributing vnto a creature more then is lawfull, or ſuch thinges as are proper vnto God onely: that then it doth pertaine vnto idolatry, for they are not referred vnto God him ſelfe, or vnto the obedience of his commaundements, but vnto vaine formes and ſhapes, which we faine to our ſelues, and conceiue in our mindes.
Twoo places of the ſcripture offer them ſelues here to be diſcuſſed, which make for the confirmation of the doctrine which we intreate of.Actorum. 10

The firſt is in the Actes of the Apoſtles, of Cornelius the Centurion, who fell down proſtrate vnto Peters feete, when Peter came vnto him, but Peter could not abide it, but reproued him, ſaying: Ne ſic feceris, ſurge, ego quoque homo ſum. Do not ſo, aryſe, for I am a man alſo.Apo. 22. Vve reade alſo in the Apocalips, how that Iohn fel downe before the Angell, but he charged him that he ſhould not ſo doo, ſaying: Conſeruus tuus ſum. I am thy fellow ſeruaunt.

Theſe two places might be thus vnderſtanded, as though Peter and the angel condemned theſe actions as idolatrous, and as though the Centurion and Iohn ſhould geue vnto them ſome diuine honour, and ſhould geue more reuerence vnto them, than is meete to be geuen vnto any creature. But ſuch impiety is not to be thought to haue bene in any of them. The ſcripture is a witnes vnto the Centurion, that he feared and worſhipped God.

Howe can we thinke therfore, that he would take Peter for a God, or at the leaſt wiſe would geue any diuine honour vnto a creature? And it is not likely, that Iohn being an Apoſtle, could not diſcerne an Angell from God. If that none of them woulde worſhippe a creature in ſteade of the creatour, it followeth, that it is not lawfull to exhibite this kinde of outward reuerence to creatures. Vvherefore it ſhoulde ſeeme alſo that thys reuerence ought not to be done vnto princes. To this I aunſwer, that we ought to put a difference betwene worldly honour, and diuine honour.

Alſo, we muſt vnderſtand, that theſe twoo menne, that is Cornelius and Iohn did not minde by this their woorſhipping, to take Gods honor from him, and to geue it vnto menne: yet it might be thought that they fell to an inordinate ſigne of reuerence, and ſo offended in exceſſe, and paſſed their bounds, but committed not idolatry. But ther is leſſe fear of committing idolatry toward Princes, than towardes ye Angels or Miniſters of Chriſt. For they, becauſe they execute a ſpirituall function, the honor which is done vnto them, doth come nigher vnto a religious adoration.

VVherfore the bowing of the knee, and the incuruation of the body in them ſelues, are not condemned, but in that they are done for the cauſe of religion. Vvherfore in this caſe a moderation is to be vſed. And let this be ſufficiently ſayd of this matter. Take this alſo by the way, that this doth alſo pertayne vnto idolatry, when we worſhip the true God by other meanes and rites then he would haue vs, or hath preſcribed and appointed vnto vs.

If we do otherwiſe, we ſhal worſhip an idoll, according vnto the ſecond forme of idolatry, ſpoken of before, that is, when we fayne vnto our ſelues in our mynde and thought ſome God, which is delighted wyth honour inuented by man, wheras there is no ſuch God at all. Vvherfore in this doing we ſhall not worſhip the true God, but an idole which we haue conceiued in our minde.

And ſurely Paule is thus to be vnderſtanded in the firſt Epiſtle to the Corinthians, wher he ſaith: Scimus quod idolum nihil eſt in mundo. Vve know that an idole is nothing in the world. Paule doth not meane,
that ther is no idole, as concerning the outward ſhape and fourme, for no man doubteth, but that the idoles haue place, either in ſome extern matter, or in our mindes. Vvherfore he meaneth not the ſigne of the idole, but the thing, vnto the which the idole is referred: meaning, that the thing it ſelfe which is ſignified by the idoles, is nothing, bicauſe there is no God any where, which would be repreſented or delighted wyth ſuch images.

Concerning the name of Baal, it is to be noted, that a goodly Epitheton of God is expreſſed therby. For Baal in the Hebrue betokeneth a Lord, a Maiſter, a Huſbande, which all things agree in very deede vnto God. For he is the Lord of all, he is the teacher of all true wyſedome, he is the onely huſbande of the Church. Therfore they doo not erre, who conſidering the properties of God, doo call him by this name Baal. Nor the Grecians are to be reprehended, when they named God 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , bycauſe with that title they declared God to be the authour of life.

Of the Romanes alſo God was called Iupiter, as they would ſay, helping Father. Theſe woordes therfore are worthy to be attributed vnto God. And it might be that the Elders which ſo ſpake, had reſpect to the true God, Prince of all thinges: but afterward, it was moſt wycked and deteſtable to geue theſe properties to planets, ſtarres, men, beaſtes, images, wherupon althinges were filled with idolatry.

div.head: Paphnutius. 17.
div.p: PAphnutius (as Epiphanius ſayth) was the ſonne of a certain woman, very famous in confeſsion of the faith.Tomo. 2. Lib 2. haereſ. 68. He was brought vp from a boy in ſoletary places, called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , for the which cauſe Epiphanius ſemeth to cal him an ancher.

He was liberally inſtructed, and a verye continent and chaſte man in all his life, and moſt famous in conſtancy of Chriſtian faith and piety. For when he was biſhop of a certaine city in the vpper Thebais,Euſc li. 8. c. 12 Lib. 1. cap. 7. at what time Maximinius the Emperour vſed great perſecution in thoſe partes, his right eye was put out, and the hamme of his left legge burned, or (as Theodoretus writeth) he was adiudged to digge in the moynes, hauyng one of his armes cut of.

But after that Conſtantinus the Emperour had reſtored peace and quietnes to the churches, Paphnutius alſo was reſtored to his Churche, and came after into the Synode of Nice, being ſent for of the Emperor, wher Conſtantinus had him in gret reuerence, aboue al other men, in ſomuch that he ſat at meate familiar with him, and calling him oftētimes into his chamber, kiſſed the place of his eye that was put out.

Paphnutius in that Synode of Nice, beſides that he was a conſtant
defender of the right faith, did alſo one verye godly and wholeſome acte for the Church, which is this.

Some of the biſhops went about to appoint a new law in the Church, that is, that prieſts, biſhops, & deacons (which had bene married when they wer laymē) ſhould not company & lie with their wiues, but ſhould forſake them, and lead a ſingle life: which law had bene almoſt allowed, vnles Paphnutius, perceiuing the perilous and greuous enterpriſe, and the great daūgers that might enſue, if the biſhops had reſiſted them. For he riſing in the middeſt of the Synode, ſayd: It is a hard thing, that ſuche a yoke ſhould be layd vpon godly men, which being done, I foreſee a great peril to hang ouer the church. Vvhy do not you permit and ſuffer, that which the ſcripture not onely graunteth, but alſo doth very wel commēd and adourne? For it ſaith, that mariage is honourable, and a bed vndefiled. Furthermore, all men cannot alwaies obſerue and keepe a lyke thys ſtraight and hard law: yea how ſhal the chaſtity of their wiues be kept?
The Synode receiued & allowed the iudgemēt of Paphnutius (which was vnmaried) to be godly and wholeſome.

Paphnutius was preſent alſo in the Synode of Tyre, in which, when he perceiued that Athanaſius (which came thether with him) was vniuſtly delt withal of his aduerſaries, he tooke Maximinius, the biſhop of Hieruſalem by the hand, and counſelled him to ariſe and depart, bicauſe is was not lawfull for them, being Confeſſours, to be preſent at a malignaunt counſell.
Beſides his great piety and ſincere doctrine, and conſtant profeſsion, he was famous alſo in doing miracles and cures of perilous diſeaſes, in driuing out diuels. &c.

div.head: Septuaginta. 18.
div.p: ELeazarus, brother to Simon Iuſtus, was Biſhop in the fiue and thirty yeare of the raigne of Ptolemy, after the death of his brother Simon, and ſate .xvii. yeares. In the time of his biſhopricke, one Demetrius told this Ptolemeus Philadelphus, king of the Egiptiās, whō he had made ruler of his library, that it was ſhewed him, that ther was a law geuen to the Iewes by the mouth of the liuing God, which law it was not lawful for any man to tranſlate, but onely for thē which worſhipped God, adding alſo this, that one Theopompus attēpting the ſame, was made blinde, and that he repenting was reſtored to health. And he ſaid further, that the lawe written in figures and the Hebrue tounge, could not be tranſlated without great labour.

The king being glad of that which Demetrius tolde him, ſent letters to Eleazarus, with great rewards by his embaſſadours. For Ptolomeus the king had not long before, at the inſtant requeſt of Ariſtenus his familiar
friend, ſet at liberty al the Iewes, which wer in bondage in Egipt. The tenour of the Epiſtle, which the king ſent to Eleazarus, was this,Lib. 12. as Ioſephus teſtifieth.

Gentem tuam, quae ſecus nos erat, libertate donaui. &c. That is: I haue ſet at liberty thy country men the Iewes, which were vnder my dominion, ſuppoſing that this my dede pleaſeth God. I haue alſo appointed ſome of them to my wars, & other of them, whoſe truſty ſeruice I had tried, I haue placed in my court. I haue determined to put your lawes in my library. Thou ſhalt do wel therfore to ſend me Elders & learned mē, which can wel interpret them. I haue ſent ouer an hundred talentes of ſyluer to offer ſacrifices. &c.

On the other ſide, when the king had receiued Eleazarus epiſtle with the interpreters, he gaue ten beds with golden feete, and al implementes therto belonging, to Eleazarus, in token of a certaine beneuolence. He gaue him alſo a cup of .xxx. talents, x. ſtooles, purple, & a beautiful crown with many other things, which he had bequeathed to the God of heauen.

Now Eleazar ſending to the king that which he requeſted, ſaid thus: I haue choſē ſixe of the beſt learned out of euery tribe. It may be the part of your godlines and iuſtice, after the copy and tranſlation written out, to ſend it againe vnto vs by the bearers hereof. And after a certain ſpace when the Elders wer come from Hieruſalem, to the king being in Alexandria, they wer entertained of him very honorably, & moſt curteouſly. And when they offred to the king the role of the lawe written in golden letters, he aſked thēfor bookes. And alſo when they had opened & ſhewed the fine thinnes of the parchment, & the incomprehenſible ioyning together of them, the king marueiled yt they wer ſo wonderfullye compact together, & rendring them thanks, he placed them euery one in ſeueral Cels, cōmaunding al things neceſſary to be miniſtred vnto them. Vvho in the ſpace of .72. daies tranſlated the law out of the Hebrue into Greke, ſo that they all agreed in one and the ſelf ſame tranſlation (as witneſſeth S. Auſtine) wtout any diſagreing either of words or of ſenſe,De ciuita. de lib. 18. cap. 42 which law being receiued & approued of the Iewes, which then were in thoſe places, Demetrius offred to the king. Then the king ſeing what was done, and ſetting a ſide the law, greatly meruailed at the knowledge & wiſdom of the Elders, & talked long with Demetrius, marueiling yt neither hiſtoriographer, nor Poet had made mēcion of ye law, which was ſo wonderfully made and ordained. And when he calling the interpreters vnto him, thanked them, and ſent them home againe, geuing to euery one of them three very rich ſtooles, & two talents of gold, and one cup of the weight of one talent, wyth the whole cupboorde and feaſting table, deſired them, that they woulde often reſorte vnto hym out of Iewry.
Vvho when they had inſtructed and taught the king in the knowledge of the onely God, and in the gouernment of his kingdome, thanking him much, returned to Eleazarus with very many rewardes.

Theſe interpreters were in number .72. Albeit they are cōmonly called Septuaginta, for the more briefe and expedite ſpeche. Like as the iudges of Rome, which gaue iudgement, who excelled at the tilt, wer called centumuiri, but they were in number an hundred and fiue.

Iuſtinus declareth, that king Ptolemei cauſed .72. Cels to be made for theſe interpreters, that he might therby be fully certified and attain the truth, by the fidelity and conſent of their interpretation, and willed euery one of them to repaire to his own Cel, wher he ſhould tranſlate. And after they had done, he conferred together al their interpretations, and found them to conſent in euery poynt.
In apologetico ad gētes.Iuſtinus alſo doth confeſſe, that he ſaw certaine remnauntes of th • ſe houſes in the high tower called Pharus, at Alexandria.
Tertullian ſaith, that Menedemus, a Philoſopher of the prouince of Iewry, did much maruaile at the one conſent of their interpretation.

Saint Hierome ſomtime doth attribute much to them, ſaying, that they were full of the holye ghoſt, affirming alſo that oft times they did tranſlate vnexpertly, and very ill. But he ſcoffeth and mocketh at the Cels, writing thus. Neſcio quis primus author ſeptuaginta cellulas Alex andriae mendacio ſuo extruxit. &c. That is: I know not who was the firſt authour of this lye, that ther were ſeuenty Cels, builded at Alexandria, in which houſes, the interpreters being ſeperated, did write and interprete all a like. For ſo much as neither Ariſtenus, which was Ptolemeus familiar friend, nor Ioſephus (who was lōg time after) recorded any ſuch thing. But they both wrote, yt thei aſſembled together in one large place.

Great learned men do attribute to the .70. interpreters ſo much, that they thinke nothing to haue ben tranſlated of them, but that the holy ghoſt it ſelfe hath ſpoken and ratified it. Vnto theſe therfore, al ſtudents of Gods booke (hauing any ſight in the toungs) ought to repair and run, as the Hart runneth to the fountaines of water, according to the ſaying of the Prophet. But (vnder correction of the better learned, and that I may ſpeake it with their pacience) many places are found in their tranſlations more perplex, and wrapped in greater darknes, then they be in the Latine verſion, which might chaunce partly through the phraſe of the Hebrue toung, being farre diſſonant from the Greeke phraſe, partly throughe the corruptinge of the text, or the negligence of the Printers. Some perchaunce maye note in me preſumptuous raſhneſſe, that I which haue taſted of the holye tounge, but tanquam canis e Nuo, doo take vppon me to ſhewe their errours and negligence in tranſlating.
But I wil (by Gods grace) ſhew manifeſtly not a few places, wherin they haue ſwarued from the true text, and from the minde of the holy ghoſt. Notwithſtanding. I do gladly attribute ſo much to their antiquitie, and to the iudgement of the holy fathers, (who had them in greate reuerēce) as may be attributed to them.
Firſt I will declare, how they diſsente from the Euangeliſtes (who doubtles were full of Gods ſpirit) and ſpecially in that point, whiche toucheth the myſterie of our faith.

Saint Mathew allegeth this place out of the old Teſtament. Vocaui filium meum ex Aegipto I haue called my ſonne out of Egipt: & he referreth this ſentēce vnto Chriſt. Now the 70. interpreters tranſlate: Iſrael dilectus meus, vocaui illum ex Aegipto: Iſraell my beloued, I haue called him out of Egipt. They do not referre this prophecie vnto Chriſt, but to the people of Iſrael. They vtterly take away the miſterie from Chriſt, that they may ſaue the faith of their hiſtorie, which declareth that ye people of Iſrael were deliuered by the mighty hand of God, from the bōdage of Egipt. And note one thing more, whiche is, that they corrupt the text and Hebrue veritie, for it is playnly read in the Hebrue accordyng as Mathew doth alledge it.

div.head: Nota.
div.p: This one place doth gretly make againſt thē, which contēd and hold, yt the hebrue text was rather corrupt, then yt the 70. interpreters did erre.

div.head: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .
div.p: VVhen the 70. interpreters did ſo tranſlate it, either they knew the myſterie, or els they were ignoraunt of it. If they were ignoraūt of it, thē they had not the holy ghost in all their tranſlations. On the other ſide, if they knew it, and would not vtter it, & conſent to the truth, that ſpirit was rather diabolical, then holy, and as Saint Hierome ſayth, it was manifeſt ſacrilege.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: Origene, when he corrected the old Teſtamente according to the Hebrue veritie, he withdrew nothing from the tranſlation of the 70. interpreters, but noted onely (Aſteriſcis quibuſdam) what things were added Ergo, there is not ſo great fault to be founde in their tranſlation.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p:
Origene doth ſhew a certaine modeſtie in him ſelf, who would not be ſe • e to curious in other mens workes: yet Origene was none of them, who aſsarted, that all the doynges of the 70. interpreters wer done by the holy ghoſt, for he doth manifeſtly diſsent from them. It is written of the .70 interpreters in the Pſalme thus: Attollite portas principes veſtras: You
princes lift vp your gates. But Origene ſayth, that this was not ſpoken to the princes, but to the gates, as it is in the Hebrue. For it is commaunded vnto the gates that they ſhould lift vp their heads, and open them ſelues vnto Christ, as a victor and conquerour.

Therfore certaine of the fathers folowed other tranſlations made & done after the 70. interpreters, as the tranſlatiō of Aquila, Symmachus, and Theodotion. Yea the Churche at the firſt did not receaue the tranſlation of the 70. interpreters vpon the Prophet Daniell, but ſetting that a part, folowed Theodotion his tranſlation. This they would not haue done, if they had thought ye trāſlatiō of ye 70. interpreters had ben ſo perfect, that no man ſhould haue ſought the truth of the text, but out of thē.
VVherupon Saint Hierome doth cite aboue an hundred tymes, Symmachus, and Aquila, and doth perferre them before the 70. interpreters. And ſo doth Origen cite Aquila.

Gen. 48.Iacob ſaith in Geneſis: In caetu illorum non laetabitur gloria mea. But the 70. interpreters read: In congregatione illorum non innitentur epata mea. I pray you what affinitie or neareneſse haue theſe two wordes, Gloria & epata cōcerning ye ſenſe? truly none. The cauſe of this error was this. The conſonant letters in the Hebrue toung haue their ſignifications of the vowels or punctes, which are ſet vnderneth them. Now there be two wordes in the hebrue very much like both in writing and in ſound. Theſe be the wordes Chauod, whiche doth ſignifie Gloria, and Chaued, which ſignifieth Eper, a liuer. And there is no more difference betwene them, but that the one is written with Vau, holem and ſignifieth glorie, & the other is written with Zere without Vau, and that ſignifieth a liuer. It is therfore manifeſt and playne, that they fell into this error through the ſimilitude and likenes of theſe two letters.
The like is in the Prophet Ionas, where they put Acuaed, id eſt, ſeruus, for this worde Iuri, id eſt, Hebraeus, they were deceaued by the likenes of the two letters Daleth and Reſc.

In the .58. Pſalme they put Manus, pro pedibus, for where they read: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . id eſt, manus ſuas lauabit in ſanguine peccatoris It is in the Hebrue Peamaiu, id eſt, veſtigia, footeſteps.

Agayne in the .36. Pſalme they put an affirmatiue, where there is a negatiue. For where the Hebrues do read Quoniā non pacifice mihi loque bantur, the 70. interpreters do read: Quoniam pacifice mihi loquebātur. But that the ſentence ought to be read negatiuely, the wordes folowing do declare, which be theſe Et iracundia dolos cogitabant.

Truly it is to be meruailed, that ſuch an error hath continued in the Church ſo many yeares, and hath ben eſpied almoſt of none, or at the leaſt of very few. The Latin interpreter might be in the fault (I ſpeake this in
defence of the 70. interpreters.) For if this Greke particle, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Quidem, be turned into 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Non, the matter were plaine, and then ye ſentēce would agree with the Hebrue veritie and the minde of the Scripture.

This place emong many other doth ſignifie vnto vs, that thoſe commentaries vpon the Pſalmes, whiche go in S. Hieromes name, are not of his doyng, for they do expound this verſe of the Pſalme after the text of the 70 whiche, S Hierome being moſt expert and perfect in the Hebrue toung, would neuer haue done.

Furthermore, in the .37. Pſalme they peruerte all things, and take frō vs a great and high myſterie. For where it is writtē in the Hebrue Schechon aeraetz v rech Emunah. id eſt, inhabita terrā, & paſceris in veritate. that is. Dwell in the land, & thou ſhalt be fed aſsuredly: they haue tranſlated: Inhabita terram & paſceris in diuitiis eius: Dwell in the land, and thou ſhalt be fed in the riches of it. But that this word Emunah, doth ſignifie Veritatem, and not Diuitias, I will bring agaynſt thē their own authoritie and tranſlation in an other place.

VVhere it is both in the Hebrue text and in the Latin text in Pſal. 39. Non abſcondi incorde meo veritatem tuam, the .70. do read: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . ſo that this word Emunah, hath none other ſignification but Veritatem, vnles it betokeneth ſometyme, Fidem. faith fidelitie or aſsurednes, whiche is farre from the ſignification of riches.

Beſide theſe errors, what a ridiculous interpretatiō, is this, in the .72 Pſalm? Erit firmamentum in terra in ſummis montium. VVhere in the Hebrue it is, Frumentū, or Placenta frumenti. Now there is a great difference in all the three tounges, that is, in Hebrue, Greke and Latin, betwixte Firmamentum, and Frumentum, Firmamentum, in the Hebrue toung is called Rakia, and Frumentum, is called Dragan, Firmamentum, in Greke is, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , vel
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and Frumentum is, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , vel,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Firmamentum in Latine, doth ſignifie in Engliſhe ſtabilitie or the grounde of a matter, ſometime the firmamēt or heauen: and Frumentum, betokeneth all maner of corne, but it is moſt vſed for wheat or Rie. I beſech you, who, (vnles he were blind and vtterly ignoraunt) would haue tranſlated the one for the other, Firmamentum, for Frumentum.

Lyranus making mencion of this place doth ſay, that the Latin booke is corrupt, and that Firmamentum, is written for Frumentum, but that is moſt vntrue, for as it is in the 70. interpreters, ſo it is in ye Latin text. VVhere the Latin booke hath Firmamentum, the Greeke hath 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . which is al one. Therfore this error is to be imputed vnto the .70. not vnto the Latin booke, or to the Latin interpreter.

Here by the way, (and yet not out of the way,) I will ſhew you how fondly, yea rather how ſtretchedly Petrus Galatinus doth alledge and
bring ſome of ye hebrue Rabbines to cōfirme by this text in this Pſalme, the ſacrifice of the Maſſe, and the leuation of the heſt, as they call it.

Rabbi Salomon doth interpret the .72. Pſalm of king Salomō. VVherupon, he expoundeth theſe woordes in the ſame Pſalme (Orietur in diebus eius iuſtitia, & abundantia pacis, donecauferatur Luna. In his dayes ſhall the rightuous floriſh, and aboundance of peace ſhalbe as long as the mone endureth) after this maner: In ye dayes of Salomon ſhal the rightuous be multiplied, and the aboūdance of peace vnto the worldes end. Notwithſtāding (as Galatinus writeth) when he came to theſe wordes: Erit frumentum in terra, vel erit fruſtum frumenti in terra in capite montiū, that is, an handfull of corne ſhalbe ſowen in the earth euen in the top of the mountaines. He being not able to conceile the truth, vttered theſe wordes agaynſt him ſelfe, ſaying. Magiſtri noſtri bonae memoriae expoſuerunt, hoc eſſe genus placētarum in diebus Meſsiae, & totum Pſalmum de Rege Meſsia explanauerunt, that is, our Rabbines of famous memorie haue expounded this kinde of cakes or wafers to be in the dayes of Meſſias, and do interpret all the whole Pſalme of king Meſsias.

Galatinus alleging many other of the Rabbines, their gloſes and their bookes, doth conclude, that this ſame Placenta, or cake ſhould be Meſsias him ſelfe, he bringeth in Rabbi Berachias in ye name of Rabbi Iſaac, ſaying after this ſorte: As there was a firſt redemer, that is, Moſes: ſo there ſhalbe a laſt redemer. For as the firſt redemer cauſed Manna to deſcend, ſo ſhall ye laſt redemer, that is Meſsias, ſhalbe a cake of wheat in ye earth, accordyng to this ſaying of the Pſalme: Erit placēta frumēti in terra that is (as Rabbi Ionathas expoūdeth it) there ſhalbe a ſacrifice of bread in ye top of the mountaines of the Churche, that is, a cake of bread ſhalbe a ſacrifice aboue the heads of the Prieſts which be in the Church. Thus ſaith ye Chaldey tranſlatiō of Rabbi Ionathas,Lib. 10. ca. 4. as Galatinus allegeth. And (ſaith he) what is more rightly ſignified by the mountaines of the Church, then Prelates and Prieſts, in whō the Scripture is fulfilled and verified, whē they lift the body of Chriſt ouer their heades? O fourefolde, nay fourtie folde blindneſſe and ignorance, ſo to adde and diminiſhe the Scriptures, ſo to racke and rent the Scriptures from the true and naturall ſenſe.

This Pſalme cōcerning ye type, is wholly writtē of the kingdome of Salomō, cōcerning the veritie and perfect accōpliſhing therof, it is made and meant of Chriſt and his kingdome. It conteineth partly deprecations and prayers, partly the Propheticall deſcription of the kingdome of Chriſt.

Some write, (and that verie wel) that this Pſalme was made of Dauid, for the good ſucceſse of the kingdome of his ſonne Salomon, and that it was geuē to the people to be ſong. For after thend of the Pſalme, theſe wordes be added: here endeth the prayers of Dauid the ſonne of Iſay.

And it appeareth manifeſtly, that when Salomon his ſonne was conſecrate
and inueſted into the kingdome, that Dauid not long after ended his life, that it may be well beleued, this Pſalme to be the laſt prayers & vowes of kyng Dauid, in whiche prayers he doth not onely deſire the ſucceſse and felecitie of his ſonne Salomon, but alſo doth touche the felicitie, the power, the rightuouſnes, the ampleneſse and continuance of the kingdome of Chriſt.

Some verſes are applied both to Salomon, beyng a type, and alſo to Chriſt. ſome onely vnto Salomon, and ſome to his ſubiectes and there felicitie, as the 16. verſe, which is this: Sit pugillus frumenti in terram ſatus in caput montium, ſtrepitum edant, ſicut libanus fructus eius, & floreant de ciuitate, ſicut herba terrae, that is, an handful of corne ſhalbe ſowen in the earth, euen in the toppe of the mountaines, and the fruite therof ſhall ſhake the trees of Libanon, and the children ſhall floriſhe out of the citie like the graſse of the erth. He praieth in this verſe for many things, firſt that there might be aboundāce of corn, and that the earth might be fertill. The wheat in that Region is both higher and greater in the ſtalk & grain, than it is in other countries. He prayeth that it may be growen as high as the hills are, and that it might be ſo thicke, that it mighte make ſuch a noiſe when it is ſhakē with the wind, as ye trees that grow vpon the mount Libanus do, when they are ſhaken with the wind. It is ſpoken as it wer 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Secondly he prayeth and wiſheth, that the ſubiectes of his kingdome, might floriſhe and increaſe, both in number and in proſperitie of all things. And theſe things did happen to the kingdome of Salomon, as it maye be gathered out of hiſtories. But to drawe this verſe vnto a Cake aboue the Prieſtes head, as Galatinus, Lyranus, and other do, is an allegorie, not ſo farre fet, as fooliſhe. Haec
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .

To our purpoſe agayne. In the .88. Pſalme, they tranſlate: Medici ſuſci tabunt, for Mortuiſurgent. But in this they wer deceued with the ambiguitie of the word, for it ſignifieth Tam medicum, quam mortuum. But when it ſignifieth Medicum, it cōmeth of this. Radicall, Rapha. And whē it betokeneth, Mortuum, it commeth of this Radicall, Raphah, with He, in thend, id eſt, diſſoluit.

They do ſometime obſcure the whole text, when they had leauer vſe the darke Hebrue phraſe, then to ſpeake playnely in the Greke toung, into whiche toung, they tranſlated the text. An example. They read in the 40. Pſalme: Holocauſtum & pro peccato non poſtulaſti. In whiche wordes there is no ſenſe. But it is in the Hebrue, Holocauſtum & peccatum non poſtulaſti VVhere this worde, Chataah is takē for oblation offered for ſinne, as Aſcham, Delictum, is takē for an offering Pro delicto, as it is often read in Leuit. & in the Prophet Eſay, where he ſayth: Sacerdotes comedunt peccata populi mei, hoc eſt, ſacrificia oblata pro peccatis
populi. And in this ſignification Chriſt is alſo called, Peccatum, id eſt, hoſtia pro peccato. VVhat ſhall I ſay more of thē? They do ſometime peruert the very cōmaundemēts of God, as in the twentie of Leuiticus, they turne, Sponſam pro nuru, a wife, for a daughter in law. For where the true tranſlation hath: Si quis dormierit cum nuru ſua, vter
que moriatur, they read: Si quis dormierit cum ſponſa ſua, whiche is agaynſt the minde and meaning of God.

Furthermore, that they know not the ſignification of ſome Hebrue wordes, this manifeſtly declareth, yt they haue left ſome hebrue wordes in the holy Scriptures vntranſlated, as in the booke of the kinges where they ſay: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. fiſſuras vel rimas domus continebunt, leauing this Hebrue woorde vntranſlated, Bedec, written in the Greke letters, & vnexpounded, whiche is to be meruailed at. For that word is cōmon to the Hebrues, it ſignifieth a place broken, or ruinous. Our vulgare tranſlation doth wonderfully erre, expounding Bedec, for Sarta tecta domus, whiche is an houſe ſubſtantially repaired, whiche hath no cleft nor hole in it, yea and whiche is ſo well reedified, that it might be lawfully and openly ſet and let to any yt would hyre it. If S. Auſten had knowē this, or at the leaſt well weighed it, whē he wrote ſo much in the commendacion of the .70. interpreters,Li. 2. de doc. Chriſt he would doubteles haue writtē otherwiſe then he did. But S. Auſten muſt be pardoned, for he knew not the Hebrue toung. Yea he began to learne the firſt elementes of that toung, when he was much paſt threſcore yeares of age.

But becauſe ye ſhall not thincke, that I haue them not in reuerēce, and do not well iudge of them. I will now ſhew what is to be commended and allowed in them. In certaine places they do better and more truly expoūd both the wordes and ſentences, then the Latin interpreter. And they do oft times (omitting the words) exhibite a miſticall ſenſe. As in Exod: Moſes ignorabat, quod cornuta eſſet facies eius. This is our vulgare tranſlation: where it is in the Hebrue: Luxit cutis faciei ſuae. Now the .70. interpreters for the other put theſe wordes, Quod aſpectus cutis vel coloris faciei ſuae erat glorificatus, that the ſight or ſkinne of his face was made glorious.

Alſo in the 40 Pſalme, where it is writtē in the Hebrue Imgillath Sephaer, id eſt, in volumine libri, in the rolle of the booke it is writtē of me, they turned that place, In capite libri ſcriptum eſt de me, in ye beginnyng of the booke it is written of me. By ye which interpretation they explaine vnto vs by the authoritie of tholde Teſtament, that Chriſt the ſonne of God was creator of heauen and earth, who ſpeaketh of him ſelfe theſe wordes: In capite libri ſcriptum eſt de me, that is, in the beginnyng of Geneſis, it is written of me.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: But it is written in the Hebrue Bimgillah, in volumine, and not, In capite libri, therfore they haue not truly tranſlated.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: This doth withdraw nothing frō the miſticall ſenſe of Chriſt. For the Hebrues by this noune Meggillah, volumen, do vnderſtand the v. bokes of M • ſes, which being written in certaine rolles, they euen at this day do honour and worſhip in their ſinagoges vpō the Sabboth dayes. Or if any will defend this their tranſlation cōcerning the miſtery, he may ſay, that this word Megillah, doth not onely ſignifie a booke, of this verbe Galal, id eſt, voluit. but doth alſo ſignifie Apertionē, of this verbe, Galah, id eſt, aperuit. And the ſenſe may be this. In apertione libri ſcriptum eſt de me, that is, in ye very opening and beginning of the booke of Geneſis. And this ſenſe did ſo greatly pleaſe ſome, that they did affirme to be writtē in the Hebrue in Geneſis: In filio creauit Deus caelum & terram. VVhiche opinion S. Hierome hath very well refelled, ſaying that it may be ſo takē cō cerning the miſticall ſenſe, but not after the ſignification of the word. For it is not there Beuen id eſt, in filio, but Bereſchith. id eſt, in principio.

Beſide this, where it is written in our cōmon tranſlation:Gene. 49. Non auferetur ſceptrū de Iuda, & dux de faemore eius donec veniat qui mittēdus eſt. The ſcepter ſhall not departe from Iuda, nor a law geuer from betwene his feete, vntill Shiloh, come. The .70 interpreters did tranſlate, Donec venerit cui repoſita ſunt, that is, to whom they are layd vp in ſtore, they meane the ſcepter and kingdome. And this tranſlation (as ſome thinke) is much better then the verſion of the Latin interpreter, who was deceaued by the likenes of, He, and Cheth. And yet I can not ſay properly, that he was deceiued. For Schiloh, with He, (as ſome learned men do write) doth come of this verbe Schalah, which ſignifieth to pacifie. And ſo Schiloh, is as much to ſay, as Author pacis, or, pacificator populo dei ꝓmiſſꝰ. And this is none but Chriſt, who is the prince of peace. But Shiloh, written with Cheth, doth ſignifie Miſſus, whiche moued him ſo to turne it. Yet he ſemeth to be ouerſene in this, that he tranſlated it into a participle of the paſsiue voyce, for the Hebrue toūg hath not participles of preterpaſsiues, nor of the future paſsiues.

Some learned men write, that Shiloh, with He, doth ſignifie Filiū, and that He, is ſet in the ſteede of Vau, as ye would ſay, Filius eius. Other againe doe ſaye, that He, is not put for Vau, but that the word is written with He, by the minde of the holy ghoſt, to ſignifie Chriſt the ſonne of a woman. For He, is a note of the article of the feminine gender.

Agayne, where the .70 interpreters do tranſlate Cui repoſita ſunt, it ſtandeth not beſt, for the text. For Origenes doth ſay, that he found diuerſitie
of tranſlations in certaine bookes. In one booke he found, Repoſita ſunt, in an other he founde Repoſitū eſt, ſo that it ought to be referred to the ſcepter or kingdome of Chriſt. And this worde, Shiloh, can in no wiſe be the plurall noumber, but this is not to be greatly maruailed at of the .70. for they do in many places turne the ſingular noumber into the plurall noumber.

To make an end, that I may not omit any thing whiche may make for the honor and renowne of the 70. I will now make mencion of ſuch places, which (as ſome do ſay) both Chriſt and thapoſtles do vſe their tranſlation, contrary to the Hebrue veritie.
But let vs diligently enquire whether it be ſo or no. I will bring forth two places, one out of the Goſpell alledged by Chriſt, an other out of the Epiſtle to the Hebrues alledged by Paul.

The firſt is,pſal. 8. wher chriſt ſaith: Exore infantiū & Iactētiū perfeciſti laudē, as the .70. did interpret it. But it is in the Hebrue Iſſarta or, fundaſti fortitudinem, that is out of the mouth of babes and ſucklings, thou haſt ordeined ſtrength: The .70. do read, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , i. perfeciſti laudem, and ſo doth alſo the Latin interpreter. And in dede this worde, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , doth ſigni-Laudē, but take away the circūflexe accēt, & then, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , doth betokē Validū, or fortem, ſeuerū, pugnacē, & thē it is one with ye hebrue word, Or.

Furthermore this greke verbe, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , i, cōponere, doth not alwayes ſignifie, Perficere, but Aptare, to make mete, frame or to apply, & it may • roperly ſignifie, Fūdare, to ordain or builde, for to builde is nothing els but to frame and to ioyne one thing wt an other, & ſo there ſhalbe no diſcrepācie betwen Chriſt, the .70. & the Hebrue veritie. And doubtles it is ſo to be read, and the boke of the .70, ought to be corrected, yt they ſhould be driuen to conſent with Chriſt, which alwayes ſpake Hebrue, and not Greke, rather then Christ to be drawen to them.

Heb. 2.The other place is alledged of Paul in thepiſtle to ye hebrues, Minuiſti eū paulominꝰ ab angelis, here S. Paule folowed the .70. although this hebrue word, Elohim, may aſwell ſignifie God, as aūgels. S. Hierome doth hardly conſent wt Paul, ſaying, that it is in ye hebrue, Deo, & nō angelis. But vnder Hieromes paciēce, Elohim, doth not onely betokē Deū, God, but alſo aūgels and iudges. And I meruaile that S. Hieromes memorie ſo failed him, who folowing the interpretation of Aquila vpō the vi. chapter of Geneſis, doth in his annotations referre this word Heloim, to angels.

To be ſhort, it is to be lamented, that the bookes whiche we haue now in the name of the 70. be ſo corrupted. And it is not meete nor ryght, that the fault and negligence of the printers ſhould be imputed vnto thē, for there be infinitie errours in thoſe bookes by the inuerſion of letters. One for exāple. There is put, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , for, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Locus pro conuiuio.
All ſuch thinges and other of greater weight ought to be amended by the great diligence of them, whiche are cunninge and expert in the Hebrue and Greke toung.

div.head: Ezechiel. 19.
div.p: EZechiell was a Prophete, who when he was led priſoner with Ioachim the king into Babilon, prophecied the calamities of the Iewes, and ſent his Prophecies out of Babilō into Hieruſalem to Sedechias the king, which beleued him not, neither the other priſoners alſo, for that they ſaw the Citie of Hieruſalē was not deſtroied, which Hieremy had prophecied ſhould be deſtroied.

In the thirty yeare of his age and fift yeare of his captiuitie, he began to write his booke of Prophecie, whiche booke is neither to eloquent nor to rude, but betwene both.Hiero. The beginnyng and end therof is darcke and obſcure, and ſome ſay, that the booke was written of certayne wyſe men, and not of Ezechiell. And therfore the Hebrues do not ſuffer them to be read, but of very well learned men. Certayne of the Iewes, that is, of the tribe of Dan, and Gad (whom he Prophecied ſhould not returne to Hieruſalem) killed him at Babylon. He was counted a martyr and buried in the Sepulchre of Sem, the ſonne of Noe, and of Arphaxah, his ſonne. Ezechiell in Hebrue betokeneth Fortitudinem Domini.

div.head: Rites. 20.
div.p: THis worde, rites, is deriued and cōmeth of this Latin word, ritus, whiche ſignifieth in Engliſh an approued vſe and cuſtome, whiche all men do ratifie and allow.

Feſtus ſayth, that ritus, is an approued vſe or ceremonie in doyng Sacrifice. Howbeit, he alſo ſayth, that it is taken and vſed more generally for any maner of vſe and cuſtome: VVherunto Cicero ſemeth to agree, ſaying: Dehiis qui omnia pecudum ritu ad voluptatem referūt, de amicitia. that is, of them whiche after the maner of brute beaſtes, do referre all thinges to pleaſure.

div.head: Perſon, time, and place: and firſt of the perſon. 21.
div.p: THe circumſtaunce of the perſon putteth vs in remēbraunce of many thinges.

Firſt, that we do weigh and conſider who ſpeaketh or intreateth, whether he be a Prophete or any other man. If he be a Prophete, whether he ſpeaketh in his owne perſon, or in the perſon of an other. If he ſpeake in the perſon of an other, whether he ſpeake in the perſon of God or of man: and whither of a godly or vngodly man. Then it is to be expounded, whither he ſpeake of hym ſelfe or of an other. For the writers of holy Scriptures ſometymes do ſpeake in
the perſons of other men, and ſometymes in the perſons of wicked men, and in the perſons of their enemyes.

In the booke of Eccleſiaſt. where it is intreated De ſummo bono, many thinges are ſpoken in the name of the vngodly, whiche deny the prouidence of God, and the bleſſed and fortunate life that ſhall folow and ſuccede the painefull and vnfortunate life in this world.

It is requiſite, that we vſe the ſame circumſpection in the booke of Iob, where diuerſe perſons are brought in ſpeaking. Furthermore, the Prophetes in their owne perſons oftentimes do reuele and make manifeſt the iudgements and councels of the wicked.
The Apoſtles alſo likewiſe ofte tymes do ſet forth & propoſe the obiections of the aduerſaries.
The hiſtory of the Goſpell comprehendeth many thinges that were ſpoken of the ſlaunderous Iewes, and many thinges alſo whiche were ſpoken godly, both of Chriſt and of other godly men.

The godly Eunuche graunteth, that he was in a ſcruple and doubt, becauſe he knew not whither the Prophet ſpake theſe wordes:Act. 8. Tanquam ouis ad occiſione ductus eſt, of him ſelfe, or of any other perſon.

Furthermore it is expedient to conſider, vnto whom the wordes are directed, whether to ſuperiours or els to inferiours, to all men or els to fewe men, to good men or els to euill men, to ſluggiſhemen, or els to quicke men, to enemyes, or els to frendes. For the Prophetes and Apoſtles are wonte to temper their ſayinges and preathynges, for the diſpoſitions and conditions of thoſe that were aſsembled.

VVherupon ye ſe, that Chriſt ordereth his talke farre otherwiſe to the proud Phariſies, Scribes & Lawyers, then to the lowly common ſort of people, or to the diſciples which were better inſtructed and taught.

Saint Paul writeth more ſharply to the Hebrues (whoſe ſluggiſhe myndes were to be ſtirred and excited by threatnynges and examples of the lawe) then to the Romanes or to the Corinthians, whiche were both more diligent, and alſo neuer before bound to the law.

He wrote otherwiſe alſo to the Galathians, beyng ſeduced and almoſt ſwarued to the Iewiſhe Religion: then to the Philippians or Theſſalonians, whiche were conſtant and ſtedfaſt in the ſounde doctrine whiche they had once receyued. I ſpeake eſpecially of theſe partes of the Epiſtles, whiche beſide the intreatyng of doctrine, do conteyne reprouinges, corrections, exhortinges. &c.

In the new Teſtament are many thinges ſpoken whiche concerne all men, and alſo there are many thinges to be applied to fewe men, whiche vſe and enioye one certayne ſtate of life. As for example: Chriſt ſayth to
his Diſciples. Dico autem vobis amicis meis, & cetera, that is.Luk. 12. I ſay vnto you my frendes, do ye not feare them that kill the body, &c. whiche wordes were namely ſpokē to the diſciples. But they muſt ſo be takē, that they may be vnderſtand to pertayne generally to all faythfull beleuers.

Agayne, wher Chriſt ſayth to the Diſciples. Reges gentium dominantur eis, et qui poteſtatem habent ſuper eis, benefici vocantur, Luk. 22. vos au tem non ſic, that is. The rulers of the people are Lordes ouer thē, and they which gouern thē are called gracious, but ye ſhall not be ſo. Theſe words do not pertain to all mē, but properly to the diſciples and to their ſucceſſours, as to byſhops and gouernors of ye Church (as witneſseth S. Peter.) For they muſt not be Lords ouer other men, but muſte leaue that iuriſdiction to the politique rulers, from whom theſe woordes of Chriſt doth derogate nothyng of their dignitie, for that in other places of the Scripture the function of Magiſtrates with euident ſentences is approued.

Of this circūſtaunce S. Auſten geueth a very good rule ſaying.Lib. de doct. chriſt. 3. ca. 17 Erit hoc in obſeruationibus intelligendarū ſcripturarii. &c. yt is, we muſt obſerue and marke this thing in vnderſtādyng the ſcriptures, yt we know ye ſome things are cōmaūded generally to all mē, and ſome things again vnto euery particular ſtates of perſons: yt the medicine may pertayne not onely to ye vniuerſall ſtate of health, but alſo that it may be miniſtred to the particular infirmitie of euery ſicke mēber of the body.

div.head: Time.
div.p: The time is diligētly to be expēded in al wordes & dedes. VVe muſt reſpect what hath ben done, cōmaūded, or expoūded before ye law, vnder ye law, in ye time of ye goſpel. Some things do oft times ſeme not to correſpōd to ye lawes of charitie, or els to be reputed & taken for abſurdities, which (whē ye times are duly perpēded & vewed) ar foūd to be cōtrary. VVher upō ſ. Auſtē writeth very wel, ſayīg: Caud̄dū ne forte ꝙ in ſcripturis veteribus. &c. we muſt take hede, leaſt yt thing in ye holy ſcriptures,Lib. 3. de do • chriſt. cap. 18 which of ye times be not vnderſtād figuratiuely, but properly, be not a flagitious or an hainous dede, leaſt any man may thincke, yt the ſame may be trāsferred to theſe our times for ye vſe of life. He ſaith alſo in an other place.Ibid. 22. Multa ſūt q̄ illo tēpore officioſe facta ſūt. &c. yt is, there haue ben many things done at that tyme godly, which cannot now be done but filthily and with abſurditie. Auſten meaneth of Poligamie, that is, pluralitie of wiues and concubines, which although it were graūted and permitted to be lawfull for the olde fathers, yet we of this time may not folow their doings.

The Apoſtle Paul in the weightie treatie of iuſtification by faith with out workes, while he doth prudently perceiue,Rom 4. that it was ſpoken of Abraham, that he beleued, and that his faith was counted to him for righteouſnes long before he was circumciſed, reaſoneth and concludeth by that circumſtaunce, that Abraham was iuſtified before circumciſion.

Likewiſe he teacheth, that God gaue the promiſe that is, the bleſsing and iuſtificatiō without the helpe of the law,Gal. 3. for ſo much as the law was made foure hundred and 30 yeres after that Abraham was iuſtified.

The diligent obſeruation of this circumſtaūce of time profiteth much
to the reconciling of thoſe places of the Scripture, whiche do ſeme in appearaunce to diſagre.Lib de verb. dom. Ser. 16. Exemp. ad Hiero. VVherupon this ſaying of Auſten is vſed of many, and taken for a Prouerbe. Diſtribuite tempora, & concordat ſcriptura. Diuide the times, and the Scripture doth agree, for he with a maruelous wiſedome by marking the diuerſities of the times, reconcileth thoſe places in whiche Saint Paul often affirmeth the law to be abrogate: and openly reproueth Peter, abſteyning from certayne meates, and in which places alſo, he is mentioned to circumciſe Timothie, and that he ſhaued his head, and purified him ſelfe with other in the Temple of Hieruſalem.
