Therfore in the preaching of the Prophet, in diſputations, in Hiſtoſtories, in the Pſalmes and the Goſpell, it is requiſite, circumſpectly to diſtinguiſh, firſt in what tyme (for there is a tyme of the Goſpell) a time of mercy, a tyme of wrath and anger, a tyme of peace and warre, a tyme wherin the Churche doth floriſhe, and a tyme agayne where it is oppreſſed: Secondly of what tyme, whether of the time paſt, preſent, or to come. And thirdly in what age any man hath ſpoken or done any thing.

div.head: Place.
div.p: The place alſo muſt be circumſpectly weighed. Saint Luke writeth, that all thinges were common to the brethren at Hieruſalem, and that Ananias with Saphira his wife, were ſodeinly ſlayne, becauſe they layde vp and kept backe ſomme of the mony, whiche they tooke for their goods and landes that they ſolde. It was expedient, that ſuch thinges ſhould be done, for a tyme among the Iewes, whoſe goodes were cruelly ſpoyled of their enemyes, & among whom ther remayned very many hipocrites, to be feared with the threatnyngs of the law. But among other Churches it ought not ſo to be done, and eſpecially in the Churches of the Gentils, for by ſuch examples their mindes might haue bene rather alienated frō the Goſpell, then induced vnto it.
Paul alſo ſhore his head to purifie him ſelfe at Hieruſalem, whiche thing (vndoubtedly) he would not haue done in any other place.

div.head: Maner or way, in wordes.
div.p: There is alſo a circūſtaūce of maner to be obſerued, both in the wordes and dedes.
Concerning wordes, if we reſpect the maner, the ſentence whiche ſemed to be ſharpe, is ſoft and gentle. And agayne, that ſentence whiche ſemeth to be ſoft, is founde ſometime ſharpe.

Concerninge the deedes, that action is commendable, whyche otherwiſe might be eſtemed and taken for flagitious and haynous. And that action alſo which appeareth to be blameleſse, yet ſometyme is found to be faulty.

div.head: Examples of maner or way concerning wordes.
div.p: Our ſauiour Chriſt ſayd to his mother the virgin: woman, what haue I to do with thee? Alſo he calleth the Iewes Serpentes,Iohn. 2. Ibid. 12.23. 8. Math. 16. and the generation of Vipers, and the children of the diuel. And he calleth Peter, Sathā, al which wordes ſemed to haue come from one of an vnpacient and angry mynde.

But if ye ponder them in the maner, conuenient and agreing to hys purpoſe, ye ſhal perceiue, that he ſpake nothing worthy of blame. For his wordes which he ſpake to his mother, do import a very profitable admonition, to acknowledge the great power of his diuine nature, and alſo to waite for the oportunity of working miracles. Therfore they were ſpoken gently, and not contentiouſly.

Againe, it is manifeſt to all them that conſider the circumſtaunces, that thoſe woordes which he ſpake to the wicked and obſtinate Iewes, appeared very bitter & vehement, but yet he ſpake with a zeale, to the aduauncement of the glory of God, and for their ſaluation.

Furthermore, we muſt weigh and conſider, whither any thing be ſpoken and propoſed ſimply or doubtfully, affirmatiuely, definitiuely, or leauing it vnreſolued. As wher Chriſt ſaith:Ma. 19. 1. Cor. 7. that ſome did geld them ſelues for the kingdome of heauen. Againe, other thinges are perſwaded and counſailed, as the Apoſtle counſaileth and perſwadeth to embrace virginity. Some thinges alſo are ſeuerely and ſtraightly commaunded, as chaſtity in wedlocke, wherby the bed is kept vndefiled, & adultery auoided.

To this agreeth very wel ſaint Hierome, ſaying: Scito in ſcripturis diuinis quaedam prohiberi. &c. Know thou, that in the holy ſcriptures,ad Demet. ſome thinges be forbidden, and ſome thinges commaunded, ſome thinges graunted, and ſome thinges counſailed. Ill things be forbidden, and good thinges commaunded, meane thinges are graunted, and perfect thinges perſwaded.

div.head: Examples of maner or waies in actions and deedes.
div.p: This circumſtaunce ye may reade,Gene. 14. Exod. 12. wher Abraham vanquiſhed ſeuen kings, and led away a great pray, and where the people of Iſrael ſpoyled the Egiptians.
Oſeas the prophet receiued the harlot. Alſo, wher Dauid did eate the ſhew bread, the prieſtes killed, and did ſeeth fleſh on the ſaboth day.

In which actions, if ye rehearſe the lawe of battaile,Hoſ. 1. Math. 12. the force and ſtrength of charity, wherwith one brother is bounde to helpe an other, the commaundementes and ordinaunces of God, vrgent neceſsity, finally, the godly affectes and mindes of the doers: ye ſhall finde all thinges to be very wel done.

As for example, when ſome do relieue the poore brethren, it happeneth
ſometyme that one man doth it with a verie godly minde, onelie reſpecting the glory of god and his neyghbours benefite, and an other man doth it not of a godly mynde, ſeekynge his owne glorie among men, and diſtributing nothing of his own. And therfore ye one may be iudged to do an acceptable thinge to god, and the other to offende and diſpleaſe god.

div.head: Cauſe.
div.p: THis circumſtaunce ſaint Paule reſpected, when he ſharplye reproued Peter, for that he abſtained from thoſe meates which before he compained with the Iewes, he frelie did eate in the preſence of the Gentiles.

Some will thinke, that Paule did this thing wickedlie and ſediciouſly:Hiero. in cō ment. ad Gal and Porphitius therfore contemptuouſly enuied the dignitie of the Apoſtles, and all our religion. But if any man will ſearche and examine the ſondrie and weyghtie cauſes, whiche moued Paule, he ſhall eaſelye perceyue, that he was wiſely and iuſtly ſtirred therunto.
Firſt, Peter did it, againſt his owne conſcience for feare of the Iewes: for he knewe that the lawe was abrogate, and that nothinge was to be called common, whiche god hath ſanctified.
Secondly, by his example other wer forthwith brought into errour, being enforced to ſuppoſe, that Moyſes lawe was nedefull to ſaluation.

Thirdlie, the weake conſciences of the Gentiles were offended, whiche iudged that they were worthie of eternall damnation, if they ſhould not obſerue ſuche ceremonies, eyther iudging that the doctrine of eternal ſaluatiō was neuer ſyncerely preached vnto thē before that tyme.

Fourthly, he greatly embaſed the dignitie of Chriſt, for ſomuche as he ſemed to ſignifie vnto the Gentiles, that onelye Chriſt was not ſufficient for our iuſtification, but that the rites of the lawe were nedefull to be obſerued.
Fiftlye, the whole doctrine of the libertie of the goſpell obteyned by Chriſte, whiche was latelie planted in the churches, and began to haue luckly ſucceſſe, was peruerted
Had not ſainct Paule I praye you iuſte cauſe to reproue Peters errour, which cōteyned ſo many and greate incommodities by that his one dede?

div.head: Inſtrumentum.
div.p: This circumſtaunce alſo is worthie to be perpended and weighed. Samſon is reported,Iud. 15. 2. Sam. 17. to haue ſlaine a thouſand Philiſtines with the iawe of an aſſe. Dauid vanquiſhed Goliath onelie with a ſlynge.
In theſe examples the maruelous powers, and goodnes of God doth appere, for ſo much as with ſo baſe inſtrumēts, ſo worthy actes were don.

To this circumſtaunce pertaineth this ſayeng of Paule: Quae erant imbecillia in mundo eleg • t deus, vt pudefaceret ea quae ſunt robuſta. &c. That is, God hath choſen the weake things of the world, to confound the mightie thinges.
• . Cor. 1.

Againe he ſayth: Experimentum quaeritis in me loquentis Chriſti: 2. Cor. 13 2. Theſ. 2. ſeke ye experience of Chriſt that ſpeaketh in me. The Lord will deſtroy that wicked man with the ſpirit of his mouth, and he ſhalbe aboliſhed by the clearenes of his comming.

div.head: Cathedra Moſis. 22.
div.p: IT appeareth in the holy ſcripture,Nehem. ca. 8. et alibi. that ther was a chaire made and ſet vp in the temple, in which the Prieſts preached and interpreted the law of Moſes vnto the people aſſembled together, like as pulpets are ſet in our churches.

To ſit in the chaire of peſtilence, or of the ſcornfull (that is of blaſphemers, which do deride and mocke the word of God, his helpe and ſaluation. &c.) ſignifieth, to declare, and to teache after the manner of peſtilent men, which do contemne and deride godly and honeſt thinges.

The chaire of peſtilence is, whē a man taketh ye counſel of wicked mē, that is, to teach and defend what thing ſemeth to them good and godly, and not to wil to condemne the way of ſinners, that is, to heare the law and word of God, which condemneth al our doinges.
So Dauid heard of the prophet Nathan, like as the Gentiles heard of the Apoſtles.

To conclude, to ſit in the chaire of Moſes, is to teach, profeſſe, and to reade Moſes law, but to ſit in iudgement ſeate of Caeſar, is to iudge according to Caeſars law, wherupon this word chaire ſignifieth doctrine.

div.head: To ſay and not to do. 23.
div.p:
SOme men ſay, that euill and wicked Miniſters cannot miniſter the Sacramentes in the church of Chriſt, and preach the word of God with fruit and profit. But Chriſt is cleane againſt them, who pronounced this of the Scribes and Phariſeis, being wicked & froward perſons. Quando ſederint ſuper Cathedram Moſis, quae dicunt, facite. &c. Vvhen they ſit in the chair of Moſes, whatſoeuer they ſay:Math. 23. do you. Saint Paul alſo vnto the Philippiās ſaith, that he was very glad,Phil 1. that the Goſpel was preached, although that ſome did it of contention and enuy, that they might bring ſaint Paule in hatred with the people. Verely, if the Apoſtle had not knowen, that the Goſpell was preached of the wicked with ſome fruit, he ſhould not haue had an occaſion of gladnes, but rather of ſorrow. Vvhat ſhall we ſay alſo of Chriſt, which both called and ſuffered the traytour Iudas to teache the Goſpell? And he ſuffred ſome other to caſt out diuels in his name, when notwithſtanding they would not follow him. This our ſauiour would not permit to haue bene done, except ſome profit therof did redound vnto the Church. Let vs reaſon, a contrario, In the church ſometimes ther maye be a doctrine
taughte, which is neither good nor godly: and I pray you, may there not out of the churche, likewiſe be exhibited ſome thinges that be good and profitable? Peter was in the congregation when he perniciouſly diſſembled, wherupon Paule was conſtrained to reſiſt him openly in the face. In the ſame churche was ſainct Cypriane, who againſte the truth would haue them to be baptized againe, that were chriſtened of heretiques. VVherfore wheras theſe ſo worthie men ſwarued from the truth being conuerſaunte in the churche, it remaineth, that it is not impoſsible, that ſomtime the worde of God and the true ſacramentes ſhoulde be adminiſtrated without the churche. And in ſacramentes it is not to be conſidered, who geueth them and who receiueth them, but the thinge is to be weighed by it ſelfe, for the whiche God woulde haue the ſacrament to be moſte holye and pure.

div.head: Vvith banquettes. 24.
div.p: I Do not a litle maruell of certaine fonde men, whiche woulde haue the ſupper of the Lorde to be miniſtred with a greate ſolemne feaſte, or banquette, becauſe mention is made in the Epiſtle to the Corinthians, of a great ſupper in whiche the riche and poore did feaſt together. But if the wordes of Paule be well expended, they ſhall finde there that Paule woulde haue no ſuche banquetting. His wordes be theſe. num domos non habetis ad edendū & bibendum? Haue you not houſes to eate and drinke, as though he ſhoulde ſaye, the quantitie of meate and drinke is not required to the ſanctification or celebration of the Lordes ſupper: for what ſoeuer it be, (be it neuer ſo litle of the holy Symboles) is ſufficient to the celebration therof, wherby we ſee, that Paule doth cōdemne and reiecte that maner of banquetting, whiche the Corinthians vſed in receyuinge the Lordes ſupper. For the churche oughte not to aſſemble together, but only to heare doctrine, to offer prayers, to rendre thankes, to confeſſe their faith, to receyue the Sacraments, and to other godly exerciſes. If any other thinge be done in the churche, it is done out of ſeaſon, for euery man hath his houſe appointed him to feaſte, to banquet, to eate, and to drincke.

The ſacraments are not inſtituted for the neceſsitie of the bodie, for that ende Manna, and water out of the rocke were geuen to the Iewes: but the Sacramentes of the goſpell pertayne not to that ende. All the holy Fathers both of the Greke church, and alſo of the weſte churche, be of that iudgement.

div.head: One forme of Baptiſing of children.
div.p:
It is lawfull in the action of baptiſme, to recite goods promiſes, to recite the Symbole, to require the faith, eyther of the adulte which come to
be baptiſed, or of them which bring infants to baptiſme.

It is lawful alſo to pray and call vpon the Lord, which prayers in the beginning wer ſhort, but in proceſſe of time they grew without meſure, hauing added vnto thē not only long benedictions, but alſo diuerſe rites and ceremonies.

Tertullian writteth, ſaieng:De coron. militis Aquam adituri ſed & aliquanto prius in eccleſia ſub Antiſtitis manu cōteſtamur, nos renūciare diabolo, & pōpae, & omnibus Angelis eius. &c. Vvhen we come to the water, we ſtaye ſomwhat before in the churche vnder the hande of the prieſte, and do proteſte, that we will renounce the diuell, his pompe, and all his Angels. After that we be thriſe dipped in the water, anſweringe no more then the Lord hath determined in his Goſpell, and than being taken out we taſte of milke and hony. And from that daye we abſtaine from beinge waſhed by the ſpace of a whole weke.

Here you may ſe by the wordes of Tertullian, what rites were added vnto baptiſme: as abrenunciation, three immerſions, taſting of milke and honie, abſtinence from waſhyng. In his firſt booke againſt Martion he maketh mention alſo of oile.

Saint Hierom teſtifieth, that wine was added to the milke, he writeth in his commentaries after this maner. Domiuus prouocat, vt non ſolum emamus vinum, ſed & lac, quod ſignificat innocentiam paruulorū, Li. 15. in Eſa. qui mos ac typus in occid. eccleſiis hodie vſ
que ſeruatur, vt renatis in Chriſto vinum & lac tribuatur, that is. The Lord doth prouoke vs not only to bye wine, but alſo milke, which ſignifieth the innocencie of infants, which maner and type is euen at this day obſerued in the weſt churches, that wine and milke be geuen to them that be borne again in Chriſt.

Saint Auguſtine in certaine places of his workes doth ſhew, that diuerſe prayers and maners were vſed about baptiſme, he maketh mention of exorciſmes, and exuſflations againſt the cōtrarie power: he ſpeaketh of godfathers which promiſe fayth for the infants, he maketh mention alſo of oile wherwith the chriſtened were anointed.

Longe time after Auguſtine Rabanus Maurus biſhoppe of Mens maketh reherſal of many more ceremonies of baptiſm, as to ſign him that was baptiſed with the croſſe in his forehead and in his breſt to bleſſe ſalt & to put it into his mouth, of a whit cloth which we call the Chriſom. All theſe thinges and many ſuch other were added from tyme to tyme by menne. But if antiquitie ſeme to defende the maner of theſe rites, who dare deny the authority of the Apoſtles farre to excel their authorities, for the Apoſtles were longe before them. Therfore it ſhalbe beſt to cleaue to, and folow the ſteppes of the Apoſtles, aſwell in the miniſterie of baptiſme, as in other godly miniſtrations. As for the conſecratyng
of the water by the prieſte, which ſaint Ciprian requireth to be had in baptiſme, I ſaye, that the exemplers of the holy ſcriptures ought to be of more force and value, then the authoritie of Ciprian.
The ſcripture recordeth, that Iohn the Baptiſte and the diſciples of Chriſt baptiſed in water not conſecrated.
Vvho conſecrated the water to the Eunuche, whome Philippe chriſtened? and to many other.

If ye will vnderſtande by conſecration, not that the water oughte to be exorciſed, annointed, croſſed, &c. but only to be appointed to holy vſes: we ſay, that that conſecration ought to be admitted. In dede the water of baptiſme is holy, not for any wordes ſpoken ouer it, not for any characters added vnto it, but by the inſtitution of God, and for the holy vſe, and prayers of holy men.

div.head: Celebration of Eaſter. 25.
div.p: THere aroſe a great contention betwen the Eaſt churches and the weſt churches about the celebration of Eſter, becauſe the prieſtes of the weſte churches thoughte their tradition of the Apoſtles, Peter and Paul in celebrating Eaſter, not to be neglected: and the prieſtes of Aſia affirmed, they would folow the tradition of ſainte Iohn. In ſo much that Victor byſhop of Rome feared not to excommunicate the prieſtes of Aſia. And in ſo doing, he was greatly reprehended of the bleſſed martyr Ireneus.

Howbeit Socrates the famous hiſtoriographer, was bold, openlye to gaine ſay both the traditions. For after certaine places of the holy ſcriptures alledged, he addeth, that the Apoſtles conſtituted no traditions for the celebration of Eaſter. Theſe be his words. Nuſquam apoſtolus nec ipſa euangelia iugum ſeruitutis illis imponunt, qui ad praedicationē accedunt. &c. The Apoſtle in no place, neyther the goſpels them ſelues do laye the yoke of bondage vpon them, which come to the preachynge, but only men by a certaine cuſtome haue celebrated the feaſt of Eaſter, and other holy dayes in all places (as they liſted) to ceaſe from labours, and in remembraunce of the paſsion. Neyther our Sauiour nor the Apoſtles commaunded vs by any law to obſerue this feaſte, neyther doth the goſpell or the Apoſtles threaten vs with puniſhment, as the law of Moyſes dyd.

Alſo a litle after he ſayth thus. Mihi videtur, quod quemadmodum multa, &c. that is. I thincke, that the feaſt of Eaſter (as many other things) in euery place hath by a cuſtome ben celebrate, becauſe none of the Apoſtles (as I ſayd) eſtabliſhed nothing of it.

div.head: Polycarpus. 26.
div.p: POlycarpus was famous amonge the Apoſtolicall men,Irene. li. 3. contr. he. c. 3. whiche liued nexte after the Apoſtles time, for he was Iohn the Apoſtles ſchollar.

Like as the dignitie of the Apoſtles was greate, whiche had receyued the doctrine of the goſpell immediatly after Chriſt, ſo the worthines of Polycarpus is greatly to be eſtemed, whiche had receyued the doctrine of Chriſt out of the liuely mouthes of the Apoſtles, as out of a moſt pure fountaine. He was not only taughte of the Apoſtles, but alſo familiarly conuerſaunte (as Irenaeus ſaith) with many, whiche had ſeen the Lord Ieſus.
He was B. of Smyrna, conſtituted and appointed ther by ye Apoſtles.

Furthermore Irenaeus teſtifieth, that Polycarpus wrote a very abſolute and perfecte Epiſtle to the Philippians. But in this our tyme there is an epiſtle extante, intituled, Epiſtola Polycarpi, ad Philippēſes, which whether it be Polycarpus his in dede, let the diligent ſearchers of antiquitie weighe and iudge. For although it doth not conteyne any manifeſt errour, yet it may moue ſuſpitiō to the diligent reader: for he ſayth that he was induced by the Philippians to write, but he doth manifeſtly declare, what was the cauſe or ſcope to which he directed his epiſtle.

Not withſtandyng it appeareth, that Polycarpus in that epiſtle intreated well of the article of Chriſt, and of his expiation, of the ſinne of all mankynde, wherin he employed great labour and trauail: for he doth adourne it with teſtimonies both of the olde and newe Teſtament, and condemneth all men which diſſent or depraue that article. For thus he ſayth. Omnis qui confitetur Ieſum Chriſtum in carne non veniſſe &c. 2 Iohn 1. Vvhoſoeuer confeſſeth not that Ieſus Chriſte came in the fleſhe, he is Antichriſte, and whoſoeuer confeſſeth not the miſterie of the croſſe, he is the diuell. And whoſoeuer ſhall peruerte the wordes of the Lord, and turne them to his owne deſire, and ſhal ſay, that there is no reſurrection nor iudgement, he is the firſt be gotten ſonne of Sathan.

Of ſaluation he ſaith: Gratia ſalui facti eſtis, non ex operibus, ſed in voluntate dei per Ieſum Chriſtū. You are ſaued by grace, not by workes,Eph. 2. but in the wil of God by Ieſus Chriſt, he ſpeaketh of the ende of workes.
Ireneus ſaith, that he taught certaine errors, whiche the verye heretiques that were without the churche, durſt not teache.Euſ. li. 5. c. 20
He was of great authoritie, not only with his owne churches, but alſo with foraine churches.
Hierome ſaith, that he was chief ruler of al Aſia,In Catal. becauſe he had to his maiſters and teachers the Apoſtles, & them which had ſeene Chriſt.

Ignatius writeth, that when he wente to ſuffer death, he did betake
the cure and ouer ſighte of the church of Antioche to Policarpus, as to a moſt famous and faithfull Paſtour.
Irenaeus alſo writeth, that Polycarpus conuerted at Rome, manye that were infected with the hereſie of Valentinus and Marcion.

Nicephorus writeth,Lib. 4. ca. 39. that Polycarpus and Anicetus the biſhoppe of Rome, varied ſomwhat in iudgemēts, howbeit they did louingly cōmunicate together, in ſo muche that Anicetus permitted Polycarpus (for reuerence ſake) to miniſter the Sacramente in the church: whiche thyng is an euident teſtimonie, that the doctrine of the libertie of ceremonies at that tyme, was frely and without perturbation of the churche, reteyned.
The ſame Irenaeus writeth, that when Marcion one a tyme met Polycarpus and ſayd vnto hym: knoweſt thou vs? Polycarpus anſwered, I know, that thou art the firſt begotten ſonne of Sathan.
It appeareth out of the Epiſtle called Smyrnenſium, that he was graue and of holy maners.
The maner and cauſe of his death was this.

Marcus Antonius Verus, Vvith them that helde the Empire, moued cruell perſecutions againſte the chriſtians, aſwell in all places, as at Smyrna. This very godly man Polycarpus could not be condemned of any wicked deede, but was adiudged to death, becauſe he had taughte and ſet forth wholeſome doctrine throughout all Aſia, hauyng throwen downe and deſtroyed the Idols of the heathen.

Not only the magiſtrat of Smyrna commaunded the godly and reuerende olde man to bee taken and put to death, but alſo Polycarpus ſcholars brought forth euidence againſt him, and iudged hym worthye of death, and of their owne accord with furious hatred caried ſmall boughes to the fier. He was buried and martyred at Smyrna about the yere of Chriſt .170. He himſelfe ſayd, that he ſerued Chriſt .86. yeres, which is to be vnderſtande immediatly after his conuerſion.

div.head: Blaſphemia. 27.
div.p:
BLaſphemia, is a greke worde ſpoken in diſpight of God, and it is deuided into two partes. The fiyſt is blaſphemie againſt the holy Goſt, whiche is a continuall blamyng of the inſpiration and workes of the holye Goſte: for when the holy Goſt doth ſo euidently worke in the myndes of men, that they cannot cauill nor excuſe them ſelues by ignoraunce, yet they ſtriue againſt theyr conſcience, againſte the reuelation of the holy Goſt, whiche they knowe to be moſt true and good. As for exemple: The Phariſies beinge ouercome in their owne
conſciences with moſte manifeſte miracles, coulde not but graunte the doctrine and geſtes of our Sauiour Chriſt to be godly. Neuertheleſſe they dyd enuiouſly & falſly accuſe Chriſte, that he did all thinges by the help & inſtigation of the deuell, but Chriſt refelled them with four ſillogiſticall arguments.

div.head: 1. Argument.
div.p: The firſt, if one diuell caſt out another, then are they deuided a ſondre, and contrary the one to the other, but the diuels are not repugnaunt nor deuided amonge them ſelues: Ergo, I caſt not out diuels by the power of Belzebub.

div.head: 2. Argument.
div.p: You ſee that your children caſt out diuels by the power whiche they haue receyued of me, but none of you will ſay that your children will caſt diuels out by the power of Belzebub: Ergo, you ought not to ſaye that I caſt out diuels by the power of Belzebub.

div.head: 3. Argument.
div.p: The kyngdome of God and the deuill cannot ſtande both in one place: but the kyngdome of God is come vpon you, by vertue wherof I caſte out diuels: Ergo I caſt not out diuels by the power of Belzebub.

div.head: 4. Argument.
div.p: Forthly and finally you ſee, that none is willyng to departe from his holde, excepte he be vanquiſhed by a greater power, and by a ſtronger then himſelf, but I beinge ſtronger then he, take awaye his armour and deuide the ſpoiles. Ergo I caſt not out diuels by his power.
But this (ſayth Chriſt) I haue to ſay to you: euery ſinne of blaſphemie ſhalbe forgeuen vnto men, but the blaſphemie againſt the holy Goſt, ſhall neuer be forgeuen.

In that you haue called me a Samaritane, a winebibber, a gluttonous perſone, and that you ſeeke to kill me, it may be forgeuen you, for you may pretende ignoraunce: but where you raile againſt the diuine Maieſtie of God, aſcribing that thing to the diuel whiche is wrought by gods holy fingar, it ſhall not be forgeuen you.

Here falleth out two goodly doctrines, the firſt, we ought to ſuffer paciently thoſe thinges that are ſpoken againſt our owne perſones, and not to reuenge it, nolite reſiſtere malo, diligite inimicos veſtros, benefacite iis qui vos oderunt, (ſayth Chriſt) but we ought with an other maner of zeale to defende gods cauſe, and to refell thoſe thinges whiche are ſpoken againſt his honour and diuine maieſtye. Moyſes paciently ſuffred the murmuryng againſt him, but when he ſawe gods glory defaced, he ſlue 23000. at one clap. Let vs expende a litle nerer the wordes of Chriſt, and ſo ſhal we the better cōſider what the ſinne againſt the holy goſt is.

The holy and learned Fathers, and namely Auguſtine that diligent
ſearcher of all the ſcriptures, had moch a do about this place, and confeſſeth plainly, that there is not an harder place in all the ſcriptures thē that, and therfore he durſt not intreat of it. But it is out of all queſtion, that ſuch a ſinne ther is, and that it is irremiſsible, and becauſe occaſion of this place ſo ſerueth, I will by gods grace ſhew the iudgements of great learned men, and ſo much the more, becauſe I intende to touch in the ende that deteſtable vice of deſperation.

The ſcholaſticall doctours define the ſinne of the holy Goſt to be, if any perſone do neglecte or reiecte heauenly inſpirations and godly ſuggeſtions, which doth moue hym not to ſinne, and yet willingly will ſinne. For example: If any man be tempted or moued to ſinne, and then preſently the ſeuerity of gods iudgement do fall into his mynd, and teacheth him that God will reuenge and puniſh ſinne, if he notwithſtanding of a purpoſe do vilipende and contemne this ſuggeſtion, and had rather taſte of the paines to come, then forſake his preſent pleaſure: this man doth ſin (ſay they) againſt the holy Goſt. And of this ſinne they recken to be ſixe ſpices.

This is the cenſure of the ſcholaſtical men cōcerning the ſinne againſt the holy Goſte. It is requiſite and neceſſary throughly to expende and weighe the wordes of Chriſt. Quicunque dixerit verbum aduerſus filium hominis, Math. 12. remittetur illi. Qui autem dixerit aduerſus ſpiritū ſanctum, non remittetur illi, neque in hoc mundo, neque in futuro. Here we ſee, that Chriſte calleth this ſinne blaſphemie and railynge. Sinne properly and comonly is that which is don againſt the rule of godlynes. Blaſphemie is when a man doth not only paſſe the limittes of vertue and honeſty, but alſo whē he checketh, taunteth and rayleth at that thing, which he knoweth to be good.

div.head: Example.
div.p: He that doth not obeye the magiſtrate in all lawfull and honeſte things, doth ſinne and offende. But he which doth check taūte and raile, doth cut and bite the magiſtrat, is a blaſphemer of the magiſtrat.

The ſonne who doth not obey his parēts, ſinneth: but he which raileth vpon his parēts, is a blaſphemer of his parents. So in the words of Chriſt, it is wel to be noted, that he doth not ſay, qui peccauerit aduerſus ſpiritū ſanctum, ſed qui dixerit aduerſus ſpiritum ſanctum conuitium. So that the ſinne againſt the holy Goſt is alwaies coupled with checks, rebukes, ſlaunders and contumelious wordes, which wordes be ſpoken of a ſet malice, and an enuious deſpighte, beinge well knowen and againſte a mans owne conſcience,
Therfore the diuiſion of the ſcholemen into thoſe vi. kindes before named ſemeth not to be conſonāt with the wordes of Chriſt. For it may be, that he which doth this day preſume of Gods mercy wtout all godly worcking, and that he which doth this day diſpaire of Gods grace, that he which is this day obſtinate and impenitent, may to morow repent and redreſse thoſe vices. But if they continue to the end in their former ſinnes, then it is, Peccatum ad mortem, And S. Auſten calleth this ſinne againſt the holy ghoſt Finalem impaenitentiam.

It may ſufficiētly appere by the Scriptures, that euery ſin againſt the holy ghoſt, is not ſo condemned of Chriſt, that it is vtterly vnforgeueable, for then their ſinnes ſhould be vnforgeueable, which ignorauntly reſiſte the preching of Gods holy grace, but vnto ſuch is not denied the place of repentaūce, nor remiſsion of ſinnes, as appeareth in the Actes of the Apoſtles, when Stephen had ſayd to the Iewes, you ſtifnecked people,Act. 7. and of vncircumciſed hartes, you alwayes reſiſte the holy ghoſt: yea when he was ſtoned to death: he praying ſayd: Domine ne imputes cis peccatum hoc, quia neſciunt quid faciunt.

To be playne and ſhort, there be two kinds of blaſphemies: one is of thē whiche do perſecute and raile vpon Gods veritie & truth thorough ignoraunce. Theſe be like vnto them, whiche railed vpon the ſonne of man by reaſon of his humble and lowly liuing, as Paul him ſelfe did, vnto ſuch remaineth a place of repentaūce. And for ſuch we may pray, for they ſinne not vnto death, ſo the Apoſtle ſpeaketh of him ſelfe.1. Timo. 1. Qui prius blaſphemus fui & perſecutor & contumelioſus, miſericordiam conſecutus ſum, quia ignorans feci. &c.

The ſecond kind of blaſphemie is, whē a man doth not ignoraūtly, but wittingly, willingly, enuiouſly, of an obſtinate malice agaynſt his owne knowledge and conſcience, blaſpheme and raile vpon the truth of Gods Goſpell, with opprobrious and ſlaūderous wordes. And for theſe we may not pray, for they ſinne vnto death agaynſt the holy ghoſt.
In this predicamēt were the Phariſies, the Scribes and they which ſaid (In Belzebub eiicit demonia.)
In this predicamēt were Iulianus Porphirius, and Alexander, the copper Smith.

Finally in this predicament are they which did once know the truth, and earneſtly embrace the veritie of Chriſtes Goſpell, but now turnyng their ſailes, haue reuolted, & do moſt diſpightfully, and cruelly perſecut, blaſpheme and raile vpon the ſame.

There is a notable and ſingular well learned man, beautified with all kind of good literature, which writeth, that as long as we be in this life, we ought not to diſpaire of ſaluation, vnles we ſinne agaynſt the holy ghoſt, whiche ſinne (ſayth he) foraſmuch as we vnderſtand it not but by
ſome priuate reuelation, hope on it neuer to be caſt of. The primatiue Churche (ſaith he) had the gift of prouing of ſpirites, by the whiche they knew this kinde of ſinne, but in theſe dayes, when we do not certainly know that a man is deteyned with the ſame ſinne, we ought to hope well of all men, be his ſinnes neuer ſo great, and neuer ſo many.

Saint Augustine for this hath two comfortable ſayinges, Quicquid egeris, quantumcumque peccaueris, noli deſperare, Nam ſi adhuc in mundo es, ſi deus te ſaluare non vult, ex mundo auferet, qui tibi parcēdo clamabit, ne recederes, iam parcendo clamat vt redeas.
The ſecond ſaying: Pro peccatis tuis ne attendas pro quo oras, ſed attende quem oras: magnitudinem morbi tui vides, & potentiam medici non vides.

Theſe be comfortable ſayinges agaynst the bottomles ſinne of deſperation. God of his mercy and gracious goodnes ſaue and deliuer all Christian hartes from theſe and ſuch like detestable and damnables falles.

div.head: Iudas Iſcarioh. 28.
div.p:
IVdas was the ſonne of one Simon, ſurnamed Iſcarioh, eyther of the tribe of Iſsachar or els of his facte, for Iſcariotes ſignifieth Virum occiſionis. How he lyued before he was Apoſtle, it is vncertayne. But after Christ entred into hys ministerie, Iudas was choſen into the noumber of the Apostles: for they were Christes beſt Diſciples, beyng dayly conuerſant with hym, & learnyng the true doctrine of the kyngdome of God. They ſawe his miracles, and they were brought vp with hym to this ende: first, that they might teache and do miracles there with Chriſt by the commaundement and will of Christ, whiche graunted them this power by his omnipotent worde. And alſo that after his reſurrection they myght preach his worde through the whole worlde. Neyther any man among all the Diſciples was admitted to that office but onely the iwelue. By this it appeareth, that Iudas at the beginnyng was not the worst Diſciple of Chriſt. Chriſt alſo declared, that he loued him, becauſe he choſed him into the nomber of the Apoſtles. And although he knewe, that he would betray him, yet he called him, and beſtowed ſo great benefites on him, that he might teſtifie, that he would gladly haue hym ſaued, and that he did not allowe his perdition nor deſperation by the ſinne committed. But Iudas neglectyng theſe ſo great benefites, and beyng werie of the pouertie and daungers whiche he was compelled to ſuffer for Chriſt, did caſt in his mynde howe goodly a thyng it was to haue money, and to haue to his frendes men of great authoritie, as were the Biſhops and Prieſts, beyng riche and plentifull in all worldly wealth: wherupon he weighed with hym ſelfe, by what meanes he myght obteyne theſe two thyngs, how be it
he did not forth with vtter that thing whiche he kept ſecret in his harte. Notwithſtanding Ieſus Chriſt the ſearcher of mens hartes, perceiued his ſecret thoughtes and pretences, and might haue repelled him forthwith as a wicked Apoſtata, and vnprofitable ſeruaunt: but of his great beniguitie he ſuffred him, and frendly warned him, to leaue of from ſo wicked enterpriſes, but all in vayne.

VVherby it is manifeſt, how peſtilent a thing it is to ſet our mindes wholly vpon the getting of riches, and alſo how great offence it is to flatter eccleſiaſticall men (as they are called) whiche be of great power and authoritie, moleſtyng Chriſt and his doctrine with great hatred (as it hath chaunced in all times, and alſo now in Antichriſtes reygne it is plainely verified,) whiche to do, is nothing els but to betraye Chriſt and his kingdome, for that the holy ſpirite is aboliſhed, and ſo great an obſtinacie groweth in ſuch mens hartes, that when they heare the word of God, they contemptuouſly neglect and hate it, neuer ceaſing from perſecuting the true teachers, in ſo much that they ſeeke pretences of moſt manifeſt and wicked deedes, yea, and do defend them with very deueliſhe vnſhamefaſtnes.

div.head: Bethel. 29.
div.p: BEthell was a Citie in the coſtes of the tribe of Beniamin, and Ephraim. It was diſtant from Hieruſalem three miles.Gen. 28. It was firſt called Luza. But after, when Iacob beyng in that place, ſaw the Lord ſtandyng vpon the ladder, he called it Bethell, that is, the houſe of God.

In this place Bethell,3. Reg. 12. 4. Reg. 2 Hieroboam ſet vp the idolatrous worſhippyng of one of the golden calues. In this place the children whiche mocked Elizeus the Prophet, were torne and rent and killed of Beares.

div.head: Seuen thouſand. 30.
div.p:
THe nomber of ſeuen, is taken in holy Scripture for a perfect nomber, an holy, and abſolute nomber, and doth contayne great mysteries, as in that ſaying of Peter to Chriſt:Math. 17. 3. Reg. 19. Shall I forgeue ſeuen tymes? It is taken alſo for an indefinite nomber and multitude,Luk. 8. as in this place (I haue left ſeuen thouſand) that is a great multitude and nomber. Likewiſe in Luke, where it is ſpoken of one of the Maries out of whom were caſt ſeuen deuils,Prou. 24. that is a great nomber. Likewiſe in the Prouerbes. Septies in die cadit iuſtus. Seuen tymes in a day the righteous man doth fall. Et ſepties in die laudem dixi tibi, Seuen tymes in a day I prayed to thee. Agayne the vniuerſitie of creatures
conſiſteth in the nomber of ſeuen. The earth is diſtinct by ſeuen climates. The heauen by ſeuen Planetes: The tyme or weeke by ſeuen dayes. In the Scriptures it may be taken both in the good and euill ſignifications. In the good parte in the Pſalme Eloquia domini, eloquia caſta, argentum igne examinatum, Pſalm. 11. purgatum ſeptuplum .i. multipliciter.
In the ill parte (as in Mathew) Aſſumit alios ſpiritus ſeptem nequiores. Math. 12. He taketh ſeuen other ſpirites worſe then hym ſelfe.

div.trailer: ❧ Here endeth the firſt Tome, both of the Praelections, and alſo of the Miſcellanes.

div.head: Certaine Miſcellanes to be added, as here doth follow, whereby ye may eaſely ſee by the Folios where they ſhould be placed. ¶Place this Miſcel. in folio .76. before Iohannes Euangeliſta.
Antichriſte, 25.
div.p:
ALthough certaine of the ſcholaſticall diuines do ſay that Antichriſt ſhalbe born of the natiō of the Iewes, and of the tribe of Dan, and that (as S. Ambroſe writeth) he ſhall come of the Circūciſion, or els be circumciſed: yet great learned men, which with depe iudgemēts haue read the Scriptures, do write that he ſhall not be one perſonall mā onely, but that vnder the name of Antichriſt is meant and comprehended the whole kingdome of falſe teachers, bearing rule in the Temple of God, & that in a great Citie, which hath rule and dominiō ouer kinges of the earth, profeſsing Chriſt outwardly in doctrine, but yet denieng his merite and office, which ſhall make diabolicall lawes, and forbid Mariage and meates, to depraue & corrupt the true worſhip of Chriſt, and to mayme & abridge the ceremonies inſtituted of Chriſt, and to alter and chaunge them to an other ende, then for whiche they were ordayned, whiche ſhall beare both the ſwordes politique and eccleſiaſticall. He ſhall ſhew him ſelf as it were a God, as to be the vicare of Chriſt and the head of the Church, and to haue power ouer all Magiſtrates, and to be aboue all Councels, and in whoſe breſt all lawes aſwell diuine as humain, are written and layd vp, and one that may prefixe and reuoke the Articles of the faith, and to haue power to commaund the Angels of God, vnto whom all men ought to obeye in euery reſpect, vnder payne of damnation, and who ought to be iudged of no man, yea although he deceiue innumerable ſoules, and not to be demaunded why he doth thus, Origene writing vpon Mathew ſaith: Generaliter vnus eſt Antichriſtus, ſpecies autem illius multae. &c. that is: Generally there is but one Antichriſt, but the ſpices be many, as though he would ſay, generally there is but one lye, but cōcerning the difference of falſe doctrines, ther ar foūd many lyes. Saint Bernard writing vpon the Pſalm, ſemeth to touch Antichriſt very nerely in the prelacie and other eccleſiaſticall offices of the Churche. His wordes be theſe: Pro Epiſcopatibus & Archidiaconatibus imprudenter hodie decertatur. &c. that is. Nowe there is ſhameles ſtrife for Biſhopprickes and Archdeaconries, that the reuenues of the Church may be waſted vpon ſuperfluous and vayne vſes. It remayneth therfore that the man of ſinne, the ſonne of perdition, a deuil not onely walking in the night, but alſo in the noon day, may be now reuealed, which is not onely tranſfigured into an aungell of light, but alſo is extolled aboue all that is called God, or is worſhipt as God. By theſe wordes of Bernarde it appeareth
vnto whom the wordes of Saint Paul ought to be referred, leaſt any man might impute them to the new writers, as though they wer the firſt that referred Antichriſt vnto the chief Biſhop of the corrupt ſtate of the clergie. He openly declared, that in his time the reuelation of Antichriſt might be gathered by the ſymonie, bying and ſellyng, ambition and riot of the eccleſiaſticall perſons. And here is to be noted that Saint Bernarde did acknowledge not onely that Antichriſt, whiche is agaynſt Chriſt, but alſo he whiche doth thruſt him ſelfe into the Churche in ſtede of Chriſt. So that Antichriſt may be called, both the aduerſarie and alſo the vicare of Chriſt. As he is not onely called Antiſtraticos, which ſetteth him ſelfe agaynſt the captaine of any hoſt, but alſo it is he whiche in ſtede of the captaine, intrudeth him ſelfe into the ſouldiours, and boſteth hym ſelfe to be captaine. For this prepoſition 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , doth ſignifie in Greke both Contra, agaynſt, and Pto for, ſo that he is properly Antichriſt, which is both the aduerſarie and vicare of Chriſt. VVherfore who ſoeuer ſhall take power vpon him in the Church and exerciſe dominion and rule ouer the people of the Lord, he is the mēber and companiō of Antichriſt: That auoureth of an old wiues tale which is feined of Nero the Emperour that he ſhould be taken out of the world, and ſhoulde come agayne to vexe the Churche with his tyrānie, and that the mindes of ſome, wer ſo bewitched, that they thought Nero to be Antichriſt. But Paul in the Epiſtle to the Theſsalonians ſpeaketh not of one man, but of a kingdome which ſhould be inuaded of Sathan, that he might erect the ſeat of abhomination in the middeſt of gods Temple, which we ſee to be accompliſhed in the Papacie, although that defection now grow ſomewhat larger. For Mahomet hath cauſed the Turkes to ſwarue from Chriſt. I am not ignoraunt that ſome of the olde diuines do hold, that Antichriſt ſhalbe borne in Babilon, and that theſe wordes, Fiat Dan coluber in via, are referred to Antichriſt as Saint Ambroſe, Theodoretus and other do expound that place, but howe aptly, I referre it to the iudgement of the learned reader.
div.note: ¶ Place this Miſcel. in folio. 83. before Paralogiſmos.

div.head: The greater parte. 35.
div.p: IN the tyme of Achab kyng of Iuda the greater part ouercame the better. Vvhen Vrias the high Prieſt, did winck at the idolatrie of the king, and other princes and Magiſtrates conſenting to the ſame: The kyng did ſhut the Temple of the Lord, and tooke away the holy ſeat, & cauſed the Miniſterie of the word and the ordinarie vſe of the Sacrifices to ceaſſe. Notwithſtanding there was an holy Church in Iuda, in the whiche Eſay the Prophet, with fewe other taught the true worſhipping of God.

Vnder Manaſses nephew vnto Achab the greater part ouercame the better, when ſincere doctrine and the lawfull celebration of the Sacraments (circumciſion onely excepted) was baniſhed. And this apoſtaſie frō God, continued vntill the Churche was refourmed of the moſt godly Ioſias. Neuertheles there was a Churche in Iuda, and Prophetes ſent, although the greater part of the people with their gouernours did folowe and defend impietie, and the defection of Manaſſes.

Vnder Ieroboam king of Iſraell the greater part ouercame the better, when ye king depoſed & put out of office the Leuits, the doctors of ye law and preachers of the ſincere veritie, and gaue vnlearned Prieſts and Paſtours to the people. He built alſo new Temples, made Idoles, and golden Calues, he inſtituted a new kinde of worſhipping God. He made new altars and appointed new feaſtes, and did ſo much abrogate the true worſhipping of God, that there appeared in Iſraell no one tokē of the Church of God. And yet there is no doubt, but God reſerued to him ſelfe a Church at that tyme, vnto whiche he ſent his Prophetes, although they wer perſecuted and driuen from place to place of the greater part.

Vnder Ieroboam the ſecond of that name, Amos the prophet, a paſtour & heardmā of Tecoa, taught the true doctrine of God (the greateſt part ſwaruing from God.) Yea and the high prieſt Amazias cōmaunding him to go vnto the land of Iuda, to preach ther, and that he ſhould not preach hereafter in Bethel, becauſe it was the foundation and tēple of the kinge.

Vnder Achab the kyng ouercomming all men before him in all kinde of impietie, the greateſt part ouercame the better, when the ſayd Achab had filled all places in Iſraell with ſuperſtitious Idolatrie and ſacrileges, & did alſo perſecute moſt cruelly the prophets for teching the ſincere doctrine of God. Notwithſtandyng there was found in Iſraell a true church of God (Elias the great and excellent Prophet of God ſetting forth the true worſhippyng of God) and mightely inueighyng agaynſt the king, agaynſt his falſe Prophetes, and agaynſt the people.

By theſe preſidētes and examples it may be gathered, that the greateſt part is not the beſt, and thoſe thinges which do pleaſe them moſt, are not alwayes to be commended. To this purpoſe do pertayne alſo the goodly ſayinges and examples of the heathen.

Diogenes going on a certaine day into the theatre or playing place, did thruſt him ſelfe in when the people were comming forth. And beyng demaunded why he did ſo, he aunſwered, I haue ben accuſtomed ſo to do all the time of my life, meanyng to be the part of a wiſe man to diſsent in all actions from the multitude, becauſe the greateſt part of men are led, not by reaſon, but by affections.

Phocion when he had made to the people of Athenes a goodly oration,
and perceiuing that he had pleaſed all men, and that his oration was commended of the greateſt nomber, turnyng to his frendes ſayde: Quid num mali quippiam dixi imprudens? Vvhat, haue I ſpoken any euill thing lyke an vnwiſe man? He was perſwaded that nothing could pleaſe the greateſt nomber, whiche ſwarued from the right and ſound iudgement.

Policarpus beyng commaunded to render a reaſon of his fayth vnto Herode the proconſul, required a day to aunſwere. The proconſul would he ſhould defend and excuſe him ſelfe before all the people. Vnto whom Policarpus aunſwered ſaying: Non faciam quū principibus & poteſtatibus honos debeatur, modo non ſit contrarius: populo autē furenti ſatisfacere nemo poſsit. I will not do ſo, for ſo much as honour is due vnto princes and to the higher powers, ſo it be not contrarie to God. But the raging and wood people no man can ſatisfie.
div.note: ¶ Place this Miſcel. before Ieruſalem. folio. 86.

div.head: Paracletus. 37.
div.p: THis word Paracletus cōmeth of this Greke verbe 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which ſignifieth, Rogare & exhortari, to deſire, pray or exhorte. It betokeneth alſo to be a ſollicitour, an aduocate or a patrone for any other perſon. The Grecians of the later time vſe it for a comforter, an aider, a fautor. Therfore the Lord promiſeth to his diſciples that he would ſend them the holy ghoſt, as a comforter which ſhould confirme them in all truth and veritie.

Paraclytus, written with Ypſilon, ſignifieth an infamous and notorious offender. For 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , in cōpoſition betokeneth Praeter, or Sinc, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , ſignifieth noble, glorious, laudable, ſo that ye may call him 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , whiche is ill reported of, not praiſe worthy, or of no renowme.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , with Iota in penultima, ſignifieth Aſſeſſorem qui vna diſcumbit, him that ſitteth downe by one.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , ſignifieth alſo a loude crier or talker which moleſteth men with his clamorous talke, and ſo Sophocles vſeth it.
Ibicus, calleth, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Diluculum the dawning of the day, becauſe at that time it is lawful to heare & to ſpeake, which in greke they cal 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .
div.note: ¶ Place this to the end of the third Prelection. folio. 91.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: THe Church hath & may conſtitute & make Articles of yt faith without Scripture, as tharticle of tranſubſtantiation, the article of reſeruation, the article of eleuation and ſuch like.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p:
Saint Paule doth manifeſtly ſay, Fides eſt ex auditu, auditus autem per verbum dei, Faith is by hearyng, & hearing by the word of God. Al the ſcholaſtical men haue alwayes in their mouthes the obiect of ſaith to be the veritie reuealed of God, and conteined in the Canon of the Bible. It is therfore not
onely folie, but alſo great impietie to affirme that the Church may make any Article of the faith without the Scripture.

What blaſphemie is it in that Cochleus doth ſay that tharticle of the Trinitie cannot be proued out of the Scripture? And it is alſo moſt falſe that he doth impudently aſſerte the Churche to haue bene before the worde. For when fayth maketh the Church, and leaneth to the worde of God, it is manifeſt the Church alſo doth leane to the worde it ſelfe as to the foundation. But the fooliſhe man dreameth and iudgeth dotingly no worde to haue bene before Moſes, and beynge blinded of the deuil, cannot or els wil not ſee Moſes to haue written of the word of God ſpoken to Adam of the bleſſed ſeede to come, that ſhoulde breake the Serpentes head. He vnderſtandeth not this worde, and the faith of this worde to conſtitute and make the Churche.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: Chriſt promiſed the holy ghoſt to be alwayes preſent to the Church that he may lead her to al truth. Wherby Fiſher Biſhop of Rocheſter proueth, that we ought to geue as good credite to the Church, as to the Apoſtles.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: This hereſie is one of the peſtilent hereſies of the Manichies, whiche hereſie Saint Auſten moſt pithily, and learnedly doth confute. For the Maniche maketh a preface before his hereſies, that he is the Apoſtle of Chriſt, and the prouidence of the father. And by this contendeth that he ought to be beleued as much and as well as thapoſtles. Vnto whom Saint Auſten aunſwereth that he will not receyue any newe worde, nor other from that whiche was deliuered of thapoſtles and receyued of the Churche. His wordes be theſe, written in the booke Contra Fauſtum Manichaerum. Diſtincta eſt a poſterioribus libris excellentia Catholicae authoritatis veteris ac noui Teſtamēti quae Apoſtolorum confirmata temporibus per ſucceſsiones Epiſcoporum & propagines Eccleſiarum tanquam in ſede quadam ſublimiter cōſtituta eſt, cui ſeruiat cuius fidelis & pius intellectus, ibi ſi quid velut abſurdum mouerit, non licet dicere, author huius libri non tenuit veritatem, ſed aut calex mendoſus eſt, aut interpres errauit, aut tu non intelligis. &c. The excellencie of the Catholique or Canonicall authoritie of tholde and new Teſtament, is diſtincte from the bookes of other that come after, whiche canonicall authoritie confirmed in the tyme of thapoſtles and by the ſucceſſion of Biſhops, & by ſpredding abroade of the Churches, is conſtitute and ſet as it were the higheſt and chiefeſt ſeat, vnto whiche euery faithful and godly vnderſtandyng ought to ſerue and geue place. If any abſurde thyng be there moued it is not lawful to ſay, the authour of this boke did not hold the truth, but it is lawful to ſay, the boke is faultie or ye interpreter erred, or yu vnderſtādeſt it not. In the works of the poſteritie (which ar conteyned in bokes innumerable) yet by no meanes ar they equal, or are to be compared to that moſt ſacred excellencie of the Canonical Scriptures, yea if in any of them ther be founde the ſame veritie, yet that authoritie is farre vnequall. Wherfore in them if any thing ſeeme to be diſſonant from the truth, becauſe they are not vnderſtand as they are ſpoken yet the reader hath free iudgement to approue that whiche pleaſeth hym, and to improue that whiche offendeth hym. This much S. Auſten.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: Saint Auſten ſaith, Euangelio non crederem niſi ad id me moueret Eccleſiae authoritas I would not haue beleued the goſpel, vnles the authoritie of the Church had moued me therto.
Therfore by the teſtimonie of Saint Auſten the authoritie of the Churche is to be preferred before the Scriptures.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Let vs examine the wordes of Saint Auſten a litle nerer and we ſhall finde theſe wordes of Saint Auſten to make rather agaynſt our aduerſaries then with them. Saint Auſten doth manifeſtly ſay that he will not beleue the Maniche or his word as the Scripture, becauſe the Scripture was diſtinct before the Apoſtles from all bookes, and was confirmed, they beyng aliue, and afterwarde receyued of all men in the Church without any contradiction. Therfore it is manifeſt that they falſifie the wordes of Saint Auſten, and do alledge them contrarie to their conſciences, for the worde not written, and the doctrines of men beſides the ſcriptures. Agaynſt the whiche Saint Auſten doth (as it were) Ex diametro fight. For he doth euidently forbidde any doctrine to be receiued in the Churche as the worde of God, whiche was not confirmed in the tyme of thapoſtles, and receyued in the Churche as the worde of God. And that this is the minde of Saint Auſten: Gerſō affirmeth, and confuteth the impudencie of them whiche attribute power to the Churche to iudge of the Goſpell, and to make articles of the fayth without the Scriptures. His wordes be theſe. Ex iſtis deducitur quod maior fuit eccleſiae primi tiuae authoritas, quam nunc ſit Papae & Epiſcoporum, & quod non eſt in poteſtate concilii, aut eccleſiae mutare traditiones datas ab euangeliſtis. Et paulo poſt. Sicut quidam delirant, nec habent, quo ad hoc, quod eſt facere aliquod pure de fide parem authoritatis firmitatem. Licet enim ipſorum inſtitutiones in dubium vocare. Et hic aperitur modus intelligendi illud Auguſtini. Eccleſiae non crederem niſi me compuliſſet authoritas eccleſiae. Ibidem enim ſumit eccleſiam pro primitiua congregatione fidelium illorum qui Chriſtum audiuerunt, & viderunt, & eius teſtes fuerunt. &c. Of theſe thinges it is deduced that the authoritie of the primatiue Church was greater, then the authoritie of the Pope is now and other Biſhops, and that it is not in the power of any councell or the Churche to alter or chaunge the traditions geuē of the Euangeliſtes. And a litle after he ſaith: Nor they haue not (as ſome dote) the like firmneſſe of the authoritie concerning this, that is, to make any thing to be of faith pure, for it is lawful to call their inſtitutions to doubte. And here is opened the way to vnderſtande that ſaying of S. Auſten: I would not haue beleued the Goſpel, except the authoritie of the Churche had compelled me. For S. Auſten taketh the church there for the primatiue cōgregation of thoſe faithful which heard Chriſt, ſawe him, and were witneſſes of him. This is the minde of Gerſon concerning theſe wordes of Saint Auſten, Euangelio non crederem. &c.

Theſe wordes alſo may be vnderſtand after this maner: Sainct Auſten did not ſay, niſi mouiſſet authoritas eccleſiae. But doth ſignificantly ſay: niſi commouiſſet, ſignifiyng the authoritie of the church by her ſelf not to haue bene ſufficiēt, but the two articles of the chriſtian faith, that is, the inſtincte of the holye ſpirite, and the ſtudie of the worde of God to moue the mindes of the electe to beleue.

Nor this argument is anie thinge worth. Sainct Auſten would not haue beleued the goſpel except he had ben moued of the church, Ergo the iudgemēt of the church beareth rule ouer the ſcripture. I wil make you the like forme of arguments.
Iohn came to beare teſtimonie of the light Chriſt, that all might beleue by hym. Ergo, Iohn is to be preferred before Chriſt.
Again, many of the Samaritanes beleued in Chriſt, through the wordes of the womā of Samaria. Ergo, the woman of Samaria is to be preferred before Chriſt.

Again, let the women be ſubiect to their huſbands that they whiche beleue not the word, might he won without the worde by the cōuerſation of women. Ergo the conuerſation of women is better then the worde.
What fonde man, what dolte, or what aſſe would thus argue or reaſon after this maner? Truly none excepte he were deſtitute of the common ſenſes.

To make Auſtenes words plaine, you ſhall note that S. Auſten had muche to do with the Manichies, who without all controuerſie would haue credit to be geuen
vnto them, and yet did not ſhew the veritie which they boaſted and promiſed to haue. And alſo that they might purchaſe faith vnto their maiſter Maniche they made a pretence and alledged the goſpel. Nowe S. Auſten demaundeth of them what they would do if they chaunced vpon ſuch a man which beleued not the goſpell, and aſketh them with what kinde of perſuaſion they woulde leade him vnto their ſentence. And afterward S. Auſten doth ſay: I would not haue beleued the goſpel, except the autoritie of the church had compelled me: ſignifieng, that when he was an alien from the fayth, he could no otherwiſe bee induced to embrace the goſpell, or the infallible veritie of God, excepte he had bene conuinced by the authoritie of the church. And what maruel is it, if one not yet knowing Chriſt, haue reſpect of men? Therfore S. Auſten dothe not in this place teache that the faith of the godly is founded vpon the authoritie of the church, nor doth vnderſtande the certaintie of the goſpel to depend therof, but doth ſhew, ſimpliciter, that the goſpell would be moſt vncertayne to the infidels that they might be wonne to Chriſt by it, except the authoritie of the church do impell them, ſo that the church is (as it were) Iſagoge, by the which we be prepared vnto fayth.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p:
Tertullian ſaith, Quodcun
que primum eſt, id rectum eſſe, adulterum vero quod poſterius. Whatſoeuer thing is firſt, that to be right and true, and that whiche is laſt, to be counterfayted and corrupted. Ergo, the doctrine of the churche of Rome which was before this new doctrine, is more true and right, than this doctryne which came in of late.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Theſe wordes of Tertullian do fight for the authoritie of the Scriptures, againſt al doctrines geuen after, and againſt the worde not written: for there was diſputation of the doctrine of the Manichies to be receyued for the Scripture and the worde of God: which Cerdon, Marcion and Praxeas did contend, with whom Tertullian had much to do. But he aunſwereth, he would not ſtand to their preſcriptions (we may call them well enough proſcriptions) vnles they would admit them whole Scripture receiued of the Church, and would acknowledge the authoritie of the church, teſtifieng of the ſcriptures. For the church is as teſtis & witnes of the doctrine of the apoſtles, which the apoſtles would to be firme and perpetual. The church hath now no reſpect to thoſe traditiōs, which the Apoſtles would not to haue bene obſerued for euer. For now none do obſerue the tradition of the apoſtolical Synode concernyng the eatyng of bloud and ſtrangled meates.

Saint Cypriane hath a ſhort ſentence, but yet ſure and firme of all ſuch traditions. Non hominum conſuetudinem, ſed dei veritatem ſequendam eſſe, nec curandum quid homines ante nos ſenſerint, ſed quid Chriſtus ante omnes mandauerit. We muſt not folow (ſaith he) the cuſtome of men, but the veritie of God, nor we ought to regarde what men haue iudged before, but what Chriſt hath commaū ded before all

To conclude S. Hierome hath a notable ſentence for the perſpicuitie and authoritie of the ſcripture. He writing vpon this verſe of the pſalme. Dominus narrauit in ſcripturis principum populorum qui fuerunt in ea. The Lord hath ſhewed in the ſcriptures of princes and of the people which were there. Nullius hominis quantumuis ſancti aut docti ſcriptum habet authoritatem, quia dominus narrauit in ſcripturis populorum & principum. The writing of no man, be he neuer ſo holy or well learned, hath authoritie, becauſe the Lorde hath declared in the ſcriptures of the Princes & people, of the people becauſe the ſcriptures perteine to al the people and not to the prieſt onely, of the princes which were in her, ſee what he ſaith (ſaith S. Hierome) which were, and not which are, nor ſhalbe. That is, that beſides the canonical ſcripture of the prophetes and of the Apoſtles, whatſoeuer ſhal be ſpoken afterwards, may be cut of and haue no authoritie.

Although therfore any man after the Apoſtles be holy, although he be eloquēte or learned, yet he hath no authoritie. He hath the like ſentence which is common. Quicquid ex ſcriptura non habet authoritatem, eadem ratione contemnitur qua probatur.

Thus I haue at the ful declared vnto you all the firſt general parte of my partition, and becauſe time draweth away, I will now end, and vntil the nexte repairyng hither, I commit you to God, to whome &c.
div.note: ¶ Place this Miſcel. before Iouinianus. in folio. 94.

div.head: Brothers wife. 4.
div.p: IT is not onely forbidden by the Scriptures for man to marrie his brothers wife, but alſo by the aunciēt and learned fathers, and by certaine generall councels. Tertullian the moſt eldeſt writer of al that wer ſince the time of the apoſtles, doth writ that this Leuiticall forbidding that a mā ſhould not marrie his brothers wife, was brought in, taught, and ordeined, ſpecially and by name, euen of Christ him ſelfe and his apostles, becauſe that all the whole Churche and company of Christes faith ſhould obſerue and kepe it with all reuerence.

Becauſe (ſaith he) that certain perſons ſomtimes do ſay that they haue nothing to do with Moſes law, which Christ doubtles did not take away, but fulfilled and made it perfect, do ſometime take thoſe things of the law that liketh them and make for their purpoſe. Plainly we alſo ſe this that the law is departed and gone as touching this point: that according to the minde and ſaying of the apostles, the burdēs of the law which our fathers wer not able to beare, be vtterly ceaſsed and taken away. But as for thoſe things that pertaine to iuſtice and vertue do remaine whole, not onely reſerued, but alſo amplified and encreaſed, ſo that our iustice and goodnes which be Christiā people, ſhould be much greater and perfecter then the iuſtice of the Scribes and phariſies, and be ſuch iuſtice as a very iuſt mā ought to haue. And our chaſtitie likewiſe ſhould excell and paſse theirs, and in no point be leſse then theirs. Now becauſe it is cōmaunded in Moſes law, that a man ſhould marry his brothers wife, that is departed with out children, becauſe he ſhould ſtirre vp ſede, or get iſſue to his brother. And becauſe this thing may happen oftentimes to one perſon, as that one woman may be married to ſix or vij. brethren one after another, for lack of iſsue by the former brother according to the ſuttle queſtiō of the Saduces in the Goſpel: therfore ſome do thinke that the oftennes of Mariage is promiſed alſo in other caſes. But theſe men ſhould haue vnderſtand firſt of all the reaſon and cōſideration of this precept, and ſo they ſhould haue knowne that this reaſon is now ceaſſed, and is one of the things which be now voide and of no ſtrength nor authoritie. For a man was bound of neceſsitie to marrie the wife of his brother, which was departed wtout children.
Firſt becauſe that as yet that old bleſsing of God (increaſe you and multiplie) ought to runne forth and continue. Second, becauſe the childrē were puniſhed for the fathers faultes. Thirdly becauſe the drie and barren perſons wer had for defamed perſons. Therfore, ordinaūce was made that they ſhould haue iſsue by other of their kinne, as ye would ſay by a proctour, and begotten after the death of the father: becauſe that they which wer departed without iſsue, not by the fault of nature and by preuention of death, ſhould not therfore be iudged accurſed and vnhappy. But now the bleſsyng of increaſing and multiplieng bodily and carnally is ceaſſed, becauſe the world is at an end. For the Apoſtle induceth and counceleth vs ſaying: There is no more but that they alſo which haue wiues ſhould be, as if they had none, becauſe the time is ſhort. And agayne. The ſoure grape that our fathers did eate, that is, the ſinne that they did eate, doth no more ſtoniſh or ſet on edge the teeth of the childrē: for euery man ſhall dye for his owne ſinne. And moreouer the barren now be not onely without infamie and rebuke, but alſo haue deſerued fauour and thanckes of God, beyng inuited and admitted into the kingdome of heauē. And therfore now this law that a mā ſhould ſuccede into his brothers mariage, or that he ſhould mary his brothers wife, is now vtterly dead & buried, and the contrarie of this law taketh place, that a man ſhoulde not ſuccede into his brothers Mariage, nor marrye his brothers wife. And by this (as is ſaid before) that law which is ceaſſed & is no more of ſtrength, becauſe the reaſon of it is ceaſsed or taken away, cannot be a conuenient proofe for another thing. This much Tertullian.

Chriſoſtome doth plainly an ſtifly holde that fable and tale that the Saduces made vpon the woman, that they ſaid was maried to ſeuen brethern, to be but a fanſie and thinge feigned & imagined. For the Iewes (ſaith he) be ſuch men, that we ſee thē euē now at this time to be mightely afraide to marrie with their brothers wiues, becauſe as ye would ſay, they thincke ſurely ther ſhould ſome miſchief come of it. And notwithſtanding that the law ſhould conſtraine and binde them to marrie their brothers wiues, yet for all that we ſee them many times litle regarde it, and make light of it, and not to do it.

Iſichius ſaith: it is in very dede vncomly and as nigh to the life of brute beaſts as can be, for a man to be married and to meddle with his brothers wife, or with any of his kinſmens wiues, namely them that be nighe of bloud. Vvherfore God commaundeth and decreeth that he which marrieth of this faſhion, ſhall die without children. Doubles becauſe that he miſuſing himſelf doth marre and confound, and vtterly diſorder the law of bringyng forth children. Again Iſichius ſaith thus. Theſe thinges be not ſpoken of onely to the Iewes, which becauſe they be circumciſed and
haue Moſes law, thincke them ſelues alone from all other nations, but they be ſpoken to euerie man, woman, and child, which entend to ſerue God. Saincte Auguſtine writinge againſte Fauſtus, ſaith thus. Certaine lawes of the booke of the olde Teſtamente wee doo not keepe now a dayes, becauſe ſuch laws were made onely to be a ſhadow of things to come. And thoſe lawes though they were conuenient and fitte to be commaunded and ſuffred for that people, and for that time, yet we now a dayes that be chriſtian people, ought not to kepe them bodily, or as the bare letter and wordes do ſpeake, but we muſt conſider what they ſignifie, and we be taught by the Apoſtles owne writings, that we muſt kepe ſuch lawes ſpiritually, not corporally. For when we read any ſuch thing in the inſtrument of the old Teſtament, which in the new Testamēt we either be not commaunded to kepe, or vtterly forbid to kepe them, we must not rebuke it, but we must ſeke out the ghostly meanyng of it: for in ſomuch as we do no more obſerue it, that proueth not that it is damned & in no wiſe to be receiued, but that it is fulfilled. And therfore this ſame ſelfe thing that Fauſtus, becauſe he doth not vnderstand it, hath layd against Chriſtian men, as a crime and grieuous offence: ſerueth for nothyng els in the world, but onely to ſhewe miſtically vnder a figure and cloud, a ſpirituall purpoſe, and it is this: that euery preacher of the Goſpell is bounde ſo to labour in the Goſpell that he ſtirre vp ſede to his brothers departed, that is, to Chryſte, whyche died for vs. And the ſeede that ſhalbe ſtirred vp, muſt haue the name of the brother that is departed. Vvherfore we be called Chriſtians, and therfore without doubt, we now be bounde to fulfill and kepe this law, not carnally by bodily generation after the olde meanyng and taking of it, but ſpiritually and by ghoſtly generation, and after the true vnderſtandyng. And for this the Apoſtle Saint Paul fulfilleth this law ſpiritually, where he is angry with thē whom he ſayth hym ſelf to haue engendred and gotten through the Goſpell and the worde of God to Christ Ieſus, his brother, and not to hym ſelfe nor to any other man. And therfore doth ſharpely blame and rebuke them whiche would be called Paulius or Paules men. Vvhat (ſayth he) was Paule crucified for you? or were you Baptized in the name of Paule? As if he had ſayd, I begat you to my brother whiche is dead, that is, to Chriſt. Be you called therfore Chriſtians, Chriſtes men, not Paulius or Paules men. Agayne Saint Auguſtine in his booke of queſtions vpon the Leuiticall, and in that worke alſo that he named the mirrour, ſayth that this forbode that a man ſhould not marry his brothers wyfe, and all other thinges that be forbid in the xviii. chaptre of Leuiticus, we be bound without doubt to kepe them now in the tyme of the new Teſtament and law of the Goſpell, when the obſeruaunce and kepyng of the
olde ſhadowes and bodily or outward tokens are taken awaye. For what ſoeuer thyng (as he ſayth in an other place) doth helpe and ſerue for good manners and vertue, lyke as they wer not ordeined to betoken any thing, but to ſhewe vs how we muſt lyue: ſo they ought not by any interpretation or vnderſtandyng be applied to any ſignifieng or tokenyng, as if they were but ſignes and tokens of thyngs. But as many as be of Chriſtes Religion or beliefe, be bounde of neceſsitie to kepe them euer, ſo as they be ſpoken. And in another place he alſo ſayth. Although in tymes paſt men marryed their ſiſters, yet that thyng was done becauſe neceſsitie compelled men to it, for becauſe then wer ſo few people. But this thyng was not ſo olde nor at any tyme ſo neceſſarie, but it is now as damnable, becauſe Religion forbiddeth it: for it ought to be done than when it might, becauſe that by marrieng of ſiſters there myght be plentie of women, and ſo that by proceſſe they myght take wiues whiche ſhould not be their ſiſters. But afterwarde once that this neceſsitie ceaſsed, and that there wer women enough, this thyng ought not onely to be vndone, but alſo if it were done, it ſhould be a crime not to be ſpoken. For I wote not howe (ſayth hee) there is amonge all the pointes of mans ſhamefaſtnes one certayne naturall and commendable poynte whiche is this, that to whatſoeuer woman we be bounde to doo honour with reuerence and ſhamefaſtnes, our carnall luſte, yea though it be for generation, yet becauſe it is carnall luſt, we refrayne it from that woman ſpecially, conſideryng that we do ſee marryed folke, namely ſuch as haue ſhame and honeſty, to be aſhamed of ſuch lust.

And in the councell of Agathen it is ordeined in this manner. VVe reſerue vtterlie no manner of forgeuenes nor pardon nor diſpenſation for inceſte in Mariages, but we will in any wyſe that they be puniſhed, excepte onely they heale their adulterie by departyng thone from thother: for as for inceſtuous perſonnes, we iudge them not worthy to haue any name of Mariage, ſeyng it is a deadly thyng, euen to make any token or mention of ſuch perſonnes. And we iudge them to be inceſtuous perſons whiche by carnall medlyng haue defiled their brothers widowe, which was in manner his ſiſter before, or he that hath taken to wife his ſister germane, and he that hath married his ſtepmother. &c.

All theſe perſonnes we doubte not but they haue beene before tyme and by this our conſtitution be inceſtuous perſonnes. And we commaunde that they praye and abyde among them that be yet vnchristened and but onely learners of the Christian fayth, and not to come amonge Chriſtian folke vntill they haue ſufficiently repented them ſelfe and amended that they haue miſdone. Furthermore in the councel of Neoceſar, and in the Synod of Gregorie the yonger it was decreed according to the words
of God, that a woman which had bene marryed to two brethren ſhould be put backe from communion and from receyuing the Sacrament vntil ſhe dye. And a man that had marryed his brothers wife ſhould be an anatheme. In the whiche Synode all together aunſwered, an anatheme be he, that is as much to ſay, as damnable to euerlastyng death.

To conclude, where VVickliff did holde that the prohibitions of Matrimonie written in the Leuiticall law, were onely Iudaicall precepts of Moſes, and therefore the cauſes of diuorce brought in by the meane of kindred and affinitie, to be onely the ordinaunce of man, his ſentence was condemned as hereticall in the great conuocation whiche was had firſt at London, and laſt at Oxford.

div.head: PRAELECTIO PRIMA TOMI SECVNDI.
div.p: WE haue dwelled a greate while from the port, vnto whiche we purpoſed and promiſed to arriue. Therfore, that theſe twoo Verſes of the Poete maie now be verified (Sed ne forte meo nimium de calle recedā,

p.hi: Deſeret hos curſus, verſa carrina vagos:)

div.p: Leaſt peraduenture I maie ſeme to goe to moche aſtraie,
The boate turning, ſhall nowe leaue his wandryng waie:

I will repaire forthwith to the text of the firſte Epiſtle of ſainct Peter, whiche beginneth thus. Petrus Apoſtolus Ieſu Chriſti. &c. Peter an Apoſtle of Ieſus Chriſte, to the ſtraungers that dwell here and there, throughout Pontus, Galatia, Capadotia, Aſia, and Bithynia, electe accordyng to the fore knowlege of God the father, vnto ſanctificacion of the ſpirite, through obedience and ſprincklyng of the blood of Ieſus Chriſte: grace and peace bée multiplied vnto you.
In this Epiſtle, I note three thinges.
Firſt, Quibus ſit ſcripta, To whom it was written,
Secondlie, Quis ſcripſit, Who wrote it,
Thirdlie, Quid ſit ſcriptum, What is written,

Concernyng the firſte. Lyranus and Beda in his commentarie doe thinke, that this Epiſtle was written vnto theim, whiche were conuerted from the Heatheneſſe religion, vnto the Lawe of Moſes, whom we call in Greke 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Thei were called Proſelites, whiche beyng of diuerſe ſectes & factions, were conuerted to Moiſes lawe. Thei are called in Hebrue Gerim. And thei bee properlie thoſe, whiche of Heathen men (beyng newlie inſtitute in the Lawes and Ceremonies of Moyſes) did profeſſe the Iudaicall lawe, thei were not Iewes by nacion, but by adopcion. Wherupon it is ſaied in the Actes of the Apoſtles: Iewes and Proſelites.Actes. 2. But this is not true, that Lyranus & Bede doe write. For it is not in the Greke: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 but 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : that is, to the ſtraungers, whiche ſtraungers were Iewes, to whom Peter was appointed to be an Apoſtle. And 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , in Greke, maie bee called in Latine populares, that is familiare frendes, companions, of the ſame toune or citée, or, as we call them countrie men, whiche wer diſperſed here and there, although certaine learned men do iudge the contrarie. But the turmoiles and troubles of the warres, vnder the kynges of the Aſſirians, of the Babilonians, the Perſians,
and of the Macedonians, did diſperſe and ſcatter abroade the Iewes, ſome to this place, and ſome to that place.

Nor it foloweth, that Peter preached the Goſpell before vnto theim, becauſe he ſente this Epiſtle vnto theim. For Paule writeth an Epiſtle vnto the Romaines, whom notwithſtandyng Iunias and Andronicus, 1. Iunias. did firſte of all other inſtitute in chriſtian religion. So Peter doeth write here to theim that were in Galatia, and in the leſſe Aſia: 2. Andronicꝰ. yet notwithſtandyng, thei were firſt inſtructed in the faithe by Paule. In fine, Peter doeth teſtifie to al theſe in his Epiſtle, the faith weiche thei receiued, whether it were of Paule, or of Peter of hymſelf, or of any other, to be the true faithe of a true chriſtian.

Theſe wordes of the texte before rehearſed, are nothyng els, but, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 that is, the inſcripcion or title, whiche Paule vſeth in the beginning of all his writinges, ſauyng in the Epiſtle to the Hebrues.
Thus moche for the firſt note, that is, to whom this Epiſtle was written.
Now to the ſeconde note, I will ſhewe you what maner of manne he was that wrote it: and firſt I will touche his proper name.

The proper name of Peter was Simon, whiche ſignifieth in the Hebrue audiens, vel, obediens, hearyng or obeiyng: It cometh of the radicall Shamagh or Shamah, whiche ſignifieth audire, parare, exaudire, obtemporare, that is, to heare or obeye.

He tooke this name Cephas (whiche is a Syrian woorde) of Chriſte, who gaue it vnto hym: whiche woorde in Greke is called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and dooeth ſignifie in Latine a rocke, or a ſtone. For as rockes and harde ſtones are wonte to be laied in the foundacion of any buildyng: ſo the faithe of Peter, and of the whole churche, doeth ſtaie vpō Chriſte, the firme and vnmouable rocke, vpon whom the whole churche is builded.

I maruaile that the Papiſtes be not aſhamed, to tranſlate this woorde Cephas, to ſignifie caput, a hedde. Euery blinde Aſſe maie perceiue moche diffrence betwene 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , in Greke betokeneth in deede, an hedde: but Cepha bekeneth a ſtone, whiche is a Caldei woorde. Chriſt did not ſaie, tu vocaberis
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , but 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 whiche ſignifieth in Hebrue properlie a rocke. And by a metapher, it ſignifieth alſo a tower, or a caſtle.

In deede if Chriſt had vſed this Hebrue woorde, thei might haue had ſome occaſion (at the leaſt apparantlie) to haue named Peter the chief tower, or the chief hedde. But for aſmoche as Chriſte vſed the Caldei woorde (Cephas) whiche alwaies doeth ſignifie a rocke, or a ſtone, nor is tranſlated to any other ſignificacion, thei can take no handfaſte by this name,3. Soch lippes to make Peter hedde of the churche. But as the common Prouerbe is, Similes habent labra lactucas. Soche lippes, ſoche Lettuſe: ſoche bokes ſoche bookemen. Thei reade this corrupte gloſe, in a certain ſpurious booke, goyng in the name of Anacletus.

By this woorde Cephas it appereth, that the Hebrue toung was not the commō toungue vnto the Iewes, in the tyme of Chriſte, but rather the Caldean or Syrian toungue, whiche bothe be verie nere vnto the Hebrue toungue.
Thus moche for the name. And now to the perſone.

He was born in a toune called Bethſaida, ſituate by the ſea ſide of Galile. His fathers name was Ihon, and therefore he was called Simon Bariona, that is, Simon the ſonne of Ihon, for ſo the Iewes called their children, as Bar Ptolomei, the ſonne of Ptolomie. He had a brother named Andrewe, who bothe gatte their liuynges by fiſſhing in the ſea. And by this it appereth, that in his youth he was not learned, and that he would haue continued a fiſſher, ſo longe as he liued, if he had not been afterward called of Chriſte to an higher funccion and office.
Some write that he was a citezen of Capernaum.

Nicephorus deſcribeth the ſtature and forme of his perſonage. Peter (ſaieth he) was no groſſe man, but ſomewhat high and tall. He was of a pale and whitelie face.
He was of a pale and whitelie face. The heere of his hedde and his bearde, wer curled and thicke. He had a longe noſe, not copped in the middes, but preſte doune and ſomewhat flatte. He was the hearer and diſciple of Ihon the Baptiſte, and brought to Chriſt by his brother Androwe. And when Chriſte ſawe hym, he ſaied vnto hym. Thou art Simon the ſonne of Ihon, thou ſhalt be called Cephas. Math. 8. Luke. 4. i. Corin. 9.
It appereth by Mathewe and by Luke, that he was a maried manne, and had a wife: for thei write that Chriſt healed Peters wiues mother of a feuer in Capernaū.
Likewiſe Paule recordeth, that Peter did leade about his wife with hym.
Euſebius alſo declareth, that Clement writeth,4. Leade aboute. Stroma. libri. 7. Peter and Philip to haue geuen them ſelues to the procreacion of children.

And Clement writeth, that when Peter ſawe his wife leade to death, beyng glad of that her callyng, he exhortyng and cōfortyng her, did call her by her proper name, ſaiyng: Heus tu, memento domini: O wife, remember the Lorde.
The moſte parte of the hiſtorie of Peter, maie be gathered out of the Euangeliſtes, and Actes of the Apoſtles.

He walked on the ſea. He confeſſed Chriſte to be the ſonne of the liuyng God.Math. 14. and .16. He aſcended with Chriſt into the mount, where he heard Elias and Moyſes talke with Chriſte. He paied tribute for Chriſt and him.5. Talke with Chriſte. Math. 17. Ibidem. Math. 26. Actes. 2.
