For euen as it was not enough then among the Iewes, that the ſacrifice ſhould be offered, and the bloud therof ſhed, vnles ye people had ben ſprinkled with the ſame: So now at this preſent it ſhal profit vs nothing that Chriſts bloud is ſhed, vnles our conſciences be clenſed and purified therwith: which thing is done by the miniſterie of the holy ghoſt, whiche doth ſprinkle our conſciences with Chriſts bloud, to waſhe them withal.

Dauid ſpeaketh of this kynd of ſprinkling, ſaying: Aſperges me domine hyſopo, & mundabor, lauabis me, & ſuper niuem dealbabor: ſprinkle me, Lorde,Pſal. 51. with hyſope,
and I ſhalbe cleane, thou ſhalte waſhe me, and I ſhalbe whiter then ſnowe.

Leu. 14. 3. Sacrificiū.We reade in Leuiticus of the ſacrifice that did purifie and clenſe from the leproſie. They tooke two ſparows, one of them was killed, and put in an earthen pot, hauinge faire and cleane running water, the other ſparow being a liue, his winges with Ceder wodde, and ſcarlet cloth with byſope wer dipped in the blood of the ſlaine ſparrow, and he that was infected and diſeaſed with the leproſie was ſprinkled with all. The ſparow that was ſlain, ſignified the humanitie of Chriſt, which was put to death. The ſparowe that was lefte a lyue, ſignifieth the godhead of Chriſte, which was impaſſible and could not be hurte.

The leproſie of the bodye betokeneth the ſinne of the ſoule. Hiſope is a lowe herbe, and of a ſwete ſauour, and it ſignifieth our fayth, by the whiche our hartes are purified. And nowe crieth Dauid, ſaying: If thou O God ſhalte ſprinkle me with thy grace, and with faith, as it were with a bundle of hyſope dipped in the bloud of Chriſt, and ſo ſhalt waſh my ſpottes, than ſhal I by & by be made cleane, and I ſhal become whiter then ſnow. I know Lord, I know, ſaith Dauid, that I neede not the ſlaughter of goates and bullocks, but this I know, that the purifyeng and clenſing of the ſoule is ſet only in the faith of Ieſus Chriſt, with whoſe bloud, whoſoeuer is ſprinkled, he is waſhed and clenſed from all his ſinnes. And vnto this end alludeth ſainct Peter here in this place.

Now, the whole minde of Peter in this place is this: we be predeſtinat, electe, and choſen of God vnto ſaluation. This election is not diſpoſed and diſpenſed raſhlye, but by the redemption of Chriſte, in the whiche is declared both the mercie and Iuſtice of god. In this Chriſt onely we muſt beleue, & obey his doctrine.

Therfore, they are muche deceiued and do greatly erre, which preach, bragge and boaſte onely of election, and do reiecte, and neglecte faith, the fruits of rightuouſnes, feruent and deuoute praiers, as things vnprofitable, as though the election of god ſhould be a raſhe and a bare thing: quos praeſciuit, eoſdem praefiniuit, conformes eſſe imaginis filii ſui: Rom. 8. thoſe which he knewe before (ſaith Paule) he alſo ordeined before, that they ſhould be like faſhioned to the ſhape of his ſonne. &c.
Now let vs gather together the whole ſumme of Peters minde, which is this.
Our ſaluation floweth of the free election of god, but this election muſt be conſidered with the experience of faith, in that that god doth ſanctifie vs with his holy ſpirite.

Finally, there be two effectes or endes of our vocation, one is obedience, by the whiche we muſt vnderſtand newnes of life, the other is the ſprinklynge of Chriſts bloud, by the which is notified the remiſſion of ſinnes, and both theſe are the workes of the holy ghoſt. And therupon Peter concludeth, that we oughte not to ſeparat election, from vocation, nor the free iuſtifieng, of faith from ye newnes of lyfe.

It foloweth in the texte: gratia & pax multiplicetur uobis, grace and peace be multiplied vnto you. There is nothinge that ought more to be wiſhed and deſired of vs, then to haue god fauorable and mercifull vnto vs, which is ſignified here by this worde gratia. And after to deſire that proſperitie and good ſucceſſe of al things maye flowe and come from god toward vs, whiche is ſignified by this word Pax. For howſo euer all thinges in this worlde be luckie, pleaſante, and fortunate vnto vs: yet if god therwith be not fauorable, that bleſſinge and ſucceſſe whiche we haue, is turned into curſe.

Therfore the only foūdacion, ground & ſtay of our felicitie, is the fauor, & beneuolence of god, by the which fauour it is brought to paſſe, that we haue the fruition of the very true and ſound proſperitie. Yea, and that our ſaluation and health is promoted and furthered in the very ſtormes of aduerſitie. Gratia & pax: Grace here, I ſay, betokeneth the fauour of god, which although it beginne here in vs, yet it is requiſite and neceſſarie that it waxe and growe in vs daily more and more, vntil our dieng daye.

He that knoweth and ſurelye beleueth: that god is fauorable vnto him, that man hath peace and quietnes of conſcience, and nedeth not, no nor doth feare neither the worlde, nor yet the deuil, for he is ſurely perſuaded, that god will deliuer him from Sathan, ſinne, and death, and from all other incommodities.

Grace, I tell you, betokeneth here, fauorem, gods fauor, by the whiche we are not onely made amiable, acceptable, and beloued vnto god, but alſo we obteyne all ſpiritual dowries and giftes, which eyther pertaine to all godlines, or els to the vtilitie and cōmoditie of our neyghbours.

Pax: Peace here ſignifieth the ſucceſſe and good going forward of al things, euen as we wold deſire and wiſhe them. And this grace and peace doth Peter here pray and deſire vnto them, to whome he wrote this epiſtle, ſome ſaye, that peace betokeneth here the quietnes of conſcience.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: But I pray you ſir, did not Peter knowe, that all the true and faithful diſciples of Chriſte ſhould beare the croſſe, and ſuſteyne afflictions and perſecutions in the worlde? And why then doth he wiſhe all thinges to be proſperouſe and luckly vnto them?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: It is moſte true, that godly and faithful men are ſubiecte, and like to ſuſteine, as long as they liue here in this world, perſecutions, afflictions, and aduerſities, at one time or other. Notwithſtāding, god doth with his great fauour and mercy ſo adourne and decke his holy ſainctes, that the very reproches and troubles of the world, do turne to their profit and glorie. And god doth ſo comforte them in their aduerſitie, that euen then be they moſt quiet, moſt ioiful, and moſt reioyſing, when they be in the middle of death. What preſidentes haue we had, I pray you, theſe late yeares, of thoſe godlye Martyrs, which teſtified chriſts truth be ſheddynge theyr bloud? This grace and fauour of God is geuen vnto man without his merites or deſertes.

Saincte Ambroſe interpreting this worde, grace, ſaith after this maner: quia hoc conſtitutum eſt a Deo, et cae. becauſe god hath ordeined, that they whiche beleue in Chriſt, ſhalbe ſaued without works, by faith onely, we ſhal freely obteine remiſſion of ſinnes.

I do not a litle meruaile, that ſome of the ſchole men are ſuche ſtoute defenders of mans power, and ſo ſmal fauorers of the grace of Chriſt, that they are not aſhamed to ſay and to write, that the very infidels and heathen, which are deſtitute of the goſpel, may with theyr moral vertues deſerue (as they term it) primā gratiam, the-firſt grace. Whiche doctrine, becauſe they would make it ſeeme and appeare more probable, they affirme, that ſuch workes done before faith, do not merite and deſerue Gods fauour and grace ſimpliciter, abſolutely, but as they terme it, de congruo, with a conuenience and meetenes. Mary, ſay they, we dare not affirme, that they merite de condigno.

Although theſe morall actions and vertues may be nombred generally amōg thoſe thinges, that be called, bona, good: yet as concernyng the auctors and workers of them, from whom they come, becauſe they be without faith, thoſe actions and morall vertues are very ſinne, and do diſpleaſe god. For as long as we be without Chriſt, the holy ghoſt declareth vs to be the ſonnes of wrath: that is, hated of god.

Our ſauiour Chriſt ſaith: qui non credit in filium, non habebit vitam aeternā, & ira dei manet ſuper eum: he that beleueth not in the ſonne, ſhall not haue eternal life, and the wrath of god ſhal abide vpon him. Therfore, foraſmuch as god doth ha • e vs, how can we do workes that be pleaſant and amiable vnto hym?
Secondly, Paule calleth thoſe glorious and noble workes, which he did in his Iudaiſme, before his conuerſion, droſſe and dounge.Phil. 3.

Thirdly, the prophet Eſaie writeth: Iuſtitiae noſtrae vt pannus menſtruatae. Al our rightuouſnes are as a diſteyned and foule cloth, which ſentence, whether it be taken and referred to them that be alredie iuſtified, eyther to thoſe that be not yet regenerated, the ſequel is al one. For if the works of ye iuſtified be counted no better before god, what maner of workes are theyrs to be counted, which are not yet come vnto Chriſt?

Luc. 17Fourthlye, Chriſt ſayth to his Apoſtles: quum feceritis haec omnia, quae facere debetis, dicite, ſerui inutiles ſumus: when you ſhall do all thoſe thinges, whiche you ought to do, ſay, we be vnprofitable ſeruauntes. Which ſentence, if it be verified of the beleuyng, what, I pray you, may be thoughte of the workes of Infidelles?

By theſe teſtimonies, and ſuch other like places, it is and may be ſufficiently proued, that their doctrine is vaine and moſt fooliſhe, whiche ſay, that Infideles may merite primam gratiam de congruo, as they terme it. But becauſe they wold haue their voluntarie and wil workes to be eſtemed and mainteined, they haue an other foliſh diſtinction concernyng them which be not Infidels, but beleuyng, and thoſe workes they call, opera ſupererogationis, the workes of ſupererogation, which to do we are not bound, but may chuſe whether we wil do them or no, but if we do them, we do more, ſay they, then we are bound to do, and therfore we deſerue gratiam dei, the fauour of god de condigno, as they terme it. And if you would know, what theſe workes of ſupererogation be, you may learne them out of theyr popiſhe and peuiſhe bokes, ſome of them I wil rehearſe: to heare ſixe or ſeuen maſſes on a day, to go on pilgrimage from poſt to piller, to make choiſe and difference of meates, as to put more holines in fiſhe then in fleſh, to builde monaſteries and chauntries, to make vowes, and to profeſſe ſingle life, to forſake father, and mother without their conſent & good wil obtained, to become monks, friers, chanons and Nuns, &c. But who hauing any ſalt in hym (as the prouerb ſayth) wil not counte theſe thinges to be vaine, fond, ſuperfluous and fooliſh, for the whiche the Lord ſhal ſay at the daye of the iudgement, as it is written in the prophet Eſaie: quis haec requiſiuit de manibus veſtris? who required theſe things a your handes?

Sainct Auguſtin writeth: quum dicitur toto corde, tota mente, tota anima, et omnibus viribus, Lib. de doct. chriſtian. nullam partem reliquit tibi vacantem: When the Lorde ſaide thou ſhalt loue thy Lord god with all thine harte, with all thy mind, with all thy ſoule, and with all thy ſtrength, he lefte no parte in thee voide, wherwith thou maiſt loue and ſerue God more then thou arte commaunded.

The ſame Auſten again ſaith in an other place: quum non plenè, dum hic viuimus, Lib. de ſpirit. et litera. deum cognoſcamus, plenè illum non poſſumus diligere: nullus enim plus diligit, quàm cognoſcit: foraſmuch, while we liue heare, we can not fully know god, we can not therfore fullye loue him: for no man loueth more then he knoweth &c. Well I haue very long deteined you. It is time to ende. Thus you haue heard the whole Epigraphe or inſcription of this epiſtle, wherwith Peter ſaluteth and wiſheth wel to them, to whome he writeth. After the inſcription foloweth that part, whiche is called exordium, or proaemium, that is, the beginning or entrance of his matter. But to diſcourſe any parte therof, I wil differre it vntyl the nexte readyng daye. In the meane tyme I commit you to the tuition of God.

div.head: Hic ſequuntur Miſcellanea praelectionis ſecondae. Tomi. 2.
Salomon. 1.
div.p:
SAlomon was the ſonne of Dauid, begotten of Bethſabe, who was the wife of Vrias. He had an other name, which was Iedida, that is, dilectus domini, beloued of the Lord. He was brought vp from a childe by his parents in godlines and learnyng, and deliuered vnto Nathan the Prophet to be taughte and inſtitute: who after he had receyued him, for his noble and cleare wittte, called hym, amabilem. His father, yet lyuinge, he receiued the kyngdome after he beganne to raigne (which was as many do write, at his age of twelue yeares) God appeared vnto him in his ſlepe, and bad him aſke what he wold. He required not long life, neyther riches, nor reuengemēt of his ennemies, but deſired intelligence and wiſdome, that he might righly gouerne the people cōmitted to his carge. God therfore did adorne and beautifie him with ſuche excellent prudencie, that he excelled all other wiſe men, not onely thoſe which were foreine, but alſo thoſe which were noble amōg the Iſraelits. But when he came to mature and ripe yeres, forgetting god the graūter and geuer of all his honors and riches, wente vp to the mounte, and falling down on his knees, worſhipt Moloch the Idole of the Egiptians, and many other Idols of the Gentils. And alſo being old, he liued filthely and fleſhly with a great nomber of women, not onely with the women of his own countrie, but alſo toke many other ſtraunge women. He had .700. wyues, and 300. cōcubines, which tourned away his hart from god vnto their falſe gods, pretendinge politickely (as it is thought) to haue peace with kyngs and princes adioyning nighe vnto him. Notwithſtandynge, he greatly offended god therin. Vvherupon ſaint Auguſtin writeth thus: Salomon bonis initiis malos habuit exitus: Lib. de ciuit. dei 17. cap. 2. Eccleſiaſticus cap. 47. Salomon with his good beginnings had euil endings. For proſperitie oft times ouercometh & blindeth the minds of wiſe mē. Ieſus the ſonne of Sirach ſaith of Salomon after this maner. collegiſti quaſi aurichalcum aurum, & vt plumbum collegiſti argentum, & denudaſti femora tua mulieribus, &c. Thou haſte gathered gold as tinne, and haſte had as much ſiluer as lead, thou diddeſt bowe thy loines to women, and waſt ouercome by thy bodye, thou diddeſt ſtaine thine honor, and haſt defiled thy poſteritie, and haſt broughte wrath vpon thy children, and haſt felte ſorow for thy folie. So the kingdome
was deuided, and Ephraim became a rebellious kyngdome. Neuertheles, the Lord lefte not of his mercy, neyther was he deſtroyed for his workes, neither did he aboliſh the poſteritie of his electe. &c. This ſad and fearefull example doth teach vs to beware that we be not to proude in proſperitie. It can not firmly be gathered out of the holy ſcriptures, whether Salomon (at the time of his death) did earneſtly repent of his impietie or no. Notwithſtanding, ſainct Hierome, Ambroſe, and Chriſoſtome do write, that he repēted before his death. Vvherupon the hebrues intituled his boke called Eccleſiaſtes, poenitentia Salomonis, the repentaunce of Salomon. After he had liued 94. yeres, he died, and was buried in Ieruſalem.

He wrote 3000. bokes of ſentences, and 5000. bokes of ſonges and modulations: he wrote of the nature of trees, from the lowe hyſope vnto the highe Ceder tree. He wrote alſo of the properties of beaſtes, birdes fiſhes, and ſerpentes, &c.
There be extant of his bokes three in nomber: the boke intituled the prouerbs, the boke intituled Eccleſiaſtes, and the boke intituled cantica canticorum.
Lib 7. de ciuitate dei. cap. 20.Sainct Auguſtine writeth, that the weſt church receaued the boke of wiſdome and Eccleſiaſticus to be the bokes of Salomon.
Some recorde, that Salomon did inſtitute certaine exorciſmes, and incantations againſte wicked ſpirits, by the which ſickneſſes and diſeaſes might be mitigated, and eaſed.

div.head: Praedeſtination. 2.
div.p: BEcauſe certaine hie climing heades make no difference betwene predeſtination and deſtenie: I wil deliuer ſomwhat worthie note, what deſtenie is, and how and in howe many points it differeth from predeſtination and gods prouidence. And to make the matter more plain, I wil ſpeake a word or two de prouidentia Dei, of the prouidence of god, of the which much mēciō is made almoſt in euery part of ye ſcriptures.

Iohn. 5.Firſt, Chriſt ſaith: Pater meus ad hoc vſ
que temporis operatur, & ego operor, my father worketh hitherto, and I worke.

Heb. 1.Againe, ſainct Paule writeth: Deus per filium ſecula condidit, moderatur
que , & portat omnia verbo potentiae ſuae: God hath eſtabliſhed the worlde by his ſonne, and doth rule and moderat all things by the word of his power.Cap. 2. Again, in Daniel: Domini eſt ſapientia, & fortitudo, ipſe eſt qui mutat tempora et quae fiunt in tempore, abiicit Reges, & inſtituit Reges, dat ſapientiam ſapientibus, & ſcientiā iis, qui pollent intelligentia. Vviſedome and ſtrength is the lords, he chaūgeth the times and ſeaſons, he taketh away kings, he ſetteth vp kings, he geueth wiſdom to the wiſe, and vnderſtanding to thoſe that do vnderſtand.
Againe in the pſalme it is writen: magnus Dominus noſter, & magna eſt virtus eius &c. greate is our Lord, and great is his power.Pſalm. 147.

There be infinite other places, beſide theſe, in the ſcriptures, abundātly teſtifieng, that god by his prouidence doth gouern all things that be in the worlde, and ſpecially man, being the poſſeſſor of the worlde, for whoſe ſake al thinges be made.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: For as much as al things in the world are done by the prouidence of god, ther is no cauſe, why we ſhuld put to our indeuour and induſtrie: we may liue idly and careleſſe, it is ſufficient that we be enforſed of God. For if he ſhal nede our endeuour, he wil violently, wil we, nill we, drive and force vs to that which he wil haue to be done by vs.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p:
Vve ſee holy men in ye ſcripture both to iudge & to ſpeake more ſincerely, and more reuerētly of ye prouidēce of god. The Angel ſaid plainly to Loth: feſtina in zoar, et illic ſeruare: ne
que em̄ facere poſsū quic
quam , Gen. 19 donec tu illuc venias: make haſt to zoar, and ther be preſerued, for I cā do nothing before yu come thether. Lo, here is Loth wt his family ſaued by ye prouidēce of god: the citizens of Sodome, and al the cities roūd about are deſtroyed. Yet the labor and will of Loth is required in the very worke of this his preſeruatiō. I can do nothing (ſaith the Lord) vntil thou come thither. Dauid euidētly ſaith: Ego in te ſperaui, dn̄e, dixi deꝰ meus es tu, in manu tua ſunt tēpora mea: I haue truſted in thee, o Lord, I haue ſaid, thou art my god: in thy handes are my times. Notwitſtādyng, he which had caſt him ſelf wholy vpon the diuine prouidence, toke diligent aduiſe, how he might by his diligēce and induſtrie eſcape and auoide the craftie aſſaults of his father in lawe Saule: neither he doth deſpiſe nor refuſe the helpe and policie of his wyfe Michol. He doth not replie againſt her, ſayeng: All things are done by the prouidēce of god, therfore ther nedeth no policie or meanes, the almightie god can deliuer me out of the handes of my fathers ſouldiours, or els he cā ſaue me by ſome other miraculous meanes. Let vs therfore quiet our ſelf, and ſuffer god to worke in vs. He vnderſtode the prouidēce, that as ye diuine prouidence doth worke by means, & by a certain order: ſo he did know it to be his duetie in the feare of god to ſubmit and referre himſelf to ye ſame meanes, and to put awaye all lettes. S. Paul heard ye Lord ſayeng euidētly: ſicut Hieroſolymis de me teſtificatꝰ es, ita oportebit te & Romae teſtificari: Actes. 23. As thou haſt teſtified of me at Ieruſalē, ſo yu muſt bear witnes of me alſo at Rome. And although he doubted not ye promiſes of god to be true, nether was ignoraunt of the power & efficacie of gods prouidēce: neuertheles, he ſent his nephew priuely vnto the chief officer, to ſhew him, that the Iewes had conſpired his death, and to deſire him that he might not be brought forth at their requeſte.

Againe, Paule ſailyng on the ſea Adriaticum, and being very nere vnto a moſt dangerous ſhipwrake, ſaid vnto the ſeldiors in the ſhip, which were very fearful: hortor vos, vt bono animo ſitis: iactura enim animae nulla erit ex vobis, ſed tantùm nauis &c. I exhorte you to be of good courage, for there ſhalbe no loſſe of any mās life among you, ſaue of the ſhip onely: for ther ſtode by me this night the Angel of God, whoſe I am, and whome I ſerue, ſayeng: feare not Paule, for thou muſte be broughte before Ceſar, and lo god hath geuē vnto thee all that ſaile with thee: wherfore ſirs, be of good courage. I beleue God, that it ſhalbe ſo as he hath told me. But afterward, whē the mariners went about to go out of the ſhip, Paule ſaid: niſi hi in naui manſerint, vos ſalui fieri non poteſtis: Excepte theſe men abide in the ſhip, you can not be ſaued.

Therfore, meanes and midles do pertaine to the prouidence of god, by the which god worketh, which are not to be neglected. For neyther the aire doth make the yearth fruitful, the waters do flow to and fro, nor the yearth bringeth furth by their owne power, but by the power and deuiſe of god. And although godly and holy men do iudge, that nothing is done here through their deſerts,Math 5. as our ſauiour Chriſt ſaith: Pluit pater ſuper iuſtos, & iniuſtos: The father raineth vpon the iuſte and vniuſte: yet they do not forget the prophetes words, ſayeng: ſi volueritis, & audieritis, bona terrae comedetis: ſi verò contumaces fueritis, gladio deuorabimini: If you conſent and obey, you ſhal eate the good things of the land: but if you refuſe, and be rebellious, you ſhalbe deuoured with the ſword: for the mouth of the Lorde hath ſpoken it.

By theſe places, authorities, and teſtimonies it is ſubſtātially proued, that god hath a great care and regard towarde vs, and that he with his diuine prouidence doth defend vs againſt all ſickneſſes, diſeaſes and dā gers: and that as he hath created all creatures to the behoof and vſe of mā: ſo he doth conſerue and applie thē to the cōmoditie and profit of mā.
This ſhalbe ſufficient de Dei prouidentiae, of the prouidence of God. Now a worde or two of fatum.

I intend not to ſpeake of fatum here, as the Poets, the Philoſophers, and Aſtronomers doe define and diſcourſe it. For to graūt Fatum after that maner, were to graunte, that al things chaunce by mere neceſsitie, whiche is a doctrine both hereticall and diabolicall. But I will ſpeake of, Fatum, ſo muche and ſo far, as the diuines graunt it.

div.head: VVhat deſtenie is, after the cenſure of the diuines.
div.p:
Firſt, the diuines do define deſtenie to be a certain diſpoſitiō in things moueable, by the which the prouidence of god knitteth all things in order. Or thus, deſtenie is an ordinance or conſtitution of the ſecōd cauſes, to bring forth their effectes in the inferiour thinges, according to the direction,
which they haue of god. This ordinance may be two wayes cō ſidered: firſt, as it is ioyned in the proſpecte of the mind of god, ordenyng and diuiding all things in their places, tymes, mouings, and maner: and ſo it is called the prouidence of god.

Secondly, the ſame ordinance is digeſted and applied by tymes in the midle cauſes appointed of God to bring forth their proper effects: and ſo it is called fatum, deſtenie. Vvherby it is manifeſt, that the will and prouidence of God may by called fatum, deſtenie, cauſaliter.
But the ſame diſpoſition and order of the ſecond cauſes, concernynge their effectes dependyng of the will and prouidence of God, may be called fatum eſſentialiter.

The diſpoſition of the ſeconde cauſes (as Thomas ſaith) is called fatū a fari, to ſpeake, as though you wold ſay,Lib. 3. cont. entiles. c. 93 the pronouncing and vtterance of gods prouidence. For God pronounced his prouidence, per fatum, by deſtenie, euen as man vttereth what he hath conceyued in his harte, by voice and wordes. And like as an artificer declareth the forme & faſhiō of that he maketh, conceyued in his minde, by the effecte and finiſhing of the worke, by the diſpoſitions of times: ſo doth god by his prouidence, ſimpliciter, diſpoſe what things he would haue done, & per fatum doth adminiſter them diuerſe wayes, and at ſondry times. And vpon this thre thinges may be obſerued, and ratified: firſt, what things are ſubiect to deſtenie, and what things not ſubiecte to deſtenie. For, in ſo much as deſtenie (as the diuines ſay) is an ordināce of the ſecond cauſes to the effects foreſene of God, it foloweth, that onely thoſe things are ſubiect to deſtenie, which are ſubiecte to the ſecōd cauſes, neither are they ſubiect to deſtenie. As for example, the creation of the firſt things, that is, angels, celeſtiall bodies, time, and matter of the foure elemēts, the firſt ſubſtāce of all kindes of thinges, which were brought forth in the beginning, the glorifieng of the heauenly ſubſtaunces, the iuſtificatiō of the wicked, and the ſoules whiche are alwayes created a newe. For all theſe thinges did flow, and were created of God immediatly, nether could they, nor can otherwſe be brought forth. Therfore, they are not ſubiect to deſtenie, for thoſe things that ar done of the ſuperior, are not chaunged or altered of the inferior. Vvherupon Boetius ſaith: Thoſe things which are moſte nere to the diuinitie, being eſtabliſhed and made ſure, do excede wholye all fatal order. But thoſe thinges that are remoued, and ſomwhat a farre of from the firſt cauſe, the further they be of from it, ſo much the more they are ſubiecte to fatall order.

Therfore, thoſe thinges which are done of God, are ſubiect onely to him. But other particuler and natural effects are ſubiect to the mouings of the elements, & the mouings of the heauenly bodies, and of that part which is called primum mobile, and finally to the prouidence of God, of
whom al things haue their ſtedfaſtnes, and without whom nothing cōtinueth in his owne ſtate. For, if you take away the firſt, the ſecond alſo is taken away. Secondly, it is to be conſidered how the faithful chriſtians may graunt, that there is fatum, deſtenie, for if deſtenie be taken for the diſpoſition & conſtellations of the ſtarres and planets (in which any mā is conceiued or borne) enforcing all the inferior effects beſide the will, and without the worke of God: ſo fatum is to be denied, as Gregorie ſaith: abſit à fidelium cordibus, vt eſſe fatum aliquid dicant: that is, let it be far from the harts of the faithful, to ſay, that ther is any deſtenie. But if fatum be taken for the diſpoſition of the ſecond cauſes, and for the ordinaunce of humaine actions, being referred to the prouidence of god, as appointed by him, and ſpoken before him: ſo may we graunt, that ther is fatū, deſtenie, although the holy fathers haue refuſed to vſe this worde, fatum, by reaſon of thoſe men which wreſted this word to the violēt diſpoſition, and fatal neceſsitie of al things. Vvherupō S. Auguſtin ſaith: Si propterea quis res humanas fato tribuit, Lib. 5. de ciui dei. cap. 1 quia ipſam dei voluntatē vel poteſtatem fati nomine appellat, ſententiam teneat, & linguam corrigat: If any man do attribute humaine affaires to deſtenie, becauſe he calleth the will or power of god by the name of Fatum, deſtenie: let him refrain his iudgment, and amend his toung. Thirdly, it is to be conſidered how the prouidēce of god and deſtenie do differ. For the diſpoſition of things, which are to be produced, gouerned & conſerued, by the proſpect & regarde of God, is called the prouidence of God. But the ſame diſpoſitiō in the middle cauſes ordeined of God to the bringing forth of the effects, & declared in times, is called deſtenie. Alſo they differ in this, that as wel neceſſarie things, as things that happen, are ſubiect to the prouidence of God: yea deſtenie it ſelfe is ſubiect to the diuine prouidence: but onely moueable things are ſubiect to deſtenie. Furthermore, they differ in this, that the diuine prouidence beinge conſtitute and ſet in God the highe and chief ruler of all things (as Boetius ſaith) conſiſteth in God, and deſtenie conſiſteth only in the ſecond cauſes. Alſo they differ in this, that the diuine prouidēce is called deſtenie cauſaliter, in aſmuch as the fatall diſpoſiō dependeth and cōmeth of gods prouidence. But the diſpoſition of the ſecond cauſes, in it ſelf, is called deſtenie eſſentialiter.

Finally, they differ, becauſe the prouidēce of god is alwaies vnmoueable, remaining, permanent, and cauſeth al things to be moued. But deſtenie, for ſomuch as it is in things moueable, is alſo moueable. To be ſhort, that ther is no ſuch fatum, as the Stoiks do imagin, I wil make it plain by exhibiting vnto you certaine verſes, which are recited in a certaine interlude or plaie intituled Aegio. In the which playe .ij. perſons interlocutorie do diſpute, the one alledging for the defence of deſtenie and fatall neceſsitie, and the other confuting the ſame.

div.head: ¶ The names of the interlocutors be, Larymos, and Phronimos.

lg.head: Larymos.
lg.l: NOne of you all can deſtinie denie,
For all thinges do chaunce by mere neceſsitie.
And that will I proue by ſufficient authoritie,
Both of Aſtronomie, and alſo diuinitie.
And firſt to begin with Gods owne booke:
God doth al thinges foreſee and forelooke.
And that thing which he doth once foreſee.
Muſt needes be ſo, and can none otherwiſe be.
Man is alſo ruled by the conſtellation
Of the bodies aboue after Ptolemies relation.
Of Lucanus alſo this is the ſentence:
That man is ruled by deſtenies violence.
Praeceps agit omnia fatum.
And beſide the doctrine of all the Aſtronomers,
It is alſo the minde of Poetes and Philoſophers,
Quod regitur fatis mortale genus,
Et venit ab alto quicquid facimus.
To be ſhort and to auoide prolixitie,
Now ſhall you heare a doctor of diuinitie.
Auſten in his booke of the heauenly citie
VVriteth theſe wordes of fatall deſtenie:
Deſtenie (ſaith he) is a certaine diſpoſition
Of cauſes, and is alſo an order and a production
Of thinges, them either to proſper or els to ſpil,
Beſide Gods purpoſe, and beſide mans will.

lg.head: Phronimos aunſwereth.
lg.l: The wicked doctrine of fatall neceſsitie
I will proue to be a deteſtable hereſie.
If man by the courſe of bodies aboue
From ſinne him ſelf could not leaue nor remoue,
And if one ſhould be a theif by fatall neceſsitie,
Then we muſt nedes reaſon and contend,
That the creatures of God are not all good,
Contrarie to thapoſtle Paules relation,
VVhich al creatures to be good made declaratiō.
And by this doctrine it ſhould folow than,
That there could be no ſinne committed by man.
For that whiche is euill is done alwaye
By mans free will, as the diuines do ſay,
And by the ſuggeſtion of the wicked fiend,
Et per fomitem peccati, that is in mans minde.
And by the doctrine of the Stoikes neceſſitie
God to him ſelfe ſhould be cleane contrarie
For if he bid vs to do good, & enforce vs to do il.
VVho then his cōmaūdements is able to fulfil?
Of this alſo ſhould enſue a damnable clauſe,
That God of al ill ſhould be the originall cauſe.
It foloweth alſo by this heatheniſh neceſsitie,
That all tranſgreſſors are puniſhed vniuſtly
For, you can not ſay that to be ill done,
VVhich a man by no meanes is able to ſhunne.
Out of this alſo it doth folowe and fall,
That in vaine are made the ſciences all:
As Geometrie, Phiſike, & moral Philoſophie,
Arithmetike, Muſicke, and alſo diuinitie
For what ſhall we neede to teach and exhort,
Or the ſicke to helpe with medicines comfort?
VVhat ſhall it auaile to rebuke any ſinne,
Or to repētaūce by preaching any mā to winne?
VVhat ſhall it boote to faſt and to pray?
Or any good thing to do or to ſay;
If all thinges by deſtenie ſhould chaunce & fal?
Marie it forceth not then what we do at all.
And to be plame, if this doctrine ſhould be knowne,
The whole life of man ſhould be quite ouerthrowne.
Ambroſe in his booke called Exameron
Doth profoundly condemne this opinion.
VVhat neede (ſaith he) any lawes to be made?
Or in a Realme any actes to be had,
To preſerue the good in quiet ſafetie,
And to puniſhe the ill for their iniquitie.
If thinges ſhould chaunce by mere neceſsitie.
VVhy laboureth the ploughman to ſow his corne?
VVhy trauaileth the marchaūt like to be forlorne
In the ſea? why do other men take care and payne,
To obteyne to them ſelues commoditie and gaine?
All occupations and artes are in vayne.
Thus writeth Ambroſe wonderfull playne.
God forbid (ſaith Gregorie) that any chriſten harte
Should with the opinion of deſtenie take any part.
For none but God, whiche gaue the creation
Doth take of our life thadminiſtration.
Ptolomie the prince of the Aſtronomie ſcoole
Doth ſay that a wiſe man the planets may rule.
And Bugufarus vpon the centiloquie
VVriteth thus concerning deſtenie:
The effectes of the planets a wiſe man may let,
By the force of wiſedome, whiche in him is ſet.
And Abrahā Auenar an aſtronomer of Chaldie
Doth ouerthrow this fatall neceſsitie.
If to heauen with prayer man lift vp his voyce,
Agaynſt deſtenie he ſhall triūphe and reioyce,
Authorities agaynſt deſtenie we neede no moe.
But yet let vs bring an example or two.
A certayne man beholding Plato his face
Did him much diſpraiſe and greatly diſgrace,
And iudged him to be a corrupter of youth,
A lyar, a diſſembler, no teller of truth.
To whom Plato aunſwered making relation
That he had ouercome the planetes inclination.
By knowledge, and learning, and wiſe gouernement,
And by godly vertues dayly intertainement.
Iacob and Eſau maketh for this matter
As is in Geneſis the xxv. chapter.
They were two twinnes you ſhall vnderſtand:
The one holding the others heele in his hand.
Although they were borne at one houres inſtāt
Yet were their liues very much diſcrepant.
VVere not ſome (ſaith Ambroſe) from grace reiected,
And into Gods fauour agayne elected▪
VVere the Apoſtles redemed by the force of natiuitie,
Or did the comming of Chriſt them bleſſe & ſanctifie?
The theif was not ſaued by deſtenies deuiſe,
But the confeſsion of faith brought him to paradiſe.
VVhat ſay you to them whom death had deuoured?
And by Thapoſtles agayne to life were reſtored▪
Did deſtenie to life reſtore them agayne?
Nay, it was God by thapoſtles, as the Scriptures ſayne▪
Nowe to make vp and knitte the concluſion,
VVe haue brought deſtenie to vtter confuſion:
Of the whiche Bardazanes was the firſt authour,
And the ſect of the Priſcillianiſtes was the next fautour,
VVhiche in the councell of Tolletane holden in Spaine
The names of heretikes for this did ſuſtayne.
And as for the authoritie which thou broughteſt out of Auſten,
He ſpake it in the Stoikes, and not in his owne perſon.

lg.head: Larimos replieth.
lg.l: Nay, then I aſke you an other queſtion,
And geue me therof ſome pithie ſolution.
VVhat ſay you to the wordes of Sirach and Amos?
I durſt lay a noble, I ſhall you appoſe.
Both good thinges and alſo thinges ill
The Lord doth appointe them and fulfill.
Riches, pouertie, life, and death.
This the booke of Sirach ſaith.
Is there (ſayth Amos) any ill,
In a Citie, but it is the Lordes will?
So althoughe ye deny deſtenie:
Yet graunt, God to be the author of iniquitie.

lg.head: Phronimos aunſwereth.
lg.l: God ſaue me from that opinion.
But nowe will I aunſwere to thine obiection.
There be, ſaith Auſten, two kindes of ills
VVhiche ſpring out of two contrarie wils.
Eſt malum culpae, eſt & malum paenae.
The il of ſinne, mans will doth committe,
The ill of payn, Gods hand doth inflicte.
Not that ill of it ſelfe is Gods puniſhement,
But ſo counted of them, to whom it is ſent.
As a childe whiche is both wanton and wilde,
Doth feare the rod, which maketh him milde,
Although he hate it wurſe then a ſerpent,
Yet is the rod a very good inſtrument:
So the puniſhment whiche God doth ſend
To cauſe the ſinnefull man to amend,
Is counted of the ſinner to be very ill,
Becauſe it liketh nothyng his will.
And the payne whiche he doth ſuſteyne
He doth much abhorre and greatly diſdayne.
But although it be agaynſt his luſt,
Yet is Gods puniſhment both good and iuſt.
So that of ill God is a iuſt reuenger,
And not of ſinne to be counted an authour.

div.p: I thought good to inſerte theſe verſes for the better explanatiō what Fatum is, and alſo for the confutation of that deteſtable article whiche affirmeth God to be the authour of ſinne: from whiche opinion God preſerue euery chriſten hart.

div.head: Sacrificium. 3.
div.p: THe ignoraunce of them is to be laughed at, whiche make no difference betwene Sacramentum, and Sacrificium, where there is a very great difference.
A ſacramēt is that in which God doth exhibite and geue vs ſome thing: as in baptiſme he geueth vnto vs by the holy Ghoſt originall iuſtice, and wipeth away the originall ſinne.

Likewiſe in the ſupper of the Lord Chriſt exhibiteth vnto vs his body and bloud to be eaten and dronken, whiche when we receaue worthily, then we receaue by faith remiſsion of ſinnes, conſolation and grace.
Sacrificium eſt, quum nos▪ Deo aliquid offerimus & damus: A ſacrifice is, when that we do offer and geue ſome thing to God.

And where our aduerſaries do obiecte againſt vs that we haue no true Churche, becauſe we haue taken awaye the dayly Sacrifice, that is, the Maſse (as they call it) and ſo haue no Sacrifice left: we aunſwere.
Firſt, that there be ſixe kindes of Sacrifices, whiche the Church doth offer dayly vnto God.

The firſt kinde is the Sacrifice of a contrite minde, and of an humble ſpirite: Of the whiche Dauid doth ſpeake in his Pſalme: Sacrificium Deo
ſpiritus contribulatus, cor contritum & humiliatum, Deus nō deſpicies: A troubled ſpirite is a Sacrifice to God, a contrite and an humble hart,Pſal 51. O God, thou wilt not deſpiſe.

It can not be declared how acceptably the diuine maieſtie doth behold that hart, which doth vexe it ſelfe with the labour of repentaunce, which doth mollifie his hart with weping and teares, whiche beating it ſelf with the morter of Gods loue, with the peſtle of wiſedom, doth make of it ſelfe a moſt ſweete and precious ointment, which beyng layd vp in ſtore in the beautifull boxe of faith, and ſeaſoned and made ſweete with a moſt fragrāt and pleaſaūt pouder of prayers, doth conſecrate and ſanctifie it ſelfe vnto the Lord. It can not be, that the hart ſo moued and affected can be deſpiſed of God. VVhat other thyng did that ointmēt ſignifie, which that ſinfull woman did poure out of an Alabaſter boxe vpon the head of Ieſus?

The ſecōd kind of Sacrifice, is, Vituli labiorum the calues of the lips:Heb. 13. of the whiche Saint Paul ſpeaketh ſaying: By him therfore we offer the Sacrifice of laude and praiſe alwayes vnto God, that is to ſay, the fruites of thoſe lippes whiche confeſse his name. And in this kinde are contained prayers, confeſsiō, geuing of thankes, and inuocation.Cap. 4 Of this maner of Sacrifice ſpeaketh Oſeas.

The third kind of Sacrifice is benificence, mercy, pitie, almes ſhewed and exhibite vnto the poore: of the which Micheas the Prophet ſpeaketh after this maner: Indicabo tibi, homo, quid ſit bonū offerre, & quid Dominus requirat a te: vtique facere iudiciū, & diligere miſericordiā: Cap. 6. I will ſhewe thee, O man, what it is to offer good thinges, and what God requireth of thee: to do iuſt iudgement, and to loue mercy.

Alſo S. Paul in the Epiſtle to the Philippians calleth that almes,Cap. 4. which came from them, ſent vnto him by Epaphroditus, and an odor that ſmelleth ſweet, a Sacrifice accepted and pleaſaunt vnto God.

The fourth kinde of Sacrifice is the mortification of the fleſhe by the ſpirite, in the whiche we offer our bodyes a lyuely, holy, and acceptable Sacrifice vnto God. Of this kinde writeth Saint Paul in the Epiſtle to the Romaines, ſaying: I beſech you brethren by the mercifulnes of God,Cap. 12. that you make your bodies a quicke Sacrifice, holy and acceptable vnto God, that is to ſay, that you kill and ſlay all your fleſhly concupiſcence and carnall luſtes. And ſo bring your fleſh, through the helpe of your ſpirites, vnder the obedience of Gods holy law.

By theſe wordes it may appeare, that the ſupper of the Lord is not a Sacrifice propitiatorie, to be offered of the Prieſtes for the expiation and remiſsion of ſinnes, both of the liuyng and of the dead.

And we ſhall not finde in all the holy Scriptures, that the Miniſters of the newe Teſtament be called either Sacerdotes, or Sacrifici. For that
is attributed wholy and onely vnto Chriſt. And as it is written in the Epiſtle to the Hebrues, the Prieſthood was tranſlated vpon him. And for as much as he remaineth for euer, he nedeth no ſucceſſor.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: The Prophet Malachie doth intreate of the ſacrifice of Minhah, which he calleth Oblationem mundam & puram, a pure and cleane oblatiō that ſhould be offered to the name of the Lord in euery place, from the riſing of the ſunne, to the goyng downe of the ſame, ſo that his name ſhould be glorified among the Gentils. And by this Sacrifice he meant none other thing but the Maſſe, in the which fine & pure matter ſhould be offered.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: This obiection is very infirme and weake. For Ireneus interpreteth that place of bread and wine, and other gifts which the faithfull did offer in the Lordes ſupper.
contraiudaeos et aduerſus marcionem.Tertullian expoundeth that place of Malachie of ſpirituall oblations, as of prayers, thankes geuing, inuocation and godly ſermons.

S. Auſten doth conſent to the ſame expoſition. Saint Paul ſaith: That Abſque ſanguinis effuſione non fit remiſsio peccatorum: VVithout ſhedding of bloud, there is no remiſsion of ſinnes. And yet there is no bloud ſhed there (ſay they) but it is done Incruentè.
See, I pray you, how they caſt doung in their owne eyes, and vomit out their owne ſhame.
But of Hoſtia incruenta, I haue ſpoken before in the firſt Tome.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: The Prieſthoode after the order of Melchiſedech is now extant and remaineth in the Churche. VVherfore as he offered bread and wine vnto God: ſo we do offer in forme of bread and wine the ſonne of God. For to euery figure the thing that is figured doth aunſwere, and is alſo more noble and worthy then the figure.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: The hiſtorie of the booke of Geneſis doth not record that Melchiſedech offered bread and wine vnto God, but that he brought forth bread and wine vnto Abraham, and his hoste being weried, to refreſh and comfort them. And ſo Rabbi Solomon doth interpret that place.

Agayn, the Hebrue word, Hozi, doth not ſignifie to offer, but to bring forth a thing. And Rabbi Solomō doth teſtifie, yt Melchiſedeth did teſtifie by this gift and good handſell to Ahraham, that he tooke it not in ill part, that his poſteritie was ſlaine of Abraham.
Saint Ambroſe doth euidently ſay, that theſe thinges were offered to Abraham, and not vnto God.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: This worde, Miſsa, is an Hebrue worde, as it appeareth in Deuteronomie, where is written this worde, Miſſath,cap. 15. whiche worde ſignifieth Spontaneam oblationem, a free offering. Ergo the Maſse muſt needes be a Sacrifice, for Miſſa is deriued of this Hebrue worde Miſſath.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: The Greke Churches neuer vſed this worde, nor called at any tyme the Lordes ſupper by this name, Miſsa. Furthermore, if this word Miſſa were deriued of this word Miſſath, it ſhould be written Miſsah with Hae in the ende: but it is no where ſo written. It is therfore rather deriued Amittendo of ſendyng, becauſe that in the tyme of the Lords ſupper euery faithfull man did ſend his gifes to the Lordes table. Or els it is called Miſſa, for that they whiche were then Cathecumeni (whiche were not yet chriſtened) were ſent forth out of the Church, when the Miniſter begon to celebrate the Lordes ſupper. For they were ſuffered to tary no lō ger, by the reaſon they were not Baptiſed.

Rabanus ſayth: Miſſa tempore ſacrificii, quando cathecumeni foras mittuntur, clamante Leuita, ſi quis cathecumenus remanſit, exeat foras, Lib. 1. inſtitutionem. ca. 32 & inde Miſſa, quia ſacramentis altaris intereſſe non poſſunt, qui nondum regenerati eſſe noſcuntur: The Maſſe (ſaith he) is in the time of the Sacrifice, when cathecumeni wer ſent forth, the Deacon crying, if any of the cathecumines remayne here, let hym go forth. And thereupon it is called, Miſſa, the Maſſe: becauſe they which were not yet known to be regenerat, might not be preſent at the miniſtration of the Sacramēt of ye altar.

Innocentius ſayth:Lib. 6. de ſacra altaris myſte. cap. 12 Officium diuiditur in Miſſam cathecumenorum & fidelium: Miſſa cathecumenorum eſt ab introitu vſque poſt offertorium, & dicitur Miſſa ab emittendo, quae eo tempore, quo ſacerdos incipiebat Euchariſtiam conſecrare, cathecumeni foras de Eccleſia emittebantur: The Miſsall office is deuided into the Maſſe of the cathecumines, and the Maſse of the Chriſtians. The Maſſe of the cathecumines indured from the entraunce vntill after the Offertorie. It is called Miſſa of ſending forth, becauſe at that tyme, when the Prieſt began to conſecrate the Euchariſt, the cathecumines were ſent out of the Church.
And by this it appeareth, that this worde Miſſa, is neither an Hebrue worde, nor yet doth ſignifie a free offering.

I heard once a bacheler of diuinitie (who was reſident in the cathedral Churche of Exeter, and did reade there the diuinitie Lecture) ſaye, that this worde Miſsa cōmeth of this word Maſsa, a lompe of dowe or flower, out of the whiche was taken and made the fine cakes called the hostes, VVhiche definition (althoughe he were ignoraunt of the Hebrue and Greke toung) he ſeemed to take out of Petrus Galatinus: whoſe wordes, concerning this matter, I haue recited before.
This ſhalbe ſufficient for this worde Sacrificium.

div.head: Gratia & pax.
div.p: GRatia hath in the Scriptures manifold ſignificatiōs: Firſt, it is takē for the gift and participation of the holy ghoſt, whiche is geuen freely.Cap. 1. And ſo S. Paul vſeth it in the Epiſtle to the Romaines, ſaying: Per quē accepimus gratiā: by whō we receaued grace, which ſome do interpret the gift pertayning to the Apoſtleſhip.

2. Cor. cap. 8.Secōdly, Gratia ſignifieth benificence and almes, and ſo it is vſed in the Epiſtle to the Corinthians: Et in hac gratia abundetis: that you be bountifull in the ſame grace.2. Cor. c, 1.

Thirdly, Gratia betokeneth Gaudiū, ioy and gladnes: as in ye Epiſtle to the Corinthiās: Hac confidentia volui prius venire ad vos, vt ſecūdā gratiam haberitis: In this cōfidēce was I minded firſt to come vnto you, that ye might haue had a double grace. And we haue a phraſe in ye Latin toūg, by the whiche it is ſaid, thoſe thinges, whiche be delectable and pleaſaūt, are ſaid Habere gratiam: to haue a grace.

Fourthly, Gratia is taken oft times for mercy, which is called in the holye tong Chen: which the 70. interpreters do tranſlate 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is, Miſericordiam, as wel in remitting of iniuries, as in cōtributing faculties & goods.

Fiftly, Gratia ſignifieth ſwetenes, and the comlines of cōmunication: as Paul cōmaūdeth our cōmunicatiō to be ſeaſoned wt wiſedome, with a pleaſaūt comelines.Prou. 10. And ſo Salomō requireth: Vt iuſtorū ſermo gratioſus ſit: that the communication of the rightuous men be ſwete and comely.
Sixtly, Gratia ſignifieth ſometime Coronā, the crown: as in the Prouerbes: Vt addatur gratia capiti tuo: that the crowne, whiche thy father promiſed thee, may be ſet on thy head.

Finally, and ſpecially, Gratia ſignifieth the fauour of god: & ſo the aū gel vſed it in the ſalutation to the virgin Marie: Aue gratia plena, that is, all hail greatly in gods fauour. But the ſcholaſtical diuines with other do vſe Gratia in that place for aboundāce of vertues, by the whiche the virgin Marie did deſerue the fauour of god. VVherupon, they inuēted great honours to be geuen vnto the virgin Marie. They did excogitate to be ſong and ſayd in her worſhippe, Roſaries, Anthemes, Salue regina, Aue maris ſtella, and the nombring of bedes called our Ladies Pſalter, inuēted by one Petrus a french mā, a lowſy & hypocritical heremite. But how aptly and well theſe thinges were applied to the virgin Marie, the godly) thankes be geuen to God) doth now moſt euidently ſee.

div.head: Pax.
div.p: Pax, firſt ſignifieth the proſperous ſucceſſe and felicitie of all thinges. This worde, Pax, hath a ſtrayghter ſignification in the Latin toung, thē the worde, Scholom, hath among the Hebrues.
Ioſeph aſked his brethren: Eſt ne patri meo Pax? as thoughe he would ſay: Is my father in good caſe, doth he want any thing?
Pax in this place of Peter ſignifieth tranquilitie and quietnes of conſcience. And this is the difference betwene grace and peace.

Grace is in God, by the which he doth fauour vs, and by the which he doth remit ſinne throughe Chriſte without all merite. Peace in vs, that we beyng ſafe & ſure of remiſsion of ſinnes through Chriſt, may be quiet in conſcience.

div.head: The thyrde Prelection of the ſeconde Tome.
div.p: BEnedictus Deus et pater domini noſtri Ieſu Chriſti, 1. Benedictus qui ſecundum miſericordiam ſuam magnam regenerauit nos in ſpē viuam per reſurrectionem Ieſu Chriſti ex mortuis. Bleſſed be God,2. Dominus. euē the father of our Lord Ieſu Chriſt, whiche according to his aboundaunt mercy hath begotten vs againe vnto a liuely hope by the reſurrectiō of Ieſus Chriſt frō the dead.

p.hi: I will diuide this leſſon into three mēbers.

div.p: The firſt parte ſhalbe the explication and openyng of the text.
The second ſhalbe the declaration and confirmation of Chriſtes diuinitie.
The third ſhalbe a ſtrong probation of Chriſtes manhoode, with aunſwers to the obiections of thoſe heretikes, whiche do deny • Chriſtes humanitie.

Concernyng the firſt: after that Peter hath abſolued & made an end of the Epigraphe and inſcription of this Epiſtle, now he goeth to that part, whiche is called Exordium, that is, the entraunce of his matter, in the whiche entrie he doth inſinuate or couertly creepe into the mindes of his hearers by a certayn gratulation, or thankesgeuing. The tenor and meaning of theſe wordes is this:

Bleſſed, prayſed, and thanked be God, which by his mercy through Chriſt hath redemed vs from death, and hath geuen vs life euerlaſting. He doth proſecute euery member, and almoſt euery worde copiouſly and largely: partly, to commend & ſet forth the great benefites of God, & partly, to make away both plaine and profitable to that whiche foloweth.

Firſt of all (ſayth he) God is to be prayſed, bleſſed, and thanked, for the Sacrifice of prayſe and thankes geuyng is an amiable and acceptable ſeruice vnto God. Whiche Sacrifice who ſoeuer doth not vſe to offer vnto God, he is not worthy of the name of a Chriſtian.

Afterward, he declareth who is that God, that muſt be ſo prayſed and thanked: verely, that is to ſay, the father of our Lord Ieſus Chriſt. By the whiche wordes he doth ſhew and ſet forth the diuinitie of Chriſt, and the ſubſtaūce of the perſon.
Now for to be god is none other thing, then to be beneficiall, gentle, and boū teous, good & helping, & finally to be the preſeruer, keper & defender of al perſons.

For aſmuch then as god did open, ſhewe, exhibite, and geue this great benificence and liberalitie to the world, euen then ſpecially, when he ſent his onely begotten ſonne into the worlde: It is not without cauſe that he is called the father of our Lord Ieſus Chriſt, as the which, doth ſhew himſelf ſpecially god in Chriſt.

For, as god in time paſt called him ſelfe the god of Abraham, and would with that note and title be diſcerned and knowne from all fained and falſe gods: Euen ſo after he had manifeſted & made him ſelf knowne in his ſonne Chriſt, he would be none otherwiſe knowne but by the ſame Chriſt.

3. dole.Therfore, they whiche do conceaue in their minde the onely, naked, & bare maieſtie of god without Chriſt, haue in the place of god an Idoll, as the Iewes, the Turkes,4. Mahomet. and the profeſſors of Machometes religion haue. For he that will know god, and haue god as a true god, let him euer inueſte, adorne, and decke god with this title: God the father of Chriſt. For as often as our minde doth ſeeke god, and looke vpon god, except Chriſt be alſo conceaued, it wilbe a vayne, a confuſed, and a deſperate conception and contemplation. For without Chriſt, the goodnes and liberalitie of god can neuer be taſted nor perceaued of vs.

5. Spes viua,It foloweth in the text: In ſpem viuam. Here Peter ſheweth the cauſe why god ſhould be bleſſed and praiſed. Which god (ſaith Peter) accordyng to his aboundāt mercy, begat vs agayn vnto a liuely hope, that is to ſay, therfore is god to be praiſed and thanked, becauſe being neither prouoked nor allured by any merites or deſertes of ours, beyng moued onely by his mere and naturall goodnes hath reuoked and called vs backe agayne from eternall death, vnto the hope of eternall life. And this is the ſum and the ſcope of the whole goſpell. And I beſeche you marke here, what an apt and meete Epitheton Peter putteth to this worde, Mercye, he calleth it an aboundant, a great, and a riche mercy.

Pſal. 103.The Prophet Dauid ſayth in his Pſalmes: Miſerator et miſericors dominus, longanimis, et multum miſericors, non imperpetuum iraſcetur: The Lord is full of cō paſſion and mercy, ſlowe to anger, and of great kindnes, he will not alway chide, neither kepe his anger for euer.

Truely, here is a great fayth, and a greate truſte whiche we oughte to haue, when we be perſuaded, that God is ours, that is, that god wilbe meeke, pityfull, gentle, & ſlowe to take vengeance, whiche cōmeth to paſſe by none other meanes, but that god is a father, no enemie, nor tyraunt.
Now, if he be a father, then is he moſt louyng vnto his children. For how can any indignation, diſdayne, or any reuēging affection continue long in the fathers mynde toward his children?

In the tyme of the law, when all thinges were terrible and fearefull, then did the wrath of God ſeeme to haue none end. But when the ſonne of god came, then would god the father haue all goodnes, all clemencie, all gentlenes to be in him, and to come with him.

Regen uit nos in ſpem viuam: He begat vs agayne to a liuely hope. This phraſe of ſpeakyng hath a greater energie, then if he ſhould haue ſayd, he hath reſtored lyfe agayne vnto vs. For this worde regeneratyng and begettyng agayne doth admoniſhe and put vs in minde of our infirmitie and miſerie. Adam begat vs, but that was vnto death. For by nature we be the children of wrath and indignation. Therfore, they had neede to be regenerate and borne agayne, whiche would be the children and heires of god. And thys begettyng agayne doth god the father worke in them whiche beleue in Chriſt.

Per reſurrectionem Ieſu Chriſti ex mortuis. It foloweth, by the reſurrection of Ieſu Chriſt from the deade. Here Peter ſheweth the maner and the waye howe we be renued and borne agayne vnto the hope of immortall lyfe. Truly euen by this (ſayth Peter) that god rayſed hys ſonne agayne from death. The reſurrection of Chriſt doth comprehende the whole myſterie of Chriſte. For by Chriſte hys reſurrection it is declared to the whole worlde, that ſinne is clenſed and put awaye. For, excepte the Lorde had clenſed and put awaye ſinne, death, whiche is the rewarde and price of ſinne, had preuayled agaynſte vs. But the Lorde dyed and is ryſen agayne. Therefore he hath put awaye both death and ſinne: not that they bee not, but that they cannot hurte the faithfull, whiche learne and
beleue by the lyuelye reſurrection of Chriſte, that the lyfe eternall is prepared for them.

To make the matter more playne, no man can beleue in God, without a certayne meane, and middle. Therfore, when we would appeare before god, or call vpon hym, we haue neede of ſome other, whiche may ſolicite our cauſe & reconcile vs to God. Nowe, there is none other meane and middle, but onely Ieſus Chriſt.

Therfore, the fayth of the Turkes, and the Iewes, is no true fayth. And where they beleue and confeſſe, that God is the maker of heauen and earth: euen ſo doth the deuil beleue, but it doth nothyng auayle hym. No more doth theyr fayth profite them, becauſe they preſume to come into the ſyght of God without Chriſte, whiche is the true and onely mediatour, as Paule ſayth to the Romaynes:Cap. 1. Acceſlum habemus ad Deum in fide, non per noſmetipſos, ſed per Chriſtum: We haue acceſſe vnto god in fayth, not by our ſelues, but by Chriſt.

Wherefore, when we go to god, we muſte bryng Chriſte with vs, we muſt come by hym, and ſatiſfye god by him, and to do all thynges with god by hym and in hys name. And this is it that Peter here ſayth: Per reſurrectionem Ieſu Chriſti: That is, becauſe Chriſte is ryſen agayne, is aſcended into heauen, and ſitteth at the ryght hande of the father. For, he aſcended for thys cauſe, for to ſende and to geue vs hys holy ſpirite, by the whiche we beyng borne agayne, myght be bolde to come to god, and ſaye: O father, beholde, I am come before thee, and do praye vnto thee, not that I haue any confidence and truſte in my prayer, but becauſe my Lorde Chriſte doth make interceſſion for me: he is myne aduocate, he is myne atturney, he hath ſuffered death for me, and hath receaued vpon hym for my cauſe both ſinne, death, and hell: he is ryſen agayne, and hath vanquyſhed all myne enemyes: he hath purchaſed for me the hope of eternall lyfe. Therefore, when I come to thee, O God, I muſt needes bryng Chriſt with me, or elles I come vnworthely, or elles I come in vayne. Awaye, therefore, you Papiſtes, awaye with your interceſſion vnto Sainctes, with your workes of ſupererogation,6. Purgarory with your pipyng Purgatorie, and ſuche other lyke traſhe. I tell you, that neither remiſſion of ſinnes, nor the fauour of God, nor eternall lyfe and ſaluation can be obteyned by none other meanes, but by Chriſt: and that (I ſay) by Chriſt onely.
Thus I haue playnely opened vnto you the texte of Sainte Peter before rehearſed. Nowe will I deſcende to the ſeconde parte, that is, to the intreatie of Chriſtes diuinitie.

div.head: Pars ſecunda.
div.p: The vniuerſall Scripture doth call God a father, and that a father eternall. None is father of hym ſelfe, but the father of a ſonne or ſome chylde. And becauſe the father is eternall, it doth neceſſarily folowe, that he haue a ſonne eternall, equall and conſubſtantiall vnto him in all thynges.

For the confirmation of this, Paul bringeth in two teſtimonies, the one out of the ſecond Pſalme, where it is writtē, I will declare the decree, yt is, the Lord hath ſayd vnto me, thou art my ſonne, this day haue I begotten thee, Hodie, this day,7. Hodie. yt is, from the beginning, or eternally (as Auſtē, and Theophilactus do expound it.)

The ſecond teſtimonie is out of the ſecond booke of Samuel: Ego ero illi pater, et ille erit mihi filius: I wilbe his father, and he ſhalbe my ſonne. Whiche wordes Paul doth apply to Chriſt the ſonne of God.

Micheas the Prophet hath for this matter a goodly teſtimonie: Et tu Bethleem Ephrata paruula quidem es in millibus Iuda, cap. 7. ex te prodibit mihi dominatur in Iſraele et exitus eius a ſeculo a diebus aeternitatis: And thou Bethleem Ephrata arte litle to be among the thouſands of Iudah: yet out of thee ſhal he come forth vnto me that ſhalbe the ruler in Iſraell, whoſe goyng forth hath bene from the begynnyng, and from euerlaſtyng.

Wherupon, Chriſt him ſelfe doth ſay: Amen, dico vobis, Iohn. 8, antequā Abraham fieret
ego ſum: Verilie I ſay vnto you, before Abrahā was, I am. He doth not ſay. I was or I ſhalbe,8. Egoſum. but I am▪ alluding to the ineffable name of the Lord, Iehouah.
There is a greeke worde 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , whiche ſignifieth to be of the ſame eſſence. Of this worde there was great altrecation amonges them of the olde tyme.

Euſebius doth compēdiouſly ſhewe, howe this worde was vſed of the Nicene Councel: where it was defined, that Chriſt was 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , cum patre, that is, of one ſubſtaunce with the father. Whiche thyng hath an expreſſe ſignification, that the ſonne of god hath no participation nor ſimilitude with the creatures that were made, but is likened onely to the father which begat him, nor is of any other eſſēce or ſubſtaunce, but of the fathers.

Cap. 13.Zacharias bringing in god ſpeakyng, doth ſay: Excitare O gladie ſuper paſtorem meum, et ſuper virum coaequalem mihi: percute paſtorem, et diſpergentur oues gregis: Ariſe O ſworde vpon my ſhephearde, and vpon the man that is my felow, ſayth the Lord of hoſtes, ſmite the ſhepheard, and the ſheepe ſhalbe ſcattered.
Behold, he calleth the ſhepheard that is ſmitten, his felow, And who was that ſmitten ſhepheard,Cap. 10. it is written and declared in the goſpell of Iohn.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: Saint Hierome, which was expert in the Hebrue tongue, did tranſlate and read Virum cohaerentem mihi, and not Coaequalem mihi. Therfore, this texte maketh nothing for his diuinitie.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: As Saint Hierome doth not denie the Hebrue worde, Amith, to ſignifie coequall or felow: ſo be putteth in the ſteede therof an other worde of the ſame equipollencie and efficacie. For he ſayth in his commentaries: Vir cohaerens deo quis eſt niſi qui ait: ego in patre, et pater in me eſt: A man cleauyng together with God, who is it, but he that ſayth: I am in the father, and the father is in me.

Cap. 5.Agayne, in the goſpell of Iohn it is written: Propterea quaerebāt Iudaei Ieſum interficere, quia no ſolū ſoluiſſet ſabathū, ſed et patrē ſuū dicebat Deū, aequalē ſe faciēs deo: Therfore the Iewes ſought the more to kill Ieſus, not onely becauſe he had brokē the ſabaoth, but ſayd alſo that god was his father, and made himſelf equall with god. Neither the equalitie can conſiſte in any other thing, but in ſubſtaunce.

The Iewes do vnderſtand that whiche the Arrians will not ſee and perceaue: that is, that the Lord by a ſingular maner did cal god his proper & natural father: of whom naturally he was begotten, his naturall and conſubſtantiall ſonne.

Cap. 8.Chriſt ſayth in Iohn alſo: Ego ex patre proceſsi et veni: I proceded frō my father, and came. He doth not ſay onely I came, but I proceded, that is, I proceded ſuch an one as the father is in ſubſtaunce, certes true god of true god.
Agayne, he ſayth: Ego et pater vnū ſumus: I and the father am one, that is, one thyng,Iohn. 10. not one in concorde and conſente, but in identitie and ſubſtaunce.
9. Vnū ſumꝰ. Cap. 2.Furthermore, al thinges that were made, were made by him, that is, by Chriſt. Therfore, he is no creature, but true god creating all thinges.

Saint Paule to the Philippians doth ſaye, that the ſonne was in the ſhape of god: but to be in the ſhape of god is none other thyng, but to be equall and conſubſtantiall vnto god in all thynges. For the Apoſtle addeth theſe woords: Non rapinam arbitratus eſt, ſe aequalem eſſe Deo: he thought it not robberie to be equall vnto god.
Nowe, that thing whiche is gotten by robberye, pertayneth to an other, and is poſſeſt by iniurie.

S. Ambroſe ſayth: Quum hanc vnitatem ſubſtantiae in patrae et filio nō ſolū prophetica et euangelica authoritate cognoſcas: quomodo dicis, in ſcripturis diuinis homouſion non inueniri? Lib. 5. de fide cont. Arrian. quaſi aliud ſit homouſion, quam quod dicit: ego de Deo patre exiui, et ego et pater vnum ſumus: For as much as thou dooſt know this vnitie of
ſubſtaunce in the father and in the ſonne, not onely by the prophets, but alſo by the goſpel: how ſaieſt thou, that homouſion is not founde in the holy ſcriptures? as though homouſion doth differ from that which he ſaith: I came out of the father, and I and the father am one.

Sainct Auſten confirmeth the ſame. Alſo Chriſt ſaith to his Apoſtles:Lib. 14. cont. Maxim. num & vos vultis abire? reſpondit omnium nomine Petrus, domine, ad quem ibimus? verba vitae aeternae habes, & nos credimus, & cognouimus, quòd tu es Chriſtus filius Dei viui: Will ye alſo go away? then Simon Peter anſwered him, maiſter, to whom ſhal we go? Thou haſte the wordes of eternal life: and we beleue and knowe, that thou arte Chriſt, the ſonne of the liuyng god.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: It is true in deede (ſaith the Arrian) that Chriſt is the ſonne of God by adoption, & imputatiō & becauſe he hath receiued a more plentiful grace thē al other of God. But he is not the natural ſonne and the conſubſtantial ſonne of the father.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: In the goſpell of Marke the high prieſt ſaid to Chriſt:Cap. 14. tu es Chriſtus ille filius benedicti? art thou that ſonne of the bleſſed god? Likewiſe he ſaith in Mathew: I adiure thee by the liuyng god, that thou tel vs, whether thou be Chriſt, the ſon of the lyuing god: Ieſus anſwered ego ſum: I am. For you ſhall ſee the ſonne of man ſitting vpon the right hand of the power of god, and comming in the clouds of the heauens.

This confeſſion of the Lorde, as moſt blaſphemouſe and worthie death they brought before Pilate, crieng: we haue a lawe, and after our lawe he oughte to dye, becauſe he made himſelfe the ſonne of God.

Furthermore, Chriſt ſaith in Iohn:Cap. 10. I haue ſhewed many good workes vnto you from my father: for which of thoſe workes do you ſtone me? The Iewes anſwered him ſayeng: for the good worke we ſtone thee not, but for blaſphemy, and that thou being a man makeſt thy ſelfe God.

Againe, Chriſt ſaith to his diſciples: ne turbetur cor veſtrum, creditis in Deum, Iohn. 14. et in me credite &c. Let not your harte be troubled: ye beleue in god,10. Many dwelling places beleue alſo in me. In my fathers houſe are many dwellyng places: if it were not ſo, I would haue tolde you: I go to prepare a place for you, & though I go to prepare a place for you, I will come again and receiue you vnto my ſelfe, that where I am, there may you be alſo. And a title after he ſaith: I am the way & the truth, & the life. &c.

Here he commaundeth vs to beleue in him as in the true God. Alſo he ſaith: Pater venit hora, glorifica filium tuum, vt filius tuus glorificet te &c. Father,Iohn· 7, the houre is come, glorifie thy ſonne, that thy ſonne alſo maye glorifie thee, as thou haſt geuen him power ouer all fleſhe, that he ſhould geue eternal life to all them that thou haſte geuen him. And this is life eternall, that they know thee to be the onely very liuyng god, and whom thou haſt ſent Ieſus Chriſt. I haue glorified thee on the earth: I haue finiſhed the worke that thou gaueſt me to do. And now glorifie me, thou father, with thine owne ſelf, with the glorie which I had wyth thee before the worlde was. By theſe wordes Chriſt doth proue him ſelfe to be the true God.

Finally, ſainct Paule in the epiſtle to the Romains hath a ſtrong teſtimonie for the diuinitie of Chriſt. His words be theſe: Of whom, concerning the fleſhe,Cap. 9. Chriſt came, whiche is god ouer all, bleſſed for euer, Amen.
The like ſayeng is in the epiſtle of ſainct Iohn, the wordes be theſe: we are in him that is true, that is in his ſonne Ieſus Chriſt.1. Ep. cap. 2. This ſame is very god and eternall lyfe.

Well, I will conclude this parte with a golden and godly ſimilitude writen by the learned father and godly byſhop Cyrillus, who writeth after this maner: filius
in patre & ex patre eſt, non profluens foras, ſed aut quaſi à ſole ſplendor, aut quaſi ab igne inſita ſibi caliditas. In his enim exemplis vnum ab vno produci, & ambo conſempiterna ſic eſſe conſpicimus, vt aliud abſque alio nec eſſe poſsit nec naturae ſuae rationem retinere: quomodo enim erit ſol ſplendore priuatus, vel quomodo erit ſplendor, niſi ſol ſit à quo defluat? Ignis verò quomodo erit calore carens? vel calor vnde prodeat, niſi ex igne, aut ab alio forſan non procul à ſubſtantiali qualitate ignis diſiecto &c. that is to ſaye: The ſonne is in the father, and of the father, not flowing out of an other, but eyther as it were the brightneſſe cōming frō the ſunne, or els as it were the natural heate coming from the fire. For in theſe examples, we ſee the one to be ſo produced and brought forth of the other, and ſo to be perpetually annexed together, that neyther one can be without the other, neyther reteine nor holde his proper nature. For, how ſhal the ſunne be without brightneſſe, or how ſhall there be brightneſſe, vnleſſe ther be a ſunne from which it may come? Or from whence can heate come, but from fire, or from ſome other thing not far diſtante from the ſubſtantial qualitie of fire? Therfore like as the natural qualities are together which their ſubiectes from whome they come, and doo alwayes ſhewe from whence they come: ſo in the onelye begotten ſonne of God we muſt vnderſtand, that not onely he is with the father, but alſo he is beleued to be in the father, not ſtraunge from the nature nor inferior to the father by nature, but is with him, and of him after the maner of an vnſpekeable generation.

Thus I haue brought you ſufficient teſtimonies for the proofe of Chriſts diuinitie: and now wil I procede to the third parte, which ſhalbe to eſtabliſhe with ſtrong arguments and reaſons that Chriſt was a very true and naturall man, ſinne only excepted.

In the firſt boke of Moyſes God ſaide vnto the ſerpente: I wil put enmitye betwene thee and the woman,Geneſ. 3. 11. He ſhall. and betwene thy ſeede & her ſeede. He ſhal breake thine head, and thou ſhalte bruſe his heele &c. Who knoweth not the head of the ſerpent to be the kyngdome, the might, and the power of the deuil? And all the ſcripture doth teſtifie, that Chriſt (who was called the ſeede of the woman) hath vanquiſhed and ouercome this mightie tirannie of the ſaid ſerpent. And Chriſt is properly called ſèmen, for the veritie of the humaine nature. But he is called the ſeede of a woman, not of man, by the reaſon he was conceiued of the holy Ghoſt, without the ſeede of man.

The like promiſe was renued and inculked vnto Abraham, In ſemine tuo benedicentur omnes gentes orbis: Geneſ. 22 In thy ſeede ſhalbe bleſſed all the nations of the worlde. Saint Paule to the Galathians doth ſay: This ſeede of Abrahā in the which we obteine bleſſednes, is Ieſus Chriſte.

The ſame Apoſtle in the epiſtle to the Hebrues doth write, that Chriſt toke not vpon him the nature of Aungels,Cap. 2. but he toke the ſeede of Abraham. By naming the Aungels, he excludeth all ſpiritual ſubſtaunces. By the ſeede of Abraham, he vnderſtandeth the very ſubſtance of mans fleſhe.

The ſcripture doth deduce the line and progenie of Chriſt out of the loynes of Abraham vnto Iacob, and out of him into Iuda, and ſo again vnto Dauid, vnto whom the promis of the ſonne of God was again renued. Nathan ſaid vnto Dauid: Thus the Lorde ſaith: when thy dayes be fulfilled, thou ſhalte ſleepe with thy fathers,12. Nathan. and I will ſet vp thy ſeede after thee, whiche ſhal procede out of thy bodie, and will eſtabliſh his kyngdome: he ſhall build an houſe for my name, and I will eſtabliſhe the throne of his kyngdome for euer.

div.head: Obiectio,
div.p: This is ſpoken of Salomon, who builded the great and ſumptuouſe temple of Ieruſalem, and not ment of Chriſt.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p:
Salomon was born while Dauid liued, and his kyngdom ſoone fayled. But
the Prophet Dauid ſpeaketh here of a ſonne which ſhould be borne vnto Dauid 〈…〉
• s death: for he ſaith: when thou ſhalt ſlepe with thy fathers, I will raiſe 〈◊〉 ſ • ede, after thee, which ſhall go forth out of thy wombe, as it is written in the pſalme: de fructu ventiis tui ponam ſuper ſedem tuam: Out of the fruite of thy wombe I will ſet out vpon thy ſeat. Now, the Virgin Mary was of the progenie of Dauid, of the whiche virgin Chriſt was borne, of whom the Aungel ſpake vnto the virgin, ſayenge: & dabit illi dominus Deus ſedem patris ipſius, Luk. 5. &c. And the Lord God ſhall geue him the ſeate of Dauid his father, & he ſhall raigne ouer the houſe of Iacob for euer, and of his kingdome there ſhalbe none end.
Sainct Paule ſaith: filium Dei factum ex muliere: Gal. 4. that the ſon of God was made of a woman, concernyng the humaine nature.

Iohn the Euangeliſt writeth, verbum caro factum eſt, & habitauit in nobis: Cap. 1. the worde was made fleſhe, and dwelled among vs: not that the worde was tourned into fleſh, but that the woorde tooke fleſhe vpon him, and that God became mā.13. Factum eſt In polymor. ſuo dial. 1 1, Ioh, ca. 4.
The Ortodoxe and chriſtian fathers do expounde this worde to ſignifie, aſſumſit: as Theodoretus and other.

The ſame Iohn ſaith: Euery ſpirite which confeſſeth Ieſus Chriſt to haue come in the fleſh, is of god: and euery ſpirit which doth not cōfeſſe Chriſt to haue come in the fleſh, is not of God. Wherupon we maye freely pronounce Valentinus, Appelles, Manicheus to be of the deuil, and their opinions to be moſte deteſtable hereſie.
Againe, ſainct Paule in the epiſtle to the Romaines ſaith: quorum ſunt patres ex quibus eſt Chriſtus ſecundum carnem: Of whome are the fathers, and of whom, concerninge the fleſhe, Chriſt came.

Tertullian, to proue that Chriſte had a verye true humaine nature, writeth after this maner: nihil ex aliqua materia deſumitur, quin eius indicia & veſtigia nonnulla conſeruet, &c. Nothing is taken or made of anie matter, but it keepeth ſome tokens and apparance thereof. Becauſe the bodi of the firſt man was made of earthe, therfore it did retaine the kinde of the two elementes. for, the fleſhe repreſenteth the earth, and the bloude repreſenteth the water. And manie things do make demonſtration, that we, concerninge oure bodies, be earthlye.
In the earth are clottes and cloddes, in our bodies are muſcles and fleſhie knottes.
In the yearthe are rockes and hard ſtones: in our bodies are bones.
In the yearth are floddes and riueres: in our bodies are vaines whiche water all the members with bloud In the yearth are diſperſed the rootes of plantes and trees: in our bodies are ſynewes.
In the yearth are ſmaleflatte ſtones: in our bodies are hornie nailes.
In the bowels of the earth are certain mettals: in the holownes of our bones are marrowe or marie.
In the yearth we ſee moſſe and herbes to growe: in our bodies do growe heres, as the beard and the buſhe.

Nowe, when all theſe particulers had place in the bodie of Chriſte, the Anabaptiſtes, without all cauſe or reaſon, goe aboute to affirme, that Chriſt brought his bodie from heauen with him, and that he paſſed throughe the wombe of the virgin Marie, as water dothe thorough a pipe.
But let vs nowe ſee their reaſons and obiections, wherwith they go aboute to eſtabliſhe their hereticall doctrine.

div.head: Obiectio. 1.
div.p: Firſt, ſay they, if the bodie of Chriſt ſhould not be celeſtiall and heauenly, but taken of the wombe of the virgin: how then doth Paule ſay, Chriſt to dwell in our hartes. For his material bodye can not enter into our harts. And ſo ſhuld we haue but halfe Chriſt to dwel in vs.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Paule doth euidently and plainly declare how Chriſt dwelleth in our hartes: for, he addeth per fidem, by faith. Now, faith it ſelfe doth apprehend not parte of Chriſt, but whole Chriſt, as in the ſacrament of the Euchariſt, and in the worde of God, whiche ſetteth forth vnto vs our ſaluation.
And that this is ſpirituallie to be vnderſtand and iudged, it appeareth by the conference of many other places in the ſcriptures.

It is written in the Epiſtle to the Romains: If Chriſt dwel in you, god which raiſed him from death,Cap. 8. will quicken and make a liue your bodies, propter ſpiritis eius qui habitat in vobis: through his ſpirite, which dwelleth in you. Here maye you manifeſtly ſee, that Chriſt dwelleth in vs by his ſpirit, not by his real and carnall bodye.

div.head: Obiectio. 2.
div.p: No creature is to be worſhiped, if Chriſt toke his bodie of a virgin, there is no doubte, but it was created. Wherfore, it ought not to be worſhipped: but Chriſt ought to be worſhiypod. Ergo, he toke not his bodie of the virgin Mary.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: We muſt take hede, that we diuide not the natures of Chriſt with the heretike Neſtorius. The vnitie of the perſon is to be vewed and cōſidered, whole Chriſt is worſhipped of vs, that is, that ſame diuine parſon, which, wherſoeuer it be, or how ſo euer it be worſhipped, hath alwayes the humanitie ioyned with it, which can not be ſeparate from the diuine nature. Now, if the reaſon and tenor of adoration be explored and tried, the ſame is to be referred not to the humanitie, but to the diuinitie. Which two natures are alwayes in Chriſt inſeparable.

div.head: Obiectio. 3.
div.p: It is written in Mathew: That which was borne in her, is of the holy ghoſte. Mark here and note,Cap. 1. how Mathew doth ſay: Chriſt was born in Marie, and not of Marie. Therfore, he toke no matter of her.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: This place of Mathew doth moſt chiefly confute them. For here is attributed vnto Chriſt, that he was borne in the virgin. Now, to be borne, is not to paſſe thorough a pipe or a conduit, but truely to take matter and ſubſtance of a bodye, of that wherof it is ſaid to be borne.

And where they vrge this prepoſition, in, as where it is ſaid, natus eſt in ea, he was borne in her: This phraſe is but onely once vſed in all the ſcriptures. Whē on the other ſide, in infinite places it may be ſhewed, that Chriſt was borne ex ſemine Dauid, of the ſeede of Dauid. But theſe heretikes are ſo far paſt ſhame (as Tertullian writeth) that where ſo euer they finde this prepoſition, ex, they put it out, and place in the ſteede therof this prepoſition, in, that they might the better eſtabliſhe their deteſtable doctrine.

div.head: Obiectio. 4.
div.p: It is written in S. Iohn, that Chriſt ſaid: vos de terra eſtis, ego de ſuperius: You are of the earth, I am from aboue. Therfore, Chriſt comming from aboue toke no bodie in the earth.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Chriſt is from aboue, concernyng his diuine nature. Furthermore, he is ſaid to be from aboue, becauſe al his actions & doinges were ruled and gouerned, not with earthly affections, but with the heauenly & diuine ſpirit. But in the Iewes (whom he reproued) it was otherwiſe. For they were mere and naked naturall men, and were lead with carnall and earthly affections and luſtes.

div.head: Obiectio. 5.
div.p:
A certaine woman in Luke cried out and ſaide: bleſſed is the wombe that
bare thee, and the paps which gaue thee ſucke. But Chriſt anſwered: yea rather bleſſed be they which heare the word of God, and do kepe it. By this it appeareth, that Chriſt denied himſelfe to be borne of the virgins wombe.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Chriſt in theſe wordes did not reiecte nor refuſe the kinred of his mother, but did ſhew which was the better degree of felicitie, as though he had ſaid: the wōbe which bare me, is not bleſſed for the bare birthes ſake, but for faiths ſake. And ſo are all they whiche heare the word of god, and kepe it. So that in theſe words of Chriſt ther appereth no negation, but rather a compariſon of the degrees of bleſſednes.

div.head: Obiectio. 6.
div.p: The Aungels in the old Teſtament tooke vnto them mans fleſh, and put vppon them our bodies, who, notwithſtanding, were not borne of women. Wherfore than may we not ſay and affirme the ſame of Chriſt, that he did put vpō him the ſhape of man, and yet tooke it not of the virgin Marie.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: The likenes of the Aungels appearing in the ſhape of man muſt not be compared with the incarnation of the Lord. For they toke not vnto them bodies, that they ſhould be crucified, that they ſhould dye, and redeme mankinde, but that they ſhould execute, and do the meſſages committed vnto them. But Chriſt woulde become very man, yt he might redeme mankind, which thing could not haue bene brought to paſſe, if he had brought his body from heauen, ſeing that the celeſtiall and terreſtrial nature do differ pluſquam genere.

div.head: Obiectio. 7.
