div.p: Hilarius wrote in his boke of the Trinitie, that the virgin Marie added nothing of her owne ſubſtaunce vnto the fleſhe and bodie of Chriſt, beſide the miniſterie of conceyuing, of bearyng, and of deliuering.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: This ſentence of Hilarie auaileth them nothing. For he doth moſt euidently teſtifie the bodie of Chriſt to be a creature: but he ſaith, that Marie added nothing of her owne ſubſtance, beſide thoſe three miniſteries, of conceiuyng, bearyng, and bringinge forth. For the fourth miniſterie had been to haue had copulation with man, and to haue admitted his ſede, which ſhe did not.

div.head: Quaeſtio.
div.p: But what maner of fleſhe was the fleſhe of Chriſt? had it a ſoule, or no ſoule? Arrius taught that the ſonne of god tooke onely fleſh without ſoule, & the worde was in ſtede of the ſoule.

Apollinarius did attribut a ſoule vnto Chriſt, but toke away that part which is called mens, denieng it to be a reaſonable ſoule.14. Mens. Cap. 20. But the holy ſcripture geueth vnto Chriſt a ſoule, and likewiſe vnto the ſame ſoule mentem a minde.

The Lorde ſayth in the goſpel of Mathew: the ſonne of man came to geue his ſoule a redemption for many. And Chriſt himſelf ſaid: triſtis eſt anima mea vſque ad mortem: my ſoule is heauie, euen to death.
Again in Iohn be ſaith: my ſoule is now troubled. Now, if this ſoule of Chriſt had ben deſtitute of that part, which is called mens: how could he be ſad, vnderſtand, deſire and remember?

Chriſt ſaith in ſ. Luke, the ſonne of mā came not to deſtroie the ſoules of men, but to ſaue them. Now man was loſt both in bodie and in ſoule: Therfore,cap. 9. that he might be ſaued both in bodie and in ſoule, Chriſt our ſauiour toke vpon hym a very true humain bodie, and a reaſonable ſoule.

To conclude for both the natures of Chriſt, the holy fathers fighting againſt heretiques, which denied, ether the humain nature or the diuine nature of Chriſt,
or els the coniunction of both natures in one perſon, tooke their arguments of the natural maner of the Euchariſte.

If Chriſt had come vnto vs onely in the diuine nature, and had no humaine fleſhe, but phantaſtical, what communion and felowſhip had ben betwen vs and Chriſt? Sainct Paule interpreting theſe wordes: Ego & pueri, quos dedit mihi Deus, beholde, here am I and the children, which god hath geuen me, ſaith thus: For aſmuche then as the children were partakers of fleſh and bloud, he alſo himſelf likewiſe tooke part with them.

If they take awaye the fleſh and bloud of Chriſt, then they do berieue vs alſo of the ſpiritual meate, which we apprehend and take by faith. And ſo they wil vtterly deſtroye the ſacrament of the Lordes table. On the other ſide, if they take away the diuine nature from Chriſt, than he ſhould be onely a mere natural mā. And ſo his fleſhe and bloud ſhould haue nothyng preuailed to our inſtauration & redemption. For, although the whole matter of heauenly lyfe to be geuen vnto vs, was executed by the fleſh of Chriſt: yet it did depēd only of the diuine nature. Nor it had ben any great matter to haue had any communion or felowſhip with the fleſhe of a bare and mere man. For, we haue that naturallie with all men, but if doth nothing profit. Therfore, the holy communion requireth the partakyng of ſuche a fleſhe, which could geue lyfe, which could not be had, if the diuine nature ſhould haue ben withdrawen from Chriſt.

15: Symbol of AthanaſiusWe will therfore conclude this leſſon with the ſcriptures, and with the ſymbole of Athanaſius. which both do affirme, that Chriſt is god begotten of the ſubſtance of the father before all worldes, and that he is man borne of the ſubſtaunce of his mother in the worlde, perfect god, and perfect man, ſubſiſting and beinge of humaine fleſhe, and of a reaſonable ſoule, Which ſhall come again in the ſame fleſhe, but yet glorified, to iudge the quick and the dead. To whome, with the father, and the holy ghoſt be all honor and glory. Amen.

div.head: Hic ſequuntur Miſcellanea praelectionis tertiae. Tomi. 2.
Benedictus. 1.
div.p:
BEnedicere in the hebrue toung is called Barak and it ſignifieth ſomtimes to make bleſſed, luckie,cap. 12. proſperous and fortunate. As in Geneſis: faciam te in gētem magnam, & benedicam te. that is: I wil make thee a great nation, and will be bleſſe thee, which is as muche to ſaie, as, I will make thee happie and fortunate.Cap. 28. Alſo it is written in Geneſis. Det quo
que tibi benedictionem Abrahae. Let him geue thee alſo the bleſſinge of Abraham, that is, let him make thee luckie and ſafe.

Secondlie benedicere, betokeneth to make plentifull, to encreace and augment the power of procreation of children,Cap. 9. as in Geneſis. Benedixit deus Noe & filios eius, & dixit ad eos creſcite & multiplicamini, that is. God bleſſed Noe and his children, and ſaide vnto them: Growe ye,
and multiplie, he bleſſed them, that is, he made them fruitfull.

Thirdlye benedicere, ſignifieth to magnifie, celebrate, and make holi, as in Geneſis: benedixit diei ſeptimo, He bleſſed the ſeuenth daye,cap. 2. that is, he did magnifie it and ſet it forth with ſingular laude and praiſe.
Fourthly, it ſignifieth ſomtime to do good, as in Geneſis, Vt benedicā benedicentibus te. I wil do good to them that do good vnto thee.Cap. 12.

Fiftely, it betokeneth to praie and wiſh well and good lucke to them that departe or go away, as in the Acte of the apoſtles. Vt nec plura locutus benedixit eis, that is. And ſpeakinge no more, he bleſſed them, that is,Cap. 1. he bidde them farewell, and ſo aſcended to heauen.
Sixtly, it betokeneth to ſalute, as in Geneſis. Benedixit Iacob Pharaoni. Iacob bleſſed Pharao, that is:Cap. 47. He ſaluted him and wiſhed him wel to doe.

Seuenthly, it ſignifieth to geue and yelde the victorie,Cap. 32. as in Geneſis Nondimittam te niſi benedixeris mihi. that is. I will not let thee go excepte thou knowledge me to be thy ouercommer, and confeſſe thy ſelfe to be ouercomme. The Latin men do ſay: Herbam dare, manus porrigere, palmam proferre, and ſuche like phraſes, to ſignifie, to geue place.

Eyghtly, it betokeneth to praiſe, and to geue thanckes, as in the pſalmes. Benedic anima mea domino, that is. My ſoule praiſe the Lorde. And againe: Benedicite omnia opera domini domino. O all ye worckes of the Lorde, praiſe the Lorde. And in this ſignification ſaincte Peter vſeth in this place, Benedictus dominus deus.

Finally, benedicere doth ſignifie to curſe and blaſpheme. For blaſphemies were ſo odious to the fathers of the olde tyme, that they were afearde to name and terme thē with their owne proper word, and therfore did expreſse them oftentimes by a contrarie word, as Iob did vſe, ſaying. Ne benedixerint filii mei deo. Leaſt my children blaſpheme god.Cap. 1. Cap. 15.

Benedictio, is taken ſomtime in the holy ſcriptures for almes, as in Paule to the Romains, where he doth ſaye after this maner. Scio quod cum venero ad vos, in plenitudine benedictionis euangelii Chriſti venturus ſum. I knowe that when I ſhall come to you, I ſhall come in the plentifulnes of the goſpel of Chriſte, that is in the aboundaunte liberalitie of your almes, geuen to the maintenaunce and ſetting forth of Chriſts goſpel and his preachers.

Benedictio, ſometimes is vſed for ſweete, pleaſant and flattering ſpeach, through the whiche the mindes of the ſimple are ſeduced and brought from the way of truth, as in the Romains.Cap. 16. S. Paule doth exhort vs to note and take heed of them which deceiue the harts of the innocents through ſwete wordes and faire ſpeakyng. Chriſt in the goſpel of Matthew vſed this worde benedico, and alſo in the goſpel of Marke. Vvhich word the papiſtes both ignoraūtly and foliſhly haue abuſed. For they ſay
benedicere in that place betokeneth to bleſſe with the ſigne of the croſſe, and to make geſtures with the hande, croſsynge to and fro. But if they would conferre this worde 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 whiche Mathewe and Marke do vſe, with the worde that ſainct Luke doth vſe, they ſhould ſoone perceyue what benedicere meaneth. Saincte Luke dooth vſe this woorde 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , id eſt, gratias agens, whiche betokeneth to geue thancks, to ſinge praiſes to God, and to wiſhe well, and no other thing is meant by this worde 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 whiche Mathewe and Marke do vſe. Againe when he gaue the cuppe, he vſed this worde 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which is an interpretation and declaration, that it ſignifieth one thyng in both places.

Likewiſe ſainct Paule doth vſe this worde benedicere, in his firſt epiſtle to the Corinthians, his words be theſe. Poculum benedictionis cui benedicimus, nomine commemoratio ſanguinis Chriſti eſt? Many do vnderſtande by this worde benedictio, conſecratio: which if it be rightly vnderſtande, we do not repell nor put from the ſacrament, becauſe that thoſe ſignes and ſymboles whiche before were vulgar and commune to eate and drinke, are now tranſlated by the worde and inſtitution of Chriſt to a ſacramentall nature, that they might be holy ſignes of the body and bloud of Chriſt: which before, were not. Conſecration is not to be taken in that ſenſe as though it were a certaine magicall excantation whiche doth tranſubſtantiate and chaunge the natures of thinges. But benedictio is the decree of Chriſte, by the which thoſe ſymboles are appointed to a holy and myſticall vſe.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: VVhy then the meate and drinke whiche is ſet vpon our commune table to be receyued at dinners and ſuppers, are as good as the ſacramentall meate and drinke, for they alſo are ſanctified by prayers, the worde of God, and (as the common terme is) by ſayenge of grace, as it is written in the Epiſtle ſent to Timothie.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: The ſignification of both is not like. For in our common meales we deſire by the worde of God and prayer, that we maye lawfully vſe the creature of God, that if any part of the fyrſt malediction be lefte in it, which was inflicted vpon the earth, and the fruites therof may nothing hurt vs. But the ſacramentall ſymboles appointed by the worde and inſtitution of God, are made ſignes and miſteries of our ſaluation.

Chriſoſtome vnderſtandeth by benediction, thankes geuynge. Quoniam (inquit, quando calicem in manus accipimus, deo benedicimus, & illi gratias agimus. Becauſe (ſayth he) when we take the cuppe into
our handes, we praiſe God and rendre thankes vnto hym. And by this he iudgeth the argument of the Apoſtle to be more firme and ſure, as thoughe it were ſayde, you gaue thankes to God, that you are clenſed from ſinne, and deliuered from the deuell. How therfore now do you returne to communicat at the tables of deuels? To be ſhort, when in receyuing of the Lords ſupper, we do geue thankes and recorde what goodnes god hath geuen and promiſed vs by Chriſt, that is the true conſecration as they cal it, and not rehearſe certaine preſcribed wordes with exerciſing and bleſsing the ſacramentall ſignes.

To make an end of this worde benedicere, I will ſhew alſo how ſainct Paule doth vſe it in the Epiſtle to the Hebrues. His wordes be theſe.cap. 7. Nemo negat qui in id quod minus eſt, ab eo quod maius eſt benedictionem accipiat, that is: No man doth denie, but that which is leſſer, doth take benediction of that whiche is greater. In this place ſainct Paule ſpeaketh of Melchiſedech and Abraham, and ſheweth that Abraham as leſſer, tooke bleſsyng of Melchiſedech as the greater. VVe muſt not vnderſtande nor thincke, concernyng this benediction, that Melchiſedech being a holy and wiſe man did vſe croſsyng and bleſsing with ſaying of certaine wordes vpon the heade of Abraham, but ſome other matter far from that kind of bleſsing is meant by the Apoſtle. For this benediction was a ſolemne precation wherewith he that was indued with ſome publique and notable honour did commende priuate men vnto god. This benediction which Paul doth make mention, is the ſymbole of ſome great power. As Iſaacke bleſſed his ſonne Iacob. And as Iacob himſelf bleſſed his nephews Ephraim and Manaſses. This benediction was not mutual, that the ſonne likewiſe ſhould geue the ſame benediction to the father. But the authoritie of the greater is required to geue this benediction, which may well appere out of that place of the booke of Numeri, Cap. 6. where it is written, that afterwards it was commaunded to the prieſte to bleſse the people. A promiſe was added forthwith that they ſhould be bleſsed of god whom the prieſt bleſsed. And it is rather to be called and iudged the benediction of god, then of man. For as the prieſt doth ſupplie the roume of Chriſt in offring ſacrifices: So he was in bleſsinge the people no other thinge but the miniſter, meſsenger and delegate of the high God.Cap. 4. And that which Luke reherſed is to be taken in the ſame ſenſe, wher it is ſaid that Chriſt liftinge vp his handes did bleſse the Apoſtles. This maner of liftyng vp the handes was borrowed of the prieſtes of the olde lawe, that Chriſt might ſhewe himſelf to be the ſame perſon, by whome God the father doth bleſse vs.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p:
Vvhere you ſaye that the leſſer euer taketh bleſsinge of the greater,
it ſemeth not to be true.Cap. 1. For it is written in Luke how Simeon being a mere naturall man, did bleſſe Chriſt being God and man. Ergo the leſſer may geue bleſsyng to the greater.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: If thou wilt reſtraine this worde benedictio, onelye to Marie and Ioſeph, the matter is anſwered very ſoone. But Luke doth comprehende in his wordes Chriſt alſo. And in dede it maye be demaunded by what authoritie and lawe, Simeon did vſurpe to hymſelfe the office of geuynge bleſſyng to Chriſt. But it may again be probablie aunſwered that Simeon bring a priuate man & none of the common ſort, did bleſſe Chriſt, and not as one which was a publique perſonne▪ for he was no prieſt as diuerſe learned men do write, and as the veritie dooth alſo declare. Benedicere therefore in this place dooth ſignifie to praye for the happie and luckie ſucceſſe of the kyngdome of Chriſt, to wiſhe helth, good fortune, and glorie vnto Chriſt. Vvhere vpon it doth appeare howe ſhamefullie they be deceyued whiche doe imagine that the benediction of Simeon was ſuche a kynde of benediction, as the popiſh biſhoppes were wonte to geue, with ſhakinge of thre fingars ouer the peoples heades. But the benediction of Simeon is nothyng els, but to wiſhe and deſire good ſucceſſe vnto Chriſte in all his doinges.

div.head: Dominus. 2.
div.p: THE ſonne, the ſeconde perſonne is called Dominus, Lorde, for two cauſes. Firſt for the miſtery of oure redemption, for Chriſt is the Lord of all the elect, whome he chalenged and deliuered from the power and dominion of Sathan, ſinne, and death, and made them vnto him a proper and pecuculiar people.

Secondly, he is called Dominus, Lorde for his diuine power and nature, by the whiche all thinges are ſubiecte vnto the ſonne of God. Paule writyng to the Corinthians doth ſaye. Licet multi ſunt domini, nobis tamen vnus eſt dominus Ieſus Chriſtus, per quem omnia & nos per illum, that is: Although there be manye Lords, yet vnto vs there is but one Lord, the Lord Ieſus Chriſt, by whome al things are, and we are alſo by hym. It litle auayleth the Arrians to boaſt that Paule doth not cal Chriſt God, but lord, as though the diuinitie were to be attributed onelye to the father. But if Chriſte be onely the one Lorde (as ſainct Paule calleth hym) he ſhall alſo be God, vnles he will exclude the father from dominion and bearyng rule. For as Chriſte
is onely one Lord, and yet doth not depoſe the father, from bearyng rule with him, So the father is onelye one God, and doth not ſeparate the ſon from the diuine nature. And as Chriſoſtome hath noted, this diſtinction is not alwayes obſerued in the ſcriptures, for ſomtime the father is called Dominus Lord, as in the pſalme. Domine dominus noſter. pſal. 18. Ierem. ca. 23. et. 33, Rom. 9. Likewiſe the ſonne is called Deus, as in Ieremie, and in the Romains, and in many other places beſides.

Vnus Dominus, one Lord: by this phraſe ye fables of ye Iewes which bable and prate that there ſhoulde he two Meſsias, one of the tribe of Iuda, an other of the tribe of Ephraim, imaginynge that the one ſhalbe a baſe and abiecte perſone, and a man afflicted. The other to come with power and greate glory. But the chriſtian faythe dothe preach and affirme that there is but one, and the ſame Chriſt, and one onely perſone. Notwithſtanding there be two kyndes of his commynge. The firſte is, humble and lowly The laſt ſhalbe with maieſtie and glorie.

div.head: Idolum. 3.
div.p: TErtullian doth write that this worde Idolum is deduced 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , id eſt forma ſpecies. Vvherof commeth this diminutiue 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 as you woulde ſay a forme or ſhape to expreſſe God, that ſome honor and worſhippe might be geuen vnto it, whiche is called Idolatria. But when in very dede god can not be expreſſed by forme or image, but by the lyinge imagination of man, it muſt nedes be graunted whiche ſainct Paule writeth to the Corinthians: Idolum nihil eſt in mundo, An idole is nothing in the worlde.

Becauſe I haue made mention of this place, of Paule, I will examine the wordes and mynde of Paule throughlie, what he meant by theſe wordes, Idolum nihil eſt in mundo. Chriſoſtome writeth that Paul was wraped in a narrowe ſtraite on both the ſides, for of one ſide he woulde reſtraine the Corinthians that they ſhould not eate of the meates offred to idols. On the other ſide he ſemed to graunt that idolles had no diuine power, eyther to ſanctifie meates offred to them, or els to pollute them. Vvhiche ſeme two contraries. For if thoſe meates be forbidden to be eaten whiche are offred to idolles, it ſemeth that they ſhould take ſome vncleanes of the idols, whiche by theyr owne nature they haue not: therfore it was greate impietie for men, eyther to touche them, or to taſte them. Againe if nothynge came vnto them by reaſon they were offred, then was it indifferent, eyther to vſe them, or not to vſe them.

To this, aunſwere may thus be made. Amonge the Corinthians there
were two ſortes of men. The one were dull, ignoraunt and blunt. The other were of a quick, ſharpe, and pregnant witte. The duller ſorte thought that ther was ſome thinge in the Idols which had in it ſom excellēt or diuine power. The wiſer ſort thought and reaſoned that Idols were nothing els but ſtones and wood, hauinge nothynge in them either to make good or bad, meates offred vnto them, and therfore tooke them as Adiaphora, things indifferent. Now Paul is compaſſed about with theſe two kyndes of men.

Firſt he graunted that which they affirmed, which was that an idol is nothing in the worlde. Vvhiche is not to be taken or vnderſtande as touchinge the matter. For no man doubteth but that ſtones, woode, Iuerye, ſiluer, gold and braſſe be ſomwhat in the worlde. But the wordes of Paule muſt be vnderſtand concernyng the artificiall imagination. And then idols are to be ſet among thoſe thinges which do ſignifie. And the nature of thoſe things which are conferred together is ſuch, that if you take awaye one, you muſt take awaye the other alſo. As when the ſonne doth ceaſe, then the father alſo ceaſeth to be a father. And theſe be relatiua. And that an idole perteineth to the nature of relatiues: Tertullian declareth in his booke De Idolatria.

Theſe wordes In mundo, in the world, are well added. For in the mindes and toughtes of fooliſh men an idole may be ſomwhat: But in the nomber of true and ſubſtantiall thinges which were created of God, an idole is nothyng. Vvhen heretiques profeſſe and worſhippe God, not as he is himſelf, but as it pleaſeth their phantaſie, then they make an idole to them ſelues. And as the other materiall idols be groſſe and externe: ſo theſe idols of the minde be ſpirituall and interne.

Origine maketh a difference betwene Idolum & ſimilitudinem. His wordes be theſe.In. 20. Exodi hom. 8. Aliud eſt ergo facere idolum, aliud ſimilitudinem. Et ſi quidem dominus nos ad ea quae dicenda ſunt illuminare dignetur, ego ſic arbitror accipiendum quod (verbi cauſa) ſi quis in quolibet metallo, auri, vel argenti, vel ligni, vel lapidis ſaciat ſpeciem quadrupedis alicuius, vel ſerpentis, vel auis, & ſtatuat illam adorandam, non idolum, ſed ſimilitudinem fecit: vel etiam ſi picturam ad hoc ipſum ſtatuat nihilominus ſimilitudinem feciſſe dicendus eſt. Idolum vero facit ille qui ſecundum apoſtolum dicentem, quia idolum nihil eſt, facit quod non eſt. Quid eſt autem quod non eſt? Species quam non vidit oculus, ſed ipſe ſibi animus fingit, &c. that is. It is one thing to make an idol and an other thinge to make a ſimilitude. As for example: if any do make the forme and ſhape of a fourefooted beaſt, or of a ſerpente, or of a birde in the metall of golde or ſiluer, or wood or ſtone, and doth ſet it vp to be worſhipped, he doth not make an idol, but a ſimilitude. Or els if he ſet vp a picture for the ſame purpoſe, he maketh alſo a ſimilitude.

He maketh an idole whiche maketh that whiche is not according to the Apoſtles ſaying, An Idole is nothing. VVhat is that whiche is not? ſome forme and ſhape whiche the eye neuer ſawe, but the mynde doth faine and imagine it. For example: if any will ſhape to the partes of man a Dogge or a Rammes head, or would fayne in one mans body to be two faces, or would put the hinder part of an horſe or of a fiſh to the vpper parte of mans body: He I ſay that imagineth and maketh theſe or ſuche lyke thynges, he maketh not a ſimilitude, but an idole. For he maketh that which is not, nor is like to it ſelfe in any part. And therfore the Apoſtle knowing theſe things, doth ſay: Idolum nihil eſt in mundo. For there is no ſhape taken or made of things that be extant. But there is onely that whiche an idle and curious minde hath inuented. That the true God cannot nor ought to be expreſsed or faſhioned with ſhapes and ſimilitudes, it is euidently commaunded and declared in Deuteronomio, and for that cauſe there was no image of no ſexe or any other thing ſene in the mount Horeb.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: The Arcke of couenaunt and the Cherubin were in the old Teſtamēt, not onely ſuffred, but alſo commaunded.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: The Arcke was no image nor ſhape wherby God might be repreſēted, but it was rather a place in the which God promiſed him ſelfe to be preſent to heare the prayers of the people, and to geue them aunſwers, when he was conſulted. Neither did men imagine or make by their owne will and phantaſie either the Arcke or Cherubin, but God commaunded them to be made.

VVho was the firſt inuentor of images the writers do not agree Saint Hierome in the Epiſtle in the whiche he maketh his preface, in the Epiſtle ſent to Tite doth ſay, that Cretēſes ſowed the firſt ſedes of Idolatrie, in the which he ſemeth to allude to the fable of Iupiter.

I ſhall thincke it no labour ill beſtowed to ſpeake ſomewhat, for what cauſe Idolatrie was brought in Saint Paul doth ſhew it to the Romains, ſaying: VVhen they knewe God, they did not glorifie God nor tender thanckes vnto him, but were fooliſhe in their owne reaſons and imaginations, for they worſhipped not one God, whoſe inuiſible maieſtie they might know by the viſible creatures of God, but did faine and frame vnto him many thinges by their owne counſels and inuentions.

div.head: Queſtio.
div.p: How can this be true that an idole is nothing in the world, whē we read in Hiſtories that images hath both ſhewed things to come, and alſo hath wrought merueilous wonders in afflicting with extreme paines their contemners, and in doing much good to thoſe whiche worſhipped them?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p:
Concerning the images them ſelues, they be nothing but woode, ſtone or mettall, and can neither ſhew things to come, nor yet of them ſelues can do neither good nor ill, which the Prophet Eſay doth teſtifie, ſaying. Nū ciate quae ventura ſunt, Cap. 41. & dicemus vos deos eſſe. Shew what things are to come, and we will ſay ye are gods, alſo do either good or il, if you can. Alſo he ſcorneth and mocketh the artificer,Cap. 45. that he maketh an idole or image of one part of the blocke, & of the other part maketh a fire wherwith he may ſeath his meate and warme him ſelfe. Therfore when any wonders are done of Idoles, they are to be aſcribed vnto deuils, which do lurcke & lye in the images, and be preſent in them, Vt
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and they draw vnto them ſelues thoſe honours and Sacrifices whiche are offred. And there is no doubt but that deuils in ſome naturall things may diuine and foreſhew ſome things, although not all: notwithſtanding they cannot certainely & infallibly tell things to come, for God is able to alter thē at his pleaſure.

Ezechias, as much as concerneth natural cauſes, ought to haue died, when the Prophet Iſaias did ſhew vnto him preſent death: yet the end of his life was prolōged by the will of God. Therf • re the deuils to kepe their eſtimation▪ do geue perplexe and doubtfull aunſwers, leaſt the euente of thoſe thinges whiche they ſhew, might confute and confound them. As this olde verſe doth teſtifie.

p.hi: Aio te Aeacida Romanos vincere poſſe.

div.p:
VVhich was a doubtfull aūſwere, whether the Romaines ſhould ouer come Aeacida, or he the Romaines. The like is recorded in Herodotus of Craeſus, & ſomtime in dede they ſhew truly things to com, but for ye moſt part they lye and deceiue. Sometime alſo they puniſh moſt greuouſly certain perſons, as Liuius writeth of Titus Lauinus. S. Auſten in his booke De ciuitate Dei, ſaith that it is no maruell that men which be ſtraūge and farre from Chriſt, be oftentimes tormented of the deuil, for that they be through ſinne his boundſlaues. As the children of God are ledde with the ſpirite of God, ſo the wicked and malignant ſpirites haue great power ouer the children of incredulitie and vnbelief, as the Epiſtle to the Epheſiās doth witnes. The deuils haue power to afflicte them whom God hath made ſubiect for their ſinnes vnto his tiranny, but if any goodnes or benefit be collated to Idolators, it commeth without queſtion from God, who is the authour of all good thinges. Some perchaunce will greatly maruell why God will an Idolatour to proſper any way. To which it may be aunſwered, that it is not for their falſe religion, but that God will declare his goodnes and pacience, as he ſuffreth dayly the ſunne to riſe vpon the iuſt and vniuſt: wherby we be taught to be frendly and well doyng to them
which be not our frendes.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: By this meanes God ſemeth to geue an occaſion of error and idolatry.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: God doth tēpt and proue vs, as it is in Deuteronomie, whether we will geue eare and credit vnto a falſe Prophet when we ſee him to haue good ſucceſse in things, and whē he in deceiuing the people in perſwading falſe worſhipping of god, doth ſhew things to come & worke wōders & ſignes
To end Nihil eſt Idolum in mundo, this is ſpoken by the figure Metonimia, becauſe the thing which is ſignified is not extant.

Idolum, is called in the Hebrue toung Alil, which ſome will haue to ſignifie a thing vayne and vnprofitable, other will haue it to ſignifie fooliſhnes. And ſome of the Rabines do ſay that it is cōpounded of, Al, which in Hebrue ſignifieth, Non, and of, El, whiche ſignifieth Deus, quaſi non deus, not God, but a thing hauing the ſhadow of God, & yet hath in it no power to helpe or to do any thing. You may call it in ye Latin toūg, Inops, poore, nedie, lacking helpe, and not able to helpe. Of Idolatria, is more ſpoken before.

div.head: Mahometus. 4.
div.p: MAhomete had to his father one Abdalla, by ſtocke and aunceſtry a Perſian or Arabian borne, & had to his mother Emma a Iewe and was borne in Ieſrab, on a monday beyng the twelf day of the month Rabe, about the year of our Lord. 597. or 621 his father died a litle before his birth.

His genealogie is reuolued with monſtrous and blaſphemous fables vnto the time of Seth and Adam.Libro de gen. Mahometi et in Chron. Sarac. He was borne without any dolour or payne felte by his mother. And when he was circumciſed, he was mery & laughing. But whither this is to be beleued, iudge you. At the very houre and time of his death the idoles fell downe by them ſelues. And Lucifer was taken of Angels and drowned in the depe ſea Alcazum, from whēce after forty dayes, being eſcaped, calling together a coūcel of deuils, he cō plained of the deſtruction of his kingdome, beſide many other friuolous, fabulous, and lying vayne wonders, which are fained to haue happened about the time of his birth.

div.head: Mahumetes education.
div.p:
Of his nurſing and education, there are alſo many fables, trifles and blaſphemies rehearſed, As how the windes, birdes and cloudes did ſtriue for his education, and that god committed him to Halima, to be brought vp. And how that an Aſse enclining her ſelfe downe ſayd of Mahomete. Hic eſt ſigillum Prophetarum▪ this is the ſeale of the Prophets. Alſo, how three men drew out his bowels, and clenſed the deuils portion out of his
hart. And that a Southſayer would haue killed him as an enemye and deſtroyer of Idoles:Cap. 1. but he eſcaped out of his nurſes hand, and was found by chaunce vnder a tree by the riuer Tuhene.
Being a boy of eight yeares old, he was brought vp of his graund father Abdaal Mutalib.
The writers ſay, that in his youth he kept the Camels of a riche marchaunt of Arabia, & alwayes when it was faire, hoat, & cleare weather, a blacke cloude was ſeen ouer his head.
In Alcorano Azoara. 17.Mahomet could neither read nor write, as he him ſelf teſtifieth, being vtterly vnſkilfull and vnlearned in his youth.

He had a great iolte head, a face mixed with white and read, a longe beard,Simoneta. lib 4. cap. 36. and he was ſwift and of very nimble feete. He had a quicke, ſuttle, and crafty wit, and learned all maner of ſectes.
Sergius the Neſtorian heretike comming to Mecha, inſtructed hym worſhipping Idols with his errour,Vincentius lib. 23. cap. 51 and deliuered vnto him certaine rules out of the old and new Teſtament.
He maried one Eadiga a riche widow, whom he allured to loue him by arte Magicke.

Paulus diaconus lib. 18. rerum Romanorum. Azoara. 58.VVhen Mahomet was ſicke of the falling ſicknes, he perſwaded his wife to beleue that he had communication with ye Archangell Gabriel, & that when he ſaw him, the force and ſtrength of his body failed him. He called him ſelfe that graine, whiche is ſayde in the Goſpell to beare plentifull fruite.

div.head: Mahometes functions.
div.p: Firſt he was a keper of Camels, afterwardes when he had maryed a riche widow, he became a marchaunt, and at the length a Prophet, and by the helpe and meanes of Sergius the Moncke, he was a ſectarie. He fayned that he receyued the lawe of God of Gabriell the Archangell in the forty yeare of his age.

At the laſt, (whē he was made a captaine in the warres) within xviij. moneth after he fained him ſelfe to haue lerned his miſteries in Ieruſalē, being tranſlated frō thence and taken vp into heauen, of Gabriel the Archangell, and after he had diſcended from heauē, tooke to his felowes Eubogaram, Ali and Zaid. And when he came to Athaif, he openly taught that he was a Prophet, and this he did by the ſpace of ten yeares running vp and down from place to place. And at length hauing gotten a bande of men, he compelled by menacinges thoſe men to conſent vnto hym whiche he could not by phantaſticall and ſuttle reaſons bring to the forme of religion and lawes that he had preſcribed.
He had two heauenly counſailours, Michaell and Gabriel, and two earthly counſailours Eubocara and Aomarus.
In the proclayming of his lawes a doue made by arte did flie vnto him, and •• tting vpon his ſhoulders did gather corne out of his care.
VVherby certain mad men fooliſhly thought that the holy ghoſt gaue lawes vnto him.
Doubtfull matters were referred to his determination.
He was ſēt to be a puniſher of ye Gentils, yt they might worſhip one God.Azoara. 9. Ibidem. 38.56

Some things he commaunded to be done, and ſome things to be vndone. He ordained ſome meates that were good and ſauorie to be lawfull to be eaten, and other ſome to be vnlawfull. He doth explane Alcoran, and extolleth it aboue all other lawes. He expoundeth the contrarieties therin, and maketh plaine the right way
He ſayd alſo he was enioyned to worſhip onely the Lord of the Citie Haram, and to beleue in him which ruled all things, and to read Alcoran plainly, and by it to geue correction.
He affirmed alſo him ſelf to be an arbitrer and iudge of diſsention in religion, and did arrogate vnto himſelfe the authoritie to diſpenſe and to diſsolue wedlocke.

Furthermore,Vincentius Lib. 23. he declared that he did folow the law of Abraham by the commaundement of God, and ſayd that he was a Prophet ſent of God to geue ſaluation, & that he might temper and mitigate lawes which was to rigorous and ſeuere for the Iewes and Chriſtians, by geuing forth more gentle and eaſie preceptes.
In the kingdome of the Sarazens he did conſtitute foure chief rulers whiche were called Ammirei,Sigibertus et Paulus diaconus. lib. 18. and he hym ſelfe was called Ammiras or Proto Simbolus.
His warres are deſcribed in the Chronicles of the Sarazens.

div.head: Mahometes workes whiche he wrote.
div.p: Mahomete beyng a ſuttle and crafty man, that he might alienate and turne the weaklinges from the Chriſtian faith, folowing certaine heretikes in compoſing and making lawes,Simoneta lib. 4. cap. 34. and taking many thinges out of the ſacred Bible, made the booke called Alcoran.

Biblander doth ſay, that in making the booke Alcoran,In apologia. he vſed the helpe and labour of two runnagate heretikes, Sergius and Iohn of Antioch, & of two Iewes that wer Apoſtataes. And that he might get more authoritie vnto his booke Alcoran, he fained it to be geuen and ſent him from heauen: for he ſwore that he beyng taken vp into heauen, learned his myſteries there.

It is written that he would haue nor do nothyng of his owne will, but onely that whiche was commaunded of God: and beyng taken vp into the higheſt of the orizon, came vnto God him ſelfe, which taught and inſtructed hym effectually, but yet he beyng two arrowes ſhot diſtant frō God.

div.head: Mahometes doctrine.
div.p: Mahomets opiniōs are a confuſed Chaos, gathered out of the vayn doctrines of Ethnicks, heretikes and Iewes.

Petrus Cluniacenſis. Vincentiꝰ. 23. In Colloquio cum Iudeis.Firſt, he denieth the Trinitie with Sabellicus, & taketh away the diuinitie of Chriſt with Neſtorius, with the Manichies he doth deny ye death of Chriſt, albeit he denieth not his goyng agayne into heauen.
He named him ſelfe Meſsias, whom the Iewes looke for to come, yet at this day.

He maketh Gabriell one appearing in the ſhape of man, ſtanding vpright, neuer ſlepyng, nor eating, neither drincking, to be a teacher & reueler of his monſtruous doctrines. He left to euery ſecte power frely to folow their owne doctrine, and ſaid vnto the vnfaithfull: I truly will not folowe your law, neither you my law, therfore let your lawes remayne to you, and my lawes to me.

He affirmeth alſo, that his people could not obtayne the gouernement of a princely rule, vnles they departed from the Chriſtian faith, and kept their owne ordinaunces and lawes. God forbiddeth him to call him ſelfe any other thing then a man, and that he ſhould teſtifie, that there is but one God. He promiſeth remiſsion of ſinnes, and good things to them that folow him, and curſeth all them whiche do diſsent from him, and menaceth vnto them the paynes of hell fire.

The ſtorie of the booke of Numbers contayned in the 13. and 14. chapters he doth peruerſly reply againſt and repell. He counteth the hiſtorie of Abel, the hiſtory of Noe, and the hiſtorie of Ioſeph to be but fables. He iudgeth likewiſe the like of Moſes. He ſaid, that he ſuffred afflictions for the truthes ſake, and for inuocating vpon the onely one God.

div.head: Mahometes Prophecies.
div.p: Mahomete prophecied that twelue of the nation of Choraſc ſhould beare rule after him, and that after them there ſhoulde riſe diſſention, and that the dignitie and obſeruation of his law ſhould endure ſo lōg as twētie of Choraſc ſhould remaine aliue, and that his ſucceſſours ſhould wear vile and baſe apparell vntill thirtie yeares were expired, and afterward they ſhould wear ſumptuous and gorgious apparell.
He prophecied alſo that Alcoran ſhould periſh and be deſtroyed after a thouſand yeares were expired.

div.head: Mahometes ſtrifes and conflictes.
div.p: Mahomete impugned the Cbriſtian religion firſt with his falſe doctrine, for he vtterly denied Ieſus Chriſt to be the ſonne of God, and condemned them that beleued in him.

Secondly, by falſe cauillations and ſlaunders, for he fayneth the vnfaithfull (whom he thought to be the Chriſtians) to affirme that the Angels
whiche be about God are women, and to worſhip the virgine Marie for a goddeſſe.
Thirdly, he did contend againſt his own profeſsion, for that he was conſtitute of God to be a teacher, and not a violent enforcer, as he ſayth hymſelfe.
Furthermore, he vſed manifeſt violence, fayning himſelfe to do it by the commaundement of God.

Finally, he did ſtriue againſt his own country men the Arabians, for ſome of them ſayd vnto him: Bring vs an other Alcoran, or els doo thou alter & chaunge this. Vnto whom he anſwered, that he would not. Some of them called him a diueliſh man, and an enchaunter, whom he doth confute by threatning of the paynes of hel fire. He publiſhed an edict in the which he did forbid vnder payne of death that no man ſhould diſpute, doubt or contend of his lawes, and alſo commaunded all mē to be contented with the authoritie of the dictatour.
He contended alſo agaynſt the Gentiles and their idoles, and agaynſt them that denied the reſurrection of the dead.

div.head: Mahometes vyces and wickednes.
div.p: Like as Mahomet was an inſtrument of the deuill, ſo alſo he bare the deuills markes, that is, notes of lying, murther and filthines. He dyd not ſweare by ye name of the true God, but by the windes, cloudes, Prophets & Angells, by the euening ſtar, & by the Mount Sinai, & by the going downe of the ſunne.

Vincentius deſcribed at length his theftes and crueltie. He was geuē ſo much to filthy luſte, that he ſayd it was geuen him of God to do more in carnall copulation, then fortie men, which is a foule thing to be ſpoken. He had fortie wiues▪ He fained alſo that God gaue him a ſingular power and licence to exerciſe his fleſhly luſtes.
The Iewes at the firſt ranne vnto him by heapes, ſuppoſing him to be Meſſias, but when they ſaw him eat of Camels fleſh, they knew yt he was not Meſſias.

div.head: Mahometes death.
div.p:
At the length by the iuſte puniſhment of God he fell into a pleuriſie, or ells into the falling ſickenes as ſome write, wherof he was wont oftentimes to be ſicke, and in his ſicknes he loſte his wittes, his bellie ſwelled,In Chronog. and his little finger was bowed backward, and died fourtene daies after hee was ſicke, when hee was. 63. yeares olde, or fourtye, as Valentinus,
and Munſterus noteth, and in the yeare of our Lorde. 632. as Sigibertus writeth, and after hee had raigned ouer the Sarazens tenne yeares. He commaunded that no man ſhould bury him, bicauſe he ſaid he ſhould be taken vp into heauen the third day. Vvhich whē they that looked for, ſaw came not to paſſe, his friendes caſt him out naked, but ſome do write that he was buried in his clothes. His carkaſſe is put in an yron coffin, and kept in the towne Mecha, where it is woorſhipped of all the Eaſt part.

div.head: Other teſtimonies of Mahomet.
div.p: Mahomet him ſelfe writeth, that many men iudged and reported of him ſaying thus: Do ye not folow that diueliſhe and mad man, who vſeth inchauntments. He did eate as other men doth, and went abroad, wherfore he hath not an Angell to his keeper, which geteth hym treaſures, or maketh hym gardeins, the fruite and hearbes wherof he might eate.
Agayne it is ſayd of him: This man is an enchaunter and a lyar, making and bringing vp all lyes of him ſelfe, and purpoſeth ſo to diſſwade vs from the ſect of our Elders.

And in an other place Mahomet ſayth thus: The vnfaithfull hearing our preceptes, doo ſay that they are arte Magicke, and that I fayned thē. But he, that he might deceiue the vnware men, fayned that Chriſt prophecied that Mahomet ſhould come, and bryng a moſt excellent law.
Rabalachbar learned in the ſcriptures, ſayd that Mahomet ſhould be borne, and alſo he approued all the hiſtory of hym, by the aſtrological teſtimony.
This ſhalbe ſufficient for the birth, life, and death of Mahomet. Now a woord or two of his ryddles and hard ſayinges, which properly may be called Enigmata.

div.head: Queſtio. 1.
div.p: WHat ſonne is ſtronger then the father? Iron. Vvhat is ſtronger then Iron? Fire. Vvhat is ſtronger then fire? Vvater. Vvhat is ſtronger than water? Vvinde.

div.head: Queſtio. 2.
div.p: VVhat earth is that, which the ſunne once ſaw, and neuer ſhall ſee agayne, vnto the worldes end?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Vvhen Moſes deuided the red ſea, the bottome of the ſea was made bare, which the ſunne then ſaw, but after the water was cloſed agayne together, the ſunne neuer ſaw it, nor ſhall ſee it agayne.

div.head: Queſtio. 3.
div.p: Vvhat houſe is that, which hauing twelue gates, by the which twelue portions went out with twelue generations?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: That rocke which Moſes ſmote with his rod, and opened twelue fountaines to the twelue tribes of Iſraell.

div.head: Queſtio. 4.
div.p: To what piece of the earth ſpake God?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: God commaunded the mount Sinay to lift Moſes vp to heauen.

div.head: Queſtio. 5.
div.p: VVhat was the firſte woode without life, and afterwarde hauyng ſpirite and lyfe.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Moſes rodde, whiche was now a rodde, and now a Serpent.

div.head: Queſtio. 6.
div.p: VVhat woman came onely of a man and father without a woman or mother. And what man was borne onely of a woman and mother without father?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Firſt, Eue was made of Adam without the companie of a woman, and Chriſt was borne of the virgine Marie, without the companie of a man.

div.head: Quaeſtio. 7.
div.p: VVhat earthly thinges be theſe whiche were made and brought forth without the coniunxtion of any male.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Adam, Abrahams Ramme that was in the buſhe behinde him, and Chriſt.

div.head: Queſtio. 8.
div.p: VVhat graue was moued with him that was buried in it?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: The whale with the prophet Ionas in his belly.

div.head: Queſtio. 9.
div.p: Vvhat were thoſe two whoſe graues are vnknowen?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Abitabil and Moſes. For Abitabill when he felt death comming, cō maunded that after his death, a Camel bearing his body, ſhould be driuen to go thither, whither ſoeuer fortune would leade him, and that they ſhould folow the Camel, vntil he lay downe of his own will. And in the place wher the Camel lay downe, ther was found a monument or graue, which Noe had prepared to Abitabil. And when he was buried there, that place was vtterly loſt, and could neuer be found againe.

Moſes when he wandred in the wildernes, found by chaunce a graue open and voyde, meete for his quantitie, both for breadth and lengthe. Vvhereat hee marueilynge, the Aungell of death came to kyll hym.
VVhom when Moſes knew, he aſked him, ſaying: VVherfore cameſt thou? the Aungell aunſwered, I am ſent for thy ſoule. Vnto whome Moſes ſayde: By what meanes canſte thou take it awaye? for thou canſte not take it out of my mouth, with whiche mouth I haue ſpoken to the Lord, nor out of my eares, wherwith I haue heard the Lorde, neyther throughe my eyes, wherewith I haue ſeen the face of the Lorde, neyther out of my handes, wherewith I haue receyued the gifte of God. Nor by my feete, becauſe I wente vp to the mounte Sinai. The Aungell hearyng this, departed, and chaunging his ſhape brought out of Paradiſe a certayne fruite: whiche when the Aungell offred to Moſes, Moſes receyued it, and put to his noſe, and then the Aungel tooke hym by the noſtrels, and ſo wroung out his ſoule: whiche beyng done, his body remayning in the ſepulchre, was neuer found after.

div.head: Quaeſtio. 10.
div.p: VVhat fire doth eate and drincke, and after it is quenched, it is neuer kindled agayne vnto the day of iudgement?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: The fire in mans body is ſuſtayned by meate, drincke and lyfe. And when the ſoule departeth from it, it is extinguiſhed, and ſhal not be kindled agayne before the ſoule returne to it.

div.head: Queſtio. 11.
div.p: VVhat is euer litle, and what is euer great?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Litle ſtones, and great • illes.

div.head: Queſtio. 12.
div.p: VVhat humour and moiſtnes is that whiche commeth neyther from heauen nor from earth.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: The ſweate of man and beaſtes when they labour.

div.head: Queſtio. 13.
div.p: How was the firſt ſhip made?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Noe began the firſte ſhippe, and Gabriell gaue the keyes, and Noe with his children entred in, and he commyng from Arabia, wente aboute ſeuen tymes the Citie Mecha, and ſaylyng from thence, came to Hieruſalem, and compaſsed that lykewyſe ſeuen tymes aboute, and ſo came into a mountaine of Iudaea, and there the waters beyng decreaſed, the ſhippe ſtayed.

div.head: Queſtio. 14.
div.p: How canſt thou meaſure all the world?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p:
VVith one naturall dayes iourney, for the ſunne goeth in one day
through the whole world from the Eaſt to the weaſt, and from the weaſt to the Eaſt.
Theſe were the queſtions and aunſwers whiche Mahomete had with the Iewes.

div.head: Purgatorie. 6.
div.p: THere is fained to be a certayne middle place after this lyfe betwene hell and heauen, whiche they call Purgatorie. In the whiche place they that be there are counted to participate ſomewhat of both the extremes, for in that reſpecte that they are ſo confirmed with hope, that felicitie at length ſhalbe geuen vnto them: they ſuffer quietly the paynes that be inflicted vpon them, and ſo are counted in the nomber of the Sainctes: but in that reſpecte that they are puniſhed and tormented with greuous paynes, they haue their lot in hell.
It is ſayd alſo that the paynes of Purgatorie ſhall not onely haue a certaine end, but that they may be alſo eaſed, relieued and redemed, with the worckes and ſuffragies of the lyuing.
Our aduerſaries do perſwade with many reaſons and authorities that there is ſuch a place. VVhiche reaſons and authorities I will alledge and bring in, and make aunſwere to the ſame orderly.

div.head: The firſte reaſon and proofe.
div.p: They doo alledge out of the olde Teſtamente the hiſtorie of the Machabees: where it is read that Iudas beleued it to be a holeſome and an holy thynge, to praye for the dead, that they myght be looſed from theyr ſinnes.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: This place cannot oppugne the veritie, becauſe theſe bookes be not in the Canon. Yet they ſay, although the Hebrues do not accept them as Canonicall, yet our Churche hath receyued them: we graunt that your Churche hath receyued them, but (as S. Cyprian doth teſtifie) that they may be read in the Churche,In expoſitione ſymboli. but not that our fayth or any article therof may be confirmed therby. In the whiche place Saint Ciprian doth rehearſe all the bookes Canonicall, and addeth theſe words. Hi ſunt ex quibus patres voluerunt dogmata noſtrae fidei conſiſtere: theſe be the books, out of the whiche our fathers woulde haue the doctrines of our fayth to conſiſte.
And Saint Hierome, when he alledgeth the bookes of the Machabees, is wont to adde, Si quis velit credere & recipere. If any man will beleue and receiue them.

Sainte Auguſtine alſo ſayth: Receptos, ſed non vt pares, Contra. ſecū dam epiſtolā gaude. legi Proph • tis & Pſalmis. I haue read them beyng receyued, but not equall to
the Prophetes and Pſalmes. VVhiche bookes, notwithſtandyng, he ſayth are not vnprofitable, ſo that they be ſoberly read and heard, that is, that we do iudge and diſcerne in what pointes they do agre with the Canonicall Scriptures, and in what pointes they do not agre.
Euſeb.Melito alſo Biſhop of Sardinia doth not rehearce the bookes of Machabees to be in the nomber of the Canonicall Scriptures.
Epiphanius alſo leaueth them out.

To this purpoſe maketh alſo the hiſtorie of one Razias in the ſame booke, who killed him ſelf, that he myght not fall into his enemies handes. In whiche booke both the man and his facte is commended and prayſed. VVhiche example the heretikes called Circumcelliones (who were in Saint Auguſtines tyme) did wickedly abuſe in laying violent handes on them ſelues. VVherupon Saint Auguſtine laboured much agaynſt the Donatiſtes to defende that booke: but howe much he preuailed, let other men iudge.

To conclude, it is written at the end of theſe bookes: Si recte ſcripſi, eſt quod volui, ſin exiliter & tenuiter, eſt quod potui. If I haue wel written, it is that I woulde, but if I haue written ſlenderlye and ſleightlye, it is that I could. VVhiche wordes do not ſeme to be ſpoken by the inſtinct of the holy ghoſt, as the authour of the ſayd bookes.

div.head: The .2 reaſon and proofe.
div.p: Cap. 9.They alledge Zacharie the Prophet wher it is written: Emiſi vinctos tuos elacu. I haue looſed thy priſoners out of the pit wherin is no water.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Saint Hierome by this lake, in the whiche was no water, playnely vnderſtandeth hell, where is no mercy, whiche when it was prepared for vs, we were redemed and deliuered from it by the merite of the bloud of Chriſt. This place is alſo expoūded of many, of the receptacle of the ſoules of the fathers before Chriſt aſcended into heauen, from whēce they were deliuered and caried vp into heauen, by the benefite and merite of Chriſt. But Saint Hierome affirmeth that the riche glutton was tormented in the ſame lake. VVherby it appeareth, that their iudgementes and expoſitions of Purgatorie are wauering, and not firme.

div.head: The .3. reaſon and proofe.
div.p: They proue Purgatorie by this ſaying of Eccleſiaſtes: De carcere atque catenis interdum quis progredietur ad regnum? Out of the priſō, who will come forth to raigne?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: This ſaying of Eccleſiaſtes maketh nothing to their purpoſe, for aſmuch as it is intreated there onely of the chaungeable courſe of things.

Gregory biſhop of Pontus, otherwiſe called Laodicenus, (as ſainct Hierome writeth) ſaith: Vt rex ſtultus at
que ſenex è regno facile poteſt derici, ſic viciſsim iuuenis, quamuis pauper, modo ſit ſapiens, ex humili loco ad regnum prouehi poteſt. Like as a kyng that is fooliſh and olde may be eaſilye depoſed from his kyngdom, ſo on the other ſide a younge man, though he be poor, ſo that he be wiſe, may be promoted out of a baſe and low place, vnto a kyngdome.

Origen and Victorinus do applie this place to an allegorie, in expounding the old Kyng to be caſt down, to ſignifie the deuel, which is called prince of the world, and by the yong man they vnderſtood Chriſt: which when he came freſhly vnto the father, he receiued all power, when before he was vexed in the worlde as in a priſon.

div.head: The .4. reaſon and proofe.
div.p:
It is written in the pſalme of Dauid: tranſiuimus per ignem & aquā, noſ
que in refrigerium eduxiſti. Vve went into fire and into water, but thou broughteſt vs out into a welthie place.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Sainct Auguſtin expoundeth this verſe of the tentatiōs of this world: So that aduerſities are ſignified by fire, and proſperities are ſignified by water. Vnder the which tentations when the godly do not lie and are ouercome, they are brought to the refreſhments of heauen.

div.head: The .5. reaſon.
div.p: In the new Teſtament there is mentioned one kinde of ſinne, which is not forgeuen neyther in this world, nor in the world to come. Therfore ther remaineth ſome ſinnes to be clenſed and purged in an other lyfe.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: This place doth not inferre nor vrge, that there be ſome ſinnes which are remitted and purged in an other life.

Among the Logicians two negatiue propoſitions doo not conclude an affirmatiue. Vvherfore not to be forgeuen in this world, and not to be forgeuen in an other worlde, doth not affirme the pardonyng of ſinnes after this lyfe. Chriſte therefore ſpake theſe woordes by an exaggeration, wherby the greuouſnes of this ſinne might be made more open and knowen. Alſo ſainct Marke doo write the ſelfe ſame thing, ſayeng ſimplie, it ſhall neuer be forgeuen, and maketh no mention neyther of this world, nor of any other, but doth expounde Mathewes meaning.

div.head: The .6. reaſon.
div.p: They obiect out of Mathew this ſayeng: leaſt the iaylour caſt them into priſon. Verely I ſay vnto thee: thou ſhalte not come forth, vntil thou haſte payde the vttermoſt farthing.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p:
Saint Auguſtin plainely vnderſtandeth hel, and he wil haue the word
donec, to be taken in the ſame ſignification in which it is ſaid: he knewe her not vntil ſhe had brought forth her firſt begotten ſonne.

Sainct Hierome expounded this place of concorde to be obſerued and kept among the fatthfull, ſo long as they are aliue, which he proueth by the ſayings that go before, and by the ſayings that do folow
Before it was ſayd. If thou offer thy gifte at the Alter, and ther doſt remember that thy brother hath ought againſt thee, leaue thy gift there &c. And now it followeth loue your ennemies.

He maketh mention alſo of an allegoricall interpretation, by the which ſom do vnderſtande by the aduerſarie, the ſpirite it ſelfe: whiche expoſition ſemeth to be very abſurde, that the holy ſpirite ſhould deliuer vs to the iudge. He omitteth not alſo to rehearſe, that ſome do vnderſtande by the aduerſarie the deuell, as you may r • ade in Ambroſe.

Tertullian alſo rehearſeth the ſame in his booke de anima, although he affirme the ſame place to be vnderſtande more ſimplie of concorde & agrement. Therfore when no certaintie can be gathered of ſuche allegories, this reaſon and proofe is very infirme and weake.

div.head: The .7. reaſon and proofe.
div.p: The riche man mentioned in Luke ſemeth to proue a purgatorie, for that he deſired Lazarus to be ſente to his brethren, to warne them that they ſhould not come there, which ſemeth to haue come of charitie, but in hell, there is no caritie. Ergo he was not in hell, but in purgatorie.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: This place of Luke is counted of many to be a parable. Of which iudgement Chriſoſtome is. And a parable proueth nothing. But let it be a true hiſtorie, howe will they by that defende him to be in purgatorie, foraſmuch as betwen the boſome of Abraham, and the place of puniſhement there was ſayd to be a great Chaos? So that from thence none could come vnto Abraham. And it is merueill that the rich man, beinge ſo greatly tormented, did not require anniuerſaries and ſuffrages of the lyuing. And when Abraham did affirme that the could receiue no helpe neither of him nor of Lazarus, what boldenes hath the prieſt to ſaye that he by his maſſe and prayers can releaſe the ſoules of the dead from the paines of purgatorie. The wiſe virgins did not communicate their oile vnto the fooliſhe virgines. Likewiſe Lazarus could not profit the riche glutton.

It were much better to expounde and weigh the wordes of Abraham, when he ſaid and made anſwere. Moſen habent & prophetas, they haue Moſes and the Prophets. By which wordes it is ſhewed that the holye ſcriptures are ſufficient to ſaluation, and that men neede not to be ſente to fathers or to humaine traditions, or apparitions of the dead.

div.head: The .8. reaſon and profe.
div.p: They pretend alſo the authoritie of the Apocalips, where it is read that no impure or vnclene perſon ſhalbe admitted into the holy citie.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Concernyng the holy citie (which is the feloſhip of the bleſsed) we graunt that no impure thinge may be tranſmitted vnto it. For they that die in the name and faith of Chriſt, are clenſed with his bloud. Ouer and beſide repentaunce and diſſolution of the fleſhe doth cauſe them to remember and confeſse their impuritie. VVherfore they oughte not to be counted vncleane, which be partakers of eternall life.

div.head: The .9. reaſon and proofe.
div.p: Paule writeth that all knees both of things in heauen, and thyngs of the earth, and things vnder the earth ought to bow them ſelues vnto god.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Theſe wordes are not to be vnderſtande of the worſhipping of God, for this worſhip ſtandeth not in this, that the knee ſhould be bowed, but doth ſpecially require the ſpiritual affectes and motions of the mynde. Paule ther ſpeaketh of the great authoritie & power, which is committed and geuen to Chriſt, by the which power euery creature of heauen, earth, and hel, is made ſubiect vnto him: yea the deuel hymſelfe, with all the wicked and damned ſpirits, wil they, nil they, are deliuered vnder his feete. And the wordes which go before do ſhewe this ſufficientlye, for it is ſaid: God gaue him a name that is aboue all names, that al knees would bow in that name. Vvhich words if ye will applie vnto the diuine worſhip, as though they which worſhip God be in purgatorie, than muſt you graunt alſo, that the deuel and all the damned ſpirites do worſhippe Chriſt.

div.head: The .10. reaſon and proofe.
div.p: It is alledged out of the Apocalips, that euery creature in heauen, in earth, and vnder the earth, and in the Sea, ſing praiſes vnto God.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: All things do praiſe God as it is conuenient to their nature: for they exhibite matter and occaſion of diuine praiſes, as hilles, mountaines, trees, woods, dragons, and ſuch other like doo truly and properlye praiſe God for their creations ſake.

div.head: The .11. reaſon and proofe.
div.p: It is written in Paule that fire ſhall trie euery mans worcke, and if any mans worck that he hath built vpon, abide, he ſhal receiue wages. If any mans worke burn, he ſhal loſe. But he ſhalbe ſafe him ſelfe neuertheles, yet as it wer by the fire. Here may you ſee that the fire of purgatorie ſhall clenſe all mens doinges.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: No man ſhall eſcape this fyre whether he builde well or ill. All are to be proued by this fire, that the doctrine whiche is builte bee proued and examined whether it doth agree with the foundation, or no. Otherwiſe god is ſaid to be like vnto a burning fyre. For god will purge the ſonnes of Leui, and will purifie them as ſiluer and gold. The doctrines that be ſound, ſhall abide, nor the fire that trieth them, ſhal hurt them, no more then the fornace doth hurte ſiluer or gold.

Auguſtine in diuerſe places of his writings maketh mention of this ſentence, and alwaies conſenting vnto himſelfe doth bring the ſelfe ſame expoſition of theſe wordes, but he affirmeth this ſaying to be in the nō bre of one of thoſe harde ſayings, which Peter ſpeake in his epiſtle.

Furthermore he warneth that we interprete this fire to be of that kind which maye be common, aſwell to the good buylders, as to the ill. At the laſt he ſaith, we muſt beware that we ſet not in this predicamēt thoſe that be baptized which haue liued ill, and that we faigne not their haynous ſinnes, as murther and whordom (by the which men are excluded from the kyngdome of heauen) to be woode, ſtrawe and chaf, becauſe to ſuch kinde of men, being giltie of ſuche greuous crimes, hell fire is due: which fire can not be common to the good builders alſo, excepte you will thruſte them alſo into hell fire. Here is alſo mention made onely of them, which markyng and obſeruing the foundation, do builde. Among whome they are not to be nombred which are burthened with deſperat vices. Sainct Auſtine goeth further and ſaith, that the foundation is Chriſt, which the Apoſtle himſelfe doth interpret. He addeth alſo fayth, becauſe Chriſt dwelleth in our harts by faith, and he maketh them to be the good builders, which obey the lawe of God. He affirmeth them to builde haye and ſtuble, which reteine the pleaſures of the worlde, which pleaſures are not expreſſely forbydden, and do ſo reteine them, that they geue them ſelues more vnto them, then equitie doth require. They which build wel (ſaith he) poſſeſſe the goods of this world, as riches, honour, wife, familie, and yet they be as though they poſseſſe them not, and do vſe them, as though they would not vſe them. The ill builders are affected with theſe things more then behoueth, yet they geue not themſelues ſo loſelye vnto theſe their deſires, that they will preferre theſe goods, before Chriſt, vnto whom as vnto the foundation they do lean, but rather ſet Chriſt before them. For if they come eyther to confeſsion of their ſaith, or to martirdome, they will rather loſe thoſe goods, than to depart from Chriſt. Notwithſtandyng becauſe they did embrace them with to vehement affect and loue in loſing them, they feele the fire. For they be very ſorowful, and take it greuouſly that theſe things are taken
from them, but yet they be ſaued, becauſe they kepe the foundation of the true faith ſafe and vnhurt, that is (ſaith he) haie, wood, and chaf to be kindled with fire and periſh, becauſe their deſires and pleaſures doth moleſte them, as the flame of fire would do, and ſo thoſe pleaſures and affections do vaniſhe awaye. And this happeneth to many (ſaith he) while they liue here. For it chaunceth many times, that the holy martirs and ſaints be beriued of the goods of this world for the name of Chriſt. He proueth fire to ſignifie tribulations, as it is taken in the pſalme.Pſal. 65. And for that cauſe be willed fire and water to be had in the exorciſme of baptiſme, that we may be admoniſhed that by theſe two we ſhalbe tried. He bringeth in alſo this ſentence of Eccleſiaſticus: Vas figuli probat fornax, at animos iuſtorum tentatio tribulationis: the fornace proueth the potters veſsell, but tentation of tribulation, trieth the mindes of the righteous.

To this interpretation of Auguſtin, Gregorie doth conſent, yet he doth wreſt it vnto purgatorie. But it doth moſt euidently appeare, that Paul by the good and bad buildings, doth ſignifie doctrine, eyther ſounde or els corrupt, whoſe end is deſcribed, that if they be good, they ſhal haue reward, but if they be ill, they ſhall periſh and vaniſh awaye. For euery plant which my father hath not planted (ſaith Chriſt) ſhalbe pulled vp by the rootes, but the word of God remaineth for euer.

He which hath not buylded well, may be ſaued, but yet by fire, becauſe he ſhal ſee his doctrine confuted & condemned, & ſhal know that he hath laboured in vaine, and be like vnto one which goeth through the fire, whoſe garments are burned, yet he himſelf eſcapeth. Some do expound this clauſe (ſo as it wer by fire) becauſe men are hardly brought from their opinions. For they do embrace and allow to much their owne inuentions. But the expoſition is more ſimple and plain, if you wyll ſay that theſe men, when god ſhal examine them, ſhal fele ſhame, ſadnes, and vnquiet conſciences. And to this interpretation doth Ambroſe condiſcend, he muſt needs be aſhamed which ſeeth himſelf to haue defended a falſity for a trouth: in this examination and iudgement of God the error of doctrine is opened, and forthwith followeth dolor and great heauines of repstāce. Chriſoſtom thought yt this fire pertaineth to hel, but becauſe he ſeeth this ſayinge to be againſt him (but he ſhalbe ſaued as it were by fire) he expounded to be ſaued, to ſignify no other thing, then to endure & cōtinu, not to be extinct, not to be turned into aſhes, or to be brought to nothinge, that this euil builder ſhoulde endure quo ad ſubſtantiam, concerning his ſubſtance, but hee ſhall not be reſerued (as he ſayth) but only to puniſhment, that he burn in this fire for euer. He did know that this interpretatiō was ſomwhat farre fetched, and therefore he wente about
to temper it, and ſheweth that Paul ſomtimes adourneth with fair wordes thoſe things, which otherwiſe are vnhoneſt and to be diſproued, and ſomtimes termeth with vnhoneſt woordes things that be commendable and allowable: In the later Epiſtle to the Corinthes Paule ſaith, that we do captiuate all our thoughtes wherby this worde captiuat, he calleth it to be a perſuaſion, by the which men do willyngly ſubmit them ſelues to the faith of Chriſt. Alſo when he ſpeaketh of the mortification of the fleſh and members, which are vpon the earth, he commendeth by this terme (mortification) a very approued and perfect thing, And likewiſe when he ſaith to the Romaines. Non regnet peccatum in veſtro mortale corpore: Let not ſinne reigne in your mortall bodies: he doth beautifie with this worde (kyngdom) tyrannie, by the whiche we are oppreſſed with ſinne: ſo by this worde (ſauing) he calleth it and meaneth eternall continuaunce in the fire of hell. But this wreſtinge and writhing of Chriſoſtome to defend his interpretation, can not conſiſt as a thyng true. For when all things here are taken allegoricallie, what nedeth he to flie the ſignification of a true fire, vnleſſe he meaneth the fire of hell to be alſo allegoricall, which the receiued doctrine of the churche will neither admitte nor ſuffer?

Furthermore when it is ſaid, the fire ſhall proue euerie mans worke, it behoueth to conſtitute ſuch a fire, whiche aſwell the good builders as ill, ſhal ſuſteine and feele, as ſainct Auguſtine very aptly doth write.

I thincke Saincte Auguſtine neither mente nor woulde, good and holye men to be tormented with the fire of hell. Notwitſtandynge the Greeke ſcholies do receiue this ſentence and interpretation of Chriſoſtome.

Eraſmus in his annotations doth count it a vaine and fooliſh thing by this place to proue purgatorie. If the fire of purgatorie be in this place conſtitute and proued, then muſt this fire be common aſwell to the Apoſtles and to other ſaincts, as to other, although they haue builded a church with moſt approued and ſincere doctrine. And by this place to defende purgatorie, is no more but that our aduerſaries do caſt doung in their owne eies. For they ſay that ſome pardons are geuen and graunted of the pope to abſolue man when he dieth, ab omni tam poena, quam culpa, aſwel from all payn, as from all faulte: ſo that his ſoule ſhall flie ſtraight waye into heauen. If it be ſo, how ſhall this man be proued with the fire of purgatorie, if this fire be common to all?

Scotus doth ſay that the action and motion of charitie may be found ſo abſolute and perfect, and of ſo great feruencie, that it may put away all paines How then can this fire of purgatorie which they will proue by this place, be common to all? vnles perchaunce they will place this
fire in the ayre, and faigne that all ſainctes when they flie to heauen, do paſse through this fire: as one Altuinus did affirme.

But it is to be marked that the opinion of them which will haue a purgatorie, is not one, but diuerſe and ſondrie. For ſome woulde haue it to be a moſt certain doctrine, and one of the articles of our faith, other do but ſuſpicate or opinate that ther is ſuch a place.

Concernyng the firſt, ſure doctrine, and the articles of our faith, ought to be proued with moſt euident teſtimonies of the ſcriptures. Their iudgement is not to be receyued which would make men to be the authours of things to be beleued. For contumelie ſhould be done to the holy ghoſt, if it ſhould be thought that he had geuen vnto vs thoſe writinges in the whiche ſhould not be perfectly contained whatſoeuer is neceſsarie to ſaluation.

The Epiſtle written to Timothie doth ſufficiently conuince them, where it is written that the ſcriptures geuen by the inſpiration of God is profitable to teach, to confute, to correct, and to inſtruct, that the man of God may be perfecte, and abſolut to all good workes: Vvherfore if they will bring any good worcke, or any thing neceſſary to be beleued, which can not be confirmed by the holy ſcriptures, it is to be anſwered, that which they bring, is neither good, nor profitable. And where they boaſt that the Apoſtles taught not al things, nor that the primatiue churche receiued not all things neceſsary to ſaluation, it is not to be graūted.

Tertullian hath a godly ſaying much repugnant to this opinion.De perſecuti one hereticorum. For he writeth. Foelix eccleſia cui totam doctrinam apoſtoli cum ſanguine profuderunt. Happie is the church vnto whom the Apoſtles with their bloud poured and gaue all neceſsarie doctrine.
Chriſt alſo ſaid▪ what things I haue heard of my father, thoſe things haue I made knowen vnto you.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: The Apoſtles in dede, ſhewed and taught all things, but they wrote not all things

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: If they wrote not al things, yet they had a reſpect that al things which they deliuered might be manifeſtly proued, either out of their owne writings, or els out of the bokes of holy ſcriptures. For otherwiſe ther ſhould crepe into the church a rablement and heap of ſuperſtitions, which would ſeme to be defended vnder the pretence of the traditions of the Apoſtles.
But to our purpoſe again. Concerning purgatorie, great doubte hath riſen therof in the church, for the greke church in the Florentin councel did long reſiſte and ſtand againſt it.

Auguſtine ſpake of purgatorie diuerſe and ſondrie wayes. For in his Enchiridion he ſaith, not to be incredible, that ſuche a place maye be after this lyfe: but (ſaith he) it maye be inquired whether there
be ſuch a place or no. And it may be founde, it may be hidden. Vvhich woordes alſo he hath ad dulcitium. Quaeſtio. 1. Likewiſe in his booke de fide & operibus, he writeth: Siue igitur in hac vita tantum homines patiuntur, ſiue etiam poſt hanc vitam talia quidem iudicia ſubſequentur non abhorret (quantum arbitror) a ratione: Cap. 16 that is. Vvhether men do ſuffer theſe thi • gs in this life onely, or els ſuch iudgementes do folow after this life, it doth not abhorre (as far as I know) from reaſon.

You may ſee that ſainct Auſtin vſeth here a diſiunctiue propoſition, to the veritie wherof one part is ſufficient. Vvho, I praye you, woulde ſpeake ſo doubtfullye of an article of the faith, as to ſay, whether Chriſt had a true fleſhe, or a phantaſticall fleſh? or whether the diuine nature were in Chriſt, or humaine nature onely? &c. Thoſe thinges whiche pertaine to the faith, ought neceſſarilye to be defined, and ought to be moſt certaine.

The ſame Auguſtine when he ſpake of the fire of purgatorie, ſaide after this maner.Lib. de ciuita te dei 21. c. 26. Non hoc redarguo quia forſitan verum eſt: I do not improue this, becauſe peraduenture it is true. But in thoſe things which are neceſſary to be beleued to ſaluation, it is not lauful to vſe ſuch phraſe, eyther of writing or of ſpeakyng.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: Although ſainct Auguſtine ſemeth to be doubtfull in theſe places alledged, yet in other places he doth moſt certainly affirme it.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Thoſe places where he ſemeth to affirme it, are to be interpreted by theſe other foure places. In the whiche he maketh it to be ambiguous and doubtful, whether there be ſuch a place or no. Therfore it muſt be graunted that ſainct Auguſtine was perſuaded rather with opinion, then with certaine ſcience and knowledge, becauſe the nature of opinion is to aſſente to one parte, with a feare and doubte of the other parte.
But it is to be tought that this maketh gretly againſt this comment and gloſe of purgatorie, that the holye ſcriptures make no mention of ſuch a place, neither in the olde Teſtament, nor in the new.

Abraham boughte for the burial of his wife a field, the graue is deſcribed, the price is expreſſed, and all thinges are there ſo diligently rehearſed, that nothing ſemeth to be omitted. Vvhere notwitſtandynge, ther is no mention made eyther of purgatorie, eyther of the ſoule to be deliuered from payne, eyther of anye ſacrifices or prayers.

In the booke of Leuiticus, and in other bookes wher the law is deſcribed, aſwell for the whole ſtate of man and ſacrifices and oblations for euery kynd of ſinne, yet ther is no mention made for the dead to be deliuered from payne.

The prophetes which where the beſt interpreters of the lawe, when they commende in euery place all offices of pietie and charitie, yet they ſet not forth in all their ſermons any thinge that concerneth ſuch a place.

Paule alſo when occaſion was offred him in writynge to the Theſſalonians (for he intreated how they ſhould mourne and lamente for the dead in funeralles, and he lifteth vp and comforteth them that he admoniſhed onely by the hope of the reſurrection:) might at the leaſt haue admoniſhed in that place to haue praied for our dere frends, leaſte they ſhould lye long in the paines of purgatorie.
He bringeth no ſuch thing, but after the doctrine of the reſurrection, he ſaith. Itaque inuicem conſolemini verbis iſtis: Therfore comfort your ſelues one an other with theſe wordes.

Dioniſius called Areopagita, when of a ſet purpoſe, he moued a queſtion, why the Miniſter of the church, doth praye for him that is dead, maketh no mention of purgatorie, but greatly trauaileth to rendre other cauſes and reaſons. If he had beleued a purgatorie, he might eaſely haue anſwered the queſtion.

Sainct Ciprian in the end of his booke doth write Quum hinc excelſum fuerit, neque locus poenitentiae, neque ſatisfactionis erit effectus: Vvhen we departe from hence, ther ſhalbe neither place of repentaunce, nor effecte of ſatiſfaction.

Our aduerſaries were wonte to pretende for this opinion, mercie, becauſe they would not thincke them to be condemned whiche died in the confeſſion of Chriſte, when notwithſtandyng, they wer yet holden wyth ſom ſpot of ſinne.

But that mercie is fooliſh which moueth vs to ordeine and conſtitute thoſe thinges which we know not, whither they ſet forth the glorie of God or no, and which alſo can not be proued by the holy ſcriptures. Furthermore we are bounde to loue God, with all our ſtrength, and all our ſoules, and to begyn nothing whiche we know not to be allowed of him, and to pertaine to his glorie.

Thus you perceiue that purgatorie is no neceſsarie doctrine to be beleued. Againe, the ſuſpition and opinion therof doth leane vpon infirme and weake reaſons, and doth hurte pietie, rather then promote it.

div.head: Certaine places of holy ſcripture which do impugne purgatorie.
div.p: Chriſt ſaide: he that heareth my words, and beleueth in him that ſent me, ſhall not enter into iudgement, but haue life euerlaſtinge,Ioan. 5 and ſhal paſſe from death to life.

In the Apocalips it is written. Bleſsed be they which die in the Lord,Cap. 14. for forthwith they ſhall reſte from their labours. But to be broiled in
fire, is not to reſte from labour.

Luk. 23.Chriſt ſayd to the theefe: This daye thou ſhalte be with me in paradiſe. Vvhiche place is againſt them whiche hold, that thoſe ſpottes which remaine in man, although he liued neuer ſo well and vertuouſly, muſt be purged. Vvhat will they ſaye then to the theefe, whiche behaued himſelf wickedlye to the ende, and yet was immediatlye after his death receiued into paradiſe?

Cap. 11.It is written in Eccleſiaſtes: If the cloudes be full, they will poure forth raine vpon the earth. And if the tree do fall towarde the South or toward the North, in the place that the tree falleth, there it ſhalbe. Salomon vſeth here two allegories, the one taken out of the clouds, and the other of the trees, by the which he admoniſheth vs to do that goodnes, whiche we will do, while we haue opportunitie and time, for when we are departed from hence, there is no place neyther of merite, nor repentaunce. There be alſo many other places in the ſcriptures which make againſt this matter.
One place I had almoſt forgotten, which the aduerſaries of late haue alledged for the defence of purgatorie.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: It is written (ſaye they) in the epiſtle to Timothie that ſaincte Paule praied, that the Lorde would graunte Oneſiphorus, which oft refreſhed him, that he might finde mercie with the Lord at that day. Now when Oneſiphorus was dead, and yet Paule prayed for him, therfore it is lawfull for vs to pray for the dead, which were in vaine, vnleſse ther were a purgatorie.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: If they looke well on their owne writers they ſhall finde that Oneſiphorus was aliue, as in Lyranus, whoſe wordes be theſe: The Lord ſende him mercy in that day, die ſcilicet mortis ſuae, vel in die generalis iudicii, in the day of his death, or in the daye of the generall iudgement.

Dioniſius Carthuſianus alſo doth ſaye that he was aliue. Ouer and beſide Oecumenius expounding the fourth chapter of the ſame Epiſtle, doth ſaye, that Oneſiphorus was at Rome: In the which chapter Paule ſaluteth the familie of Oneſiphorus whiche was at Epheſus, but Oneſiphorus himſelfe was at Rome. And ſo writeth Chriſoſtome. Therfore this place maketh nothing for purgatorie.

I am not ignoraunt that the moſt part of the fathers are bent in their writings to graunt a purgatorie. But we muſt vnderſtande that the fathers wer men, & did ſomtime erre as mē. For they did not alwais build gold, ſiluer and precious ſtones vpon the foundation, which is Chriſt.

As for antiquitie and cuſtome it ought not to preſcribe and to be
preiudiciall vnto veritie and truth: for in the very tyme of Paule errours began in the church. For ſome euen than thought that baptiſme ought to be receiued for the dead. But Ciprian doth admoniſhe, that that cuſtome with reaſon and truth, is the mother of errour.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: The church hath vſed alwayes to praye for the dead, euen from the tyme of the apoſtles.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: It can not be denied but that the church hath ſo done. But this their doing or ſaying hath none authoritie out of the holy ſcriptures. Men be moued and as it were impelled with a certaine naturall loue towarde their frindes that be dead, to wiſhe them well to doe, and to breake out ſometime into prayers for them. But heede is to be taken that this affection be not diſsonant vnto faith.
Other cauſes beſide the opinion of purgatorie maye be aſsigned and alledged why prayers were made in the church for the dead.
They would not haue the name and memorie of their frends departed, to periſhe and to be extinguiſhed, but tooke great care that it might long continue among the faithfull.

Furthermore thoſe prayers pertained to geuinge of thankes vnto God, who hath called them that are departed vnto himſelfe out of this miſerable world. Vvherupon ſainct Ambroſe in his funerall orations, which he had at the death of Theodoſius and Valentinianus the Emperours, doth reioice that they had alredie obteined eternall felicitie, and that they reigned with Chriſt: yet notwithſtandyng he prayed that God woulde geue vnto them that reſt, which they deſired, whiche two things ſeme to be repugnaunt, vnles you will expounde prayers for thankes geuyng.

Furthermore, ſome of the fathers wente ſo far, that they thought prayers ſomwhat to profit them that were in hell, not in ſhortning their plaines, for they be eternall, but to diminiſh and eaſe them at the leaſt for the tyme of the praiers.
Chriſoſtome, Auguſtine, and Hierome ſeme to be of that minde.

Againe ſome might ſeme to praye for the dead, not for the ende to deliuer them from purgatorie, but that Chriſt might the ſooner come to iudge the quicke and the dead, that the faithful which died in the Lord, might the ſooner haue the fruition of felicitie, both of the bodye and the ſoule.

Furthermore, other did praie for the dead whiche were not in purgatorie, (for they beleued it not) but in paradiſe,De monogamia. as it appeareth in Tertullian, who writeth yt the church was wont to pray for the martirs, for
