whome (as ſainct Auſtine ſaith) if any man do pray, he doth them iniurie.

Thoſe prayers therfore were nothing els but thankes geuing. For they rendred thankes vnto God for the great gifts and benefites graunted to them of god, by the which they did moſt gloriouſly triumph ouer their ennemies, they did alſo ſtirre and comforte other to be theyr followers. They did ſet forth their noble actes, declaryng that they were gone into their countrie.

Lib. 3. epiſt. 3Therfore in the primatiue church they prayed for the dead, but yet for the martirs (as Ciprian teſtifieth.) Euen as we do geue thanckes vnto god for all thoſe that die godly in the Lord.

Eccleſiaſt.Eraſmus ſaith that in tymes paſt the people aſsembled together vpon certaine dayes to ſinge. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is geuyng of thanckes. And the Prophete preacher or biſhoppe did extoll with godly wordes the diuine goodnes towards his creatures: they did ſet forth the praiſe of the godly martirs, which glorified Chriſt with their death, the people ſong hymnes, pſalmes and ſpirituall ſonges vnto the Lord.
Now a word or two concernyng the doctours iudgement.

Epiſt. 54Sainct Auguſtin in this Epiſtle ad Macedonium ſaith: Morum corrigendorum nullus alius quam in hac vita locus: nam poſt hanc vitam quiſque id habebit quod in hac ſibimet conquiſierit that is. Ther is none other place to haue correction for maners, then in this lyfe: for euery one ſhall receyue that after this life, which he hath gotten to himſ • lfe in this lyfe.

De verb. apo ſermo. 19.Againe in an other place he ſayth. Duae habitationes ſunt, vna in igne aeterno, altera in regno aeterno. There be two habitations or manſions, the one in eternall fire, and the other in the eternall kyngdome of heauen. Furthermore in his hypognoſtichon againſt the Pelagians, he writeth.Lib. 5. Primum fides cathoilcorum diuina authoritate regnum credit eſſe caelorum, vnde non baptizatus excipitur: ſecundum gehennam vbi omnis apoſtata vel a Chriſti fide alienus ſupplicia reperitur. Tertium penitus ignoramus, nec eſſe in ſcripturis ſanctis reperimus.

The catholique faith beleueth by the authoritie of gods word, firſt, that there is a kingdome of heauen, from the which he that is not chriſtened, is exempted. Second, that ther is hell wher euery Apoſtata or vnfaithful doth receiue puniſhment. The third place we vtterly know not, neither we finde it in the holy ſcriptures.

Sainct Hierome doth ſaye, that when we be in this preſente world, we may helpe one another, whether it be by good prayers, or by good counſell. But when we ſhal come before the iudgement ſeate of Chriſt, neither Iob nor Daniel can pray for any man. For euery one ſhall beare hys own burthen.

Chriſoſtome ſayth: Omnia hic diſſolue vt citra moleſtiam illud viduas tribunal. &c. That is: Bring all thinges to paſse here, that with out all moleſtation or grefe thou mayſt ſee that iudgement ſeate. Vvhile we be here, we haue manifeſt and noble hopes, but when we are departed thither, it lyeth not in vs after, either to repent, or to wipe & waſh away any thing that we haue committed.
I could bring the authorities of many other fathers, but to him that will be reſolued without obſtinacy, theſe be ſufficient. And thus muche for Purgatory.

div.head: Hodie. 7.
div.p:
HOdie is called in the Greke toung 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , or attice
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , in the Hebrue it is called Haiom, which is compounded of iom, with the demonſtration He before it.

Hodie in the ſcriptures is taken diuers and ſundrye waies Firſt, for the certaine and preſent time, as in the prophet Eſay: Non ieiunatis hodie, vt in ſublimi exaudiatur vox veſtra You ſhall not faſt as you doo to day, to make your voyce to be heard aboue.

Secondly, Hodie doth not ſignify this preſent day or to morrow, but perpetuity of time, or from the beginning of the world, as in the epiſtle to the Hebrues, Paule doth vſe it ſaying: Ieſus Chriſtus heri, Cap. 13. et hodie idem eſt etiam in ſecula. Ieſus Chriſt yeſterday and to day, the ſame alſo is for euer. Notwithſtanding this ſentence of Paule is of diuers, diuerſly expounded.
Some do write that Paul bringeth in here an argument to confirme faith and truſt in God, in them to whom he wrote.

One might obiect and ſay: Paul thou dooſt wel admoniſh vs. God did aboue meaſure fauour the Apoſtles and apoſtolike men, as his chief darlings and friendes, but he will not embrace me, with the like fauour and grace. To the which obiection Paul geueth an apt and mete anſwer, ſaying: Ieſus Chriſt yeſterday and to day, and the ſame for euer. As though he ſhould haue ſayd. Ieſus Chriſt, which was yeſterday, that is in tyme paſt, that ſame is to day, and ſhall continue for euer. He hath that ſame benignity and gentlenes which he had then. His handes are not abbreuiated nor ſhortened. He which ſuſteyned and nouriſhed with meate and drinke Elias, and the people of Iſrael, by the ſpace of fourty yeares, the ſame will alſo nouriſh and feede you: doubtles if hys benignity and gentlenes ſhould ceaſe, he ſhould alſo ceaſe to be God. Other do referre thys ſentence to Paul, to this end, that we ſhould know that ſame manner of ſaluation to haue bene before Chriſt was incarnate, and the ſame which is after the incarnation of Chriſt to be all one. Other do referre it to the
doctrine of Chriſt, and that this word ſhal remaine for euer. Vvhich expoſitions, although they be godly: yet in my iudgement the firſt expoſition is the very natural ſenſe of the place.

And note here one thing, that the Apoſtle doth not entreate of the diuine eſſence of Chriſt, but of the knowledge of him, which flooriſhed alwaies among the godly, and is the perpetual foundation of the church.
Therfore this ſentence muſt be referred, not to the eſſence, but to the quality (if we may ſo ſay.)
Nor Paule diſputeth here whither Chriſt were eternal with the father, but what manner of knowledge and benignitye was among men of him, and from him.

Thirdly, Hodie, is properly vſed to be ſpoken of that time, which is after the comming of Chriſt, as Paule vſeth it to the Hebrues ſaying: Hodie, ſi vocem eius audieritis, To day if ye heare his voyce.

Lib. 2. cap. 2 Heſichius in Leuiticum, doth vſe Hodie, for eternity and perpetuity, alledging theſe words of the ſecond pſalme: Ego hodie genui te. This day I begat thee, that is, ab eterno, from euer and eternallye. For with God heri, & cras haue no place. Ther is alwaies with him a continual and perpetual Hodie, as Theophilactus writeth vpō the epiſtle to the Hebrues.

Notwithſtanding ſome learned men which be of great iudgement write vpon theſe words (Filius meus es tu, ego hodie genui te: thou art my ſonne, this day haue I begot thee) after this maner. Ther be, ſay they, diuers kindes of ſonnes, ſome are children by nature, ſome by adoption, ſome of regeneration, ſome of alteration, by ye which the priſtinate ſtate and condition is chaunged into a new ſtate. As touching Chriſt our Sauiour, the true Chriſtians be not ignoraunt by what kind of theſe ſonnes he is the ſonne of God. Our faith doth beleue him to be the naturall, the onely begotten and conſubſtantial ſonne of the father.

Concerning this preſent place of ſcripture, let vs ſee how this agreeth vnto Chriſt, that the father did not ſimply ſay I begat thee, but this day I begat thee. This phraſe doth not agree vnto children of adoption, of age, or of loue, but onely of the ſonnes of generation, that is, that be begotten.
Now this generation is three fold.
The naturall generation is, by the which God the father begat the woord, and hys natural and conſubſtantial ſonne, and by the which one man begetteth an other.

The ſpirituall generation is, by the which the myndes of men are ſo
regenerate, that of wicked they be made godly. Of the which generation Paul ſpeaketh in the Epiſtle to the Corinthians, ſaying: In Chriſto Ieſu per euangelium vos genui. I haue begot you in Ieſus Chriſt by the Goſpell. Agayne, filioli quos iterum parturio. My litle children, with whom again I trauel with child.

Conditional generation is, by the which man is chaunged into an other ſtate and condition, diuers and diſcrepant from his former ſtate, as if one of a priuat mā be made a king, one from an obſcure & baſe calling is made noble and honorable, of mortal, is made immortal.

Now theſe wordes, Hodie genui te, this day I begat thee, doth not agree to Chriſt, according to the firſt generation. Yet not ſo, but that he is the natural ſonne of God, nor that this generation being eternall, can be made temporal, or ſubiect to any time, except ye wil referre it to that day, in the which ye word being incarnate, was born of the virgin Mary.

Neither the generation which is called ſpirituall, maye agree vnto Chriſt, for when he is and was moſt pure in minde, he had none impiety nor vnpurenes, from the which he might be regenerate vnto godlynes. But the third generation, that is the condicional, may be applied & referred to Chriſt. For what other thing was ye imutation & chaung of the ſtate and condicion of Chriſt, when he was by the holy ghoſt dedicated, conſecrated, and declared from heauē to be the ſonne of God, at the floud Iordan, when he was baptiſed: But a certaine regeneration, that is, he was ſene to be another maner of man, thē he was before? In ſo much that the inhabitauntes of the city did ſay: Vnde huic haec omnia, & quae ſapientia haec quae data eſt illi? &c. From whence hath he theſe thinges? what wiſedome is this that is geuen vnto hym, that euen ſuch great woorkes are done by his handes? Is not this the carpenter Maries ſonne? The brother of Iames and Ioſes, and of Iuda and Simon?

Or ells theſe wordes. Ego hodie genui te. This day haue I begot thee, may he referred to Chriſt, when being rayſed from death he puttyng of the infirmity and mortalitye of our fleſh was tranſlated and exalted aboue all, vnto the heauenly glorye, and to the right hand of the Father. This is the cenſure and iudgement of certain learned diuines.
Hodie is taken alſo for euery time, or dayly tyme, as we aſke in the Lordes prayer, panem noſtrum quotidianum da nobis hodie, Geue vs this day our dayly bread.

Hodie ſignifieth ſomtime the whole time of our life, as Baſilius Magnus writeth in a certain Epiſtle,In epiſtola ad Chilonem de vita ſolit. where he bringeth in this ſaying of the Apoſtle: Inuicem adhortamini, et in id ipſum aedificate vſquequo hodie dicitur. Exhorte one another dayly, while it is called to day.
This ſhall be ſufficient for this word Hodie.

div.head: Manie places or Manſions. 10.
div.p: Cap. 14 IN Iohn Chriſt ſaith to his diſciples: let not your hartes be troubled, ye beleue in God, beleue alſo in me. In my fathers houſe are many dwelling places. If it were not ſo, I would haue told you. I go to prepare a place for you. The occaſiō why Chriſt ſpake theſe words, was for that Chriſt told them before that he would depart from them. Vvherof the diſciples conceiued heauines and ſorow. Vvherefore Chriſt with theſe words did comfort them again, ſaying that he would not depart from thē, as alwaies to be ſeperate and deuided from them, but that vnto them alſo ther was a place in the kingdome of heauen. And therfore he ſaid: In domo patris mei multae manſiones ſunt, in my fathers houſe ar many dwelling places or manſions.

This place of ſcripture hath bene peruerſlye drawen into an other ſenſe, as though Chriſt by theſe words ſhould teach, that ther were diſtinct degrees of honour and glory in the kingdome of heauē. But Chriſt did not ſay, ther be diuers & ſundry manſions, but many māſions, which be ſufficiēt vnto many. As though he ſhould ſay: ther is not onely a place ther for me, but alſo for al my diſciples. Ther is no cauſe therfore, that ye ſhould mourne and lament for my corporal departure, for the kingdom of my father was prepared vnto you from the beginning of the world, & you wer elect and choſen before the foundations of the world were layd. Therfore ther is nothing that cā annoy or hurt you, whither it be ſinne, the world, death, hell, or Sathan. For no man can take the elect from the hand of my father.

div.head: Queſtio.
div.p: If the election wer done, and manſions prepared before the beginning of the world, what nede haue we then of Chriſt? Or wherfore came he into the world?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: The election was done before the world was made, but yet in Chriſt, and by Chriſt. For ther is none adopted of God vnto his ſonne, but by Ieſus Chriſt. So many manſions were prepared from the beginning of the world, but by Chriſt our mediatour and interceſſor.

Therfore Chriſt came into the world to reueale and declare theſe māſions before prepared, yt he might opē ye gate of electiō & prepare vs by his ſpirit to receaue theſe māſions. For what had it auailed to be elect, and in ye meane time not to haue knowē or entred into ye gate of election?

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: Math. 20How cā it be ſaid, yt there be many manſions, whē yt very few be elect?

div.head: Reſponſio
div.p:
They be called many manſions in cōpariſon to Chriſt, ſo yt the meaning
is this: Heauen is not prepared to me onely, nor I alone am elect of the father from the beginning, but many other by me are elect of the father, vnto whom the kingdome of heauen, through faith which they haue in me, is opened. I verely am the true and onely ſonne of God, and alone naturally elected of the father, and to whom heauen naturally is prepared. But ther be many other whom the father hath choſen in me, & which by me ſhall poſſeſſe the heauenlye kingdome prepared from the beginning. Therfore (ſaith Chriſt to his diſciples) if it were not ſo, I woulde haue told you, As though he ſhould haue ſaid, if heauenly glorye ſhoulde receiue me onely, I would haue told you, but the matter is otherwyſe, for I go before to prepare you a place, for there be places as well for you, as for me.

I do not a litle marueil, that the moſt part of the later writers, which were in the corrupt time, did not onely alledge his place out of Iohn, to proue the diuerſities of glories and ioyes in heauen, but alſo other places, wherof I wil touch three or foure: Not that I entende to proue or geue forth, yt ther is vtterly an equality in heauen, or els a diſparity & vnequality▪ But that as farre as the ſcriptures doo geue, none of both opinions can be proued in the ſcriptures, by the iudgement of learned men. Both the ſentences are probable, but yet not to be proued by the ſcriptures.
Now ſhall we go to the places which they alledge, for the diuerſitye of degrees in glory.

div.head: The firſt reaſon.
div.p: Firſt ſay they, euery man ſhall receiue according to his woorkes, and euery one ſhal receiue his reward, according to his labour.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: I vnderſtand this ſentence to be ſpoken generally concerning glory,Cap. 2. and damnation which interpretation I haue out of the epiſtle to the Romaines. And Chriſt in the laſt ſentence of iudgement doth ſo expounde, that euery man ſhal receiue his reward, when he calleth thē on the right hand to ſaluation, and caſteth out them on the left hand vnto damnatiō. He whoſe labour ſhalbe found godly and iuſt, ſhalbe ſaued, and he who ſhalbe found to haue laboured ill, ſhal periſh.

div.head: The ſecond reaſon.
div.p: It is written in Daniel, that they which teach other and be wyſe,Cap. 11 ſhal ſhine as the brightnes of the firmament, and they that turne many to righteouſnes, ſhal ſhine as the ſtars for euer and euer.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p:
This place maketh litle for the purpoſe: for it happeneth oft times in the holy ſcriptures, that thoſe things which be ſpoken in the firſt place, are repeated agayne in the ſecond place. The difference which ſeemeth to
be in this ſentence, is of the firmament, and of the ſtars. But when they which teach, and they which do inſtruct to righteouſnes, be vtterlye all one, and are contained in one degree, diuers rewardes are not due vnto them, foraſmuch as they labour both in one thing. Vvherfore it appeareth that the ſame thing, which was ſpoken firſt, is affirmed after, but yet more plainly.

div.head: Queſtio.
div.p: Vvhy doth Daniel make mencion of thoſe whiche doo teache, more then of other?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Becauſe they are more to be confirmed and comforted, for that they be more ſubiect vnto perſecutions, then other are. Therfore they haue nede of conſolation. Yet it followeth not out of this, but that the rewards are due vnto other faithful alſo. For Chriſt doth euidently ſay: Iuſti fulgebunt ſicut ſol in regno Dei, the righteous ſhal ſhine as the ſunne in the kingdome of God.

Saint Hierome expounding this place, when he had ſimply intreated this ſentence, did ſay, that many do aſke, whither the vnlearned being holy, and the learned being alſo holy, ſhal haue one and the ſame glory. And he ſaith, that by the tranſlation of Theodoſion, we may anſwer that the one ſhalbe as the firmament, and the other as the ſtarres. But other diuines do ſay, that both the partes of this ſentence be one thing.

div.head: The third reaſon.
div.p: If there be diuerſity of paines, there muſt needes be alſo diuerſity of ioyes per argumentum a contrariis. And that paines for ſinne are not one and equall, Chriſt doth proue, when he ſaid, that it ſhould be eaſier for Tire and Sidon, then to Corozaim and Bethſaida, likewiſe vnto Sodom, then vnto Capernaum.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: An argument a contrariis, although it runne like a probable reaſon, yet the ſame reaſon is not alwaies neceſſary For this kind of argumentation doth ſometimes deceiue. As for example: A man may kill him ſelfe, therfore a mā may make him ſelf a liue againe. This is no good argumēt.

Many other inſtances might be brought, but to auoyd tediouſnes they ſhalbe omitted. It cannot be denied, but that in puniſhments and paines ther is diuerſitye: yet it ſeemeth not, that the ſame likewiſe ſhould be in ioyes, bicauſe by our ill workes we deſerue paine, but by our good works we do not deſerue felicity. Therfore this reaſon a contrariis, is far diuers.

div.head: The fourth reaſon.
div.p: VVe ſhal be like vnto angels, but the angels haue diuers degrees and orders among them ſelues: Ergo we all ſhall haue diuers degrees and orders amongeſt our ſelues.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: The ſcripture doth graunt that the Angels haue now diuers orders and gouernmentes, bicauſe God doth vſe their miniſterye to conſerue the world and the church. But in the end all theſe principalities and powers ſhal be aboliſhed: nor we doo knowe after the daye of iudgement, whether ther ſhalbe any more diuers orders and degrees among angels concerning felicity.

Furthermore, they which graunt diuers orders in angels, do graunt that they do differ betwene them ſelues, ſpecie, or as they ſaye, proximo genere, which cannot be graūted of holy ſaintes, or of our ſpirites. Vvherfore the ſimilitude betwene vs and the angels, doth not in all pointes agree. For then al angels ſhould be taken to be of one kinde, and of one order. But of the orders of Aungels I haue ſpoken of largelye before in the Miſcellane Angelus.

div.head: The fift reaſon.
div.p: The ſede, which is ſowen in the ground, doth bring forth fruit, ſome thirty fold, ſome threſcore fold, ſome an hundred fold.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: This parable doth pertaine vnto the ſtate of this preſent life, bicauſe the word of God doth not bring forth fruit, nor take place in the godly hearers, like and after one manner.

div.head: The .6. reaſon.
div.p: In the parable of the talents, which the ſeruauntes did render vnto their Lord, ſome more, ſome fewer, may be proued, that the diuerſity of the gaine is recompenſed with diuers rewardes.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: This parable doth nothing proue this purpoſe. For he which vſeth wel the gifts of God, is made worthy to be placed ouer many, and graces and giftes are increaſed vnto him, and is made dayly more participante of the ſpiritual dowries of Gods ſpirite.

div.head: The .7. reaſon.
div.p: It is written in the Apocalips, that ſome do folow the Lambe, whether ſoeuer he goeth, which is not graunted vnto other.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: This place wyth other of the ſame booke is obſcure & darke, bicauſe the booke is ſayd to be ſealed, and is vnderſtand of very few.

And it appeareth not vnto vs, whether this allegacion doth appertaine vnto this preſent life, or to the life to come. VVe graunt, that they which be of a more pure life, maye enter and pearce to the vnderſtanding of Chriſtes miſteries. And on the other ſide, maye be taught, that wherſoeuer Chriſt is, there his faithful Miniſters ſhalbe. Vvherfore it
is promiſed not onelye to ſome, but alſo to all whiche ſerue Chriſte, that they may follow the Lambe.

div.head: The .8. reaſon.
div.p: He that ſhall do and teache men ſo, ſhall be called great in the kingdome of God.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: The kingdome of God in this place betokeneth the church militant, wher they are to be had in great price and eſtimation which doo teache well, and do thoſe thinges which they teach. Therfore this place maketh nothing for the diuerſitie of glories.

div.head: The .9. reaſon.
div.p: It is written in the latter epiſtle to the Corinthians: Qui parce ſeminat, parce metet. &c. He that ſoweth ſparely, ſhall reape ſparely, he that ſoweth in bleſsing, ſhall reape in bleſsing.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: This place pertaineth to ſpiritual fruites, to be receiued in thys lyfe. For they which be liberal in geuing almes do aboūd with ſpiritual goods, and God ſomtime doth geue vnto them riches more plentifully, that they might more largelye ſhewe their pitye and mercye vnto them that haue neede therof.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: As one ſtarre differeth from an other in glory, ſo ſhall the reſurrection of the dead be: Ergo ther is a difference and diuerſitye of gloryes in heauen.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: This compariſon of Paul doth not inferre nor proue that ther ſhould be diuerſity of glories, as the wordes following do import, wher it is ſaid: the body is ſowen in corruption, it ſhal riſe agayne in incorruption, it is ſowen in ignominy, it ſhall riſe againe in glory: where it appeareth that this diuerſity is to be taken onely betwene the body that is buried, and the body that ſhall riſe againe. Paule doth not conclude here any thyng of the difference of clarified bodies them ſelues, but betwene the bodies that are layd in the earth, and the bodies that ſhall ryſe againe. And this is a general compariſon, and not a particular. Therfore Paule ment nothing leſse in this place, then diuerſities of degrees in glorye, but onelye putteth the differences betwene the bodies, that we haue now, and the bodies that we ſhall haue then.

div.head: The .10. reaſon.
div.p: All the fathers and doctours, which euer wrote, be of this minde, that diuerſity and diuers degrees of glory is geuen to the ſaintes in heauen.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p:
As touching the fathers, it cannot be denied, but that they do confeſſe
and graunt differences of ioyes. But here onely is called in to queſtion, whether this aſſertion may be proued by the teſtimony of the holy ſcriptures?

Furthermore, they do not alwayes ſpeake one thing. For ſaint Hierome in his epiſtles, wher he commended the wydow, and ſemed to compare her vnto the virgin, ſaith, that he wyl not gladly graūt theſe diuerſities betwene the holy ſaintes, when not withſtanding he himſelfe is a ſtout defender of theſe differences.

div.head: The 11. reaſon.
div.p: If you wil not graunt diuerſity of ioyes, many will not be ſo earneſt and painefull to go forward, and to grow to vertue, but wil wax ſlothful and ſluggiſh.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: They which be not moued through faith of Gods word, and through hope of eternall felicity to do wel, will not be eaſily moued for the conſideration of theſe diuerſities. For if they ſhould do otherwiſe, they are rather to be counted hirelings, then the ſonnes of God.

To end, theſe authorities, proofes and aunſwers, are not here alledged vtterly to deny the differences of rewards. Here is onely ſayd that this opinion cannot be concluded out of holy ſcriptures. It maye be notwithſtanding, that when the ſaintes do record & remember, that God hath wrought by them many noble workes, doo perchaunce conceiue in them ſelues more delectation and ioy, then the other, which cānot repeate ſuch workes done by them. But that diſtinction of the ſcholemen which they fayne of certaine crownes, atque de praemio ſubſtantiali et accidentali, is moſt friuolous and fooliſh.

div.head: He ſhall, 11.
div.p: IT is written in Geneſis how God ſpake to the Serpent after this maner: Inimicitias ponam inter te, et inter mulierem, et inter ſemen tuum et inter ſemen eius. Ipſum conteret tibi caput. I wyll put enmity betwene thee and the woman, and betwene thy ſeede and her ſeede. He ſhal breake thy head. &c. In this ſentence the pronoune Ipſum is of diuers diuerſly vſed. For ſome do reade ipſum, other ipſe, and other ipſa. The Hebrues do read ipſum, referring it to ſemen.

Septuaginta do tranſlate 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ipſe, and then it is referred vnto Chriſt.

The commune tranſlation doth read ipſa, whervpon certain ſcolaſtical diuines refer it and expound it of the virgin Mary, who by mediatiō of her ſonne, ouercame Sathan. And ſo writeth Lyranus. Other refer it vnto the church. But here ye may ſee and lerne what great ignorance & negligence was in the popiſh Churche, and in the Doctours and wryters being of the ſame church.

The femine gender is put of them in ſtede of the maſculine or neuter They would neuer conſult the Hebrue or Greke bookes. They would neuer confer the latine tranſlations one with an other. And therfore by cō mon errour, this corrupt reding was receiued, that is to put ipſa for ipſū.

But it may be that they were deceiued by the likenes of the two hebrue letters, Vau and Iod, which be very like, ſauing that Vau is draw en a litle longer downward. Therfore wher the Hebrue hath Hu, which be tokeneth ipſe, or els ipſum, thei did read Hi, which ſignifieth ipſa. And by that meanes they might be deceiued.

But the truth is that ye muſt reade ipſe, or ipſum. If you reade ipſe, it hath relation vnto this Greke word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which is of one ſignificatiō with the word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . If you read ipſum, it muſt be referred to this word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . In the words of Moſes ther is no ambiguity, but concerning the ſenſe and meaning of the words, the interpreters of the holye ſcriptures do not agree. For many do take ſemen, the ſede, without queſtion or dout for Chriſt, as though it ſhould be ſaid, ſome man ſhalbe borne of the ſede of a woman, which ſhal wound the ſerpents head.
Their ſentence and iudgement might eaſily be allowed, but that they do wreſt this word ſemen to violently. For who wil graunt a nowne collectiue to be ſpoken of one onely man?
Alſo, as the perpetuity of diſcord and debate is noted betwene the Serpents ſede, and the womās ſede, ſo by continual courſe of ages victory is promiſed to the children of men.

Generally therfore ſome diuines do interprete ſemen, of the poſterity of Eue. But when experience teacheth that all the ſonnes of Adam become not the victours and ouercommers of the deuil, it is neceſſary that they come and flee vnto one head, that they may ſo finde, vnto whom the victory doth pertaine. So Paule doth deduce vs from the ſeede of Abraham vnto Chriſt.Gal. 3.

The ſenſe therfore is, that mankinde which Sathan endeuored to oppres ſhould haue the vpper hand. But that maner to ouercome & to haue the vpper hand, is to be marked, which is deſcribed in the ſcriptures. Sathan at his pleaſure hath led the children of men captiue in all ages, and doth continue the ſame woful triumph vnto this day, and therfore is called the prince of the world.Ioan 12. But bicauſe a ſtronger came from heauen, which ſhould ſubdue him, by that meanes it cam to paſse, that the whole church of God ſhould valiantly reſiſt him, as Paul ſaith to the Romanes Dominus breui conteret Sathanam ſub pedibus veſtris. Gap. 6. The Lord ſhortly ſhall beate downe Sathan vnder your feete. By the which woordes he doth ſignify that the vertue and power of beating downe Sathan, is diſperſed
and poured vpon all the faithful, and that is the common benediction and bleſsing of the whole church.
But here note one thing, that this is onely begonne in this world, and not finiſhed, bicauſe the Lord doth not crowne none but his approued champions and ſoldiours.
Furthermore, the image and maner of theſe thinges which are done from the beginning of the world, vnto the end of the ſame, is to be obſerued and marked.

The ſede of Sathan are al the wicked, as wel men as ſpirites. The ſede of the woman is Chriſt, with the whole body of his elect. And as enmities are betwene the Serpent and mankinde, ſo are they likewiſe betwene the ſede of Sathan and Chriſt, with his elect. For the generation of the wicked doth alwaies fight againſt the elect of God to deſtroy the good. But the elect ſhall at length eſcape ſtronger, through theyr heade Chriſt. Vvho by his death hath aboliſhed & vanquiſhed him which had empire and rule of death.

Caietanus alſo doth referre theſe woords Ipſum ſemen conteret caput tuum, vnto the elect of God, bicauſe euery elect doth treade vpon the heade of the Serpent, that is, vpon the office and propertye of the the deuill, prouoking vnto ſynne.

div.trailer: ¶ The end of the Miſcellanes of the third Prelection, of the ſecond Tome.

div.head: ❧ The fourth Prelection of the ſecond Tome.
div.p: IN our laſte leſſon I declared vnto you the minde of S. Peter vpon theſe wordes: Benedictus deus pater domini noſtri Ieſu Chriſti, &c. Bleſſed be God, euen the father of our Lord Ieſus Chriſt, which, according to hys aboundaunt mercy, hath begotten vs agayne vnto a liuely hope by the reſurrection of Ieſus Chriſt from the dead. Now, I entend, by Gods grace, to goe forward with more of the texte.

It followeth in Peter: Inheriditatem incorruptibilem et incontaminatam, et immarceſſibilem, conſeruatam in caelis in vobis, &c. That is. To an inheritaunce immortall, and vndefiled, and that fadeth not awaye, reſerued in heauen for you, which are kept by the power of God, through fayth, vnto ſaluation, which is prepared to be ſhewed in the laſte time.

The Apoſtle doth proſecute here all thinges with very due and Rhetoricall order. This hope of life (ſaith he) is happened vnto vs by the reſurrection of Chriſt. His death is made our lyfe, and he with hys reſurrection, hath rayſed vs from the eternall death, to which we were ſubiecte.

Cap. 6Saint Paule writeth to the Romaines. Si inſiti facti ſumus illi per ſimilitudinē mortus eius, nimirum et reſurrectionis participes erimus: for if we graffed with him to the ſimilitude of his death, euen ſo ſhal we be to the ſimilitude of hys reſurrection. And in an other place. If you be dead, your life is hidden with Chriſt in God.

In hereditatem, to an inheritaunce: As though he ſhoulde ſaye, in that Chriſt roſe agayne, he reſtored and recouered vnto vs that immortall inheritance which we had ſpent and loſte by our firſt parentes in paradyſe. Chriſt therefore taking the ſhape of a ſeruaunt doth reconcile vs to the father, and dyd agayne make vs coheires with him.

1. InheritāceThis inheritaunce is Incontaminata, vndefiled, that is: It neyther hath, nor can haue any ſuch filthines as the earthly inheritaunces haue, which make the ſoule vncleane by their abuſes, that the ſoule may not be ſeene at the day of iudgement adourned and decked with that wedding garment.

This heauenly inheritaunce is pure, and maketh vs to bee glorious, this inheritaunce fadeth not away, it feeleth no decreaſe. It can not be taken away of theues, it can not be conſumed of fier, it can not be troubled with any ſtorme.

But let vs aſke Peter here a queſtion, where is this inheritaunce? where is (I ſay) this wholeſome inheritaunce kept and preſerued for vs?2. Heauen. In caelis, in heauen, (ſayth Peter) as though he ſhould ſay: your names are written in heauen, you are receaued into the number of the electe: It followeth.

Erga vos, for you. This feaſt, this banquet, this inheritaunce in heauen is prepared for you which beleue in Chriſt: for vs, I ſay, which haue bene and ar poore, this inheritaunce is prepared, that we might be made ryche.

Saint Auſten hath for thys a goodly ſaying: Subiecit ſe, vt exaltaret te inclinauit ſe, vt ſuſciperet te, exinaniuit ſe in maieſtate, vt impleret te diuinitate: deſcendit vſ
que ad te, vt tu aſcenderes vſ
que ad eum. He did humble him ſelfe, that he myght exalte thee: He inclined himſelfe, that he myght take vp thee: He beriued himſelf of hys maieſtie, that he might repleniſhe thee with his diuinitie: He diſcended euen to thee, that thou ſhouldeſt aſcend euen to him. It followeth.

3. Vertue. 4. Hel. Qui virtute dei cuſtodimini per fidem ad ſalutem: Which are kept by the power of God through fayth vnto ſaluation. That is, we are kept by his word. For of our ſelues we be weake ſhepe, in whom there lyeth neither wiſedome nor power to defend our ſelues from the Wolfe. But how are we kept? Through faith (ſaith Peter) leaſt the gates of hell ſhould preuaile agaynſt vs in the time of aduerſitie.

div.head: Queſtio.
div.p: What doth it profit ſaluation and inheritaunce to be layd vp in ſtore for vs in heauen, when that we are toſte vp and down in this world, as it were in a troubleſome ſea? What doth it helpe, to conſtitute our ſaluation in a ſafe and quiet porte, when we are in daunger of a thouſand ſhipwrackes?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Peter doth here preuent ſuch obiections, when he teacheth vs to be kept here in this world by fayth in the middle of daungers, and ſo to approch vnto death, that, notwithſtanding, we may be ſafe vnder the cuſtodie of faith. But becauſe fayth oftentimes waxeth faint in this infirmitie of our fleſh, we may be alwaies doubtfull,5. To morow what ſhall chaunce vnto vs to morrowe, excepte God did here ſuccour and comfort vs.
The opinion of the papiſtes is moſt diabolicall, which doubteth of final perſeueraunce, becauſe we be vncertaine whether we ſhall be in the ſame grace and fauour to morrowe, as we be now.

But Peter doth not leaue vs ſo doubtfull: for he affyrmeth vs to be kepte of the power of God, that no doubt by the conſcience of our proper infirmitie ſhould trouble vs. Although we be infirme and weake, yet our ſaluatiō is not vnſtable, becauſe it is holden vp by the power of God. Therefore as we are defended by fayth: ſo fayth her ſelfe hath her ſtabilitie in the power of God, wherby we may be ſafe, not onely for the time preſent, but alſo for the time to come.

Saint Paule writeth, ſaying: Perſuaſus ſum, quòd ne
que mors, ne
que vita, Cap. 8. ne
que angeli. &c. I am perſwaded, that neyther death, nor life, nor angells, nor principalities, nor powers, nor things preſent, nor thinges to come, nor height, nor depth,6. Height nor depth. Cap. 1. nor any other creature ſhall be able to ſeperate vs from the loue of God, which is in Chriſt Ieſu our Lord.

Againe, to the Philippians: Hoc ipſum perſuaſus, quod qui cepit in vobis opus bonum, per faciet vſque in diem Ieſu Chriſti. I am perſuaded of this ſame thing, that he that hath begonne this good worcke in you, will perfourme it vntill the day of Ieſus Chriſt.

It followeth, ad ſalutem quae in hoc parata eſt &c. Vnto ſaluation whiche is prepared to be ſhewed in the laſt tyme. Which is as muche to ſay as this: Now your rewardes are hidden. And oftentimes they which ſeme to be in beſt caſe, are in the worſte, and they whiche ſeme to be in the worſte caſe, are in the beſt.

In this worlde there is a tyme to exerciſe and practiſe godlines. To the rewards to the ſayd exerciſe du, ether is a tyme preſcribed, which it behoueth vs not to preuente and to craue before tyme. Let it ſuffiſe vs, that eternal felicitie is laide vp in ſtore and in ſafetie for vs, which neither man nor deuel can take frō vs, ſo that faith faile vs not, by the which neglecting of worldly things we do whollie depēd of heauenly things. This doctrine doth greatly make to nouriſhe and ſuſtaine our hope. For the inheritaunce, to whiche we are appointed, is gotten and prepared from the beginning of the world, which as yet lieth hidden, ſhut vp, & ſealed. But within ſhorte time it ſhalbe opened & reuealed, that it may be plainely ſeen and felte. Therfore, while we be in this worlde, no truce, no tranquillitie or peace is to be hoped, but when we ſhall finiſhe this warfare like life, then that incorruptible crowne laide vp in heauen ſhalbe ſet vpon them whiche do ouercome by faith.
But when ſhall this be? when Peter? when I ſay ſhall it be geuen?7. Golden hilles. Thou ſheweſt many gay and noble thinges, thou promiſeſt golden hilles: but nothinge we ſee, nothing we feele.

Peter anſwereth: In tempore ſupremo: in the laſt time, that is, at the laſte day of Iudgement. Becauſe the inſtauratiō of all things is not to be looked for before. But in that tyme this crowne, this inheritaunce, theſe rewards ſhalbe reuealed and made open. And then ſhall we ſuſteine no labour, no affliction, no paſſions, but ſhal haue eternall reſt, wherof Chriſt gaue a taſte vnto his diſciples in the mounte Thabor. When Peter flowing with ioye ſaid vnto Chriſt: Domine, bonum eſt hic nos eſſe. O lord, it is good for vs to tarie ſtil here.

It foloweth: In quo exultatis nunc ad breue tempus afflicti in variis experimē tis ſi opus ſit: Wherin ye reioyce,8. Tētations. though now for a ſeaſon (if need require) ye are in heauines through manifold temtations.

Now, Peter buildeth vpon the foundation, which he hath layd, a noble edifice of patience, ſaying: in quo exultatis: in which you reioyce, that is, be glad, exalte, and reioice in the hope of this ſaluation laid vp in heauen. He doth not here onely prayſe them, but alſo exhorte, and comfort them. For he teacheth what fruict ſhal come vnto vs by the hope of this ſaluation laid vp in heauen, that is, ſpiritual ioye, by the whiche the bitternes of all euels & aduerſities is not onely mitigated, but alſo all ſadnes and heauines is vanquiſht and extinct. Therfore, if thou be a chriſtian and doeſt expecte this inheritaunce? thou muſt depende all and whollye
on this hope: ſo that thou contemne whatſoeuer thinges be in this worlde, and openlie profeſſe and confeſſe all the wiſdome, and all the holynes of this worlde to be vtterly nothing. Therfore none other thing is to be loked for here but to be condemned and perſecuted of the world. But yet (as Peter ſayth) ad breue tempꝰ for a ſhorte time, as though he had ſayd, you which now do wepe, the world reioyſing, ſhalbe in ſhort time filled with great ioy: you which now ſuffer aduerſity & afflictions remember, that they ſhall not continue long.

div.head: Notio.
div.p: Here ſemeth to be ſome repugnancie and contradiction while he ſayth, that the faythful which reioyce with gladnes, are alſo afflicted, ſadde and heauye, for theſe two be con • rary affectes. But the faythfull themſelues do know better by experimente, that theſe two contrarye affectes doo conſiſte together in them, than canne be expreſſed with wordes. For the faythfull are not ſtockes and blocks, nor haue not ſo put of humayn ſenſe and feling, but that they be touched with dolor and ſorow, but that they feare perils and daungers, but that they fele what a greuous thing pouerty is, and how ſharpe and hard perſecutions be, yea and furthermore do apprehend what tears,9 Peſtilence. what ſicknes, what cares, what coldes, what ſterility and barenneſſe, what peſtilence, what hunger doo chaunce in the whole life of man, and that aduerſity (which is thought to haue this day an ende) beginneth again to morrow. So that in this life be it neuer ſo long, there ſemeth little life or comfort. Of theſe euels the faythfull perceiue and feele heauines, but yet this heauines is ſo mitigat by faith, that the faithful notwithſtanding ceaſe not to reioyce: ſo that ſorow doth not hynder their ioy, but rather geue place vnto it. On the other ſide, althoughe ioye do ouercome ſadnes, yet it doth not vtterly aboliſh it, becauſe it doth not beriue vs of our humayne nature.

It foloweth, Si opus ſit: If nede require. This ſaying of Peter is ful of comfort, if the matter ſo requyre, if it do tend to our ſaluation, god will ſhortly fyniſh theſe afflictions and tentations.10. Aboue that For as Paule ſayth, fidelis deus, qui non ſinit nos tentari ſupra id quod poſsumus: God is faythful, which doth not ſuffer vs to be tempted aboue that we be able to beare. And God doth not afflicte and trouble vs, but for the beſt: Si opus ſit: If neede require. Peter putteth here the condition, for the cauſe, for he ſheweth that it is not without cauſe, that God doth ſo exerciſe & trye hys. For if he ſhould afflicte vs for no cauſe, it would be very grieuous to beare and to ſuffer. Peter therfore doth take here an argument of conſolation out of the counſell and decree of God: Not that the reaſon and cauſe may alway appeare vnto vs,11. If God will ſo. but that we ſhould be reſolued and fullie perſwaded, that it ought ſo to be, becauſe it pleaſeth God. And therfore Peter doth ſay: Si opus ſit, If nede requyre. Which in other words he doth after in the .3. chapter repeate, ſaying, Si ita velit deus, if God wil ſo. Which place doth make much againſt them, which laie croſſes and burthens vpon them ſelues,12. Hauing no nede. hauing no nede, that is, not looking for the ſentence and will of God. There be many which endeuour, as it were with certaine violence, to runne and to burſte into heauen by their workes and choſen croſſes: as Baſilius Magnus and Gregorius Nazianzenus did,13. Faſtings. who both gaue them ſelues to ſuch faſtinges, watchings and lying on the ground, thinking therby to enter into heauen, that they could not execute their paſtorall function and office. But God doth condemne ſuche workes. For theſe proper workes, which we do chuſe vnto vs of our own mind & choice, are nothing worth in the ſight of god. We ought to expecte and looke what god will put and lay vpon vs,14 Croſſes on our ſelues. that we walke and followe as he doth lead vs.

Therfore, we nede not to ſeke and to lay croſſes vpon our ſelues, but as Peter ſayth, Si opus ſit, that is, if the matter ſo require, which is: If god do appointe vnto thee that thou ſuffer, thē paciētly receiue the croſſe, and comfort thy ſelf with the
hope and expectation of that inheritaunce which is not temporall but eternall.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: Doth not Paule ſay: Si nos ipſos iudicaremeus, non diiudicaremura domino. 1. Cor. 11. If we would iudge our ſelues, we ſhould not be iudged of the Lord.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Paul doth not in this place ſpeake of the croſſe & outward afflictions, but of repentaunce, and of the right and due proofe of our ſelues, before we doo eate of the bread, and drincke of the cuppe of the Lordes table. The godlye and faythfull do preuente the iudgmente of god by repentaunce. And there is none other iudgment, by the whiche we maye obtaine abſolution and remiſſion before god, than franckelie and freelye to accuſe our ſelues, in the acknowledginge of our ſinnes.

It followeth: Quo ex ploracio fidei veſtrae, multo pretioſior auro quod perit &c. that the tryall of your faith, beinge muche more precious than golde that p • riſheth (though it be tried with fire) might be found vnto your praiſe and honor and glorie, at the appering of Ieſus Chriſt.15. Homaeoſis Peter doth here bringe in pulchram
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 an apte ſimilitude betwene gold and fire, and the croſſe and affliction.

The croſſe and diuerſe affl • ctions do bring to paſſe, that ſincere and pure faith may be knowen,16. Faith. from a counterfeit and feigned faith. And for that cauſe God doth ſo tempte vs, that our faith may be proued and made manifeſt to the worlde, and that by our example other maye be inuited and allured vnto faith alſo.

He bringeth in an argument a minoriad maius. For if gold,17 Gold. which is a corruptible mettall, is ſo much eſteemed of vs, that we wil haue it tried by fyre, that the worth and price therof may be better knowne of vs: What meruell is it, if God require the ſame proofe and trial in our faith, conſidering that the excellencie of our faith is ſo greatly regarded of God?

That which fyre is vnto golde, the ſame affliction is vnto the faithful.18. Fire. Golde is not loſt and periſhed by fyre, but proued and purged. So the faythfull are not loſt and deſtroied by afflictions, but are tried, and (as ye would ſay) broiled, that th • y may be ſincere and pure in the faith.
Faith is compared vnto gold, but fayth is much more noble then gold. For as gold is the moſt precious mettal in things mortall: ſo fayth doth moſt excell in things ſpirituall.
Gold is temporal, fayth is eternall: gold is tried two maner of wayes. Firſt when it is purged by fire from the droſſe.

Secondly when the goodnes therof is tried by iudgement. Both theſe maners of prouinge do moſt aptly agree vnto faith. For firſt when many dregges of incredulitie do remaine in vs, while they be (as you would ſay) ſodden in the fornace of God, by diuerſe afflictions, then the droſſes of our faith are purged, that it might be pure and cleane before God.
Secondly experimente and iudgement is taken of vs, whether it be a fained or a ſincere fayth.

When we come vnto fayth by the worde and hearyng of the goſpell, we are iuſtified and begin to be purged, but as longe as we be in this fleſhe, we can not eſcape throughlye clean. Therfore, God doth throwe vs into the middeſt of the fire, that is, into afflictions, ignominie, ſhame, and other incommodities, by the which we be daily more and more purged and tried, vntil death do come.
This purgation & mortification we can not obteine be any of our owne works. For how can an outwarde worke purifie and make cleane the inwarde harte?19. Booke of wiſedome.

Peter doth allude, here to diuerſe places of the ſcriptures: as the ſaying of the booke of wiſdom: tanquam aurum in fornace probauit electos dominus: God trieth the elect, as gold is tried in the fire.

Again, in the pſalmes it is written: thou O God haſt proued vs, thou haſte tried vs,Pſalm. 65 as ſiluer is tried. Thou haſt brought vs into the ſnare, and laid a ſtraite chaine vpon our loines. Thou haſt cauſed men to ride ouer our heads. We went into fire and water, but thou broughteſt vs out into a welthie place.

Chriſoſtome that golden doctour, hath for this matter of affliction, a golden ſaying. Talis eſt natura fidei, quanto magis vetatur: tanto magis accenditur. Virtus fidei in periculis ſecura eſt, in ſecuritate periclitatur. Quid enim alium ſic laxat vigorem fidei, ſicut tranquillitas longa? Suche is the nature of faith, that the more it is forbiddē, the more it is kindled and ſet forward. The power of faith is ſecure and ſafe, in the middle of perils and daunger, and in ſecuritie it is in perill and daunger. For what other thinge doth ſo looſe the force of fayth, as long ſecuritie and tranquillitie?
It followeth, In laudem gloriam & honorem in reuelationem Ieſu Chriſti: Vnto your praiſe and honour and glorie at the appearyng of Ieſus Chriſt.

Peter exhorteth them to perſeueraunce, and doth make an argument ab vtili: As cunning huſbandmen are wonte to foreſhew the corne & the rime, to gather the corne vnto them that do ſowe it: ſo Peter in this place doth not onely ſhewe the fruict and reward, which they ſhal receiue (which liue godly in Chriſt) but alſo the time of gathering and receiuyng the ſame fruict & reward. Not in this tyme (ſaith he) nor in this worlde, but when the ſonne of God ſhall appear in his maieſtie. Then the pacience of the godly afflicted, ſhalbe to their praiſe, then it ſhalbe to their honour, whē the wicked fal into fire, they ſhal enter into euerlaſting life.
It followeth: Quem quum non videritis, diligitis &c. Whome ye haue not ſeen, and yet loue, in whome nowe, though ye ſee him not, yet do you beleue and reioyce with ioye vnſpeakable and glorious.

Peter ſpeaketh theſe wordes of the energie,20. Fleſh. force, and ſtrength of faith, to declare and ſet forth the certaintie and aſſuraunce of the ſame. And doth make as it were a certaine Antitheſis betwene the fleſhe and fayth.
The fleſhe requireth experimēts, and doth leane to earthly and viſible things: But faith doth ſticke and cleaue in things heauenly and inuiſible.

Cap. 11.Paule ſaith to the Hebrues: Faith is the grounde of things which are hoped for, and the euidence of things which are not ſeen, that is, faith is occupied about thoſe thinges which do not appeare. And thoſe things be not earthlye, but heauenly, not viſible, but inuiſible, as the common ſaying is, vbi ratio habet experimentum, fides non habet meritum. Where reaſon hath experimente, their fayth hath no merite.

Sainct Ambroſe alſo writeth: Aufer argumenta, vbi fides quaeritur in ipſis gymnaſijs ſuis iamdudum dialectica taceat, piſcatoribus creditur non dialecticis. Wh • re there is any queſtions of fayth, there take awaye arguments and reaſons. Yea where faith is, let Logicke kepe ſilence in her own ſcholes, credit is geuen to fiſhers, not to Logicians.
Sainct Auſtin ſaith: Noli intelligere vt credas, ſed crede vt intelligas. Vnderſtande not that thou mayeſt beleue, but beleue that thou maieſt vnderſtande.

Chriſt ſaide to Thomas: becauſe thou haſte ſeen me Thomas, thou doeſt beleue, bleſſed are thoſe which haue not ſeen, and yet do beleue. So Peter here doth ſaye: when you haue not ſeen Chriſt with theſe corporal eyes conuerſant in this world, yet notwithſtandyng you do loue him: Therfore you are bleſſed.

But there is no loue without the knowledge of the thing loued. But you know by fayth, for fayth hath her eye, fayth hath her eare, yet ſpiritual, not carnall. By this meanes Chriſt is ſeene in the myſticall ſupper, whiche if it ſhould be furniſhed onely with cōmon bread and prophane wine, now it ſhould not be a myſticall ſupper, nor worthy to be called the ſupper of the Lorde. Now thoſe things which fayth doth comprehend, it doth truly comprehend. Therfore▪ when in the ſupper we
beholde and ſee the Lord by the eyes of faith, the Lord is truely preſent in the ſupper. I ſay truely, I ſay he is truely preſent as the nature of fayth requireth, and where other ſay he is preſent carnally, it is againſt the nature of faith. Fayth beleueth Chriſt to haue bene incarnate, to haue dyed in the fleſh, to haue riſen again, to haue aſcended into heauen, and to ſit at the right hand of the father, and from thence to come to iudge the quicke & the dead. Therfore concerning theſe thinges to be done in the worlde the faythfull doo not ſee, doo not touche, doo not eate Chriſt carnally, but ſpiritually. And this faith doth worke in the harts of the faithful, the loue aſwell of God as of our neighbour. Therfore Peter ſayth here: Quē quum non videatis, diligitis. Whom when you haue not ſene, yet you loue.

Paule ſayth to the Galathian: In Chriſto Ieſu ne
que circumciſio ne
que praeputium quicquam valet, ſed fides per dilectionem. Cap. 5. Neyther circumciſion nor vncircumciſion do any thing auayle, but fayth by loue.

Saint Iohn weighing and vewing the loue of the neighbour and of God, writeth: Si quis dicit, diligo deum, et fratrem ſuum odit, mendax eſt. If any man ſay, I loue God, and hateth his brother, he is a lyar: for he that loueth not hys brother whom he ſeeth, how can he loue God whom he ſeeth not? It followeth.

Credentes tamen exultatis gaudio ineffabili et glorificato: yet do you beleue and reioyce with ioye vnſpeakeable and glorious. Here doth Peter adde the fruite of truſt and fayth in Chriſt & ſemeth to ſpeake after this manner: You do fele peace and ioye in your harts with moſt ſwete tranquillitie of conſcience more pleaſantly, then I can expreſſe with words. This ioye is an vnſpeakeable ioye, not vulgar, not common, but a glorified ioye, that is, it agreeth for the moſt part with that eternall ioye which is to come.

The ioyes of the world are diſturbed by miſfortunes and afflictions, and are fraile and fal away, but the ioy of fayth is not onely not diſturbed by miſfortunes, and by the croſſe of perſecution, but is made perfecte more and more. And when the ſtormes of aduerſities do wax raging and fierce, then is fayth moſt cleare.
All the godly being ſenſed with the ſtrength of fayth and pacience, do conteine all the whole world and the tyrannie therof.

Let vs heare what Paule ſayth: Who ſhall ſeperate vs from the loue of God?Rom. 8 Shall tribulation, or anguiſhe, or perſecution, or famine, or nakednes, or perill, or ſworde? As it is written, for thy ſake are we killed al the day long. We are counted as ſhepe of the ſlaughter. Neuertheles in all theſe thinges we are more then conquerours, through hym that loued vs. For I am perſwaded that neither death nor life, nor angels, nor principalities nor powers, nor things preſent, nor things to come, nor height, nor depth, nor any other creature ſhall be able to ſeperate vs from the loue of God, which is in Chriſt Ieſu our Lord.

Diocleſian the Emperour a moſt ſharpe & cruell perſecutour of the chriſtians, when he knewe that one Peter one of his Chamberleines had embraced the faith of Chriſt, minding to pull him againe from that fayth, cōmaunded hym to be beaten with plummettes of lead, and with ſharpe yron nayles, when Peter, notwithſtand theſe tormentes, did ſtand ſtoutly and couragiouſly: with a pleaſaunt and merie countenaunce: he commaunded his body to be rubbed with ſalte and vinegar, and him to be brought out naked, and to be racked and ſtretched forth vppon an yron grate, and with a ſofte fire to be burned, that his tormentes might increaſe more and more.
But what countenaunce he had in the beginning of his tormentes, the ſame he kepte in the ende. It foloweth.

Reportantes finem fidei veſtrae, ſalutem animarū veſtrarum, receiuing the end of your faith euen the ſaluation of your ſoules. That is,21. End of our fayth. by faith loue & ioy in Chriſt Ieſu, you ſhall obtaine that eternal glorie, which is your ſaluation: you muſte enter into the glorie of God by many tribulations. Therfore faith onely is not certaine, but the rewarde anſwering to the ſame is alſo moſt certaine

Sainct Paule ſaith: I am appointed a preacher of the goſpell, and an Apoſtle, and a teacher of the Gentils,2. Tim. 1. for the which cauſe I alſo ſuffer theſe things, I am not aſhamed, for I know whome I haue beleued, and I am perſuaded that he is able to kepe that whiche I haue committed vnto him againſt that daye.

Alſo in an other place he ſaith. Bonum certamen certaui &c. I haue foughte a good fight,2. Tim. 4 and haue finiſhed my courſe: I haue kept the faith. For henſforth is layd vp for me the crowne of righteouſnes whiche the Lord the righteous iudge ſhall geue me in that daye. This life and whatſoeuer pertaineth to this body, are great impediments that our ſoule can not applie it ſelfe to the contemplation and cogitation of the ſpiritual life to come.

The Apoſtle Peter doth ſet forth here with moſt earneſt ſtudie and care this ſpirituall life, this glorie and felicitie to be had in remembraunce at all tymes, & doth teach that we nede to paſſe and care for nothing. So that we may bear away the end of our faith which is the ſaluation of our ſoules. It foloweth.

De qua ſalute ex quiſierunt & ſcrutati ſunt prophetae &c. Of the which ſaluation the Prophetes haue inquired and ſearched, whiche prophecied of the grace that ſhould come vnto you, ſearchynge when or what time the ſpirit which teſtified before of Chriſt whiche was in them, ſhould declare the ſuffrings that ſhould come vnto Chriſt, and the glorie that ſhuld folow vnto whome it was reuealed, that not vnto them ſelues, but vnto vs they ſhould miniſter the things which are now ſhewed vnto you by them whiche haue preached vnto you the goſpell by the holy goſt ſente down from heauen, the which things the Angels deſire to behold.

Peter in theſe wordes doth confute and refell theſe whiche iudged the Prophetes and their writings to be geuen onely to the people of the old Teſtament,22. People of t e old teſtament. and to pertaine nothing vnto them, whoſe obiection Peter here doth diſſolue, as though he ſhould ſay.

The miſteries of our ſaluation, were reuealed vnto the Prophetes for that end that they ſhould be knowē and made open, not onelye to the prophetes them ſelues, and to them which were of their tyme, but alſo they wroughte for our felicitie and ſaluation, that we myghte be learned and inſtructed of them as of ſchol-maiſters and teachers.

Cap. 15.Sainct Paul to the Romains ſaith: Quaecunque ſcripta ſunt, in noſtram doctrinā ſcripta ſunt &c. Whatſoeuer things ar writen afore tyme, are written for our lerning, that we through pacience and comforte of the ſcriptures might haue hope. And Paule himſelfe pleading his cauſe afore Agrippa ſaith:23. Agrippa. I teache nothing but that which the Prophets and Moyſes taught before. And the ſame things which were written and done after the prophetes, of the Apoſtles, came of one and the ſelf ſame ſpirite.

All thoſe things ſaith Peter whiche were before ſhewed of the prophets, are now declared by me and my other felowe Apoſtles to be fulfilled in Chriſt. And this declaration was done by none other authour,24. Penthecoſt then by the holye ghoſte comming from heauen in the daye of Penthecoſt.
De qua ſalute exquiſierunt & ſcrutati ſunt prophetae: of the which ſaluation the Apoſtles haue inquired and ſearched.

He abſolueth in theſe woordes two thinges. For he intreateth of the veritie and certainty of our faith,25. Feare. that the afflicted ſhould not feare that they ſuffred for an ill cauſe or an il doctrine. But he teacheth by prophecies & examples of Chriſt, that there is no entrie into bleſſednes, but by aduerſities and affliction.

And that which Peter ſaith here. (The Prophets haue required & ſearched) it pertaineth not ſo much vnto their writinges & doctrine, as to their priuat & earneſt deſire wherwith they burned to ſee chriſt (as Chriſt writeth in Luke) multi reges & prophetae voluerūt videre quae vos videtis, Cap. 10. & non viderūt. Many kings and prophetes would haue ſeen thoſe things. &c.

div.head: Quaeſtio
div.p: Peter ſaye the fathers to haue ſoughte it, as though they had not obteyned that thinge which at thys tyme is offred and geuen vnto vs.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Saluation is taken here for manyfeſtation which was geuen at the tyme of his comminge, when he which was promiſed before, was then verilie and corporallie exhibite and geuen, when the prophetes had but a litle taſte of the grace wroughte by Chriſte, not concerninge the ſubſtaunce therof, but touchinge the manner of reuelation, they did not without cauſe enquire, ſearche, and with wiſhes deſired Chriſte preſentlie to be geuen them.
When Simeon after he had ſene Chriſt with a quiet and peaceable mynde, did prepare him ſelfe vnto death, he ſheweth that before that, he was vnquiet & carefull. It followeth.

Scrutantes ad quem aut ad cuiuſmodi temporis articulum &c. ſearchinge when or at what tyme, he dothe now note the maner of their inquiſition, for the difference of the lawe and the goſpell was as it were a certayne vaile put betwene, that they could not loke ſo nerely vpon thoſe thinges which were ſet out to oure eies. Nor it was mete the ful lighte to ſhine as it were in the midde daye, when Chriſte beinge the ſonne of righteouſnes was yet abſent. And when they daylie deſired redemption to haſten that they might ſee it: yet that their deſire did not make them vnpacient, but they did paciently ſuſteyn how long it pleaſed god to deferre the ſame.

Peter dothe not ſaie, that the prophetes did ſearche by their owne ſenſe and laboure what tyme the kingdome of Chriſte ſhoulde come, but did applye all their ſtudie and endeuoures to the reuelation of the ſpirite.26. Sobriety of inquiring. And by this example they teache a certayne ſobritie of inquiringe and learninge. For they wente no further then the ſpirite did leade them. And verilie there ſhould be none ende nor meane of the curioſitie of man, vnleſſe the ſpirite of god ſhould rule and ſtaye our wittes, to deſire to learne none other waye than of the ſame ſpirite. It followeth: Qui in illiserat ſpiritus. The ſpirite whiche was in them. By theſe wordes he dothe ſignifie that the prophetes were indued and beautified with the ſpirite of intelligence, not after a common maner, but larglie and aboūdantly. And this is a great praiſe of their doctrine, that it was the teſtimonie of the holie ghoſte.

Well, to drawe to an ende, becauſe tyme calleth awaye, I will goe to the clauſe and ſenſe of this preſent texte, which is this. In quam deſiderant angeli proſpicere: or as ſome reade in quae deſiderant proſpicere: whom or which things the angels deſire to beholde. In the greeke it is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. in quae, that is thoſe thinges which were ſhewed before of the prophetes, and afterwarde preached by the apoſtles.

The text might eaſilie be depraued to put 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Nor Peter here doth meane of the ſpirit of ye prophets (which the angels deſire to behold) but doth ſet forthe the maieſtie of the goſpell which the angelles do reuerence and honoure.
Beda doth interprete it of Chriſte glorified, and ſaith alſo that it may be taken and vnderſtande of the holie ghoſt, ſente downe vpon the earthe.
Irenaeus expoundeth this place of the promiſes of the prophetes which Chriſt comminge into this worlde did accompliſhe and fulfill.Lib, 4. ca. 67

In quae angeli deſiderant proſpicere, the whiche thinges the angels deſire to beholde. Here is a meruelous greate praiſe of the goſpel, whiche conteyneth the treaſure of wiſedome, as yet concealed and hidden from the angels: as thoughe Peter ſhoulde ſaie, it is no meruaile if the prophetes deſired to ſee thinges done by the vnſpeakable counſell of God, ſeinge that the angels had ſo ardent a deſire to ſee the perfection and accompliſhment of the ſame.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p:
It is neither mete nor reaſon that thoſe thinges ſhoulde be open and knowne
vnto vs which are conceled from the angels, who do alwayes ſee the face of god, and are miniſters in the churche to be gouerned, and adminiſtratours of al good thinges done in the churche.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Suche thinges be opened vnto vs as it were in the glaſſe and ſpeculation of the word, not that our knowledge is counted higher or greater then the knowledge of the angels.27. Glori be to god. Luke 1. Ephe. 5. Peter onelie vnderſtandeth in theſe wordes thoſe thinges to be promiſed vnto vs, the accompliſhment and performance wherof the angels deſire to ſee. And therfore when theſe thinges began to be don, the angels not without great ioye did ſinge, gloria in excelſis deo, glorie be to god on high.

Furthermore ſaincte Paule ſaith, that when the Gentiles were called, the meruelous wiſdome of god began to be knowen to the angles, for this was a merye & pleaſant ſpectacle and ſight vnto them, that Chriſte did gather the whole world, ſo manie yeares loſte and alienate from the hope of life, vnto his bodie, that is, the churche.

But howe muche more will they meruell at the higheſte and chiefeſt preſidente of gods iuſtice, goodnes, and wiſdome, when the kingdome of Chriſt ſhalbe accompliſhed? The citezens of the whiche kingdome, god the lorde and ruler of angels make vs, through the force of the death of his ſonne Ieſus Chriſt, to whome with the holy ghoſt be al honour and glorie nowe and for euer. Amen.

div.head: Hic ſequuntur Miſcellanea praelectionis quartae ſecondi Tomi,
Inheritaunce. 1.
div.p: IT may be demaunded, whether this inheritance ſhalbe geuen to the ſoule immediatly after our death: or whether it ſhalbe deferred vnto the laſt day, and whether the ſoules in the meane times do ſleepe, and then this inheritaūce be geuen both to body & ſoule, whē they be ioined together, and not before.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: 1. ep. cap. 13.Paule writeth to the Corinthians: Tunc videbimus eum facie ad faciem: then we ſhal ſe him face to face, al the diuines do ſay, that this aduerbe, tunc, being an aduerbe of time, doth ſignifie furthwt after death, that the ſoule being loſed from the bodie, ſhal haue furthwt the fruition of the gloriouſe ſight of God.

But Ireneus would in no wiſe graunte that to be true, before the day of Reſurrection, and doth ſay, that it is the doctrine of heretikes to perſwade them ſelues, that they ſhal aſcend into heauen, and to be inhaūced to the ſight of the father before the general reſurrection of the dead. He would haue vs, & ſaith that we ought, to ſuffer thoſe things which chriſt himſelfe did put in experience: who was not ſodenly and ſtraight way
raiſed from death, nor did aſcend immediatly vnto his father, but after his reſurrection ſaid vnto Marie: noli me tangere, quia non dum aſcēdi ad patrem meum: touch me not, for I haue not yet aſcended to my father: Nor it is mete (ſaith Ireneus) that the diſciple ſhould be aboue the maſter. Therfore, as Chriſt did not ſtraight waye after his death aſcend into heauen: ſo ought we to expecte and looke for the reſurrection of the dead, before we aſcend into heauen.

div.head: Confutatio.
div.p: This collation betwene Chriſt and vs is not generallye true. For we graunt, that we ought to conforme our ſelues vnto Chriſt. But in euery part the collatiō is not to be admitted. For Chriſt did many things, which it is not neceſſarie for to do.

It was thre daies or Chriſt did riſe, becauſe he would declare the veritie of his death. And he aſcended not before 40 dayes, that his reſurrectiō might appeare more certaine: in the which time he did eate & drink with his diſciples, and did offer himſelf to be touched of them for the cō firmatiō of their faith. But when it behoueth vs not ſo to do, nor any neceſsitie doth ſo exacte of vs, there is no impediment, but that oure ſoules may aſcend into heauen, immediatly after their ſeparation frō the bodye.

It is true, that the dtſciple ought not to be aboue the maſter: but ſhall we therfore gather, that what ſoeuer Chriſt ſuffred, we ought to ſuffer the ſame? He was called Belzebub: doth it folow therfore that we ſhuld be ſo called? He was offred vpō ye croſſe, and did hang betwen ij. theefes, is it therfore requiſite that we ſhould do the like? No, it foloweth not.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: It is written in the Apocalips, that the ſoules of them whiche were ſlaine for Chriſts ſake do crie: how long, O Lord, will it be,Cap. 6 ere thou do reuenge the bloud of them that dwel vpon the earth? Here you maye ſee, that the ſoules of the ſaincts be not in heauen, but do lye vnder the altar, and ſeeme to lye a ſleepe.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: They are ſaide here to crie and to haue a meruailous earneſt requeſt and deſire, but to crie, and ſo feruētly to pray, is not to lie a ſleepe. Vvhite robes were geuen vnto them, that is, they haue receyued parte of theyr felicitie, which is the ioye of the ſoule. And it was ſaid vnto them, that they ſhoulde reſt for a litle ſeaſon, vntil their felow ſeruantes and theyr brethern that ſhould be killed euen as they were, wer fulfilled. And thē, that is, after the daye of the general reſurrection, they ſhall haue the abſolute and conſummate glorie, both of body and ſoule.

div.head: Obiectio.Cap. 11
div.p:
Sainct Paule in the epiſtle to the Hebrues (when he had nombred
the fathers of he olde Teſtamēt, which were noble and valiant in faith) ſaith, that they haue not receiued the promiſſe, God prouidyng a better thing for vs, that they without vs, ſhould not be made perfect.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: VVe graunt in deede, that they haue not receiued the perfection and conſummation of the promiſe, or of this inheritaunce. For they looke for the reſurrection whiche we ſhal haue altogether.

Other expound this place after this ſorte: They had not ſuche cleare light of Chriſt as we: for they loked for that which we haue. Therfore, it were ſhame for vs, if at leaſt we haue not as great conſtancie as they hadde.
¶ Reaſons out of the ſcripture to proue that the ſoules ſleepe not.

Chriſt a litle before his death ſaid to the theef: This daye thou ſhalte be with me in Paradiſe. Theſe wordes, this day, do euidentlie declare, that his felicitie ſhould not be proroged vnto the laſte day.

Paule writeth to the Philippians, that he wiſhed to be looſed out of this worlde, and to be with Chriſt: for he doubted not that to be profitable for him. This his deſire ſhould not haue ben ſounde and good, if his ſoule ſhoulde ſlepe.

The hiſtorie of the riche man and Lazarus, doth proue that the ſoule after this life doth in no wiſe ſlepe, but to be either in ioy or in paine. And where the aduerſaries do ſaye, it to be a parable, and therfore to make nothing againſte them: I aunſwere, that many of the fathers do ſaye it not to be a parable, but an hiſtorie, as Gregorie and Hierome. And Tertullian goeth ſo farre, that he iudgeth the rich man to be Herode, Eleazar, Iohn Baptiſte. Chriſoſtome, and Auguſtine do affirme it to be a parable.
Salomon ſaith: duſte ſhall returne vnto earthe, from whence it came, and the ſoule ſhal returne vnto God which made him. If it returne again vnto God,Eccle. hiſtor. Lib. 4. it ſleepeth not
Policarpus which floriſhed in the Apostles time, when he went to be burned for the confeſsion of the faith of Chriſt, declared that he ſhoulde that daye be preſent before God in ſoule.

Chriſt ſaid that it was writen, that he ſhould be the God of Abraham, Iſaac, & Iacob: & further added, that he is the God of the lyuing, not of the dead. And if they do liue, they muſt needes do ſomwhat, that is, they muſt know God, and loue him.
Nor the ſcripture doth allowe their ſentence, when it ſaith, them that be dead to ſleepe.

This phraſe is applied vnto the bodye, which after death is ſayd to
ſleepe, becauſe it ſhal riſe againe. And by this phraſe the old writers affirmed churchyards to be the places appointed for burials, as though you would ſaye, places to ſleepe in. And therefore they bee called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .

div.head: Heauen. 2.
div.p: HEauen is called in the Hebrue, Schamaim: which is a worde cō pound of, Scham, and maim. And it hath his appellation of his waterie ſubſtance. For, maim betokeneth waters. It hath ye form of the duall nombre, for the two waters, that is, thoſe waters whiche are aboue the firmament, whiche be called, aquae ſuperiores, and the waters which be vnder the firmament, which be called aquae inferiores.

And note here, that both the greeke worde, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and the latin word, coelum, are put in the plurall nomber in the Lords prayer, becauſe that this Hebrue worde Schamaim hath no ſingular nomber. And therfore the greeke and latin tranſlation is put plurallye. Vvhere the Hebrue ſaith Schebaſchamaim, the greke hath, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , the latin hath: qui es in caelis.

Heauen in greeke is called, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , quaſi
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , as ſainct Ambroſe writeth in his Examerō. And it doth come ab
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which betokeneth to ſe: becauſe heauen is cleare to be ſeene, and not thicke, as the water and the yearth is. Philo in his boke de mundo, doth deduce it of this worde 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , whiche betokeneth a limite, a marke, a bounde: becauſe that heauen is the vttermoſt bounde of all the ſuperiour bodies.

Heauen is called in latin, coelum, which cometh of the verbe caelare, whiche betokeneth to couer: becauſe heauen couereth all the inferior things. Other (as ſainct Ambroſe) would haue it called caelum, a coelare, to graue: becauſe the ſtarres ſeeme to be engraued in it. Varro doth cal it caelum quaſi
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. cauum, hollowe.

The philoſophers do ſaye, that there be x. heauens: wherof ſeuen haue the names of the planets, as of:
Saturnus.
Iupiter.
Mars.
Sol.
Venus.
Mercurius.
Luna.

The eight heauen is called caelum ſy dereum, ſiue ſtellatū, the ninth they called caelum aqueum, vel cryſtallynū: not of coldneſſe, but of clearneſſe: becauſe by that the ſtarres did clearely appeare and ſhine. The tenthe they called primum mobile. But the eleuenth heauen, whiche is the place of the bleſſed ſpirites, the heathē Philoſophers knew not.

This heauen the diuines do call caelum empy reum, not of heate, but of
brightnes: becauſe it doth excell all the other heauens in brightnes and ſhinynge.

Becauſe I haue made mention here of certaine heauens, I thought it expedient to geue a litle note her of that place of ſainct Paul, where he ſaith, that he was taken vp into the third heauen, whiche of diuerſe is diuerſely taken.
The ſcholaſticall diuines do ſay, that heauē is takē three maner of wayes.
Firſt, it ſignifieth thoſe things that be vnder the ſoule, ſecondly, thoſe thinges that be in the ſoule, thirdly, thoſe thinges that be aboue the ſoule.
Vnder the ſoule are all bodies and corporall thinges, as S. Auſten writeth. So we may take and make to be three heauens, Videlicet.

p.hi: Aereum. Sydereum. Empyreum.

div.p: Vnto the whiche laſt the Apoſtle was ſayd to be rapt and taken, not to be or remaine there, for thē he ſhould haue knowne whether he had ben there in the body, or out of the body.

Damaſcen ſaith, that the Apoſtle was taken aboue the eight Sphere, that he might clearely ſee thoſe thinges which are aboue the whole corporall nature. If you take heauen for thoſe thinges which be in the ſoule, thē heauen betokeneth ſome hie matter or knowledge, whiche ſurmounteth and excedeth the naturall knowledge of man.

They ſaye alſo, that there is triplex viſio, that is, three maner of viſions. Firſt a corporall viſion, by the whiche we ſee and know ſpiritual bodies. Secondly, a viſion imaginarie, by the which we ſee and knowe the ſimilitudes and likeneſſes of bodies. Thirdly, an intellectuall viſ • on, by the which we know the natures of things in them ſelues. If theſe viſions be after the naturall maner (that is to ſay, if I ſee any ſ • nſible thing, if I ſee by imagination any thinge that was ſeene before, if I vnderſtand any thing by phantaſie) all theſe viſions can not be called caelum. But then anye of theſe viſions is called Caelum heauen, when it is aboue the naturall facultie and power of mannes knowledge. As for example: If thou ſee anye thinge with thy corporall eyes aboue the facultie of nature,Daniel 5. ſo arte thou rapte and taken vnto the firſte heauen, as Balthazar was rapte and taken, when he ſaw the hand of a man writynge vpon a wall. But if thou be lifte vp and taken by imagination or ſpirite, to knowe or ſee any thyng ſupernaturally, then art thou rapte and takē vnto the ſecond heauen:Act. 10. as Peter was rapte and taken when he ſawe the ſheete ſente downe from heauen.
But if any man do ſee things intelligible, and the natures of them not by any ſenſe or phantaſie, then he ſhould be takē vp vnto the third heauē.

And here is to be noted, that to be taken vp to the firſt heauen, is to be alienate from the corporall ſenſes. Vvherupon when none can
be fully and wholy abſtract and drawen from the corporal ſenſes, it can not be ſaid, that any man is taken vp ſimpliciter, vnto the third heauen, but ſecundum quid: For as much as it chaūceth, that a mā ſomtime is ſo intent and bent vnto one ſenſe, that he is vtterly abſtract and taken frō the act and vſe of the other ſenſes.

To be rapt and taken vnto the ſecond heauen, is when any is alienate & takē from his ſenſe, to ſee & behold things by imagination. And ſuch viſions are wont to be done in extaciſes and traunſes: as Peter was in a traunce, when he ſaw the linnen cloth come downe from heauen.

But Paule was rapte and taken vnto the third heauen, becauſe he was ſo alienate from his ſenſes, and ſo inhaunced aboue all corporall things and viſions, that he ſaw things intelligible, ſimplye, purelye, and plainly, euen after that maner as the angels, & the ſoules ſeperate from the body, doo ſee: yea and (that which is more) did ſee God by eſſence,In Gen. 12. as Saint Auſten doth expreſly write.
Nor it is probable, that Moſes the miniſter of the old teſtament vnto the Iewes, ſhould ſee God: and that Paule the Miniſter of the new teſtament vnto the Gentiles, ſhould be voide of the ſame gift.
Theſe woordes with manye other diuiſions and diſtinctions writeth Thomas Aquinas.In 2. Cor. 12.

Caietanus did call that third heauen the higheſt place of all: becauſe in the ſcripture ther is mencion made of three heauens. The loweſt is coelū aereum wher the foules of the ayre are. In the middeſt is coelum ſydereū, of the which mencion is made in the beginning of Geneſis, Et poſuit eas in firmamento coeli and he hath ſet them in the firmament of the heauē. The third and the higheſt is, wher be all the waters that are aboue the heauen, wherof the ſcripture maketh much mencion, which we doo call coelum aqueum, and the Philoſophers call it primum mobile. But Empyreum caelum, which the latter writers do ſpeake of, is not mencioned in any place of the ſcripture.
Saint Auguſtine diſputeth, whether by this third heauen we muſt vnderſtand Paradiſe.

Lyranus affirmeth this third heauen to be the ſame that Paradiſe is, whom ſome of the later writers do follow. But the taking vp of Paul is to be vnderſtanded twoo manner of wayes, that is: he was rapt vnto the third heauen, that he might ſee the glory of God, and the glory of Chriſt raigning in heauen. And he was taken vnto Paradiſe, that is, vnto the ſeate and place of the bleſſed ſpirites, Patriarches, and prophets, to the end that he might not onely ſee whether he himſelfe ſhoulde come after death, but alſo that hee might heare the miſteries of God, whereby he might returne the better inſtructed and prepared to his Apoſtleſhip.
Other diuines do ſay, that numerus ternarius, the number of three is put of Paule, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , for the higheſt and most perfect ſight.
This word, Caelum, in the ſcripture is taken many wayes. Firſt it is taken for that firmament wherin the ſtarres are ſet.

Secondly, it is vſed and taken for the middle region of the aire, wher the windes and cloudes be,Pſal. 149. as in the pſalmes: which couereth the heauen with cloudes, and prepareth raine for the earth.
Thirdly, it is taken for the throne and ſeate of God, as: The Lorde hath prepared his ſeate in heauen.Pſal. 103.
Fourthly, it is taken for God, as in Daniell: After yt thou ſhalt know, that the heauens haue the rule.Cap▪ 4.
Fiftly, it is vſed and taken in the plurall number for the Apoſtles, as: Ca • lienarrant gloriam Dei. The heauens declare the glory of God.

div.head: Vertue. 3.
div.p: THis word, virtus, vertue, is of doubtful ſignification: for there be two words in Greke of diuers ſignifications, which are tranſlated in Latine into this word virtus.
The one of the Greke wordes is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which doth ſignifie vertue, as it is oppoſite and contrary to vice.

The other word is, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which ſignifieth alſo virtutem, but as it is oppoſite and contrary vnto infirmitye and weakenes. And ſo 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , in Greke, and virtus in Latin doth betoken power, might and ſtrength.
pſal. 45. Virtus ſometime is vſed and put for ſtrength & power, as Deus adiutorium noſtrum, & virtus noſtra. God is our help, and our ſtrength.

Alſo it is taken for maieſty, authority, and power. It is alſo put and vſed for iuſtice,1. Cor. 4. innocency, and faith, as Non in ſermone eſt regnum dei, ſed in virtute: The kingdome of God is not in word, but in power.

Sometime it is taken for the hoſt & furniture of heauen, as the ſtars & light,Pſal. 148 as in the pſalme: Laudate eum omnes virtutes eius, praiſe him all his army.
