Finally, the holy ghoſt is called virtus dei, the power of God, becauſe it maketh perfect, and finiſheth all thinges. As Chriſt is the word of God, by which althings are made.

div.head: Hell. 4.
div.p:
HEl is called in Greke 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which is called of the Latines Pluto, Orcus, Tartarus, Infernus. The Greke word is written with an aſpiration, although it be compounded ab α priuatiua particula, &
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , id eſt videre, to ſee, as though you would ſay, a deepe place vnder the earth, darke, and without light. It is called in the Hebrue Scheol, & it is written with Vau holem, although ſomtime it is red without Vau. It ſignifieth (as ſome men do ſay) a pit, a graue, death it ſelfe, the ſtate of the dead, hel, & the place of the damned ſpirites. And it is ſo called wt the Hebrues, becauſe all heauy thinges do go and tend downward, It cannot
be ſatiſfied, as in the prouerbs in this verſe: Tria ſunt, quae non ſaturātur et quartum quod nunquam dicit, ſufficit: infernus, et os vuluae, et terra quae non ſatiatur aqua, ignis vero nunquam dicit. Ther be three things that wyll not be ſatiſfied, yeo foure that ſay not, it is inough: the graue, and the baren wombe, the earth that cannot be ſatiſfied with water, & the fire that ſaith not, it is inough. And ſo this word Scheol, ſeemeth to come of this radical Schaal, which ſignifieth (when it is referred to the perſon) to demaund, to conſult: but if it be referred to any thing or matter, then it ſignifieth to aſk, & to craue. And in that ſignification Scheol cōmeth of Schaal. It is taken for a graue in the boke of the kings, wher it is ſayd of Dauid againſt Ioab vnto Salomon: Non ſinas deſcendere camtiom eius pacificè ad ſepulchrum: Let thou not his hoare head go downe to the graue in peace.

It is alſo vſed for the place wher damned ſpirites are, as in the Pſalmes: Si aſcendero in coelum tu ecce ibi es: ſi deſcendero ad infernum, ecce ades: If I aſcende into heauen, thou art ther: if I deſcend into hell, thou art there alſo.

Scheol is taken ſometime for the horrible diſmay of the minde, and for the feeling of the wrath of God, and for the taſte (as it were) of the infernal paines for ſinne. Such agonies the holy ſaintes did often feele in them ſelues in this life: in ſomuch that they thought them ſelues to be reiected of God, and to be deſtitute of al grace and helpe. Such kinde of agony Chriſt felt vpon the croſſe, when he cried: O God my God, why haſt thou left me?

Hell in this ſignification is very frequent in the ſcriptures, as in Samuel: Dominus mortificat, & viuificat, deducit ad infernum, et reducit. The Lord doth mortify and make a liue againe, bringeth downe to hell, and bringeth vp againe.

Alſo in the pſalmes. Circumcinxerunt mefunes mortis, et anguſtiae inferni apprehenderunt me. The ſnares of death haue compaſſed me, and the grefes of hel caught me, when I found trouble and ſorow. Diuers do diuerſly expound this verſe of the pſalme: Quoniam non relinques animam meam in inferno. For thou ſhalt not leaue my ſoule in hell. Some do take infernus, in this place, for the graue: ſome for the ſtate of the dead, ſome for horrible ſorrow in mynd, ſome for hel it ſelfe. So that this prouerbe may be verified: Quot capita, tot ſenſus, how many heades, ſo many wyttes.

But becauſe I haue made mēcion of this matter, I wil recite the iudgements of the old fathers, as wel of the Latinists, as of the Grecians, how they take this clauſe: Non relinques animam meā in inferno: thou ſhalt not leaue my ſoule in hel, and afterwarde I will declare the mindes of the
later writers. And when I haue done, I will ſubmit my ſelf to the iudgement of the catholike and Apoſtolicke church, which I would wyſhe all Chriſtians to do.

div.head: ¶ Patres eccleſiae occidentalis.
div.p: Firſt I wil begin with the doctors of the weſt church. And I will firſt place S. Auſtē, bicauſe he, amōg al other doctors in diuinity beareth ye hel
But it ſhall be neceſsary to alledge thoſe ſcriptures, vpon which they do ground their ſayings. The ſcriptures be namely theſe following.

q.p: Pſal. 16. Non derelinques animam meam in inferno, nec dabis ſanctum tuum videre corruptionem: Thou wilt not leaue my ſoule in hell, neyther wilt thou ſuffer thine holy one to ſee corruption.
Pſal. 88. Cruiſti animam meam ex inferno inferiore: Thou haſt taken my ſoule out of the loweſt hell.

Zach. 9. Tu quo
que in ſanguine teſtamenti eduxiſti vinctos tuos de lacu, in quo non erat aqua: Thou alſo in the bloud of the teſtament haſt brought out thy priſoners out of the lake, where was no water.

1. Pet. 3. Chriſtus mortificatus carne, ſed viuificatus ſpiritu, inquo etiam abiit, et ſpiritibus, qui erant in carcere, praedicauit: Chriſt was put to death concerning the fleſh, but was quickened in the ſpirit, by the which alſo he went and preached to the ſpirites yt were in priſon.

p.hi: Now to the fathers. Auguſtinus.

Si ergo ſecundum hominē quem verbum deus ſuſcepit putas dictum eſſe, (hodie mecum eris in paradiſo) non ex hiis verbis in caelo exiſtimā dus eſt eſſe paradiſus, neque enim ipſo in coelo futurus erat homo ieſus Chriſtus, ſed in inferno ſecundum animam, in ſepulchro autem ſecundū carnem. Quod vero illa anima in infernum deſcenderit, apoſtolica doctrina predicat. Quandoquidem beatus Petrus ad hanc rem teſtimonium de pſalmis adhibet, vbi de ipſo Chriſto praedictum eſſe monſtrat. Quoniam non relinques animam meam in inferno, nec dabis ſanctum tuum videre corruptionem. Illud de anima dictum, hoc de corpore.

div.p: That is to ſay: If thou thinke theſe words (thou ſhalt be with me this day in Paradiſe) to be ſpoken concerning the manhode (which the word being God, tooke) not by theſe words, Paradiſe is compted to be in heauen: For the man Ieſus Chriſt was not in heauen it ſelfe, but in hel, as touching the ſoule, and in the graue as touching the body. And truly that the ſoule deſcended into hel, the Apoſtolicke doctrine doth declare. For bleſſed Peter for this matter bringeth teſtimony out of ye pſalmes, wher he ſheweth this to bee prophecied of Chriſt: For thou wilt not leaue my ſoule in hel, nor ſuffer thy holy one to ſee corruption. That was ſpoken of the ſoule, this of the body. And he ſaith a litle after thus: Reſtat igitur vt ſi ſecundum hominem dictum ſit (hodie mecum eris in paradiſo) in inferno intelligitur eſſe paradiſus, vbi erat eo die futurus, ſecundum humanam animam Chriſtus. That is to ſaye: It remaineth therfore that theſe words (thou ſhalt be with me this day in paradiſe) concerning the man, that paradiſe may be vnderſtand to be in hell, wher Chriſte ſhoulde bee that day, concerning the humane ſoule.

div.head: ¶ Idem Auguſtinus rurſum ſcribit.

p.hi: Dominum carne mortificatum veniſſe in infernum ſatis conſtat, Neque enim contra dici poteſt vel ꝓphetiae quae dixit (quoniā non relinques animam meam in inferno) quod ne aliter quiſpiam ſapere auderet in actibus apoſtolorum idem Petrus exponit, vel eiuſdem Petri verbis, quibus eum aſſeret ſoluiſſe inferni dolores, in quibus impoſſibile erat eum teneri. Quis ergo niſi infidelis negauerit fuiſſe apud inferos Chriſtum?

div.p: That is: It appeareth ſufficiently, that the Lord being mortified in the fleſh, came downe into hell: for the prophecie cannot be gainſayd, which hath ſaid (for thou ſhalt not leaue my ſoule in hel) which thing leaſt any man ſhould be bold to ſauour or vnderſtand otherwiſe, the ſame Peter doth expound, euen with thoſe woordes of Peter, by the which he affirmeth him to haue looſed the ſorowes of hell, in the which it was impoſſible for him to be holden. VVho therfore vnles an infidel, will deny Chriſt to haue bene in hell?

If ye wil aſke, whom Chriſt ſet out from thence, Saint Auſtine doth geue you a reſolute anſwer, ſaying: De illo quidem primo homine patre generis humaniquod eum ibidem ſolueret, eccleſia fere tota conſētit, quod eam non inaniter credidiſſe, credendum eſt. Vndecum
que hoc traditum ſit etiam ſi Canonicarum ſcripturarum hinc expreſſa non proferatur autoritas. That is to ſay: Of that firſt man, being the father of al mankind that Chriſt looſed him there, the whole church almost doth conſent, which thing the church not vainly to haue credited, is to be beleued. Frō whenceſoeuer this was deliuered, yea although there be no expreſſe autority of the canonical ſcriptures brought forth for the ſame. And wyth Adam he numbreth Abel, Seh, Noe, Abrahā, Iſaac, & Iacob, wt other.

div.head: ¶ Idem Auguſtinus rurſum ſcribit.

p.hi: Aliam opinionem dicam! fortaſsis enim eſt apud inferos aliqua pars inferior, quo traduntur impii, qui plurimum peccauerunt. Et paulo poſt: Nondum enim dominus venerat ad infernum, vt erueret inde omnium ſanctorum praecedentium animas, et tamen Abraham in requie ibi erat, et diues non poſsit, leuatis oculis, niſi ille eſſet ſuperius, ille infernus.

div.p: That is to ſay: I wyll ſhew you an other opinion: For perchaunce ther is in hell a lower part, wherin are thruſt downe the wicked which haue grieuouſly ſinned. And a litle after: For the Lord came not yet into hell, to take from them the ſoules of all the ſaintes that went before Chriſt. And yet Abraham was ther in reſt, and the rich man could not lyft vp his eyes to ſee, vnles Lazarus were aboue, and the other beneath.

div.head: ¶ Caſsiodorus.
div.p:
Caſsiodorus alſo conſenteth to Auguſtine, ſaying: Infernum vero habere inferiorem partem, euangelii locus ille de Diuite & Lazaro teſtatur. Apparet vtrun
que apud inferos fuiſſe, vt ſe videre valuiſſent, & Diuitem ex inferiore loco ad ſuperiora oculos eleuaſſe. Sed licet vter
que apud inferos eſſe viderentur, pro meritorum tamen diſcretione, ſuperior locus
ſanctis, inferior peccatoribus deputatur. That is to ſay:

That place in the goſpell of the riche man and Lazarus doth teſtifye, that hel hath a neather part. And it appeareth that they both wer in hel, that they might ſee ech other, and the rich man to haue lift vp his eyes from the neather part, to the higher. And although they were counted to be both in hel, yet for the difference of their works, the higher part was deputed to the ſaints, & the lower part to the ſinful and wicked.

div.head: Ambroſius.
div.p:
Quis potuit aſcendere in coelum? quia ideo paſſus eſt, vt expoliatis inferis virtute patris deuicta morte reſurgens, quum animabus ereptis in coelum aſcenderet. Omnis enim quicun
que viſo ſaluatore apud inferos ſperauit de illo ſalutem liberatus eſt. that is to ſay.

VVho could aſcend into heauen? becauſe he ſuffered therfore, that hell being ſpoyled by the power of the father, and death vanquiſhed, he ryſing againe, ſhould aſcend into heauē with the ſoules taken out. For whoſoeuer, the ſauiour being ſene in hel, hoped of him ſaluatiō, was deliuered.

div.head: Hieronimus.
div.p: Nunquid apertae ſunt tibi portae? et hoſtia tenebroſa vidiſti? In paſsio ne domini, et in morte domini quae dicuntur luce ſunt clariera, qui clauſtra inferorum aperuit, et ſanctorum inde animas liberauit that is to ſay

Vvere the gates open vnto thee? or diddeſt thou ſee the darcke doores? Theſe things which be ſpoken, are clearelye verified in the paſsion and death of our Lord, which opened the cloiſters of hell, and deliuered the ſoules of holy men from thence. For Hierom ſaith inde, from thence, that is to ſay, from hell.

div.head: Gregorius Magnus.
div.p:
Gregory writeth after this maner: Ante aduentum mediatoris dei & hominis, omnis homo (quantumuis mundae probatae
que vitae fuerit) ad inferna clauſtra deſcendit. Euery man, before the comming of Chriſt (althoughe hee were of neuer ſo cleane and approued life) deſcended to the cloyſters of hell.

Againe in an other place he ſaith: Si ſuſtinuero, infernus domus mea eſt, et in tenebris ſtraui lectum meum: ſpiritus etenim ſancti, et ſuſtinere aduerſa poterant, et tamen è corporibus educti, adhuc ab inferni locis liberari non poterant, quia nec dum venerat, qui illuc ſine culpa deſcenderet, vt eos qui ibi tenebantur ex culpa liberaret. Though I hope, yet hel ſhalbe mine houſe, and I ſhal make my bed in the darke. For the holy ſpirites both could ſustaine aduerſity, and yet coulde not be deliuered from the place of hel, becauſe that he was not yet come that ſhould deſcēd thether without gilt, that he might deliuer from gilt them which were holden there.

And in the ſame place a little after he ſayth: Et quia in ipſis quoque in ferni locis iuſtorum animae ſine tormento tenebantur, vt et pro originali
culpa illuc deſcenderent, et tamen ex propriis actibus ſupplicium nō haberent (quaſi in tenebris lectulum ſtrauiſſe) eſt, in inferno ſibi requiē praeparaſſe Becauſe the ſoules of righteous men are holden in the very places of hel wtout torment or pain, yt they ſhould yet go thither for ye original gilt, & yet ſuſtaine no puniſhment for their actes & dedes (to make their bed as it wer in darknes) is, to prepare them a rest in hel.

div.head: Cyprianus.
div.p: Ciprianus in the end of his treatie in ſymbolum, writeth thus: Si ergo intellexerimus quid partus virginis, quid verbi in carne natiuitas, quid ſacramentū crucis, quid vtilitas diuini ad inferna deſcenſus, quid reſurrectionis gloria, & animarum de infernis reuocata captiuitas. &c. That is to ſay: If we ſhal vnderſtande, what the deliuery of the virgin, what the natiuity of the ſonne in the fleſh, what the miſtery of the cros, what the profit of the diuine deſcenſe into hel, what the glory of the reſurrectiō, & the captiuity of the ſoules being reuoked again frō hel.Sermo de aſcētione &c.

Againe, Ciprian ſaith: Semel Chriſtus deſcendit ad inferos, vlterius non deſcendet, non vltra videbunt deum in tenebris ſigillati Once Chriſt went downe into hel, any more he ſhal not deſcend, any more they ſhall not ſee God, which are ſealed and ſhut vp in darknes.

div.head: Vigilius.
div.p: Vigilius writeth after this maner:Lib. 2. Cont. Eutichem. Cōſtat dominū noſtrū Ieſū Chriſtū ſexta feria crucifixū, et ipſa die ad infernū deſſēdiſſe, ipſa die in ſepulchro iacuiſſe ipſa dielatroni dixiſſe, hodie mecū eris in paradiſo caro igit ipſa die nō fuit in paradiſo, ſed examinis iacuit in ſepulchro. Anima per illud triduum in inferno, non in ſepulchro. That is to ſaye; It is euidente, that the Lord Ieſus Christ, being crucified on the friday, the ſame day deſcended into hel, the ſame day he lay in the ſepulchre, the ſame day he ſaid to the theefe: this day thou ſhalt be with me in Paradiſe. Thē his fleſh was not the ſame day in Paradiſe, neither in hel, but lay dead in ye ſepulcher: but his ſoule thoſe whole three daies was in hel, not in the graue.

Here might be alledged other Doctors alſo of the Latine Churche, which conſent vnto the fathers before mencioned, as Primaſius, Sedulius, Leo, and other. But theſe ſhall be ſufficient for the Vveſt Church. Now you ſhall heare the opinion and iudgement of the Grecian fathers of the Eaſt church.

div.head: Authores Graeci. Chriſoſtomus.
div.p: Conſiderandum eſt, quod Abraham apud inferos erat, In. 16. Luk. nec dum Chriſtus reſurrexerat, qui illum ad paradiſum duceret. Antequam Chriſtus moreretur nemo in paradiſum conſcendit. It is to be conſidered, that Abraham was in hell, neither yet was Chriſte riſen which ſhoulde bring him vnto Paradiſe. Before Chriſt died, no man went vp into Paradiſe.

Alſo in an other place he ſaith: Nullam animam ante Chriſtum arbitror aſcēdiſſe in coelum, ex quo peccauit Adam, et clauſi ſunt ei coeli, ſed omnes in inferno detenti ſunt, propter quos etiam deſcendit ad inferos. I iudge no ſoule before Chriſt to haue aſcended into heauen, ſince Adam tranſgreſſed, and the heauens were ſhut vnto him, but all were holden in hel, for the which alſo Chriſt deſcended into hel.

div.head: Euſebius.
div.p: Euſebius Emiſſenus writeth thus: Sciendum eſt, quod illa hora qua ſaluator noſter inclinato capita emiſit ſpiritum, Lib de reſurrectione. corpore in cruce derelic to, anima ſimul cum diuinitate ad inferna ſpolianda deſcendit. It is to be knowen, that in that houre in which our ſauiour bowing down his head, gaue vp the ſpirit, his body being left on the croſſe, his ſoul with the diuinitie deſcended to ſpoile hell.

div.head: Damaſcenus.
div.p:
Deſcendit in infernum anima deificata, vt quemadmodū is qui in terra iuſtitiae ortus eſt ſol, ſic et eis qui ſub terra in tenebris et vmbra mortis ſedebant, lux fulgeret. Et vt quemadmodum in terra euangelizauerit pacem, captiuis remiſſionem, caecis viſum, et iis qui crediderunt factus eſt cauſa ſalutis aeternae, incredulis autem infidelitatis improperium et redar gutio: ſic et iis qui in inferno, vt ipſi omne genu flectatur coeleſtium terreſtrium, ac infernorum, At
que hoc pacto a ſeculo cōpeditos ſoluens ru •
ſus ex mortuis rediit nobis, viam parans ad reſurrectionē: That is: He went down into hell in his ſoule deified, that as to thoſe which were in earth he ſprong the ſunne of righteouſnes: ſo alſo vnto thoſe which vnder the earth ſat in darkenes, and in the ſhadow of death, he might be a ſhining light. And that as on earth he had preached peace, remiſsion to the captiues, ſight to the blind, and to thoſe which did beleue, he was made the cauſe of eternal ſaluation, but to the vnbeleuing, an imbraiding and reprofe of infidelity: So alſo to thoſe which were in hel, that euery knee ſhould bow vnto him, both of things in heauen, in earth, & in hell. And by this meanes, looſing them yt wer boūd frō the beginning of the world, he returned again from the dead, preparing vs a way to riſe againe.

div.head: A general councel.

p.hi:
Chriſtus deus et homo, non autem duo filii, ſed idem vna perſona in vtra
que natura perferens paſsionem et mortem pro ſalute noſtra,
non in virtute diuinitatis, ſed in infirmitate humanitatis deſcendit ad inferos, vt ſanctos, qui ibi tenebantur, erueret, et deuicto mortis imperio reſurrexit.

div.p: That is to ſay: Chriſt God and man, but not two ſonnes, & two Gods, but being both in one perſon, in both the natures ſuffering his paſsion & death for our ſaluation, not in ye power of diuinitye, but in ye infirmity of humanity, deſcēded into hel, yt he might deliuer from thence the ſaintes that were holden ther, and when he had ouercome death, roſe againe.

div.head: ¶ The iudgements of the later Diuines, concerning this article: Deſcendit ad inferna. Eraſmus.
div.p: Eraſmus in his Cathechiſme doth write of this article after this maner

This is the article which Ciprian ſayde not to be had in the Romaine Symbole, no neither yet to be added in the East churches. Yea and moreouer, although the ſymbole of the Synode holden at Nice, or of the Synode holden at Conſtantinople, is none other thing then a declaration of this Symbole: yet is not ther neither ſo much as any one thing that is correſpondent to this article.
Alſo the very inconcinnitye or vnhandſome ioyning or hanging together of the ſpeche and oration, is an euident proofe, that ther is a percell thrust in among the other articles, by ſome other man.

Theſe words, ſepultus eſt, that is, he was buried, doo belong to the body, which laid a ſleepe by death, doth riſe againe, that is, doth as it were waken from ſlepe. But theſe wordes, deſcendit ad inferos, that is, went down to hel: they do referre vnto the ſoule, which neither was buried, neither did riſe againe, but being departed and ſundried for a tyme, ſhortly after returned againe into the dead body.

Vvhether Thomas Aquinas did adde this article, I am in doubt. Ther is a certain ſuſpitiō that it ſhould be added of ſome other man, or at the leaſte by this argumente, for that it is not in the mete place. For when he doth make the third article of the reſurrectiō, he maketh the fourth article of the going downe into hel, except peraduenture he ment this, that Chriſt, after he was riſen againe from death to life, went down in body and ſoule to hel.

And an other litle worke which goeth abroade, bearing the title of Thomas Aquinas vpon the Symbol, doth interpret and declare the contrary therof, and vſeth alſo a contrary order. For ther the going downe to hel, goeth before the reſurrection. How be it, this ſaid Opuſcle (although it be a learned and an holy woorke) yet it ſeemeth not to be the worke of Thomas Aquinas.

Eraſmus ſaith alſo, that thoſe ſcriptures & reaſons, which are alledged to confirme this article, cannot conſtraine him which deſireth to thwart and to finde cauilations, to beleue that the ſoule of Chriſt went down by it ſelfe perſonally to hel. For the ſcriptures (ſaith he) doth often times call death and the graue by this name Inferos, which ſame word is ſomtimes engliſhed hel. As for example in the booke of Geneſis: Morietur & deducent famuli tui canos eius cum dolore ad inferos, that is to ſay: he ſhal die, and thy ſeruauntes ſhal bring his hoare heares with ſorow to his graue. He calleth here the aged body of Iacob, hoare heares. And by this word inferos, he ment the ſepulchre or graue. And this thing doth Saint Ciprian in few woords in a manner ſhewe, when after he had ſayd before, that this particle is not had neither in the weſt churches, nor in the Eaſt churches, he addeth afterwards theſe wordes.
Vis tamen verbi videtur eſſe in eo quod ſepultus dicitur That is: how be it ther ſemeth to be the ſame ſtrēgth of the word, in that yt he is ſaid to haue bene buried. As who ſhould ſay, yt deſcendere ad inferna, to deſcende into hel, were nothing els, but to be buried in the graue, which our Lord ſpeaking of his owne buriall, called to be in the harte of the earth. Haec Eraſmus.

But yet the ſame Ciprian in other places ſemeth to make a diſtinction betwene theſe two clauſes Sepultus eſt, et deſcendit ad inferna: for vpon the Symbole he writeth: ſed et quod in infernum deſcendit, euidēter pro nunciatur in pſalmis. &c but that he alſo deſcended into hel, it is euidētly pronounced in the pſalmes. And ſo bringing in teſtimonies of the pſalmes, he alledgeth ſaint Peter and other authorities out of the Pſalmes, writing on this wiſe: Vnde et Petrus dixit, quia Chriſtus mortificatus carne viuificatus autem ſpiritu, in ipſo ait. Et eis qui in carcere incluſi erant in diebus Noe in quo etiam quid operis egerit in inferno declaratur. Sed et ipſe dominus per prophae • am dicit, tanquam de futuro: quia non relinques animam meam in inferno, nec dabis ſanctum tuum videre corruptionem: that is to ſay: Vvhereof Peter alſo ſaide, that Chriſt mortified in the fleſh, was quickned in the ſpirite, and to them that wer in priſon in ye daies of Noe he preached. In ye which alſo is declared what work • s he did in hell. But the Lord alſo by the prophet ſaith as of the time to come: Thou wilt not leaue my ſoule in hel, neither wilt thou ſuffer thy holy one to ſee corruption: which againe he ſheweth prophetically to be fulfilled when he ſaith: Lord thou haſt brought my ſoule out of hell, thou haſt ſaued me from thoſe that go downe to the pit.

Before theſe wordes ſaint Ciprian doth ſpeake of the burial of Chriſt ſaying: ſepultus quo
que pethibetur, et lapis magnus poſitus ad oſtium monumenti: He is alſo ſaid to be buried, and ther was a great ſtone laide at the doore of the tombe: which article when he had confirmed with many ſcriptures, then inferreth theſe wordes: Sed et quod ad infernum deſcendit. &c.
Nowe the Grammarians ſaye, that this coniunction ſed, is not vox exegetica, but diſcretiua, & his property is alwaies to bring in an other matter diſtinct from the matter going before.

Alſo in the end of his treatie in ſymbolum he writeth: Si ergo intellexerimus quid partus virginis, quid verbum in carne natiuitatis, quid ſacramentum crucis, quid vtilitas diuini ad inferna deſcenſus quid reſurrectionis gloria. &c. that is: If we ſhall vnderſtand what the deliuery of the virgin, what the natiuity of the ſonne in the fleſh, what the miſterye of the croſſe, what the profit of the diuine deſcence of Chriſt into hel, what the glory of the reſurrection. &c

Furthermore, Ciprian writeth in his ſermon De aſcenſione. Semel
Chriſtus deſcendit ad inferos, vlterius non deſcendet, non vltra videbunt deum in tenebris ſigillati. Once Christ went down into hell, any more he ſhall not deſcend, any more they ſhall not ſee God, which are ſealed and ſhut vp in darcknes.
Now conferre Cripian with Ciprian, and ſo he may be the better vnderſtanded.

Maiſter Caluine doth count it 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , to expound this article: ſepultus eſt, by the other words which follow, deſcendit ad inferna, ſaying that they do interprete plaine and manifeſt woordes by a more obſcure and darke phraſe.

But now to Eraſmus againe, whoſe wordes be theſe. If the vniuerſall church hath now receaued this article, it is not lawful for thee not to beleue it. It is ſufficient for thee to profeſse, that Chriſt did ſo deſcend (ad inferos) as the ſcripture & the church doth thinke and meane. But yet as it is a poynt of chriſtian wiſedom, not to beleue very lightly that thing for certain and vndoubted, which is not expreſsed in the holy ſcriptures: Euen ſo is it a poynt of chriſtian mekenes, not to refuſe proudly and frowardly that thing which the religious contemplacion of God and godly men hath taught, eyther to the ſolace and comfort, or els to the erudition of them that do beleue, of which ſort are thoſe things alſo. That the holy ghoſt toke one of the moſt pureſt droppes of bloud out of the Virgin Maries hart, and laide it down into her matrice: and that hereof was ſodainly made the perfect body of a man, ſo ſmall as is a litle ſpider, which is but euen now cropen out of the egge, but yet with all the members full finiſhed and perfect in all powers and qualities, as it is now in heauen. Likewiſe where they do teach, that Chriſt by reaſon of the complexion of his humane bodye (which they will to haue bene in him most ſubtill, and ſo therfore of moſt quicke and ſharpe feeling) did ſuffer more grieuous and bitter paines than any man may poſſiblie ſuffer, the paine of them onely excepted which are perpetually damned in hell.

Theſe things and ſuche other like vnto theſe, let them bee ſo hearde, as deuout and holye contemplacions of men, concerning Chriſte, but not as articles of the faithe. Manye ſuche manner of thinges haue certaine m • n imagined alſo aboute this particle, telling what perſonnes Chriſte brought oute from hell, and whom he didde leaue there ſtill, and what thinges, and with what woordes hee didde ſpeake to euerye one of the circles.

But this is ſufficient for vs, that he was once in fleſh borne a very man, that he did verely ſuffer paſsion, that he hath verily died, and bene buried,
and that he hath verily reuiued againe, the verye ſame ſoule returned againe into the natural body. Haec Eraſmus.
Pſal. 16.Stephanus in his annotations vpon the pſalme, declaring this verſe: Non derelinques animam meam in inferno, doth interprete it, non relinques corpus meum in ſepulchro.

And Beza vpon the ſecond of the Actes, doth tranſlate that verſe after this maner: Non relinques cadauer meum in ſepulchro, which trāſlation and interpretation ſemeth to ſome very ſtraunge, and much ſtretched. Yet it cannot be denied, but that the word Nepeſch, hath many ſignifications. This verſe in the Hebrue hath theſe woordes: Kilo taazab nepeſchi leſcheol.

This word Nepeſch, De opificio Dei. hath many ſignificatiōs. First it ſignifieth wind, breath or blowing, wherupon Lactantius doth write, that ſome called the ſoule fire, ſome wind, wherof this word anima, or animus toke the name, bicauſe 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in Greke is called ventus.

Cap. 1.And in that ſignification this word Nepeſch is vſed in Geneſis: Sed & omni beſtiae terrae, et omni volatili caelorum, et omni motabili ſuper terram, in quo eſt anhelitus viuens &c. To euery beast of the earth, to euery foule of the heauen, and to euery thing that moueth vpon the earth, which hath life in it ſelfe. &c.
Likewiſe it is vſed in Iob: Habitus eius prunas accendit. His breath maketh the coales to burne. This word breath, here is called in Hebrue Nepeſch.

Seccondly, Nepeſch, ſignifieth ye ſoule which is the chiefeſt, and principalleſt part of man. And ſo it is vſed in many places of the Scriptures. As in Geneſis,Gen. 27.35. 1. Samuel. 1 25 Iob 9.24 Pſal. 13.119. in Samuell, in Iob, and in the Pſalmes: as in this place: viuat anima mea et laudabit te. Let my ſoule liue, and it ſhall praiſe thee. Soule here is called in Hebrue, Nepeſch.

Thirdly, Nepeſch, betokeneth that power of the ſoule which we call appetitinam, ſeu concupiſcibilem, that is, it is taken for the appetite, for affection, will, mind, and deſire. As in Exodus: Ne opprimas peregrinū, vos enim noſtis animam peregrini. Cap. 23. Thou ſhalt not oppreſſe a ſtraunger, for you know the hart of a ſtraunger. Hart here is taken for the ſorrow of the hart.

And the word in Hebrue is,Cap. 23. Nepeſch, Likewiſe in Geneſis. Si eſt cum anima veſtra vt ſepetiam mortuum meum. If it be in your mind or pleaſure that I ſhould burie my dead. And ſo Nepeſch is vſed in manye other places of the ſcriptures.
Fourthly nepeſch ſignifieth bloode and life, bicauſe life conſiſteth in bloud, which is, vehiculum, that is as you would ſay, the wagon or chariot of the ſpirites.

And ſo it is vſed in Geneſis, and in Deuteronomie, where it is ſaid: ne comedas ſanguinem, quia ſanguis eſt ipſa anima: Cap. 9. Cap. 12. thou ſhalte not eate the bloud, for the bloude is the life, and thou muſt not eate the life with the fleſhe. In the which place nepeſch is put both for life and bloud.

Fiftly, nepeſch, ſignifieth the bodie, which is the other parte of man: and ſo it is vſed in the pſalmes. As, Infernum venit anima eius. His bodie was layed in yrons. The body here is called in Hebrue nepeſch Likewiſe in an other pſalm: miſit maciem in animam eorum. He ſent lenneſſe into their ſoule. Here is the ſoule taken for the bodie, which is called in hebrue, nepeſch, And in this ſignification Stephanus might ſeeme to vſe this worde, nepeſch: and to haue taken anima pro corpus, when he tranſlateth non relinques animam meam in ſepulchro, for non relinques animam meam in inferno.

Sixtly, nepeſch is put in ſome places of the ſcriptures, per 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , for a dead carcaſse or a bodie without a ſoule, as in Leuiticus:Cap. 19. Et inciſionem ſuper anima non ponetis in carne veſtra You ſhall not cut your fleſhe for the deade. Nepeſch betokeneth here the deade bodies. Alſo in the ſame booke, non contaminabit ſe ſacerdos ſuper animam populi ſui. Let not the prieſt defile him ſelfe by the dead, that is, by touchynge the corpes. Here this worde anima, is put for the dead bodie, and is called in Hebrue, nepeſch. And the olde tranſlation hath: ne contaminetur ſacerdos in mortibus ciuium ſuorum. Let not the prieſt be defiled in the death of any of his. And Castalio tranſlateth in funeribus eorum, in their funeralles. Nepeſch is likewiſe ſo vſed in the booke of nombres. And vpon theſe and ſuch like places,Cap. 5.6. •
Beza might ſeme to haue grounded his interpretation, when he tranſlated: non relinques cadauer meū in ſepulchro, for, non relinques animā meā in inferno. But ther be great lerned men which do very much miſtike this tranſlatiō, & they cal it a corruption of the verie letter of the holy ſcripture.

They write alſo, that it is pitie, that an article of our faith, conſtantly and vniformely taught in the church of Chriſt, ſhould now be drawen into queſtion, and to be made a wauering opinion: ſeing that all the fathers both of the Eaſt, and the Vveſt church with one conſent and agrement hath allowed this article. And maiſter Caluin himſelfe confeſseth alſo, that to be true. For he ſaith: Id certe extra controuerſiam eſt, ex communi piorum omnino ſenſu, fuiſſe deſumptam particulam, quando nemo eſt patrum qui non in ſuis ſcriptis deſcenſum Chriſti ad inferos nō commemorat. That is to ſaye: It is without all controuerſie and doubt, that this particle (deſcendit ad inferna) was taken of the common iudgement and conſent of the godly, for as much as ther is none of the fathers, but doth make mention and reherſall in their writings of the deſcenſe of
Chriſte into hell. Yet maiſter Caluin himſelfe is of an other iudgement: For he counteth the deſcence of Chriſte into hell, to be done vpon the croſſe, where he felte the ſeueritie of gods vengeaunce, and did wreſtell with hel, and with the horrour of death, and was ſmitten of God for our ſinnes, as a moſt wicked offender, and to be as one forſaken of God, and therfore cried, O god my God, why haſte thou thus lefte me.

And that Chriſte after this maner deſcended into hell, it is no meruel, when that he ſuffred that death which is inflicted vpon the wicked: And truly there can be no more terribler hell, then one to feele him ſelfe forſaken and alienate from God, and not to be hearde when he calleth, as thoughe God had conſpired to his deſtruction. And therfore we ſee Chriſt to be caſte downe, that he was compelled, anguiſh enforcing him, to crie, O God my God, why haſt thou forſaken me? Haec Caluinus.

Other writers, both of great learning, and depe iudgement, do expounde this article in another ſenſe, who iudgeth the deſcenſe of Chriſt into hell to be nothing els, but the vertue of the death of Chriſt to haue come euen vnto the dead, and to haue proffited them, that is, that all the Patriarches and faithfull men before the comming of chriſt, be preſerued from eternall death, through the death of Chriſt.

Or els by this worde, Inferos, or inferna, ther maye be vnderſtande not the place of puniſhment appointed vnto the wicked, but all the faithfull departed, as by this worde, ſuperos, we do vnderſtande all them that remaine aliue. Therfore we maye ſaye, that the ſoule of Chriſte wente downe to hell, that is, that it was brought into the boſome of Abraham, where all the faithfall departed were gathered together. Vvherfore, when Chriſt ſaid to the theefe crucified with him, this day ſhalte thou be with me in paradiſe: he promiſed him participation of life, and companie of the bleſsed ſpirits. But it perteineth rather to a curious and buſie head, then to a godly and quiet mind, curiouſly to enquire, and diſpute of this mater. Haec Bullingerus.

In expoſitio. Symboli.The ſame Bullinger wrting vpon the epiſtle of Peter, where he entreateth ther of the priſon in which the ſpirites were, doth ſay: Vbi nam locorum hic fuerit carcer, ignotum eſt. In what place this priſon was, it is vnknowne. Bullinger here doth conſtitute a place whiche he calleth with Peter a priſon. And where that ſame place is, he knoweth not. Moreouer he ſaith, in that place there was no filthe, no darcknes, no pain▪ but a place of refreſhing. And the place is therfore called a priſon, becauſe the ſoules of the bleſſed were there reteined.
Alſo he writeth, that this ſaying of Zacharie: Tu quoque in ſanguine teſtamenti tui dimiſiſti vinctos tuos ex puteo, in quo non eſt aqua, may apparteine to this purpoſe.

Caluine alſo writing vpon the ſame Epiſtle doth ſaye: a queſtion may be moued, why Peter doth place in a priſon the ſoules of the godly,1 Epiſt. 3. pet after they wer departed from their bodies. And truly this greeke worde 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , in my iudgement, doth ſignifie rather an highe tower, wherin watche is kept, or the verie acte of keping watch. But if it ſhal pleaſe any man to kepe the name of a priſon, it ſhall not ill agree. For when they were liuinge, the lawe was to them (as Paul witneſſeth) a ſtraight cuſtodie or priſon, in whiche they were deteyned. So after their death, it behoued them to be bounde with the carefull deſire of Chriſt, becauſe the ſpirite of libertie was not yet exhibite vnto them. Therfore, the carefulnes of lookyng for Chriſt, was to them a priſon.

Lebanriſch writeth after this maner: Sainct Peter alledgeth this ſaying of the prophet Dauid: Non derelinques animam meam in inferno, nec ſines ſanctum tuum videre corruptionem, that is: Thou ſhalte not leaue my ſoule in hel, neither ſhalte thou ſuffer thine holy one to ſee corruption. After that he had declared, that this could not be ſpoken of Dauid himſelfe (for that his graue remained yet among them, and his body ſuffred corruption) he addeth: foraſmuch as Dauid was a Prophet, and did know that God ſwore vnto him, that Chriſt ſhould come of the fruict of his loines, touching the fleſh, he ſpeake euidently of the reſurrection of Chriſt, becauſe his ſoule ſhould not be left in hell, nor his fleſhe ſawe corruption. You ſee how ſainct Peter applieth this ſentence of the Prophet to ſet forth Chriſts reſurrection. And in ſteede of this worde ſanctū eius, ſainct Peter hath carnem eius, which is to be marked. Is not reſurrection contrary vnto death? And what other thinge is death, then the ſeparation of the body from the ſoule? And what other thing then can reſurrection be, but a renuing and knitting together againe of the bodie and the ſoule? Sainct Peter therfore applyieng this ſentence to the reſurrection of Chriſt, doth (as it were) pointe with his fingers the places from whence theſe two partes ſeuered, muſte be brought again: namely the ſoule from hell, for hel could not hold it: and the bodie from the graue, that it ſhould not corrupt. Haèc Rabbi Lebanriſch.

Thus I haue declared at large the opinions and iudgements aſwell of the olde fathers, as of the later writers, concerninge this article of the fayth: Deſcendit ad inferna, he deſcended into hell. So that euery man (as Paule ſaith) maye abounde in his owne iudgement. One thinge I would wiſhe that neither this article, nor any other conteyned in the ſymbole, commonly called Symbolum Apoſtolorum, ſhould be lightlye ſhaken of, but to be beleued as they ſtande there. As for my part, I am fullye reſolued, that this article is true: He deſcended into hell.

div.head: To morowe. 5.
div.p: THis worde is called in latin, cras, in greeke, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , in Hebrue, Machar. And it ſignifieth not onely the nexte daye folowyng, but alſo the time to come: as Iacob vſed it in Geneſis, ſaying: Teſtificabitur de me iuſtitia mea die craſtina: My rightuouſnes ſhall anſwere for me hereafter.Cap. 30.

Alſo in Deuteronomie: Quum interrogarit te filius tuus cras: whē thy ſonne ſhal aſke thee in time to come.Cap. 6. Cap. 13. It is alſo vſed for a ſhorte time to come: as in Luke, where Chriſt ſaith: oportet me hodie & cras, & ſequenti die ambulare: I muſt walke to day, and to morow, and the nexte daye folowing, that is, a litle while.

Craſtinus, the adiectiue is ſomtime vſed for daily and continual. For wheras the Grecians do reade 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : panem noſtrū quotidianum, ſainct Hierome ſaith, that he founde in the goſpell (whiche is called, Euangelium hebraeorum) machar craſtinum. As if it ſhoulde be ſaid, da nobis panem hodiernum & craſtinum.

Sainct Auſten ſeemeth to ſhew the like in one of his ſermons. For as the earthly fathers do prouide for their children bread and meat,Sermo. 28. for the morow and the time to come, wherewith their bodies mighte be ſuſteined: ſo prouide thou, O father, which art the heauenly father, and the father of ſpirits, for vs thy children, the heauēly bread of the minde.
Symachus did tranſlate 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . 1. eximium, & egregium, excellent, greate, ſingular.
Some expound this greeke worde, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , ſuper ſubſtantialem, vel ſupereſſentialem.

To our purpoſe againe. As this worde, hodie, doth ſignifie the time preſente: ſo cras ſignifieth time to come. And by this worde, to morow, is ſignified any procraſtination or delaye, whether it be good or ill. And the ſcolaſtical diuines do diuide Cras into fiue kindes. id eſt.

By the firſt Cras, is vnderſtand good aduiſement, diſcretion, deliberation, which one taketh before he doth any thing. For prudent, graue and wiſe men wil not do things headlong and in haſt, but will worke aduiſedly, accordyng to the prouerbe, feſtina lentè: make haſte ſlowlye.

By the ſecond Cras, is vnderſtand negligence, remiſſenes, and ſlowneſse of doinge of thinges. And thoſe perſons whiche be ſubiect to this ſlackneſse, may be compared to the Crowe, whiche crieth alwayes cras,
cras. They differre to do any thinge, vntil the power or facultie of doing be taken from them. They will not honour and praye vnto God, they will not helpe their neighbour, they will not hope for godly things.

It is writen in the prouerbes: Ne dicas amico tuo, vade & reuertere, cras dabo tibi, quum ſtatim poſsis dare: Say not vnto thy neighbour,Cap. 3. go and come againe, and to morowe will I geue thee, if thou now haue it.

Alſo in an other place of the ſame boke it is written: Ne glorieris in craſtinum, ignorans quid ſuperuentura pariat dies: Cap. 27. Boaſte not thy ſelfe to morowe: for thou knoweſt not what a daye may bring furth.

Alſo in Eccleſiaſticus it is written: Non tardes conuerti ad Dominū, & ne differas de die in diem. Subito enim veniet ira illius, Cap. 5. & in tempore vindictae diſperdet te: Make no long tariyng to turne vnto the Lord, and put not of from daye to day: for ſodenly ſhal the wrath of the Lord breake furth, and in thy ſecuritie thou ſhalt be deſtroyed, and thou ſhalt periſhe in time of vengeaunce.

By the third Cras, is vnderſtande the daye of death, vnto which all men be ſubiecte. It is written in Eccleſiaſticus: Rex eſt hodie, Cap. 10. & cras morietur: He that is to daye a King, to morowe is dead. This Cras, taketh awaye all corporall pleaſures, all temporall riches, all pompes, and honors.

By the fourth Cras, are vnderſtand the paines of hell, to the which the wicked and impenitent ſinners ſhal be ſubiect. They haue two dayes, hodie & cras, to day and to morow. To daye they haue proſperitie, to morow they ſhall haue calamitie.

l.hi: Hodie habent gaudere: cras habebunt dolere.
Hodie rident: craſtino ſtrident.
Hodie ſaltent: craſtino nutant.
Hodie ſunt pleni: cras erunt egeni.
Hodie ſunt primi: cras erunt infimi.
Hodie ſunt equites: cras erunt pedites.
Hodie ſunt in gloria: cras erunt in miſeria.
Hodie abundant auro: cras erunt in demonum theſauro.
To daye they be glad: to morowe they ſhalbe ſadde.
To day they laugh: to morow they ſhall weepe.
To day they leappe: to morowe they ſhal quake.
To day they be full: to morowe they ſhalbe emptie.
To day they be firſt: to morowe they ſhalbe laſt.
To day they be horſemen: to morow footemen.
To day in glorie: to morow in miſerie.

p.hi: To day abounding with gold: to morow in the deuils treaſure houſe ſhall lie ful colde.

div.p:
Of this Cras that maye be ſpoken, which is written of Luke:Cap. 12. foenum quod hodie in agro eſt, cras in clibanum mittitur. The graſſe which to
daye is in the fielde, to morowe is caſt into the ouen.

By the fifte Cras is vnderſtand conſolation, and eternall life, whiche the godly ſhal poſseſſe and enioye. For they haue alſo two dayes, hodie & cras: In this preſent life they ſuſteine miſerie, but in the life to come they ſhall receiue glorie. This hodie and cras receiued poore Lazarus which lay in Abrahams boſome. Haec ex ſcholaſticis.

div.head: Heighte nor depth. 6.
div.p: Cap. 8. HEighte in this place of ſainct Paule to the Romanes, ſignifieth any ſtraunge miracle or wonder not ſeene before, which cometh from heauen: And depthe ſignifieth any thinge that commeth from the deepeſt and loweſt parts of the earth.

Heighte ſomtime may be taken for the excellencie and profoundnes of mans witte and reaſon,2. Cor. 10. in philoſophie. For ſainct Paule ſaid to the Corinthes: Arma militiae noſtrae non ſunt car nalia, ſed potentia Deo ad demolitionem munitionum, quibus conſilia demolimur, & omnem altitudinem, quae ſe extollit aduerſus cognitionem Dei: The weapons of our warfare are not carnal, but mighty through god, to caſt down holds, to caſt down the imaginatiōs, & euery high thing that is exalted againſt the knowledge of god. And accordyng to this ſaying of Paul, we may vnderſtand by depth, the humilitie of the minde, and the hurte of the bodie, after the rules and doctrine of men, whiche in wordes haue an appearaunce of wiſedome, as the ſame Apoſtle writeth to the Coloſsians.

Cap. 2.Haymo writing vpon this place bringeth in a ſtraunge interpretatiō. For by height he vnderſtandeth Aſtrologie, and by depth, Necromācie, by whiche two, many men were turned from the fayth. He would haue S Paules meaninge to be this: Although all the Aſtronomers (which do affirme them ſelues to be cunning in the conſtellation and courſe of the planets) do come againſt vs: yea although they (which by Necromancie do raiſe vp ſpirits out of hell, as the woman that had a familiar ſpirite raiſed vp Samuels ſpirite) do come againſt vs, yet they ſhalbe neuer able to ſeparate vs from the loue of Chriſt.

div.head: Golden hiles. 7.
div.p: THere is a prouerb in greeke: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : Aureos montes polliceri: To promiſe golden hilles. Vvhich prouerbe is ſpoken of them that do promiſe vnmeaſurable things, and do make men to hope very much for them. It is deduced and taken of the arrogancie of the Perſians, which for their mines of gold, did boaſt of golden hilles.
Plautus ſaith: Neque ille ſibi mereat Perſarum montes, qui eſſe aurei perhibentur: Neither let him thinke to deſerue the hilles of the Perſians, which are ſaid to be golden hilles.

The like prouerbe is mentioned of Porphirion, who thinketh the ſame prouerbe to be taken out of one of Aeſops fables. The prouerbe is recited by Horace: Parturiunt montes, naſcetur ridiculus mus: In arte po The hilles do ſwell and trauell, but out cōmeth the foliſh mouſe. It may be ſpoken againſt gloriouſe men, againſt boaſters and braggers, which with greate promiſes & by maieſtie of countenāce & autoritie of gay apparel, moue men to expect much at their hands, and when it commeth to the purpoſe, they bring and ſhew forth nothing but toyes and trifles.

The originall of the prouerbe is this: Vvhen, at a certain time, rude and fooliſh men did ſee the grounde ſwell and moue in a hill, they ranne on heapes on euerye ſide to beholde ſo horrible a ſighte, looking that the earth ſhould bring forth ſome ſtraunge and great wonder, that is, that the hill ſhould bring furth other Titans that ſhould renue warres with the Gods. At the length, after they had looked a long time what would come forth, a Mouſe crept out of the ground, at the which ſight they all did greatly laughe.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: HOwe doth Peter here ſaye truely, that we are tempted of God? when Iames ſaith: Deus neminem tentat: God tempteth no mā. In which wordes there appeareth great difference betwen theſe two Apoſtles.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Peter here vnderſtandeth two kynds of temptation, the temptation of God, and the temptation of our fleſhe. God tempteth vs with croſses, falſe prophets, with famine, with warre, with fire, with water, with diſeaſes, with afflictions and perſecutions, and with a thouſand kindes of aduerſities, that he may trie our faith, whether we will perſeuer in the confeſsing of Ieſus Chriſt.

Many men do ſwarue and go backe in the time of temptation, as ſone as any grieuouſe affliction doth ariſe. But the godly at no time do better proue and trie their weakenes and wittes, than in the time of temptation and affliction.
Alſo we are tempted, that the ſinceritie of our mindes may be made manifeſt to other men. So did god tempte Abraham,Gen. 22. when he commaunded him to offer his ſonne Iſaac for a ſacrifice.

God ſayde to Moyſes: Beholde, I will cauſe bread to raine from heauen for you, and the people ſhall go out,Exod. 16 and gather that that is ſufficient for euerie daye, that I maye proue them whether they will walke in my lawes or no.

Againe, in Deuteronomie: if there ariſe among you a prophet or a dreamer of dreames, (and geue thee a ſigne or wonder, and the ſigne or the wonder whiche he hath tolde thee, come to paſse) ſaying: let vs goe after other gods which thou haſt not knowne, and let vs ſerue them: thou ſhalt not hearken vnto the words of that prophet, or vnto that dreamer of dreames: for the Lord your God proueth you, to knowe whether you loue the Lord your god, with al your hart, and with all your ſoule.
Iames. 1.Sainct Iames ſayth: Take it to be greate ioye, my brethern, when you do fall into diuerſe temptations, knowing this, that the trial of your faith bringeth pacience.
Ibid.Againe he ſaith: Happie is the man that doth ſuffer temptation. For when he is tried, he ſhall receaue the crowne of life, which the Lord hath promiſed to them that loue him.

The ſecond kind of temptation is, the temptation of the fleſh, and the malice and euill affection which by nature is graffed in vs. The ſenſes and thoughtes of mans hart, are prone and readie to ill from their youth.
Gal. 5Sainct Paule ſaith: Caro concupiſcit aduerſus ſpiritum. Nihil eſt in carne noſtra bonum. The fleſh luſteth againſt the ſpirite. There is no goodneſſe in our fleſhe

This temptation and luſte of the fleſh, which Sathan by meruailouſe ſuggeſtions doth ſet on fire, tempteth vs to infidelitie, to blaſpheme the name of god, to contempne the goſpel, and to hate our neighboures, and to all maner of wickedneſse & ſinne. Of this temptation ſpeaketh ſainct Iames, ſaying: God is not a tempter of the wicked, for he tempteth no man They are tempted which be lead awaye and intiſed by luſt and concupiſcence, that is: God is not the author of ill, he tempteth not to wickedneſse, that ye may laye the faulte on him. Your ſinfull fleſhe, and wicked concupiſcence entiſeth you to ill. Accuſe your ſelues, not God. God in deede tempteth you, but not to commit ſinne, but that you ſhould be tried. But the luſt of the fleſhe tempteth and deriueth you to committe ſinne:
Here you ſee Peter and Iames not to diſſente, but to agree in ſenſe and meaning.

div.head: Peſtilence. 9.
div.p: THis queſtion is much toſsed and moued among men, what is to be iudged and thought of them, which in the time of plague and peſtilence do flye and departe from their vſuall dwellings.

Many do iuſtifie and hold well with their departing and going awaie: Other do condemne and diſalowe it. And they which do flye, do ſo defend their owne going awaye, that they reproue them of raſhnes which do not
flie, and do iudge them as tempters of God.
On the other ſide, they which do not flie, do ſo iudge of them that do flie, yea and do geue out ſuch ill report of them, that they do ſcarſe counte them worthie to be called Chriſtians.
Somwhat to ſpeake of both theſe parties, I ſhall thinke it verie expediēt & neceſsarie, to ſhew you what Muſculus mind is in this matter.

Firſte (ſaith he) they that do flie, let them acknowlege and deplore the infirmitie of their faith, let them not ſtoutlie defend it. For what pretence ſoeuer they make, it is moſt certaine, that they neither iudge well of them ſelues, neither yet of god, which doth ſmite and plague men.

They thinke, that this rodde of peſtilence is like to 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a nightlye conflicte, in which ther is no certaine direction of the ſtroke or blow that is geuen. They thinke (I ſaye) that this plague of peſtilence is brought by ſome chaunce, and that it doth ſmite them which be preſente, and that it can not touch thē, which haue withdrawen them ſelues from the infected place. But we knowe, that is moſt certainly affirmed of Chriſt, that all the heares of our head are nōbred to our heauenly father.

They ſaye, that they which do abide ſtill, do ſo tempt God, as they do, which when the houſe is on fire, and like to be burned, yet do remaine ſtill in the houſe, and put them ſelues in daunger of death.

But theſe men do not obſerue and marke, that manye which do not flie, yet are not taken nor infected with the peſtilence. And on the other ſide, that many alſo which do flie, yet they do not eſcape, but are infected.Exod. 9. Leuiticus. 26 Deuter. 28. 1. Paral. 21. Ezechiel. 6 14. et. 33. Vvhereupon it euidently appeareth that the plague of peſtilence is inflicted by the moderation of God. And that the peſtilence is the plague & ſcourge of god, it may be proued in many places of the ſcriptures.

Vvhat Chriſtian will ſo thincke or iudge of God, that he doth eyther raſhly or without ſcience or nombre ſo ſmit, that whoſoeuer dieth of the peſtilence, doth therfore die, becauſe he fled not from the place infected. And that man by chaungyng of places might eſcape the handes of God. But the ſcriptures do other wiſe inſtruct vs.

In Ezechiel they be marcked and ſigned, whome god ſpared and fauoured. Againe in an other place it is graunted vnto Noe, Iob, and Daniel, that if they wer preſent when the peſtilence rageth, for their righteouſnes they ſhuld ſaue theyr own liues or ſoules. Therfore, they which flie the peſtilence, do ſeme to me to do as vnhapie children do, who when their father is angrie, hauing a rod in his hand minding to beate thē, do flie out of the houſe, and by that meanes do the more exaſperate the fathers moode and angre. And yet notwithſtanding they not eſcape the rod by this their fliyng away, but do by it purchace to them ſelues more anger and ſharper ſtripes.

But they ſeme rather to flye well, which with humble ſubmiſsion of
mind, with the acknowledging of their ſinnes, and by true repentaunce do pacifie and mittigat the wrath of God ſo ſmiting them.

Ouer and beſide, they offende againſt chriſtian charitie, which do relinquiſh and forſake their brothers and neighbours in ſuch troubles and afflictions. The chriſtians in times paſte were wonte to imparte their helpe and pitie, euen vnto the heathen and gentiles, in ſuch plages and diſeaſes. They therfore whiche do labour with ſuch infirmitie of fayth and charitie, what maruell is it that they do flie from the horrour of death?

Nowe as touchinge them whiche do not flie, let them firſt conſider wherfore, and for what cauſe they do not flye, whither it be for lacke of certain neceſsarie charges whereby they may the better flie, or for any other cauſe. It is one thing, not to flie eyther by temeritie, or by contempte of the wrath of God, or for wante of monie or coſtage (for ſo the Turcks and infideles do.) And it is another thing, for one being armed with faith and charitie, to humble himſelfe in the ſight of god, and to deſire God to appeaſe his wrath, and ſo to tarrie with his brethren and neighbours, miſerablie a afflicted, and to mourn with them that mourne.

Alſo let them take hede that they iudge not ill of them which do flie, nor raile on them, nor curſe them, but by the affection of brotherly loue, be ſorie for their infirmitie, and committe their flight vnto gods clemencie: for excepte they do ſo, they may be counted a great deale worſe than they which do flie. Haec Muſculus in Pſalm.

But by maiſter Muſculus leaue and pacience I do iudge that god doth allow euerie man to vſe ſuche remedies as phiſicke doth appointe. For the wiſe man ſaith in his booke Eccleſiaſticus. Honour the Phiſition with that honour that is due vnto him, becauſe of neceſsitie, for the Lord hath created him, for of the moſt high commeth healing. And a litle after he ſaith: The Lorde hath created medicines of the earth, and he that is wiſe, will not abhorre it.

Nowe the phiſition ſaith that the beſt remedie to auoide the peſtilence, is to flie the aire. For to ſpeake naturallie, all peſtilence, as Galene writeth, commeth of the putrefaction and corruption of the aire. And the inſpiration of that aire is the cauſe why beaſtes and menne are ſo infected and taken with the peſtilence: whiche aire we canne not auoide, vnles wee flie to ſome other place where the aire is not ſo infected. Yet here is to be cōſidered, that they which haue office, and can not well by reaſon of their office flie, as paſtours, preachers, and certaine magiſtrats, either politique or oeconomicall, ought to tarie ſtill in their vſuall abode, and to prouide other remedies preſcribed by phyſicke to conſerue them in health.
Therfore to hold, that all without exception ought not to flye the peſtilente aire, I can not be induced to graunte, nor to conſente.

div.head: Aboue that you be hable to beare. 10.
div.p: PAule writeth to the Corinthians ſaying. There hath no tentation taken you, but ſuche as apperteineth to man. And God is faithful, which will not ſuffer you to be tempted aboue that you be able, but will euen geeue the iſſue with the tentation, that you may be able to beare it.

There be ſome whiche reade this ſentence in the Optatiue moode, as though Paule ſhould haue ſaid: I would to God, that no other temptation may take you, but the temptation of man. And they make a diſtinction betwene this and that temptation, wherwith God is tempted. But other (as Chriſoſtome) do reade it in the Indicatiue mode, ſaying: that it is a conſolation geuen of Paul vnto the Corinthians, leaſt they hearyng ſo horrible examples of ye wrath of God, being cōfuſed with feare, ſhould be vtterly diſmaid. For it is the continuall maner of the Apoſtle, after ſharp rebukyngs, ſtraight way to mittigate and appeaſe them. Therfore Paule doth here geue vnto them hope of pardon, and doth ſaye, that they fel into ſuch temptation as appertaineh to man. His meaning is this: There is no cauſe why you ſhuld be diſmaied. It is not my mind to bring vnto you any matter of deſperation. There is none other thinge chaunced vnto you, then that which happeneth vnto men.
Sainct Paule wrote to the Philippians,Cap. 2. ſaying & cum timore ac tremore operenum ſalutem veſtram: Make an ende of your owne ſaluation with feare and trembling.

This ſayinge mighte be thought to be very heauie and hearde. But ſainct Paule addeth immediatly theſe wordes. God worketh in you both the will and the deede, euen of his good pleaſure. So Paule addeth here in this place to the Corinthians: God is faithful &c. In the which words he doth ſhow howe they may reſiſte temptatiō. He biddeth thē to haue reſpecte vnto the Lorde, becauſe euery temptation, being neuer ſo ſmal, would ſtraight way oppreſſe vs, and we ſhuld vtterly periſhe if we wold truſte and leane onely to our owne power and ſtrength. Therfore, we muſt arme our ſelues with faith to reſiſt the ſondrie aſſaults of Sathan. For this is the victorie which ouercōmeth the world, euen our faith.

Paule calleth the Lorde faithfull, not onely becauſe he is true in his promiſes, but alſo becauſe he is a ſure keper and defender of his, vnder whoſe tuition we be ſafe. For God doth neuer forſake nor leaue his deſtitute.

Therfore ſayth Paule to the Corinthians, foraſmuch as he receaued you into his tuition, you neede not to feare, ſo that you wholy depend on him. For God will faithfully performe thoſe things which he hath promiſed. They can wante nothing which ſtriue for his honor. He geueth them power and ſtrength. He meaſureth temptations, and ſheweth awaye to come out of them.
Vnder the name of temptation, he comprehendeth generallie al things which do moleſte and trouble vs.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: Cap. 1.Paule writeth in the ſecond epiſtle to the Corinthians, ſaying: we are preſsed out of meaſure paſsing ſtrength. Ergo, this ſaying of Paul here- and an other ſaying there, can not be both true, for they be two cōtraries.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: The ſaying of Paule in the .2. epiſtle to the Corinthians, is to be vnderſtand of the vſuall ſtrength of man.
For Paule did alſo at the laſte vanquiſhe and ouercome that temptation.

Marke furthermore, that the croſſe of temptation is laide of God vpon the ſhoulders of the faithful, but it is not perpetual, leaſt they ſhould fall from grace, and in temptation deſpaire of ſaluation.
Therfore, God doth cauſe the temptation to ceaſse, that we ſhoulde not be tempted aboue that we are able to beare.

div.head: If God will ſo. 11.
div.p: SAinct Iames in his epiſtle rebuketh them, which ſay, go to now, to daye or to morowe we will goe into ſuche a citie, and continue there a yeare, and bye and ſell, and get gaine, and yet you can not tell what ſhalbe to morow. For what is your life? It is euē a vapour that continueth for a little time, and afterward vaniſheth awaye.
Therfore, ye ought to ſay: if the Lorde will, and if we liue, we wyll do this or that. &c.

It is a moſt fooliſh thinge for man to promiſe to him ſelfe any greate thing, when he his vncertaine what ſhall chaunce the nexte daye, as I haue lately declared before in the Miſcellane (To mororow.)
Here ſainct Iames doth elegantly by a ſimilitude of vapor, ſhew, that the counſels and deuiſes of man are but vaine, fadinge and vaniſhinge awaye.

Vapour is an airy coagulation comming of heat and of moiſtnes, hauing in it but a litle ſubſtaunce and is ſone diſolued, vnto ſuch a vapour S. Iames compared our life, and that very aptly. For, (as the prouerbe ſayth) homo bulla eſt: man is but a booble of water.
And Sophocles ſaith: homo ſpiritus eſt, et vmbra tantùm: Man is but onely breath and ſhadow.
Pindarus ſaith, that the life of man is nothing els, but vmbrae ſomnium, the dreame of a ſhadow. And ther is nothing more vaine then a ſhadow, for it ſemeth to be, and yet is nothing.

Therfore (ſaith Iames) ye ought in your ſayinges and doinges to haue both in minde and in mouth: if God wil, and if we liue. And yet it may chaunce ſomtime, that the godly and faithfull (who doth knowe that all their doings are directed by the wil of God) doo ſometime ſay, that they wil do this or that, without any ſuch exception.

It is very godly, when we promis any thing in time to come, to vſe theſe maners of ſpeaking: if it pleaſe the Lord, or if the Lord wil ſuffer. Yet we muſt make no religion of it, as though it were an haynous thing to omit ſuch phraſes. For we reade in the ſcriptures, that the holy men of God did ſpeake of things to come mithout condicion, when notwithſtanding they had in memory, yt they could do nothing but by ye permiſsion of God.

Saint Iames here doth touch them, which hauing litle reſpect to the prouidence of God, do make ſubiect vnto them ſelues the whole courſe of the yeare, when they haue not ſo much as one moment in their power. They promis to them ſelues lucre and gaine, which is far from them, whē they be not ſure to hold that, which is before their feete.

div.head: Hauing no nede. 12.
div.p: THer is a great queſtion, et adhuc ſub iudice lis eſt, whither the children may marry or contract them ſelues without ye conſent of the Parents.
To this queſtion, I wil in this Miſcellane make a reſolute anſwer. And firſt I wil put down myne aſſertion, & after proue the ſame with ſufficient teſtimonies.

div.head: Aſſertio.
div.p: It is of neceſsity, and not onely of honeſty, that the children ought not to marry without the conſent of their Parents.
This doctrine is proued and ratified by the holy ſcriptures, by the mindes of holy fathers, by the conſent of general councels, by the old Canons, and by the ciuile lawes.

div.head: Scriptures.
div.p: VVhen Iſaac came to mans ſtate, Abraham ſent his ſeruaunt vnto his kinred to finde out ther a wife for his ſonne. Note here, the Father ſent, and the ſonne ſought not.
Iſaac ſent Iacob into Meſopotamia to his vncle to get him a wife ther. His father ſent him.

After this, a law was geuen of God vnto Moſes, that children ſhould
honour their Parents. This honour doth not conſiſt onely in putting of the cap, and making curteſy, but in the relieuing and ſustaining them if nede be, and in ſhewing obedience and duty vnto them in al things lawful and honeſt,Cap. 22 wherupon ther is a peculiar law made in Exodus.

If a man entiſe a maide that is not betrothed, and lie with her, he ſhal endow her, and take her to his wife. If her father refuſe to geue her to him, he ſhal pay the dowry. Note here that this law ſaith: Si pater voluerit.

Cap. 30.In the booke of Numbers it is written: if a woman vow a vow vnto the Lord, and binde her ſelf by a bond, being in the fathers houſe in the time of her youth, and the father heare her vowe, wherewith ſhe hath bound her ſelfe, and the father hold his peace: the vow ſhal ſtand. If the father diſalow the vow, then the ſame ſhall be of no value. Note, if the Father diſallow.

Now I aſke what a vow is? It is a promiſe made to God, but Matrimony is a promiſe made to man. Now by an argument a maiori, if God doth permit and referre a vow made to him, to the iudgement of the father: much more will he permit and refer matrimony vnto his iudgemēt, for aſmuch as it is but a promiſe made betwene man.
In the booke of Iudges it is recorded, how that Sampſon ſayd to hys father and mother:Cap. 14. I ſaw a woman in Tinnath, nowe therefore geue me her to wyfe.
In Geneſis it is written, how that Sychem ſaid to his father Hamor: Get me the maide Dina, of her father Iacob to wyfe.
By this place it appeareth that the conſent of Parents is requiſite in mariage, ſeing the very infidels did alſo obſerue it as a thing neceſſary.
It is written that Thamar ſaid to her brother Amnon: Si me petieris a patre meo, me tibi non negabit. Note here: Si me petieris a patre meo.
Paule to the Epheſians ſaith: Filii obedite parentibus in omnibus. He excepteth nothing, but ſaith, in al thinges, ſpeciallye thoſe thinges which be not againſt Gods word.
In his epiſtle to the Corinthians he doth manifeſtly and plainly ſhew that it lieth in the Parents power to ſet their daughters to huſbandes.
This thing is proued, not onely by the law of god, but alſo by the light of nature, as certaine comedies do teache and declare.
In Euripides the daughter ſaith: Pater meus habet ſolicitudinem, & curam mei connubi.

div.head: Veteres patres.
div.p: Tertullianus ad vxorem ſaith: Ne in terris quidem filiae rite ac iure contrahere poſſunt matrimonium ſine conſenſu parentum. Lib. 2. That is: Not vpon the earth truly daughters can wel and rightly contract Matrimonie, without the conſent of their parentes.

Chriſoſtome writing vpon Timothie, doth exhorte the Parents to ioyne their children in Matrimony, by the reaſon of their ſlippery age.Q 1. hom. 9. He doth not exhort the children to chuſe them ſelues wiues where they will. His wordes be theſe. Mature illos matrimonio iungamus, vt munda atque integra illorum corpora ſponſae admoneantur. Let vs (ſaith he) (meaning the parents) couple our children in mariage in due time, that their bodies may be ioyned pure and whole vnto a wife.

Saint Auſtine being deſired to make a mariage betwene a yong man and a maiden, anſwereth: Facerem (inquit) ſed mater pueri non adeſt, Epiſt. 1.3.3. & tuſcis ad nuptias contrahendas eius voluntatem eſſe neceſſariam. I wold (ſayth he) but the mother of the man is not preſent. And you know that the conſent and will of her is requiſite to contract mariage.
Sainct Ambroſe doth ſo much allowe the ſaying of Euripides before rehearſed, that he putteth it into his booke of the Patriarches.

div.head: Quorundam patrum decreta et Cannones.
div.p: Euariſcus ſayth. Matrimonia tunc ſunt legittima, quando ſponſae petuntur a parentibus, et traduntur publice, aliter vero preſumpta, non coniugia, ſed adulteria, contubernia & fornicationes. That is to ſay: Matrimonies are then lawfull, when the wiues are aſked of their parentes, and are deliuered openly, otherwiſe they ar not mariages, but adulteries, vnlawfull companies and fornications.
Nicholaus ſayth.Ibidem capit Noſtrates. Ea firma ſunt matrimonia quae iunguntur conſenſu contrahenſium, et eorum in quorum ſunt poteſtate.
Thoſe be firme and true mariages which are coupled by the conſent of them that do contracte themſelues, and with the conſent of thoſe perſons, vnder whoſe authoritie they are.

Leo the firſt ſaith.Ibidem cap. qualis. Tunc intelligendum eſt matrimonium cum puella a parentibus traditur ſponſo. Then that is to be demed lawful matrimony, when the maiden is geuen of her parents to a huſband.

Againe, it is written in the decrees: Mulier que nupſit arbitrio patris eſt extra culpam ſi quis poſtea illi matrimonio detrahat. The womā that hath married by the arbiterment of her father, is without blame, yea although any hereafter do depraue or ſay againſt that matrimony.

div.head: Generalia concilia.
div.p:
The fourth general councel of Toletum:32. queſt. 1. ca hoc ſanctum Hoc ſanctum confirmat concilium vt viduae quibus placuerit teneant caſtitatem: quod ſi priuſquam profiteantur nubere elegerint, illis nubant quos propria voluntate voluerint habere maritos. Similis conditio de virginibus habeatur, nec extra voluntatem parentum, vel ſuam cogantur maritos accipere, that is: This holy councel doth confirme & ratifie that widowes which wil, mai liue chaſtly: but if before they profeſſe chaſtity, they wil chuſe to marry: let them marry them whō by their own wil they deſire to haue to their huſbands. Let the like condicion be had of maidens, neither let them be
conſtrained to marry without the conſent of their parents, nor againſt their own wils.

div.head: Reges ciuiles.
div.p: Titulo de Nuptiis.Iuſtinianus in his institutions, will in no wiſe Matrimony to conſiſt without the aſſent of the parents.

In. ff. de ſtatu. hom. Paulu.Againe: ſi filius vxorem duxerit invitis parentibus, filius qui naſcitur ex illis nuptiis, non erit legittimus, if the ſonne marry a wife againſt his fathers will, the childe that ſhall be borne in that mariage, ſhal not be lawfull.

Againe it is written: Filia patris voluntate nubit, ea poſtea conqueritur de marito, et ab eo diuertit, deinde in gratiam redit, et invito patre iterum eidem nubit. Reſpondetur illud non eſſe legittimū matrimoniū. That is: The daughter with the good will of her father doth marry, ſhe afterward doth complaine of her huſband, and departeth from him: afterward ſhe is againe reconciled to him, and marrieth him againe againſt her fathers will. It is anſwered, that yt matrimony is not lawfull.

Fu. L. Si ſurioſus.Finally, it is written. Filii ſi forte parentes furioſos habent et mente captos, quoniam illorum conſenſu vti non poſſunt in contrahendo matrimonio, curatorum ſuorum conſenſum adhibebunt. If peraduenture children haue to their parents mad men, & out of their mindes, becauſe they cannot haue their conſentes, they ought to haue the conſent of their gouernours.

Therfore, for as much as the law of God, the law of nature, the law politicke, Fathers, old Canons and Councels, do graunt the conſentes of parents to be neceſſarily required, why ſhould not we graunt and iudge the ſame? Beſides this, the example of Chriſt ſhould moue vs, who was geuen of his father a huſband vnto the church, and did alwaies ſay that he did not his own wyll, but the wyll of his father, who ſent him.

div.head: ¶Anſwers geuen vnto certain arguments and reaſons of the contrary part.
div.p: Firſt they ſay, that in contract of Matrimony, there ought to be a great liberty, and no ſeruile restraint, otherwiſe there wil fall out inconuenience.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: I do aſke what liberty they do meane, whether of the fleſh, or of the ſpirit? Truly the chiefeſt liberty of the ſpirit, is when we obey the commaundements of God, who if he wil haue vs to be obedient vnto our parents in other things, why not alſo I pray you in Matrimony?

If they pretend and craue ſo much liberty for the contract of matrimony, why haue they forbidden ſo many degrees to marry? Yea the Byſhops of Rome haue forbidden euen vnto the ſeuenth degree of kinred.
And if they wil haue ſo much liberty, why haue they forbidden and reſtrained matrimony, from the Miniſters of the church?
Furthermore, if ther ought to be ſo great libertie in mariage as they pretend, why did God forbid matrimony vnto a contrary religion?

div.head: The ſecond obiection.
div.p: The ſonnes and children for feare of the diſpleaſure of their parents may ſay that matrimony doth pleaſe them, which their fathers doth appoint, and yet in deede doth not pleaſe them, and ſo are conſtrained to marry againſt their wils, and to hate one another.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: The children are not conſtrained ſo to ſay, but may freely anſwer and ſay, that wife, or that huſband doth not pleaſe me. I wil none of thys matrimony. And doubtles alſo without the conſent of the child, matrimonie is to be contracted by no maner of meanes, as it is red in the law:In ff. de ritu nuptiarum. l. non cogitur. Filius non poteſt addigi vt vxorem ducat. A ſonne cannot be compelled to marrie a wyfe.

Vvhen Abrahams ſeruaunt came into Meſopotamia, and had found a wife for his maisters ſonne, when the parents of the mayd would haue the ſeruaunt to tary longer, and he would not, they called the Damoſell and aſked whither ſhe would go with him, or no.

Vvhen the fathers deale with their children tirantlike, and would conſtraine them to marry wiues, which they cannot brooke nor beare withal, then the matter is to be brought before the Magiſtrate, whoſe office it is to heare the cauſe, and to deliuer the ſame from iniury: than if the ſonne do marry by the authority of the Magistrate, yea although it be againſt the parents wil, it cannot be ſaid that he marrieth vtterly without the conſēt of his father, for a Magiſtrate eſt pater patriae, is the father of the country.

The ſcholemen doo not rightly ſay that the ſonnes haue power ouer their own bodies, they ought not in dede to be compelled againſt theyr will to marry: but that they may marry without the conſent of their parents, it cannot be graunted.

By the ciuile law the power of the father is ſo great, that he may ſell him, if he fal into extreme neceſsity.Cap. 21 The ſame is permitted alſo by the law of God, as in the booke of Exodus, yet with certaine cautions and circumſtances.
Vpon this I conclude, that they argue not well, which ſaye that that matrimony is a certaine kinde of bondage, which the ſonne cannot enter into, without conſent of the father.

div.head: The third obiection.
div.p:
The conſent of the parents in matrimony, is required in deede ad honeſtatem,
ſed non ad neceſsitatem, and ſo certaine diuines hold.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: This is a friuolous and vaine reaſon. For what neceſsity can be greater then that which the law and commaundement of God doth bring & require. Children are commaunded to honour father and mother. Saint Paule alſo doth preſcribe them to obey their parents in all thinges.

Againe to the Philippians he ſaith furthermore: brethren, whatſoeuer things are true, whatſoeuer thinges are honeſt, whatſoeuer thinges are iuſt, whatſoeuer things are pure whatſoeuer things pertain to loue, whatſoeuer things are of good report, thinke on thoſe things, do them.

By theſe words it appeareth, that thoſe thinges which be honeſt, are not to be ſeperated from the cōmaundement of God, and ſo I make this argument. The conſent of the parents is required, quoàd honeſtatem, honeſty is compriſed within the commaundements of God. Euery part of Gods commaundement is require of neceſsitye.

div.head: The fourth reaſon.
div.p: The conſente of Parentes is to be required, but yet if the Parentes will not conſent, then the matrimony of the children is good and lawful enough.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: This is nothing els but to deride and mocke the parents. For what contumely is this, the ſonne ſo to require the conſent of the father, and yet whither the father will or will not, he will remaine ſtill in his purpoſe, to put the ſame in execution? It wer much better not to aſke at al, then ſo to deſire it.

div.head: The fift reaſon.
div.p: VVhat ſhal we ſay of our forefathers, and of many other which now liueth and hath maried without the conſent of the parents? Shal we call them adulterers, and ſhal we take their childrē pro illegittimus?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: VVhen before the light of the goſpel ſuch mariages were had, ſuche perſons could not vtterly be excuſed from ſinne (for it was not lawfull for them to be ignoraunt of Gods law). Notwitſtanding, becauſe they were maried, the Magiſtrate than permitting them, they are to be takē for firme and ratified matrimony.

div.head: Replicatio,
div.p: But here wanted the conſent of the parents: Ergo. &c.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p:
The conſent of the parents was had ther, and not had there. For the Magiſtrate made the ciuil lawes ſubiect and vnder the Canons, whiche they ought not to haue done, and to this all menne almoſte doth agree. Then for as much as the magiſtrate hath authoritye ouer the people, if
the Magiſtrate doth conſent to any thing, that in a maner doth the publicke and common conſent of the people graunt. As for example, when in a great aſſembly the Magistrate and al the people meete to pay a great ſomme of money, although ſome one priuate man of the people doth diſſent, and doth not take it in good part: yet becauſe the Magiſtrate doth conſent, the ſame priuate man is counted alſo to conſent. So the Father would not haue his ſonnes mariage to be firme, without his conſent: yet becauſe he doth put his will to the iudgement of the Magiſtrate, he ſeemeth in a maner to conſent.

Therfore, the Matrimonies which hitherto haue bene made, before the knowledge of the light of the Goſpell, are to be taken and had as firme: but if the Magiſtrate doth now reuoke backe that errour, mariages to be made hereafter, ought to haue the conſent of the Parentes (iure diuino) ergo ex neceſſitate.
Alwaies this prouided and excepted, that in the cauſe of religion, fathers are not to be hearde, becauſe that in that caſe, God is to be hearde before all, for he is the father of all.

div.head: Concluſio.
div.p: The Canonistes doo iudge thoſe mariages to be lawfull, which are done without the conſent of Parentes, as it is written in their decrees, when the gloſe doth ſay, that when the woman commeth to adulte age, ſhe is releaſed from the power and authority of her father, both quoad iuramentum, & matrimonium.
And thys ſentence doo the Scholemen alſo follow. They diſpute that the ſonne hath power ouer his own body, and that he is not bound to his Parents, but may at his own arbitrement and choyce, marry.

The maister of the ſentence, himſelfe doth write, quod conſenſus patentum facit ad decoum nuptiarum, non ad neceſſitatem. That is to ſay: that the conſent of the parentes doth make the mariage comely, but is not of neceſsity. But how aptly and truly this is ſpoken, it is aunſwered before.

And marke (I pray you) how finely he doth interpreate the woordes of Euariſcus before recited: As when Euariſcus doth ſaye, that mariages contracted wythout the conſent of Parentes be not true mariages, but ſcortations and adulteries: that is (ſayth he) not for that they be ſo in dede, but bicauſe the parties doo agree betwene themſelues, as adulterers and fornicatours doo.

Euariſcus ſayth. Sunt adulteria, they be adulteries, Lumbardus ſaith: hoc eſt, videntur eſſe, that is, they ſeme to be: Vvhat expoſions be theſe, I pray you? Iuſtitia eſt virtus, videtur ſic eſſe virtus. Furta et homicidia ſunt peccata, ergo videntur ſic eſſe, et quod non ſic, ſunt re vera. O profundam theologicam, imo inanem potius ſophiſticationem.

To end, I am not, nor cannot be of that iudgemēt nor minde, that the Canoniſtes and ſcholemen be of, in this point, but do plainlye aſſerte and hold, that the conſent of the Parents to the childrens mariage is to bee graunted (ex neceſsitate, and not ex honeſtate ſolum,) and as yet canne not otherwiſe be reſolued, vnleſſe I heare better reaſons than hetherto I haue either heard or reade.

div.head: Ieiunium. Faſting. 13.
div.p: IEiunium is called in Hebrue Zom, in Greke 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Ieiuniū taketh ye name of inteſtinum, a bowel or gut, called ieiunū, becauſe it doth not containe and hold that which it receyueth, but forthwith letteth it go down into ye lower partes, yt by the example of it, we ſhould not burdē our ſelues wt to much meat.

Ieiunium a faſt, is a diſciplin, and chaſtiſing of the body, taken willingly for the time preſent, by the which we are made humble before God, and doo beriue the bodye of nouriſhment, that it maye obey the ſpirite.
There are two neceſsities which make vs to faſt, that is, a publicke neceſsity, and a priuate.
