Ioel. 2. Ionas. 3.Publicke neceſsity is when ſome calamity eyther preſſeth, or is ready to come vpon the church of God. The examples wherof do appeare in the Prophets.

This kinde of faſt was vſed in the time of the Apoſtles, as is read in the Actes. And this faſt to the old fathers ſemeth nothing or very little to haue differed from publicke mourning, wherof ther are many examples in the ſcriptures.
Priuate neceſsity is, when any man doth faſt, feeling him ſelfe to be vexed of his own luſt or concupiſcence, from which he taketh away the cauſe, that it may the leſſe inflame and burne.
In the Goſpell the Lord ſayde, that the ſonnes of the bride doo faſt, when the Bride is taken away from them, that is, in a hard time of neceſsitie.

Matrimony ſignifieth the bond with which we are ioyned to Chriſt in faith & ſpirit. In this perfect bond the godly eateth & drinketh with thanks geuing, & with that yt is ſufficient. The godly is glad, and reioyceth in theſe external giftes of God. But when he perceiueth the Bride to be ready to depart, or that he is almoſt gone out of his hart, that is to ſaye, when he feeleth the ſpirite to be ouercome with inſolencie of the fleſh, and perceiueth his fayth to be cold, then he prayeth and faſteth, that eyther he may retayne and keepe the Bride, or els ſtay hym when he is about to depart.

The whole life of Christians must be a fast, as Christ exhorteth vs ſaying. Videte ne grauentur corda veſtra crapula vel ebrietate. Take hede least your harts be laden with ſurfets, or with dronkennes.

In olde time (when diſcipline was of force) the people gaue thēſelues wholy ſometimes to puniſhe the fleſh and to prayers. And this diſcipline was inſtitute, and ordained, either when calamitie was at hand (which thing oftentimes happened in the primatiue church when grieuous perſecutions wer in al places put in vre) or els when ſome gret and worthy thing was to be done in the church, which had nede to implore and pray for the aſsiſtaunce of the holy ghost. As when Ministers and Paſtours of the church wer ordered. The example wherof we reade in the Actes of the Apoſtles, when Paule and Barnabas were called to the miniſterie.
In the old law once in the yeare ther was a faſt ordained to pourge ſinnes.

The Lord would (when Moſes aſcended into the mount Sinai, and gaue lawes) that the people ſhould come before him, waſhing their garments, and abſtaining from their wiues for the ſpace of three daies. And when they faſted, they did ſet apart all other buſines, and attended to faſting and prayer. Vvherupon the day of faſting was made a ſolemne holy day among the Iewes.

I do euidently finde both in the old teſtament, and in the new, that faſting was cōmaūded. But on what daies we oght to faſt, or not to faſt, I do finde cōmaunded neither of God, nor of the Apostles.Epiſt. 86.

Saint Auſtine ſaith: Pariter duo ieiunia ieiunauerunt, id enim eſt cor poris et animae. &c. That is: they faſted two faſtes together, to wyt, of the body, and of the ſoule, that is to ſay, refraining from wrath, from furie, ſlaundring, blaſphemy, and brawling, becauſe theſe are the deadly meates of the ſoule, which do feede and procure it to do ill, and do bring it to euerlaſting death.

Againe, the meates of the body and ſoule be theſe: gluttony, ſluggiſhnes, fornication, dronkennes, and ſecurity. Theſe be the meates of the body and ſoule, which doo feede the body, and kill the ſoule.De ſalutar. do cumētis. c. 48.

The ſame S. Auſtine ſaith in an other place: Nihil prodeſt tota die lō gum duxiſſe ieiunium, ſi poſtea ſua vitate ciborum vel nimietate anima obruatur, &c. That is. It doth nothing auaile to faste all the day, if afterwardes the ſoule be ouerwhelmed with delicate meates. The minde being filled, forthwith is ſluggiſhe, and the earth of our body being watered, will bring forth filthy luſt: therfore let the meate be temperate, and let the bellie be neuer to full.

Origine writeth thus. Ieiunio ſic adhibenda temperies, vt corpus veſtrū
nec ſaturitas excitet, nec inedia immoderata debilitet. Faſting muſt ſo be temperated, that neither fulnes maye excite and ſtir the body, neither immoderate hunger may weaken the body.Eccleſi hiſto.

Euſebius ſayth. Quale eſt illud ieiunium, quod non veſceris carnibus, et de ore tuo omni eſca ſordidius egreditur? &c. That is. VVhat maner of faſte is that, that thou eatest not fleſhe, and that which is more filthye than all meates, goeth out of thy mouth? Vvhat faſt is that that the belly is ſancttified with faſtings,Conc. 2. and the toung is polluted with lies?
The Councell Barcarenſe, doth anathematiſe him which abstaineth from eating of fleſh, vnleſſe there be a cauſe of abſtinencie.

Apollonius diſputing againſt Montanus the hereticke, ſaith: Hic eſt qui docuit nuptias ſolui, et qui ieiuniorum leges primus impoſuit. This is he which taught that Matrimony is to be diſſolued, and which firſt made the lawes of faſting.Euſe hiſt. lib 5. Cap. 18.

Vve reade alſo in Euſebius this ſaying: Non ſolum de die paſchae agitur controuerſia, ſed de ipſa ſpecie ieiuniorum. &c. that is. There is a great controuerſy not onely of Eaſter day, but alſo of the kind and manner of faſtings: for ſome do thinke, that the faſt ought to be obſerued one ly one day, ſome two dayes, ſome more, ſome alſo forty daies, counting the nightes with the dayes: which diuerſity of obſeruations, did not firſt begin in our time, but long before vs. And they (I thinke) beganne it firſt, which not ſincerely obſeruing that which was taught at the beginning, did otherwiſe, either by negligence, or by ignoraunce determine and appoynte them.

Notwithſtanding al theſe, though they dyd vary in obſeruations, yet they wer and be at peace with vs. Neither did the diſſention of faſtinge breake the vnity and agrement of faith. Theſe be the wordes of Ireneus gathered out of the eccleſiaſticall hiſtories.Tripart hiſt. lib 9. cap. 58.
Socrates declareth, that this diuerſity of faſtings was in the church in the reigne of Theodoſius Anno. 1453.

But they hadde not like abſtinence from meats, for ſome didde altogether abſtayne from meates that hadde life: Some didde eate onelye fiſhe: ſome with fiſhes didde eate alſo foules, ſayenge with Moſes, that ſoules do get their liuing in the water, and haue theyr ſubſtance out of it ſome alſo did abſteine from rootes and from egges ſome did eat onely dry bread ſome did faſt vntill nine of the clocke, making no difference of meates: with innumerable kinds of obſeruations and cuſtome. And becauſe ther is found no aunciente and old hiſtory of this matter, I thinke that the Apoſtles left it free for euery man to do good woorkes, not for feare,Eſdras 18. Iudith 4. Heſter. 4. nor for neceſsity. Haec Socrates.
Faſting goeth before praier, as it appeareth in Eſdras, Iudith, and Heſter.

Saint Hierome ſaith:In epiſt. ad Galath. ca. 4. Ieiunia et congregationes inter dies propter eos a viris prudentibus conſtituuntur. &c. That is: Faſting and praier on certaine daies is appointed of wiſe men, for them which ſerue the world more than God: neither they can, yea they will not aſſemble and pray together in the church all their life time. Neither they will offer their ſacrifice of praier vnto God before their worldly buſines. For how many are ther, which at the leaſt wil obſerue and kepe theſe few daies that are appointed for faſting and praier?In prolog. in Math.
The ſame Hierome ſaith, that faſting was ordeined with prayer, when ſaint Iohn wrote his goſpel.

Againe, ſaint Hierome ſaith:Lib. 2. cont. Iouinianum. Nos vnam quadrageſimam ſecundum traditionem apoſtolorum toto anno, tempore nobis congruo ieiunamus &c. Vve do faſt one Lent (after the traditions of the Apoſtles) all the yeare, at a time expedient and meete for vs. But the Montaniſtes doo make three Lents in the yeare, as though there had ſuffered three Sauiours.

Chriſoſtome ſaith: Medicina eſt ieiunium, ſed medicina, Tomo. 4. Homil. 8. de ieiunio. lieet millies vtilis ſit, tamen per imperitiam vtentis invtilis fit ſaepe. &c. That is: Faſting is a medicine, but the medicine (although it be much profitable) yet by the ignoraunce of him that faſteth, it is often times made vnprofitable. Vve must know wel both the time in which it is nedeful to faſt, and alſo the quantity of the medicine, the temperature of the body, the nature of the country, the tyme of the yeare, and conueniēt foode muſt be wel knowne. Faſting did not deliuer the Niniuites from perill, the chaunging and amendment of life did appeaſe the wrath of God.

This I haue ſpoken, not that we ſhould contemne faſting, but that we ſhould honour it. For the honour of faſting is not abſtinence frō meates, but the flieng from ſinne. Therfore, he that defineth faſting to be onely an abſtinence from meates, doth greatly contemne faſting.

Chriſoſtome ſaith:Ibidem. Si quotidie huc conuenimus totam quadrageſimam, ieiunemus, & non mutemus vitam, in melius maioris damnationis occaſio fieret. If we dayly aſsemble hether, if we fast all the Lent, & doo not amende our liues, it will cauſe vs to haue the greater dampnation.Mar. 5.
Our Sauiour Chriſt ſayth: Hoc genus demoniorum in nullo poteſt exire, niſi in oratione et ieiunio. This kinde of deuils can not go out of a man, but by prayer and fasting.In epiſt. ad fannarium.

Saint Austine ſayth. Alia vero quae per loca terrarum regioneſ
que variantur. And other thinges that doo varry and differ in Countries (as this that ſome doo fast on the Saboth day, and ſome not, ſome doo communicate and be partakers of the bodye and bloude of Christe euerye daye,
and ſome on certaine daies, and ſuch other like) may be obſerued at liberty. For that which doth not repugne the faith and good cuſtomes, may be vſed indifferently, and may be obſerued for the ſociety of them among whom we liue.

My mother following me to Millaine, found a church that fasted not on the Saboth day, and beganne to doubt what ſhe might doo. Then I aſked counſell of this matter of Saint Ambroſe, then Biſhoppe of Millaine: who aunſwered, when I come to Rome, I doo fast on the Saboth, when I am at Millaine, I do not faſt. So alſo thou, to what Church ſoeuer thou ſhalt happen to come, keepe their vſe and cuſtome, if thou wilt offend no man, neither any man will offend thee. Vvhen I told this to my mother, ſhe gladly embraced it.

Epiſt. ad fannar.Againe, ſaint Auſtine ſaith: Si volumus deo placida exhibere ieiunia, ſumus in oratione continui, in iudiciis iuſti. &c. That is: if we will pleaſe God with faſting, let vs pray continually, let vs iudge vprightly, let vs be faithfull in friendſhip, let vs ſuffer iniuries paciently, in contentions let vs be moderate, let vs auoide filthy talke. Let vs be ſtoute againſt iniquitye, in banquets temperate, in charitye ſimple and pure, ware among them that be ſubtill, ſorowing among them that be ſadde, reſiſting them that be ſtubborne, in ſuperſticions ſpare, ſilent among euil ſpeakers, among the humble coequal.

De ſpiritu et anima.The ſame Auguſtine ſayth: Sic debes ieiunare, vt non palpites, vt vix reſpirare poſsis. &c. So thou oughteſt to faſt, that thou maieſt not pant, that thou maieſt ſcarce take breath, and that thou maieſt eyther be caried or drawen with the handes of thy fellowes: but that the concupiſcence of the body being broken, thou doo not beſtow leſſe time in reading in the Pſalmes, nor in watchinges, then thou waſt wont to doo.

Ad Demetriadem.Saint Hierome alſo ſaith: Non ſanat oculum quod calcaneo adhibetur, ieiunio paſsiones corporis, oratione peſtes ſanandae ſunt mentis: the medicine that is put to the heele, doth not heale the eye, that lust of the body is to be healed with faſting, the diſeaſe of the minde with praier.

Super marcū Sermo. 38.Againe he ſaith in an other place: Tantum tibi ieiuniorum impone modum, quantum ferre poteſt. &c. That is: Meaſure thy faſtinges ſo much as thou canſt ſuffer. Let them be pure, ſimple, and chaſte, let them be moderate, and not ſuperſticious.

VVhat doth it proffit, not to eate oyle, and to ſeeke certaine troubleſome and difficull meates, as drye figges, pepper, nuttes and ſuche like? And while we doo ſeeke for delicate meates, we are drawen backe from the kingdome of heauen.

Furthermore, I doo heare that ſome menne againſte nature doo not drinke water, nor eate bread, but doo ſuppe thinne delicate broathes,
not in a cuppe, but in a bole curiouſly made. Are we not aſhamed of ſuch fooliſhnes? nor doth it yrcke vs of ſuch ſuperſtitions?In epiſtola ad Galath.

Bernardus ſaith: If onely thy mouth haue ſinned in gluttonie, let it onely faſte, and it is enoughe. But if the other members haue ſinned, why do not they alſo faſt? Therfore, let thine eye faſt both from curiouſe ſightes, and from all wantonnes, that it being well humbled, may be corrected with penaunce, which walked at libertie in ſinne. Let the eare faſte whiche ytched wickedly at fables and tales, and idle words, nothing perteinyng to ſaluation. Let the tongue faſt from backbytinge, murmuryng from vnproffitable and naughtie words. Let the hands faſt from all workes, that are not commaunded to be done.

But let the ſoule much more faſte from vice, and from her owne will and luſt. For without this faſt all other are reproued of the Lorde. As it is written: Quia in diebus ieiuniorum veſtrorum, voluntates veſtrae inueniuntur. For becauſe in the dayes of your faſtings, your own willes are founde.

Furthermore, ſainct Hierome ſaith: Dies obſeruatis, & menſes, De doctrina chriſtiana. di. & tempora, & annos, dicat aliquis &c. Some man maye ſay, you do obſerue dayes, moneths, times and yeres, we alſo do incurre the like faulte obſeruing the fourth daye after the Saboth, the fridaye and the Sondaye, the faſt alſo of Lent, the feaſt of Eaſter, whitſondaye, and the feaſtes of holy martirs in ſondrie countries diuerſly ordeined & inſtituted. To the which a man may plainly anſwere, that the dayes of the Iewiſhe obſeruations are not the ſame that ours be: for wee do not celebrate the paſseouer of vnleauened breade, but of the reſurrections of the croſſe.

Neither we do nombre ſeuen weekes in Pentecoſte, after the cuſtome of the Iewes, but we do obſerue the comminge of the holy ghoſt. And leaſt a diſordered congregation of the people, ſhould diminiſh the fayth in Chriſt, therfore ſome dayes are appointed, that we ſhould aſsemble and come all together. Not, that that daye (in which we meete together) ſhould be the more ſolemne, but that, on what daye ſo euer we muſt come together, we may ye more reioyce by beholding one an other. But they which do anſwere this queſtion more pithilie, do affirme that all dayes are alike, and that Chriſt not onely is crucified on the fridaye, and riſeth againe on the Sonday, but the daye of reſurrection is alwaies, and that they do alwayes eate the fleſhe of Chriſt.41. cant. quiſquis.

Saint Auſtine alſo ſaith: Quiſquis rebus praeterenutibus reſtrictius vtitur, quam ſe habent mores eorum cum quibus viuit, aut intemperans, aut ſuperſtitioſus eſt. &c. that is. Vvhoſoeuer doth obſerue tranſitorie things, more ſtraitly then is vſed amongs them with whome he liueth, he is eyther vntemperate, or ſuperſtitious.

And whoſoeuer doth ſo obſerue them that he do excede the boundes, that good men (with whome he liueth) do obſerue, eyther he ſignifieth ſome thing, or els he is an euel man. For in al ſuch thinges the vſe and cuſtome is not in fault, but the vnlawfull appetite and luſt. Therfore that which is conuenient, and agreable to the time, place, and perſon, is diligently to be obſerued: leaſte we reprehende and raſhly counte any thinge to be ſinne. For it may be, that a wiſe man may vſe precious & delicate meat without any gredie deſire, and an vnwiſe man may burne vpon vile and courſe meate with the filthie flame of gluttonie. &c.
I read an olde verſe in which is conteyned the vſe and abuſe of faſting, this is the verſe.
div.q: Abſtinet aeger, egens, cupidus, gula, Simia, virtus.
div.p: The ſicke man faſteth becauſe he hath no appetite to eate, or by the reaſon of ſome medicine receiued.
The poore man faſteth, becauſe he hath not for to eate.
The couetous man faſteth, to ſpare meate and drincke.
The gluttonous man faſteth, that he may after eate the more gredily.
The ape, that is, the hipocrite, faſteth, to ſeke the praiſe of man.
The godlyy man faſteth to mortifie his fleſhe, and to mourne for his ſinnes.

div.head: Faſting may be vnlawfull in fiue caſes.
div.p: Firſt, when that thing which is neceſsarie for the ſuſtention of life, is denied to man.
Secondly, when that thing which is neceſsarie (concerning office & ſocietie) is withdrawn, as from the preacher and other that be in office.
Thirdly, when any perſon is hindered or let from the workes of charitie.
Fourthly, when any perſone through a voluntarie vowe of faſtinge doth macerat and conſume his bodie, which vowe ought not to be kept, but chaunged.
Fiftely, when by reaſon of the fasting daye, men do eate and drincke exceſsiuely without meaſure, or when in the faſting day, more exquiſite meates, are more ſought and had, then on other dayes.
Looke more for faſting in the Miſcellane. Choice of meates.

div.head: Croſſes on our ſelues. 14.
div.p:
SAinct Auſtin in his retractions maketh mention of the Donatiſts, who threatned to deſtroye themſelues with fire, rather thē they would returne to the church. From the which wicked opinion one Dulcitius did diſuade them: ſaying, that if they thought them
ſelues iuſte and good men, they ſhould rather flie, according to Chriſtes commaundement: than wickedly to burne them ſelues in the fyre.Epiſt. 50

Alſo in his epistle ad Bonifacium, he reherceth three kinds of death, wherewith the Donatiſtes willingly deſired to be killed, or rather killed them ſelues. Firſt, ſome of them woulde deſire thoſe whiche were worſhippers and kepers of Idoles, to deſtroye them: Other would offer them ſelues to the armed men, lying by the high waye ſide, to be ſlayne of them. Other of them thought it a ſport to throwe them ſelues downe hedlonge from high places into the water and into the fire. Theſe three kindes of death (ſaith Auſtine) the deuell taught them, who ſuggeſted Chriſt to caſt himſelf downe hedlong from the pinacle of the temple.

So in like maner in theſe daies the Anabaptiſts with certain other, deſire to haue croſses layde vpon them without iuſt cauſe, or before God doth lay them vpon their ſhoulders. Vvhere they both tempte God, & breake the commaundement of Chriſt, who ſaith to his diſciples: If they perſecute you in one citie, flie to an other. For Chriſte would not haue vs to caſte our ſelues raſhely and without vrgent cauſe into the handes of the raging enemies, or to the perill of death. Nor a chriſtian ought to be imbraided or rebuked for flying of perſecution, ſo that he flie as he ought to do: and alſo when he ought to do, as Helias by flying did eſcape the furie of Ieſabel. Dauid by flying did eſcape the raging crueltie of Saul. Paul by flying did aduoide the perſecuting handes of the ruler of the citie of Damaſcus. He was let downe ouer the wall by the diſciples, and ſo eſcaped.

Notwithſtanding the ſame Paule, when the faith ought manfullie to be deſended, did ſtand to his tackle, and offred his neck to the blocke, and woulde not flie nor departe. Vvhen the diſciples moſte earneſtly deſired him that he woulde not go to Hieruſalem, leaſt he ſhould ſuffer thoſe things which Agabus had prophecied: he would in no wiſe conſent, but ſaid: what do you thus weping and troubling my hartes? I do deſire and wiſh, not onely to be bounde in bondes, but alſo to ſuffer death at Hieruſalem, for the name of my Lorde Ieſus Chriſt.

div.head: Quaeſtio cum obiectione.Cap. 10.
div.p: Maye we then ſomtime flye, and ſomtime not flye? Saint Iohn in his goſpell ſaith, that a good ſhepherde geueth his life for his ſhepe. But an hireling, and he which is not the ſhepheard, neither the ſhepe ar his own, ſeeth the wolfe comming, and he leaueth the ſhepe and flyeth, and the wolfe catcheth them, and ſcattereth the ſhepe. Now if the ſhephearde ought to put his life in ieopardie for his ſhepe: Ergo he ought not to flye, for al that do flye, ar no ſhepheards but hirelings.

div.head: Reſponſio
div.p: If the paſtour of a church be ſo neceſſarie to the christian publique weale, and for his ſhepe to be fedde that his preſence muſt needes be had, than he ought not to flie, but ought with daunger of life to gouerne, kepe and deliuer his ſhepe committed to his charge, from the perill of ſpirituall death. For when & wher there is none to ſupplie his roume, & ſo by fliyng doth bring his ſhepe into daunger of destruction, he ought with a bolde minde to abide and to ſustein perſecution, euen vnto death (if nede be.) For it is a noble thing to ſuffer death for the commoditie of a publique weale.

On the other parte. If the Prelate or paſtour be ſought of the fierce perſecutours, and threatned to be put to death, if there be in that place other learned, wiſe, and godly miniſters, which can as well prouide for the inſtructiō & ſauing of the ſhepe, as he can, then he may lawfully flie.

And the reaſon is this: He ſought not to loſe his life and bodie, and to put himſelfe forth to the perill of death, when his flocke may otherwiſe be kepte ſounde and ſafe, and do ſuffer none or verie litle hurte by his flyinge.
And it may happen that a greater commoditie may follow if he flye for a time from them, then if he had remained with them.

Saint Auſtine vpon theſe wordes of Chriſt: cum vos perſecuti fueritis in vna ciuitate, fugite in aliā, writeth after this maner: Quis autē credit ita haec dominum fieri voluiſſe vt neceſſario miniſterio, ſine quo viuere nequeunt deſerantur greges, quos ſuo ſauguine comparauit? &c. Vvho may beleue that the Lord would haue it ſo, that the flocke whcih Chriſt hath purchaſed and gotten with his owne bloud, ſhould be forſaken and made deſtitute of the neceſsarie miniſterie without the which they can not liue? Vvhen the Apoſtle Paule fledde, the church was not lefte voide of the neceſsarie miniſterie, but that thing whiche ought to be done, was accompliſhed by other faithfull brethren, which remained there. For the Apoſtle did flye, the other diſciples willinge and egginge him forward, that he ſhould preſerue and kepe himſelfe to the vſe and proffit of the church. Therfore l • t the ſeruants of Christ, the miniſters of his wordes and ſacraments, do that which he hath commaunded and permitted, let thē flye at all tymes frō citie to citie, when any of thē ſpecially and perſonally is ſought of the perſecutours, ſo that the church be not left deſolate of other whiche are not ſo perſecuted, and which may geue foode to their felowe ſeruaunts, whome they know not to be able otherwiſe to liue. But when the perill and perſecution is generall, perteinyng to the whole nombre of biſhops and the clergye, then let not thē which lack other, be lefte & forſaken of them whan they lack and wāt.
Therfore eyther let them go all to places where they may be defended, or they which muſt nedes tarie • , let them not be lefte and forſaken of them, by whome their eccleſiaſticall neceſsitie ought to be ſupplied: ſo that they may altogether eyther liue, or els altogether ſuffer, that which the father of the houſe will haue them to ſuffer. And ſo forth you may reade more of this matter in all the ſaide epiſtle written to Honoratus.
To this iudgemēt of ſainct Auſtine Lyranus doth conſent and agree, expoundinge that place of Iohn whee it is ſaid, that a good ſhepheard doth put his life for his ſhepe, his wordes be theſe.

Nomine lupi venientis ſuper oues, aliquando intelligitur diabolus per tentationes fideles infeſtans: aliquando hereticus per falſam doctrinam corrumpens: aliquando tyrannꝰ violentia armorū perſequens. &c. that is: By the name of the wolfe comming vpon the ſhepe, ſomtime the deuell is vnderſtand, moleſting the godly chriſtians by tentations, and ſomtime by the name of the wolfe is vnderſtande an heretique, corrupting the ſheepe by falſe doctrine, and ſomtime a tyraunte perſecutinge by violent armes and ſtrength, is vnderſtande by the name of a wolfe.

In the firſt and ſecond ſignifications, it is to flye, becauſe ſuch wolfes ought not to be reſiſted by the paſtour corporallye, but rather ſpirituallye by deuoute prayer, by holy preaching, and ſounde doctrine.

In the thirde ſignification of the name of a wolfe, a diſtinction is to be made. For the perſecution is eyther perſonall, or els generall. If it be perſonall, ſo that it be againſt the paſtour onely, & not against the flock committed vnto him, than he may lawfully flie: But if the perſecution be common both againſt the ſhepherd and alſo the floke, yet a diſtinction is to be made. For eyther ther is but onely one paſtour, or els there be many paſtours and preachers. If ther be but one onely, than he ought not to flye and forſake his flocke, for otherwiſe he ſhoulde be an hirelyng, and not a ſhepherd. If there be many paſtours, of whom the church hath nede, than ſome ought to remaine, and other maye flye, that the flocke remainyng behinde, may be ſufficienly gouerned and fed. And if they contende who ſhal tarrie, and who ſhall flee, they may, callyng for grace of the holy ghoſt, decide the matter by lots.

Athanaſius hath made a long and goodly apologie concerning flying from perſecution, in the which among all other things he writeth thus. Age iam quid ſacrae ſcripturae de iſtiuſmodi reloquātur inſpiciamus, &c. Go to nowe, let vs ſe what the ſcriptures do ſpeake of this thing, and ſo ſhall it appere that they fighte with the holy ſcriptures, and that they ſlaunder the vertues and godly dealynges of the ſainctes and of the holy men. For if they diſpiſe thē which had and conueyed them ſelues awaye, and if they do ſlaunder them which flye and auoyde perſecutours, when
they ſought them vnto death, what will they do I praye you, when they ſee Iacob flying from his brother Eſau? and Moſes for feare of Pharao to departe to the Madianites? Or what will theſe bablers and ianglers anſwere vnto Dauid flying out of his owne houſe, when Saul ſent ſouldiours to kill him? and when he hidde himſelfe in a denne and chaunged his countenaunce, to eſcape from Abimelech and his aſſaultes?

Again, what will theſe praters ſaye, when they ſee that great prophete Elias called a God, and raiſing the dead, to hide him ſelfe for feare of Achab, and to flye the menaces of Ieſabell: At what tyme alſo the children of the prophetes being ſoughte vnto death, did kepe them ſelues cloſe in dennes with Abdias. Peraduenture they haue read nothynge of theſe thinges, as ouer olde, or do not remember what thinges are written in the goſpell. But what do they not know that the diſciples for feare of the Iewes did ſeeke ſecrete and cloſe places? Do they not know, that Paule was let ouer the wall in a baſket at Damaſcus, when the Gentiles ſought him to deliuer hym to the Rular?

And a litle after he ſayth, in the conſummation of the worlde when that worde of the father came whiche ſpake to Moſes, before he made and gaue againe a commaundement of flying, ſaying: when they perſecute you in one citie, flye to an other.

He ſaith alſo, when ye ſhall ſe the abhomination, of deſolation which was ſpoken of before in Daniel ſtanding in ye holy place, he that redeth let him vnderſtande. Then let them which be in Iewrie, flee vnto the hilles, and he that is in the houſe toppe, let him not come downe to take any thyng out of his houſe, and he which is in the feildes, let him not returne home to fetch his garments.

Vvhen the holye men of God knewe this, they framed their lyfe to this rule, for that which God hath inioyned, is to be done. And ther fore the worde it ſelfe whiche was made man for vs, would (when he was ſought to be perſecuted) flye and auoyde the aſſaultes of the perſecutour. For it becomed him to ſhewe hym ſelfe to beare our fleſhe, and to be made man, not onely in hungryng, thyrſtyng, and ſuffring, but alſo in the reaſon and meanes of flying. For aſſone as he was borne, and alſo when he was a childe, Ioſeph was commaunded of the Angel to take the child, and his mother to flye awaye, for Herode ſought his life. And after, when Herod was dead, fearing Archelaus, departed into Nazareth.
Furthermore when by healyng the withered hande, he ſhewed hym ſelfe to be God, and the Iewes ſeekyng counſell to kill him, he beynge not ignoraunt of their aſsaults, departed from theſe places.

Alſo after he had raiſed Lazarus from death, from that houre
they tooke counſell to kill him. Vvherfore Ieſus did not walke openlye among the Iewes, but went into a place nere to the wildernes.

Furthermore when he ſaid: Antequam Abraham fieret, ego ſum. Before Abraham was, I am. The Iewes takyng vp ſtones to caſte at him, he hidde him ſelfe, and wente out of the temple, paſsing through the middeſt of them.

Ieſus alſo hearing the martyrdome of Iohn the Baptiſt, whom when his diſciples had buried, he went into a ſhippe and departed into the deſerte. Therfore as the Lorde did, ſo he taught. Now I feare leaſt theſe men not ſtayinge their luſt and pleaſure of imbraidyng within the compaſſe of mans checkes, but being caried further with their madnes, will obiecte alſo vnto their Lorde God timiditie and fearfulnes. But who can abide and ſuffer them ſo raging and running into ſuch madnes? It is better that they be ſayd and counted to be ignoraunt of the goſpell &c, where he entreateth of this matter at large.

Saint Auſtine maketh mention of this Athanaſius,Epiſt 1280. and ſaith that he did well to flye, when Conſtantius the emperour did deſire to apprehende ſpeciallye hym, yet he lefte not the Catholique congregation (which was at Alexandria) deſtitute of other miniſters.
Thus haue I ſhewed at large when a paſtour ought to flye, and when he ought not to flye.

div.head: Homaeoſis. 15.
div.p: HOmaeoſis is called in Latin ſimilitudo, and it is thus defined: Homaeoſis eſt minus notae rei per ſimilitudinem eius quae magis nota eſt, demonſtratio: that is. Homaeoſis is a demonſtration of a thing leſse knowen, by the ſimilitude of that thing, which which is more knowen. As in the pſalmes. Ecce ſicut oculus ſeruorum in manibus dominorum ſuorum: ſicut oculi ancillae in manibus dominae ſuae: Ita oculi noſtri ad dominum deum noſtrum, donec miſcreatur noſtri.

Beholde, lyke as the eyes of ſeruauntes looke vnto the hande of their maiſter, and as the eyes of a mayden, vnto the hand of her maiſtres: ſo our eyes waite vpon the Lorde our God, vntill he haue mercie vpon vs.
This figure doth bring vnto the oration great light and dignitie, and it is very proffitable to proue.

div.head: Example.
div.p:
As they do moſte greuouſly offende which do infecte with poyſon a common wel where all men do draw: ſo they deſerue worſe of a common
weale, which do corrupt the mind of a prince with pernitiouſe counſels.

div.head: An other example
div.p: As in daungerous ſaylynge the ſterne is not committed to him which excelleth in riches and nobilitie, but to him which is experte in the cunnynge of nauigation: So it behoueth not to deliuer vnto him a princely gouernment (whiche is richer and more honorable than other) but to him which doth excell other in wiſdom, pollicie and fidelitie.
The holye ſcriptures are ful euerie where of this figure. Among the doctours of the church none vſeth this figure more ofte and largely, then Iohn Chriſoſtome.

This figure may be varied fiue maner of wayes. For there is,
Similitudo.
Iucunda.
Grandis.
Acris.
Mediocris.
Humilis.

div.head: An example of the firſt.
div.p: As when the Vveſte winde bloweth with her pleaſant blaſtes, the foulenes and ſadnes of winter is put awaye, and the whole face of nature waxeth newe and younge, again the trees are beautified with boughes, and the grene graſſe is diſtinguiſhed with the ſight of diuerſe flowers, and the ſunne it ſelfe, and the whole ſhewe of heauen doth delight the eies with a pleaſaunte aſpect: ſo aſsoone as the grace of the holy ſpirite doth blowe vpon the minde of man, forthwith doth the deformitie and foulnes of the former life paſse awaye. And in the ſteede of vices, the whole life ſhineth with vertues of comelines. So that, that man may be counted to be borne againe, and luckely to waxe younge.

div.head: Example of the ſeconde.
div.p: As God, when he lacketh nothing, yet by his own nature is glad to do good to all men: ſo they which call God father, ought frelye to deſerue well of all men, as much as in them lieth.

div.head: Example of the third.
div.p: Doeſt thou waxe pale, and arte thou afraide of the hiſsing and biting of a viper, and doeſt runne to the phiſition?
Howe muche more is filthie ſinne to be abhorred and feared, which hath worſer poiſon then all vipers: and howe much ſooner ought medicine to be ſoughte?

div.head: Example of the forth.
div.p:
As they which by the counſell of Heſiodus do often adde ſmal things to ſmall, and ſo at laſt do become rich: So he which groweth in vertue
more and more, at laſt becometh perfect.

div.head: Example of the fifte.
div.p: As beggers if they haue any good thing do conceile it, and do onelye ſhewe their ragges and their ſores, wherby they maye ſtirre the compaſsion of the beholders: ſo it behoueth vs not to boaſte our good dedes before God, but to profeſſe and confeſſe our euilles, if we wil prouoke his mercie towarde vs.

There be three kinds or ſpices of this ſcheme Homaeoſis, as Mancinellus declareth in his Diſtichon:
Fertur homaeoſis quoties fit ſimilitudo.
Sunt ſpecies, Icon & parabola & paradigma.
Icon is an oration ſhewinge the ſimilitude of bodies or of natures, or els it is a compariſon of perſons betwen themſelues, or of thoſe thinges which are incident vnto perſons.
In Virgil the like is vſed, where it is ſaid:Aene. 1. Os humeroſque deo ſimilis, lyke vnto God both in countenaunce and in bodie.
The poete here compareth Aeneas to the image of God.
The like is in the ſcriptures: Vidimus gloriam eius, Iohn. 1. gloriam quaſi vnigeniti a patre. Vve ſawe the glorie therof, as the glorie of the onelye begotten ſonne of the father.

Note here one thing by the way yt this word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in greke, which is in latine tanquam, veluti, quaſi, is not a note of improprietie in this place, but ſignifieth rather a true and whole approbation. As Paule vſeth it, when he ſaith: tanquam fiui lucis ambulate: Vvalke as the children of light. So the euangeliſt ſaint Iohn vnderſtandeth here that glorie to be ſeen in Chriſt, which agreeth to the ſonne of God, and which ſhoulde be a certaine teſtimonie of his diuinitie.

Saint Gregorie writeth. Quod in ſacro eloquio, ſicut & quaſi aliquando non pro ſimilitudine ponitur, ſed pro veritate: In the holy ſcripture theſe two particles ſicut and quaſi, ſōtime ar put not for a ſimilitude but for a veritie and confirmation.

div.head: Parabola.
div.p:
Parabola, whiche Cicero calleth collationem, Queſt 6. ad Algarian. is called parabola (as ſaint Hierome ſaith) quod alteri
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . id eſt aſſimilatur: becauſe it is likened to an other thing.

Parabola eſt (vtinquit Beda) rerum genere diſsimilium comparatio: Math. 13 A parable is (as ſaith Beda) a compariſon of thinges differing, genere, As in Mathew. Simile eſt regnum caelorum grano ſinapis. The kingdome of heauen is like vnto a graine of muſtarde ſede.
Againe in the pſalmes. Erit ſicut arbor plantata &c. He ſhalbe as a tree planted by the waters ſide.
Iohn. 3.Likewiſe in Iohn: As Moſes exalted the ſerpent in the wildernes, ſo muſt the ſonne of man be exalted. There be many other examples of this ſcheme in the ſcriptures.

div.head: Paradigma.
div.p: Paradigma is called in latine exemplum. It is a ſhewing of an example, exhorting or deterring.

Fabius defineth it after this maner: Paradigma eſt rei geſtae vtilis ad perſuadendum, id quod intenderis commemoratio. It is a declaration of a thynge done or as done, proffitable to perſuade that whiche thou intendeſt.

div.head: Example of paradigma, exhortinge.
div.p: Cap 5An example of a paradigma, exhorting, is written in Iames when he exhorteth to prayer by the example of Elias.

Cap. 6.The like is in Mathew, where Chriſt exhorteth vs from carefulnes, by the example of the foules of the aire, whiche do neither ſowe, nor reape, nor gather into the barne, yet the heauenlye father doth feede them.

div.head: Example of paradigma deterring.
div.p: Cap. 17.An example of paradigma deterring, is written in Luke: memores eſtote vxoris Loth. Remember Lottes wife, by whiche example he woulde not haue vs to looke backe vnto filthines.

There is none other difference betwene ſimilitudo and paradigma, but that examples are taken out of thynges done, as this: As a horſe if he be occupied is made tamer and milder to ſuffer greate labours: So the body of man (if it be vſed by degrees vnto great thynges) it is able to beare and ſuſteyne, that whiche an other dare not touche.

Examples are taken out of perſons eyther true or fabulouſe, out of brute beaſtes and thinges without lyfe. As the Elephantes do not vſe carnall copulation, but in moſte ſecret places, and if any man do come in the meane tyme, they kyll hym. Howe muche more ought ſhamefaſtnes to be had in the congreſſe of man and wife, although it he lawfull?
Alſo as the Dolphins do not ſuffer the yonge ones to wander vnaccompanied, how much more behoueth it man to appoint vnto his tender children a gouernour and ſcholemaiſter?
Again, as euerye tree doth nouriſhe that whiche it bringeth forth, ſo it becōmeth naturall mothers to nouriſhe their children with their owne milke.
Thus muche I thoughte good to ſpeake of this figure homaeoſis.

div.head: Fayth. 16.
div.p: ALthough I haue ſpoken of fayth ſufficiently before, yet I wil ſomwhat now touch yt fayth which is called fides iuſtificans, not meaning in this place to make the whole diſcourſe howe onely fayth doth iuſtifie (for that ſhalbe differred vntill I anſweare to the foure billes whiche were caſt againſte me by the ennemies of God, and laid in the preaching place where I ſtoode), but I will onely ſhewe here a neceſsarie note or two of fayth.

div.head: Prima nota.
div.p: This worde fides, doth ſo take her name aſwell among the Grecians as among the Hebrewes, that her conſtancie and firmitie may eaſely appeare by the etymologie of the worde.
It is called in Hebrue Amnah of the worde Aman which ſignifieth firmum eſſe, to be firme and ſure.

The Grecians called fidē
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , quod eſt perſuaſum eſſe, that is, to be perſuaded. If you will require the originall of the worde, it ſemeth to be deriued ab
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , for that which is perſuaded and beleued, it ſtandeth as moſt true.
It is called in Latine fides, quaſi fiat quod dicitur, that that which is ſaide maye be done. Of this, much is intreated before.
But the true definition of that fayth which is fides iuſtificans, is this.

div.head: Fidei definitio.
div.p: Fides eſt firmus atque conſtans animi aſſenſus, verbis dei, ſpiritu ſancto affatu ad credentium ſalutem. that is: Faith is a ſure and conſtant aſſent of mind, inſpired with the holye ghoſt, to the ſaluation of them whiche beleue.
In this definition no kinde of the cauſes doth wante.

list.item: Cauſa materialis is the worde of God.
Cauſa formalis. is the acte of conſente.
Cauſa efficiens. is the holy ghoſt.
Cauſa finalis. is our ſaluation.

div.p: And the aſsent of faith is therfore called firme and constante, that it may be diuerſe from opinion. For when we do embrace one parte of the queſtion propoſed, if eyther feare or ſuſpition for the veritie of the other parte do ariſe, then we are ſaide to haue opinionem. which muſte be far ſet from fayth.
Alſo that this faith ſhould depende of the holy Ghoſt, there be three neceſsarie cauſes.

Firſt, becauſe the wordes of God to the which we do geue fayth by
aſsent ſhould not be extant, except they were reuealed of the holy ghost.

Secondly by the aide and helpe of the holy ghoſt our mindes are lightned, that we maye vnderſtande thoſe thinges which are propoſed in the holy ſcriptures, for otherwiſe the naturall man perceyueth not thoſe thinges which be of God.

Thirdly, that this light wherwith we be made mete to vnderſtande, may haue followinge it, the promptnes of our will and affections, ſo to bridle the wiſedome of the fleſhe and other affaires of our life, that they hinder nor let the ſure aſsent vnto faith.

div.head: Secunda nota.
div.p: You muſt vnderſtand that faith (as it is our action) doth not iuſtifie, for ſo it is alwaye weake and imperfecte, nor we can in that ſorte ſurely and ſafely leane vnto it. But the hedde and ſpring of our iuſtification commeth of Chriſte, of the promiſes and mercie of God, whiche are obiected and offred vnto fayth, who is the firſt power and facultie which bringeth thoſe thinges into our minde.
Therfore when we ſaye that we be iuſtified by faith, it is no more to ſay, but that iuſtification is obteined and had by Chriſt, and the promiſes of God, whiche are receyued and apprehended by fayth.

div.head: An example or ſimilitude.
div.p: He that hath a weake and not a perfect ſight in his eies, yet if he ſee a faire ſigne and goodlye colour, is ſayd perfectly to ſee it, not by the benefit of his dimme ſight, but becauſe the faire ſight and goodly colour is an obiect to the ſight, and is by that perceyued and ſeene.

div.head: The order of our iuſtification.
div.p: Firſte, it is God which doth iuſtifie by imparting vnto vs his mercie and promiſes.
Secondlye, it is Chriſt which hath deſerued this mercie of God, and promiſe of ſaluation by ſuffring thoſe paines for vs, which we our ſelues ſhould haue ſuffred.
Faith commeth in the thirde place as an organ and inſtrument by the which we perceiue and receiue Chriſt, and with him the mercie and promiſes of God by the which we be iuſtified.
Fourthly of them which be iuſtified, by good workes are expreſsed and practiſed.

div.head: Concluſio.
div.p: By this it appereth that faith is not the thing which doth iuſtifie vs, but rather that thing by the which we perceiue and apprehend righteouſnes and iustification.

div.head: Gold. 17.
div.p: GOld is called in Latine Aurum, Lib. 6. de lingua latina. whereof is deriued (as Varro ſaith) this word Aurora, which ſignifieth the earlye morning, which is before the riſing of the ſunne. It is ſo called, becauſe the aire then hath the coulour of gold, by reaſon of the ſunne ready to riſe.

And this is the difference betwene mane, and aurora, that mane, is after the ſunne riſing, when the day is cleare. For the old writers (as Nonius ſaith) did call it manum clarum, clere.Lib. 1. Saturnalium. Macrobius doth thinke that it is called mane, a manibus, becauſe the beginning of the light doth then appeare from the lower partes.
Varro doth deriue it of this verbe Manando becauſe yt the day with the Sunne doth flowe from the Eaſt. VVherupon they which be borne in the morning are called Manii, ſiue Lucis.
Aurora, (as I ſayd) is before the Sunne riſing.

Aurum, is called in Greke 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , vel
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . It is called in Hebrue Zaab, and it taketh that name of his colour. For Tzachab betokeneth Yellowe, or the like colour.
Aurum hath in the Scripture ſixe ſignifications.
Firſt, it is takē for oyle. As in the Prophet Zacharie:Cap. 4. VVhat be theſe two Oliue braunches which through the two golden pipes, emptie them ſelues into Golde.
Secondly, it is taken for wine, as in the Prophet Ieremy:Cap. 51. Babell hath bene as a golden cuppe in the Lords hand, that made all the earth dronken. The golden cuppe is taken here for wine.

Thirdly Aurum is taken for wiſedome in the Apocalips:Cap. 3 where it is ſaid: Suadeo tibi emerea me aurum ignitum. I counſel thee that thou bie of me gold that is tried by fire, that thou maieſt be made rich. By gold is ſignified here metaphorically, wiſdome and faith.

Fourthly,1. Epiſt. 3. Aurum ſignifieth pure and ſincere doctrine (as ſaint Ambroſe expoundeth it vpon the epiſtle to the Corinthians) or it may be taken for the good workes of the godly, as ſaint Hierome taketh it.

Fiftly, aurum doth ſignify a good man and a godly, and one elect of God. As it is vſed in the epiſtle to Timothie, wher ſaint Paule ſaith:2. epiſt. 2. In a great houſe are veſſels, not onely of gold and ſiluer, but alſo of wood & of earth, ſome for honour, and ſome for diſhonour. By gold here are ſignified the elect and perfect men of God.
Sixtly, gold ſignifieth bright and cleare aire, as in Iob,Cap. 3.7. wher it is ſayd: Ab aquilone aurum veniet. Gold ſhal come out of the North. By gold here is ſignified ſerenity and faire weather.

div.head: Fire. 18.
div.p: FIre is called in Latine, ignis, and is deriued of this prepoſition in, which is a priuate particle of this verbe gignenpo, which betokeneth to get, bcauſe nothing is gendred in the fire. It is called in Greke 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and in Hebrue it is called aeſch, by reaſon of Nun taken away perſyncopen. And it is ſo called becauſe it denoureth al things with out any recouery or mercie. And therfore this verbe Akal, which betokeneth to cōſume, is attributed vnto it.
Ignis in the ſcripture hath fiue ſignifications.

Cap. 9.Firſt, it betokeneth perſecution and correction, as in the Euāgeliſt Marke, wher it is written. Omnis igne ſalietur, euery man ſhall be ſalted with fire, and euery ſacrifice ſhal be ſalted with ſalt. In the which wordes he teacheth, that it is better to be ſacrificed vnto God by ſalt & fire, that is, to be purged and ſanctified, then to be ſent into hel fire.

Cap. 10.Secondly, it ſignifieth the wrath and plage of God, as Paule vſeth it in the epistle to the Hebrues, wher he calleth iudgement the vehemencie of fire, which ſhal deuour the aduerſaries and the wicked.
Cap. 3.Thirdly, fire ſignifieth the loue of God, as in Mathew. He ſhal baptize you with fire and ſpirite, that is, he ſhall inflame your hartes with the loue of him.

Fourthly, fire ſignifieth the word of God, which ſtirreth vp in ſome the burning of ſaluation,Cap. 12. and in other ſome the burning of eternal damnation. As in Luke: Ignem veni miſſurus in terram. I came to ſend fire into the earth, that is the Goſpel, which is a burning fire, which doth purge al pure things, and conſume al impure things, as the leuitie and filthines of the fleſh.
Theophilactus ſaith: By fire preaching is vnderſtand. For the woord is fire, which conſumeth al material and vnperfect thoughts, and aboliſheth images, of what matter ſoeuer they be.
Fiftly, fire is taken for al calamity, as in Amos. Mittam ignem in domum Aſael. I wil ſend fire into the houſe of Aſael.

div.head: Booke of Wiſedome. 19.
div.p: THe booke of wiſedome called commonlye Liber ſapientiae, is not in the Canon of the Hebrues.

The Iewes in dede reade this booke, but very ſeldome, ſuppoſing it to be the booke of one Philo a Iew, but a Greeke borne. For the title it ſelfe (as ſaint Hierome ſaith) doth ſauour rather of the Greeke eloquence, then of any other toung.

Certayne ſuppoſe that thys Philo is not he that liued vnder the raigne of Nero,Lib. de viris Illuſtribus. and wrote diuers workes in the praiſe of chriſtian religion (as Hierome doth testify) but to be another Philo, of a more auncient
time, very cunning in the Greeke toung: which liued. 160. yeares before the birth of Chriſt, in the time of Onias the highe prieſt.

And becauſe the eccleſiaſtical fathers do iudge theſe two bokes, that is, the bookes of wiſedome, and Eccleſiaſticus prophetical: they are beleued therfore not to be made of Philo, which was after Chriſt, but of other that wer before Chriſt.Lib. de ciuitate. 17. ca. 20 Of the which booke ſaint Auſtine ſpeaketh after this maner: Alii duo libri, quorum vnus ſapientia, alter vero eccleſiaſticus, dicitur propter eloquii nonnullam ſimilitudinem, vt Salomonis dicantur obtinuit conſuetudo: non autem non eſſe ipſius non dubirant doctores. &c. That is: The other two bookes, of the which one is called wiſdome, the other Eccleſiaſticus, cuſtome obteined that they were called the bookes of Salomon, for ſome ſimilitude of eloquence of his phraſe: but the doctours doo not doubt that they be not his, yet the weſt church hath of long time receiued them into authority: in the one,Cap. 1. that is the booke of wiſdome, the paſsion of Chriſt is moſt euidently prophecied. In Eccleſiaſtico, that faith of the Gētiles is foreſhewed after this maner. Miſerere noſtri dominator deus omnium, et immitte timorē ſuper omnes gentes. O God the ruler of all things, haue mercy vpon vs, and ſende feare vpon all the Gentiles.In catalogo ſacrae ſcript. Lib. 1.

Dreido in his diſſolution of the fift difficulty, writeth, that the boke of wiſdome is intituled of the auncient Fathers, the booke of Salomon, not that it was written of Salomon the carnal ſonne of Dauid, but that it containeth the ſentences of Chriſt the true Salomon, vttred of hym which was Salomō him ſelf figuring Chriſt, or els bering his perſon. For it is vſed often in the ſcriptures, that that which ſpeaketh, doth ſpeake in the perſon of an other. So many ſentences of this booke,Cap. 7.8.9. which the authour ſpeaketh of him ſelfe litterally vnderſtand, agreeth onely to Salomon, who being made king, wiſhed aboue all goods in the world, that he might obtaine wiſdome, with the which there came vnto him all other goods: vnto whom God alſo ſaid, that he ſhould build him a temple in his holy hill. Vvherupon Salomon knew in ſpirit that Chriſt was the wiſedome of God the father. Therfore, although this booke is now (as ſaint Hierome ſaith) any wher found in the Hebrue toung, but doth rather ſauour of the Greeke eloquence: yet it doth not follow that Salomon did not make or geue forth the ſentences and doctrines of this booke. For as much as Salomon (as the ſcripture teſtifieth) wrate. 3000 parables, and 5000. verſes, and intreated of beastes, foules, creeping things, & fiſhes, and diſputed of herbes and trees, euen frō the yſope vnto the Cedar tree. It is manifeſt that he made and ſpake certaine ſentences, gathered of diuers other, and perchaunce of them which came from farre countries to heare his wyſdome.

The prouerbs of Salomon, made of Salomon, were not written & couched of him into one booke, but thoſe things which wer diſperſed abrod, were afterward brought into one booke in the time of Ezechias, & wer gathered together of the Ministers of Ezechias,Cap. 25. king of Iuda, as it appeareth in the booke of Prouerbs. So it might chaunce that the ſentences of this booke of wyſdome, being originally the ſayinges of Salomon, were gathered together and wrote into one Greeke booke by ſome authour, full of the ſpirite of God.
Furthermore, conſider this, that Hierome doth not affirme thys booke to be the booke of Philo, but doth ſay, that the Iewes do affirme it to be the booke of Philo.
Ciprian, Ambroſe, and other fathers do often alledge, ſaying: In ſapientia Salomonis dicitur. It is ſaid in the wiſdome of Salomon, which is none other thing to ſay, than in the booke of wiſdome.

Retract. 2. Cap. 4.Vvher ſaint Auſtine in his booke de doctrina chriſtiana, doth conſtātly affirme that Ieſus the ſonne of Syrach wrote booke of wiſdome, he doth in his retractations, reuoke that ſaying. Haec Dreido.

div.head: Fleſh. 20.
div.p: FLeſh is called in latine Caro, and it is properly ſaid of dead beaſtes, & therfore it is called Caro, quaſi anima carens, as lacking life or ſoule (as Donatus writeth.) And it is not onely ſpoken of foure footed beaſtes and foules,Lib 16. Cap. 38. Lib. 9. Cap. 17. 1. Cor. 15 but alſo of fiſhes and fruite, who are ſaid to haue carnem in ſe as Plinius writeth, who attributeth both vnto fiſhes and to trees car • em, fleſh. And ſo ſaint Paule in the Epiſtle to the Corinthians, doth vſe it ſaying. Nō omnis caro, eadem caro, ſed alia quidem caro hominum alia vero pecorum, alia vero piſcium, alia vero volucrum All fleſh is not one and the ſame fleſh, but ther is one fleſh of men, an other fleſh of beastes, an other of fiſh, and an other of birdes.

Saint Hierome doth make a difference inter carnem et pulpam, that is of him called Caro, which is knit together with bloud, vaines, ſynews and bones. And that is called pulpa, which we eate, & that is onely fleſhly, becauſe it is eaten and gnawen of vs.
Some wold haue this word caro, to be deriued of ye Greke word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .
Caro is called in greeke 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in hebrewe baſhar. It hath in the ſcriptures many ſignifications.
Firſt, it is the fleſhly carnoſity which is ſuſtained with bones, both in man and beaſt. As in Geneſis. Et clauſit carnem loco eius, and cloſed the fleſh in the ſtede therof.
Againe in the ſame place: Hoc os de oſſibus meis, et caro de carne mea this is the bone of my bones, and fleſh of my fleſh.

Secondly Caro ſignifieth the whole man, as in Deuteronomy. Quae
vnquam fuit caro quae audiuit vocem dei viui loquentis de medio ignis, ſicut nos, et vixit? Vvhat fleſh was ther euer that heard the voice of the liuing God ſpeaking out of the middeſt of the fire, as we haue, & liued?Cap. 7.

Thirdly, it betokeneth all maner of beaſtes, as in Geneſis: Venerunt ergo ad Noah in arcam bina ex omni carne, in qua erat ſpiritus vitae. They came to Noah in the Arke two and two of all fleſh, wherin is the breath of life.

Fourthly, it is taken in the good ſenſe,Cap. 11. and is contrary vnto obſtinacy and hardnes of the hart, as it is vſed in Ezechiel: Auferam cor lapi deum de carne eorum, et dabo eis cor carneum. I wil take away the ſtonye hart out of their bodies, & wil geue them an hart of fleſh, that is, a ſoft, gentle, and mollified hart, ready to receiue the word of God.

Fiftly, it is taken in the ill ſenſe, and ſo it is taken moſt often, & then it ſignifieth euery thing that lacketh the ſpirite of God, as in Geneſis. Ed dixit Iehoua: non iudicabit ſpiritus meus in homine, quia caro eſt. My ſpirite ſhal not alwaies ſtriue with man, becauſe he is but fleſh.
And likewiſe in the Epistle to the Corinthians,1. Cor. 15 ſapientia carnis mors eſt, and in infinite other places of the ſcriptures.
Caro betokeneth not onely ſenſuality, but what ſo euer is without the compaſſe of the grace and ſpirite of Chriſt.

div.head: End of our faith. 21.
div.p: HOw doth Peter ſay ther that faith hath an end,1. Epiſt. 14. when Paul writeth to the Corinthians, yt theſe three things do alwaies remaine, faith, hope, & charity: but the greatest of theſe is charity?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Paule in that place had entreated of the gifts of the holy ghost which were to be aboliſhed, neither could alwaies endure: and he ſetteth forth thoſe things that be more durable, faith, hope, and charity, and of theſe thre he maketh charity the chiefest, becauſe it continueth not only here, but alſo hath a place in heauen.

Certaine do thinke that Paule ſpeaketh onelye of the continuance in this life, as though he would ſay: The gifts of the holy ghoſt ſhall not alwaies endure. For when the faith of the Goſpel ſhalbe enlarged and ſet forth, they ſhal ceaſſe and geue place, becauſe they were geuen for the promulgacion of faith. But charity in the Church is alwaies neceſſarye. Therfore faith, hope, and charity do abide, becauſe chriſtian religion cā not be ſafe without them.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: Againſt this ſentence doth ſaint Paule repugne, who ſeemeth to reſpect the life to come, ſaying: Nunc videns per ſpeculum in aenigmare, tunc facie ad faciem. &c. Now ſeing by a glaſſe in a darke ſpeeche, thē face to face. Now we know partly, then I ſhal know as I am knowē.

Alſo Eraſmus ſaith: Si ſpectemus charitatem prout nunc. &c. If we reſpect charity, as ſaint Paule in that place taketh it, it is to be doubted how it may endure in heauen, for that we ſhal not be able to deſerue wel of our neighbours. For all men ſhal be happy, neither any ſhal haue nede of our helpe.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: This is not a ſtronger argument. For who will deny the bleſſed ſpirites to haue charity? And if ther want occaſion to helpe our neighbours, yet the affection and faculty of doing is accepted, if either occaſion or faculty ſhalbe offred. Therfore we muſt not doubt that charity ſhal endure in heauen. And this is the minde and cenſure of al the chiefeſt fathers.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: Ireneus ſaith, that faith ſhal abide in heauen, and bringeth this reaſon: becauſe ther we ſhal better know and learne, and more throughly pearce vnto diuine things, then we can do in this life. How then doth Peter ſay that faith hath her end?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Ireneus either by great and vrgent buſines in planting and gouerning the church, or els by diuers perſecutions, and manifold incommodities, could not diligently diſcuſſe the ſcriptures, and therfore he myght eaſily erre.

Phocius (as the Greke ſcholies do reporte) was of the ſame ſentence, who ſaith that faith ſhal endure in heauen. For then we ſhal be moſt delighted with the contemplacion of God. He affirmeth the ſame alſo of hope, becauſe ther is (ſaith he) a ſure poſſeſsion: for that which we hoped for, will be preſent vnto vs, and they which hoped, ſhal not be defrauded of the things hoped for.
And among the ſcholemen Durandus was of this cenſure.

But their aſſertions are againſt the ſayings of Paule, which attribute imperfection to faith, that is, to the notice and knowledge of God, which we haue in this world, becauſe it is had by a glaſſe in a darke ſpeeche, neither it is in the whole, but in part. And per antitheſin, he ſaith, that we ſhall know in our country, as we be knowne, and ſee face to face.

Furthermore, the definition of faith is againſt them. For in the Epiſtle to the Hebrues, faith is ſaid to be an euidence of thinges which are not ſene, but then althings ſhall appeare and be made open. Therfore faith than and there can haue no place.
And in the epiſtle to the Romaines we reade, that the hope which is ſene, is not hope, for els how doth a man hope for that he ſeeth?

But let vs ſee what Paule wil haue to be vnderſtand by theſe words
Maxima ex hiis charitas, the greateſt of theſe is charity.
Euery mans faith and hope profiteth himſelfe, charitye is extended to other.
Faith and hope are in the time of imperfection, Charity ſhall abide in the ſtate of perfection, that is, it ſhalbe perpetuall, when faith and hope ſhal haue their end.
If we diſcuſſe and ſearche out al the effectes of faith, faith ſhalbe the worthier and ſuperiour to charity: for charity is the effect of faith. The effect without doubt is inferiour to the cauſe.
Saint Iohn ſaith, that faith is the victory which ouercommeth the world: which cannot be ſaid of charity.

By faith we are borne againe, and made the ſonnes of God, and do obteine the eternal faith, and by faith Chriſt dwelleth in vs. And ſo faith in many things is ſuperiour to charity. And chariti is called the greateſt, not in all reſpectes, but in that it ſhalbe perpetual, and becauſe nowe it is the greateſt meane and way to preſerue the church.

I maruel here that the Papiſts doo ſtand in thei owne conceites, in miſtaking theſe words of Paule. If faith (ſay they) doth iustify: thē much more charity doth iuſtify, becauſe charity is called greater.
See I pray you what an argument this is: Charity is greater thē faith. Ergo charity doth iuſtify.
The like argument is this: The king is more noble and greater than a plough man and a ſhoomaker. Therfore the king can plow the ground or ſoe a ſhoo better, then either of them.
Again, a man is more noble & better then an horſe. Therfore he wil runne ſwifter then an horſe, and wil cary a greater burden.
The angels are more excellent than the Sunne and Moone. Therfore they wyl geue more light to the earth.
If the power and ſtrength of iuſtifieng did depend of the woorthines and merite of faith, it were another matter.
But faith iuſtifieth not, becauſe it is more worthy, but bicauſe it doth apprend righteouſnes, frely offred and geuen in the Goſpel.

div.head: People of the old teſtament. 22.
div.p:
WHat difference is betwene the old teſtament & the new, I ſhewed largely before. Here I note onely one thing, which is temeritie, ignoraunce, and blaſphemy of certaine phantaſtical heades, which hold yt the prophets do write onely to the people of ye old teſtamēt, and that their doctrine did pertain onely to their time, & would ſeclude al ye fathers yt liued vnder ye law frō the hope of eternal ſaluatiō. And here is alſo a note to be gathered againſt thē which vtterly reiect ye old teſtamēt, as a boke nothing neceſſari to ye chriſtiās which liue vnder ye goſpel.
But as I haue ſaid before, ther is no difference betwene the old teſtamēt and the newe, but onelye in circumſtaunce, and nothing in ſubſtaunce. And therfore the one is aſwel to be allowed and receiued, as the other.

div.head: Pentecoſte. 24.
div.p: PEntecoſte is a Greke word, and betokeneth in latine fifty, and when it is read in the ſcriptures, this word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , id eſt, dies, is to be vnderſtand, as you would ſay, the fifty day: becauſe that feaſt was kept among the Iewes, in remembraunce that the law was geuen them in the mount Sinai, the fifty day after their departure out of Egipt. It is called, Feſtum hebdomadum, et nouarum frugum, the feaſt of weekes, and of new corne. For they numbred from the firſt day of the Paſche, ſeuen weekes, which contained fifty daies, & they did celebrate the fifty day, in the memory of the law geuen from heauen.

Becauſe I haue made mencion of Pentecoſte, a feaſt of the Iewes: I wil geue a note of al the feaſtes of the Iewes, and of the feaſtes which ar kept in our daies, and wherfore they are conſtitute and ordained.

God in the old teſtament did institute many and diuers feastes, that he might admoniſh the people of the benefites done vnto them, that he might inſtruct the ignoraunt, and that he might keepe them all in the true woorſhipping of God. But all their feaſtes were not ſolemniſed a like. They did ſacrifice dayly at morning and Euening. The ſeuenth day of euery weeke was kept holy. Euery moneth had a proper feaſt: Alſo euery yeare ther were thre ſolempne holy daies obſerued and kept. They did offer ſacrifice dayly at morning and euening, in remembraunce of continual worſhipping of God. The godly praied, they called to remembraūce the promiſe of the ſeede, vnto which they looked by faith in all their ſacrifices. In ſteede hereof the church hath ſubstitute morning and euening praier.

Alſo the ſeuenth day of the weeke, the memoriall of the creation of the world, was celebrate by offring ſacrifices, and by thankes geuing. In ſtede wherof the church hath ordained the firſt day of the weeke in remembraūce of the ſecond creation, that is, of regeneration which is done by the reſurrection of ye Lord, that was ſolemniſed on the first day of the weke, & therfore yt day was called of ye apostles, dies dominicꝰ, ye ſondai.

In the begīning of euery moneth, one day was kept holy, in remēbrāce of the conſeruatiō. For whē they ſaw ye Moone kepe her ordinary courſe & ſhining, God would yt for the whole benefite of gouernaunce, thanks ſhould be geuen to God, and therfore he did inſtitute that feaſt.
Although this feaſt doth not binde the chriſtians yet we ought to be no leſſe thankefull vnto God, then the godly Iewes were.
Euerye yeare, three ſolemne feaſtes were obſerued, Paſcha, Pentecoſte, Scenopegia.
Paſcha, the paſſeouer, was ordeined of the remembraunce of the deliueraunce of the Iewes from the bondage of the Egiptians.
Pentecoſte, was obſerued in remembraunce of the law, geuen in the mount Sinai.

Scenopegia was celebrate in remembraunce of the habitation of the people of Iſrael in the deſert, fourty yeares in tabernacles, that by thys ceremony, they might call to remembraunce all the benefite of their deliueraunce. In ſtede of theſe three Iudaical feaſtes, the church hath ordained Eaſter in remembraunce of the reſurrection of the Lord, which deliuered vs from the bondage of the deuil.
Pentecoſte was ordeined in remembraunce of the confirmation of the Goſpel, by the viſible ſending of the holye ghoſt, and by the miraculous giftes of the tounges.
The natiuity of Chriſt in remembraunce that Chriſt was geuen and ſent of God the father vnto vs.
Now a woord or two of other of our feaſtes.
Although it be idolatry to inuocate and pray vnto ſaintes (as the Papiſts do in their holy daies) yet I thinke it very profitable to retaine & kepe ſome of the feastes, and that for many cauſes.
Firſt, it is profitable to know the histories of the church, for out of them we may take doctrine, confirmation, and conſolation.
Secondly, it is a ſwete thing to haue in minde the benefite of God beſtowed vpon his church, wherof ſingular fruit commeth to the godly.
Thirdly, yt thanks may be geuē to god for his benefits done to ye church

Fourthly, that by weighing the diuers & ſūdry aduerſities of ſaints, we may bodly ſtrengthen our ſelues to ſuffer the aduerſity that is preſent, & alſo that is to come, which thing we muſt nedes take vpon vs.

Fiftly, that ſaintes may be vnto vs examples of repentance and godly life, of true worſhipping, of confeſsiō of our faith, of conſtancy, of paciēce & of other vertues, yt we may frame our liues after their godly exāples.
Sixtly, that with godly affection we may deſire the company and felowſhip of the ſaintes.

Theſe & other mo are weighty cauſes why we do retaine and keepe ſome feastes of ſaints in the church. Vvould God that many did not abuſe the feaſtes of Saintes and Martirs vnto voluptuouſnes and madnes, as the papiſtes do in nightly daunecs, in garlands of loue, in ſwilling and bolling and other vices not pleaſing God, his angels, and ſaintes, but they do ſerue Sathan, to the contempt of God, his Aungels and Saintes. Thus much of the feastes of Saintes.

div.head: Feare. 25.
div.p: FEare is called in Latine Timor, or metus, in Greeke 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , in hebrue Girah, and it ſignifieth reuerence, veneration, religion. As in the pſalme:Pſal. 2. Colite Iehouam in timore, worſhip the Lord in feare.

div.head: Queſtio.
div.p: Iohn. 4.How can we ſerue the Lord in feare, when it is written in Iohn: Timor non eſt in charitate, feare is not in loue?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: The old & auncient fathers affirme, that ther is two kindes of feare, that is Timor filialis, and Timorſeruilis.

div.head: Filial feare.
div.p: Timor filialis, is the true feare and worſhipping of God: as when we do worſhip, loue and feare God, for none other cauſe, then that he is our God and father.

And as the ſonne doth reuerence and feare his father, not becauſe he is corrected of him, but becauſe he loueth him, and taketh him for his father. And this feare of God commeth and riſeth of loue and faith, not of fleſhly hate or feare, and it is none other thing then very faith.

Pſal. 28.It is written in the prouerbes: Beatus eſt qui ſemper pauidus. Bleſſed is he that is alway fearful. And this filial feare is the knowledge of God, according to that ſaying alſo in ye prouerbes: Initium ſapientiae timor domini. But of this feare ſpeaketh the prophet Dauid ſaying. Beati omnes qui timent dominum, bleſsed be al they which feare the Lord. Againe, in an other place.Pſal. 33. Timete dominum omnes ſancti eius, quoniam nihil deeſt timemtbus eum. Feare the Lord all his ſaintes, for they lacke nothing which feare the Lord.
And as the virgin Mary did ſing in her ſong. Et miſericordia eius a progenie in progeniem timentibus eum. And his mercy is from one generation to another, to them which feare him.

div.head: Of the ſeruile feare.
div.p: The other feare is called timor ſeruilis, which is hipocritical, carnal, fained, & this fear (as ſ Iohn ſaith) is not in loue: but perfecte charitie doth caſt forth all feare. For this feare hath in it a torment, and cōmeth of the feare of paines and puniſhment. As the ſeruaunts doo feare their maiſters, not of any loue, but for feare of ſtripes. Vvhereupon roſe that prouerbe: Oderunt, quem metuetunt, whom they feare, them they hate. A ſaying much vſed of Cicero, and is counted of Seneca a voyce to be deteſted.

They carnally and ſeruilely do feare God, which do ſerue him without faith and charity, which do feare God as a terrible iudge. Such feare
was in the Iewes at the mount Sinai,Exod. 1 •
when they heard thundringes and lightnings, when they ſaid to Moſes: ſpeake thou vnto vs, and we wyll heare. Let not the Lord ſpeake to vs, leaſt we dye.
In fine, the faithful and godly doo honour and feare God as a father. The hipocrites and vnfaithful do feare him as a iudge and a tyraunt.

The godly feare for the loue of vertue, the vngodly for feare of puniſhment. And that ful wel ſawe the Heathen Poete Horace, when he ſayd:
Oderunt peccare boni, virtutis amore.
Oderunt peccare mali, formidine penae.
The good from offence, vertues loue doth detaine:
The euyl to offend, feare of payne doth reſtraine.

div.head: Sobriety of inquiring. 26.Cap. 12.
div.p: SAinct Paule writing to the Romaines doth geue a doctrine touching this matter writing thus: I ſay to euery one that is, among you that no mā preſume to vnderſtand aboue that which is mete to vnderſtand, but that he vnderſtand according to ſobriety.

Saint Hierome writing againſt Iouinian, when he went about to defend moſt ſharply virginity, and continencye, that he might abuſe thys place of Paule to his purpoſe, condemned the receiued tranſlation of the latine bookes, and thought that we ſhould not reade, ſapere ad ſobrietatem, but ſapere ad pudicitiam, to be ſober not to modeſty and wiſdome, but to chaſtity. It may be graunted in dede that this woord 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , doth ſignify ſometime chastity. But in this place that ſenſe doth not agree. For Paule generally here ſpeaketh of arrogantiae, and of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 by the which euery man endeuoreth to preferre him ſelfe before another.

Origene doth take it in a muche better ſenſe, and vnderſtandeth per
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , temperauncie, not that by the which we moderat our pleaſure in meate and drinke and other carnall luſtes, but that by the which we keepe a meaſure in all thinges, both in our affections and doings. So that Paule ſemeth to teache none other thing here, then that no man ſhoulde take more vpon him, that his degree and calling will ſuffer.

And doubtles they which yelde to muche to their owne arrogancye, and haue an eſtimation of them ſelues, more then is conuenient and mete, are made deſtitute of their wyſdome, and runne into a certaine kinde of madnes, as certayne Emperours and Monarches did, which would haue them ſelues to be worſhipped for Gods: of which number he was which feared not to ſay, Et quis eſt deꝰ, vt poſſit vos liberare de manu mea? that is to ſay: and who is that God, which can deliuer you out of my hand?

In this nūber alſo may thei be counted, which truſting to their doctrine and learning, go about to ſearch the inſcrutable ſecretes of God. King Agrippa did imbraide Paule ſaying: Multae literae te ad inſaniam adegerunt. Much learning hath made thee mad. Chriſoſtome writeth, that if any man, either for great learning or wiſdome, or for any gift of the holy ghoſt, do runne into dotage and waxe mad: that fault (ſaith he) lacketh mercy. For he that is borne a foole (ſaith he) hath his excuſe, and al men do pity his condicion. But he that waxeth mad, becauſe he ſemeth to him ſelfe to be excellently learned, or through any ſpeciall gift of the holy ghoſt, is puft vp with pride: he hurteth him ſelfe, and abuſeth intemperantly wholſome thinges.
A man ſhall perceiue many, which reiecting the knowledge of things neceſſary, aſpire vainely to know other things.

Did not the Emperour Adrianus make him ſelfe a laughing ſtocke, when among the weighty affaires of the common wealth, he enquired of the Grammarians who was Euanders Nourſe, and who was the great graundfathers graundfather of Priamus, and occupied him ſelfe wyth ſuch trifles and toyes?

VVas not Thales the Philoſopher derided and mocked of his owne mayden, when beholding and viewing most attentiuely the ſtarres, fell into the ditche before his feete? And ſuch things do often chaunce in curioſity, that when we deſire to know thoſe things which perteineth nothing vnto vs, we are moſt ſhamefully ignoraunt of other thinges which are moſt profitable and neceſſary.

Seneca complained & lamented, that a great part of our life periſheth, when we do nothing, a greater part when we doo ill, the greatest part of all is lost when we be occupied about thinges vnprofitable, and ſpecially when they be aboue our capacity.

Socrates hath a worthy ſaying, which is driuen into a prouerb: Quae ſupra nos, nihil ad nos. Things which be aboue vs, do pertain nothing to vs. By the which he deterreth vs from curious ſearching of heauenly things, and the ſecretes of nature, and of the misteries of diuinity.

Plutarchus ſaith: Homo curioſus vtilior eſt hoſtibus, quam ſibi. A curious mā is more profitable to his enemies, thā to him ſelfe. Again he ſaith: Omni fide caret homo curioſus, quamobrem famulis et hoſpitibꝰ citius credimus epiſtolas at ſigilla, quam amicis ac familiaribus curioſis. A curious man lacketh credite, therfore we commit our letters and ſeales rather to our ſeruaunts and hoſtes, then to our familiar friendes being curious.
Saint Bernard ſaith: Multi ſtudent plus alta, quam apta proferre. Many deſire to vtter rather high thinges, than meete things.

Proſper hath a verye notable ſayinge. Quae deus occulta eſſe voluit, non ſunt ſcrutanda, quae autem manifeſta fecit, non ſunt negligenda, ne etenim in illis illicite curioſi, & in hus damnabiliter inueniamur ingrati. That is to ſay: thoſe thinges which God would haue to be hidden, are not to be ſeached, and thoſe things which he hath made manifeſte, are not to be neglected, leaſt in the one we be founde to be vnlawfullye curiouſe, and in the other damnablie vnthanckfull.

Socrates being demaunded of a certaine perſon what was done in hel, made anſwer, that he neuer went thither, nor communed with any that returned from thence: by the which anſwere he derided the curioſitie of of the aſker.Sermo. 23.

Euclides (as Maximus doth reporte) being demaunded of one, what the gods did, and with what things they were beſt delighted: as for other things (ſaith he) I know not, but of this I am moſt ſure, that they do hate all curiouſe perſons.

Veſpaſianus the Emperour, being admoniſhed of one of the Conſulles whoſe name was Florus, that he ſhould rather ſay, plauſtra quam ploſtra, the nexte daye ſaluted him, callyng him not by the name of Florus, but flaurus, merilye alluding to his curiouſnes.

Saint Auſtine hath a golden ſaying. Compeſcat ſe humana temeritas, & id quod non eſt, non quaerat: ne illud quod eſt, non inueniat Let the temeritie of man ſtaye it ſelfe, and let it not ſearch that which is not, leaſt it finde not that which is.

To conclude with the holy ſcriptures, Ieſus the ſonne of Syrach ſaith: Seke not out the thinges that are to harde for thee, neither ſearche the thinges raſhly that are to mightie for thee. But what God hath commaunded thee, thincke vpon that with reuerence, and be not curiouſe in many of his worckes: for it is not nedefull for thee to ſee with thine eies the things that are ſecrete: be not curiouſe in ſuperfluous thinges, for many thinges are ſhewed vnto thee aboue the capacitie of men. The medling with ſuch hath begiled many, and an euell opinion hath deceiued their iudgement. Thou canſt not ſee without eyes: profeſſe not the knowledge therfore that thou haſt not.

div.head: Glory be to God. 27.
div.p: THeſe be the wordes of Angels, whereby they ſignifie that no man can glorifie God trulye, without the knowledge of Chriſt. Man was created for this ende, that he ſhould geue glorie to God his maker. But by the fall of our firſte parents it came to paſſe, that man neither did knowe God aright, neither gaue glorie vnto him.

If you wil aſke, what is to geue glory vnto god? To geue glory vnto any
mā, is nothing els then to attribut true vertu vnto him. As when a king or prince doth rule iuſtly, wiſely, puiſauntly and mercifully, his ſubiectes do attribut glory vnto him, that is, they do allow his doings, and with a ſingular beneuolence do reporte wel of him. Likewiſe glorie is geuen to God when his vertues, wiſdome, righteouſnes, power, mercie, &c are truly knowledged and vnderſtanded.

The wiſdom of god is knowen in this, that he doth repair man which he had made to his owne glorie, that he might recouer againe the image which he had loſt through ſinne, by the merits of his derelye beloued ſon Ieſus Chriſt, and to geue the glory of wiſdome vnto god.

The righteouſnes of God is knowen by this, that he would not receyue mankinde againe into his fauour, without recompence of the wrong don. For, when it was nedeful, either that man ſhould periſh and die for euer through ſin, or els, yt ſom, which came of the ſeed of man, ſhould appeaſe almighty god by ſuffring puniſhment for all mākind: God gaue his onely begotten ſonne, which tooke vpon him the nature of man, in the which he ſatisfied the iuſtice of god. Vvherfore, ye praiſe & glorie of righteouſnes is worthely to be attributed vnto god our Lord and ſauiour Ieſus Chriſt.

The puiſſaunce and power of god is knowne in this, that he ouercame the ſerpent and his ſeed by Chriſt, and vtterly aboliſhed the kingdome of ye diuel, as touching al thē which haue apprehended Ieſus Chriſt by faith. And therfore the glorie and power of ſtrength is to be geuen to God.

The mercie of god appeareth in this, that mākind being deſtroyed & oppreſſed with the tirannie of the deuel, and with gret aduerſities & calamities, as with death, hel, and dānatiō, is taken again into the fauor of God by his ſon, and for his ſonne. This mercie of god excelleth all other worckes of god, which mercy the holy Angels and electe people of God do and ſhal ſet forth, yea the deuels alſo, wil they, nill they, ſhal acknowledge it. And ſo the glorie of mercy is to be geuen to God.

The veritie of god is opened and declared in this, yt god being mindfull of his former couenaūts, doth performe that which he promiſed. For whē our firſt parents did fall into ſin, God promiſed the ſeed of the woman, which ſhould breake the ſerpents hed, which promiſe he perfourmed in geuing his ſonne. And ſo the glory of truth is to be geuen to god.

Therfore for theſe great vertues, glory is to be geuen vnto God: and chiefly of thē which do fele his benefits. This glorie is thā geuē vnto god: Firſt, when we do acknowledge the great benefit of god. Secondly, whē we do apprehende the ſonne of god by faith. Thirdly, when we do laude and praiſe god with our minde, wordes, and godly conuerſation and confeſsion of the faith. Fourthly, when we do inuite and ſtirre many other to the knowledge of God.

div.head: ❧ The fyft Prelection of the ſecond Come.
div.p: LEet vs go onwarde in Gods name with the text which followeth in thys maner.
Propter quod ſuccincti lumbos mentis veſtrae, ſobrij perfecte ſperate in eam quae offertur vobis gratiam in reuelationem Ieſu Chriſti. That is to ſay.
Wherfore gyrde vp the Loines of your minde,1. Loynes. be ſober and truſt perfectly on the grace that is brought vnto you by the reuelation of Ieſus Chriſt, &c.

For aſmuch as the promiſes of God are made vnto vs, ſo that we nede not to paſſe or care for any afflictions after ye example of chriſt, who entred into his glory by the croſſe and afflictions: Peter by an elegant manner of ſpeaking doth egge vs forth, and exhort vs that we perſiſte firme, and conſtant, aſwell in the puritie of life, as in chriſtian religion.

In the firſt word he doth open how we ought to be entāgled from a laſciuious and carnal life, that al the impediments of truth being ſet a part, nothing ſhould hurt or hinder our courſe and running vnto Chriſt.
