He ſayth here, girde vp the loynes of your minde, by the which he doth ſignifie vnderſtanding and will, which he woulde haue moſt readie to embrace the truth, and to be beautified with charitie, and this is a very apte metaphor.Cap. 12.

Chriſt doth ſay in Luke: Sint lumbi veſtri praecincti, et lucernae ardentes in manibus veſtris. Let your loynes be girded about, and your lightes burning in your handes, that is: Be alwayes inſtructed and readie, looking as good ſeruantes for your Lord and maiſter.Cap. 5. Lib. 4. cont. Marcionem.
S. Paule to the Epheſians doth ſay. State ſuccincti lumbos veſtros in veritate.

Tertullian ſayth. We oughte to gird vp our loynes, that is, to be vnwrapped from the impedimentes of a wanton & intangled life. Alſo we ought to haue burning lightes, that is, our mindes kindled with fayth, and ſhining with the works of veritie, and ſo to looke and wayte for our Lord Ieſus Chriſt.

Therefore gyrd vp the Loynes of your mynde. The loynes in many places of the Scripture do ſignifie pleaſure and luſte corporall. But Peter ſpeaketh here of ſpirituall loynes. When the scripture ſpeaketh of the body, calling thē loynes, then is meant the naturall generation of man, as we read in Geneſis, Cap. 49. that Chriſt ſhoulde be borne of the loynes of Iudah. And ſo corporally to gird vp the loynes is nothing ells, but chaſtitie, as in the Prophet Eſaie:Eſay. 11. Et erit iuſticia ſingulum lumborum eius, et fides cinctorium renum eius. That is to ſay: And iuſtice ſhall be the girdle of his loynes, and faythfulnes the girdle of his raynes. That is, onely by fayth is reſtinguiſhed and reſtrayned filthie pleaſure.

But the ſpiritual girding, wherof Saint Peter ſpeaketh here,2. Virgin vntouched. hath it ſelf after this maner: As a virgin not touched of man, is chaſte and whole of bodye, ſo the minde through faith is inuiolate and vnſpotted. But aſſone as the minde doth degenerate from fayth, vnto falſe doctrine, than is it corrupted and polluted. Therefore the ſcriptures do cal infidelitie and idolatry, adulterie and fornication. Peter therfore doth here exhorte them to gird vp the loynes of their minde, which is as much to ſay as this: you haue heard now ye Goſpell, and you are come vnto faith, ſee now that you perſiſt manfully in it, neyther ſuffer your ſelues to be corrupted with falſe doctrine, running hither and thither to the workes of your owne deuice and inuention. It followeth.

Be ſober, and truſt perfectly on the grace that is brought vnto you.3. Sobriety. Sobrietie here is the worke and fruit of a liuely fayth. Peter meaneth here by this ſobrietie, not onely that vertue which doth meaſure and bridle glottonie and gurmandyſe,
but alſo that vertue which doth ſhake of ſinggyſhnes and ſlouth, and maketh vs to be geuen vnto prayer.4. Idleneſſe. For what ſhall it profit to ouercome glottonie, if we ſuffer fayth to waxe faint and colde by ſlouthfull idleneſſe?

Although a man be iuſtified, yet he feeleth for the moſt part alwayes the fleſhe riſing and rebelling againſt the ſpirit. Which fleſh is tamed by this ſobernes, and is (as it were) a bridle vnto the fleſhe. They do erre therfore much, which perſwading them ſelues to haue done theyr duties, boaſt and bragge them ſelues to haue fayth, and yet geue them ſelues to pleaſures and luſtes.

Peter doth here improue ſuche, and ſayth that they ought to be ſober, and denieth their fayth to be a liuely fayth, and doth commend ſuch a fayth which ſheweth her ſelfe forth by good workes and godly conuerſation.

Note here, that as great watchinges doth conſume the groſſe humours of the body, and doth make a groſſe man ſlenderer and leaner: So a chriſtian watch, that is, a liuely fayth, doth ſeeth away & conſume vnchaſte affections. It taketh away the ſurfet of mans wiſedome, it taketh away feare, inconſtancie and impacience, it contemneth the ioyes and pleaſures of the worlde, and doth wholye bequeath it ſelfe vnto God.

Although Peter would haue vs to be ſober eyther in minde or in bodye: yet he meaneth not, nor commaundeth that a man ſhould deſtroy his bodye, or make it more weake then it ought to be, either with faſtings or watchings, wherwith many haue made them ſelues vnprofitable members, both to a common wealth, and to the eccleſiaſticall miniſterye.

5. BernardIn this fooliſhe errour was S. Bernarde of a long time, although he were otherwiſe a learned and godly man. For he did afflicte his bodye with great abſtinence, that he got him ſuch a lothſome ſauour by it, that he could not liue together in the companye of other men. But at length he was deliuered from this errour, and commaunded his brethren, that they ſhould not ouermuch weare awaye and conſume theyr bodye by ſuch ſtraight kynde of lyfe. It followeth.

Perfecte ſperate in eam graciam quae vobis offertur, that is: Truſt perfectly on the grace that is brought vnto you. Such is a true chriſtian fayth, that it wholy and vtterly with a moſt perfecte truſt doth leane vnto the worde of God, & attempteth to do boldly thoſe things, what ſoeuer ought or behoueth to be done. And therfore Peter ſayth: Then are the loynes of your minde girded vp, then is your fayth whole and ſound, when committing your ſelues ſurely and ſafely vnto the worde of God, you dare do al things, not weighing nor regarding what thing ſoeuer of yours is brought into perill & daunger: Whether it be your goods, your worldly name, yea or your whole life. In thoſe wordes S. Peter doth deſcribe very aptlie a ſincere and not a fayned fayth: For that fayth which is not liuely, is to be counted rather a dreame, than a fayth. But a liuely and perfecte fayth, doth cauſe man to depend wholye on the worde, and not to paſſe or care what fortune ſoeuer God doth caſte on his ſhoulders, yea and to runne through thicke and thinne, and to ſuſteine both ſharpe and ſower for the Lordes ſake and his worde. As when death is offred, it behoueth a faythfull man to committe himſelfe boldlye vnto Chriſt, to offer hys necke vnto the axe, hys body to the fire and boldly to reſiſte the aduerſaries power. Such a fayth and truſt doth S. Peter here require of all chriſtians, which faith doth not ſtand in cogitation and words onely, but in vertue & power.

Now (ſayth Peter after) truſte on the grace that is brought vnto you. That is to ſay: You haue not deſerued thys great grace, but it is freely offred vnto you. For the Goſpell which doth ſhewe and ſet forth this grace vnto vs, was not excogitate and inuented of vs, but the holy ghoſt ſent it from heauen vnto vs.

But what I pray you is offred vnto vs? Forſoth euen this: that he which beleueth in Chriſt, and doth ſtedfaſtly cleaue vnto his worde, now hath and poſſeſſeth
all the goods of the Lord, with the Lord. So that he is made Lorde and maiſter of ſinne, death, deuill, and hell, and is aſſured of eternall life.

This ſo great treaſure is offred vnto vs euen at our doores. It is put into our boſome without all our endeuour, merite, or deſerte. It commeth (I ſay) vnlooked for, we thinking of no ſuch thing. Therfore thapoſtle Peter exhorteth vs, that we boldly and ſurely looke for this truſt and grace, becauſe God which doth offer it, cannot lie.

This word offred or brought, hath a merueilous energie and great liberalitie in it, as though Peter ſhould ſay, you nede not to take great labours and paynes, you nede not to runne on pilgrimage, you nede not to go from countrey to countrey to ſeeke this grace. It offreth it ſelfe vnto you, although you be at home, although you be in the field, or where ſoeuer you ſhal be. This onely remaineth that you do receaue it, when it is offred. Theſe be the true riches of God, that franckly, frelie, and willinglye he geueth his mercye and grace to them which ſeeke it not:Eſay. 52. (As it is written in Eſay:) Palam factus ſum non quaerentibus me. I was made open and knowen to them which ſought me not.

Againe in an other place. Quia quibus non eſt narratum de eo, viderunt et qui non audierunt, contemplati. That which hath not bene tolde them, ſhall they ſee, and that which hath not bene heard, ſhall they vnderſtand. How great therfore is our ingratitude. if we do neglecte and contemne this grace ſo gentlie, and louinglye ſhewed and offred vnto vs? Which if we do contemn, the great wrath and diſpleaſure of God is to be looked for. Saint Paule in the Epiſtle to the Hebrewes ſaith. Quomodo effugiemus, ſi tantam neglexirimus ſalutem? How ſhal we eſcape, if we neglecte ſo great a ſaluation? It followeth.

In reuelatione Ieſu Chriſti: by the reuelation of Ieſus Chriſt. That is, God the father offreth his grace vnto none, but by Chriſt. Wherefore let no mortall man preſume to come into the preſence & ſight of God, without this Mediatour Chriſt. He will here none except he bring as an aduocate his deare beloued ſonne Chriſt, whom onely he doth reſpecte and regarde,6. Baptiſme. and for whoſe ſake all perſons and all things do pleaſe God the father, as his voyce declared in the time of the Baptiſme of Chriſt, which ſounded and ſaid: Hic eſt filius meus dilectus, in quo mihi bene cō placui. This is my beloued ſonne, in whom I am well pleaſed.

Chriſt came for this end, that taking our fleſhe and bloud, he might ioyne hym ſelfe with vs to obteine grace with the father for vs. By this fayth in Chriſt all the Prophets and Patriarches were ſaued. For it behoued al men to beleue that promyſe which was made to Abraham: In ſemine tuo benedicentur omnes gentes, In thy ſeede ſhall all nations be bleſſed. Therefore the faith of the Iewes, and of the Turkes, and of them that truſt in theyr own workes, and hope by them to obteyne, heauen is a vayne faith, or rather no fayth. For euery religion which hath not Chriſt for a captaine and guide, is prophane, wicked, and naughtie. But if it haue Chriſt, it is perfect, and abſolute.
I remember two olde verſes tending much to this matter, which be very ſenſible and worthy to be noted.

q.l: Hoc eſt ne ſcire, ſine Chriſto plurima ſcire,
Chriſtum ſi bene ſcis, ſatis eſt, ſi caetera neſcis.
To know much without Chriſt, is nothing expedient,
But well to know Chriſt, is onely ſufficient.

div.p:
In reuelatione Ieſu Chriſti: That is, by the reuelation of Ieſus Chriſt. By the Goſpel declared vnto vs, what chriſt is, that is to ſay, that he is our Sauiour, that it is he which taketh awaye our ſinnes, that it is he which deliuereth vs from all euills, that it is he which doth reconcile vs to the father, and maketh vs iuſte and
righteous without our owne worckes. He whiche knoweth not Chriſt after this maner, is much deceyued, and cleane out of the waye. For although thou knowe Chriſt to be the ſonne of God,7. Rihgt hād. to haue died, to haue riſen again, and now to ſyt on the right hande of the father: thou doeſt not yet know Chriſt, nor this knowledge ſhall any thing proffitte thee. But it is neceſſary that thou know and beleue him to haue done all theſe thinges for thee, to helpe, ſuccour, and comfort thee.

Chriſte ought not ſo to be preached, that he liueth and reigneth onely to hym ſelfe, but that he is ours. For otherwiſe what ſhould it haue proffited hym to deſcende into the earth, and to haue ſhed his bloud? Therfore he was ſente into the world, not for his owne cauſe, but that the world might be ſaued by hym, and that he might become whollie ours.

In reuelatione Ieſu Chriſti: by the reuelation of Ieſus Chriſt. That is, with a moſt ſted faſte hope apprehende and receyue you this grace offred. For Chriſt is not ſhewed vnto vs obſcurely and darckly, as he was ſhewed in olde tyme to the prophetes,8. Goliah. and by the Prophetes. For they do ſet forth Chriſt to be a ſauiour alwayes, as it were in miſteries. For they ſignified hym ſomtimes by Iſaac to be ſlayne of his father. Somtime by Dauid who ſlewe great Goliath: ſomtime by Salomon and his peaſable kyngdome, with ſuch and other like places was Chriſt vnderſtanded of the faithful in time paſt. But vnto vs, he is openly and plainlye declared without al figures, types, and miſteries.

Summa ſummarum. This is the minde of Peter: You neede not to take any great iourney to come vnto the grace of God. For God hath preuented your iourney in bringing and offringe this grace vnto you. But becauſe the fruition therof is not yet hadde, vntill Chriſte appeare from heauen (in whome is hidden the ſaluation of the godly) in the meane time we muſt hope, and that perfectly hope, for otherwiſe this grace of Chriſte is offred to vs in vaine, vnles we ſuſteine and abide paciently, vntil the comming of Chriſt. It followeth.

Quaſi filii obedientiae. As obedient children: It is ordeyned by nature, that the children repreſent and followe their fathers. You are made (ſaith Peter) the children of Chriſte by a liuelye faith, whiche was made obedient vnto his father euen vnto death, folow you therfore your father. And foraſmuch as it is appointed be nature, that we ſhould obeye our parentes, it is neceſſary that we become obedient children.
To obeye, doth ſignifie in the ſcriptures to beleue. And he is an obedient ſon which doth heare the goſpel and word of God, and by fayth embraceth it.

In Titum.Therfore if it be not the worde of God, heare it not, but rather ſpurne at it with thy feete, and regarde it not. For (as ſaint Hierome ſaith) Sine authoritate ſcripturas, garrulitas non habet fidem: without the authoritie of ſcriptures, all pratyng and talkyng ought to haue no credite.
Li. de virg. 4Saint Ambroſe alſo writeth. Si Chriſtus non docuit quod docemus, etiam nos id deteſtabile iudicamus. If chriſt hath not taught that which wedo teach, we iudge it deteſtable.9. Adoption.

Quaſi filii obedientiae, as obedient children. Peter doth firſt ſignifie that we are called of the Lord by the goſpel into the right title and honour of adoption. Secondly he ſheweth that we be adopted on this condition, that God might haue vs as children obedient vnto him. For although obedience doth not make vs children (for that is the free gifte of God) yet obedience doth diſcerne and diſtinguiſhe vs from ſtraungers. And howe farre this obedience doth extende and ſtretche it ſelfe, Peter doth teach, when he forbiddeth the children of God to faſhiō and frame them ſelues to the deſires of this world, but doth exhort that they ſhuld conforme them ſelues rather vnto God. The ſumme and ſcope of the whole law & of all things whiche god doth require of vs, doth pertayne to this ende: that the
image of God maye ſhine in vs, leaſte we become children whiche do degenerat from the father. But becauſe all the ſenſes and whole diſpoſition of our fleſh, are repugnaunt vnto God, and the whole nature and condition of our mynd, is enemie vnto him, therfore Peter beginneth our obedience from the renouncyng and forſakyng of the worlde and the luſtes therof, & that we do put of the image of olde Adam with his luſtes. Therfore Peter ſayth as followeth.

Non configurati prioribus ignorantiae veſtrae deſideriis: 10. Ignorance. Not faſhionynge your ſelues vnto the former luſtes of your ignoraunce. Peter here doth exhorte vs vnto puritie of life, by an agrument taken of hurte, and perill like to enſue. Doe ye not faſhion your ſelues (ſaith he) to your olde concupiſcences and luſtes, and to the corrupt maners of the olde man, by the which death and perpetuall priſonment hangeth ouer you. You haue put on a newe lyfe, and none other then heauenlye, before the whiche obteyned, you gaue your ſelues to gluttonie,11. Ambition. deſires of the fleſhe, ambition, pride, hatred, enuie, and to ſuche other thynges which are not lawfull to be named. Theſe were the workes of darckenes and ignoraunce. You knew not Chriſt, therfore light and true knowledge was far from you. You were ignoraunt of thoſe thynges which were geuen and ſhalbe geuen hereafter through Chriſt. You lyued before as blinde,Prouerb. 14. not knowynge which waye to holde or kepe. It is the propretie of ſinne to deceyue fooles. But nowe callinge to remembraunce what daungers you haue eſcaped, be not you deceyued nor lead from the right waye, no not in one pointe.

To the minde of Peter,Cap. 12. here that pertaineth whiche ſainct Paule writeth to the Romaines: Obſecro vos frates per miſericordiam dei &c. I beſeche you therfore brethren, by the mercies of God, that you geue vp your bodies a liuing ſacrifice, holy, & acceptable vnto God, which is your reaſonable ſeruyng of God. And faſhion not your ſelues lyke vnto this worlde, but be you chaunged by the renuing of your minde, that ye maye proue what is the good will of God, and acceptable and perfecte.

Non configurati &c. Not faſhionyng your ſelues vnto the former luſtes of your ignoraunce. Here you ſee that Peter doth impute all thynges vnto ignoraunce, as the chiefeſt ſprynge of all euels. For where the fayth and knowledge of Chriſt is abſente, there can be none other thyng, but errour and blindnes, that it can not be knowen what is right, what is wronge, what is true, what is falſe, what is good, what is badde, ſo that men through ignoraunce do fall hedlonge into diuerſe kyndes of vices. After what maner it was with vs of late dayes in the time of ſuperſtition, when Chriſt and his glory was darckened, and his word aboliſhed. For then had we errour for truth, ignoraunce for knowledge, blindenes for lyght. Then was there reaſoninge and debatynge throughe the whole worlde, howe men might attaine eternall felicitie. Of this ſprange vp ſo many ſectes, as Friers, ſome being blacke, ſome white, ſome Franciſcanes, ſome Auguſtines, ſome obſeruantes, and of Monckes, Nunnes,12. Heremites & anchorites. Chanons, and Heremites, of Anchorites and Anchorizes. So that al things wer deuided, euery man almoſt ſeekyng and framing to him ſelfe awaye how to come to heauen. But Peter ſayth here: you haue played the fooles longe ynoughe. Nowe throwe fooliſhnes awaye. For you are made wiſe and haue attained true knowledge.

Ignorantiae veſtrae: of your ignoraunce. Peter calleth the tyme of ignoraunce, before they were called to the fayth of Chriſt, wherby we learne that incredulitie is the fountaine of all miſchiefe:13. Priuation. Where the knowledge of God doth not floriſhe, there are darcknes, errour, vanitie, priuation both of lyght and of lyfe

div.head: Quaeſtio.
div.p: Foraſmuche as Peter ſpeaketh to the Iewes, whiche were alwayes conuerſaunt

Qui ergo hunc inuocatis patrem. &c. And if you call him father, which without reſpecte of perſon iudgeth accordinge to euerie mans worcke, paſſe the time of your dwellinge here in feare. By faithe you are made the ſonnes of god, and he is your father, you haue obteined an incorruptible enheritaunce, whereof mētion is made before. Nowe therfore there remayneth none other thinge, than (the vayle beinge put away) that thinge maie be made manifeſt, which nowe is hidden, but we muſt looke for it vntil we maie ſee and vnderſtande it. Therfore for aſmuch as you are come to this poynt, that you maie inuocate and call vpon god the father by faith, becauſe notwithſtandinge he is a righteous iudge, and rewardeth euerye man according to their worcks:17. Reſpect of perſon. Let no man perſuade himſelfe for that he is called a chriſtian, or the ſonne of God, that god will ſpare him, if he liue without feare, and thincketh it ſufficient to be called by that name. The worlde iudgeth by reſpecte of perſone, and not al men a like, for it is partiall to frends, rich men, learned, wiſe, and men of authoritie and power, But god regardeth none of theſe, he iudgeth al men a like, be the perſon neuer ſo great. Like as in Egipt he ſlew the kings ſonne, aſwel as the ſonne of anye poore ſhepheard. And therfore the apoſtle Peter admoniſheth vs to looke for ſuche iudgment, and to ſtande in feare, and that we ſhould not boaſte nor bragge of our faythe, becauſe we are called chriſtians, neither that we ſhould preſume therfore that god wil ſpare vs more than other. For that thing in times paſt deceiued the Iewes alſo, who bragged them ſelues to be the ſonnes of Abraham, and the people of god. The ſcripture maketh no differēce by the fleſh, but by the ſpirite. It is certaine that god did promiſe Chriſt to be borne of the ſeede of Abraham, and that of Abraham ſhould riſe a holy people. But it followeth not therfore, that all men are the ſonnes of god which do come of Abraham. God alſo promiſed the Gentiles to be ſaued, but he ſayde not, that he woulde ſaue all the Gentiles.

div.head: Quaeſtio.
div.p: Foraſmoch as you do ſaie that god doth ſaue vs by faith onelie, without reſpect of worcks, howe then doth Peter here ſaie that god doth iudge without reſpecte of perſone, accordinge to euerie mans worcke?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: That which we haue taught of faithe, that it onelie iuſtifieth vs before god, is vndoubtedlie true: for the ſcripture approueth the ſame more manifeſtlie, then that it can be denied or diſproued. Nowe where Peter ſaith here, that God iudgeth accordinge to euerie mans worke, it is true alſo. But this is certainlie to be beleued, that where faithe is not, there can no good worcks be had.

Agayne, there faithe is not to be founde, where no good worcks are: therfore faith and good worcks concurre, and can not be the one without the other, as in whiche two the ſūme of chriſtian life is comprehended. For as thou haſt liued, ſo ſhalt thou be rewarded and iudged of god. And therfore although god iudgeth according to euerie mans worke, yet notwithſtandinge this is true, that good workes are but the fruites of faith, by the which is proued where faith and infidilitie is.18. Lie & lier, God therfore wil iudge thee by thy worckes, and will proue and trye thee whether thou haue fayth or no. Lyke as a man ſhall not knowe a lyar better than by his owne wordes: Notwithſtanding it appeareth that not by theſe wordes onelye he is made a lyer, but he was a lyer before he made anye lye, becauſe a lye muſte come out of the harte, into the mouthe. Wherfore you muſte ſo take this ſaiynge of Peter, that you vnderſtand good worckes to be the fruites of fayth, and that god accordinge to theſe fruites (whiche we muſte nedes exerciſe) dothe iudge vs, that it maie manifeſtlye appeare, whether faith or infidilitie do dwell in our hartes.

God will not iudge thee accordynge to this that thou arte called a chriſtian,
that thou art baptiſed, but he will aſke thee thus: If thou be a chriſtian, where be the fruites by the whych thou maiſt proue thy chriſtian faith?

And therfore ſainct Peter ſaith: In as much as you haue ſuch a father that iudgeth without reſpecte of perſon, paſſe the tyme of your dwellynge here in feare, that is, feare this father, not for feare of puniſhment or reuengement, as the deuils do, but for feare leaſte he caſte you of, and withdrawe his hande from you, lyke as a good ſonne feareth leaſt in any thynge he offende or diſpleaſe his father.
Such a feare god doth require of vs, that we may abhorre and deteſte ſinne, and that wee maye diligentlye benefitte and do good to our neyghboures, while we liue in this worlde.

A chriſtian whiche hath a right faith, hath all the good benefittes of God, and is the ſonne of God, but his tyme in this worlde is nothing els but a pilgrimage. For his ſpirite is alredie in heauen by fayth, by the which ſpirite he is gouernour of all thynges. But god ſuffreth hym to liue yet in the fleſhe, and to haue bodilye conuerſation in the worlde, that he maye helpe other, and that he may bring them with him to be heauen.

Therfore we muſt behaue our ſelues in this worlde, none otherwiſe then they do which iourneying into farre countries, do take their inne and eaſe, for they are ſatiſfied if they haue meate and lodgyng for one night of the hoſte, neither do they clayme or chalendge to them ſelues his ſubſtaunce or goodes.

Likewiſe euery man muſt vſe worldly goods as though they wer not his own, and muſt take ſo muche of them, as is ſufficient for the ſuſtentation of oure bodie, helping our neighbours with the ouerplus.

Therfore the life of man is as it were but a reſtyng place, we muſt take our iourney thither where our father is, that is, into heauen. Wherfore we muſt laye awaye all ſlouthfull, wanton and careles liuyng, and paſſe the time of our dwelling here (as ſainct Peter ſayth) in the feare of god. It followeth.

Scientes quòd non corruptibilibus auro, &c. Knowing that ye were not redemed with corruptible thinges, as ſiluer and gold, from your vaine conuerſation receyued by the traditions of the fathers. Peter doth perſeuer to exhorte vs to holy lyfe and chriſtian religion, takynge his argument of the ineſtimable price of oure redemption, as if he ſhoulde ſaye: Continue you in faith, and in louing one an other, conſideringe that you are redemed with ſuche a price, as farre paſſeth mans reaſon. You that firſte were inhabitantes and citizens of this world, vnder the thraldome and yoke of Sathan, are nowe made the citizens of heauen,19. Tradicion. and houſehold ſeruauntes of god, and you are deliuered, not onely from Sathan, but alſo from the vaine conuerſation of your fathers traditions. He calleth their fathers traditions vaine and fonde, becauſe they whiche were gentiles, were inſtructe and brought vp in Idolatrie, and they which were Iewes, had learned manie ſuperſtitions. By the which they did violate and breake many waies the commaundements of God, wherfore Chriſt reproued them in Mathew ſaying: Quare & vos tranſgredimini mandatum dei propter traditionem veſtram? Why do you alſo breake the commaundement of God by your traditions?

Sainct Paule ſaith, that he perſecuted the church of God, when not withſtandyng he thought him ſelfe to be a great follower of the traditions of the fathers. All traditions are vain and fooliſh whatſoeuer they be, which do repugne the doctrine of Chriſt. For where Chriſt wanteth, ther is mere vanitie.

Or els ſaincte Peter by the vayne traditions of the fathers, doth meane conuerſation of life, according to Moiſes law, which was vaine and weake to the atteyninge of eternall life. The worckes of the lawe did not iuſtifie of them ſelues, they were but ſhadowes and figures, and could not remitte ſinne. From theſe lawiſhe
worckes the Iewes were deliuered, beinge no more bounde to Moſes lawe, which Chriſt our ſauyour hath ſo fulfilled, that it nede not anye more to be ſought. For what can it demaunde or aſke of vs, when we are nothinge bounde to it, but it is in al poyntes fulfilled by Chriſt? It followeth.

Sed pretioſo ſanguine Chriſti, quaſi agni immaculati & incontamninati. But with the precious bloude of chriſt,20. Lambe. as of a lambe vndefiled and without ſpotte. Peter here doth declare with a large amplification the price of our redemption, and doth by thys prouoke vs to ſtande in ye feare of god, and to expend and waigh how muche this our redemption did coſte him. Before this, ſaithe Peter, ye were citizens of the worlde, liuinge vnder the imperie and rule of the deuel: but god nowe hath deliuered you from that wicked conuerſation, and hath brought you into another place, that nowe ye mighte be citizens in heauen, and ſtraungers in earth. But conſider you howe muche god hathe beſtowed for you, and how great a treaſure it is, by the which ye are redemed and brought to this point, that ye are becom the ſonnes of god. But what is that great and precious treaſure wherwith ye are redemed? Not corruptible thinges as golde and ſiluer, but the precious bloude of the ſonne of god. This treaſure is ſo noble and excellente, and of ſo imcomparable a price, that no ſenſe or reaſon is able to comprehende and conceyue it.

Yea, it is ſo precious, that one droppe of this innocent bloud had bene ſufficient for the ſinnes of the whole worlde. But it pleaſed the eternall father to poure his grace ſo largelie vpon vs,21. All his bloude. and with ſo great a price to purchace our ſaluation, that he would his ſonne Ieſus Chriſte to ſhed all his bloud, and to geue alſo that whole treaſure vnto vs.

Peter therfore requireth that we ſhake not of this ſo great a grace, and to weighe it lightlie and ſlenderlie, but rather ſo to eſteme it, that we maie be moued and egged forwarde to feare. In the which feare we liuinge, maye not againe deſerue to be depriued of this noble treaſure. It followeth.

Quaſi agni immaculati & incontaminati: as of a lambe vndefiled and without ſpotte, that is: Chriſt willingly was brought vnto the ſlaughter without murmurynge, and without cryinge, for our reparation and redemption. To this place alludeth ſainct Iohn the Baptiſte ſaying.Cap. 53. 22. Taketh away ſinnes Ecce agnus dei, ecce qui tollit peccata mundi. Beholde the lambe of God, beholde the lambe whiche taketh awaye the ſinnes of the worlde. Likewiſe the Prophete Eſaie ſaith: He is brought as a ſhepe to the ſlaughter, and as a ſhepe before his ſherer is dumme, ſo he openeth not his mouth.
Alſo Ieremie ſpeaketh in the perſon of Chriſt: I was like a lambe or bullocke that was brought vnto the ſlaughter.Cap. 11.

This Chriſt was an immaculate lambe, that is, he was conceyued by the holy ghoſt, borne of the virgin Marie, he was a lambe without ſpotte. And therfore he onely and none other could be a pure and holy ſacrifice for ſinnes, for which he hath fullie ſatiſfied, and ſuſteyned the paine therof, as it is in the prophete Eſaie. The Lorde hath laied vpon him the iniquitie of vs all.Cap. 53.

div.head: Queſtio.
div.p: From what thing are we redemed by this ſo preciouſe a treaſure?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Peter ſaith, a vana veſtra conuerſatione: from your vaine conuerſation, receyued by the traditions of the fathers. In the whiche wordes Peter doth throughly ouerthrowe that thinge which we are wonte to leane vnto, thincking that whatſoeuer we do, ought to be allowed, for that they were done of olde tyme, and becauſe our elders and fathers (amonge whome there were many, both wiſe and good) did obſerue and kepe the like thinges.

But Peter here doth ſay, whatſoeuer thinges your fathers dyd, eyther ordayne or vſed to do, were al ill: yea inſomuch that thoſe things which you learned of them,
concerning the worſhipping of God, were ſo ill, that it behoued, notwithſtanding the ſonne of God to beſtowe his bloud, that men might be deliuered from the ſame wickednes. Whatſoeuer therfore is not waſhed and clenſed by thys bloud, it is all infecte, corrupte and curſed. Whereby it followeth that howe much the more any doth aſpire to righteouſnes without Chriſt, ſo much the more is he remoued from true righteouſnes: and is the more depely drowned into the bottome of blindnes and curſe, and doth make him ſelf giltie of the bloud of Chriſt. Thoſe groſſe ſinnes are truely of litle weight, if they be compared with this ſinne, which teacheth that we may obteine righteouſnes by workes, and after the decree of reaſō doth frame and ordeine a worſhipping of God. For by this meanes is ye moſte innocent bloud of Chriſt diſhonoured and blaſphemed.

The Gentiles did much more grieuouſly ſinne in worſhipping the Sunne and Moone (which they counted to be the true worſhipping of God,) than in cōmitting other ſinnes which they doubted not to be haynous.

Wherfore the righteouſnes of man without Chriſt is nothing but blaſphemie, and the moſt haynous ſinne that man can committe. Therfore he that deſireth the grace of God by any other thing than by the bloud of Chriſt, let him neuer come into the ſight of god. For he doth nothing els but more and more, through his own righteouſnes, offend the maieſtye of God. And by thys may be gathered that men do moſt deteſtable erre, and the farther depart from Chriſt, which without Chriſt will leane and truſt to the authoritye of the fathers, or to olde cuſtome.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: Paule boaſteth him ſelf to haue worſhipped God with a pure conſcience, euen from his elders,2. Tim. 1 and writing to Timothie doth commend him that he dyd followe the fayth of his Graundmother Loìs, and his mother Euniche. And Chriſt alſo ſayeth of the Iewes, that they knowe what God they ought to worſhip. And therfore it may ſeeme abſurde here that Peter did affirme, that the Iewes of his time learned nothing of the traditions of the fathers, but meere vanitie.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Where Chriſt did ſaye that the maner and knowledge of the worſhipping of God was knowen to the Iewes, he had more reſpecte to the law and commaundement of God, than to the common people of the Iewes, becauſe the temple was erected at Hieruſalem, and god worſhipped there, not by the arbitrement of mā, but by the preſcripte of the lawe. Therfore Chriſt doth ſay that the Iewes did not erre in obſeruing that lawe.

Concerning the progenitours, that is, the graundmother and mother of Timothie and ſuch like (of whom Saint Paule ſpeaketh) there is no doubte, but God had ſome remnaunt in that people, in whom true pietie did alwaies remaine. But the moſt part of the whole bodye of the people was merueilouſlye corrupte, and fell into al kindes of error, as into ſuperſtitions, hypocriſie, truſt in their own works, ill opinions, and other groſſe vices.

Therfore where Peter condemneth the inſtitution and traditions of ye fathers, he doth ſeperate them from Chriſt, which onely and alone is the ſoule, lyfe, and truth of the lawe. Wherupon we may conclude, that the papiſtes do moſt foliſhlye erre, which thinke that the bare name of the fathers and theyr traditions, are ſufficient for them to defend al ſuperſtitions, and that by this truſt they might reiect whatſoeuer was brought out of the word of God. It followeth.

Praecogniti quidemante mundi conſtitutionem: Which was ordeyned before the foundation of the world, but was declared in the laſte tymes for your ſakes. Peter here doth ſtirre his hearers to the loue of Chriſt, and to receaue theyr ſaluatiō with great honour, by an argument brought ab antiquitate, as though he ſhoulde ſay: Thinke not, nor perſwade your ſelues, that thoſe thinges which I haue ſpoken
of the price of your redemption, that is, of the immaculate Lambe Ieſus Chriſt, and of the effuſion of his bloud, to be new things, or to be inuented by the arte and wiſedome of man: but they were ordeined before the foundation of the world, and came from the counſell of the eternall father.

God ſayeth, Peter dyd from euerlaſting, foreordeine his ſonne to be ſacrificed for the expiation of our ſinnes,Cap. 1. as Paule ſayth to the Epheſians: Elegit nos deus in Chriſto ante mundi conſtitutionem. God hath choſen vs in Chriſt before ye foundatiō of the world, that we ſhould be holy and without blame before him in loue.

Likewyſe Iohn in his reuelation calleth this Lambe, ab origine mundi occiſū. Slaine from the beginning of the world, that is, he was before ordeyned from the beginning to be a ſacrifice for our ſinnes, by the which ſacrifice all ye electe ſhoulde be clenſed from the beginning of the worlde. If therfore this ſaluation was foreknowen and before ordeyned, according to the good wil and pleaſure of God, that we ſhould be holy: it chaunceth not vnto vs by any of our owne merites, but by the meere and pure grace of God, vnto whom we owe all thinges, both our ſelues and all ours. It followeth.

Manifeſtati autem nouiſsimis temporibus propter vos: But was declared in the laſte times for your ſakes. The Apoſtle here aunſwereth to the obiection of them which perchaunce might haue ſayd thus: Foraſmuch as Chriſt was foreknowen frō euerlaſting to be the ſacrifice and expiation of our ſinnes,23. So lōg ere he came. why was it ſo longe ere he came into the world? Peter aunſwereth, becauſe it ſo pleaſed hym, he came in the laſte time. And ſo Paule aunſwereth, ſaying: Vbi venit plenitudo temporis, deus dedit filium ſuum factum ex muliere. When the fulnes of the time came, god gaue hys ſonne borne of a woman, made ſubiecte to the law, that he might redeme thoſe which are vnder the law, from the curſe of the lawe.

div.head: Queſtio.
div.p: Why doth Peter call that tyme in which he was, the laſte tyme? Seing that a great tyme is expired and gone from the tyme of Peter hetherto.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Peter calleth it the laſte tyme in two reſpectes. Fyrſt, that it is the laſte tyme from the aſcenſion of the Lorde, that ſhall continue vnto the laſte daye. And thys tyme the Prophetes, Apoſtles, and Chriſt him ſelf did call the laſte houre. Secondlye, it is called the laſte tyme in reſpecte of viſions and prophecyes, which were to be fulfilled of Chriſt. It is called (I ſaye) the laſte tyme, not that ſtreight way from the aſcention of Chriſt the laſte day ſhould come: but becauſe after thys preaching of the Goſpell, which than was, and now is, none other preaching is to come, nor to be looked for, nor that the matter of Gods grace myght be more reuealed and made more manifeſt, thā it is now reuealed & ſhewed ſince the aſcenſion of Chriſt. Before this, one reuelation euer followed another. Whereupon the Lorde ſayd in Exodus:24. Adonai. Nomen meum Adonai non reuelaui eis. I dyd not reueale my name Adonai vnto them. For although the Patriarches knewe God: yet they had not ſo manifeſt a preaching and knowledge of God, as was afterward geuen by Moſes and the Prophets. But now there cannot be a more noble & manifeſte preaching of the Goſpel, than is had in the world ſince the aſcenſion of Chriſt. And in that reſpecte Peter doth call this time the laſte tyme, becauſe there can neuer be a more clerer preaching of the Goſpel, than now is: It followeth.

Propter vos qui per eum creditis. For your ſakes which by his meanes doe beleue in God. For your ſakes (ſaith Peter) is the Goſpell preached. God the father and Chriſt hys ſonne had no nede therof, but it was done for our ſaluatiō, that is: that we ſhould beleue in him, not by our own ſtrēgth, but by Chriſt which maketh interceſſion for vs to the father. Therfore we muſte learne and beleue that Chriſt was made manifeſt and knowen vnto vs for none other end and purpoſe, thā that
by him we ſhould be ſaued, and that in him we ſhould behold the truth, goodnes, and righteouſnes of God, and that in embracing the ſame, we ſhould haue a full minde and truſt to him, and in him. It followeth.

Qui ſuſcitauit eum a mortuis. &c. Which raiſed him from the dead, and gaue him glory, that your faith and hope might be in God. The whole, holy, & bleſſed Trinity hath rayſed Chriſt as man from death. For the outward woorkes of the Trinity ar indiuiſible. For what things ſo euer ye father doth, ye ſame both the ſon & the holy ghoſt doth. And ſo likewiſe on the otherſide whatſoeuer ye ſon & the holye ghoſt do, the ſame doth ye father. Chriſt roſe as a mā glorified, yt is, the diuinity roſe not, but Ieſus Chriſt touching his humanity, was raiſed frō death, by ye glory of ye father. For the ſon him ſelf as God, did rayſe him ſelfe cōcerning his humanity, for he ſaid in Iohn: Soluite templum hoc, et in tribus diebus excitabo illud. Deſtroy you this temple, and in three daies I ſhal rayſe it vp. He ſpake this of the temple of his body. God (I ſay) did rayſe Chriſtes body from the deade, and gaue to hym glory, becauſe he roſe immortal.25. Giuen to me to iudg. He gaue vnto his body perpetual glorification & power to iudge, as it is ſayd in the Goſpel of Mathew: Data eſt mihi omnis poteſtas, et in caelo et in terra. All power is geuen to me, both in heauen and in earth. God the father gaue vnto him, not onely the glory of his body, but alſo the glorye of his name, as it is written by Paule: Dedit illi nomen quod eſt ſuper omne nomen, vt in nomine Ieſu omne genu flectatur, coeleſtium, terreſtrium, et infernorū. 26. Knee ſhuld bowe. He gaue vnto him a name which is aboue al names, that in the name of Ieſus euery knee ſhould bow, both of thinges in heauen, of things in earth, and of things vnder the earth. Alſo God gaue, that in calling on his name, maruailes, wonders and miracles ſhould be done.

He gaue vnto him (I ſaye) this glorye, that our faith and hope ſhoulde be in God, and not in mere man, that is, that we ſhoulde beleue and truſt in God, becauſe Chriſt both God and man is he, whom God gaue foorth as a propitiatour for ſynne by fayth in his bloud, to the declaration of righteouſnes in thys tyme. It followeth.

Vt fidem et ſpem veſtram in deum habeatis. That you may beleue and truſt in God. Peter here doth ſay, that Chriſt was raiſed from death, that faith and hope might haue a firme and ſure ſtay, wherunto they might leane. And here is that comment and gloſe refelled of the vniuerſal and confuſed faith in God. For although that Chriſt had neuer ryſen againe, God notwithſtanding doth remaine in heauen. But Peter denieth that we cannot beleue in hym, vnleſſe Chriſt had ryſen agayne.

It is euident therfore, that fayth ought to behold and conſider another thing, then the bare maieſty of God. For it is the property of fayth,Phil. 3 Cap. 4. to flee and pearce in to heauen, that he might ther finde the father. And how can he doo that, except he haue Chriſt his guide and leader? For (as Paule ſayth) per ipſum habemus adeun di fiduciam, by him we haue ſure hope and truſt to go to the father.27. Our highe prieſt. Againe to the Hebrues he ſayth: Freti noſtro pōtifice accedere poſſumus ad thronum gratiae cum fiducia. 28. Shoot anchor. Truſting in our highe prieſt wee maye go to the throne of grace with a ſure hope.

Hope is the ſhoote anchor of the ſoule which entreth into the inward cloſet of the ſanctuarye, yet not ſo, but that Chriſt muſt go before. Faith is our victorye againſt the worlde. And what maketh her to ouercome, but that Chriſt Lord of heauen and earth hath vs in his tuicion and keeping?

Becauſe therefore our ſaluation is conſtitute and ſet in the reſurrection of Chriſt, and his high impery and rule, faith and hope found ther how to ſtaye and vphold them ſelues. For except Chriſt by riſing again had triumphed ouer death, and had borne the chiefe rule to defend vs with his might and power, what would haue bene done vnto vs, in ſo great a power of our enemies, and among ſo many violent aſſaults? Let vs learne therefore, to what ſcope and marke we ought to
tende and ſhoote, which is, that we beleue and truſt in God, but in and by Chriſt, riſyng agayne from death. It followeth.

Animas veſtras caſtificantes in obedientia veritatis. Seing your ſoules are purified in obeyng the truth, through the ſpirite, to loue brotherly without fayning, loue one another with a pure hart feruently. We haue heard hitherto how Peter exhorteth vs. Firſt that we gird vp the loynes of our mindes, that we myght walke ſincerely in the fayth. Secondly, becauſe this thing did coſt him ſo muche, that we ſhould liue in feare, not putting anye confidence in this, becauſe we are called Chriſtians: foraſmuch as God is ſuch a iudge, which reſpecteth no man, not one more then another. And now at ye laſt Peter goeth forward to make an end of this firſt chapter, ſaying, purifying your ſoules in obeing ye truth through ye ſprit.

Gala. 5.Sainct Paule to the Galathians rehearſeth the fruites which do follow fayth, ſaying: The fruites of the ſpirite are charitie, ioye, peace, long ſuffring, gentlenes, goodnes, fayth, meekenes, temperancie. So alſo doth S. Peter here teach which are the fruites of fayth, that is, that we doe purifie our ſelues by obeying the truth in the ſpirite. For wher true faith is, it ſubdueth the body vnto it, and reſtrayneth the luſt and concupiſcence of the fleſh. And although it doth not vtterly deſtroy it, yet it maketh the body ſubiect to the ſpirit.

Saint Paule meaneth the ſame, when he ſpeaketh of the fruites of the ſpirite. It is a great labour to ſubdue the body vnto the ſpirite, and to repres the naughty and euil luſtes, graffed in vs by nature. For it is not poſſible for vs to liue well wythout grace.

Why doth he ſay: Purify your ſoules, rather then your bodies? Saint Peter did know that our carnall luſtes (yea although we be baptiſed) cannot be extincte before we be dead. Now it is not inough that a man do refrain him ſelfe from the act, and be onely outwardly pure, hauing an hart burning with euill luſtes: but we muſt ſhoot at this marcke, that our ſoules may be ſo purified, that the clenſing therof may come from the hart, and that the ſoule may be an enemy vnto euil luſtes, and continually fight with them, vntil it be deliuered.
Saint Peter addeth here very aptly, that we ought to purify our ſelues, in obeying the truth through the ſpirite.
Many thinges are ſpoken of chaſtity, & many be bookes written of the ſame. They haue taught to extinguiſh the carnal luſtes of the fleſhe by long faſtinges, abſtinence from fleſh and wyne.
Which thinges (although they ſomewhat helpe to that ende) yet they are not ſufficient to extinguiſh the ſayd luſtes and deſires.

Saint Hierome writeth of him ſelfe, that he did ſo puniſh his bodye, & brought it ſo low, that he was like to an Ethiopian or blacke Moore. Notwithſtanding he did not ſo much preuaile by it. For he often times dreamed in his ſleepe, that he was preſent in the company of the faire damoſels at Rome. And ſaint Bernarde (as I ſaid before) did puniſh his body with ſo great abſtinence, that he ſtanck, and no man could abide his preſence. They both wer marueilouſly tempted, & thought them ſelues able to ouercome thoſe temptations, by thoſe externe thinges.

But becauſe thoſe remedies which they vſed, were but externe and outwarde, and not applied inwardly, wher the roote of temptacion did lye, they were not ſufficient to extinguiſh the ill deſires and luſts of the minde. But Peter here ſheweth a true and effectual remedy for this miſchief: that is to ſay, the obeing of the truth thorow the ſpirit, which alſo is declared in many other places of the ſcripture. As in Eſay:Eſay. 11. Fides erit cinctorium renum eius. Faith ſhall be the girdle of his raynes. This is the true plaiſter, with the which the raynes are girded vp. The euil which we would heale, is not outward in cloth and garment, but bred inwardlye, and is fierce in the bloud, in the fleſh, and in the vaynes.

Wherfore it is not the beſt way to endeuour to extinguiſhe theſe luſtes with externe
thinges onely, and to debilitate and weaken the bodye with faſtings and labours, for that is not ye beſt and chiefeſt way, although they ſomwhat helpe to that end, but it is fayth which can extinguiſh and reſtraine them, that they maye geue place to the ſpirite.

So the Prophet Zacharie ſpeaketh of ye wyne which Chriſt doth offer to drink, wherof virgens are gendered and begotten. Other kindes of wine are wonte to kindle euill luſtes, but thys wine, that is the Goſpel, reſtrayneth thoſe luſtes, and maketh the hart pure.

And this is it which Peter ſayth: when truth is receaued in hart, and obedience geuen to it in ſpirit, that is the moſt preſent remedie and beſt cure of all euil luſtes and deſires. For when the Goſpell entreth into the hart, immediatlye all euill motions do ceaſe and geue place.

To be ſhort, the meaning of Peter is this: If ye wil remaine chaſte and pure, it behoueth you to embrace the obedience of truth, that is to ſay: It is neceſſarye for you not onely to read and to heare the word of God, but alſo to embrace it in hart.

Wherfore it is not ſufficiēt that the Goſpel be preached or heard once or twiſe, but ye muſt cleaue vnto it, and followe it continually.29. Fruite hundred fold. For the worde of God hath this grace, that the oftener ye handle it, and vſe it, the ſweter it waxeth, and ſhall bring forth fructū centeſimum tempore ſuo, fruite an hundred fold in his tyme. It followeth.

In fraternitatis amore, qui ſit abſ
que fuco: To loue brotherlye without fayning. For what end ought we to liue this chaſte and pure life? To obteyne eternall bleſſednes by it? No truely, but to this end, that we ſerue & be profitable to our neighbours. What ſhall we do to repreſſe ſinne? Forſoth we muſte embrace fayth of the word of God. Now we doe reſtraine our ſinnes to profit other men, for when we bridle the body and fleſhe by the ſpirite, than we maye be ſome vſe and profite vnto our neighbours. It followeth.

Simplici ex corde diligite attentius. &c. Loue one another with a pure hart feruentlye. In theſe wordes Peter doth very elegantly deſcribe & expreſſe the partes and nature of true loue.30. Loue. The ſame obedience of which we haue ſpokē (ſayth Peter) draweth after it loue, not all maner of loue, but that loue which commeth from the minde and hart, wherwith we do vehemently and earneſtly, and not fainedly loue our brother and neighbour. True frendſhip loueth no colours,31. Flattery. true frendſhip hath learned no flatterie. Therfore ſayth Peter loue one another with a pure hart, feruently, readie to beſtowe all that you haue for your neighbours ſake. Charitie, which is poured into the hartes of the faythfull, knoweth not a double or diſſembling hart. Therefore Chriſt ſayth: Eſtote ſimplices ſicut columbae. Be ye ſimple as Doues.

Loue one another with a pure hart feruentlie. The Apoſtles Peter and Paule do ſeparate and deuyde a ſunder brotherly loue and common loue. By brotherlye loue chriſtians ought to be as brethren, and to make no difference betwene them ſelues, for we haue all in common, one Chriſt, one baptiſme, one fayth, & one treaſure. I can not be in this reſpecte of greater price, than thou art, that which thou haſte, I haue, and am as riche as thou art, the ſame treaſure is vnto vs both: ſauing that peraduenture thou doeſt receaue it more worthelye than I do: as if thou ſhouldeſt lay it vp in golde, and I in ſome courſe cloth. Therfore as we haue grace and all the ſpirituall goods of Chriſt common: ſo ought we to haue, (if nede ſo require) our bodyes, our life, our goods, our dignities and offices common, that we may ſerue and do good to one another in all thinges.

Loue one another with a pure hart feruentlye. Peter doth ſignificantlie here ſaye with a pure hart. And thys worde 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , whiche ſignifieth without diſſimulation, is often vſed of ye Apoſtles. And for this cauſe vndoubtedly, becauſe they ſaw before ye chriſtians would cal them ſelues brothers, but falſly & hipocriticallie.

Ther were many fraternities erected in the world, which were nothing els but mere lies & deceits, excogitate of the diuel, & ſo brought into the world, which wholy and vtterly were contrary vnto faith & ſincere loue.32. Sainte Fraunces For why ſhould not Chriſt be aſwel mine, as ſaint Bernardes and his fraternity? Why ſhould not Chriſt be as wel thine, as ſaint Fraunces & his fraternity? Therfore when any doo ſaye: I ſhal go to heauen, if I be in this fraternity, or in that fraternity: Anſwer thou him that he vttereth nothing but blaſphemies & lies. For Chriſt can ſuffer none other fraternity but common, and ſuch as we al ought to haue among our ſelues.

I would not haue you ſo to take me, as though I condemne all Fraternities. For thoſe fraternities may be ſuffered, wher ther be aſſemblies gathered together for ſome treaſure, wherby the neceſſities of the poore and of the ſicke maye bee ſuſtained and relieued.33. Brotherne But theſe fraternities are not ſuche, that by them the ſoules may peculiarly be the more holy: but they are onely or maye be permitted to prouide for ye body, & for neceſſaries of ye poore & nedy, as al our hoſpitals cōmonly ar.

But to ſpeake of brotherly loue, al Chriſtians haue one fraternity, which they obtained in baptiſme. Of the which fraternity no man (be he neuer ſo holye) hath more then either I or thou haſt. For with what price he was redeemed, with the ſame waſt thou redemed, and God beſtowed no leſſe for my cauſe, or for thy cauſe, then for the greateſt ſaynt in heauen, ſauing that he peraduenture had a more firme and ſtrong faith, then eyther thou or I.

Now common loue is a litle more large, then brotherly loue. For cōmon loue pertaineth vnto the enemies, and ſpecially againſt them which are not worthye of loue. For as faith doth exerciſe, & ſetteth forth her woorke, wher ſhe ſeeth nothing: ſo loue ought to ſee nothing,34. Vnworthy and to practiſe her worke ther, where nothing appeareth to be loued. As Chriſt loued vs, when we wer in all reſpectes vtterly vnworthy of hys loue. It followeth.

Renati non ex ſemine incorruptibile. &c. Being borne of new, and not of mortal ſeede, but of immortal by the word of God, who loueth and endureth for euer. All theſe thinges (ſaith Peter) ye ought to doo, becauſe ye are not the ſame nowe, which you were before, but you be borne a new, and made new men. This thyng was not brought to paſſe by your owne woorkes and meanes, but ther needed a new birth. For thou canſt not make a new man by thy own worke, but he muſt be begotten and borne. What Carpenter can by his own arte and cunning make a tree, which muſt grow out of the earth of his own accord? Therfore, as we are not made, but born the children of Adam, and drew ſyn of our Parents: ſo we can not be by our owne induſtry the children of God, but muſt be regenerate and borne agayne ſuche.

The Apoſtle Peter meaneth thus: Foraſmuch as you are made a new creature, it behoueth alſo yt you behaue your ſelues otherwiſe thā you did before, & that you purpoſe to leade a new life. As you liued before in hatred, ſo liue you now in loue. As you liued before in fleſhly luſts, ſo lyue you now in purenes & clearnes of life. Let all be turned vpſide downe. But how chaunceth or cōmeth this new natiuitie and byrth? Not of mortall ſede (ſaith Peter) but of immortal, by the word of God, who liueth here for euer: that is, we are borne againe of a certaine ſeede, as we ſee all other things to ſpringe and grow of ſede. If therfore that old natiuitie ſprange and came of ſeede, it behoueth alſo the newe byrth to be of ſome ſeede. But what a ſeede is that? Truly, neither fleſh nor bloud, nor none other corruptible thing, but the eternal word of God, that is, the whole, wherby we lyue, whereby we are nouriſhed, and ſpeciallye whereby we are regenerate. But after what manner is this wont to be done? By this God ſendeth forth his woord, that is, the Goſpell, which ſeede he throweth into the hart of man. If that ſede abide in the hart, the holy goſt is preſent, and frameth, and maketh a new man, which is farre other then he was before. He hath other thoughtes, other words, & other workes. And by this meanes is he wholy chaunged: whatſoeuer he fled before, that he now ſeeketh, whatſoeuer
he ſought before, that he now fleeth. And this ſeede of the ſpirite cannot be chaunged, it remaineth for euer, and changeth vs in to it ſelfe. Therefore, this marueylous natiuity and birth is of an excellent ſeede. It followeth.

Quia omnis caro vt faenum. &c. For al fleſh is as graſſe, and al the glory of mā is as the flower of graſſe. This place is taken out of the prophet Eſay,Eſay. 40. wher it is ſaid to the prophet: Clama, cry thou. And to him demaunding what he ſhould cry, it was ſayde agayne: ita clames, cry thus: omnis caro gramen eſt. &c. All fleſhe is graſſe, and al the graſſe therof is as the floure of the fielde. The graſſe wythereth, ye floure fadeth, but the word of our God ſhal ſtāfaſt for euer. The prophet Eſay & Peter the apoſtle do meane no more but this. The fleſh of man is no more but corruption & death. All things ar fading, brittle & frayle. As ye gras (flouriſh it neuer ſo pleaſauntly) the beuty therof immediately withereth & periſheth: ſo what ſoeuer flouriſheth in man, whether it be in age or in beuty, in riches or anye ſuche like, in ſhort time it waxeth old, it falleth away, and periſheth.

The Prophet Eſaie with this ſentence cōforteth ye Iewes being captiue in Babilon, cōparing Babilon, the kingdome therof, the riches & the felicitie, vnto graſſe floriſhing and freſhe: whoſe flower and beauty ſtreight way falleth awaye. And he willeth the Iewes to vnderſtand and that the councell and decree of the Lorde, which promiſed them deliueraunce & returne into Hieruſalem, is eternall and immutable: But Babilon to fal away as the graſſe, & the flower of the graſſe, is an elegant and goodly preſident and ſpectacle of the miſerie and frailtie of man.

Here is to be noted that fleſhe profiteth nothing, when we neede to be borne againe. By the name of fleſh I vnderſtand all the glory therof, as riches, pleaſures, wiſedome, and what ſoeuer ſeemeth excellent and noble in mortall thynges. It followeth.

Verbum autem domini manet in aeternum: But the worde of the Lorde endureth for euer. The fleſhe paſſeth away, the fleſh with al her impurity corrupteth, and is corrupted: but the word of God remaineth for euer. That is to ſay, all theſe thinges which we haue ſpoken of in this whole chapter, as faith, pacience and holynes, are according to the word of God: they ſhal remain for euer.Math. 24. For as Chriſt ſaith in Mathew: Caelum et terra tranſibunt, verba autem mea non tranſibunt, heauen and earth ſhal paſſe away, but my wordes ſhal not paſſe. Now Peter concludeth, ſaying: Hoc eſt autem verbum quod euangelizatum et vobis. It is the woorde that hath bene preached vnto you. As though he ſhould ſay, you nede not loke farre of to come to this word, ye haue it before your eyes, this is ye word which we prech vnto you. By thys worde ye may extinguiſhe and reſtrayne all euill deſires, you nede not to goe farre for it, do you onely this, embrace it when it is preached vnto you. For it is ſo nigh vnto you that you may heare it: as Moſes ſayth in Deuteronomie: Verbum quod tibi praecipio, non longe eſt a te, &c. The commaundement which I commaunde thee this day, is not farre of. It is not in heauen,Cap. 30. that thou ſhouldeſt ſay, who ſhall go vp for vs into heauen, & bring it vs, & cauſe vs to heare it, that we may do it? Neither is it beyond the ſea, that thou ſhouldeſt ſay, who ſhal go ouer ye ſea for vs & bring it vs, and cauſe vs to heare it, that we may do it? But the word is very nere vnto thee, euen in thy mouth, and in thine hart for to do it.

The worde is ſoone preached and heard, but when it ſhall occupie & enter into thine hart, it cannot againe die & peryſh, nor wil ſuffer thee to die, but wil preſerue thee as long as thou dooſt ſticke and cleaue vnto it. As for example: when I heare that Ieſus Chriſt died, bare my ſinnes, and deſerued heauen for me, & alſo hath geuen me what goodnes ſo euer he him ſelfe hath: when this (I ſay) is preached, than I heare the Goſpell, than I heare the worde. This woorde when it is preached, the ſounde therof paſſeth away. But if thou receaue it in thine hart, and embrace it by fayth, it can not fall away. No creature is able to ſuppreſſe this truth. The pitte of hell can preuaile nothing againſt it: yea if I ſhould ſticke in the very iawes of the
deuill, yet if I could apprehend and take holde of this word by fayth, I muſt nedes be deliuered and remaine ſafe where thys word doth abide. Therfore Peter ſayth not without cauſe, there is none other word to be looked for, beſide that which we haue preached vnto you. To this maketh ye which Paul writeth to the Romaines: non pudet me euangelij, virtus enim dei eſt in ſalutem omni credenti. I am not aſhamed of the Goſpell, for it is the power of God to ſaue all that do beleue.

This word is ye diuine & eternall power. For although the ſound, voyce & talke therof forthwith vaniſheth away, yet ye pith, the truth, the knowledge which is cō teyned in the voyce, abideth. As for example: Whē thou putteſt to thy mouth ye cup in ye which wine is conteyned, thou drinkeſt yt wine, but ye cup remaineth: ſo ye word which is brought by ye voyce, deſcendeth into the hart, (the voice vaniſhing away:) therfore ye word is rightly called diuina virtus, the power of God, yea God himſelf: for ſo God ſpake to Moſes in Exodus.Exod. 4. Iohn. 14. Ego ero in ore tuo. I will be in thy mouth.

Chriſt ſayth in Iohn. Ego ſum via, veritas et vita. I am the way, truth and lyfe. He that cleaueth vnto this word, is borne of God. Therfore that ſede by the which we are borne agayne, is our Lord God himſelf, and hys worde.
This is ye tenor & ſumme of ye whole firſt chapter. Now I do think it expedient to geue you an Epilogus or ſhort recapitulation,35. Epilogius. of all that Peter hath ſpoken in this chapter.

Peter hath ſpoken here of fayth, pacience, of ſanctimonie and holynes, of purenes, & regeneration. The ſumme of all theſe is ye word, that is, Chriſt preached vnto you. He is ye ſumme of ye whole Goſpell preached for your ſaluation. That is to ſay. God being moued by his great goodnes & free liberalitie did appoint his ſōne before the beginning of the world to be a ſacrifice for the ſinnes of ye whole world.

After this Peter doth ſhew how God reuealed this grace vnto the Prophets, ſignifying when theſe thinges ſhould be, that is, when Chriſt ſhoulde come, what he ſhould ſuffer, and how he ſhould be gloryfied.

This done, Peter doth ſhew how Chriſt waſhed vs with his bloud, & gaue hys ſpirit to incite & ſtirre vs to embrace theſe myſteries, that is, yt we ſhould be ſpirituallie borne agayne, & that ſhe ſhould be conſtant in aduerſitie by fayth & hope: that we ſhould obey ye Goſpel, & loue one another brotherly without feining: and finallie ye we ſhould liue euerlaſtingly with ye word, by ye which we are born again to be ye childrē of God. And thus haue you heard ye minde of Peter in this firſt chapter.

I intended (if it had pleaſed God to ſuffer me to remaine in this office & place) to haue entred at my next cōming into ye diſcourſing of the ſecond chapter, & ſo orderly to haue gone through the whole epiſtle. But it hath pleaſed ye Quéenes Maieſtie to cal me to another office & prouince, which to ſuſtein & beare I muſt nedes confeſſe my ſelf to be amōg al other moſt vnapte, vnmete & moſt weake. Notwithſtāding I muſt (as gods law doth require of me) ſhew my loyaltie & obedience vnto my prince. Wyſhing (if it had ſo pleaſed God & her highnes) that I might haue ſtill remained in this godly exerciſe. But I truſt ye another much more able, more worthy, & better learned, ſhal be appoynted to ſerue ye turne in this place. And thus deſiring you all to pray for me, as I may & will pray for you, yt God may geue me his grace ſo to vſe my ſelf in ye office, to ye which I am called, yt Gods glory may be aduaunced, & the chriſtian congregation edified, to the extirpation of al Idolatry, ſuperſticiō & hipocriſie: I cōmend you to ye tuition of almightie God, who through ye merites of his ſonne Ieſus Chriſt, with the ſanctification of his holy ſpirit, preſerue & kepe you both now, and for euer. To God the Father, to God the Sonne, to God the holy Ghoſt, three perſons in trinitie, and one God in vnitie, be all glorye, honour and prayſe, for euer and euer. Amen.

div.head: Hic ſequuntur Miſcellanea praelectionis quintae, Tomi ſecundi.
Loynes 1.
div.p: LOynes are called in latine Lumbi. They are (as they which be expert in Anatomie do ſay) the lower part of the backebone conſiſting in fiue ioyntes which are called vertebrae. Now vertebra, is a place or ioynte in ye body, where the bones do not meete, but are knit together in ſuch wiſe with ſinewes, that they turn the more lightly. The loynes ar ſet in the middle, betwene, os ſacrum, that is, the place where the excrementes do iſſue, and the vertebras of the backe. Lumbi do ſignifie ſometimes the pleaſure and luſte of the fleſh, for that effecte is ſet in the Loynes. As in Geneſis. Reges de lumbis tuis egredientur. Kings ſhall come out of thy Loynes.Cap. 35. So that in ye loynes there is the ſimbole of generation.
Lumbus is called in Greeke 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . It is properly as they ſay, the lower middle part of the reines in man.
Baptiſta Egnatius doth ſay, that it is that part wher men are girt, or wher the girdle ſitteth.

Lumbi are called in Hebrue Motnaim a nowne of the dual number becauſe there be in man two loines. God ſpake to Moſes ſaying: Fac tibi ſubligacula linea vt operiat carnem nuditatis, a lumbis vſque ad femora. Exod. 28 Thou ſhalt make them linnen breches to couer their priuities, which frō the loynes vnto the thighes ſhal reach.

Lumbi ſomtime ſignifie ſtrength and power. Looke in Heſichius,Lib. 1. Cap. 5. writing vpon Leuiticus. And it is vſed in the prophet: Naum corrobora lumbos make thy loynes ſtrong, encreaſe thy ſtrength mightely. And ſo it is vſed in many places of the ſcripture.
Lumbis ſuccingi, to haue the loynes girded, ſignifieth to be ready & luſty to do any thing.

Lumbos nutare, ſignifieth, to be depreſſed with falſe doctrines and opinions, to walke in the vanitye of their ſenſe, as Dauid ſaith in the pſalmes: Lumbos eorum iugiterfac nutare: make theyr loines alwaies to tremble: that is, take both iudgemente and power from them.

Lumbis impingere, is a ſigne and token of ſorow & grief, that is, comming vpon one more & more. So it is vſed in ye prophet Ieremy: Vidi omnem virum habentem manum ſuam ſuper lumbos tanquam parturiens. Cap. 30. I beheld euery man with his handes on his loines, as a woman in trauail, that is to be in great heauines, griefe and ſorrow.

Likewiſe in the pſalm: poſuiſti ſtridorem in lumbis noſtris. Thou haſt
laid a ſtrait chain vpon our loines. By this is ment, that the church is led ſomtimes by Gods prouidence into troubles.

Of lumbus commeth elumbus, or elumbis, which betokeneth weake and out of power. For the chiefeſt part of the ſtrēgth is ſet in the loines, as the which alone with the helpe of another bone, doth ſuſtaine & hold vp the ioyning of the body.

Delumbis is taken ſometimes for effeminate and wanton, and ſo delumbe carmen, is taken for a laſciuious & wanton verſe or ſong. Alſo ye verbe delumbare ſignifieth to debilitate or make weake. And by a metaphor delumbare ſententias vel argumenta, is to ſpoil ſentences & arguments of their pith and ſtrength, that is, to make them nothing worth.

div.head: Queſtio.
div.p: IF a virgin be corrupt & oppreſſed by violence againſt her wil, & ſo leſe her chaſtity, doth ſhe remain ſtil a virgin, or no?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p:
The diuines do diuide ſinne into two ſpices or kindes, that is: In peccatum
Voluntarium.
Inuoluntarium.
Becauſe ſin voluntary is impertinent to this caſe, I wil ſpeake only of inuoluntary or violent, as they cal it.
Of violēt ſinne ther be. 2. ſpices, the one abſolute, & ye other cōdicional

Sinne violent abſolute is, when it lieth not in vs to do or not to do, but cōmeth externly, we nothing conſenting nor helping to the ſame. As for example: if a violent winde ſhould driue vs thither whither we wold not go: or if the miniſters of any Heathen Magiſtrate ſhould by force moue our handes to the incenſing of idols: than we being thus coacted, are deliuered from all fault and paine.

Sinne violent condicional is, when he yt is conſtrained, either conſenteth to it, or not cōſenteth. If he do conſent: as for example, if he deny the verity of the goſpel, which hitherto he hath cōfeſſed & profeſſed, he (although he be constrained through feare) is not void from ſinne. For he is not excuſed by the terror of death, nor by the fear of tormēts. He ought rather to die, thē to deny the truth. If he choſe rather to die, thē to do or cōſent to ſuch horrible things, thē the tirant cānot conſtrain him againſt his wil. He may wel kil him, but he cānot make him ſubiect to ſin, either volūtary or inuolūtary. For by death he confeſſeth the truth, by death he declareth, yt he wil not do yt which they require of him being a liue to do.

Antiochus Epiphanes attempted to pollute the holy bodies of the Machabees, by the eating of meate forbidden by the law: but he chuſing rather to die, than to be prophaned, by death ouercame the Tirant.

But if ther be no cōſent to inuolūtary ſin, but mere violence is inferred
to any godly man, yt violence doth not pollute an holy & incorrupt mind. As for exāple: if any godly mā hauing his hands & fete bound, be caried & brought into a prophane church, wher he is cōſtrained (wil he nil he) to be preſent at wicked ſacrifices, he is not ſubiect to ſin. Or if any holy virgin, or honeſt matrone, in the time of wars be corrupt, & conſenteth not to ye wickednes, ſhe doth certainly remaine vncorrupt before ye iudgement of God. S. Auſtine ſaid not without great cauſe: Nō iniuſte aliquid pati, ſed iniuſtè aliquid facere peccatum eſt. Not to ſuffer ani thing wrōgfully,De lib. arbit. lib. 3. c. 16. De mēdatio ad conſentiū Cap. 7. but to do any thing vniuſtly is ſin. Again, ye ſaid Austen in an other place writeth: Quod violenter, nō praecedente libidine, patitur corpus, vexatio potius quā corruptio nominanda eſt. Aut ſi omnis vexatio corruptio eſt, nō omnis corruptio turpis eſt, ſed quam libido procurauit, aut cui libido conſenſerit. That is to ſay: that which the body ſuffreth violently, no pleaſure nor luſt going before, is to he named rather a vexatiō thē corruption. Or if euery vexation be corruptiō: yet not all corruptiō is filthy, but yt which pleſure hath procured, or to which luſt hath cōſēted

Alſo the ſame Auſtine in an other place ſaith:De ciuit. dei. Lib. 1. Ca. 18. Propoſito animi permanente, per quod etiam corpus ſanctificari meruit, nec ipſi corpori, aufert ſāctitatē violētiā libidinis alienae, quā ſeruat perſeuerātia cōtinentiae ſuae The purpoſe of the mind remaining firm & ſtedfaſt, by which the body hath deſerued to be ſanctified, the violence of an other mās luſt & pleaſure, taketh not away the holines from yt body, which the purpoſe & perſeuerance of his own continency doth preſerue & kepe. Saint Auſtine diſputeth much of ſuch like things in that place.
In like maner we ought gently & with clemency to iudge of the inuoluntary death of furious and mad men, killing them ſelues.

div.head: Sobrietie. 3.
div.p: HE whō we cal in latin ſobrium, we cal in Greke 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which cō meth of ye verbe 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which ſignifieth to be of a ſoūd minde, to be wiſe & ware, to be chast, modeſt, & temperat, to behaue one gently, and liue holy. Euripides ſaith: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , id eſt, erga te ſum modeſtus: that is, towards thee I am gentle and curteous.

Sobriety is defined (as ſome ſay) quaſi ſine ebrietate, without dronkennes, which is a ſin to be abhorred in all perſons. The prophet Eſay ſaith: ve qui cōſurgitis mane ad ebrietatē ſectandā, et potandū vſ
que ad veſperā. Cap. 5. Vvo be vnto you which riſe early in the morning and geue your ſelues to dronkennes vnto the euening.

This vice is deſcribed of S. Auſtine after this maner. Ebrietas eſt blā dus demon, dulce venenum, ſuaue peccatum, quam qui habet, ſeipſum non babet: quam qui facit, peccatū non facit, ſed totus eſt peccatū. that is. dronkēnes is a flattring deuil, ſwete poyſō, & a pleaſāt ſin, which whoſoeuer
hath, hath not himſelfe, which whoſoeuer doth, doth not commit ſinne, but is wholy ſinne him felfe.

This vice did ouercome thoſe men which coulde not otherwiſe be allured with more hainous ſinnes (as ſaint Auguſtin writeth in Geneſis.Lib. 5.) Ebrietas (inquit) decipit, quem Sodoma non decepit: vritur ille flammis mulierum, quem ſulphuria flamma non vrebat. Dronkēnes deceued him, whō Sodoma could not deciue: he was burned with the burning cōcupiſcance of wemen, whom the flames of brimſtone could not burne.
Noe through the dronkennes of one houre, vncouered his priuities which he had kept cloſe before, by the ſpace of. 600. yeares.

Lib. tertio. Floridorum.Apuleus rehearceth a notable ſaying of one Aurelius a wiſe man, ſitting at the table: Prima cratera ad ſitim pertinet, ſecunda ad amicitiā, tertia ad voluptatem, quarta ad inſaniam. The firſt cuppe quencheth the thirſt, the ſecond pertaineth to frendſhip, ye third to pleaſure, the fourth gendreth madnes: and (as Menander writeth) Multum merum pauca cogit ſapere Much wine maketh litle wiſdome.

Aſtiages, when he demaunded of king Cyrus why he had not dronke vp the wine: becauſe I feared (quoth he by my faith) leaſt ſome poyſon were mixt in the cup. For when thou in the feaſt of thy birth day, haddeſt thy frend to thee, I euidentlye learned, that he poured poyſon vpon you. And by what meanes (ſaith he) O my ſonne, kneweſt thou this? Bicauſe (quod he) I did ſee you neither wel aduiſed in body, nor in minde.
Saint Ambroſe doth ſay: Ebrietatis malum eſt pudicitiae periculum, that is: the diſorder of dronkennes bringeth chaſtity into peril.

div.head: Idlenes. 4.
div.p: IDlenes is called in latine otium, or as ſome write ocium it is a ceaſing and vacation from al labour. His contrary is negotium, buſines.

Otium ſomtime is taken for an eaſy exerciſe of the minde, or of the body, a relaxatiō from waighty affaires & matters of great importāce. Vvherupon we cal otium litterarū, for the ſtudy of learning, becauſe that kinde of exerciſe, is counted a delectation, rather than any ſerious occupation, (as Cicero ſaith) Quid dulcius otio literario: what is pleaſaunter then the ſtudy of learning?

Otium ſomtime is taken for quietnes,Cap, 28. tranquility and peace, as Tully vſeth it in his familiar epiſtles: ſi antea auditum erit otium eſſe in Syria. If it be heard before that ther is peace in Syria. Theſe two laſt ſignifications ar impertinent to my matter: therfore I wil ſpeake ſom what of the firſt, which is properly called idlenes, & is the daughter of ſlouth.
The ſonne of Syrach ſaith: Multam malitiam docuit otioſitas idlenes hath taught much miſchief. Dauid being idle committed adultery.

Behold (ſaith Ezechiel.) this was the iniquitie of thy ſiſter Sodome,Cap. 16. pride, fulnes of bread, and aboundaunce of idlenes was in her: and in her daughters, neither did ſhe ſtrengthen the hande of the poore and nedie.1. Timot. 5.

Saint Paule ſpeaketh of certaine widowes which being idle, went about from houſe to houſe. Chriſt imbraided the idle perſons, ſayinge:Math. 20. Quid ſtatis hic tota die otioſi: why ſtande you here idle all the daye?

Sainct Auguſtin ſayeth. Quod in otio non debet eſſe iners vacatio, De ciuit. dei. Lib. 19. ſed aut inquiſitio veritatis aut inuentio. In idlenes ſluggiſhe reſte ought to be abſente. And when a man is at reſt, ther oughte to be eyther inquiſition of the truth, or inuention of the ſame. And (as ſainct Hierome ſaith) non ſufficit a malis eſſe otioſū, ſi quis fuerit a bonis otioſus. Epiſt. 17. It is not inough for a man to reſte and ceaſe from iuell things, if a man be idle from good things.

div.head: Bernard. 5.
div.p: BErnard was an abbot of Clarenalla, he was a Burgondian borne & floriſhed in the time of Fridericꝰ Barbaroſſa. He entred into the monaſterie about the yere of our Lorde. 1112. He was Abbot in the ſame place by the ſpace of. 36. yeres, and died the yere of our Lorde 1163. He entred into the ſaid monaſterie when he was twentie and two yeres olde. He lefte behinde him many goodly bookes whiche are noble monumentes of his worckes. His life is deſcribed in fiue bookes which were wonte to be ſet in the ende of all his worckes.

Fulgoſus writeth of ſaint Bernard a worthy hiſtorie. Vvhen there was ſente vnto Bernarde two hundred pounds of mony, towards the building and repayring of the monaſterie, the ſaid mony was taken awaye by robbers and theues, which when Bernard heard, he gaue God thākes that he had deliuered him of ſo great a burthen.

There is a prouerbe riſen of Bernard which is this. Bernardus non vidit omnia. Bernarde ſaw not all things, by the which is ſignified that a man be he neuer ſo wel learned, may be ignoraunt in ſome things. And that a man be he neuer ſo expert and cūning, may faile in ſome matters. To this is the like ſaying. Non nunquam bonus dormitat Homerus, ſomtimes the beſt horſe may ſtomble.

div.head: Baptiſme. 6.
div.p: BEcauſe I intende to make a longe diſcourſe of Baptiſme, and all the circumſtances therof in mine apologie and anſwere to certaine billes which were throwen againſt me: I will in this place touche onely one ſentence of Paule, written to the Corinthians.

The ſentence is this Alioquin quid facient ii qui baptiſantur pro mortuis? ſi omnino mortui non reſurgunt, cur baptiſantur pro mortuis?
Els what ſhall they do, which ar baptiſed for ye dead? If the dead riſe not at all, why are they then baptiſed for the dead?

There be diuerſe and ſondrie interpretations howe any are baptiſed for the dead. Chriſoſtome ſayth, that the Marcionites did accuſtome, when any of their cathecumines died without baptiſme, to put one vnder the bed, and when they came to the dead corps, they aſked whether he would be baptiſed. Then he whiche laye vnder anſwered that he deſired baptiſme. And ſo the dead corps was baptiſed. Vvhen the Marcionites for this matter were reprehended, they defended them ſelues by this place of Paule.

This maner of doing and worke was truely very ſuperſtitiouſe and rather to be counted a ſtage playe then a chriſtian rite. Nor the Apoſtle Paule doth make his argument as though he woulde ratifie and allowe this doing, but doth ſhew only that theſe mē (although they wer not very well inſtructed of baptiſme) did feare the ſtate of the dead. And in his name did geue the ſacrament vnto an other, that the dead perſone ſhuld not be made fruſtrat of the reſurrection. And ſo by this their owne facte Paule vrgeth them to graunte the reſurrection of the dead.

Sainct Ambroſe, willing to declare that the faith of other men maye ſomtime be praiſed, and not their fact to be proued, bringeth the exāple of Iephte. Vvho although he did not well in ſlaying and ſacrificyng his daughter, yet his fayth and conſtancie is praiſed in the epiſtle to the Hebrues. But this ſayinge of Ambroſe is not to be embraced nor allowed. For, we ought not to do ill, that good may come therof: nor euill deedes oght to be excuſed by any good intēt, as they cal it, nor euils ar to be praiſed, although they may ſeme to be don by a ſincere faith & a good minde. Iephte in dede is praiſed in the epiſtle to the Hebrues, but it is not ther expreſsed, that he was cōmended for ſlaying & ſacrificing his daughter. For, ther wer many things faithfully and luckely done of him in the cō mon wealth of the Iſraelits. Ther be other men, whom this interpretation pleaſeth not, neither they do thinke that this rite, which the Marcionits afterward vſed, was obſerued of the Corinthians in Pauls time. For the Apoſtle would not haue refrained to haue taxed and touched ſo great an abuſe of ſo worthy a Sacrament. But how ſo euer it be, this fond opinion, to be baptiſed for ye dead, hath old and auncient authors & defenders of the ſame. For Tertullian when he intreated of the reſurrection of the bodie, made mention of this ſurrogat baptiſme, and doth ſo interprete this place, that he would deduce his argument out of this maner of baptiſing. Yet he doth not affirme that Paule doth allow this rite, maner, and ordinance.

Sainct Ambroſe and Chriſoſtome do conſent vnto Tertullian. Notwithſtāding,
Chriſoſtome confeſseth, (which is worthy to be noted) that it is an hereſie & ſuperſtition that one ſhould receiue the Sacramentes for an other. But yet, euen at this daye it is allowed and taught in the popiſhe church, that they which be preſent at maſſe, neede not to communicate, becauſe the prieſt doth receiue the ſacrament for all.

It is read in the life of S Benedict out of one of the dialoges of Gregorie, that Benedict commaunded the communion to be geuen to a certaine Nunne which was dead, ſo that the cōſecrate bread was brought vnto the dead corps. And although many of the ſcholemen do ſaye, that this bread or hoſt was not conſecrate, they haue not that out of the wordes of ſainct Gregorie.

The Iewes (as it is reported) do laboure with the like madneſſe, which do circumciſe the bodies of their children being dead, if they dye before the eight daye without circumciſion, as thoughe the Sacramentes were magicall excantations, which do profitte (as they ſay) onely opere operato.

But that one maye communicate or receiue the ſacrament for an other, it is contrarie to the propertie of thoſe myſteries.
