For the holye ſcripture calleth them, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , conſignations and ſeales of fayth and the giftes of God, whiche onely haue place there, where either faith is, or where the giftes of God are collated and geuen. It is not conuenient, that the miſteries be in one parte, and the ſeale ſet in an other parte. Let this bee a ſimilitude, or example: Be it that a kynges or Prince doth graunte greate priuileges and large giftes to anye man by letters patentes: I praye you, where ſhal the ſeale be ſet? In the paper or parchment where the grauntes are written, or els in an other peece of parchment or paper? Truely, it ought to be put to the ſame. In like maner muſt we iudge, that he whiche beleueth, which is regenerate and incorporat vnto Chriſt, ought to receiue the conſignations and ſeales of thoſe giftes by himſelfe, and not by his vicar or ſurrogate.
The ſecond maner of interpretation of this place of Paule is this: it chaunced oftentimes in the primatiue church, that they which laye at the point of death and were not baptiſed, deſired baptiſme.

Saint Ciprian maketh mention of this maner and rite. He was conſulted, whether they which were in the extremes of death (when they could not well be thorougly baptiſed or dipped, but were onely ſprinkled with water) were to be counted to be of the nomber of them that were baptiſed? He anſwereth, that they were baptiſed: and doth perſuade & counſell the grace of baptiſme not to be denied vnto them. And in this ſenſe the interpretation of Pauls words is this: Vvhat do they which ar baptiſed for the dead? that is, which when the laſt houre commeth are
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
rather to be counted to be of the nomber of the dead, then of the liuing.

Sainte Auſtine in the booke of his Confeſsions maketh mention of the geuing of baptiſme after this maner: where it is written that a certain frind of his was chriſtened in ſuch extremitie of life, that when he was waſhed, he felte nothing, but when he was ſomwhat recouered, they declared vnto him what was don about him.

Saint Auſtin himſelfe being ſomtime greued with great ſickneſſe deſired to be baptiſed. Nor he leaueth vntouched the abuſe of his time, in the which many of a ſet purpoſe did deferre their baptiſme, leaſte if they ſhould ſinne after they had receiued it, theyr ſins ſhould haue ben more greuouſe, and puniſhed with greater and ſharper paines. Therfore when any of the Catechumines did offend, if any man had rebuked him, it was ſaid for his excuſe: let him alone, he is not yet baptiſed. Vvhich thing ſainct Auſtin refelleth after this maner: There is as much (ſaith he) as if any man ſhould be greuouſly wounded, and ſhould perchaunce receiue an other wound, and they that ſawe this ſhould ſay: It maketh no matter, or it ſkilleth not, for he is not yet healed of his olde wound.

The third interpretation of theſe wordes of Paul is that, which doth affirme Paule to ſpeake here of true and lawfull baptiſme, and not of the ſuperſtitious baptiſing. Vve are all baptiſed for the dead, when we conf • ſse this article, that Chriſt roſe from the dead, and that the reſurrection of the dead is to be beleued and looked for. For if this article be ouerthrowen, all the miſteries of our faith do periſh, and are nothinge worth. Therfore, expreſse mentiō of this article is required in baptiſme. In the church of Aquilege, when the profeſſion of the faith was made, and the ſymbole rehearſed, and when they came to this clauſe of the reſurrection of the fleſh, it was expreſly ſaid and openly ſpoken: I beleue the reſurrection of this fleſh. Furthermore, the auncient fathers ordeined, that ſolemne baptiſme ſhould be celebrat and had in the time of Eaſter. Alſo, the words of Paule to the Romains do manifeſtly ſhew, that this ſacrament of Baptiſme reſpecteth the reſurrection of the dead, when it is ſayde: do you not know, that as many as be baptiſed in Chriſt Ieſu, are baptiſed to die with him? that as he roſe from death by the glory of the father: ſo we might likewiſe walke in newneſse of life? &c.

Furthermore, the adminiſtration of the Symbole and outward ſigne, declareth the ſame. For they which are baptiſed, are dipped in water, and riſe from thence again, that death and reſurrection from the dead might by it be declared.

Theophilacte vnderſtandeth, to be baptiſed for the dead, to be nothing els, but to be baptiſed in this faith and belief, that our corrupt
fleſhe, bodies and bones to be raiſed again from the dead.

Martinus Lutherus, doth iudge, that baptiſme in many places was ſolēniſed and geuen in the Churchyards at the ſepulchres & graues of the dead, that the article of reſurrection from death ſhould be confeſſed and confirmed, not only by the profeſsion of faith, by the ceremonie of baptiſme, by externe wordes, but alſo by the teſtimonie of the place where the dead laye.

div.head: Righte hande. 7.
div.p: THe right hande of god the father hath in the ſcripture two ſignifications. Firſt, the right hand of God is the place of the bleſſed, and eternall felicitie in heauen, as ſaint Auſtin writeth in his booke de agone Chriſtiano. Cap. 26 Dextera patris eſt beatitudo perpetua quae ſanctis datur: ſicut ſiniſtra rectiſsimè dicitur miſeria perpetua quae impiis datur, &c. The right hand of the father is perpetuall bleſsednes, whiche is geuen to ſainctes: as the lefte hand is rightly called the perpetuall miſerie, which is geuen to the wicked, ſo that the right and left hand is to be vnderſtande not in God himſelfe, but in the creatures.

Saint Auſtin ſpake this according to the ſcriptures. For Dauid ſingeth: Notam mihi facies ſemitam vitae, ſatietas gaudiorum in conſpectu tuo eſt, & iucunditates in dextera tua in perpetuū: Thou ſhalt make knowen to me the path of life, aboundance of ioye is in thy ſight, and great mirth at thy right hande for euer. Vvhat other thing is this, then if the ſhould haue ſaid? thou ſhalt leade me into life, that is, into heauen it ſelfe, wher I ſhalbe filled with ioyes in beholdyng and hauyng the fruition of thee. In thy right hand, that is, in eternall bleſſednes, or in ioyes perpetuall.

Vve reade in the goſpell, that the ſhepe ſhalbe ſet on the right hand, and the goates on the left hande. Therfore, the right hand of the father in this ſignification is (as the diuines terme it) finita. And when we confeſse the ſonne to ſyt at the right hand of the father, we do confeſse that he is deliuered from all grief, all ſufferings, and from the infirmitie of man, and that touching his humaine nature, is at reſte, and at mirth in heauen, where we beleue our ſoules and bodies to bee and to liue for euer. But becauſe our bodies in bleſſedneſse ſhall not be in euery place, but in one certaine place: therfore ſainct Auſtin ſayd Chriſt our Lord, for the maner of a true bodie, to be in one certaine place of heauen.
Sainct Ciprian alſo ſayth: ſedere ad dexteram patris carnis aſſumptae myſterium eſt. To ſyt at the right hande of the father, is a myſterie of the fleſhe taken vp.

Secondly, the right hand of God is taken for vertue, power, kyngdome,
protection, and the might of God. Dauid ſaid, the right hande of God is high and mightye, the right hand of the Lorde maketh ſtronge things. And Moſes ſayth. Dextara tua, Domine, magnificata eſt in virtute, dextera tua, domine, fregit inimicum: Thy right hand, O Lord, is mightie in power, thy right hand, O Lorde, hath vanquiſhed the enemye.

In this ſignification, to ſit at the right hande of the father, is to raigne, to exerciſe might and power, to execute the office of a Prince or King. For Dauid ſaid: The lord ſayd to my Lord, ſit at my right hand vntill I make thine enemies the foote ſtoole. In this ſenſe the right hand of God is (as the diuines ſaye) infinita, and is concluded in no place.
The olde interpreters of the holy ſcripture do diſcourſe this article, he ſitteth at the right hande of the father, none otherwiſe then is ſayd before.

Saint Hierome vpon the Epheſians writeth: Per humanam ſimilitudinem dei potentiam monſtrauit, non quò ſolium ponatur, & Deus pater in eo ſedeat, ſecum
que filium habeat reſidentem &c. He ſhewed by a humaine ſimilitude the power of God, not that there is a ſeate put in the which God the father ſitteth and hath his ſonne ſitting by him, but that we can not otherwiſe vnderſtand God, iudging and raigning, but by our owne wordes. Therfore, as to be nighe vnto God, or to be far from God, is not to be vnderſtande concernyng the ſpace of places, but concernyng merites, becauſe ſainctes be by hym, and ſinners remoued far from him: ſo to be at the right or left hande of God, is to be taken, that the ſainctes are on the right hand, and the ſinners on the left. Our ſauiour approueth the ſame in the goſpell, wher he maketh mention of the ſhepe at the right hand, and the goates at the lefte hand.

Saint Auſtine ſayth. Credimus quod ſedet ad dexteram dei patris: nec ideo tamen quaſi humana forma circumſcriptum eſſe Deum patrem arbitrandum eſt, &c. VVe beleue that he ſitteth at the right hand of God the father: Yet we muſt not iudge or ſuppoſe God the father to be circumſcribed with the ſhape of man, that when we thinke of him, we conceiue in our mind either a right hand or a left: nor we ought to thincke, that when he is ſaid to ſit, that to be done by the bowing of hammes, leſt we fall into that ſacrilege, wherewith the Apoſtle curſeth thoſe, which chaunge the glory of the incorruptible god, to the ſimilitude of a corruptible man. For it is an hainous wickednes to place ſuche an image in a chriſtian church. It is much more wicked to place ſuch an image in the harte where the true temple of god is, if at the leaſte it be cleane from earthly luſt and errour.

To ſit therfore at the right hande of the father, is to be vnderſtand
to be in hie bleſſednes, where righteouſnes, peace and ioye is, &c.

div.head: Golias. 8.
div.p: GOlias was a puiſſant kyng of the Philiſtians, whome Dauid beinge yet a childe ſlewe, whan the Iewes were afraid to fighte with him man for man. His ſtature was, as the Bible rehearſeth, ſixe cubites and a ſpanne, whiche was tenne feete lackyng three inches, accomptyng it with the feete of men liuing at that time, whiche vndoubtedly were more then they be now. His habergeon weighed 5000. ſicles, which is two thouſand and fiue hundred ounces, and the yron of his ſpeare weighed ſixe hundred ſicles, whiche is 300. ounces, wherby his greatnes and ſtrength maye be coniectured to excede anye man liuyng in this time.

div.head: Adoption. 9.
div.p: ADoptio was done two maner of wayes. It was done one way be the Pretour or chief iudge. An other way, it was done by the people or Tribune, thas is the chiefe officer among the communes, which adoption is called rather arrogatio then adoptio. But Caius doth make an other diſtinction betwene adoption and arrogation. So that adoptio, is, when he that is not his own man, nor in full libertie, doth paſse into an other mans familie, and is counted his ſonne. Arrogatio, is, by the authoritie of the prince, who doth adopte thoſe whiche be their own men, and in full libertie. For they were arrogate, that is, demaunded whether they would be in the ſteede of lawfull children to him that did adopte them. In like maner he which did adopte, was demaunded whether he woulde receyue him that was arrogate in the ſteede of his lawfull ſon. But in the ſcriptures we be ye children of God, not by arrogation, but by adoption.

To ſpeake plaine, Adoptio is an election of an heire, out of the courſe of inheritaunce, as by will or gifte. Alſo adoptio, is ſomtime taken for graffing. It may be applied to thinges inanimate or without life, as Plinius ſaith: Adoptare herbam, that is, to call an herbe after a mans propre name. So Lyſimachus inuented the herbe Lyſimachiam whiche holdeth the name of him. VVemē alſo did affecte this glorie, as Artemiſia the wife of Manſolus adopted an herbe to her owne name, whiche herbe was called before Parth • nis: whyche Arthemiſia, was a noble princeſſe, wife to Manſolus King of Caria, of a notable chaſtitie, and excelled ſo in loue towards her huſbande, that whan he was dead, ſhe cauſed his harte to be dried in a veſsell of golde into poulder, and by litle and litle ſhe drancke it vp, ſayinge: their two hartes ſhoulde neuer departe a ſunder.

div.head: Ignorantia. 10.
div.p: IGnorantia in greeke is called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . And ſignifieth ſomtimes lacke of knowledge. Somtimes it is contrarie vnto knowledge, as when a man hath habitum falſorum principiorum, & falſarum opinionum, through the which he is let and hindered from the knowledge of the truth.

A great queſtion is wonte to be toſsed among the diuines pro & contra, whether ignoraunce doth excuſe men or no. Some hold yea, and bring for their purpoſe this ſaying of ſainct Paule. Firſt I was a blaſphemer, a perſecutour and railer.Tim. 1. epiſt. Cap. 1. But I obteined mercie, becauſe I did it ignorauntly. To the which maye be anſwered there be two kindes of ignoraunces, that is.

p.hi: Or as the ſcholemen do terme them.

div.p: Naturall ignoraunce is of it ſelfe offence and ſinnne, becauſe it commeth of a beginning infected with poyſon,Lib. 3. de libe. arbitrio. ca. 19 that is of the originall ſinne.

Saincte Auſten ſayth. Quod ignorans quiſque non recte facit, & quod recte volens facere non poteſt: ideo dicuntur peccata, quia de peccato illo libere voluntatis originem ducunt. Illud enim praecedens maeruit illa ſequentia. Nam ſicut linguam dicimus non ſolum membrum, quod mouemus in ore dum loquimur, ſed etiam illud quod huius membri motum ſequitur, id eſt, formam & tenorem verborum, & ſecundum hunc morem (dicitur lingua, alia graeca, alia latina) Sic non ſolum peccatum illud dicimus, quod proprie vocatur peccatum (libera enim voluntate a ſciente committitur) ſed etiam illud quod de huius ſupplicio conſequitur, that is. That thing which a man being ignoraunt doth not well, and that thynge which a man willingly can not do well, are therfore called ſinnes, becauſe they proceede of the ſinne of free will, the which goinge before deſerued theſe thinges followynge▪ For as the tongue is not onely called that membre whiche will moue in the mouth when we ſpeake, but alſo that thynge whiche followeth the mouinge of this membre, that is, the forme and maner of wordes and ſpeaking (wherupon one is called the Latine tongue, an other the greeke tongue.) So we call that not onely ſinne, whiche is properly called ſinne (whiche is committed willinglye by free will), but alſo that which followeth of the puniſhment of the other.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p:
Chriſt doth ſaye in Iohn. Si non veniſſem & locutus fuiſſem eis, peccatum
non haberent. If I had not comme and ſpoken to them, they had had no ſinne. Ergo they to whome nothing is ſhewed and declared, are free from all ſinne and blame.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Chriſt in that place doth not ſpeake of their innocencie and giltleſnes, but of their pretence. But euery pretence is not iuſte and good. The meanynge of Chriſte is no more but this: Nowe the Iewes haue nothinge to pretende and excuſe theyr ſinne, becauſe I came and ſpake to them Againe Chriſte doth not deliuer the ignoraunt vniuerſallye from all ſinne, but onely from the ſinne of rebellion and wilfull obſtinacie. For ſainct Auſten doth ſaye: Habent excuſationem non de omni peccato ſuo, ſed de hoc quod in Chriſtum non crediderunt, quod ad eos non venit, omnes enim qui non audierunt, nec audiunt, poſſunt habere hanc excuſationem, ſed non poſſunt effugere condemnationem, qui enim ſine lege peccauerunt, ſine lege peribunt, that is. The ignoraunt hath excuſe not from all their ſinnes, but of this, that they beleue not in Chriſt, becauſe he came not to them. All whiche haue not had, nor do not heare, may haue an excuſe, but they can not auoide condemnation. For they whiche ſinne without lawe, ſhal periſhe without lawe.

To this agreeth Chriſoſtome. Non de hiis puniendi ſumus quae ſciendo peccamus, verum etiam pro illis quae ignorando committimus, &c. that is:Hom. 7 in cap. 2. Math. VVe ſhalbe puniſhed not onely of thoſe thinges which we committe wittingly, but alſo for thoſe thinges whiche we commit ignorauntly. I do beare them witnes (ſayth Paule) that they haue the zeale of God, but not accordynge to knowledge. But this is not ſufficient for their purgation and excuſe.

Sainct Auſten againe doth ſaye: Non recte dici poteſt, ſi neſcit homo, non peccat, ſunt enim peccata ignorantium, quamuis minora quam ſcientium. It cannot be well ſaid, that a man doth not ſinne,De adult. coniugiis. becauſe he knoweth not, for there be ſinnes aſwell of the ignoraunt, as of them that know, although they be not ſo great.

Saincte Bernarde doth not ablude nor ſwerue from this iudgement, who writeth thus. Vtraque cognitio dei ſcilicet & tui, tibi eſt neceſſaria ad ſalutem, quia ſicut ex noticia tui, venit in te timor dei, Super càtica. & ex dei noticia amor: ſic e contra de ignorantia tui ſuperbia, ac de Dei ignorantia deſperatio, that is. Both the knowledge of God and of thy ſelfe is neceſsarie to ſaluation, becauſe by the knowledge of thy ſelfe, the feare of God commeth vpon thee, and by the knowledge of God commeth loue: contrarie wiſe by the ignoraunce of thy ſelfe, commeth pride, and by the ignorance of God, commeth deſperation:
This much concernyng naturall ignoraunce.

div.head: Ignorantia affectata.
div.p: The other ignoraunce is when a man willingly, wilfully and obſtinatly is ignoraunt of a ſet purpoſe and malice, as if any ſhould ſay, he wil not vnderſtand and know that thing, which doth and may diſpleaſe him, nor will vnderſtande or knowe when he may: Such ignoraunce was in the Iewes enemies of the grace of God. Paule ſaith of them They not knowing the righteouſnes of God, but ſeekyng to place their owne righteouſnes, are not ſubiect to the righteouſnes of God.

Chriſt anſwereth the Phariſies, aſkynge whether they them ſelues were blinde. Si caeci eſſetis, non haberetis peccatum, nunc vero dicitis peccatum veſtrum manet. If ye were blynde, ye ſhould haue no ſinne, but now ye ſaye, we do ſinne, therfore your ſinne remaineth.

De. 12. grad. humilitatis.Saincte Bernarde ſpeaketh of this kinde of ignoraunce verye handſomlye. Non eſt parum ſcire quod neſcias fruſtra ſibi de ignorantia blandiuntur, qui vt liberius peccent libenter ignorant. It is no light matter to ſeeke to know that which thou knoweſt not, they vainlye flatter them ſelues, who are willingly ignoraunt, that they may the more freely ſinne. Of ſuch ſpeaketh the ſcripture alſo. Nolunt apponere ſcientiam ne apponant dolorem. They wyll not know, leaſt theyr ſorowe ſhoulde be increaſed.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: Is there no kynd of ignoraunce that doth excuſe?

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Lect. 28. ſapientiae.The ſcholemen, and ſpecially Holcot put two kyndes of ignoraunce which they call, ignorantiam inuincibilem, & vincibilem.

In queſt. ex. vtroque teſt. queſt. 67.Inuincible ignoraunce is that whiche can not be ouercomed wyth ſtudie or diligence, (as ſainct Auſtene very learnedly writeth.) Non omnis ignorans immunis eſt a paena. Ille ignorans poteſt excuſaria poena, quia quo diſceret non inuenit. Illis autem ignoſci non potuit hoc qui habentes a quo diſcerent operam non dederunt. that is: Not euery on that is ignoraunt is free from pain: that ignoraunt man may be excuſed from paynes, whiche coulde not finde of whome he might learne.
But they can not be forgeuen, whiche hauynge of whome they mighte learne, gaue not their diligence to learne.

Chriſoſtome writeth. Non poteſt eſſe excuſatio condemnationis ignorantia veritatis, quibus fuit inneniendi facultas ſi fuiſſet quaerendi voluntas. Ignorance of the truth can not be an excuſe of condemnation, vnto them who had power and facultie to haue found it, if they had had good will to ſeeke it.

div.head: Ignorantia vincibilis.
div.p: Vincible ignoraunce is when a man deſireth not to knowe thinges which he ought to know, nor to geue his diligence to know thoſe things, which pertaine to ſaluation.

Saint Auſtin ſaith. Licet grauius ſit peccare ſcienter, quam ignoranter, non ideo tamen confugiendum eſt ad ignorantiae tenebras, vt in eis quiſquam excuſationem requirat. Aliud enim eſt neſcire, & aliud nolle ſcire. Although it be more greuous to ſinne wittingly, then ignorauntlye, yet none ought to flee to the darckenes of ignorance, to find in them an excuſe. For it is one thing not to know, and an other thing not to be willing to know. That which is written in the booke of wiſdome, may well be veryfied in them. Excaecauit eos malitia eorum. Cap. 2. Their owne maliciouſnes made them blind.

Saint Auſtin agreeth to the ſame ſaying: Impia mens odit etiam ipſum intellectum, et homo aliquando minimum mente peruerſa, De verbis domini. 78. timet in telligere ne cogatur quod intellexerit facere. &c. A wicked mynde doth hate vnderſtandinge, and one of to peruerſe a mynde feareth to vnderſtand, leſt he be compelled to do that which he vnderſtandeth: whervpon the pſalme ſaith. Noluit intelligere, vt benefaceret. He would not vnderſtand, leaſte he ſhould be driuen to do well
This ignoraunce commeth of pride, maliciouſnes and contempte. And this ignoraunce is called of ſome, Ignorantia craſſa & ſupina, and it is damnable.

The wordes Error, neſcientia, ignorantia, ignoratio, haue this difference. Error eſt approbatio falſorum pro veris. Errour is the allowinge of falſe thinges for true. Neſcientia importat ſimplicem ſcientiae negationem. Ignoratio perteyneth to the very acte and matter, whiche is vtterly vnknowen, nor cannot be knowen, except it be vttered. Ignorantia is when a man doth not knowe that whiche he is bounde to know.
I ſhall thincke it nothing impertinent if I ſpeake here a worde or two of memorie, which is as it wer almoſt oppoſite vnto ignoraunce although not directly.

div.head: De memoria.
div.p: All doctrine and diſcipline doth conſiſte in memorie, and we are taught but in vain, if that which we do heare, paſſe from vs and be forgotten. Quintilianus.

Notwithſtandynge euell thinges are better to be forgotten, then to be kepte in memorie. Themistocles (as Cicero writeth) paſsyng by a certaine ſchole demaunded what was there profeſſed and taught. One anſweringe that the arte of memorie was taughte, he ſayde.

Mallem obliuionis quam memoriae artem memini eorum quae volo, obliuiſci, non poſſum quae nolo. I remembre well thoſe thinges which I woulde to be ſo, but I can not forget thoſe thinges which I would not to be ſo.

Caſsius Seuerus, when his booke was burned by the commaundement of the Senate: Nunc (inquit) ſupereſt vt ipſe vnius comburar qui illos edidici. Now it reſteth alſo that ye burne me aliue, which haue learned without booke euery worde in them. For that whiche is depely grauen in mind, can not be taken away, but with life and all.

A certaine Proconſul, intending to torment and puniſh a certaine theef, and when he doubted what puniſhment he might take of hym, one Polemon comminge that waye, ſayde: Iube illum edicere veterum ſcripta: Commaund him to learne without booke the writinges of the old authours. For Polemon had learned by memorie many thinges. But in all exercyſes he compted nothynge to be more laborious and paynefull then to conne without booke. Therfore Fabius woulde haue this kynde of labour and ſtudie to be devoured euen from childhode. Haec Philoſtratus.

Oenipodes when he ſawe a certaine yonge man getting to him ſelfe many bookes: Non ciſtae (inquit) ſed pectori. Not to thy cheſte, not to thy preſse, but to thy breſt, and to thy memorie. By the which ſayinge he iudged them not to be learned whiche haue nombre of bookes: but which out of bookes committe all thinges to the treaſure of memory.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: VVhy then, it nedeth not to haue copies of bookes, nor it forceth to haue any good librarie, yea it maketh no matter whether we haue anye bookes or no.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: Cartae ſunt rerum fidae cuſtodes, bookes are faithfull kepers of things. Seneca writeth in his epiſtles:Epiſt. 46. Non refert quam multos, ſed quam bonos habeas libros. Lectio certa prodeſt, varia delectat, multitudo librorum onerat, non inſtruit. It is not materiall how many bookes, but how good bookes thou haſt. One ſpeciall kinde of readynge doth proffit, varietie delighteth, multitude of bookes lodeth, and not inſtructeth.

Mithridates Kinge of Pontus is worthy to be had in admiration, which was wont to geue lawes to. 22. diuerſe nations, ouer whom he bare rule in their own proper tonges, and could ſpeake to euery one of them without an interpreter.
King Cyrus hauyng mightie, huge, and great hoſtes, called euerye one of his ſouldiors by his proper name.

div.head: Ambitio. 11.
div.p: AMbition is the inordinat deſire of dignity and honour. Ambitio commeth of this verbe ambio, which properly ſignifieth to compaſſe or go about, and by a metaphor betokeneth ſometyme to flatter and circumuent. And becauſe the Romanes when they did affect honour and bearing of rule, they went about to euery one, ſpake fayre, tooke them by the handes, and deſired them that they would helpe them with their voices: So it came to paſſe, that ambire, is taken to deſire honour, and the roume of a Magiſtrate.

Ther is ambitus, and ambitio, but this is the difference, that ambitiō properly is the immoderate deſire of honour and praiſe. Ambitus is whē we come to publicke honour by filthy meanes and vnlawful waies, as by flattery, faire ſpeaking, and geuing of large gifts, which properly may be called bribery, or ſimony: what ſo euer ambitus doth, ambition compelleth to doo the ſame.

Saint Auſtine hath a notable ſaying: Laudari a male viuentibus nolo et deteſtor, laudari autem a bene viuentibus, ſi dicam nolo, mentior, ſi dicam volo timeo ne ſim humanitatis plus quam ſodalitatis. &c. I abhorre to be praiſed of the ill liuers, and to be praiſed of good liuers, if I ſay I wyll, I lye: if I ſay I wyll, I feare leaſt I maye be counted, more humaine then ſound. Vvhat ſhall I ſay therfore? Nec plene nolo, nec volo. Neither fully I nill nor wyll. I fully will not, leaſt I be endomaged by the praiſe of man: nor fully I nill, leaſt they may be vnthankefull to whom I preach.

Chriſoſtome writeth: Opus quidem deſiderare bonum, bonum eſt: In Math. homil. 25. primatum autem honoris concupiſcere vanitas eſt. Primatus enim fugientem ſe deſiderat, deſiderantē ſe onerat. It is a good thing to deſire a good worke, but to deſire primacy of honor is vanity. For primacy and honour do deſire him that fleeth frō her, & burdeneth him that doth deſire her.

The like ſaying hath ſaint Gregory: Locus regiminis deſiderantibus negandus eſt, fugientibus offerendus. The place of bearing rule is to be denied to them that deſire it, and to be offred to them that flee it.In paſtorali.
Perſius ſpeaketh in his firſt Satyre after this maner.

l.hi: Scire tuum nihil eſt, niſi te ſcire hoc ſciat alter,
At pulchrum eſt digito monſtrari et dicier hic eſt.

q.l: Except other men know that thou be learned.
Both thou and thy learning are nothing regarded.
For it is a goodly thing to be poynted with finger,
And to be ſayd: lo, who goeth yonder?

div.p:
Phanorinus ſaith: that men are partly to be mocked, partly to be hated, and partly miſerable. To be laughed at, becauſe they aſpire ambitiouſly
to higher degrees. Hatefull, when they obtaine them. Miſerable, when they be voyd of their hope.

An ambicious ſonne of a certaine cooke, when being like to haue office, came into the field, and deſired Cicero his conſent. Tully knowing him to be a Cooke, ſayd: Ego quoque tibi fauebo. Tully had a reſpect vnto the Cookes office, in ſaying: Ego quoque.

div.head: Eremites, 12.
div.p: THe Greke word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , betokeneth ſolitudinem, a deſert, a wildernes, wherof commeth Eremitae, which dwel in wildernes, and leade a ſolitary life for the cauſe of religiō. They are called alſo Anachoritae. They liued euery one in his proper Cel. They were very frequent and many in the Eaſt part, and in the deſertes of Egipt,Hom. 8. Math. 2. wherof Chriſostome ſaith: Si quis nunc ad Egipti ſolitudines veniat, paradiſo prorſus omnem illam videbit eremum digniorem, et innumerabiles angelorum coetus in corporibus fulgere mortalibus. That is, if any now go to the deſertes of Egipt, he ſhal ſee vtterly all that wildernes, more worthy then paradiſe, and ſhall ſee innumerable aſsembles of angels, ſhine in mortal bodies.
But by Chriſoſtomes leaue, theſe woordes be agaynſt the ſaying of Chriſt: Nolite exire, nolite credere, wil you not go foorth, beleue not.

Caſsianus maketh mencion of a certaine Eremite in Egipt, whoſe name was Archebius: who liued. 37. yeares in the order of the Eremits or Anchorites. And from thence he was taken of the Church, and made a Biſhop.

I remember a prety hiſtory of a certaine Eremite, who liued very auſterely, and fared very courſely, who did ſpred his table with a net, whē he tooke his refection. At the laſt, whether it were through his holines, or hipocriſy, he was choſen to be a Biſhop. And when he was biſhop, he had forgotten his net, and cauſed his table to be ſpred and laid with very fine and faire clothes. At the laſt one demaunded of him wher his net was, and why he did not lay his table with the net? Vvhat neede I nowe (ſaith he) the net? for I haue caught the fiſh that I would haue: meaning by the fiſh the biſhopricke.

By this ye may ſee their hipocriſie, and what maner of men they wer. At the last they crept from the wildernes, to townes endes, where they might liue more eaſely, quietly, and daintely: but howe continently they liued in their Celles, I ſhall not neede to ſpeake. For it is to manifeſt to al the world.

div.head: Priuation. 13.
div.p:
TThey are properly called homines priuati, which are not ſet in any authority. Priuatus alſo being a participle of ye verb priuor,
betokeneth ſpoliatum, one that is ſpoiled or robbed. Priuatio the verbal is the lacking of any quality that is contrarye: As voluptas eſt doloris priuatio. Pleaſure is the priuation of dolour and ſorrow. Aegritudo eſt priuatio valetudinis: Sicknes is the priuation of health. But for priuation in this ſignification, you muſt conſult the Logicians.

div.head: Be ye holy, as I am holy. 14.
div.p: THeſe words are written in Leuiticus:Leuit. 11. & thei are the words of God vnto the people of Iſrael, after he hadde forbidden them to eate of any creeping thing. For that was an abhominacion vnto the Lord. Therfore ſaide God vnto them: you ſhall not pollute your ſelues with any thing that creepeth, neither make your ſelues vncleane with them, neither defile your ſelues therby. For I am the Lord your God: be ſanctified therfore, & be holy, for I am holy. By the which words is ment, that the people of God ſhould not be drowned in filthines, or any kinde of ſinne, wherof the creeping Serpent was the firſt author and original. Vvho would not laugh at, or rather lament the obſtinate blindnes of the Papiſts, which do wreſt this peece of ſcripture againſt mariage of Prieſtes? Vvherin they offende in two pointes. Firſt, in that they reſtraine theſe wordes to be ſpoken onely to prieſtes, wher it was ſpoken to al the people. Secondly, in that they count Matrimony to be vnholy, wher Saint Paule doth cal it both honorable, and alſo immaculate.

div.head: Al maner of companies. 15.
div.p: THer be two prouerbes, the one is, Polypi mentem obtinere, to follow the nature of Polypus: which Polypus is a fiſh that chaungeth his coulour often times, and when the fiſhers purſue him, he doth cleaue to the rockes, and doth imate the couloure of the ſame rocke, to the which he cleaueth. The other prouerbe is, Chamaeleonte uerſatilior, more chaungeable than the Chamaeleon.

Vvhich both prouerbes may be very wel applied and ſpoken of them, which faſhion and frame them ſelues to the qualities and condicions of them with whom they be conuerſant. Vvith the Papiſts, they wil be Papiſts, with the Proteſtants, they wil be Proteſtants. Such may be well compared vnto the Serpent Chamaeleon, of the which ther is gret ſtore in Aphrica, but they are more frequent in India.
Plinius maketh mention of this beaſt, and ſaith,Lib. 28. cap. 8. he is almoſt as byg as a Crocodile, but the backbone is ſharper, and more crooked, and the tayle is greater.

Plutarchus writeth,In commentariis de adulatione. that the Chamaeleon wil turne himſelf to al coulours, ſauing to the white coulour. Such Chamaeleons be theſe perſons,
which for the ſtate and condition of the time, will frame them ſelues to faſhions, and will ſay with Terentius his Gnato: Ais, aio, neges, nego: if you ſay it is thus, ſo do I alſo: if you ſay nay, ſo wyl I. Plutarchus writeth of one named Leontychides, who whē he was noted not to be ſo conſtant as he ought to be, anſwered: Mutor pro temporum ratione. As the time chaungeth (ſaith he) ſo do I chaunge.

Do you thinke that ther be not a great number of ſuch Leontychides in England, which wil turne with euery winde, and wil be of al religiōs? And when the prince turneth, they wil turne alſo, and will with euery winde turne as the wethercocke. But what may we ſay of ſuche? Euen that which one Laborius ſaid vnto Cicero. For when Laborias was appoynted by Ceſar to be one of the Senate houſe, and he came to ſit down among the Senators, Cicero ſayd. Reciperem te niſi auguſte ſederemus. I would receaue thee, but that the roum is very ſtraight. Vnto whom Laborius anſwered: At tu ſolebas duabus ſedere ſellis. But thou art wonte to ſit vpon two ſeates: noting Cicero his inconſtancie, who would ſeme to play on both the handes. VVhat ſhall we ſay of that Chamaeleon of Oxford, who hath ſo often chaunged his colour, and ſo often reuoking hys papacie, and reuolting againe to the ſame. But leaſt I might be noted Luctari cum laruis, becauſe he is departed out of this world, I wyll ſay no more of him, leaſt he haue left behinde a number of that heare, which wilbe as ready to play the foxiſh part, as euer he was.

Take a yong Foxe or Cub (as ſome terme it) & tie him with a chain, and fede him by the ſpace of ſeuen yeare with milke and ſops, as long as he is tied, he wil abide with you, but if the chain break, or any linke therof, he wil forſake his milke and ſops, and go to his denne as faſt as he can run. So it is to be feared, that ther be a great many of ſuch cubs, which as long as the chaine holdeth, that is, as long as the prince liueth, and the law continueth, they wil eate milke and ſops with vs, that is, they wil be of our religion, & profes the Goſpel with vs: but if the chaine ſhoulde breake, that is, if the prince ſhould die, or the law chaunge, the Fox neuer went ſo faſt to his den, as they wold run to Rome againe.

div.head: Confeſſe. 16.
div.p: AS for the confeſsion inſtitute by God, as wel the publicke as the priuate confeſsion, is ſo copiouſly declared in the ſcriptures, that I ſhal not nede to intreate any thing of it. Therfore I wold wiſh the Reader to go to the ſcriptures, whiche will fully inſtruſt him what confeſsion ordeined of God is, and into how many kinds it is diuided.

I wil concerning this Miſcellane make ſome diſcourſe of the confeſſion of ſinnes inſtitute by man. You ſhall vnderſtand that this confeſsion is of two ſortes. The firſt is publicke, rituall, or ceremonial confeſsion,
which they cal as it were, exomologeſin.

The priuate or ſecrete confeſsion is called auricular. The publicke confeſsion may be called rituall, becauſe it is not ſo much the acknowledging and confeſsing of ſinne, as the act of penaunce.Lib. etimol. 6 cap. 18. And ſo Iſidorus doth almoſt define it ſaying: Exomologeſis proſternendi et humiliandi hominis diſciplina eſt, habitu atque victu, ſacco et cinere incubare, corpus ſordibus obſcurare, animum maeroribus deiicere, illa quae peccauit triſti tractatione mutare. That is to ſay: Publike confeſsion is a diſciplin to caſt downe and to humiliate man by habite and diet, and to lye in ſack cloth and aſhes, to make the body ill fauoured with vncleane keeping, to throw downe the minde with heauines, and to amend his faultes wyth a heauy demeanor.
I would not haue rehearſed theſe wordes of Iſidorus,Lib. de penitentia. being a meane authour, vnles almoſt the ſame were read in Tertullian.

An example of this hath Euſebius, ſaying:Eccleſ. hiſto. Lib. 5. ca. vlt. Natalis martyr deceptus ab haereticis, tandem errorem intelligens, manè conſurgit. &c. Natalis the confeſſor, being deceiued of heretickes, at the length knowledging his error, roſe betime in the morning, put vpon him ſacke cloth and aſhes, and with many teares bewailing his error, did proſtrate him ſelfe at the feete of Zepherinus the Biſhop: & likewiſe with great lamentation, being throwne downe at the feete, as wel of the Clergie, as of Laity, cauſed all the Church to weepe, and with continuall praier to craue pardon for him of Chriſt.

But this ritual confeſsion ſemeth not to be commaunded of God (as it was vſed in old time) that at this day alſo, whoſoeuer hath committed any ſinne, ſhould forth with be compelled to do opē penance. For wher in the Goſpel is ſuch a penaunce read to be inioyned to the ſinfull and adulterous woman? Ther were many other ſinners receiued into the ſauour of God by Chriſt, without ſuch maner of penaunce. For it is very wel knowne how Christ our Lord delt with Mathewe, with Zacheus, with Peter which denied him, and with many other. Therfore, I thinke and iudge, that the Biſhops and Prieſtes in old time inuented this publicke confeſsion for diſciplines ſake, and that ther might be leſſe liberty and liſence to ſinne.

Sozomenus writeth thus: Ab initio ſacerdotibus placuit, vt velut in theatro, teſte multitudine eccleſiae, peccata manifeſtarentur. Eccleſ. hiſt. Lib. 7. ca. 16 That is to ſay: At the beginning it pleaſed the prieſtes, that as it were in a theater the whole congregation bearing witnes, ſinnes ſhould be made manifeſt. Lo here he ſaith, it pleaſed the prieſtes. He addeth alſo, that ther was a priest appointed, to whom they which had ſinned, did come to confeſſe their ſinnes, and to heare and learne their penaunce, that is, what they
ſhould do, or what puniſhment they ſhould ſuffer. And a litle after the ſame Sozomenus ſheweth the vſe of the Romiſhe Church in putting to penaunce.

Furthermore, he ſaith that in the church of Conſtantinople, ther was a Prieſt appointed to heare the confeſsion of the repentaunts, vntil a certaine noble woman, for the ſinnes ſhe had confeſſed, being cōmaunded of the Priest to faſt and to pray, and therfore abode in the Church: was found to haue committed fornication with a Deacon. For the which fact the Prieſts were then ill reported of. But Nectarius the Biſhop being doubtful what puniſhment was cōuenient for that offence, depriued the Deacon from his function and office. And becauſe ſome men gaue counſel, that euery man might haue liberty (according to his conſcience) to come to the communion of the holy miſteries, the penitenciary prieſt was no longer ſuffered to remaine in that office. And ſince that time thys counſel tooke effest, and continueth ſo at this day. &c.

This holy biſhop Nectarius would not haue abrogate this publicke maner of confeſsion, if he had vnderſtand & knowne it to be ordeined of God: neither it ſhould haue bene lawfull for him ſo to doo For he did know (as Sozomenus alſo doth graunt) that this forme and maner of cō feſsion was vſed in the church, by the counſel and deuiſe of biſhops. Neither we reade, that Chriſoſtom (which did next ſuccede Nectarius, who alſo was a very diligent & ſeuere biſhop) did reſtore againe this rituall kinde of penaunce.In epiſt. ad heb. hom. 31 For he writeth thus: Nō dico tibi vt teprodas in publicum, ne
que vt te apud alios accuſes: ſed obedire te volo prophetae dicenti, Reuela Domino viam tuam. &c. that is: I do not ſay vnto thee, that thou ſhouldeſt vtter thy ſelfe openly, nor that thou ſhouldeſt accuſe thy ſelfe before other men: but I would haue thee obey the prophet ſaying, declare and open thy way vnto the Lord. Confeſſe thy ſinnes therfore vnto God the true iudge, with continual praier to obtaine remiſsion: not wyth thy toung, but by remorſe of thy conſcience. And than beleue, yt thou maieſt obtaine mercy, if thou ſhalt haue it continually in thy minde. &c.

In Pſal. 56.Againe, Chriſoſtome ſaith in an other place: Si confunderis alicui dicere, quia peccaſti, dicito ea quotidie in anima tua. &c. If thou be aſhamed to tel thy ſinnes to any man, bicauſe thou haſt offended, tel them daily in thy ſoule. I do not bid thee to confeſſe them to thy fellow ſeruaunt, that he might imbraide thee, confeſſe them to thy God, which healeth them. If thou wilt not confeſſe them, God knoweth them, which was preſent when thou didſt commit them.

Furthermore, he writeth thus in an other place: Caue homini dixeris, ne tibi opprobret. Neque enim conſeruo tuo eſt confitendum, qu • m publicum proferat, ſed domino, qui tui curam gerit, qui et humanus eſt,
et medicus: ei ergo oſtendes vulnera. That is: Tel not thy ſins to mā, leſt he do imbraide thee. For thou muſt not confes them to thy fellowe ſeruaunt, that may vtter them, but to the Lord, which taketh care ouer thee, which is both merciful, and alſo a gentle Phiſition.

He bringeth in alſo the Lord ſpeaking and ſaying: Non cogo te in medium prodire theatrum, ac multos adhibere teſtes: mihi ſoli dic peccatū tuum priuatim, vt ſanem vlcus. I do not compel thee to come foorth into the midde of the multitude, & to take many witneſſes: cōfeſſe thy ſinnes to me alone priuatelye, that I maye heale thy grefe.

All theſe teſtimonies of Chriſoſtome do euidentlye inough proue and declare, that this ritual and publicke confeſsion (as it hath bene in time paſt vſed in the church) was not inſtitute of God, and therfore remoued not without cauſe out of the Church.

I would not haue my meaning ſo taken, as though I vtterly denied opē penaunce to be inioyned and done for notorious and open ſinnes, that the congregation may be ſatiſfied for the offence committed. But my meaning is, that Exomologeſis (as it was vſed in Nectarius time) was not institute nor ordained by God.

div.head: ¶ Of auricular confeſſion.
div.p: Priuate or ſecrete confeſsion is wont to be made onely to the prieſts, al other arbitrers and witneſſes being remoued & ſet apart. In ye which confeſsion euery man whiſpered priuily his ſinnes into the prieſtes eare, and receauing abſolution of him, by certain conceiued woords, thought himſelfe to be purged from al his ſinnes. This confeſſion is called auricular confeſſion, which was vnknowen in the time of the Apoſtles. And although it began to take rote & place in time paſt, yet in the beginning it was free and not vſed. At the laſt it began to be cōmaunded & extorted of the biſhop of Rome, when the ſtate of the Church was most corrupt, in the yeare of the Lord. 1215. or ther about. It was diſputed of. 80. yeares or more (before it was cōmaunded by a certain law) whither it was ſufficient to confes onely to God, or els to the prieſt alſo?

One Hugo a learned writer of that time, ſaith: Audacter dico, Lib. de. eccle. ptāte ligandi et ſoluendi. ſi ante ſacerdotis abſolutionem. &c. I ſay boldly, if any man com to the communiō of the body & bloud of ye lord, before he be abſolued of ye prieſt, he vndoutedly eateth & drinketh his iudgemēt, although he be greatly penitent, and be ſorowful and doth much lament. Theſe be the woordes of Hugo, ſpoken not ſo boldly as buſily, and more then true, except Gods word be falſe. This Hugo liued about the yeare of the Lord. 1130.

Not long after followed him Petrus Lumbardus, commonly called the maſter of the ſentence, becauſe he gathered together the ſayings of the fathers, and made (as it were) an abridgement of their doctrine.

This man liued about the yeare of the Lord. 1150. He in his booke of ſentences ſheweth firſt the authority of the fathers,Lib. 4. diſt. 17 et. 18. that confeſsiō made to God onely is ſufficient. Afterward, he bringeth in other ſentences teaching the contrary. Laſt of all, he himſelfe geuing ſentence, concludeth ſaying: Ex his indubitanter oſtenditur, oportere deo primum. &c. bi this doubtles it followeth, that we must firſt offer our confeſsion to God, & then to the prieſt. Otherwiſe, no man can enter into Paradiſe, if at the leaſt he haue oportunity and faculty ſo to confeſſe.

Gratianus the patcher together of the decrees, which liued in Lumbardus time, is more gentle and fauorable. For he doth define no certainty, but bringing in ſentences pro et contra, for both partes, concludeth thus: Cui horum potius adhaerendum ſit, lectoris iudicio reſeruatur. To which of both theſe partes a man ought to leane and cleaue, it is reſerued to the iudgement of the Reader, that is, whether we ought to cōfeſſe our ſinnes to God onely, or ells to God and to the prieſt alſo. For both the partes hath wyſe and religious men for fautors and defenders.

Fyftye yeares after thys followed one Lotharius, a Doctor of Paris, a diligent follower of Lumbarde▪ He being created Byſhop of Rome, & called Innocentius the thyrd, ſummoned a generall counſell called concilium Lateranenſe, Lib. 5. cap. 12. in the which he made a law which Gregory the ninth reciteth in his decretalls. His wordes be theſe. Omnis vtriuſ
que ſexus fidelis, poſt
que ad annos diſcretionis peruenerit, omnia ſua ſolus peccata ſaltem ſemel in anno fideliter confiteatur proprio ſacerdoti, &c. Euerye Chriſtian of both kindes, when he ſhall come to the yeares of diſcretion, ſhall by hymſelf confeſſe all his ſinnes at the leaſt once in the yeare to his own proper prieſt, and fulfill the penaunce enioyned vnto him: Theſe be the wordes of this new lawe.

Is not this a moſt wicked law to binde the poore penitent ſinner vnto one onely prieſt? And I praye you, who is able to confeſse all his ſinnes vnto the prieſt? Doth not the Prophet Ieremie crye: prauum eſt cor hominis et inſcrutabile: The hart of mā is wicked and vnſearchable? Doth not Dauid ſinge: Delicta quis intelligit? ab occultis meis munda me Domine: VVho vnderſtandeth his offences? clenſe me, Lord, from ſinnes hidden from me.

Again in other place Dauid ſaith: Si iniquitatē obſeruaueris, Domine, domine quis ſuſtinebit? If thou, O Lord, ſtraightly markeſt iniquity O Lord who ſhal abide it? It is impoſſible for mā to confes all his faults. Therfore this their new law doth nothing els but driue and drowne mē in the bottome of deſperation.

div.head: Obiectio.
div.p: Ther be ſcriptures, which do confirme this auricular confeſsion, as yt ſaying of Chriſt ſpoken to the leaper; Go & ſhew thy ſelf to the prieſt.

div.head: Reſponſio.
div.p: This place maketh rather againſt their confeſsion, than with it. For the leaper was healed before he came to the prieſt. But the ſinner (ſay they) is not healed nor abſolued before he go from the prieſt. And Beda writeth, that by the leapers are onely ſignified hereticks. If therfore thei wil eſtaliſh their confeſsion auricular, by the hiſtory of the leapers, thē muſt none confes themſelues vnto the prieſt, but onely hereticks. And thus ye may ſee how they caſt doung in their own eyes.
They do not onely moſt ſhamefully detort this peece of ſcripture, contrary to the natiue ſenſe, but al other places of ſcripture which they are wont to alledge. Of many I wil bring but one.

Bonauenture in his cōmentaries vpon the maiſter of the ſentēces,Lib. 4. diſt. 17 quaeſt. •
frameth, or rather faineth two things to be in confeſsion: the one he calleth formale, that is, abſolution. And this was institute of the Lord, when he gaue the keyes to the Diſciyles. The other he calleth materiale, that is, ye detection and opening of ſinne. And he ſaith, that the Lord did not inſtitute this part by him ſelfe, but did onely inſinuate it.

Then Bonauenture addeth theſe words: Confeſsion was inſinuate of the Lord, inſtitute of the Apoſtles, & promulgate of S. Iames biſhop of Ieruſalem. For as he did promulgate the ſentence for not obſeruing the legal ceremonies: ſo did he inioyne confeſsion to al ſinners, when he ſayde: Confiteminialterutrum peccata veſtra: Confeſſe your ſinnes one to an other. Thus much Bonauenture.

Vvho wil not maruail, nay who may not rather lament the blindnes of that world? Vvhat is not to wreſt the ſcriptures, if this be not? It is moſt euident, that the Apoſtle Iames ſpeaketh not here of auricular confeſsiō, but of that confeſsion wherewith one neighbour doth confes, and reconcile himſelf to an other, whē one hath offended an other, and do pray one for the other. Ther be two words in this ſaying of the Apoſtle, which being diligently expended and weighed, will cauſe them to be laughed to ſcorne. Firſt the apostle vſeth this word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which ſignifieth mutually, by courſe, one after an other, & as ye would ſay, reciprocè: Vvhervpō we may gather this: if the lay men be commaunded by this place of • ames to confeſſe themſelues to the prieſtes: Then must ye prieſtes by courſe cō feſſe themſelues to the lay men. For that is to confeſſe themſelues one to an other, as the Greeke word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , importeth. But if it do greeue the prieſt ſo to do, thē let them acknowledge this place of Iames to mak • nothing for their auricular confeſſion.

Furthermore, Iames ſayth afterward: praye one for a • other, that you maye be ſaued. For he doth couple and knitte, a • it were vnder one yoke confeſſion and prayer. VVhereupon we maye gather thus: If we muſt confeſſe onely to the prieſtes, than we muſt praye onely for
prieſtes. But we muſt not pray onely for the prieſtes: Ergo neither we ought to confeſse onely to the prieſtes. And thus you may plainly ſe, that theſe ſcriptures which they alledge for their purpoſe, maketh nothing for auricular confeſsion.

div.head: Reſpect of perſons. 17.
div.p: Thomas ſecū da ſecundae. 4 83. art. 4. REſpect of perſons is called in the Greeke tounge, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . And it is defined of the ſcolaſtical diuines after this maner: Acceptio perſonarum eſt inaequalitas iuſtitia diſtributiuae in quantum aliquid attribuitur alicui praeter proportionem. Reſpect of perſons is inequality of iuſtice distributiue, when any thing is attributed to any perſon beſide proportion and equality.

Cap. 19.God ſaith in Leuiticus: Non conſideres perſonam pauperis, nec honores vultum potentis: Thou ſhalt not fauor the perſon of the poore, nor honour the perſon of the mighty, but thou ſhalt iudge thy neighbour iuſtly.
Cap. 5.It is commaunded in Eccleſiaſticus: Iuſtifica puſillum et magum ſimiliter: Iuſtifie the weake and mighty a like.
Rom. 2. Cap. 2.S. Paul ſaith. Ther is none acception of perſons with God.
Haue no reſpect of perſons ſaith Iames, in matters of faith.

Saint Auſten, concerning this matter, writeth thus: Si hanc diſtantiam ſedendi et ſtandi ad honores eccleſiaſticos referamus. &c. If we refer the diſtance of ſitting and ſtanding to eccleſiasticall honors, it is to be counted no light ſinne to reſpect faith in reſpect of perſons. For who might ſuffer a rich mā to be choſen to ye ſeate of the honor of the church, & to cōtemne & deſpiſe a poore mā being better learned & more holy?

Ad Pammachium.Saint Hierom ſaith: Nec bonis aduerſariorum, ſi honeſtum quid habuerint, detrahendum, nec amicorum laudanda ſunt vitia. &c. Neyther any thing is to be taken nor detracted from our aduerſaries, if they haue any honeſt thing, nor the faults of our friends ar to be praiſed, but euery thing is to be iudged, not by weing ye perſōs, but by expēding the matters

Lib. 4. de ſummo bono.Iſidorus ſaith: Iudices iniqui errant à veritate ſentētiae, dum intendūt q • alitatem perſonae. &c. Vnrighteous iudges do erre from the verity of the ſentence, while they conſider the quality of the perſon, & do oftimes vexe & greue the righteous, when vniuſtly they defend the wicked.

Lib. 2.. vili. conditioni • . humanae.Innocentius hath two goodly and golden ſaings againſt reſpect of perſons. The first is thys: Vos non attenditis merita cauſarum, ſed perſonar •• , non iura, ſed munera, non quod ratio dicter, ſed quod voluntas affectet, n •• quod ſentiat, ſed quod mens cupiat, non quod liceat, ſed quod libeat. &c. You do not conſider the merits of the cauſes, but of the perſons, not the right •• , but the rewardes, not that reaſon preſcribeth, but that the wil affecteth not that the minde iudgeth, but that it deſireth, not ye which is lawful, but that which liketh and pleaſeth.

The other ſaying hath no leſſe grace then the former: Clamat pauper, et nullus exaudit, loquitur diues, et quilibet applaudit. &c. That is: the poore man crieth, and no man heareth, the rich man ſpeaketh, and euery man flattereth, the rich man ſpeaketh, and al do conſent, and extol his wordes euen to the cloudes, the poore man ſpeaketh, and they ſay, who is this? They ſay to the rich man, ſit thou here, they ſay to the poore man, ſtand thou there.
Xenocrates, ſeing a certain thefe lead to the galowes ſmiled and ſaid: magni fures minores morte damnant. Greate theeues doo condemne the leſſe theeues to death.
Iuuenalis hath for this purpoſe a very meete verſe.

l.hi: Dat veniam coruis, vexat cenſura columbas.

q.l: The law vexeth Dooues with penaltie,
But ſhee ſetteth the Rauens at libertie.

div.head: Lie and Lyar. 18.
div.p:
OF lies there be three kindes, that is: Mendacium.
Iocoſum.
Officioſum.
Pernicioſum.

The firſt is called mendacium iocoſum, a pleaſaunt or ſporting lye, as for example: when I ſay that I do lye, and other men do know that I doo lie, and therby do take ſome profit, or rather pleaſure. This kinde of lye (although it be no great ſinne) yet it hath very much leuity, which the Apoſtle reproueth in Chriſtians, as appeareth in the epiſtle to the Epheſians.Cap. 5. I do not iudge that fables, parables, and fained narrations are to be referred to this kinde, which as the ſcripture in many places applieth to very weighty matters: ſo they haue in them much grace, neceſsitye, and profit. Saint Augustine doth not place ieſt in words among lies.

The ſecond kinde of lies is called mendacium officioſum, a dutiful lie, if I may ſo cal it▪ As for example: when I do faine or tel an vntroth for duties ſake, that is, that I may put away ſome great euil that might happen and chaunce to my neighbour. Of this kinde ther he many examples in the holy ſcriptures.

The midwiues of the Egiptians did ſaue a liue the newe borne male children of the Hebrues, which Pharao had commaunded to be ſlayne: and being accuſed before the king, of breking & tranſgreſsing the law, they pretended by a dutiful and witty lie a certaine meruailous celeritie of bringing forth childrē, wherin they much excelled the Egiptiā womē.
Rahab the harlot by a wonderful lie did mocke the Citizens of Iericho, and by lying did ſaue the ſpies of the people of God.
Michol alſo did ſaue her huſband Dauid by a lie, and ſent away her father Saules ſeruaunts voide of their purpoſe.
The holy woman Iudith by lieng and diſsimulation entred into Holofernes tent, ſlew him, & deliuered the people of God from affliction.
Furthermore, the auncient diuines did diſpute whether thoſe whom we haue alledged haue ſinned or no, by lying and diſsimulation.

Origen with his folowers, did permit and ſuffer a good man to lye, ſo that it were profitable to them, for whoſe ſake it was done. And Saint Hierom is thought to fauour Origens iudgement. For he affirmeth that Peter and Paule did for the time diſſemble.In epiſt. ad Gala. But Saint Auſtine admoniſhed Hierome therof, denying that the ſcripture woulde admit anye maner of lie. Saint Hierome contrarywiſe anſwered, that the beſt interpreters in the primatiue church were of his iudgement. There were learned and long Epiſtles ſent from them both to and fro: Vvhich Epiſtles, ſeing that they are now extant, it needeth not that I doo dwell long in this matter.

Lib. cont. mē dacium. ca. 15The ſame ſaint Auguſtine ſaid: Nihil iudicandus eſt dicere, qui dicit aliqua iuſta eſſe mandacia, niſi aliqua iuſta eſſe peccata, ac per hoc aliqua iuſta eſſe quae iniuſta ſūt. That is to ſay: he is iudged to ſay nothing, which ſaith that ſome lies are iuſt and right, vnles he ſay that ſome ſinnes are iuſt, and ſo by this that ſome things are iuſt, which be vniuſt. Vvhat I pray you can be ſpoken more abſurdly than this? For wherof doth ſinne take her name, but in that it is contrary to righteouſnes? Now, thoſe thinges that are done against the law of God can not be iuſt. The prophet Dauid ſaith vnto God: Lex tua veritas. Thy lawe is truth: Nowe ſinne, for aſmuch as it is againſt truth, cannot be righteous. For who doubteth that euery lye is not against the truth? Therfore no lye may be called iuſt.

Furthermore, other learned and godlye men do iudge Saint Auguſtine to ſpeake to ſiniſter lye and obſtinately against all kinde of lyes. Therfore, ther be ſome that, as it were going in the mid way, do not acquite theſe men (whoſe examples I brought in) from al maner of ſin, but do count lying to be a light and ſmal offence.

This is alſo an other example of a duetyfull lye, when a Phiſicion affirmeth that a ſickeman, which is verye weake, is not greeued with ſo daungerous a diſeaſe, as he himſelfe imagineth, that therby he may put him in hope to recouer his health, and that he may the leſſe encreaſe hys ſickenſſe by taking thought. Alſo, when a Paſtour or Curate affirmeth him ſelfe to haue bene tempted, and to haue eſcaped and ouercome temptation, by the helpe of God (although he doo faine it) that he might the more effectually comfort him that is afflicted and tempted, and might make him to hope, that he alſo ſhould ſhortly auoyde the ſame temptation by the helpe of God.

The third kinde of lie is called pernicioſum mendacium, a pernicious lye, becauſe it commeth out of an euill harte, and tendeth to the hurte of the neighbour which deſerued no harme. This kinde is vtterly cōdemned in all the ſcriptures, and her faulte increaſeth according to the greatnes of the detriment. For falſe teachers do moſte perniciouſlye lye, when with their falſe and corrupt doctrine they do deſtroye mens ſoules, and bring vpon their bodies and goods the curſe of God, with manifolde perils and daungers.

To this kinde perteyneth hypocriſie, whiche our ſauiour Chriſt in the goſpell doth greatly rebuke. But hypocriſie appeareth not onely in deceiptfull wordes, but moſt of all in the whole conuerſation of life, as whē we do fayne thoſe thinges to be, whiche are not, and ſo do lie vnto God, and deceiue our neighbour.

div.head: Traditions. 19.
div.p: THE auncient fathers make mention of manye traditions. Firſt in the time of Tertullian this traditiō was vſed, that they ſhuld geue honie and milke to children, immediatly after their baptiſme, vt (as he termeth it) infantarentur.
In the time of ſaincte Auguſtin and Ciprian this tradition was vſed, that the Euchariſtie, yea vnder both kinds, ſhould be geuen to infantes, as neceſſarie to ſaluation.

Epiphanius ſaith, that it was a tradition of the Apoſtles,In doct. compendiaria aduerſus haereſes. that the fridaye ſhould be faſted, becauſe Chriſt ſuffered on a fridaye. Likewiſe, that the thurſdaye ſhould be faſted, becauſe Chriſt on that day was taken vp into heauen, & whē he was conuerſant in earth with his diſciples ſaid, that they ſhould not faſte ſo long as they had their bridgrome with them, but when the bridgrome ſhould be taken from them, then they ſhould faſt.
Epiphanius alſo in the ſame place writeth,Aug. in epiſt ad Caſſolanu and ſaint Auſten confirmeth the ſame, that there was a tradition, not to faſte from Eaſter vnto Pentecoſte.Lib. de ſpiritu ſancto.

There was an other tradition (as Baſilius writeth) that betwene Eaſter and Pentecoſte God ſhould not be worſhipped with bowing the knee, which tradition was alſo obſerued on ſondayes. There was a tradition of the Apoſtles at Epheſus and in Aſia, that Eaſter ſhould be ſolemnized after the maner and cuſtome of the Iewes. In the churche of Rome the Apoſtolicall tradition was ſaid to be otherwiſe.

Therfore, foraſmuch as the traditions are ſo diuerſe, and do ſo much diſſent among them ſelues, they can not be the traditions of Paule or of the Apoſtles. For Paule ſaith, that in all places, and in euery Church he
taughte one and the ſelfe ſame doctrine. Vvherupon Ciprian writeth, that he would not admitte any traditions, whiche are not founde in the goſpel, or in the actes and epiſtles of the Apoſtles. To the whiche I adde thoſe traditiōs which are neceſsarily brought out of the ſacred ſcripture. Other traditions (what ſoeuer they be) are vncertaine, and not vſed in all places. VVherfore, if a iuſt conſent ought to be kept in the church, we muſt needes cleaue firmlie and conſtantlye to the ſcripture onely.

I will bring one tradition more, by the whiche you maye knowe what all the reſidue are. Ireneus ſpeakynge of Chriſt ſayd: Non ergo multū aberat a quinquaginta annis. Lib. cont. Valentinianos 2. cap. 40. Lib. 2. ca. 36. Et ideo dicebant ei: Quinquaginta annorum nondum es, & Abraham vidiſti? that is. He was not farre frō the age of .50. yeares. And therfore, they ſaide vnto him: Thou art not yet 50. yeares olde, and haſt thou ſeene Abraham? And he confirmeth this his opinion by the Apoſtolicall tradition, ſaying: From fourtie or fiftie yere olde he grewe elder, in which age our Lorde taughte: as the goſpell and all the elders teſtifie, which came to Iohn the diſciple of the Lord, that Iohn declared the ſame vnto them. And our ſauiour Chriſt liued vnto Traianes time. Furthermore, ſome of the elders ſawe not only Iohn, but alſo the other Apoſtles, and hearde the ſame of them, and do beare witnes of this relation.

Theſe be Ireneus his words, which is of the nomber of the moſt auncient writers: But if we ſhould receaue and admitte that tradition, ther woulde enſue a meruailous confuſion (that I maye ſaye nothing els) of times alſo. For after that accompt, the Lorde Ieſus came almoſt to the age of .50. yeres (let vs graunt .48.) then it ſhall followe that he preached .18. yeres: when contrarie wiſe it appeareth plainly inough, that he beganne to preache about the .15. yere of the Empire of Tiberius. And in the .30. yere of his owne age. And they which do accompte the time of Chriſt thoroughly, folowe none other ſupputation. But accordyng to the Apoſtolicall tradition (after the relation of Ireneus) Chriſt ſhoulde haue died, riſen again, aſcended into heauen, and to haue ſent the holye ghoſt in the ſeuenth or eight yere of Claudius the Emperour. But the verie order and diſcourſe of the Euangelicall hiſtorie, and of the actes of the Apoſtles do repugne to that ſupputation. For in the time of Claudius, Paule had much to do. In that time alſo a great and ſharpe famine troubled the whole worlde.

Therfore, the tradition which Ireneus recordeth, doth moſt ſhamefully deceyue, and is vtterly falſe. VVho therfore, after this foule error of tradition perceiued, would beleue hereafter any traditions, yea be they reported to be neuer ſo auncient? It may be that this tradition was taken out of Papias. For as Papias did attribute muche to liuely tradicions
(wherwith he was meruailouſly delighted) ſo he had his folowers, Ireneus, Appollinarius, Lactantius, and certain other through the reuerence of antiquitie in the error of the Millinaries. Of the which hereſie Papias (as ſome do write) laide the firſt foundation.
Euſebius that learned Biſhop doth not attribute much vnto ye iudgement of Papias, but ſayth in plaine wordes, that he wrote manye fabulous thinges,

div.head: Lambe. 20.
div.p: PEter by the ſimilitude of the lambe doth ſignifie that we haue perfourmed in Chriſt and by Chriſt whatſoeuer was ſignified in the ſacrifices of the olde teſtament. Peter ſpecially alludeth to the paſchall lambe And here we maye learne how greatly it proffiteth vs to reade the olde teſtament. For although the olde maner of ſacrificing is aboliſhed, yet it doth greatly helpe our faith to conferre and compare the veritie with the figures, that we may ſeeke and finde in this, whatſoeuer was conteyned in thoſe figures.
Moyſes commaunded to chooſe a lambe that was whole and without ſpot, to be ſlayne and ſacrificed at the Paſche.

Peter doth applie the ſame to Chriſt, and teacheth that his ſacrifice was moſt lawfull and approued before God. Becauſe Chriſt was holye and pure from all ſpotte of ſinne. For if he had had any one blemiſhe, he could not haue bene offred rightly vnto god, & leſse to haue pacified gods wrath.

div.head: A compariſon betwene Chriſte and the paſchal lambe.
div.p: The lambe was male, and of the age of one yere. Chriſt is ſtronge and mighty, the ſame to daye, yeſterdaye, and the ſame for euer.
The lambe was taken out of the lambes or kiddes. Chriſt came of ſinners and vnrighteous men, as it is written in Mathewe.
The church of the Iſraelites were ſpared through the bloud of the lambe.Cap. 8. Through the bloud of Chriſt being ſhedde, the whole churche was clenſed and ſaued.
They be eaten ſpedilye and without taryinge: Chriſt is to be eaten by fayth with great deſire, and without delaye of time.
Vvith the lambe were eaten ſoure herbes and vnleauened bread.
The faithfull chriſtian ought to repent him of his euell life paſte, and to geue him ſelfe to puritie of lyfe.
They did eate the lambe ſtanding, hauing their loynes girded, and holding ſtaues in their handes. This was the maner of waifaring men.

So we ought to behaue our ſelues in this preſent world as pilgrims, to contemne the worlde, and to ſeeke for our countrey which is in heauen.
And in our iourney to geue our ſelues to temperauncie, and to haue our feete ſhodde with the goſpell of peace: and to leane to the ſtaffe of gods helpe and mercie. And to haſten with all feſtination from the ſeruiuitude and corruption of ſinne. Let vs wear the wolle of this lambe, that is, put vpon vs the holy conuerſation of Chriſt. Let vs nouriſhe oure ſelues with the moiſtnes of this lambe, that is with Chriſtes doctrine. Let vs eate the fleſhe of this lambe, that is: Let vs comfort and make our ſelues ſtronge with the worthie receiuynge ſacrament of the bodie and bloud of Chriſt.

div.head: All his bloud. 21.
div.p: ALthough the queſtion be ſuperfluous, whether Chriſt reſumed againe when he roſe from death, all his bloud which he did ſhed in the time before his death, as ſome writers do holde: yet I will ſhewe in a worde or two what ſainct Auſten, and other diuines, and alſo what the ſcholemen did write of the age and quantitie of the bodies whē they ſhall riſe againe, and of ſuche particular partes, whiche the bodies ſhall take again at the time of their riſyng from death.

For the firſt, ſainct Auſten in his booke de ciuitate dei, writeth afafter his maner.Lib. 22. ca. 15, Reſtat vt ſuam recipiat quiſque menſuram, vel quam habuit in iuuentute (etiam ſi ſenex eſt mortuus) vel fuerat habiturus ſi ante eſt defunctus, &c. It remaineth therfore that euery man ſhall receyue that meaſure whiche he had, eyther in his youth (yea although he died an olde man) or els which he ſhould haue had, if he died before he came to the perfecte ſtate of youth.Ephe. 4. And that which the Apoſtle Paule recordeth of the meaſure of the age of the fulnes of Chriſt, is either to be vnderſtand, that the meaſure of his age maie be fulfilled, when the perfection of all the membres in the Chriſtiā people came to the ſame head: or els (if it be ſpoken of the reſurrection of the bodies) let vs take it ſo ſpoken, that the bodies of the dead ſhall riſe, neyther aboue nor vnder the perfecte forme and ſtate of the iuuenile age: but they ſhall riſe in the ſame age and ſtrength, vnto the whiche we knowe Chriſt to haue come. Greate learned men do define this iuuenile age to be about the yeres of thirtye.
Therfore this place of Paule is not ſpoken concernynge the meaſure of the bodie, or of the ſtature, but for the meaſure or age of the fulnes of Chriſt. Hactenus Auguſtinus.

The maiſter of the ſentence ſemeth to agree to the ſame, whoſe words be theſe: Omnes in eadē aetate reſurgent, in qua Chriſtus mortuus eſt, &
reſurrexit, cuiuſcū
que aetatis mortui fuerint. All ſhall riſe again in that age in whiche Chriſt died and roſe again, in what age ſoeuer they died.

But although the age of all that riſe ſhalbe one and like, yet the ſtature and quantitie ſhalbe diuerſe, that is, they ſhall haue the ſame ſtature and quantitie which they had in theyr iuuenile age, or ſhould haue had if they died before. For of the ſubſtaunce (of which the fleſh of man is made) nothing ſhall periſh. But all the particular partes, which were diſperſed before, gathered together, the naturall ſubstaunce of the bodie ſhalbe redintegrate and made whole againe. Thus much for the firſt.

Nowe for the ſeconde: Concernyng euerie parte that was in the bodie, the ſcholemen and ſpecially Bonauenture, diſputing pro & contra, maketh many wordes. He demaundeth whether the humours ſhall riſe again in the bodie? He concludeth, quòd ſic: he demaundeth whether the verie bloud roſe again in the bodie of Chriſt, and ſhall riſe again in our bodies? He doth conclude, quod ſic, and confirmeth the ſame by the authoritie of ſainct Ambroſe, whoſe wordes be theſe. Notum nobis faciāt quemadmodum in exanimae iam corpus & frigidum ſe calor inſinuauerit, ſpiritus ingeſſerit, ſanguis infuderit &c. that is. Let them ſignifie vnto vs, howe heate did inſinuate her ſelfe, how the ſpirite did put in it ſelfe, and how the bloud did poure in it ſelfe into a cold bodie, and bodie without life.

Bonauenture anſwerynge them, which do obiecte,In lib. 4. diſti chon. 44. that the humours and bloud are not of the veritie of mans nature, doth make three diſtinctions howe any thing is of the veritie of the nature of man. Eyther (ſayth he) it is of the veritie of mans nature, concernyng eſſe neceſſarium, as all the principall members, or els, quoad eſſe integrum & completum, as all theſe partes be which make the perfection of the bodie: or els, quoad eſſe decorum, as which that maketh to the comlines and beautie of the bodie. And by this he concludeth, that the humours and bloud, which maketh to the fulnes and integritie of the bodie, ſhall riſe againe in ſuch quantitie, as is competent and conuenient vnto the bodie. And by this appeareth (ſayth he) that al the bloud whith goeth from vs eyther by flebytynge or letting of bloud, or by any other meanes, ſhall not riſe all and wholly again, but ſo much as is mete and agreable to the bodie. Haec Bonauentura.

Sainct Auſten demaundeth, what he ſhall anſwere to the heares and nailes, whether they ſhall riſe again, and euery part of them ſhalbe reſtored to the bodie? and maketh this anſwere.Lib. de ciuit. dei. 22. cap. 19 Quapropter ſi capilli toties tonſi, vngueſue deſecti ad loca ſua deformiter redeunt, non redibunt. Vvherfore if the heares ſo often ſhorne or cut, and the nailes ſo often pared do with deformitie come again to their places, they ſhall not
come againe. For no deformitie ſhalbe in the bodie.

And where the Lorde ſayth. Capillus capitis noſtri non peribit. One heare of our head ſhall not periſh: non de longitudine (ſaith ſainct Auſten) ſed de numero capillorum dictum eſt. It is not ſpoken of the length of the heares, but of the nombre of them. VVherof it is ſayde in an other place. Capilli capitis veſtri numerati ſunt omnes. All the heares of your head are nombred. And thus maye you ſee by the mynde of ſainct Auſten, that neither deformitie nor ſuperfluitie ſhall riſe again with the bodie, but ſo much onely as is congruent and comely, no parte of the ſubſtaunce of the bodie diminiſhed.

div.head: Taketh awaye ſinnes. 22.
div.p: IT is in the greeke 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , id eſt peccatum mundi, the ſinne of the worlde, in the ſingular nombre. And the Euangeliſte doeth expreſſe more by vſynge the ſingular nombre, then if he ſhoulde haue ſaide, peccata mundi, the ſinnes of the worlde, in the plurall nombre. This lambe is innocencie it ſelfe, and onely he taketh awaye ſinne from his, that is, taketh awaye the tirannie and power of all ſinnes, that now there be no ſinne in thē. For as Iohn in his epiſtle calleth malignitie the ſinne of all impietie, and (as it were) a worlde of all ſinnes, when he writeth that the world is ſet in wickednes: ſo he calleth here the ſinne of the worlde, the ſincke of all miſchief.

Orig. hom. in Nomerio. Aug. cont. Fauſt. Lib. 22 cap. 30.Origen, ſainct Auſten, and Thomas, do reade this place in the ſingular nombre, peccatum, & non peccata. One thinge alſo is here worthie to be noted, that is, that the Euangeliſte doth ſaye: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . id eſt, tollit, he taketh awaye, that is, either becauſe he vtterly taketh it away, or doth laye it vpon him ſelfe. For we take vp burdens which we laye vpon our ſelues.

Chriſoſtome very well noteth the preſente tence of the verbe, becauſe the Euangeliſte ſaid not, tulit, or, tollet, but tollit, hath taken awaye, or ſhall take awaye, but doth take, becauſe all purgations of ſinnes do alwayes come from him. As for example: Vvhen we do ſay: Helleborus doth purge the brayne, we ſignifie by theſe wordes that perpetuall and naturall ſtrength and power to purge the head is in Helleborus.

Vvherof there be two kyndes, the one is called Helleborus albus, that is, neeſinge pouder, the other is called Helleborus niger, whiche they call ſetworte. And Helleborum edere, is a prouerbe, ſpoken to men which are very melancholike, or be wilde brained.

div.head: So long ere he came. 23.
div.p: CVrious and buſie heddes whiche will take vpon them to diſpute with God) might demaunde why it was ſo longe ere God ſent his ſonne into the worlde, and ſuffred all the world, ſauinge the nation of the Iewes, to liue in idolatrie, and darcknes, by the ſpace of 3000. yeares or more, before Chriſt came into the world to geue light? To whom thre aunſwers maye be made:Rom. 9. Ibidem. Fyrſt we maye ſaye to them with ſainct Paule: O man what arte thou which pleadeſt againſt God? Again: O the depenes of the riches, both of the wiſdom and knowledge of God. Howe vnſearcheable are his iudgements, and his wayes paſte findyng out?

Secondly, they may be aunſwered by the ſaying of ſainct Paule in an other place, where he writeth thus.Cala. 5. When the fulnes of the tyme was come, God ſente forth his ſonne made of a woman, and made vnder the law, that he might redeme them which wer vnder the lawe.
Thirdly and finally, this anſwere woulde ſuffiſe and ſatiſfie a Godly quiet head: Quia deo ſic fuit complacitum. Becauſe it ſo pleaſed God.

The like captious and curiouſe heds we haue in theſe dayes, whiche contemptuouſly and ſcornefullye do demaunde of them which profeſse the puritie of the goſpell: Vvhere was your church before the tyme of Luther and Zuingius? where was your church 60 yeares paſte? as though God had had no church, but ſuch a church as the Pope had faſhioned & framed vnto him with the gloriouſe note or badge of vniuerſalitie. As though god could or did neuer reſerue to him ſelf a church, vnles the cō panie therof had ben the greater ſorte and moſt part of the worlde. And yet in the ſcripture it is manifeſt, that when all the gouernors of ye church (as wel the prince as the prieſt) did degenerat and ſwarue from the true worſhipping of God: yet God had a church, although it were not ſo vniuerſall, as the Pope would haue it. In the time of Achas King of Iuda, who was ſeen to be of the church, but Eſaias & a few other? In the time of Manaſses ſincere doctrine, celebration of the ſacraments, were vtterly exiled, and this defection continued vntil the time of Ioſias: yet there remained in the church ſome prophetes although they were few. In the time of Ieroboam King of Iſrael, who was ſene to be of the church, but onely Amos, the ſhephearde or heard man whiche deliuered the true doctrine of God? In the time of Achab who wer of the church, but onely Elias and Micheas.
And yet anſwere was made to Elias by God, that he had lefte vnto him ſelfe .7000. that had neuer bowed them ſelues to Baal.

So it is not to be doubted, but that God did reſerue ſome to be of his
church, although they were not ſo coūted in al the time in which ye tyrāny of the Pope and his complices tooke the chiefeſt place. In ſo much that our enemies neede not to imbraid vs, that this religion, which we now profeſſe, was not neither knowen nor profeſsed before the time of Luther and Zuinglius. For ther were many which did not onely confeſse, but alſo openly profeſſed the puritie of the goſpell longe before the tyme eyther of Zuinglius or of Luther. As Bertramus, and one Iohannes Philoſophus, cognomento Scotus, whiche was in Bertramus tyme, which two liued almoſt .700. yeres ago. And after them Berengarius, and after him came Iohannes Hus, and Hieronymus de Praga, whiche were condemned be the councell of Conſtaunce for the profeſsion of the Goſpell: beſide many other which are recited in the booke of Actes and monuments done in the church lately ſetforth by the Godly and lerned man maiſter Foxe.

But this religion is now (thanks be to God) more generally known and profeſſed, then it hath ben heretofore. Therfore if the enemies will aſke why the light of the goſpell was not ſo generally knowen before, as it is was ſince Luther began to write: Let them contente them ſelues with this aunſwere, quod deo ſic placuit, beecauſe it ſo pleaſed God. If they wil go further, they ſhew them ſelues to be but buſie bodies, who will neuer be anſwered nor ſatisfied.

div.head: Adonai. 24.
div.p: ADon ſignifieth in Hebrue Dominum, and Adonai is dominus meus. The Iewes did alwayes place Adonai in ſteede of Iehoua. But when it ſignifieth a creature, it is writtē with patha vnder nun. But when it is ſpoken of God the creatour, it is written with caemets, & adonai is put either for the ſingular nombre abſolutly, or els it is ſet pro domino meo. And when it is put in the plural nombre, it is honoris gratia, for honors ſake.

Secondly it ſignignifieth baſim, that is, the fote of a piller, or that ſuſteineth any thing:Cap, 26. as it is vſed in Exodus. Et quadraginta baſes argenteas facies ſub viginti tabulis. Thou ſhalte make fortie ſokets of ſiluer vnder the twentie bords. But in this ſignification it is pointed with Segol.

div.head: Geuen me to iudge. 25.
div.p:
Ioan. 8. CHriſt ſayth in the goſpell of Iohn: Ego non iudico quenquam I do iudge no man. Again he ſaith in Iohn: Pater omne iudicium dedit filio: The father hath geuen all iudgement to the ſonne. Theſe two places (if they be carnallie vnderſtād) do greatly diſſent: but they may be recōciled, if you vnderſtand thē ſpiritually. For Chriſt doth
condemne the carnall and temerouſe iudgement of the Iewes, which did iudge without reſpecte and perfecte knowledge of the cauſe, ſaying vnto them: vos ſecundum carnem iudicatis. You do iudge after the fleſh, & do thincke that my iudgement is carnall, and not godly and ſpirituall. I do not iudge any man after this maner, that is, according to the eye ſight. For I do iudge according to the hart and mind,Eſay. 11. not accordyng to the outward perſon. And if I iudge, my iudgement is true and right, becauſe it is the fathers. I alone do not iudge, but I and my father which ſente me, do iudge. The father and I are one. The father hath geuen all iudgement to the ſonne. Therfore I do not iudge, the iudgement of the father and the ſonne is one. I do nothing by mans raſhnes, and therfore my iudgement is not wrongfull. The fathers worckes and mine be cōmon, the one doth nothyng without the other. If I do iudge, I do it not alone, but I and the father which ſent me. I am come to ſaue the world, and to preache the goſpell, not to condemne the worlde. I came into the worlde as a ſauiour: not a iudge.
