He that beleuetb in me or my worde, ſhalbe ſaued, and he that doth not beleue, ſhalbe condemned. Therfore thou condemneſt thy ſelfe (O man) whiche continuest in infidelitie. If any man ſhall heare my word, and not beleue it, I do not iudge him: the worde which I haue ſpoken, ſhall iudge him at the laſt daye.Ioan. 12.

div.head: Knee ſhould bowe. 26.
div.p: SAinct Paule writeth to the Philippians, that God gaue vnto Chriſt a name aboue euery name, that at the name of Ieſus euery knee ſhould bow, both of things in heuen, and of things in earth, and things vnder the earth. Nomen, name, in this place is taken for dignitie and honoure, and ſo it is vſed almost in all tongues, eſpecially in the ſcriptures it is a familiar ſpeche. Paule therfore by this word name, ſignifieth high & gret power to be geuen vnto Christ, & christ to be ſet in the chiefeſt degree of honour, that ther may no dignitie be found like, eyther in heauen or in earth.

It is to be wondered of ſome which do coactly restraine this ſentence of Paule to the two ſillables of this name Ieſus Paule ſpeaketh of the whole Maiestie of Chriſt. For they whiche do conſider and haue no further reſpecte, but onely to the two ſillables of the name, do like as one woulde diſcuſſe and finde out by this worde Alexander, the great proweſse of the name which Alexander gatte hym. But I pray you how much more fooliſh are ye Sorbonists, which gather by this place of Paule that the knee is to be bowed, as often as this name Ieſus is pronounced? As though this worde were a worde which had in the verie ſounde all the power included. But Paule ſpeaketh here of the honour which is to
be geuen to the ſonne of God, and to his maieſtie, and not to the ſillables eyther ſounded or written. And in this behalfe howe muche (I paye you) did the peltynge pardoners deceyue the people in ſellynge thys name in golden or paynted papers. As though they might reteine eyther remiſsion of ſinnes, or els the ſauour of God ther by. Notwithſtandyng, it is not to be gayneſaid, but that bowing of the knee, and puttinge of of the cap are ſymboles of the honour or reuerence to be geuen to the maieſtie of Christ, when this name is heard. And he that vſeth theſe ſymboles ought not to ſtand and ſtaye onely in the ſillables of the name. But to lifte vp his minde with great reuerence to be geuen to the maieſtie of the perſon, who is ſo named. As for example: when we heare the Quene named in any ſolemne aſſemblie, we do our obeyſaunce in vailyng our bonets, whiche we do not vnto the letters written in this worde Quene, or to the worde it ſelfe, but vnto her highnes authoritie and royall eſtate.

Petrus Galatinus, writeth that neuer man was named Ieſuah, id eſt, Ieſus. But onely Chriſt the ſonne of God, and ſaith, that Ioſue the ſonne of Naue, and Ieſus the ſonne of Sirach, and Ieſus Ioſedech were called corruptlye Ieſus: becauſe their name is read in Hebrue not Ieſua, but Iehoſua: And that Ieſua by interpretation betokeneth ſaluation or ſauiour, whiche pertaineth onelye to the ſonne of God: And that Iehoſua doth ſignifie by interpretation Deus ſaluauit. Although (ſayth he) theſe thre men named Iehoſua do beare the figure of true Ieſus: for as Naue that ſtronge and mightie man ouercōminge his enemies, brought the children of Iſrael into the lande of promiſe, and as the moſt wiſe doctour the ſonne of Sirach gaue in his time many godly and wiſe leſſons: And as the holy prieſt Ieſus Ioſedech did reſtore and builde the temple of the Lorde: So Chriſt the true Ieſus (the enemies of mankinde bring vanquiſhed by his ſtrength) brought his faythful into the celeſtial lande, and by his wiſedome did illuminate the world, clenſing it from errour, and by his holynes (as being a prieſt for euer) did builde him a ſpirituall temple of liuely ſtones, that is, the church or congregation of the faythfull. Haec Galatinus.

div.head: Our high Prieſt. 27.
div.p:
AN high prieſt is called in latine Pontifex, and ſo called (as Scaeuola, writeth) a poſſe et facere, as you woulde ſaye one that is able to do: or (as Varro writeth) it commeth, a ponte & facere, to make a bridge: becauſe the bridge in Rome called pons ſublicius, was made firſt of the prieſtes, and oftentimes repaired. Now ſublica, or ſublicium, betokeneth a proppe, a ſhore, a poſte, or other like thinge to
kepe a thinge vp. It ſignifieth alſo a pile driuen into the grounde for buildyng, wherof commeth this adiectiue ſublicius, that is, made of piles or poſtes of tymber. And therfore that bridge at Rome was called pons ſublicius: becauſe it was made on piles.

Sainct Paule in the epiſtle to the Hebrues doth ſhew that the dignitie of our high prieſt Chriſt (concerning his perſon) is far aboue the dignitie of the high prieste of the olde Teſtament in three thinges:
1. Gratiae plenitudine.
2. Fideli interceſsione.
3. Efficaci mediatione.

Concernynge the firſt, our high prieſt is called Chriſtus, which betokeneth in latine vnctus, annointed. For God the father hath annointed him with the holy ghoſt and all power. In him dwelleth all the fulnes of the godhead corporally. Again, the prophet Dauid ſaith: vnxit te deus, deus tuus oleo laetitiae prae conſortibus tuis. Col. 2. pſal, God thy God hath annoynted thee with the oile of gladnes aboue thy felows. Of the fulnes of this ointment all haue taken. For the ointment from the head of the high prieſt Chriſt, did not onely deſcende into his bearde, that is, vnto his Apoſtles and diſciples, which being very nigh vnto Chriſt, were ioyned vnto him as his bearde: but alſo into the ſkirtes of his garmente, that is, into the extreme and miſerablie membres of his faithfull flocke. By this ointment are vnderſtand all the giftes of grace, as of mercie, meekenes and liberalitie.

Furthermore by this name Chriſt, that is, annointed, is ſignified both the natures of Christ, that is, the humane and the diuine nature, that Chriſte as true and verye man did receiue the vnction, and as God did geue the ointment.
Finally the high prieſt of the old Teſtament was onely man, but Christ was both God and man.

Concerning the ſecond, the dignitie of the perſon of Chriſt doth farre excel the prieſt of the old teſtamēt, in the faithful interceſsion for vs vnto the father. For Paule ſaith Chriſtus aſsiſtens, Chriſt aſsiſting, that is, being at the right hande of God the father, doth not onely make interpellatiō for vs, but alſo ſtāding & aſsiſting, doth offer & exhibit his help vnto vs, when we haue fallen and be in daunger, as Iohn the Apoſtle ſaith in his epiſtle: Vve haue an aduocate with the father Ieſus Chriſt the righteouſe, and he is the propitiation for our ſinnes.

Concernynge the third, the dignitie of the perſon of Chriſte is ſhewed to be far aboue the highe prieſt of the olde teſtament, in obteininge the ende whiche euerie man wiſheth for. And this is noted by this worde pontifex, whiche touching the etymologye of the worde doth ſignifie factorem pontis, a bridge maker. And he that maketh the bridge, ſhooteth
at this marke, that the wayfaringe man maye paſse ouer the water, from one bancke to an other. Now Chriſt is the onely mediatour betwene God and man: who ſaith: Nemo venit ad patrem, niſi per me. No man commeth to the father, but by me, I am the waye, I am the bridge, by whome onely ye may paſse through the bancke of miſerie, to the bancke of felicitie.

Now Chriſt again doth excell the high prieſt of the olde Teſtament in the dignitie of place. For the highe prieſte of the olde Teſtament went into a temple made with mans hande, but Christ our high prieſte entred into a temple not made with mans hande, that is, into heauen it ſelfe, which Paule calleth a greater tabernacle: partly, becauſe it receyued more then the earthly tabernacle, partly, becauſe it concerneth the greatnes of heauenly treaſures.

Finally, Chriſt doth excell the high priest of the olde Teſtament in a maner of mediatiō, far more worthie then the rites and ceremonies of the olde Teſtament. For the prieſt of the olde Teſtament when he ſhould praye for the people, entred not into the inwarde tabernacle once for al, but euery yere once. Christ entred in once for all obteynyng redemptiō, and with one oblation made perfecte for euer them that are ſanctified. Therfore Christ our high priest is that lambe which was ſlayne from the beginning of the worlde which was verified in righteous Abel,Lib. 22. ca. 15, bearing a type of Chriſt.

Againe, the prieſt of the olde Testament entred into the tabernacle with the bloud of beastes as of goates, and of calues, and the bloud of other beasts. But Christ entred into the tabernacle with his owne bloud. Vvherupon the prophet Dauid ſaith:Ephe. 4. Holocauſtum pro peccato non poſtulaſti &c. Thou requirest no burnt ſacrifice for ſinne. Then he ſayde: Ecce venio. Behold I come, that is to ſay: I will an oblation and ſacrifice for the ſinne of the worlde, which could by no means be purged and clenſed by the bloud of beaſtes.

Last of all the high prieſt of the old Testament did geue onely temporall and fraile thinges, and prayed only for temporall things to be put away. But Chriſt our high priest gaue eternall thinges which ſhal neuer fade nor fall away. The high priest of the old Testament made interceſſion onely for the nation of the Iewes. But Chriſt made interceſsion for the ſaluation of all mankind.

div.head: Shoote anchor. 28.
div.p:
SAcram ancorem ſoluere, in greeke, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , is a prouerbe, vſed when we flye vnto the vttermost refuge. It is tranſlated frō ſhipmen which do call the greateſt and ſtrongeſt ancor,
ſacram, the holy ancor which they then caſt forth, when they are in extreme daunger.

Lucianus vſeth this prouerbe ſaying:In Ioue tra gaedo. Audi iam ſacram (vt aiunt) ancorom, quanquam nulla vi queas abrumpere. Heare thou now the holy or ſhoote ancor (as they call it) which thou art able to breake with no violence. For ſo he termeth an argument which cannot be diſſolued.
Euripides ſaith likewiſe. Mihi ab vnica fortuna pendet ancora: In hecuba. My fortune doth depend of one onely anchor, that is, one onely hope remayneth vnto me.De Lazaro concionc. 4.

Chriſoſtome doth call the conſcience 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : becauſe ſhe doth neuer ſuffer man to be taken away with the violence of luſtes (as it were) with a ſtorme of windes, but alwaies doth reſiſt them.
Ancoras tollere, is prouerbially ſpoken, to entend to go away, as the ſhipmen do when they take vp their ancors, meaning to remoue.

div.head: Fruit hundredfold. 29.
div.p: WHen Chriſt had told the parable of the ſede vnto a great multitude, and had applied the ſame parable of the diuerſity of ſedes vnto the hearers of the Goſpell: He did at the laſt compare the ſede in the good ground, to him that heareth the woord, and vnderſtandeth it, which alſo beareth fruit, and bringeth forth ſome an hundreth fold, ſome ſixty fold, and ſome thirty fold.
Here may be a queſtion moued, what is ment by the diuers numbers of fruites, as a hundred, ſixty, and thirty.
Some of the old writers do expound this ſame diuerſly, and do wreſt and writhe it to a marueilous ſtraunge ſenſe.
Some of them attribute a hundreth fold fruit to virginity,In quaeſt. Euangelii. ca. 9 the ſixty fold fruit to widowhood, and to the maried perſons thirty fold. Of this opinion is ſaint Auguſtine.

Other do aſcribe an hundred fold to Martyrs, ſixty fold to Virgins, thirty fold to widowes, and to matrimony they attribute nothing. As though (to be maried) were to be counted that kinde of life which is not acceptable vnto God, but as a thing onely ſuffered by permiſsion, yea and ſome writers were not aſhamed to define (to be in wedlocke) is nothing els but to be in the fleſh, and to ſerue wantonnes. But what other thing is this (as ſaint Paul ſaith) but the very doctrine of diuels?

Theophilactus aſcribeth theſe fruits, the hundred fold to Anchorits, the ſixty fold to Monkes, & the thirty fold to maried perſons. But this kind of interpretation, are not to aſsigne the fruits of the Goſpell preached, but to commend the ſtates of certain men, which are had in admiration. As though Chriſt here ſhould entreate of rewards to be geuen to
them which embrace piety and godlines. But here is nothing leſſe ment then of rewardes to be receiued in the life to come: but of the fruits to be geuen in this life out of the word of God. Here is nothing ment what fruites of piety, virgins, widowes, maried men, Moonkes, or Heremites do bring forth, but how diuerſly the word of God bringeth foorth fruit in them that do beleue. It may be ſaid, that a faithfull maried man maye haue an hundreth fold, and the virgin none, and that he which liueth in the world, may haue an hundreth fold, and the Anchorite none.

Lib. 21. cap. Vltimo.Saint Auſtine in his booke De ciuitate dei, rehearſeth that certein had a more fooliſh and more wicked opinion of this place, which expounded theſe fruites ſo, that they ſaid that euery ſaint at the day of iudgement, ſhall obtaine and redeme for his merites them that be damned, to whom God, through the diuers merites of ſaints, ſhould geue eternal life. And of this minde were they which thought that no man ſhould be damned eternally, and which thought that the ſaintes wer ſo merciful, that they would not ſuffer ſo many thouſand ſoules to be damned, but that they would pray vnto God for them, that ſhould be damned: vnto the which ſaintes God cannot deny that which they require. Looke more in that place of ſaint Auſtine for this wicked and fooliſhe opinion to be laughed at.
But ſetting a part all ſuch fond, falſe, and vain opinions contrary one to the other, let vs vnderſtand that the fruites of the woorde of God be theſe which grow out of the word.

The ſimilitude or parable it ſelfe declareth no leſſe. Vvherfore is the ſeede ſowen in the field, but that it may bring forth fruit in his kinde? Vvhat other thing ſhould the ſeede of wheate bring foorth, but graine and corne, according to his nature and kinde? So the Goſpell preached, what other thing ſhould it bring foorth out of a godly hart, then that which hath in it ſelfe, that which it teacheth, and that which it deliuereth. Faith in Christ, amendement of the former life, the knowledge of God, loue toward God and our neigbbour, and ſuch other are ſowen and preached. And what other thing ſhould the preaching of the woord of God bring forth, but ſuch fruites?

That which Chriſt preacheth of an hundred fold, ſixty fold, and thirty fold, is to be vnderſtand ſimpliciter: For that the Goſpell doth bring forth in one faithful beleuer, more fruit, in an other leſſe fruit, according to the meaſure of the gift of God. Vvher we be admoniſhed, not that one and the ſame meaſure of faith, loue, and piety, is to be looked for of all beleuers: but that the ſame meaſure ſhall be different, which difference and equalitye maketh not the beleuers to be enuied of God.
He is no les beloued of God, which hath thirty fold, then he which hath an hundred fold. He that wan two talents, heard alſo theſe words: Euge ſerue bone, O good ſeruaunt, enter into the ioy of the Lord, as well as he that had won fiue talents. Therfore they which be perfect, and do bring forth an hundred fold, let them not contemne thoſe which are not ſo perfect, and bring forth onely thirty fold. On the other ſide, they which be infirme, and bring forth onely thirty fold: let them not enuy them which be perfecter, and bring forth an hundreth fold.

div.head: Loue. 30.
div.p: LOue is called in latine Amor, in Greeke 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , in hebrue Ahabah, and it is deuided into fiue kindes.

In
Amorem dei, the loue of God.
Amorem proximi, the loue of our neighbour.
Amorem patriae, the loue of our country.
Amorem ſeculi, the loue of the world.
Amorem ſui, the loue of him ſelfe.

div.head: ¶ Loue of God.
div.p: Loue of God is both ſet foorth in Deuteronomy, and alſo in Luke,Deut. 6. Luke. 10. wher it is written: Thou ſhalt loue thy Lord God with all thine hart, with all thy ſoule, with all thy ſtrength, and with al thy minde.

Of this loue ſpeaketh Saint Hierome ſaying: Faelix illa conſcientia, ad Demetriadem. in cuius corde praeter amorem Chriſti, quae eſt ſapientia, caſtitas, pacientia atque iuſtitia, nullus alius verſatur amor: Happy is the conſcience of that man, in whoſe hart beſide the loue of Chriſt (which is wiſdom, chaſtity, patience, and righteouſnes) none other loue is conuerſant.

Saint Bernard vpon the Canticles ſheweth how God loueth vs,Sermo, 20. and how we ought to loue him, his woordes be theſe. Dilexit nos deus dulciter, ſapienter, fortiter, Dulciter, quod carnem induit, ſapienter, quia culpam cauit, fortiter, quia mortem ſuſtinuit: Diſce ergo Chriſtiane a Chriſto, quomodo diligas Chriſtum. Diſce amare dulciter, ne illecti, prudenter, ne decepti, fortiter: ne oppreſſi amore domini auertamur. That is to ſay: God loued vs ſwetely, wiſely, and ſtrongly, ſwetely in that he tooke vpon him our fleſh: wiſely and warely, for that we auoided ſinne: ſtrongly, becauſe he ſuſtained death. Learne thou of Chriſt (O Chriſtiā) how thou maieſt loue Chriſte, learne to loue ſwetely, to loue wiſely, to loue ſtrongly: ſwetely, leaſt being otherwiſe intiſed: wiſely, leaſt being deceiued: ſtrongly, leaſt being oppreſſed, we turne away from the loue of the Lord.

Hugo ſheweth the difference betwene the loue of God, and the loue of the world after this maner: Amor mundi a principio dulcis eſſe videtur, ſed finem amarum habet: amor vero dei ab a maritudine incipit, ſed vltima eius dulcedine plaena ſunt. The loue of the world at the beginning ſemeth to be ſwete and pleaſant, but it hath a ſower end. Contrariwiſe ye
loue of God beginneth wt bitternes, but ye laſt end of it is ful of ſweetenes.

div.head: Loue of neighbour.
div.p: The loue of thy neighbour is ſet forth in infinite places of the ſcripture. I will alledge but onely two.

The firſt is in Toby: Quod ab alio oderis fieri tibi, vide ne tu aliquā do alteri facias. That which thou hateſt to be done to thy ſelf of an other, take hede that thou at any time do not the ſame to him. The like words ſpake Chriſt in the Goſpel of Mathew: what ſoeuer you would that men ſhould do vnto you, euen ſo do ye to them.
Alexander Seuerus did ſet vp in euery corner of his palace this poiſie: Quod tibi non vis fieri, alteri ne feceris: That thing which thou wilt not to be done to thy ſelfe, do it not to an other man.

Rom. 13.The ſecond place of ſcripture is written in the Epiſtle to the Romains. He that loueth another, hath fufilled the law. For this: thou ſhalt not cō mit adultery, thou ſhalt not kil, thou ſhalt not ſteale, thou ſhalt not bear falſe witnes, thou ſhalt not couet: and if ther be any other commaundement, it is briefly comprehended in this ſaying, euen this: Thou ſhalt loue thy neighbour as thy ſelfe: Loue doth not euil to his neighbour, therfore is loue the fulfilling of the law.

De doctrina chriſtiana.Saint Auſtine ſaith: Sola charitas eſt quae vincit omnia, & ſine qua nihil valent omnia, quae vbicunque fuerit, trahit ad ſe omnia: that is. Onely loue and charity is that which vanquiſheth all thinges, & without which althings are nought worth: which loue wherſoeuer it ſhalbe, it draweth vnto it althinges.

Againe, in an other place he ſaith: Non putes tunc amare ſeruum tuum, Super. epiſt. Ioann. quando eum non caedis: aut tunc amare filium tuum, quando ei non das diſciplinam: at tunc amarevicinum tuum, quando eum non corrigis. Non eſt iſta charitas, ſed languor. Ferneat charitas ad emendandum & corrigendum. Si ſunt boni mores delectent, ſin autem mali emendentur. That is to ſay: Do not thinke that thou doeſt then loue thy ſeruant, whē thou doeſt not beate him: or than to loue thy ſonne, when thou doeſt not chaſtiſe hym, or than to loue thy neighboure, when thou dooſt not correct him. This is not loue, but faintnes. Let loue be feruent to amend and correct. If the maners and conuerſation be good, let them delight thee, but if they be euil, let them be amended.

De form. vitaeVve maye conclude the loue of our neighboure in theſe woordes of Seneca: Deum amabis, ſi illum in hoc imitaberis, vt velis omnibus prodeſſe nulli nocere. Thou ſhalt loue god, if yu wilt follow him in this thing, to wil to profit al men, and to hurt no man.

div.head: Loue of our country.
div.p:
Concerning the loue of our country, although I haue ſpoken ſomewhat before in the firſt Tome, yet I wil bring in here what may be ſpoken of the country pro et contra by two interloqutours. The firſt is named
Philopatrios, the ſecond is called Miſopatrios.

div.head: Philopatrios.
div.l: Your countrie you ought to haue in ſuch ſtore,
That neither parentes nor children you ought to loue more.
And becauſe againſt this you ſhall not ſay naye,
You ſhall heare what diuines and other do ſaye.
As vpon the Pſalmes Auſten doth comment,
Theſe wordes he hath concerning this entent.

l.hi: Valde patriam ille execratur.
Qui ſibi bene putat cum peregrinatur.

div.l: He hath his countrie in much indignatiō,
Which thinketh him ſelfe well in his peregrination.
The wilde beaſt (ſayth Caſiodore) louing his denne,
May be a ſpeciall preſident for all maner of men:
To loue their countrie and therein to remain,
And for the loue of it to abandon no payne.
The byrdes of the ayre loue their owne neſt,
And the beaſtes in the wooddes do go to their reſt.
The fiſhes to their holes themſelues do betake,
And ſhould man then hys countrie leaue and forſake?
It is written of Plato very noblie
That we be not borne to our owne commoditie,
Our countrie the chiefeſt parte doth requyre,
And our frendes and kinne the next parte doth deſire.
Vlyſſes the politique (as Homere doth ſaye)
Deſired with his life to be at a ſtaye,
If to his countrie he might come ſo neare,
That he myght ſee the ſmoke but once appeare.
Be willing (ſaith Periander) for thy countrie to die,
Thou canſt purchaſe (ſayth Horace) no greater glorie.

div.head: Miſopatrios.
div.l: In the epiſtle of Caſſiodore the nine and thirtie
Theſe wordes I read concerning our countrie.

l.hi: Interdum expedit patriam negligere
Vt ſapientiam quis poſſit acquirere.

div.l: Of our countrie ſometyme we muſt haue negligence
To purchaſe wyſedome, wytte, and experience.
And I read in Euripides a poete of Grecia,
Theſe two verſes intreating de patria.

l.hi: Omnis quidem aer penetratur ab aquila
Omnis vero terra viro forti patria.

div.l: As the Egle in the ayre doth finde a playne way
Finding nothing her flight to ſtoppe and to ſtay:
So a man that is ſtronge counteth euery place,
To be his owne countrie be it neuer ſo baſe.
Plutarchus to Traiane the Emperour, being Maiſter of the ſchole
Doth count him an idiote and a very ſtarke foole
Which counteth the Moone to ſhyne more clere and bright
At Athens, then at Rome, and there to geue more lyght:
So he that counteth one place better than another,
May be dame Morias owne naturall brother.
Socrates being demaunded wher he had his natiuitie.
Aunſwered the whole world to be his natiue countrie.
Ariſtophanes in Greeke geueth this ſame ſpell,
That there is his countrie where a man liueth well,
Where learned Pythagoras the courſe of Aſtronomie?
Where obteyned Socrates his ciuile mortalitie?
Where had Plato his profounde diuinitie?
Where gatte Ariſtotle the ſcience of Philoſophie?
By ſitting ſtill at home in his owne countrie?
Nay, ſome went to Egypt, and ſome to Babilonia,
Some to Italye and ſome to Sicilia.
To a woodcocke I may him very well compare
Which to no place but to his countrie will at any time repaire.
For when her bill is in a hole ſhe thinketh her ſelfe wel,
And ſo doth he which loueth euer in his countrie to dwell.
Seeke ſayth the Scripture, and ſo ſhall you fynd,
Both treaſures for the body, and alſo for the minde.

div.head: Loue of the world.
div.p: 1. Epiſt. 2The loue of the worlde is declared of Sainte Iohn to conſiſt in theſe three thinges.

p.hi: In

div.p: The luſt of the fleſh comprehendeth al filthy and carnal deſires.

The luſt of the eyes comprehendeth aſwell all wanton ſights, as the gredy deſire of mony. Salomon ſaith: Non ſatiantur oculi auari diuitis: The eyes of a rich couetous man are neuer ſatiſfied. Againe the ſonne of Syrach ſaith: inſatiabiles oculi cupidi: the eyes of a couetous man are vnſatiable.
The luſt of the pride of life comprehendeth ambition, boaſting, deſire to haue honour, and to beare rule.
Vvhatſoeuer the natural or carnal man doth, he doth it eyther for the loue and luſt of the filthy pleaſure of the fleſhe, or for the riches of the world, or els for vaine ambicion.
Concerning the loue of the fleſh, I remember two old verſes.

q.l: Neſcio quid ſit amor, nec amoris ſentio nodum,
Sed ſcio, ſi quis amat, neſcit habere modum.

div.p: Elegia. 15Propertius hath a like ſaying.
div.q: Scilicet in inſano nemo in amore videt.
div.p: Plato ſaid, that all they which were in loue, liued in an other body, and were dead in their own. Theophraſtus being demaunded quid eſſet amor, what thing loue might be anſwered, animi otioſi affectus: the affection of an idle minde or ſoule.

Vvhen a certaine Eunuche was taken in act with a concubine of the king of Babilon, the king demaūded of Apollonius, what he did iudge to be done with the Eunuche. Vvhat (ſaith he) but that he liue? The king marueiling at this anſwer, Apollonius ſaid: loue wil enforce him to ſuffer
all torment and paine. And therfore ſaith the Poet.

l.hi: Heu mihi quod nullis amor eſt medicabilis herbis.

q.l: Wo is me which with loue am ſo indured,
That my loue with no herbes can be cured.

div.p: Concerning the loue of riches, Virgil writeth: Quid nō mortalia pectora cogis, auri ſacra fames? Aenaeid, 3.

Concerning the loue of honour, and bearing of rule, Bernard hath a notable ſaying: O ambitio ambitientium crux, quomodo omnes torques? omnibus places? nihil acrius cruciat, nihil moleſtius inquietat, nil tamen apud miſeros mortales celebrius negotiis eius. That is to ſay: O ambition the croſſe of ambitious men, how doeſt thou vexe all men? how doeſt thou pleaſe all men? Nothing doth vexe more vehemently, nothing doth diſquiet more greuouſly, and yet nothing is more frequent and ſolemne among miſerable men, then the affaires of ambition.

div.head: Loue of our ſelues.
div.p: The loue of our ſelf is called in Greke 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , ſelfe loue, of the which Ariſtotle entreteth in his Ethicks. This 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is a perilous monſter,Lib. 9. cap. 8. De charita. cent. 3, 56. & bringeth forth almoſt all miſchiefes (as ye holy mā Maximus recordeth.)

Philautia omnium cogitationem adfectus inducentium cauſa conſtituitur. Ex hoc enim generantur tres concupiſcentiae cogitationes, etiam fortiſſimae, nempe crapulae, auaritiae, et manis gloriae. Ceterum ex crapula naſcitur ſcortationis cogitatio, ex inani gloria ſuperbiae. That is to ſay: Philautia, ſelf loue, is the cauſe of all cogitatiōs gendring affections. For of it ar gendered three ſtrong cogitacions of luſt, that is, of gurmandiſe, of couetouſnes, and of vaine glory. But out of gurmandiſe ſpringeth the cogitation of whooredome, and out of vayne glorye ſpringeth the cogitation of pride.

Socrates ſaith, if a man in the theater or ſporting place ſhoulde commaund all ſhoomakers to ariſe, & none but they, they onely would ariſe. Likewiſe if he ſhould commaunde Smithes, Braſiers, weauers, and all other Artificers to ariſe by them ſelues, and none but they, they onelye would ariſe. But if he ſhould commaund and ſay: Now ariſe you all that be wiſe and iuſt, than al would riſe. Here you may ſee how the moſt part being fooliſh, yet ſeeme to them ſelues to be wiſe.

Diogines being demaunded what was the hardieſt thing in the whole courſe of nature, aunſwered: No ſce ſeipſum, a man to knowe him ſelfe. And Demoſthenes did ſay, that the eaſieſt thing of al thinges, was for a man to flatter and deceiue him ſelfe.

Eſope ſaid, that euery man did carry two wallets or bags, the one before him, & an other at his backe. And that he doth put into the wallet that is before, other mens faultes, and caſteth his owne faultes into the bag that is behinde. Vvherupon Cicero ſaiih: Fit, neſcio quomodo, vt magis in alienis cernamus, quam in nobis ipſis, ſi quid delinquitur.

It commeth to paſſe, I cannot tel how, that we ſee further in other men, then in our ſelues, when any thing is done amis. And as Menander writeth, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : No man knoweth him ſelfe to be euil.

div.head: Flattery. 31.
div.p: Lib. 5. cap. 66 TO flatter in the latine is called, aſſentari, adulari, & blandiri. Valla in his elegancies ſheweth the difference betwene theſe three verbes.

Aſſentari ſaith he is to flatter any body, affirming his ſayinges, and vpholding his yea, and his naye, or prayſing him to much, or ells many times otherwiſe than the truth is, to the end to get ſome profit and aduauntage therby, and it is properly in wordes. And therfore thys kinde of flattery called aſſentation, is not in any brute beaſt, but onely in mā. Adulari is to flatter another man in humbling him ſelf, & being ſeruiſable about him, and to labour in ſuch faſhions to winne and gette his fauour, whether it be by voice and wordes, or ells by gesture of the body, or by any other way and meane what ſoeuer it be.

Nonnius Marcellus ſayth thus: Addulatio eſt proprie canum blandimentum quod ad homines conſuetudine tranſlatum eſt. Adulation properly ſignifieth the fauning and leaping of dogges vppon their maiſters, from which property by tranſlation it is applied to men onely, by vſe of ſpeaking, and not by proper ſignification of the word. Some Grammarians fourme adulo, of the word aula, which is lattine for a Princes court (wher ſuch flattery is very much vſed, and is commonly called holy water of the court) by chaunging the diphthong Au into V long. But Valla holdeth with them yt do deriue Adulor of the Greke worde 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which is in lattin ſeruus. For adulari is a ſeruile thing, & is only in ſuch as can abide to be ſubiect & boūd to another body, which is not in honest mē
Blandiri betokeneth to flatter, properly by touching and handling, and by vnproper vſing by a Metaphor tranſlated to the partes of the body, and many times to the minde.

The Hebrues do ſay that this word Patha betokeneth to flatter, of the which woord it is very like that the Grecians borowed this verbe 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which betokeneth to perſwade with faire flattring words.

Againſt al maner of flattery Salomon in his prouerbs hath a worthy ſaying: Meliora ſunt vulnera diligentis, quam oſcula blandientis. Better are the woundes of a louer,Prou. 27. then the deceitful kiſſes of a flatterer.

Saint Auſtine writeth: Quod duo ſunt genera perſequutorum, ſcilicet vituperantium et adulantium, ſed plus perſequitur lingua adulantis, quàm manus perſequentis. In pſal. 97, Ther are two kindes of perſecutors, that is, of raylers and flatterers. But the toung of the flatterer doth more perſecute, then the hand of the perſecutour.
Adulator (ſaith Gregory) eſt qui palpando incedit, ſed cauda ferit. A flatterer is a ſcorpion which flattereth by faining, but geueth a ierke with his taile.

Antiſthenes ſaid, that it was better incidere in
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , quam
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : It is better to fall into the handes of Rauens, than into the hands of Paraſites. For flatterers do corrupt the minde of the liuing, the Rauens eat onely the bodies of the dead.

Ariſtonymus was wont often to ſaye: Ligna dum augent ignem conſumi ab ipſo: ſic opes dum alunt adulatores ab eis ipſis perire: That the greater fire the wood maketh, it is conſumed of the fire. Euen ſo riches (while they nouriſh flatterers) they are deuoured of them.

div.head: Sainct Fraunces. 32.
div.p:
SAinct Fraunces was the firſt inuentor and author of the Minorite fryers. He lyued about the yeare of the Lorde .1208. Vincēt. lib. 3. cap. 11. par. 3. titu. 24. Manye thinges are written of him which are recorded in ſpeculo hiſtoriali vincentii, and in the thirde Tome of the hiſtorie of Antoninus. He liued as they write in his youth in aboundaūce of riches, in vanities of the world, in paſtimes, in wantonnes, and vnchaſt ſongs, and was very prodigal. And thus he liued vnto the .25. yere of his age, and than (as they write) was conuerted to great holynes. In ſo much yt beſide many other miracles (which he is reported to haue don) he was called Franciſcus Seraphicus, by applieng this piece of ſcripture vnto him: Aſcendit ſuper Cherubin, et volauit ſuper pennas ventorum. He rode vpon the Cherubin, & did flye vpon the winges of the windes. But how aptlye this piece of ſcripture is applied vnto Fraunces, I referre it to the godly and learned, who be expert in the ſacred ſcriptures. It maketh as much for Fraunces, as a ſhoulder of mutton is mete for a horſe. But becauſe ſome of the ſchole diuines do place the order of Angels named Seraphin, aboue the order called Cherubin, and for that Fraunces (as they ſay) wēt vpon Cherubin, and was placed in the order of Seraphin, therfore they cal him: Fraunciſcum Seraphicum. O beta inſipidiores, O noctuas in ſole caligantes. O men more vnſauery then the Beete, O Owles and Buſſards not able to ſee in the noone day, which do make ſuch ſhamefull applications of the ſacred word of God: becauſe I will not be tedious, I wil ſhew .ii. trifling toies, or rather vain fables which ar writtē of him. Firſt the diuell (ſay they) tempted him of a greuous temptation of the luſt of the fleſh: which Fraunciſcus perceiuing (putting of his clothes) did beat him ſelfe with a verye hard and ſharpe coarde, ſaying vnto him ſelfe: Eia a ſine ſic te manere decet. O Aſſe ſo it becommeth thee to remaine.
But when the temptacion did not depart: going forth at the doores in a very ſharpe winter, he threw him ſelf naked into agreat heape of ſnow, and made of the ſnow ſeuen balles, which he ſetting before him, ſpake to his body after this maner: Behold (ſaith he) this greter balle is thy wife, other foure be thy children, two male, and two female: the other two be thy man ſeruaunt and maidſeruaunt. Make haſte therfore to put them on, becauſe they die for cold. This is very good ſtuffe, and a verye meete way (ſi diis placet) to reſtrayne the inwarde concupiſcence and luſt of the fleſh.

The other thing which is reported of him is this. Two yeres before his death, he ſaw in a viſion, as it were, one of the Seraphins in the aire, hauing ſixe wings, his hands ſpread abroad, and his feete ioyned together, and faſtened to the croſſe. Two of the winges were erected aboue his head: he had two ſpred forth to flye, and with the other two he couered all his whole body. Fraunces at the ſight was marueilouſly astonied, and did both feare and reioyce. He feared to ſee the fearful faſtening to the croſſe. He reioyced that the Seraphin did ſo graciouſly and fauourablie looke vpon him. And when he had thought with him ſelfe a long time, what this viſion ment, at the last he ſaw a miracle that the like was neuer heard before. For there appeared in his own hands and feete (as it were) the token of faſtning of nayles. His right ſide appeared as though it had bene pearced with a ſpeare: and in his hands and fete ther appeared certaine long markes of hard and longe nailes. Vvhen this man of God ſaw this wonderfull ſight, and that God had indued him with ſuch a precious treaſure, he thought to conceale it from all men, rehearſing often times in his mouth this ſaying of the prophet: in corde meo abſcondi eloquia tua, vt non peccem tibi. I haue hidden thy wordes in my hart, that I may not ſinne vnto thee. He bare in his ſide the woūd as long as he liued, which was not ſene, but onely of his brother Elias the Friar, and that by chaunce.

Alexander the Pope, the fourth of that name, being elect Pope at Naples, about the yeare of the Lord .1254. in the firſt yeare of his popedome, ſtraightly commaunded, that the Friars ſhould go and dwel in the mount Aluernia, where theſe markes were made in the body of Saynt Fraunces, and that they ſhould neuer depart from thence, and ſent certaine letters, in which he declareth that he ſaw with his own eyes theſe markes in Fraunces.
This they wrote of Fraunces, with mo other lies, wherwith I am aſhamed to blot the cleane paper.

One mery ſtory commeth to my remembraunce by the meanes of rehearſing
the wings of Seraphin. I heard of a Friar, which alwaies in his ſermons, did ſhew forth a feather, which he affirmed to be one of the feathers of the wings of Gabriel: by which he proled from the ſimple people great ſummes of mony. At the laſt in his dronkennes this feather was taken out of his boxe, and coales put in the ſtede therof. At the next dai (which was Saint Laurences day) when in his ſermon he thought to pul out his feather out of his boxe, he found nothing but coales And being diſmaied, and yet intending to colour & cloke his knauery with ſo great a lie as the other was, taking the coales in hys hand, ſaid to the people after this maner: O good people what a miracle is this? ye feather of Gabriels winge is turned into ſaincte Laurences coales. For theſe be the verye coales wherewith ſaincte Laurence was burned. Such were the frutes of our holy friers, and confirmed to be true by the authoritie of the holy fathers. If this bee not pagens of Antechriſte, I thinke there be none. But thankes be to god the friers with the whole rable of their religion are ſent out of this Realme thether, from whence they came, that is, to their father of Rome.

div.head: Brethren. 33.
div.p: BRother in ye Latine tong is called Frater, Gel. li. 13. c. 10 born of one and ye ſame parēts. And it is named Frater, quaſi fere alter, as Aegidius doth teach, and Gellius after him.

Some authors do deriue it of the greeke woord 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ,: For the Gretians do cal thoſe that be nere ioined together in company, ſociety, or otherwiſe, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , And they cal the felowſhip it ſelfe 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .

Frater is in greeke 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , as ye woulde ſaye Frater vternius. Brother of one wombe, becauſe 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , commeth of this woord 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , whiche ſignifieth a wombe, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , is put for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : as ye would ſay, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a like brother.

And it is called in the hebrue Ach: And it ſignifieth in the ſcripture not only a brother that is borne in the ſame wombe, but alſo it ſignifieth a nephewe, a couſen germane, a kinſman. As in the goſſpell of Mathew it is ſaid of the brother of Chriſt, not that they were his brethren vternie, but that they were coſen germans, ſiſters children.

As Iude, Simon, Ioſes, Iames, and Iohn, whiche were called the brethren of Christ, yet they were but coſen germans vnto him. Frater alſo be tokeneth a neighbour, and ſpecially him that is of one religion. As Paule vſeth it in many places of his Epiſtles, and ſpecially to the Corinthians,1. Cor, 5. where he ſayth. Si quis, quum frater appelletur, fuerit formicarius aut auarus: If any that is called a brother, be a fornicator or couetouſe.

A brother is here called and ment of Paule, to be of one profeſsion of Chriſt. And note here that none may be called more properly fratres, brethren, than Chriſtians, and that for ſundry and diuers reſpectes.
Firſt, for that they are the ſonnes of our father, that is, of God, whervpon they pray, ſaying: Pater noſter qui es in caelis. Our father which art in heauen.

Secondly, becauſe they be regenerate of our mother, that is, of the church diſpouſed vnto Chriſt, in the vnity of our faith and baptiſme. As Paule ſaith to the Epheſians:Ephe. 4, Vnus deus, vna fides, vnum baptiſma, One God, one faith, one baptiſme.
Thirdly, becauſe we be adopted of Chriſt into his brethren, as Auſtine doth very well declare.
Fourthly, becauſe we are bought all with one price, that is, with the bloude of Chriſt.
Fiftly, becauſe we profeſſe one and the ſame religion, that is, the chriſtian religion.
Sixtly and laſtly, becauſe they ſhalbe enobled with one heauenly dignity, and bleſſed enheritaunce.

By theſe notes ye may learn one goodly document, that is, that a chriſtian which loueth not his brother, but hateth him, or doth hurt him by any maner of meanes, either in perſon or in goods, he doth loſe the priuilege, title, and appellation of a brother. Firſt, he leeſeth to be called the ſonne of God, becauſe he is made the childe of the deuill, as ſaint Iohn ſaith vnto the Iewes: vos ex patre diabolo eſtis, you ar of your father the diuel.Ioan. 8. Secondly, he leeſeth the participation or communion of holy things done in the church. Thirdlye, he leeſeth the benefite and remedye of the bloud of Chriſt.

div.head: Vnworthy. 34.
div.p: Rom. 5. SAint Paule writeth to the Romaines: Chriſtus, quum adhuc infirmi eſſemus, ſecundum tempus pro impiis mortuus eſt. &c. that is: Chriſt, when we were yet of no ſtrength, at his time died for the godly, doubtles one wil ſcarce die for a righteous man, but yet for a good man it may be that one dare die. But God ſetteth out his loue towarde vs, ſeing that while we were yet ſinners, Christ died for vs. Paule in theſe wordes ſetteth forth three thinges.
Firſt, the great benefit that was geuen to mankind, that is, the ſonne of God geuen to death for vs.
Secondly, he maketh a collation or compariſon by the which the hope of the faithful is greatly confirmed.
Thirdly, he ſheweth that we ought not onely to hope, but alſo greatly to glory and reioyce of this loue of God toward vs.

He doth with an amplification exaggerate, that Chriſt died not for all maner of men: but for them which were vnworthie of all helpe and mercie. Therfore, he calleth vs Infirmos, weake, deſtitute, and voyde of all helpe and ſuccour. And when men them ſelues would not gladly dye: by this it appeareth howe great the charitie of Chriſt was towarde vs, which woulde dye for vs that were weake, wicked ſinners, enemies, and vtterly vnworthy.

Theſe two particles, pro iuſto & bono, maye be expounded two maner of wayes. For the grecians do reade here in this place 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Vvhiche we maye interprete both in the neutre gendre, for a iuſte and righteous thing, and alſo in the maſculine gendre for a righteous man. If it be taken neutrally, for a righteous cauſe, then the mening is, that they which haue reſerued death, would be loth to die with a quiet and pacient minde. Likewiſe, if 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , here be taken for a good thing or cauſe, then the meanyng is, that men will offer them ſelues to death for ſom proffitable or welbeloued thinge. As the parents for their children, the huſbands, for their wiues, merchants for their merchandiſe.
Origen expoundeth it of the martyrs which ſuffred death for Christ, qui vere bonus eſt, which is good in dede.

Other do rehearſe Decios, Curtios, Godros and Philenos, Vvhiche all willingly died for their countrie. All they might be counted to be enforced by ſome iust and proffitable cauſe to ſuffer death. For it ſemed to be a iuſte cauſe to rendre ſuche thancke and fauour vnto the countrie, that they would die for the cauſe therof.

Chriſostome vnderſtādeth per iuſtum & bonum, Ad Algati. quaeſt. 7. a iuſt and righteous man. And to Chriſoſtome do conſente the moſt parte of the learned, although Hierome doth expounde 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . ſubſtantiuely for a iuſt and good cauſe.

Vvhy Paule doth ſaye vix pro iuſto, ſcarce for a righteous man, and addeth forſitan pro bono, peraduenture for a good man, this maye be the cauſe. That they which maye ſeme ſomtime to die for other (which appeareth very rarely) the thing being well conſidered and weighed, maye be counted for their own, & not for an other mans cauſe, either for that they deſire ſome glorie therby, or els that they ſee them ſelues ſubiecte to all kinde of aduerſitie, which when they can not ſuffer, they had rather die then liue. How much Decii, Curtii, and ſuch others did differ from the pure loue of Chriſt, it may be declared by many arguments.

First, they were not of the ſame dignitie and worthines that they might be compared with Christ. For the life which they loſt, was not of equal price. Furthermore (wil they nil they) they ſhuld haue once died & peraduenture at that time when their hoſt was vanquiſhed and ſlaine
of their enemies, and death hangyng ouer a mans head, which can not be auoided, maketh man the bolder to die, which is reported of Solon. For he when he was called to beare weapon againſt Pyſiſtratus the tyrant, beinge demaunded with what boldnes he onely durſte attempte this ſo bolde a dede, beſide other, anſwered: ſenectute, by mine age. For when he ſawe that he was not like to liue longe, he eaſilye perſuaded him ſelfe to put him ſelf in aduenture to die for his countrie.

But Chriſt, when he was in no point ſubiecte or giltie to death, and purpoſed to die for our ſake, he declared a much more great loue toward vs, than they had to their countrie. They died for their wiues, for their children, for the lawes of their countrie: But Chriſt would be ſlaine and die for vs beinge weake, for vs, being ſinners, for vs being enemies, for vs in all reſpectes being vtterly vnworthie. They by their death ſought their glorie and praiſe, and were had in admiration of all men. But Chriſt ſuſteined a death moſt reprochefull and infamous. In ſo muche that he was nombred and counted among theues and murtherers: Vvhen notwithſtandyng he was the moſt innocent of all other.
Finally, they in their death had no reſpecte of God: but whatſoeuer Chriſt did, he did it by obedience to the eternal God his father.

Therfore, we, if we reſpecte other, our owne ſelues, or Chriſt which ſuffred, we can finde none other cauſe of his death, but the mere loue of God toward vs. For we were ſo miſerable, ſo vtterly loſt, and ſo vnworthie, that we could be no merite of ours allure God to loue vs. For we were neither iuſt nor good. But it came I ſay onely of the mere loue and mercie of God through Chriſt to vs.

This particle, ſecundum tempus, at his time maye be referred to the death of Chriſt, which happened not at all tymes, but at that certaine tyme whiche was preſcribed and appointed of God. Therfore ſainct Paule ſayth that chriſt was geuen, when the fulnes of time was come.
Sainct Ambroſe vnderſtandeth ſecundum tempus, of the three daies, by the which ſpace Chriſt did lye in the graue.

div.head: Epilogus. 35.
div.p: Epilogus, is the laſt parte of an oration which the latine men do cal concluſionem, or perorationem. The Rhetoricians do make three partes of an Epilogus.
By enumeration repetion is made of things that were ſpoken before. It is called in Greeke 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . id eſt recapitulatio.
By amplification the mindes of the hearers are ſtirred and moued to be attentiue.
By commiſeration the hearers are moued, and bowed to pitie and compaſsion.

div.head: Prouince. 36.
div.p: PRouincia is called in the greeke 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . And it is properly that region which is gotten by warres.
The firſte region that was called a prouince was Sicilia as Cicero teacheth.

The Romains in old time called prouinciam any out region or farre countrie that they had ſubdued vnto their dominion, empire and iuriſdiction, and held in the ſame prouince their power by a liuetenaunt ſent thither to gouerne and rule it. And becauſe that thoſe perſones which were admitted and ſent by the Romaines to rule in any prouince were ſente thither as officers and with commiſsion, and with great charge, therfore the very office it ſelfe of rulynge in any prouince, was alſo called in latine prouincia, and therof by a metaphor all the burden and labour, or buſines of doing in any maner of office, or thing to be done, is called in latin ſpeaking prouincia.

div.head: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .
div.p: WHereas I purpoſed to ſet in the ende of thys booke myne apologye, to aunſwere certayne rayling billes caſt into the preaching place againſt me by certayne chattering choghes: I thought it good to deferre the ſame vnto an other tyme, & to place it in my booke intitled 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Which by gods grace I intend to diuulgate with a great deale more expedition, thē I haue done this. But what impedimentes and ſtayes I haue had for the diuulgation of this preſent booke ſo long, it is not vnknowē to a great number of my dioceſſe. The eſpecial cauſe why mine apologie is not here inſerte, is, leaſt the booke might growe to more than to a iuſte quantitie. And by that meanes the title might be counted to be falſe. For, The poore mans librarie is made for poore men: for ſuche (I meane) that haue no great ſtoore eyther of bookes, or of money. Therefore, leaſt the price ſhoulde be to exceſſiue for poore men, I will nowe end bequething, this poore mans librarie, to the poore.

p.hi: Ni purges, et molas non comedes.

div.head: ❧ Certaine Miſcellans omitted to be added to the 3. Lecture in the ſecond Tome, as here doth followe, where by you maye eaſely ſee by the folios where they ſhould be placed.
div.note: Place this miſcellan following in folio .51. before Purgatorie.

div.head: Spes viua. 5,
div.p:
EVery worde of Peter hath in it a meruailous Emphaſis: as this worde ſpes, which is not a vulgare and common hope, but a liuely hope, or the hope of life. And therfore Peter calleth it ſpem viuam. The Gentiles had a certaine hope in this life: of which Theocritus maketh mention:
Fidere Batte decet, melius cras forſan habebis.
Sperandum eſt viuis, non eſt ſpes vlla ſepultis.

But this hope is but a momentanie, ſhort, and vaine hope: but oure hope wherof Peter ſpeaketh, is a hope that neuer faileth, by the whiche we are ſaued. And this hope is nothing els but Chriſt, which leadeth vs vnto eternall life.
div.note:
¶ Place theſe two Miſcellans one after an other in folio .59. before, many places.
Ego ſum.
Vnum ſumus.

div.head: Ego ſum. 8.
div.p: IT is writen in Exodus that when god ſent Moſes to the children of Iſrael, to ſaye vnto them: The God of their fathers ſent him vnto them, Moſes aſked God what anſwere he ſhould geue them, if they aſked him, what is his name? And God anſwered Moſes: Ego ſum qui ſum: I am that I am. For the future tenſe doth comprehend in it thre tenſes. The hebrue words are Aehiaeh aſchar aehiaeh, id eſt, ero qui ero.

The Hebrues are wonte to put often times the future tenſe in ſteede of the preſente. And they do write, that by this maner of ſpeache the eternitie of God is ſignified. The Thalmudiſtes alſo do ſaye, that this word Achiaeh ero doth conteine the differences of thre tenſes, that is, the preter tenſe, preſent tenſe, and the future tenſe, fui, ſum, & ero, I haue ben, I am, and I ſhalbe. And by this they affirme the high and euerlaſtyng ſtabilitie of God, which euer hath ben, is, and ſhalbe. For God neuer began, nor neuer doth end: but doth tranſcend and paſse all reaſon of time. He onely can ſay: ſum & ero. I am ſhalbe. For he is the fountaine and fulneſſe of all ſubſtaunce and life: of whom all things that be, haue their being.Act. 17. He onely geueth life and ſpirite to all: As Paule ſaith: In ipſo mouemur, viuimus & ſumus: In him we liue, and moue, and
haue oure being. Vvherfore, becauſe the eternitie of God can not be cōprehended within any bounds or compaſſe, therfore he can be deſcribed by no tyme. Vvherupon he is rightly called, qui eſt, qui fuit, qui erit, For all times, when we ſpeake of God, are confounded.
This name of God is expreſſed by Iohn the Euangeliſt in the greeke toung 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . id eſt, qui eſt, & qui erat, & qui erit: Apoc. 1. which is, which was, and is to come.

div.head: Vnum ſumus. 9.
div.p: CHrist ſaith in Iohn: Ego & pater vnum ſumus: Cap. 10. I and the father are one. In the which ſaying he diſſolued not only that queſtion which the Iewes demaunded, whether he was Chriſt: but alſo ſhewed the deteſtable madneſſe of the heretikes that were to come.

Firſt, Arrius did ſeperat the ſonne frō the ſubſtaunce of the father. After him Sabellus confounded the perſon of the father and the ſonne, makyng no difference betwene them. Sainct Auſten ſayth. Pereant vaniloqui, & mētis ſeductores, Arrianus & Sabellianus, &c. Let thoſe vain deceyuers of the minde, the Arrian and Sabellian be confounded and periſh. For I and the father are one: he ſaid not: ego & pater vnus ſum, I and the father am one, but he ſayd: Ego & pater vnum ſumus: I and the father are one. In that he ſayth one, let the Arrian heare, that he ſaith, we are, let the Sabellian heare. Let not the Arrian diuide vnum, let not the Sabellian put out ſumus. Thus muche Austen.

The meanyng of theſe wordes: Ego & pater vnum ſumus, I and the father are one, is this: I the ſonne an other perſon different from the father: and the father, or the perſonne of the father, beinge an other perſon different from mine, are one, that is, are one eſſence, one power, one equalitie, one God, one vertue.

As ther is an abſolute ſocietie betwene the father and me, ſo ther is one and the ſame conſente of will. In all reſpects we are one, like mighty, willynge one thing, and nillynge one thing. Therefore, I and the father together defend the beleuing, and do take cure and regard of them againſt all wolues, theeues, and raueners, that they may not periſhe, but haue lyfe euerlaſtyng.
Some of the learned, do expound this place of Iohn of the conſent of Chriſt with the father. For whatſoeuer is don of Chriſt: the ſame is confirmed by the power of the father.

But in my ſimple iudgemēt, they take it not in the worſe ſenſe, which expound it, as well of the ſubstance, as of the conſent of Chriſt with the father. It were great pitie to open any windowe or ſtartinge hole to an heretike.
div.note: Place theſe .4. Miſcellans folowing in fol. 63. after the Miſcelan He ſhall. 12. Nathan. 13. Factum eſt. 14. Mens. 15. Symbol. Athanaſii.

div.head: Nathan. 12
div.p: 2. Reg. 7. THere were two of that name: the one was a prophet chaplain or confeſsor to King dauid.
Angelomus doth thinke, that this Nathan was Ionathas the ſonne of Samma, which was Dauids brother.

1. par. 3, 2. Reg 5. Luke 3, Homil. in. Luca. 28.The other Nathan was the ſonne of Dauid, and brother to Salomon. Of which Nathan, Philo writeth, that Ioas, and the kinges folowynge did come. Origen thinketh that this Nathan was the Prophet, for he ſayth: Non per Salomonem, ſed per Nathan naſcitur, qui eius arguit patrem ſuper Vriae mortem, that is: He doth not come of Salomon, but of Nathan, which reproued his father for the death of Vrias.

Of Nathan the ſonne of Dauid, which was the ſecond ſonne of Bethſabe, begotten after Salomon, this is ſpeciallye to be noted. Saint Luke in his genealogie doth deduce the lineall deſcente of Chriſt from Nathan to Elie, who was (as ſome do write) the naturall father of the virgin Marie, and was otherwiſe called Iehoakym. And ſo Luke doth deſcribe the legall genealogie of Chriſt.

Other do write, that theſe two Mathan, and Mathat, were brethren of the houſe of Dauid by Nathan. Mathan had to his ſonne Iacob of his wife Heſta. Vvhen Mathan was dead, Mathat had to his wife the ſame Heſta, of whom he bega • te Heli. For Iacob and Heli were brothren born in on womb. Now when Heli was dead without childrē, Iacob toke his brother Helies wife, of whom he begat Ioſeph being his naturall ſonne, but legallie beinge the ſonne of Hely. For it is writen in Deuteronomie:Deut. 25. Si frater abſ
que liberis mortuus fuerit, alius accipiat illam in vxorem &c. If the brother die without children, let the other brother take her to wife, that his name be not put out of Iſrael.

The Iewes in their commentaries do recorde, that Dauid commaunded, that if Salomon ſhould at any time be deſtitute of heires lineallie deſcending from him, the kingdome ſhould come to the heires and poſteritie of Nathan.

div.head: Factum eſt. 13.
div.p: Cap. 1. SAinct Iohn writeth in his goſpell, quòd caro verbum factum eſt: that the worde was made fleſhe.

Vve muſt not thinke theſe words to be ſpoken in ſuch a ſenſe, as the water is read, to be made wine. For the water was made wine in ſuch maner, that it ceaſsed to be water, and ther remained onely wine. But here the worde was not ſo made fleſhie, that the worde, that is, God
ceaſed to be God, and ther was nothing els but fleſh. God forbid. For it cannot be, that God was chaunged into man, and left to be God. The diuine ſubſtaunce of the word admitteth neither chaunge, nor end, foraſmuch as it is immutable and infinite. Againe, neither the fleſh of Chriſt leauing his own proper nature was chaunged into the word, God forbid, this alſo. For if it ſhould be ſo, as Chriſt ſhould be on the one ſide depriued of his diuinity: ſo on the other ſide he ſhould be bireft of his true humanity, yt he might not be true man, nor truly cōceiued, nor truly borne, nor truly haue ſuffred and died, and therfore not to haue truly riſē again.

Let vs therfore ſtedfaſtly beleue, that God being made man, tooke vnto him that which he was not, and loſt not that which he was. Vvherfore in this article of our faith, two thinges are chiefly to be beleued the one, that two are ſo vnited and knit together in Chriſt, that one and the ſame Chriſt is true God, and true man. The ſecond is, that the vnitye of the perſons letteth not, but that the natures may be diſtinct & ſeperat, ſo that the diuinity may retaine and keepe that which is proper vnto it, and the humanity likewiſe may reſerue that which belongeth vnto it. If we hold wel theſe two pointes, we ſhal eaſily refel all errours, which Sathan by his members hath brought into the church, of the diuinitye and humanity of Chriſt. For Neſtorius, Eutiches, Seruetus, and the Anabaptiſtes haue done no ſmal deſpite vnto Chriſt, when ſome of them went about to depriue Chriſt of his humanity, and other ſome went about to depriue him of his diuinity.

Chriſoſtome writeth thus: Quum audieris: verbum caro factum eſt, ne turberis. &c. Vvhen thou ſhalt heare: The word was made fleſh, be not troubled: For he doth not conuert the ſubſtance into fleſh (for it is a wicked thing ſo to vnderſtand it) but abiding that which he is, tooke vpon him the ſhape of a ſeruaunt. For, becauſe ther are ſome which ſay that the wordes of Incarnation are (as it were) dreames and phantaſies confounding their blaſphemye, he did put this particle factum eſt, not meaning to repreſent and ſhew forth the chaunging of the ſubſtaunce, but the aſſumption and taking on him true fleſh.

Alſo ſaint Auſten ſaith:De Trin. 15 ſicut autem vetbum noſtrum vox quodammodo corporis fit, aſſumēdo eam in qua manifeſtatur ſenſibus hominū: ſic verbum Dei caro factum eſt, aſſumendo eam, in qua et ipſum manifeſtaretur ſenſibus hominum. That is: like as our word is made (as it wer) a voyce or ſound of the body, by taking the voice vnto it, in which voice it is made manifeſt to the ſenſes of man: euen ſo the woorde of God was made fleſh, bi putting on him fleſh, in which the word might be manifeſt to the ſenſes of man. And as our word is made a voice, and yet not turned into the voyce: ſo the word of God is made fleſh, but God forbid, that it
ſhould be turned into fleſh: for that word was made fleſh, by taking the fleſh, and not conſuming it ſelfe into the fleſh.
Theodoretus and all other diuines do expounde Eſt in this place for aſſumpſit. In Polymorpho

div.head: Mens. 14.
div.p: MEns is the principal part of the ſoule, which is called of ſome intelligence, with the which onely man being endued, doth excell all other beaſtes, and by the which he doth contemplate and behold thinges incorporal and indiuiſible. Vvherupon ſome do thinke, that it is called Mens quaſi eminens, becauſe this facultye of the ſoule doth greatly excel all the other faculties.

Lactantius ſaith: Primùm non idem eſt mēs in anima: aliud eſt enim quo viuimus, Lib. 7. aliud quo cogitamus. Nam dormientium mens nō anima ſopitur, & in furioſis mens extinguitur, anima manet. &c. Firſt, ye minde and the ſoule are not one thing. For that is one thing wherby we liue, & that is an other wherby we thinke and vnderſtand. The minde of them that ſleepe, and not the ſoule is brought from ſleepe, and in mad men the minde is extinguiſhed, and the ſoule remaineth.

Thales Mileſius ſaid, that the ſwifteſt of all thinges that are is the minde: for it is of ſuch celerity, that in one point and moment of time, it doth behold heauen, it is ouer the ſeas, and goeth to cities and nations.
They which doe iudge animum et mentem to be one, are deceiued. For Mens is a certaine ſubtility of vnderſtanding or counſell conſonant to reaſon. Animus is the foundation of life and will.

Terence maketh a difference betwene theſe two in Andria, where he ſaith: mala mens, malus animus. Mens ſomtime is put for the will or good intent, ſomtime it is put for counſel, ſomtime for the minde.

Ther is a cōmon diſtinctiō of theſe .3. words: Anima, Animus, Mens. Anima eſt qua viuimus, animus quo ſapimus, mens, qua diuina intelligimus. By the firſt we liue, by the ſecond we vnderſtand, and by the third we perceiue and contemplate diuine and heauenly thinges.

i. Theſ. 5.Saint Paule ſemeth to cal that part, which is called mens, ſpiritum. His wordes be theſe: ipſe autem Deus pacis author ſanctificet vos totos, et integer veſter ſpiritus, et anima et corpus inculpatae in aduentum Domini noſtri Ieſu Chriſti ſeruentur. The very God of peace ſanctifie you throughout: and I pray God, that your whole ſpirit, and ſoule and bodye may be kept blameles vnto the comming of our Lord Ieſus Chriſt.

Paule here diuideth man into three partes: into ſpirit, ſoule, and body. Notwithſtanding cōmonly man conſiſteth, ſimpliciter, of bodye and ſoule, and then the ſoule doth ſignify the immortal ſpirite, which dwelleth in the body. But becauſe ther be two principall faculties of the ſoule (vnderſtanding and wyll) the ſcripture ſometime maketh a diſtinction
betwene theſe two, eſpecially when it will expreſſe the power and nature of the ſoule: but than the ſoule is taken for the ſeate of affections, and is the part oppoſite to the ſpirite. Therfore, ſaint Paule here doth vnderſtand by the name of Spirit, godly intelligence: As by the name of the ſoule are ſignified will, and all affections. The meaning of theſe wordes of Paul is this: Than is a man fully ſanctified, and perfect, when his minde thinketh nothing, his ſoule, that is, his vnderſtanding & will couet nothing: neither his body doth execute any thing contrarye to the will of God.
Finally, the Spirit properly here betokeneth the minde when it is indued with the grace and gift of the holy ghoſt, whereof if it be voide, it cānot properly be called ſpiritus or mens.

div.head: Symbolum Athanaſii. 15.
div.p:
OF Athanaſius himſelfe I haue ſpoken before in the firſte Tome: now I wil ſpeake & intreate of the ſymbole or crede made by him, commonly called, Quicun
que vult.

The ſymbole of Athanaſius comprendeth the catholicke faith, in the true profeſsion of the holy Trinity, of the Incarnation of Ieſus Chriſt, true God & true mā, of his paſsion, death, deſcēding into hel, reſurrection, aſcenſion into heauen, ſitting at the right hande of the father, of his cōming to iudge, of the reſurrection of the body, and in the confeſsion of the laſt iudgement, of the eternal fire, and of the life euerlaſting. And after that Athanaſius had rehearſed this confeſsion of the faith, he ſaid: This is the catholicke faith, which vnles euerye one faythfully and ſtedfaſtly beleue, can not be ſaued.
Therfore, they that beleue thus, haue the catholike faith. It followeth than that they are not heretickes, but catholickes, knit together in the vnity of the catholicke church, and of this faith.

Gratianus alſo did acknowledge the ſame, when he publiſhed a lawe to the people of Conſtantinople, in the which he decreed, that they onely which worſhiyped the holy Trinity with like honour ſhould be counted to be of the catholicke church, and they that iudged otherwiſe,Sozome. eccleſ. hiſtor. lib. 7. cap. 4 ſhould be taken for heretickes. And into this faith we are ſo manifeſtly and agreably baptiſed, that the confeſsion of the ſame is made through all Chriſtendome, as wel of them that be ſprong vp in yeres (if any be baptiſed) as alſo of infants, by ye mouthes of them yt be witneſſes of their baptiſme.

Vvherfore, they are very vngodly, and timerous mē, which not being content with his faith, do require other things to be beleued of the faithfull, wherof ther is mencion made, neither in the catholick ſymbole, nor in the tenor of baptiſme. Neither they do require thoſe things to be beleued
lightly, but with like neceſsitye and condicion, as the catholicke faith is required to be beleued of them that will be members of the catholicke church. As for example: To beleue in the ſaintes that are dead, doeſt thou not beleue (ſay they) in the ſaintes. Thou art then an hereticke. To inuocate, and to pray vnto ſaintes. Saintes to make interceſſiō for vs in heauen. Images of Saintes to be worſhipped in churches. The Maſſe to be a ſacrifice propitiatory for the quicke and the deade. The ſubſtance of bread and wyne to be chaunged into the body and bloud of Chriſt by the conſecration of the ſacrificing prieſt. That ther be .7. ſacraments. The biſhop of Rome to be Chriſtes Vicar on earth, and ſupreme head and gouernour of all Churches. Not to be lawfull for prieſts to marry: that I may not ſpeake of thoſe thinges which they ſet forth to be beleued, of mans free wyll, of ſatiſfaction, of good works, of indulgences, that is, the marchandiſes of the Romiſhe Antichriſt, and his eccleſiaſticall traditions: Vnles ye beleue all theſe thinges to be true and chriſtian doctrine, you are condemned to be an hereticke: although you beleue the old and auncient faith, which theſe men do little esteme, but the aunciēt Paſtors, and faithful Miniſters haue onely regarded.

div.head: Agrippa. 23.
div.p: AGrippa was the ſonne of Herode. He was made king of Chalcis, and chiefe Preſidēt of the temple, & of the prieſts to be created, fiue yeares after the death of his father, and in the .22. yeare of his owne age, and in the .51. yeare after Chriſt. He was made king by Claudius the Emperour. Vnder him Ieruſalem was deſtroyed of Titus, Veſpaſianus ſonne. He died .5. yeares after the deſtruction of Ieruſalem. He was called Agrippa, id eſt Aeger pedibus. vel aegre partus, becauſe when he was borne, his feete came firſt foorth.

div.head: ❧ Faultes eſcaped, deſiring thee gentle Reader, to correct the ſame in thy booke, before thou begynneſt to read this worcke, whiche ſhall helpe thee much in the vnderſtandyng of thoſe places. The order of whiche correction here vnder thou mayeſt ſee. The letters a. and. b. which ſtand by the firſt numbers, ſignifie the ſides of euery leafe, a. ſignifieng the firſt ſyde, and b. the ſeconde ſyde.
❧ Faultes eſcaped in the ſecond Tome of thys booke.
div.p: IN fol. 2. page. a. line. 1. He was of a pale and whitely face, is twyſe printed.
In the ſame fol. pag. b. line. 35, for tollerauerunt, is tolerauerunt.
Fol. 3. pag. b. line. 20. for videbitur, is videlitur.
Fol. 10. pag. a. line. 6. for Domitius, is Donictius.
Fol. 14. pag. a. line. 29. for remiſeritis, is remiſceritis.
Fol. 15. pag. a. line. 17. for aequali, is aegnati.
Fol. 18. pag. a. line. 16. for ſummis apoſtolis, is ſummus apoſtolus.
Fol. 21. pag. b. line. 11, for Achitob, is Achitus printed in two places.
Fol. 22. pag. a. for Ioſaphat, is Leoſaphat.
Fol. 25. pag. b. for, that the tithes ſhould be payde to the church, and that the ſolemne feaſt of Sunday ſhould be kept: is put, that the tithes ſhould be kept.
Fol. 72. pag. a. line. 12. for thoſe wordes, is, thoſe wordes of Peter.
Fol. 94. b. line. 2. for primatiue, is put priuate: for gigno, is gignenpo.
Fol. 120. pag. a. line. 16. for Natalis the Martyr, is Natalis the Confeſſor.
